**Hongdao Lu**
**Scripture Title:** *Hongdao Lu*. Compiled by Shao Jingbang of the Ming dynasty. Fifty-six juan. Source text: *Xu Daozang*.

**Hongdao Lu, Juan 1**
*Ren* (Humaneness) – Humaneness Between Ruler and Minister

Confucius said: "How great was Yao as a ruler! Towering indeed! Only Heaven is great, and only Yao took it as his model. Boundless indeed! The people could find no name for him."

The record states: Yao as a ruler was the guiding principle for all ages. The Master’s discourse is the eternal standard for ten thousand generations. "How great" signifies a name that cannot be surpassed, a meaning that cannot be exhausted. "Heaven" refers to the virtue of benevolence that covers and pities all below. "The king" refers to one who embodies benevolence and nurtures the people. The Way of benevolence is supremely great, identical in substance to Heaven, and the sage takes Heaven as his model. If one truly takes Heaven as one’s model, then one delights in every person and encompasses every thing—yet this may be described in words. If it can be described in words, then it must have limits and obstructions, and cannot be called "great." Thus, only Heaven is great: its entire being is ceaseless, and its position above is such that none can know its height or depth. This is why it is said: "This is how Heaven is Heaven." Only Yao is great: his virtue matches the boundless, and his emulation of Heaven is such that none can fathom its limits. This is why it is said: "This is how Yao is Yao." The Master’s lofty words reveal that one who rules must always possess a heart that embraces and broadly covers all without exception, and only then can one achieve a work of vastness, depth, height, and brilliance, enduring without limit. Thus one does not betray Heaven, does not fall short of Yao, and does not disgrace the Master’s discourse. Therefore, this record begins by elucidating this.

The *Outer Records* state: Yao set his heart upon the world and directed his will toward the destitute. If one person starved, he said, "It is I who have starved him"; if one person froze, he said, "It is I who have frozen him"; if one person committed a crime, he said, "It is I who have led him astray." The hundred clans bore him as the sun and moon, cherished him as father and mother. His benevolence shone forth, his righteousness was established, his virtue was vast, and his transformation was far-reaching. Thus, though he did not reward, the people were encouraged; though he did not punish, the people were governed.

The record states: This is what is meant by "Yao’s benevolence was like Heaven." Now, Heaven is towering indeed, but if one seeks its essence, it is utterly empty—what use is Heaven? Now, Yao is boundless indeed, but if one seeks his essence and finds even one person left unprotected, then it is but an empty name—what use is Yao? This record fears that one may neglect practical affairs, pursue only the lofty and distant, and claim, "Yao is here." Alas, how remote!

The *Canon of Yao* states: "He was able to make his lofty virtue illustrious, thereby bringing harmony to the nine clans. When the nine clans were harmonious, he distinguished and illuminated the hundred clans. When the hundred clans were illustrious, he harmonized the myriad states, and the black-haired people were transformed and became concordant."

The record states: The Master’s praise of Yao as "towering" and the historian’s praise of Yao as "lofty virtue" both signify that which cannot be surpassed. Yet this was achieved not by transcendent feats beyond reach, but by bringing harmony to the nine clans and distinguishing the hundred clans. This is precisely what is meant by calling him "Fangxun."

The *Liezi* states: After Yao had ruled the world for fifty years, he traveled to the broad thoroughfares and heard children singing: "He established us as the people, and none failed to reach his utmost. Unknowing and unperceiving, we follow the patterns of the Lord." There was also an old man, chewing and drumming his belly, striking the clods and singing: "When the sun rises, I work; when the sun sets, I rest. I dig a well to drink, till the fields to eat—what has the Emperor’s power to do with me?"

The record states: This is how "the black-haired people were transformed and became concordant." The children were innocent, the old man was senile—how could they know what was meant by the "patterns of the Lord"? Yet in that flourishing age of antiquity, even the most ignorant men and women were as close as family, their virtue permeating their skin and marrow, so deeply ingrained that they did not realize their words were thus. The Three Dynasties henceforth gathered the songs of the lanes and alleys, established them as fixed standards, listed them among the music officials, set them to pipes and strings, and observed them as customs.

The *Odes* of Zhou says: "The people are simple, daily using food and drink. The masses of the black-haired people all become your virtue." This expresses the same idea.

By the time of Qin, the court treated the black-haired people as fools, and thus the constraints have persisted to this day. How lamentable!

Confucius said: "He who governs by non-action—was this not Shun?" What did he do? He merely maintained reverence and faced due south.

The Record says: Confucius extolled Yao as "great" and praised Shun for "non-action"—what did he mean by this? Heaven is one and the same. In its boundless entirety, it is called "great"; in its soundlessness and scentlessness, it is called "non-action." People see the sun and call it day, the moon and call it night, cold and call it winter, warmth and call it spring—what is this if not Heaven’s movement? Yet how can they perceive its form? It unfolds as kindness, manifests as awe, bestows as reward, and seizes as punishment—what is this if not the ruler’s enactments? Yet how can they see its traces?

Yao and Shun, though named differently, were in essence one. Had one clamored, "Yao’s achievements tower thus, Yao’s institutions shine thus—why can I not do the same?"—they would have seen his toil but not his ease, his grandeur but not his tranquility. How could they have maintained reverence while facing south? They did not realize that in Shun’s time, governance could not be separated from Yao. If governance could not be separated from Yao, neither could the heart. How could the heart be burdened by even a single thing? Only by keeping the heart free of all attachments could one avoid the slightest outward imposition. This is what is meant by "profound reverence bringing peace to the world"—not the superficial transformation of the people through sights and sounds.

Thus, Confucius repeated, "What did he do?" to deepen his praise.

Gaoyao said: "The Emperor’s virtue was flawless. He oversaw the realm with simplicity, governed the masses with leniency, punished without extending to descendants, rewarded with benefits spanning generations, pardoned transgressions regardless of magnitude, meted out penalties for crimes without leniency for minor offenses, lightened sentences when guilt was doubtful, and weighed merits heavily when achievements were uncertain. Rather than kill the innocent, he would err on the side of irregularity. His love for life permeated the people’s hearts."

The Record says: Shun’s essence—beginning, end, root, and branch—is fully revealed here. For one who rules, leniency is fundamental; in treating others, generosity is fundamental; in governing the people, benevolence is fundamental; in mourning the dead, sorrow is fundamental. Without these foundations, how could one maintain reverence while facing south? Of later ages, only Emperor Wen of Han and Emperor Renzong of Song came close. Yet their achievements did not reach the heights of Yao and Shun, for they lacked a Gaoyao of exceptional talent to share in governance. How could they be expected to cultivate themselves with enduring thought, striving for clarity and diligence? This, too, must not be overlooked.

The *Family Sayings* states: As a ruler, Shun favored life and detested killing. He entrusted office to the worthy and dismissed the unfit. His virtue was like Heaven and Earth, serene and empty; his transformation was like the four seasons, nurturing all things. Thus, the Four Seas embraced his influence, and all living beings flourished. Phoenixes soared, qilin appeared, and birds and beasts were tamed by his virtue. There was no other reason—it was his love for life.

The Record says: Confucius’s praise of Shun was already profound, yet he added, "There was no other reason—it was his love for life." What did he mean? The true king embodies the vast virtue of Heaven and deepens the grace of life. Heaven has four seasons, presiding over the generation of things, not their destruction. Though it enforces severity in autumn and closure in winter, this is precisely to gather and release without end. The ruler wields eight powers, presiding over the nurturing of the people, not their harm. Though he eliminates evil with strictness and suppresses violence with awe, this is precisely to protect and cherish without cease.

Thus, when the Four Fiends were executed, though the world acknowledged their guilt, Shun’s heart was filled with reluctance, as if compelled. Gaoyao carried out the sentence, and the Minister of Justice recognized it—though it proceeded from Shun, it was not his true inclination. Hence it is said: "The world put them to death; it was not Shun who killed them." How did this harm his virtue of loving life? Suppose Shun’s heart had been swayed: if Gaoyao said, "Kill them," and he spared them, sparing them might seem benevolent—but what of the harm to the people? Harming the people is not Heaven’s way. If the Minister of Justice said, "Do not kill them," and he executed them, executing them might seem authoritative—but what of the harm to his heart? Harming the heart is not virtue. Thus it is said: "Rather than kill the innocent, better to err on the side of irregularity. The virtue of loving life permeates the people’s hearts."

Shun plucked his five-stringed zither and sang the *Song of the Southern Wind*:
*"The balmy southern wind—
Ah, it can dispel my people’s resentment!
The timely southern wind—
Ah, it can enrich my people’s wealth!"*

The Record says: In Yao’s time, his vast and all-embracing virtue was like Heaven and Earth, sustaining and covering all without exception. Thus, how could the people perceive the Emperor’s power? In Shun’s time, his influence was warm and pervasive, like the wind stirring and breathing upon all things, reaching every corner without omission. Thus, he knew there was resentment to dispel and wealth to enrich. Yet all arose from his heart and responded through his hands, unfolding naturally without premeditation. When this was set to the *Shun’s Music*, how could it not be perfectly good and perfectly beautiful?

The Xia dynasty was swift and precise, its virtue unerring, its benevolence endearing.

The Record says: Yao, Shun, and Yu were all great sages. The *Family Sayings* describes them differently. Yao had long occupied the throne, uniquely revered for all ages; Shun and Yu rose from humble origins, and their engagement with the people could not be equated with Heaven’s majesty. Our Master Confucius’s intent in his words surely had its own purpose.

The *Book of Yu* states: "Virtue is good governance; governance lies in nurturing the people."

The waters, fires, metals, woods, soils, and grains—only through cultivation; in rectifying virtue, facilitating use, and enriching life—only through harmony.

The Record says: How did Yu achieve such swiftness and precision? When the great floods surged to the heavens and the people suffered in mud and ashes, it was precisely because the Five Phases failed to restrain one another, and water and fire could not achieve mutual completion. Thus, Heaven bestowed upon Yu the *Great Plan* of the Nine Categories. Had Yu not acted with swift diligence—reducing excess, supplementing deficiency, and striving for balance—how could the constant norms have been properly ordered? The so-called Six Treasuries and Three Affairs are none other than the royal standard of the *Great Plan*. And that his benevolence was endearing—nothing surpasses this.

The *Zhou Odes* says:
*"We think of Hou Ji’s cultured grace,
Who matched the powers of Heaven’s might.
He fed our multitudes with grain,
No one but owed him boundless right.
He left us wheat and barley bright,
By Heaven’s charge to nurture all.
No bounds, no borders did he slight,
His constant laws through Xia did call."*

The Record says: This "right" is none other than the "utmost goodness" of the *Great Learning*. For Heaven’s heart is in the generation of all things—how could its yin and yang, the Dao of Qian and Kun, not fully realize their potential? If even the slightest measure were lacking, or a single breath failed in benevolence, it would not suffice to generate all things and could not be called Heaven. The sage’s heart is in nurturing the people—how could he not strive for perfection in every grain, whether coarse or fine? If even one creature were deprived or one plot of land left unsuitable, it would not suffice to nourish the people and could not be called Hou Ji. This is the utmost of benevolence, which none but the Duke of Zhou could fully comprehend. Thus arose the sacrifices to honor ancestors and match Heaven, born of righteousness and reverence.

The *Mencius* says: "Humans possess their Dao: when they are fed and clothed, dwell in ease, yet receive no instruction, they verge on the bestial." The sage, troubled by this, appointed Xie as Minister of Instruction, teaching the human relationships: affection between father and son, righteousness between ruler and minister, distinction between husband and wife, order between elder and younger, and trust between friends.

Fang Xun said: "Exert them, summon them, correct them, straighten them, assist them, shelter them, enabling them to find their own way, and further bestow virtue upon them."

The Record says: Fish and turtles cannot sustain life; wood and stone cannot enrich it; birds and beasts cannot establish governance—all would lead to ruin and drowning. Thus, if the people do not eat, they hunger; if they dwell in caves, they toil. Yet the innate goodness of their hearts remains intact. Without instruction, however, human hearts grow confused, human desires run rampant, and Heavenly principle is obstructed. Then all under Heaven—those with teeth and hair—revert to a state worse than horned, maned, clawed, or fanged creatures. Why? The horned merely butt; the maned merely flee; the clawed and fanged merely bite. But humans, without Heavenly principle to restrain them and human desires to guard against, become deceitful and treacherous, harming the people and all things in ways beyond description. Only then do we realize that the Dark King’s laws for all under Heaven, transmissible to later generations, were no mere trifling aid. Was it not fitting that his sacrifices to Yin matched Heaven?

The *Book of Yu* says: "Gao Yao advanced and planted virtue, and virtue descended, so the black-haired people cherished him."

The Record says: Why was Gao Yao’s virtue called "advancing and planting"? For punishment touches the people’s hearts—greatly, it concerns life and limb; subtly, it affects honor and shame. Its impact on the people is most pressing, its penetration deepest, and their fear of it exceeds even that of water and fire. If one knows its weight yet hesitates, avoids suspicion, or shrinks back, this cannot be called "advancing." Even if one grasps the truth of a case, if one cannot temper judgment with compassion, aiming for no punishment, this cannot be called "planting." Without the slightest obstruction—this is "advancing"; without the slightest entanglement—this is "planting." Thus, the people’s harmony within differs not from the Three Sages, and the phrase *"We examine the ancients"* is not amiss in its repetition.

Yi assisted Yu, saying: "Only virtue moves Heaven; nothing is too distant to reach. Pride invites loss; humility receives gain—such is Heaven’s Dao. Utmost sincerity moves the spirits, as when the Miao were subdued."

Yu bowed and accepted this wise counsel, saying: "Indeed!" He then arrayed his troops and marshaled his forces. The Emperor thereupon broadly spread civil virtue, dancing with shields and feathers upon the two steps. Within seventy days, the Miao submitted.

The Record says: Why did Yu achieve such success? When the earth was leveled and Heaven’s work completed, even the distant and near became one—how could a single person be left untouched by Yao and Shun’s grace? Why did Yi offer such praise? In perfect sincerity and accomplishment, one must not claim fullness or indulge in self-congratulation. This is the overflowing of utmost benevolence, extending its fragrance to ten thousand generations—something today’s noble ones must not fail to understand.

The *Book of Shang* says: "Be tolerant and benevolent."

The Record says: "Tolerant" speaks to one’s capacity. Can tolerance be added to benevolence? Master Shao said: "The eras of the Three Kings were like autumn." Like autumn—cold and severe—yet not free from the awe of punitive force. Thus, these two words praise Tang, for he was one who replaced tyranny.

The *Records of the Grand Historian* state: Tang went out and saw a man setting a net on four sides, praying: "May those falling from Heaven, rising from earth, or coming from the four directions all be caught in my net." Tang loosened three sides, leaving only one, and prayed anew: "Go left if you wish to go left, right if you wish to go right, high if you wish to go high, low if you wish to go low. Only those who disobey will enter my net." The lords of Hanzhong heard of this and said: "Tang’s benevolence extends even to birds and beasts." Over forty states submitted to him.

The Record says: Here we see his tolerance. Tang’s campaign against Xia was to save the people. Yet observe his words: "Go left if you wish to go left, right if you wish to go right. Only those who disobey will enter my net."

Alas! If even toward creatures he acted thus—would one commit a single act of injustice, slay a single innocent life, to gain the world? Later ages saw those who forbade the capture of birds and sparrows, erecting steles for the release of living beings. Yet why could they not win the people’s hearts?

Mencius said: "Love kin, then extend benevolence to the people; extend benevolence to the people, then cherish all things." Tang, by diligently manifesting great virtue and establishing harmony among the people, thus turned his compassion toward creatures into a force that drew the multitudes to submit. Had his virtuous deeds not yet reached their fullness, and he merely acted on a fleeting impulse—pursuing mercy with a troubled heart, clinging to purity with rigid resolve, taking non-killing as virtue and Dao-seeking as a mere habit—then his efforts would have been in vain. Such is the intent of this record.

The *Great Learning* says: "Majestic was King Wen, ever reverent in his radiant virtue, as a ruler resting in benevolence." The record states: Heaven’s workings are soundless and scentless. Benevolence is most difficult to describe—can it be sought in the shallow or near? It begins in the faint stirrings of thought, so subtle as to be invisible. Yet when it reaches its fullness, the world cannot contain it, so vast and boundless is it. Wisdom encompasses all things yet does not depart from the heart’s foundation; the Dao sustains the world yet does not extend beyond the confines of a single breast—this is what it means for a ruler to rest in benevolence.

Moreover, the *Odes* praises King Wen as "majestic." The text further declares: "The Son of Heaven is majestic." How unlike the haste of the feudal lords! The Son of Heaven is like Heaven revolving above—profound and unfathomable, thus able to work its wonders with a power that is swift yet not hurried, present yet not moving. The ruler, too, is profound and unfathomable, thus able to govern with a subtlety that requires neither loud commands nor drastic changes. Were Heaven to thunder at every drumbeat or rain at every drop, its ways would be known to all, and none would hold it in awe. Were a ruler’s wrath or joy as plain as a raised finger or a flushed face, how could the people stand in reverence? This is the poet’s profound insight, which must not be overlooked.

Mencius said: "King Wen regarded the people as if they were wounded." The record states: This is the heart that rests in benevolence. Mencius said: "All people possess a heart that cannot bear the suffering of others." Is this not the heart that regards the people as wounded?

One may ask: In King Wen’s time, there were no festering sores, no groaning sufferers. His kindness and care were so thorough that none lacked shelter—why then did he regard them as wounded? Yet the great sage never presumed his own perfection. When summer heat was slight or rain scant, the people grumbled; when spring prayers for cold were unanswered or summer rains fell short, the people grumbled still. Not only this—even the vastness of Heaven and Earth leaves room for regret. How then could King Wen’s heart not be ever anxious and earnest?

Such gradual cultivation of the people in benevolence, penetrating to the marrow and saturating the bones, cannot be achieved in a single morning or evening. In former times, when King Wen governed Qi, those who tilled the land kept nine parts of ten, while officials enjoyed hereditary emoluments. At passes and markets, scrutiny was applied but no taxes levied; ponds and weirs faced no prohibitions, and the families of criminals were not implicated. The old without wives were called *guan*; the old without husbands, *gua*; the old without children, *du*; the young without fathers, *gu*—these four were the most destitute and helpless among all under Heaven. When King Wen issued policies and extended benevolence, he invariably placed these four first. As the *Odes* says: *"To enrich all, yet first reach these toiling and solitary ones."* The record states: This is the practice of resting in benevolence.

Thus it is said that King Wen, ruling over a mere hundred *li*, did not by mere hexagram lines become Son of Heaven. Yet within that hundred *li* of Qi, the ethos of eight hundred years of governance was fully embodied—was this not the administration of all under Heaven? Heaven is called Father, Earth is called Mother, and the people are our siblings. Though distinctions exist between the honored and the solitary, the *guan* and the *gua*, the sage regards them as if they were sores upon his own body or pains within his own flesh. Though he might wish to ignore them, who could ignore them? Though he might wish to defer them, who could defer them?

Yet people fail to emulate the virtue of Heaven and Earth, to follow the nature of Heaven and Earth. Thus they oppress and slaughter the innocent, cast aside the aged and common folk, severing themselves from Heaven without even knowing it—how lamentable! The *Zhounan* says: *"The bream bends its tail; the royal house seems ruined. Though it seems ruined, Father and Mother are ever near."* The record states: This is the effect of resting in benevolence.

Zhou, occupying the throne as Son of Heaven, acted as father and mother to the people. With power over life and death, authority to depose and install, yet the people’s allegiance turned thus—if one seeks the reason, it lies in this: what they desired, he gathered and granted; what they detested, he did not impose. Thus it is said: *"Jie and Zhou lost the world because they lost the hearts of the people."* How then could King Wen have summoned them to come or pushed them to leave? To observe the human heart is to see the heart of Heaven; to observe the fate of the people is to see the Mandate of Heaven—nothing more.

*The "Zhou Odes" states: "Pacify the myriad states, and harvests abound year after year."*
The record notes: This is the true manifestation of the sage’s use of benevolence to serve Heaven, the ultimate response of Heaven’s heart—no mere embellished rhetoric. Yet how did Zhou, though famine-stricken, conquer Yin and still enjoy abundant years? King Zhou of Yin, as lord of all under Heaven, appointed the unworthy, extorted through exactions, and ruled with tyranny. Heaven’s revulsion was as swift and fierce as thunder and lightning—would it discriminate in whom it struck? Thus, Zhou’s famine was the scourge of Yin’s cruelty. Later, when King Wu released the horses on the southern slopes of Mount Hua and set the oxen free in the fields of Taolin, the common people returned to their livelihoods, the good and virtuous were spared, and Hou Ji’s teachings of farming were imparted to Yin’s remnant subjects. Thus, Yin’s peace was Zhou’s blessing. This is the implicit meaning of the record.

*The Comprehensive Mirror* states: South of Jiaozhi, the Yuechang people, after repeated translations, presented tribute, saying: "The roads are distant, mountains and rivers treacherous—we feared a single envoy might not reach you. Thus, we came through threefold translation to pay homage." The Duke of Zhou replied: "If virtue and grace do not extend to them, the noble man does not accept their tribute. If governance and commands are not enacted, the noble man does not serve their people." The interpreters conveyed: "We have received the Mandate to govern our land." The elders of Huangqi said: "For three years now, there have been no violent winds or excessive rains, and the seas have not stirred. We surmised that a sage must have arisen in the Central Kingdom—why not go and pay homage?" The Duke of Zhou attributed this to the king, praising the numinous spirits of the former kings and offering sacrifices at the suburban and ancestral temples.

The record notes: This is a sight unparalleled since the invention of writing—how was such a response achieved? *The Doctrine of the Mean* states: "Thus, the sage’s reputation overflows within the Central Kingdom and extends to the barbarian lands. Wherever the vermilion carriage reaches, wherever human effort penetrates, wherever Heaven covers, Earth bears, the sun and moon shine, and frost and dew fall—all beings with blood and breath revere and cherish him." Hence it is said: "He matches Heaven in sagely spirit, the pinnacle of transformative power." Such was the response. The House of Zhou accumulated merit and amassed virtue for over a thousand years, culminating in the reigns of Kings Wen, Wu, Cheng, and Kang, when the primal forces converged. Heaven and Earth harmonized, all things flourished, the Three Luminaries shone brightly, winds and rains came in season, the mountains of the Nine Provinces were not barren, and the rivers did not run dry. Within the borders, auspicious grain sprouted and double-eared wheat appeared; beyond the suburbs, phoenixes sang and qilin emerged. How then could the distant Eight Wastes not send envoys through repeated translation to pay homage? This was the natural response to the sage’s profound and subtle virtue. Otherwise, what use were the white wolves and white pheasants to the declining Yin, or the bowing and prostrations to the feeble Han? Wang Mang’s flattery and eulogies only served as tools for usurpation—how could they be mentioned in the same breath?

When the Duke of Shao toured the southern lands to disseminate King Wen’s governance, he sometimes rested beneath a sweet pear tree. Later generations cherished his virtue, so they loved the tree and could not bear to harm it, singing: *"Lush is the sweet pear, / Do not cut, do not fell— / The Duke of Shao lodged here. / Lush is the sweet pear, / Do not cut, do not break— / The Duke of Shao rested here. / Lush is the sweet pear, / Do not cut, do not bend— / The Duke of Shao delighted here."*

The record notes: Observing the ode to the sweet pear, I understand how deeply governance and teaching penetrate the people. The bestowal of grace upon things is like the harmonious wind: when it blows in the warmth of spring, people do not resent the confinement of deep winter; like the sweet rain: when it pours forth in the season of growth, people do not forget the withering drought. Though countless years have passed since the Duke of Shao’s time, when we recite his writings and read his poems, his lingering grace is still vivid before our eyes. How much more must those who lived in his era have felt? This is why the noble man is moved by governance that cannot bear to harm others.

The lords of the southern lands followed the Duke of Shao’s teachings and embraced King Wen’s transformative influence. They cultivated themselves, ordered their families, and governed their states. Their benevolence toward the people overflowed to benefit all living things. Thus, the poet praised them, singing: *"That sprouting reed, / One shoot yields five plump stalks— / Ah, the skillful archer! / That sprouting mallow, / One shoot yields five branches— / Ah, the skillful archer!"*

The record notes: Observing the era of the *Two Southern Lands*, I see that its rulers were like qilin, its ministers like *jiaoyu*, its scholars like lambs, and its people like nobles—how fully did harmonious qi permeate it! Harmony is the heart of Heaven and Earth, the virtue of the divine and enlightened. When the ruler embodies harmony, the hundred officials gather in harmony below, and the harmony of all things follows naturally. If the ruler is tyrannical, his ministers become like hawks and owls. If the ruler is as harsh as thorns, his ministers become like executioners. Then the land harbors barbarians, the wilds teem with rhinoceroses and tigers—how can its grass and trees flourish, or its birds and beasts multiply? In the second year of the Yongle reign, the Prince of Zhou presented a *jiaoyu*, and the scholar-officials composed odes in the same vein.

*The Appended Judgments* states: "The great virtue of Heaven and Earth is life; the great treasure of the sage is position. How does one preserve position? Through benevolence. How does one gather the people? Through wealth."

The record notes: Since ancient times, many have spoken of benevolence. Only our Master [Confucius] examined it closely. *Qian* is called father, *Kun* is called mother—is it not through the sage’s attainment of position that Heaven and Earth are ordered and the myriad things nurtured? Thus, virtue cannot be merely observed. Only by embodying benevolence can one lead others. Position cannot be merely occupied. Wealth is the heart of the people—gaining the people is gaining the world. Thus, benevolence cannot be applied indiscriminately. As the *Book of Rites* says: "To align with others is benevolence; to pursue profit is resentment." In a single phrase: it lies solely in the distinction between public and private.

Duke Ai asked about governance. The Master said: "The governance of Kings Wen and Wu is recorded on bamboo and wooden slips. When such men exist, their governance is enacted; when they perish, their governance ceases. The Way of man is swift in governance, just as the Way of earth is swift in growing trees. Governance is like the reed and bulrush—pliable yet resilient. Thus, governance depends on men. To secure men, one must cultivate the self; to cultivate the self, one must follow the Dao; to follow the Dao, one must embody benevolence. Benevolence is humanity—loving one’s kin is its essence. Righteousness is appropriateness—honoring the worthy is its essence. The gradations of loving kin and the ranks of honoring the worthy give rise to ritual. Therefore, the noble person cannot but cultivate the self. To cultivate the self, one must serve one’s kin; to serve one’s kin, one must understand others; to understand others, one must understand Heaven."

"There are five universal Ways in the world, and three virtues by which they are practiced. The five are: ruler and minister, father and son, husband and wife, elder and younger brothers, and the exchange between friends. These are the five universal Ways of the world. Wisdom, benevolence, and courage are the three universal virtues of the world, and there is one principle by which they are practiced. Some are born knowing them; some learn to know them; some come to know them through hardship—yet when they know them, it is the same. Some practice them with ease; some practice them for profit; some practice them through strenuous effort—yet when they succeed, it is the same."

Duke Ai said: "Your words, Master, are beautiful and perfect. Yet I am truly too dull to achieve them." The Master said: "To love learning is near to wisdom; to exert effort is near to benevolence; to know shame is near to courage. Knowing these three, one knows how to cultivate the self. Knowing how to cultivate the self, one knows how to govern others. Knowing how to govern others, one knows how to govern the world and the state."

"In governing the world and the state, there are nine principles: cultivating the self, honoring the worthy, loving kin, respecting great ministers, empathizing with all officials, cherishing the common people, attracting all artisans, pacifying distant peoples, and embracing the feudal lords. Cultivating the self establishes the Dao; honoring the worthy prevents confusion; loving kin ensures that uncles and brothers harbor no resentment; respecting great ministers prevents bewilderment; empathizing with all officials makes the scholars’ reciprocation weighty; cherishing the common people encourages the hundred clans; attracting all artisans ensures sufficiency of resources; pacifying distant peoples makes the four directions submit; embracing the feudal lords makes the world stand in awe."

"Purity of mind, solemn attire, and non-action contrary to ritual—these cultivate the self. Rejecting slander, distancing oneself from licentiousness, despising wealth and valuing virtue—these encourage the worthy. Honoring their positions, increasing their emoluments, and aligning with their likes and dislikes—these encourage love of kin. Appointing many officials to employ them—this encourages great ministers. Loyalty, trust, and generous emoluments—these encourage scholars. Timely employment and light taxation—these encourage the common people. Monthly assessments and rewards commensurate with work—these encourage artisans. Sending off the departing and welcoming the arriving, praising the good and pitying the incapable—these pacify distant peoples. Restoring extinguished lineages, reviving ruined states, stabilizing chaos and upholding the endangered, conducting court visits at proper times, giving generously and receiving modestly—these embrace the feudal lords. In governing the world and the state, there are nine principles, and there is one principle by which they are practiced."

"In all affairs, preparation leads to success; lack of preparation leads to failure. Words decided in advance do not falter; affairs decided in advance are not hindered; actions decided in advance are not remorseful; the Dao decided in advance is not exhausted. If one in a lower position does not gain the trust of superiors, the people cannot be governed. To gain the trust of superiors, there is a Way: if one is not trusted by friends, one cannot gain the trust of superiors. To be trusted by friends, there is a Way: if one does not accord with kin, one cannot be trusted by friends. To accord with kin, there is a Way: if one’s reflection on the self is not sincere, one cannot accord with kin. To make the self sincere, there is a Way: if one does not understand goodness, one cannot make the self sincere."

"Sincerity is the Way of Heaven; achieving sincerity is the Way of man. The sincere do not strive or deliberate yet attain it effortlessly, abiding in the mean—these are sages. Those who achieve sincerity choose goodness and firmly hold to it. They study broadly, inquire carefully, think cautiously, discern clearly, and act earnestly. If there is something they have not learned, they do not cease until they have learned it; if they have not mastered it, they do not cease. If there is something they have not inquired about, they do not cease until they have inquired; if they have not understood it, they do not cease. If there is something they have not thought about, they do not cease until they have thought it through; if they have not attained it, they do not cease. If there is something they have not discerned, they do not cease until they have discerned it clearly; if it is not clear, they do not cease. If there is something they have not practiced, they do not cease until they have practiced it earnestly; if they have not acted with sincerity, they do not cease. If others can do it once, they do it a hundred times. If others can do it ten times, they do it a thousand times. If one truly can follow this Way, though dull, one will become enlightened; though weak, one will become strong."

The record notes: "Governance depends on men, yet can it be achieved without learning and inquiry? This is why our Master stands above the hundred kings and surpasses all others. Moreover, our Master’s discourse on governance encompasses the universal Ways and virtues, the nine principles. Later generations’ discussions of governance focus on laws, decrees, and regulations. They believe that the four characters of the *Analects* are inexhaustible in a lifetime, and that the *Zhenguan* reign records stand above all ages—here, one may take heed."

Mencius said: "All people have a heart that cannot bear the suffering of others. When former kings had such a heart, they enacted governance that could not bear the suffering of others. Governing the world with a heart that cannot bear suffering, one may turn it in the palm of one’s hand." Why is it said that all people have a heart that cannot bear suffering? Now, if one suddenly sees a child about to fall into a well, everyone feels alarm and compassion—not to ingratiate themselves with the child’s parents, not to seek praise from neighbors and friends, nor to dislike the child’s cries.

The record notes: "What is called 'bearing' is like placing a blade to the heart and enduring it. The heart cannot be cut, yet while the edge of a physical blade may be avoided, the intangible edge is difficult to withstand."

Thus, when King Xuan of Qi could not bear the death of a single ox, yet went so far as to destroy ancestral temples, relocate sacred vessels, and imprison the innocent—who could endure such contradictions? When King Hui of Liang could not bear his people’s hunger, yet suffered defeat to Qi in the east, loss to Qin in the west, and humiliation by Chu in the south—how could such suffering be endured? In Mencius’ time, the ancient ways had receded further, and the world was plunged into chaos. The heart of alarm and compassion had all but vanished. Though he debated endlessly, his words were overpowered by the absence of this heart. Had he not pressed upon them the urgency of examining the innate goodness within—something every person could verify for themselves—what benefit would there have been? This discourse on the child falling into the well reveals what even the former sages had not articulated; it cannot be omitted.

When Duke Wen of Teng asked about governing the state, Mencius replied: "The people’s affairs cannot be delayed." As the *Odes* says:
*"By day gather the thatch,
By night twist the ropes,
Hasten to climb the roofs—
Then begin to sow the hundred grains."*

The Way of the people is this: those with constant property have constant hearts; those without constant property have no constant hearts. Without constant hearts, they become dissolute, perverse, reckless, and extravagant, stopping at nothing. Only after they fall into crime does one punish them—this is to ensnare the people. How can a humane ruler in power ensnare the people? Therefore, a worthy ruler must be reverent, frugal, and deferential, taking from the people only in regulated measure. The Xia dynasty levied a tax of one part in fifty; the Yin practiced the *assistance* system of one part in seventy; the Zhou implemented the *thorough* system of one part in a hundred—yet in reality, all amounted to a tithe. *Thorough* means thorough; *assistance* means corvée. As for hereditary stipends, Teng had long practiced them. The *Odes* says:
*"Rain upon our public fields,
Then upon our private plots."*
Only the *assistance* system has public fields. From this, we see that even the Zhou practiced *assistance*.

Establish schools—*xiang*, *xiao*, and *xu*—to educate the people. *Xiang* means nurturing; *xiao* means teaching; *xu* means archery. The Xia called them *xiao*, the Yin *xu*, and the Zhou *xiang*, but the institution of learning was shared by all three dynasties. Their purpose was to clarify human relationships. When human relationships are clear at the top, the common people will be harmonious below. Should a true king arise, he will surely come to adopt this model, making you the teacher of kings. As the *Odes* says:
*"Though Zhou is an old state,
Its mandate is ever renewed."*
This refers to King Wen. If you put this into practice, you too will renew your state.

When Bi Zhan inquired about the well-field system, Mencius said: "Your lord is about to implement humane governance. He has chosen you for this task—you must strive to fulfill it. Humane governance must begin with the demarcation of boundaries. If boundaries are not properly set, the well-fields will not be equitable, and grain stipends will not be fair. Thus, tyrannical rulers and corrupt officials invariably neglect boundary demarcation. Once boundaries are properly set, the distribution of fields and stipends can be determined with ease. Though Teng’s territory is small, it will have both gentlemen and commoners. Without gentlemen, there is none to govern the commoners; without commoners, there is none to sustain the gentlemen. In the countryside, adopt the *nine-one assistance* system; in the capital, let households pay a tithe themselves. Ministers and below must have *gui* fields—*gui* fields of fifty *mu*, and an additional twenty-five *mu* for each surplus laborer. When death or relocation occurs, there will be no disruption to the communal well-fields. Within a village, fields are shared in the same well-field system: neighbors support one another in coming and going, defend one another in watch, and assist one another in illness and hardship. Thus, the hundred surnames live in harmony. A square *li* forms a well-field of nine hundred *mu*, with the central plot as public field. The eight households each have a hundred *mu* of private land, and together they cultivate the public field. Only after public work is completed may they attend to private affairs—this is how the commoners are distinguished. This is the general outline. As for refining and enriching it, that lies with you and your lord."

The record notes: Mencius instructed Duke Wen with the *seven-one* method, just as Zengzi instructed Duke Ai with the *comprehensive thorough* system. Yet Duke Wen was able to send Bi Zhan to inquire about the well-field system—his natural endowment was as far superior to Duke Ai’s as heaven is from the abyss. Since the invention of writing, no one has expounded humane governance more thoroughly than this. Yet the noble person cannot help but sigh in lament. Alas! It is not the speaking that is difficult—it is the doing. How different are the Three Dynasties from later ages? The sagely and worthy ones’ teachings are like a carpenter’s marking line or a physician’s prescription. If one does not wish to craft squares and circles, so be it. But if one desires to craft squares and circles, can one say, "I will dispense with the compass and square"? If one does not wish to apply acupuncture and moxibustion, so be it. But if one desires to apply them, can one say, "I will dispense with the needle and stone"? Thus it is said: Should a true king arise, he will surely come to adopt this model, making you the teacher of kings. The sagely and worthy ones’ ultimate concern is this alone—how could it be the same as later ages, where success is pursued with urgency and results expected by dawn and dusk?

The *Record of Rites: Monthly Ordinances* states: On the day of the Beginning of Spring, the Son of Heaven personally leads the Three Dukes, the Nine Ministers, the feudal lords, and the great officers to welcome spring in the eastern suburbs. Upon returning, he rewards the dukes, ministers, and great officers at court, commanding the prime minister to spread virtue and harmonize decrees, bestow favors and confer benefits, extending them to all the people. In this month, heavenly *qi* descends and earthly *qi* ascends; heaven and earth harmonize, and plants and trees begin to sprout. The king commands the promotion of agriculture to instruct and guide the people. He then performs the sacrificial rites, using no female animals as victims, prohibiting the felling of trees, the destruction of nests, the killing of young insects, fledglings, or unhatched birds, the capture of pregnant animals or those with eggs, the gathering of large crowds, or the construction of coffins and outer coffins. Exposed bones and abandoned corpses are to be buried. In this month, one must not mobilize troops. To mobilize troops will surely bring heavenly calamity. If warfare must arise, let it not begin with me. Do not alter heaven’s Way, do not sever earth’s principles, do not disrupt human order.

The record notes: This concludes with the *Monthly Ordinances* because, as the world declines and morality deteriorates, the Way of humanity lies barren, and the virtue of rulers decays.

Only the saints reverently uphold the Heavenly Dao above and exhaustively fulfill human affairs below. For my part, I must also cultivate this heart in advance and broadly extend the proliferation of benevolence.

*Hongdao Record*, Scroll One, concludes.

*Hongdao Record*, Scroll Two: Benevolence

**Benevolence Between Ruler and Minister**

From the *Records of the Han*: In the first year of Emperor Xiaowen’s reign, during spring, he issued an edict: "Now is the harmonious season of spring, when grasses and trees flourish, all finding joy in their own way. Yet among my people, the widowed, orphaned, solitary, and destitute may face peril and ruin, with none to attend to their sorrows. As the father and mother of the people, what am I to do?" He then deliberated on measures to provide relief and loans.

The record notes: Placing this edict from the first year after the *Monthly Ordinances* is fitting, for the Han succeeded the Qin. The grace of rulers had grown sparse and desolate, akin to heaven and earth sealed in winter. Reading this, one feels as though the withered revive and the severed resurrect—what a magnificent atmosphere! It reveals that the grace of life-giving virtue is never extinguished, even when exhausted to its depths. How could one not consider this for the world?

He further said: "The elderly cannot stay warm without silk, nor be sated without meat. At the start of this year, I did not timely send envoys to inquire after the aged, nor grant them silk, wine, or meat. How then can the children and grandchildren of the realm be encouraged to honor and support their parents?" He commanded the officials to issue an order: in counties and districts, those aged eighty and above were to be granted one *shi* of grain per person each month, twenty *jin* of meat, and five *dou* of wine. Those ninety and above were to receive two bolts of silk and three *jin* of wadding.

The record notes: "Honor the elderly as you honor your own, extending this to others’ elderly"—the emperor may be said to have embodied this heart. Yet while the Lord of the West (King Wen) excelled in caring for the aged, he did not personally bestow gifts but instead enriched the people. He guided their wives and children, teaching them to cultivate and raise livestock. The emperor, knowing to bestow care upon the elderly, dispatched chief clerks to inspect the prefects, magistrates, and officials of the two-thousand-*shi* rank, each sending officers to patrol. Those found inadequate were to be reprimanded. Alas! Why not institute five-*mu* homesteads and hundred-*mu* fields, making local officials responsible for their oversight?

In the twelfth month, he issued an edict: "The law is the standard of governance. Now, those who have already been tried for crimes cause their innocent parents, wives, children, and siblings to be implicated and seized. I find this deeply unacceptable. Abolish the laws on collective punishment and confiscation."

The record notes: Mencius praised King Wen, saying, "The kin of criminals are not implicated." Though the emperor did not fully expand this principle, the vital energy of the Han surged forth. This is why Jia Shan said: When the emperor’s edicts were posted, even the elderly, infirm, and ailing would lean on staffs to go and listen, wishing to delay death even briefly to witness the fruition of virtuous transformation.

In the second year, autumn, ninth month, he issued an edict: "Agriculture is the great foundation of the realm, the means by which the people sustain themselves. Yet some neglect the root and pursue the branch, leading to lives unfulfilled. I am troubled by this. Therefore, this year I personally lead the ministers in plowing to encourage the people. I grant the realm a reduction of half this year’s field taxes."

The record notes: The emperor followed the advice of Jia Yi, a man well-versed in the fundamentals of statecraft. How could he not understand the reasons for abandoning the root to chase the branch? If the people are left to farm as they please, without limits on the amount, it leads to the powerful seizing land and the poor turning to secondary pursuits—this is a discussion that cuts to the root. Those engaged in secondary crafts or idle livelihoods are not unwilling to return to farming, but without even a sliver of land, where can they set foot? Can those who govern fail to adapt?

Jia Yi once urged the establishment of Han institutions to reform Qin laws, but his words went unheeded. Thus, he spoke only of what the emperor could achieve. The emperor’s love for the people was innate, and his personal plowing to lead the realm, along with the reduction of half the field taxes, became a tale of beauty for a thousand generations. Yet to those who truly understand, this may seem merely an encouragement for the powerful, while the common people are still driven by the strong. It is not the way of the Three Dynasties to encourage agriculture.

In the twelfth year, spring, he issued an edict: "The path to guiding the people lies in focusing on the root. I have personally led the realm in farming for ten years, yet the fields have not expanded, and in years of poor harvest, the people show signs of hunger. This is because those engaged in the work are too few, and the officials have not devoted themselves to it. My edicts have repeatedly urged the people to plant trees, yet no progress has been made. This is because the officials have not diligently implemented my decrees or clearly encouraged the people. Moreover, our farmers suffer greatly, yet the officials pay no heed to their hardships. How then can they be encouraged? I grant the farming people a reduction of half this year’s field taxes."

The record notes: The emperor followed the advice of Chao Cuo, a man of harshness and little grace, yet even he understood the importance of agriculture and the value of grain. His proposal to grant ranks in exchange for grain contributions had barely begun when the border regions could be supplied for five years and the commanderies and counties for one year. Thus, he again reduced the field taxes by half. Later dynasties repeatedly implemented policies to grant ranks in exchange for grain, yet none matched this. Why? Because Emperor Wen’s grain contributions were for the people, while later dynasties’ contributions were for themselves. The former used boundless wealth for limited needs, while the latter used limited wealth for boundless desires. This is the difference.

In the thirteenth year, sixth month, he issued an edict: "Agriculture is the foundation of the realm, and no duty is greater. Now, those who personally engage in farming are still subject to taxes and levies, making no distinction between root and branch. This is insufficient to fully encourage agriculture. Abolish the field taxes, and grant the realm’s orphans and widows silk, wadding, and other provisions in fixed amounts."

Here follows the translation:

---

The Record states: From this year onward, for more than a decade, no field taxes were collected from the people—was this not a rarity unmatched through the ages? For the emperor himself cultivated profound stillness, while his generals and ministers favored substance over ornament. Thus, officials remained secure in their posts, the people delighted in their labors, and year by year, stores accumulated while households multiplied in peace.

Yet the empire’s prosperity arose from the emperor’s own virtue, not from extracting gain from the people. What benefit could there be? For the powerful and strong amassed vast fields, claiming more than half the harvest in reckonings. Though the court abolished field taxes, private households still exacted their surplus. Even Yao and Shun could not have brought benefit under such conditions. Thus, the emperor’s grace surpassed that of the Three Dynasties, yet the people’s suffering rivaled that of the fallen Qin. This was because the ruler and his ministers failed to grasp the root, merely enriching the great and mighty. How lamentable!

In the spring of the sixteenth year, third month, an edict proclaimed: "In recent years, harvests have repeatedly failed, compounded by floods, droughts, epidemics, and pestilence. I am deeply troubled. Ignorant and unenlightened, I have not discerned the cause. Is it that my governance has faltered, my conduct erred? Or has the Dao of Heaven turned unpropitious, the bounty of Earth gone unclaimed, human affairs lost their harmony, or the spirits abandoned their offerings—how else could this have come to pass? Have the stipends of officials been neglected, or frivolous expenditures multiplied, that the people’s food should grow so scarce?

When fields are measured, they have not diminished; when the populace is counted, it has not decreased. By mouth, the land should still suffice, yet food remains woefully inadequate—where lies the fault? Is it that the people have turned to secondary pursuits, harming agriculture; that brewing and feasting waste grain; or that livestock consume too much? In matters great and small, I have yet to grasp the crux. Let the Chancellor, the nobles, the officials of two thousand *shi*, and the Academicians deliberate. If there is any way to aid the people, think deeply and speak without reserve."

The Record states: Emperor Wen’s devotion to the people could not be surpassed. Why then did he say, "Ignorant and unenlightened"? For a minister is the ruler’s resource for seeking counsel, dispelling confusion, and resolving doubts. Yet one such as Zhang Cang, who could not distinguish water from earth—how could he be expected to think deeply and speak without reserve? In a word: he fretted not over scarcity but over inequality. Had he possessed a heart for equalizing the people, measuring fields would have sufficed, and counting mouths would have increased abundance. Why then should the past have had surplus while the present suffers want?

He knew only to turn inward but not how to turn aright; he confessed faults but not their source; he summoned the Chancellor, nobles, officials, and Academicians to counsel but not how to counsel. Did not Mencius say: "As for enriching them, that lies with you and your son"? After reading this, those below might still fail to grasp the fault.

In the first year of Emperor Jing’s reign, fifth month, field taxes were reinstated at one part in thirty.

The Record states: To critique Emperor Wen follows the principle of the *Spring and Autumn Annals*. To praise Emperor Jing arises from a heart that honors virtue. Jing did not distance himself from Wen’s ways. To have changed nothing of his father’s Dao for three years—could this not be called filial?

In the sixth year of Emperor Guangwu of the Eastern Han, an edict restored the collection of field taxes at one part in thirty, "as in the former system." The "former system" referred to the first year’s ordinance. The beneficence of Wen and Jing endured long indeed!

---

In the second year thereafter, in the fourth month of summer, an edict proclaimed: "Carved patterns and intricate engravings harm the work of farming. Brocade and embroidery, woven cords and tassels, impair women’s labor. When farming is harmed, it becomes the root of hunger. When women’s work is impaired, it becomes the source of cold. If hunger and cold arrive together, few can avoid wrongdoing. We Ourself plow the fields, and the Empress tends the mulberry trees, to offer grain and silk for the ancestral temple, to prepare sacrificial vessels and robes, and to set an example for all under Heaven. We accept no tribute, reduce the provisions of the imperial kitchen, and lighten the taxes of the counties, desiring that all under Heaven devote themselves to farming. Let there be simple cloth and ample stores to prepare for disasters. Let the strong not encroach upon the weak, the many not oppress the few. Let the elderly live out their years in peace, and orphans grow to maturity. Yet this year, the harvest may fail in some places, and the people’s food grow scarce—where does the fault lie? Some officials act with deceit and fraud, using bribes as currency, plundering the common folk and exploiting the people. County magistrates and local officials, who should uphold the law, instead collude with thieves and steal—this is most senseless. Let all officials of the two-thousand-*shi* rank attend to their duties."

The Record states: Even in the time of Wen and Jing, there were deceitful officials who took bribes and plundered the people, no different from thieves. Why blame not the chief ministers, but only order the two-thousand-*shi* officials to attend to their duties? After Xiao [He] and Cao [Shen] established order, when Chen Ping was asked about money and grain, he could not answer, yet was praised for it. When Bing Ji passed by a corpse by the roadside, he did not inquire, and this was deemed understanding of proper priorities.

King Ling, upon receiving forthright counsel from Wang Ling, dismissed him in disgrace; when Zhou Yafu upheld the emperor’s covenant with unwavering loyalty, he too was dismissed; while Tao Qing, Liu She, and Wei Wan—all mediocre men—how could one expect them to guide and assist the throne in governing the people? Thus, throughout the Han dynasty, not a single minister’s achievements could be praised. When rulers indulge their own whims, groping blindly like a man stumbling in the dark, how can they dare hope that every county magistrate and local official will prove worthy of their posts?

In the third year, during the first month of spring, an edict proclaimed: “Agriculture is the foundation of all under Heaven. Gold, pearls, and jade cannot fill hunger or clothe the cold; though used as currency, their ultimate worth is unfathomable. When harvests fail in some years, it is because those engaged in secondary pursuits are many, while farmers are few. Let commanderies and kingdoms diligently encourage farming and sericulture, increase planting, and thereby secure clothing and food. If officials conscript the people, press them into service, or extract gold, pearls, or jade, they shall be charged with theft for illicit gain.”

The Record states: Emperor Jing did not commission carved ornaments, intricate engravings, brocades, or embroidered silks. In forbidding the mining of gold, pearls, and jade, he differed not at all from Emperor Wen’s reverence for simplicity. The foundation of the two emperors’ abundant prosperity lay precisely here. What is relaxed for the people has limits, while expenditures at the top know no end. If one loosens one measure while spending twice as much, though it may bear the name of relaxation, its encouragement is no different from what Emperor Jing warned against. Thus, after the decree against illicit gain was issued, there arose the custom of leading oxen and wearing calves—those in high positions must not fail to examine this.

The *Book of Han: Treatise on Food and Goods* records: When the Han first rose, even the Son of Heaven could not equip a team of four matched horses, while generals and ministers sometimes rode in oxcarts, and the common folk had no savings. Once the realm was pacified, Emperor Gaozu decreed that merchants could not wear silk or ride in carriages. During the reigns of Emperor Hui and Empress Dowager Lü, officials’ salaries were measured, government expenses calculated, and taxes levied upon the people accordingly. Yet the revenues from mountains, rivers, gardens, and marketplaces—along with the taxes from these sources—from the Son of Heaven down to the enfeoffed lords’ private estates for bathing and anointing, all served their personal upkeep and were not included in the empire’s general expenditures. Grain transported by water from the mountains of Shandong to supply the capital’s officials did not exceed several hundred thousand *shi* per year. Succeeded by Emperors Wen and Jing, who vied in frugality and reverence, nurturing and pacifying all under Heaven, for over seventy years the state knew no trouble. Except in times of flood or drought, the people were all self-sufficient, their households well-provided; granaries in cities and villages overflowed, and government storehouses brimmed with surplus goods. In the capital, coins piled up in the millions, rotting beyond counting; the granaries of the Grand Storehouse held grain heaped upon grain, spilling out in the open until it spoiled and became inedible. The common folk in streets and alleys owned horses, while in the fields and byways they roamed in herds. Those who rode calves or mares were so numerous they could not be gathered together; gatekeepers and watchmen ate millet and meat; officials saw their descendants prosper; and those who held office passed it down as a family name. Thus, every person...

Though there were men of lofty brilliance and magnanimity like Master Dong, none could supplant the age of Emperor Shizong, who delighted in grand achievements; and how could Jia Yi, young and gifted as he was, prevail over the plain-spoken, unadorned Jiang and Guan? Such was the rarity of the meeting of Yi and Zhou with their sovereigns, or of Tang and Wen in mutual aid—times when the virtue of unity could scarcely be repeated.

The *Biographies of Model Officials of the Western Han* records that during Emperor Jing’s reign, Wen Xi served as Governor of Shu Commandery. Benevolent and fond of education, he sought to transform the crude and barbaric customs of Shu. To guide and elevate its people, he selected over a thousand of the most promising young clerks from the commandery and counties—men like Zhang Shu—and personally instructed and encouraged them before sending them to the capital to study under the Erudites. After several years, the Shu students completed their studies and returned. Wen Xi appointed them to key positions, promoting them by merit, and some rose to become commandery governors and regional inspectors. He also established a school in the city of Chengdu, enrolling the sons of local families as students and exempting them from corvée labor. The most accomplished were appointed as clerks in the commandery and counties. He honored filial piety, brotherly respect, and diligent farming, often selecting students from the school to serve in his presence. Whenever he toured the counties, he brought along students well-versed in the classics and of exemplary conduct, dispatching them to teach and guide the people, allowing them to enter government offices and interact with officials. The local clerks and commoners, seeing this, held them in high esteem. Within a few years, many vied to become students of the school, and even the wealthy offered money to gain admission. Thus, the region underwent a profound transformation, rivaling Qi and Lu in cultural refinement. By Emperor Wu’s reign, the court ordered all commanderies and kingdoms to establish schools—an institution that began with Wen Xi. After his death in Shu, the officials and people built a shrine in his honor, where sacrifices have been offered without interruption to this day. The love of literature and refinement in Ba and Shu was the legacy of Wen Xi’s teachings.

The record states: The efforts of Wen Xi were not without cause—indeed, not without cause! For the teaching of the *xiang* and *xu* schools, reinforced by the principles of filial piety and brotherly respect, is the foundation of royal governance. The great achievements of Emperors Wen and Jing were marred only by the lack of this. Heaven, in its benevolence, brought forth this man. Though he did not hold high office in the Han court, his example endured, and commanderies and kingdoms followed suit, establishing schools that persist to this day. He was not only a teacher to kings but also a model for later generations. That a shrine was built to honor him was no accident.

Yue’s Prefect Tuo declared himself emperor, but when summoned along with his brothers and treated with virtue, he submitted and became a vassal, even forming a marriage alliance with the Xiongnu. Later, he betrayed his oath and raided the border defenses. The border guards did not retaliate, fearing that a deep incursion would burden the people. King Wu of Wu feigned illness to avoid attending court, so the emperor sent him a cane and staff. Though his ministers, including Yuan Ang, remonstrated earnestly, the emperor often granted his requests. Zhang Wu accepted bribes of gold and money, but when discovered, the emperor instead bestowed greater rewards to shame him. The court focused on governing through virtue, and thus the realm prospered in wealth and inclined toward ritual and righteousness. Legal cases dwindled to a few hundred, nearly rendering punishments obsolete. Alas, how benevolent!

It is also said: Confucius declared that the people of his time were as upright as those of the Three Dynasties—how true! The excesses of Zhou and Qin, with their dense nets of laws, could not suppress the worthy, but when the Han arose, it swept away the burdensome and harsh, allowing the people to rest. Emperor Wen added frugality and reverence, and Emperor Jing upheld his legacy. Over fifty or sixty years, customs were transformed, and the common people became pure and sincere. The Zhou had its Cheng and Kang; the Han, its Wen and Jing—how splendid!

The record states: Reading these two eulogies, one cannot help but sigh with emotion, glimpsing the enduring grace of the former kings. Thus, they are preserved here in full.

Some may ask: Can they be compared to the rulers of the Three Dynasties? The *Book of Changes* says: "Exhausting principle and fulfilling one’s nature leads to destiny." The *Doctrine of the Mean* says: "Next is to extend to the utmost the partial." For nature cannot be restrained. Thus, before expression, it is called the Mean; when expressed, if it accords with the norm, it is called Harmony. If not, one must correct the partiality of its manifestations to return to the original nature of Heaven’s mandate. This is what the *Hong Fan* means by "establishing and employing the August Ultimate" and "employing the Three Virtues."

Therefore, the sage kings of antiquity governed the world and responded to things by adapting to the times, using yang to expand and yin to restrain, grasping both extremes and employing the Mean among the people. Thus, they guided the world toward the August Ultimate. Though the emperors’ natural endowments approached this ideal, they could not exhaust the principles of things or fully realize the nature of the original substance. They did not broadly seek the wisdom of the primordial sages to align with them, nor did they daily receive instruction to awaken the heart of Heaven. Thus, their achievements were limited to one generation and could not advance to the level of the Three Dynasties.

Huang Ba was keenly perceptive and quick-witted, gentle and yielding. From Emperor Wu’s strict enforcement of laws to Emperor Zhao’s continuation of them, officials were harshly punished, and the bureaucracy became severe. Yet Huang Ba alone gained renown for his leniency and kindness. Emperor Xuan took a personal interest in governance, frequently issuing edicts of grace and favor, but officials often failed to convey them. As governor, Huang Ba selected capable clerks, divided them into districts, and had them announce the imperial decrees, ensuring the people understood the emperor’s intentions. He ordered postal stations and local offices to raise chickens and pigs to aid the widowed, orphaned, and impoverished. He then issued detailed regulations for village leaders, distributing them among the people to promote farming, sericulture, and frugality, eliminating wasteful practices like feeding grain to horses. Huang Ba’s diligence and energy enabled him to implement these measures effectively. Officials and commoners who encountered him scrutinized his every word and action, cross-referencing them with hidden details. When he wished to dispatch an investigation, he chose elderly, incorruptible clerks, giving strict instructions. The clerks dared not stay at postal stations or eat at roadside inns, and they questioned every household without daring to conceal anything. If someone died without means for burial, the local officials reported it, noting where a large tree could be used for a coffin. When officials were sent to verify, they found everything as described. Such was his discernment and wisdom that officials and people could not fathom its source, calling him divine.

The wicked departed, and as Huang Ba governed the commandery, banditry diminished. The villages transformed, nurturing filial sons and respectful younger brothers. To provide for the elderly, he encouraged goodness, guarded against villainy, practiced frugality, and amassed wealth. He promoted planting trees and raising livestock—though these measures seemed trivial, their effects unfolded step by step. Ba thoroughly understood the origins of hardship among widows, widowers, orphans, and the childless, and he established districts and wards to implement moral instruction before resorting to punishment. His primary aim was to foster completion and ensure peace. Thus, he won the hearts of officials and people, and with each passing year, his governance was deemed the finest in the realm. An imperial edict proclaimed: "The Prefect of Yingchuan, Huang Ba, truly embodies wifely obedience and filial piety. Fields are yielded at their borders, and lost items remain unclaimed on the roads." The Son of Heaven, recognizing his administrative achievements, issued decrees to the populace, declaring that the multitude should be cared for, and the widowed, orphaned, and impoverished should be provided for.

For eight years, there were no major criminal cases, and the population grew. Officials and people were guided by moral instruction, and virtue flourished in their conduct. He could indeed be called a worthy gentleman. It is recorded: Confucius told Duke Ai, "When the right person is present, governance thrives; when they are gone, governance withers." Mencius advised the rulers of Qi and Liang, urging them to raise chickens, pigs, dogs, and swine, and to care for the widowed, orphaned, and solitary. Yet none of these lords could act upon his words. Only in the Han dynasty did Huang Ba possess the strength to fulfill them. Thus, the words of sages and worthies shine like the sun and moon, while the heavenly nature of the human heart remains unchanged across ancient and modern times. The foundation of governance is as simple as weaving reeds, and the people should not be divided like Qin and Yue. Alas, his influence was confined to Yingchuan and did not extend across the realm. Though skilled in governing the people, he was less adept as a grand minister. This is why his governance, though effective, did not match the Three Dynasties, nor his achievements those of the sages.

Gong Sui was loyal, honest, resolute, and possessed great integrity. During Emperor Xuan’s long reign, the regions around Bohai suffered annual famines, and banditry surged, yet the local officials could not suppress it. The emperor sought someone capable of restoring order, and the Chancellor and Censor-in-Chief recommended Gong Sui as the Prefect of Bohai, though he was already over seventy. Emperor Xuan said to him: "Bohai is in chaos, and I am deeply concerned. How will you quell the bandits?" Sui replied: "The sea’s edge is remote and untouched by imperial virtue. The people suffer from cold and hunger, yet the officials show no compassion, driving these innocent children to brandish weapons in the marshes. Do you wish me to conquer them or pacify them?" The emperor, pleased with his response, said: "I selected a worthy man precisely to pacify them." Sui replied: "I have heard that governing a rebellious people is like straightening a tangled rope—it cannot be done in haste. Only with patience can it be untangled. I ask that the Chancellor and Censor-in-Chief not restrict me, allowing me to act flexibly within the law." The emperor granted his request.

When the commandery learned of the new prefect’s arrival, they sent troops to welcome him, but Sui dismissed them all. He issued orders to the counties, disbanding the pursuit of bandits. Those carrying sickles, hooks, or farming tools were deemed good citizens, and officials were forbidden from questioning them. Only those bearing weapons were considered bandits. Arriving in a single carriage, he entered the prefectural seat, and the commandery was immediately pacified. The bandits disbanded, and even the pirates along the Bohai coast, upon hearing Sui’s decrees, laid down their weapons and took up plows and looms. Thus, the region was entirely pacified, and the people settled, delighting in their work. He opened the granaries to relieve the poor, lent grain to the needy, appointed capable officials, and ensured the people were comforted and nurtured.

Observing the extravagant customs of the Qi region, where people favored frivolous crafts over farming, Sui personally led by example in frugality and encouraged the people to devote themselves to agriculture and sericulture. He ordered each household to plant one tree, a hundred elms, fifty mulberries, a plot of onions and leeks, two sows, and five hens. Those who carried swords were instructed to sell them and buy oxen, and those with knives were told to sell them and buy calves. He declared: "Why carry oxen and calves at your waist? In spring and summer, you must tend the fields, and in autumn and winter, you must gather the harvest. Store fruits, melons, and gourds, and diligently inspect the fields." The commandery soon accumulated surplus, officials and people grew prosperous, and lawsuits ceased.

It is recorded: Gong Sui’s response is a timeless maxim. The emperor praised his trust in rewards and punishments, and the officials and people praised the resulting peace—such was his achievement. Yet if one truth is met with a hundred falsehoods, how can this be called a revival to rival the virtue of Shang and Zhou? Alas! Gong Sui is gone, and with him, the hooks, clasps, swords, and knives, the competing oxen and calves. Only my fond memories remain. If household fowl and domestic animals flourish, if oxen are led and calves are carried, yet turmoil persists, while words like swords and tongues like blades wield spears and bare blades, turning good people into enemies—what heart drives this? What heart drives this?

Zhao Xinchen, a top graduate in the classics, treated the people as his children and was praised wherever he served. Promoted to Prefect of Nanyang, he was diligent and strategic, devoted to benefiting the people and enriching them. He personally encouraged farming, traversing the fields, staying in villages and wards, rarely resting at home, and frequently inspecting the commandery. He opened water channels, dredged ditches, and constructed sluice gates and dams in dozens of locations to expand irrigation. Year by year, the irrigated land increased, reaching thirty thousand *qing*. The people reaped the benefits, accumulating surplus. Xinchen established equitable water-sharing agreements for the people, carving them in stone at field edges to prevent disputes. He prohibited extravagance in weddings and funerals, ensuring all adhered to frugality. The sons of officials and clerks, who idled and neglected farming, were reprimanded or dismissed, and the worst offenders were investigated for unlawful conduct to set an example.

His transformative influence spread, and the commandery wholeheartedly embraced farming. The people flocked to him, the population doubled, banditry and lawsuits ceased, and officials and people grew close. He was called "Father Zhao." Du Shi, a man of talent, served as Imperial Censor during the *Jianwu* era, pacifying Luoyang. Later, he was sent to Hebei to suppress rebellious bandits and was appointed Magistrate of Chenggao. After three years in office, his governance was exceptional, and he was promoted to Prefect of Nanyang.

He was frugal by nature, and his governance was pure and equitable. He established authority by punishing the violent, excelled in strategy, and reduced the burdens of corvée labor on the people. He devised water-powered trip hammers to forge agricultural tools, achieving much with little effort, which greatly benefited the common folk. He also repaired and expanded irrigation ponds, reclaiming vast tracts of farmland, so that every household in the commandery grew prosperous. His contemporaries compared him to Zhao Xincheng. Thus, the people of Nanyang said: "Before, there was Father Zhao; after, there is Mother Du."

*Recorded:* The *Book of Songs* says: "The joyous and gracious lord is the people’s father and mother." I have heard these words, but never seen such a man—until now. Is this not a delight for all ages?

During the Eastern Han, Zhang Kan was known for his noble aspirations and exemplary conduct. At sixteen, he studied in Chang’an, where the scholars called him "the sagely youth." Emperor Guangwu summoned him to serve as Cavalry Commandant, later appointing him to lead the Tiger-Toothed Cavalry General. When Du Mao campaigned against the Xiongnu at Gaoliang, Zhang Kan was made Prefect of Yuyang. He arrested and bound the cunning and treacherous, enforcing rewards and punishments with absolute reliability, so that officials and people alike gladly served under him. When ten thousand Xiongnu cavalry raided Yuyang, Zhang Kan led a few thousand horsemen in a swift counterattack, crushing them and bringing peace to the commandery’s borders. He then opened over eight thousand *qing* of rice paddies at Husunu, encouraging the people to farm, which led to great prosperity. The people sang:
