*"Mulberry trees bear no side branches,
Wheat stalks grow twin ears.
Under Zhang’s governance,
Joy knows no bounds."*

After years in office, the Xiongnu dared not violate the frontier. The Emperor, hearing of this, summoned the fiscal officers of all commanderies to inquire about local customs and the abilities of past and present prefects. Fan Xian, the fiscal officer of Shu Commandery, said: "The Prefect of Yuyang, Zhang Kan, was once in Shu. His benevolence brought grace to the people, and his authority could suppress the wicked. When Gongsun Shu was defeated, treasures piled like mountains, yet when Zhang Kan left office, he rode a broken-down carriage and carried only coarse cloth sacks."

*Recorded:* Emperor Wen of Han once said: "If I had generals like Lian Po and Li Mu, would I fear the Xiongnu?" The ancient Yuyang is now the outskirts of the capital. During the *Jiajing* era, auspicious wheat with twin ears frequently appeared—just as Zhang Kan’s song described. If such virtues were his aspiration, how could the world lack men like him?

*Master Xingzi said:* "Only by refraining from certain actions can one achieve great deeds. Then, what are mountains of gold and jewels compared to wheat with twin ears? The noble man may thus find his own strength."

Zhuo Mao was generous, kind, respectful, and affectionate. Though his fellow villagers and old friends differed in conduct and ability, all admired and delighted in him. When he was appointed Magistrate of Mi, he labored earnestly, treating the people as his children. He commended the good and instructed them, never speaking harshly. Officials and people loved him and could not bear to deceive him. Someone once reported that a post-house chief had accepted gifts of rice and meat from him. Zhuo Mao asked: "Did the chief demand them from you? Did you have business with him and ask him to accept them? Or did you give them out of goodwill in ordinary times?" The man replied: "I simply gave them." Zhuo Mao said: "If you gave them and he accepted, why report it?" The man said: "I heard that a worthy and enlightened lord makes people unafraid of officials, and officials do not take from the people. Now, I fear officials, so I gave them. Since the chief accepted, I came to report it." Zhuo Mao said: "You are deluded. What distinguishes humans from beasts is our capacity for benevolence, love, wisdom, and mutual respect. If you alone refuse to cultivate these, can you soar high and flee far, never to dwell among men?" The chief had long been a good official, and seasonal gifts were customary. Zhuo Mao told the man: "Go home and reflect on this." Thus, the people heeded his teachings, officials cherished his kindness, and moral transformation spread widely—so much so that lost items remained unclaimed on the roads.

When Emperor Guangwu first sought out Zhuo Mao, he issued an edict: "Formerly the Magistrate of Mi, Zhuo Mao, cultivated himself with integrity, upheld his principles with steadfast sincerity, and truly accomplished what others could not. His name resounds throughout the realm, and he deserves the highest reward under heaven. Now, let Zhuo Mao be appointed Grand Mentor and enfeoffed as Marquis of Baode."

The Record states: Ban Yue’s commentary says: "At the beginning of the Jianwu era, when heroes and warlords still stirred unrest, the times were indeed turbulent and pressing. Yet Zhuo Mao, a minor magistrate of unremarkable talent, was the first to receive an imperial summons, honored with gracious words and lavish courtesy. How does this differ from King Wu of Zhou’s elevation of the reclusive Jian to high office? Though Zhuo Mao’s virtue was pure, it was the emperor’s supreme benevolence that made this possible. In this, Emperor Guangwu remains unmatched."

Lu Gong was appointed Magistrate of Zhongmou and governed solely through moral transformation, never resorting to punishments. When litigants Xu Bo and others engaged in prolonged disputes over farmland, successive officials had failed to resolve the case. Lu Gong adjudicated the rights and wrongs fairly, and both parties withdrew, reproaching themselves, abandoning their plows, and yielding the land to one another. Thus, the officials and people trusted and obeyed him.

In the seventh year of the Jianchu era, locusts ravaged the crops of commanderies and kingdoms, their swarms stretching like jagged teeth along the borders—yet they did not enter Zhongmou.

When Prefect Yuan An of Henan heard of this, he doubted its veracity and dispatched his aide Fei Qin to investigate. Lu Gong accompanied him through the fields, and together they sat beneath a mulberry tree. A pheasant alighted nearby, beside which stood a young boy. Qin asked, "Why do you not capture it?" The boy replied, "The pheasant is tending its chicks." Qin started in surprise, rose, and took leave of Gong, saying, "I came to observe your governance at close hand. Now, the locusts do not invade your borders—this is the first marvel. Your transformation extends even to birds and beasts—this is the second. That a mere child possesses such benevolent heart—this is the third. I shall return to the prefecture and report all in full."

That year, auspicious grain sprouted, and Gong was promoted to Judge of the Court of Judicial Review. Yuan An thereupon memorialized the throne with an account of these events, and the emperor marveled at them.

It is recorded: From the Han to the present, over fifteen hundred years have passed, yet the names of Gong, Huang, Zao, and Lu have never faded. Not only were they honored in life and mourned in death, but in truth, they surpassed the ancients and outshone the moderns. How rare their selection! Since the Tang and Wu dynasties, such excellence has become difficult to attain.

**Hongdao Record, Scroll Two (conclusion)** #1 The following text is missing. According to the *Book of Han, Treatise on Food and Goods*, the subsequent passage reads: *"Each person cherished self-respect and held transgression in dread; they first practiced righteousness and shunned disgrace. Thus, the net of law grew sparse while the people prospered. Yet as wealth swelled, arrogance overflowed, and some even resorted to consolidation and domination, wielding force to tyrannize their villages. The imperial clans possessed land, and from the dukes and ministers downward, all vied in extravagance—mansions, carriages, and attire emulated the throne without limit. When things reach their peak, decline follows: such is the nature of change."*

#2 The preceding text is missing.

---

**Hongdao Record, Scroll Three**
**Benevolence**
**The Benevolence of Ruler and Minister**

The *Old Book of Tang, Treatise on Food and Goods* states: At the founding of the Tang, land was allotted to the people as "mouth-share" and "hereditary fields," and taxes were levied through the system of *zu*, *yong*, and *diao*. Expenditures were measured. Since soldiers were maintained through the *fǔwèi* system, the army, though large, incurred no loss. Official posts were fixed in number, so offices did not proliferate, and salaries were easily met. Though it did not match the prosperity of the Three Dynasties, it could still serve as a permanent system.

**Recorded Note:** Emperor Taizong of the Tang cannot be ranked among the ancient sage-kings. Yet in recording his virtues, one cannot help but feel regret. Dong Zhongshu once proposed: "The Qin adopted the laws of Shang Yang, abolished the well-field system, and permitted the buying and selling of land. The rich amassed fields spanning *qiān* and *mò*, while the poor had not even a speck of ground to stand on. How could the common folk not suffer? Though reviving the well-field system would be difficult, we should at least draw nearer to antiquity. Limit the land holdings of the wealthy to aid the destitute and block the path of consolidation." At the time, Emperor Wu was bent on pursuing profit and did not heed the advice. By the reign of Emperor Ai, Shi Dan renewed the proposal, noting that after generations of peace, the wealthy and powerful had amassed fortunes in the tens of millions, while the poor grew ever more destitute. He urged some form of restriction. Yet the powerful and influential found it inconvenient, and the measure was not implemented. Later, Wang Mang exploited the pretext of "royal fields," plunging the realm into deeper chaos and prolonging disaster—what benefit was there? After Jin Wudi pacified Wu, though he instituted a system of seventy *mǔ* per household, the Five Barbarians soon rebelled. Only under Emperor Xiaowen of the Northern Wei did Li Anshe’s proposal for the equal-field system take effect, which the Northern Qi, Northern Zhou, and Sui later adopted. Alas! Who now recalls the four hundred years of the great Han...

One may ask: why did the proposals of great worthies, though repeatedly voiced, prove insufficient, while in the brief span of the Six Dynasties, a single word from Li Anshe sufficed—and when the Tang resolutely implemented it, how could this fool contain his exultant joy?

The Tang measured fields by *bu*: a *mu* was one *bu* wide and two hundred forty *bu* long, and one hundred *mu* made a *qing*. All commoners were registered at birth as "yellow"; at four, as "small"; at six, as "middle"; at eleven, as "adult"; and at sixty, as "elderly." Under the system of land allocation, adults and males aged eighteen or older received one *qing* each—eighty *mu* as "allotted land" and twenty *mu* as "perpetual holding." The elderly, the severely ill, and the disabled received forty *mu*; widows and concubines, thirty *mu*; and household heads, an additional twenty *mu*. Of these, twenty *mu* were designated as perpetual holdings, the rest as allotted land. On perpetual holdings, elms, jujubes, mulberries, and other suitable trees were to be planted, each in specified numbers. Where land was abundant enough to suffice the population, it was deemed a "generous precinct"; where scarce, a "narrow precinct." In narrow precincts, allocated land was halved. For land of varying fertility—where fields were rotated annually—double the usual allotment was granted, but in generous precincts with triennial rotation, no such doubling occurred. Artisans and merchants in generous precincts received half the standard allotment, while in narrow precincts, none was given.

Commoners who relocated or lacked means for burial could sell their perpetual holdings. Those moving from narrow to generous precincts could sell both their perpetual and allotted land. Once sold, no further allotment was granted; upon death, the land reverted to the state for redistribution. All allocations and reclamations occurred in the tenth month, with priority given to the poor and those liable for corvée. Surplus land in a precinct was allocated to neighboring precincts; surplus in a county, to neighboring counties; and surplus in a prefecture, to nearby prefectures.

It is recorded: this was the Tang system of land allocation. After the turmoil of the Five Barbarians, few remained to till the soil. The Later Wei adopted the practice, granting "open fields" to the people—open fields being ownerless wasteland where no trees were planted. Mulberry fields were exempt from allocation limits, for they were the people’s perpetual holdings, their constant cultivation. The Tang inherited this system, distinguishing between perpetual holdings and allotted land. Initially, these were likely not state-owned lands reclaimed and redistributed to the landless. Rather, because mulberry fields were exempt from allocation, they became known as perpetual holdings, while the originally granted open fields were limited as allotted land. Otherwise, if perpetual holdings were state property planted with suitable trees like mulberries and jujubes, how could they still be bought and sold? Since allocations varied by age, labor capacity, and local land availability, with the state reclaiming and redistributing them, the people were merely allowed to consume the produce, not own the land—so how could they sell it outright?

Ancient laws most strictly forbade frequent relocation. The *Royal Regulations* states: "The well-field system is not constant." Mencius said: "For death or relocation, do not leave the village." Yet now, commoners were permitted to move freely, and those relocating from narrow to generous precincts could even sell their allotted land, with only the deceased’s land reclaimed for redistribution. Under such conditions, how could the people not relocate? How could they not lose their land? And how could the reclaimed land be redistributed? These contradictions in implementation raise doubt: was the error in the historian’s record, or in governance itself?

From the Qin onward, over fourteen hundred years passed before a land-allocation system could be implemented—beginning with the Tang, which alone suffices to show its difficulty. Yet the system was not without flaws. Only after the Yonghui era was the ban on buying and selling land enforced, with violators forced to return the land and punished. Alas, this came too late. No wonder land consolidation persisted as before.

All those granted land were to pay two *hu* of silk and three *hu* of rice per adult male annually, termed "rent." Based on local produce, each adult male was to deliver two bolts of silk, two *zhang* of fine silk or *luo*, one-fifth more cloth, three taels of cotton, or three catties of hemp—except in remote regions, where fourteen taels of silver were accepted instead—termed "tribute." For corvée labor, twenty days of service were required per year, with two additional days in leap years; those who did not serve paid three *chi* of silk instead, termed "labor tax." If extraordinary service exceeded twenty-five days, tribute was waived; if it reached thirty days, both rent and tribute were waived, though total service never exceeded fifty days.

A note states: These were the Tang’s tax levies. The system of rent, labor tax, and tribute was based on the adult male population. The term "tribute" (*diao*) implies adjustment—balancing local resources. For instance, silk or fine silk was levied at one *zhang* per region, not two *zhang* of each totaling six *zhang*; cloth and hemp were similarly adjusted. Yet later records describe an annual output of two bolts of silk, two *zhang* each of fine silk and *luo*, one-fifth more cloth, three taels of cotton, and three catties of hemp—or fourteen taels of silver in non-mulberry regions—raising doubts that this burden exceeded the original calculation. Readers should refer to the *Tongdian* and *Huiji Yao* for accuracy. The *Huiji Yao* specifies: based on local produce, each adult male delivered two *zhang* of silk or fine silk, one-fifth more cloth, two taels of cotton, or three catties of hemp for cloth-producing regions, as tribute.

From princes and dukes downward, all held hereditary land. The Grand Empress Dowager, Empress Dowager, Empress, maternal relatives above the mourning grade, titled ladies of the first rank and above, imperial princes and officials of the fifth rank and above, those with hereditary titles or whose fathers, brothers, or uncles held active or meritorious posts of the third rank and above, sons of county barons, students of the Imperial University and National Academy, filial sons, obedient grandsons, righteous husbands, and chaste widows—along with their registered households—were exempt from taxes and corvée. Households with taxable members were termed "taxable households." Exemptions applied to the elderly, disabled, severely ill, widows and concubines, private retainers, female slaves, and officials of the ninth rank and above.

Each village submitted annual registers detailing residents’ ages and landholdings, compiled into township records, then county, prefectural, and finally Ministry of Revenue reports. Separate fiscal registers projected the following year’s taxes and labor services, submitted to the Ministry of Revenue. When the state required funds, a memorial was first presented, and the levy amount was posted at county gates and village markers for public notice. In cases of flood, drought, frost, locusts, or losses exceeding forty percent, rent was waived; if mulberry or hemp crops failed entirely, tribute was waived; if land losses reached sixty percent, both rent and tribute were waived; if losses were total, all services were exempted.

A note states: These were the Tang’s policies of relief and restoration. From princes to commoners, all were subject to graded limits, enabling their descendants to preserve their holdings indefinitely. Why, then, could enduring peace not be achieved? Alas, the system was lost almost immediately. Thus, I have observed: the Han descendants upheld the thirty-tax-one system, though their ancestors failed to establish the equitable tithe; the Tang ancestors devised detailed regulations and prohibitions, yet their descendants abandoned frugality and care for the people. Neither matched the governance of the Three Dynasties.

When Taizong first pursued governance with vigor, officials’ evaluations prioritized those who aided the widowed, orphaned, and young. Those who failed in exhortation were punished by reclassification as "concealed households." A note states: This was the Tang’s system of merit and demerit. Directing fifth-rank officials and above to recommend local administrators demonstrated initial emphasis on governance. Evaluating officials by their success with the vulnerable and demoting those who failed showed final accountability. Yet in practice, only prefectural governors were truly scrutinized. Alas, from the Zhenguan era onward, the court favored inner officials over local administrators, often appointing military men as prefects or exiling incompetent capital officials to the provinces. Though the emperor was earnest in governance, could he personally lead the realm? This is why Tang’s capable officials never matched the Han’s in number.

Rent levies varied by harvest timing, terrain, and distance; tribute was collected in the eighth month and dispatched in the ninth. Simultaneous deliveries prioritized distant regions, with villagers responsible for transport. Prefectures annually procured local products as tribute, priced according to silk quality, never exceeding fifty bolts. Exotic goods, delicacies, dogs, horses, hawks, and hounds were not offered without imperial decree. Additional levies were offset against rent and taxes.

A note states: These were the Tang’s transport policies. Later, under the Two-Tax system, summer payments were due in the sixth month and autumn payments in the eleventh—this earlier system was abandoned. At the time, Taizong was deeply attentive to the people, curbing desires and abandoning luxuries, postponing grand ceremonies like fengshan sacrifices and military campaigns. Thus, prefectural tribute was priced by silk quality, never exceeding fifty bolts, and additional levies were credited against taxes. What a noble vision! Yet after Zhenguan, such standards gradually declined.

In times of famine, community granaries provided relief, and if supplies were insufficient, the people were relocated to other prefectures for sustenance. The Left Vice Director of the Department of State Affairs, Dai Zhou, proposed: "From princes and nobles downward, calculate the cultivated land, and in autumn, establish charity granaries based on the harvest in each locale. In years of poor harvest, these would provide for the people." Taizong approved and decreed a tax of two *sheng* per *mu*, with millet, wheat, glutinous rice, or non-glutinous rice collected according to local suitability. In regions with ample land, levies were based on what was sown; in densely populated areas, assessments were made according to the young crops, with lighter burdens. If a field’s yield fell by fourteen percent, half the tax was remitted; if by seventeen percent, the entire tax was waived. For merchants without land, households were classified into nine ranks, contributing grain from five *shi* to five *dou* in gradations. The lowest households and non-Han peoples were exempt. In years of poor harvest, the grain was used to relieve the people. If lent as seed, repayment was due in autumn. Later, in Luoyang, Xiang, You, Xu, Qi, Bing, Qin, and Pu prefectures, ever-normal granaries were established, storing millet for nine years and rice for five; in low-lying, damp areas, millet for five years and rice for three, all codified in regulations.

A note states: These were the Tang’s famine-relief policies. At the time, Taizong placed great importance on the selection of local officials, ensuring that prefects and county magistrates were competent. Thus, community granaries sufficed for relief, charity granaries for provision, and ever-normal granaries for storage. Without capable officials, even if levies were imposed from princes downward based on cultivated land, it would only add another layer of strictures. This, too, is something rulers must understand. In the early Zhenguan era, households numbered fewer than three million, and one bolt of silk could exchange for a *dou* of rice. By the fourth year, rice cost four or five *qian* per *dou*, and for months on end, doors remained unlocked. Horses and cattle roamed the wilds, and travelers journeyed thousands of *li* without carrying provisions. The people and resources flourished, and over 1.2 million from the Four Barbarians submitted in allegiance. That year, the empire recorded only twenty-nine capital sentences, earning the era the name "Great Peace."

Upon his ascension, the emperor often discussed governance with his ministers, saying: "Now, following great turmoil, I fear the people may not be easily transformed." Wei Zheng replied: "Not so. People long at peace grow arrogant and indolent, and the arrogant are difficult to teach. Those who have endured chaos are distressed and suffering, and the suffering are easily transformed—like the hungry readily accepting food or the thirsty readily accepting drink." The emperor deeply agreed, though Feng Deyi disagreed. Ultimately, the emperor followed Wei Zheng’s counsel. That year, the empire enjoyed a bumper harvest, and the scattered returned to their homes. In villages, a *dou* of rice cost no more than three or four *qian*, and from the eastern seas to the southern Five Ridges, doors remained unlocked, travelers carried no provisions, and sustenance was found along the roads. The emperor said to his ministers: "This is the result of Wei Zheng urging me to practice benevolence and righteousness. It is a pity Feng Deyi did not live to see it."

A note states: The *Yijing*’s hexagram *Daguo* says: "The ridgepole sags; it is advantageous to have somewhere to go, and there will be success." The second line reads: "A withered poplar sprouts new shoots; an old man takes a young wife—nothing is inauspicious." Taizong truly possessed extraordinary talent, yet he lacked the celestial virtue and kingly Way as his foundation—like a sagging ridgepole or a withered poplar. Fortunately, the governance of the Zhenguan era was aided by worthy ministers like Fang, Du, Wang, and Wei—like an old man taking a young wife. Thus, though there were signs of sagging beams and withered poplars, there was also a path to success and advantage. The noble man does not reject this.

The *Annals of Song* records: Emperor Renzong embodied Heaven and followed the Dao, perfecting merit and completing virtue, divine in culture and martial prowess, wise and enlightened, sagacious and filial. The emperor’s nature was benevolent, filial, magnanimous, and composed; joy and anger never showed on his face. Initially enfeoffed as Prince of Shouchun, he studied in the Zishan Hall. In the first year of Tianxi, he concurrently served as President of the Secretariat; the following year, he was promoted to Prince of Sheng and enfeoffed as Crown Prince in the ninth month on the *dingmao* day.

A note states: In the millennia of historical records, none have been so purely benevolent as the emperor—he is truly a rarity. Thus, his posthumous title preserves his greatness, offering a model for rulers. The *Mengzi* says: "To nourish the correct nature is the work of a sage." At that time, the emperor’s perfect nature was unspoiled. In such an era, upright men could have made it an age of Yao and Shun. By establishing the Zishan Hall for study, he nurtured his nature without allowing private desires to interfere—this was the work of sage-making, and the Song dynasty’s family tradition surpassed that of Han and Tang. The Assistant Director of the Department of State Affairs, Li Di, was appointed as the Crown Prince’s Attendant.

*Zun Yao Lu* states: Li Di and others often attended banquets with the crown prince and observed his dignified demeanor. Even when entertainers performed before him, he paid little heed. Another day, during a memorial, the emperor remarked: "Even in private, he never speaks or laughs idly."

A note states: Li Di’s noble character was well-known, but declining the title of Grand Tutor was perhaps excessive. The positions of *gong* and *gu* assist the Son of Heaven, while the *shibao* nurture the crown prince—these are ancient and enduring institutions, not innovations of Taizong’s time, existing when established and absent when not. Since the Song dynasty relied solely on chief ministers, the emperor had no *gong* or *gu* to advise him, and thus the crown prince had no *shibao* to guide him. This was a flaw in their system compared to the Zhou dynasty.

In the fourth year, an edict ordered the Grand Tutor to oversee the state, and every five days, the Zishan Hall was opened. The crown prince stood facing south, with assisting ministers and officials in attendance. He listened to their discussions and was told: "Simply uphold the public good, and all will be well."

A note states: The emperor never spoke or laughed idly about himself, and in dealing with others, he strove to uphold the public good. What purity and integrity!

The *Meng* hexagram’s nine in the fifth place states: "A youthful learner—auspicious." Could this not describe this emperor? In the first year of Qianxing, on the *wu-wu* day of the second month, an imperial testament commanded the crown prince to ascend the throne.

A note states: At that time, the emperor was but thirteen—like a dragon newly shedding its skin, not yet ready for clouds and rain; like a qilin newly formed in hoof, not yet ready to tread the earth. Thus the *Yijing* says: "A spring issues from beneath the mountain—*Meng*. The noble person, through resolute action, nurtures virtue." Was this not because his governance had not yet reached maturity, his nature not yet firmly established? Had there been an Yi Yin or a Duke of Zhou to assist him from without, a Tai Si or a Yi Jiang to guide him from within, then even the virtues of Tai Jia or King Cheng would have paled in comparison. Alas! Empress Liu wielded absolute power within the palace, while Ding Wei and his faction conspired without. Had it not been for Wang Zeng’s unyielding integrity in court, serving as a stabilizing force, how could the aspiration of the nine in the second place—resonating with the ruler above—have been fulfilled? Observing the intent behind the Sage’s composition of the *Yijing*, one understands the division that marked the early governance of Emperor Renzong.

In the first year of Mingdao, an edict proclaimed: "I, in my humble person, have inherited this great lineage. I have forsaken the pleasures of the hunt and refrained from constructing terraces and pavilions. For ten years now, I have not dared to indulge in leisure. Yet unexpectedly, within the palace chambers, where precautions against fire were not stringent, a single night’s blaze spread to engulf eight halls. Reflecting on this descent from Heaven’s favor, I examine my conduct and seek respite from remorse. Let all officials within and beyond the court forthrightly point out the shortcomings of the court, concealing nothing, to fulfill my intentions."

A note states: At that time, the emperor was in the prime of youth, without moral failings. His claim to have abandoned hunting and eschewed the construction of terraces and pavilions was no empty boast—so how could such a calamity have arisen from governance? The palace chambers and inner quarters are domains of the *yin* principle, and eight halls represent the culmination of *yin* numerology. As Empress Dowager Zhangxian’s regency neared its end, was this not a harbinger of the removal of the old and the inauguration of the new? In the third month of that year, the emperor began to personally attend to governance. He halted the construction of temples and monasteries, curbed the influence of the undeserving, summoned Song Shou and Fan Zhongyan, and dismissed the eunuchs Luo Chongxun and others. Both within and beyond the court, all rejoiced.

A note states: The personal rule of Emperor Ren and that of Emperor Zhe were most unfortunate. When Emperor Ren took power, he ceased the construction of temples and monasteries; when Emperor Zhe took power, he initiated new policies. When Emperor Ren took power, he curbed the influence of the undeserving; when Emperor Zhe took power, he appointed treacherous men. Thus, one brought universal joy to the realm, while the other disheartened the loyal and good. The distinction between success and failure is starkly evident.

Earlier, Empress Dowager Liu had exercised regency, and in her later years, she relied on the eunuchs Luo Chongxun and Jiang Deming to gather intelligence on external affairs. Through this, Chongxun’s power came to dominate both within and beyond the court.

A note states: A mother empress ruling in place of the emperor, while eunuchs usurped power—what an extraordinary time this was! As Fan Zuyu observed, this was the root of the Song dynasty’s rise and fall, the pivot of the altars of state’s safety or peril, the origin of the people’s fortune or misfortune, the juncture of the advancement or retreat of the noble and the base, the moment when Heaven’s Mandate and the people’s hearts would either unite or part. How could one slight the emperor’s great virtue? Alas! With the dismissal of Luo Chongxun alone, all within and beyond the court fixed their gaze, witnessing the fullness of his virtue.

With the single recall of Liu Huan and his associates, the people’s hearts grew restless, and the path to ruin was already trodden. For ten thousand generations to come, rulers at the outset of their reign must take heed. The emperor, observing how Emperor Zhangsheng had restricted the western sacrifices and undertaken the construction of the Jade Purity Radiance and Responsive Numinous Spirits temples—projects that exhausted the realm’s craftsmanship and exceeded all bounds of extravagance—remarked to his ministers: "Though these are flourishing affairs of a time of great peace, they are nonetheless excessive." The chief ministers of the time could not but bear the responsibility, and Lü Yijian said: "The treasury was emptied, and to this day it has not been replenished—this is the reason." The emperor replied: "In matters such as these, I must exercise restraint."

A note states: This is why the emperor halted such constructions. Confucius said: "For three years, do not alter the Way of one’s father." The interpreters explain: "Three years without change" refers only to those things that ought to be changed but may be left unchanged for the time being. Earlier scholars, fearing a misinterpretation of the Master’s intent, took issue with past errors and faults, thus clarifying the matter. The western sacrifices and the construction of palaces and temples merely squandered the realm’s wealth. But policies like the Green Sprouts and the exemption of labor service, which carved up the people and provoked resentment, risked losing the hearts of all under Heaven. To blame Wang Anshi for this might still be justified, but to attribute it to one’s sovereign or father is not. The wise may see this as a necessary correction, while the unwise may call it an unauthorized change. Yet even the unwise, in merely exposing a parent’s faults, differ greatly from those who seek to atone for past wrongs.

Alas! This moment, when Empress Xuanren offered sacrifice, was unlike the day when Empress Zhangxian withdrew behind the screen. In the early years, as the era of peace lengthened, those seeking office all relied on powerful patrons to advance their careers, and the scramble for favor became the prevailing wind. Emperor Renzong once asked his ministers: "Of late, when officials request an audience, many seek advancement, while few ask to retire—why is this?" Wang Zeng replied: "Seven men sharing a meal—this depends on the times and the court’s preferences. Only if the court suppresses the scramble for favor and honors those who withdraw in quietude will there be hope for a spirit of reluctance to advance." The emperor agreed.

The Record states: This was how the emperor suppressed those who sought undeserved favor. Such men are risk-takers. At first, they fawn and flatter, slander and ingratiate, stopping at nothing; in the end, they lick sores and suck ulcers, indulging the ruler’s vices and descending to every depravity. Thus, the sovereign must deeply detest and utterly reject them. Yet unless he maintains perfect impartiality in his heart and perfect clarity in discerning others, he will inevitably mistake minor integrity for great principle, and under the pretense of reluctance to advance, indulge their restless ambition. Hence it is said: “Purify the heart and know men.” And again: “To know men is wisdom.” Neither can be lacking.

In the second year of Jingyou, Wang Zeng became Co-Chief Minister. By nature upright and steadfast, he conducted himself with constancy in court, spoke little in private, and allowed no one to approach him with private requests. When he promoted or dismissed officials, none knew his reasons. Fan Zhongyan once asked him: “To exalt and advance the worthy is the duty of the chief minister. Your great virtue lacks only this.” Wang replied: “If a chief minister seeks to claim all credit for himself, to whom shall blame be assigned?” Fan admired his words.

When the emperor first ascended the throne, the empress dowager threatened to monopolize power. Wang stood firm in court with stern words, so that eunuchs and favorites dared not encroach, the emperor’s virtue daily grew, and the empress dowager preserved her good name. The Record states: From this, one may glimpse the spirit of ruler and minister in that era.

Wang was praised as a great minister, and his relationship with officials was like that of creation to all things—his heart desired that each fulfill their potential. Yet if some could not, he reflected inwardly. With perfect impartiality and sincerity, he felt no shame. If one busily sought to prove one’s usefulness to claim favor, or resented those set aside, the role of great minister would become ever more untenable. Hence it is said: “Be steadfast, with no other skill.” Even Lü Xu did not escape this failing. This is why his pursuit of favor and avoidance of blame differed from Wang’s stern words and upright bearing.

In the winter of the first year of Qingli, on the eleventh month, the emperor performed the southern suburban sacrifice and issued a general amnesty. Since the western campaign, he had fasted and abstained from meat. Zhang Fangping, Supervising Censor, said: “Your Majesty is like heaven and earth, like father and mother—how can you contend with great boars and wolves? I hope you will use this amnesty to acknowledge fault, demonstrate good faith, and open the path to renewal.” The emperor rejoiced: “This is my heart’s desire.” He ordered Zhang’s memorial sent to the Secretariat. When Lü Yijian read it, he clasped his hands and said: “Your words bring fortune to the altars of soil and grain.” The Record states: This is what Kou Zhun meant when he repeatedly praised Lü as having the makings of a chief minister.

The benevolent must also be courageous—this western campaign should have been vigorously pursued. Yet the gentleman did not compete in this, for was it merely to open the path to renewal for others? When abroad there are no rival states, and at home no calamities, the subtle intent of acknowledging fault and demonstrating good faith is evident.

At that time, Zhang Dexiang, Yan Shu, Jia Changchao, Han Qi, Fan Zhongyan, Fu Bi, and Du Yan served as chief ministers together, while Ouyang Xiu, Yu Jing, Wang Su, and Cai Xiang were all remonstrance officials. When the western campaign was abandoned, Shi Jie rejoiced: “This is an act of great virtue. As one who sings praises, how can I remain silent?” He composed the *Qingli Sacred Virtue Poem*:

Ah, in Qingli,
the third year, third month,
the emperor ascended the dragon throne.
Slowly he emerged from the palace gate,
his great voice resounding,
shaking the six directions,
like the movement of Heaven,
like the eruption of thunder.
At first, hearing the emperor’s solemn words:
“My grandfather, my father,
entrusted me with great responsibility.
I fear to lose or fail it—
truly, I rely on my ministers.”

“You, Dexiang and Shu, were deeply cautious and discreet—long have you served as my ministers, and I commend your loyal service. Changchao, a scholar of broad learning, discussed governance with me, grounding his counsel in classical scholarship.

As for you, Zhongyan—you, whom I truly discerned—when you served as my remonstrance official, you rectified the gates of my court; when you governed the capital, you fortified my defenses with your talent and eloquence. When rebels rose in Xia, you were sent to suppress them. In the scorching heat of June and the deep snows of winter, you endured cold and heat alike, never once complaining of exhaustion.

Later, I gained Bi, and my heart rejoiced in him. He aided me with the Dao, his admonitions profound and earnest. Though I am no Yao or Shun, he chastised himself as if he had failed. In a single year as remonstrance official, his memorials filled baskets.

When the Khitan, forgetting righteousness, dared insult our great state, Bi carried my command without fear or hesitation. Across ten thousand miles of desert, he held fast to his resolve, whether facing life or death. Behold his skin—frost-worn, wind-cracked; observe his heart—tempered like forged iron.

Zhongyan and Bi—one like Kui, one like Qi—were my pillars. Then you, Yan, came to me. Your hair has turned white, your teeth have fallen out, yet your heart remains steadfast as ever. You have walked the proper path without deviation, long presiding over the Bureau of Military Affairs, where military and civil governance never faltered.

I did not know Qi at first. But Qi possesses an extraordinary bearing—his demeanor is open and unconstrained, his character simple and unadorned. He is fit for great affairs, as steadfast as a drum. I appointed you as Yan’s deputy, for my wisdom in discerning men is sound.

As for Xiu and Jing, standing in court, their words were weighty and resolute, their loyalty unmistakable. Though they returned from distant lands, their unyielding spirit remained unbroken. After the death of Su, they upheld loyalty and purity. Once, as censors, they nearly knocked at my bedchamber door. Xiang, though a minor official, was widely known to me. He too offered counsel, admonishing my faults, his integrity as pure and steadfast as Xiu’s.

The emperor’s sagacity distinguishes loyalty from treachery, promoting the worthy and expelling the wicked. The advancement of these many worthies was like plucking reeds—swift and effortless; the removal of great villains was like shedding shackles—sudden and complete.”

**Recorded Note:**
At the time, a copy of the *Qingli Sacred Virtue Poem* circulated in Shu, and people sought to know its author. Yet why only then? Who today would not wish to know them? Chief ministers and remonstrance officials are the vital qi of the state, the sacrificial piglets of the court. The emperor possessed a virtue vast as the wilderness, while these worthies displayed courage bold and decisive. This was a time when Heaven and Earth harmonized, when above and below shared a single purpose—no wonder the worthy advanced like reeds plucked, and great villains fled like shackles cast off.

But what of the so-called “factional strife”? The unity of gentlemen in the Dao is a fine thing, yet how could petty men share their aspirations? Once memorials had been submitted to dismiss them, and then this poem was composed—was this not excessive? Thus, alongside Shi Jie’s eulogy came the slander of the palace maid; alongside the “reeds plucked” came the sighs of “leaves falling.” This marked the beginning of Shi Jie’s misfortune and the rise of factional disputes. The warnings of the sages run deep indeed.

On the *wuzi* day of the fifth month, the two chief ministers offered congratulations. The emperor said: “The heavens have long withheld rain, threatening the people’s fields. I have burned incense and prayed earnestly to Heaven. Last night, in my bedchamber, I suddenly heard a faint rumble of thunder. I rose at once, donned my robes and cap, and stood barefoot in the courtyard. Soon, rain fell, soaking my clothes. After a moment, the rain ceased, and I bowed twice in gratitude before daring to ascend the steps. Now I still hope the withered seedlings may yet be saved.

I had considered issuing an edict blaming myself, suspending music and reducing my meals. But I feared this might resemble empty ritual, and that nothing is better than sincere, secret prayer.”

**Recorded Note:**
Prayer and supplication were not abandoned by the ancients. Some even offered their own bodies in place of sacrificial animals, or swallowed locusts to avert disaster—why then dismiss such acts as mere embellishment? This refers to empty ritual. In ancient times, when a ruler’s virtue moved Heaven, he might then issue six acts of self-reproach. But without true substance, an edict of self-blame, the suspension of music, or reduced meals would be meaningless. This is why the emperor deemed sincere, secret prayer the better course.

Fan Zhongyan, as Participant in Determining Government Affairs, found the emperor ardently pursuing peace and prosperity, frequently inquiring about current affairs. The emperor even opened the Hall of Heavenly Manifestations, summoning the chief ministers for audience and providing brush and paper to record their proposals. Zhongyan, filled with awe, withdrew and presented *Ten Proposals*: clarifying promotions and demotions, curbing favoritism, refining the examination system, selecting capable officials, equalizing public fields, enriching agriculture and sericulture, strengthening military preparedness, extending benevolence and trust, emphasizing decrees, and reforming corvée labor. The emperor, placing full trust in Zhongyan, implemented them all.

**Recorded Note:**
The principles of Wenzheng (Fan Zhongyan) were rooted in the loyalty and integrity of age, placing concern before joy. His moral character was as lofty as the blue sky and white sun—impossible to conceal. Emperor Renzong’s ardor lay in securing worthy men and pacifying the people, treating omens and portents as secondary. His governance flourished like the sun ascending and the moon waxing—boundless in measure.

When Emperor Wen of Han once asked about the empire’s finances and legal cases, Zhou Bo and Chen Ping could not answer and the matter was dropped. How much more so when a ruler opens the Hall of Heavenly Manifestations to summon his ministers, provides brush and paper to encourage their words—who would not be filled with awe? Yet even so, it falls short of antiquity.

Gao Yao said: "To truly follow virtue, one must model clarity and harmonize with assisting counsel." When the Emperor’s inquiries were abundant yet his words and conduct fell short, though his plans were forthright and his intentions keen, his decrees remained unsettled and his achievements unfulfilled. Compared to the anxieties of later ages, Yao and Shun remain forever beyond reach.

At the time, when the two bureaus jointly presented memorials, Han Qi, as Vice Director of the Bureau of Military Affairs, though his duties pertained to the Secretariat, would nonetheless speak his mind in full. Some pointed out his faults, and his colleagues grew displeased. The Emperor alone recognized him, saying: "Han Qi is forthright by nature." Qi outlined seven matters that ought to be prioritized: purifying governance at its root, attending to border defenses, promoting worthy talent, preparing for Hebei, securing Hedong, winning the people’s hearts, and developing Luoyi. He subsequently presented eight measures to remedy abuses: selecting generals, clarifying oversight, enriching finances, curbing favoritism, advancing capable officials, dismissing the incompetent, regulating official appointments, and eliminating redundant posts. The Emperor praised and accepted them. Qi further proposed four strategies: that for now, peaceful relations should be a temporary expedient, while preparing for war and defense remained the true priority; he requested the repair of armor and sharpening of weapons, the construction of Luoyang, and the secret planning of punitive campaigns.

The Record states: The tradition holds that only the benevolent can fully accept forthright counsel. Had Qi not encountered this Emperor, how could he alone have recognized him? Thus, at the end of the Zhiping era, Qi spoke his mind in full, yet Emperor Shenzong remained indifferent. At the beginning of the Xining era, he again spoke his mind in full, but not only did the Emperor ultimately doubt him—he even itemized refutations of Qi’s arguments and inscribed them on stone to proclaim them to the realm. Alas! The same Han Qi—before, he bore no reputation for encroaching on others’ authority or parading his integrity; later, he faced widespread censure and condemnation. Was the difference in his exertions? It lay solely in whether his words were received or not. Thus, observing Shenzong’s failings allows one to perceive Renzong’s benevolence.

In the summer of the second year of Huangyou, the sixth month, an edict was issued: "From now on, prefectures and commanderies shall not present auspicious omens." When Ru Xiaobiao, Magistrate of Wuwei Commandery, presented three hundred and fifty stalks of *lingzhi*, the Emperor said: "I regard abundant harvests as auspicious and worthy ministers as treasures. As for the anomalies of plants, insects, and fish—how can they be prized?" He punished Ru Xiaobiao and admonished the realm against further offerings.

The Record states: Han Wendi and Song Renzong cannot be ranked in superiority. Why, then, did the former reject [such offerings] with ease, while the latter spared Ru Xiaobiao from differing treatment? Confucius said: "Good men, though they may not tread the old paths, do not commit evil. Yet neither have they entered the chamber of the sages." Thus, Han Wendi rejected them, and though rejection might lead to other deviations, he did not act—not that he could not. Song Renzong pondered them, and though his reflection nearly failed to spur action, he could not act—not that he would not. Herein lies the distinction between rulers.

When Wang Gongchen, Director of the Three Bureaus, proposed monopolizing salt in Hebei, the law had been established but not yet implemented. Zhang Fangping, Hanlin Academician, said to the Emperor: "Why monopolize salt in Hebei again?" The Emperor, startled, replied: "This is the first time the law has been established, not a repetition." Fangping said: "When Emperor Shizong of Zhou monopolized salt in Hebei, violators were executed. During Shizong’s northern campaign, elders blocked the roads, weeping as they petitioned, wishing to distribute the salt tax evenly among the Two Taxes—this was the salt money. Is this not a second monopolization?" The Emperor, greatly enlightened, said: "Convey this to the chief minister and abolish it at once." Fangping replied: "Though the edict has not yet been issued, the people already know of it. It should be rescinded directly by imperial hand, not through the offices." The Emperor was greatly pleased and ordered Fangping to secretly draft a handwritten edict to abolish it. Elders of the Hebei region gathered to welcome the edict at Chanzhou, holding Buddhist and Daoist assemblies for seven days to repay the Emperor’s grace. They also carved the edict on stone in Beijing, and all who passed beneath it bowed their heads in tears.

The Record states: What can be praised in the governance of Emperor Huizong’s era is the presence of virtuous intent in his inquiries. Thus, upon hearing a single opinion, he was first startled, then enlightened, and finally acted to abolish [the policy] without delay. How vast is the difference between this and those who listen without reflection and persist without change! Such virtue suffices to move the people’s hearts, and their gratitude knows no bounds.

Wang Gongchen said to the Emperor: "What merit does Fu Bi possess? He merely increases the quantity of gold and silk, enriching the barbarians while impoverishing China." Renzong replied: "Not so. What I cherish are the land and the people; wealth is not what I惜." Gongchen said: "Is wealth not extracted from the people?" Renzong said: "The state’s expenditures are not drawn from a single day’s accumulation. The annual gifts to the barbarians have not yet burdened the people. If war were to break out and troops were mobilized, the yearly expenditures would be incalculable—not like the gradual extraction of today." Gongchen said: "The Rong and Di are insatiable, ever seeking gaps in China’s defenses. Moreover, Your Majesty has only one daughter. If they were to demand a marriage alliance, what then?" Renzong’s expression grew solemn, and he said: "If it benefits the altars of state, why would I惜 a single daughter?" Gongchen, his words cut short, said: "I did not know Your Majesty would humble yourself and cherish the people to such an extent—a ruler like Yao and Shun!" He bowed twice, weeping, and departed.

The Record states: Observing Wang Gongchen’s words, they resemble those of [Wang] Qinruo’s desperate gamble. Not only did they fail to gain traction, but even when the Emperor humbled himself, there was no regret. At this moment, he truly resembled heaven, which covers all without exception, and earth, which bears all without limit. To call him a ruler like Yao and Shun is no exaggeration.

When Wen Yanbo and Fu Bi were both appointed as Chief Ministers, the Emperor once asked Wang Su about selecting a prime minister. Su said: "Only those unknown to eunuchs and palace women would suffice." The Emperor said: "In that case, Fu Bi would be the one." When they were later summoned together to the outskirts, an edict ordered all officials to welcome them. Fan Zhen said: "Honoring them with empty rituals is not as good as advancing them with utmost sincerity."

When Your Majesty appointed these two as Chief Ministers, the entire court declared it a fitting choice. Yet under recent regulations, officials of the Two Bureaus were forbidden from visiting the residences of the Chief Ministers, and all officials were barred from meeting them—this is hardly "advancing them with utmost sincerity." I humbly suggest abolishing the ceremonial suburban welcome and lifting the prohibition on visits, so that Your Majesty’s governance of ministers may achieve mutual benefit.

When the edict was proclaimed, scholar-officials rejoiced in the court. The Emperor sent the eunuch Xian to inform Hanlin Academician Ouyang Xiu, saying: "In ancient times, some ministers were chosen through dreams or divination. Now that I have appointed these men, and the people’s sentiments are thus, is this not superior to dreams or divination?"

**Record states:** Were all Chief Ministers of our dynasty truly beholden to eunuchs and palace women? Yet during the reign of Emperor Renzong, the court teemed with gentlemen, and Li Di, Wang Zeng, Fan Zhongyan, Wen Yanbo, Fu Bi, and Han Qi were especially renowned. Tracing the reason, it was precisely because the appointments reflected the public will of the realm rather than the private inclinations of one man. Not only was this superior to dreams or divination, but it could be transmitted to later generations. Thus, I record the benevolent words of Emperor Wen of Han and the benevolent ministers of the Song to preserve their legacy. Alas! When the Way of ministerial selection is rightly ordered, the myriad states are governed.

Initially, the Hebei and Jingdong regions suffered catastrophic floods, and the people fled to Qingzhou in search of food. Fu Bi urged the local populace to donate grain, supplemented by official reserves, securing over one hundred thousand public and private dwellings. He dispersed the refugees among them for convenience in procuring firewood and water. Officials awaiting appointments who were residing there were all granted stipends to assist. He selected the elderly, weak, sick, and emaciated for relief, recording their labor and promising future memorials to request rewards. Every five days, he sent envoys bearing wine, meat, and rice to comfort them, acting with such utmost sincerity that everyone exerted themselves to the fullest. He permitted the people to freely exploit the resources of mountains, forests, rivers, and marshes for sustenance. When the wheat harvest ripened, the people returned to their homes in accordance with their distance, each receiving grain. In total, over fifty million lives were saved, and tens of thousands were recruited as soldiers.

Previously, disaster relief efforts had gathered the people in walled cities, distributing gruel that bred epidemics and trampling. Some, awaiting food for days without receiving a single bowl, collapsed—so-called "relief" that was in truth slaughter. Fu Bi’s methods, simple and effective, were implemented throughout the empire and became the standard.

The Emperor, upon hearing of this, dispatched envoys to commend and reward him, promoting him to Vice Minister of Rites. Later, when famine struck the Yizhou region, Han Qi was appointed as the Pacification Commissioner. He reduced taxes to encourage grain donations, recruited able-bodied men as local garrison troops, and decreed that for every man enlisted, several members of his family would be spared starvation. He issued an order at Jianmen Pass that refugees seeking to return eastward should not be barred. In Jianzhou, where the famine was most severe, he had previously, during the Mingdao era, encouraged grain contributions. Later, over 160,000 strings of surplus cash were returned to the Ever-Normal Granary. Han Qi said: "This money is the surplus of relief efforts, not official revenue." He distributed it entirely to households of the fourth rank and below, dismissed 760 corrupt, incompetent, or redundant officials, and established gruel stations that saved over 1.9 million lives. Later, as Prefect of Yangzhou and then Dingzhou, concurrently serving as Pacification Commissioner, he rescued millions more famine victims. Imperial edicts lauded his achievements, and neighboring circuits took his methods as a model.

**Record states:** Just as the Emperor’s concern for the people was profound, Fu Bi and Han Qi devoted themselves wholeheartedly to disaster governance. It was as if a nation of myriad blossoms had encountered a master weaver, whose craftsmanship shaped the pattern, or a workshop of fine jade had met a skilled smelter, whose artistry perfected the carving. Heaven does not wish to withhold warmth, yet the cycles of circulation make cold inevitable—relying on our means to counter it, we ensure only warmth. The people do not wish to hunger, yet the vagaries of fortune make famine inescapable—depending on our measures to address it, we prevent suffering.

Though Fu Bi saved over fifty million and Han Qi saved millions more, had they not been truly sincere, regarding the people’s drowning as their own and their hunger as their own, with utmost sincerity moving all—public and private, high and low—how could they have ensured that everyone was treated as themselves? Alas! The methods...

The methods may be transmitted, yet the heart cannot be transmitted—only by fully dedicating the heart to selflessness can one fully dedicate the heart to the governance of the two ministers. In the spring of the eighth year of Jiayou, on the day *xinhai* of the third month, the Emperor passed away. His final edict was issued, and even in the deepest mountains and remotest valleys, none could refrain from rushing forth in grief, their wails unceasing.

The *Record* states: As the *Doctrine of the Mean* says, "Thus, great virtue must accord with one’s position, must secure its emoluments, must attain its renown, must fulfill its longevity." Truly, such an Emperor was rare indeed. For while rank may be attained by others, how could one so young upon ascending the throne, so flourishing in the prime of rule, sustain it for as long as forty-two years—this was unparalleled. While wealth may be attained by others, how could one so effortlessly at ease, so leisurely in repose, preside over an age of such unparalleled peace and prosperity—this was unmatched. While renown may be attained by others, how could one witness the Way of the noble flourish while the way of the petty wane, as in the eras of Kangding and Qingli—this was unrivaled. While longevity may be attained by others, how could one move even those in the deepest mountains and remotest valleys to mourn as though they had lost their parents, their grief so profound—this was unparalleled. Such was the Emperor’s virtue that made him Renzong.

The historian’s eulogy states: Renzong was reverent, frugal, benevolent, and forgiving—qualities innate to his nature. Whenever floods or droughts struck, he would either secretly pray within the palace or stand barefoot before the court. When officials proposed converting the former Jade Clarity precinct into an imperial garden, the Emperor said, "I already find the gardens bequeathed by my predecessors too vast—why would I need more?" His private attire, though often laundered, consisted only of simple curtains and coarse garments, often patched with embroidered cloth. When he grew hungry at night and craved roasted lamb, he forbade its preparation, fearing that the imperial kitchen would thereafter slaughter animals to meet such whims. For all death sentences in doubt, he ordered further review, sparing over a thousand lives each year. When an official of the Ministry of Personnel was once condemned to death for a single error, the Emperor decreed that he never be promoted again.

The Emperor often admonished his ministers: "I have never commended anyone to death—how dare I recklessly impose capital punishment?" When the Xia people violated the frontier, he repelled them beyond the border; when the Khitan broke their covenant, he increased the annual tribute. During his forty-two years on the throne, though the administration of officials seemed indolent and those who took office were seldom harsh or oppressive, and though the penal code appeared lax, the judges were largely fair and impartial. The realm never lacked flatterers, yet they could not undermine the order of the age; the court never lacked petty men, yet they could not overpower the qi of the virtuous. From ruler to subject, all shared a heart of compassion and a government of magnanimity, thus nurturing and fortifying the foundation of the Song for over three hundred years. Yet his descendants, in correcting his ways, gradually led the realm to chaos.

As the saying goes: "For one who would be lord over men, let him rest in benevolence." In this, the Emperor was truly without shame.

The Hu family of Xin’an remarked: During the reign of Renzong, someone once presented twenty-eight clams, each worth a thousand coins. The Emperor said, "A single bite costs a thousand coins—I cannot bear it." When a northern envoy reported that Goryeo had neglected its tribute and suggested sending troops, the Emperor replied, "This is but the fault of their prince. To send troops now would be to slaughter the common people." In the end, he withdrew the forces. When an epidemic struck the capital, he distributed *tongtianxi* rhinoceros horn for treatment. When some suggested keeping it for his own use, he said, "Do I value rare things above the lives of my people?"

When Su Zhe’s examination response was deemed too forthright, some urged his dismissal. The Emperor said, "I seek forthright words—how can I cast them aside for being forthright? What would the realm think of me?" Moreover, he cherished learning and exalted the Confucian Way, upholding its principles with particular vigor. At a lecture for the imperial study, he told his attending ministers, "Though the height of summer brings me no weariness, I fear only that you may be taxed by it."

Alas! In governing with such a heart and striving for order, the Emperor was so pure that none could find fault.

The record states: Someone asked, "The Emperor was truly blameless as a ruler. Yet can he be compared to the sage-kings of antiquity?" The answer came: "Not yet." Had he not read Confucius’ counsel to Duke Ai? "If one truly embodies this Way, even the dull become enlightened, even the weak grow strong." The Emperor’s nature was indeed pure, yet the momentary lapse in virtue with Empress Guo revealed an imperfection in his sagely learning. Though worthy ministers filled his court, none could rectify his character—his benevolence and gentleness were abundant, but his resolute judgment fell short. Thus he remained but a ruler of the Song dynasty. Hence it is said: "Be precise, be single-minded." And again: "Attend to the subtle, seek tranquility." These are the essential methods of the ancient enlightened kings.

*The Five Relations Book* records: Emperor Zhaoxuan of the Song, endowed with innate purity and clarity, practiced filial piety and fraternal love as if by natural disposition. During his twenty years as heir apparent, he deeply understood the Way of the sovereign. Upon ascending the throne, he exerted himself to govern, entrusting matters to others with sincerity. He often said, "For a ruler, nothing surpasses benevolence." Thus he bestowed timely relief like seasonal rains, abolished forced purchases, remitted debts, inquired into the people’s hardships, prioritized agriculture, honored long service, revived neglected institutions, repeatedly exhorted judicial officials to temper severity with leniency, and made compassion for the people his sole concern.

The record states: From the Song to the present, over five hundred years have passed, yet rulers who truly rivaled Zhaoxuan have appeared but once or twice. How splendid his illustrious name and virtuous title must seem to filial descendants and reverent heirs a hundred generations hence!

*The Record of Illustrious Ministers of the August Ming* states: Emperor Xiaojing reigned for eighteen years, ever mindful of the realm. Once, he summoned Minister of War Liu Daxia and asked, "When will the world know peace? When will I govern like the sage-kings of old?" Daxia replied, "One should not seek governance too hastily. In all matters of personnel and policy, if doubts arise, summon the Grand Secretariat and chief ministers to deliberate face-to-face. Once settled, proceed accordingly—this is the natural order, and it is peace." When Censor-in-Chief Dai Shan sought to retire due to age and illness, the Emperor issued an edict: "Tell Dai Shan this: I entrust the affairs of the realm to him as a father does to his son. With peace not yet achieved, how can I bear to let him leave me first?"

The record states: The *Zhou Odes* says:
*"Vast Heaven’s mandate is accomplished,
Two sovereigns received it.
King Cheng dared not rest,
Day and night he laid its foundation,
Attending to its subtleties with care,
Illuminating his single heart,
Thus he brought tranquility to all."*
These words might well serve as an ode to our Filial Emperor. Since the founding of the Ming over a hundred and fifty years ago, the mandate of Heaven has been received by successive sages. Emperor Xiaojing inherited it and truly "dared not rest," laying its foundation with meticulous care, illuminating his single heart—this was especially fitting. His virtue was profound yet unassuming, serene yet rooted, accumulated day and night as he upheld Heaven’s mandate and longed for peace. He was indeed able to continue and illuminate the grand legacy of the Two Founders and Four Ancestors, fulfilling his duty to the utmost. Thus the realm enjoys enduring stability, and the blessings of a myriad ages are secured. Had Heaven granted him more years, what sage-king of antiquity could he not have equaled?

At the time, Minister of Revenue Li Mengyang once submitted a memorial criticizing government policies. The Filial Emperor, enraged, imprisoned him. When the charges were presented, an edict ordered his reinstatement. Later, after Liu Daxia had finished his report, the Emperor asked, "How fare recent affairs abroad?" Daxia kowtowed and replied, "Recently, Your Majesty issued an edict releasing Li Mengyang. Within and without the court, all praise your virtue as vast as heaven and earth." The Emperor said, "Li Mengyang’s words were reckless. I had no choice but to imprison him. The Embroidered Uniform Guard submitted a report, and I tested my attendants by asking how they would respond. One said, 'This man is reckless—he should be handed to the Embroidered Uniform Guard, flogged, and released.' I discerned their intent: they wished for an edict to condemn him, then have him severely beaten to death to satisfy the palace’s anger, leaving me with the reputation of killing a forthright minister. Such disloyalty from my attendants! Thus I immediately ordered his release and reinstatement, without even allowing the judicial officials to propose a sentence." Daxia again kowtowed and said, "In this act, Your Majesty embodies the benevolence of Yao and Shun."

Once, when Zhang Tianxiang, a regional commander in Liaodong, claimed merit for ambushing and killing enemy raiders, Vice Minister of Justice Wu Yiguan sentenced him to death. As Zhang died in prison, the Filial Emperor was furious and personally interrogated Wu in court, intending to impose a heavier penalty. At that moment, Minister of Justice Min Gui and Censor-in-Chief Dai Shan stepped forward and said, "Yiguan’s investigation was incomplete—his crime warrants exile." Though the Emperor’s will was set, they still remonstrated forcefully, saying, "The law is sufficient as it stands." The Emperor then asked Liu Daxia, "Tell me—has any ruler or minister in history ever acted thus?" Daxia replied, "In my youth, I read the *Mencius*, which says: 'When Shun was Son of Heaven and Gao Yao was judge, if Gu Sou killed a man, Gao Yao would merely arrest him.' Today’s judicial officials, I fear, act no differently." The Emperor nodded in assent.

The imperial decree was issued the next day, and Yiguan’s punishment was reduced to mere dismissal from office.

Another day, the Filial Emperor summoned Liu Daxia to discuss current governance and the talents of the time. The Emperor said, "Take Shanxi Vice Commissioner Wang Hongru, for instance—he is a man of great promise."

Daxia replied, "Truly, as Your Majesty observes."

Later, Daxia told his fellow townsman, the gentleman Xu Wenxiang, "When the court employs men of this caliber, it is then capable of shouldering great affairs. I am too old to witness it, but you must remember this."

Recorded here: All these instances reflect the Filial Emperor’s sincere heart and profound intent, far surpassing the emperors of recent ages by ten thousandfold. Alas, this humble minister, confined to a distant corner by the sea, has no means to survey the full breadth of the national histories and witness the boundless benevolence of heaven and earth. What little I have glimpsed in the records of ministers’ words and deeds is but a fragment, and so I have compiled these accounts to bring this volume to a close.

*Hongdao Record*, Volume Three, ends here.

[*Note: One character missing in the original; in the *New唐书□Food and Commerce Annals*, it appears as "余". The passage reads: "凡乡田有余以给比乡".*]

*Hongdao Record*, Volume Four
"Benevolence"

**"Filial Benevolence Between Father and Son"**

*The Canon of Yao* states: "Shun’s father was obstinate, his mother was harsh, and his brother Xiang was arrogant, yet he harmonized them all through filial piety."

**Recorded here:** This is the first principle revered by historians of antiquity. Filial piety is the source of all goodness and the fundamental duty of benevolence. Even with the great sagacity of Yao and Shun, in the momentous act of abdication, all that was said was "he harmonized them through filial piety." If so, what virtue of the sages could surpass filial piety?

Mencius said: "The Emperor sent his nine sons and two daughters, along with a hundred officials, cattle, sheep, granaries, and supplies, to serve Shun in the fields. Scholars from all over the world flocked to him, and the Emperor was ready to yield the realm to him. Yet Shun was still troubled, as if he had no refuge, for he was not at peace with his parents. The favor of the world’s scholars is what people desire, yet it could not relieve his sorrow. Beauty is what people desire, yet marrying the Emperor’s two daughters could not relieve his sorrow. Wealth is what people desire, yet possessing the empire could not relieve his sorrow. Honor is what people desire, yet being Son of Heaven could not relieve his sorrow. Nothing—neither favor, beauty, wealth, nor honor—could relieve his sorrow, save only being at peace with his parents. In youth, one longs for one’s parents; when one knows the allure of beauty, one longs for young loveliness; when one has a wife and children, one longs for them; when one enters officialdom, one longs for one’s lord. If one is not favored by one’s lord, one burns with frustration, and even then, one longs for one’s parents all one’s life. To long for one’s parents at fifty—this we see in the great Shun."

**Recorded here:** Yet it is not only Shun. Our present Emperor’s filial piety truly resembles that of the great Shun. Observe how, in his repeated admonitions to his ministers, he does not take pleasure in being Son of Heaven or possessing the realm, but instead sighs and weeps as if he could not bear a single day of ease. His words are fully recorded in the *Great Compendium of Ethics*—truly, he is one who longs for his parents all his life.

Wan Zhang asked: "Some say that with Yu, virtue declined, for he did not pass the throne to a worthy man but to his son. Is this true?"

Mencius replied: "No, it is not. If Heaven grants the throne to a worthy, it goes to the worthy; if Heaven grants it to a son, it goes to the son. Formerly, Yu recommended Yi to Heaven. After seven years, Yu died. When the three years of mourning were complete, Yi withdrew before Yu’s son before the northern slopes of Mount Ji. Those who came to court, to pay tribute, or to settle disputes did not go to Yi but to Qi, saying, ‘He is our lord’s son.’ Those who sang praises did not sing for Yi but for Qi, saying, ‘He is our lord’s son.’ Dan Zhu was unworthy, and Shun’s son was also unworthy. When Shun assisted Yao and Yu assisted Shun, they served for many years, and their beneficence to the people was long-lasting. Qi was worthy and could reverently carry on Yu’s Way. When Yi assisted Yu, he served for few years, and his beneficence to the people was not long-lasting. The time between Shun, Yu, and Yi was long, and whether their sons were worthy or not was a matter of Heaven, not something men could bring about. What happens without being made to happen is the work of Heaven; what arrives without being sought is fate."

**Recorded here:** This marks the beginning of hereditary rule, a path followed by ten thousand generations without alteration. Only after exhausting the mind and knowing one’s nature can one speak of Heaven; only after fully understanding principle and exhausting one’s nature can one speak of fate. If even the slightest trace of these remains unfulfilled, one cannot avoid becoming like Zhao Pu, who spoke of Heaven and fate. What Zhao Pu established was not the utmost impartiality of the realm, for nothing can replace the utmost love of human nature; what he conferred was not the utmost intent of the ancestral line, for nothing can manifest the utmost grace of succession. Thus, though Yao and Shun loved Zhu and Jun, for the realm, finding a worthy man was difficult, so they did not forcibly decline. As for Yi, was he not also recommended to Heaven and made known to the people? Yet the people did not go to Yi but to Qi, so there was no forcible seizure. How could this be the work of men? Mencius clarified the reasons for long and short service, distinguishing clearly between worthiness and unworthiness as matters of Heaven’s mandate. This must not escape the recorder’s notice.

*The Counsels of Tai Jia* states: "When the king’s ancestor dwelt in mourning at Tong Palace, he was able to fulfill his true virtue in the end."

**Recorded here:** The heart of compassion is the beginning of benevolence. Why was this said? Is it not because the nature of ordinary men does not stir with sorrow unless they see what is sorrowful, nor with fear unless they see what is fearful? Thus, they gradually drift into moral failings without realizing it, resist instruction without awareness. Should one not consider how to rouse them? Tong Palace was where the royal garments and caps were kept, the place of morning and evening rites. Even an ordinary man, seeing the pines and cypresses there, would be moved to emotion. How much more so for Tai Jia, whose heart must have swelled with reverence and awe? His closeness to the former king’s teachings far surpassed the admonitions of tutors and guardians. Thus, he did not draw near to sensual pleasures that constantly assailed his eyes, nor did he begrudge correcting his faults, ever vigilant in his heart. This is how his former transgressions transformed into the virtue of fulfillment—was this not the work of compassion?

*The Unremitting* states: "In the time of Gao Zong, he had long labored among the people. When the petty men acted, and he ascended the throne, he observed mourning and did not speak for three years. Only when he did not speak did his words bring harmony."

**Recorded here:** The Shang dynasty’s simplicity resembled the customs of high antiquity. The crown prince is the foundation of the realm. He should not be treated as inferior or superior, yet he was made to dwell long among the common people, sharing their labors. This shows how Xiao Yi loved his son—not with the indulgence of later ages, but with a sincerity that was true and unfeigned.

The court is the foundation of the myriad affairs, where favor must not obscure righteousness—yet he observed mourning and did not speak for three years. This shows how Gao Zong loved his father, not with the empty rituals of later ages, but with a love born of natural heavenly nature.

Such were the lofty virtues and noble deeds of the rulers of the Three Dynasties, not merely spoken of in terms of exalted rank or wealth.

*The Greater Odes* states:
*"Like intertwining melons, the people’s first beginnings,
From the lands of Tu, Ju, and Qi,
Gu Gong Dan Fu,
Carved caves and dug dwellings,
Ere houses were built."*

**Recorded here:** Why does *The Odes* speak of *"intertwining melons"*? It is because King Tai laid the foundation for royal succession. *"Intertwining"* refers to the tracks of the chariot’s wheels. The people of Bin said: *"He is a man of benevolence—we cannot lose him!"* Those who followed him came as if to market. Was this not the chariot-track of a true king? Later, King Wu inherited King Tai’s legacy—this was the *"intertwining"* thread. Without the customs of *"carving caves and digging dwellings,"* how could the ambition to overthrow Shang have arisen? Those who observe well must discern this.

It further states:
*"Then came Wang Ji,
Whose virtue was in action.
Tai Ren conceived,
And gave birth to this King Wen."*

**Recorded here:** I observe that in the flourishing age of Cheng Zhou, fathers and sons, grandfathers and grandsons, achieved such greatness—yet in Yao’s time, this was not so. Why? Perhaps when heaven and earth first opened, the *qi* was not yet fully pure. By the Zhou, the true *yuan* had converged, not merely through the accumulated blessings of a single family, but through the accumulated sincerity of the world—this was no matter of a single morning or evening. Otherwise, how could the lands of Qi and Wei compare with the descent of Xi and Wei? *The Biographies of Exemplary Women* states: *"Tai Ren’s nature was upright, sincere, and solemn. During her pregnancy, her eyes did not behold unseemly sights, her ears did not hear unwholesome sounds, her mouth did not utter arrogant or reckless words. She gave birth to King Wen, who was enlightened and sagely. Tai Ren taught him one thing, and he understood a hundred, becoming the model of Zhou’s noble lords."* It is said that Tai Ren was capable of *tai jiao* (fetal education).

**Recorded here:** Whenever I consider the principle of *tai jiao*, I cannot but marvel at the profound truth it contains. Heaven-endowed nature is formless; the union of man and woman involves *qi*. The formless cannot be spoken of in terms of good or evil, for nature is inherently good. But in the realm of *qi*, right and wrong, good and evil begin to diverge. Not only this, but nobility and humility, long life and early death—all are determined here. This is the division of the *qi* and substance one receives at birth, fixed and unchanging from the moment of life. That it culminated in the founding of the Zhou house was only fitting.

*The Doctrine of the Mean* states: *"He who was without sorrow—was it not King Wen?"* With Wang Ji as his father and King Wu as his son, the father laid the foundation, and the son carried it forward.

**Recorded here:**

Confucius said: *"The humane are without sorrow."* The exegetes explain: *"Their principle is sufficient to overcome selfishness, hence they are without sorrow."* With Wang Ji as his father, had King Wen allowed selfish desire to prevail, he would have indulged his impetuous impulses, thereby entrapping his father in impropriety. With King Wu as his son, had selfish desire prevailed, he would have prematurely usurped the throne, thereby entrapping his son in disloyalty. Taking this as a lesson, later generations still aspire to emulate King Wen of Zhou. Alas, how numerous are those who claim to be King Wen!

His queen and consorts harbored no jealousy, and thus his descendants were many. His numerous concubines dwelled in harmony like a swarm of *lisi* insects, and his descendants flourished. The *Book of Songs* praises them, saying:
*"Like the wings of the *lisi*, gleaming and joyous—may your descendants be thriving!*
*Like the wings of the *lisi*, humming in unison—may your descendants be boundless!*
*Like the wings of the *lisi*, clustered in ranks—may your posterity be abundant!"*
