**Recorded here:** How can one say that such virtue rightfully merits such fortune? For those before him, many royal houses failed to establish lasting legacies, and how could they endure? Those after him often met with hidden calamities that could not be suppressed, and how could they long persist? If a man’s words to his parents and brothers reveal no discord, his filial piety is evident. If his words never depart from the lips of his consorts and principal wife, his virtue is manifest.

Harmony does not mean the women and children merely chatter in delight; rather, like fish strung in order by rank, each receives favor according to her station, and none fails to benefit from the grace of his reign. Prosperity does not resemble the withered willow sprouting new shoots; when the king extends his rule to the household, mutual love prevails. Such was the family code of King Wen. Discussing virtue in this light, his virtue was vast; speaking of fortune, his fortune was great.

King Wen’s queen cultivated virtue in herself, and all her descendants were transformed by goodness. Thus the poet extols them, saying:
*"The hooves of the qilin—how the lord’s sons thrive! Ah, the qilin!"*

**Recorded here:** In my foolish observation, no royal beginning has ever been so genuine and free of pretense, nor has any eulogy been so intimate and rich in meaning. Thus, though the qilin may dwell in the wilds, it has never been seen. Of the four spiritually endowed creatures, it is formless yet appears in groups. The lord’s sons bear its likeness, yet none so perfectly as those who "thrive" in emulation. This is how the followers of the sage deeply grasp the power of observation and inspiration—far beyond mere recitation and admiration.

Yet the Shang had Waibing and He Dan who died young; the Han had the Prince of Yin and the Young Emperor who met untimely deaths; the Tang had the strife of Jiancheng and Guangji; the Song had the disputes over Guangmei and Dezhao. Where else has there been a succession like that of Wen, Wu, Cheng, and Kang of Zhou? Truly, this is no false omen of royal virtue.

**As the records state:** When King Wen fell ill, King Wu was displeased and tended to him in full court regalia. When King Wen ate once, he ate once; when King Wen ate twice, he ate twice. Only after twelve days did he inquire after his father. King Wen asked King Wu: *"What did you dream?"* He replied: *"I dreamed the Lord granted me nine *ling*."* King Wen said: *"What do you take this to mean?"* King Wu said: *"There are nine states in the west; perhaps you will ultimately pacify them."* King Wen said: *"No. In ancient times, *ling* referred to age. I am ninety of your years, and I share three with you."*

King Wen died at ninety-seven, and King Wu at ninety-three.

**Recorded here:** Why did King Wu have such a dream? His love for his father was profound—what is called *"preceding Heaven, yet Heaven does not oppose it."* Why did King Wen receive such a response? His love for his son was profound—what is called *"following Heaven and complying with its timing."* If even Heaven does not oppose it, why should men doubt or dispute it?

Though the bodies of Wen and Wu were two, the sincerity that connected them knew no separation. From the first meal to the second, and even after twelve days of inquiry, his devotion to his father was pure. Among all things under Heaven, what could surpass this? Even wood, stone, pigs, and fish may be moved, let alone the supreme principle of spirit and illumination.

As for the ages of ninety-seven and ninety-three, these were the actual responses of principle, coinciding with those numbers. Even without adding King Wen’s three years, how could one know that King Wu’s life was not shortened? In any case, human life is measured by a century, and one should not be overly fixated on such details. The reader should not let the words obscure the meaning.

From the *Zhou Odes* ["Min Yu Xiao Zi"]: "Our house has met with misfortune; sorrow and grief weigh heavily upon me. Oh, my august father, may you be eternally filial. I think of my royal ancestors, who descended to the court. As for me, the humble one, I rise early and retire late in reverence. Oh, may the august kings’ succession continue, their ordered thoughts never forgotten."

**Recorded Commentary:** What is meant by "continuing the work of Wen and Wu and honoring the root of great transformation"? The great transformation of Heaven and Earth is called *ren* (benevolence); the supreme virtue of the sage is called *xiao* (filial piety). All that pleases this one man and responds to the timely virtues of the lords is but the unfolding of this foundation. Thus, when Tai Jia mourned at Tong, when Gao Zong dwelled in seclusion during his grief, and when King Cheng grieved with unceasing sorrow—these three kings, in their excellence as heirs and guardians, followed the same Dao. The filial piety of the august kings sought nothing else; its origin lay in Heaven, a true and earnest expression of the innate heart. Their thoughts extended to their ancestors, a profound concern reaching even the subtlest depths. Their essence was attuned to the spirits, a boundless compliance. This is why they thought to continue the succession without forgetfulness.

Later, when the Great Han arose, its governance was no different in this regard. After the reigns of Yuan and Cheng, this Dao declined. No wonder the scholars of the classics were so earnest in their exhortations.

**"Gu Ming" (The Testamentary Charge):** In the fourth month, on the day of *zaishengchou*, the king did not rest. On the day *jiazi*, the king bathed and purified himself, donned his ceremonial cap and robes, and leaned upon his jade table. He summoned the Grand Protector Shu, the Earl of Yin, the Earl of Tong, the Duke of Bi, the Marquis of Wei, the Duke of Mao, the Master of Ceremonies, the Tiger Warriors, and the hundred ministers and officers. The king said: "Alas! My illness grows severe. As the end nears, and my condition worsens, I fear I may not live to swear my testament. Now I earnestly instruct you: In former times, Kings Wen and Wu displayed their radiant glory, established their grand array, and taught their precepts through practice. By not deviating from their practice, they overcame Yin and received the great mandate. You who come after, take heed and revere the Heavenly majesty. Succeed to the great teachings of Wen and Wu, and dare not be negligent or transgress. Now Heaven has sent down this illness; I do not rise, nor do I awaken. You must heed my words and respectfully protect my eldest son Zhao, aiding him through hardship and peril."

**Recorded Commentary:** This is how King Cheng ensured a proper end, just as King Kang began his reign rightly—both may serve as models for ten thousand generations. Entrusting the orphan and the mandate to such men as Zhou had was truly exceptional. With the royal house’s most esteemed kin bearing the weighty duty of Grand Protector, though there was the distinction of ruler and minister, their shared joys and sorrows were like those of companions in a boat tossed upon the currents or riders galloping side by side on a broad road—how could they not be vigilant? King Cheng, at the outset, had to be warned and restrained from later complacency; without the Duke of Zhou, how could he have preserved his own clarity? In the end, he proclaimed his radiant glory and fulfilled the great mandate; without the Duke of Shao, how could he have respectfully protected his eldest son? This sense of hardship and peril King Cheng personally experienced, so his words were earnest and full of meaning—not like the reckless gambits of An Liu or Xia Hou.

The king further said: "Pacify the distant and bring near the capable; reassure and encourage the great and small states. Consider that men may disrupt my dignity. Do not let Zhao rashly offer tribute in improper circumstances."

**Recorded Commentary:** By this point, King Cheng differed not at all from the sages of antiquity. For *ji* (subtle signs) were the essential teachings of the Yu court—only the most discerning could perceive them, and only the most resolute could decide upon them. This was the result of his diligent cultivation of the Way, not some casual conjecture. In action, responding to all things, how could one forget for even a moment the succession of the court, the descent of the ancestral line? In stillness, practicing vigilance in solitude, how could one allow even an instant of wrongdoing in the myriad affairs? Yet the heir was especially urged because his heart was not yet pure, his grasp not yet firm. Once he stood above others, he might easily grow arrogant; when close to familiar attendants, he might rashly advance improper signs. Then the means to pacify the distant, bring near the capable, and reassure the great and small states would all be lost. This was the profound concern of a dying man, the eternal parting, the ultimate plan for completion, the full achievement of the guardians’ duty. The words of those who speak only of "fine sons and fine wives," seeing only what is done for kin without discerning principle and Dao, are not to be mentioned in the same breath.

The Duke of Zhou said to the Duke of Lu: "The noble man does not neglect his kin, nor does he cause great ministers to resent him. He does not abandon old friends without grave cause. He does not demand perfection from any one person."

**Recorded Commentary:** This was the Duke of Zhou’s family tradition—what Confucius meant when he said, "If Lu were to change, it would reach the Dao." Later, in his governance, the Duke of Lu put the inner before the outer, *ren* before *yi*, so deeply did he take the admonitions to heart. Thus it is said: "Lu’s beneficence extended for ten generations." Lu preserved the traces of the kingly way through its *ren* and generosity—this is why Qi could not equal Lu.

Yet when I once passed through Qufu and observed the temple of the Duke of Zhou, I saw that no one was enshrined there to receive offerings alongside him. In my humble opinion, the virtue of the great sage in life could match Heaven, and in death, none should be paired with him in sacrifice. Moreover, the Duke of Lu’s worthiness did no dishonor to the Duke of Zhou’s teachings—would it not have been fitting to enshrine him there? Perhaps one day this oversight may be corrected.

**"Tan Xi" (Lament):** When Duke Xian of Jin died, Duke Mu of Qin sent a messenger to condole with Prince Chong’er, saying: "I have heard that the fall of a state often occurs at such a time, and the rise of a state often occurs at such a time. Though you, my lord, are solemn in your mourning garb, grief cannot last forever, nor can opportunity be lost. Consider this carefully." Chong’er reported this to his uncle Jiu Fan, who said: "My lord, decline the offer. A man in mourning has no treasure; *ren* and kinship are his only treasure. What does it mean that your father has died?"

Moreover, if one were to exploit this for personal gain, who in the world could justify such conduct? "My lord, decline the offer."

Prince Chong’er replied: "Your lordship’s kindness condoles with this exiled subject, Chong’er. With my person in exile and my father dead, I could not even share in the mourning rites of weeping and wailing. How could I dare cause you further concern? What does it mean that my father has died? Should I harbor any other intention and thus dishonor your righteousness, I would bow my head without prostrating, rise from weeping without private counsel."

Zixian conveyed this to Duke Mu, who said: "Virtuous indeed is Prince Chong’er. To bow the head without prostrating is to refuse succession; thus the bow is incomplete. To rise from weeping is to cherish his father. To rise without private counsel is to reject personal gain."

**Record:** The establishment of a lesser son as heir is not a matter of favor; favor perishes with the father. Chong’er was the eldest, and none could replace him. As for Duke Hui, he neither honored his elder brother above nor his younger brother below, seeking power through external alliances and internal scheming, seizing the throne by mere chance. Chong’er, meanwhile, stood solemn in grief, bowing his head in weeping—his demeanor was clearly unfeigned. Thus, the *Spring and Autumn Annals* does not record Duke Hui’s entry into Jin, nor does it condemn Li Ke, while the *Great Learning* also cites Jiu Fan’s words, all reflecting a spirit of guiding others toward goodness. Who could say that Duke Mu’s decision to receive Chong’er was not settled by Zixian’s report? Had Duke Wen acted thus in every matter, how could he have lingered abroad so long without returning?

Alas! His heart was not pure, and he grew adept at cunning stratagems. Though this was largely the fault of his lack of learning, Jiu Fan’s failure to properly guide his lord and shield him from harm cannot escape reproach.

**From the *Zuozhuan*:** Deng Shu asked Jia Ji, son of Jiu Fan: "Between Zhao Cui and Zhao Dun, who was the worthier?" He replied: "Zhao Cui is like the sun in winter; Zhao Dun, like the sun in summer."

**Record:** The sun in winter is beloved; the sun in summer, feared. Zhao Cui followed the exiled prince with a flask of broth, refusing to eat even when famished—his love was perfect. When Zhao Dun later governed the state, he established institutions, rectified laws, reformed punishments, oversaw promotions, and ensured that all were guided by both reverence and affection. This is why Jia Ji praised him so highly.

**From the *Kong Family Annals*:** Confucius’s ancestors descended from the house of Song. Weizi Qi, eldest son of Emperor Yi of Yin, served as a minister in the royal court and was enfeoffed as a viscount in the state of Wei. When the Duke of Zhou assisted King Cheng, he commanded Weizi to succeed the Yin as ruler of Song. His younger brother was known as Weizhong; Weizhong’s son was Duke Song Xi; Xi’s son was Ding Gong Shen; Shen’s son was Min Gong Xi; Xi’s son was Fufu He, who, though entitled to the succession, yielded it to his younger brother, Duke Li. He’s son was Songfu Zhou; Zhou’s son was Shifu Sheng, who served as a minister in Song; Sheng’s son was Zhengkao Fu; Fu’s son was Kongfu Jia, whose descendants took "Kong" as their surname. Jia’s son was Mujinfu; Mujinfu’s son was Gaoyifu; his son was Fang Shu, who fled to Lu to escape the disaster of the Hua clan, making Confucius a native of Lu. Fang Shu’s son was Boxia; Boxia’s son was Shuliang He, who prayed at Mount Niqiu and begot Confucius.

**Record:** One who traces Confucius’s lineage knows his era, yet why omit his ancestral line? Weizi inherited the legacy of the former kings, and Confucius truly continued the Yin succession. Through three dynasties, their fortunes rose and fell—this may be called perfect *ren*. Kuo spread the Five Teachings and illuminated human relationships, becoming the fountainhead of *ren*, *yi*, ritual, and music for ten thousand generations. Tang succeeded the Xia and ruled the world; his foundation and origins truly began here. By the time of Weizi, another sage arose, and both Emperor Yi and his ministers wished to enthrone him—thus Weizi was surely destined to be a ruler for his generation. Yet when he fled to Zhou bearing the sacrificial vessels, Heaven had abandoned Zhou, though it had not yet fully rejected the Yin. Zhou dared not treat him as a subject but allowed him to preserve his rituals and serve as a guest in the royal house. After several generations, when Zhou’s virtue also declined, Heaven then brought forth the Ultimate Sage to become the fountainhead of *ren*, *yi*, ritual, and music for all ages. Though he did not succeed Zhou as king, he effectively governed in place of the Yin.

Observe how the Master once said: "I study the rites of Yin; the state of Song preserves them." His implicit sense of responsibility is evident. How could this be omitted from discussion?

*The Comprehensive Records* corrects Sima Qian’s omissions, yet it too remains cursory—this is hardly sufficient. Such an account cannot be omitted. At nineteen, Confucius married a woman of the Kai Guan clan of Song, and within a year, Bo Yu was born. When Duke Zhao of Lu sent him a gift of carp, Confucius, honoring the ruler’s grace, named his son *Li* ("Carp") and styled him *Bo Yu* ("Elder Fish"). Bo Yu fathered Ji, styled Zisi, who composed *The Doctrine of the Mean*.

It is recorded: From Xie of Shang down to Tang, and from Tang onward to the enfeoffment in Song, over a thousand years passed before the House of Kong arose. Moreover, from Zheng Kaofu’s service under Dukes Dai, Wu, and Xuan through successive generations, Confucius finally emerged. Confucius then married again into the Kai Guan clan of Song, fathering Bo Yu, who in turn fathered Ji—thus the transmission of the Dao’s lineage found its proper heir. Heaven’s design for ten thousand generations was to continue the past and inaugurate the future, not merely to glorify what came before and enrich what followed. The stakes of this matter are no small contribution; how could it be passed over in silence? It is recorded here to supplement the omissions of the *Records of the Grand Historian*, *Ancient History*, *Comprehensive Records*, and other works.

*The Classic of Filial Piety* states: While Confucius was at leisure, Zengzi attended him. The Master said, "The former kings possessed the ultimate virtue and essential Dao, by which they brought harmony to the world. The people lived in concord, and none above or below harbored resentment. Do you understand this?" Zengzi rose from his mat and said, "Shen is dull—how could I presume to know it?" The Master said, "Filial piety is the root of virtue and the wellspring from which teaching arises." Resuming his seat, he continued, "Your body, hair, and skin are received from your parents—dare you not preserve them? This is the beginning of filial piety. Establish yourself and practice the Dao, glorify your name in later generations to bring honor to your parents, be loyal in serving your lord, and bear in mind your ancestors, thereby cultivating their virtue."

It is recorded: What, then, is this "ultimate virtue and essential Dao"? It is the heart. Why is the heart called "ultimate" and "essential"? Because it speaks to the world, the people, and those above and below—hence its ultimacy and essentiality. Why does it address the world, the people, and those above and below? Is this not because it is ultimate and essential? The world is vast, yet the sage deems it a burden—this is universal bestowal. The myriad people are numerous, yet the sage deems them a burden—this is aiding the multitude. Those above and below are unequal, yet the sage deems them a burden—this is the measuring square. How could one simply cease? Though the world is vast, kinship is one; though the myriad people are numerous, love is singular—this is the culmination of filial piety. Filial piety begins with serving one’s parents and ends with establishing oneself. *The Greater Odes* says: "None..." Though those above and below may be discordant, harmony is one. Kinship and harmony—these were the former kings’ heart, ample and unconstrained, expansive and generous. Though unseen, it could be applied to the hundred clans; though unheard, it could serve as a model for the four seas. Thus it is said: "The root of virtue and the wellspring from which teaching arises." This is the inception of the text, the foundation of the entire classic—not merely beginning with serving one’s parents, but clarifying the fivefold filial piety: loyalty in serving one’s lord and culmination in establishing oneself.

Youzi said: "Of those who are filial toward their parents and fraternal toward their elder brothers, few delight in defying their superiors. Of those who do not delight in defying their superiors, none delight in creating disorder." The noble person devotes himself to the root, for once the root is established, the Dao arises. Has there ever been one who was filial and fraternal yet failed to be *ren*? This is the root of *ren*."

It is recorded: Filial piety and fraternity are the root of *ren*. The root is like the trunk of a tree. A thing with a root will have branches, limbs, and leaves—thus one must cultivate the root, for the vital force resides here, not there. Suppose there is a person who greets others with a harmonious demeanor yet neglects his family—can he be called *ren*? Or suppose another is filial and fraternal toward his brothers yet treats others with hostility—is this possible? Thus it is said: "Of those who are filial and fraternal, few delight in defying their superiors. Of those who do not delight in defying their superiors, none delight in creating disorder." Yet this is merely the ordinary practice of the Dao, involving no particularly lofty or difficult deeds. Why, then, does the noble person devote himself so earnestly to it? Precisely because once the root is established and the Dao arises, it can be extended to heaven, earth, and the myriad things, each finding its proper place. Is this not the root of *ren*? The disciples, observing Youzi’s words and conduct, saw his bearing resembled that of the sage, and so recorded them at the beginning of the text. Thus, is devotion to the root not the foremost principle of constant practice?

Mencius said: "There has never been one who was *ren* yet neglected his parents." It is recorded: What is meant by "neglecting one’s parents"? It refers to the five types of unfilial conduct in common custom. Only the un-*ren* are ensnared by selfish human desires and commit such acts. The *ren* person, with every step and every word, dares not forget his parents. Thus, he listens for what is soundless and observes what is formless—how could he be indolent in his limbs? At home, he exerts utmost reverence; in providing for them, he ensures their joy—how could he indulge in gambling or drinking? What his parents love, he also loves—how could he covet wealth or favor his wife and children? Colors do not fade from his eyes, sounds do not cease in his ears—how could he follow the desires of his ears and eyes? In high position, he is not arrogant; in low position, he does not create disorder; among the vulgar, he does not contend—how could he delight in bravery or fighting? These are the greatest blessings of human relations, the boundless benefits of the family way, and the opening passages of the Three Classics—how could they not be examined?

Mencius also said: "The substance of *ren* is serving one’s parents." It is recorded: This "substance" is not opposed to the ornamental, nor is it like the kernel of a fruit. Rather, it is the inherent and ultimate destination. Thus it is called "substance." For *ren* to be *ren* is not an empty designation. It arises from heaven’s endowment of the parent-child bond, the utmost love of our nature, and the inherent destination of serving one’s parents.

Thus it is called *ren*. Below this, *yi*, *zhi*, *li*, and *yue*—none are otherwise. As for *yue*, life arises, and once life arises, how can it be stopped? Here, the full embodiment of *ren* reveals its great function, manifesting its utmost expression. Then hands dance and feet stamp, yet all emerge from these five. Their inherent destination requires no external seeking, no borrowed aid—it directly shows humanity the vital and vibrant Dao.

Generally, the words of sages and worthies are like the work of creation, containing all vitality within. Though people see them as layered petals, they are but a single bud, and what unfolds from within is the substance of *ren*. Let the reader ponder deeply.

*The Lesser Odes* says:
*"Vast and desolate is the marker—*
*Not a marker, but mugwort.*
*Turning back, I mourn my parents,*
*Who bore me with toil and labor.*

*Vast and desolate is righteousness—*
*Not righteousness, but weeds.*
*Mourning now my parents,*
*Who bore me with weariness and hardship.*

*The vessel is empty,*
*Yet shame remains for the unworthy.*
*The orphan’s life—*
*Better to have died long ago.*

*Without a father, what support?*
*Without a mother, what reliance?*
*Going out, none to guard or pity;*
*Coming in, none to receive.*

*Father, you gave me life;*
*Mother, you nurtured me.*
*You stroked me, cherished me,*
*Raised me, reared me,*
*Watched over me, returned to me,*
*Carried me in and out.*
*I long to repay your virtue—*
*Vast as heaven, without end."*

*"The southern mountain stands stern,*
*Whirling winds howl fiercely.*
*None lack sustenance—*
*Why am I alone afflicted?*
*The southern mountain looms steep,*
*Whirling winds rage wildly.*
*None lack sustenance—*
*Why do I alone not endure?"*

Recorded: The words of a well-ordered age flow smoothly, their phrases even; the words of a declining age are forced, their phrases sharp and urgent.

Thus, those who bring their mothers to live with them do not do so out of ignorance of their toil, care, and nurturance. If a ruler probes their true feelings and reproaches them with words, then they will harbor no private resentment. As for Lu Gu and Lu Fei, they were not unaware of the shame of a broken wall or the sound of an empty jar, yet they remained cautious in their wanderings—this still allowed them to fully express their devotion. Now, having been unable to complete their filial service and exhaust the love of a child, and lacking any labor or compassion to demonstrate the duty of a subject to their lord and father, with no one to blame, they turn the fault upon themselves, saying: "It is not I, but the artemisia," or "Vast as heaven, without end." Their cries to heaven and longing laments—how could these be restrained?

As for the lines *"The southern mountain stands stern, / Whirling winds howl fiercely,"* these express what cannot be fully conveyed. They weep tears of blood, exhausting their grief and resentment without even realizing it. Mencius said: "Shun was the greatest of the filial. Even at fifty, he longed for his parents." If this poem is not the most profound expression of love and longing, what is?

*The Record of Rites* states: "The filial child who harbors deep love must possess a harmonious qi. One with harmonious qi must have a joyful countenance. One with a joyful countenance must have a gentle demeanor. When a filial child holds jade, it is as if bearing a full vessel—steady and reverent, as though unable to bear its weight, as though about to lose it. Sternness and severity are not the way to serve one’s parents."

Recorded: Zixia said: "In serving one’s parents, one should exhaust one’s strength." Yet Confucius taught him: "The difficulty lies in the countenance." What does this mean? When Shun wailed to heaven, saying, "I have exhausted my strength plowing the fields and fulfilling my duties as a son," it is clear that the expression of one’s countenance differs from the exertion of one’s strength. For the bond between father and child is rooted in affection: parents are not merely parents—they are the ones who have made me who I am; I am not merely myself—I am the one who exists for my parents. The countenance arises from the movement of qi. It cannot be feigned or forced. When the heart is at peace, the qi is harmonious; when the qi is harmonious, it fills the face with an expression that arises naturally, without conscious effort.

Zixia was not merely a man of principle; he was cautious in his observance of ritual. He feared that one might mistake exhausting one’s strength for fulfilling benevolence, so the Master enlightened him. Otherwise, with Zixia’s mastery of literature and the many records of ritual that came from his disciples, how could he not have known that sternness and severity are not the way to serve one’s parents?

Zengzi said: "When a filial child cares for the elderly, they delight their hearts without opposing their wishes; they please their eyes and ears, ensuring their comfort in rest and movement, and in their food and drink, they serve them with devotion." Thus, what parents love, they also love; what parents respect, they also respect. Even dogs and horses are treated thus—how much more so should one serve one’s parents as a human being?

Recorded: The so-called "devoted service" means exhausting one’s heart in loyalty, which differs from merely exhausting one’s strength. Mencius said: "When Zengzi cared for Zeng Xi, whenever there was wine or meat, he would ask whom to share the leftovers with, and if asked whether there was any remaining, he would say there was." Yet was this the only way? Zeng Xi loved jujubes, and Zengzi could not bear to eat them—what act was not an expression of exhausting his heart? In serving one’s parents as Zengzi did, one may nearly fulfill benevolence.

Zilu said: "How grievous is poverty! In life, there is nothing to offer for sustenance; in death, nothing for burial." The Master said: "To sip bean broth and drink water, yet exhaust one’s joy—this is called filial piety."

Recorded: The so-called "exhausting one’s joy" does not mean demanding three sacrificial animals and five delicacies, for then even scholars would have no way to provide good care; nor does it mean urging others to prepare fine wine and grand coffins, for then the poor would have no way to give proper burials. Bean broth is not delicious—it is the abstemious who refine themselves with it. Water is not sweet—it is the drunkard who sobers himself with it. Who would say that a single question does not contain the highest teaching?

The filial children of Nanxia admonished one another in their service:
*"Following that southern slope, / Gathering orchids there, / Longing for the courtyard and hall, / My heart finds no peace.*
*That dweller of the house— / None wander idly about. / Fragrant are your many dishes, / Pure your morning meal.*
*Following that southern slope, / Its grasses lush and green, / That dweller of the house— / His countenance gentle and soft. / Longing for the courtyard and hall, / My heart finds no rest. / Fragrant your evening meal, / Pure your morning offering."*

*"Otter, otter, / By the river’s bend. / Swift waves rush forth— / Cast the net, catch the carp. / The forest birds cry out, / Fed by their young. / When care is deep and respect shallow, / Even birds resemble us. / Increase your reverence, / To bring forth great blessings."*

Recorded: This concludes with a supplementary poem because, as the Way of Zhou declined and benevolence and filial piety waned, there were those who did not act as fathers to their fathers, and those who accused their fathers of stealing sheep. Worse still, some sang during their mother’s mourning, taking callousness as the Way, unaware of the duty to repay one’s roots or the debt of returning nourishment. How lamentable! Are they not inferior even to beasts?

Though this poem lacks words, it is inscribed in the village and used in drinking feasts and musical gatherings. The noble person, through its melody, conveys its meaning, and through its meaning, extends its grace—perhaps then benevolence and filial piety will not be abandoned.

*Hongdao Record, Volume Four, concludes.*
*Hongdao Record, Volume Five.*

**Virtue: The Benevolence Between Father and Son**

From the *Book of Han*: In the first year of Emperor Wen’s reign, his officials petitioned to establish an heir apparent early. The Emperor said: “I am already lacking in virtue. Even if I cannot broadly seek out the worthy and sagacious of the world to cede the realm to them, to preemptively establish an heir apparent would only compound my inadequacy.” The officials firmly insisted: “To establish an heir apparent early is to honor the ancestral temples and altars of state, ensuring the realm is not forgotten. In antiquity, the Yin and Zhou dynasties endured for over a thousand years in peace and stability by following this principle. The succession of heirs through sons has been the unbroken way since time immemorial. The High Emperor pacified the realm and became its founding ancestor, and his descendants have inherited the succession without interruption. Now, to abandon the proper course and debate its impropriety—Prince Qi is the eldest, pure in character, kind, and benevolent. We petition to establish him as heir apparent.” The Emperor then assented.

*Record*: Since the Qin abandoned Fusu and enthroned Huhai, the realm has been thrown into chaos, warfare unceasing, and the people plunged into suffering—never has there been a worse time. As the *Book of Changes* states: “Only with father and son can there be ruler and minister.” Can the bond between father and son be left undetermined? The High Emperor of Han witnessed these ills firsthand, yet even he was swayed by anxious doubts. Though he spoke with such vehement conviction, he could not immediately halt the trend, and thus the Lǚ clan’s rebellion was summoned forth. In the end, the base-born usurped the true line, and the Han nearly met the same fate as the Qin. The scheme to welcome the Prince of Dai was one critical juncture; the edict of the first year was another. The two centuries of the Western Han’s enduring legacy rested upon the will of the people and the Mandate of Heaven. Herein we also see that the bond between father and son, once severed, was restored; its Way, once fallen, was revived. Alas! Can this not be called benevolence?

Emperor Wen, while residing in the Palace of Dai, saw Empress Bo fall gravely ill for three years. Through it all, he never once closed his eyes to sleep nor loosened his sash, and no broth or medicine passed his lips until he had first tasted it himself. Thus Yuan Ang remarked that even Zeng Shen, though but a commoner, would have found such devotion difficult—yet now Your Majesty, as a king, has surpassed him by far.

*Recorded here:* Does one’s conduct toward kin truly differ with rank, or the duty grow easier or harder? The Way of filial piety and fraternal love is the nature of Heaven. From the Son of Heaven to the humblest commoner, the station may vary, but the nature remains unchanged. Follow that nature, and what was difficult becomes easy; turn from it, and what was easy becomes hard. Whether Zeng Shen or the Emperor—who would weigh this lightly?

When Qi’s Grand Granary Prefect, Chunyu Yi, was convicted of a crime punishable by mutilation and sent under guard to the capital, his youngest daughter, Ti Ying, submitted a memorial: “My father served as an official, and all in Qi praised his honesty and fairness. Now, condemned by law to mutilation, I grieve that the dead cannot be revived, nor severed limbs rejoined. Though he might later seek to reform and begin anew, no path remains. I beg to be enslaved as a palace bondmaid to ransom my father’s punishment and allow him to start afresh.” The Son of Heaven, moved by her plea, abolished the practice of corporal mutilation.

*Recorded here:* Was Emperor Wen of Han not far superior to King Xuan of Qi? The worth of all under Heaven outweighs a single ox at the plow’s tip, and the counsel of great sages surpasses the words of a young girl. Yet when the Emperor bent the law to extend mercy, it was no mere exchange of small for great. Why, then, did many still decry it as misguided? Why not say instead that such a heart suffices to rule as king? If this was not done to curry favor or seek renown—if it arose from no fear of reproach—then it was surely an excess of love, an excess of generosity.

The grandson of Crown Prince Wei of the Han, known as Imperial Grandson, had a son named Bingyi, styled Imperial Great-Grandson. When the boy was but a few months old, the witchcraft affair erupted. The Crown Prince’s sons, daughters, wives, and concubines were all put to death—only the Imperial Great-Grandson survived, though he too was imprisoned. Bing Ji, charged with overseeing the case, knew the Crown Prince was innocent and pitied the Great-Grandson’s undeserved suffering. He selected a trustworthy female prisoner to nurse and care for the child, ensuring he was kept warm and dry.

Later, when the King of Changyi was deposed, Huo Guang and Zhang Anshi, along with other high ministers, debated whom to enthrone. Bing Ji submitted a memorial to Huo Guang: “The grandson of Emperor Wu, named Bingyi, is well-versed in the classics, possesses fine talents, and conducts himself with composure and moderation. I urge you, General, to settle this great matter.”

Huo Guang and Chancellor Chang then jointly memorialized: “The grandson of Emperor Wu, Bingyi, now eighteen, has studied the *Book of Songs*, the *Analects*, and the *Classic of Filial Piety*. He practices frugality in person, is kind and benevolent to others, and is fit to succeed Emperor Zhaoxiao.” The Grand Empress Dowager subsequently decreed: “He may be welcomed.” And so the Great-Grandson ascended the imperial throne.

The Record states: As the saying goes, "When the people unite, they can overcome Heaven; when Heaven's decree is fixed, it can overcome the people." How true this is! The histories relate that Crown Prince Li was benevolent, forgiving, temperate, and prudent, yet the Emperor嫌 his talents, finding them too similar to his own. It is further said: "The Emperor enforced the law with severity, often employing harsh officials. The Crown Prince, however, was lenient and merciful, frequently overturning unjust verdicts." The Crown Prince was sincere and bore no fault against the Han. Yet when the Emperor had grown old and his favor waned, the disaster of witchcraft and curses arose in tumult, and the calamity of chaos erupted suddenly—this was the people overcoming Heaven, hence the perilous state of affairs. Later, when the Emperor's heart awakened and the realm mourned in sorrow, the stones of Mount Tai stood upright without support, and the trees of Shanglin Park rose without summons—this was Heaven's decree overcoming man, hence the perfect alignment as if tallying tokens.

Though Crown Prince Li did not himself rule the realm, his descendants were destined to inherit it. From this, it is evident that the legacy of father and grandfather to son and grandson never truly perishes or fades; it is only when man opposes Heaven, or when timing and circumstance clash, that Bingyi was left without kin and Fuling without heirs. How tragic indeed!

*The Later Han Records* states: Emperor Guangwu of the Restoration was a descendant of Emperor Jing, through his son Liu Fa, the Prince Ding of Changsha. Fa begot Mai, the Marquis Jie of Chongling; Mai begot Xiongqu, the Marquis Dai; Xiongqu begot Ren, the Marquis Kao. Ren, finding the southern lands low and damp, relocated his fief to Baishui Township in Nanyang, where he settled with his clan. After Ren's death, his son Chang succeeded him. When Wang Mang usurped the throne, the state was abolished, and the title of Marquis Jie was lost. Ren's youngest son, Wai, became the Governor of Yulin. Wai begot Hui, the Commandant of Julu; Hui begot Qin, the Magistrate of Nandun. Qin married the daughter of Fan Chong of Huyang and fathered three sons: Yan, Zhong, and Xiu. Xiu had a high-bridged nose and protruding forehead, and he was diligent in farming. Xiu's aunt Yuan was married to Deng Chen of Xinye. Once, Xiu and Chen visited the diviner Cai Shaogong, who was well-versed in apocryphal prophecies. Shaogong declared, "Liu Xiu shall become the Son of Heaven." Later, Xiu ascended the throne as Emperor Guangwu of the Restoration.

*The Records of the Three Kingdoms* states: Liu Bei, the First Sovereign of Shu, was also a descendant of Emperor Jing, through his son Liu Sheng, the Prince Jing of Zhongshan. Sheng's son, Zhen, was enfeoffed as the Marquis of Lucheng Pavilion in Zhuo County in the sixth year of the Yuanshou era. He lost his title due to a gold-related offense while intoxicated and settled there. His grandfather, Xiong, and father, Hong, served in the provincial and commandery administrations for generations. Xiong was nominated as a Filial and Incorrupt candidate and later became the Prefect of Fan in Dong Commandery. The First Sovereign was orphaned young and, with his mother, made a living by selling sandals and weaving mats.

To the southeast corner of the house stood a mulberry tree by the fence, growing over five *zhang* tall. From afar, its canopy resembled a small carriage’s parasol, and passersby marveled at the tree’s extraordinary appearance, some saying it foretold the rise of a noble person. In his youth, the First Sovereign played beneath the tree with other children of his clan and declared, "I shall one day ride in a carriage adorned with feathered canopies." Later, he rose through the ranks to become Governor of Yizhou. When Cao Pi usurped the throne, the First Sovereign ascended the throne in Shu, styling himself Emperor Zhaolie.

*Recorded Notes:* Observing the circumstances of Emperor Guangwu and Emperor Zhaolie, I cannot but sigh in lament. When the Qin abolished the enfeoffment system, the Han, learning from its perils of isolation, generously enfeoffed its kinsmen, their virtue thus abundantly manifest. Yet in the blink of an eye, they were nearly exterminated—rendered not only incapable of serving as protective barriers but also stripped of their very flesh and blood. What was the reason for this? Since the founding of ancient states, only the Han arose from a commoner. At that time, fathers, brothers, sons, and nephews rode the tide of fortune’s rise, yet none had rendered even the slightest merit to the people. The Emperor himself was but a lowly post captain from Sishang. The stench of the sword that severed the serpent still lingered, and the momentum of his soaring ambition remained. How could such a legacy endure and flourish? Only after fifty or sixty years under Emperors Wen and Jing did the realm grow prosperous, rites and propriety flourish, customs transform, and the common folk become honest and sincere. By then, the Han’s primal *qi* had solidified, and its mandate had fully taken root. Only then did the sprouts of illegitimate scions wither and fade, while the blessings of loyalty and virtue extended far and wide. Thus, enfeoffment began in Changsha, and later Emperor Guangwu was peacefully enfeoffed in Zhongshan, followed by Emperor Zhaolie, who emerged from obscurity to inherit a broken mandate. Yet the descendants of Emperors Hui, Wu, Zhao, and Xuan could not match this. Had it not been for the beneficence of Emperors Wen and Jing, the Han’s rule might not have endured so steadfastly. Thus, we see that between father and son, and across dynastic transitions, benevolence and tyranny diverge sharply, as do the fortunes of continuity and severance. How can the noble-minded afford to overlook this? How can they afford to overlook this?

Empress Mingde of the Eastern Han, née Ma, was the daughter of General Fubo. In her youth, a physiognomist saw her and declared, "By fate, she shall attain great nobility." However, he added, "If she raises a younger son as if he were another’s, her strength will surpass that of his birth mother." When she became an *Imperial Consort*, her maternal aunt’s daughter, Jia, was also selected for the palace and bore Emperor Suzong. Emperor Ming, having no sons of his own, commanded her to raise the child, saying, "A child need not be one’s own; what matters is whether one’s love and care are sufficient." The Empress thereafter devoted herself wholeheartedly to his upbringing, her toil and weariness exceeding even that for her own child. Emperor Suzong, too, was deeply filial, his affection innate and sincere. The bond between mother and son remained unbroken, without the slightest discord. The Empress often lamented the scarcity of imperial heirs, her heart heavy with worry, and tirelessly recommended and promoted palace attendants, as if fearing she might not do enough. When new consorts were presented, she comforted and welcomed them, and if any gained favor, she treated them with even greater kindness.

*Recorded Notes:* During the reign of Emperor Cheng of Han, a palace scribe once bore a son. The Emperor and Lady Zhao, enraged, forced the scribe to drink poison and abandon the child. Lady Xu, another consort, also gave birth to a son, but Lady Zhao wept and refused to eat until the child was killed and buried beneath a screen. Those who miscarried due to self-inflicted harm were too numerous to count. The historian recorded all these events, leaving a grievance for ten thousand generations. I have repeatedly sighed in reflection: what kind of heart could commit such acts? Love arises from kinship, and affection from love. Though the Emperor was utterly benighted and foolish, could he not reflect that affection flows from himself, and love from his own being? How could he bear such perversity? Perhaps Heaven, weary of his debauchery, had reached its limit with Lady Zhao. Had it not been so, the imperial line would not have been severed, and future generations would have been spared the unnatural horror of patricide. Yet the principle of blessing the good and punishing the wicked remained unfulfilled. Thus, I am moved by the Empress’s conduct and record these events as a warning to all ages.

Emperor Suzong, the Filial and Illustrious Emperor Zhang, initially succeeded to the throne during the Yongping era, when the precedents of governance and official administration remained severe and exacting, with punishments tending toward the harsh. Minister of Works Chen Chong, observing that the Emperor had newly ascended, deemed it fitting to reform the lax and vulgar customs of former reigns. He thus memorialized: "Your servant has heard that the governance of the former kings was such that rewards did not exceed their due, and punishments were not indiscriminate. When compelled to choose, it is better to err on the side of excess in reward than in punishment. In the past, the strict and clear administration of justice served to awe and suppress villainy. Now that villainy has been pacified, it is imperative to temper severity with leniency. Governing is like tuning a zither or lute: if the thick strings are drawn too taut, the thin strings will snap. Your Majesty ought to exalt the Way of the former kings, sweep away the tangled and oppressive laws, lighten the weight of flogging and cudgeling to succor the multitudes, and magnify the utmost virtue to accord with the will of Heaven."

The Emperor deeply accepted Chong’s counsel and, in all matters, strove for magnanimity and generosity. Chong’s great-grandfather, Chen Xian, had served as Minister of Works during the Cheng and Ai reigns, specializing in statutes and ordinances. During the reign of Emperor Ping, when Wang Mang acted as regent and altered many Han institutions, Xian inwardly disapproved. By nature benevolent and forgiving, he often admonished his descendants: "When deliberating on the law, one should always incline toward leniency and caution, never aligning with the harshest interpretation against others." His grandfather, Qin, and father, Gong, both held office, and Gong served as Commandant of Justice in the early Jianwu era. The family had long been versed in the law. Chong, well-versed in the family profession and by nature meticulous, often spoke of the duty of ministers to be ever vigilant and cautious. From the time he entered the central administration, he dismissed his disciples and associates, devoting himself solely to public affairs. The court held him in high esteem.

Chong’s son, Zhong, inherited his father’s ethos, further emphasizing leniency and deliberation. He adjusted and refined legal procedures, establishing graded precedents to reduce the abuses of litigiousness. The chronicler observes: Chong’s words were not without foundation. By this time, the primordial qi of the Han was nearly exhausted. Had there not been above a sovereign of Zhang’s compliance and below ministers of prudence, who governed with magnanimity and succored with compassion, would the life-generating virtue of Heaven and Earth, the unbroken beauty of descendants, not have perished? Thereafter, Emperor He left few heirs, and his grandsons You, Chong, and Zeng successively ascended the throne. All were descendants of Emperor Zhang, and Chong’s line likewise continued unbroken for generations—was this not the enduring Dao? The wisdom of brothers...

From *The Book of Jin*: Xie Xuan was the nephew of Xie An. An, ever loyal to the imperial house, admonished his sons and nephews, saying: “Why should you meddle in worldly affairs? Yet if you must, strive to excel.” None of the others spoke, but Xuan replied: “It is like planting orchids and jade trees—we wish only to see them flourish in our courtyard.” An was pleased.

At the time, Fu Jian’s power was at its height, and his incursions along the frontier had shaken the court. Seeking a capable commander to defend the north, An recommended Xie Xuan for the post. Huan Chong, upon hearing this, sighed: “An defies convention to advance his kin—this is wisdom. Xuan will not betray his nomination—this is talent.” Thus, Xuan was appointed General Who Establishes Martial Power and Inspector of the Armies North of the Yangzi. From Guangling, he marched west, seized Baima, and crushed the enemy in battle.

Fu Jian personally led his forces to Xiangcheng, boasting a million men. He first dispatched Fu Rong and Murong Chui to Yingkou, while the court named Xuan Commander of the Vanguard, ordering him to resist with eighty thousand troops. Xuan sent word to Fu Rong: “You have come deep into our land and arrayed your forces along the river—surely you do not wish to fight at once. Why not withdraw slightly, allowing our officers and men room to maneuver? Then we may ride unhurriedly and observe the spectacle. Would that not be delightful?” Fu Jian’s generals urged: “We should hold the Fei River and prevent them from crossing.” But Jian said: “Simply withdraw and let them pass. Then we shall press them with our iron cavalry and annihilate them—how could we fail?” Fu Rong agreed and ordered the retreat. The troops, thrown into chaos, could not be halted.

Xuan seized the moment, leading eight thousand elite soldiers across the Fei River to engage in fierce combat. Fu Jian’s forces collapsed in rout, trampling one another, drowning in the river in numbers beyond count. The very wind and cranes seemed to cry out for the royal army. Fleeing through the wilderness, exposed to frost and famine, seven or eight out of ten perished. Later, An memorialized that the court should exploit this opportunity to reclaim the old capital. Xuan advanced his troops to Pengcheng, where the Three Wei regions all surrendered. He was appointed Commander of the Armies of Ten Provinces—Yan, Qing, Yu, Xu, Ji, You, Bing, and others—and enfeoffed as Duke of Kangle County.

The chronicler observes: Some have asked how Xie An’s victory at the Fei River compares to Zhou Yu’s triumph at Red Cliffs. An earlier scholar remarked: “Skill lies in matching the Qi, clumsiness in contending with Chu.” Thus, the difference between swift and slow, artful and artless, advance and retreat, fast and slow—this is precisely when the superior man’s careful planning bears fruit. For Wu and Wei were no match, just as Qin and Jin had long been unequal. At the time, one side spoke of meeting the enemy head-on, while the other fretted over its foundations. Without a settled strategy, how could victory be assured?

Thus, Cao Cao’s million-strong host and Fu Jian’s attempt to dam the Yellow River were blunders of Qin-like clumsiness. Zhou Yu’s advantage of a single reed’s passage and Xie An’s exploitation of the half-crossing were strokes of Qi-like skill. How apt! To plan for one’s enemy is to ensure that, whether they advance or retreat, none can withstand you. Yet the failure of the Six Dynasties to unify was Heaven’s will. By Heaven’s decree, many submitted, and the very winds, crows, mountains, clouds, and grasses seemed to conspire in ways no mortal foresight could anticipate. Even the wisdom of the Xie brothers could not surpass this, nor could the keenest observer’s judgment.

From *The History of the Southern Dynasties*: Xie Xian was the elder brother of Xie Hui. When Hui served as Right Guard of the Song court, his influence already rivaled that of the Prince of Pengcheng. Upon returning to the capital, he found his home besieged by guests, the streets choked with visitors. Xian was alarmed and said to Hui: “Your rank is not yet high, yet the people flock to you in such numbers. Our family has always been retiring, uninvolved in worldly affairs, with a circle no wider than kin and friends. Now your power overshadows the court and the realm—is this a blessing for our house?” He then separated their households, declaring: “I cannot bear to witness this.”

Later, in Pengcheng, he addressed Emperor Gaozu: “I am but a humble scholar; my father and grandfather never rose above the rank of two thousand *shi*. My brother is barely thirty, his ambitions modest, yet he has been honored above all in the court, entrusted with weighty and secret duties. When fortune exceeds its due, calamity follows—its arrival cannot be far. I beg to be demoted, that our declining house may be preserved.” When Hui later rendered meritorious service in founding the dynasty and was entrusted with great responsibilities...

Penglian grew ever more anxious and fearful. While serving as prefect, he fell ill but refused treatment, hoping for an early death. On his deathbed, he wrote to Hui: *"I have been granted this life, and by good fortune, my bones may return to the mountains whole."*

The compiler notes: *Observing Boqi’s words before and after, they suffice to shatter the delusions of later generations who cling to gain. Zhen truly lived up to the title ‘Master of the Guanzhong School.’ The hidden is most visible, the subtle most manifest—along with the admonition that ‘ten eyes watch, ten hands point’—these are all essential teachings of the Confucian school. As for the so-called ‘pure and incorruptible officials,’ how could they be compared to those who merely seek fame? Truly so. When virtue follows in unbroken succession, blessings flow far, surpassing even the Yuan clan of old. Few in later ages could match this.*

History records that Yuan Chang, a eunuch of the Eastern Han, was of the same lineage as Yuan Pu. When Pu held power at court, his family’s prestige soared, and they relied on external support. Thus, the Yuans enjoyed wealth and favor for generations, their opulence exceeding that of other noble clans—yet this was not the same.

At the time, Xun Shu of Dangtu had eight sons: Jian, Kun, Jing, Tao, Wang, Shuang, Su, and Zhuan, all renowned in their day. The people called them the "Eight Dragons." The governor of Bohai, Yuan Kang, renamed their village "Gaoyangli," comparing it to antiquity. Shuang, styled Ciming, was studious from childhood. By twelve, he had mastered the *Spring and Autumn Annals* and the *Analects*. The Grand Commandant Du Qiao praised him, saying, *"He could be a teacher to others."* Devoted to the classics, he declined all official summons.

In Yingchuan, a saying arose: *"The Eight Dragons of the Xun clan—none compare to Ciming."* Jing, styled Shucai, was gifted from youth and conducted himself with perfect propriety. When Xu Zhang of Runan asked who was the worthier between Shuang and Jing, he replied, *"Both are jade. Ciming shines outwardly, Shucai glows within."*

Later, Chen Fan, the magistrate of Taiqiu, had six sons. Ji, styled Yuanfang, was famed for his virtue. Shen, styled Jifang, matched his brother in conduct, leading to the saying: *"Yuanfang makes a brother hard to be, Jifang makes a younger brother hard to be."* Their filial devotion and harmonious household inspired admiration. Scholars of later generations revered their example, and father and sons together earned the title "Three Gentlemen."

Once, when visiting Xun Shu, Chen Fan arrived without attendants. Chen Ji drove the carriage, Chen Shen followed behind, and the young Chen Qun rode inside. Upon reaching the Xun residence, Shu’s wife answered the gate, Ciming served wine, and Wenruo, still a child, sat on his father’s lap as the sons engaged in learned discussion. At that moment, auspicious stars gathered in the sky, and the imperial astronomer reported: *"Within five hundred *li*, worthy men have convened."*

The compiler notes: *Observing the Eastern Han dynasty, at its rise, a guest star appeared; at its fall, auspicious stars shone. Can celestial omens truly be trusted? Rulers are the standard of their age, while the worthy are the heart of the people. Heaven does not obscure the radiance of virtue with mist and haze, just as the times do not extinguish the birth of sages because of comets or misfortune. Thus, the harmony of divine listening endures. Reading the ‘Ping’ poem, one understands the flourishing of the Ji lineage; seeing Yan’s tears and turning sleeves, one grasps the fall of the Zhou. Yet this was not unique to the Han’s decline.*

The *Book of Jin* records: Ji Shao, son of Ji Kang, was orphaned at ten. He served his mother with filial devotion and lived in seclusion after his father’s execution. Shan Tao recommended him to Emperor Wu, comparing him to Gao Yao and Qi Huang, urging that he be summoned. When Shao first entered Luoyang, someone remarked to Wang Rong: *"Yesterday, amid the crowd, I saw Ji Shao—tall and proud as a crane among chickens."* Rong replied: *"You have not yet seen his father."*

The President of the Secretariat, Pei Wei, also esteemed him. At the time, the young imperial relative Jia Mi held high office, and scholars like Pan Yue and Du Yu curried his favor. Mi sought Shao’s friendship, but Shao rebuffed him. When Mi was executed, Shao was enfeoffed as Marquis of Gaoyang for his integrity and promoted to Cavalier Attendant-in-Ordinary.

After the restoration of order, he memorialized: *"May Your Majesty never forget Jintang, may the Grand Marshal never forget Yingshang, may the Grand General never forget Huangqiao—then the seeds of chaos will have no chance to sprout."*

When the Prince of Hejian, Sima Yong, and the Prince of Chengdu, Sima Ying, marched on the capital to attack the Prince of Changsha, Sima Yi, the imperial cortege halted east of the city. Yi declared to the troops: *"Today we march west—who shall be our commander?"* The six armies cried out: *"Let the Cavalier Attendant Ji lead us!"*

Shao, seeing the emperor in peril, received the edict to proceed to the imperial presence. As the royal army suffered defeat at Dangyin, officials and guards scattered in panic. Only Shao, dignified in full court regalia, shielded the emperor with his body. Amid the clash of weapons and the rain of arrows, he fell at the emperor’s side, his blood spattering the imperial robes. The emperor mourned him deeply. When order was restored, attendants sought to wash the bloodstains, but the emperor said: *"This is the blood of Cavalier Attendant Ji—do not remove it."*

Earlier, as Shao prepared to depart, the Cavalier Attendant Qin Zhun asked: *"Today you face peril—do you have a fine horse?"* Shao replied sternly: *"If the imperial carriage is lost, my duty remains. What need have I for a swift steed?"* Those who heard him sighed in admiration.

The compiler notes: *According to the* Jin History*, the Cavalier Attendant’s loyalty was paramount—why then is it recorded under ‘filial piety between father and son’? The* Book of Changes *says: ‘Correcting the father’s errors brings peril, but ends in good fortune.’ The father, Zhongsan, was a criminal against the moral teachings of all ages; the son, the Cavalier Attendant, was the paragon of loyalty in his time. The father’s death was lighter than a goose feather and fouler than the annals of history; the son’s death was weightier than Mount Tai and brighter than the sun and moon. The father’s praise was no more than ‘a worthy companion to Gao Yao’; the son’s glory will forever be ‘a family steadfast in loyalty.’*

The young Bian was orphaned at ten, yet served his mother with filial devotion, as if by natural endowment.

The compiler notes: "To seek loyal ministers at the gates of filial sons—lord and minister, father and son share the same Dao."

Bian Kun was diligent in official duties, handling affairs with integrity, determined to uphold rectitude and oversee the age without compromise. Emperor Ming valued him above all ministers for his steadfast service. Ruan Fu often remarked that Kun never knew ease, to which Kun replied: "Among you gentlemen, who else but I clings to such narrow-mindedness, while you all esteem moral expansiveness and refined elegance?"

At the time, the sons of noble families admired Wang Cheng and Xie Kun for their unconventionality. Kun rebuked them sternly: "Nothing is more grievous than defying ritual and harming moral instruction. The collapse of the central court was precisely due to this."

When Yu Liang prepared to campaign against Su Jun, Kun vehemently opposed him, warning: "Jun commands strong troops, harbors many rogues, and presses close to the capital. Should he rebel even once, we would stumble irrecoverably. We must weigh this with deep and far-reaching consideration—haste is unwise." Liang did not heed him, and Jun indeed rose in revolt.

The court ordered Kun to oversee military affairs. He fought Jun at Lingxi, battling fiercely despite grave illness, and perished. His two sons, Miao and Xu, followed him into the fray and were slain alongside him.

After Jun’s defeat, Minister Hong Ne discussed the case: "Nothing surpasses filial piety in serving one’s parents, nor loyalty in serving one’s lord. Only through filial devotion can one offer utmost reverence and wholehearted sincerity; only through loyalty can one face danger and offer one’s life. These are the great virtues of the Three Bonds, the highest conduct of minister and child. Kun served three reigns, offering counsel and support. When the realm faced peril, he staked his life upon it. When the traitor Jun rebelled, he exerted all his strength to suppress him, standing in the path of arrows and blades, confronting the enemy’s vanguard twice. Father and sons perished together—one might say he ruined his family for the state, held fast to death in devoted service. Above, he matched Xu Mu; below, he equaled Ji Shao."

Thus, he was posthumously appointed Cavalier Attendant-in-Ordinary, General of the Chariot and Cavalry, and granted the privilege of establishing an office with the full ceremonial of the Three Dukes. The imperial decree declared: "For his loyalty and steadfastness, offer a grand sacrifice." His son Tai was posthumously named Gentleman Cavalier Attendant, and Xu, Attendant-in-Ordinary of the Imperial Carriage. His wife, Lady Pei, embraced his corpse and wept: "A father loyal to his lord, sons filial to their father—what regret could there be?"

The recluse Zhai Tang also said: "A father dies for his lord, sons die for their father—here, the Dao of loyalty and filial piety converges in one household."

The compiler notes: "Observing the two Jin dynasties, one finds the Bian father and sons—truly outstanding, rising above their generation. When Su Jun rebelled, Liang summoned him, and Liang died for it—this was fitting. Yet Kun, clearly foreseeing the disaster, still chose death. Why? The pursuit of reputation and the commitment to truth stand worlds apart.

The followers of Wang and Xie pursued fame: their self-regard was boundless. Those who chase reputation polish their demeanor and refine their discourse; when words align, they exult, but when crisis comes, they falter. They prize lofty detachment, and others see them as no different from the common run—content with what is acceptable.

Those who pursue truth hold fast to unyielding integrity and steadfast principles. Confronted with affairs, they regard wrongdoing as a personal enemy; facing peril, they refuse to shrink, even at the brink of ruin. They take resolute action as their constant resolve, and others defer to them, unaware of what they cannot endure. Thus, they do not cease until death.

Yet in dying to perfect their humanity, they illuminate their unblemished integrity. The sons, too, sought and attained humanity—loyalty and filial piety preserved their names whole. They will endure as long as heaven and earth, shine as brightly as the sun and moon. How do they compare to those 'refined gentlemen'? A thousand, ten thousand times greater!

Alas! They were truly humane."

In Tao Qian’s *"Letter to My Sons Yan, Si, Fen, and Chan"*:

To Yan, Si, Fen, and Chan:

Heaven and earth bestow life, and all who are born must die. From ancient times, even the wise and sagely—who could escape this fate? As Zixia said: *"Life and death are decreed by fate; wealth and honor rest with Heaven."* These words came from one of the Four Companions, who received the Master’s teachings firsthand. Does not this saying imply that success and failure cannot be recklessly sought, nor longevity or early death arbitrarily requested?

I am now past fifty. From youth, I have known hardship and poverty, often driven to wander east and west to sustain my family. My nature is unyielding, my talents crude, and I have clashed with the world at every turn. Knowing my own limits, I feared bringing trouble upon myself, so I resigned from office, sparing you from hunger and cold in your youth. Yet I have often recalled the words of Ruzhong’s wise wife: *"Wrapped in rags, how can I warm my sons?"* This, too, is my plight. But what grieves me most is the absence of a caring mother like Lady Mi for my two younger brothers. Bearing this sorrow, I feel only deep shame within.

In my youth, I studied the zither and books, finding solace in quietude. When I opened a scroll and grasped its meaning, I would forget to eat. Seeing trees cast their intertwined shade, hearing birds change their songs with the seasons, I would rejoice as if blessed. I once said that in the fifth or sixth month, lying beneath the north window when a cool breeze briefly arose, I felt like a man of the era of Fuxi. My understanding was shallow, my knowledge scant—I thought such words could endure. Yet time fleets, and with it, my strength and skill have faded. Looking back now, how distant and faint those days seem.

Since falling ill, I have grown increasingly frail. Though relatives and old friends have not abandoned me, sending medicines and remedies, I fear my allotted time is nearly spent. You are still young, and our family is poor. You toil daily with firewood and water—when will this end? The thought of it weighs on my heart like a burning coal, beyond words.

Though you share the same parents, remember the truth that *"all within the four seas are brothers."* When Bao Shu and Guan Zhong divided their wealth, they harbored no suspicion; when Gui Sheng and Wu Ju met on the road, they spread rushes to sit and reminisce. From ruin, they built success; from loss, they achieved great deeds. If even strangers can do this, how much more should those born of the same father?

Han Yuanchang of Yingchuan, a renowned scholar of the late Han, served as a high official and lived to eighty. His brothers lived together until their teeth fell out. Fan Zhichun of Jibei, a man of exemplary conduct in the Jin dynasty, shared wealth with seven generations of his family, and no one bore resentment. As the *Book of Songs* says: *"Like gazing up at a lofty mountain, like following a shining path."* Though I cannot match such virtue, my heart aspires to it.

Beware, my words end here.

It is recorded: In the human Dao, the Three Bonds stand foremost. Jingjie [Tao Yuanming] lived alone, yet nothing in his conduct was amiss. He forgot words in pursuit of true meaning and entrusted his fate to the great transformation, nearly attaining unity with the Dao.

Some may suspect this elder’s meticulous instructions were an excessive concern for what comes after death—this is far from the case. The bond between father and child is of heavenly nature; how could it be abandoned? Since the dawn of writing, this innate sincerity has remained unchanging. Even a thousand years later, one can imagine his boundless kindness, his meticulous care, his profound humanity and virtue—far beyond mere considerations of honor or disgrace, bitterness or joy. How can those who hide in obscurity, act strangely, and purify themselves at the cost of great human relationships be spoken of in the same breath?

Ku Yin, in his youth, stood firm with unyielding integrity. When he was just over ten, his father passed away, and his weeping moved all who heard it to tears. He served his mother with filial devotion. When he observed mourning, his grief exceeded ritual propriety. Once, when tasting food, he found its flavor agreeable and, ashamed, cast it aside. He lived in poverty with Han Kangbo, the Grand Master of Ceremonies. Kangbo’s mother, the sister of Yin Hao, was a wise and virtuous woman. Whenever she heard Yin’s weeping, she would set down her meal and chopsticks, moved to tears. Later, she said to Kangbo: *"If you ever hold the power of appointment, you must promote men like this."* When Kangbo became Minister of Personnel, Yin ascended through the ranks of pure office.

It is recorded: Those who drink from the spring of responsibility without changing their hearts do so to establish themselves, practice the Dao, and glorify their names for posterity—to honor their parents, not merely for their own sake. Had he not stood firm from youth, mourning his parents with such devotion, how could he have remained so steadfast? His grief exceeding ritual had its reasons. Kangbo’s discernment and Han’s mother’s insight into character—were they not of one mind, even sharing the same neighborhood? This embodies the ancient ideal of choosing worthy neighbors, a beauty indeed.

It is recorded in *The Book of Wei*: Gao Yun, Duke of Xianyang and Grand Master of Splendor, served five emperors, entering and leaving the Three Departments for over fifty years without ever incurring blame. Benevolent, forgiving, simple, and serene, though he held high office, his heart remained as humble as a commoner. He held books to read day and night without cease. He tirelessly taught others goodness, ever gentle and patient, cherishing both the new and the old, leaving none behind.

As General of Tasked Forces in the East and Governor of Huaizhou, he toured his jurisdiction in the autumn months, inquiring after the people’s hardships. Arriving at Zhaoxian County, he saw that the temple of the Duke of Shao lay in ruins, unbuilt, and said: “The virtue of the Duke of Shao, left unhonored and without ritual—what hope is there for those who do good?” He then memorialized the throne to have it repaired. At that time, nearing ninety years of age, he exhorted the people to study and cultivate their livelihoods, and his transformative influence spread widely.

Later, during the Zhengguang era, the Palace Gentleman of the Secretariat, Chang Jing, reflecting on Yun’s legacy, led the elders of the commandery to establish a shrine for him south of Yewang, erecting a stele to record his virtue.

When the Emperor Shizu pacified Qing and Qi, he relocated their eminent clans to Dai. At that time, many scholars and gentry had been displaced and arrived from afar, most suffering from hunger and cold, and many were his relatives by marriage. Yun distributed his wealth and exhausted his property to provide for them, offering relief and consolation with thorough care. All were moved by his benevolence and generosity.

Yun’s mother, in her advanced years, once said to others: “When my son served in the Secretariat, he performed hidden acts of virtue, saving and aiding lives. If his yang retribution is not amiss, I should live to a hundred.” In the end, she indeed passed away at the age of ninety-eight.

Recorded thus:

Life and death are indeed matters of great weight. Gao Bogong, free from doubt or hesitation, saw both mother and son ultimately attain long life. Those who understand destiny—why must they toil restlessly? Yet even a low-ranking official, if he harbors a heart that cherishes all things and aids others in some small way, is no different from one who served in the Secretariat. He served five emperors, moving in and out of the Three Departments for over fifty years—unlike the "Old Man of Everlasting Joy," and thus the gentleman did not reject him.

*The Old Tang History* records: In the twelfth month of the twentieth year of the Zhenguan era, the Emperor said to Changsun Wuji and others, "Today is my birthday. The world celebrates with joy, but in such moments, sorrow often arises. Now I rule all under heaven and possess the four seas, yet I can never again receive my parents’ affection at my knees. This is why Zilu bore the regret of carrying rice for his parents." He then recited the *Book of Songs*: *"When I think of my parents’ toil in raising me, how can I turn their days of labor into mere feasting and pleasure?"* Tears streamed down his face, and all around him were moved to grief.

Recorded thus: These words of Taizong reveal the insight of a truly enlightened ruler. Though "boundless longevity" has been the prayer of emperors past and present, it is the duty of ministers and sons to fulfill their roles with devotion. If one were to place oneself in such a position, how could empty celebrations bring joy when the heart is weighed down by sorrow? This shows Taizong’s innate goodness. Had he cultivated it with the learning of sages, how could Yao and Shun have been beyond his reach?

Di Renjie once spoke to Empress Wu with measured words: "Between aunt and nephew, and mother and son—which bond is closer? If Your Majesty enthrones your son, then for ten thousand generations after, he will be enshrined in the ancestral temple, ensuring an unbroken line of succession. But if you enthrone your nephew, it has never been heard that a nephew, as emperor, would offer sacrifices to his aunt in the temple." The Empress’s heart stirred slightly, and she summoned the Prince of Luling to the imperial court. In the ninth month, she named him Crown Prince.

Recorded thus: The integrity of Duke Liang was rooted in the utmost principles of Heavenly reason and human relations. Yet his approach was not to impose but to illuminate what was already clear and dispel what was obscured. The bond between father and son is the foundation of natural affection, while that between aunt and nephew is a distant tie of different surnames. Even tigers and wolves, fierce as they are, know the intimacy of parent and child—so long as their lusts have not reached their extreme. It is only when human desires run rampant that the original heart becomes obstructed. Once the original heart is blocked, alien influences take hold. Though one may appear human in form, who is truly without self-interest? The mere mention of offering sacrifices to an aunt in the temple was enough to stir the Empress’s unfulfilled maternal heart. In discussing affairs of state, his words possessed the power to turn the tide of Heaven—such was Duke Liang.

Early in his career, when Duke Liang served as Legal Clerk of Bingzhou, his parents resided in Heyang. One day, as he ascended Mount Taihang, he turned back and saw a solitary white cloud drifting above. He said to his attendants, "My parents’ home lies beneath it," and gazed longingly for some time. Only when the cloud moved on did he depart. Those around him were deeply moved.

Recorded thus: The world knew of Duke Liang’s exemplary conduct, but few knew of his filial piety. As the saying goes: *"One who is filial to his parents can transfer that loyalty to his lord."* From this, we understand that a minister’s failure to remonstrate does not stem from the impossibility of persuasion but from the lack of resolve in his own conduct. Nor does the difficulty of accomplishing great deeds lie in external challenges but in the insufficiency of sincerity.

Li Jingye, on the other hand, rose in rebellion with his father’s corpse still unburied, lamenting only that *"the soil on his grave is not yet dry"* and *"where now is the six-foot orphan?"*—how far had he strayed from the path? His cause was doomed to fail.

Li Chen lost his father in childhood and served his mother with utmost filial devotion. Bold and talented, he would don embroidered robes and a brocade cap before battle, leading the charge to inspire his troops. When Zhu Ci occupied the capital and Li Huaiguang plotted treachery, Chen addressed his assembled forces: "The nation faces endless crises, and rebellions arise one after another. The imperial carriage has fled west, leaving Guanzhong without a ruler. We have all received the state’s grace—when danger arises, to die for loyalty is the duty of a minister and subject. If we cannot slay the traitors at such a time, we are no heroes." He then declared, "The Wei Bridge spans a great river, cutting off the enemy’s head and tail. Let us join forces, seize the advantage, and advance to restore the great enterprise and achieve an unparalleled feat. What say you?" The troops wept and replied, "We follow your command."

When they reached the Tonghua Gate, Chen said, "If we first secure the markets and alleys, the narrow streets will be filled with residents. Should the enemy set ambushes and engage in close combat, the people will panic and scatter—this is no strategy. The enemy’s main forces are in the palace gardens. If we strike at their heart from the gardens, they will have no time to flee. Thus, the palaces will be secured, the markets undisturbed, and the people unharmed—this is the best plan." The generals agreed. That night, they breached the garden wall in over two hundred places, dividing their forces to advance simultaneously. The battle cries shook the earth, and they pressed forward relentlessly, driving the enemy to Baihua. Zhu Ci and Yao Lingyan fled in disarray.

Chen’s army entered the capital and encamped before the Hall of Manifest Origin. He issued orders: "The people of Chang’an have long suffered under the rebels. If we cause even the slightest alarm, it would betray the righteousness of punishing the guilty and comforting the people. Proclaim to all: let the residents remain in peace, and not a single blade of grass shall be harmed." The people rejoiced, and even those from distant regions did not realize the city had been retaken until the official report arrived. The Emperor declared: "In ancient times, generals who restored capitals by force were not uncommon. But to spare the ancestral temples, leave the markets untouched, and ensure the people of Chang’an never saw the banners of war—such a feat has not been seen since the Three Dynasties. Heaven raised Li Chen for the sake of the state and its people, not for me alone."

Later, when his son Li Su became commander, he once launched a night attack in a snowstorm to defeat Wu Yuanji, halting at the rebel’s outer residence. When the officials of Cai reported the city’s fall, Yuanji refused to believe it—until he heard Su’s troops issuing commands. Only then did his officers say, "How did the eunuch reach this point?"

Then he drove his retinue to the inner city to resist, while Yuanji on the city walls begged for mercy. They lowered him by ladder and sent him in a caged cart to the capital. Over twenty thousand troops from Shen and Guang Prefectures and various garrisons surrendered in succession. From the moment Yuanji was captured, not a single life was taken; all who had served in his headquarters, kitchens, or stables were restored to their posts.
