The army encamped in the polo field to await Pei Du.

Like Chen’s earlier triumph, this feat resounded with equal renown. The father and son’s great merit defies comparison.

Recorded: When Tang of Shang campaigned against Ge, his invincible host practiced the governance of a true king, and the people knew not war—so natural was their submission. The Chens’ rescue of Tang, however, stemmed a deluge with a cracked vessel; that markets remained unchanged bespeaks the difficulty of quelling rebellion. Had the court heeded the clamorous counsel of generals, streets would have been thrown into chaos, and no sweeping victory achieved. Had it trusted the words of military clerks and executed Li You, no such monumental success would have followed. Thus it is said: “Only Xiping has such a son; only I have such ministers.” Between father and son, the benefits were boundless.

The historian praises Li Guangbi: born to a frontier lineage, steadfast and resolute, he rose to command amid upheaval, outmaneuvering enemies and securing victory. His rewards and punishments were just, his troops fiercely loyal—unmistakably the bearing of an ancient great general. Yet he observed full mourning for his father, never entering his wife’s chambers, and served his stepmother with utmost filial piety, setting him apart from common warriors.

It is often said of Duke Duan of Jin that he was merely a soldier who seized fame through reckless bravery—this is untrue. Duan Xiushi was solemn and restrained, always walking with head bowed and hands clasped, his speech and manner unassuming. He never met others with harshness, and people took him for a scholar. At six, when his mother fell ill, he refused even a spoonful of water for seven days, eating only when her condition improved—earning the title of “Filial Child.” Again, when Li Xun and his brother Jian sojourned in Jingzhou, their mother cherished Jian’s devotion, saying, “When Jian urges me to eat, I am always sated; when he administers medicine, I feel it will surely work.” The villagers emulated him, bringing disputes to Jian rather than the magistrate. Emperor Dezong promoted him from Right Reminder and Hanlin Academician to Prefect of Lizhou, then summoned him as Vice Minister of Justice, posthumously honoring him as Minister of Works.

Recorded: Xue Fang observed that those who practice filial piety and kindness foster harmonious qi. Thus, whether in frontier legacies, martial ranks, or humble wanderers, all who established merit, integrity, or renown did so from this foundation. How much more so for nobles, the esteemed of the Central Kingdom, or the learned gentry—need one even speak of it? Such histories serve the world’s teachings, and records cannot be omitted.

*Hongdao Record*, Volume 5, ends.
(Note: “Song” emended to “family” per context.)

*Hongdao Record*, Volume 6: Benevolence.

**Filial and Parental Benevolence**

From *The History of the Song*: During the ninth year of the Dazhong Xiangfu era of Emperor Zhenzong (1016), on the first day of the fifth month, a prince was born to Consort Li of the rear palace. Zhou Qi, then Prefect of Kaifeng, was reporting on affairs when the emperor said, “Do you know of my joy?” Qi replied, “I do not.” The emperor said, “I have just had a son.” He then entered the inner palace, emerged with gold coins in his sleeve, and scattered them as gifts to Qi.

Consort Li, a native of Hangzhou, had initially entered the palace to serve Consort Liu. She was solemn and reticent, and the emperor favored her, appointing her as Lady of the Court. Once with child, she accompanied the emperor to Qitai Terrace, where her jade hairpin fell. The emperor secretly divined that if the pin remained unbroken, she would bear a son. When attendants retrieved it, the pin was undamaged. The emperor rejoiced, and soon after, she indeed gave birth to a son—this was Emperor Renzong.

**Recorded:** The founding and destiny of the entire Song dynasty hinged upon this event. Though the dynasty was established amid haste and turmoil, with no dissent at the time, later generations would not have readily accepted it. Yet through three reigns, Renzong’s forty-two-year rule—marked by profound benevolence and deep virtue, which permeated flesh and bone—further illuminated the grandeur of his ancestors’ legacy and secured the legitimacy of imperial succession. Even a hundred generations later, the virtuous man cannot but feel a surge of joy and gratitude at the birth of such a benevolent ruler.

**Further Recorded:** The imperial consort from Hangzhou gave birth to Renzong. Now, our Empress Dowager Shou’an, also from Hangzhou, bore Emperor Xingsheng. Their dragon’s ascent and phoenix’s dance, the mountains and rivers bearing witness—this is no mere coincidence. And if five hundred years later another true sovereign arises, it will be further proof of this pattern.

In the second year of Jingyou (1035), Emperor Renzong adopted Zongshi, son of Prince Yunrang of Runan, and raised him in the palace. Yunrang was a grandson of Emperor Taizong, his father being Prince Shang, Yuanyuan. As the emperor had no heir, he took Zongshi, then four years old, and commanded the empress to foster him.

**Recorded:** At the time, the emperor had reigned for thirteen years and was only twenty-six, while Empress Cao had been installed for little over a year. Why then adopt another’s son to raise in the palace? This is why, a hundred generations later, the emperor is praised as benevolent and the empress as virtuous. Of all the most just and magnanimous acts of antiquity, none surpasses the matter of succession. Even among commoners with modest wealth, men cling to hope and hesitate to openly raise a brother’s son if forced to do so. How much more so for the vastness of the realm, the weight of ancestral legacy, the trust of the divine mandate, and the destiny of dynastic succession? Had the emperor’s heart not been purely attuned to the impartiality of great principle, free of even a trace of selfish desire, who could have acted without entanglement?

If later sovereigns follow the example of Renzong and Empress Cao—though their heirs may not be of their own blood—posterity will still hail them as sagely, as founders of a lasting line, their descendants enduring unbroken. But if even a hint of selfishness intrudes, if they do not regard the realm as belonging to all but instead conceal the truth of succession, then in a moment of crisis, they may fail to act with the same luminous righteousness as Renzong of the Song.

**Or one might ask:** If the emperor was so benevolent, why did he have no heir of his own? The answer lies in the *Book of Changes*: “He washes his hands but does not present the offering—yet his countenance is bright and clear.” One who purifies heart and mind to govern the realm may not see immediate signs of response, yet all under heaven and for all time will revere his virtue. What harm, then, in whether the offering is made or not?

Thus, the noble man may strive to perpetuate good deeds, but cannot ensure his descendants will continue them; he may devote himself to cultivating virtue that endures, but cannot guarantee his legacy will persist. What lies within human power is possible; what does not is the domain of Heaven. That which is done without being done—that is Heaven. That which arrives without being summoned—that is fate. Such is the meaning here.

In the first year of Jianyan (1127), on the gengyin day of the fifth month, Prince Kang ascended the throne as emperor. Earlier, Empress Dowager Yuanxiao had sent a handwritten decree to announce the news throughout the realm. Its gist was this: For two hundred years, the people knew no war; through nine reigns, no ruler lacked virtue. Though the imperial clan faced the calamity of the Jingkang era, the hearts of all under heaven turned in loyalty. Thus, Heaven favored a worthy prince to restore the old order—just as the Han, after ten generations of hardship, saw Guangwu’s revival, and of Duke Xian’s nine sons, only Chong’er remained. This is the will of Heaven, not the design of man.

Zong Ze advised that Nanjing was the founding ground of Emperor Taizu and urged the emperor to proceed there. The decision was made to go to Yingtian Prefecture, where an altar was erected to the left of the prefectural gate. The prince ascended the altar to receive the mandate. On that day, Empress Dowager Yuanxiao withdrew the palace screen in the Eastern Capital.

**Recorded:** Emperors Yuan of Jin, Suzong of Tang, and Gaozong of Song all established themselves as rulers. Yet the decree of Empress Dowager Yuanxiao was clear and unequivocal—Heaven thus granted an aged remnant to the dynasty. Compared to the two captured emperors, this was far more blameless in terms of benevolent succession.

At that time, the Three Bonds were overturned, the Two Modes nearly extinguished. Not only was the great enterprise of one founder and eight ancestors lost, but the very legitimacy of the Central Kingdom since ancient times hung by a thread. Hu Mingsheng’s memorial was, in my view, excessive.

Emperor Xiaozong was the seventh-generation descendant of Emperor Taizu. Prince De of Qin begot Duke Ying of Guo, Weixian; Weixian begot Marquis Xinxing, Congyu; Congyu begot Marquis Huayin, Shijiang; Shijiang begot Duke Qing of Guo, Linggui; Linggui begot Zhuan, Prince Xiu. His consort, Lady Zhang, gave birth to the emperor in the fourth year of Jianyan (1127), on the wuyin day of the tenth month, at the official residence in Qingshanfan, Xiuzhou.

When Crown Prince Yuanyi passed away and Emperor Gaozong had no heir, Empress Dowager Zhaoci Shengxian, returning from Jiangxi, privately advised him. The Right Chief Councilor Fan Zongyin knelt to plead, and Lou Renliang, Vice Censor-in-Chief, submitted a memorial urging the matter.

Emperor Gaozong, greatly enlightened, declared: "Taizu established the realm through divine martial prowess, yet his descendants could not inherit it. Buffeted by tumultuous times, they have scattered in pitiful decline. If We do not follow the example of Emperor Renzong for the sake of the realm, how shall We console the spirits in heaven?" Thereupon, he issued an edict to select from Taizu’s descendants. In the fifth month of the second year of Shaoxing (1132), the chosen heir was raised within the palace. Thirty-two years later, he was established as Crown Prince, and on the *yihai* day ascended the imperial throne as Emperor Xiaozong.

Emperor Lizong was likewise a tenth-generation descendant of Taizu. His father, Xi Lu, was posthumously enfeoffed as Prince Rong; his mother, Lady Quan, gave birth to him on the *guihai* day of the first month of the first year of Kaixi (1205) at the Hongqiao residence in Shaoxing. In the thirteenth year of Jiading under Emperor Ningzong, when Crown Prince Jingxian passed away without issue, Taizu’s grandsons aged fifteen and above were selected for education, following the precedent of Gaozong’s choice of the Princes of Pu’an and Enping. Alongside Prince Ji, they were raised within the palace. The emperor was of solemn and reticent disposition, pure and studious by nature. Each morning at court, while others chattered and laughed as they awaited the dawn audience, he alone remained dignified, earning reverence from all who beheld him. As Prince Ji had clashed with the Chancellor Shi Miyuan, the latter turned his favor toward the emperor. On the *bingxu* day of the eighth month in the seventeenth year (1224), as Ningzong’s health declined, he was named Crown Prince. The next day, the *dingyou*, he succeeded to the imperial throne as Emperor Lizong.

A record observes: Examining the affairs of the Southern Song, one cannot but marvel at the workings of Heaven’s will. Since Gaozong’s enthronement, he forgot the enmity of his father and elder brother—who did not resent this, who did not grieve? Yet unbeknownst to all, Heaven’s design was already in motion, as though purging for Taizu’s sake. Consider this: Emperor Huizong had thirty-one sons, yet in an instant, all perished. Could Heaven have acted without purpose? Had the two emperors returned from the northern deserts, Huizong would not yet have aged, Qinzong would have been in his prime, and their progeny would have been boundless. Even if Gaozong and Ningzong had left no heirs, how could Xiaozong and Lizong have risen? In the end, the throne passed through six emperors for a hundred and fifty years, rivaling the Northern Song in duration. Herein lies the proof of Heaven’s just retribution. Some, failing to grasp these principles, absurdly claim oblivion or even proclaim the reincarnation of Taizu. Alas!

Alas, how could such claims be believed? Alas, how could they be believed?

Cao Wei-Hui Wang’s father, Yun, gave birth to Bin. In his infancy, Yun arrayed a hundred playthings before the child to observe his choices. Bin seized a halberd in his left hand and ritual vessels in his right, then swiftly took up a seal, paying no heed to the rest. Those present marveled at this.

In adulthood, he became a great general and led the campaign against Jiangnan. With each delay of the army, he hoped Li Yu would submit, sending envoys to advise him: “The situation being as it is, what is truly to be cherished is the city’s people. If you surrender, it will be the wisest course.”

As the city neared capture, Bin suddenly claimed illness and ceased attending to affairs. All the generals came to inquire after him. Bin said: “My illness cannot be cured by medicine or stone needles. Only if you gentlemen sincerely swear that on the day the city falls, not a single life will be taken without cause, will I recover.” The generals agreed and together burned incense to take the oath.

Thereupon, the Lord of Tang led his ministers to surrender. Bin consoled and reassured them, treating them with the rites due to guests. From the army’s departure to its triumphant return, not a single person was killed, and Jiangnan was thus preserved intact.

Bin had seven sons. Can and Zhang became renowned generals. Li married the daughter of Prince Qin, Princess Juping. Fa rose to the rank of *Zhaoxuan* Envoy. Yi served as Vice Director of the Bureau of Sacrifices. Xun became *Shu Shangge Men* Envoy. Zong was appointed Vice *Xishang He Men* Envoy and concurrently Military Commissioner of Zhenhai. Yi’s daughter became Empress Cisheng Guangxian.

Later, Yun was posthumously enfeoffed as Prince Wei, Bin as Prince Han, and Yi as Prince Wu. All their descendants rose to prominence, none falling short.

The record states: The *Mu Shi* speaks of “six generations, seven generations”—this is the sage’s use of force. The *Tai Shi* speaks of “one virtue, one heart”—this is the sage’s foundation for meritorious achievement. Warfare is not to be resorted to lightly. If matters can be resolved without harm, yet one still inflicts suffering upon the people to satisfy one’s ambitions, this not only defies the Dao of Heaven but invites retribution in human affairs. Witness the fates of Qin and Xiang in ancient times, or Han and Quan in more recent days.

Men are not ghosts—retribution comes swiftly, cutting off descendants and leaving no posterity. How then could their fathers, grandfathers, children, and grandchildren enjoy full prosperity across the entire clan? Moreover, Jiangnan was not guilty; it was merely that "beside one’s own sleeping mat, another’s snoring could not be tolerated"—such an approach was hardly that of a righteous army. Had it not been for a resolve to refrain from killing, one would still be treading the path of demons, following in their nightmares.

Bin’s aspirations were lofty and far-reaching, not merely calculating future outcomes before acting. Minister Wang Wenzheng—his father, Ku, having served as Minister of War and Vice Minister of the Board of War—rose to prominence through his literary achievements during the Han and Zhou dynasties. Entering the Song, he served Emperors Taizu and Taizong as a distinguished minister. He once advised Du Chongwei against rebelling against the Han, thwarted Lu Duoxun’s scheme to harm Zhao Pu, and vouched with his entire family for Fu Yanjing’s innocence. The world often praised his hidden virtue. You planted three pagoda trees in his courtyard, declaring, "My descendants will surely hold the rank of the Three Dukes." This was the aspiration that guided him.

His youngest son, Yi, was quiet, studious, and gifted in literature. You esteemed him, saying, "This child will rise to the position of chief minister." Initially, You, renowned for his long tenure in drafting imperial decrees, remarked that Yi would succeed him within a decade—a sentiment widely admired. Qian Ruoshui, known for his discernment of character, saw Dan and said, "He is truly a prime minister in the making." When serving alongside him, he often remarked, "Master Wang soars above the clouds and stands tall among the peaks—a pillar of the state, his nobility boundless, beyond my reach." Li Hang, a contemporary, also revered him as a man of great promise. The Emperor, who held Dan in high regard, declared, "The one who will bring great peace to my reign is surely this man."

The record states: Observing the obscure teachings of Minister Sima, one understands what is meant by hidden virtue. The principles of Heaven are luminous. Only when one internalizes them, embodies them, and perceives them as invisible and inaudible—this is what is called obscurity. Yet how could such virtue be accumulated in a single day? Speaking of it now: the capacity for magnanimity—without it, one becomes impatient, narrow, and constrained. Would I willingly endure even a moment of such a state? Thus, magnanimity can accumulate hidden virtue. The virtue of benevolence—without it, one becomes cruel, envious, and harsh. Would I willingly depart from it even for an instant? Thus, benevolence can accumulate hidden virtue. The impartiality of a public-minded heart—without it, one becomes biased, selfish, and crooked. Would I willingly stray from it even for a breath? Thus, impartiality can accumulate hidden virtue. The principle of forbearance—without it, one becomes nitpicking and fault-finding. Would I willingly harbor even a single such thought? Thus, forbearance can accumulate hidden virtue. This is not the same as the Buddhists’ empty obscurity and extinction.

Fan Wenzheng had four sons: Chunyou, Chunren, Chunli, and Chunzui. Chunyou was filial to his parents, never leaving their side. Though he did not pursue the imperial examinations, he was appointed Acting Director of the Bureau of Palace Construction through hereditary privilege. Finding the post unsuited to his interests, he resigned and followed his father to Deng. Chunren passed the imperial examinations but, due to his parents’ distant location, did not take office, saying, "How could I value official salary over being near my parents?" After Zhongyan’s death, he began his official career, once remarking, "All my life, I have learned but two words—loyalty and forbearance—and they have never been exhausted." In his governance, dealings with colleagues, and care for his clan, he never strayed from these principles for even a moment. He often admonished his descendants: "Even the dullest person is clear when criticizing others, while even the wise become muddled when judging themselves. If one could use the rigor applied to others to examine oneself, and the forbearance applied to oneself to treat others, one would have no fear of failing to reach the realm of the sages." He also said, "The Six Classics are the deeds of the sages. To know a single word is to practice it. One must uphold this even in haste or adversity—this is what it means to be a person of action."

Zhongyan once remarked of his sons: Chunren embodied his loyalty, Chunli his tranquility, and Chunzui his breadth. Who knows a child better than their father?

The record states: The saying goes, "The benevolent have descendants"—how could one abandon this? Wenzheng began as a solitary orphan, a poor scholar of unyielding integrity. Yet in later years, he became a general and minister, and his sons all achieved renown. Had this not been the guiding principle of his heart, how could it have differed so greatly from others? To set aside personal joy and sorrow is the nature of one man. To rejoice with the world and grieve with the world—even kings must do this, let alone their ministers. Loyalty and forbearance are the essence of self-cultivation. To extend one’s heart to all things without conflict—even sages must do this, let alone scholars. This is why some of his sons inherited his loyalty, others his tranquility, and others his breadth. Alas! Observing what they inherited reveals that their achievements were no accident.

Minister Han Zhongxian had eight sons: Gang, Zong, Feng, Yi, Wei, Zhen, Wei, and Mian. Feng, Wei, and Zhen all held high office, each excelling in different virtues—Feng in harmony, Wei in uprightness, and Zhen in strictness. Yi was steadfast and solemn in character, governing his household with strict discipline. Even in leisure, he never appeared idle. Whenever he saw memorials from the circuits criticizing minor faults of officials, his expression would darken, and he would say, "In this era of great peace, the Sage Emperor’s heart desires that even insects and plants find their proper place. Those in office aspire to be high ministers, or at least attendants or officials in the capital or provinces. How could we confine them in such a flourishing age?"

When Wei served as Vice Director of the Chancellery, the censor Zhang Shunmin was dismissed for speaking out. Wang Yansou defended him, and Wei secretly sent a letter to the emperor, explaining that officials exchanging letters to encourage one another in good conduct was a collective effort for virtue, posing no harm to governance. To nitpick such matters would be of no benefit to state affairs. Thus, the matter was dropped.

The Record states: Observing the words of Han Zhongxian, though separated by eras, they align with the same path as Yuan Shaogong. How could a noble person disregard them? Yet if one does not serve as a censor or hold the responsibility of selecting officials, one may decline such duties. If, however, one assumes such a role and can hold these principles in heart, it would not only invigorate the nation’s vital *qi* but also augment one’s own blessings and posterity—how admirable this would be.

It is said: In one’s own heart, to seek faults where none exist, to find affairs where none occur, to discern intentions where none are present—this is not the result of deep reflection. It is said: Feng Tong, Wei Zheng, Shen Zhen, and Yi Fang—even a single father’s several sons cannot be entirely alike, let alone the vastness of the Four Seas. If one does not merely select the easy path like a mother hen but manifests virtue in the world, one may stand without shame.

Master Xu of Jiexiao, renowned for filial piety, was born with innate devotion. At three, his father died, and each dawn he sought him with profound sorrow. Upon reading the *Classic of Filial Piety*, his tears would not cease. He served his mother with utmost devotion, dressing formally morning and night to pay respects. When he journeyed to the capital for examinations, he could not bear to leave his parents. As his father’s name contained the character for "stone," he avoided all stone vessels throughout his life; when he encountered stones while walking, he would stop in grief, unable to step upon them.

When his mother passed, he refused all food and drink for seven days, weeping until he vomited blood. He built a hut by her grave and mourned for three years, sleeping on rough straw and resting his head on clods of earth, never removing his mourning garments. On snowy nights, he would prostrate himself by the grave, his sobs unceasing. When Academician Lü Feng passed by his hut and heard his lament, he too was moved to tears. Sweet dew descended upon the burial site, and two branches of a cypress miraculously intertwined.

After the mourning period, he did not replace the mourning mats or furnishings, continuing his daily routines as before. The prefecture reported his conduct, and the court bestowed grain and silk upon him. In the early Yuanyou era, high officials jointly memorialized: "He is famed for filial devotion in serving his parents, integrity in his village, and virtue and learning renowned in the east." Thus, he was appointed Professor of Chuzhou. He instructed his students: "If you wish to be noble persons yet must exert your strength and spend your wealth, and still do not act, this may be excusable. But if it costs neither your strength nor your wealth, why not be noble? If your village despises you and your parents disdain you, and you still do not act, this may be excusable. But if your village honors you and your parents desire it, why not be noble?"

He further said: "Speak of what is good, act upon what is good, contemplate what is good—those who do so yet fail to become noble persons have never existed. Speak of what is not good, act upon what is not good, contemplate what is not good—those who do so yet fail to become petty persons have never existed." Those who heard him listened with reverence and respect.

The Record states: Observing the flourishing and accumulating prosperity of the Sacred Song Dynasty, one understands the origin of such filial devotion. While one person’s filial piety may arise from innate nature, it may not extend to the entire world. Only when all strive to do good can the generations beneath one’s knees rely upon it. Extending this to the world, how could there fail to be noble conduct among all? The accumulation of such intent reaches its height here.

As for lifelong avoidance of stone vessels and never removing mourning garments, these are acts one can achieve through effort. Yue Fei’s filial nature was innate. When his mother, née Yao, was giving birth, a great bird circled and cried above the house, so he was named accordingly. Before he was a month old, the Yellow River breached its banks, and the waters of Neihuang surged violently. His mother held him in a jar, and the waves carried them to shore, where they were saved—people marveled at this.

As he grew, he bore a resolute spirit, was steadfast and reticent, studied diligently despite poverty, and particularly favored the *Zuoshi Spring and Autumn Annals* and *Sun and Wu’s Art of War*. When the northern frontier fell into chaos, his mother urged him to join the army and repay the nation. He could not bear to leave, but she repeatedly pressed him, so he reluctantly left his wife to care for her and followed Emperor Gaozong across the river alone.

When Hebei fell, all communication was severed. He sought news of his mother day and night for years without success. Then, someone arrived from his mother’s village and relayed her message: "Tell Fifth Son to serve the Sacred Son of Heaven diligently and not worry about this old woman." He secretly sent someone to fetch her, but bandits obstructed the way. After eighteen attempts, she finally returned.

Later, she suffered from a hernia. Though he was occupied with royal duties, he would steal moments at dawn and dusk to visit, personally tasting her medicine, feeding her, and discussing its effects. His footsteps were silent as he moved about. Before each military campaign, he strictly instructed his family to attend to her carefully.

When she died, he refused all food and drink for three days, nearly wasting away. He and his son Yun carried her coffin to the grave. After the burial, he built a hut by the grave, carved a wooden likeness of her, and performed the rituals of warmth, cleansing, morning, and evening greetings as if she were alive.

He had five sons: Yun, Lei, Lin, Zhen, and Ting. Yun enlisted at twelve and performed many extraordinary feats in battle; the army called him "The Frail Official." He died at twenty-three. His daughter, not yet married, grieved over her father and brother’s wrongful deaths and drowned herself in a well with a silver vase.

When Emperor Xiaozong ascended the throne, Yue Fei’s original rank was posthumously restored, and his family—father, sons, and daughter—were honored accordingly.

The Record states: How could Yue Fei’s entire family be deemed insignificant? Zixia said: "In serving parents, one should exhaust one’s strength; in serving the ruler, one should dedicate one’s life." Yue Fei did not merely study or discuss these words—he embodied and practiced them. Though one might call him unlearned, I would still call him a scholar. Is this not truly the case?

Yet Yue Fei could have sons like Yun, who, though adopted and lacking the guidance of a strict teacher or worthy father, and a daughter who was young and unlearned, knew the beauty of sacrificing oneself to fulfill righteousness. It is said: "When one’s own conduct is upright, one’s orders are followed without command." In the father, brothers, and children of the Yue family, I have witnessed this.

In the late Xianchun era, Xu Yingbiao was admitted as a National University student after passing the examination. In the second year of Deyou, when the Song fell, Emperor Ying of Ying followed the Yuan to Yan, and the three students all accompanied him.

Xu Yingbiao refused to follow and instead swore with his son Qi Song and daughter Yuan Niang to die together in fire, and both children gladly complied. There stood an old shrine to Yue Fei’s younger brother within the National University, where Yingbiao prepared wine and meat to offer in sacrifice. He prayed to Fei, saying: “Heaven has not protected the Song, and the altars of the state lie in ruins. Yingbiao will die to repay the nation, vowing never to journey north with the other students. Though death may burden Your Majesty with my soul, I shall serve as an attendant to Your spirit, forever and without end.”

Qi likewise composed a poem to pledge his resolve. After the rites, Yingbiao shared the sacrificial wine and meat with his servants, allowing them to drink until drunk. Then, with his son and daughter, he entered the Tiyun Tower, piling books, chests, and baskets from the rooms all around. They set the fire and perished together.

One servant, still awake, heard the flames and rushed to the tower. Peering through a window, he saw the father and children seated and standing in solemn stillness, like statues in a temple. He ran to alert the other servants, who broke through the wall and extinguished the fire. Yingbiao, however, could not die, and with his children, he departed in dejection, their whereabouts unknown by night’s end.

The next day, their bodies were found in a well before the shrine—all stiff and upright, eyes wide, faces as though still living. The servants prepared coffins and laid them to rest. When King Yi ascended, he honored Yingbiao’s integrity, posthumously appointing him Gentleman for Court Service and Compiler of the Secret Pavilion.

Later, his fellow student Liu Wenjun gathered their remains and buried them at Fangjiayu, privately conferring the posthumous title *Master of Unyielding Integrity*.

**Record states:** Since the virtue of the Song had unraveled, the spirit of its scholars had been tarnished and withered. Those who passed through this era were wounded by its urgency—men like Chen Shu and Ouyang Che, who clamored without rest...

Those who fell short sank into ignominy and baseness—like the three Taixue students, their spirits dimmed and conscience troubled. How could one have expected the father and son, the venerable Ying, to emerge from their midst?

To lay down one’s life for humanity is the noble virtue of the gentleman. Yet even with Yingbiao’s cultivated bearing, and with Qi and Song’s long-standing renown, they still claimed that the crisis did not concern them, that their high station excused them. What, then, of his daughter Yuan-niang? In nature, she was frail, lacking any bold and generous resolve; in years, she was young, without the steadfast integrity of frost-enduring pines. Yet when the nation fell and the sovereign perished, she willingly chose to die alongside them—proof that the goodness of inborn endowment cannot be dismissed on account of youth or weakness. How could the traitors of that time, those who sold the country and surrendered to the barbarians, face themselves without spitting in shame?

Moreover, Yingbiao’s death was reported to Yue Fei, whose spirit had long resonated with his. Would not such a household of loyalty and filial piety stir his heart and rouse his resolve? The example of Yue’s daughter would not have been in vain.

Alas! This may truly be called *ren*.

From the *History of Yuan*: Shi Tianze had eight sons—Ge, Zhang, Di, Gang, Qi, Zi, Kai, and Bin—all of whom held prominent offices. At forty, Tianze began to humble himself and devote himself to study. In private, he never boasted, yet when facing matters of great consequence or deliberating weighty affairs, he resolutely took the burdens of the realm upon himself, his judgments surpassing others’ expectations. On the day he was appointed chancellor, his household remained quiet and unassuming. Someone urged him to wield power to assert himself, but he replied: “Rank, emolument, punishment, and reward are the prerogatives of the Son of Heaven. What need have I for power?” Thereupon he declined, and the speaker, ashamed, withdrew. When renowned scholars and displaced literati of the fallen Jin dynasty found themselves without refuge, he provided for their livelihoods and treated them with the courtesy due guests, and many later rose to prominence. After capturing Guide, he spared Li Dalang and sent him to Zhen ding, appointing him as an advisor. For over fifty years, he served as both general and minister, trusted by the throne and unopposed by his subordinates. People compared him to Guo Ziyi and Cao Wuhui.

**Recorded Remarks:** Observing the Yuan dynasty’s rise from near-collapse to reclaim China, one sees how Tianze and his brothers and sons, though they held the highest military and civil ranks, regarded wealth, honor, and power with restraint, as if they were but fleeting shadows. And when he neared his end, he foretold the devastation of slaughter and plunder, yet ultimately secured the submission of Jiangnan—so that Bayan cannot alone claim the glory. This is worth recording.

From the *Book of the Five Relations*: When Yuan Yingzong was still Crown Prince, Emperor Renzong fell ill, and Yingzong’s distress was evident in his countenance. At night, he burned incense and wept, saying: “The Supreme One rules the realm with benevolence, and all affairs prosper in harmony; the Four Seas are at peace. Now Heaven sends this great affliction—let the punishment fall upon me instead, that the Supreme One may forever remain the sovereign of the people.” When Renzong passed, Yingzong mourned beyond the rites of a single day, wearing plain garments and prostrating himself upon the ground. He ate but a single bowl of porridge. Upon ascending the throne, he issued an edict to the Court of Imperial Sacrifices: “I shall personally offer sacrifices at the Grand Temple in each of the four seasons. Let the rites be deliberated and conducted in full accordance with the classics, without any reduction on account of my toil in reverence before the ancestral spirits.” **Recorded Remarks:** The histories praise Emperor Renzong as a ruler of innate benevolence and filial piety, intelligence, reverence, frugality, and mastery of Confucian learning. He cherished and nurtured the people’s strength, governing with tireless diligence, and was the guardian of the Yuan’s golden age of virtuous rule. Succeeded by Yingzong, whose filial devotion was profound and sincere, these two sovereigns alone stand out in the final years of the Yuan.

From the *Record of Illustrious Ministers of the August Ming*: Zhang Yi was of the utmost filial nature. In his youth, he followed local scholars and, hearing that Jinhua was a land of literary heritage, traveled there to seek instruction in its traditions. Arriving in Wulin, he suddenly felt a pang of dread and hurried home, only to find his father’s illness had reached its crisis. Eight days later, his father passed. People attributed this to the power of his filial devotion. Before the funeral rites could be held, bandits rose in the village, and his home was burned to the ground.

Zhang Yi struck his forehead and cried out to Heaven; the fire reached the coffin’s resting place and then extinguished. Later, in mourning his mother, his grief was so overwhelming that when he personally carried earth and stone to prepare her grave, his illness worsened. His relative He Jun came to visit and said, “You must restrain this heart of yours and not cling so stubbornly.” Zhang Yi replied, “I understand.”

Having long lived apart from his two elder brothers, he built a new residence at Longge and invited them to live together, their harmonious affection as warm as ever. At that time, with the realm in chaos, he withdrew to take refuge in Min. The Taizu Emperor dispatched envoys to summon Zhang Yi, Liu Ji, Ye Shen, and Song Lian to Jianye for an audience. Upon meeting them, he declared, “I have humbled myself before the four masters for the sake of the realm.”

The *Record* states: Wei Wuzhi, with the conduct of Weisheng and Xiaoji, could not alter the course of victory or defeat—was this not so? Zhang Yi, with his capacity for both prominence and obscurity, embodied the learning of cultivating the heart and nurturing the self. Observe how his filial devotion stirred such alarm, how his grief for his mother seemed as though it would last a lifetime. Yet when he later assisted the illustrious founder, his achievements became manifest—securing Min’s submission, devising strategies for land reclamation and troop deployment—all proving effective. Truly, he was one in whom inner essence and outward function were complete, whether in prominence or obscurity. How could this be the work of one dull and inept? From this, one may glimpse the principles by which the Ming and Han employed men.

Chen Xianzhang lost his father early, and his mother, née Cai, served him with the utmost care, making it difficult for him to leave her side. Though he once sat for the Ministry of Rites examination, he did not proceed further. Later, despite repeated summons, he declined them all. When pressed to come to the capital, he submitted a memorial, which read in part: “My mother, widowed in poverty and lowly circumstances, has lived without comfort, her deep sorrows turning to illness, which has grown worse with age. If I were to travel far to a foreign land, her anxiety for me would only intensify. The more she worries, the sicker she becomes; the sicker she becomes, the more she worries—this cycle of distress cannot endure long. With my ailing body and my mother’s advanced age, though my years are not yet spent, my qi has already weakened. My heart desires to serve, but my strength is insufficient. If one’s inner heart is not afflicted, then external duties present no difficulty. With a sovereign of utmost benevolence above, there will be many officials below who accommodate and fulfill.”

The memorial was submitted, and Emperor Xianzong personally read it again and again. The next day, he specially appointed the author as Hanlin Academy Examining Editor and permitted him to return home to care for his parent.

A record states: This memorial shines even brighter than *Chen Qing Biao*. Truly, "with a sovereign of utmost benevolence above, there will be many officials below who accommodate and fulfill." The sagely court’s governance through filial piety is not to be compared with Lingbo’s time, when transformation was possible. Yet in the end, his deep devotion to nurturing his family at home won the admiration of all under heaven—how does this compare to serving as Prefect of Wen or laboring in office while ill? The imperial decree was forcefully issued, exempting him from departmental examinations, unlike those who rely on connections or circumstances. "When the court lacks men of integrity, it is better to return to the fields." Thus, it is recorded.

When Chen Maolie served as censor, he impeached Minister of Works Chang and Vice Minister Cui. Later, due to his mother’s advanced age, he submitted a request to resign and care for her. The Ministry of Personnel, considering his family’s poverty, followed the precedent of Vice Minister Pan Li and memorialized to grant him three *shi* of rice monthly to support his filial devotion. Chen firmly declined in a memorial, which read in part: "Your Majesty has descended the transformative influence of filial governance and fostered the wind of integrity. Even a lowly official like myself has received your compassion—how could this be the fortune of my family alone? Yet I recall that my family has long been poor, our meals simple and frugal. Thus, my mother and I have grown accustomed to my meager support, and I, too, have learned to endure our poverty. This is not because I possess extraordinary integrity or surpassing filial devotion. The ancients carried firewood and shouldered rice, but I have not even reached such a state. My mother raised me in poverty and widowhood, enduring hardships a hundredfold. Though I exhaust my strength in caring for her, I have not repaid even a drop of her boundless kindness. Now she is eighty-six, and the days ahead may not be many. My private desire to fulfill the duty of returning nurture compels me to devote all my resources to her care. Yet I secretly feel uneasy about accepting the monthly stipend. The court governs the realm through filial piety." The imperial edict declared: "Chen Maolie’s frugality and integrity are admirable; his request to decline is not permitted."

After his mother’s death, Chen wailed and collapsed to the ground, never recovering. To this day, his village is marked with a stele inscribed: "Filial and Incorrupt." A record states: *The History of the Song* praises Master Xu of Jiexiao as steadfast in virtue. Was Chen Maolie’s conduct not the same? He practiced frugality and self-cultivation at home, composed his thoughts in stillness among friends, and was known for his uprightness at court. Yet his profound devotion to nurturing his mother and his pure, hidden virtue—why was he left without descendants? I once passed by his gate and thus recorded his story in this way.

Geng Qinghui, Duke of Integrity, whose courtesy name was Jiuzhou, and his son, Geng Wenke, Duke of Erudition, whose courtesy name was Yu, served four reigns—Xuan, Ying, Xian, and Xiao. Qinghui rose to Minister of Justice in Nanjing, his incorruptible virtue and weighty reputation renowned throughout the realm. Though he held high office, he never abandoned his Confucian principles. Wenke later served as Minister of Personnel, known as "Qingya," and was appointed as a historiographer, Libationer, and Minister of Rites. The family maintained its purity and integrity, standing at the forefront of the Confucian tradition. Censor Wang Xuan memorialized that his heart was open and unobstructed, utterly free of self-interest, comparing him to Wang Zhongsu and Wang Duanyi.

Zhou Zhuangyi, Duke of Virtue, whose courtesy name was Yi, and his son, Zhou Wenrui, Duke of Culture, whose courtesy name was Jing, were both renowned ministers.

Duke of Virtue Zhuangyi rose to Minister of Justice in Nanjing. His nature was magnanimous, his bearing refined and graceful. Throughout his life, he served his superiors with particular reverence and prudence. For nearly forty years, he moved between the judicial offices of the two capitals, never inflicting harm upon others or damaging any living thing. His achievements in overseeing relief distributions, managing granaries, and sustaining the people’s welfare were especially great. He ascended to the Eight Seats of honor and lived nearly to eighty.

His descendants held offices of purity and importance. Duke of Culture Wenduan passed the imperial examinations and spent nearly thirty years in the Hanlin Academy and the Spring Pavilion. When the Filial Emperor was still Crown Prince, the Duke served as his tutor, offering many enlightening insights. He frequently lectured on the *Great Instructions of Wenhua*. Each time, the Filial Emperor would rise and listen with hands clasped in respect—such was his observance of ritual propriety.

Later, as Vice Minister of Rites, whenever he discussed governance, he invariably cited the classics. If the court undertook matters of great virtue, he would vigorously support them. Transferred to the Ministry of Personnel, he urged early court assemblies and diligent governance. Appointed Minister of Revenue, he took personal responsibility for affairs, undeterred by considerations of profit or harm. He carefully selected subordinates, personally overseeing granary management, cutting through complexity, and responding to crises without delay. In administering governance and upholding the law, he remained unyielding to the influence of imperial in-laws or powerful factions, embodying the spirit of the ancient great ministers.

Minister Xu Xiangyi advanced through the ranks. His eight sons received imperial edicts, encomiums, records, poems, lyrics, discourses, and epitaphs. By nature, he was filial and prudent. Once, when chastised by his father’s instruction, he was struck until his fingers bled; thereafter, whenever he showed the scars to others, he would be overcome with emotion. When the northern tribes invaded the western frontier, he was appointed Grand Coordinator and Governor of Gansu.

The Turpan held an age-old grudge against Hami, dispatching their tribal chieftains to drive out its king and occupy its city. Minister Xu, together with Commander-in-Chief Liu Ning, mobilized the Chijin, Han, and Shushu tribes as reinforcements. On a snowy night, they breached the city and crushed the rebellion. Among the eight hundred who had joined the revolt, some proposed slaughtering them all, but Minister Xu refused. Commentators remarked: "Xu the Resolute granted life to eight hundred doomed souls—truly a man of benevolence. That his descendants prosper is only fitting." Later, his son Xu Gao again served as Minister of Revenue, assisting the Ministers of Personnel, Revenue, and Justice. As Grand Secretary of the Hall of Martial Valor, he was appointed Censor-in-Chief and Governor of Shuntian, a legacy that endures to this day.

Minister Lin Wen’an, posthumously honored as Duke Wen’an, had nine sons: Lin Tinggui, Tingyang, Tingkai, Tingshuo, Tingzhang, Tingtou, Tingban, Tingzhi, and Tingji. As Director of the Directorate of Education, he governed with strictness yet kindness, petitioning to expand the imperial examinations and tribute system to cultivate talent without stifling potential. During the Zhengde era, he memorialized the throne on four matters: securing Nanjing to uphold the ancestral foundation, nurturing the heir apparent to safeguard the realm’s root, pacifying the people to strengthen the state’s foundation, and fostering worthy talent to ensure effective governance. Later promoted to Minister of War in Nanjing and Advisor to Military Affairs, he again submitted twelve proposals in response to natural disasters, broadly urging: "Your Majesty, entrusted with the weighty legacy of your predecessor, must rely on great ministers as the late emperor did, uphold established policies without altering his designs, dismiss sycophants near and far to emulate his devotion to worthy counsel, reject favoritism toward imperial relatives to fulfill his commitment to impartiality, fortify border defenses as he never forgot the threat of barbarians, and practice frugality as he never forgot the people’s welfare." Scholars praised his governance, with Yao Jing comparing him to Han Qi and Fan Zhongyan in the flourishing era of the Xiaozong Emperor. His family was harmonious, his descendants upright and prudent, evoking the legacy of the Wanshi Clan. In his hometown, his influence swayed the entire province, akin to Yang Cheng and Jin Bi’s transformative impact. With hoary brows and silver hair, he was revered by his community, much like Fu Bi of the Luoshe, the esteemed Duke Wenyi. Later, his son Lin Tingzhi served as Minister of Works and Grand Guardian of the Heir Apparent, Tingshuo as Prefect, and Tingji as Hanlin Academy Examining Editor. Their descendants, including Tingji’s son Lin Xuan and Lin Lian, continued the family’s distinguished legacy.

This record observes: The Lü and Yuan clans of Taiyuan and Lingbao produced eminent ministers for their age, yet the virtue of Quanshan and Yuande is not to be overlooked. Witnessing the bond between these fathers and sons, one sees no small measure of such excellence. Thus, the noble man is ever encouraged to pursue goodness. So it is recorded.

*The Great Compendium of Ming Ethics*: In the sixteenth year of the Zhengde reign, on the *renwu* day of the fourth month, the Emperor bade farewell at the newly completed tomb of Xingxian Wang. Overcome with grief, he prostrated himself weeping upon the ground; attendants raised him to his feet, yet he lingered, circling and gazing back, unwilling to depart. Twice he bowed, weeping bitterly. None among his retinue remained unmoved.

On the *guiwei* day, the imperial procession departed from Anlu. The Emperor could not bear to leave his Sacred Mother so soon and wept with stifled sobs. The Sacred Mother said: "My son, this journey bears a weighty duty—guard your words well." The Emperor replied: "I humbly receive your instruction."

This record observes: The beginning takes the filial piety of the Great Shun to illuminate the transmission of the abdicated succession, marking the wellspring of all virtues. The end takes the Emperor’s grief and longing to fulfill the trust of a true king and serve as a model for the realm below. As the *Book of Songs* says: *"Ever mindful of filial devotion."* When filial devotion is the guiding thought, how could the sages of old and those of later times not share the same thread and common principle?

*Hongdao Lu*, Scroll Six, concludes.
*Hongdao Lu*, Scroll Seven.

The Benevolence of Husband and Wife

Mencius said: "When Shun was Son of Heaven, he wore simple robes, played the zither, and enjoyed the company of his two wives as if they had always been his." This record observes: I see that the Great Shun, in his harmonious governance, carried such a demeanor. Yet some meddlesome contemporaries fabricated tales of "two sisters-in-law managing his dwelling," how perverse! Thus, rather than refuting such falsehoods, it would be better if they had never been written at all.

It further says: The *Book of Songs* states:
*"When zither and lute are played in harmony,
None fail to find peace and goodness."*
This is not only true for the Son of Heaven—even the humblest husband and wife, within their inner chambers, are no different.

In the Han dynasty, there were also "chamber lyrics and music," composed by Emperor Gaozu’s consort, Lady Tangshan. Later, Emperor Wu appointed Li Yannian as Master of Harmonizing Pitch, yet the likes of Lady Li were worlds apart from the ancients—how could they not fall short of antiquity?

It further says: Long ago, King Tai loved beauty and cherished his consort. The *Book of Songs* says:
*"Lord Gu Gong,
Came at dawn, riding swiftly,
Following the western waters’ flow,
To the foot of Mount Qi.
There with his lady Jiang,
They came to choose their home."*
At that time, within the kingdom, there were no resentful maidens, nor were there bachelors left unwed. If the king delighted in beauty, sharing such joy with his people, what harm could it bring to his rule?

This record observes: Should not Heaven’s delight in beauty be like this? From birth, men wish to have a wife, and women wish to have a husband—sages have never forbidden such desires. With no resentful maidens within and no unwed men without, beauty has never been a calamity to humankind. This is what is called *xing* (natural disposition), not *ji* (disease). Yet people, ignorant of this truth, often indulge in alluring beauty and seductive charm, leading to arrogance, dissipation, and excess. They see only its harm, not its virtue, turning Heaven’s natural disposition into a thicket of human desire—so much so that it topples states and ruins cities, bringing dire disaster. This was never the intent of the ancient kings’ delight in beauty.

*The Book of Songs.*

**The Great Brightness:**

To speak of King Wen’s sageliness, one must trace its origin: Zhong Ren of Zhi, from the distant Yin Shang, came to marry into Zhou, becoming a consort in its capital.

This record observes: The *Commentary* states, "When a state is about to rise, there are always auspicious omens; when a state is about to fall, there are always portents." Disasters appear in the heavens, and transformations arise on earth. Though omens may manifest, they are not yet true calamities. Only the portents of women are irredeemable. At that time, Yin’s rightful heir still held the throne, with no sign of peril or ruin—yet a single Daji was born. The interrogations could not but grow severe, the punishments could not but turn excessive. Yet Heaven established its counterpart: the Zhou consorts Tai Ren, Tai Si, and Yi Jiang, all gathered at one gate. Never had Heaven’s favor been so abundant. How then could Tai Wang, King Ji, King Wen, and King Wu dare act with presumption? They could only say: "The radiance is manifest below."

King Wen of Zhou was born with sagely virtue and was matched with the sagely lady of the Si clan. When she first arrived in the palace, those within saw her quiet, retiring, chaste, and serene virtue. They composed a poem:

*Guan guan cry the ospreys,*
*On the isle in the river.*
*Graceful and fair is the maiden,*
*A fit mate for the lord.*

*Long and short the water plants,*
*Left and right we gather them.*
*Graceful and fair is the maiden,*
*Waking and sleeping we seek her.*

*Seeking her yet not attaining,*
*Waking and sleeping we long for her.*
*Endlessly, endlessly,*
*Tossing and turning we lie.*

*Long and short the water plants,*
*Left and right we cull them.*
*Graceful and fair is the maiden,*
*With zither and lute we befriend her.*

*Long and short the water plants,*
*Left and right we bind them.*
*Graceful and fair is the maiden,*
*With bells and drums we delight her.*

Kuang Heng said: "The union of husband and wife is the beginning of the people, the source of all blessings. When the rites of marriage are correct, all things flourish and Heaven’s mandate is fulfilled." Confucius placed *Guan Ju* at the beginning of the *Book of Songs*, saying, "The highest are the parents of the people." If the conduct of the queen and consorts does not align with Heaven and Earth, they cannot serve the lineage of the spirits or govern the proper order of all things. Since high antiquity, the rise and fall of the Three Dynasties have never deviated from this principle.

This record observes: Confucius said, "*Guan Ju* is joyful yet not wanton, mournful yet not harmed." He also said, "From Shi Zhi’s beginning to *Guan Ju*’s conclusion, how abundant and full it sounds!" And again: "One who does not study the *Zhou Nan* and *Shao Nan* is like standing facing a wall." Why then does our Son of Heaven show such disdain for the *Guan Ju* poem? Truly, the Way of the sage and worthy is rooted in the near, and the governance of emperors and kings begins with the self. In perfect goodness and complete beauty, with inner and outer harmony fully realized, none have matched King Wen and Tai Si.

Thus, though Yao’s two daughters were sagely, had he married without proper announcement, even their tossing and turning in longing would have gone unseen. Though Yu of Tu Shan was virtuous, from *xin* to *jia*, he passed his own gate three times without entering—even had there been the joy of zither, lute, bells, and drums, how could it have been expressed, leading to the completion of his great work? When Emperor Cheng took Zhao Feiyan into the palace, those within, upon her arrival, called her "calamity’s waters," saying, "Fire will be extinguished again." Though there may have been deep sorrow and pressing concern, where could such feelings find expression? Kuang Heng’s words have their origins. Yet even our Master Confucius, the greatest of sages, harbored regret over his wife’s conduct. How deeply he must have been moved by Bo Yu! How deeply moved by Bo Yu!

The queen and consorts, free from jealousy and envy, brought joy to the many concubines, who praised their virtue, singing:

*In the south there is a bending tree,*
*Creepers coil all around it.*
*Joyful is our lord,*
*Fortune and blessing attend him.*

*In the south there is a bending tree,*
*Creepers spread all over it.*
*Joyful is our lord,*
*Fortune and blessing uphold him.*

*In the south there is a bending tree,*
*Creepers twine all about it.*
*Joyful is our lord,*
*Fortune and blessing complete him.*

This record observes: Observing the song of the creeping vines, I grasp the author’s effortless artistry. The tendrils of the vine are the queen’s nine duties. That the queen’s affairs become the praise of the concubines—does this require reflection to attain? Melons, wood, and firewood—things even the Duke of Zhou did not discard—how could the palace women forget the bending tree and creeping vines? From this, one sees that the learning of the ancients did not depend on forced seeking. Even women and girls walked the same path as the greatest sages and worthies. Was this not self-attainment?

King Wen’s transformation began in the home and extended to the state: men and women were rectified, marriages occurred in their proper season. Thus, the poets, inspired by what they saw, sang:

*Peach tree young and fair,*
*Bright its blossoms glow.*
*This maiden weds today,*
*Fitting for her household.*

*Peach tree young and fair,*
*Abundant its fruit.*
*This maiden weds today,*
*Fitting for her home.*

*Peach tree young and fair,*
*Lush its leaves unfold.*
*This maiden weds today,*
*Fitting for her kin.*

This record observes: Mencius, speaking of Tai Wang, said, "Within, no resentful maidens; without, no unwed men." The poets, singing of the king, said, "This maiden weds today, fitting for her kin." Is this not because the kingly Way begins with husband and wife? Nothing is as timely and flourishing as the peach in bloom, nothing as fresh and fine as young men and women. Here one sees the diligence of timely action, the care of nurturing love, the kindness of the myriad people, the fullness of harmonious qi. To exhaust the goodness of poetry, one may observe it here.

The transformation spread, customs improved, households were at peace, and women, with nothing to occupy them, gathered *fu yi* together, composing verses to delight in their task:

*Gather, gather the plantain,*
*Quickly now, pluck it.*
*Gather, gather the plantain,*
*Quickly now, take it.*

Gather, gather the plantain,
Quickly now, gather it in.
Gather, gather the plantain,
Quickly now, take it away.

Gather, gather the plantain,
Quickly now, bind it up.
Gather, gather the plantain,
Quickly now, tuck it in.

Recorded note: Where could women find no occupation?
"By the banks of the Ru," they toil for the king’s affairs;
"Spinning fish-tail knots," they serve a disordered state;
"Dew soaks the path," they guard against assault;
"Sparrows’ beaks and rats’ teeth," they fear brute force.
In times of firm governance, such moments must not be lost—lest they breed resentment. Even a dog’s bark at the door cannot be dismissed as mere noise.

Yet when transformation spreads and customs improve, when households are cautious and at peace, is it not in such gathering of plantain that we see it?

From the *Greater Odes*: The wife of the Marquis of Han was the daughter of Juefu. The *Poetry* says:
"Juefu, mighty in valor,
No land he left unvisited,
To arrange the marriage of Han’s lady—
Nothing compares to Han’s joy.
How joyous is Han’s land!
Its rivers and marshes teem,
Its fields are rich and broad,
Its deer and stags abound,
With bears and brown bears,
With wildcats and tigers.
Blessed with such a fine abode,
Han’s lady feasts in praise."

Recorded note: The affairs of the Marquis of Han cannot be verified. Yet observing "The gentleman in old age," with her headdress and six pendants, one may well feast. But the words of Zhongsuan cannot be taken as praise. "The great officer retires without troubling his lord"—this may be called a blessing. Yet his early rise and violent end do not make him worthy. Thus, "Blessed with such a fine abode, Han’s lady feasts in praise"—the gentleman ascribes virtue to this.

From the *Zuo Tradition*: When the House of Yi divined a wife for Jing Zhong, his wife interpreted the oracle, saying: "Auspicious. This is called 'phoenixes in flight, harmonious cries ringing clear.' After the rise of the Ji clan, they will be nurtured by the Jiang. In five generations, they will prosper; by the rank of chief minister, in eight generations, none will surpass them."

Recorded note: The hexagrams *Xian* and *Heng* say: *Xian* means "to feel," *Heng* means "to endure." The Way of husband and wife exists only when feeling endures. Is this not the "harmonious cries ringing clear" and "prosperity in five generations"? Yet if one indulges in revelry and dance, without spring or summer, even to the point of Zhu Lin and Xia Nan—this is what is meant by "not enduring in virtue, and perhaps inheriting shame." This is why Chen perished and why Gu Zhong met his fate. One need not rely on the divination of the House of Yi to know this.

When Zhao Chengzi resided in Jin, he married the daughter of Duke Wen, named Zhao Ji, who bore Yuan Tong, Ping Kuo, and Lou Ying. Later, while following Duke Wen in Di, the Di people attacked Fu Jiu, capturing his two daughters, Shu Yuan and Ji Yuan, and presenting them to Duke Wen. The duke took Ji Yuan for himself and gave Shu Yuan to Chengzi, who bore Dun. When Duke Wen returned to his state, Zhao Ji requested that Dun and his mother be brought to her. Chengzi declined, but Ji said: "To gain favor and forget the old—how can one command others? You must allow it." She insisted, and he consented. Seeing Dun’s talent, she firmly requested of the duke that he be made the primary heir, demoting her own three sons to serve under him. She also elevated Shu Yuan as his principal wife, demoting herself to a secondary position.

Recorded note: Zhao Ji surpassed others in virtue by several degrees. She possessed the capacity to accommodate others, the virtue of humility, and the wisdom to recognize talent. A mother-in-law who cannot tolerate, a wife who is arrogant, or a woman who loves blindly—these are the common failings of women. How much more so when she was the noble daughter of a duke, while her rival was a lowly Di wife, and when her own sons were many, while the other’s child was of humble birth? Yet she said: "To gain favor and forget the old—how can one command others?" Truly, she understood the bond of shared hardship, not merely the desire for fresh well-water. And when she saw Dun’s talent and firmly requested he be made the primary heir, she truly cut away her own fleshly love, not merely distinguishing between the Jing and Wei rivers. In the end, he succeeded Chengzi in governance, bringing glory to the ducal clan. Who would say a woman could not favor her kin? Alas! She may be called benevolent.

From the *Biographies of Exemplary Women*: The Two Compliant Women of Wei were the wife and concubine of Duke Ling of Wei. When the duke died, his wife had no son. She said to the concubine: "The young one served me with great care. You attend to the ancestral rites, while I, as a concubine, serve you—I find this unbearable. Moreover, I have heard that the mother of a ruler does not serve others as a concubine. Now, with no son, I am one who should be cast aside by ritual. Yet I am allowed to remain and fulfill my duty—this is my good fortune. Now, to further trouble the young one would be too much. I wish to move outside, to live in the outer chambers, which would be most fitting." The concubine wept and said: "Does my lady wish for the House of Ling to incur three misfortunes? To not serve the lord to the end—this is the first misfortune. For the lady to have no son while the concubine has one—this is the second misfortune. For the lady to move outside while the concubine’s son remains within—this is the third misfortune. Your servant has heard that a loyal minister serves his lord without rest, and a filial son attends to his parents without wearying of the days. How could I, for the sake of a slight elevation in status, alter my duty?" She then told her son: "I have heard that a gentleman abides in compliance, upholding the rites of high and low, following the ancient ways—this is the Way of compliance. Now, the lady finds me difficult and wishes to move outside, placing me within—this is the Way of disorder. To live in defiance is not as good as to die in compliance." She wished to take her own life, but the spirits and people, hearing of it, were alarmed. They allowed her to remain and serve to the end.

The gentleman said: "These two women may be called those whose conduct was perfected within the inner chambers, and whose names were established for later generations."

Recorded note: The lady had no son, while the concubine did—this posed no harm to her status as primary wife. What need was there for distinction, or for inner and outer chambers? If this were so, then a son could not be without a mother, but the primary wife might be diminished. In Qin, the custom was to honor Lady Huayang and discard Queen Yang, treating her like worn-out straw sandals—was this simply the way of the times? Or was it that when Emperor Xiao of Han deposed Empress Xu and enthroned Zhao Feiyan, when Ban Jieyu sought to move outside and together served in the Changxin Palace, they were making veiled criticisms?

Should such indulgence be left unchecked, it would become the root of later usurpations of the legitimate heir in favor of a favored one—though this may not have been transmitted, it is worth recording. Here, the note preserves the doubtful implications.

From *The Western Han History*: In his youth, Chen Ping was poor and fond of study, and as he grew, he was handsome. When he reached marriageable age, no wealthy family would give him their daughter, and the poor families also shunned him for long. A wealthy man of Huyou named Zhang Fu had a granddaughter and said to his son Zhong: "I wish to marry her to Chen Ping." Zhong replied: "Ping is poor and does not attend to his affairs; the whole county laughs at his conduct. Why would you give her to him?" Fu said: "Is there truly one as fine as Chen Ping who should remain poor?" In the end, he gave his granddaughter to him. As Ping was poor, Fu lent him silk and cloth for the betrothal gifts, provided funds for wine and meat, and sent her in as his wife. He further admonished his granddaughter: "Do not, on account of poverty, fail to serve others with respect. Serve your elder brother as you would your father, and your sister-in-law as you would your mother." After Chen Ping married Zhang’s daughter, his resources grew more abundant, and his connections expanded daily.

The note states: Amid the remnants of a decadent and shallow age, there was still the discernment of the wealthy man Zhang Fu—this may be taken as evidence of the sprouts of dynastic change. If even a single hairpin’s worth was begrudged, how much more so a daughter as fine as jade? If even a single basket’s worth was boasted of, how much more so wealth like flowing springs? When the great Han rose to glory, there was Lü Gong’s daughter, a beauty from childhood, and later, Zhang Fu’s granddaughter, whose reputation spread. Yet she did not grow arrogant with wealth and prominence; in the end, her wifely conduct became ever more refined, and her husband’s virtue ever more advanced—this was what is called "inner achievement bringing good fortune." Could this not be deemed benevolence?

When Emperor Xuan was first the imperial great-grandson, he was caught up in the witchcraft affair and raised in the palace rear chambers. As *The History of the Han by Xu Guang* records: The Son of Heaven, reduced to the same rank, lived together with him in the same temple. At the time, the eunuch Zhang He, formerly of Crown Prince Wei, treated the young imperial scion with great kindness. Guang had a daughter, Pingjun, aged fourteen or fifteen, who was divined to be destined for great nobility. He requested that she be married to the imperial great-grandson, and within a year, she bore the future Emperor Yuan. After he ascended the throne, he made Xu Pingjun his *jieyu*. When the time came to establish an empress, General Huo had a young daughter, closely related to the Empress Dowager, and all the court officials privately favored the general’s daughter, though none dared speak of it. The emperor then issued an edict seeking the sword from his humble days. The ministers understood the implication and established Xu Jieyu as empress.

The note states: Was the disaster of the Huo clan not already sprouting here? The trigger was subtle, but its consequences were vast. If all in the court privately favored her, did the Huo clan not secretly presume as much? If Huo Guang did not know, did the emperor perhaps already know? The emperor’s intent was already fixed. When Shaofu was advanced, the emperor had long pondered the matter; his silence on the intent was not truly silence. The earlier intent could be revealed, but the present intent was difficult to make clear. If Guang did not endorse it, could the emperor be blamed for Guang’s fault? The historians did not examine this closely, attributing the cause to the verification of reckless indulgence—how superficial!

From *The Eastern Han History*: In the third year of Yongping, the officials memorialized to establish the Changqiu Palace. The Empress Dowager said: "Lady Ma’s virtue surpasses that of the rear palace." She was thus established as empress. The empress could recite the *Book of Changes*, enjoyed reading the *Spring and Autumn Annals* and the *Chu Ci*, and was especially skilled in the *Rites of Zhou* and the writings of Dong Zhongshu. After assuming her position, she became ever more modest and solemn, often wearing coarse silk, her skirts unadorned with green. When the emperor visited the gardens and detached palaces, she would caution him against wind, miasma, and baleful vapors, her words earnest and well-considered, and many of her suggestions were adopted. Thus, his excursions and amusements were rarely accompanied by her. At the time, the Chu trials dragged on for years, with mutual accusations leading to many arrests. The empress, concerned about the excesses, took the opportunity to speak of it, her tone deeply compassionate. The emperor was moved, rising at night in restless thought, and in the end, many were pardoned. When Emperor Suzong ascended the throne, he honored her as Empress Dowager. She often discussed governance and Dao with him morning and night, instructed the various princes in the classics, and recounted the virtues of her late husband, speaking all day with reverence: "In my youth, I admired only the bamboo and silk [of the classics], and my aspirations did not consider life’s brevity. Now, though I am old, I am again warned against excess. Thus, I remain vigilant at night, striving to restrain myself, not seeking comfort in my dwelling nor fullness in my meals, hoping by this Dao to not fail the late emperor."

The note states: Was it not fitting that the empress’s virtue shone as bright virtue? The female is the embodiment of yin, her nature soft. Thus, she is often inclined toward extravagance, acquisitiveness, pleasure, and generosity, wearying of rich foods and fine grains, seeking ease and indulgence—this is her norm. Yet how much more so when she is honored as the mother of the empire, possessing all under heaven, and yet she devoted herself ever more to diligence and frugality: wearing coarse silk, personally tending silkworms and weaving, declining excursions and amusements, remonstrating against the Chu trials, rejecting external favors, and refusing prayers and sacrifices. These were not empty displays or superficial adornments, but true virtue and sincere intent flowing through twenty-three years—how could one be deluded? Tracing the source, the empress did not regard herself as merely yin’s embodiment or constrained by her soft nature; what she admired lay in the bamboo and silk [of the classics], and her aspirations lay in the sages. These words laid the foundation—could this be called virtue pervading the rear palace? Truly so. Between the two Han dynasties, none could compare.

When Song Hong served as Grand Minister of Works, Lady Huyang, the Princess, had recently been widowed. Emperor Guangwu discussed court officials with her, subtly gauging her inclinations. The Princess said, "Minister Song’s dignified bearing and virtuous capacity surpass all others." The Emperor replied, "I shall arrange it then."

Later, when Song Hong was summoned for an audience, the Emperor had the Princess sit behind a screen. He then said to Hong, "As the proverb goes: *The noble change their friends, the wealthy change their wives*—is this not human nature?" Hong replied, "Your servant has heard that *one must not forget friends from poverty and low station, nor cast aside a wife who shared hardship and coarse fare*." The Emperor turned to the Princess and said, "The matter will not proceed."

*Recorded:* This was the first step toward the eventual deposition of Empress Guo. "To serve as an official, one should aspire to be Commander of the Imperial Guard; to take a wife, one should seek a woman like Yin Lihua"—such was the Emperor’s early ambition, embodying the very proverb of *changing friends with nobility and wives with wealth*. Hong’s father had once been punished for refusing to ingratiate himself with Dong Xian; such principles had long been instilled in his household. How much more, then, should Hong’s restraint in rejecting extravagant music and resisting licentious beauty, so evident at court, have been known to the Emperor? Why did he still broach such a misguided proposal?

Yet even if the Emperor himself were not worth discussing, how could the Princess, as one who would become Lady Huyang, bear to have such a reputation spread to neighboring states? How could she bear it?

*The Old Book of Tang:* Empress Wende, née Changsun, was by nature benevolent, filial, and frugal, with a lifelong love of reading. She often discussed ancient affairs with the Emperor at leisure, offering counsel and corrections that greatly benefited governance. When her illness grew severe and she took leave of the Emperor, Fang Xuanling was dismissed from court under censure. The Empress said to the Emperor, "Xuanling has served Your Majesty long, with caution and discretion. Unless there is grave cause, I hope you will not cast him aside. I further urge you to draw near to the virtuous, distance the petty, accept loyal remonstrance, reject slander and malice, reduce corvée labor, and cease hunting expeditions. Though I may perish beneath the Nine Springs, I shall have no regrets."

She had once compiled examples of women’s conduct from antiquity, both successes and failures, into *The Women’s Code* in thirty scrolls. The Emperor read it and showed it to his close ministers, saying, "This book by the Empress is sufficient to serve as a model for a hundred generations." When she passed, the Emperor, though he knew the decree of Heaven, indulged in grief without profit. "Now that she is gone," he said, "I enter the palace and hear no more admonitions. I have lost a fine counselor—how can I forget her?"

When she was interred at Zhaoling, the Emperor’s longing for her did not cease. He had a multi-tiered tower built in the imperial park from which to gaze upon her tomb.

*Recorded:* When the Nine Ministers governed the outer realm and Jiang [Yuan] nurtured the inner, their teachings were of no small benefit. Alas, Emperor Taizong of Tang was not the equal of King Wu of Zhou—how could he have been free of fault? Before the queen and concubines were established and Cao Wang Ziming was enfeoffed, he feared only that he would no longer hear admonitions, hence his poignant gaze toward Zhaoling. But after the Lady Wu entered the palace, such earnest devotion would no longer be the same.

Taizong once said to Yu Chi Jingde, "I wish to marry my daughter to you. What do you think?" Jingde kowtowed and declined, saying, "Though my wife is coarse and unrefined, we have shared poverty and low station for many years. Though I am unlearned, I have heard that the ancients did not change their wives for wealth or rank. This is my wish as well." The Emperor approved and did not press the matter.

The Record states: Jingde was a fierce and valiant general—how could he have heard the subtle intent of the *feng* poets? In plain silk robes and hempen headscarves, he seemed far from the swift decisiveness of one who seizes spears, yet with but a single bolt of cloth ascending the six steps, he further displayed the intimacy of his sworn devotion. Compare this to Du He, Fang Yiai, Xue Wanche, and Chai Lingwu, who one after another married imperial princesses—what was there they could not have done, yet they instead brought ruin upon themselves. What was the reason for their downfall? "He who knows contentment is not disgraced; he who knows when to stop is not imperiled"—this was not merely about foreseeing and preventing trouble. Jingde surpassed even Fang [Xuanling] and Du [Ruhui] in this regard, ultimately preserving his integrity in his later years, living in ease and contentment, and alone keeping intact his reputation for propriety. In the exchanges between ruler and minister, they began well and ended well, without the slightest trace of suspicion or mistrust—was this not admirable? Alas!

In matters of the inner chambers, he could truly be called humane.

From *The Gazetteer of Lin’an*: The Reverent and Virtuous Lady of Wu-Yue, née Wu, named Hanyue, was a native of Qiantang. Her nature was gentle, kind, and benevolent. She served King Wenmu (Qian Yuanguang) with filial devotion, lived with constant frugality, and wore only plain cloth. Whenever she heard of harsh punishments being meted out, she would frown and speak of benevolence and forbearance. Among the various members of the Wu clan who received promotions...

All who sought audience with her from distant regions were sternly denied entry, and she often admonished and encouraged them; if any committed faults, she would reprove them to their faces. Thus, throughout her lifetime, none among them grew arrogant or self-indulgent.

The consort of King Zhongyi, née Sun, named Taizhen, was also a native of Qiantang. Her nature was upright, dignified, and keenly intelligent. Whenever she received her in-laws or the various members of the clan, she treated them all with utmost propriety. Fond of study, she read books and was well-versed in the *Mao Odes* and the *Analects of Lu*. She valued frugality and simplicity, and unless receiving official visits or paying respects, she never held lavish banquets.
