When King Shu was campaigning in Piling, Sun remained in the capital and dispatched palace attendants to comfort and inquire after the families of the generals and officers who had followed him on the expedition. Both within the court and beyond, all stood in awe of her, as though serving the king himself.

The record states: History praises the Qian clan for its enduring legacy, not merely for the virtue and favor it bestowed upon the region. For a century, they ruled with severity over their people, yet their descendants have flourished to this day, thriving without end—how vastly different from the sovereigns of the Five Dynasties! This was surely due to the worthy couples who governed their households, laying the foundation for such prosperity. Thus, it is recorded.

From *The History of the Song*: Empress Cao, the Benevolent and Sagely Empress Dowager of Emperor Renzong, was betrothed and entered the palace in the second year of the *Mingdao* era. In the first year of *Jingyou*, she was invested as empress, and in the first year of *Xining*, she was honored as Grand Empress Dowager. Her nature was profoundly kind and loving. Whenever Emperor Shenzong returned late from court, she would personally go to the screen of the imperial chamber to await and inquire after him, offering him broth with her own hands. Once, the emperor harbored intentions toward Yan and Ji and had already settled the matter with his ministers. He then went to the Qingshou Palace to inform her. The empress asked: "Are the reserves and bestowals prepared? Are the armor and weapons in order? Are the soldiers and officers well-trained?" The emperor replied, "All has been arranged."

The empress said: "This matter is of the utmost gravity—fortune and misfortune, regret and shame arise from action. Should we succeed, it would be no more than receiving congratulations as we face south. Yet if we fail, the fate of the living hangs in the balance, and the consequences defy easy description. If these lands could be taken, the Taizu and Taizong emperors would have reclaimed them long ago. Why wait until now?" The emperor replied, "I dare not disregard your counsel."

When Su Shi was imprisoned for his poetry and all believed he would surely die, the empress, though gravely ill, heard of it and said to the emperor: "I recall when your grandfather, Emperor Renzong, discovered the Su brothers through the imperial examinations and rejoiced, saying, *'I have secured two future prime ministers for my descendants.'* Now I hear Su Shi has been jailed for composing poetry—could this be the work of enemies slandering him? Even if his offense lies in verse, it is but a minor transgression. My illness grows severe, and I cannot bear to see injustice spread, lest it disrupt the harmony of the realm. You must examine this carefully." The emperor wept. Thus, Su Shi was spared.

It is recorded: Was it not fitting that she was called *Guangxian*? Her understanding of statecraft was truly worthy of an emperor. Her admonition on the matter of Yan and Ji, in particular, should serve as a model for all ages. Later, during Wang Shao’s campaign in Xihe and the boastful debates over the Xia state, war and strife spread, poisoning the lives of the people. The sins of Wang Anshi and Li Xian reached even to Heaven, while the compassionate and venerable empress had long since departed this world—yet still, the very calamities she foresaw came to pass. This shows how deeply such matters affect the order and security of the realm. Even in the matter of cherishing talent, one cannot help but sigh with sorrow. How fortunate Su Shi was! Had she wept for him only later, her voice would have come too late.

Empress Xuanzhao Shenglie Gao, wife of Emperor Yingzong, was the daughter of Quan Zunfu and Lady Cao, the elder sister of Empress Dowager Guangxian. From childhood, she often entered the inner palace. When Emperor Yingzong was raised within the palace, he and the future empress were of the same age. Emperor Renzong told Empress Dowager Guangxian, "She will surely be his match." As they grew, they were wed in the Palace of Pu, where she gave birth to the future Emperor Shenzong. In the second year of the *Zhiping* era, she was invested as empress. Emperor Shenzong later honored her as Empress Dowager, and upon Emperor Zhezong’s ascension, she was elevated to Grand Empress Dowager. She assumed regency and governed from the throne, first urgently summoning Sima Guang and Lü Gongzhu. Before their arrival, she appointed both as prime ministers, commanding them to work in harmony to assist the state. At once, all the renowned scholars of the age gathered at court. Every policy enacted since the *Xining* era that had proven harmful was systematically abolished. Thus, the *Green Sprouts* system was reformed based on the old regulations of the *Changshi* era, the *Jiayou* corvée system was reinstated alongside the recruitment of mercenaries, the *Market Exchange* laws were abolished, the tea monopoly was relaxed, and barren borderlands were ceded to the Western Rong tribes. The realm was once more at peace. She instructed border officials not to provoke the Khitan, saying, "The Southern Court has fully restored the reforms of Emperor Renzong." When officials proposed following the precedent of the *Tiansheng* era for the palace examination, requesting that both emperor and empress dowager preside from the rear of the hall, she forbade it. When they further requested that she receive the ceremonial tablets in the *Wende* Hall, she replied, "Do not."

Her presiding in the central position was not a commendable matter for the state. How could she occupy the emperor’s formal throne? The *Chongzheng* Hall would suffice. She also deemed the excess of officials to require reduction, and decreed that one-quarter of the favors granted to her maternal relatives be withdrawn to benefit the palace staff.

During her nine years of regency, the court was clear and bright, the realm pacified, and the old precedents rigorously observed. She suppressed imperial decrees issued from within the palace and rejected private favors to her family. The *Wensi* Institute’s offerings to the throne—whether great or small—went untouched throughout her lifetime. The court and the realm revered her as a Yao or Shun among women.

The record states: Yao and Shun were the paragons of sagely perfection—could such praise be applied to a female sovereign? For the Dao of Yao and Shun lies in moderation alone. Among the rulers of her time, the overzealous erred through excessive rigor, while the lax succumbed to indulgence and delusion. Who did not aspire to Yao and Shun’s example, yet dared not claim it? Yet this empress dowager truly nurtured the common people with benevolence, neither yielding to weakness nor overstepping firmness. She upheld the old ways with resolve, revoked the new laws, and the humble folk of the lanes and alleys emerged from fire and water to rest upon their mats. The petty schemers were cast out, and the old ministers of the court, as if parting clouds to see the blue sky, rejoiced.

Had succeeding emperors followed her path generation after generation, the blessings of Yao and Shun would have endured without end, and the vital essence of the Song would not have declined. Alas! Before the sacrificial rice was consumed, the state’s affairs were wholly overturned. The wicked triumphed, and even Yao and Shun could do nothing against them. Was this not because such an age does not often arise?

Empress Xiànshèng Xiànsù of Divine Reverence, consort to Emperor Shénzōng, entered the residence of Prince Yǐng in the third year of the Zhìpíng era. When the Prince of Yǐng ascended the imperial throne, she was established as Empress. Upon the accession of Emperor Zhézōng, she was honored as Empress Dowager. Empress Dowager Xuānrén ordered the renovation of the former palace of Qìngshòu for her residence, but she declined, saying: "How can a mother-in-law dwell in the west while the daughter-in-law resides in the east? This would confuse the proper order of superior and inferior." When members of her clan sought to exchange favors for official posts by precedent, or when others petitioned for promotions from local to capital ranks, she replied: "My family has never relied on such precedents. Why should private interests disrupt public affairs?" She refused every such request. When Emperor Zhézōng suddenly passed away, she alone made the critical decision, and no dissenting voices could obstruct it. Upon the accession of Emperor Huīzōng, she was asked to assume temporary regency, but she declined, citing the emperor’s maturity. Only after Huīzōng wept and bowed for some time did she consent. Throughout the reigns from Shàoshèng to Yuánfú, she gradually reinstated the worthy officials and scholar-officials who had been exiled. She abolished outdated customs such as avoiding the imperial ancestral taboo when holding court in the main hall, or establishing birth celebrations for the emperor. When she heard of measures like summoning retired elders, easing corvée labor, halting military campaigns, cherishing the people, and promoting frugality, her joy was evident. After just six months, she returned governance to the emperor.

The record states: Among the Song dynasty, four empresses shone with comparable brilliance, illuminating the annals of history. Observing their most virtuous deeds, none failed to prioritize the summoning of retired elders and the honoring of worthy scholars, while curbing private favors and restraining personal desires to love the people. Few since have matched their example. Alas! Truly, they were benevolent.

Empress Zhāocí Shèngxiàn Mèng, chosen by Empress Dowager Xuānrén and installed as Empress, faced calamity when Xuānrén passed away. Zhāng Dūn slandered Xuānrén and the empress, and secretly allied with Consort Liú to propose her replacement. With Hǎo Suí, they fabricated charges, enduring through the Chóngníng and Jìngkāng eras. When the Jurchen captured the capital, all titled consorts of the six palaces were taken north, but the deposed empress alone remained. Zhāng Bāngchāng honored her as Empress Dowager of Sòng and welcomed her to reside in Yánfú Palace, where she received the court’s homage and governed behind the screen. Learning that Prince Kāng was in Jì, she dispatched the Left and Right Vice Directors of the Department of State Affairs, Féng Yū and Lǐ Huí, along with her nephew Zhōnghòu, bearing a letter to welcome him. She ordered Commander Guō Zhòngxūn to lead his troops as an escort, and sent the commander of the Imperial Guard’s vanguard, Zhāng Jùn, to meet him en route. When the prince arrived in Nánjīng, she again sent the imperial clansman Shìliǎng and the eunuch Shào Érchē to present the imperial seals, regalia, and carriages, inviting Prince Kāng to ascend the throne. She was then honored as Empress Dowager Yuányòu and welcomed to the temporary court, where she lived until her passing.

Initially, when she was selected, Empress Dowager Xuānrén sighed: "This woman is virtuous and gentle, though her blessings are profound." She added: "If the state faces turmoil, she will surely bear the burden." All unfolded as she foretold.

The record states: In my humble view, the empresses Guāngxiàn, Xuānrén, and Qīnshèng conducted themselves like the gentle breeze of spring, harmonious and unassuming, following the emperor’s principles without pretense. Empress Zhāocí Mèng, however, was like autumn’s frost and dew—cleansed, she shone anew; obscured, she regained her brilliance. Yet all upheld the maternal virtues of the earth and the rites of feminine instruction, reflecting the accumulated blessings of the ancestral line. Was this not also the natural duty of empresses who cultivated virtue?

Sūn Míngfù lived in seclusion south of Mount Tài, already forty years old and dwelling alone. Chancellor Lǐ Dí, then serving as prefect of Yǎn, met him and sighed: "Sir, you live alone without a companion. Who will care for you in wind and rain, prepare your meals, or tend to you in illness?" He offered his younger brother’s daughter to serve as his wife. Míngfù firmly declined. Shí Jiè and his disciples pleaded: "For too long, high officials have neglected scholars. Now the chancellor, undeterred by your poverty and low status, wishes to entrust his niece to you, thereby demonstrating his own virtue." Thus, he married her. The Lǐ family embraced simplicity, serving their husband with utmost devotion. At the time, all scholar-officials praised them.

The record states: Observing Sūn Míngfù’s conduct, I lament that Lǐ Wén-dìng’s virtue is unattainable. Though a chancellor’s achievements may be unknowable, when governing a region, nothing surpasses the conduct of scholars and the refinement of customs. His wife’s marriage not only humbled the noble to honor the lowly, fulfilling one man’s goodness, but also addressed the fear of dying without heirs, nurturing the wellspring of great transformation. Moreover, it corrected the frivolity of shallow customs and preserved the lofty integrity of a reclusive scholar. Later, when Míngfù entered public service, he did not betray those who had recommended him. The Lǐ family, content in poverty and rich in propriety, honored their husband without shame. Both set an example for later generations.

Before Liú Tíngshì passed the imperial examinations, he had arranged to marry a local girl. After succeeding in the exams, the girl lost her sight to illness. Some urged him to marry her younger sister instead, but Tíngshì smiled: "My heart is already pledged. How could I betray my original intent?" He married her as promised, and they had several children. When his wife later died, Tíngshì, then serving as vice prefect of Mì Prefecture, did not remarry for over a year. At the time, Sū Shì was the prefect, and he asked: "Grief arises from love, and love arises from desire. Now, from what does your love arise, and from what does your grief emerge?" Tíngshì replied: "I know only that I have lost my wife. If love were born from desire, and grief from love, then when desire fades and love wanes, my grief would vanish too. Would that mean any woman who catches my eye on the street could become my wife?" Shì deeply admired his words.

The record states: Husband and wife are equals. Confucius said: "Beware of desire." And again: "I have never seen one who loves virtue as much as beauty." The Sage’s intent was to prevent desire from leading to licentiousness, thereby averting disaster and moderating excess. As the *Book of Songs* says: "Though they may be as numerous as clouds, they are not the ones I think of. In plain white robes and hempen sashes, they alone bring me joy."

If one such as Tíngshì may be said to love virtue and not be swayed by material desires, then had he advanced within the gate of Confucius, he would surely have earned the Sage’s profound approval—how could it be merely that Shì deeply admired him?

Zhōu Xíngjǐ, styled Gōngshū, passed the imperial examinations in his early years before the age of thirty. Observing Yíchuān’s austere self-discipline—secluded alone in his chamber, never once glancing at the courtyard or discussing the daughters of his mother’s kin—he took no wife. After passing the examinations, when he learned that a certain woman had gone blind in both eyes, he married her nonetheless, loving her more deeply than most men would. Yíchuān remarked: "Even I, at thirty, could not have done such a thing."

The record states: Yǎnchuān’s praise for Gōngshū carried the meaning of self-reflection and restraint, embodying the spirit of guiding others toward goodness. As for the one from Méishān, he was forever freed from the snares of emotion. Herein lies the division between the Luò and Shǔ schools—how could it be merely a matter of not singing while mourning or not mourning while singing?

Lǚ Zé sat for the imperial examinations and was betrothed to a woman from his hometown, though the marriage had not yet taken place. After he passed the examinations, the woman’s family said: "Our daughter had no illness before, but after the betrothal, she went blind." Zé replied: "You have not deceived me—what reason is there to refuse?" And so he married her.

She bore six sons, five of whom passed the imperial examinations, one being the Chancellor Dafang. Zé rose to the rank of Director in the Ministry of Personnel.

The record states: In reviewing the seven grounds for divorce, none mention blindness—thus, there was certainly no impediment to taking her as wife. Yet when it comes to severe illness or childlessness, there is a reluctance to act. Why? Within the inner chambers, affection outweighs duty. Though she was once free of illness, once afflicted, even a sage could not guarantee her health. Their bond was that of husband and wife; to abandon her in solitude would be unthinkable, even to a fool. Did the former kings, in establishing these regulations, truly not consider this? I suspect that in cases where a woman is barren or fails to conceive, or where a physician diagnoses her as "sterile," the verdict of "severe illness and childlessness" is applied without hesitation, leaving no room for doubt.

*The Ming Dynasty’s Official Biographies* records: Emperor Taizu’s empress, the virtuous and filial Ma, was from her youth serene, steadfast, and singular, her wisdom surpassing all expectations. After entering the palace, during years of great famine, she often endured hunger, saving dried meats and preserved fruits to offer the Emperor, ensuring he never lacked sustenance. The Emperor once remarked to his attendants: "Formerly, Emperor Guangwu thanked Feng Yi, saying, ‘Your kindness has long gone unanswered.’ I recall that the Empress rose from common origins, sharing hardship with me. In times of urgency, she would go hungry to feed me. Compared to the bean gruel and wheat porridge of old, our struggles were far harsher. When Emperor Taizong of Tang faced discord with his heir, Empress Changshun, within the palace, fulfilled her filial duties, carefully attending to the consorts, and dispelled resentment. I, however, was repeatedly suspected by the Guo clan, acting recklessly without regard. When soldiers presented gifts of clothing or goods, the Empress would first offer them to the Guos to soothe their feelings. When they sought to endanger me, she repeatedly mediated, ultimately averting disaster—a feat even more difficult than that of Changshun. A good wife in a household is like a good minister in a state; how could I forget her?"

One morning, the Emperor spoke of this to the Empress, who replied: "I have heard that it is easier for husband and wife to protect one another than for ruler and minister to do so. Since Your Majesty cannot bear to forget me in my humble origins, I pray you will not forget the common people in their hardship. Though I dare not compare myself to Empress Changshun in virtue, I only hope Your Majesty will take Yao and Shun as your model."

When her illness grew critical, the Emperor asked what she wished to say. The Empress replied: "May Your Majesty seek worthy counsel, heed remonstrance, clarify governance and education to bring about harmony, and instruct your sons to cultivate virtue and achievement." The Emperor said: "I have already taken this to heart, but how can I bear to part with you in my old age?" The Empress added: "Life and death are matters of fate. I only hope Your Majesty will remain vigilant to the end as you were at the beginning, that your descendants may all be virtuous, and that the people may find their place. Though I die, it will be as if I live on." With that, she passed away. The Emperor wept in grief and never again took another empress.

The record states: After the Three Dynasties came Han; after Tang and Song came Ming—their rise to power followed a similar pattern. Yet Empress Lü of Han and Empress Xiaoci Zhaoxian of Ming, though both aided their dynasties, were as different as ice and fire. How could Empress Lü of Han compare even to a fraction of the virtue of the Ming’s Empress Ma? Moreover, when our Emperor Taizu, out of righteousness, resolved never to take another empress, he stood worlds apart from the affair of Lady Qi. His filial piety in upholding Heaven’s mandate and his compliance with the sagely will may serve as a model for all ages.

*Hongdao Lu*, Volume Seven concludes.
*Hongdao Lu*, Volume Eight begins.

**On Brotherly Benevolence**

From the *Zuo Zhuan*: The Gao Yang clan had eight talented sons—Qi, Sheng, Guang, Yuan, Ming, Yun, Du, and Cheng—whom the world called the Eight Harmonious Ones. The Gao Xin clan had eight talented sons—Zhong, Su, Gong, Yi, Xuan, Ci, Hui, and He—whom the world called the Eight Excellencies. These sixteen clans perpetuated their virtues through the generations, preserving their names unblemished until the time of Yao. Yao could not employ Shun as his minister, but he appointed the Eight Harmonious Ones to oversee the earth, regulating all affairs. Nothing was out of order; the land was level, and Heaven’s work was complete. He also appointed the Eight Excellencies to spread the Five Teachings across the four directions: fathers righteous, mothers kind, elder brothers friendly, younger brothers respectful, and children filial. Thus, all was harmonious within and without. The *Book of Yu* recounts Shun’s achievements: "He carefully upheld the Five Constants, and the Five Constants were duly followed—no teachings were disobeyed. He entrusted them to the Hundred Administrators, and the Hundred Administrators were timely in their duties—no affairs were neglected."

The record states: The *Tongyi Qianbian* explains that the term "clan" here refers to a dynasty, meaning these two dynasties produced these sixteen men. It further clarifies that they were not born of a single mother with four births, like the Eight Officers of Zhou. Some, not understanding, mistakenly assume they were the sons of the two emperors. If so, how could the eight sons of Gao Yang have lived so long, and were the eight sons of Gao Xin all younger brothers of Yao? Let the reader consider this carefully.

Wan Zhang asked: "Xiang made killing Shun his business. When Shun became the Son of Heaven, he merely exiled Xiang. Why?" Mencius replied: "He enfeoffed him." Some say: "He exiled him." A benevolent man toward his younger brother does not harbor anger or nurse grudges; he simply cherishes him. To cherish him is to wish him honor; to love him is to wish him wealth. Enfeoffing him with Youbi gave him both wealth and honor. If one is the Son of Heaven while his brother remains a commoner, can this truly be called cherishing and loving him?

The record states: Zheng Zhuang’s treatment of his younger brother, Shu Duan, exemplifies harboring anger. Duke Xian of Jin’s treatment of Huan and Zhuang exemplifies nursing grudges. Not only did he harbor anger, but he also swore never to see his mother again at Chengying. Not only did he nurse grudges, but he also cursed that none of the ducal sons should be raised. The *Doctrine of the Mean* says: "When brothers are in harmony, their joy and delight are profound." It also says: "Thus, parents are at peace." Yet if one cannot be kind to an arrogant younger brother, how can one rectify the heart of the stubborn and unyielding?

From the *Major Odes* of the *Book of Songs*: "The Emperor established states and appointed lords, beginning with Tai Bo and King Ji. This King Ji, following his heart, befriended his elder brother, deeply cherishing their bond. Thus, he was granted radiant blessings, received blessings without loss, and eventually possessed the four directions."

The record states: Confucius said: "Tai Bo may be called a man of utmost virtue. Thrice he yielded the world, yet the people could find no words to praise his humility." The commentators explain: "There was nothing to praise in his yielding, for it was so subtle and unobtrusive as to be invisible." Yet when we examine the poet’s words—"King Ji’s friendship with his elder brother arose naturally from his heart, not from compulsion"—does this not imply that Tai Bo’s yielding to his younger brother was not natural but required effort? If so, how could others perceive it, and how could they praise it? It is self-evident without needing the phrase "subtle and unobtrusive."

From the *Minor Odes* of the *Book of Songs*: "Tall stands the mugwort, heavy with dew. Having met this lord, how joyful and at ease! Fitting as elder brother, fitting as younger brother, may they together enjoy virtue and longevity. Orderly flows the stream, dark and deep the Southern Mountains. Like bamboo they are firmly rooted, like pines they flourish. Elder and younger brothers, ever in good relations, never deceiving one another."

The record states: These two poems precisely address the flaws of the Seven States of Han. Consider Liu An of Huainan, who loved guests, and Yuan of Chu, who prepared sweet wine—were these not joyful occasions? Yet lacking the virtue of ease, they ultimately failed to attain happiness and longevity. Later, they cast coins from mountains and boiled the sea for salt, recruiting fugitives and harboring rebels. Their schemes multiplied endlessly, only hastening their downfall. And this was not merely about succession or mutual suspicion.

From the *Records of the Grand Historian*: Bo Yi and Shu Qi were the two sons of the Lord of Guzhu. Their father wished to enthrone Shu Qi. After their father’s death, Shu Qi yielded to Bo Yi. Bo Yi said: "It was our father’s command." And so he fled. Shu Qi likewise refused the throne and fled. The people of the state then enthroned the middle son. Zigong asked: "What manner of men were Bo Yi and Shu Qi?" Confucius replied: "They were worthy men of old." "Did they harbor resentment?" "They sought benevolence and attained it. What resentment could there be?"

The record states: Someone asked: "Why have later generations not matched the yielding of Bo Yi and Shu Qi?" I replied: "Matters that have no precedent arise naturally from Heaven and Earth, and thus are never flawed. Those with a precedent are later shaped by human deliberation and calculation, and thus vary endlessly. Bo Yi and Shu Qi, regarding their father’s command, acted according to principle without thought of later consequences. Later men, in their dealings with brothers, feign virtue to create affairs, deliberately seeking the reputation of the ancients. This is why they differ—and why disorder arises from it."

From the *Book of Zhou*: Two years after conquering Shang, King Wu fell gravely ill. The Duke of Tai and the Duke of Shao said: "Let us divine for the king’s well-being." The Duke of Zhou replied: "We must not distress our former kings." He then performed a ritual for himself, constructing three altars on a single platform. On the southern altar, facing north, the Duke of Zhou stood. Holding a jade tablet and grasping a scepter, he addressed Tai Wang, Wang Ji, and King Wen. The scribe then read from the prayer text: "Your eldest grandson, so-and-so, has contracted a severe and cruel illness..."

"If you, the Three Kings, bear the great responsibility of a son toward Heaven, then let me, Dan, take the place of so-and-so’s person."

He then divined with three tortoises, and each divination repeated the same auspicious result. Upon opening the lock and examining the oracle texts, all proved favorable. The Duke said: "The king’s person shall suffer no harm." He then placed the prayer tablets into a golden casket.

The king’s condition improved and he recovered. After King Wu passed away, Guan Shu spread rumors among the royal brothers throughout the state, saying: "The Duke intends harm to the young heir."

The Duke of Zhou then addressed the two dukes: "If I do not act, I will have nothing to report to our former kings." The Duke of Zhou remained in the east for two years, until the guilty were apprehended.

He then composed a poem to present to the king, saying:
*O turtledove, magpie,*
*You have taken my fledglings—*
*Do not destroy my nest.*
*With toil and care I labored,*
*Grieving for my young ones’ plight.*

*Before Heaven’s darkening rain,*
*I stripped the mulberry bark,*
*Mending windows and doors.*
*Now you, the people below,*
*Dare to mock and slight me.*

*My hands are chapped and calloused,*
*From gathering bitter herbs,*
*From storing my harvest.*
*My mouth is parched and cracked—*
*I have no home to shelter me.*

*My feathers are frayed and thin,*
*My tail is worn and ragged,*
*My nest sways precariously.*
*Tossed by wind and rain,*
*I can only cry out in distress.*

The record states: Though the king and his uncles held the distinction of ruler and subject, the Duke regarded them as limbs of one body—thus all were the same. When the king died, he acted in his stead; when the uncles rebelled, he punished them—was there any difference in his resolve? None at all.

For whether through blindness or madness, though the degrees of kinship may vary, their threat to the royal house was the same. Thus, if the young heir is secure, the people will have no cause for doubt; if the young heir is imperiled, the people will have no one to respect.

In this light, was there any difference in the sage’s heart—whether holding jade tablets and scepters or wielding broken axes and shattered halberds? His compassion for the people remained the same, regardless of circumstance.

It is further said: The term *yí* (贻) signifies transmission, the means by which intent is conveyed. Rumors arise from obscurity, without root or foundation. If one remains silent and does not speak, should the royal house suddenly face calamity, who would know? And who would act?

Could a benevolent man truly remain thus? Yet if one speaks only out of expediency, and the noble kin suddenly face ruin, could this be endured? What could be more unbearable? A benevolent man does not act in such a way.

Now, observing his words—they were not urgent, yet their meaning reached its mark alone.

Should a child of five feet in height hear these words, would they not know that the malice of crows and magpies cannot be undone, and that the toil of sawing and hewing is to be trusted? Such is the depth of their power to move, surpassing even the most earnest sincerity.

In their choice of words and comparison of events, they are like the wind stirring all things. Yet when Heaven’s thunder and lightning are borne by the wind, do they arise without cause?

In the *Zuozhuan*, it is recorded that during the Li Ji Disturbance, Jin cursed itself, vowing never to retain the sons of its former lords. From then on, Jin had no *gongzu* (ducal clansmen). When Duke Cheng ascended, he ennobled the legitimate son of Xiang and granted him fields, establishing him as *gongzu*. He also ennobled Xiang’s other sons as *yuzǐ* (secondary clansmen), and his lesser sons as *gongxíng* (ducal attendants). Thus, Jin once more had *gongzu*, *yuzǐ*, and *gongxíng*.

Zhao Xuanzi requested that Kuo be made *gongzu*, saying: “My lord is the beloved son of the Ji clan. Without the Lady Ji, your servant would be but a Di barbarian.” The duke consented, making Xuanzi the head of the *nichē* (chariot-escort) clan and appointing Ping Ji to oversee them, while designating Xuanzi’s former clan as *gongzu dafu* (ducal clansmen ministers).

The record states: Zhao Xuanzi’s plea for his clan was stirred by the Ji clan’s plea for its legitimate heir. Yet though the legitimate heir was proclaimed, the Zhao clan’s lineage endured through Kuo, while the clan of the legitimate heir perished. Where, then, was the *nichē*? Where was the *gongzu*? Thus the noble man values having sons.

When Han Xianzi retired, he sought to establish Muzi as *gongzu*. Muzi, afflicted with illness, declined, saying: “As the *Book of Songs* says, ‘If one does not attend to matters personally, the common people will not trust.’ I, Wuji, am unworthy—pray establish Qi instead.” Qi had befriended Tian Su and was known for his love of benevolence. The *Book of Songs* says: “Be reverent in your office, love uprightness—then the spirits will heed you and grant you great blessings.” To show compassion for the people is virtue; to be upright is rectitude; to harmonize both is benevolence. If one acts thus, the spirits will heed, blessings will descend, and one’s establishment will be assured. Xianzi then retired from court.

The lord of Jin, deeming Han Wuji benevolent, appointed him to oversee the *gongzu* as *gongzu dafu*.

The record states: Han and Zhao were the mighty arms of the Three Jin. Thus Xianzi did not forsake Zhao Meng, recognizing his understanding of righteousness. Qi and Dun were the great trees of their noble houses, so Wuji did not place Han Qi first, valuing his hidden benevolence. Yet righteousness must be established before benevolence. The proclamation of the legitimate heir and the elevation of Xuan Meng served to transform Muzi; the enfeoffment of Ping Ji and the clan’s restoration moved Duke Dao. The *Book of Songs* says: “Though their line was not illustrious, their plans were steadfast.” Was this not the reason for the Three Jin’s prosperity and the division of Quwo?

When Duke Mu of Song fell ill, he summoned the Grand Marshal Kong Fu and entrusted him with Duke Shang, saying: “Our late lord passed over Yu Yi to establish me. I dare not forget. If, by your grace, I may preserve my life until its end, and our late lord should ask about Yu Yi, what answer could I give? I beg you to serve him as lord of the altars of soil and grain. Though I die, I will have no regrets.”

Kong Fu replied: “The ministers wish to serve Feng.”

The duke said: “That will not do. Our late lord deemed me worthy and made me lord of the altars. If I abandon virtue and refuse to yield, I would undo our late lord’s act. How could I claim worthiness? Should I not strive to illuminate our late lord’s virtuous power?” He urged Kong Fu: “Do not forsake our late lord’s merit.” Thus, he sent Prince Feng to reside in Zheng.

On the *gengchen* day of the eighth month, Duke Mu of Song died, and Duke Shang ascended the throne.

The noble man says: Duke Xuan of Song could be called one who knew men. He established Duke Mu, and his son reaped the reward, for he acted with righteousness.

The record states: Duke Xuan’s transfer of the state to Duke Mu was deemed “knowing men” by Zuo, but “the beginning of disaster” by *Gongyang*. How is one to reconcile this? When Yao recommended Shun, and Shun recommended Yu, they had already heeded Heaven’s mandate. Yet in their court audiences, legal judgments, and musical performances, they never failed to win the people’s trust—even extending to Yi. With Qi, however, it was otherwise: court audiences, legal judgments, and musical performances were not directed to Yi but to Qi. Qi said: “I am the son of our lord.” The affairs of Yao, Shun, Yu, and Yi arose from Heaven’s natural mandate and the impartiality of Heavenly principle—hence their endurance for ten thousand generations without flaw. The affairs of Mu, Xuan, Yi, and Feng stemmed from the passions of preference and the selfishness of “you” and “me”—hence their failure within two transmissions. Yet Kong Fu’s acceptance of the mandate was nobler than Zhao Pu’s repeated insistence; and Prince Feng’s residence in Zheng was better than De Fang’s breach of covenant. Duke Mu could be said not to have betrayed his original intent.

When Duke Huan of Song fell ill, Crown Prince Zi Fu urgently requested: “Mu Yi is both elder and benevolent—pray establish him.” The duke commanded Zi Yu. Zi Yu declined, saying: “What could be greater than yielding the state to a benevolent man? I am not his equal.” He then fled and withdrew.

When Duke Xiang of Song ascended, he deemed Prince Mu Yi benevolent and appointed him Left Minister to oversee governance. Thus, Song was well-ordered, and the Yu clan perpetually held the office of Left Minister.

The record states: Duke Mu passed over Feng to establish Yu Yi, confounding the bond between father and son—hence the eventual usurpation and regicide. Mu Yi firmly insisted on establishing Zi Fu, upholding the proper order between brothers—hence the achievement of Song’s good governance. Yet why did they vie in yielding as a matter of righteousness? Was it to outdo one another in reputation? In essence, when a father dies, the son succeeds—this is the constant way of ten thousand generations. When an elder brother dies, the younger succeeds—this is a temporary expedient. To treat the extraordinary as ordinary and the expedient as constant is but disorder.

Gongsun Ao of Lu married a woman of Ju, who bore Wen Bo. Her elder sister, Sheng Ji, bore Hui Shu. After Dai Ji died, he sought another bride from Ju. The people of Ju offered Sheng Ji, but he instead arranged for Xiang Zhong to betroth her. Upon seeing her beauty from the city wall, he took her for himself, and his entire household fled to Ju to join the Ji clan.

The people of Lu enthroned their eldest son, Gu, who became known as Wen Bo. When Wen Bo fell ill, he petitioned, saying: "My son Gu is young; I request that Nan be installed instead." His request was granted. After Wen Bo’s death, Hui Shu was enthroned.

The record states: In the reign of Duke Wen of Lu, the legitimate heir was slain and the concubine-born son installed—yet there was the yielding between Gu and Nan. The noble man may well feel shame before Xiang Zhong, yet in the end could not escape the calamity of ruin. As the *Tradition* says: "A lord begins with this, and ends with this." The killings by Qing Fu of Ban and Min, and by Xiang Zhong of E and Shi—these are one and the same. Thus, though one may wish not to die, how can one avoid death?

The *Book of Han* records: King De of Hejian was the elder brother of Emperor Wu. He cultivated learning and cherished antiquity, seeking truth in facts. When he obtained fine books from the people, he would have them copied and returned to their owners, keeping the originals and rewarding them with gold and silk. Thus, scholars of the Dao and arts from all directions, though they might come from a thousand *li* away, or possess ancient texts handed down from their ancestors, presented them in tribute. As a result, he amassed a great many books. All were pre-Qin ancient scripts, such as the *Rites of Zhou*, the *Book of Documents*, the *Rites*, the *Record of Rites*, the *Mencius*, and the *Laozi*—all classics and commentaries. The explanations and records of the seventy disciples’ discussions on their studies encompassed the Six Arts. He established the Mao *Odes* and the Zuo *Spring and Autumn Annals* as official teachings, refined ritual and music, donned the robes of Confucian scholars, and in all matters, however trivial, deferred to the Ru. Many Ru from the eastern mountains followed and studied under him. During Emperor Wu’s reign, he came to court, presented refined music at the Three Sacred Halls, and answered over thirty questions in the imperial edict. His responses, grounded in the Dao and its safeguards, struck the heart of affairs—concise in wording, clear in intent.

When he had reigned for twenty-six years, he passed away. The Chief Commandant Chang Li reported this, saying: "The king’s person was upright in conduct, his governance temperate, benevolent, reverent, and frugal. He was deeply respectful and loving toward his subjects, discerning and profoundly perceptive, and showed kindness to the widowed and orphaned." The posthumous eulogy, following the *Law of Posthumous Titles*, read: "Intelligent, enlightened, wise, and sagacious." It was decreed: "Let him be called *Xian*." Thus, he was titled Prince Yi of Mi.

The record states: Since the Western Han dynasty, when the custom of mocking and reviling the Ru arose, of the hundreds of princes enfeoffed over the generations, most grew arrogant, licentious, and lost the Dao, becoming perverse, rebellious, and wicked in every conceivable way. Was this truly because Heaven had bestowed upon them such disparate natures? Rather, it was the circumstances that ensnared and drowned their hearts. What fault, then, did the Ru bear before the world? The standards set by the Two Emperors and Three Kings for later generations are fully recorded in the classics. This prince’s person was upright in conduct, his governance temperate, benevolent, reverent, and frugal. Compared to those who found comfort in poison and profit in peril and ruin, how vast was the difference! The histories praise the *Greater Ya* as towering and peerless—only the princes of the Hejian region approached such distinction. He may truly be called benevolent.

According to the *Book of Later Han*: Liu Qiang, Prince Gong of Donghai, was the son of Empress Guo and the elder brother of Emperor Ming. In the second year of the Jianwu era, he was established as Crown Prince. In the seventeenth year, when Empress Guo was deposed, Qiang was often sorrowful and ill at ease. He repeatedly petitioned through his attendants and other princes, expressing his earnest sincerity and desire to serve as a vassal prince to provide for his mother. Emperor Guangwu could not bear this, and the matter remained unresolved for several years. In the sixth month of the nineteenth year, an edict was issued: "Crown Prince Qiang has long upheld humility and restraint. The bond between father and son is profound, and to separate them for so long has been difficult. Let Qiang be made Prince of Donghai, and let Yang be established as Crown Prince."

Yuan Hong remarked: "Donghai’s submission as a vassal state revealed a heart of filial reverence all the more radiant. When Emperor Ming ascended the throne, the affection between brothers grew even deeper. Though their fates differed—one rising, the other demoted—their innate love as father and son and brothers remained unquestionable."

The record states: In observing the successive sovereigns who inherited the mandate, I see that they often took past events as mirrors. The change of the Crown Prince was precisely a response to the hardships of the times. Had Emperor Ming’s virtue not been foreseen in the former Han, would the realm not have been shaken? In the first year of the Yongping era, Qiang indeed passed away from illness. Though the emperor had long anticipated this, he was ultimately able to preserve his heartfelt love. Such fraternal affection may well be what the *Odes* calls "profound blessing."

Liu Cang, Prince Xian of Dongping, was Emperor Ming’s younger brother. Emperor Ming held him in deep affection. In the eleventh year of the Yongping era, he came to court and, after a month’s stay, returned to his fief. The emperor personally saw him off. Upon returning to the palace, he was overcome with melancholy longing and dispatched envoys bearing a handwritten edict to the Dongping kingdom. The edict read: "Since parting, I have sat alone in sorrow. I went to my carriage, leaned upon the crossbar, and sang, gazing into the distance with longing—truly, it wearies my heart. Some time ago, I asked the prince what was most joyful in managing a household. The prince replied that doing good was the greatest joy. His words were grand, and they matched his true intent. Now, I send nineteen seals for the various marquises. All sons aged five and above who can bow and pay respects shall be permitted to wear them."

The record states: Dongping’s delight in goodness is a tale of beauty for the ages. The princes of old were ever diligent—this diligence was a virtue, meaning goodness, trustworthiness, and fulfillment. Those who sought to attract officials and wandering scholars, whose fame and reputation shone brightly, did not embody such goodness, trustworthiness, or fulfillment. Were they like those who forged golden turtles, jade cranes, inscribed talismans, and fabricated auspicious omens? The emperor’s praise for his words was indeed well-founded.

Some say: "Doing good as the greatest joy means acting without ulterior motive. When one acts without ulterior motive, what could one not achieve?" Jiang Kengbo, Huai, and their younger brother Jiang Jijiang, of an illustrious lineage, were all renowned for their filial piety. Their fraternal love was innate and profound. They often went out together, and even after each took a wife, their mutual affection remained so strong that they could not bear to live apart. As the succession to the lineage was at stake, they took turns visiting each other’s chambers. Jiang Gong was broadly learned in the Five Classics and well-versed in astral and apocryphal texts. Many scholars from afar came to study under him, and though he was repeatedly summoned to office, he declined every appointment. His two brothers, equally renowned, also refused all offers of employment. The people admired them. Emperor Huan of the Later Han then dispatched artisans to Pengcheng to paint their likenesses and report back. Gong concealed himself in seclusion, covering his face with a quilt and claiming to suffer from dizziness and an aversion to wind, so that the artisans never saw him.

The record states: Gong’s steadfast conduct was truly remarkable. The *Odes* say: "Though she had seven sons, none could console their mother’s heart." Gong may be called one who could console his mother’s heart. Those who embody sagely goodness move others through their words, while those who wield whips and rods compel obedience through their demeanor.

Those who conceal their eagerness for reclusion invite the very summons they seek to avoid; those who exhaust their vessels in shameful succession suffer the pain of their past missteps. Thus, though mother and son dwelt in separate chambers, the brothers shared a single quilt—yet their words never faltered. Though a mother’s kindness and a younger brother’s love arose naturally from the heart, leaving no trace in their countenance, their conduct spoke plainly. No summons reached their ears, nor did they partake in the calamities of their clan—thus they avoided the very conflicts they might have provoked. They served their mother with devotion until her death, preserving their integrity in pristine wholeness—thus they spared themselves the pain of regret. Measured against the standards of Confucius’ disciples, could they not be called those who "found joy in poverty"?

According to the *Book of Xie Cheng*: Gong’s stepmother was young and stern of disposition. Moved by the righteousness of the *"Kai Feng"* ode, the brothers shared a single quilt and never entered her private chambers, all to console their mother’s heart. The *Book of Jin* records: Wang Xiang’s younger brother, Wang Lan, suffered his mother Zhu’s cruel treatment of Xiang. When Lan was but a few years old, he would weep and cling to Xiang whenever he saw him beaten. As he grew older, he constantly admonished his mother, gradually curbing her violence. Zhu repeatedly forced Xiang and Lan to act against reason, and wherever she sent Xiang, Lan followed. When she abused Xiang’s wife, Lan’s wife would rush to join her. After their father’s death, Xiang’s conduct grew increasingly irreproachable, and Zhu grew to detest him. She secretly poisoned his wine, but Lan learned of it and seized the cup before Xiang could drink. Xiang hesitated, but Zhu snatched it back and drank it herself. Thereafter, whenever Zhu offered Xiang food, Lan would taste it first, and Zhu, fearful, ceased her schemes. Lan’s filial piety, fraternal devotion, reverence, and prudence were nearly equal to Xiang’s. When Xiang entered official service, Lan also accepted his home commandery’s summons.

Earlier, Lü Qian possessed a ceremonial blade, and a diviner had declared that only one destined for the rank of the Three Excellencies could rightfully wear it. If bestowed upon the unworthy, the blade might bring misfortune. Believing Xiang possessed the capacity for the highest offices, Lü Qian gave it to him. As Xiang lay dying, he bequeathed it to Lan, saying, "Your descendants will surely prosper and prove worthy of this blade." Indeed, their lineage flourished with virtue and rose to prominence in the lands east of the Yangtze. Lan had six sons: Cai, styled Shichu, who served as Chief Clerk to the General-in-Chief; Ji, styled Shixian, who was Investigating Censor; Hui, styled Shihe, who was Imperial Censor; Zheng, styled Shize, who was Gentleman of the Palace; Yan, styled Shizhi, who was Central Protector; and Chen, styled Shizhang, who was Libationer of the National University. Cai’s son, Dao, became a renowned chief minister.

The record states: Xiang’s service to his parents left nothing to be desired, while Lan’s devotion to his elder brother was beyond reproach. Their father’s neglect had its reasons, but their mother’s cruelty knew no cause. Yet in the end, they gathered filial sons and fraternal brothers under one roof, and auspicious harmony flourished in their descendants. This was Heaven’s way of perfecting the reputations of these two men and extending the Jin dynasty’s reign for generations. Lü Qian’s tale may not be entirely credible, yet was it not akin to the omen of the golden ox? Though Yuan later received the Mandate, it was Dao who laid its foundations—the signs were already apparent. Could this not be the response to virtue’s influence?

From the *Old Book of Tang*: Prince Song, Chengqi, and Prince Shen, Chengyi, were Emperor Xuanzong’s elder brothers. Prince Qi, Fan, and Prince Xue, Ye, were his younger brothers. Prince You, Shouli, was his cousin. The emperor cherished them with a fraternal affection unmatched in recent ages. In the early years of the Shengli era, when they left the palace to reside in separate mansions, they were granted estates in the Jishan Ward of the eastern capital, where the five brothers lived together in divided courtyards. In the first year of the Dazu era, they accompanied the emperor on his journey to the western capital and were bestowed residences in the Xingqing Ward. After the *Xiantian* era, the Xingqing estate—once the emperor’s private residence during his years in obscurity—was converted into a palace, with a tower erected in its southwest corner. On its western face was inscribed: *The Tower Where Flowers and Calyxes Shine Upon One Another*; on its southern face: *The Tower of Diligence in Governance and Devotion to Fundamentals*. Whenever the emperor heard the music of the princes, he would summon them to ascend the tower, where they feasted together on the same couch. At times, he would visit their mansions, bestowing gold and silks to deepen their joy. Prince Song, in particular, was reverent, cautious, and circumspect, never presuming to interfere in state affairs or form improper alliances. Thus, the emperor held him in especial esteem, once writing to him: “Emperor Wen of Wei composed a poem: *The western mountain rises high, / Its summit boundless in the sky. / Two immortal youths dwell there, / Neither eating nor drinking, yet fair. / They granted me a pill of light, / Radiant with five colors bright. / After four or five days’ grace, / My body grew light as a feathered race.* Yet I often ponder: what is the elixir that grants wings compared to the wings of flesh-and-blood brothers, bestowed by Heaven itself? Of old, Cao Zhi possessed the talent to succeed his father and the ability to govern, yet Emperor Wen barred him from court, driving him to die of sorrow. Before the Wei’s mandate was spent, it was usurped by Sima Xuanwang—was this the efficacy of the divine pill? Even the sagely Emperor Shun forgave the faults of his arrogant brother Xiang. This is the model for rulers, and I have never ceased to reflect upon it with admiration, often forgetting even to eat. Recently, I obtained this divine formula during my leisure. Now, I share this elixir with you, my brothers, that we may together preserve our longevity without end.”

The record states: In the *Yi Jing*, the ninth line of *Yi* reads: *“Sincere trust, a kind heart—ask not, for supreme fortune is assured. Sincere trust enriches my virtue.”* The *Xiang* commentary says: *“Sincere trust and a kind heart—ask not. Enriching my virtue, great is the fulfillment of will.”* Emperor Xuanzong’s achievements were vast and his virtue eminent, while the five princes responded with humility and compliance, aligning with the correctness of Heaven’s principle and the peace of human hearts. As limbs trust one another and hearts and qi resonate in harmony, the bonds of fraternal love arose naturally. In that era, the altars of state stood secure, the common people rejoiced, and great goodness and fortune were self-evident without need for inquiry. Since they harbored utmost sincerity and cherished his virtue, he was able to unfold his strategies, expand the Way of governance, and fully realize the aspirations of a great sovereign. Thus, the governance of the *Kaiyuan* era rivaled even that of the *Zhenguan* reign. What need was there for further question?

From the *Book of Tang*: Zhang Gongyi maintained nine generations of his family under one roof, a harmony comparable to that of the Qi state. Since the Sui and Tang dynasties, his household had been honored with imperial commendations. During the Linde era, Emperor Gaozong, while on his eastern progress to Mount Tai, visited Gongyi’s residence. Summoning him, the emperor inquired about the secret to his family’s harmony. Gongyi requested paper and brush to respond. He wrote the character *ren* (忍, forbearance) over a hundred times, conveying his meaning: discord in a clan arises when elders’ provisions are unequal or when juniors neglect propriety, leading to mutual reproach and strife. If all could practice forbearance, the household would flourish in harmony.

The record states: Forbearance is the heart of not being unbearable. The heart of not being unbearable is the heart of Heaven. A clan spanning nine generations is a matter of Heaven-endowed nature. Applying the heart of not being unbearable to an unchanging lineage, one regards the nine clans as a single person and nine generations as a single day. What could they not share together? Yet if forbearance is merely enforced by coercion, without the practice of compassion and love among them, then such forbearance is but a blade that wounds the heart. Zhang Gongyi’s intent was surely not of this kind.

Yuan Dexiu, styled Zizhi, was a man of simple sincerity who ate no meat in his youth. As he had not yet married while his parents were alive, he refused to take a wife afterward. Others said this would cut off his descendants.

Yuan Dexiu replied, "My elder brother has a son—our ancestors’ sacrifices are already secured. Why should I marry?" When his brother’s son came of age, he sought to arrange a marriage for him, but the family was mired in poverty, so he petitioned to become magistrate of Lushan. During Emperor Xuanzong’s revelry at the Five Phoenix Tower in the eastern capital, he commanded that all county magistrates and prefects within three hundred *li* gather with their musicians. Dexiu sent dozens of musicians, who linked arms and sang in unison. The emperor, hearing of this, marveled and sighed, "Truly the words of a worthy man!" All the salary he received, he spent on clothing and feeding the orphaned and destitute. When his term ended, he departed. Fond of the fine mountains and waters of Luhun, he settled there. He built no walls or gates, and his household had no servants or concubines. In years of famine, he might go without cooking a meal, yet he would play the zither with serene delight. He was especially skilled in literary composition. Fang Guan would often sigh, saying, "To see Zizhi’s countenance is to have all thoughts of fame and profit extinguished." Su Yuanming told others, "Born into this degenerate age, the one thing I do not regret is having known Yuan Zizhi." When he died, his younger brother Jie wept for him in inconsolable grief. Someone said, "Your mourning exceeds the bounds of propriety." Jie replied, "You speak of exceeding propriety, but you do not understand the depth of my feeling. A gentleman in youth has no fixed attachments, in maturity no rigid preferences, in old age no lingering ties, and in death no surplus. All the passions and indulgences that enthrall others—the gentleman was free of them. He lived sixty years without ever knowing the allure of feminine beauty, never owned ten *mu* of land, ten feet of a house, or a ten-year-old servant. He never wore whole cloth nor ate a meal with all five flavors. I mourn him to warn those sunk in dissipation, greed, flattery, and extravagance."

The record states: Observing Huishan’s character, he stood vast as the empty heavens, without a speck of dust to cloud him; he flowed deep as a limpid abyss, without a grain of sediment to sully him. That he personally nursed his brother’s child is a deed so rare in ancient or modern times as to defy emulation. Thus, it is not recorded here.

Yet *The Jin History* records that his disciple Gui wore mourning for three years, while *The Tang History* neither names Luzhan’s brother’s son nor mentions any observance of mourning rites—merely noting Cishan’s grief as extraordinary. In essence, grief is an expression of feeling, while mourning is an enactment of duty. Measured by the twin principles of compassionate nurture and the absence of posterity, the obligation to observe mourning is self-evident. Can it truly be that the histories are deficient in their records?

*The Song History* states: Emperor Taizu was by nature benevolent and filial, his character artless and unforced. When his younger brother, Prince Jin of Guangyi, fell gravely ill, the emperor personally went to attend him and applied moxa with his own hand. The prince, sensing the burn, winced in pain, whereupon the emperor took the moxa and applied it to himself, sharing in his brother’s suffering. In private conversation with his ministers, he often remarked: “Prince Jin moves with the stride of a dragon and the bearing of a tiger; one day he shall be a sovereign of a peaceful realm. His fortune and virtue surpass anything I possess.”

The record states: At the Chenqiao Incident, Prince Jin and his generals took the lead, and only afterward did the emperor learn of what had transpired—truly the first step in severing the Shang. Yet the dragon’s stride and tiger’s bearing were already manifest in the radiance of his countenance. And the act of sharing pain through moxa further confirmed his destiny as a sovereign of peace and virtue. As for the axe’s echo in the candlelight—Monk Wenyin lightly recorded it, awaiting Li Shou’s account, while Li Shou transmitted the doubt, leaving Hu Chen to lament. These two, being from Qiongshan, relied solely on the standard histories to refute the slander.

In my view, later generations sought to substantiate Taizong’s crimes solely on the grounds of his later treatment of his younger brother. Thus, they first cast suspicion on his regard for his elder brother and his feelings toward his nephew, ultimately imputing to him the sin of regicide. Yet Taizu’s benevolence and filial piety were innate and unfeigned; even if he had a worthless son, how could he have stooped to such an act? This record, grounded in reason, sets the matter right, and thus I have ventured to argue the case.

Fan Wenzhenggong admonished his sons: “When I was poor, your mother and I cared for my parents. Your mother personally prepared the meals, yet the delicacies we offered never fully satisfied them. Now, having attained high office and generous emoluments, I wish to provide for my parents, but they are no longer here, and your mother has also passed away long ago. What I most regret is that I cannot bear to let you alone enjoy the pleasures of wealth and rank.

Among my clan in Wu Prefecture, I have far more relatives than most. Though there are degrees of kinship, in the eyes of our ancestors, all are equally their descendants, without distinction. If our ancestors made no such distinctions, how can I fail to succor those who suffer hunger and cold? Moreover, our family has accumulated virtue for over a hundred years, and only now has it manifested in me, elevating me to high office. If I alone enjoy wealth and rank while neglecting my clan, how shall I face our ancestors in the underworld? What countenance shall I have to enter the ancestral temple?”

Thereupon, he ensured that his stipends and gifts were regularly distributed among his kinsmen. From his surplus salary, he purchased a thousand *mu* of fertile land near the capital, naming it the “Charitable Estate.”

The record states: This was Wenzhenggong’s aspiration before attaining office and his practice after attaining it. Since the invention of writing, only he has achieved such distinction. In pondering the reasons, I find four: first, the impartiality of his heart; second, the virtue of his successive generations; third, the generosity of the prevailing customs; and fourth, the sagacity of the sovereign’s virtue.

From his days as a scholar, he was “the first to worry for the realm’s troubles and the last to enjoy its pleasures.” Such insight naturally gave rise to such magnanimity—this was the impartiality of his heart. His son, Pure Jade, inherited his resolve and carried on his work; how could he not have made his father’s impartiality his own? This was the virtue of his successive generations.

Today, were one to purchase a thousand *mu* of fertile land near the capital, not only would envious slander arise, but one might also fear unnecessary complications—accusations of overreach by the powerful, entanglements in debt, disputes over corvée labor, and harassment by petty officials—how could one rest easy and uphold lofty principles? This was the generosity of the prevailing customs.

Moreover, Wenzhenggong stood firm in court, upright and unyielding, advancing and retiring with integrity, never currying favor. Had he not served under a supremely sagacious sovereign, how could he have preserved himself to the end and provided for his clan? This was the sagacity of the sovereign’s virtue.

In later times, misfortune befell some families: clansmen vied for precedence, quarreled over right and wrong, or, when opportunity arose, shrank in cowardice and sighed; when calamity struck, they willingly endured humiliation. How could such petty striving compare to the ancients? Here lies the divide between public and private motives, the distinction between worthy and unworthy descendants, the contrast between noble and base customs, and the rise and fall of the age—matters far exceeding the mere relief of hardship.

Sima Dan and his younger brother Guang shared a bond of profound affection. When Dan was nearly eighty, Guang tended to him as to a revered father and cared for him as for an infant. After every meal, he would ask, “Are you not hungry?” At the slightest chill, he would stroke his brother’s back and say, “Is your clothing not too thin?” Later, Guang resided in Luoyang while Dan lived in Xia County. Dan’s estate boasted fine gardens and ponds, and Guang visited once a year to pay his respects; Dan, in turn, traveled to Luoyang to see Guang. Whatever Guang discussed regarding state affairs, Dan would invariably offer his counsel.

When Guang was summoned to the post of *Menxia Shilang*, he firmly declined the appointment. Dan invoked the great principle, saying: “All your life, you have recited the Way of Yao and Shun, aspiring to guide your sovereign. Now, when the time is ripe, to refuse is not the proper course for advancing or retiring.” Guang then reversed his decision and set out. At the time, the realm feared he would never emerge from seclusion, but upon hearing these words, all rejoiced, exclaiming: “These are the words of a true elder!”

The record states: In the hexagram *Tongren*, the second line, central and correct in its position, responds to the ninth line above—does this not describe Guang? The fifth line, strong and central, responds to the second below—does this not describe Dan? Thus, one illuminates the sovereign and delights the realm, while the other, through sincerity and rectitude, upholds the great righteousness of the world. A hundred generations hence, their example remains worthy of contemplation.

Master Cheng Yi’s preface to *The Conduct of Master Mingdao* states:

Endowed with extraordinary nature and nurtured by the Way, the Master was pure as refined gold and warm as fine jade. Broad yet disciplined, harmonious yet unyielding, his loyalty and sincerity pierced metal and stone, while his filial piety and fraternal love reached the spirits. To behold his countenance in meeting others was to feel the warmth of spring’s sun; to hear his words was to receive the nourishment of timely rain. His heart was open and luminous, his insight penetrating without obstruction. To fathom his depths was to gaze upon the boundless vastness of the sea and sky; to exhaust his virtue, even the most eloquent words would fall short of description.

In his own conduct, he governed inwardly with reverence and acted outwardly with forbearance. He regarded goodness as if it originated in himself and refrained from imposing on others what he himself did not desire. Dwelling in the broadest dwelling and walking the great Way, his words carried substance and his actions followed constancy. He discerned the divisions of things and understood human relationships. He knew that to fully realize one’s nature and fulfill destiny must begin with fraternal devotion, and that to fathom the divine and comprehend transformation arises from mastery of ritual and music. He distinguished the heterodox from the seemingly correct, resolved confusions that had persisted for a hundred generations, and attained a depth of principle unmatched since the Qin and Han dynasties.

The record states: The hexagram *Daxu* embodies strength, sincerity, and radiant brilliance. Thus, the supreme virtue of Bo Chun was not mere discourse, nor was the profound scholarship of Zheng Shu excessive praise. Like auspicious clouds on a joyous day, his light illumined all quarters; like gentle winds and sweet rains, his influence nourished the four directions. In establishing virtue and leaving teachings, none could surpass him.

*The Four Ming Gazetteer* records: During the imperial dynasty, the Yang brothers of the Six Ministries—descendants of their father Qi Yun—were Zi Cheng, Zi Nian, and Zi Xi. Zi Cheng, styled Meidu, had a son, Shouchen, who rose to Vice Minister of Personnel, while his grandson Shoulu became Minister of Personnel in Nanjing. Zi Nian, styled Jiansu, had a son, Shousui, who served as Minister of Works. Zi Xi, styled Weian, had a son, Shouyu, who became Right Administration Commissioner of Guangxi, and a grandson, Maoyuan, who served as Vice Minister of Justice, while Maoren became Surveillance Commissioner of Sichuan. All were sons of Wenyi.

Qi Yun mastered the *Book of Changes*, the *Book of Documents*, and the *Book of Songs*, and devoted himself to the learning of Lian, Luo, Guan, and Min. His moral character was steadfast and upright, his practice sincere and unwavering. In his later years, his virtue deepened, and he took the additional name Sicheng.

Wenyi, styled Jingchuan, and his younger brother, styled Bichuan, were filial by nature and treated their brothers with amiable respect, as if they were teachers and friends. From afar, they carried forward the legacy of the Confucian predecessors; up close, they upheld the transmission of their family’s learning. In Siming, since Yang Cihu studied under Xiangshan and Huang Shufa studied under Kaoting, both had distinguished themselves by embodying the unity of substance and function, the integration of the manifest and the subtle—scholars revered them as exemplars. Qi Yun truly inherited their tradition, and Wenyi further expanded it.

In the beginning, they embraced the classical texts to seek the Sage beyond mere words, rejecting mere philology and literary embellishment as true ability. Thus, in self-discipline, family governance, official duties, and interactions with others, they treated the old and young with equal respect, never indulging in the slightest laxity. Their descendants all strictly observed ritual propriety, refusing to yield to unrighteousness, and held the ancients as their unshakable standard.

Wenyi once firmly declined a position in the Ministry of Personnel, saying: “The Ministry of Personnel’s promotions and demotions are the focus of a hundred officials’ grievances. Even someone of Wang Shu’s reputation attracted criticism—how could I, with my inflexible and unsophisticated nature, bear such a responsibility?” He also stated: “A ruler may change, but history must not be erased. Former court historians failed to record the reign of Emperor Jianwen, leaving the reforms of those years and the loyal ministers who served him lost to obscurity. If we compile these records now, we may yet fill the gaps in the national history.” When Emperor Jingtai was restored to the throne, the *Veritable Records* still referred to him as the “Deposed Prince of Langye”—this should be corrected. Furthermore, the old practice of withholding memorials from the emperor should be abolished, and all such documents should be submitted to the Historiography Institute. These were all words of wisdom.

The record states: Song Qianhan’s refusal to serve as chief minister and Yang Jingchuan’s refusal to serve in the Ministry of Personnel—both were Confucian scholars of the Daoist tradition in our Zhe region. Those who restrain themselves and exhaust their own capacities are rarely seen in this age. Thus, they are recorded here.

*Hongdao Record*, Volume Eight, concludes.
*Hongdao Record*, Volume Nine: Benevolence in Friendship.

*The Tongshu* records Master Zhou’s words: “Lofty in the Dao, profound in virtue, boundless in transformative teaching—truly one with Heaven and Earth. Aligning with the four seasons, who but Confucius could this be? The Dao’s loftiness is like Heaven: yang. Virtue’s profundity is like Earth: yin. The boundlessness of transformative teaching is like the four seasons: the Five Phases. Is not Confucius the Supreme Polarity?”

The record states: This is the role of the eternal Teacher of All Ages, sharing the same exalted honor as Yao and Shun. Thus, Zai Wo said, “The Master surpasses Yao and Shun,” and Zigong said, “Since the birth of humankind, none has equaled Confucius.” Yet never before has he been directly likened to the Supreme Polarity. Is there a basis for this? The *Book of Changes* passed through three sages, but it was Confucius who first unveiled the hidden mysteries of the Prior and Posterior Heaven. And it was Master Zhou who unveiled the hidden mysteries of Confucius’ Supreme Polarity.

Thus, before the Supreme Polarity divided, it dwelled in the realm of “not knowing, not perceiving,” yet attained the subtlety of “no sound, no scent.” After it divided, it stood before the formation of form and qi, yet operated within the realm where form and qi exist—truly the pivot of creation, the root of all things. Why is Confucius the Supreme Polarity? Before its activation, the nature of benevolence, righteousness, propriety, and wisdom resides within, all-encompassing. Once activated, the virtue of centrality, correctness, harmony, and joy responds to stimuli without fail—truly the wellspring of sincerity and the master key of the myriad transformations.

Viewed in its radiant manifestation, Heaven generates the myriad things through yang, and its Dao is manifest. Yet the sage gazes upward, ever higher, delving ever deeper—how could it be exhausted? Viewed in its tranquil profundity and rootedness, Earth completes the myriad things through yin, and its virtue is subtle. Yet the sage’s sincerity runs deep, his benevolence abyssal—where is its limit?

The four seasons proceed: spring, summer, autumn, winter. The four teachings correspond: culture, conduct, loyalty, trust. Their way of nurturing each according to its capacity, assigning each thing to its proper place, is like the Five Phases, each generating according to its nature. Thus, in synthesis, the Master’s person fully embodies the Supreme Polarity, uniting the myriad things as one. In analysis, each thing attains completion through its own way, each possessing its own Supreme Polarity. That he surpasses Yao and Shun lies precisely in his boundless transformative teaching. That none since the birth of humankind has equaled him lies in his lofty and profound virtue. Though their words differ, their principle converges—these three disciples speak as one.

When Yan Yuan asked about benevolence, the Master said, “To master oneself and return to ritual is benevolence.” Elsewhere, he added, “Master oneself and return to ritual, and the world will turn toward benevolence.” Is benevolence to be sought from others, or from oneself? Yan Yuan asked, “May I inquire into its details?” The Master said, “Look not at what is contrary to ritual, listen not to what is contrary to ritual, speak not of what is contrary to ritual, act not in ways contrary to ritual.” Yan Yuan replied, “Though I am not quick-witted, I shall strive to put these words into practice.”

The record states: This is the beginning of the Confucian school’s discourse on benevolence—what is called “penetrating above and below.” That the world turns toward benevolence is the achievement of Yao and Shun. Not a single person fails to find their place, not a single thing lies outside its inherent nature—this is what is meant by “when released, it fills the Six Directions.” To master oneself and return to ritual is the complete work of sages and worthies. Not a single thought fails to align with Heaven, not a single act fails to accord with ritual—this is what is meant by “when gathered, it retreats into profound concealment.” This is the ultimate attainment of the Way of benevolence, the abstruse subtlety of the learning of the heart—known to none but oneself. To know what others cannot, and to do what others cannot—what need is there for anything external? The Master’s instruction to Yan Yuan left no further mysteries.

When those who favor the lofty rush toward the “Four Spirits” and the “Nine Possessions,” and those who cling to the humble remain mired in incompleteness, how wise is Yan Yuan, who asked for its details! For “truly reverent” was Yao, and “truly sincere” was Shun. To master one’s kind begins with seeing, hearing, speaking, and acting. Thus, first clarify the four details, extend the four faculties, and only then can one’s actions serve as the world’s Dao, one’s words as the world’s law, and one’s conduct as the world’s standard. The Master’s answer had its origins here.

Not merely asking about benevolence but earnestly seeking its details, not merely seeking details but putting these words into practice—did Yan Yuan take the role of a supreme sage upon himself? Otherwise, why would he say, “Shun—what sort of person was he? I—what sort of person am I? Let those who would act be like this.”

The Master said, “Hui’s heart does not stray from benevolence for three months. The others may attain it for a month, or even a day.” The record states: I observe the true substance of the Confucian school’s encouragement, the teaching that exhorts all ages to earnestness. Though eighteen hundred years have passed since the sage, we may still measure ourselves against it.

That “three months” does not stray refers not to the minor changes of Heaven’s cycles passing without adherence, nor does “a day or a month” imply progress today and regression tomorrow. Rather, Yan Yuan’s deep immersion and purity allowed him to remain unwavering all day, exhausting his capacity and standing firm—how, after three months of unbroken continuity in the fullness of Heavenly principle, could others match him?

The others may have been nearly as perceptive as Yan Yuan, yet their discernment of goodness was not refined. Their virtue may have matched his in kind, yet their excellence and greatness fell short. Some, in a single day, attained clarity and purity, their Heavenly sagehood shining bright. Others, within a month, strayed but returned, with no regrets. Though they could not yet rest at the center of benevolence, they were not the sort of gentlemen who lacked it. This was the sage’s profound intent, not a slight against those who asked.

The Master said, “How worthy is Hui! With a single basket of rice to eat, a single gourd of water to drink, living in a humble alley—others would find such hardship unbearable, yet Hui never alters his joy. How worthy is Hui!”

Recorded commentary: Here we see how he went three months without straying from benevolence. For coarse food is not a matter of a day or two, nor is a humble alley a temporary circumstance. Others cannot endure such hardship, and so cannot long remain at ease. But Hui—with Heavenly principle shining bright and selfish desires stilled to nothing—felt his heart expand and his body at peace, forgetting his poverty. Seeing the greatness, his mind was at ease and nothing lacked. Thus it is said: he never altered his joy. This aligns with the meaning of the phrase “poor yet rejoicing” in the other passage. Those who study well should consider them together.

The Master said, “Eating coarse food, drinking plain water, resting one’s head on a bent arm—joy lies therein. Wealth and honor gained through unrighteousness are to me like floating clouds.”

Recorded commentary: Here lies the distinction between Confucius and Yan Hui, which those who have not yet grasped the Way fail to understand. The phrase “never alters his joy” may not always hold true. But “joy lies therein” suggests that the Heavenly principle is boundless, without form or limit—yet in truth, the difference is not so great. Confucius said, “Since I had Hui, my disciples have grown ever closer.” Recorded commentary: The phrase “grown ever closer” does not refer to mutual observation and emulation, nor to following in another’s footsteps. Rather, when words are never idle, even casual remarks are not wasted. When nothing fails to bring delight, earnest reminders are not empty words. Seeing his progress without end, how could one not be moved? Returning in joy to reflect in private, one finds ample cause for gladness. This is what is meant by “Is this not also joy?” Such is the art of patient guidance, so thorough that one cannot help but treat the teacher as a father—indeed, one cannot help but do so. How could they not grow ever closer?

When Yan Yuan died, the Master wept bitterly. His followers said, “Master, you grieve excessively.” He replied, “Do I grieve excessively? If not for this man, for whom would I grieve?” Recorded commentary: When Yan Yuan died, Heaven did not cherish the Dao. When the unicorn was captured in the west of Lu, Earth did not cherish its treasure. Both events were enough to move the Master to grief. When Yan Yuan died, the Master said, “Alas! Heaven has bereft me. Heaven has bereft me.” Recorded commentary: The sage’s person was the vessel of the Dao. The Dao does not speak of itself, nor does the person speak of the Dao. Now that the Dao has no transmitter, it is as if I have been bereft. Yet how could the sage abruptly claim that all generations must revere him? “Heaven has bereft me” expresses the utmost love for the Dao. That all generations revere him arises from their true admiration for the Dao. The Dao endures through the ages, and thus the sage does not die.
