Here we see how weighty Yan Hui’s role was in transmitting the Dao, how vital the bond between teacher and friend in preserving benevolence—this is the ultimate meaning of the Five Constant Relationships.

Master Zeng said, “A scholar cannot but be resolute and steadfast, for his burden is heavy and his path long. Taking benevolence as one’s task—is this not a heavy burden? Enduring until death—is this not a long path?” Recorded commentary: Here we see Master Zeng’s firmness. To take these words as one’s mission is to strive to fulfill them. To take benevolence as one’s task is to hold fast to it—this is the capacity of the highest wisdom. Thus it is said: “Vast and steadfast”—their purpose is one and the same.

Zhong Gong asked about benevolence. The Master said, “When you go out your door, act as if receiving an honored guest. When employing the people, act as if officiating a great sacrifice. What you do not desire, do not impose on others. Let there be no resentment in the state, no resentment in the family.” Zhong Gong said, “Though I am not quick-witted, I ask to take these words as my mission.” Recorded commentary: The Master often praised Yong, saying he was fit to govern. Thus he instructed him in the duties of governance, which are the affairs of a ruler. Even now, reflecting on these words, we can still glimpse Zhong Gong’s demeanor as a model of conduct—how much more those who personally experienced his magnanimous, unhurried, and dignified bearing? Among the disciples of the sage, Yan Hui and Ran Yong were both counted among the virtuous. With such words, understanding comes at first hearing, and the strength to practice them follows. How could one not ask to take them as one’s mission?

Someone said, “Yong is benevolent but not eloquent.” The Master said, “What use is eloquence? Those who overwhelm others with glib speech often incur resentment. Not knowing whether he is benevolent—what use is eloquence?” Recorded commentary: Benevolence is the opposite of glibness. Glibness is a flaw in benevolence. With Yong’s reverence, he maintained self-restraint and extended forbearance to others, leaving no room for resentment. Thus the remark was made. At the time, people knew that benevolence was a fine thing. If one also possessed eloquence, it would be unattainable—this was not a matter of begrudging it. Moreover, the world often mistakes glibness for talent, not realizing its harm. If one of virtue speaks, it is not glibness. Thus the Master repeated, “What use is eloquence?” to thoroughly enlighten the questioner. When he said, “Not knowing whether he is benevolent,” it was like Meng Wubo’s question about Zilu and Ran Qiu—he was not denying their benevolence. Readers should ponder this deeply.

Sima Niu asked about benevolence. The Master said, “The benevolent person is cautious in speech.” “Cautious in speech—can this be called benevolence?” “When practice is difficult, can speech not be cautious?” Recorded commentary: Niu’s repeated question was not without reason. He had seen what Yan Hui and Ran Qiu were taught—earnest and weighty admonitions. Yet what he was told concerned only words and tone. He did not realize that “do not speak what is contrary to ritual” and the steps of self-discipline are the essentials of benevolence. It was not merely about being talkative or hasty, which prompted this response. If one can be careful in speech and not reckless, extending this to what is seen and heard, maintaining vigilance in every thought, then self-discipline and the return to ritual begin here.

Alas, he never heard the words of seeking instruction in affairs, nor grasped the meaning of "difficulty" in practice—merely fretting and fearing, unaware that benevolence arises from oneself. This is why the learning of Yan [Hui] and Ran [Qiu] was so difficult.

When Fan Chi asked about benevolence, the Master said: “In your dwelling, be reverent; in handling affairs, be respectful; in dealing with others, be loyal. Even among the barbarian tribes, these must not be abandoned.”

Recorded commentary: This is most immediately relevant to learners. For one cannot yet receive great guests as if they were present, yet must first conduct oneself with reverence; cannot yet perform grand sacrifices as if bearing them, yet must first handle affairs with respect; cannot yet refrain from imposing one’s desires on others, yet must first deal with others in loyalty. As for the barbarians—this is spoken in profound terms. Fan Chi was coarse and uncouth within the Master’s gate; perhaps he could be exhorted to these virtues, but among barbarians, even this would be impossible. Here the Master deeply admonished his flaws, unlike the saying “no resentment in the state, no resentment in the family.”

When Fan Chi asked about benevolence, the Master said: “The benevolent person first endures hardship and later reaps reward—this may be called benevolence.”

Recorded commentary: I observe that among those in Confucius’ school who repeatedly asked about benevolence, none did so as often as Fan Chi, yet he ultimately failed to transmit the Dao. Why? Because the learning of the sagely gate is pursued for its own sake. One may hear of planning for the Dao without planning for food, but never of requesting instruction in farming—he who plows will hunger. Nor of requesting instruction in gardening—even those who wander within the sagely gate remain thus. Yet Dong Zhongshu of the Han could understand that righteousness is pursued without scheming for profit, and the Dao is illuminated without calculating gain. Can this be regarded as ordinary? Let scholars examine this closely.

When Fan Chi asked about benevolence, the Master said: “Love others.” He asked about wisdom, and the Master said: “Know others.” Fan Chi did not understand. The Master said: “Elevate the upright and place them above the crooked, so that the crooked may be made straight.” Fan Chi withdrew and saw Zixia, saying: “Just now, I saw the Master and asked about wisdom. He said: ‘Elevate the upright and place them above the crooked, so that the crooked may be made straight.’ What does this mean?” Zixia said: “How rich these words are! When Shun ruled the world, he chose from the multitude and elevated Gaoyao—those without benevolence withdrew. When Tang ruled the world, he chose from the multitude and elevated Yi Yin—those without benevolence withdrew.”

Recorded commentary: I observe that Zixia’s words not only elucidated what the Master had left unsaid but also remain irrefutable through the ages. Why must those who rule the world elevate the upright and place them above the crooked? Because right and wrong, good and evil, are ever in opposition. When the wicked advance, the upright become wicked; when the upright advance, the wicked are transformed into uprightness—the critical moment allows no delay. When the Tang dynasty ruled the world, it elevated Wei Zheng, and the customs of the Sui were entirely reformed; when the Song dynasty ruled the world, it elevated Sima Guang, and the policies of Xifeng and Feng suddenly changed. Later, however, the appointment of a single Li Linfu led to the immediate expulsion of the upright, and the appointment of a single Zhang Dun filled the court with petty men. The Master’s words must have lamented the lack of such elevation in Lu. Otherwise, why would he have repeatedly admonished Duke Ai with such urgency? Yet his meaning was vast and profound, concealed rather than revealed, nurtured rather than exhausted. The finest minds within his gate debated and questioned one another, ultimately bringing it to light. Later, [Zi] Shang said “increase,” while Fan Chi remained unenlightened. Thus, the difference between comprehension and incomprehension lies in progress—or the critical moment of advancement or stagnation.

Zigong said: “If one could broadly bestow benefits upon the people and rescue the multitude, how would that be? Could it be called benevolence?” The Master said: “Why stop at benevolence? It would surely be sageliness. Even Yao and Shun would have found this difficult.” The benevolent person, desiring to establish himself, establishes others; desiring to reach understanding, helps others reach understanding. Being able to draw analogies from what is near at hand may be called the method of benevolence.

Recorded commentary: Zigong’s nature approached the highest wisdom, yet he could not fully enter the realm of the sage because he pursued lofty and distant goals. Zengzi’s endowment was limited by his dullness, yet he ultimately transmitted the Dao because he could draw analogies from what was near. Many asked questions at the time. They proposed scenarios and framed their words as if they had gained some insight, yet they did not understand that writings may be broad, but bestowal cannot; love may be widespread, but benevolence cannot. Zigong’s learning had grasped the broad but not the essential, so it was fitting that his approach was diffuse rather than precise. “Desiring to establish” refers to standing firm; “desiring to reach understanding” refers to leaping forward. Both are means of restraining oneself through ritual. If this is taken as a boundary, later generations still speak of “broad love” as benevolence. Yet this is not a failure of the original Dao, but a failure to perceive the Dao through its manifestations. To perceive the Dao through its manifestations is to fail in restraining oneself through ritual. And so it should be.

Zigong asked about practicing benevolence.

The Master said: "A craftsman who wishes to do his work well must first sharpen his tools. When dwelling in a state, serve its worthy ministers and befriend its virtuous scholars."

The Record states: At this time, Zeng [Dian, courtesy name Zigong] had already come to realize that what was right today had been wrong yesterday. Thus he again asked about practicing benevolence—just as one might request instruction in a task. Now, "desiring to establish oneself and establishing others, desiring to reach understanding and enabling others to do so"—this is not something to be done lightly. With worthy ministers above to guide, support, encourage, and exhort, and with virtuous scholars below to influence, nurture, and refine, one will unconsciously stand firm and leap forward. Without such aid, one stands alone. How can one who leads others while isolated and uninformed serve as a model? This is the deep fear I, a humble student, now feel—seeking those to serve and befriend yet finding none.

Meng Wubo asked: "Is Zilu benevolent?"
The Master said: "I do not know."
He asked again.
The Master said: "You [Zilu] could be entrusted with military levies in a state of a thousand chariots, but I do not know whether he is benevolent. What of Qiu [Ran You]?"
The Master said: "Qiu could serve as steward of a city of a thousand households or a noble house of a hundred chariots, but I do not know whether he is benevolent. What of Chi [Gongxi Hua]?"
The Master said: "Chi, girded and standing in court, could engage with guests and envoys, but I do not know whether he is benevolent."

The Record states: Wubo was the son of Yizi and a minister of Lu. His understanding of benevolence had already taken shape—such as the idea that "broad bestowal is difficult." At the time, Zilu, Ran You, and Gongxi Chi served in his household, and observing their bearing and interactions, all showed potential for achievement. Thus he asked about benevolence, knowing that in the Master’s school, benevolence was the foremost virtue. The Master spoke according to reality: one could be entrusted with military levies, stewardship, or diplomatic duties, yet still not be called benevolent. For benevolence is the complete virtue of the original heart, not easily spoken of in the Master’s school. Talent, however, is what the three families needed, and such men were not easily found. Thus the Master neither diminished the three disciples’ true qualities nor lightly affirmed the essence of benevolence. The exchanges of the Sage may indeed serve as a model for all ages.

Zilu said: "I wish to share my carriages, horses, and light furs with friends, wearing them out without regret."

The Record states: Zilu’s worn hempen robe and his carriages, horses, and light furs—was there a difference? No. What he did not feel ashamed of was his resolve to restrain himself. What he felt no regret about was his magnanimous benevolence toward others. One must first hold fast to the resolve not to feel shame, and only then can one place the heart that feels no regret. Thus, strutting through the lanes would be despised by all with understanding, while appearing refined like a pearl in its shell would be something men of resolve would not do—how could this be much for You [Zilu]? This is why he wore them out without regret.

The Master said: "As for sageliness and benevolence, how dare I claim them? Yet in ceaselessly practicing and tirelessly teaching others, one may be said to have attained this much."
Gongxi Hua said: "This is precisely what we disciples cannot learn."

The Record states: Here, the term "benevolence" refers to the undivided whole, the inherent nature of the Dao of Heaven—different from the word-by-word, matter-by-matter exchanges in the Master’s daily teachings. The Master’s refusal to claim it was not mere modesty in response to others’ praise, nor was it simply a humble turn of phrase. "Ceaselessly practicing and tirelessly teaching others" is the pure and unceasing expression of Heaven’s own nature. To hastily claim sageliness and benevolence for oneself would not only confuse learners but also, as long as a single breath remains, allow no slackening in this resolve. Only one who embodies the whole without ceasing can achieve this—how could it be something disciples could learn?

Zizhang asked Confucius about benevolence.
Confucius said: "One who can practice five things in the world may be called benevolent."
He asked what they were.
The Master said: "Reverence, magnanimity, trustworthiness, diligence, and kindness. Reverence avoids insult; magnanimity wins the multitude; trustworthiness gains others’ trust; diligence brings success; kindness enables one to employ others."

The Record states: Zizhang’s question was not like Yuan’s request for specifics. Thus the Master spoke of what he lacked. Reverence is the opposite of arrogance; magnanimity, of cruelty; trustworthiness, of deception; diligence, of indolence; kindness, of harm. Given Zizhang’s tendency to focus on externals and seek lofty heights, he might mistake imposing presence for reverence, lack of resistance for magnanimity, superficial charm for trustworthiness, haste for diligence, and lax commands for kindness—rendering the effects of the five virtues indistinct. This was the profound intent of the Master’s guidance, a fine remedy for his flaws, sharing the same purpose as other passages on the five virtues and four vices.

Master Zeng said: "How imposing is Zizhang! Yet it is difficult to practice benevolence alongside him."
Ziyou said: "My friend Zizhang is capable of what is difficult, yet he has not attained benevolence."

The Record states: The teaching of the Sage’s school took seeking benevolence as its aim, and the learning of the seventy disciples invariably took the Dao of benevolence as its end. Compared with Master Zeng’s "I daily examine myself on three counts" and Ziyou’s "learning the Dao and loving others," their view of Zizhang was as distant as the heavens from the earth. If judged by the standards of later generations’ friendships—where one either flatters or competes—who would admonish another’s faults and prescribe remedies? This shows the true meaning of "using friendship to assist benevolence": neither flattering nor concealing faults, demanding what is difficult, and correcting what is lacking. Such a way is of utmost importance, and such a person is of closest kinship. Thus it concludes.

The *Book of Han* states: Dong Zhongshu, from his youth, was diligent in study and ardent in pursuit of learning. Lowering the curtains to lecture and recite, his disciples transmitted the teachings in order of seniority, and some never even saw his face. For three years, he did not glance at the garden.

Such was his dedication—his every advance and retreat, every gesture and bearing, adhered strictly to ritual propriety. Scholars all revered him as their teacher. During Emperor Jing’s reign, he served as Academician, and later as Chancellor to the King of Jiangdu, who was the Emperor’s elder brother and by nature arrogant and fond of martial prowess. Zhongshu guided him with righteousness, and the King held him in deep respect.

After some time, the King asked: “King Goujian of Yue and his ministers Xie Pu and Fan Li plotted to attack and destroy Wu. I consider these three men of Yue to be paragons of benevolence. What do you think?” Zhongshu replied: “In former times, the Lord of Lu asked Liuxia Hui: ‘I wish to attack Qi. What do you say?’ Liuxia Hui replied: ‘You must not.’ Upon returning home, he wore a troubled expression, saying: ‘I have heard that one does not consult a benevolent man when planning to attack a state. How could such a question have been put to me?’ He was merely asked, and yet he felt shame. How much more should one feel shame for employing deceit to destroy Wu, a state of ten thousand chariots? In this case, there was not a single act of benevolence. The benevolent man rectifies righteousness without scheming for profit, illuminates the Way without calculating gain. Thus, in the school of Confucius, even a child of five feet would feel shame in praising the Five Hegemons, for they placed deceit and force before benevolence and righteousness.”

A later note records: Earlier scholars said that Zhongshu possessed the bearing of a true Confucian. I humbly suggest that he had ascended the hall, though he had not yet entered the inner chamber. Why? Even Fan Chi, a distinguished disciple of the Sage’s school, remained mired in vulgar concerns of near-term advantage. The Master taught him to ‘first endure hardship, then reap reward,’ yet he never fully grasped the lesson. By contrast, in Zhongshu’s three memorials—*The Enlightened Ruler*, *The Two Ministers*, and *The Arrogant Monarch*—he embraced hardship without thought of reward, never displaying the slightest resentment. Compared to Jia Yi, one sees in him no trace of envy or stinginess. This is precisely what it means to ‘rectify righteousness without scheming for profit, illuminate the Way without calculating gain.’ These were not empty words without substance, but the lived reality of his conduct. Even Guan Zhong and Yan Ying would feel shame to be ranked beside him. His lowering of the curtain to lecture and recite brought him close to the joy of ‘daily practice,’ and scholars revered him as their teacher, fulfilling the delight of ‘friends coming from afar.’ Was he not then a gentleman who ‘though others knew him not, felt no resentment’? Though seated beside the apricot altar, he would have felt no shame in keeping pace with the other disciples.

The *Later Han Book* states: Huang Xian was fourteen when Xin Shu encountered him at an inn. Struck by his extraordinary presence, Xin bowed and spoke with him, finding himself unable to leave. He said to Xian: “You are my teacher and model.” Later, when Xin visited Yuan Hong, he asked: “Does your state have a Yan Hui?” Hong replied: “Have you seen our Shu Du?” A man of the same commandery, Dai Liang, was highly talented and haughty, yet in Xian’s presence, he always composed himself with gravity. Upon returning home, he would be lost in thought, as if something were missing. His mother asked: “Have you been with that cow-doctor’s son again?” He replied: “When I do not see Shu Du, I feel myself his inferior.” Observing the man, one found him ever before one’s gaze, yet suddenly behind—so profound as to be unfathomable.

Chen Fan and Zhou Ju often remarked to each other: “In the intervals between our meetings with Huang Sheng, the sprouts of vulgarity and stinginess take root in our hearts.”

When Guo Linzong was young and traveled to Runan, he first visited Yuan Hong but left without staying the night. Proceeding to Xian’s home, he lingered for days before returning. Someone asked Linzong about this. Linzong replied: “Fenggao’s capacity is like a vast overflow—though clear, it is easy to embrace. Shudu’s is boundless as a thousand-acre expanse of waves: unstirred, it does not settle; disturbed, it does not muddy—immeasurable.”

Xian was initially recommended as a Filial and Incorrupt candidate and later summoned to public office. A friend urged him to serve, and though Xian did not refuse, he briefly went to the capital and then returned, ultimately taking no position. The world styled him “The Recluse Summoned.”

*Recorded:* Fan [lacuna] remarked: “Though no record of Huang Xian’s words or manner survives, all gentlemen who met him submitted without exception. He had deeply transcended vulgarity and stinginess, embodying the Dao in its fullness and preserving his nature whole—nothing can be said of him. My great-grandfather, the Venerable Mu, held that Xian’s brilliance lay in his dwelling in perfect harmony with the abyss. His resemblance to the Dao is unfathomable in depth, his distinction of purity and turbidity beyond debate. Were he placed among the disciples of Confucius, he would nearly approach the mark. Among the scholars of the Eastern Capital, I have esteemed none but Xian.”

*Hongdao Lu*, Volume Nine concludes.
*Hongdao Lu*, Volume Ten: Benevolence in Friendship.

Master Zhou Dunyi of Lianxi in the Song awakened to the Dao at a remarkably young age. His character was lofty, his heart as untrammeled as the radiant wind after rain or the moon emerging from clouds, his refined spirit drawn to forests and valleys. Never constrained by others, he was indifferent to fame yet earnest in pursuing his aspirations; sparing in seeking blessings yet generous in winning the people’s hearts; frugal in personal comfort yet lavish in extending kindness to all beings; disdainful of worldly acclaim yet cherishing friendship with the ancients. He once declared: “The scholar aspires to worthiness, the worthy to sageliness, the sage to Heaven. Yi Yin and Yan Yuan were great worthies. Emulate Yi Yin’s aspirations, study what Yanzi studied. Surpass them and you become a sage; match them and you become worthy; fall short and you still preserve an honorable name.”

Noticing the grass before his window left uncut, he was asked why. He replied: “It shares the same intent as my own heart—within my breast, the vitality of life surges boundlessly.” He composed the *Taiji Diagram* and *Penetrating the Book of Changes*, among other works, which profoundly grasped the esoteric teachings left untransmitted for a thousand years, thus continuing the lineage of the Dao from Yao, Shun, Yu, Tang, Kings Wen and Wu, the Duke of Zhou, and Confucius.

Cheng Hao of Henan sent his two sons, Hao and Yi, to study under him. He often instructed them to seek the joy of Confucius and Yanzi, asking: “What is the source of their delight?” The learning of the two Chengs thus originated here. Cheng Hao later remarked: “Since I saw Master Zhou Dunyi returning from gazing at the wind and playing with the moon, I have harbored the same sentiment as ‘I would be like Zeng Dian.’”

Hou Shisheng, who had not yet awakened during his studies with Master Yi of the Yi River, visited Lianxi and stayed for three nights of conversation before returning. Master Yi marveled: “Had he not studied with Zhou Dunyi, how could he have so swiftly absorbed such goodness and enlightened others?”

*Recorded:* The joy of Confucius and Yanzi lay in their dragon-like virtue, centered and upright. The noble person, whose virtue harmonizes with Heaven and Earth, moves with boundless ease, flowing in unison with all things—how could it be measured? Dunyi aspired to this dragon-like virtue, though it remained concealed. The gentleman’s conduct is the cultivation of virtue, as gentle as a balmy breeze, as luminous as the bright moon—how could it be forced or feigned? This was likely Heaven’s gift, bestowed to inaugurate the transmission of the Dao’s learning for ten thousand generations. What he gained from observation and reflection extended beyond merely chanting to the wind and playing with the moon; even strolling among flowers and willows was all part of the same Dao. This is the marvel of the sage’s praise—resonance of like voices, the affinity of like qi—not to be equated with mere words or texts.

Master Cheng Hao of the Mingdao school, even in his youth at fifteen or sixteen, grew weary of the pursuit of imperial examinations and resolved to seek the Dao. Turning inward to the Six Classics, he attained realization on his own, declaring that with Mencius’ passing, the transmission of sagely learning had been lost. He took it upon himself to revive this tradition, aiming to awaken his contemporaries and, in retirement, to illuminate the texts. His life was cut short, yet his words were plain and easily understood, benefiting both the wise and the foolish alike, like a multitude drinking from a river, each according to their capacity.

It is said: The obscurity of the Dao arises from the harm wrought by heterodox teachings. In the past, such harm was near and easily recognized; today, it runs deep and is difficult to discern. In former times, they deceived people by exploiting their confusion; now, they infiltrate by appealing to their loftiness. They claim to fathom the divine and comprehend transformation, yet this is insufficient to disclose things or accomplish tasks. Their words appear all-encompassing, but their deeds neglect human relationships. They probe the profound and the subtle, yet remain inaccessible to the Dao of Yao and Shun. Among the world’s scholars, those who are not shallow, obstinate, or stagnant inevitably fall into this trap.

Since the Dao has been obscured, perverse and monstrous doctrines have arisen in competition, deluding the eyes and ears of the people and drowning the world in filth. Even those of great talent and wisdom, ensnared by what they see and hear, live as if drunk or dreaming, unaware of their own state. These are the overgrowth that chokes the true path and the obstructions that block the gate of the sages. Only by refuting them can one enter the Dao.

It is recorded: Among the disciples of Confucius, Yanzi stood first in the four categories. At the time, he was called "fond of learning." He did not redirect his anger, nor repeat his mistakes. He would not look, listen, speak, or act contrary to ritual propriety. He was as if absent when present, as if empty when full, and though provoked, he did not contend. These virtues were not beyond the reach of Master Cheng Hao (Bochun). Yet observe his end: seated upright like a clay figurine, yet when engaging with others, he radiated a harmonious qi. He never redirected anger or repeated mistakes. His cultivation was so refined that it manifested in his voice and countenance; those who saw him revered his depth and dared not treat him lightly. In handling affairs, he was unhurried and composed, inspiring such sincerity and respect that none dared act carelessly. How could he have spoken or acted recklessly? He preferred to strive toward sageliness without attaining it rather than gain fame for a single virtue. He would rather be troubled by failing to benefit even one being than claim credit for momentary gain. Was this not also to be as if absent or empty?

Among all the Confucians, he alone attained such purity without deviation.

Master Cheng Yi (Yichuan), at the age of eighteen, submitted a memorial to the imperial court, urging the emperor to reject the commonplace discourse of the age and take the kingly Dao as his heart’s intent. While studying at the Imperial Academy, he met Master Hu Yuan (Anding) and asked what learning Yanzi had pursued. Hu replied: "To learn the Dao that leads to sageliness." Cheng Yi asked, "What is the way of learning?" Hu answered: "Heaven and Earth store essence, and those who receive the finest of the Five Phases become human. Their root is truth and stillness. Before emotions arise, the Five Virtues—humaneness, rightness, ritual propriety, wisdom, and trustworthiness—are all present. Once form is born, external things touch it and stir the inner self. When stirred, the Seven Emotions—joy, anger, sorrow, fear, love, aversion, and desire—emerge. If the emotions blaze unchecked, they erode one’s nature. Thus, the wise restrain their emotions to align with the mean, rectify their minds, and cultivate their natures. The foolish, unaware of restraint, indulge their emotions to the point of ruin.

Therefore, learners must first clarify their minds and understand their natures, then practice diligently to attain humaneness, rightness, loyalty, and trustworthiness, never departing from them even in haste or peril. Over time, they will abide in them with ease. Their movements and demeanor will accord with ritual, and deviant thoughts will have no way to arise." Deeply impressed, Hu Yuan placed Cheng Yi in charge of teaching. Lü Xizhe became his disciple, practicing antiquity with diligence, embracing poverty, and upholding integrity. Cheng Yi read widely, grounding his learning in sincerity. His every action, word, and silence took the sages as his teachers, and he did not cease until he attained sageliness. Thus, he ultimately grasped the learning untransmitted since Confucius and Mencius, becoming a leader among Confucians.

He once said: "For a scholar to pass his years idly without benefiting others is to be a mere parasite in heaven and earth. Only by compiling and studying the sages’ lost writings can one hope to contribute." Thereupon, he composed *Commentaries on the Book of Changes and the Spring and Autumn Annals* to transmit to the world.

It is recorded: What the Han scholars sought was what Confucius and Yanzi delighted in. What Hu Yuan asked was what Yanzi pursued in his learning. Thus, the teaching of masters and the learning of disciples alike took the great sages’ moral nature and destiny as their ultimate aim. This is why the transmission of Dao Learning in the Song dynasty surpassed all previous ages, and why the flourishing of the world and the refinement of customs were so profoundly linked.

Master Zhang Zai (Hengqu) of Guanzhong grounded his learning in fundamental principles, revered antiquity, and practiced with diligence, becoming the leading teacher of scholars in the region. He composed *The Western Inscription*, saying:

"Heaven is called Father, Earth is called Mother. I, so small, dwell harmoniously between them. Thus, what fills Heaven and Earth constitutes my body; what guides Heaven and Earth constitutes my nature. The people are my siblings; all things are my companions. The great ruler is the eldest son of my parents; his high ministers are the stewards of the eldest son’s household. To honor the aged is to extend respect to the elderly; to cherish the orphaned and weak is to nurture the young. Let the sagely embody the union of virtues; let the worthy manifest the finest essence. All in the world who are weary, sick, disabled, orphaned, widowed, or childless—these are my brothers in distress, with none to turn to. At such times, I protect them as a child under my wing. Rejoicing without sorrow, this is pure filial piety. To oppose is to defy virtue; to harm humaneness is to be a thief. Those who aid the wicked are unworthy; only those who fulfill their form are true heirs. To understand transformation is to excel in continuing its work; to fathom the divine is to excel in inheriting its will. To feel no shame in the hidden depths is to be without fault; to preserve the mind and nurture the nature is to be unwavering. To shun fine wine is to follow Boyi’s care for his health; to cultivate talented youth is to emulate the lord of Ying’s bestowal of blessings. To achieve ease without exertion is the accomplishment of Shun; to await cooking without reproach is the reverence of Shensheng. To return to wholeness through what one has received is the way of Zengzi; to bravely follow and obey destiny is the devotion of Boqi."

Wealth, honor, blessings, and grace serve to enrich our lives; poverty, lowliness, sorrow, and distress are but the grinding stone that polishes you to perfection. In life, I follow the course of events; in death, I find peace.

Master Yichuan once remarked: *The Western Inscription* clarifies the principle of unity amidst diversity, expanding upon what the former sages left unsaid. Its achievement equals Mencius’ discourse on the goodness of human nature and the cultivation of *qi*—since Mencius, there has been but one such figure.

It is recorded: The two Cheng brothers possessed innate brilliance and completeness. Upon first meeting Master Lianxi and Master Anding, and hearing of the joy of Confucius and Yan Hui, it was as if they saw with their own eyes and pointed with their own hands—no deliberation, no hesitation. Such was the clarity of their illumination, so seamless and unobstructed.

Master Hengqu’s great elixir bore the fruit of arduous effort, yet lacked the ease of unhurried mastery. His intent and phrasing could not achieve the same seamless flow. Thus, those who read his words may not feel fully enlightened until they reach the end and only then find their doubts dispelled. This is how the two Chengs and Master Zhang diverged.

When we observe how Master Guishan engaged in repeated debates and refutations, and how Master Zhu later expounded upon its intricacies, we see that *The Western Inscription* has flourished to this day. Clearly, their gatherings were not merely to discuss texts with friends but to use friendship to cultivate virtue—here, this becomes all the more evident.

Master Kangjie, Shao Yong, in his youth, was proud of his talents and aspired to establish merit and fame. He was resolute and disciplined, enduring cold without a brazier, heat without a fan, and passing nights without sleep for years. Li Zhicai of Beihai, hearing of his love for learning, said to him: "Have you heard of the study of the nature of things and the principles of life?" Shao then became his disciple, and Li transmitted to him the profound meanings of the *River Chart* and *Luo Writing*, as well as the transmission of the sixty-four hexagrams and their images. Though the origins of this transmission were distant, Shao delved deeply, seeking hidden truths, achieving wondrous insight and spiritual resonance. He penetrated the mysteries, his understanding vast and boundless, gaining much through his own discoveries. As he aged, his learning deepened, and his virtue grew ever more refined. He contemplated the sublime, observing the transformations of heaven and earth, the waxing and waning of yin and yang. From the grand shifts of ancient and modern eras to the subtle natures of birds, beasts, grasses, and trees, he explored every nuance, ultimately expounding the profound teachings of Fuxi’s *Xiantian* (Prior Heaven). He composed over a hundred thousand words.

Fu Bi, Sima Guang, Lü Gongzhu, and other worthies, in their retirement in Luoyang, deeply respected Master Kangjie. They purchased gardens and residences for him, naming his dwelling "Anle Wo" (Nest of Peace and Joy), and thus he was called Master Anle. Sima Guang treated Shao as an elder brother, and the two men’s pure virtue became the admiration of their hometown. They often exhorted one another: "Do no evil, for Sima Duanning is watching." Shao’s wife, Lady Yao, possessed a virtue so pure that her goodness was evident at a glance. Yet she did not flaunt herself, nor did she put on airs. In her presence, all laughed and conversed freely, and though she never acted unusually, when she spoke, she delighted in discussing goodness and concealed others’ faults. If someone sought her counsel, she answered; otherwise, she never forced her words upon anyone. She treated all—regardless of status, age, or rank—with sincerity. Thus, the virtuous rejoiced in her character, while the unvirtuous were transformed by her influence. At that time, Luoyang’s talent flourished, and its atmosphere of loyalty and sincerity spread throughout the realm.

It is recorded: In observing the moral and intellectual accomplishments of the ancients, some achieved them through innate purity, others through the richness of their learning, and still others through the beauty of their environment. Master Shao possessed all three, which is why he stands out as a singular figure across the ages.

Master Guishan, Yang Shi, was by nature open and magnanimous, his attainments profound. From childhood, he was exceptionally gifted, his moral character matured early. What accumulated within him was pure and vast; what manifested outwardly was simple and unadorned. In leisure, he was harmonious and joyful, his demeanor and smile endearing. When handling affairs, he remained composed, never raising his voice.

Those who kept company with him, though gathered in groups all day, would sit in tranquil silence, their presence imbuing others with harmony, while never displaying the slightest hint of disdain or condescension. His magnanimity could embrace all things, its boundlessness imperceptible. Yet he never pursued eccentric or unconventional conduct; his vast reservoir of cultivation remained ever-expanding, never daring to indulge in careless self-expression. Even at eighty, his spirit and vitality showed no decline, surpassing what most youths could muster. In resolving critical dilemmas or managing worldly affairs, his judgment was as clear as a candle’s illumination or a tortoise-shell divination.

Master Yuzhang, Luo Congyan, possessed a nature both luminous and refined, his conduct whole and pure. He enriched himself with breadth and magnanimity, embodying benevolence and forbearance. His insights were profound and subtle, often reaching their utmost depths—unmatched by any Confucian scholars of the Han or Tang dynasties. Without uttering a word, he would suffuse others with harmony; standing beside him, one would be transformed as if by the vernal breeze stirring all things—yet none could fathom how this came to be. Upon hearing of Guishan’s mastery of the Cheng brothers’ teachings, he yearned for it with fervent admiration and set out on foot to study under him, declaring, “Without attaining this, my life would have been lived in vain.” Through deep reflection and steadfast practice, he took the weight of the Way upon himself. After three years of quiet sitting on Luofu Mountain, he plumbed the principles of heaven, earth, and the myriad things, achieving a profound sense of self-possession. He often said, “The ancestral laws and institutions must not be abandoned, nor should one rely complacently on inherited virtue.” He also taught, “When a scholar serves in court, integrity and loyalty must be the foundation. Integrity ensures the court remains free of errors, while loyalty prevents the realm from harboring grievances. To cling solely to integrity without loyalty is to verge on harshness; to lean only on loyalty without integrity is to drift into weakness.” His discourses were always pure and upright, following this pattern.

Master Yanping, Li Gou, was endowed with a resolute and exceptional disposition, his bearing bold and unrestrained. Yet through cultivation, he achieved a state of flawless refinement, his sharp edges smoothed away. His spirit, pure and unadulterated, manifested in his countenance—his expression gentle, his words firm, his demeanor composed, his qi harmonious. Whether speaking or silent, moving or still, he embodied dignity, tranquility, and natural ease, as if guided by an inherent principle. In daily life, he appeared unassuming, indifferent to matters as if they held little consequence. Yet when confronted with critical affairs or sudden crises, he would judge them by principle, displaying an unyielding resolve that brooked no violation. Beyond his lectures and recitations, he would sit in solemn stillness for entire days to verify his insights. He sought the “mean” before joy, anger, sorrow, or pleasure arose, regarding it as the wellspring from which all principles of the world emerged. Once grasping this root, he found that all things branching from it—though myriad in form and endlessly varied—could be encompassed, penetrated, and systematically resolved, each falling into its proper order like the unerring flow of a river’s veins. From the vastness of heaven and earth’s height and depth to the minutiae of living beings’ transformation and nurturance, from the subtle words of classical teachings to the smallest objects of daily use, all could be measured against this standard, none failing to find its proper balance. Through this, his self-cultivation grew ever more steadfast, his nurturing of virtue ever more mature. His spirit became luminous and unified, all things clear to him upon contact, his responses fluid and fitting, his actions always in accord with the mean. Scholars of his time extolled him, saying, “His inner state is like an ice-filled vase beneath autumn moonlight—luminous and flawless, beyond our reach.”

It is recorded: These three masters were the true heirs of the Cheng brothers and Zhu Xi, models for later learners. Their words and bearing stood as exemplary teachings, not only for their own time but for all ages to come. For as long as the innate goodness of the human heart endures, so too will this supreme virtue—worthy of reverent embrace and unwavering adherence.

Master Hui’an, Zhu Xi, from his youth aspired to the learning of the sages and worthies. His father, Weizhai, had received the transmission of classical scholarship from the Central Plains and elucidated the legacy of the sages, focusing his efforts on the cultivation of knowledge and sincerity. Master Zhu, even in his early years, grasped these teachings and held them dear. Yanping, a fellow student of Weizhai, traveled hundreds of li to study under him. Yanping praised him, saying, “His love of goodness and righteousness is unparalleled,” and, “His intelligence surpasses others, his dedication to practice is awe-inspiring.” In his studies, he pursued principle to attain knowledge and turned inward to practice it in action. “Reverence” was the means by which he began and completed his path. He taught that without reverence, the pursuit of knowledge would lead to confusion and distraction, obscuring the true nature of principle. Without reverence, the practice of action would lapse into indolence and self-indulgence, failing to realize principle in reality. The method of maintaining reverence began with “focusing the mind,” sitting in solemn dignity throughout the day, engaging with the classics and canons. From the mind and body of the individual to the myriad affairs and things of the world, all possessed their own principles. He preserved this mind in solemnity, stillness, and unity, while exhaustively investigating these principles through study, inquiry, reflection, and discernment. Yet the knowledge thus cultivated, when manifested in action, was always brought back to the self. The state before perception or hearing demanded ever-greater vigilance and reverence; the hidden and solitary moments required ever-deeper introspection and scrutiny. Before thoughts arose, his awareness remained unclouded; upon encountering things, his responses were precise and unerring. There was no room for the selfishness of human desire, only the fullness of the Heavenly Principle’s rectitude. Herein lay the orthodox transmission of the Dao.

It is recorded: This was the wellspring of Master Zhu’s learning. With Weizhai as his father, his foundation was laid from afar; with Jixi, Baishui, Pingshan, and Yanping as his teachers, his assistance ran deep. As for the three principles—“reverence to establish the foundation, the exhaustive investigation of principle to attain knowledge, and turning inward to practice it in action”—these were the insights Master Zhu made his own, the path he followed from beginning to end without deviation. Such a figure had not been seen since the Qin and Han dynasties, a span of over a thousand years. In his personal cultivation and virtue, he used his singular mind to plumb the origins of creation, fathom the wonders of human nature and emotions, and grasp the profound depths of the sages. Through his singular being, he embodied the Dao of heaven and earth, encompassed the principles of all things, and bore the responsibilities of the fundamental human relationships.

His preservation of the Dao was empty yet sincere; his expression of it was resolute and steadfast. In its application, he responded to affairs and engaged with others with perfect propriety; in its adherence, he remained unchanging through vicissitudes and perils. Through profound cultivation, what was once deep and abstruse became thoroughly refined, and what was once stern and severe grew gentle and harmonious. His mind required no deliberate effort to remain present; his learning needed no further explication to become precise. Yet he still felt the principles of righteousness were boundless while his years were limited, and thus harbored a constant sense of insufficiency.

It is recorded: This was the accomplishment of Master Zhu’s virtue and power. Observing his self-eulogy, he said: *"At ease within the realm of ritual and law, immersed in the treasury of benevolence and righteousness."* Only when these were perfectly aligned did he declare them manifest—perhaps approaching the words of Mencius. Having attained this, he dwelled in it with ease. Dwelling in it with ease, his resources deepened, and drawing from them, he found his source everywhere. How great was the Master! He had reached the ultimate.

It was said that the transmission of the sagely Dao had scattered across texts and records. As the essence of the sages grew obscure, the transmission of the Dao began to fade. Thereupon, he devoted his full energy to exhaustive study, plumbing the classics and teachings of the sages. For the *Great Learning* and the *Doctrine of the Mean*, he filled their gaps, distinguished their sequences, and clarified their guiding principles and details. For the *Analects* and *Mencius*, he delved into the intent behind the questions and answers of their time, so that readers savoring his work might feel as though they stood face-to-face with the sages, receiving their instructions. For the *Book of Changes* and the *Book of Songs*, he sought their original meanings, correcting later distortions to recover the ancient scholars’ intent from millennia past. For the *Book of Documents*, he doubted the coherence of the modern text, finding the ancient version more natural and accessible. For the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, he questioned whether the Sage’s true, magnanimous intent had been distorted by forced interpretations in the commentaries. For the *Rites*, he lamented Wang Anshi’s abolition of the *Ceremonial Rites*, leaving only the *Records* behind. For *Music*, he grieved the loss of pitch standards in later ages, leaving tones without foundation. As for the historical records of successive dynasties, he examined the Western Zhou through the Five Dynasties, selecting chronological works that preserved lineage, and refined them using the *Spring and Autumn Annals’* method of historical narration—comprehensive yet uncluttered, expansive yet not empty.

It is recorded: This was Master Zhu’s merit in continuing the legacy of past sages. Since the Han dynasty, Confucians had engaged in forced interpretations and fragmented speculations, never attaining true insight. Take the *Commentaries on the Changes* and the *Preface to the Songs*—countless schools emerged, while the authoritative annotations of specialized traditions grew vast yet aimless. None could firmly address the subtleties of Heaven’s mandate, the depths of the human mind, or the gateway to virtue, as the present commentaries did. Moreover, every word and meaning was elucidated with clarity and coherence, serving as a compass for scholars across countless generations, enduring as long as heaven and earth.

The works of Zhou, Cheng, Zhang, and Shao had continued the transmission of the Dao from Confucius and Mencius. Yet before long, their profound words and grand principles faded from view. Master Zhu compiled and illuminated them, enabling their flourishing in the world. The *Taiji and Xiantian Diagrams* were profound and boundless, impossible to exhaust. Through his explanations and analyses, the origins of heaven and earth and the hidden depths of the sages were preserved from oblivion.

Master Zhang of Nanjian and Master Lü of Donglai lived in the same era. Sharing the same aspirations and Dao, Master Zhu delighted in their friendship. Even when their views slightly diverged, they would engage in discussion, debate, and refinement to unify their conclusions. Some criticized the rote recitation of commentaries as burdensome, claiming that one could grasp the mind and perceive nature without relying on texts. Scholars, drawn to this simplicity, grew biased and narrow, believing they had attained enlightenment. The more misguided among them even extolled Han and Tang practices, likening them to the Three Dynasties to serve their own utilitarian ends. Master Zhu firmly opposed such trends.

He taught others to begin with the *Great Learning*, the *Analects*, *Mencius*, and the *Doctrine of the Mean* as the proper sequence for entering the Dao, before proceeding to the other classics. Without the *Great Learning* first, one could not grasp the essentials or master the fundamentals. Without studying the subtleties of the *Analects* and *Mencius*, one could not achieve synthesis and thorough understanding, nor fully realize the *Doctrine of the Mean*’s profound aims. Yet without reaching the ultimate in the *Doctrine of the Mean*, how could one establish the great foundation, order the grand principles, read the world’s books, or discuss its affairs? This was likely how Heaven aided the flourishing of culture, sending forth a sage to propagate the great Dao.

After Confucius, Zengzi and Zisi carried on his subtle teachings, until Mencius made them manifest. After Mencius, the Masters Zhou, Cheng, and Zhang revived the interrupted transmission, until Master Zhu made them manifest once more!

It is recorded: This was Master Zhu’s merit in opening the way for future learning. After the Master had synthesized the great achievements of all sages, surpassing even Yao and Shun, Master Zhu synthesized the great achievements of all Confucians—how could his merit be lesser than Mencius’? Scholars of all ages would ponder his words, seek their meaning, and draw lifelong benefit without end, unaware of the depth of his research, the intensity of his reflection, the sleepless nights, or the months of unrelenting effort. How tirelessly he labored! Such was the pinnacle of his great virtue. No matter one’s wisdom or folly, age or rank, wealth or poverty, none could match his earnest devotion.

Master Zhang Shi of Nanjian possessed extraordinary qualities, his intelligence and understanding maturing early. His father, the Loyal and Worthy Duke, taught him the essence of loyalty, filial piety, benevolence, and righteousness. As he grew, he was sent to study under Hu Renzhong. At their first meeting, Hu recognized his great potential and shared with him the profound teachings of Confucius’ discourse on benevolence. Zhang withdrew to reflect, as if gaining insight, and later wrote to seek confirmation.

Master Hu replied, "There are men of the sagely gate—how fortunate for our Dao!" Thus encouraged, Zhang redoubled his efforts, holding himself to the standard of the ancient sages and worthies. He composed the *Record of Aspiring to Yan* as a spur to his own resolve. Though his attainments had already run deep, he dared not rest content, but sought out friends from all quarters to further pursue what he had yet to master. Only after prolonged study, discussion, practice, and personal verification did his former achievements grow ever more refined and profound—until, in the end, he arrived at a realm of simplicity, ease, and unadorned truth.

All the principles under heaven now lay clearly before his mind’s eye, and he truly perceived that which could not be otherwise. Thus his courage in inquiry, vigor in action, and steadfastness in adherence were unshakable. All that he devoted to his lord and kin, all that he unified in Dao and righteousness without ever forgetting his duty to the world—none of this arose from forced effort or mere admiration. In teaching others, he always began by ensuring they first discerned the boundary between righteousness and profit, then clarified the principles and cultivated reverence to reach the utmost. His analyses were incisive and illuminating, his exhortations earnest and compelling, and he would exhaust every angle before ceasing.

He often said, "In learning, nothing comes before the distinction between righteousness and profit. As for righteousness, it is what the original mind must do and cannot refrain from—it is not something one does for the sake of something else. If one acts for the sake of something else, then it is all the selfishness of human desire, and not where the heavenly principle abides." How profound were his words!

This may be called an expansion of what the former sages left "unexpressed," aligning with the work of nurturing the innate goodness of human nature and cultivating qi. The record states: Since the distinction between righteousness and profit became obscured, the harm to the human heart grew acute, its calamities reaching such extremes that barbarians overran the land, hills became ruins, rulers and ministers were bound in captivity, and states were overthrown—not merely confined to the Warring States era. In its final stages, expediency and appeasement were deemed the highest strategy, surrender was seen as wisdom, and people willingly served their enemies, lowering their aspirations and adopting foreign customs—far beyond mere rulers like Guan Zhong or Shang Yang. Yet in those times, within the court and among rulers and ministers, were they all men who had lost their minds or gone mad? Yet Jingfu (Wen Tianxiang) contested this with ever greater resolve, his efforts growing more fervent. Had he not truly perceived the inherent rightness of heavenly principle, free from the falsity of human desire, how could he have advanced so fearlessly, heedless of consequences? In this, his discernment of righteousness and profit was not merely theoretical but embodied and rigorously examined—far from empty words meant to deceive the world.

Master Zhen Xishan (Zhen Dexiu), when the prohibition on learning grew ever stricter, took it upon himself to uphold this cultural legacy, lecturing on it and putting it into practice. He compiled the *Reading Notes*, placing the study of nature and destiny at the forefront as the source of moral principles. The nature’s expression is emotion, while the mind governs both nature and emotion—these three form the framework of the work. Its sections address the virtues of benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust as the heavenly-endowed nature; the relationships of father and son, ruler and minister, husband and wife, elder and younger, and friends as the Way of following one’s nature. What all people traverse is called the Way; what one attains within oneself is called virtue—yet in reality, they are not two. Thus, he followed with "the Mean," "the One," "the Ultimate," and "sincerity," all being the Way, though named differently. He then asked: Where should scholars seeking the Way begin? Reverence is the root of learning, so he placed it first, followed by the Way of the teacher, methods of instruction, and the sage. Distinguishing between the gentleman and the petty man, and between the true Way and heterodoxies, pertains to the *Great Learning*, so he addressed these next. The principles of yin-yang and creation were briefly introduced in the section on nature and destiny, with further details concluding the work.

His *Extended Meanings* (*Daxue Yanyi*) argued that a ruler ignorant of the *Great Learning* could not purify the source of governance, nor could a minister ignorant of it fulfill the duties of ruler and minister. The principles expounded in this work are truly the essential canon for transmitting the mind across generations, not merely the private teachings of Confucius. Recent great scholars have composed commentaries and dialogues to elucidate its meaning, and I humbly sought to provide supplementary support. This work is rooted in the learning of sages and worthies to illuminate the governance of emperors and kings. Drawing from the near past to prepare for future affairs, it is resolutely presented as the laws, statutes, and models for ruling all under heaven. Thus, it takes clarifying the Dao and discerning talent as the essence of "investigating things and extending knowledge"; reverence, awe, caution, and restraining desire as the essence of "making thoughts sincere and rectifying the mind"; prudence in speech and conduct, and proper demeanor as the essence of "cultivating the self"; valuing marriage, strict inner governance, securing the state’s foundation, and educating relatives as the essence of "regulating the family." When the Way of these four is attained, governing the state and bringing peace to the world are encompassed within.

The record states: Observing the principles of these two works, I privately drew parallels in compiling this record. Citing the words and deeds of former sages, worthies, and contemporary authors, I followed the model of the *Extended Meanings*, adding my own insights without rigidly adhering to exegetical conventions—this too reflects my humble intent. In an age when the Dao’s learning was widely proclaimed, recited in every household, would clinging to old conventions be preferable to no record at all? Yet principles are infinite, and the human heart is responsive; myriad transformations arise from them. To fixate on exegetical details is to limit one’s own progress. Confucius said, "It is people who enlarge the Way, not the Way that enlarges people." How dare later generations not strive to emulate and reach it? Seeking correction from those of the Dao, I privately echo the three sighs of Master Zhen Wengong.

Master Heshān (Wei Liaoweng) displayed extraordinary intelligence from youth, earning the title of "divine child." At a time when discussing the learning of the Dao was taboo, after passing the imperial examinations, he encountered the successive administrations of Han Tuozhou and Shi Miyuan. He firmly declined official appointments, built a retreat on White Crane Mountain, and opened his doors to teach disciples, transmitting what he had learned from Li Fan of Fuliang. Thus, the people of Shu came to fully understand the learning of moral principles. In his studies, he illuminated moral principles through things and sought benevolence by reflecting on the self. He examined the minutiae of elementary learning and ritual arts to deduce the grandeur of ritual integration; he grounded himself in the subtleties of daily life to extend his understanding to the manifest workings of heaven, earth, and spirits. He held that the books of sages and worthies, passed down through recitation and transmission since the Han, have endured to the present. Though the transmission between masters and disciples often missed the essentials, the ancient institutions and the words of former sages remain within them—elements that cannot be discarded. Since the teachings of the Lian-Luo school spread, Master Zhu (Xi) inherited and elucidated them, and scholars turned toward the root of morality and destiny, gaining clarity. Yet those who pursued this path recited its phrases tirelessly, while the work of broad learning and extensive knowledge seemed neglected. Moreover, the ills of recent times incline toward recklessness: those who seek this learning may not apply it deeply to their own minds and bodies, while those who extend it elsewhere often lack thoroughness and breadth. Thus, the errors and distortions in transmitted commentaries remain unclarified, and the surviving details of names, objects, and measurements are not examined at their source. If one truly seeks to contribute to the world, how can they grasp the intent behind the sages’ creations or serve as instruments for reform and adaptation?

The Master, deeply concerned, thus devoted careful attention to the records of the *Yili*, the *Zhouguan* and its greater and lesser codes, and selected the finest exegeses and correct interpretations from the Nine Classics. Arranging them by matter and category, he compiled them into the *Essential Meanings of the Nine Classics*. His aim was to demonstrate the inseparability of Dao and its vessels, and to rectify the confusions of arbitrary theories and contentious debates that mislead the world. This aligns precisely with Master Zhang’s teaching through ritual and Master Cheng’s principle of thoroughness from beginning to end.

The compiler notes: Observing Heshan’s critiques, I sigh for today’s scholars—matters too distressing to speak of. They pursue mere verbal mastery, neglecting the transmitted commentaries; they seek the shortcuts of official advancement, disregarding the names and objects of the classics. They recognize their errors yet do not know where to halt before reaching ruin. Previously, there were still those who earnestly engaged in learning, though their contemporaries gathered to oppose them. Now, their voices have faded into silence, and none find it strange, merely dismissing them as shallow and base. Yet the corruption they wrought upon the people’s minds and the harm to the Way of governance are far from trivial. Who among us feels the alarm and dread that Master Wei did? This is why this compilation persists tirelessly.

During the Yuan dynasty, Master Xu Heng of Luzhai, steadfast by nature, acquired the learning of the He-Luo school from his teacher Yao Shu of Xuezhai. Wherever he taught, his influence flourished, and his reputation for great virtue resounded across the north and south. When the First Emperor of the Yuan first heard of the Way of emperors and kings, it was Master Xu who enlightened him, preserving the Confucian Dao from decline. Thus, the Emperor did not惜名爵 to summon scholars from all corners, and though Xu firmly declined the post of chief minister, he oversaw education as the head of the Imperial Academy. Beginning with elementary learning, he advanced through the Four Books, then to the *Yijing*, *Shijing*, *Shujing*, and *Chunqiu*, instructing his disciples directly, always grounding them in filial piety, brotherly respect, loyalty, and trust. The people were transformed by his teachings—fathers instructed their sons, elder brothers exhorted their younger brothers. Not only did he tailor instruction to each student’s abilities, but he also guided them progressively according to their capacities, clarifying their insights while dispelling their obstructions, nurturing their goodness. He timed his teachings to their activities and rest, guarded against nascent faults, and fortified their defenses. Day by day, month by month, they were transformed without realizing it. Thus, all who entered his gate were bound to him as father and son, and each became capable of serving the world.

He also said: In learning, managing one’s livelihood comes first. If basic needs are unmet, one’s pursuit of learning will be hindered, leading to reckless pursuits or misguided advancement. Even those who become officials and crave profit often do so out of financial hardship. Scholars and gentlemen should prioritize agriculture, though commerce, though a lesser pursuit, is not without merit. If conducted without violating principles of righteousness, it may serve as a temporary expedient. But to rely on teaching or official positions to secure one’s livelihood is not the intent of the ancients.

The compiler notes: Some have compared Zhongping to Ziyun and Jiefu, but how could this be so? The times and circumstances of those two were unlike his. In Ziyun’s era, the realm had no rival sun, and Wang Mang’s hidden motives were discernible. Thus, those like Feng Meng and Qiao Xuan could withdraw—this was acceptable. In the reign of Emperor Shenzong, the people acknowledged no second king, and Wang Anshi’s private ambitions were evident. To speak then of "inner refinement and outer barbarism" was indeed severe. But Xu Heng lived in an age of divided realms, witnessing treacherous officials misleading the state—a time when, as the saying goes, "the Yi and Autumn lack rulers, unlike the Xia without one." Could one demand of him that he defy the principles of the *Chunqiu* and tread the path of the tyrannical Qin? Observe his conduct since the founding of the Yuan: summoned ten times, he never compromised an inch for a foot, resolutely declining the post of chief minister to serve in the Imperial Academy. He never engaged in reckless discussions of usurping kings or deceitful Xia, but tirelessly devoted himself to the good of others. His heart is thus discernible. If Xu Heng’s life was one of misfortune, it was not because he took risks for personal gain.

During the present dynasty, Master Xue Xuan, the Duke of Wenqing, from youth studied and clarified the learning of Zhou, Cheng, Zhang, and Zhu, declaring: "This is the true lineage of the Dao." He devoted himself to it wholeheartedly, even forgetting to eat. As he matured, his character became upright and unyielding; in his conduct and interactions, he never wavered or compromised. He often said: "In reading and investigating principles, one must truly grasp them, then verify them in one’s own mind and body, embodying and practicing them. Otherwise, it is like buying a chest and returning the pearl." He earnestly taught the restoration of one’s nature, saying: "This is the crucial point of Cheng and Zhu’s teachings for humanity. The Six Classics and Four Books are all encompassed in the single word *nature*. After Mencius, the Dao did not flourish because *nature* remained obscure." Thus, his learning was a direct transmission from the hearts of Lian and Luo, a spiritual communion with Mo and Si. From the one mind and one body, he extended it to all affairs and all things, then distilled it back to unity. Often, he would close his eyes and sit in meditation, pondering until he attained insight, his joy manifesting on his face. He had reached the realm of delighting in the Dao. As for the joy of wind and crane, the songs of kite and fish—these were his private realizations, visible to all who looked. Truly, he could have joined Zeng Dian in playing music and roaming freely.

In matters of giving and receiving, entering or leaving office, or the duration of service, his conduct was luminous and upright. After Luzhai, none have matched him. His spirit was free and unburdened, untroubled by worldly concerns. Even Liu Jingxiu’s soaring phoenix, with its lofty aspirations, could not surpass him.

The compiler notes: Among the Confucian scholars of the present dynasty, after Wang Huangu, Zhao Kaogu, Song Qianxi, and Fang Zhengxue, came Xue Wenqing, Wu Kangzhai, Yang Wenyi, and Qiu Wenzhuang. By the Chenghua era, a flourishing generation emerged—Luo Yifeng, Zhang Fengshan, Huang Weixuan, Zhuang Dingshan, He Yixian, Hu Jingqi, Zou Lizhai, Chen Baisha, Chen Buyi, Zhou Cuiqu, and Zhang Shubai. Truly, it was a time of great prosperity.

Yet none of these figures revealed the wellspring from which their learning flowed, nor the lineage to which the Dao’s transmission belonged. Even in their passing, the direction of their teachings and the branching of their legacies remained unseen. Consider the likes of Zhou, Cheng, Zhang, Zhu, He, Wang, Jin, and Xu—when the great learning of the Dao shone forth, scholars divided themselves between Zhu and Lu, or aligned with the schools of You and Yang. Yet was this not merely a matter of those whose natural endowments approximated the Way claiming merit, rather than a transmission of the Dao’s essence through silent resonance with a master?

Now, observing Jingxuan’s steadfast devotion to the recovery of human nature as the essential task—extending from the singular heart and body to the myriad affairs and things, then contracting all back to the One—we may say he grasped the root of the sagely learning. Thus, this record is made so that those with aspiration may follow this path to enter the Way. Not only will the undertakings of Cheng and Zhu become readily apparent, but the transmission of Confucius and Yan Hui will also be found to lie nowhere beyond this.

*Hongdao Record*, Volume Ten (concluded)
*Hongdao Record*, Volume Eleven

**Righteousness: The Righteousness of Ruler and Minister**

Yao said: *"Ah, you Shun! The celestial mandate now rests upon you. Hold faithfully to the Mean. If the Four Seas fall into hardship and poverty, the Heaven-bestowed emolument will end forever."*

The compiler notes: The character *"Mean"* was first uttered by Yao, marking the wellspring of the Dao’s transmission. For the righteousness between ruler and minister is not merely a matter of hierarchical order, each occupying their proper station. That which Heaven cannot purify, Earth cannot settle, spirits cannot verify, and sun and moon cannot illuminate—none of these exist apart from this principle. Thus, the hexagrams embody the Way of the Three Powers, pairing with Heaven and Earth, penetrating and unifying all, filling and suffusing the space between. Yet this is not the product of private cleverness or forced interpretation.

From the recognition that human nature is fundamentally good arises the principle of impartiality—neither leaning nor overreaching, without excess or deficiency—a decree of Heaven itself. The ultimate refinement of this subtlety can only be faithfully upheld by the utmost sage, just as Heaven revolves above, and the celestial mandate operates without exception. Without this, how could one engage with the vastness of Heaven and Earth or the multitudes of the people? How could one ensure the Four Seas do not fall into hardship or the Heaven-bestowed emolument endure forever? Herein lies the guiding thread, the establishment of the celestial standard, and the opening of the primordial righteousness between ruler and minister for all ages.

Shun commanded Yu, saying: *"The human heart is perilous; the heart of the Dao is subtle. Be discerning and unified, and hold faithfully to the Mean."*

The compiler notes: This principle of the *"Mean"* grows ever more precise without confusion when refined, ever deeper without exhaustion when explored, ever more intimate without strain when sought, and ever more concise without complexity when examined. With Yao’s single utterance, it was complete. Yet Shun further elaborated with three additional phrases—not to add to it, but because without reverence, clarity, cultured thought, and profound wisdom, the principles of Heaven and human desires risk blending into one path. The difference between them may seem as slight as a hair’s breadth, yet the divergence of a hair’s breadth leads to an error of a thousand miles. This is the crux of the sage’s concern for the Dao and the urgency of his effort—something later enlightened rulers and worthy ministers must carefully consider.

Yu’s *Counsels* state: *"Let the ruler be diligent in his role as ruler, and the minister in his role as minister."*

The compiler notes: This first counsel of Yu’s is deeply personal and resonant, for both Shun and Yu embodied it. Shun rose from humble origins to be summoned for service, tested through trials, and entrusted with regency before ascending to the throne. His governance—whether aligning the Seven Governors, overseeing the Hundred Administrators, appointing the Nine Ministers, or punishing the Four Felons—was never taken lightly. Yu’s labors were even more arduous: his toils in water and land control pained him more than a father’s neglect, his calloused hands and feet were earned without a son’s aid, eight years of toil left him without a home, and his fourfold suffering exceeded what he endured for himself. Had he approached these tasks with ease, how could he have avoided repeating past failures?

Thus, he detested indulgence in fine wine, mastered his desires; cherished every moment, mastered time; regulated his voice and bearing, mastered himself; adhered to the plumb line and carpenter’s square, mastered governance; rose ten times for a single mirror, mastered diligence; and grasped his hair thrice during a single bath, mastered caution. From exhausting his mind and scorching his thoughts to the point of *"I have no leisure"*—what was not a difficult task? Alas! Difficulty brings order; ease brings chaos. Difficulty brings stability; ease brings peril. Elsewhere, the Master urgently declared: *"A single word can build a state; a single word can ruin it."* Oh, how can one not be vigilant?

Gaoyao said: *"Do not indulge in ease or desire when governing a state. Be vigilant and diligent, attending to the myriad affairs day after day. Do not neglect any office, for Heaven’s work is carried out by human hands."*

The compiler notes: Gaoyao’s intent was to emphasize that the more diligent one is, the more meticulous one must be. The failure to be diligent lies in the heart, yet the means to fulfill this lie in the myriad affairs. Consider Heaven: in a single day and night, it completes a cycle of 365 degrees and a quarter. Within this, the revolutions of the sun and moon, the movements of the stars, the interplay of yin and yang, and the convergence and dispersion of the Five Phases—are these not a myriadfold? So too with the ruler: between one day and the next, from sweeping the floor to commanding chariots and armies, from managing court ministers to overseeing distant barbarians, the order or chaos of the court, the weal or woe of the people, the security or peril of the altars of soil and grain, and the rise or decline of the realm—are these not a myriadfold in their diversity? Yet all hinge upon a single thought.

The subtlest stirrings of the heart, when inclined toward goodness, ensure that nothing is not good, and the myriad threads are all ordered. When inclined toward evil, nothing remains good, and all affairs go awry. Thus, one must guard it with vigilance and uphold it with care, attending to the slightest signs. In oneself, there must be no trace of selfishness, no deviation by a hair’s breadth. Though the world may be tangled and chaotic, with ten thousand things unequal, all can be threaded through the One without omission. This is the meaning of *"Heaven’s work carried out by human hands"*—unifying inner and outer as one.

Yi and Ji said: "A minister indeed! A neighbor indeed! A neighbor indeed! A minister indeed!"

The Record states: Where there is Heaven, there is Earth—Earth clings to Heaven. Where there is a ruler, there is a minister—a minister depends upon the ruler. Heaven is but a single qi, yet through it the manifestations of life and the profusion of things arise. Heaven encompasses the towering, the flying, the hidden, the looming and bearing, the stirring and flowing—vast in breadth, boundless in depth, reaching everywhere—all the work of Earth. The ruler is but one man, yet through him the court is rightly ordered and the myriad states are rectified. In employing men and enacting governance, in pacifying the high and governing the people, from the Three Luminaries above to the multitudes of living beings below, from the Four Barbarians without to the Eight Wastes afar, none is not fittingly served—all the work of ministers. This principle of ruler and minister advances nothing beyond the relationship of Heaven and Earth, yet the counsels of the Yu court first proclaimed the meaning of *"A minister indeed! A neighbor indeed!"*—reiterating and expounding its import with profound reflection, a truth those above should immerse themselves in and never lose.

The Emperor said: "Ministers serve as my limbs, ears, and eyes. When I desire to aid and sustain the people, you are my wings. When I desire to extend my strength to the four quarters, you act. When I desire to behold the forms of the ancients—the sun, moon, and stars; mountains, dragons, and flowering vines; sacrificial vessels and ancestral wine jars; waterweeds, fire, grain, and the axe-emblems—adorned with the five colors upon the five hues to make the robes, you make them clear. When I desire to hear the six pitch-pipes, the five notes, the eight timbres, in governance or neglect, to receive and issue the five words, you listen."

The Record states: Only after the principle of limbs, ears, and eyes is made manifest does the head and heart grow ever more endearing. This is not merely the natural order of reason, but the inevitable course of circumstance.

Should the hands and feet grow numb and withered, we call it "lacking humaneness"; if the ears and eyes fail in clarity, one ceases to be fully human. Can any part of the body be spared? Only when the body commands the arm, the arm commands the fingers, when outward grace resides in ears and eyes and inward substance in keen perception—only then can one bear the heavens and tread the earth as a true human being. Without these, one sees nothing, takes no step forward.

So too with the ruler. Only with limbs does he gain wings; only with limbs does he possess ears and eyes; only then can he see clearly, hear keenly, and fulfill the functions of his entire being. Thus governing the world becomes as effortless as turning his palm. Yet this principle lies in the ruler’s own cultivation of virtue. As the *Poetry* says: "If your virtue shines not, none will stand at your back or side; if your virtue shines not, none will serve as your ministers or lords."

Alas! Let him take heed! If I stray, you must correct me; do not feign compliance to my face, then murmur dissent in private—reverence your four neighbors.

The Record states: Is feigned compliance ever a minister’s rightful choice? Even if the executioner’s blade and the tiger’s trap lie before and behind, it may yet be excusable. Yet how swiftly loyalty is severed in the span of a brief exchange, how readily one flatters the ruler with a glance or gesture—knowing only to echo his words without daring dissent, heedless of reason’s right or wrong, of affairs’ success or failure. Alas, to what depths this descends!

And what ruler delights in private murmurs? Even if one shifts with others’ influence or adapts to circumstances, it may yet be excusable. Yet how quickly private bonds are forged, how readily grievances are pointed out in court debates—worse still, how one gathers scraps of the past to prove one’s own twisted arguments. Alas, to what depths this descends!

This arises because the ruler fails to honor the principle of correction, because the minister neglects the duty of loyal counsel, because between ruler and subject there is only biased listening and solitary trust. Do they not know the court belongs to all the people, the world to all under heaven? How can the inclinations of one man determine the right and wrong of ten thousand affairs?

The Record further states: Alas! Let this be a warning.
