Let there be no negligence in vigilance, no deviation from the law and standards, no indulgence in idleness, no excess in pleasure. Appoint the worthy without hesitation, remove the wicked without doubt. Do not finalize plans when uncertain, and let all aspirations flourish in harmony. Do not violate the Dao to curry favor with the people, nor deceive the people to satisfy one’s own desires. Remain neither idle nor negligent, and the four barbarians will come to submit.

The Record states: You must not merely obey in person while harboring dissent in private. In the grand court, before the assembled officials, one must strike at the dragon’s reversed scales and challenge taboos—this is how to suppress human desires at their inception and preserve Heaven’s principles before they fade. Beware! Those who guard against negligence, who stand beneath the vast roof, who tread the fine path, with a wise ruler before them and admonishing ministers behind, thus bring order before chaos arises and secure the state before peril emerges. That the four barbarians come to submit is not due to strong armor or sharp weapons, but to appointing the worthy, removing the wicked, and uniting minds in singular purpose. The intent of the *Yi* is thus revealed. That the Miao tribes came to submit and moved Heaven’s heart—was this mere coincidence? Mencius said: "Tang held to the center and established the worthy without fixed criteria."

The Record states: Yao, Shun, and Yu merely spoke of holding to the center, not of establishing the worthy. For in the time of Yao and Shun, there were the Eight Yuan and Eight Kai, the Nine Ministers and Twelve Governors, all flourishing in mutual deference, filling the court. In Tang’s time, he sought the most sagely, yet Yi Yin went five times to Tang and five times to Jie. Had Tang not sent envoys thrice to invite him, how could he have risen so readily? This is why yielding the throne to another differs from preserving a state on the brink of collapse. Yet in both cases, attaining sageliness through holding to the center and refining unity follows the same path.

The *Tang Gao* says: "We sought the most sagely and joined with him in effort." It also says: "Yearning for one of singular virtue, we made him the divine sovereign." The Record states: This shows the weight of aligning with the Dao, and Tang’s own commitment cannot be denied. He did not merely speak of "sageliness" but of "the most sagely"; not merely of "virtue" but of "singular virtue." For he established the heart of Heaven and Earth, the mandate of the people, preceding Heaven yet not defying it, following Heaven yet adhering to its timing. Thus it is said: "Joined with him in effort, we made him the divine sovereign." How unlike later ages, where rulers favor ministers who merely follow their teachings rather than those who truly guide them. Such teachings, confined to the ruler’s path, remain trivial and base. No wonder they claim sageliness for themselves.

Wan Zhang asked: "Is it true that Yi Yin sought Tang’s favor through cooking?" Mencius replied: "Yi Yin plowed in the wilds of Youxin, delighting in the Dao of Yao and Shun. If it were not righteous, if it were not the Dao, even offering him the world as salary, he would not glance at it. Even if given a thousand teams of four horses, he would not look. If it were not righteous, if it were not the Dao, he would not give or take even the smallest thing. When Tang sent messengers with gifts to invite him, Yi Yin calmly said: 'Why should I care for Tang’s gifts? How could I compare to remaining here in the fields, delighting in the Dao of Yao and Shun?' After Tang sent envoys three times, Yi Yin suddenly changed his mind, saying: 'Rather than remain in the fields delighting in the Dao of Yao and Shun, how much better to make this ruler a ruler like Yao and Shun, to make these people a people like those of Yao and Shun, to witness this with my own eyes! Heaven gave birth to these people so that those who know first awaken those who know later, so that those who awaken first awaken those who awaken later. I am one of Heaven’s people who awakens first; I will use this Dao to awaken these people. If not I, then who?' He thought of the people of the world—every man and woman who had not received the blessings of Yao and Shun—as if he himself had pushed them into the ditch. Such was his sense of responsibility for the world’s weight. Thus he went to Tang and persuaded him to attack Xia and save the people."

The Record states: When the Four Mountains recommended Shun, Yao still tested him through hardships, for Yao had no choice. Within the family, it was difficult, while the world was easy; family was close, while the world was distant—could Shun truly be entrusted with the throne? "I have tested him thus." When Tang sent three envoys to invite Yi Yin, who still scorned and boasted of his contentment, it was not that Yi Yin was disrespectful. For a ruler with great ambitions must have ministers he cannot summon. If he does not honor virtue and delight in the Dao to this extent, he is unworthy of great deeds. This threefold invitation was truly the noble conduct of a ruler, the grand virtue of an emperor. Yet even so, some mocked Yi Yin for seeking favor through cooking—how can one not be cautious in matters of entering or withdrawing from office?

It is also said: Why did Yi Yin delight in the Dao of Yao and Shun? The Dao of Yao and Shun is inherently present in one’s nature—how could it exist in me but not in others? People only fail to value themselves, fretting over poverty and low status. Poverty and low status—what are mere rice and wild herbs? They chase after wealth and nobility, yet wealth and nobility—what are mere wooden deer and swine? Thus, nothing is greater than refining unity and holding to the center, and without righteousness and the Dao, how can one refine anything? Nothing is more difficult than possessing the world yet not claiming it, and without even the smallest thing or a thousand teams of horses, how can one hold fast? Nothing is more urgent than preserving the heart for the world, where the first to know awaken those who know later, the first to awaken awaken those who awaken later—how intimate is this vision! Nothing comes before dedicating oneself to the poor, where every man and woman of the world is entrusted to one’s care—how pressing is this duty! Was this mere empty talk or pretense to deceive the world and steal fame?

Later, Master Meng nearly embodied this. He said: "Whether people know me or not, I remain content," reflecting the same heart as Yi Yin’s three refusals of the invitation. He said: "In poverty, I do not lose righteousness; in success, I do not depart from the Dao," reflecting the same heart as Yi Yin’s disregard for the world. He said: "Standing at the center of the world, I stabilize the people of the four seas," reflecting the same heart as Yi Yin’s "If not I, then who?"

He said: "When one’s aspirations are realized, grace extends to the people; when one attains success, one brings goodness to all under heaven"—this reflects the same heart of shouldering heavy responsibility. Yet why, in the Warring States, did the Three Dynasties’ way not return? Why, under Kings Hui and Xuan, did the virtue of Tang not reappear? We see only three nights’ hesitation before leaving the capital, but never three summonses crossing the border—how lamentable!

*The Counsels of Gao Yao* states: "Morning and evening, receive instruction to aid my virtue. Like metal, I will use you as a whetstone; like crossing a great river, I will use you as a boat and oars; like a year of great drought, I will use you as timely rain." The *Record* explains: "A whetstone is a stone from another mountain, able to polish jade; a boat is for traversing peril, overcoming difficulty, and safely crossing great rivers; timely rain is when remonstrance is heeded and words are followed, so that nourishing grace flows down to the people." These three are the Way of the minister.

Yet there are those who, like metal, bring about change and reform; those who, like cinnabar, drown together; and those who, like drought, share in the burning. Thus, if a ruler obtains the right minister, what matter cannot be accomplished? But if he fails to obtain the right minister, then not only will his illness darken his sight until it festers—my concern!—but he may also wound his own feet until he walks barefoot—my fear! This is the profound meaning of the *Record*.

Gao Yao further said to the king: "Only when wood follows the marking line does it become straight; only when a ruler heeds remonstrance does he become sagely." The *Record* states: "Wood following the line is the perfection of compass and square; a ruler heeding remonstrance is the perfection of human relations for a sage." The rulers of the Three Dynasties who maintained their legacy bore this burden without losing their thread, relying entirely on this principle. Emperor Taizong of Tang once used it to instruct his heir—he was nearly one with whom such words could be shared.

It is also said: "If the heart of the wood is not straight, all its veins and patterns become crooked." Alas! Is this wood not entirely different from wood that follows the line?

Confucius said: "Though he possessed two-thirds of the world, King Wen served the Yin with the virtue of Zhou—this may be called the ultimate virtue." The *Record* states: Confucius’s praise of King Wen arose from his understanding of the *Book of Changes*. *Qian* represents heaven, the ruler, the superior, the crown, the head; *Kun* represents earth, the minister, the inferior, the shoe, the foot. That a minister cannot be placed above the ruler is like earth not being placed above heaven, the inferior not above the superior, shoes not above the crown, or feet not above the head—all are the meanings of the sage’s commentary on the *Changes*. Though it is said: "Heaven grants it, the people return to it; I would rather preserve my inner brilliance, I would rather tread upon frost"—this is the magnanimity of his heart, the grandeur of his self-conduct, the steadfast compliance in governing things, and the boundless nature of his virtue and fortune. What limit could there be? What measure could contain it? Thus, it is not merely called "virtue" but "ultimate virtue."

The *Records of the Historian* state that King Wen secretly practiced goodness, so he needed no trial to exonerate himself. When King Wu campaigned against Zhou, Boyi and Shuqi grasped his horse’s bridle to remonstrate. The attendants wished to strike them, but the Grand Duke said: "These are righteous men." He helped them away.

The *Record* states: Observing Boyi and Shuqi’s integrity, even today it remains awe-inspiring, as if alive. Yet in the end, they could not stop the campaign against Zhou. Were the words of these righteous men truly of no use? No. The reason the principles of heaven endure and the human heart does not perish is that a single word from a person stands between heaven and earth. If the Zhou were to rise, if they were to defeat the Yin, if they were to assemble without expectation, if "God is watching over you"—yet the principle of heaven’s supremacy and earth’s humility is real. If no one speaks of it, will not the hexagram *Qian* nearly cease? Will not the ruler’s role nearly vanish? Thus, they had no choice but to contend. Their contention was not to prevent the fall of Yin—it was to preserve the heart of Yin; nor was it to halt the rise of Zhou—it was to uphold the principle of Zhou. Is this not the primordial *qi* between heaven and earth that cannot be extinguished or exhausted?

Some say that a commoner’s will cannot be altered, that what their lord permitted, Boyi and Shuqi did not permit—this narrows the Way. *The Successful Completion of the War* states: "Heaven aids the people, establishing rulers and teachers for them. Only those who can assist God and soothe the four directions—whether guilty or innocent, how dare I overstep their will?"

The *Record* states: *The Great Declaration* already presents the ruler as the people’s parent, and *The Successful Completion* again presents him as their ruler and teacher—why repeat this? No. Heaven nurtures the myriad things with benevolence and rectifies the people with righteousness.

From the former statement, it is through *ren* (benevolence) that one fully realizes *yi* (righteousness); from the latter, it is through *yi* that *ren* is put into practice. Therefore, none but the Son of Heaven may reverently uphold the canonical rites and ordinances, or command the virtuous to punish the guilty. Once enthroned as the Son of Heaven, if he instead exerts himself without measure, neglects and abandons the sacrifices, where then lie the canonical rites? If he punishes men by exterminating their clans and appoints officials by hereditary succession, where then lies the command to punish and reward? Should one fail to assist in this, yet seek to soothe and favor the realm, the hearing of Heaven and Earth would fall silent, and the spirit of the myriad things would vanish. This is the great *yi* of Heaven and Earth, which awaits the ruler and teacher before it can be enacted in the world. Without King Wu, not a single day could be governed, not a single matter settled, not a single step taken in safety, not a single man preserved. If one harbors even the slightest intention to benefit the world, then guilt is shared equally—how could one ensure that no will is overstepped?

Thus, he overturned the policies of Shang. Governance reverted to the old ways: he freed Jizi from imprisonment, restored the tomb of Bigan, honored Shang Rong’s inquiry, distributed the wealth of Lutai, and released the grain from Juqiao. He bestowed great bounty upon the Four Seas, and the myriad people rejoiced in submission.

The *Record* states: This marked the beginning of his victory over Yin. His deeds and bearing outshone even those of Tang. For the old policies of Shang were the new policies of Zhou. The transmission of the Dao by Jizi could not be absent for a single day; the rites and laws preserved by Shang Rong could not be abolished for a single day; the upright Way upheld by Bigan could not be uprooted for even a day; the will of the people and the heart of Heaven could not be estranged for a single day. The distribution of wealth was not a private favor but a means to enrich the world. The great bounty was not indiscriminate charity but a means to enrich the virtuous. This is why the myriad people rejoiced in submission.

He established five ranks of nobility and three divisions of officers, appointed officials based on worthiness, and assigned positions according to ability. He emphasized the Five Teachings among the people—food, mourning, and sacrifice. He esteemed trustworthiness and illuminated *yi*, exalted virtue and rewarded merit, and with hands folded in his lap, the world was governed.

The *Record* states: This marked the completion of the founding of Zhou. His deeds and bearing left nothing to be ashamed of when measured against antiquity. For the promulgation of the royal standard is the beginning and end of this text. Once the people are enriched, ranks and lands cannot be treated lightly; when one draws near to the radiance of the Son of Heaven, worthiness and ability cannot be neglected; when bestowing upon the common people, the Five Teachings cannot be slighted; when entering governance to enrich life, the people’s sustenance cannot be delayed. By earnestly clarifying trustworthiness and *yi*, the kingly Way is vast and boundless; by exalting virtue and rewarding merit, the kingly Way is level and even. This is how, with hands folded in his lap, the world was governed.

The *Rites of Zhou* states: The king said, "As in the great plans of old, govern before disorder arises, secure the state before danger comes. In the time of Yao and Shun, they examined antiquity and established a hundred offices: within, the Hundred Stewards and the Four Mountains; without, the governors of provinces and the lords of domains. All policies were harmonized, and the myriad states attained peace. In the Xia and Shang dynasties, the number of offices doubled, yet they too were able to employ them effectively. Enlightened kings in establishing governance do not merely consider the offices but the men who fill them. Now I, your humble servant, reverently cultivate virtue, rising early and retiring late, striving to emulate the timely ways of former ages. I instruct and guide my officials, establishing the Grand Preceptor, Grand Tutor, and Grand Protector—these are the Three Dukes. They discourse on the Dao and manage the state, harmonizing and regulating *yin* and *yang*. Offices need not be fully staffed; it is the men that matter. The Junior Preceptor, Junior Tutor, and Junior Protector—these are the Three Solitaries. Together with the Two Dukes, they assist in transforming and illuminating Heaven and Earth, aiding me, the One Man. The Chief Minister oversees the governance of the state, unifies the hundred officials, and equalizes the Four Seas. The Minister of Education oversees the teaching of the state, disseminates the Five Constants, and pacifies the multitudes. The Minister of Rites oversees the rituals of the state, regulates the spirits and the people, and harmonizes high and low. The Minister of War oversees the governance of the state, commands the Six Armies, and pacifies the domains. The Minister of Justice oversees the prohibitions of the state, roots out evil and treachery, and punishes violence and disorder. The Minister of Works oversees the lands of the state, settles the Four Peoples, and ensures the timely use of the earth’s resources. The Six Ministers divide their duties, each leading their subordinates to guide the Nine Governors and enrich the multitudes."

The *Record* states: This is what King Cheng received from the Duke of Zhou’s discourse on the Dao, becoming an enduring ordinance for ten thousand generations. The book of the *Rites of Zhou* speaks of the Three Dukes and Six Ministers, yet in a single phrase summarizes it: "Offices need not be fully staffed; it is the men that matter." The establishment of the Zhou rites comprised three hundred and sixty offices, yet in a single phrase summarizes it: "Do not merely consider the offices; consider the men." The Duke’s intent is thus evident—why then do those who study the Zhou rites remain divided and inconsistent? What the Duke established were the institutions; what he encompassed was the intent. To appreciate the institutions and emulate the intent is sufficient. To scrutinize their details and seek their patterns is not the intention of a good scholar. This *Record* thus concludes with the *Rites of Zhou*.

"Study antiquity to enter office, discuss affairs according to the institutions, and governance will not go astray. You, the constant assistants and teachers, must not let clever speech disrupt your duties. Harboring doubts spoils plans; negligence and indolence lead to abandoned governance. Without learning, one faces the wall; approaching affairs is only troublesome. Warn you, the ministers: achievements are built on resolve, undertakings expand through diligence. Only with decisiveness can future difficulties be avoided. Do not let rank breed arrogance, nor wealth extravagance. Reverence and frugality are virtues; do not burden yourself with deceit. Cultivating virtue brings ease of mind and is called excellence; practicing deceit brings labor of mind and is called clumsiness. Abiding in favor, think of peril—there is nothing not to be feared; without fear, one enters fear. Promote the worthy and yield to the capable, and the various offices will be harmonious. Without harmony, governance becomes cumbersome. Appoint the capable to their offices—this is your responsibility. To recommend those unfit is your failure to bear the task."

The *Record* states: This is what is meant by "do not merely consider the offices; consider the men." For offices are empty vessels; men are their true use. What is meant by "consider the men" is that they must study from youth and practice in maturity. This is the standard for cultivating scholars. Those who advance in this way will surely achieve great deeds and broad undertakings, neither arrogant nor extravagant. Cultivating virtue is called excellence; abiding in favor, they think of peril—this is the bearing of great ministers.

As for recommending the worthy and yielding to the capable, appointing the capable to their offices—this ensures that the duties of office are well-governed, enduringly and without need for correction. This Dao was truly practiced by the Duke of Zhou in his ability to employ men, and by King Cheng in his ability to enact it. Later generations cannot surpass this.

The *Rites of Zhou: Minister of State* states: With the Eight Handles, the king governs his many ministers: first, rank to govern their nobility; second, emolument to govern their wealth; third, removal to govern their offenses; fourth, appointment to govern their conduct; fifth, punishment to govern their transgressions; sixth, bestowal to govern their blessings; seventh, granting to govern their favor; eighth, deprivation to govern their poverty.

The *Record* states: They are called "handles" because they are what one grasps to initiate affairs—the king governs the Nine Provinces and unifies them in his hand. They are called "governance" because they are what one wields to achieve far-reaching ends—the king drives an entire generation and guides them toward goodness. Heaven, though it neither blesses the good nor curses the wicked, cannot make people stand in awe; the ruler, though he neither rewards the good nor punishes the evil, cannot make people submit. What they stand in awe of is not what they love; what they receive in return is not what they favor. The king is the Son of Heaven; the officials are the officers of Heaven. Heaven covers all without partiality—how could the sage have private preferences? Without private preferences, there is neither private love nor private hatred. Thus, rank must match one’s virtue, emolument must match one’s merit, appointments must suit one’s worthiness, and bestowals must suit one’s toil. These are bestowed according to the nature of things, not by my own will. Grants must suit one’s goodness, deprivations must suit one’s offenses, removals must match one’s guilt, and punishments must precisely address one’s transgressions. People seek these for themselves; they are not imposed by the ruler’s will. Thus, without expending excess effort, he can invigorate the Nine Provinces; without wasting spirit, he can drive an entire generation forward.

If, however, rank and emolument are bestowed according to personal favor, while removals and deprivations are imposed on those one hates, this is to disrupt the root and abandon the handle—like rotten reins instead of the six steeds. Such means were intended to instruct the king, yet they instead hasten disaster. How then can they be used for the officers of Heaven? This is the first principle of governing the world—one cannot afford not to know it.

The Grand Minister of Education uses the Eight Punishments to correct the myriad people: first, the punishment for disobedience; second, the punishment for discord; third, the punishment for disrespect; fourth, the punishment for irreverence; fifth, the punishment for incompetence; sixth, the punishment for neglect; seventh, the punishment for slander; eighth, the punishment for disorderly conduct.

The *Record* states: Among the Eight Punishments, why are slander and disorderly conduct included? Speech that accords with principle is not what is meant by "slander." Only the flatterers, sycophants, and wicked who condemn what people universally approve and approve what people universally condemn—those who delight in unrighteousness and entangle others in their webs—bring harm to the world. This is what the *Book of Songs* refers to as "do not indulge in devious compliance, lest you starve the good." Conduct that follows constancy is not what is meant by "disorder." Only those who act recklessly and seek fortune, who cast aside the fundamental norms to pursue illicit ambitions, who disrupt order to hasten their selfish schemes—those whom the good people, like vipers and scorpions, follow without remedy—bring calamity to the realm. This is what the *Book of Songs* refers to as "the people now face peril, gazing at Heaven in confusion." These were the offenses that the ancients were sure to punish.

The *Tan Gong* states: In serving one’s lord, one must admonish without concealment; in attending to his needs, one must follow proper methods. One serves diligently until death, and during the three-year mourning period after his passing.

The *Record* states: Why must one "admonish" the lord? The lord’s heart bears the weight of myriad affairs—his favor can shape a person’s fate, his authority can determine a person’s life, his advancement can bring peace to the world, and his withdrawal can plunge it into peril. When compelled to speak, it concerns matters of life and death, safety and danger. Thus, it is called "admonition." Why must the minister "follow proper methods"? The minister’s loyalty to the lord in life and death is boundless in intent but limited in duty; his responsibilities are vast, yet his strength is insufficient. Thus, the great must not encroach upon the small, nor the low upon the high. When compelled to attend to their respective duties, it concerns matters of fortune and misfortune, honor and disgrace. Thus, it is called "proper methods." Attendants have their duties; "without concealment" is their principle. Responding to "without concealment" with "proper methods," though their roles differ, their admonition is the same. To shirk one’s office and lack responsibility for words, or to restrain others by overstepping one’s bounds—neither is the way of diligent service.

The *No Indulgence* states: The Duke of Zhou said: Alas! The noble person should not be indulgent. First, know the hardships of farming. If one is indulgent, one will understand the common people’s plight. Observe the common people: their fathers and mothers toil in farming, yet their children do not know the hardships of farming—they become indulgent and arrogant. Once spoiled, they will insult their parents, saying: "The people of old knew nothing." The Duke of Zhou said: Alas!

I have heard it said: In former times, the Yin king Zhongzong was reverent and awe-inspired by Heaven’s Mandate. He measured himself, governing the people with fear and trepidation, never daring to indulge in ease. Thus, Zhongzong’s reign endured for fifty-five years.

As for Gaozong, he had once toiled among the common folk. When he ascended the throne, he did not dare to indulge in ease. He brought peace to the Yin state, from the great to the small, so that none harbored resentment at any time. Thus, Gaozong’s reign endured for fifty-nine years.

As for Zu Jia, he understood the plight of the common people and was able to protect and benefit the multitude, never daring to slight the widowed or orphaned. Thus, Zu Jia’s reign endured for thirty-three years.

From that time onward, the kings who were enthroned lived in indulgence. They knew not the hardships of farming, nor heard of the toil of the common folk, only following after pleasure. Thereafter, none among them attained longevity—some reigned ten years, some seven or eight, some five or six, some three or four.

The Duke of Zhou said: Alas!

Yet it was only our Zhou’s Grandfather Tai and Father Ji who were able to restrain themselves in awe. King Wen wore humble attire, engaging in peaceful works and field labors. From dawn until the sun declined past noon, he had no leisure even to eat.

King Wen received the Mandate in his middle years, and his reign endured fifty years.

The Duke of Zhou said: Alas!

From this day forward, let the succeeding kings not be excessive in their pleasures—whether in spectacles, indulgence, hunting, or excursions—using the people’s rightful tribute for such ends. Let them not arrogantly say: "Today we indulge in pleasure," for this is no teaching for the people, nor what Heaven approves. If the people greatly transgress, let there be no repetition of the Yin king’s delusion and disorder, his debauchery in the virtue of wine.

The Duke of Zhou said: Alas!

I have heard it said: The ancients would mutually instruct, mutually protect and benefit, mutually teach and admonish. The people did not deceive one another with sorcery or illusions. Otherwise, their hearts would turn to resentment, their mouths to curses.

The Duke of Zhou said: Alas!

From the Yin king Zhongzong to our Zhou’s King Wen, these four men were enlightened and wise. If someone warned them, saying: "The common folk resent and revile you," they would greatly reverence virtue. If they erred, they would say: "This is my fault," truly reflecting on the matter without delay, never harboring anger.

The Duke of Zhou said: Alas!

Let the succeeding kings take heed of this.

It is recorded: This is the first principle the Duke of Zhou taught King Cheng. Of all things under heaven, none is more base than farming; none more toilsome; yet none more beneficial to the people. And when it reaches its utmost, to personally farm and yet possess all under heaven—none is more perfectly humane. This is the root of Heaven’s Mandate, whether it departs or remains; the source of the people’s hearts, whether they turn toward or away; the foundation of longevity, whether long or short; the proof of virtue and fortune, whether broad or narrow.

Since the founding ancestors, through accumulated merit and layered virtue, for over a thousand years, not a single day has this been forgotten. Yet if one does not know the condition of the common people, this is not the way of enlightenment and wisdom.

For to love ease is the common nature of the people. Moreover, to mutually instruct, mutually teach and admonish, to overlook their resentful reviling and cursing, and instead reflect upon oneself and take responsibility—this is the virtue of "no indulgence," which unites above and below. How could this be only what King Cheng should take heed of? All later worthies and kings must do the same; indeed, for all generations of rulers and ministers, there is no other way.

Thus, each instance of "Alas!" is uttered to deeply express sighs of lamentation and to rouse reflection.

The Duke of Zhou, seeing that King Cheng did not know the hardships of farming, recounted the transformative influence of Hou Ji and Gong Liu, having him recite and chant these lessons morning and night to instruct him.

The poem says:
In the seventh month, the Fire Star declines;
In the ninth month, garments are distributed.
On the first day of the first month, the wind howls;
On the second day, the cold bites—
Without robes, without coarse cloth,
How shall we survive the year?

On the third day, we go to the plow;
On the fourth day, we lift our feet—
With our wives and children,
We head to the southern fields,
Where the Field Overseer comes with joy.

In the seventh month, the Fire Star declines;
In the ninth month, garments are distributed.
In spring, the sun grows warm,
The orioles sing—
Women take their fine baskets,
Following narrow paths,
Seeking tender mulberry leaves.

The spring days lengthen,
The gathering of greens is abundant—
The women’s hearts grow sorrowful,
Fearing they will be taken away with the lord’s sons.

In the seventh month, the Fire Star declines;
In the eighth month, reeds are harvested.
In the silkworm month, mulberry branches are pruned;
Taking axes, new and sharp,
They fell the tall poplars,
Gathering the tender mulberry leaves.

In the seventh month, the shrike cries;
In the eighth month, they spin thread.
They dye black, they dye yellow—
Our crimson is most bright,
For the lord’s sons’ garments.

In the fourth month, the bramble blooms;
In the fifth month, the cicadas sing.
In the eighth month, the harvest is gathered;
In the tenth month, the leaves fall—
On the first day, they hunt the raccoon,
Taking fox and badger pelts,
For the lord’s sons’ furs.

On the second day, they gather,
Drilling and practicing martial arts—
Keeping the small boars for themselves,
Offering the fat ones to the lord.

In the fifth month, the locusts stir their legs;
In the sixth month, the katydids flap their wings.
In the seventh month, they are in the wilds;
In the eighth month, under the eaves;
In the ninth month, at the door;
In the tenth month, the crickets enter beneath our beds.
We block the holes, seal the north windows,
Plaster the doors—
Alas, my lord’s sons,
Saying: "The year is changing,
Come into this dwelling."

In the sixth month, they eat plums and grapes;
In the seventh month, they cook melons and beans;
In the eighth month, they knock down dates;
In the tenth month, they harvest rice—
To brew spring wine,
To prolong life.

In the seventh month, they eat gourds;
In the eighth month, they cut calabashes;
In the ninth month, they gather hemp stalks,
Picking bitter herbs, gathering firewood—
The food of us farmers.

In the ninth month, they build the threshing ground;
In the tenth month, they bring in the harvest—
Millet and glutinous millet, early and late,
Rice and hemp, beans and wheat.
Alas, us farmers!
Our crops now gathered,
We ascend to work on the palace halls—
By day, we gather thatch;
By night, we twist ropes.
Hastily, we climb to roof the houses,
Then begin to sow the hundred grains.

On the second day, they hew ice with a resounding clang;
On the third day, they store it in the icehouse.
On the fourth day, early in the morning,
They offer lambs and leeks in sacrifice.
In the ninth month, the frost descends;
In the tenth month, they sweep the threshing ground.
With paired cups of wine, they feast,
Slaying lambs—
Ascending to the lord’s hall,
Raising the rhinoceros-horn cups,
They wish him: "Ten thousand years without end!"

The Record states: This poem and *The Against Idleness* (《无逸》) complement each other. Observe how every word and meaning is known to the common folk, yet also to the noble. When it reaches its utmost depth, even the sage has not fully exhausted it—truly a text that weaves heaven and earth, a discourse that penetrates high and low. Moreover, it does not present its admonition directly but allows one to chant and reflect upon it indirectly, surpassing the effect of didactic speech.

For song and chant nurture one’s nature and emotions. The young king’s temperament is still unformed, his vital energies unsettled; if blind musicians and tutors present such verses to him, the influence of sycophants and private attendants will be kept at bay. The poems of antiquity are like today’s songs, yet if they are recited morning and night, indulgence and arrogance will be swept away.

Thus, the ancients admonished kings not by forcibly distancing them from music and sensual pleasures, yet these naturally became distant; not by forbidding hunting and excursions, yet these naturally ceased; not by halting their brush to stop writing, yet they unconsciously delved deeper; not by confronting them with remonstrance, yet they unconsciously listened intently. How rare are the three successive rulers who maintained the legacy of their predecessors!

The Duke of Shao accompanied King Cheng on an outing and sang upon the winding slopes of *Juan’e*. Inspired by the king’s song, he composed this to serve as a warning:

*"Oh, the winding slopes of Juan’e,
A whirling wind blows from the south.
O joyful and gracious lord,
Come wander, come sing,
To offer your melody.
How splendid your journey,
How leisurely your repose!
O joyful and gracious lord,
May you fulfill your nature,
And emulate the former lords of old.
Your lands and domains are vast,
Your blessings profound.
O joyful and gracious lord,
May you fulfill your nature,
And preside over the hundred spirits.
Long has your mandate endured,
And your prosperity is secure.
O joyful and gracious lord,
May you fulfill your nature,
And your constancy be pure and enduring.
With strength and support,
With filial piety and virtue,
You are guided and upheld.
O joyful and gracious lord,
A model for the four quarters,
Radiant and majestic,
Like a jade scepter, like a jade tablet,
Your fame and renown resound.
O joyful and gracious lord,
A net for the four directions,
Phoenixes take flight,
Their wings gracefully fluttering,
Alighting together in harmony.
How abundant the king’s noble men,
Whom the lord employs,
Winning the Son of Heaven’s favor.
Phoenixes take flight,
Their plumage resplendent,
Soaring even to the heavens.
How abundant the king’s worthy men,
Whom the lord commands,
Winning the people’s favor.
Hark! The phoenixes cry
Upon that lofty ridge,
Where parasol trees grow.
Facing the morning sun,
Lush and verdant,
Their leaves rustle in the breeze.
The lord’s chariots,
Numerous and abundant;
The lord’s horses,
Trained and swift.
The verses offered are few,
Yet suffice to convey the song."*

The Record states: In contemplating the ancients, their earnest loyalty and devotion to their lords—even in the case of King Cheng of Zhou—cannot be surpassed. Yet observe how they framed their admonition: first, through the delightful setting of *Juan’e* and the pleasing sight of the whirling wind; second, by using song as a vehicle for warning, without harsh or urgent intent. The verses offered were few, lacking pressing words. They began by stirring the king’s personal inclinations and concluded with the auspicious omens of great peace.

Thus did the sages and worthies of antiquity ensure their words were never abandoned, their Dao mutually fulfilled. When their lords heard them, they naturally lingered in leisurely delight, savoring the counsel without perceiving how deeply it resonated within their hearts.

Alas! When the heart is truly aligned, words may be forgotten—what need then for solemn admonition?

*Hongdao Record*, Scroll Eleven

[Textual Notes: *Originally "推" (tuī), emended to "惟" (wéi) according to the *Thirteen Classics Commentaries and Subcommentaries*; originally "归" (guī), emended to "妇" (fù); originally "治" (zhì), emended to "殆" (dài); originally "以" (yǐ), emended to "其" (qí).]

*Hongdao Record*, Scroll Twelve

**On the Righteousness of Ruler and Minister**

The *Proclamation of King Kang* states: As the king emerged within the Gate of Response, the Grand Protector led the feudal lords of the western regions to enter through the left side of the Gate of Response, while the Duke of Bi led those of the eastern regions to enter through the right. All arrayed their chariots in yellow and vermilion, and as envoys, presented jade tablets and silken gifts, saying: "We, your humble ministers and guards, dare to offer this earth and pledge our allegiance." They bowed twice, touching their heads to the ground. The king, righteous heir to virtue, returned their bow.

The Grand Protector and the Earl of Mao both advanced, saying: "We dare to reverently inform the Son of Heaven: August Heaven altered the great mandate of the state of Yin. Only Kings Wen and Wu of Zhou, having received the blessing of the Supreme Ancestor, were able to succor the western lands. Now, as the new king arises, let rewards and punishments be meted out in full accord, and his achievements be firmly established, that they may be bestowed as blessings upon posterity. Let the present king take heed! Expand and glorify the Six Armies, and do not betray the meager mandate of our exalted ancestors."

The king proclaimed: "Ye feudal lords of the various states—marquises, earls, counts, viscounts, and barons—I, Zhao, hereby respond to your proclamation. In former times, Kings Wen and Wu brought great peace and prosperity, avoiding blame and attaining perfect harmony. They faithfully upheld the luminous mandate throughout the realm, and thus there were valiant warriors and ministers of unwavering loyalty who long preserved the royal house. Now, my uncles and elder ministers, I exhort you to look back and comfort the servants of your former lords, who served the preceding kings. Though your bodies may be afar, let your hearts never stray from the royal court. Thereby shall you attend to their needs and ensure no shame befalls the orphaned heir."

The *Record* states: Former scholars have interpreted the phrase "expand and glorify the Six Armies" as an encouragement for the king to valorize martial prowess. Others have said that in an era of established rule, rulers often indulge in ease and pleasure, lacking resolve—both views are mistaken. The great affairs of the state lie in sacrifice and warfare. When King Kang received the dying charge, the Grand Protector presented the sacrificial vessels, performing the threefold offering and the threefold libation. At that time, the king emerged from the gate to await the lords—there was no extraordinary occasion. Yet the proclamation began with "expand and glorify the Six Armies" precisely to underscore the great affairs of the state. This version of the text aligns with the *Dying Charge*, and for good reason. The king’s returning of bows and the mention of names all pertain to events before his coming of age. Thus, the phrase "righteous heir to virtue" does not imply foreseeing future concerns but rather reflects an overinterpretation.

**On Ruler and Minister**

The king proclaimed: "Junchen, your virtuous conduct is marked by filial piety and reverence. Your filial devotion extends to fraternal love, enabling you to enact good governance. I command you to oversee the eastern suburbs—be diligent!"

"In former times, the Duke of Zhou served as teacher and protector to the myriad people, who cherished his virtue. Go forth and attend to your duties with care, upholding the established norms. Strive to illuminate the Duke of Zhou’s teachings, that the people may long endure. I have heard it said: The fragrance of perfect governance moves the divine spirits. Millet and grain are not the true fragrance—only bright virtue is truly fragrant. You must model yourself on the Duke of Zhou’s plans and teachings, ever diligent, never indulging in ease. Before encountering a sage, one may not be reverent enough to perceive him; after encountering a sage, one may still fail to follow his path. Take heed!"

The *Record* states: In my humble view, though the Duke of Zhou resided in the east for three years, he did not personally oversee Yin. Yet the people of the east cherished him, saying: "Our lord’s son, adorned in embroidered robes." And again: "Do not take our lord away, lest our hearts grieve." The people of Shang had thus already recognized that only bright virtue is truly fragrant. To personally witness a sage is to be moved beyond measure. Precisely because Junchen’s filial piety, fraternal love, reverence, and respect enabled him to emulate the sage, he was commanded to take office and inspired to think of equaling the worthy. King Cheng’s treatment of Junchen was thus most fitting—not because the king sought to transform stubborn subjects by eschewing stern, resolute men in favor of those who embodied filial piety and fraternal love.

Junchen, if this is truly so, then the Way of ruler and minister is narrow indeed. If you have excellent plans and strategies, present them to your lord within the court, then carry them out without. Such counsel and plans shall be the virtue of our lord.

Alas! When all ministers act thus, how illustrious and manifest shall they be! Do not rely on power to intimidate, nor on law to oppress. Be magnanimous yet disciplined, composed yet harmonious. When the people of Yin transgress, I call it transgression; if you refrain from transgressing, I call it pardon; if you refrain from pardon, act with moderation. If there are those who do not conform to your governance or heed your instruction, punish transgression to halt transgression—this is transgression. Those who scheme against the law, subvert norms, and disrupt customs shall not be pardoned for even the slightest offense. Do not harbor resentment toward the stubborn, nor demand perfection from any single person. There must be forbearance—only then can there be success. With tolerance, virtue grows great. Be discerning in cultivating the cultivated, and also in addressing the uncultivated; promote the good to lead those who are not. Truly ascend to the great Way, that I alone may bear the weight of manifold blessings.

The *Record* states: In my humble view, King Cheng’s decree to Junchen was in truth a decree for all ages. For bright virtue and filial piety are the foundation of governance, while loyalty, compliance, magnanimity, and harmony are its instruments. If, in matters of authority, fortune, punishment, and law, or in moments of impulsive action, one errs by currying favor, leaning toward bias, demanding the impossible from others, leading them astray, or expecting perfection, none of these are the Way of perfect goodness. Thus, the king enumerated them all and concluded with the great virtue of forbearance. At that time, King Cheng was in the prime of his years, and what he could not endure or tolerate, he nonetheless proclaimed to others—thereby he could also exhort himself.

If not so, I say "punish," why wait for you not to punish? You say "pardon," why wait for you not to pardon, only to revert to halting punishment?

The *Bi Ming* states: In the twelfth year, on the sixth month and the gengwu day, three days later, on the renshen day, the king walked from Zongzhou in the morning and arrived at Feng. With the multitudes of Chengzhou, he commanded the Duke of Bi to oversee and regulate the eastern outskirts.

The king spoke thus: Alas! Father and Preceptor, it was King Wen and King Wu who spread great virtue throughout the realm, thereby succeeding in receiving the Mandate of Yin. It was the Duke of Zhou who assisted the former kings, stabilized their house, and settled the obstinate people of Yin, relocating them to Luoyi, close to the royal court, to transform them through instruction. After three generations, the world changed and customs shifted; the four quarters were without peril, and I alone enjoyed peace. The Dao rises and falls, governance follows the reform of customs. If one does not excel in excellence, the people will not exert themselves. Only you, Duke, have cultivated virtue, diligently attending to minor matters, aiding and illuminating four reigns. With upright demeanor, you lead those below, none failing to heed your words. Your fine achievements surpass those of the former kings. I, the little one, recline in reverence and rely on your accomplishments.

Now I command you with the affairs of the Duke of Zhou. Go forth! Distinguish the good from the wicked, mark their dwellings, make virtue manifest and evil concealed, establish a model in customs and reputation. Those who do not follow the canonical teachings shall have their fields and borders separated, so they may come to revere and emulate. Clearly delineate the outskirts, carefully secure the frontiers, to bring peace to the four seas. In governance, value consistency; in speech, uphold essential principles, not merely favoring the unusual.

The customs of Shang are decadent; glib speech is deemed worthy. The remnants of this wind have not yet vanished—bear this in mind, Duke! It was the Duke of Zhou who was prudent at the beginning, Lord Chen who harmonized the middle, and you, Duke, who will perfect the end. The three lords, with unified hearts, together attain the Dao. When the Dao permeates governance, its blessings moisten the people. The four barbarians, with robes folded left, all rely on this. May I, the little one, forever receive manifold blessings.

The *Record* states: In my humble view, the command to oversee and regulate was not solely for the obstinate people of Yin. Indeed, King Cheng’s system divided the realm in two, governing through the Two Lords. East of the Shan, the Duke of Zhou presided; his successor was Lord Chen; and the next successor was the Duke of Bi. Thus, upon ascending the throne, he regularly led the eastern lords to enter the Gate of Response. How solemn was his command—yet it was not his first departure. When the king newly ascended the throne, there were always words of announcement, yet the Duke of Shao, as the Western Lord, alone had none. Was this because he remained to assist the Son of Heaven? Or was it an omission in the records? We cannot know.

When it speaks of "settling the obstinate people of Yin," it refers to their origins. When it speaks of "the customs of Shang and the men of Yin," the people of Zhou always took Yin as their model in all matters—was this merely the language of announcement? Their poems all say: "The men of Yin are fair and keen, the descendants of Shang," and so on. When it says, "Distinguish the good from the wicked, make virtue manifest and evil concealed," this is the fundamental task of the state, not merely zeal for Yin. Nor does it mean that the Duke of Zhou’s strenuous efforts to subdue Yin were merely prudence at the beginning, or that Lord Chen’s tolerance harmonized the middle. Only now can one truly distinguish the good from the wicked.

All commentators fail to grasp the main purport of the classic text, taking the subjugation of the obstinate people of Yin in Luoyi alone as their focus. Thus, the grand intent of overseeing and regulating becomes a partial discourse on transforming Yin, not the legacy of King Kang’s reverent reliance on accomplishment. Clinging to one side, they nearly obstruct the passages on "the four quarters without peril," "bringing peace to the four seas," "blessings moistening the people," and "the four barbarians all relying on this." Readers must correct their understanding accordingly.

I have heard it said: Families with hereditary emoluments rarely abide by ritual, and their dissolute conduct violates virtue, truly contravening the heavenly Dao. The corruption of customs through extravagance flows the same through ten thousand generations. These many men of Yin, seated in the favor of old privileges, recklessly abandon righteousness to vie in finery, indulging in arrogance, excess, and self-importance, tending toward a wicked end. Though one may recover a wayward heart, restraining it is difficult. Wealth and nobility can instruct, but only through enduring years; only righteousness is the great instruction of the times. Without following the ancient teachings, how can one be instructed?

The *Record* states: In my humble view, how earnest was King Cheng’s warning to the men of Yin! A widespread reputation and far-reaching praise attach to oneself—why then covet another’s embroidered robes? The deceptive cap of Zizang of Zheng and the jade pendants of Dechen of Chu both ended in misfortune. And not only these. The nature that delights in fine food, the winds of seductive beauty, the desires of intoxication, the passions for wealth—these are all inevitable. Yet with the weight of royal commands, one cannot intermingle familiarity and levity. Thus, he spoke only of vying in finery.

Alas! Even in the Three Dynasties, this was so—how much more in later ages! This is why those who neither indulge nor seek are so difficult to select.

The *Jun Ya* states: The king spoke thus: Alas! Lord Ya, your grandfather and father were steadfast in loyalty and integrity, serving the royal house with labor, their achievements recorded on the grand banners. I, the little one, inherit the legacy of Wen, Wu, Cheng, and Kang, and also rely on the ministers of the former kings. Assisting in governing the four quarters, my heart’s anxieties are like treading on a tiger’s tail or crossing spring ice.

Now I command you to be my wing, my limbs and heart’s core. Polish your inherited service, do not disgrace your ancestors. Vastly spread the Five Canons, harmonizing the people’s norms. In your own conduct, be upright; dare not fail to be upright. The people’s hearts lack constancy; only your constancy can be their guide. In summer’s heat and rain, the little people only sigh in resentment; in winter’s bitter cold, the little people also only sigh in resentment—how arduous it is! Contemplate its difficulty to plan for ease, and the people will be at peace. Alas!

Greatly illustrious were the counsels of King Wen!
Greatly enduring were the achievements of King Wu!
They aided and enlightened their successors, all maintaining rectitude without flaw.

*Recorded thus: This refers to King Mu.*
The Master—would he have approved? He said, "No."
I observe that in the former court, there were no lack of chariot tracks and horse trails,
yet the paths of public and private affairs were ever divided into two distinct Ways.
Thus, the great principles of governance—laws, punishments, rites, and music—were the domain of impartial selection.
Indulgence in pleasure, excursions, music, beauty, wealth, and profit were the offerings of private desire.
The public was never to be abandoned for the sake of the private,
nor was the private to encroach upon the public.
The two proceeded in parallel without conflict, and thus disorder was averted.
Did not the Master say: "Zhong Buyu managed guests, Wangsun Jia commanded the army"?
How could the state have declined if King Mu had exercised his private judgment,
appointing Zaofu as his heart and core instead of Jun Ya as Minister of Education,
confounding the Five Teachings and Five Canons into a single path,
and mingling the noble and the base in key positions?
Then who would have planned for the sighs of resentment from the common people?
Who would have carried forward the counsels and instructions of Wen and Wu?
The sages included this in the Classics precisely to show that the constant norms must not be disordered,
and the great principles must not be neglected—its meaning is profound.

---

*The "Same Mandate" states:*
The king proclaims: "Bo Tong, I am inadequate in virtue, yet I succeed my ancestors to occupy this great legacy.
Restless and vigilant, I rise in the dead of night, striving to avoid error.
In the time of Wen and Wu, wisdom and sagacity were complete;
their ministers, great and small, were all loyal and good.
Their attendants, servants, and retinue were without exception upright men,
who from dawn to dusk assisted and corrected their lord.
In his going out and coming in, his rising and resting, there was none who did not revere him;
in his proclamations and decrees, there was none that was not excellent.
The people below revered and obeyed, and the myriad states achieved prosperity.
But I, alone, am without goodness. I rely entirely on the officers before and behind me,
who correct my shortcomings, restrain my errors, and rectify my misjudgments,
guiding me to overcome my unworthy heart and enabling me to carry forward the legacy of the former kings.
Now I command you to serve as Grand Rectifier, to oversee the attendants, servants, and retinue.
Exert yourself in cultivating the virtue of your lord, mutually refining what is lacking.
Carefully select your colleagues; do not employ those who are glib of speech and fair of face,
or those who are obsequious, fawning, and sycophantic.
Only the auspicious man—if the servants are upright, their lord will be upright;
if the servants flatter, their lord will deem himself sagely.
The lord’s virtue depends on his ministers; his lack of virtue also depends on his ministers.
Do not be intimate with petty men, who fill the offices of his ears and eyes.
Lead your superior away from the canons of the former kings—
if a man is not virtuous, his auspiciousness is not in his person but in his wealth.
If at any time you fail in reverence for your office,
unable to respect your lord, I will hold you accountable."

*Recorded thus: This refers to the Rectifier of Servants.*
As seen in the *Rites of Zhou*, these were the duties of officers,
those with whom the king associated day and night, never leaving his side in his movements and repose.
Their subordinates included:
- the Sacrificial Attendants, who assisted in rites;
- the Chamberlains, who attended to his rising and retiring;
- the Chariot Officers, who managed his war chariots;
- the Equipage Officers, who prepared his ceremonial carriages;
- the Stewards, who oversaw his household.
If the right men were chosen, their influence would be gradual and transformative,
leading the king toward goodness without his awareness.
If the wrong men were chosen, their flattery and blindness would lead him into evil unawares.
In later ages, when eunuchs were exclusively employed,
and favorites were indulged without official duties or the responsibility of remonstrance,
they concerned themselves only with glib speech, fair faces, obsequiousness, and flattery,
offering flattering words to gain favor and promoting greed to accept bribes.
Even in the Three Dynasties, historians foresaw the beginnings of this trend.
Though the mandate was given to Bo Tong, it was truly an instruction for all ages—
not waiting until the roots of disorder had formed before its evils became manifest.

---

It is further said: These two texts were composed by the benevolent and upright scholars of the time,
who spoke with sincerity to exhort their ministers—
precisely to move the king.
Yet observe: in one it is said, "their lord will deem himself sagely,"
and in the other, "his auspiciousness is in his wealth."
These two phrases are the root of the malady.
Was King Mu one who deferred to others?
He galloped and indulged himself, comparing himself to Yao and Shun or the lands of Lu and Fang.
He rejected remonstrance and concealed his faults, yet claimed the sagacity of Yu and Tang.
He had no leisure for rest, yet excused himself with the diligence of Wen and Wu.
Only then did he act with complete abandon, without restraint.
Once extravagant desires arose, who would suffice to satisfy the state?
This is why the *Lü Xing* speaks of redemption throughout—
the weight of wealth in that era is evident.
Yet it earnestly hoped that his servants would restrain his errors and correct his faults,
warning his ears and eyes against obsequiousness and flattery.
This was truly a skillful admonition of the ruler.
But whether Bo Wen would listen and take heed, or whether he would take it upon himself—
I cannot know, and thus cannot hold him accountable.

In the *Guoyu*, when King Mu planned to campaign against the Great Rong, Jigong Moufu remonstrated, saying: "It must not be done. The former kings radiated virtue and did not display military force. When arms are sheathed, they move only in due season; when they move, they inspire awe. To display them is to make a spectacle, and spectacle breeds contempt, leaving no reverence for the former kings’ way with the people. They cultivated upright virtue and enriched their nature, enriched their resources and improved their tools, clarified the paths of profit and harm, and refined them with culture. Thus they made the people pursue profit and avoid harm, cherish virtue and stand in awe of power—thereby preserving their reign and prospering.

The former kings’ system divided the realm thus: within the royal domain, the *dian* service; beyond it, the *hou* service; beyond that, the *bin* service; farther still, the *yao* service; and at the outer reaches, the *huang* service. Those in *dian* service offered sacrifices; those in *hou* service, seasonal rites; those in *bin* service, feasts; those in *yao* service, tribute; and those in *huang* service, acknowledged the king’s suzerainty. The rule was: monthly sacrifices, seasonal feasts, annual tribute—this was the former kings’ teaching. If sacrifices were neglected, they refined their intentions; if seasonal rites were omitted, they refined their words; if feasts were not held, they refined their culture; if tribute was withheld, they refined their reputation; if suzerainty was unrecognized, they refined their virtue. Once the proper order was established, if any still failed to comply, they applied punishments. Thus, those who did not sacrifice were punished; those who did not perform seasonal rites were attacked; those who did not feast were chastised; those who did not pay tribute were reprimanded; and those who did not acknowledge the king were admonished. Hence there were penal laws, punitive expeditions, campaigns of chastisement, commands of censure, and proclamations of reproof. If proclamations were issued and words delivered, yet compliance still failed, they further refined their virtue and spared the people distant labor. Thus, those near obeyed without fail, and those far submitted without resistance.

Now, since the death of the Great Bi and Bo Shi, the Great Rong have come to court in fulfillment of their duty. Yet the Son of Heaven says: ‘I shall punish them for their failure to feast and display my military might.’ Is this not to abandon the former kings’ teaching and bring the royal house to near ruin? I have heard that the Great Rong are steadfast in loyalty, able to follow ancient virtue and maintain unswerving constancy. They may well resist us."

The king did not heed him and proceeded with the campaign, returning with four white wolves and four white deer. From then on, those in *huang* service ceased to come.

A note observes: This was the beginning of the decline that led to King You’s murder. As the saying goes, ‘Treading on frost, one foresees solid ice’—calamity does not arise in a single day. From Mu to Kang was but two generations. The legacy of Wen and Wu still flourished, and the foundations of great peace remained unshaken. What was there to fear from the paltry Great Rong? Yet they did not realize that the venom of wasps and scorpions, once brewed, would swell into a deluge. The fall of the House of Zhou began here. The *Guoyu*’s opening admonition echoes Confucius’ intent.

Yet even with such warnings, there have been those who, without cause, schemed to conquer Yan, only to bring about the Jingkang disaster; and those who, recklessly launching northern expeditions, reaped the sorrow of Ya Mountain. Does not Mencius say: ‘A state that attacks itself will be attacked by others’? Is this not what is meant by ‘radiating virtue and not displaying military force’?

When King Li favored Rong Yigong, Yin Liangfu said: "The royal house will surely decline. Rong values monopolizing profit yet knows nothing of great peril. Profit is what gives rise to the myriad things, what heaven and earth sustain. To monopolize it invites great harm. Heaven, earth, and the myriad things all seek it—how can it be monopolized? The resentments it provokes will be many, yet he makes no provision against great peril. Can one who teaches the king thus endure for long? The king’s duty is to guide profit and distribute it throughout the realm, ensuring that gods, men, and the myriad things all attain their fullest potential. Even then, one must remain vigilant, fearing the rise of grievances. How can the king be taught to monopolize profit? Even a commoner who monopolizes profit is called a thief; if a king does so, few will follow him. If Rong Yigong is employed, Zhou will surely fall."

After Rong Yigong became minister, the feudal lords ceased their feasts, and the king was exiled to Li.

A note observes: How could profit alone sustain the royal house? When Zhou arose, it first dispersed the wealth of Lutai and then distributed the grain of Juqiao. The realm turned toward it as if blown by the wind, and governance and punishment were nearly set aside—people still praise it to this day. Yet as it declined, it was said: ‘Only goods are auspicious,’ and ‘All ends in wealth.’ The royal house gradually weakened until it was no better than the feudal states. From then on, the Son of Heaven descended to the hall to receive the lords. Yin Bo’s words were a timely warning, a mirror from Yin’s fall.

Though later sages and worthies—like Zihan, who spoke little of profit; Zengzi, who took rightness as profit; and Mencius, who also spoke of profit—differed in expression, their intent and purport were the same. As the age declined and the Dao waned, men clung to private desires. Only then did Liangfu’s words prove true. The Way of Wen and Wu had not yet fallen to earth, which is why, though there were the troubles of Yi, Li, You, and Ping, they did not end in the total ruin of head-counts and basket-levies.

The *Book of Songs* records Fan Bo’s rebuke of King Li:
"The Lord on High is perverse,
The common people utterly afflicted.
His words are not right,
His plans not far-reaching.
The wise are frivolous,
Not steadfast in uprightness.
His plans are not far-reaching—
Thus I offer great admonition.

When Heaven brings calamity,
Do not be so gleeful;
When Heaven topples the state,
Do not be so careless.
Words well-ordered,
The people are harmonious;
Words well-chosen,
The people are at peace.

Though our duties differ,
We share the same office.
I join you in counsel—
Hear my earnest plea.
My words are for service,
Do not take them as jest.
The ancients said:
‘Consult even the humble.’

When Heaven brings cruelty,
Do not be so reckless.
This old man speaks sincerely,
You, young man, are so constrained.
It is not that my words are senile—
You take them as raving.
The more you add to the flames,
The harder it is to save.

When Heaven brings disorder,
Do not be so obsequious.
Dignity is utterly lost,
The good play dead.
When the people are in distress,
None dare speak out.
Disaster and chaos abound,
Yet none show kindness to our hosts.

Heaven guides the people
Like ocarina and flute,
Like zhang and gui jades,
Like grasping and seizing.
Do not say ‘It is enough’—
Guiding the people is easy indeed."

When the people abound in depravity,
Do not set your own depravity.
The common folk are the fence,
The great army is the wall,
The great state is the screen,
The great clan is the pillar.
Embracing virtue brings tranquility,
The eldest son is the city.
Let not the city crumble,
Lest solitude breed fear.

Revere Heaven’s wrath,
Dare not jest or idle.
Revere Heaven’s descent,
Dare not gallop recklessly.
Vast Heaven is bright—
As you go forth to rule.
Vast Heaven is radiant—
As you wander in leisure.

The Record says: What is called reversal
Is when brightness shines below
And majesty above—this is the constant.
When the Supreme is perverse,
The people below perish—this is reversal.
In times of calamity, stumbling, cruelty, and disorder,
Heaven’s wrath has not long endured.
When all is flourishing, lax, clamorous, and frivolous,
The beginning’s intent slackens into complacency.

For human nature is such:
Without far-reaching vision or grand strategy,
The heart assumes no further peril,
And the sage’s warnings seem unwarranted.
One grows content with mere expediency, unaware.
If stern admonition could guide them,
And upright counsel correct them,
It might yet curb their reckless hearts
And restrain their rash habits,
Dispelling strife and monstrosity—
Perhaps then there would be hope.

Yet if petty men do not deceive with grand words,
They flatter with smooth talk.
Thus their hearts grow wanton,
Deceiving Heaven and deluding men without limit.
Then treacherous, unprincipled men enter,
And cruel, fearless deeds arise.
The good can do nothing,
And the people’s suffering reaches its extremity.
This is the origin of such decline.

Boundless is the Supreme,
The people’s sovereign.
Swift and stern is the Supreme,
Whose decrees are full of perversity.
Heaven births the black-haired people,
Yet its mandate is not steadfast.
All have a beginning,
Few endure to the end.

King Wen sighed,
“Alas, you, Yin-Shang!
Once so strong in defense,
Once so resolute in governance,
Once so steadfast in office,
Once so diligent in service.
Heaven sent down corrupt virtue,
And you exerted yourselves for it.”

King Wen sighed,
“Alas, you, Yin-Shang!
Holding to what is right,
Your defenses grew cunning,
Responding with slander,
And brigands thrived within.
Curses and imprecations arose,
Without end or limit.”

King Wen sighed,
“Alas, you, Yin-Shang!
You brought no order to the central lands,
But amassed resentment as virtue.
Your virtue was not bright,
Neither turning away nor aside.
With virtue so dim,
You had no ministers, no counselors.”

King Wen sighed,
“Alas, you, Yin-Shang!
Heaven did not drown you in wine,
Nor did it sanction wrongdoing.
Yet your conduct strayed,
Neither day nor night discerned.
With shouts and cries,
You turned day into night.”

King Wen sighed,
“Alas, you, Yin-Shang!
Like cicadas, like crickets,
Like boiling broth.
Great and small neared ruin,
Yet men still followed your ways.
Within, you ravaged the central lands,
And your reach extended to distant lands.”

King Wen sighed,
“Alas, you, Shang!
The Supreme is not timely,
Yin abandoned the old.
Though no elders remained,
There were still ancient models.
Yet you heeded none,
And the great mandate toppled.”

King Wen sighed,
“Alas, you, Yin-Shang!
Men have a saying:
When the roots are uprooted,
The branches and leaves cannot endure.
The mirror of Yin is not distant—
It lies in the age of the Xia.”

The Record says: This speaks of its end.
The distance between benevolence and tyranny is vast.
Yet it is not that Heaven bestowed different natures—
It is what ensnares the heart.
And so the decline reached such depths:
No order within, chaos without,
Like cicadas’ din, like boiling broth.

Confucius did not say,
“Zhou’s evil was not so extreme.”
Thus the noble man hates to dwell in the lower currents,
For all the world’s evils gather there.

At that time, the ministers of state,
From the Duke of Zhou and the Duke of Shao downward,
Mao, Ji, Ran, and Zai—
All shared the nation’s joys and sorrows.
Their lament could not but be deep,
Their grief could not but be keen.
Thus it is said:
“The fierce wind tests the sturdy grass,
In turmoil, loyal ministers are known.”
Through the ages,
Who would not sigh again and again?

King Xuan of Zhou, within, harbored the will to restore order.
Alarmed by disaster, he turned himself to cultivation,
Seeking to dispel it.
The realm rejoiced as royal governance returned,
And the people saw his concern.
Still Shu composed a poem in praise, saying:

“Mournful is that Milky Way,
Shining in the heavens.
The king said, ‘Alas! What guilt have the people of today?
Heaven sends down ruin and chaos,
Famine and starvation follow one upon another.
No god is left uninvoked,
No sacrifice withheld.
The jades and ritual tablets are spent,
Yet none heed my plea.

The drought is too severe,
The heat oppressive, sweltering.
No village rites are spared,
From the suburbs to the ancestral temples.
Above and below, no offering is neglected,
No god left unvenerated.
Yet Hou Ji does not respond,
The Supreme does not descend.
The land below is laid waste—
Why must it befall me?

The drought is too severe,
It cannot be averted.
Diligent and reverent,
Like thunder, like lightning,
The remnant of Zhou’s people
Are left with none surviving.
Vast Heaven, Supreme,
Why do you not aid us?
Why do you not fear
The wrath of our ancestors?

The drought is too severe,
It cannot be washed away.
Scorching, blazing,
We have no refuge.
The great mandate nears its end,
None look back, none heed.
The former lords and ministers
Do not assist us.
Our fathers and ancestors,
How can you bear this?

The drought is too severe,
Rivers and mountains run dry.
The drought-demon rages,
Devouring, burning.
My heart dreads the heat,
My sorrow is like dye.
The former lords and ministers
Do not hear us.
Vast Heaven, Supreme,
Will you let us wander?

The drought is too severe,
I strive in fear to depart.
Why do you afflict me with drought,
So suddenly, without cause?
I have prayed early and earnestly,
Made offerings to the gods of earth and grain.
Vast Heaven, Supreme,
Why do you not protect us?
Reverent and respectful to the bright spirits,
There should be no regret or wrath.

The drought is too severe,
All bonds are broken.
Alas, the many ministers,
Alas, the steward of the household!”

The Masters of the Horse and the Household Stewards,
The royal chefs and attendants—
No one is uninvolved,
None can cease their duties.

Gazing up to Vast Heaven,
What is to be done?
Gazing up to Vast Heaven,
Its stars are dim and ravenous.
Great officers and noble lords,
Make your bright prayers without fail.
The great mandate draws near its end—
Do not abandon what you have achieved.
What do you seek for me,
To bring ruin upon the many ministers?
Gazing up to Vast Heaven,
When will it grant us peace?

**Recorded Note:** This is the foundation of King Xuan’s restoration.
To regard the people as if wounded—this was the true heart of King Wen’s ancestor.
The Grand Minister of Education, with the twelve famine policies, gathered the myriad people—this was the practical affair of the *Rites of Zhou*.
With a true heart seeking true action, how could one not be earnest and vigilant, as if reviving from fire?
Here we see that the former kings did not use routine measures as an excuse, nor did they resort to vague indifference, but rather took it upon themselves to bear the burden. Only then did the many ministers cry out in distress, and the steward of the household grieve.
No one is uninvolved,
None can cease their duties.
If even a single thought of slackness arises, I see the Three Dukes and great officers no longer toiling day and night, the feudal lords no longer attending morning and evening—how then could they stabilize the many offices?
Thus, the words of Emperor Wu of Han on water and drought as mere routine, and Emperor Shenzong of Song on heavenly portents as nothing to fear, were but their own regrets, not the regrets of others.
Alas!
Those who grasp heat without washing will never cease; those who fear disaster only when it strikes will turn back in an instant.
This sudden collapse and abrupt revival cannot be spoken of in the same breath.
When the House of Zhou was in decline, the myriad people scattered, yet King Xuan was able to toil and gather them, returning and settling the wandering masses. The people rejoiced and composed a poem, saying:
*The swans and geese take flight,
Their wings rustling in formation.
These men on the march toil and labor,
In the wilds they reach even the bereaved—
In a single dawn, the widowed and orphaned.*

*The swans and geese take flight,
Gathering in the central marsh.
These men build walls a hundred spans high,
Though they toil and labor,
In the end, they secure a peaceful home.*

*The swans and geese take flight,
Their cries resounding in unison.
These wise men call me toiling,
Those fools call me proud.*

**Recorded Note:** This was the governance of King Xuan’s restoration.
Only with a heart of diligence, caution, and vigilance could there be policies of toil and gathering, of settling the people.
Before the *Lesser Odes*, the *Sixth Month* stands at the head of its achievements.
This record is made.
As for the profound meaning of the swans and geese—it differs from the mere praise of cicadas and crickets.

A great officer, reproaching King You, said:
*“In the royal month, frost thickens,
My heart is filled with sorrow.
The people’s rumors spread,
And greatly they swell.
Thinking of myself alone,
My anxious heart is heavy.
Pity my timid heart,
Wracked with pain and distress.
My parents gave me life—
Why must I suffer so?
Not before me, not after me—
Good words come from the mouth,
Weeds come from the same mouth.
My anxious heart grows heavier,
Thus I am humiliated.
My anxious heart is restless,
Thinking of my ill fortune.
The people’s innocence is lost,
Even their servants are enslaved.
Pity us, the people here—
From whom shall we seek fortune?
Watching the crows alight,
Upon whose roof do they settle?
Gazing at the central grove,
Now kindling, now brushwood.
The people now face peril,
Heaven’s will is dark and confused.
Once order is established,
No one will fail to prevail.
August Heaven above—
Who does it truly hate?
They say the mountains are low,
Yet they become deceptive ridges.
The people’s rumors spread—
Why is no one to restrain them?
Summon the elders of old,
Question them on their dreams.
All claim to be sages—
Who knows if the crow is male or female?
They say Heaven is high,
Yet one dare not stand upright;
They say the earth is thick,
Yet one dare not tread firmly.
Who utters such words,
With reason and kinship?
Why do the people today
Act like venomous snakes?
Gazing at those slope fields,
The solitary reeds stand tall.
Heaven has burdened me,
As if it cannot endure me.
When I seek them, they flee,
As if they cannot find me.
They grasp me with enmity,
Nor do they aid me.
My heart’s sorrow,
Is like a knot tied within.
This year’s governance—
Why is it so harsh?
The fire blazes high,
Yet someone may extinguish it.
Radiant was the House of Zhou,
Yet Bao Si destroyed it.
Ever I ponder this,
Now beset by dark clouds.
The cart is loaded,
Yet you discard its supports.
The load is shifted,
‘Elder brother, help me!’
Do not discard the supports,
Strengthen the spokes.
Turn often to your driver,
Lest the load shift.
Though you traverse perilous paths,
How could you not be mindful?
The fish in the pond
Are not truly at ease.
Though they hide in the depths,
They are clearly seen.
My heart is filled with sorrow,
Thinking of the state’s cruelty.
There is fine wine,
And excellent dishes.
In harmony with neighbors,
Marriage ties are close.
Thinking of myself alone,
My heart is deeply troubled.
Those in distress have homes,
The trembling have grain.
The people now are ill-fated—
Heaven marks them for ruin.
How strange the wealthy—
They too reach this bitter solitude!”*

**Recorded Note:** The *anguish* spoken of in *The Planks* and *The Ruin*—that was the time of heavenly reprimand. The *anguish* in this poem—this is the time of self-abandonment.
The *destruction* in *The Mulberry*—that was the day disorder arose. The *destruction* in this poem—this was the day of the state’s collapse.
For the cruel and violent reign of King Li, and the debauchery of King You that brought it to its extreme—this is why Heaven and earth seemed to offer no refuge.
Yet this poem both names Bao Si as the one who brought ruin and refers to the enslavement of ministers—taboo words—yet it was not charged as slanderous or seditious. Had there been no tragedy of kin or the disaster of the Quan Rong, it might have been foretold.
Alas! The spokes break, the wheels shatter—yet no one could stop it.
Heaven’s benevolence could not overcome human delusion—how pitiful!

On the conjunction of the tenth month, at the new moon on the day *xinmao*, the sun was eclipsed—how utterly foul!
That moon was dimmed, and now this sun is dimmed.
The people below today—how utterly wretched!
Sun and moon foretell calamity, yet their paths are not heeded;
The four lands lack governance, and their worthy men are not employed.
That the moon is eclipsed is but its usual course;
That the sun is eclipsed—what is not amiss?
Thunder crashes and lightning flashes, unsettling and unruly.
The hundred rivers boil and surge, mountains and hills collapse.
High banks become valleys, deep ravines become mounds.
The people of this wretched age—why do they not correct their transgressions?
The Grand Minister Huangfu, Fan as Minister of Education,
Jiabo as Steward, Zhongyun as Master of the Kitchen,
Zhizi as Internal Scribe, Jue as Master of the Horse,
and Qiao as Master of the Guards—his favored wife stirs trouble in every quarter.

Yet this Huangfu—was he not appointed in due time?
Why then does he act against me, refusing to consult me?
