He tears down my walls and houses, leaving my fields to rot and my crops to wither.
He says, "I do not harm you—such is the ritual propriety."
Huangfu, so sagely wise, builds a capital at Xiang,
selecting three officials for his service, all men of wealth and rank.
Not a single elder is left behind to guard our king.
He chooses those with chariots and horses to dwell in Zu and Xiang.
I toil diligently, never daring to complain of hardship.
Innocent and blameless, yet slanderous tongues clamor against me.
The people’s suffering is not sent down from Heaven—
it arises from those who lead them astray and incite hatred, all by human hands.
Oh, my homeland—how grievously afflicted!
All around, others live in ease, while I alone dwell in sorrow.
None rest, yet I dare not cease my labor.
Heaven’s decree is not yet fulfilled; I dare not follow my peers in complacency.

---

*Recorded Note:*
According to the *Rites of Zhou*, the Three Dukes deliberate on the Dao, and the Six Ministers divide their duties—there is no such office as "Prime Minister." Yet in King You’s reign, beyond the Six Ministers, he established the office of *Du Guan* to oversee all six ministries, though it was not a prime ministerial post. How then did Huangfu alone disrupt the established order, bringing about the ominous eclipse even in the pure yang month of the tenth? It was because King You’s virtue was benighted and weak, heaping disaster upon the common people. Construction of private estates never ceased, and ministers colluded in factions—how long could the state endure?

Alas!
In King Li’s time, the laws were not yet abolished;
In King You’s age, not a single elder was spared.
In King Li’s time, monopolies were held by the throne;
In King You’s age, private enrichment was rampant.
Though both kings brought ruin upon themselves, the survival of the royal house differed—why?

When the Zhou court was forced to relocate eastward, the ministers, passing through the old ancestral temples and palaces now overgrown with millet and sorghum, grieved for the fallen altars of state. Hesitating, unable to bear leaving, they composed a poem:

*"Those millets stand in rows, those sorghums sprout anew.
My steps are slow, my heart adrift.
Those who know me say my heart is full of sorrow;
Those who know me not ask what I seek.
Oh, boundless Heaven—who is this man?"*

*Recorded Note:*
When Confucius spoke of the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, he said: *"Those who know me will do so through the* Spring and Autumn*; those who condemn me will do so through the* Spring and Autumn."*
Is this different from the poem’s *"Those who know me say my heart is full of sorrow; those who know me not ask what I seek"*?
No, there is no difference.
The eastern relocation was no minor upheaval. For the Son of Heaven, it meant regicide; for ministers and sons, it meant humiliation; for the altars of state, it meant destruction; for the ancestral temples, it meant ruin. Since the dawn of time, there had never been a catastrophe so great. Yet at the time, no one questioned it. The lord grew complacent in serving his enemies, the ministers in enduring disgrace. Heaven and earth closed, yet none sought to open them; the people’s hearts perished, yet none sought to revive them. Did they not see the rows of millet and ask, *"What do I seek?"*
It was grief for the collapse of royal governance, fear that Heaven’s punishment would be abandoned—thus they wished to advance but could not move forward.
Those who knew them understood: they sighed at the sight of millet, grieved at the desolation of temples and halls.
Those who did not know them asked: *"Why does a mere minister presume to bear the burden of survival, overstep his bounds to plan for the altars of state, attempt what is impossible, and strive for what cannot be achieved?"*
Hence: *"What do I seek?"*
Yet in truth, they could not forget it for even a moment. Thus they cried out to Heaven in lament—not for themselves, nor from overstepping their station.
When our Master edited the *Book of Songs*, he deeply grasped this sentiment, which is why he echoed it to show that the *Spring and Autumn Annals* could not be abandoned, nor could the ministers’ lament be suppressed.
How profound!

The *Spring and Autumn Annals* begins: *"In the first year of Duke Yin of Lu, in spring, in the king’s first month..."*

*Recorded Note:*
When the *Songs* perished, the *Spring and Autumn Annals* arose. The *Spring and Autumn* was composed to teach the principles of the world for ten thousand generations—yet where did these principles first take root?
At that time, the true king had ceased to rule, the feudal lords ran wild, and governance and decrees no longer reached the realm. Thus, each lord recorded their own years, no longer observing the Son of Heaven’s calendar; each state chronicled its own affairs, no longer adhering to the king’s universal authority. What an age this was!
Shaozi said: *"The time of the Five Hegemons was like winter."*
Like winter—when earth’s *qi* does not rise, Heaven’s *qi* does not descend, all is closed and stagnant. How could one hope for the return of spring?
Even Zigong, so wise and capable, wished to abolish the practice of presenting the sacrificial lamb at the announcement of the new moon. The Master told him: *"You love the lamb, but I love the ritual."*
This ritual is why the Middle Kingdom does not resemble the barbarian tribes, why the Dao does not resemble the beasts. Why? The barbarians do not recognize a lord; the beasts do not recognize spring. Can men be less than they?
First, the king; then, spring—how solemn is the principle of Great Unity!
To violate it is to invite unforgivable punishment; to usurp it is to incur unrecorded guilt.

The rectification of the fundamental norms elevates the dignity of the hierarchical order; the establishment of human principles gives rise to ritual and righteousness. Thus, the great righteousness between ruler and minister endures alongside Heaven and Earth without fail.

*Hongdao Lu*, Scroll Twelve, concludes. #1 "Shang" was originally written as "商," corrected here according to the context.

*Hongdao Lu*, Scroll Thirteen: *Righteousness*
**The Righteousness Between Ruler and Minister**

From the *Records of the Grand Historian*: The Han King crossed south at Pingyin Ford and arrived at Luoyang. Dong Gong, the Tribal Elder of Xincheng, intercepted and addressed the King, saying: "I have heard that those who follow virtue prosper, while those who defy it perish. If an army marches without just cause, its affairs will not succeed. Therefore, it is said: ‘Make clear that they are rebels, and the enemy may then be subdued.’ Xiang Yu acted without the Dao, deposing and killing his lord—he is a traitor to all under Heaven. Now, benevolence does not rely on courage, nor righteousness on brute strength. Your Majesty should lead the Three Armies in mourning attire, proclaiming this to the feudal lords and then punishing him." Thereupon, the King held a funeral for Emperor Yi, announcing to the lords: "All under Heaven jointly enthroned Emperor Yi, yet Xiang Yu has deposed and killed him. I personally mourn him, and my troops all wear white. I will mobilize all forces from within the Pass, gather the warriors of the Three Rivers, and sail south along the Yangtze and Han to join the feudal kings in attacking the one who murdered Emperor Yi."

The compiler notes: This single act secured the Han’s four hundred and twenty years of rule. The grand principle and great righteousness that shine as brightly as the sun and stars originate precisely here. Alas, the ranks of the founding meritorious officials did not include him, and so the name of Xincheng has faded into obscurity to this day. What a pity!

It is further said: That Emperor Zhaolie of Han could not unify the realm was only to be expected. "If an army marches without just cause, its affairs will not succeed; make clear that they are rebels, and the enemy may then be subdued." This is a matter of eternal strategy, a pivotal moment for all under Heaven. Xiang Yu and Cao Cao were comparable in power, one preceding the other, while Liu Bang and Liu Bei were both outmatched at the time. Yet Bang could brand Xiang Yu a traitor, while Bei could not publicly condemn Cao’s crimes—why? The righteousness between ruler and successor is of equal weight. When Cao murdered Empress Fu, had Bei truly been able to uphold great righteousness—issuing proclamations to the realm, holding a funeral, donning mourning garb, condemning Cao’s heinous crime, and declaring his punishment unforgivable—before raising troops to punish him, how few would have failed to respond, and how unlikely Cao would have been to escape unscathed! This was a path identical to that of his grandfather. Yet, unaware of this course, he conspired with Dong Cheng, relying on a secret edict hidden in the emperor’s robe, plotting Cao’s assassination. Alas! To call it "secret" is one thing, but how could such words befit one who rules over others? Thus, the Dong of the Three Kingdoms was clearly inferior to the Dong of Xincheng. Though Cheng himself is not worth reproach, at the time Fa Zheng was renowned for his strategic acumen, and Zhuge Liang for his understanding of grand principles—yet they failed to seize the moment. Merely denouncing Cao as a "traitor to Han" in a memorial at Sanguan Pass was of no avail. Only when Master Zhu later compiled the *Outline of the Comprehensive Mirror* and explicitly recorded the murder of the empress did the righteousness become clear. Was this not a regret for the ages!

From the *Book of Han*: Emperor Gao did not cultivate literature but was by nature perceptive, fond of planning, and able to heed advice. Even gatekeepers and soldiers treated him as an old friend. Initially, he aligned with the people’s will, establishing the Three Articles of Law. After pacifying the realm, he ordered Xiao He to codify statutes and decrees, Han Xin to refine military regulations, Zhang Cang to standardize administrative procedures, and Shusun Tong to devise rituals and ceremonies. He also divided tokens of investiture with his meritorious officials, inscribing iron charters in cinnabar, storing them in golden caskets and stone chambers within the ancestral temple. Though he claimed to have no leisure, his vision was vast and far-reaching.

The compiler notes: This "vast and far-reaching vision" was a lesson drawn from the successes and failures of Qin and Xin. For leniency in simplicity is the Way of Heaven. When Qin rose, its prohibitions were so dense they allowed no room; when Xin rose, its reforms were so hurried they seemed never-ending. Even to the point of weighing documents by the stone and setting quotas for paperwork, leaving no time for rest—this left no loopholes in governance, yet they did not realize that Heaven’s Way is not so rigidly constrained. Now, Heaven is vast—whether fine or coarse, high or low, it accommodates all without fail, yet never deviates from its principles. A ruler who models his governance on Heaven’s Way may grant or withhold, take or give, yet never transgress his measure. Qin abolished the feudal system, and Xin restricted land ownership, calculating to the last fraction—yet they did not foresee that collapse comes like tiles shattering or earth crumbling, not piece by piece. The Grand Historian also observed that continuity and adaptability prevent weariness, showing keen insight into human nature.

In the second year of Emperor Wen’s reign, an edict proclaimed: "When a ruler lacks virtue, Heaven sends disasters to warn of misrule. I, below, have failed to govern and nurture the people; above, I have burdened the brilliance of the Three Luminaries—my lack of virtue is great indeed. Let all reflect on my faults and what my knowledge and vision have failed to grasp, and report them to me in detail. Also, recommend those who are worthy, upright, and capable of forthright remonstrance to correct my shortcomings."

The compiler notes: This marked the beginning of forthright remonstrance. Thereupon, Jia Shan submitted a memorial titled *Utmost Words*. However, it was not recorded here, for while Shan’s words may be called forthright, they cannot be called "utmost." He drew analogies from Qin, believing it a warning, yet he did not realize that the Emperor revered Heaven, moved the people, cherished them, economized, broadened the paths for speech, honored modesty, curbed extravagance, and rejected tribute—these were his true intentions. Within months of his accession, it was already evident that the faults Shan cited were not the Emperor’s shortcomings. Why, then, did he persist in emphasizing the ruler’s awe-inspiring might, comparing it not only to thunder and lightning but to the weight of ten thousand jun? And why did he speak of the Zhou supporting eighteen hundred states while Qin received sustenance from eighteen hundred? At the time, the court ministers were still mired in Qin’s taboos. Upon seeing this, they blindly praised it as *Utmost Words*.

From my humble perspective, the Emperor’s shortcomings lay not in failing to attain the utmost good, but in contenting himself with the base and the near while neglecting the worthy and the sagely. This was no minor failing. As the *Tradition* says: *"In resting, know where to rest—can man be inferior to the birds?"* The implications for rousing the realm and all generations to come are most profound.

Deluded by the Yellow Emperor and Laozi’s doctrine of purity and quiescence, he did not grasp that the noble man spares no effort in pursuing the ultimate. How, then, could one wonder at his taking pleasure in galloping, archery, and the hunt, or finding joy in striking down hares and felling the solitary? Had he but gained the company of men like Yi, Fu, Guan, or Shao, sitting with them to discourse on the Dao, I would have seen him revere them as divine, trust them as oracles—how could such cultivation flourish in a household yet falter in the imperial court?

All that he did was the work of a vulgar man, not the province of sages and worthies. Yet while the ruler sought worthies above, those below responded only with sycophants. How could Shan, no pure Confucian, be expected to comprehend the kingly Way?

Jia Yi memorialized: *"I privately consider the present governance—one matter calls for bitter weeping, two for flowing tears, and six for long sighs. As for other transgressions against principle and harm to the Dao, they are too numerous to list in full."* Yet those who offered counsel all claimed: *"The realm is at peace; it is already well-ordered."*

I alone hold that this is not so. Those who say the realm is at peace and well-ordered are either fools or flatterers—none truly grasp the essence of order and chaos. It is like one who embraces fire beneath a pile of kindling and sleeps atop it, calling it safe before the flames ignite. How is the present situation any different?

The Record states: *"In Emperor Wen’s time, there were two men named Jia. The Jia of Luoyang was no match for the Jia of Yingchuan."* Not only were his words urgently relevant to the moment, but his critique of Qin’s failures struck at the vital points of Han’s governance. Thus, I have recorded them in full.

Yet while governing a state relies on ritual propriety, his words lacked restraint—even Confucius would have smiled in disapproval. Having just ascended the grand court, he immediately spoke of bitter weeping, flowing tears, and long sighs—this was an unmeasured display, not a virtuous one.

To establish a stable state, one must first resolve the mutual suspicions between ruler and ministers. If the ministers frequently suffer calamity and the ruler is constantly beset by worries, this is no way to secure the throne or preserve the people. If one desires the realm’s peace and order, nothing is better than enfeoffing many lords while diminishing their power. With less power, they are easier to guide with righteousness; with smaller domains, they harbor no treacherous ambitions.

Now, the governance of the realm is like the body commanding the arm, the arm commanding the fingers—all submit without resistance. The lords of the feudal states dare not entertain disloyal thoughts; they converge like spokes to a hub, pledging allegiance to the Son of Heaven. Divide the lands and establish fixed boundaries, ordering Qi, Zhao, and Chu each to form several states, so that their descendants may inherit them in succession. Where lands are plentiful but heirs are few, establish new states and leave them vacant. When descendants are born, appoint them as rulers. Not an inch of land nor a single subject would the Son of Heaven seek to claim—this is done solely to secure order.

The Record states: *"Later, the proposals of Chao Cuo and Mainfu Yan both originated from this idea. The difference lay in Jingdi’s poor handling, which led to chaos, while Wudi’s adept use brought success—yet the core of the argument remained sound."*

Emperor Wen’s reign was a time when such measures could have been taken. The era of enfeoffment was not distant; the kings of the great states were either aged and senile or too young to be strong. The officials appointed by Han still held sway over affairs. Had he subtly divided the power of the Seven States and quietly stripped the feudal lords of their authority at that time, it would have required no great effort. To have missed this opportunity and later endured the toil of shattered axes and broken blades—was this the folly of youthful impracticality?

In the early days of Han’s founding, no hasty measure was as reckless as the system of enfeoffment.

*The Rites of Zhou* established the distinctions between major and minor lineages, between ancestral temples and branch shrines—where the main line of descent remained emperors for a hundred generations, collateral branches became feudal lords for a hundred generations, and cadet houses became grand officers for a hundred generations. Thus, the widespread enfeoffment of feudal lords was the natural order of things. How could it be that the sovereign himself remained a king, while his collateral kin became commoners; that the wealthy possessed fifty or seventy cities, while the poor had not even a foothold of land? This was not merely a matter of impractical power dynamics—it was also a violation of principle. Yet with all the Emperor’s wisdom, filial piety, and boundless love, he failed to examine its causes. Those who were fortunate enough to live in his time merely broached the subject without pursuing it to its conclusion, while Jiang and Guan further disparaged the idea. If even scholars of talent met with such misfortune, could this not be the will of Heaven? Could this not be the will of Heaven?

They asked the ruler to abandon ritual propriety and cast aside benevolence and grace, uniting all hearts in the pursuit of advancement. After two years of such governance, Qin declared it a failure. In old families, when sons grew strong, they were sent out to establish their own households; in poor families, when sons grew strong, they were sent out as live-in sons-in-law. Borrowing their father’s sacrificial vessels, they wore the air of virtue; their mothers took up dustpans and brooms, standing to berate them, while they cradled their own children, sitting as equals with their fathers. When mother and daughter-in-law could not please one another, they turned on each other with sharp tongues. Their love for their children and greed for profit differed little from beasts. Even now, the remnants of these customs remain unchanged—abandoning ritual propriety, competing in self-righteousness, with each month bringing new extremes and each year new excesses. In the worst cases, they even kill their fathers and brothers. Yet the great ministers treat only the failure to submit reports or meet deadlines as grave matters, while the corruption of customs and the ruin of the age pass unnoticed, accepted as if it were all inevitable.

To transform customs and turn the hearts of the world toward the Dao—this is not something petty officials can achieve. The concerns of petty officials lie in brushes and ledgers, unaware of the greater whole. And Your Majesty does not take it upon yourself to grieve. I can only lament this for Your Majesty.

A Record states: This is what I call the disease of the Middle Han, deep in the marrow and beyond cure.

Consider how the ancients used omens to distinguish good from evil and display them in their villages, how they employed bells to manifest virtue and suppress vice, establishing customs that inspired awe and admiration—was this because they delighted in such complexity? Truly, with the decadence of Shang customs lingering unchecked, even in times of repeated prosperity, they did not forget the harm of extravagance and excess. One saying declared: "The security or peril of the state rests upon these men of Yin." Another warned: "Arrogance, excess, and self-satisfaction will lead to a bad end." Yet the Duke of Zhou was vigilant at the beginning, Jun Chen harmonized the middle, and the Duke of Bi perfected the end. Only after three sages had governed a single region did they come to understand how difficult it is to transform customs and turn the hearts of the world toward the Dao.

The Han arose by force of arms and ruled by the power of the brush, inheriting from Qin a chaotic mix of hegemonic practices. In the worst cases, they were led astray by Huang-Lao teachings—how could they not suffer the pain of a life in turmoil? If they had possessed the resolve of Kings Cheng and Kang, seeking elders of virtuous power and diligent governance to support their rule, achieving success through non-action, they might still have feared that day and night would prove insufficient, that sitting idle would lead to irreparable loss. Yet they regarded such men as mere youths and novices—how could this not evoke deep sighs?

Master Guan said: "Ritual, propriety, integrity, and shame—these are called the Four Pillars. When the Four Pillars are not upheld, the state perishes." If Master Guan were a fool, one might dismiss him; but if he had even a slight grasp of governance, how could one not shudder? When Qin destroyed the Four Pillars and failed to uphold them, ruler and minister fell into chaos, the six relations suffered calamity, traitors arose in droves, and the people rebelled. In just thirteen years, the altars of state lay in ruins. Today, the Four Pillars remain incomplete, so traitors still find opportunity, and the people’s hearts waver in doubt. How can this compare to establishing fixed institutions, ensuring that ruler acts as ruler and minister as minister, with proper order between high and low; that father and son, the six relations, each fulfill their roles; that traitors find no opportunity, and the multitude of ministers and people trust without suspicion? If institutions are not fixed, it is like crossing a river without oars or moorings—caught in the current amid wind and waves, the boat will surely capsize. This is what calls for endless sighs.

A Record states: This is the urgent task of statecraft, a matter demanding deep reflection from all under heaven. Master Guan, whom even the Five Schools of Thought would be ashamed to cite, still understood that ritual, propriety, integrity, and shame are the Four Pillars of the state—how could the disciples of the great sages not know the path to a state’s destruction? The opportunism of traitors has been a constant since antiquity. Where favor and profit reside, where power and authority converge, men swarm like flies drawn to filth, like ants gathering without agreement—how much more so when the ruler’s call beckons? Thus, all boundaries of shame and moral restraint dissolve, and the most intelligent of creatures become no better than gnats or mosquitoes. The reason they ultimately perish is that what makes a state is its people, and what makes people is their hearts.

The sages of old valued sincerity in governance and prized concision in speech, aiming to guide the human heart firmly toward rectitude, to unify it clearly in oneness. Only then could the Dao flourish, politics be ordered, the people be nourished, and the barbarians of the four directions, with their collars left unfastened, all rely upon them. Without the Way of steadfast adherence and maintenance, the world would drift in confusion, not knowing where to turn. Human desires would run rampant, Heavenly principle would vanish, and the state’s ruin would be but a matter of time. This was the disaster that befell the Western Capital when its institutions collapsed, leading to the calamity of Wang Mang—and only then were Jia Yi’s warnings proven true. Was Master Guan truly a fool?

Ritual restrains before transgression occurs, while law punishes after the fact. Thus, the effects of law are easily seen, while the effects of ritual are difficult to perceive. Did the former kings refrain from using rewards to encourage virtue and punishments to deter evil? Yet they spoke of ritual because it is noble to extinguish evil before it sprouts and to cultivate teaching in its subtlest forms, so that the people daily move toward goodness without realizing it. For those who plan for the ruler, nothing is more important than first carefully examining what to accept and what to reject. When acceptance and rejection are firmly settled within, the sprouts of safety or peril will manifest without.

Tang and Wu broadly cultivated their virtue and conduct, and their dynasties endured for six or seven hundred years without faltering. The Qin ruler governed the world for little more than a decade before suffering total defeat. There was no other reason for this. Tang and Wu’s decisions on acceptance and rejection were judicious, while the Qin ruler’s were not. The world is a great vessel: place it in safety, and it is safe; place it in danger, and it is in peril. Tang and Wu placed the world upon benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music; the Qin ruler placed it upon laws, decrees, and punishments. This is plain for all to see—how could the outcome not be as clear as the difference between a great steed and a nag?

A Record states: Mencius said: "Is the arrow-maker less humane than the armor-maker? The arrow-maker fears only that he will not harm others, while the armor-maker fears only that he will." The shaman and the carpenter are the same. Thus, one cannot be too careful. This so-called "extension" refers precisely to acceptance and rejection. Tang and Wu placed the world upon benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music because they feared harming others. The Qin ruler placed it upon laws, decrees, and punishments because he feared not harming enough. In their origins, were they truly evil by nature? A deviation of a hair’s breadth leads to an error of a thousand miles. This is why those who govern must be urgently attentive to what they esteem.

Likes and dislikes take shape within, and only then are acceptance and rejection settled internally. The sage’s heart embraces all things yet remains unattached, his emotions accord with all things yet remain unmoved—truly because likes and dislikes cannot be indulged. If what he likes is biased toward one thing, the world rushes toward it in unison; if what he dislikes falls into partiality, the world suddenly turns against it.

The emperor was not unaware of the merits and flaws of benevolence, righteousness, laws, and decrees—only, deluded by other paths, he lacked the resolve to hold firm. His judgment was not without insight when he spoke thus. Had the emperor truly set aside his biases to reform institutions, goodness would have followed; to establish laws, compliance would have ensued. What was there to fear that he would not do? Yet yielding is a matter of conduct, while humility is a matter of the heart. If the heart does not lie in action, one sees only one’s own meddling.

In the first year of Emperor Wu’s reign, a decree summoned men of worth, uprightness, and forthright counsel. The emperor personally posed questions on governance past and present. Dong Zhongshu of Guangchuan responded: “I observe the awe-inspiring interplay between Heaven and man. Unless it is an age utterly devoid of the Dao, Heaven ever desires to uphold and secure all things—this lies in nothing but unrelenting effort. By striving diligently in learning, one’s knowledge broadens and insight sharpens; by striving diligently in practicing the Dao, virtue daily arises and great achievements follow. The Dao is the path on which all governance depends, and benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and music are its instruments. Thus, when sagely kings have passed, their descendants endure for generations, enjoying peace for hundreds of years—all through the power of ritual and music’s transformative teaching. The Zhou’s Dao declined under Kings You and Li, yet the Dao itself did not vanish; You and Li merely failed to adhere to it. When King Xuan later reflected on the virtue of the former kings, revived what had languished, and repaired what was broken, clarifying the achievements of Kings Wen and Wu, the Zhou’s Dao flourished once more. This was the result of unceasing diligence in practicing goodness.”

*Recorded:* This was the first of the *Heaven-and-Man* memorials. His call to “strive unrelentingly” aligns with the *Doctrine of the Mean*’s teaching on gradual progress leading even lesser men to greatness. Since the Han, few scholars have grasped this—yet Dong, lowering his curtain to study with single-minded devotion, gained much from such striving. Thus, in the grand court examination, he placed this at the forefront of his response, unlike later generations who merely cobbled together hackneyed phrases with no bearing on reality. Yet the emperor, endowed by Heaven with a bold and unrefined nature, sought only to surpass the ancients and outshine his contemporaries. How could he willingly submit to the humble task of striving in the practice of the Dao? Had Jia Yi or Dong Zhongshu encountered the civil and martial rulers of the Han, their exhortations to diligence might have found purchase with a yielding sovereign, while their own breadth of understanding would have suited a ruler of grand vision. Alas, Heaven does not bend to accommodate, and they were cast where they did not belong. Thus, for a hundred generations, men recite their words, long for their persons, discuss their era, and lament their lord—what sighs of regret!

For one who would be a true ruler: rectify the heart to rectify the court; rectify the court to rectify the officials; rectify the officials to rectify the common people; rectify the common people to rectify the four quarters. When the four quarters are rectified, near and far alike dare not stray from the upright, and no perverse *qi* or treachery can arise between them. Thus, yin and yang harmonize, wind and rain come in their seasons, all living things flourish, and the people multiply. All auspicious omens and blessings that can be summoned will arrive in full, and the kingly Way is complete.

Now Your Majesty, exalted as the Son of Heaven and enriched by the possession of the Four Seas, occupies a position where attainment is possible and wields power that can bring it about. Moreover, you possess the capacity to achieve it—your conduct is lofty, your kindness profound, your wisdom clear, your intentions noble, your love for the people sincere, and your regard for scholars earnest. You may be called a ruler of righteousness. Yet Heaven and Earth do not respond, and no felicitous signs appear—why? It is solely because transformative teaching has not been established, and the common people remain unrectified. The people’s pursuit of profit is like water flowing downward; without the embankment of transformative teaching, it cannot be halted. The kings of old understood this well. Thus, in ruling the world from their southern-facing throne, none failed to make transformative teaching their foremost duty. They established the Grand Academy to instruct the capital and set up local schools to civilize the towns. They gradually imbued the people with benevolence, polished them with righteousness, and regulated them with ritual. Thus, their punishments were light and prohibitions few, for transformative teaching was in effect and customs were refined.

*Recorded:* Since the Qin, the learning of the heart has nearly vanished. Zhongshu’s words were a true compass for the Han court. Yet alas, the ruler was driven by many desires, and his ministers, though offering counsel on rectifying the heart, were like one yoking oxen to the north while expecting the cart to go south—such was the blindness that went unheeded. In the Song dynasty’s *Longxing* era, Emperor Taizu came to understand this principle, saying: “Few ancient rulers could rectify their hearts to reach a state of flawlessness. I, day and night, stand in awe and fear, guarding against wrongdoing and restraining desires, hoping to fulfill the meaning of transforming the people through virtue.” Such a man could indeed be spoken to of rectifying the heart to rectify the court. And so, throughout the Song dynasty, yin and yang harmonized, wind and rain came in their seasons, all living things flourished, and the myriad beings thrived. Who can say that Zhongshu’s words were without effect?

I have heard that when sagely kings governed the world, they used ranks and emoluments to nurture virtue and punishments to deter evil. Thus, the people understood ritual and righteousness and felt shame in offending their superiors. King Wu practiced great righteousness, pacifying the cruel and violent, while the Duke of Zhou composed ritual and music to refine the age. By the flourishing reigns of Kings Cheng and Kang, the prisons were empty for over forty years—this, too, was the gradual effect of transformative teaching and the flow of benevolence and righteousness. Now Your Majesty rules all under Heaven, yet your achievements do not extend to the common people—this is likely because the kingly heart has not been applied. Master Zeng said: “Revere what you have heard, and you will attain loftiness; practice what you know, and you will achieve greatness.” Loftiness and greatness lie in nothing else but applying one’s intention. I hope Your Majesty will establish sincerity within and carry it into action—then how will you differ from the Three Kings?

*Recorded:* This was the second memorial. When the ruler of men, in his supreme dignity, deigns to inquire twice, his intent is clear. Zhongshu could not alter his argument, so he further emphasized revering what one has heard and practicing what one knows, making his words as distinct as black and white. How could they be confused with the likes of Du Qin or Gu Yong, who wielded their cunning and peddled their deceptive schemes? This is why his memory lingers, evoking admiration—not like those who merely gleaned fragments of stale rhetoric.

Yet if a single word suffices for understanding, why wait for a second inquiry before changing course?

The Dao is everlasting, without flaw through ten thousand generations. Flaws arise only from the loss of the Dao. The Xia esteemed loyalty, the Shang valued substance, and the Zhou honored refinement—each adapted to the needs of their succession. The great origin of the Dao issues from Heaven; as Heaven does not change, neither does the Dao. Thus, Yu succeeded Shun, Shun succeeded Yao, and the Three Sages transmitted and upheld one unchanging Way, free from the decay of governance. Therefore, they did not speak of what they had altered or added.

From this, we see: those who succeed a well-ordered age follow the same Dao, while those who succeed a disordered age must adapt their Way. Now, the Han has arisen after great chaos; it would be fitting to slightly reduce the refinement of the Zhou and govern with the loyalty of the Xia.

The *Spring and Autumn Annals* upholds grand unification as the constant principle of Heaven and Earth, the shared norm of past and present. Yet today, masters teach divergent Ways, men hold conflicting doctrines, and the Hundred Schools offer disparate methods with differing aims—so that above, there is no means to maintain unity. I, in my foolishness, believe that all teachings not encompassed within the Six Arts or the scholarship of Confucius should have their Ways severed, not permitted to advance alongside. Only then can the system of governance be unified, laws be made clear, and the people know what to follow.

*Recorded:* This was the third memorial. What Zhongshu presented was the transmitted Way of Yao, Shun, and the Three Dynasties. What the Emperor favored were the words of power, defense, merit, profit, and literary ornamentation. Yet what the Chancellor memorialized to abolish were the doctrines of Shen [Buhai], Shang [Yang], Han Fei, Su Qin, and Zhang Yi. How could these three be more disparate than wind and horse or ox, utterly unrelated?

Moreover, if one wished to discard the Hundred Schools and exalt Confucius, why not adopt Zhongshu’s proposals? Diligently pursuing learning and practicing what one knows would distance the harm of heterodox and perverse teachings day by day, while the effects of loftiness and greatness would draw ever nearer.

Yet the Emperor spurned true scholars and kept them at a distance, while men like Zhuang Zhu, Sima Xiangru, Dongfang Shuo, and Mei Gao all stood at his side. Where, then, was his elevation of one and suppression of the other? From this, the Emperor’s conception of a "scholar" may be discerned.

At the time, the Emperor was summoning scholars from the Grand Academy, often saying, “I wish to...” But Ji An, a man of blunt nature and little courtesy, who would confront others to their faces and brook no tolerance for their faults, replied: “Your Majesty harbors many desires within yet outwardly practices benevolence and righteousness—how can you hope to emulate the governance of Tang and Yu?” The Emperor fell silent, his face darkening with anger, and dismissed the court. To his attendants, he said: “How excessive is Ji An’s insolence!”

At the time, all the high ministers feared for Ji An, and some even berated him. Ji An said: “The Son of Heaven appoints ministers of the Three Dukes to assist and correct him—should we merely flatter and comply with his wishes, leading the ruler into unrighteousness? Moreover, I occupy this position; even if I cherish my own life, how can I bear the disgrace to the court?”

*Recorded:* Emperor Wu could tolerate Ji An but not Yan Yi—because the bonds of fame and profit prevailed. Those who praise Tang and Yu or delight in the Yin and Zhou—how could they truly avoid forthright speech? Yet they do so not out of joy but necessity. Those who indulge in extravagance and excess or pursue every desire—how could they escape the need for levies and corvée? Yet they do so not through persuasion but coercion.

Thus, though the words of many desires may linger in the ruler’s heart, the reproach of retort truly harms his governance. This is why some were executed and others were not.

In the fourth year of the *Zhenghe* era, the Emperor issued an edict deeply lamenting his past regrets, saying: “There are those who have memorialized requesting distant military colonies at Luntai, intending to establish garrisons and outposts—this would disturb and weary the realm, not bring peace to the people. I cannot bear to hear of it. Henceforth, our efforts must lie in prohibiting harshness, halting unauthorized taxes, strengthening agriculture, and restoring the horse-rearing ordinances to fill shortages, ensuring our military preparedness does not falter—nothing more.”

Thereafter, he no longer dispatched armies, and enfeoffed Tian Qianqiu as Marquis of Enriching the People, to make clear his intent to rest and enrich the people.

*Recorded:* The edict of self-reproach at Luntai and the edict of self-reproach at Fengtian—are they the same?
It said: “They are not.”

The remorse of Emperor Wu arose from his innermost heart—what is called, "As the bird is about to die, its song is mournful; as the man is about to die, his words are kind." Thus was he able to wash clean the stains of old and embrace the transformation of renewal. The awakening of Emperor Dezong relied upon Lu Zhi—what is called, "The virtue of the noble man is like wind; the virtue of the petty man is like grass. When the wind blows over the grass, it must bend." Thus was he also able to turn chaos into order and peril into peace. Since ancient times, the movement of creatures and the resonance of sound have never stirred men so swiftly—truly so.

Wind and clouds, frost and dew—ever-changing and unpredictable; the eclipses of sun and moon—yet their brilliance cannot be obscured. How can later rulers afford to be heedless?

Emperor Xuan arose from the lanes and alleys, knowing the hardships of the people’s affairs. After Huo Guang’s death, he began to attend to governance himself, rousing himself to order, holding court every five days. From the Chancellor downward, each official presented his duties and memorials; he examined their words and tested their abilities. For the Attending Secretaries and Ministers whose merit warranted promotion, or who had exceptional virtue, he bestowed generous rewards, extending even to their descendants, never to be altered. The mechanisms of governance were meticulous, the standards and forms complete; above and below were at peace, with no room for carelessness.

*Recorded:* There were the sagely kings of Shang, who succeeded six or seven times because they had labored long in the field. There were the sovereigns of Zhou, Cheng and Kang, who so ably followed their predecessors because they knew the peril of ease. For the nature of ordinary men is such that without seeing what they desire, they cannot be moved to love; without seeing what they detest, they cannot be stirred to hate. Though Emperor Xuan was of lofty character and fond of learning, had he not arisen from the lanes and alleys, how could he have known the hardships of the people’s affairs, the successes and failures of official governance, and thus achieved a restoration rivaling the virtue of Shang and Zhou? This was not merely born of adversity and refined by Heaven’s favor—here, the will of Heaven is yet more manifest.

At the time, Bing Ji and Wei Xiang served together as Chancellors. Xiang was fond of studying past precedents, frequently compiling the expedient measures and policies of the Han dynasty since its founding, as well as the proposals of worthy ministers like Jia Yi, Chao Cuo, and Dong Zhongshu, and submitting them for implementation. He instructed officials to inspect affairs in the commanderies and kingdoms. Even when on leave from court, upon returning to the capital, he would report unusual news from the four quarters. If there were rebellions, unseasonable winds or rains, or disasters that the commanderies had not yet reported, he would memorialize them at once. Together with Bing Ji, he aided governance with one heart. Ji valued magnanimity, favored ritual propriety, and did not involve himself in minor matters. The people of the time considered him a man of great understanding, and they said of them: "When Gaozu laid the foundation, Xiao and Cao stood foremost; when Xiaoxuan revived the dynasty, Bing and Wei resounded with renown." Later Chancellors could not match them.

*Recorded:* After Xiao He and Cao Shen, the Chancellors appointed by the Han were mostly old generals or meritorious officials. These men of arms could not read literature or recite the classics, while those like Gongsun Hong, who came after, merely curried favor with their learning. Only Wei Xiang rose from the ranks of the worthy and virtuous, known for his stern integrity. Meeting with Emperor Xuan’s reign, he was able to remove the secondary marquisates, remonstrate against military campaigns, reclaim the power of the Huo clan, and curb the excesses of the imperial house. Had men like Jia Yi and Dong Zhongshu encountered such an opportunity, would they have failed the Han? Alas! "If I am not at ease, how can I expect my descendants to follow my example?" Thus the noble man grieves that his words are not established, not that his virtue has no peer. This is not only the renown of Bing and Wei—it is also the vindication of Jia and Dong.

The emperor, seeing the submission of the Rong and Di barbarians, thought of the excellence of his ministers, and so had their likenesses painted in the Unicorn Pavilion, depicting their forms, and inscribing their ranks, names, and titles. Only Huo Guang was not named, but recorded as "Grand Commandant, Grand General, Marquis of Boling, of the Huo clan." Following him were Zhang Anshi, Han Zeng, Zhao Chongguo, Wei Xiang, Bing Ji, Du Yannian, Liu De, Liangqiu He, Xiao Wangzhi, and Su Wu—eleven men in all—each renowned in their time for merit and virtue. Thus were they honored and exalted, their restoration of the dynasty made manifest, ranked alongside Fang Shu, Shao Hu, and Zhong Shanfu.

*Recorded:* In the order of the Unicorn Pavilion, precedence was given to those who had aided the emperor’s accession. Yet the purpose of these portraits was to reflect the submission of the four barbarians and to honor the excellence of the emperor’s ministers—it did not prioritize Su Wu’s steadfast integrity. If the intent were to display the abundance of China’s talent, then in Emperor Wu’s time, though he exhausted his heart and mind, often seeking "horses that outrun their teams" and "men who gallop ahead," his efforts to employ extraordinary envoys for distant missions were extreme. Yet Li Ling and Wei Lü defected in droves, and among them, only Ziqing held fast for nineteen years without wavering—truly a lament for the decline of China’s talent. Had Wu returned in Emperor Shizong’s reign, he would surely have been elevated to an exceptional rank. Alas, the white silk of his memorials came too late, and his black hair turned early. This was Wu’s misfortune, not the Han’s wise strategy—how much more so when the Xiongnu were still unruly? The arguments of examination candidates, for the most part, are not the words of those who have attained the Way and cannot serve as instruction.

Emperor Cheng, when still Crown Prince, indulged in wine and revelry. When the Prince of Zhongshan, Ai, died, the Crown Prince paid his respects without sorrow, greatly displeasing Emperor Yuan. Only when the Attached Cavalry Commander, Shi Dan, removed his cap in apology did the emperor’s anger subside. As Emperor Yuan lay gravely ill, he repeatedly questioned the Secretariat about the precedent of Emperor Jing’s establishment of the Prince of Jiaodong. Shi Dan, as an intimate minister, was able to attend the emperor during his illness. Waiting until the emperor was alone, he entered the bedchamber, prostrated himself upon the green rush mats, and wept as he said: "The Crown Prince, as the eldest legitimate heir, has been established for over ten years. His name and title are bound to the people, and all under Heaven turn their hearts to him. Yet now, rumors spread through the streets, suggesting that the Crown Prince’s position is in question."

Should this be the case, the ministers and officials from the Three Dukes downward would surely resist to the death and refuse to obey the edict. I beg to be put to death first as an example to the assembled ministers." Moved by these words, the emperor’s resolve wavered, and he said to Dan: "My illness grows ever worse, and I can no longer recover. You must assist the Crown Prince well and not defy my wishes." Dan, sighing deeply, rose to his feet, and thus the Crown Prince’s position was secured until his accession.

During the Yuanyan era, the former magistrate of Huaili, Wei Yun, submitted a memorial requesting an audience. In the presence of the assembled ministers, Yun declared: "The great officials of the present court are all mere placeholders, consuming salary without merit. I beg to be granted the executioner’s sword from the Imperial Armory to sever the head of one sycophantic minister, that the rest may be admonished." The emperor demanded: "Who is it?" Yun replied: "The Marquis of Anchang, Zhang Yu." Enraged, the emperor declared: "A petty official dares to slander his superiors and humiliate his teacher in open court—his crime is death, and he shall not be pardoned." The imperial censors seized Yun and dragged him away. Clinging to the palace railing, Yun broke it as he was pulled down, crying: "To descend and join Long Feng and Bi Gan in the underworld would be enough for me!" The censors then hauled Yun away. Thereupon, the Left General Xin Qingji removed his cap, kowtowed at the foot of the dais, and pleaded: "This minister has long known Yun to be recklessly forthright. If his words are correct, they cannot be punished; if they are false, they should be tolerated for his past conduct." The emperor’s anger subsided. Later, when the railing was to be repaired, the emperor said: "Do not replace it."

Thus was it compiled, to honor the upright minister.

The record states: Shi Dan’s prostration upon the green rushes and Zhu Yun’s breaking of the palace railing—both were celebrated events of their time, yet it remains unclear which course truly yielded gain or loss. The disasters of the Han dynasty began with Emperor Cheng, and the Wang clan’s usurpation was consummated by Zhang Yu. Had it not been for Shi Dan’s seasoned judgment, the indecisive sovereign might well have been replaced, and whether the Han would have remained the Han is uncertain. Had Zhu Yun’s words been heeded, the head of the treacherous minister would have been struck off, and whether the Wang would have become the Wang is likewise uncertain. Alas! Dan acted with seasoned conduct, while Yun shattered the railing. The former’s course was one with which one could stand firm, though not one with which one could weigh shifting circumstances. The latter’s act was persuasive yet lacked thorough deliberation, followed yet left unamended—herein lies the division between gain and loss.

From the *Later Han History*:
Deng Yu of Nanyang, staff in hand, pursued Emperor Guangwu to Ye. Guangwu said: “I now hold sole authority over enfeoffments. Having come from afar, do you seek office?” Yu replied: “I do not.” He continued: “I only wish that your illustrious virtue and power extend to the four seas, and that I may contribute my modest efforts, leaving my name recorded upon bamboo and silk.” Guangwu laughed and detained him for the night. Yu then offered counsel, saying: “Now the land east of the mountains remains unsettled. The Red Eyebrows and Green Calves number in the tens of thousands. Gengshi, though mediocre, does not heed wise counsel, while his generals are all common men. Their ambitions lie in wealth and coin, their methods in brute force, seeking only momentary gratification. None possess loyalty, wisdom, deep foresight, or long-term planning to honor their lord and pacify the people. Your Excellency, by contrast, has long been renowned for your great virtue and merit, revered throughout the realm. Your military governance is solemn and strict, your rewards and punishments clear and trustworthy.”

For the present strategy, nothing is better than to summon heroes far and wide, strive to please the people’s hearts, establish a lofty and enduring enterprise, and save the lives of the myriad people. If you, my lord, take the realm into consideration, its pacification will not be difficult.

Guangwu was greatly pleased.

The record states: Who does not wish to leave their name and achievements upon bamboo and silk? When drought becomes a disaster, the divine dragon is trapped in the shallows; when nets and snares are not removed, the auspicious qilin suffers calamity. Had Wenshu not risen, Nanyang would remain a wilderness of weeds—how then could one offer even the slightest contribution? Now, observing Deng Yu, though he has just reached the age of twenty, he already comprehends grand strategy, aspiring directly to establish the enterprise of Gaozu and save the lives of the myriad people—far beyond what an ordinary man could achieve. Moreover, his words on the depth of virtue subtly align with the principle that the benevolent are invincible. Thus, his coming from afar—was it truly to seek office? It further confirms that when the dragon rises, clouds follow; when the qilin arrives, auspicious omens respond. Is it not fitting that he should be counted among the foremost meritorious officials?

The Red Eyebrows wrought havoc, and the great clans of the Three Auxiliaries’ commanderies and counties each hoarded troops. Guangwu then dispatched the Deputy General Feng Yi to suppress them. The imperial carriage escorted him to Henan, where Guangwu instructed Feng Yi: “The Three Auxiliaries have suffered the chaos of Wang Mang and Gengshi, compounded by the cruelty of the Red Eyebrows and Cen Peng. The common people are mired in suffering, with nowhere to turn for redress. General, as you now carry out the imperial mandate to subdue the lawless strongholds, send those who surrender with their chieftains to the capital. Disperse the common folk to return to farming and sericulture, and dismantle their fortifications to prevent them from regrouping. Conquest does not necessarily require seizing land or massacring cities; what matters is pacification and restoration. The generals are not lacking in martial prowess, yet they are fond of seizing spoils and plundering. They must be restrained from such conduct. The officers and soldiers should be mindful of self-discipline, so as not to be viewed with suspicion by the commanderies and counties.”

Feng Yi bowed deeply, received the command, and marched west. Wherever he went, he displayed authority and trustworthiness, and many bandits surrendered.

The record states: The Emperor’s instructions to Feng Yi did not merely issue warnings. Deng Yu’s grand vision, singularly focused on pacification and restoration, reveals the heart of one who would be a parent to the people. For benevolence cannot be matched by violence, and Feng Yi and Deng Yu were of one mind. Deng Yu’s timely intervention corrected the excesses of the age. That such a course was both necessary and true to principle is precisely what a ruler should esteem. By contrast, the Northern Song court, through men like Wang Anshi, Tong Dun, and Cai Bian, brought about chaos, while the restoration under Gaozong later entrusted power to Huang Qianshan, Wang Boyan, and Qin Hui without reproach—like ill-omened birds taking flight, nothing could be done. In such cases, no blame can be assigned.

In the third year of Yongping during the reign of Emperor Ming of the Han, the Emperor, reflecting upon the meritorious officials of the Restoration, had portraits of the twenty-eight generals painted in the Yun Terrace of the Southern Palace. Deng Yu was placed first, followed by Ma Cheng, Wu Han, Wang Liang, Jia Fu, Chen Jun, Geng Yi, Du Mao, Kou Xun, Chuan Jun, Cen Peng, Jian Tan, Feng Yi, Wang Ba, Zhu You, Ren Guang, Ji Zun, Li Zhong, Jing Dan, Wan Xiu, Gai Yan, Xing Tong, Yao Qi, Liu Zhi, Geng Chun, Zang Gong, Ma Wu, and Liu Long. Additionally, Wang Chang, Li Tong, Dou Rong, and Zhuo Mao were included, making thirty-two in total. Notably absent were those related to the imperial consort.

It is recorded: In my humble observation, the strategies and bearing of the Yun Terrace generals seem not to match those of the founding heroes of the Western Han, yet they achieved fame that eclipsed their age. Why is this? For Gaozu excelled at commanding generals, while Guangwu excelled at commanding troops. Those of magnanimous vision and great capacity embody the essence of leading generals; those of keen talent, courage, and strategic acumen embody the foundation of leading soldiers. Thus, though the battle array at the Backwater was beyond Gaozu’s comprehension, the victory at Kunyang was Guangwu’s to claim. Zhang Liang alone could devise the stratagem of borrowing arrows, yet Guangwu’s "rice-map" planning was already clear in his mind’s eye. Had Gaozu encountered such circumstances, Kou [Xun] and Deng [Yu] would not have swiftly reaped the fruits of victory in their twilight years. Had Guangwu been at the helm, Han [Xin] and Peng [Yue] might not have achieved the triumph at Gaixia. The generals of these two Han dynasties, each encountering their time and sovereign in different ways, nonetheless achieved the same success.

*Hongdao Record, Volume Thirteen, concludes*
*Hongdao Record, Volume Fourteen, "Righteousness"*

The Righteousness of Ruler and Minister

In Zhuge Liang’s *Memorial on Dispatching the Army*, he states: "The late Emperor’s enterprise was not yet half-completed when he passed midway, and now the realm is divided into three, with Yizhou exhausted—this is truly a critical moment of survival or extinction. Yet the ministers who attend and guard within do not slacken, and the loyal and devoted officers who risk their lives without regard abroad do so because they cherish the late Emperor’s extraordinary favor and wish to repay it to Your Majesty. It is truly fitting to broaden the scope of sagely hearing, to illuminate the late Emperor’s bequeathed virtue, and to invigorate the spirit of the aspiring officers. One should not recklessly belittle oneself, draw improper analogies, or obstruct the path of loyal remonstrance. The palace and the court are one body; rewards and punishments, praise and censure should not differ. If there are those who commit treachery or violate the law, or those who act with loyalty and goodness, they should be handed over to the responsible officials to deliberate their punishment or reward, thereby manifesting Your Majesty’s impartial and enlightened governance. Partiality should not be shown, lest the laws within and without diverge.

Attendants Guo Youzhi, Fei Wei, and Dong Yun—these are all men of integrity, whose aspirations and thoughts are loyal and pure. The late Emperor selected and promoted them to bequeath them to Your Majesty. I believe that for matters within the palace, all should be consulted with them, for they will surely remedy omissions and oversights, yielding great benefit. General Xiang Chong is virtuous and impartial in conduct, well-versed in military affairs. The late Emperor praised his ability, and the consensus appointed him as commander. I believe that for matters within the camp, all should be consulted with him, for he will surely harmonize the ranks and ensure that the capable and the less capable are each properly placed.

To draw near worthy ministers and distance petty men—this is how the Former Han flourished. To draw near petty men and distance worthy scholars—this is how the Later Han declined. I, your minister, was originally a commoner, tilling the soil in Nanyang, seeking only to preserve my life in a chaotic age, not aspiring to fame among the feudal lords. The late Emperor did not regard my lowliness and baseness, but humbly condescended to visit me thrice in my thatched cottage, consulting me on the affairs of the age. Moved by this, I pledged myself to his service. Later, when defeat befell us, I received my commission amid the ruins of the army and carried out my mission in times of peril—twenty-one years have passed since then. The late Emperor knew my prudence, and so on his deathbed entrusted me with the great task. Since receiving this command, I have labored day and night in anxiety, fearing that the trust would not be fulfilled and that the late Emperor’s wisdom would be impugned. Thus, in the fifth month, I crossed the Lu River and ventured deep into barren lands. Now the southern lands are pacified, and our arms are sufficient; it is time to rally and lead the three armies to conquer the Central Plains.

This is how I repay the late Emperor and fulfill my duty to Your Majesty. As for weighing gains and losses and offering loyal counsel to the utmost, that is the responsibility of Youzhi, Wei, and Yun. I hope Your Majesty will entrust me with the task of punishing the rebels and reviving the dynasty. If I fail, then punish my crime. Your Majesty should also deliberate for yourself, seeking and heeding wise counsel, scrutinizing and accepting refined advice, and pursuing the late Emperor’s final decrees. Now, as I part from you, tears wet this memorial, and I know not what I have said."

The *Record* states: How rare and steadfast was Liang’s loyalty! When one can be assisted, one assists; when one cannot, one withdraws. This was the command of Emperor Zhaolie on his deathbed, yet Liang could not but sacrifice himself for the times. To cherish the late Emperor’s extraordinary favor and desire to repay it to Your Majesty—this was Marquis Wu’s unparalleled insight, resolutely dedicating himself to righteousness. Preceding him were men like Dong [Zhuo], Yuan [Shu], Cao [Cao], and Sima [Yi], yet he left behind these two memorials as his personal vows. It is like the clash of deviant and upright arrows, from which a brilliant star emerges in their wake, or the surge of obstinate and venomous forces, against which the sun and moon shine forth in radiant clarity.

When he said, "The palace and the court are one body," it was not merely the language of family and kin, but truly a matter of life and death for the Latter Lord. When he said, "Draw near worthy ministers and distance petty men," it was not merely a pressing concern of recent warning, but truly the origin of order and chaos for all ages. When he said, "Your Majesty should also deliberate for yourself, seeking and heeding wise counsel, scrutinizing and accepting refined advice," it was not merely the hope of a vital plan in his lifetime, but truly the ultimate fate of the Han enterprise after his death. Thus it is said: Kongming was a figure of the Three Dynasties; Guan Zhong and Yue Yi are not worth discussing.

In the *Second Memorial on Dispatching the Army*, he states: "The late Emperor deeply considered that the Han and the rebels could not coexist, and that the royal enterprise could not be content with partial security, so he entrusted me with the task of punishing the rebels. Given the late Emperor’s discernment and my own meager talent, he knew well that my strength was insufficient to overcome the enemy. Yet if the rebels were not punished, the royal enterprise would still perish. To sit and await destruction—how is that better than taking action? Thus he entrusted me without hesitation.

Since receiving this command, I have not rested easy, nor found savor in my food. It is not that I do not value myself, but that the royal enterprise cannot be content with partial security in the capital of Shu. Thus I brave peril and hardship to fulfill the late Emperor’s bequeathed intent, though critics call this unwise. Now the enemy is weary in the west and occupied in the east—military strategy dictates seizing the moment when the enemy is exhausted. This is the time to advance. Emperor Gao’s brilliance rivaled the sun and moon, and his strategists were profound, yet he endured hardship and danger before achieving security. Your Majesty does not yet match Emperor Gao, nor do your strategists equal Zhang [Liang] and Chen [Ping], yet you seek to secure the realm with long-term plans and a passive strategy—this is something I do not understand.

Since I arrived in Hanzhong, barely a year has passed, yet we have lost Zhao Yun, Yang Qun, and others—all elite warriors gathered from the four corners over decades, not confined to one province. If several more years pass, what will we use to contend with the enemy? Now the people are impoverished and the troops exhausted, yet the task cannot cease. If it cannot cease, then whether we remain or advance, the toll in labor and expense will be the same."

Yet have you not considered planning with emptiness in mind? For the most difficult to pacify is the course of events.

Long ago, the late Emperor suffered defeat in Chu. At that time, Cao Cao clapped his hands, declaring the realm already settled. Yet afterward, the late Emperor forged alliances with Wu and Yue, took Ba and Shu in the west, raised troops for a northern campaign, and beheaded Xiahou. This was Cao Cao’s miscalculation, and the Han cause nearly succeeded. Then Wu broke its covenant, Guan Yu met ruin, setbacks followed at Zigui, and Cao Pi proclaimed himself emperor. Affairs unfold thus—hard to foresee in reverse.

I shall exert myself to the utmost, until death. As for success or failure, advantage or dullness, these lie beyond the foresight of my limited wisdom.

*Recorded:* Zhuge Liang deemed Cao Cao’s generalship equal to Sun and Wu, yet in these two memorials he proposed no extraordinary schemes or secret strategies—only the military principle of striking the weary as his present plan. Could Liang truly have failed to consider other options? Yet without the self-effacing humility of Tang of old, how could the campaign at Mingtiao have been launched? Without the unwavering resolve of King Wu, how could the valor of Mengjin have been displayed? With Liu Shan as sovereign and Liang as his minister, with Sun Quan as foe and Sima Yi as subject—it is as if one sought to lift a burden by gazing upward like Yao, or to herd sheep by entrusting them to wolves. How could this be governance?

Yet the Han and the usurpers cannot both stand; the royal enterprise cannot endure in partial retreat. The grand righteousness must resound throughout the realm. Thus he declared first: "I shall rouse and lead the Three Armies, pacify the Central Plains, restore the Han, and return to the old capital." And second: "I shall not rest easy in my seat nor savor my food, but devote myself wholly until death." Liang’s heart knew its own impotence. Yet his forthrightness and integrity stand apart from those who fawn and scurry in hope of luck.

Tang Zhang Yungu’s *Admonition on the Great Treasure* says:

From ancient times to the present, gazing below and above, only the sovereign bestows fortune—truly, to be a ruler is difficult. Presiding over all beneath heaven, enthroned above princes and dukes, receiving tribute from the lands and counsel from the assembled officials—thus the heart of fear slackens, and the passions of perversity grow unchecked. How could one know that affairs arise from what is overlooked, and calamity from what is unanticipated?

Thus the sage receives the Mandate, rescues the drowning, relieves distress, takes blame upon himself, and aligns his heart with the people. The great brightness shines without partiality; the utmost impartiality admits no private favor. Therefore, with one man he governs the world, not with the world he serves one man. Ritual curbs excess; music prevents dissipation.

Do not say, "No one knows"—from on high, he hears the lowly. Do not say, "What harm?"—small accumulations become great. Joy must not reach its limit, for at its height sorrow is born. Desire must not be indulged, for indulgence breeds disaster.

Though he dwells within ninefold gates, his chambers need not exceed what shelters his knees. Yet the deluded adorn their towers with jade and their halls with gems. Though eight delicacies are arrayed before him, his meal need not surpass what satisfies his palate. Yet the mad dream of heaping their dregs into hills and pooling their wine into lakes.

Do not let lust within lead you astray; do not let hunting without lead you astray. Do not prize rare goods; do not heed the music of fallen states. Punish only after all abandon a man; reward only after all delight in him. Weaken the strong and govern the chaotic; extend the bent and redress the wronged.

Thus it is said: Like the balance and the stone, do not weigh things with partiality—what hangs will reveal its true weight. Like water and the mirror, do not show things your bias—what is reflected will reveal its true nature. Do not be turbid, for turbidity muddies; do not be too pure, for purity exposes. Do not be obscure, for obscurity confounds; do not be too keen, for keenness blinds.

Though the crown’s tassels veil your eyes, see what has no form. Though the earplugs block your ears, hear what has no sound. Let your mind roam in the realm of clarity; let your spirit wander in the essence of the supreme Dao. Those who know it respond to the vast and the minute like an echo; those who draw from it fill themselves whether they take little or much.

Thus it is said: Heaven’s constancy, earth’s tranquility, the king’s steadfastness—though the four seasons do not speak, they alternate in order; though the myriad things do not speak, they are transformed and completed. How could one know the emperor’s power and yet the world be at peace?

Our king overthrew disorder with wisdom and force; the people feared his might but did not yet cherish his virtue. Our sovereign governs with pure wind; the people embrace his beginning but do not yet secure his end. Therefore, I set forth this golden mirror, exhausting the divine and perfecting the sagely, so that men may respond with their hearts to its words, and their conduct encompass the principles of governance. Its phrases rise and fall, its admonitions take shape.

The world is held in common; if one man has cause for celebration, the net of blessings unfolds, the zither is strummed, and poems are composed. Day after day, this remains ever in mind. What men summon, Heaven aids. With upright ministers to oversee integrity, I dare to present these doubts before you.

The Record states: Since the Han, China passed through six dynasties, and the North and South endured the two Jin. Yet to the rulers and ministers of Sui, great righteousness was as fleeting as gourds cast aside, and for long had upright ministers who oversaw integrity fallen silent, their remonstrations erased.

Then the Tang arose like a dragon, parting the heavens and raising the sun. Only then did rulers begin to grasp the difficulty of governance, and the precious admonition of the *Great Treasure* once more found voice—truly a rare thing.

Yet though Yan and Yun served the same sovereign in ancient times, one was praised for flattery, the other censured for forthright reproof. Though their rewards and punishments were alike in the moment, later their fates diverged under the weight of power and punishment. This reveals the difficulty of perfect impartiality and the ideal of "the world held in common," making it nearly impossible for men to respond with their hearts to its words and embody its principles in conduct.

From the *Comprehensive Mirror*: Taizong grew ever closer to Wei Zheng. Zheng, feeling his favor unparalleled in an age, laid bare his deepest thoughts in over two hundred memorials, each piercing and perfectly aligned with the emperor’s will. When someone accused Zheng of favoring his relatives, the emperor sent Wen Yanbo to investigate, but no wrongdoing was found. Yanbo said to the emperor: "Zheng does not maintain appearances or avoid suspicion. Though his heart is free of bias, he is still open to reproach." The emperor rebuked Zheng, saying: "From now on, you must maintain appearances and stay close."

Later, Zheng entered court and said: "I have heard that when ruler and minister share one heart, they become as one body and should deal with one another in utmost sincerity. If above and below merely maintain appearances and stay close, the rise or fall of the state remains uncertain." He dared not accept the decree. The emperor, moved, said: "I already regret it."

Zheng bowed twice and said: "I am fortunate to serve Your Majesty. I hope you will let me be a *good* minister, not a *loyal* one." The emperor asked: "Is there a difference between loyalty and goodness?" Zheng replied: "Hou Ji, Xie, and Gao Yao—ministers who harmonized with their rulers—all enjoyed honor and glory. These were *good* ministers. Long Feng and Bi Gan, who remonstrated to their deaths and brought ruin to themselves and their states, were *loyal* ministers." The emperor was pleased.

The Record states: The learning of Duke Wei originated from the masters of He and Fen...

Yet his words touch nothing of the self or the heart—why is this? Were Hou Ji, Xie, and Gao Yao merely ministers who harmonized with their rulers and enjoyed honor and glory? Above, they ensured fathers acted as fathers and sons as sons; below, elder brothers as elder brothers and younger brothers as younger brothers; within, husbands as husbands and wives as wives—none failed to find their proper place. Thus they secured enduring honor and glory, unwaning through the ages. In the reign of Taizong, father and son transgressed their proper roles, brothers violated their order, and husbands and wives confounded ethics. Only in matters of reward and punishment, promotion and demotion, the establishment of statutes and decrees did his innate brilliance and acuity prevent disorder. Thus Wei Zheng could admonish and Li Shuli could debate. This was precisely what Zhang Yungu meant by "the people fear his might but do not cherish his virtue." How could it compare to the Three Dynasties of Yao, Shun, and Yu? As for the so-called Way of loyalty and goodness, it was but a hollow name between ruler and minister. Those who observe must discern its truth.

Wei Zheng memorialized the throne, saying: "Many rulers begin well, but few end well. Is it because seizing power is easy while preserving it is hard? When deeply troubled, one exhausts sincerity to serve those below; in ease and comfort, one grows arrogant and scorns others. Serving those below unites even distant lands in shared purpose; scorning others severs the bonds of the six relations. Though one may shake them with threats and wrath, they will only feign obedience while their hearts remain unyielding. If Your Majesty can, upon seeing what is desirable, think of knowing contentment; when about to embark on construction, think of knowing restraint; when in high and perilous station, think of humility and deference; when facing fullness and abundance, think of moderation; when encountering pleasure and ease, think of temperance; when in comfort and security, think of future peril; when guarding against obstruction, think of extending welcome; when detesting slander and deceit, think of rectifying one’s own conduct; when bestowing ranks, think of the excess that may come with joy; when imposing punishments, think of the excess that may come with anger—if you embrace these ten reflections and select the worthy to employ the capable, you may govern effortlessly. Why then exhaust mind and body to take on the burdens of the people?"

The Record states: Zheng’s counsel was excellent, yet it failed to reach the root of sagely achievement. The office of the heart is to reflect—how could reflection be limited to ten? Can the myriad affairs of a single day be confined to a fixed number? Only by guarding it in the unseen and unheard, in solitude and secrecy, with unwavering constancy and tranquil persistence, can one attain the One. With the One, there is no beginning; without beginning, things cannot intrude. In stillness, there is no disturbance; without disturbance, the heart remains steadfast. Though the ruler may deliberate a thousand times, what need has he for ten?

For the eyes and ears perceive what is desirable, but it is the heart’s office to reflect on contentment. Once one sees what is desirable, one has already engaged with things. When things interact with things, and only then does one apply reflection—how few can avoid being led astray? Thus the ancients found it easier to discipline the heart than to achieve the effects of Zheng’s ten reflections.

Zheng said: "I serve at Your Majesty’s side and You have permitted me to uphold the Way of benevolence and righteousness without fail, to remain frugal and unadorned from beginning to end. Yet in recent years, You have not sustained this. In the early years of the Zhenguan era, You were serene and sparing in desire, and Your transformative influence reached beyond the borders. Now You dispatch envoys thousands of miles to seek fine horses and rare curios—this is the first decline. In the early Zhenguan era, You guarded the people’s toil as if they were Your children and did not lightly expend their labor. Recently, You have grown extravagant and reckless, demanding their strength—this is the second decline. In the early Zhenguan era, You labored for the benefit of others; lately, You indulge Your desires at the people’s expense. Though Your lips speak ceaselessly of concern for the people, Your heart clings to the pleasures of the self—this is the third decline. In the early Zhenguan era, You drew near to the noble and distanced the base; lately, You honor the noble yet keep them at a remove, while growing intimate with the base—this is the fourth decline. In the early Zhenguan era, You did not prize exotic goods or undertake useless projects; now rare and precious items pour in together, and the crafting of playthings never ceases—this is the fifth decline. In the early Zhenguan era, You sought scholars as if parched, valuing their strengths and fearing You might miss them; lately, Your likes and dislikes dictate their rise and fall, advancing the many worthy on one man’s praise and discarding them on one man’s slander—this is the sixth decline. In the early Zhenguan era, You dwelled in lofty tranquility, without the pleasures of hunting and archery; after several years, Your resolve could not hold, and tribute of hawks and hounds came from the distant four quarters. You ride out at dawn and return at dusk, finding joy in the chase—this is the seventh decline. In the early Zhenguan era, You treated those below with courtesy, and the sentiments of the people reached You; now when officials from beyond the court submit memorials, You do not deign to meet their gaze, interrogating them for their faults and nitpicking their minor errors. Though they harbor loyal devotion, it cannot be expressed—this is the eighth decline. In the early Zhenguan era, You diligently pursued the Way as if never satisfied; lately, You rely on the greatness of Your achievements, the brilliance of Your sagacity, growing proud and indulging Your desires, launching military campaigns in distant lands without cause—this is the ninth decline. In the early Zhenguan era, after years of frost and drought, the people of the capital fled beyond the passes, carrying the old and leading the young, yet none abandoned their homes; lately, exhausted by corvée labor, the people of Guanzhong suffer most acutely—this is the tenth decline.

Disaster and fortune have no fixed gate; they are summoned by men. A thousand years of prosperous rule are difficult to regain once lost. That a wise ruler could act but does not—this is why I am choked with sorrow and sigh without end."

The memorial was submitted. The emperor said: "I have heard my faults."

The memorial was inscribed upon screens and curtains, and a copy was also submitted to the historiographers, that all ages might know the righteousness between ruler and minister.

It was recorded: What is meant by "at first, reverence overcomes laxity"? Virtue overcomes desire. What is meant by "gradually, laxity overcomes reverence"? Desire overcomes virtue. In their beginnings, how did King Wu of Zhou and Emperor Taizong of Tang differ? Yet in the end, they diverged—this was the result of gradual decline.
