Though Wei Zheng’s admonitions struck precisely at the ailments of rulers through the ages, the emperor, having ordered the memorial recorded by the historiographers to illuminate the great righteousness between ruler and minister, soon thereafter violated it, mourning it only as a screen beside his seat—no different from the past when gold was used to shelter horses, inviting ridicule in later days. Thus, not only did gradual decline prove unconquerable, but in the end, he even entirely forgot his original resolve.

The emperor, reflecting on the meritorious service of his founding ministers, commanded artisans to paint the portraits of Duke Zhao, Changsun Wuji; Prince Yuan of Zhao Commandery, Li Xiaogong; Duke Cheng, Du Ruhui; Duke Wenzhen of Zheng, Wei Zheng; Duke Liang, Fang Xuanling; Duke Shen, Gao Shilian; Duke E, Yuchi Jingde; Duke Wei, Li Jing; Duke Song, Xiao Mafu; Duke Zhongsheng, Duan Zhixuan; Duke Kui, Liu Hongji; Duke Zhong, Qu Tu Tong; Duke Jie of Zheng, Yin Kaishan; Duke Xiang of Qiao, Chai Shao; Duke Xiang of Na, Changsun Shunde; Duke Zheng, Zhang Liang; Duke Chen, Hou Junji; Duke Xiang of Bang, Zhang Gongjin; Duke Lu, Cheng Zhijie; Duke Wenyi of Yongxing, Yu Shinan; Duke Xiang of Qiao, Liu Zhengzhui; Duke Ju, Tang Jian; Duke Ying, Li Shiji; and Duke Zhuang of Hu, Qin Shubao—twenty-four men in all—upon the Lingyan Pavilion.

It was recorded: The portraits in the Lingyan Pavilion were painted without including Pei Ji and Liu Wenzhen—why? Ji Bu was an enemy of Han, yet he was pardoned; Ding Gong was a benefactor of Han, yet he was executed. How could the discernment of a wise ruler differ in such matters? Thus, though Wang Gui and Wei Zheng were adversaries, their loyalty to their lord made them like dragons in harmony; Pei Ji and Liu Wenzhen, though favored, betrayed righteousness, and so their portraits became a disgrace. Observing this, how could one fail to know where to turn?

In the early years of Emperor Xuanzong’s reign, Yao Yuanzhong served as Minister of War and concurrent Grand Councilor. Yuanzhong, knowing the emperor’s magnanimity and eagerness to govern, first established precedents to strengthen the emperor’s resolve. He memorialized: "Since the *Chuigong* era, harsh laws have bound the people. I wish that governance might first embrace benevolence and forgiveness—would this be acceptable? The court has suffered defeat in Qinghai, yet there is no remorse for past failures. I wish that we might not pursue military glory on the frontiers—would this be acceptable? Recently, flatterers have violated the law and constitution, yet all have escaped punishment through favor. I wish that the law might be enforced beginning with those closest to the throne—would this be acceptable? When Empress Wu ruled, the words of the court issued from the mouths of palace women. I wish that eunuchs might not interfere in governance—would this be acceptable? The imperial in-laws present tribute to curry favor with the throne, and high officials and regional commanders have begun to follow suit. I wish that all such offerings beyond taxes and tribute might be abolished—would this be acceptable? Imperial relatives and noble consorts vie for influence, disrupting the order of ranks. I wish that imperial kin might not hold positions in the central administration—would this be acceptable? The late emperor treated his ministers with undue familiarity, undermining the dignity between ruler and minister. I wish that Your Majesty might receive them with ritual propriety—would this be acceptable? Yan Qinyu and Wei Yuejiang were punished for their loyalty, and since then, remonstrating ministers have been discouraged. I wish that all ministers might be permitted to criticize even the most sensitive matters—would this be acceptable? Empress Wu built the Fushan Temple, and the retired emperor constructed the Jinxian and Yuzhen Observatories, each costing millions. I wish that the construction of Daoist and Buddhist temples might cease—would this be acceptable? In Han, the Lü, Wang, Yan, and Liang clans brought the greatest disorder to the state and nation. I wish that we might take this as a warning and establish it as a model for punishment—would this be acceptable?"

The emperor replied: "I am able to implement these."

It was recorded: Mencius said, "One cannot discuss matters with a petty man, nor consult governance with him; only a great man can correct the faults in a ruler’s heart." In the early years of Emperor Xuanzong’s reign, his vigor was sharp, but his heart remained unknown. Yao Yuanzhong, by establishing precedents, sought to correct his heart, guiding what was not upright toward rectitude, perhaps averting later regrets. Yet now, reviewing his ten proposals—such as governance first embracing benevolence, not pursuing frontier glory, enforcing the law beginning with those closest, and eunuchs and imperial kin not interfering in governance—all addressed the failures of personnel and administration at the time, while the essential matter of correcting the ruler’s heart went entirely unmentioned. Moreover, the most crucial proposals are concise; they must be feasible before being presented—this differs from merely making demands of the ruler. Later, the emperor honored and favored frontier generals, indulged in the charms of women, empowered eunuchs and imperial kin, and gave free rein to extravagance, leading to the ruin of the state. How did Yao Yuanzhong’s words ultimately benefit him? From this, we know that the words of great worthies may seem impractical but are in fact incisive, while Yao’s ten proposals seemed incisive but were in fact impractical.

When Minister of Justice Song Jing served as Grand Councilor, his governance focused on selecting the right people, assigning tasks according to their abilities, ensuring that all officials fulfilled their duties, administering rewards and punishments without partiality, and daring to admonish the emperor to his face. The emperor deeply respected and feared him; even when their views differed, he often yielded. The Türks under Mo-ch’uo had long been a scourge to the Middle Kingdom, and despite the court’s exhaustion of the realm’s resources, they could not be subdued. When Hao Lingquan obtained Mo-ch’uo’s head, he considered it an unparalleled achievement. Jing, however, fearing that the emperor’s fondness for martial glory might encourage others to seek fortune through reckless ventures, severely restrained the rewards. Only after a year was Lingquan appointed a captain, and he died weeping in despair.

At that time, Yao Chong and Song Jing served as grand councilors in succession. Chong excelled at adapting to circumstances, while Jing was steadfast in upholding the law and righteousness. Though their principles and conduct differed, they worked in harmony to assist the emperor, lightening taxes and corvée labor, simplifying punishments, and enriching the people. Among the worthy grand councilors of the Tang, the earlier generation praised Fang Xuanling and Du Ruhui, while the later generation praised Yao Chong and Song Jing—no others matched them.

It was recorded: In my humble opinion, Song Jing of Guangping may truly be called a great minister. He showed reverence and fear before the Zhang brothers, humbled himself before Yao Chong, wept bitterly for Hao Lingquan, and resolutely opposed Gao Lishi’s demands—all were the deeds of a great minister.

Had Song Jing and Yao Chong served rulers of the Three Dynasties, could they have matched Yi Yin and the Duke of Zhou? The answer is no. Yi Yin declared, "All must possess unified virtue," while the Duke of Zhou aspired to "emulate the Three Kings"—what lofty standards they set! Yet Jing’s governance did no more than restore the institutions of the Zhenguan era. Thus, the horses used in palace ceremonies were soon dismissed again, and the words of actors were swiftly heeded once more. Their achievements were incomplete, and so they cannot be compared to those ancient sages. Nevertheless, in selecting officials and making appointments, in forthright remonstrance despite imperial displeasure—these were acts within the capacity of any grand councilor. To dismiss Jing and Chong as shallow would be a grave error.

Han Xiu served as Vice Director of the Chancellery and concurrently Grand Councilor. A man of stern integrity, he cared nothing for personal gain or glory. Upon assuming the grand councilorship, he fulfilled the expectations of his time, upholding righteousness without flattery. Whenever the emperor indulged in palace banquets or hunted in the imperial gardens, even the slightest impropriety would prompt him to ask his attendants, "Does Han Xiu know of this?" Before the words were fully spoken, a memorial of remonstrance would already have arrived. Once, the emperor gazed into a mirror in silence, looking displeased. His attendants said, "Ever since Han Xiu became grand councilor, Your Majesty has grown noticeably thinner. Why not dismiss him?" The emperor replied, "Though my appearance has grown gaunt, the realm must surely prosper. When Xiao Song submitted memorials, he always aligned with my wishes, yet after his departure, I could not sleep in peace. When Han Xiu remonstrated forcefully, I found rest only after he left. I employ Han Xiu for the sake of the altars of state, not for myself."

It was recorded: When Emperor Xuanzong’s attendants remarked that the grand councilor Han Xiu had made him thin, it was as clear as a bell that his successor, Li Linfu, would make him fat. For the emperor’s emaciation was not for the sake of the realm, but because the allure of beauty was insufficient to please his eyes, the charm of music inadequate to delight his ears, and the flattery of sycophants lacking to gratify his desires. Yet once he obtained the radiant splendor of Yang Guifei, the cunning allure of An Lushan, and the seductive melodies of *Nishang Yuyi*, he was utterly content—how could his heart not swell and his body not grow plump? In the end, his indulgence led him astray, and he was forced into exile, a fate so dire that no outcry was needed to reveal his suffering. Thus, his lament before the mirror foreshadowed the sorrow that would later resound like a tolling bell.

Therefore, the noble man declares: "A ruler’s gaunt appearance while the realm prospers" is but an empty reputation, whereas "a ruler’s plump appearance while the realm suffers" is a true calamity. On the emperor’s millennial birthday, his ministers all presented precious mirrors. Zhang Jiuling said, "The late emperor once declared: 'With bronze as a mirror, one may adjust one’s robes and cap; with history as a mirror, one may perceive the rise and fall of dynasties; with men as a mirror, one may discern success and failure.'"

Thus, he recounted the origins of the rise and fall of past dynasties and compiled a five-volume work: *Founding the State and Establishing the Enterprise* as the first, *Selecting Literary Talent and Preparing Military Strength* as the second, *Repaying the State and Restoring Prosperity* as the third, *Expending One’s Life to Serve the State* as the fourth, and *Discarding Ancient Simplicity and Advancing New Beauty* as the fifth. With these five volumes as a bulwark against calamity, he titled it *The Golden Mirror of a Thousand Autumns*. He urged the Emperor: "Do not take sensual beauty as joy. Should the state later face ruin and the realm collapse, it would be fitting to rectify oneself and govern, reflecting on the past to illuminate the present." The record was presented, and the Emperor bestowed upon it a laudatory inscription.

The record states: According to *The Golden Yi Record*, when Zhang Jiuling served in the Central Secretariat, he burned his elixirs and did not transmit them to the world, entrusting them instead to his two sons-in-law, Han and Song. Thereafter, this record would only circulate among men a thousand years later. Now that it has been obtained and read, how profound it is! These words shine as brightly as the sun and moon. For he not only recognized An Lushan but also all those who shared in the disaster of that time. Was his insight merely into the rise and fall of dynasties? In truth, he was deeply versed in the principles of all things. What is called "distinguishing things as with a mirror" is precisely this—not some casual compilation.

It states: An Lushan was the essence of a wild boar, his belly hanging past his knees. Shi Siming was the essence of a quail-crow, with two feathers growing from his flanks. Yang Guifei was the essence of a white roc, her fingers and nails pure red, bearing the signs of "wood-child" and "double wood," with "wood overcoming metal." It further says: "Neither rhinoceros nor tiger, yet they bound the west and raised the east; with demonic dances and spectral whispers, palaces turned to millet fields." Again, it says: "In governing the state, Your Majesty, long has your benevolent heart grown scarce; loyal admonitions are treated as enemies, while flatterers and sycophants cling together, like sheep and carp adrift." The "sheep" referred to Yang Guozhong, and the "carp" to Li Linfu. As "coconut and oak" advanced together, the state collapsed and the house fell—regret should then turn to remembrance of the past.

It also says: "The sovereign’s tears fell upon Mount Ba; the journey along the Shu Road was arduous. Grace turned to enmity, and only then did he yearn for the foolish." At the height of the Kaiyuan era’s prosperity, before the Tianbao era had ended, how did Jiuling foresee the hardships of the Shu Road and the ease of Lingwu? For his mirror did not merely reflect men’s forms but truly illuminated their hearts, not just the gains and losses of a single era but the rise and fall of two dynasties.

Yet, observing later ages through Jiuling’s eyes, one sees that "demonic dances and spectral whispers" have recurred time and again. How could one obtain Jiuling’s foresight and discuss with him the rise and fall of states?

When Yan Zhenqing, the Governor of Pingyuan, learned of An Lushan’s rebellion, he took advantage of the prolonged rains to repair the city walls, dredge the moats, muster the able-bodied, and fill the granaries. Lushan, dismissing him as a mere scholar, did not take him seriously. When the rebellion erupted, Lushan assigned seven thousand soldiers from Pingyuan and Boyang to guard the river fords. Zhenqing resisted, then dispatched Li Ping, the Prefectural Military Officer of Pingyuan, to take a secret route and report to the court. When the court learned of Lushan’s rebellion, it heard only that the commanderies and counties of Hebei had all surrendered at the first sign of trouble. The Emperor sighed in dismay: "Among the twenty-four commanderies, is there not a single righteous man?"

When Li Ping arrived, the Emperor rejoiced greatly: "I do not know what Yan Zhenqing looks like, yet he has acted thus!" Zhenqing sent his personal guests to secretly carry copies of the rebels’ documents to the various commanderies, and as a result, many commanderies responded in kind.

The record states: Confucius said, "If the ruler values ritual, none among the people dare be disrespectful. If the ruler values righteousness, none dare be disobedient. If the ruler values trustworthiness, none dare be insincere." The Sage spoke these words to set an example for the world, ever fearful that it would follow the wind and bend. In the era of Emperor Minghuang, flattery and pleasing appearances were prized, while ritual, righteousness, and trustworthiness were swept away entirely. To then lament the absence of a single righteous man—is this not absurd? From this, one knows the greatness of the Three Bonds and the weight of the Four Virtues, which cannot be absent for a single day. How could the customs of the Tang and Yu dynasties be mere empty talk?

When Yan Gaoqing raised troops, he had only eight days to prepare his defenses, which were still incomplete when Shi Siming and Cai Xide led their forces to the city walls. Gaoqing sent word to Wang Chengye, who, coveting the credit for himself, held back his troops and refused to aid him. Gaoqing fought day and night, but when his provisions and arrows were exhausted, the city fell, and the rebels took him and Yuan Lüqian captive, sending them to Luoyang. Lushan reproached him: "You were but a minor official in Fan Prefecture, and I recommended you for the post of judge. In just a few years, you rose to governor—how have I wronged you that you rebel?" Gaoqing, eyes closed, cursed him: "You were but a Khitan slave herding sheep in Yingzhou, yet the Son of Heaven raised you to the rank of military governor of three circuits. No favor has been greater—how have you been wronged that you rebel? I am a lifelong subject of the Tang; my rank and emoluments all come from the Tang. Even if you recommended me, how could I follow you in rebellion? I am punishing a traitor for the state—how could I not slay you? What rebellion is this?" Lushan, enraged, had both Gaoqing and Lüqian dismembered, yet even in death, they did not cease their curses.

The record states: Observing the two gentlemen of the Yan family, how could their resolve be merely about facing death in a moment of peril? For they upheld the three-hundred-year bond between ruler and minister of the Tang. Since the rebellion in Jinyang and the betrayal of Liu and Pei against the Sui, and the Mandate of Heaven bestowed upon the Zhou and Tang, for over a hundred years, men had forgotten what it meant to submit to principle and die for righteousness. When news of the two Yans’ actions spread, it was as if they had descended from heaven or risen from the earth. Thus it was said: "I do not know what Yan Zhenqing looks like, yet he has acted thus!" Though their bodies were crushed and their tongues severed, their fragrance spread far, their glory shone forth, surpassing the corrupt Sui and redeeming the tyrannical Zhou. Was this not magnificent?

When Zhang Xun raised troops to resist Lushan, Linghu Chao besieged him at Yongqiu for over forty days. Hearing that Emperor Xuanzong had fled to Shu, six of Xun’s generals urged him, saying the enemy’s forces were too strong and the Emperor’s fate unknown—it would be better to surrender. Xun feigned agreement. The next day, he set up the Emperor’s portrait in the hall and led his officers to pay homage. Bringing the six generals before him, he rebuked them for their lack of principle and executed them, steeling the resolve of his troops.

With five hundred dead-set warriors, he launched a raid on Chao’s camp, prompting Chao to reinforce the siege. Xun dispatched General Lei Wanspring to the city wall to parley with Chao. Before their words were finished, enemy crossbows struck him—six arrows pierced his face, yet he stood unmoved. Suspecting a wooden effigy, Chao sent scouts to investigate and was stunned. From afar, he called to Xun: “Just now, seeing General Lei, I understood the discipline of your army. Yet what can you do against the Dao of Heaven?” Xun replied: “You fail to grasp human ethics—how could you know the Dao of Heaven?”

**Recorded Note:** Was Xun’s sacrifice of life for righteousness in vain? Only when perception is settled does one’s center hold firm. With a firm center, affairs can be resolved and merit achieved. When human ethics are fulfilled, the principles of Heaven naturally appear. Thus we hear of the Great Tang’s restoration, never of the rebels’ triumph; we hear of Zhang and Xu’s enduring legacy, never of Linghu’s immortality. Who says moments of haste and peril are not times for unhurried adherence to the Middle Way?

Yin Ziqi besieged Suiyang for months. As provisions ran out, the city debated abandoning it. Zhang Xun and Xu Yuan counseled: “Suiyang is the shield of Jiang and Huai. If we abandon it, the rebels will surge forward unchecked—Jiang and Huai will be lost.” They resolved to hold fast. At first, soldiers ate tea leaves and paper; when those were gone, they ate the horses. Horses exhausted, they trapped sparrows and dug for rats. When even those were gone, Xun brought out his beloved concubine and slaughtered her to feed his men; Yuan likewise killed his servant. Then they gathered the city’s women to eat, followed by the old and weak men. Though all knew death was certain, none defected. Only four hundred remained.

On the *guichou* day, the rebels scaled the walls. The defenders, too weak to fight, could only watch. Xun faced west and bowed: “My strength is spent. I cannot save the city. In life, I failed to repay Your Majesty; in death, I will become a vengeful ghost to slay the rebels.”

**Recorded Note:** Can we truly believe in vengeful ghosts? Peng Sheng and Bo Yi were but two men’s grievances—yet Suiyang’s martyrs perfected a virtue for ten thousand generations. Their strength could be broken, but not their will; their bodies could fall, but not their *qi*.

Though the loyal souls and righteous spirits cannot be seen or heard, when Chu Xiong turned his blade against his own kin at dawn, or when righteousness wielded the halberd as if moved by ghosts and gods—who can say they were not vengeful? The Tang restored its lost lands, yet could not exact vengeance upon the bodies of An and Shi. Does this mean the words of vengeful ghosts cannot be trusted?

In the second year of Jianzhong during the reign of Emperor Dezong, Guo Ziyi, the Loyal and Martial King of Fenyang, passed away. As the Tang’s supreme general, he commanded vast armies. Cheng Yuanzhen and Yu Chao’en slandered him relentlessly, yet a single imperial summons brought him to the capital without delay, thus silencing their calumnies. Once, when he sent an envoy to Tian Chengsi’s domain, Chengsi gazed in all directions before bowing and declaring, “These knees have not bent to another for many years.” When Li Lingyao seized Bianzhou, he seized all public and private goods passing through, yet dared not touch Guo’s property, instead dispatching troops to escort it safely beyond his borders. Guo’s official salary as *Zhongshu Ling* totaled twenty thousand *jin* over twenty-four months, not including his private wealth. His treasuries overflowed with treasures, his household numbered three thousand, eight sons and seven sons-in-law held high office, and his dozens of grandsons were too many to greet individually—he merely nodded in acknowledgment. Pugu Huai’en, Li Huaiguang, and Hun Cheng all emerged from his command; though ennobled as dukes and princes, they remained at his beck and call, rushing to serve before him. For thirty years, the empire’s fate rested upon his shoulders. His merits eclipsed all others, yet the emperor never doubted him; he rose to the highest rank, yet none envied him; he indulged in extravagance, yet none criticized him. He died at eighty-five, and many of his generals and aides became renowned ministers.

**Recorded Note:** The rise and retreat of Fenyang were tied to the empire’s stability. Why, then, was he not spared jealousy? First, Chao’en pulled him forward; then, Yuanzhen dragged him back—yet Guo bore no grudge. Why? The *Book of Changes* states: *“In the time of Pi, it is not the man; it is not favorable for the superior man to persist. The small departs, the great arrives—auspicious and smooth.”* In the era of Suzong and Daizong, the superior man found no advantage. Yet, relying on one man’s life to uphold the empire’s might, he fulfilled his resolve to turn peril into safety—this was the small departing and the great arriving. When summoned, he answered without hesitation; when not, he bore all with patience. Thus, when he wished for leisure, he found it; when he ordered dispersal, it was done. Wherever he turned, he was at ease. The An Lushan rebellion? He emerged once. The Tubo invasion? He emerged again. The Huai’en crisis? He emerged twice more. The Uyghur threat? Again, he emerged. Had he ignored the warning of *Baosang*, been swayed by shameful slander, known only safety and not danger, or profit and not harm, his life would have been imperiled, and the state would have followed. How could this be the great man’s auspicious smoothness?

In the first year of Xingyuan, after the amnesty was prepared, the emperor entrusted the edict to Lu Zhi for review. Knowing the emperor’s virtue was not steadfast, Lu submitted a memorial: “To move men with words is already shallow; if the words are not earnest, who will heed them? This decree must express deep remorse and full accountability. Let the realm hear it, and all will transform as if emerging from thick darkness into radiant light.” The emperor then issued an edict: “Reared in the depths of the palace, I was ignorant of governance. Habit led me astray; in ease, I forgot peril. I did not know the hardship of farming or the toil of soldiers. My grace did not reach the people; my heart did not connect with the land. Affairs became obstructed, and the people grew suspicious. Unaware of my own faults, I provoked war. Armies were raised from all directions, supplies transported from afar. Taxes and conscriptions spread chaos near and far. The people labored under burdens, yet I did not awaken to Heaven’s warnings or the people’s anger. Thus, rebellion arose, the capital was shaken, all things lost order, the ancestral temples trembled. Above, I failed my forebears; below, I betrayed the people. My heart shames me; the fault is mine alone. My remorse is bottomless, as if falling into an abyss. From now on, all memorials shall omit the titles *Sacred, Martial, Civil, and Martial*.” When the amnesty was proclaimed, the people rejoiced.

The following year, Li Baozhen entered the court and reported: “In Shandong, the amnesty was announced, and the soldiers wept with gratitude. Seeing the people’s response, I know the rebels cannot stand.” **Recorded Note:** The *Hexagram Yang*’s fourth line states: *“Yang has hills—beyond the thoughts of the common.”* The fifth line says: *“Yang defiles its great name.”* Truly, one who treads extraordinary peril cannot be secured by ordinary means; one who resolves extraordinary chaos cannot be enlightened by common words. If sincerity is lacking, the people will not be moved; if self-reduction is not extreme, benefits will not be fully realized. Indeed, virtue spreads faster than couriers bearing orders. Dezong knew Heaven had raised Li Xian for the state, yet did not grasp that the people’s hearts, once stirred, would leave the rebels no foothold. In peril, he sought loyal counsel; in peace, he turned against forthright speech. Thus, though he cast aside his peach and gained his wish, he could not cleanse his flock and achieve greatness. What a pity.

Lu Zhi vehemently condemned Pei Yanling’s treachery, enumerating his crimes: “Yanling treats extortion as strategy, deceit as wisdom, hoarding and resentment as selflessness, and slander as loyalty. He is the Gonggong of Yao’s age, the Shaoyou of Lu’s realm.” The memorial displeased the emperor. Though Lu treated him as a confidant, whenever matters displeased him, he would argue fiercely.

Those close to him sometimes cautioned against his excessive zeal, to which he replied: “I neither betray the Son of Heaven above nor betray what I have studied below—nothing else concerns me.”

The record observes: How could one bear to betray the Son of Heaven? Yet when the sovereign grows arrogant, his ministers become obsequious; when the ruler is suspicious, his courtiers turn sycophantic. This is the Son of Heaven’s own betrayal of himself—how could he willingly betray what he has studied? To treat extortion as the highest strategy and hoarding as sound policy is to regret one’s own learning. The noble man, however, does not act thus.

What the noble man studies is how to become a sage or a worthy. Thus, the rulership of Yao, Shun, Yu, Tang, Wen, and Wu is what he holds himself accountable to; the ministerial conduct of Gaoyao, Yi, Fu, Zhou, and Shao is what he aspires to emulate. If the ruler is harsh and exacting, he responds with loyalty and kindness; if the ruler is jealous and distrustful, he offers reverence and sincerity. Is this a forced fit of square pegs into round holes? No—his inner truth is simply thus.

Mencius did not say: “If my lord cannot [be virtuous], he is a thief”? Then to betray what one has studied is truly worse than a burglar’s tunnel—yet how can the Son of Heaven teach others to betray their learning?

Li Chen’s family of a hundred mouths, along with the households of the Divine Strategy Army’s soldiers, all remained in Chang’an. When anyone in the army mentioned home, Chen wept and said: “Where is the Son of Heaven? How dare we speak of home?” When Zhu Ci sent a trusted messenger with a letter from Chen’s family, saying, “Your household is safe,” Chen grew furious: “How dare you relay inquiries from rebels?” He had the man executed on the spot.

The record observes: One who acts for all under Heaven does not consider his family—even if he did, what good would it do? The *Book of Changes* says: “In peril, with sincerity, the heart finds clarity, and action is esteemed.” At the time, Zhu Ci had seized the capital, and Huai Guang had rebelled in Xianyang—danger compounded by hardship. Without unwavering resolve, the mind would falter; how then could one achieve success? Not only could one not attend to family and possessions, but the state itself would be lost.

Later, when [Li Chen] was granted a mansion with furnishings, and his procession was met with banners and escorts, how could it compare to his former household? Even if there had been kin like Xian or Tai among the rebels, how could he not have treated them well? How could he have overthrown them?

In the third year of Yuanhe during the reign of Emperor Xianzong, Pei Chi served as *Zhongshu Shilang* and *Tong Pingzhangshi*. Initially, Emperor Dezong did not entrust matters to his chief ministers, handling even minor affairs himself. When the emperor was still in his princely residence, he recognized the impropriety of this, and upon ascending the throne, he selected and promoted chief ministers, entrusting them with his full confidence. Pei Chi, too, devoted himself sincerely to assisting the ruler. Once, the emperor asked Pei Chi what should take precedence in governance. He replied, "First, rectify the heart."

When Emperor Muzong ascended the throne, he once saw the calligraphic works of Liu Gongquan, the judicial officer of Aizhou, and admired them, appointing him as *You Shi Yi*. The emperor asked Liu Gongquan, "How is it that your calligraphy is so excellent?" He replied, "The brush follows the heart; when the heart is upright, the brush is upright." The emperor fell silent and altered his expression, for he understood that Liu was admonishing him through his brush.

It is recorded: Since the time of Emperor Taizong of Tang, there have been many remonstrators, but none have probed so deeply to the root as Pei Chi’s "first rectify the heart" or Liu Gongquan’s "when the heart is upright, the brush is upright." Yet in the end, Emperor Xianzong could not rectify his later years, nor could Emperor Muzong rectify his early reign—why? It is said: The heart is merely *li* (principle). Though the vessel is inherent in man, *li* truly emanates from Heaven; without study, there is no way to illuminate it. Thus, the *Way of the Great Learning* begins with *gewu zhizhi* (investigating things and extending knowledge) and culminates in *yicheng xinzheng* (making intentions sincere and rectifying the heart). Its sequence cannot be disordered, nor its effort omitted. Pei and Liu could open the path but could not complete the discourse; Emperors Xianzong and Muzong merely heard the words but could not awaken to their truth. No wonder then—like one who seeks immortality yet neglects humanity, or like a land left desolate and ungoverned—what is the heart for? Only a long sigh remains.

Since the late Yuanhe era, the eunuchs grew increasingly overbearing, installing and deposing emperors at their whim, their authority surpassing even that of the sovereign, yet none dared speak against them. In the second year of Taihe under Emperor Wenzong, Liu Ze of Changping presented a memorial in response to the imperial examination, forthrightly exposing their calamities. In brief, he declared: "Your Majesty’s foremost concern should be the impending upheaval in the palace, the peril to the altars of state, the imminent collapse of the realm, and the looming chaos across the land."

He further warned: "If Your Majesty wishes to forestall the gradual encroachment of usurpation and regicide, then let the ruler occupy his rightful place, draw near to upright men, distance himself from the ignoble wielders of the knife and saw, and befriend the forthright of noble grain. Let your ministers of state fulfill their duties without hindrance, and let all officials guard their posts. Why, then, entrust the governance of the empire to five or six men of debased familiarity? Disaster ripens within the palace walls, and treachery festers behind the curtains. I fear that Cao Jie and Hou Lan have been reborn in our time."

Again, he lamented: "The loyal and worthy are not entrusted as confidants, while the eunuchs of the inner palace wield the power to depose and enthrone. They caused the late emperor to fail in rectifying his reign’s end, leaving Your Majesty unable to rectify its beginning."

He urged: "Why does Your Majesty not block the path of hidden malice, banish the ministers of debased intimacy, curb the hearts that encroach and coerce, restore the duties of gatekeeping and sweeping, heed what must be heeded, and grieve what must be grieved?"

The examiners, Feng Su and others, all marveled and approved, yet feared the eunuchs and dared not select his response.

The record states: That such forthright speech arose in the reign of Emperor Wenzong is like one who, starving in broad daylight, beats the drum and races about—though the distance from Heaven remains vast, it reveals at least that he could not remain idle. This is to mark the impending end of the Tang’s mandate.

*Hongdao Record*, Volume Fourteen, concludes.

*Hongdao Record*, Volume Fifteen.

**"The Righteousness Between Ruler and Minister"**

From *The History of the Song*: At the beginning of Emperor Taizu’s reign, Jiaozhou, Guangzhou, Jiannan, Taiyuan, Jinghu, Jiangbiao, Liao, and Xia were all rival states. He therefore paid close attention to his generals and commanders, dispatching Li Hanchao to garrison Guannan, Ma Renpu to defend Yingzhou, Han Lingkun to hold Changzhou, He Weizhong to guard Yizhou, He Jiyun to command Dizhou, Guo Jin to control Xishan, Wu Shouqi to fortify Jinzhou, Li Qianpu to defend Dizhou, Li Jixun to pacify Zhaoyi and resist Taiyuan, Zhao Zan to station at Yanzhou, Yao Neifu to guard Qingzhou, Dong Zunhao to encamp at Huanzhou, Wang Yansheng to defend Yuanzhou, and Feng Jiye to garrison Lingwu in preparation against Western Xia. Their clansmen residing in Bianjing were treated with great generosity; all profits from state monopolies in their commanderies were granted to them, and they were permitted to engage in trade freely, exempt from transit taxes. They were also allowed to recruit fugitives as their personal enforcers. In all military matters, they were granted full discretion. Whenever they came to court, the emperor would summon them for private audience, seat them, and bestow lavish rewards before sending them off. As a result, the frontier commanders grew wealthy, enabling them to maintain elite troops, employ spies, and thoroughly understand enemy movements. When invaders arrived, ambushes and surprise attacks often led to victory. For twenty years, there was no anxiety from the northwest, and eventually Shu, Chu, Wu, and Yue were pacified, every campaign achieving its aim. This was the result of his ability to govern his subordinates with wholehearted sincerity.

The record states: In my humble observation, Emperor Taizu’s grand strategy comprised five elements: first, the ability to recognize men of talent; second, the skill to employ them effectively; third, the practice of extending complete trust...

Abundant generosity in rewards and comfort, the fourth; as for the profits from state monopolies, he entrusted them entirely to his generals, allowing them free rein in trade and acting always as they saw fit—this, the fifth.

Today, the north suffers the harassment of the Tartar raiders, while the south contends with the intrigues of Jiaozhi. The revenues from state monopolies, though incorporated into the regular fiscal system, are not the proper subject of debate here. Yet the wealth derived from the maritime trade of the southeastern barbarians is beyond calculation. Those who deliberate on statecraft speak only of channeling profit without addressing the issue, while those who clarify the law speak only of opening the frontier without discussion—both fail to understand human nature. For every one benefit, there are ten harms, yet they remain heedless.

Now the seas have been calm for not merely three years. Ships come and go as if traveling a well-trodden path, so much so that the Fujian proverb declares the sea "ripe"—and this is no empty saying. The foreign barbarians profit from their trade, while China gains nothing in return. I humbly submit that this has not been given due thought.

The wealth of the Eastern Sea lies in salt. Beyond salt, there are also timber of a thousand spans and spices by the myriad bushels. The military administrations of the Two Guangs have long relied on these resources, following established regulations. Why not transfer a portion of the trade from Fujian and Zhejiang, establish a sealed treasury to exchange for the submission of Annam, and thereby secure the surplus profits? With these, we could address the anxieties of the northwest—this too would be feasible. Why, then, is this treated as a taboo and left unspoken?

To abandon such measures and instead focus narrowly on suppressing informants and seizing goods, thereby increasing the bait for bandits and smugglers, is not what one would call a grand strategy.

Emperor Taizong said to Song Qi and others: "The order or chaos of an age depends on rewards matching merit and punishments fitting crimes—then there is nothing that cannot be governed. If these are merely tools to adorn one’s anger or delight, then there is nothing that cannot be thrown into chaos. You, my ministers, must take heed."

The Emperor further addressed Lü Mengzheng: "When a scholar has yet to attain office and sees the affairs of the age deviating from principle, he feels discontent in his heart. Once he ascends to a position where he may propose what is proper and reject what is not, he ought to exhaust all that he has accumulated—though his words may not be exhaustive, he should still submit proposals for revision to bring them into accord with the Dao. I certainly do not rely on my lofty status to deter others from speaking.

It is recorded: The utility of a king lies in rewards and punishments; the utility of a minister lies in offering counsel and correction. Taizong may be said to have grasped the essence of governance. Yet when we observe his actions, were they truly so? As for Duoduo’s rivalry with Zhao Pu—these two could not coexist. Had the Emperor cherished Pu, he would have first removed Duoduo. Even if he insisted that rewards and punishments issue solely from himself, who would have objected? Instead, he allowed them to scheme against Tingmei, for the Emperor’s heart was set upon Tingmei. Thus, not only did he wield rewards and punishments as tools to adorn his anger or delight, but he also missed the subtle shifts of success and failure.

After Chai Yutang’s report of treason, today we reward the merit of informants, and tomorrow we deliberate the case of the court scribe—among the ranks of high and low officials, were there none who perceived the affairs of the age? Yet the Grand Preceptor Wang Pu and seventy-four others flattered and complied, leading their sovereign into unrighteousness. Could this be called bringing things into accord with the Dao? It was not merely a matter of relying on his lofty status.

Li Hang, from youth, possessed a magnanimous and far-reaching demeanor. His father, Bing, once told others: 'This child is extraordinary—he will surely rise to the highest offices.' Once, while attending an informal banquet, Taizong remarked as he sent him off: 'Li Hang’s bearing is dignified and steadfast—truly a man of nobility.' When Zhenzong inquired about the principles of governance, Hang replied first: 'The most urgent priority is to avoid employing frivolous, ambitious newcomers who delight in stirring up trouble.'

One evening, an emissary was dispatched bearing a handwritten edict to elevate Lady Liu to the rank of Noble Consort. Hang, in the presence of the messenger, lit a candle and burned the edict, attaching a memorial that read: 'Simply report that Minister Hang deems this inadvisable.' The matter was thus abandoned.

It is recorded: Observing the act of burning the edict by candlelight, I cannot but admire the noble integrity of [Li Hang, posthumously titled] Wenjing. To return a sealed document is already a praiseworthy act; to amend or supplement it is a grand gesture—how much more so to burn it? Had his heart not been vast and his judgment of the Grand Duke [Jiang Ziya] unshakably firm, he would not have remained unmoved by considerations of profit and harm. Moreover, what was Lady Liu? By her lineage, she was most humble; by her skills, most base; by her surname, most distant. 'A flat stone beneath one’s shoe—how low!' Did the Emperor not reflect? Yet her nature was alert and quick, versed in calligraphy and documents, and through this, the gradual foundations of governance were laid. Hang’s foresight not only quietly averted the subtle warning of 'treading on frost' but also openly rejected the imperial decree as if it were a sacred edict. Later, Li Di’s refusal to comply with flattery and Yang Yi’s refusal to draft an improper decree—these were all those who rose in emulation of his example. Who would say that the actions of that moment did not bear upon the gains and losses of an entire reign?

The Emperor, noting that Hang never submitted secret memorials, asked him: 'Everyone else presents confidential reports—why do you alone refrain?' Hang replied: 'As a minister bearing the weight of the office of Grand Councilor, I speak openly of public matters. What need is there for secret memorials? If a minister submits confidential reports, they are either slanderous or sycophantic. I have always despised such things—how could I imitate them?'

It is recorded: Since the flourishing of the wind of slander and deceit, the calamity of mutual destruction has arisen—never has there been a greater harm than secret memorials. The most cunning deceivers are those who point to a deer and call it a horse; the most insidious flatterers are those who point to a crow and call it a phoenix. Yet there remains a deer that can be pointed to, a crow that can be examined—though their intent is to deceive their sovereign, their reasoning may still be traced."

As for the submission of sealed memorials, in their inception, they leave no trace, their origins concealed—no one knows of them. In the end, they pass from one hand to another, yet by what evidence can they be verified? How much worse is it than calling a musk deer a greyhound, or turning white into black? During the reign of Zhenzong, the likes of Wang Qinruo and Ding Wei thronged the court. One of their accusations against Li Hang was precisely that he treated them as they deserved. Yet from the perspective of a true gentleman, how could one, standing beneath the vast sky and under the transforming light of the sun, tolerate even the slightest shadow of concealment, much less willingly place oneself in the realm of private favoritism?

The heart of the petty man is otherwise: in his own affairs, he seeks only convenience and profit; in dealing with others, he harbors only resentment or envy. Profit cannot advance without flattery, and envy cannot penetrate without slander. Slander and flattery are what people deeply detest. Thus, under the guise of secrecy, they peddle their treacherous schemes. Moreover, they exploit the sovereign’s subtle, inexpressible anger and probe the hidden thoughts that cannot be laid bare. Between ruler and minister, they claim to be as inseparable as glue and lacquer, with no flaw to be found. They even seal their memorials with signs and mark them with official seals, their hearts fierce as tigers and wings swift as eagles. Wherever they point, they deceive heaven and delude men, stopping at nothing—what do they have to fear? As a result, the sovereign’s hearing becomes biased, his trust becomes one-sided. Not only do the people suffer in darkness from their calamities, but the court itself is openly disrupted by their machinations. This is why Li Hang’s admonition is revered across the ages.

Zhang Qixian was a man of fervent ambition and grand vision, ever aspiring to guide his sovereign. Once, he spoke to Zhenzong at leisure, tracing the Dao of emperors and kings to its roots and explaining its essence. The emperor said, “I believe the Dao of emperors and kings leaves no trace. As long as all affairs are properly governed, one approaches the Dao.” It is recorded: *The Greater Odes* states, “Do not act thus perversely.” Zhenzong, it seems, had not reflected upon this. For the term “emperors and kings” refers to Yao, Shun, Yu, Tang, Wen, and Wu—their Dao was to hold fast to the center, a transmission of utmost refinement and singular focus. Thus, it resides in the heart as the virtue of heaven and manifests in governance as the kingly Way. The reverence for heaven, diligence for the people, and the proper ordering of human affairs and spiritual rites, as recorded in the classics—how can these be called “without trace”? To say it leaves no trace is but vague, rootless speech, wild and unprincipled words. Alas! Zhang Qixian began well but did not see it through. He sought extraordinary rewards but failed to grasp the enduring principles of canonical models and instructive admonitions, which are not found in obscure mysteries or bizarre, world-defying frugality, but simply in the realm of daily conduct and common practice. Later, the doctrine of “governing through spiritual teachings” indeed aligned with this view, leading to rampant fabrication and deception, with no limit to their excesses. Thus, the ford and shore of the Dao grew distant indeed.

Han Qi, from an early age, bore a illustrious reputation, his insight and magnanimity towering above others. In matters of state, his joy or anger never showed on his face. Serving twice as Grand Councilor, he implemented great strategies to secure the altars of state. At a time when the court faced many crises, Han Qi navigated perilous uncertainties, acting without hesitation. Someone once said to him, “What you do is truly good. But if, by chance, you stumble, not only will you fail to protect yourself, but your family will have no place to stand.” Han Qi sighed and replied, “What kind of talk is this? A minister must exert all his strength in serving his sovereign, staking his life upon it. As for success or failure, that is up to heaven. How can one fret over possible failure and thus shrink from action?” Those who heard this were filled with admiration and respect. In all his proposals, he considered only where righteousness lay, without partiality or prejudice, and alongside Fu Bi, he left behind a legacy of meritorious deeds. Thus, when people of that era spoke of worthy ministers, they invariably mentioned “Fu and Han.” It is recorded: Han Qi’s “acting without hesitation” was first articulated by Mencius, who said, “One who delights in securing the altars of state is a minister who secures the altars of state.” Another interpretation states: “A great minister’s plan to secure the altars of state is like a lesser minister’s duty to please his sovereign.” Devoted to this principle without wavering, how could he be swayed by considerations of safety or danger, profit or harm? If one’s heart is moved by such concerns, one is unfit for great deeds.

Bao Zheng was stern, upright, and resolute. He detested harsh and oppressive officials, and in governance, he emphasized sincerity and generosity. Though he loathed evil as one would an enemy, he never failed to extend loyalty and forbearance to others. He never curried favor, nor did he feign pleasantries to please others. Throughout his life, he kept no private correspondence. When he served as Prefect of Kaifeng, even the powerful relatives and eunuchs of the court restrained themselves, and officials and commoners dared not deceive him. Even children and women knew his name, calling him “Vice Director Bao.” In the capital, a saying arose: “If your connections don’t reach him, you’ll meet old Bao, the Yama King.” His integrity was likened to the clarity of the Yellow River. It is recorded: In my humble observation, the metaphor of “Yama King Bao” is unprecedented in history, unheard of until now. Yet it arises from the hearts of the people and aligns with the principles of heaven. Those who are wronged—we will surely correct them; the upright—we will surely vindicate them. The truth—we will surely investigate it; the false—we will surely expose it. There has never been a case where right and wrong were not adjudicated, where crooked and straight were not distinguished, and where arbitrary willfulness became the wellspring of secret memorials. If the netherworld truly had a Yama King, he would surely elevate the good and cast down the wicked. If not, heaven itself would punish him—how much more so mere mortals? In recent times, some have flaunted their “unyielding integrity,” yet they act recklessly, oblivious to all around them, as if no one else exists. Before long, they vanish without a trace. Not only will they find it hard to escape the judgment of the Supreme Emperor, but they will also face the punishment of the Yama King. What, then, remains of their “unreachable connections”?

Zhao Pu served as Supervising Censor and impeached officials without fear of the powerful or favored, his reputation awe-inspiring. The capital called him “Iron-Faced Zhao.”

He insisted that the court must clearly distinguish between the noble-minded and the petty, arguing that even minor faults in the latter should be firmly suppressed and eradicated, while the former, if mistakenly judged, ought to be preserved and cherished to nurture their virtue. Many eminent officials of the time found security in his stance. Later transferred to serve as Fiscal Commissioner of the Zizhou Circuit, he was soon reassigned to Yizhou. The western lands of Shu were remote, its people vulnerable, and its officials brazenly flouted the law, with prefectures and commanderies exchanging public gifts. Zhao entered Shu ahead of his retinue, accompanied only by a single horse, a zither, and a crane. His governance was simple and unburdened, marked by magnanimity, integrity, and self-cultivation; no one ever saw him display joy or anger. Each day’s affairs, once concluded, he would report to heaven at night, clad in full court attire, burning incense in the open air—whatever he could not honestly declare, he dared not do. His administration was effective, adapting to local customs with a balance of firmness and leniency. In Chengdu, his reputation became especially celebrated. Whenever Emperor Shenzong issued edicts to regional governors, he invariably cited Zhao as an exemplar, emphasizing that governance must be rooted in beneficence and advantage.

In his later years, he delved into the Dao and attained insight. As he neared the end, he bid farewell to his son Zhao Fan, his composure unshaken, and passed away in quiet repose. Han Qi once praised Zhao as a true paragon of his age, declaring him beyond compare.

**Record states:** Zhao Qingmo’s attainment of the Dao—was it through the power of elixirs, cinnabar, or mercury? No. It arose from the aid of tempering desire to nurture the heart, and the proof of his pure conduct transcending worldly俗. This is something no one can afford to ignore. Nowadays, those who refine their forms like withered wood or cast off restraints like whirling winds—who would not call them "attained"? Yet they contribute nothing to human relations or worldly teachings, merely seeking a fleeting, self-serving survival. The noble-minded do not follow such a path. How much finer to leave behind grace that endures in others, to accumulate virtue in all things, so that court and countryside resound with one voice, and no distinction remains between inner and outer realms. Such was Zhao Qinxian: though heaven and earth may perish, his heroic spirit remains boundless. No wonder he is deemed beyond reach.

Lu Zongdao, as Right Rectifier of the Court of Judicature and Revision, spoke without fear or evasion in his memorials. Emperor Zhenzong once inscribed on the palace wall: *"Lu the Upright,"* in remembrance of him. When Lu later entered the Secretariat, he repeatedly offered forthright counsel.

At the time, Empress Dowager Mingsu held court. Once, she asked how Empress Wu of Tang compared as a ruler. Lu Zongdao replied: "She was a criminal of the Tang, nearly bringing ruin to the altars of state." The Empress Dowager fell silent.

A minor official, Fang Zhongxi, petitioned to establish the Seven Ancestral Temples of the Liu clan. The Empress Dowager sought counsel, but the assisting ministers dared not respond. Zongdao alone stepped forward and said: "If the Seven Ancestral Temples of the Liu clan are established, what will become of the heir apparent?" The matter was thus abandoned.

On another occasion, the Empress Dowager accompanied the Emperor to Cixiao Temple. She wished to ride in the imperial palanquin ahead of the Emperor. Zongdao said: "In death, a husband follows his son—such is the Way of a woman." The Empress Dowager then ordered her palanquin to follow behind.

During his seven years as chief minister, Zongdao was unyielding and detested evil. Those among the imperial relatives and favored courtiers who neglected their duties all feared him, calling him the "Fish-Head Chief Minister," both for his surname and his unyielding nature.

Later, Xue Kui succeeded him as chief minister. His disposition was likewise upright and uncompromising; he did not curry favor and spoke boldly on all matters. When the Empress Dowager wished to don the *yibiao* and *mian* crown for a visit to the Imperial Ancestral Temple, Kui said: "If you must wear these, how then will you perform the rites of obeisance?" As she lay on her deathbed, the Emperor, weeping before his assembled ministers, said: "The Empress Dowager is too ill to speak, yet she repeatedly tugs at her robes, as if wishing to convey something. What does it mean?" Kui replied: "It must concern the *yibiao* and *mian* crown. How could she face the late Emperor in the underworld wearing them?" The Emperor understood, and she was ultimately interred in her proper mourning attire.

The record states: The integrity of Shi Yu was only recognized after his death; the unyielding backbone of Zongdao was renowned in his own lifetime.

When Yin served as chief minister, officials of the Selection Bureau never consulted with one another—how could there be one called the "Fish-Head Chief Minister"? Yet the excesses of Empress Mingsu far surpassed those of Wu Zetian. Nevertheless, the remonstrances of these two gentlemen required no elaborate persuasion, for they invoked principle with precision and urgency, upon which the living and the dead alike depended. Could this not be attributed to the dynastic house’s tradition of fostering such conduct? Otherwise, how could both their words and actions have been so perilous?

It is recorded that Fu Yaoyu could compose essays at the age of ten. Shi Jie and Yan Zhu both marveled at him, saying: "Your discernment is keen, your bearing refined; your writing is concise yet exhaustive in principle. You possess the makings of a chief minister." When Wang Anshi later implemented his New Policies, Yaoyu, though on good terms with him, vehemently opposed every measure he found unworkable. When Cai Que was demoted, seven or eight officials—from chief ministers and grand councilors down to attendants—were dismissed, leaving the Censorate and the government bureaus virtually empty. Yaoyu said: "Those who were Cai’s most egregious partisans were right to be banished, but the rest should be left alone. I hope Your Majesty will regard their words as no more than the buzzing of gnats and flies, and not allow the slightest disturbance to disrupt the great harmony of *qi*. This is how the sage-kings nurtured perfect sincerity to secure lasting fortune."

Later, when he was reassigned from remonstrance official to prefect, he enforced every law, even those he deemed flawed, saying: "The noble person acts in accordance with his station. As a remonstrance official, one bears the duty to speak; as a prefect, one must uphold the law." He was subsequently appointed Vice Director of the Secretariat. Emperor Shenzong remarked to the Grand Empress Dowager: "Vice Director Fu’s purity and integrity have remained unchanged from beginning to end. He is a gentleman of gold and jade." Sima Guang said to Shao Yong: "The virtues of purity, integrity, and courage are difficult to combine in one person, yet I see them all in Qin Zhi." Yong replied: "Qin Zhi is pure but not ostentatious, upright but not strident, courageous yet temperate—this is what makes him exceptional."

The record states: The so-called gentleman of gold and jade traces his lineage to the *Wei Feng*’s "Qi Ao," where he is likened to "gold and tin, to jade tablets and disks." The exegetes explain: "Gold and tin" signify the refinement of his tempering, while "jade tablets and disks" denote the warmth and luster of his innate nature. Even Duke Wu of Wei could not claim sole glory for such virtues. Thereafter, those who were haughty often clashed, those who formed cliques often schemed, turning the court into a den of leopards and tigers, a thicket of thorns, a realm of demons and barbarians. How could the noble person do more than grind and polish such a world as one would a whetstone? How could he refine its raw jade or reveal its golden and jadelike essence? Thus, one cannot merely admire the perfected virtue of such men; their rise and fall indeed reflect the world’s ascent and decline, the Dao’s purity and corruption.

When Sima Guang served as Remonstrance Official, he presented three memorials to the throne. The first addressed the three virtues of a ruler: benevolence, wisdom, and martial prowess. Benevolence does not mean coddling or indulgence; it means promoting education, refining governance, nurturing the people, and benefiting all things—this is the benevolence of a sovereign. Wisdom does not mean petty scrutiny or surveillance; it means understanding principle and righteousness, discerning safety and danger, distinguishing the worthy from the foolish, and differentiating right from wrong—this is the wisdom of a sovereign. Martial prowess does not mean aggression or brutality; it means unwavering resolve where the Dao lies, imperviousness to the deceptions of the treacherous, and immovability before the flattery of sycophants—this is the martial prowess of a sovereign.

Your servant observes that Your Majesty governs with an open heart, maintaining a dignified and serene demeanor. When ministers present their proposals, you no longer inquire into their advantages and disadvantages or thoroughly examine their merits and flaws, but instead approve them all. I hope Your Majesty will expand your innate, boundless benevolence like the radiance of the sun and moon, and rouse the firm resolve of the *qian* hexagram, so that the prosperity of the Tang, Yu, and the Three Dynasties may not be far off.

The second memorial discussed the three pillars of good governance: appointing officials, ensuring trustworthy rewards, and enforcing inevitable punishments. The state values reputation over substance and punishes the letter of the law rather than the intent. If rewards are given based on reputation, the world will embellish their names to seek merit; if punishments are meted out based on legalistic formalities, the world will manipulate the law to evade guilt.

The third memorial addressed military selection, arguing that the art of maintaining an army lies in quality, not quantity. The emperor retained the first memorial for his personal consideration, sent the second to the Secretariat, and forwarded the third to the Bureau of Military Affairs. Guang also presented five admonitions: first, to preserve the legacy; second, to cherish time; third, to plan for the long term; fourth, to be vigilant in small matters; and fifth, to prioritize leniency. The emperor deeply accepted his counsel.

The record states: The late Master Zhu Xi said: "Wengong (Sima Guang) may be called a man of wisdom, benevolence, and courage. His governance was of the highest order, his vision broad. He was learned, stern, and upright. Alas!"

Observing Xi’s words, one sees that the remonstrances presented by the Remonstrance Bureau were indeed his own insights. The three virtues—wisdom, benevolence, and courage—are the gateway through which the sage enters the Dao. As for being free from sorrow, confusion, and fear, he never ceased to strive earnestly. Could Guang’s endowment from Heaven be anything but profound? Could his devotion to learning be anything but sincere? As for the three memorials and five admonitions, their implementation is but a matter of sequence, while the cultivation of the ruler’s virtue is the root. *The Doctrine of the Mean* does not say: "That by which they are practiced is one"? Thus, Guang’s preservation of sincerity had its source.

When Emperor Zhezong ascended the throne, Guang was appointed Left Vice Director of the Department of State Affairs. By then, he had already fallen ill, yet the Green Sprouts and Hired Service laws he had opposed remained in force, and the Western Xia had not yet submitted. Guang sighed, saying: "The four harms remain unremoved; I shall not close my eyes in death." He penned a brief note to Lord Lü, writing: "I entrust my person to the physicians, my family affairs to my foolish son, but the affairs of state have yet to be entrusted—today, I place them in your care."

Soon after, an edict excused him from court audiences and permitted him to be carried in a sedan chair, attending the ministry only once every three days. Guang dared not accept this, saying: "Without seeing the ruler, I cannot conduct affairs." The court ordered his son Kang to support him into the audience. When the Khitan heard of this, they instructed their border officials: "The Chinese have a minister—Minister Sima. Take care not to provoke incidents or open rifts along the frontier." At that time, the two courts humbled themselves in virtue, and Guang, seeing his words and plans consistently followed, sought to devote himself to the state like a watchdog, attending to every duty without rest, day or night.

Visitors, seeing his frail body, cautioned him with the example of Zhuge Liang—too little food for too many affairs. Guang replied: "Life and death are matters of fate." Though he redoubled his efforts, his illness worsened until he could no longer rise. Even then, his words remained earnest, as if spoken in a dream—yet all concerned the affairs of court and realm.

It is recorded: As Lü Xianke lay dying, he wrote by hand to entrust Minister Sima, saying: "The affairs of the realm may yet be saved—Junshi, I urge you to strive." As Minister Sima himself neared death, he sent a note to Lord Lü, saying: "The state’s affairs remain unentrusted—I now place them in your care." The upright ends of these two men were much alike, for their aspirations were one. The *Book of Changes* says: "The king’s ministers toil tirelessly, not for themselves." Thus did they labor to the utmost until their last breath. So long as a single breath remained, their devotion to the state allowed no slackening—how could their earnest words, like speech in a dream, be otherwise?

During the Xining era, the emperor, in response to calamities, withdrew to a secondary hall, reduced his meals, and silenced the music. Wang Anshi said to the emperor: "Disasters and omens are all matters of heavenly decree, unrelated to the success or failure of human affairs." Fu Bi, traveling on the road, heard this and sighed: "What the ruler fears is Heaven. If he fears not Heaven, what may he not do?" This must be the work of a treacherous man advancing perverse doctrines to sway the emperor’s heart, rendering the counsel of his ministers and remonstrators powerless. This is the pivot of order and chaos—it cannot be left unchecked. He immediately submitted a memorial of several thousand words, citing the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, the *Great Plan*, and historical records both ancient and modern, along with human nature and the principles of things, to demonstrate why such claims were utterly untenable. When he entered to address the throne, he further said: "The advancement or retreat of gentlemen and petty men hinges upon whether the kingly Way is pleased or displeased. Your Majesty favors sending men to spy on external affairs, and so the treacherous and frugal thrive. Moreover, the governance of court and realm has gradually begun to change—this must be the work of petty men offering counsel to Your Majesty. Petty men, by nature, delight in action and stirring up trouble, for they harbor secret ambitions. If the court maintains stillness, affairs proceed by established laws—what then can petty men hope for?"

It is recorded: Though the emperor wavered and Fu Bi spoke forthrightly, it was like urging the deaf to listen or demanding sight from the blind. Yet such words were not discarded, for though times differ, principle never ceases. Heaven is not to be feared, but the principles of Heaven are. Men are not to be pitied, but the hearts of men must be. The whims of one man cannot be relied upon, but the sentiments of the hundred officials and myriad people can. The fleeting alignment of the moment cannot be trusted, but the judgments of all under Heaven and later ages can. To dismiss such counsel as futile and abandon it would plunge ten thousand generations into eternal night.

When Wang Anshi took office, all believed him the right man for the hour—only Lü Huai alone declared him unfit for the times. To employ him in great office would be unwise, he said, and sought to be transferred elsewhere. Sima Guang also attended the imperial lectures and privately asked what Lü had spoken of that day. Lü replied: "I have a memorial in my sleeve—it concerns the new appointee." Guang, startled, said: "All rejoice at having found the right man—why do you oppose him?" Lü said: "Do you, Junshi, also speak thus? This man may have some reputation, but he clings stubbornly to his own views, readily trusts the treacherous, and delights in flattery. His words sound fine at first, but when put into practice, they falter. If placed in the highest office, the realm will surely suffer his calamity." He then submitted a memorial stating: "The greatest treachery wears the guise of loyalty; the deepest deceit, the semblance of sincerity. Anshi outwardly appears rustic and unrefined, but inwardly harbors cunning and deceit. Arrogant and disdainful toward his superiors, secretly cruel and harmful to others—here I briefly recount over a dozen matters. I fear Your Majesty, pleased by his eloquence, may come to rely on him, and in time, his true nature will remain hidden. Once the path for great treachery is opened, the wicked will gather like water converging in a ravine, the worthy will be driven out, and chaos will arise. I privately grieve for this. He who will bring ruin to the black-haired masses is surely this man."

It is recorded: How can the words of a gentleman be taken lightly? "Outwardly rustic and unrefined, inwardly cunning and deceitful; arrogant and disdainful toward his superiors, secretly cruel and harmful to others"—these four phrases exhaust the depths of Anshi’s nature, which no one under Heaven for ten thousand generations can conceal. Yet what does it matter whether he was heeded or not, acted upon or not? If one merely praises Lü’s foresight, then Li Shizhong also foresaw this—not only Xianke. When Shizhong first served in the provinces and counties, a palace report announced that Bao Zheng had been appointed Assistant Minister. Some said the court would henceforth see much trouble. Shizhong said: "What can Lord Bao do? The magistrate of Yin County now—that is the man who will one day bring chaos to the realm." He referred to Wang Anshi, whose eyes had much white, much like Wang Shu. Twenty years later, his words proved true—indeed, he had foreseen it even before Lü Huai.

Fan Chunren memorialized: "Anshi extorts wealth and profit, unsettling the people’s hearts." The *Book of Documents* says: "Resentment—does it lie only in what is seen and not seen?" The emperor asked: "What is resentment that is not seen?" He replied: "It is what Du Mu called 'not daring to speak, but daring to be angry.'" The emperor said: "You discuss affairs well. For my sake, set forth the lessons of order and chaos from ancient and modern times that may serve as warnings." Thereupon, he composed the *Exegesis on the Book of Documents* and presented it, drawing on the deeds of Yao, Shun, Yu, Tang, King Wen, King Wu, and the Duke of Zhou. He said: "There is no better way to govern the realm than this. I wish to delve deeply into it and practice it with all my strength." When the equalized tax law was implemented in the six circuits, he again said: "I once personally received Your Majesty’s virtuous decree, desiring to restore the policies of the former kings to aid the people. Now, instead, you emulate Sang Hongyang’s equalized transport system, employing petty men to extort and oppress, provoking the people’s resentment and inviting disaster." Anshi, using the pretext of enriching the state and strengthening the military, had awakened the emperor’s ambitions, seeking quick results while forgetting his former learning. In matters of law, he invoked Shang Yang; in matters of wealth and profit, he turned his back on Mengzi.

The aged and decrepit had become mere followers of convention, casting aside public consensus as vulgar custom, branding those who differed as unworthy while praising those who aligned with their views as virtuous. His remonstrances went unheeded. Each time Chunren submitted memorials with fervent urgency, the emperor withheld them entirely from external circulation—until now, when they were all compiled and presented to the central administration.

Anshi flew into a rage and demanded severe demotion. The emperor replied: "He has committed no crime; let him be assigned to a favorable post." Thus, he was appointed Prefect of Hezhong. The record states: Of all the critiques against the New Policies, none have been as incisive as Chunren’s. And why did Mu’s words arise? For just as Qin employed Shang Yang, so too does this reign employ Shi; and just as Shi’s policies were put into effect, so too were Shang Yang’s doctrines extended. When he declared: "Those who discourse on the highest virtue do not conform to established custom; those who achieve great deeds do not consult the masses," this was precisely Shi’s obstinate inflexibility. And when he said: "Ordinary people are content with old customs, while scholars are drowned in received knowledge," this was precisely Shi’s defiance of the multitude to assert his singularity. Relentlessly pursuing profit, they bled the people’s essence and exhausted their strength—how could the people’s resentment not pour forth as if from their own mouths? Thus, applying Mu’s critique of Qin to Shi, we see that in the end, his policies gnawed at the state and betrayed the Dao, leaving the people joyless in life, and the disaster of barbarian invasion followed on its heels. How little does this differ from the path that doomed Qin! Alas, how lamentable!

At that time, prolonged drought and famine pressed heavily, with exactions harsh and urgent. Refugees from the northeast, carrying their young and elderly, clogged the roads—emaciated, sick, and sorrowful. With each gust of wind and sand, they stood exposed, their clothing in tatters. Even the city-dwellers resorted to mixing hemp, wheat bran, and chaff with rice to make gruel, supplementing it with tree bark and grass roots. Some, shackled in chains and carrying tiles, sold timber to repay official debts, their numbers unending.

When Zheng Xia, Judicial Officer of Guangzhou, was stationed at the Anshang Gate, he painted a scene of this suffering and submitted it with a memorial: "When Your Majesty campaigns south and north, all reports speak of triumphant victories. Yet no one has presented a painting depicting the people’s hardships—how parents, wives, and children can no longer protect one another, how they wander destitute, their lives in disarray. I have carefully observed the Anshang Gate and, though what I have depicted captures but a fraction of the reality, even this glimpse should move Your Majesty to tears—how much more so from a thousand *li* away? I implore Your Majesty to view my painting and act upon my words. If even a single day passes without heeding both, then execute me for the crime of deceiving the throne."

Upon receiving the memorial, the emperor pored over the painting again and again, sighing deeply. He tucked it into his sleeve and retired. That night, he lay awake, unable to sleep. The next day, he ordered the capital to suspend the *xingqian* tax, the Three Departments to investigate the *shiyi* system, the Ministry of Agriculture to open the Ever-Normal Granaries, and the Three Guards to prepare for the troops in Xihe. He also commanded the provinces to address the dispersal of people and resources. Thus, the Green Sprouts and Labor Service laws were temporarily halted, collections ceased, and the Square Fields and Baojia systems were abolished—eighteen measures in all. When the people heard this, they cheered and congratulated one another.

The knight-errant then took the biographies of Wei Zheng, Yao Chong, Song Jing, Li Linfu, and Lu Qi from the *Old Tang Book* and arranged them into two scrolls, inscribing them: *"The Upright Gentleman and the Wicked Knave."* Along the borders of the illustrations, he noted: *"Officials in Office."* Those who secretly aligned with Li Linfu yet turned against Chong and Jing were each categorized and presented in written form.

Censorate official Yang Zhongxin visited the knight-errant and said: "The Censorate remains silent, yet you persist in submitting memorials—this places the duty of remonstrance at the palace gate while leaving the Censorate empty of men." He drew from his sleeve two volumes of memorials by eminent ministers and handed them to the knight-errant, saying: "Let these aid the upright."

The record states: *"The gentleman’s thoughts do not exceed his station,"* yet the knight-errant may be said to have overstepped his. Speech may differ in approval or disdain, but the painting rests upon the truth of what is seen and heard. As for the knight-errant—would he refuse the post of *jianmen* to accept the duty of *jiantao*? His resolve is thus known, and his words are not reckless. The dead lie but a moment away, so he spares no effort to assist; the flames lick at his eyelashes, so why惜 his life? Yet the emperor, though sleepless, remained deluded and did not act. Why? In the end, the fragrance of Yingzhou endured for posterity, while the calamity of Bianzhou brought misery in its time. The gentleman must not reject even the humblest office to avert such fates.

During the reign of Emperor Huizong, Chen He served as *You Zhengyan*. Tong Guan, Huang Jingchen, and Lu Hang colluded in treachery. Chen declared: "This concerns the very survival of the state. I bear the duty of remonstrance—how can I remain silent?" He submitted a memorial impeaching Tong Guan for abusing his favor and wielding power. Before he could finish reading it, the emperor rose abruptly, brushing off his robe. Chen grasped the emperor’s sleeve to plead for the chance to complete his speech, tearing the garment. The emperor said: "The *Zhengyan* has torn my robe." Chen replied: "Your Majesty does not惜 this torn robe—how could I惜 a shattered skull? These men now enjoy wealth and honor, but Your Majesty will one day face ruin." His words grew ever more urgent. The emperor’s expression shifted as he said: "If you can speak thus, what should I fear?" The eunuchs urged the emperor to change his robe, but he refused, saying: "Keep it to honor this forthright minister."

The record states: One has heard of mending a torn garment, but never of tearing the emperor’s robe. Is this not worthy of record? The disasters of the Song began with Wang Anshi and Lü Huishu and ended with Tong Guan and Wang Fu. By then, the realm lay shattered, and even a minister like Zhong Shanfu could find no remedy.

Li Ruoshui served as *Shilang* of the Ministry of Rites. When Emperor Qinzong was summoned again, the Jin army forced the emperor to change his robes. Li embraced him, weeping, and reviled the invaders as "dog barbarians." The Jin soldiers dragged him out and flung him to the ground. The Khitan commander Hemo shouted: "Ensure the *Shilang* comes to no harm!" Li refused all food. Some urged him: "There is nothing to be done. Submit today, and tomorrow you will have wealth and rank." He sighed: "Heaven has no two suns—how could I serve two masters?" His servant also tried to console him: "Your parents are advanced in years. If you yield even slightly, you might return to see them." Li rebuked him: "I have put my family aside. A loyal minister serves his lord with death, not divided loyalty. But my parents are elderly—I fear they will be alarmed, so I will write to reassure them." When the discussion turned to establishing a puppet regime, Zhang Bangchang summoned Li to discuss matters. Li cursed him roundly, and the Jin overseer struck him, splitting his lips, tearing his throat, and severing his tongue before he died at thirty-five. The Jin remarked among themselves: "When the Liao fell, a dozen men died for righteousness. In the Southern Court, only *Shilang* Li stands alone."

Liu Ge served as *Zizhengdian Xueshi*. When the Jin entered Zhen Ding, the elders wailed: "Had *Zizheng* Liu been here, how could this calamity have befallen our town?" The Jin, hearing his name, insisted on seizing him. When the capital fell, he was taken to the Jin camp. The Jin chancellor Han Zheng lodged him at Shousheng Monastery south of the city, saying: "The chancellor knows you. Now we will employ you." Liu replied: "To live in shame and serve two dynasties—I will not do it." Han said: "The army intends to establish a ruler of another surname. We wish to make you *Shangshu*. The chancellor may take his family with him. To die with your followers is less than going north for wealth and rank." Liu looked to the heavens and cried: "Is this so?" He returned home with a slip of paper recounting the matter and sent a kinsman to deliver it to his son.
