Liu Yu and the others bathed, changed into fresh clothes, poured a cup of wine, and hanged themselves. The Jin marveled at his loyalty and buried him on a hill south of the temple. Eighty days later, when they exhumed him, his complexion remained as in life.

The record states: The *Shilang* of the Southern Court and the *Zizheng* of Zhen Ding—even today, the people praise them. Compared to Bangchang and Liu Yu, they are as far removed as spittle cast aside. What need is there to speak of them further?

*Hongdao Lu*, Scroll Fifteen, concludes.
*Hongdao Lu*, Scroll Sixteen: *Righteousness*.

"The Righteousness of Ruler and Minister"

In the first year of the *Shaoxing* reign of Emperor Gaozong, Li Gang was summoned to serve as *You Chengxiang* (Right Grand Councilor). He submitted a memorial stating: "A sovereign who revives a fallen state and restores order must be of heroic wisdom to be equal to the task. Only with heroism can one’s resolve be firm enough to oversee great affairs without being swayed by petty concerns. Only with wisdom can one’s perception of virtue be clear enough to employ the noble without being misled by the base. In former times, rulers who embodied this Dao were none other than Emperor Gao and Emperor Guangwu of Han, Emperor Taizong of Tang, and our dynasty’s Emperor Taizu and Emperor Taizong. May Your Majesty take them as models."

The record states: In speaking of heroic wisdom, did Li Gang not have grounds for his words? Observing the emperor’s early conduct—when the northern tribes were still rampant, he boldly requested to go forth himself—this could be called heroic. Later, in a moment of crisis, he stabilized the precarious succession—this could be called wise. Alas, the mediocre nature of the sovereign became mired in ease and comfort, while the emperor’s attendants were content with mere expediency. Though Li Gang’s worth was evident, his talents could not be fully employed; though generals like Zhang, Han, Liu, and Yue stood ready, their achievements could not be completed. Thus, petty men like Wang Huang and Qin Hui concealed their true intentions and indulged their desires without restraint, unaware that the spirits of the illustrious rulers of Han and Tang had long since been buried beneath the earth. Who could say Li Gang lacked foresight?

Upon arriving at the imperial refuge, Li Gang memorialized: "The Jin act without principle, relying solely on deceit and stratagem to prevail. China, failing to perceive this, has fallen entirely into their schemes. Yet, by the grace of Heaven, the Mandate has not yet changed. Your Majesty now commands the armies in the field, upheld by the ministers and people of the realm. To cultivate virtue within and repel the enemy without, to restore the Two Sacred Ones and pacify the myriad states—this responsibility rests with Your Majesty and your chief minister." He then humbly declared: "In my own estimation, I am lacking and unworthy of such a weighty commission. I humbly beg that the appointment be revoked." The emperor replied: "I have long known of your loyalty, righteousness, wisdom, and resourcefulness. Do not decline."

Li Gang kowtowed in tears to express his gratitude, then said: "When the Tang Emperor Minghuang sought to appoint Yao Chong as his chief minister, Yao presented ten conditions, each addressing the ills of the time. Now, I too venture to lay ten proposals before Your Majesty’s celestial hearing. Should Your Majesty deem any of them feasible and grant their implementation, I shall then dare to accept the commission.

First, to deliberate on the state’s fundamental policies;
second, to deliberate on the imperial progress;
third, to deliberate on amnesties;
fourth, to deliberate on usurpation and rebellion;
fifth, to deliberate on false mandates;
sixth, to deliberate on warfare;
seventh, to deliberate on defense;
eighth, to deliberate on governance at its root;
ninth, to deliberate on long-term appointments;
tenth, to deliberate on the cultivation of virtue.

The following day, these proposals were presented for discussion in court. Only the matters of usurpation, rebellion, and false mandates were withheld from public decree.

Alas! Emperor Gaozong of Song was not one with whom great deeds could be accomplished. To firmly establish authority, one must first clearly identify the enemy—this was the grand strategy of Emperor Gao of Han. To execute Wei and slay Guan in pursuit of restoration was also the heroic valor of Emperor Xuan of Tang. The enmity of the Song house, though not immediately reversible, should not have been met with leniency toward the likes of Zhang Bangchang. His crimes reached to Heaven; his filth defiled our altars, his stench polluted our court. Even if we were to trace his every evil, the very dogs and fowl would find him intolerable—why then spare him our blade? Among these ten proposals, this was the most critical, for it concerned the hierarchy of ruler and subject and the very foundation of the people’s moral order. Yet the emperor concealed it and took no action. What more need one say of his timidity and failure to rule?

Though Li Gang contested fiercely, he could do no more than resign in protest, never having publicly denounced the traitor’s crimes before the realm. Soon after, Liu Yu followed the same path, brazenly enthroning himself and ordering his son to invade the Song. How different this was from the executions of Wei and the destruction of Xiang! This is why the Southern Song ultimately met its demise.

Li Gang further stated: 'Though the current state of the realm is no worse than during the Jingkang era, there remains hope. If Your Majesty exercises resolute judgment from above while ministers foster harmony below, the corruptions of Jingkang may yet be rectified, and restoration achieved. Yet without a clear vision and an understanding of priorities and urgency, success will remain elusive.

Externally, we must resist the powerful enemy; internally, we must suppress bandits and rebels. We must reform military governance, transform the spirit of the soldiery, enrich the state’s coffers, ease the people’s burdens, amend corrupt laws, reduce superfluous offices, issue sincere decrees to move the people’s hearts, and enforce rewards and punishments to rouse the troops’ morale. We must select capable generals to command the frontiers and choose supervisory officials and prefectural governors to implement the new policies. Only when our own house is in order can we then punish the Jin and welcome back the Two Emperors. This is what I mean by a grand design.

As for immediate priorities, the first must be the management of Hebei and Hedong. These regions are the nation’s shield. Once they are stabilized, the Central Plains can be secured, and the southeast pacified. In Hedong, the lost territories include Heng, Dai, Taiyuan, Ze, and Zezhou, while the remaining prefectures remain under our control. In Hebei, only Zhen, Huai, Wei, and Xun have been lost; over twenty other prefectures are still held by the court. The people, soldiers, and generals of both circuits remain steadfastly loyal to the Song, rallying under local heroes—some leading tens of thousands, others no fewer than ten thousand. If the court does not seize this moment to establish administrative offices, dispatch envoys to console and reassure them, and send troops to relieve their distress, I fear that with supplies exhausted and strength depleted, they will succumb to the Jin’s encirclement. Though their hearts remain loyal, if no aid arrives and they are left desperate and unheard, they may grow resentful toward the court. The Jin, seizing the opportunity, will then win them over—these are all elite troops.

It would be far better to establish a Pacification Office in Hebei and an Administration Office in Hedong, appointing men of talent and strategy to serve as envoys. They should proclaim the emperor’s benevolence and the court’s unwillingness to abandon the Two Rivers to the enemy. Those who preserve a prefecture or recover a commandery should be granted titles such as *jiedushi*, *fangyushi*, or *tuanlianshi*, following the Tang system of regional military governors, enabling them to defend themselves. This would not only sever their inclination to side with the enemy but also harness their strength to resist. This is the most urgent task of the moment.'

The emperor approved his words and asked whom he might appoint. Li Gang recommended Zhang Suo and Fu Liang. Alas! Observing the discussions on the Two Rivers and the establishment of the Administration and Campaign Offices, the revival of the Song seemed within reach. That a southerner like Li Gang should uphold such towering righteousness, transcending the prevailing winds—was this not a great turning point? Yet before long, Huang Qianshan and Wang Boyan forcibly ousted Li Gang, and the Pacification and Administration Offices were abolished. The imperial carriage hastened eastward, and the prefectures and counties of the Two Rivers fell one after another. All of Li Gang’s planned military and civil policies were discarded, the Jin grew ever stronger, the Guanzhong region lay in ruins, bandits swarmed the Central Plains, and the state became irredeemable.

Zong Ze memorialized: 'The realm belongs to the Great Ancestor. Your Majesty, with reverent diligence, seeks to transmit it to ten thousand generations—how then can you so readily discuss ceding the east and west of the Yellow River, or even the regions of Pu and Jie? Since the Jin’s second invasion, the court has not dispatched a single general or soldier. Instead, we hear only of treacherous ministers, who in the morning propose peace talks and by evening beg for alliances, until the Two Emperors were carried north and the ancestral temples disgraced. I had thought Your Majesty would rise in righteous fury, openly denounce and punish the traitors, and thus restore the royal house. Yet since your enthronement, no grand decrees have been issued—only a directive from the Ministry of Justice forbidding the public proclamation of amnesties in the east and west of the Yellow River or in Pu and Jie of Shaanxi. This strips the loyal and righteous of their resolve and severs the bond between ruler and people. Though I am weak and cowardly, I would charge ahead of the generals, arrows and stones be damned, and lay down my life to repay the state—what more could I ask?'"

The Emperor read his words and was struck by their valor. At that time, the position of Prefect of Kaifeng was vacant. Li Gang argued that the restoration of the old realm could not be achieved without [Zhao] Ze, and so he was appointed Military Commissioner of the Eastern Capital and Prefect of Kaifeng. Ze then submitted another memorial, stating: "In Kaifeng, market prices and shops have gradually returned to normal. Soldiers, farmers, merchants, and scholar-officials who cherish loyalty and righteousness all wish for Your Majesty to swiftly return to the capital to console the people’s hearts. Those who advocate dissenting opinions do not offer loyal counsel to Your Majesty but merely collude with the likes of Zhang Bangchang, secretly aligning with the Jin for their own gain."

At that time, the regions of Zhen, Ding, Huai, and Wei were heavily occupied by enemy forces, who were covertly preparing for battle and devising plans for invasion. Ze crossed the Yellow River to confer with the generals and discuss strategies for recovery. Within the capital, he stationed commanders on all four sides to oversee the recruitment of troops and constructed twelve hundred war chariots. He also established twenty-four fortified strongholds outside the city based on strategic terrain, garrisoning tens of thousands of soldiers. Ze personally inspected and drilled them, while along the river, he arranged defenses in a continuous, interlocking formation, linking the loyal militia of the eastern and northern regions with the mountains and waters. As a result, the armies of Shaanxi and the eastern and western circuits of the capital all wished to be placed under Ze’s command.

Ze repeatedly memorialized the throne, urging the Emperor to return to the capital. However, the Emperor followed the counsel of Huang Qianshan and resolved to flee southeast. The chronicler notes: The essence of Ze’s two memorials aligned with Li Gang’s. For the realm’s situation is such that one either advances or retreats. To advance would not only preserve the old borders but also reclaim lost territory, avenge humiliation, and restore honor. To retreat would not only forfeit Hebei and Hedong but also render Henan beyond recovery. Not only Henan, but even the Huai region would fall into chaos. Retreat across the Yangtze, or further by sea—such consequences would be inevitable. This was the depth of Ze’s grief and indignation, which would not cease until his death. Alas! Could the crimes of Wang [Boyan] and Huang [Qianshan] ever be adequately punished? This was the first of Emperor Gaozong’s lifelong regrets.

In the winter of the fourth year of the Jianyan era, the tenth month, an edict ordered Han Shizhong to advance to Yangzhou. Upon receiving the command, Shizhong wept with emotion and declared, "With the sovereign in such distress, how can a subject live on?" He personally led his cavalry to confront the enemy, felling trees to build palisades and cutting off his own retreat. As he marched, the court dispatched Wei Liangchen as an envoy to the Jin camp. Shizhong deceived Liangchen by claiming the edict ordered him to shift his forces to guard the river. Once Liangchen departed, Shizhong mounted his horse and commanded his troops, "Follow where my whip points." He then moved his army toward Dayi, arraying five battle formations and setting over twenty ambushes.

When Liangchen reached the Jin forces, the Jin inquired about the movements of the Song army, and he relayed the false report of the relocation. Nie’er Bodong, upon hearing this, rejoiced and led his troops to the riverbank, halting five *li* from Dayi. Another Jin general, Tiebuye, advanced with armored cavalry through the five Song formations from the east. Shizhong signaled with a small banner and sounded the drums; ambushes sprang up on all sides. The Song banners intermingled with those of the Jin, throwing the enemy into confusion as the Song forces pressed forward. Shizhong ordered his "Ghost Soldiers" to wield long axes, striking at the enemy’s chests above and severing their horses’ legs below. The Jin, clad in heavy armor, became mired in the mud. Shizhong then directed his elite cavalry to trample them from all sides, slaughtering men and horses alike. He captured over two hundred prisoners, including Tiebuye. Meanwhile, Shizhong’s subordinate Dong Ying also defeated the Jin at Yamouth Bridge in Tianchang.

Xie Yuan, reaching the north gate of Gaoyou, encountered an enemy ambush. His naval forces engaged in thirteen battles along the river in a single day, holding their ground without yielding. Shizhong dispatched Cheng Min with cavalry to reinforce them, and another fierce battle ensued, resulting in many captives. Shizhong then personally pursued the fleeing Jin to the Huai River, where the enemy panicked and stampeded, many drowning in the chaos. When news of the victory reached the court, officials entered to offer congratulations. The Emperor declared, "Shizhong’s loyalty and bravery are such that I knew he would succeed." Shen Yuqiu remarked, "Since the Jianyan era began, our generals have never engaged the Jin in battle. Now, with Shizhong’s successive victories, his achievements are no small matter. This campaign stands as the foremost military triumph of our time."

Later, when the Emperor personally led his forces to resist the Jin, halting at Pingjiang Prefecture, the combined forces of the Jin and Qi pressed close. Court officials urged the Emperor to flee elsewhere to evade them.

Zhang Jun said, "Where could we flee to? Only by advancing to command the army ourselves can we avoid disaster." Zhao Ding remarked, "If we fight and do not prevail, retreat will not come too late." The Emperor then declared, "For the Two Sacred Ones, still held afar, I have already sought peace, yet they persist in violence and oppression. I shall personally lead the Six Armies to the Yangtze and engage them in battle." Shen Yuqiu again strongly endorsed Zhao Ding’s counsel, adding with delight, "Years of retreat and timidity have only emboldened the enemy. Now, with Your Majesty’s resolute decision to lead the campaign, the officers and soldiers will surely rise to the occasion—success is assured. I humbly offer my meager talents to devise strategies for the nation’s sake."

When Zhang Jun inspected the troops at Zhenjiang, he met Zhao Ding and grasped his hand, saying, "Every move in this campaign aligns with the people’s will." Zhao Ding smiled and replied, "This is Yu Zicai’s achievement." An edict then appointed Zhang Jun as Commissioner of the Bureau of Military Affairs. Upon receiving the command, he immediately set out for the Yangtze to oversee the forces. At that time, Tahan Wumu amassed a hundred thousand troops, vowing to cross the Yangtze and fight. Zhang Jun advanced swiftly to the riverbank, summoning Liu Guangshi, Han Shizhong, and Zhang Jun to council. The officers, witnessing his bold spirit, were tenfold emboldened. After organizing the troops and assigning commands, Zhang Jun remained in Zhenjiang to direct operations.

Yue Fei, stationed in Jiankang, repeatedly presented the Emperor with strategies for reclaiming lost territories, stating, "The reason the Jin installed Liu Yu in the Central Plains was to ravage the region, using Chinese to attack Chinese, allowing them to rest their troops and watch for opportunities. If Your Majesty grants me but a few months, I shall lead my forces to Jing and Luo, seize Heyang, Shanfu, and Tong Pass, and rally the rebel generals of the Five Routes. Once these rebels return to allegiance, I will dispatch the imperial armies forward. The enemy will surely abandon Bian and flee north of the Yellow River, allowing us to recover the capital region and the lands west of Shaan. Then, dividing our forces to dredge Hua and Hua, we shall reclaim the Two Rivers. Thus, Liu Yu can be captured, and the Jin destroyed. This is the enduring plan for the dynasty’s restoration."

The Emperor replied, "...With such ministers, what need have I to worry about the timing of advance or retreat? I shall not interfere." He then summoned Yue Fei to his private chambers and commanded, "The task of reviving the dynasty I entrust entirely to you." Yue Fei thus prepared for a grand campaign.

**Record:** In my humble view, Yue Fei’s words reflected his true capabilities, not empty boasts to deceive. When he crushed Yang Mo, pitting water bandits against water bandits, his swift success proved his skill. Now, using rebel generals to subdue rebel ministers—would this not be even easier? Had the Emperor followed through on his words, entrusting the restoration entirely to Yue Fei, his far-sighted plans would have borne fruit in no time. Yet he was thwarted by the treacherous Qin Hui. When Yue Fei requested to report to the Supreme Commander, how could Qin Hui not have known of Zhang Jun’s enmity? Yet he ultimately obstructed and demoralized Yue Fei, and by the time Yue Fei sought to act again, it was too late. Though Qin Hui’s jealousy was despicable, was this not also a case of Heaven thwarting success? This was the second of Emperor Gaozong’s great regrets.

At that time, Liang Xing, leader of the Loyal and Righteous Society of the Taihang Mountains, along with heroes from the Two Rivers, led their followers to join Yue Fei. Thus, the Jin’s every move and the lay of the land’s strategic points were known to him. From the Central Plains to the borders of Ci, Xiang, Ze, Di, Jin, Fenyang, and Wei, all awaited his arrival, their troops converging with the imperial forces, raising banners emblazoned with "Yue." Elders and common folk vied to pull carts and lead oxen, laden with grain to support the righteous army. Those bearing incense basins to welcome them lined the roads. South of Yan, the Jin’s commands held no sway. When Wumu sought to rally his forces against Yue Fei, not a single man in Hebei responded. He sighed, "Since I rose in the north, I have never suffered such a setback."

Jin generals Wang Zhen, Cui Qing, Li Ji, Cui Hu, and Hua Wang, along with their troops, surrendered to Yue Fei. The generals of the Dragon-Tiger Prince, including Chi Zha, secretly received Yue Fei’s banners and defected from their kingdom. Han Chang also sought to submit with fifty thousand men. Yue Fei rejoiced and told his officers, "We shall march straight to Huanglongfu and drink deeply with all of you!" He then memorialized the throne: "As Xing and others cross the river, the people’s hearts turn toward the court. The Jin, repeatedly defeated, have ordered the old and young to flee north—this is the perfect moment for restoration!"

Yet Qin Hui, intent on ceding all lands north of the Huai to the Jin in a peace settlement, incited court officials to petition for the generals’ withdrawal. Knowing Yue Fei’s resolve could not be swayed, he memorialized, "Yue Fei’s isolated army cannot remain long; I beg you to recall him swiftly." Thus, in a single day, Yue Fei received twelve golden tablets. Grieving and weeping, he bound his hair, bowed twice, and said, "A decade’s effort is undone in an instant."

**Record:** In my humble view, during Emperor Gaozong’s reign, there were three opportunities for action. At the beginning of the Jianyan era, the Hebei region had not yet rebelled, and the people’s hearts had not yet turned away. Li Gang was at court, and Zong Ze was in the field. At that time, defense could have secured the realm, and offense could have reclaimed lost lands—restoration was within reach. The second opportunity came when the generals achieved victories, the Emperor personally led the armies to the Yangtze, and Zhao Ding and Zhang Jun governed, enacting policies and appointing officials in due order. Thus, key positions were filled with men of the hour, earning the era the name "Little Yuan You." The third came at the end, when the Jin were defeated at Yancheng, Zhuxian, and Shunchang, and south of Yan, their commands held no sway. Wumu sighed, "Since I took up arms, I have never faced such a day." Yue Fei, overjoyed, declared, "We shall march straight to Huanglongfu and drink deeply with all of you!" What a moment of promise! Yet the Emperor’s true desire was not the return of the Two Emperors, fearing it would threaten his position. He thus deferred to the machinations of treacherous ministers.

Thus, before the cunning hare and soaring crow were slain, he had already devised schemes to boil the hounds and store the bows. The great affairs of the realm were lost from that moment. For this reason, I have recorded the deeds of the generals in full above and now offer this comprehensive assessment, that it may serve as a warning for all ages.

Yue Fei was resolute and impassioned, ever fixed on reclaiming the Central Plains and capturing the cunning foe. He lived with great austerity. In his youth, he could drink several *dou* of wine, but the Emperor cautioned him, "When you reach the banks of the Yellow River, then you may drink." From that day, he never touched wine again. His household had no concubines; Wu Zhu, admiring his virtue, adorned his younger sister and offered her to him. Yue Fei refused, saying, "The Emperor lies awake with worry—how can a general indulge in pleasure?" Wu Zhu only revered him more. When the Emperor wished to build him a mansion, he declined, "While the Jin barbarians remain unvanquished, how can I think of a home?"

Someone once asked, "When will the realm know peace?" Yue Fei replied, "When civil officials do not love wealth, and military officers do not fear death, the realm will know peace." If a soldier took so much as a thread or a bundle of straw from the people, he would execute them on the spot. When he lodged among the common folk, though they opened their doors in welcome, none dared let him enter. He was called "the one who would not dismantle a roof to stay warm, nor plunder to stave off hunger." If his soldiers fell ill, he personally prepared their medicine. When his generals were stationed far away, he sent his wife to inquire after their families. For those who died in service, he wept and raised their orphans, sometimes even marrying his own sons to their daughters. Whatever rewards or provisions were bestowed, he distributed equally among his officers and men, keeping nothing for himself.

Skilled in defeating the many with the few, he would summon all his commanders to deliberate before any campaign. Once the strategy was set, they fought—never losing, only winning. So steadfast was his army that the enemy said, "Shaking a mountain is easy; shaking Yue’s army is hard." When Zhang Jun once asked the key to warfare, he replied, "Benevolence, trust, wisdom, courage, and discipline—none can be lacking."

He honored the worthy and treated scholars with courtesy. He read the classics and histories, composed refined poetry, and played *touhu* with the demeanor of a scholar. Whenever he declined honors, he would say, "The soldiers have done the work—what merit is mine?" His loyalty burned fiercely, his principles unyielding, never bending to others. In the end, this brought him ruin. For Yue Fei and Qin Hui could not coexist.

**Record:** In my view, Yue Wu Mu stands peerless. Why? Among the great generals of old—Sun, Wu, Han, Peng, Ying, Wei, Li, Guo—few can be counted. Yet Sun betrayed his friend, Wu killed his wife, Han usurped the throne, Ying abandoned his lord, Wei wallowed in extravagance—none bear scrutiny. In recent times, Zhang Wei Gong suffered defeat at Fuping, Han Jun Wang fled at the Yangtze, Zhang Bo Ying’s heart wavered, Liu Ping Shu’s command was lawless—only Wu Mu remained steadfast.

He honored Zhou Tong as a true friend, refused Wu Zhu’s sister to avoid lust, and tended his mother’s illness with his own hands—filial devotion. The banner inscribed with "Utmost Loyalty" and the tattoo "Serve the Nation" marked his devotion to the throne. His virtues were rooted in nature, and in every matter, he never forgot loyalty and filial piety—true integrity. In command, he mastered all five virtues, fought a hundred battles without defeat, and cherished the people’s strength, never taking so much as a thread. Compared to the ancients, he was the equal of Fang Shu and Ji Fu, yet fate denied him the chance to restore the glory of King Xuan. Heaven did not bless the Song—one cannot merely blame the sovereign and his ministers.

Hu Quan submitted a memorial: "I have examined Wang Lun—a base and deceitful man, a rogue from the marketplace. A shortsighted prime minister sent him as an envoy to the Jin, where he resorted to lies and deception, deluding the imperial ear. Now, without cause, he lures the Jin envoys under the pretext of 'instructing the south'—this is to make us their servants, to reduce us to the likes of Liu Yu. The realm belongs to the ancestors, and the throne Your Majesty occupies is theirs. How can you surrender the ancestors’ realm to the barbarians, their throne to the barbarians? If Your Majesty bows the knee, the spirits of the ancestral temples will be defiled, the people of the Central Plains will don foreign robes, the court’s ministers will become vassals, and the empire’s scholars will tear their caps and destroy their sashes, forced into barbarian dress.

Even if the Jin could be trusted, how will history judge Your Majesty? The Jin are treacherous, and Wang Lun aids their deceit. The imperial coffins cannot return, the Empress Dowager cannot be restored, Emperor Qianshu cannot be rescued, and the Central Plains cannot be reclaimed. Once this knee is bent, it cannot be straightened again—this is cause for bitter tears and endless sighs. Before, when the realm teetered like stacked eggs, Your Majesty refused to bow to the barbarians. Now, with the state’s fortunes slightly improved—victories at Xiangyang, the Huai, and Wo Kou, far surpassing past defeats—why suddenly submit? To humble the Son of Heaven and bow to a barbarian tent? This is why Lu Lian refused to serve Qin—not for empty prestige, but because the fate of the realm could not permit it.

Within the court and without, officials and soldiers, the people with one voice demand Wang Lun’s flesh. I say: if Wang Lun is not executed, the survival of the state is uncertain. Yet Wang Lun is beneath contempt—it is Qin Hui, the trusted minister, who enables him. Your Majesty possesses the virtues of Yao and Shun, yet Qin Hui cannot guide you to the heights of Tang and Yu but instead leads you to the shame of Shi Jing Tang. Sun Jin echoes his words, gaining office as a counselor. When Qin Hui says 'peace is possible,' Sun Jin agrees; when Qin Hui says 'we must bow,' Sun Jin concurs. I say: Qin Hui and Sun Jin should both be executed."

"I, though but a humble member of the privy council, hold these men as mortal enemies with whom I cannot share the sky. My humble wish is to sever the heads of these three, impale them on poles, and display them in the streets. Then, detain the barbarian envoys, reproach them for their insolence, and in due course raise an army to punish their crimes—thus shall the soldiers of our three armies find their qi redoubled without even engaging in battle. Otherwise, I would sooner cast myself into the eastern sea and die than live on in this diminished court, begging for survival.

**Record states:** This memorial is like the biting frost and scorching sun—nothing less than the upright qi of Heaven and Earth. Even a hundred generations hence, should one recite it but once, the awe of Dan’an’s presence would still linger before their eyes. How much more, then, in that moment, when the treacherous ministers and shameless barbarians must have had their qi shaken and their resolve broken! Only then does one realize that the words of a noble man shine as brightly as the sun and moon, endure as long as Heaven and Earth, and their merit is no small contribution. Though the Jin’s million-strong army was repelled, and the Middle Kingdom’s sigh of ‘we still have men’ was deepened, even after a hundred humiliations, that which is greatest and most unyielding, filling the space between Heaven and Earth, cannot be erased. Was this not the greatest triumph of the Southern Court in two hundred years!

In the seventh year of Emperor Lizong’s *Longxing* reign, Liu Hong was recalled to serve as Pacification Commissioner of Jing and Xiang. He declined the appointment and submitted a memorial, saying: 'Jing and Xiang are the limbs; the court is the vital qi of the heart and viscera. When the vital qi is strong, the limbs grow robust. If the court’s governance is sound and its root and foundation flourishing, then the strategic interests of Jing and Xiang may be gradually secured. I beg first to discuss the great strategy of the state, and only then address the substance of its foundation.

What is this great strategy? It is *recovery*—the restoration of lost lands. I say that today we possess its form but not yet its substance. Generally speaking, to have substance without form is to settle on a plan and achieve success before the enemy realizes it; to have form without substance is to invite disaster and summon invaders without the means to resist them. King Zhao of Yan and Zhuge Liang of Han—these were men of substance without form. The barbarians cannot forget us, just as we cannot forget them. For years, there have been no alarms at the frontier, for they too have learned from Wanyan Liang’s reckless incursions and now seek a strategy of absolute security. Yet now, before our troops have even moved, our intentions are already known; before our strength is gathered, our posturing is already visible. This teaches the barbarians to plot deeply against us and prepare rigorously for us. I grieve over this.

What, then, is the substance of self-cultivation? It is to seek worthy men, to relieve the people’s suffering, to employ capable generals, and to nurture the army."

King Xuan of Zhou employed the worthy and entrusted the capable, pitying widows and orphans. The tasks of gathering ferns, commanding chariots, leading assaults, and managing governance—these four alone encompassed all major affairs. The foundation of order and peace does not lie in rewards, punishments, or proclamations, but in the person of the ruler. The goodness or evil of the ruler resides in a single thought; when such thoughts accumulate and settle within the heart, then good becomes clearly visible, and right and wrong stand distinctly before him.

Your Majesty has reigned for nine years now. There are matters once deemed right that are now wrong, and men once deemed worthy who have since declined. I urge you to set aside your own views and adopt the views of the realm as your own, to abandon your own wisdom and embrace the wisdom of the multitude. If you wish to summon true worthies of this age, you must first endure the forthright air of upright ministers. If flatterers and sycophants are not wholly expelled, the straight path cannot be walked, and such men will retreat into the mountains and forests, beyond reach and use.

As for the decline of scholar-officials’ mores, it is especially lamentable. Those who spout grand, empty words, currying favor with the throne, are rewarded with extraordinary favor if great, or at least stolen affection if small. Some even rely on shadowy connections, suppressing dissent, stifling the spirit of loyalty, and blocking all knowledge of harm and benefit—this is not yet the full reality of seeking the worthy.

Today, though there are officials charged with nurturing the people, they cannot fulfill their duties. Driven by fiscal demands and pressed by superiors, they advance through reprimands and punishments, devising clever pretexts for exactions and issuing documents to hound the people. As for the work of laboring to settle the displaced, easing hardship, and pacifying the weary—no such men are to be seen. This is not yet the full reality of relieving the people’s suffering.

As for generals, those who enrich themselves while impoverishing others and fawn on superiors should indeed be expelled. Yet many newly promoted are pampered sons of privilege, untested in battle, and in times of crisis, I fear they will fail to meet the enemy. This is not yet the full reality of employing capable generals.

In ancient times, nurturing soldiers included the joy of pushing carts and drinking coarse wine, the vigor of hurling stones and leaping distances. Thus, they were brave in the public cause, roused at the sound of the enemy, and fought fiercely for their lord. Generals showed kindness like the gift of a coat, compassion like sucking poison from a wound, loving their men as sons and brothers, and wielding them as their own limbs.

Now, it is not so. Soldiers are exploited, overworked, and driven to exhaustion. Thus, when new recruits are sought, none answer the call. Recently, I heard of cavalry being relocated to Jiankang, and along the roads, sorrowful sighs spread in all directions, breeding resentment among the living, grievances among the dead, and sapping the courage of the three armies. This is not yet the full reality of nurturing the army.

With the people impoverished, resources depleted, soldiers resentful, and generals arrogant, bandits and rebels will surely rise within the realm. Yet you would still clash swords in the north at Yiwu—this is what I cannot comprehend.

The record states: I observe that the words of the loyal and solemn are like the counsel of the late Song, reviving the declining winds of mediocre rulers and correcting the long-standing abuses of the Six Tombs—not merely to admonish Xiaozong. In time, if the primal qi is not secured and the four limbs wither, the great mandate will swiftly depart.

As for the precedents of military campaigns, high ministers and chief councilors often exploit them to seize great office and cling to great power. Without ministers of unyielding integrity or scions of divine wisdom, who could refuse seven summonses and decline seven times? Thus, I record this to fulfill the meaning of overturning the incense burner and the resolve to punish the rebels. Beyond this, all is but a day of endless sighs. Alas!

In his youth, Wen Tianxiang saw the portraits of the local worthies enshrined in the school temple—Ouyang Xiu, Yang Bangyou, and Hu Quan—all men of unwavering loyalty and integrity. He admired them deeply and declared, "To die without being honored with offerings of grain and meat is no true man." At twenty, he passed the imperial examinations. During the policy debate, Emperor Lizong had reigned for many years, and governance had gradually stagnated. Wen responded with the principle of "emulating Heaven’s ceaselessness," his words numbering over ten thousand, composed in a single flourish. The emperor selected him as first place. The examiner, Wang Yinglin, memorialized: "His ancient righteousness is like a mirror of antiquity; his loyal heart is as unyielding as iron and stone. Your servant dares to congratulate Your Majesty on finding such a man."

In the ninth year of Xianchun, Wen was appointed as the judicial commissioner of Hunan. There, he met the former chief councilor Jiang Wanli, who had long marveled at Wen’s resolve and character. When they spoke of state affairs, Jiang sighed mournfully: "I am old. The burden of the world’s course now rests with you." At the beginning of Deyou, an edict was issued calling the realm to arms in defense of the emperor. Wen Tianxiang, clutching the decree, wept bitterly. He dispatched Chen Jizhou to rally the valiant men of the prefecture and unite the tribal leaders of the mountain streams, amassing a force of ten thousand. His friends sought to dissuade him. Wen replied: "I know this well. Yet the state has nurtured its people for over two hundred years. Now, on the day of crisis, when troops are summoned from across the land, not a single man or horse has entered the passes. This is my deepest sorrow. Thus, though I know my strength is insufficient, I offer myself as a hound or a sacrificial beast, hoping that loyal ministers and righteous scholars throughout the realm may rise upon hearing of it. If righteousness prevails, if plans are laid and men gathered, and if success is thus achieved, then the altars of the state may yet be preserved." The Prince of Yi summoned him to Fuzhou with the title of *Guangwen Dian Xueshi*, appointing him as Right Chancellor. When the Prince of Wei succeeded to the throne, Wen was further honored as *Shaobao* and enfeoffed as the Duke of Xinguo.

After the fall of Yashan, Wen was taken to the capital. At the time, Emperor Shizu sought talented men, and the southern official Wang Jixi declared that no southerner surpassed Wen Tianxiang. The emperor dispatched Wang to convey his decree. Wen replied: "With the state’s demise, my duty is to die." When summoned and questioned, "What is your wish?" he answered: "I, Tianxiang, received the Song’s favor as its chancellor. How could I serve two dynasties? I only wish for death." At his execution, he faced it with composure, saying, "My task is complete." His wife, née Ouyang, gathered his remains and clothing. In his belt, she found a eulogy that read:

*Confucius spoke of achieving ren;*
*Mencius spoke of attaining yi.*
*Only when yi is fully realized*
*does ren reach its perfection.*
*What is the purpose of reading the books of sages and worthies?*
*From this moment onward,*
*may I at last be without shame.*

*The History of the Song* concludes with this judgment: Among the loyal and righteous ministers of the fallen Song, after Wen Tianxiang, there were Hunan Pacification Commissioner Li Fei, Chizhou Circuit Judge Zhao Angfa, Yangzhou Commander Jiang Cai, Zhenzhou Prefect Miao Zaicheng, Changzhou Commander Wang Anjie, Hubei Judicial Commissioner Zhang Qiyan, Anji Prefect Zhao Liangchun, Wuwei Prefect Zhao Huai, Huaidong Commander Li Tingzhi, Prefect Zhao Mengliang, Changzhou Prefect Yao Gao, Inspector Zhao Yugao, Xinghua Prefect Chen Zan, Circuit Judge Zhang Yuezhong, Chaozhou Prefect Ma Fa, Jiangdong Commander Xie Fangde, Xinzhou Prefect Tang Zhen, along with Zhang Shijie, Lu Xiufu, and Chen Wenlong—all were the most eminent. Many others besides these also stood firm.

The record states: Yu Zhang once said, "The hearts of the Zhou [Dynasty] and Confucius enable people to understand the Dao." If scholars truly grasp the Dao, then the hearts of the Zhou and Confucius will be profoundly realized within them.

The talents of the Three Dynasties possessed the hearts of the Zhou and Confucius, thus regarding life and death, departure and loyalty as naturally as the shifting of cold and heat, day and night—so that loyalty and righteousness were easily practiced. By the Han and Tang, the study of classics and the veneration of ancient prose had supplanted the hearts of the Zhou and Confucius. Thus, the *Xiaojing* and self-defense were championed by Chao Cuo and Dong Zhongshu, while the ancient prose movement was initiated by Han Yu and Liu Zongyuan. As a result, those who understood the Dao became few, and life and death, departure and loyalty weighed upon them like nine tripods of a thousand jun—so that loyalty and righteousness were difficult to practice.

Now, observing the Song: Wang Anshi further corrupted the Six Classics, and the Way of integrity and shame perished. Thus, when the Northern Song fell, few held fast to their principles. Yet the teachings of Zhou Dunyi, Cheng Yi, Zhang Zai, and Zhu Xi illuminated the Dao, clarifying the principles of learning. When the Southern Song was destroyed, many died for righteousness—a clear and manifest effect.

Therefore, my unwavering resolve and tireless effort are not truly a love of debate, but a necessity. Let the reader consider this carefully.

Zhang Shijie began as a low-ranking officer and, through accumulated merit, rose to become Commander of the Huangzhou and Wuding Armies. At a time of great peril, when summons to defend the throne went unanswered, Shijie alone led his troops to the capital’s defense. All marveled at his resolve. From Defender of Hezhou, he was promoted in mere months to Grand Master for Palace Counsel, assuming command of the imperial armies. As the enemy forces closed in on Lin’an, Shijie urged the relocation of the three palaces to the sea and proposed joining forces with Wen Tianxiang for a final stand. Yet Chen Yizhong, then dispatching envoys to sue for peace, refused his plan.

After the Song surrendered, Shijie, filled with grief and indignation, led his troops from Lin’an to Dinghai. The Yuan envoy, Commander Bian Biao, attempted to persuade him to yield. Shijie severed Biao’s tongue and stoned him to death, swearing to die rather than surrender. He then followed the two princes to Fuzhou. When Emperor Duanzong ascended, Shijie was appointed Vice Director of the Bureau of Military Affairs. Upon Emperor Hua’s enthronement, he was further honored as Junior Preceptor and enfeoffed as Duke of Yue. Deeming Chaozhou unsuitable, he relocated to Yashan in Xinhui.

When Zhang Hongfan attacked Yashan, some advised Shijie: "The Yuan forces have blockaded the harbor with their fleet, leaving us no room to advance or retreat. Why not seize the harbor first? If we prevail, it will be the nation’s fortune; if not, we may still flee westward." Shijie, fearing disunity and certain dissolution if they moved, replied: "For years we have wandered the seas—when will it end? Now we must decide victory or defeat here." He then burned the temporary court and market, lashing together over a thousand large ships to form a floating fortress, resolved to fight to the death.

Hongfan captured Shijie’s nephew Han and sent him as an envoy, offering rank three times to induce surrender. Shijie recounted the deeds of ancient loyal ministers, declaring: "I know surrender would bring wealth and honor, but I will die for my lord—this I will not change." Soon after, a violent typhoon arose, and the sailors sought to turn toward shore. Shijie said: "It is useless."

Bring me a stick of incense.

Looking up to heaven, he cried aloud: "I have done all I could for the House of Zhao. One lord perished, and another was enthroned. Now we perish again—if any survive, perhaps they may yet repel the enemy and restore a Zhao prince to preserve the ancestral sacrifices. But if this is so, is it truly Heaven’s will? If Heaven no longer wishes the Zhao lineage to endure, then let this great wind capsize my ship." The ship capsized, and he drowned.

Lu Xiufu, from the age of three, studied under Master Meng of his village, who alone pointed to him as no ordinary child. In adulthood, he passed the imperial examinations. When Li Tingzhi governed Huainan, he summoned Xiufu to his staff and promoted him to the rank of policy advisor. At the time, border affairs grew dire, and many fled, but Xiufu alone remained. Tingzhi recommended him to the court, and he was appointed Vice Minister of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices, later rising to Vice Minister of the Court of the Imperial Clan.

When the Yuan invaded and the two Song princes fled to Wenzhou, Xiufu pursued and joined them. He sent messengers to summon Chen Yizhong, Zhang Shijie, and others, and together they enthroned Emperor Duzong’s son, the Prince of Yi. Yizhong, recognizing Xiufu’s long experience in military affairs, consulted him on every matter before acting. Xiufu devoted himself wholeheartedly to assisting, leaving no detail unaddressed.

As the court wandered in exile, affairs were hastily managed, yet whenever they held court, Xiufu maintained solemn dignity, as if conducting state rituals in a proper hall. Sometimes, while traveling, he would weep uncontrollably, wiping his tears with his court robes until they were soaked, moving all around him to sorrow.

When Emperor Duanzong died, the ministers all wished to scatter. Xiufu said: "The late Emperor’s sole surviving son remains—where shall we abandon him? The ancients revived a dynasty with but a single regiment or a lone fortress. Now we have all the officials and tens of thousands of soldiers. If Heaven has not yet decreed the end of Song, how can we not strive to restore the state?" With the others, he enthroned Emperor Duzong’s younger brother, the Prince of Wei, appointing Xiufu as Left Chancellor to wield authority.

At the time, Shijie stationed his troops at Yashan. Xiufu oversaw military affairs abroad and managed labor and construction at home, with every initiative originating from him. Though buffeted by flight and displacement, he still recited the *Great Learning* daily, never ceasing his exhortations.

When Yashan fell, Xiufu fled to the Prince of Wei’s ship. The royal vessel was large, surrounded by a ring of ships, making escape impossible. Drawing his sword, he drove his wife and children into the sea, then carried the young emperor on his back and leapt into the waves to drown.

**Record:** Observing Shijie’s drowning and Xiufu’s bearing the emperor into the sea, I cannot but sigh in profound sorrow. Alas! The lament of the broken chariot pole—grief for the times—have we truly witnessed such men in our age? At that time, all Shu was lost, Jingxiang had fallen, and the realm offered no refuge. Yet these few steadfast gentlemen, clinging to loyalty and righteousness, persevered to the very end. They met their deaths with uprightness—were they not akin to Qu Yuan and Jia Yi of old?

Chen Wenlong was a descendant of Junqing. Gifted in literature and resolute in integrity, he ranked first in the imperial examinations of Xianchun 5. From Military Commissioner of Zhenjiang, he was appointed Supervising Censor. When Xiangyang was besieged, Jia Sidao feigned a request to lead the army while secretly ensuring his own retention, ultimately losing Xiangyang. Wenlong submitted a memorial in vehement remonstrance.

At the time, Wang Huan and Chen Yizhong could devise no unified strategy, instead squabbling in court over private interests. Wenlong again memorialized: "When the Three Sovereigns harmonized their hearts to align with the Dao, the northern troops seized cities and built forts, while we engaged in empty courtesy and mutual suspicion—like one who, rescuing the drowning and extinguishing fires, observes the decorum of a leisurely stroll. I urge the summoning of the great ministers to unite in governance and cease futile debate." Yet the two remained irreconcilable and departed. By the time they returned in the tenth month, all was already lost.

That winter, he was repeatedly promoted to the position of Participant in Determining Government Affairs. When Prince Yi was established as the Pacification Commissioner of Min and Guang, the surrendered general Wang Shijiang once again led a great army into Guang. Jianning, Quanzhou, and Fuzhou all surrendered. Wang Gangzhong, the prefect of Fuzhou, dispatched an envoy to Gou Xinghua. Wenlong beheaded the envoy and sent a letter of censure to Shijiang and Gangzhong for betraying the state. He then mobilized the local militia to defend themselves, though the city’s troops numbered fewer than a thousand. When the great army came to attack, they sent Wenlong’s in-law to deliver a letter urging surrender. Wenlong burned the letter and executed the messenger, declaring: "You gentlemen merely fear death, yet do you know that even this life cannot escape death?" He then sent his general Lin Hua to scout the borders. Hua immediately defected, guiding the enemy to the city walls. Cao Chengsun, the Vice Prefect, opened the gates to surrender. Wenlong was seized and brought to the enemy camp, where they sought to force his submission. Unyielding, he pointed to his abdomen and said: "All within here is loyalty, righteousness, and learning. How can you compel me?" He was then shackled and sent to Hangzhou. From the moment he left Xinghua, Wenlong refused all food and starved to death upon reaching Hangzhou.

The record states: Both Tianxiang and Wenlong ranked first in the court examinations—could their loyalty and righteousness alone have made them renowned? At that time, those in power cherished the joy of life but lacked the resolve to die. Fortunately, one or two gentlemen devoted their hearts to the state, their literary grace and moral integrity setting an example for the age. In such times, within they harbored the resolve to die, while without, they found no joy in life. This is why they sacrificed themselves to fulfill their humanity without regret.

For some, integrity is innate from youth, while for others, learning matures naturally in adulthood. Thus, one set his heart on ritual and virtue from childhood, and those who failed to do so were no true men. The other scorned those who feared death and clung to life, unaware that life itself cannot escape death. Though their paths were the same, their fates were one.

*Hongdao Lu*, Volume Sixteen—concluded
*Hongdao Lu*, Volume Seventeen

**On the Righteousness of Ruler and Minister**

From *The Imperial Literary Collection*: The Great Ming’s Proclamation to the Central Plains states: Since ancient times, emperors and kings have ruled all under heaven, with the Central Kingdom governing the inner lands to command the barbarians, and the barbarians dwelling beyond to serve the Central Kingdom. Never has it been heard that barbarians should rule all under heaven. When the Song dynasty’s mandate declined, the Yuan, a northern tribe, usurped the Central Kingdom, causing men of insight and integrity to lament the inversion of cap and shoe. Later, their heirs grew indolent, forsaking the Way of ruler and minister, compounded by the usurpation of power by chief ministers, the vengeance of the Censorate, and the cruelty of local officials. Thus, the people’s hearts turned away, the realm rose in rebellion, and the people of our Central Kingdom perished in such numbers that their brains and entrails covered the earth, while survivors could not protect their own flesh and blood. Though this arose from human affairs, it was truly a time when Heaven loathed their virtue and cast them aside.

I, originally a commoner, was thrust into chaos by the world’s turmoil and raised by the people’s will. Leading my forces across the Yangtze, I established myself in the strategic land of Jianye. Soon, the entire south came under my sway, and the people lived in peace with ample food. Yet, seeing the people of the Central Plains long without a true lord, my heart ached with sorrow. Reverently accepting Heaven’s mandate, I dared not rest at ease. I resolved to dispatch troops northward to expel the barbarian usurpers, rescue the people from suffering, and restore the dignity of Han governance. Fearing the people might not understand and flee in alarm, taking their families northward only to sink deeper into misery, I first issued this proclamation: when my armies arrive, let the people not flee. My commands are strict and inviolable, not a single hair’s harm shall befall them. Those who submit shall dwell forever in peace within the Central Kingdom; those who resist shall be driven beyond the frontier. For the people of our Central Kingdom, Heaven must surely appoint a son of the Central Kingdom to bring them peace—how could barbarians be fit to rule them?

It is recorded: This was how our August Ancestor succeeded Heaven and established the supreme principle—what he embodied in himself, he verified among the people; he examined it against the Three Kings and found no error; he established it upon heaven and earth and found no contradiction; he tested it before ghosts and spirits and found no doubt; and a hundred generations hence, even sages shall not question it. Some may compare this to the Han founder’s rise. The Qin was indeed tyrannical, yet its system of enfeoffment endured for over a thousand years after the Three Dynasties—still part of our Central Kingdom. The lands of Qi and Feng, where King Wen used them to spread the transforming influence of the *Er Nan*, were still our people. How could they be likened to the Yuan, with their foul stench, filth, and alien customs of left-buttoned robes? Even if one speaks of the Qin’s might in destroying the Six States and its legal system, or the common people’s perspective, or its corruption of ritual and propriety and disruption of human relations, there is still no comparison. Since our Master Confucius distinguished the civilized within from the barbarian without and restored order after chaos, over two thousand years have passed before this great righteousness was once more upheld. Rare indeed is the reader of these words who does not bow in reverence and sigh in awe.

From *Records of Illustrious Ministers*: When the Ming Ancestor first rose in Huaiyou, he invoked the punitive expeditions of Tang and Wu, and men of discernment flocked to his banner. At that time, his ministers—pillars and vital limbs of the state—were all heroes of surpassing talent and virtue, such as those of single-minded sincerity and deep virtue, whose hearts were set on honoring their lord and sheltering the people. Foremost among them was Xu Da, the Prince of Zhongshan and Martial Pacifier; next, Chang Yuchun, the Prince of Kaiping and Loyal and Martial; then Li Wen Zhong, the Prince of Qiyang and Martial and Tranquil; followed by Deng Yu, the Prince of Ninghe and Martial and Compliant; then Tang He, the Prince of Shou’ou and Magnanimous and Martial; and Mu Ying, the Prince of Qianning and Illustrious and Tranquil. Minister Peng Shao eulogized: "Heaven favored the sagely and enlightened, bestowing worthy aides. They swept away the rebellious lords and upheld our Hongwu Emperor."

Against the northern tribes at Yin Mountain, avenging a thousand years of shame. Storming cities yet sparing their people, his hands preserved the treasuries intact. Enfeoffed with titles and lands, he held sway over the Wei territories. He stabilized the northern wilds—none dared insult him. His qi shaped mountains and rivers, leaving no thing to rot.

Chang Yuchun’s eulogy:
A man of towering stature and mighty bearing, fierce as a tiger or leopard. Wielding hammer and spade, he early pledged to the true lord. The false Han and pretender Wu were swept away in a single stroke. He charged into Yan, restoring the Central Plains. Granted lands and titles, he opened the lands of Ezhu. Truly a marshal of renown, his might resplendent. Enshrined in the ancestral temple at Tong, his sacrifices endure for a thousand ages.

Li Wen Zhong’s eulogy:
Among the meritorious and imperial kin, a hero of his generation. Well-versed in military classics, master of the Six Strategies. Crimson his armor, crimson his robes—his household held only battle garb. The former capitals of Song and Yuan were both seized and encompassed. His might proclaimed across ten thousand li, his toil undeniable. Rewarded with the highest rank, his state established in Cao. Posthumously enfeoffed as a prince, his temple offerings honored with imperial favor.

Deng Yu’s eulogy:
Our Compliant King, a stalwart and imposing man. His merit matched the founding ministers, from the first raising of the righteous banner. His qi towered over the six armies, regarding foes as nothing. What fortress did he not breach? What strength did he not uproot? He comforted the people and honored the learned, bringing relief to those revived. Governing eight provinces as military commissioner, he spread benevolence and trust. Following ancient rites, he was ennobled at Ezhu.

Tang He’s eulogy:
Magnanimous and Martial, a man of Feng and Pei, a pillar and vital limb. Aiding the throne as heart and backbone, he followed the campaign from the lower Yangtze, swiftly conquering Ou and Min. Crushing the stubborn and soothing the compliant, he executed punitive expeditions with justice. The Six Directions unified, his merit foundational. Laying down his arms to retire, his bond with the throne grew ever closer. His achievement ranked with Wu and Deng, his peers.

Mu Ying’s eulogy:
Ah, Illustrious and Tranquil! Early nurtured in the palace’s inner chambers. Wisdom and courage flourished in him, and he emulated the martial feats of the ancients. Entrusted with defense and governance of the frontiers, his charge was weighty. The southwest was pacified. The remnant clans of the Yuan, entrenched for years, defied orders and refused communication. With a single strike he subdued them—none failed to submit. There he established his headquarters, enfeoffed with hereditary titles.

The Record states:

The first to issue proclamations throughout the Central Plains marked the great divide between Hua and Yi, the natural order of Heaven and humanity—what is called "a majestic battle array, a righteous banner." The subsequent praises of the Six Kings were like the roar of a tiger stirring the wind, the rise of a dragon summoning clouds—what is meant by "like sounds resonating, like qi seeking its kind."

Mencius said: "Every five hundred years, a true king must arise." Within this span, there must also be those of illustrious renown. This is when Heaven and Earth close and reopen, the sun and moon darken and brighten again, the Central Realm endures hardship and returns to peace, and humankind, once intermixed, is once more distinguished.

Since the eras of Tang, Yu, and the Three Dynasties, there has never been such great chaos, nor such great order. Thus, the bond between ruler and minister is brought to its conclusion. As for those whose fine words and virtuous deeds may serve as models for the age, they are listed beside them.

Minister Wang Wendu was stern and solemn by nature, sparing of speech and laughter. At home, he carried himself with gravity; yet when receiving others, his amiability was palpable. Learned and quick-witted, he repeatedly oversaw the spring examinations and the palace tests, selecting talent most abundantly. He served in the Hanlin Academy for thirty years, diligent and untiring. When he later assumed the post of Minister of Personnel, he grew even more modest and cautious. At the time, the dismissal of court officials and the recommendation of worthy candidates were entrusted solely to the Ministry of Personnel. Minister Wang took care to promote and delegate authority to his subordinates. When censors were dispatched on inspection tours, he ensured their careful selection. From then on, discipline was rigorously upheld, and the scramble for favor abruptly ceased.

Minister Liu Wen’an once remarked: "Minister Wang first held positions in literary office, rising to Academician; then bore the responsibility of governance, ascending to Minister of Personnel; and finally, walked the path of moral cultivation, attaining the rank of Grand Preceptor. In these three stations, public opinion unanimously affirmed his fitness without dissent."

Moreover, in his time, grand proclamations and great manifestos stirred the ears of the realm; the discernment of worthies and the elevation of the exceptional each bore their fruits. With dignified bearing and courtly demeanor, his conduct set a standard that evoked the ancients. Even today, one may still look back with admiration and longing—such a legacy cannot be erased.

Minister Wang Zhongsou Ao was upright, resolute, and steadfast—pure, frugal, and disciplined. He adhered to principle and upheld the law, not yielding even a hair’s breadth. No matter how great or small the affair, once he had experienced it, he never forgot. When a matter required action, he was restless in sleep and food, sitting up to await dawn. His residence remained unchanged from its original state. After court duties, he retired to the chamber for officials, returning home only on the first and fifteenth days of the month to pay respects at his ancestral shrine. No private petitions crossed his threshold; bribes dared not approach. When powerful figures sought favors, he gently but firmly refused. Thus, people feared him yet bore no grudge. Though he endured many upheavals, he remained untroubled, harboring no resentment or partiality toward friend or foe. He once declared: "Is the Ministry of Personnel a place for settling scores?"

Minister Li Wenda said: "Gaoyao spoke of the Nine Virtues—Minister Wang embodied five: in chaos, he was reverent; in turmoil, resolute; in simplicity, incorruptible; in strength, steadfast; and in vigor, righteous."

Minister Liu Wen’an further remarked: "When Minister Wang was dispatched to govern renowned provinces and distant frontiers—whether in the south along the Jiang and Guang, where he subdued powerful outlaws and pacified the Man and Liao tribes; in the west across Guan and Shaan, where the Qiang and Rong peoples obeyed his commands; or in the east near Liao and Jie, where barbarian chieftains were awed by his integrity—wherever treacherous rebels rose like floodwaters, his presence stood firm as a great bulwark. In overseeing the selection of officials, through the reigns of Jingtai, Tianshun, and Chenghua, though the years changed, his appointment and favor remained unwavering. This was not only due to the grandeur of his strategies but also because his handling of affairs was without flaw."

Minister Wang Duanyi Ru served five reigns with unyielding integrity and forthright speech, discerning right from wrong. Once, as magistrate of Yangzhou, the people erected a stele to praise his virtue. When he governed Dengyang, bandits arose in Xiangyang, and the court summoned him to suppress them.

The Grand Masters Liu Qianjin and others wished to unleash troops to scour the mountains, but Minister Wang refused. Instead, he posted proclamations urging displaced people to return to their livelihoods, and for this, they built him a shrine and painted his portrait in reverence. When he served as provincial inspector of Yunnan, the eunuch overseer secretly traded with foreign tribes, extorting without end, and none dared to intervene. Minister Wang declared: "In the past, the eunuch overseer of Jiaozhi was unfit for his post, leading to the loss of an entire region and the rebellion of Tengchong and Luchuan. What is happening now is even more dire." Over nine months, he submitted twenty memorials, his forthright voice resounding throughout the realm.

Later, as inspector of the Southern Metropolitan Region, the eunuch Wang Jing traveled through the southeast by imperial post, seizing rare treasures, causing terror wherever he went. Minister Wang submitted a memorial detailing how such actions lost the people’s hearts, damaged the dignity of the state, harmed harmonious qi, and invited disaster. The emperor ordered his arrest and imprisonment, but both court and commoners rejoiced, declaring that he possessed the power to turn the tide of heaven. He was then transferred to the Ministry of War in Nanjing as minister. When the vice director Lin Jun was imprisoned for remonstrating against the construction of Yongchang Temple, Minister Wang spoke in his defense, and the emperor ordered him to retire.

When Emperor Xiaozong ascended the throne, he recalled Minister Wang as minister of the Ministry of Personnel. He curbed the influence of opportunists, commended those of noble character, and promoted long-neglected talents, allowing no favoritism. Men such as Geng of Julu, Zhang of Huating, Li of Xiangcheng, Peng of Putian, He of Xujiang, Zhou of Taiyuan, and Ni of Qiantang—all paragons of the realm—were elevated to key positions to assist in realizing the transformative governance of the Hongzhi era. To this day, the people of the realm still praise the name of San Yuan without cease.

Minister Ma Duansu Wensheng stood in court for over fifty years, dedicating himself to the state without shirking hardship or peril. His nature was upright and unyielding, sparing in speech and laughter, and he disdained extravagance. Initially, as an inspector in Shanxi and Huguang, he earned a reputation wherever he went. Promoted to surveillance commissioner of Fujian, he meted out the law to eunuch overseers who oppressed the people, and the people revered his virtue, singing his praises along the roads. When the native chieftain Man Si of Guyuan incited rebellion, Minister Ma, then serving as chief censor, captured him alive.

At the time, bandit uprisings surged like swarms of bees: Li Huzi in Hanzhong, Huojier in Tong Pass, and Wang Biao of Mancheng each amassed followers to plunder and kill, their forces sharp and fierce. Minister Ma eliminated them all through strategy. Later, as commander of the Three Frontiers, he lured the northern barbarians deep into the mountains, where he had troops lie in ambush at Tangyang Ridge. When the barbarians arrived, they were ambushed and suffered heavy casualties, prompting the renaming of the ridge to Deshengpo ("Victory Slope").

Promoted to vice minister of war, he was dispatched to the northeastern frontier when an alert was raised. Drawing on his expertise in military affairs, he organized the Five-Flower Camp and the Eight-Formation Diagram to train the troops. He also submitted fifteen memorials on border defense, all timely and practical, and the barbarian threat subsided. When the Jianzhou Jurchens rebelled, he was sent again. The chief censor Chen Tie sought to lure and kill tribute-bearing foreigners to cover his own mistakes, while the eunuch Wang Zhi, relying on imperial favor and past achievements, covertly supported Chen’s scheme. Because Minister Ma treated Wang with defiance and disdained his attendants, Chen bribed others to slander him. Wang Zhi returned to the capital and falsely accused Minister Ma of recklessly provoking border conflicts, leading to his demotion and exile. After Wang Zhi’s downfall, the emperor recalled Minister Ma to pacify the northeast. By this time, he had been sent there three times, each time achieving extraordinary feats, and the people of the northeast still remember him fondly.

Promoted to minister of war, he addressed the repeated rebellions of Hami, stating: "If we show only kindness without demonstrating might, they will never learn to fear." He urged Peng Qing, the vice commander of Suzhou, to lead a mixed force of Han and tribal soldiers in a surprise attack, greatly enhancing his prestige. Aheima, cowed by this display of power, repented and sent envoys to offer tribute, returning the golden seal of Shanba. Thus, the Western Regions were pacified.

When the barbarian chieftain Huosai led his forces to raid Datong in a fierce onslaught, the capital was placed on high alert. The emperor summoned Minister Ma to the inner palace to consult on strategies for defense and warfare. He recommended the Duke of Baoguo, Zhu Hui, and others to reinforce the defenses and ordered all border regions to strengthen their watchtowers and prepare their weapons. With officials dismissed and defenses in place, the enemy soon fled far away. He was later transferred to minister of personnel.

During the Hongzhi era, the Filial Emperor summoned him to the Warm Pavilion for a private audience, entrusting him with the scrutiny of all state affairs, and even commanded eunuch attendants to support him as he descended the steps.

That year, in the grand evaluation of officials, over a thousand incompetent or negligent officers from various provinces were dismissed without dispute.

At the dawn of the Zhengde era, he earnestly petitioned to retire from office. Yet from the moment he departed, the conduct of governance underwent a marked shift—the very mechanism of promotion and demotion had lost its guiding principle.

Minister Han, posthumously honored as Loyal and Steadfast, possessed a bearing as towering and unyielding as a mountain, his demeanor grave and composed, his refinement as if naturally endowed. Through diligent self-cultivation and frugal living, he served in the provincial and central administrations for over forty years, faithfully attending to three successive reigns. Favored by the sagely emperors, he toiled day and night in repayment of their trust, ever striving to deepen his loyalty and enhance his service.

As Minister of Revenue, he memorialized seven abuses requiring reform: first, the corruption in the *kaizhong* salt permit system; second, the illicit trafficking of private salt; third, the undervaluing of official salt sales; fourth, the fraudulent compensation for salt deficits; fifth, the smuggling of inferior salt in official shipments; sixth, the cross-border sale of salt; and seventh, the neglect and laxity of the salt transport authorities. His indictments were incisive and precise, exposing decades of accumulated malpractice without omission, thereby bringing relief to both the public and private sectors.

At the time, the situation in Xuanfu and Datong grew dire, with incessant demands for supplies. This coincided with successive imperial funerals and weddings, along with unceasing expenditures for the court, the imperial family, the various princely households, and the border defenses. He managed these affairs with meticulous care, ensuring that urgent needs were met as they arose.

Later, the treacherous eunuchs Liu Jin and his ilk, relying on imperial favor and long-standing influence, obscured the sovereign’s judgment with their bewitching schemes. They turned night into day, indulging in dissipation without restraint, and in their wake, usurped power to wield tyranny, their malevolence casting a shadow over the realm. The scholar-officials trembled in fear, each seeking only to protect themselves and avoid calamity.

Yet he, grieving for the late Filial Emperor and deeply concerned for the fate of the imperial house, took the lead among the officials of the ministries, the Censorate, and the Six Offices of Scrutiny. They prostrated themselves before the palace gates, submitting memorials to expose the villains’ crimes, their pleas accompanied by tears, beseeching that the law be upheld and righteousness preserved. Though he suffered persecution for his stance, his unwavering integrity and resolute virtue inspired awe throughout the court and the realm.

Grand Secretary Liu Jian once remarked: “The state has nurtured its scholars for a hundred and fifty years, yet in this generation, it has produced only one Han Guandao.”

Minister Liu, posthumously honored as Loyal and Illustrious, enjoyed even greater imperial favor. During the Hongzhi era, when he served as Minister of War and Dai Shan as Left Censor-in-Chief, the Filial Emperor, whenever faced with major state affairs, would summon the two for private counsel, saying: “If there is any matter of concern, I wish to consult with you both.” Yet if the matter did not pertain to their respective offices, he would refrain from troubling them further.

Hereafter, when there are matters that ought to be enacted or abolished, you may write a sealed memorial and submit it privately." The minister replied, "I dare not." The emperor asked, "Why not?" Grand Secretary Dai Shan answered, "The precedent of Li Zixing from the previous reign serves as a warning." The emperor said, "I discuss state affairs with you—how could this be compared to Zixing, who schemed for private gain and harmed the common good?" Dai Shan replied, "If ministers submit sealed memorials and the court acts upon them, it differs little from the underhanded decrees of former dynasties. Today, we should model ourselves on the distant examples of ancient sage-kings and the recent precedents of our imperial ancestors: major matters should be entrusted externally to the Six Ministries and internally consulted with the Grand Secretariat. If sealed memorials become the norm, over time both ruler and ministers will fall into corruption, and it will set no proper example for later generations. I dare not comply." The emperor praised his response.

On another occasion, he wrote to Wu Tingju, saying: "The Way of holding office begins with rectifying oneself. By 'rectifying oneself,' I mean not only guarding against profit but also distancing oneself from fame. If one harbors even the slightest intent to seek renown, then every action becomes self-serving—what Master Cheng called 'today’s officials serving themselves.' Proceeding thus, how can one hope for good governance, a contented populace, and the achievement of meritorious service? Reflect deeply and examine yourself. In serving superiors and governing subordinates, one must act with sincerity and forbearance. Sincerity naturally moves others, while forbearance allows one to empathize with the feelings of all. By empathizing and moving them, there is no person one cannot guide and no matter one cannot resolve."

Minister Dai Shan, posthumously honored as Respectful and Upright, was mild in temperament yet inwardly steadfast, never compromising his principles. Transparent and without guile, he served as Left Censor-in-Chief, where he redoubled his self-discipline, rigorously upholding the moral standards of the court. Even in minor administrative details, he pursued precision. He participated once in the evaluation of metropolitan officials and twice in the assessment of provincial officials.

In the year *yichou* of the Hongzhi era, after discussing state affairs with Grand Secretary Liu Daxia, the emperor ordered an eunuch to present them each with two ingots of silver, saying: "I have heard that during the court assemblies, some civil officials avoid suspicion by shutting their doors and refusing visitors. But even if you, like others, keep your doors open to guests, who would dare approach you with bribes? I know your integrity personally, hence this reward." He further instructed them not to attend court to express gratitude, fearing that other ministers might feel ashamed or apprehensive upon learning of it.

When the emperor personally presided over a major judicial inquiry, all officials trembled in awe, yet Minister Dai remained composed in his responses. At times, his reasoned arguments would dispel the emperor’s anger, and imperial wrath would suddenly clear. The emperor, recognizing his integrity and prudence, would often summon him for private audiences, engaging in discussions that lasted for hours. Such was the esteem in which he was held.

Minister Zhang Fuhua, posthumously honored as Solemn and Resolute, carried himself with dignified composure, never speaking or laughing frivolously. Upholding the law with unwavering dedication, he commanded great respect in his time. He distinguished right from wrong as clearly as black from white, and though he might occasionally yield on minor matters, his resolve in matters of principle never wavered. Early in his career as a Hanlin bachelor, when Li Wenda and Peng Wenxian sought to retain him in the Hanlin Academy, he and Liu Shushan firmly declined, later earning renown as statesmen for their governance. Thus, those of pure reputation often disdained financial administration. Yet when Minister Zhang oversaw fiscal affairs in two provinces, he managed them with such competence that resources were abundant, while his integrity was so unassailable that it seemed divinely attested. Gentle yet unyielding, principled yet not harsh, he remained unmoved by personal likes or dislikes. His thoughts were upright, his considerations meticulous, and his demeanor serene and composed—so much so that the corrupt and deceitful reformed of their own accord. His incorruptibility, impartiality, and sound judgment were rooted in his nature and sprang from his heart, further refined by his literary and scholarly pursuits. Thus, his aspirations and policies were flawless, boundless in their purity, enduring and unchanging. Truly, he was a vessel of great capacity.

As Left Censor-in-Chief, he petitioned for stricter prohibitions against the greed, cruelty, and unscrupulous ambition of local officials. When reviewing a complex case involving a favored courtier convicted of a crime, some doubted whether the punishment was excessive. Minister Zhang remained steadfast in his judgment, and even when the emperor reconsidered and issued a revised decree, he insisted that the man’s descendants should not be burdened by his ill-gotten gains—remaining uncompromising until his death.

In summation: Observing the conduct of Minister Wen Duan and those who followed, their moral examples and demeanor were often alike, as were their ranks, reputations, and longevity. Yet upon closer examination, distinctions emerge. Li Xiangi once remarked: "The institutional apex of civil governance lies in the Six Ministries, where the ministers are as revered as the Northern Dipper. Whether in the height of summer or the depths of winter, their governance spans the realm. When the Taizong Emperor campaigned in the north, the entire nation was entrusted to them. The Three Yangs—bright, harmonious, and diligent—presided over the court, ushering in an era of peace. The ruler enjoyed ease while his ministers labored—such were the ministers who served as heaven’s stewards."

The Yingzong Emperor’s treatment of Minister Wen Da was comparable to Taizong’s regard for Ma Zhou, where a single virtuous official received profound trust. Through discreet planning and decisive action, the myriad affairs of state were managed with precision, marking a transformation in governance.
