During the Chenghua era, Ministers Wang Shu of Sanyuan, Wang Tai of Hezhou, Qin Xian of Shan County, Huang Fu of Fengqiu, and others stood forth like towering peaks—still as mountains when at rest, striking like thunder when in motion. In major matters, they wielded authority like an axe; in minor details, they were as meticulous as the tides. They guarded against flatterers and favored officials, wielding the sword of justice to rescue the realm. Their presence inspired awe, and those who crossed them trembled. Could such men be swayed by considerations of life or death, wealth or honor? Yet compared to the era before the Great Pacification, they were markedly different. Was this due to the times, the differences in rank, or the extent of their entrusted authority?

During the Hongzhi era, ministers such as Liu Daxia of Huating, Han Wen of Hongdong, Ma Wenzhou of Junyang, Xu Jin of Lingbao, Zhou Jing of Yangqu, Geng Yu of Lushi, Ni Yue of Jinling, and Zhang Fuhua of Anfu all earned renown as eminent statesmen. Yet their aspirations lay in restraint and frugality, their conduct in precision and discretion. If a minor compromise could achieve a greater good, they would not hesitate. Thus, the style of governance shifted once more. Though their actions left little visible trace, their adherence to principle was resolute—perhaps this too was a matter of destiny.

When the voices of remonstrance grew bold, criticism and praise determined promotions and demotions, and the air was thick with contention, even high ministers deferred in humility. Since the Zhengde era, such uprightness has become rare. Yet when these men enjoyed imperial favor and received praise, they would promptly erect shrines and erect steles, commissioning odes and inscriptions, carving their names into wood and stone, lest their legacy fail to endure for posterity.

With this mindset prevailing, cunning and artifice arose of themselves—those skilled in rhetoric now labored to gloss over faults, marking yet another shift.

So the chronicles record.

The Censor-in-Chief, Lord Gu Zuo, was stern by nature and steadfast in upholding the law, his unyielding integrity unbowed. He championed rectitude and detested wickedness, so that both officials and commoners stood in awe. As Intendant of the Capital Prefecture, even meritorious nobles and imperial kinsmen dared not overstep, and his administrative renown blazed forth, drawing comparison to Bao Xiaosu. Emperor Xuanzong once asked, “Among the court ministers, who might be fit to oversee the Censorate?” Yang Shiqu replied, “The Minister of Communications, Gu Zuo, is incorruptible and commands authority. His tenure as Surveillance Commissioner and in the provincial judicial offices was distinguished by his striking presence.” Yang Rong added, “When he served as Intendant of the Capital, his governance was pure and abuses were eradicated.” Pleased, the emperor promoted him to Right Censor-in-Chief. His enforcement of discipline was rigorous and impartial; he impeached over twenty unworthy officials, and even petty clerks and runners trembled in fear. Never did he speak ill or well of others. From dawn to dusk, he rested briefly in the waiting chamber, then retired alone to a small side room, never idling with other officials unless on public business. Though he enjoyed the full favor of the sovereign and the height of influence, he also possessed the substantive power to curb and suppress.

Lord Qin Xianyi was resolute, upright, and incorruptible, his prestige long established. As a censor, he performed his duties with forthright diligence, exuding an air of authority. When he served as Grand Coordinator of Shaanxi, the guards of the Qin princely establishment ran amok, oppressing the people. He arrested them all and showed no leniency. The prince could not endure it and memorialized that Lord Qin had acted with overbearing arrogance. The Martial Emperor flew into a rage and had him imprisoned in the Embroidered-Uniform Guard’s jail. The eunuch Shang Hong was ordered to confiscate his property, but found only a bolt of yellow silk and a few old garments. When Hong reported this, the emperor sighed in admiration for a long while, then issued an edict releasing him and even bestowed ten thousand strings of cash to commend his integrity. He was reassigned as Grand Coordinator of Henan, where the formidable Wang Zhi arrived on an inspection tour. At the time, Wang was arrogating power and authority, his influence towering. Other grand coordinators all bowed in deference, but Lord Qin alone met him as an equal, refusing to yield in the slightest. Wang, recognizing his weight, did not press the matter. Later, when Wang returned to the capital and the emperor inquired about the worthiness of the provincial governors, Wang singled out Lord Qin for praise. Upon his promotion to Left Censor-in-Chief, his presence grew even more imposing, and people said he had the bearing of Gu Zuo.

Minister Wang Tai was by nature upright and unyielding, incapable of the slightest pretense to please others. As a Supervising Secretary during the crisis of *jisi* in the Zhengtong era, Wang Zhen’s monopolization of power had led the state astray, resulting in the emperor’s captivity. When the Prince of Cheng assumed the regency and held court at the Meridian Gate, the assembled officials impeached the treacherous ministers. The Embroidered-Uniform Guard commander Ma Shun shouted from the side, “All officials, disperse!” Minister Wang strode forward and seized Ma Shun by the head, declaring, “This is the very traitor—he must be removed!” The regent withdrew, and the officials beat Ma Shun to death. Later, when the barbarians invaded and advanced on the capital, Minister Wang was ordered to command the defense. He donned his armor, mounted his horse, and rode to the army, where his commands and dispositions were all apt and timely. He died in office as Minister of War.

Minister Huang Ju was incorruptible, severe, and forthright, confronting matters with swift resolve and an unshakable demeanor. He cared nothing for the powerful. Where others shunned guile and cunning, he shouldered the burden without hesitation. As a Section Chief, he was known in the bureaucracy as “unyielding Huang.”

When he served as Provincial Administration Commissioner of Hubei, the monk Jixiao, who had gained favor through sorcery and flattery, indulged in debauchery and gluttony. Returning home to sweep his ancestors’ graves was merely a pretext for advancing his own interests, so Huang ordered the Wuchang Prefecture to calculate and detain him. Before long, Jixiao’s crimes were exposed, and he was sent to the capital in a caged cart to be executed.

Later, as Chief Supervising Censor of the Left, Huang assessed officials’ abilities and entrusted them accordingly. He burned the roster of assignments before the court, declaring, “What matters in governance is securing the right people. How can seniority and length of service be the sole basis for office?” He discarded all his memorials, administrative records, and literary works, leaving none behind. When Jiangnan’s tax payments were remitted in damaged banknotes, the people suffered from brokers’ extortion and coercion, groaning under the burden. As Minister of Revenue, Huang forcefully memorialized the throne to convert these payments to silver, a measure that has benefited the region to this day. No mere words can compare—his integrity was as clear as Zhang Jia’s.

Those who strive to leave a legacy for posterity do not weigh gain and loss; their deeds stand plain and bright. When Duke Xuan of the Du clan was appointed Supervising Censor, he alone upheld a reputation as pure as ice and bitter as the lotus root. As Provincial Surveillance Commissioner, he wore plain cloth robes and ate simple vegetarian meals, which many of his colleagues found unbearable. Upon his promotion to Chief Supervising Censor, his integrity grew even more resolute. During the annual New Year’s ceremony in Nanjing, when officials gathered at the Ministry of Rites to offer congratulations, he would withdraw to a solitary chamber, dismiss the attendants bearing candles, don his court robes, and sit in silence. Only when the drums signaled the start of the ceremony would he emerge to complete the rites. Without informing his colleagues, he would then depart in his sedan chair. Throughout his life, his noble character relied solely on official documents for remembrance. He ordered clerks to transcribe them into dozens of large volumes, intending them to serve as records for future generations.

Duke Yang of the Du clan, Jizong, was by nature upright and forthright, his words and deeds extraordinary. Initially serving as a Department Director in the Ministry of Justice, he found that prisoners in heavy shackles often perished from filth and decay. Whenever he oversaw the prison, he ensured they were given food and drink and allowed to bathe every three days, reviving countless lives. Duke Wang the Loyal recommended him to govern Jiaxing Prefecture, where he arrived with only a single attendant, as if on a brief sojourn. After nine years, he was promoted to Provincial Surveillance Commissioner of Zhejiang, where his strict enforcement of judicial discipline invigorated the entire administration. Previously, local officials had relied on subordinates to procure supplies, and the demands of the eunuch overseers were exorbitant—he abolished all such practices. The people loved him as a parent, and officials revered him as a divine presence. Soon promoted to Chief Supervising Censor and Grand Coordinator of Shuntian, he reclaimed lands seized by imperial relatives and eunuchs, forcing the powerful to retreat. He was naturally inclined to goodness and despised evil, his integrity rooted in his very nature. He never compromised with others, and people stood in awe of his stern rectitude. Even the common folk and children knew his name for his loyalty, filial piety, moral courage, and dignified bearing.

The Record states: Confucius said, “I have never seen a truly resolute man.” And again, “Shen, how could you be resolute?” The commentators explain: “A man with desires cannot be resolute; resoluteness means not yielding to desire.” Were not these men the very embodiment of such resolve? In the radiant splendor of the Great Ming, where crookedness was banished and obstruction cleared, the vast and luminous qi filled the cosmos. How could there fail to emerge men of supreme greatness and resoluteness, nurtured without harm? This is why they so decisively aligned themselves with righteousness and the Dao, free from the slightest trace of weakness or self-interest. How magnificent!

Minister Li the Cultivated, Shimian, harbored great ambitions from youth and was diligent in his studies, plumbing the depths of nature, destiny, morality, and the Dao. Initially appointed as a Department Director in the Ministry of Justice, he was later transferred to the Hanlin Academy as a Reader-in-Waiting. In the nineteenth year of the Yongle reign, when the Three Palaces were struck by fire, an edict sought forthright counsel. Li submitted fifteen proposals, all addressing the ills of the time. The emperor approved fourteen and ordered their implementation. At the start of the Hongxi reign, he again submitted two memorials on current policies, presenting them in person. The emperor, enraged, ordered guards to strike him with sixteen or seventeen metal claws, breaking three of his ribs. Dragged out, he could no longer speak. Soon after, he was reassigned as a censor, with orders to review a batch of prisoners and submit a memorial on current affairs. After three submissions, he was imprisoned in the Embroidered Uniform Guard’s dungeon. His ribs, initially misaligned, were set with splints, and the broken bones suddenly realigned—a miracle attributed to his loyalty. His external injuries healed within a month.

In the first year of the Xuande reign, the emperor visited Wansui Mountain and summoned Li to inquire about the reasons for his earlier offense against the late emperor. The questioning was repeated several times before Li recited his memorial, stopping after the sixth item. The emperor asked, “There were more—why did you not speak further?” Li replied, “Your Majesty’s awe-inspiring presence made it difficult for me to recall the details.” The emperor smiled and said, “These were simply the hardest to voice. Do you still have the draft?” Li answered, “I burned it.” Thus, he was pardoned.

Minister Liu the Loyal and Earnest, Qiu, served as a Hanlin Academician and Lecturer during the Zhengtong reign. He was earnest in his guidance and instruction, his discussions impassioned and unyielding to the powerful. In private, his concern for the times was ever-present. When the northern barbarians repeatedly offered tribute, he grew deeply apprehensive. Later, when unrest erupted in Luchuan and Wang Zhen, newly empowered, indulged his private grudges by launching a massive military campaign, Liu submitted a memorial urging the abandonment of the campaign, the establishment of military colonies, and the use of appeasement to pacify the region, while focusing on defending the northwestern frontier against the barbarian threat. When Luchuan rebelled a second time and troops were again dispatched to suppress it, Liu submitted ten proposals. The first stated: “Your Majesty should personally attend to governance; authority must not be delegated.” Wang Zhen, enraged upon reading it, sought to shift blame but found no pretext. Coincidentally, the compiler Dong Lin, who had offended Wang Zhen by requesting appointment as Minister of Rites, was imprisoned by the Embroidered Uniform Guard. The guard commander Ma Shun was instructed to delve deeply into the case, framing Liu as the mastermind behind Dong’s scheme and falsely accusing them of forming a clique. Liu was dragged before the throne and ultimately died in the Embroidered Uniform Guard’s prison.

Minister Zhong the Reverent and Earnest, Tong, was appointed Supervising Censor during the Jingtai reign. Earlier, in the Zhengtong reign, the heir apparent had already been established, but some now proposed replacing him. Zhong, outraged by the suggestion, was willing to emulate the loyalty of Di Liang and endure the fate of Bi Gan, with no regrets. His words were stern and resolute, and he wept as he spoke. In essence, he argued that the foundation of the state lay in the heir apparent, whose restoration should not be delayed. He also addressed various abuses in governance, ultimately sacrificing himself for the cause.

The imperial decree sent him to the Embroidered Uniform Guard’s prison, where he died.

**Record states:** The three ministers were of one heart and one virtue—some died, some did not. Those who died preserved their integrity in their time, their spirits roaming the eight wilds, rivaling the sun and moon in brilliance, lending color to the cosmos. Those who lived were shielded by divine protection, their flaws concealed like a blemish on a jade disc, their stains cleansed like a flaw in white jade. Before their jade was polished, they were already exalted and celebrated—far beyond those obscure and hidden spirits who become malevolent wraiths or demonic chiefs. Both paths bring honor for ten thousand generations.

**Of Minister Yu the Solemn and Earnest, Qian:** From youth, he harbored great ambition. At twenty, he passed the imperial examination and was appointed censor. Upright and fearless in speech, he was swiftly promoted to Vice Minister of War at just thirty. For eighteen years, he served as inspector-general of Henan and Shanxi before returning to oversee the ministry’s affairs.

In the *jisi* year of Zhengtong (1449), the northern chieftain Esen invaded. At the time, the eunuch Wang Zhen wielded power and urged the emperor to lead the campaign personally. Minister Yu and Minister of War Yong petitioned to dissuade him, but their pleas were ignored. The imperial procession reached Wolf Mountain, where, unprepared and caught off guard, the court faced the sudden arrival of the barbarian cavalry. The imperial army was routed, the emperor’s carriage seized, and the capital plunged into panic. Minister Yu, then in the capital, received the news and wept bitterly. The Empress Dowager, the Sacred and Illustrious, knew of his reputation and promoted him to Minister of War.

At the time, the elite troops of the Three Camps had all been selected for the campaign, leaving only the old, weak, and feeble behind. The city was in turmoil, with a thousand crises unfolding. Minister Yu, with singular focus, managed the lives of millions, and the ancestral temples and altars of the state depended on him for survival. He supported the enthronement of Emperor Jing and honored Emperor Ying as the Supreme Emperor from afar. Only then did the realm recognize its sovereign, the north and south reconnected, tribute flowed in, and within a month, the tools of war and defense were fully prepared. The soldiers’ morale revived, and the people’s hearts steadied.

When the eunuch Xi Ning defected, he first served the enemy, revealing every detail, great and small. He then guided the barbarians, urging them toward Zijing Pass. The capital was placed under martial law, and many fled south with their families. The academician Xu Li recklessly interpreted omens and advocated relocating the capital south. Minister Yu wept in court, declaring with resolve: *"The capital is the root of the realm. The ancestral temples and imperial tombs are here, along with the officials, the people, the treasuries, and the granaries—all fully prepared. If we move, all will be lost. We must learn from the Southern Song’s mistake."* He then firmly upheld the policy of defense.

He selected trusted officials and relatives of the imperial consort to guard the palace, while the resolute and principled censor Wang Tai and others were tasked with securing the nine gates. All those outside the city were ordered to enter, and along the barbarians’ route, a scorched-earth policy was enforced—fortifying defenses and refusing battle. Minister Yu vowed to lead by example, donning armor and helmet himself. He stationed troops outside Desheng Gate and sealed the city gates. With tears, he exhorted the army, reminding them of the nation’s grace, the rarity of loyalty, and the dire consequences of failure. *"To live now is worse than death,"* he declared. The soldiers were moved, their courage redoubled.

On the first day of the tenth month, a scout re-entered the pass, claiming the emperor’s return was imminent. The barbarians charged forward, but the army held firm. Realizing the capital was prepared, they began to retreat. Xi Ning then incited them to demand high-ranking officials for peace talks, along with gold and silk worth millions, seeking to sow discord. The court was at a loss. Minister Yu declared: *"Our only concern now is military affairs. We dare not hear of anything else."*

After seven days, the strategy was refined. The emperor was moved to a secure location, separated from the barbarian camp, and cannons bombarded their position. Countless barbarians perished beneath the artillery, and their morale shattered. They fled under cover of night.

**Record states:** Our Emperor Jing of the Ming surpassed the Song’s Gaozong by far. Observing his actions and demeanor, though his victories were won through momentary strategies, his unwavering resolve and unshakable will were the true foundation. He heeded Wang Zhan’s counsel and executed Ma Shun, then followed Lin Cong’s plan to imprison Wang Zhen. Later, he acted on Ye Sheng’s advice, relentlessly pursuing those who had failed in their duty during the imperial escort. Compared to the likes of Geng Nanzhong, Huang Qianshan, and Wang Boyan—who had no part in such schemes—his refusal to dismiss Li Gang to appease the Jin, to strip Zong Ze of his command and demoralize the loyal, or to sacrifice Yue Fei to satisfy traitors’ whims, stands in stark contrast. This is why Minister Shang the Cultured and Earnest declared: *"Emperor Jing rendered great service to the altars of state."* Was this not the reason?

As for Minister Yu’s death, it was in accordance with the principles of the *Spring and Autumn*—a debt repaid to his sovereign in the underworld.

Thus, it was said again and again: *"Leave behind but a single frame of flesh."* How could he not have known? Had there been even the slightest trace of attachment or reluctance, all his past wise counsels would have shattered like tiles, and his clarity of judgment could not have remained so resolute and bright. Alas! The bond between sovereign and minister may indeed be called righteous.

When the Loyal and Martyred Duke Sun Sui served as Regional Inspector of Jiangxi, Zhu Chenhao, the Prince of Ning, oppressed the people with tyranny, eroded governance with corruption, and secretly plotted rebellion. Upon his arrival, Duke Sun first exposed the abuses of the prince’s officers—how they harmed the good and virtuous, how treacherous commoners seized property, and how the prince’s musicians murdered in broad daylight—then petitioned for their indictment. Chenhao, fearing reprisal, shifted blame to other prefectures, while General Wang, seeking to cover his own faults, submitted memorials in self-justification. Though Duke Sun saw through this, the rebellion had not yet openly manifested, and despite his repeated memorials detailing the prince’s crimes, they were suppressed and never reached the throne. He could only secretly coordinate with Surveillance Vice Censor Li Run, Regional Inspector Fan Xia, Assistant Administration Commissioner Chen Hongmo, and Vice Commissioner Xu Da, stockpiling grain, readying troops, stationing officials at strategic points, and thus containing the prince’s movements within while suppressing his partisans without.

Later, a man of Nanchang named Zhang Yi submitted a full report to Surveillance Censor Xiao Huai, who then exposed the prince’s crimes to the court and dispatched meritorious nobles and high ministers to admonish him. Before their warning arrived, however, the prince’s officer Lin Hua galloped back from the capital with news, and Chenhao, seized by fear, rebelled. On the fourteenth day of the sixth month of the *jimao* year, during the prince’s birthday banquet, all officials entered to offer felicitations. Chenhao stood on the open terrace and declared: *"The Empress Dowager has issued a secret decree commanding me to raise troops and act as regent."* Duke Sun demanded to see the decree, but Chenhao faltered and said only: *"No need for further words. I am going to Nanjing—will you escort me?"* Duke Sun replied: *"There are not two suns in the sky; how can a minister serve two lords? Who dares defy the laws of the ancestral dynasty?"* Enraged, Chenhao withdrew into the palace hall to don his armor, then emerged and shouted at Duke Sun: *"What wrong have I done you that you impeached me seven times?"* Duke Sun retorted: *"What wrong has the court done you that you rebel?"* At that moment, all the assembled officials stood aghast.

Only Minister Xu, the Loyal and Principled Duke Kui, argued back and forth, insisting it could not be done. He raised his voice and declared: *"We are high ministers of the realm—how can we act thus?"* Enraged, Chenhao demanded: *"What does Xu Kui say?"* Xu replied: *"Only that I have a heart of red loyalty—would I follow you in rebellion?"* Thereupon Chenhao roared an order to bind the two ministers and drag them out. Xu turned to Duke Sun and said: *"Had you heeded my words earlier, this would not have come to pass."* For there had once been a plan to strike first and report afterward, but others had thwarted it.

Once bound, Xu Kui grew ever more vehement, shouting curses without cease until he was slain alongside Duke Sun. On the day of their deaths, the flames of martyrdom burned fiercely, and suddenly the sky darkened with a choking gloom; soldiers and civilians, young and old, all wept. When word reached the court, posthumous offices and honors were conferred, and a temple was ordered built to enshrine them both, its plaque inscribed: *"Exalting Loyalty."*

The record states: *"Beholding the deaths of these two ministers, we see how they above revived the unbroken heroic spirit of antiquity, and below inspired the indomitable vitality of ages to come; how they forestalled the manifest calamity of a traitor’s disloyalty, and thwarted the hidden schemes of treacherous factions. Can this be called a small contribution?*

*When Duke Sun first took office, the realm enjoyed perfect peace and prosperity—who did not believe all was secure? Yet who could have foreseen disaster rising from within the imperial house, rebellion springing from the sovereign’s own kin? Only he stood resolute against it. In life, he seemed as one already dead: seven memorials he submitted to restrain Chenhao, a hundred stratagems to clip his wings. In death, he seemed as one not dead: his forthright words exposed the traitor’s plot, his refusal to mount his horse foiled his advance. In him, composure and righteous fervor were as one—this is the first reason he is to be revered.*

*When the Martial Emperor ascended the throne, a succession of wicked factions arose, their deceits and debaucheries beyond remedy; all hearts were sick with loathing. But upon hearing the words ‘There are not two suns in the sky; how can a minister serve two lords?’—like autumn frost and scorching sun, awe-inspiring—then the hearts of those who would rebel were reformed, and the spirit of defiance grew stronger. In death for filial piety, in death for loyalty, there is an inevitability that transcends intention—this is the second reason he is to be revered.*

*In the middle period of the Han, there was the Revolt of the Seven States; in the Tang, the troops of Yuyang—both brought prolonged suffering. Even in the Ning Shu rebellion, though its schemes were deep and its evil long-nurtured, it was crushed in fifty days. Yet tracing its origins, in the Han not a single man died in resistance. In the Tang, only after twenty-four prefectures had fallen did the son of the Yan family refuse to yield to bandits—how different from today, when loyal blood splattered the traitor’s filthy chariot-wheels, when a single cry snatched away his false mandate, when the sky darkened in mourning and snow swirled in the air at a rebuke! The gentleman had long since foreseen its destruction—this is the third reason he is to be revered.*

*The great enterprise of pacifying the realm and rectifying the state seemed within reach, yet the Dao of Heaven, once manifest, was again obscured; the imperial path, once opened, was again blocked. The loyal and good had nearly despaired of averting disaster. Yet in the end, the realm suffered no lasting blemish—precisely because the hearts of men are not easily swayed. Even if men like Hou Yi or Wang Mang had arisen, their efforts would have been in vain; how much more so for such petty vermin as these! This is the fourth reason he is to be revered.*

*These four virtues—no defiance of Heaven, no lagging behind opportunity, no betrayal of self, no frustration of duty—are not small contributions. Let those who read this take heed."*

**Hongdao Record, Scroll Seventeen (conclusion)**
**Hongdao Record, Scroll Eighteen: On Righteousness—The Righteousness Between Father and Son**

Mencius said: "Shun fully practiced the Way of serving his parents, and Gu Sou* was thereby made joyful, and all under Heaven was transformed. Gu Sou being made joyful, the father-son relationship throughout the world was settled."

The Record states: What is meant by "settled"? The *Classic of Filial Piety* says: "When one man has cause for celebration, the millions of people rely upon him." For in the relationship between father and son, righteousness is often obscured. People know only of affection but not of reverence. Only now do they begin to understand the Way of revering the other, and the roles of father and son become clearly defined. This is why the customs of Qin—where fathers doted on their sons and craved profit, differing little from beasts—truly paved the way for great chaos in later ages.

The *Records of the Grand Historian* state: In the time of Yao, the floods rose to the heavens, and the Four Peaks recommended Gun to regulate the waters. He achieved no success, and Gun hastened to his death. After Shun ascended the throne, he raised up Yu to continue his father’s work.

The Record states: In the flourishing age of Tang and Yu, not only was abdication and succession carried out with perfect impartiality, but even matters of merit and fault were not concealed. Gun was a criminal. Even if a criminal’s descendant served in the same court, could he truly replace his father? Yu was a filial son. His heart, burdened with grief for his father, could scarcely bear to offer himself in service—how much less to inherit his father’s work! Yet Shun’s rescue of Gun and Gun’s being rescued both proceeded from the perfect impartiality of all under Heaven. The one who bestowed it harbored no resentment, and the one who received it felt no enmity. When Shun raised Yu to continue his father’s work, this too accorded with the perfect harmony of human hearts. The one who appointed him felt no misgivings, and the one who took up the task felt no regret. Had there been the slightest trace of self-interest, the relationships between ruler and minister, father and son, would all have been obstructed. How then could this be called righteousness?

Yu married the daughter of the Tushan clan and had a son, Qi. From the days of *xin*, *ren*, *gui*, to *jia*, Qi wailed incessantly, yet Yu, unmindful of his son, devoted himself wholly to measuring the land and managing the waters.

The Record states: Gun was dismissed for defying orders and ruining his clan, while Yu rose to prominence through his responsiveness and diligent service. If fine wine is detestable, can the human Way be abandoned? If every inch of time is precious, can even the days of *xin* and *ren* be begrudged? This is the essence of "public-mindedness forgetting the private, the state forgetting the family"—a virtue that admits of no greater height.

The *Book of Rites* in the *Tan Gong* chapter states: In serving one’s parents, one conceals their faults without defying them, attends to their needs without fixed methods, serves them diligently until death, and observes three years of mourning.

The Record states: Why must their faults be concealed? For the Way of father and son is rooted in Heavenly nature. The *Book of Changes* says: "In correcting his father’s errors, the son ensures that his father incurs no blame." Though a parent may err, if the child can rectify it, the parent’s failure becomes the child’s achievement. Thus, Shun’s father was originally obstinate, but Shun was able to guide him, and his obstinacy was transformed into kindness—how could there be any defiance? Yu’s father was originally cruel, but Yu was able to guide him, and his merits eclipsed his faults—what need was there for direct confrontation? Yet merely concealing their wrongs, to the point of bringing ruin to state and family, is not the meaning of "attending to their needs without fixed methods."

If a father’s faults are concealed to the point of national collapse and familial destruction, this is not the meaning of "attending to their needs without fixed methods." When King Cheng was too young to govern, the Duke of Zhou assisted him in ruling, and he upheld the laws of the heir apparent before Bo Qin, wishing to make King Cheng understand the Way of father and son, ruler and minister, elder and younger.

The Record states: I observe that upholding the laws of the heir apparent before Bo Qin was a stroke of genius for all ages. Though the heir apparent was a young ruler, and the tutors and guardians appointed were esteemed ministers, could a minister truly reproach a ruler? Would mere formal bows and seated courtesies convey any true sense of awe? Yet Bo Qin, as the heir to Lu, was subject to the authority of his tutors and guardians. Thus, while King Cheng could not be flogged, Bo Qin could suffer no such impropriety. Not only was there no impropriety in flogging Bo Qin, but even King Cheng could harbor no resentment. Though it was Qin who received the lashes, it was the king who was being chastised. Would this not jolt him into reflection and self-improvement? If one does not correct one’s faults, others will not cease their reproofs. Faults have limits, but reproofs are boundless—until they become fewer and fewer, and finally vanish altogether. Over time, the one who metes out the lashes may cease, and the one who commits the faults may be transformed. People see only that he became an excellent ruler, unaware of how deeply he was shaped by this process. Is this not the height of ingenuity?

Thus Confucius said: "The Duke of Zhou excelled in this." This is the highest praise.

In all the Three Dynasties, the heir apparent was educated with ritual and music. Music cultivates the inner self, while ritual cultivates the outer. When ritual and music intermingle within, they manifest outwardly. Thus, when fully realized, they produce a demeanor that is gracious, reverent, and refined.

The Record states: Above the Three Dynasties, ritual and music were put into practice. Below the Three Dynasties, they became empty formalities. The heir apparent is the foundation of all under Heaven. Ritual and music are the foundation of the heir apparent. If the heir apparent is reverent and refined, the ruler of men will be free from indolence, cruelty, and harshness. If the ruler of men is free from indolence, cruelty, and harshness, the court will be free from perversity, discord, and rebellion. If the court is free from perversity, discord, and rebellion, the world will be free from dissolution, peril, and ruin. The beginnings of early cultivation and preparation lie here, subtly guiding the realm into a state of peace and order without one’s awareness.

They appointed a Grand Tutor and a Junior Tutor to nurture him, wishing him to understand the Way of father and son, ruler and minister. The Grand Tutor examined the Way of father and son, ruler and minister, and demonstrated it to him. The Junior Tutor accompanied the heir apparent, observing the Grand Tutor’s virtuous conduct and explaining it clearly. The Grand Tutor stood before him, the Junior Tutor behind. When inside, he had guardians; when outside, he had teachers. Thus, through instruction and explanation, his virtue was perfected.

The teacher is one who teaches with affairs and elucidates virtue. The guardian is one who carefully attends to his own conduct, assists and guides him, and leads him to the Way.

The Record states: In the Xia, Shang, and Zhou dynasties, there were teachers and guardians, as well as counselors for doubts, the Four Assistants, and the Three Dukes. These positions were not necessarily all filled—only those who were capable were appointed. The establishment of teachers, guardians, and tutors was thus of such great importance.

---
*Gu Sou: Shun’s blind father.*

In later ages, these positions became mere concurrent offices—some elevated their rituals in vain, others retained only their names, some appointed unworthy individuals, while others assigned duties unrelated to their roles. None of these aligned with the original intent of the Duke of Zhou. How, then, could one expect the proper method of educating the crown prince to endure?

To the ruler, the crown prince is both a son in kinship and a lord in rank. Possessing the intimacy of a father and the authority of a sovereign, he is then entrusted with the realm. Thus, the upbringing of the crown prince must be approached with utmost care. There is but one path where a single act yields threefold virtue—this is the crown prince’s enrollment in learning. When the crown prince attends school alongside others, the people observe and ask: *"He who will rule us now shares our rank in learning—why?"* The answer: *"Because his father still lives, and thus the rites demand it."* Through this, the multitude comes to understand the Way of father and son.

Again, they ask: *"He who will rule us now shares our rank in learning—why?"* The answer: *"Because his lord still reigns, and thus the rites demand it."* Through this, the people grasp the principle of lord and subject.

A third time, they ask: *"He who will rule us now shares our rank in learning—why?"* The answer: *"Because he honors his elders."* Through this, the people learn the order of seniority and juniority.

Thus, while the father lives, he is a son; while the lord reigns, he is a subject. By observing the proper conduct of son and subject, he upholds reverence for the lord and love for kin. Therefore, in learning, he embodies the Way of father and son; in learning, he embodies the Way of lord and subject; in learning, he embodies the Way of senior and junior. When the Ways of father and son, lord and subject, senior and junior are realized, the state is well-governed.

As the saying goes: *"The Music Master oversees instruction, the Father-Teacher ensures completion. When one man is truly excellent, the myriad states attain rectitude."* This refers to the crown prince.

*Record states:* Observing the excellence of the institutions of the Zhou, none surpass the meticulous and detailed regulations for the crown prince—readers cannot but rejoice in them. Though the crown prince is born within the secluded palace and stands above ten thousand men, who would dare to share his rank? Yet who would also follow his example? Still, his birth has its origins, his succession its inheritance, and his emergence from seclusion has its precedence—these are matters the crown prince shares with all people. Though he shares these with others, who can make them understand what they share?

For most people merely know they have a father but not the Way of the father—though they revere him, they do not change. They merely know they have a lord but not the Way of the lord—though they honor him, they do not shift. They merely know they have elders but not the Way of the elder—though they exalt them, they do not alter. Yet through a single question of shared rank in learning, the subtlest principles of the realm are exhaustively revealed—is this not as clear as pointing to one’s palm?

Thus it is said: *"When one man is truly excellent, the myriad states attain rectitude."* This is the ultimate praise, boundless in its scope.

*The Garden of Persuasions* records: When Bo Qin and Kang Shu received their fiefs, they paid court to King Cheng and met the Duke of Zhou. Thrice they were received, and thrice they were dismissed. Kang Shu grew alarmed and said to Bo Qin: *"There is a worthy man named Shangzi—let us go and see him."* Kang Shu and Bo Qin visited Shangzi and sought his counsel. Shangzi said: *"On the southern slope of Mount Nan, there is a tree called *qiao*—go and observe it."* The two went and saw the *qiao*: its branches stretched upward, bearing fruit with pride. They reported this to Shangzi, who said: *"The *qiao* embodies the Way of the father."*

*"On the northern slope of Mount Nan, there is a tree called *zi*—go and observe it."* The two went and saw the *zi*: its branches bent downward, bearing fruit in humility. They reported this to Shangzi, who said: *"The *zi* embodies the Way of the son."*

The next day, the two met the Duke of Zhou. Upon entering the gate, they hastened forward; upon ascending the hall, they knelt. The Duke of Zhou stroked their heads, commended them, and offered them food, asking: *"Where have you seen a gentleman?"* They replied: *"We saw Shangzi."* The Duke of Zhou said: *"Truly a gentleman, this Shangzi!"*

*Record states:* This admonition from Bo Qin was not only to instruct King Cheng but also to instruct Kang Shu. When a household has a stern lord, reverence for the master and righteousness for the ruler are established, and the Way of loving kin is never isolated. When a household is in turmoil, misfortune and calamity follow—this is why children are exchanged for instruction. Exchanging children for instruction preserves the affection between father and son. Truly a gentleman, this Shangzi! He neither harmed affection nor lost righteousness, yet his virtue extended for ten generations—is this not the clearest proof of *"majesty enduring to a blessed end"*?

By contrast, the vulgar customs of Qin and the harsh laws of Han severed affection, while wives and children, laughing heedlessly, lost the proper order of the household. Is it any wonder that ruin and chaos followed one after another?

*The Discourses of the States* records: King Gong of Zhou was traveling along the Jing River when Mi Kang Gong followed with three fleeing women. His mother said: *"You must present them to the king. Three beasts make a herd, three people make a crowd, and three women make a gathering. A gathering is a thing of beauty. When the crowd offers a beautiful thing to you, what virtue do you possess to deserve it?"* Kang Gong did not present them. Within a year, the king destroyed Mi.

*Record states:* How deeply Mi Kang Gong’s mother loved her son, yet how blind she was to the duty of serving her lord! Though the intimacy of the hall differs from that of the knee, the singleness of the heart should be the same. If her words were meant to protect her son, they were wise. But if they were meant to advise the king, then I do not understand. Betraying one’s state is a grave crime, a great transgression against humanity. If an act is righteous, even a multitude like clouds would not be deemed excessive. If it is unrighteous, a single Bao Si was enough to destroy the House of Zhou—what difference did it make that there were three women? To regard them as firewood and present them to the king—was this the king’s beauty or Mi’s wickedness?

*The Zuo Tradition* records: In the second year of Duke Huan’s reign, he seized the bells of Bao from Song and installed them in the Grand Temple. Zang Ai Bo remonstrated: *"One who rules over others must display virtue and block transgressions to oversee the hundred officials, yet still fears some may err. Thus, he manifests exemplary virtue to instruct his descendants. This is why the Pure Temple has a thatched roof, the grand chariot has a mat of rushes, the great broth is unseasoned, and the sacrificial grain is uncarved—all to display frugality. The inner and outer robes, caps, sashes, lower garments, leggings, black slippers, jade pendants, sashes, bowstrings, and quivers—all display proper measure."*

The adornments of the carriage—*zao*, *shuai*, *zhuan*, and *xia*; the brush, whetstone, tassel, and cap strings—all display their proper number. The fire, dragon, *ling*, and *bi* patterns display their ornamentation. The five colors arranged in symbolic order display their correspondence to things. The bronze ornaments—*xi*, *luan*, *he*, and bells—display their sounds. The three celestial bodies emblazoned on the banners display their radiance. Virtue is frugal yet measured, with ascending and descending governed by precise numbers; patterns and objects serve to record it, while sounds and lights serve to manifest it, thereby illuminating the hundred officials. Thus do they remain vigilant, daring not to transgress the established laws.

Now, by obliterating virtue and erecting transgression, you enshrine these bribe-vessels in the Grand Temple, making them plainly visible to the hundred officials. If the hundred officials emulate this, what punishment could suffice? The ruin of the state arises from the corruption of its officials; the corruption of officials stems from the flaunting of favor and bribes. With the *Du* cauldrons installed in the temple, what display could be more egregious? The duke did not heed the advice.

When the Inner Scribe of Zhou heard of this, he said: "Will Zang Sun Da not have descendants in Lu?" Though the lord transgressed, he did not forget to admonish him with virtue.

The record states: Zang Ai Bo’s posterity was due to Zang Xi Bo’s exhortation. For to observe fish is to indulge in trivial excess, while to display the grand chariot is to invite greater disorder—Yu Fu’s regard for Hua Du was but a single inquiry. Once the chaos in Song had taken root, how could the villainy in Lu be redressed? Though the charges were formally returned, Duke Huan’s guilt was foremost in instigating it, while the calamity in the chariot was but a reversal of fortune. Thus did Ziya, Qingfu, Zhong Sui, and Yiru arise, their schemes proliferating without end. Was this not the consequence of making law the province of the noble?

Alas!

The descendants of the Zang clan may truly be said to have borne no disgrace to Lu. Among their later generations, some—like Zang Rangyi—faced urgent illness with equanimity, some—like those driven from the Eastern Gate—were exiled, and some were even hailed as sages. Was the prediction of the Zhou court historian mere empty words? Only then does one realize that advocating virtue and establishing principles, though they may go unheeded, must never be abandoned.

When Zhou Xu failed to harmonize with his people, Hou sought counsel from Shi Zi on how to secure his lord’s position. Shi Zi replied, “An audience with the king would suffice.” Hou asked, “How might one obtain such an audience?” Shi Zi said, “Duke Huan of Chen currently enjoys the king’s favor, and Chen and Wei are on good terms. If you go to Chen and request their intercession, the audience will surely be granted.” Hou followed Zhou Xu to Chen, where Shi Qing informed the Chen court: “Our state of Wei is small, and I am old and feeble, unable to do much. These two men murdered our ruler—dare we not act against them?” The men of Chen seized them and requested Wei’s presence to carry out the execution. In the ninth month, Wei dispatched Youzai Chou to Pu, where he put Zhou Xu to death. Shi Ge then sent his steward Ru Yangjian to Chen to execute Shi Hou. The noble man remarked: “Shi Ge was a loyal minister indeed. Though he despised Zhou Xu, he included Hou in his condemnation. To uphold great righteousness by cutting off even one’s kin—is this not the very meaning of such loyalty?”

The record states: The sacrificial rites of La nearly enabled one to join in rebellion. For perversity and drowning alike lead to destruction. The lord had already strayed into perversity, and Cuo nearly drowned in it. Had a true king arisen, how could he have been purified? Then what use were the earlier remonstrances? When Huan ascended and Cuo grew old, when Hou died and Shi was at peace, Cuo nearly became fit to join in rebellion. Had Huo Guang of Han understood this and plainly informed the emperor, saying, “Lady Xian was complicit in the regicide,” then the crime of Chun Yu could have been righted, the marriage of the younger daughter halted, and the Huo clan might not have perished. Yet in the end, they drowned together—was this not due to a failure to study? Thus it is said: A minister who does not grasp the principles of the *Spring and Autumn Annals* risks falling into the crime of usurpation or regicide. This is what it means.

When Duke Xian of Jin sought to kill his heir, Prince Shensheng, his brother Chong’er said to him, “Why not explain your intentions to the duke?” The heir replied, “I cannot. If the duke finds comfort in Lady Li, I would only wound his heart.” Chong’er then asked, “Then why not flee?” Shensheng said, “I cannot. The duke would believe I meant to murder him. Is there any state in the world without a father?” He sent a message to Hu Tu, saying: “Shensheng has erred and failed to heed your counsel, bringing himself to death. I dare not cling to life. Yet our lord is old, his son young, and the state beset by troubles. If you do not emerge to guide our lord, who will? If you do emerge to guide him, Shensheng will accept my fate and die.” He bowed twice, kowtowed, and then perished. Thus he is called the Reverent Heir.

The record states: Duke Xian’s lack of kindness could be punished by others, but his lack of filial piety could not. For father and son succeed one another as generations. Thus Heaven, in bestowing its mandate, first determines their union and rightly orders their succession. What is this union if not the household’s inner sanctum? How could it be profaned? How grievous was the Reverent Heir’s misfortune! The way of beasts is to wait passively—Heaven casts them into the dust to serve as offerings for man’s slaughter. Yet man is the most intelligent of creatures, and among men, the finest are chosen. Though the world may rarely lack states without fathers, can it abide men without mothers? To be deluded by Lady Li might still be spoken of, but to be deceived by Lady Qi—this cannot be spoken of. The heir must have weighed this. Heaven punishes the unfilial to warn the unworthy—how could I dare to cling to life? With no path forward, I await the cauldron. Shensheng’s reverence lay in his resolve to yield his place to his successor.

The duke sent the eunuch Pi to attack Pu. Chong’er said, “A command from one’s lord and father must not be resisted.” He then fled, saying, “To resist would be my warning.” He scaled the wall and escaped, but Pi cut off his sleeve. Chong’er then fled to Di.

The record states: Chong’er was nearly fit to face peril. For a command from one’s lord and father must not be resisted—resistance serves as a fivefold warning. When the Crown Prince of Wei was exiled, Shi De instructed him to falsify credentials, and Shou Chong and others were imprisoned—was this not a warning? To accept a light punishment but flee a heavy one—this is the way of a filial son. Though he scaled the wall and fled to Di, how did this harm his conduct in escaping danger?

When Duke Xiang of Jin died, Lady Mu Ying carried the heir in her arms and wept at court, crying, “What crime did the late lord commit? What crime does his heir commit? To set aside the rightful heir and seek a ruler from outside—where will this lead?” She left the court and went to the Zhao clan, where she kowtowed to Xuanzi, saying, “The late lord entrusted this child to you, saying, ‘If this son is capable, I will owe you a debt of gratitude. If he is not, I will hold you in resentment.’ Now, though the lord has passed, his words still ring in my ears—how can you abandon him?” Xuanzi and the other ministers, troubled by Lady Mu Ying and fearing the power of the outer clans, disregarded Xian Mie and enthroned Duke Ling.

The record states: Duke Ling’s plot against Zhao Dun did not wait for repeated remonstrances—it began the moment he heard the kowtow. For a lord to kowtow to his minister is a grave humiliation. Why did Dun not reflect on his own conduct? By diminishing his private authority and restoring governance to the public realm, yet remaining blind to the principles of advancement and retreat, survival and ruin, he invited regret with every move.

Some say: Duke Ling of Jin was lawless—had Xuanzi withdrawn, would he not have perished? Zhuge Liang said: “A minister exhausts himself in service until death.” As for success or failure, advantage or setback—these lie beyond a minister’s foresight. If this principle is not understood, then the clamor of voices—like a demon striking a locust tree, or Mi Ming dying beneath the great mulberry, or Ling Zhe reversing his halberd at the crossroads—seems to blame the minister, but how could one advance under such circumstances?

When the Inner Scribe of Zhou, Shu Fu, arrived in Lu, Gongsun Ao heard of his skill in physiognomy. Upon meeting his two sons, Shu Fu declared: "Gu will bring hardship upon his father. As for Shou, Gu—his broad jaw foretells that his descendants shall prosper in the state of Lu."

Gu fathered Mie, Mie fathered Su, Su fathered Jie, and Jie fathered Jue, who became known as Xi Zi. As Xi Zi lay dying, he summoned his ministers and said: "Kong Qiu is a descendant of sages. Zhuang Sun He once observed: 'If a sage of luminous virtue does not flourish in his own time, his descendants are certain to produce an eminent figure.' Now, that eminent one may well be Kong Qiu. Should I pass away, I entrust Shuo and He Ji to study under the Master, that they may learn ritual and secure their standing."

Thus, Meng Yi Zi and Nan Gong Jing Shu became Confucius’ disciples. Confucius said: "One who can redress his errors is a noble man." The record notes: This lord was a descendant of Qing Fu, yet Confucius praised him as one who could redress errors, thereby exemplifying instruction. For the virtuous, this is the Way to ensure posterity. You Zi examined the matter and found no fault—such is the Way of rectification. The Duke of Zhou charged Cai Zhong, saying: "You must strive to atone for the transgressions of your forebears." This expresses the same principle.

Viewed together, one sees how the sage embraces all under Heaven’s goodness.

Duke Wen of the Ji clan served as chief minister of Lu, keeping no concubines clad in silk nor horses fed with grain. Zhongsun Ta remonstrated, saying: "You, my lord, are Lu’s highest minister, having served two rulers. Yet your concubines wear no silk, and your horses eat no grain—will others not deem this miserly and unworthy of a state’s splendor?"

Wen replied: "I, too, would wish otherwise. Yet when I observe the people of our state, many among their fathers and elder brothers still eat coarse fare and wear shabby clothes. How dare I adorn my concubines and horses? Moreover, I have heard that a state’s splendor lies in the glory of virtue, not in the finery of concubines and horses."

Wen later recounted this to Meng Xian Zi, who imprisoned Ta for seven days. Thereafter, the concubines of Zifu (Ta’s courtesy name) wore only cloth of seven *sheng* weave, and their horses’ fodder was no better than piled chaff. When Wen heard of this, he declared: "One who corrects his errors is the people’s superior." He then appointed him to the rank of senior grand master.

Zifu was Ta’s courtesy name, the son of Mie.

The record notes: When Duke Kang of Liu paid a visit to Lu and presented gifts to the ministers, both Ji Wen Zi and Meng Xian Zi were frugal. Upon returning, he told the king: "The Ji and Meng clans must have long resided in Lu—they are reverent, diligent, respectful, and thrifty. As ministers, they uphold reverence to fulfill their duties without fail, and with diligence they guard their offices without slack."

The practice of reverence in service ensures leniency in death; the practice of frugality in sufficiency keeps one far from worry. When superiors and subordinates share no rifts, what task cannot be borne? This is how one earns a lasting reputation across generations. These words align perfectly with such principles.

Gongfu Wenbo returned from court and paid his respects to his mother. His mother was spinning thread at the time. Wenbo said, "With a household as grand as Chou’s, how can its mistress still be spinning?" His mother sighed and said, "Is Lu doomed? Has my son, now an official, truly heard nothing of duty? Sit, and I will tell you. When the people toil, they reflect; reflection gives rise to good intentions. When they grow idle, they turn to excess; excess makes them forget goodness, and forgetting goodness breeds evil intentions. The people of fertile lands lack ability because of excess; the people of barren lands are all upright because of toil. Thus, the queen personally tends the black silk, the wives of dukes and marquises add silk cords to their robes, the wives of ministers wear grand sashes as titled ladies, the wives of officers completing sacrificial robes wear court attire, and from the common officers downward, all women clothe their husbands. At the altar, they present their tasks; in mourning, they offer their achievements. Transgressions incur punishment—this was the system of old. I hoped you would attend to my teachings day and night, saying, ‘I must not fail our ancestors.’ Yet now you ask, ‘Why not seek ease?’ Entrusted with the lord’s office, I fear for the extinction of Mubo’s line."

The record notes: Observing Yixiu’s abandonment of weaving and Jing Jiang’s diligent spinning—is there any difference? None. The distinction between men and women lies in inner and outer roles, while the warnings of rise and fall lie in excess and responsibility. In office, one’s treasure is to avoid arrogance; at home, one’s treasure is to avoid indulgence. As a minister, Yi could not harbor even the suspicion of seeking gain; as a mother, Jing Jiang could not entertain the poison of complacency. As for Wenbo—outwardly lacking devotion to public duty, inwardly burdened by excessive desires—his ruin is near. That his mother’s words were not only worth hearing but also trustworthy marks her as a paragon of the household. No wonder she was posthumously titled "Reverent Jiang."

When Fan Wuzi was about to retire, he summoned his son, Xie, and said, "Xie, I have heard that those whose joy and anger follow their nature are few, while those who let them run wild are many. A noble person’s joy and anger do not disrupt themselves; if they disrupt others, it will only worsen. Perhaps Quezi seeks to disrupt himself in Qi? If not, I fear he will only amplify it. I am about to retire, so let Quezi fulfill his ambitions—perhaps he will distinguish himself. You, follow the other ministers and remain reverent." He then requested retirement, and Que Xianzi took office.

Wenzi returned from court at dusk. Wuzi asked, "Why so late?" He replied, "A Qin envoy delivered a speech in court, and none of the ministers could respond. I knew three points." Wuzi grew angry and said, "The ministers are not incapable—they defer to their elders. You, a mere youth, have upstaged them all in court. If I were not in Jin, the state would perish any day now!" He struck him with his staff.

Later, when Quezi attacked Qi and the army returned victorious, Wenzi entered last. Wuzi said, "Did you not wish to await my gaze?" He replied, "The army had achieved merit, and the people rejoiced. To greet them first would have drawn all attention to me—usurping the commander’s renown. Thus, I dared not." Wuzi said, "I know you are safe now." Therefore, Wenzi governed with a fine reputation, and Jin relied upon him.

The record notes: Observing Hui’s instruction to Xie, I now understand why some great clans endure while others perish. The Hu, Zhao, Ji, Bu, Yue, Fan, and Jin—these were the so-called great clans. When a clan grows large, excess arises; excess breeds arrogance, and arrogance invites resentment. These are the ones to fear, not to rely upon. And if one further indulges in joy and anger? Thus, Chuan’s regicide was not due to the attack at Taolin but to the battle at Hequ. Bu’s downfall was not due to Xu Tong’s plot but to the humiliation by his wife. Wuzi saw this clearly. Had Dun not restrained his reckless schemes to curb his arrogance and favor, the calamity of the lower officials might have been averted. Had Xian not suppressed his resentful and covetous heart to temper his competitive nature, the guilt of the three Que might have been avoided. How wise! Following Wuzi’s example, he instructed his son with reverence and deference. Reverence gathers virtue; deference exalts propriety. With reverence, Dun did not act wantonly; with deference, Xie did not boast. Later, at the Battle of Junling, he conducted himself with composure and correctness, preserving the fine reputation of Gai Yang’s lineage. How does this compare to the Hu, Zhao, Yue, and Que?

Wei Xianzi said to Cheng Zhuan, "If I ally with Wu, will the people of the county not see me as partisan?" Zhuan replied, "Wu’s character is such that he does not forget his lord when distant, nor does he flaunt agreement when near. In prosperity, he thinks of righteousness; in hardship, he thinks of purity. He has a steadfast heart and no wanton conduct. Even if you ally with him, is it not fitting?" Later, when the people of Gengyang had a lawsuit, their clan bribed the court with female musicians. Weizi was about to accept them. Wei Wu said to Yan Mo and Nü Kuan, "Our lord is known among the feudal lords for refusing bribes. If he accepts the bribe from Gengyang, nothing could be worse. You must remonstrate." Both agreed.

After court, they waited in the courtyard. When summoned, they sighed three times before entering. Once seated, Weizi said, "I have heard that only eating can make one forget worries. You have sighed three times during the meal—why?" They replied, "Earlier, someone gave us two lowly ones wine, and we did not eat until evening. When the food was first served, we feared it would be insufficient, hence the first sigh. Midway, we reproached ourselves, thinking, ‘How could the general’s meal be inadequate?’ and sighed again. By the end, we wished to make our bellies like the hearts of gentlemen—content with mere fullness." Xianzi declined the bribe.

The record notes: A father should not demand goodness from his son—Wei Wu could be said to have known how to heed remonstrance.

No one knows a minister better than his lord, just as no one knows a son better than his father. Xianzi may be said to have known how to employ others. Subtle words and artful persuasion allow speakers to speak without fear and listeners to accept readily. The two may be said to have known how to use speech.

Yet what suspicion is there to avoid, that one should be so earnestly concerned with the turning of words? Excellent indeed! Master Cheng said: "Those who avoid suspicion are all inwardly deficient. When one is inwardly sufficient, why would one resort to bribes?" This is why his governance among the noble aroused no surprise.

To follow beasts without satiety, only to incur the censure of *qiao* and *guo*, cannot be called loyalty. In the *Analects*, Chen Gang asked Boyu, "Have you received any special teachings?" He replied, "Not yet. Once, when he stood alone, I hurried past the courtyard. He asked, 'Have you studied the *Poetry*?' I replied, 'Not yet.' He said, 'Without studying the *Poetry*, one has no means of speech.' I withdrew and studied the *Poetry*. Another time, when he stood alone, I hurried past the courtyard. He asked, 'Have you studied the rites?' I replied, 'Not yet.' He said, 'Without studying the rites, one has no means of standing.' I withdrew and studied the rites."

Upon hearing these two exchanges, Chen Gang withdrew and rejoiced, saying, "I asked one question and gained three insights: I learned of the *Poetry*, the rites, and that the noble man keeps his distance from his son." The record notes: Boyu’s responses contained five virtues, though keeping distance from his son was not among them. "Once, when he stood alone"—the moment was leisurely and fitting, with nothing to shame him above or trouble him below. "Hurried"—his manner was reverent and solemn, without familiarity from favor or reliance on affection. *Poetry* and rites are public matters. "Not yet"—he knew and did not deceive, without laziness or arrogance. "Without... one has no means"—his words were generous and accommodating, without demanding goodness or harming affection. As for "withdrew and studied," he was then fully cultivated.

Even in his "not yet," the question of difference revealed something profoundly different within. How regrettable that Chen Gang’s perception did not reach this! At first, he peered with private intent; in the end, he rejoiced at a small gain. That a thousand years later, one cannot help but lament Boyu’s missed opportunity—is this not Chen Gang’s fault?

The *Complete Works* claims that Boyu’s nature was somewhat inferior, so the Sage taught him only thus. Had his nature been keen and perceptive, he might have reached the heights of Yan and Zeng. This statement does not seem correct.

In the *Family Sayings*: Once, when Master Zeng lay gravely ill, Zichun of Lezheng sat by the bed, while Zeng Yuan and Zeng Shen sat at his feet. A boy holding a candle sat in the corner. The boy said, "How splendid and smooth—is that the mat of a great officer?" Zichun said, "Stop." Master Zeng heard this and started, saying, "How splendid and smooth—is that the waking mat of a great officer?" Master Zeng said, "Yes. This was a gift from Jisun. I have not yet been able to replace it." Yuan rose to change the mat. Zeng Yuan said, "The Master’s illness is critical. We cannot risk waiting until dawn. Please change it with reverence." Master Zeng said, "Your love for me is not like that of a noble man. A noble man loves others with virtue; you love with indulgence. What more do I seek? I wish only to die rightly. That is all."

They lifted him to change the mat, but before he could settle back upon the new one, he passed away.

The record states: What is meant by "parents preserve one whole at birth, and a child returns whole to them" is thus explained. The foundation of life’s principle lies in wholeness—how could it be merely a matter of "extending my feet" or "moving my hands"? From the Three Reflections to his final illness, from transmitting the teachings to grasping the One Thread, from yielding his seat to awaiting the candle’s light—had there been even the slightest deviation from rightness, it could not be called a whole return. Otherwise, would the Heaven-endowed conscience be deemed lighter than the body bequeathed by one’s parents? Thus, only after the mat was changed did I know he had avoided failure.

If he had merely allowed his disciples to part the bedding and look upon him, it would have been a trivial matter.

In *The Elementary Learning*, it is recorded: Meng Ke’s mother lived near a graveyard. When Mencius was young, his play consisted of grave-digging and burial rites. His mother said, "This is no place to raise a child," and they moved away. They then lived near a market, where his play turned to hawking and bargaining. His mother said, "This is no place to raise a child," and they moved again, settling beside a school. There, his play became arranging ritual vessels, bowing, yielding, advancing, and retiring. His mother said, "This is truly a place to raise a child," and they remained.

The record states: Confucius, in his play, always arranged ritual vessels and practiced ceremonial deportment, rooted in innate knowledge. Mencius, in his play, also arranged ritual vessels, bowed, yielded, advanced, and retired, but this was rooted in learning. Herein lies the distinction between the great sage and the great worthy, determined from the time they were mere lads.

In *The Comprehensive Mirror*, it is recorded: Suo Gao of Anling had a son who served in Qin. Qin appointed him to guard Guan. When Lord Xinling of Wei attacked Guan without success, he sent word to the Lord of Anling: "Send Suo Gao to me. I will appoint him as a Fifth-Rank Grandee and make him a Commandant of Credentials." The Lord of Anling conveyed this to Suo Gao, who replied, "Your lordship’s favor toward me is to have me attack Guan. A father attacking while his son defends—this would be a laughingstock. To appear before you in submission would be to betray my lord. A father teaching his son to betray—this is hardly what your lordship would desire." He bowed twice, declined the messenger, and reported back to Lord Xinling. Enraged, Lord Xinling sent another messenger to the Lord of Anling, saying, "The land of Anling is as much a part of Wei as any other. If I fail to take Guan, Qin’s forces will reach us, and our altars of soil and grain will be imperiled. I ask that you bind Suo Gao and send him to me. If you refuse, I will dispatch a hundred thousand troops to lay siege to Anling." The Lord of Anling replied, "Our former lord, Marquis Cheng, received a decree from King Xiang to guard this city. He was handed the statutes of the Grand Treasury, which stated: 'Even if the state grants a general amnesty or a city surrenders, a son may not partake in it.' Now Suo Gao has declined high office to preserve the righteousness between father and son, yet you demand that I forcibly send him. This would make me violate King Xiang’s decree and abolish the statutes of the Grand Treasury. Though I die, I dare not comply." When Suo Gao heard this, he said, "Lord Xinling is fierce, impetuous, and self-willed. If I refuse and he retaliates, it will bring disaster to the state. I have already preserved my own integrity and not violated righteousness—how can I allow my lord to suffer Wei’s calamity?" He then slit his own throat and died.

The record states: Anling’s refusal to send Suo Gao was not superior to Hou Ying’s counsel to Lord Xinling? To accept a father’s favor, follow a lord’s command, and thereby attain high office—even a commoner would feel shame. Yet to instruct one’s minister to defy his lord’s command in pursuit of a vainglorious victory—would Hou Ying willingly do such a thing? The usurpations of Wang Mang, the fall of the Ji clan to Yin, the treachery of Zhai Yi, the betrayal of Bi Chen, and the cunning of Wuji—all were incited by Ying’s machinations. Had Wuji succeeded in his rebellion, could Ying have escaped blame? Could Zhai Yi have been rewarded? Could the Ji clan have treated it as child’s play? Could Bi Chen have remained idle? Thus we know that when a true king does not arise, such chaos emerges. The punishment of beheading without pardon—was this an excessive measure on the part of the sages?

During the rebellion of Tan Chi in Qi, King Min fled, and Wangsun Jia followed him. Later, they lost track of the king’s whereabouts. His mother said, "When you leave in the morning and return at dusk, I wait by the gate for you. When you leave at dusk and do not return, I wait by the lane for you. Now you serve the king, and the king has fled—yet you do not know where he is. Where, then, will you return?" Wangsun Jia then attacked and killed Tan Chi. Thereupon, Qi’s ministers sought King Min’s son, Fa Zhang, and enthroned him as the King of Qi. They defended Ju City against Yan.

The record states: What of Wangsun Jia’s mother compared to Lord Mengchang? In peacetime, he stole the state’s reputation, basking in glory and peril alike, acting as he pleased. Yet when the state was broken and the king fled, did he give it even a moment’s thought? That he ultimately killed Tan Chi, enthroned King Xiang, and defended Ju City against Yan—all was spurred by his mother’s sense of righteousness. Thus, those who wield the brush may well die of shame.

Some say: King Min wished to dismiss Wen, but Wen fled to Wei, so it was too late. I say: Could King Min truly have done so? Above, he saw not Heaven; below, he saw not Earth; in between, he saw not men—yet he saw Wen. Could King Min truly have done so? Then his mother’s words must have already planted the seed.

*Hongdao Record*, Scroll Eighteen, concludes.
*Hongdao Record*, Scroll Nineteen.

**On the Virtue of Father and Son**

From *The History of the Western Han*: During the reign of Emperor Wen, Jia Yi submitted a memorial stating: The Xia, Yin, and Zhou dynasties ruled as Sons of Heaven for dozens of generations, while the Qin, though also a Son of Heaven, perished after only two. Human nature is not so different—why then did the rulers of the Three Dynasties enjoy such long reigns through the Dao, while the Qin collapsed under tyranny? In ancient times, when the heir apparent was born, he was raised with ritual propriety. The officials, robed in solemn attire, presented him at the southern suburbs, and whenever he passed the palace gates, he dismounted; when he passed the ancestral temple, he hastened his steps. Thus, from infancy, he was taught the proper conduct. As soon as he could recognize things, the Three Dukes and Three Minors were appointed to instruct him in filial piety, benevolence, righteousness, and ritual, guiding him in the Dao while keeping him from evil influences. The court selected upright scholars from across the land—those of filial devotion, fraternal respect, broad learning, and mastery of the Dao—to attend him, sharing his residence and accompanying him in all his comings and goings. Thus, from birth, the heir apparent heard only upright words and walked only the right path, surrounded on all sides by virtuous men. This was why the Three Dynasties endured so long: they ensured the heir apparent was nurtured with such care. The Qin, however, did otherwise. They appointed Zhao Gao to tutor Hu Hai in the ways of the prison, so that all he learned was the execution of men—be it beheading, mutilation, or the extermination of entire clans. Thus, when Hu Hai ascended the throne, he began by shooting men for sport the very next day. Those who offered loyal remonstrance were branded as slanderers; those who probed his intentions were accused of uttering ominous words. To him, killing men was as effortless as reaping grass. Was this merely because Hu Hai was inherently evil? No—it was because the path he was led down was not the true Dao.

The *Record* states: Jia Yi’s memorial was profoundly prescient. In antiquity, the eldest sons of the Son of Heaven, the sons of the nobility, and even the most promising youths from the common folk all entered the Grand Academy, where they were taught the Dao of exhausting principle, rectifying the mind, cultivating the self, and governing others. By the decline of the Zhou, the teachings had decayed, and the Dao had long been abandoned—not only in the Qin. Even with Emperor Wen’s virtue, he could not heed Jia Yi’s counsel, a matter of deep regret for the noble-minded. Thus, this account is preserved here. Later, Emperor Jing executed ministers, altered the succession of the heir apparent, deposed and enthroned empresses, and indulged his favored younger brother—nearly repeating the Qin’s missteps. Who then could dismiss Jia Yi’s warnings as the folly of youth?

The Grand Mentor Shi Fen retired to his home, and whenever he passed the palace gates, he would dismount and hasten his steps; upon seeing the emperor’s carriage, he would bow in respect. When his sons and grandsons, who served as minor officials, returned to pay their respects, Shi Fen would receive them in full court attire, addressing them not by name. If they had faults, he would not rebuke them directly but would sit at the table without eating. Only then would his sons reproach one another, and the elders would bare their shoulders in apology, vowing to reform. Only after this would he permit his grown grandsons to remain in his presence. Even in private, he wore his cap with solemn dignity, while his servants and attendants were ever cheerful and reverent. When the court bestowed food upon his household, he would bow deeply and eat as though in the emperor’s presence. In mourning, his grief was profound, and his descendants followed his example. The Shi family became renowned across commanderies and kingdoms for their filial piety and reverence, so much so that even the Confucian scholars of Qi and Lu, famed for their moral conduct, considered themselves inferior.

His eldest son, Jian, served as Prefect of the Palace Gentlemen; his youngest, Qing, as Prefect of the Capital. When Jian was old and gray, Shi Fen was still in good health. Every five days, Jian would return home for his rest day, entering his son’s quarters in secret to inquire of the attendants. He would personally tend to his son’s garments and even clean his chamber pot, then return it to the servants, never letting Shi Fen know—this was his regular practice. Once, Qing returned home drunk and did not dismount at the outer gate. Shi Fen, upon hearing of this, refused to eat. Qing, terrified, bared his shoulders in apology, but Shi Fen would not forgive him. The entire clan, including his elder brother Jian, bared their shoulders in remorse. Shi Fen rebuked them, saying: "When a high official of the palace enters a village, even the elders flee in haste—yet the Prefect of the Capital sits in his carriage as though nothing were amiss. Is this not cause for apology?" He then dismissed Qing and his sons, ordering them to walk home from the village gate. Only then did he relent.

The *Record* states: Observing the aftermath of the Qin’s destruction, when even the families of executed criminals were eradicated, and yet the Shi family upheld such ritual propriety, one glimpses the innate nature of the human heart. Had men like him been entrusted with the education of the heir apparent and the instruction of the feudal lords—following the example of Bo Qin’s strict discipline of the crown prince—would not the customs of the Han dynasty have been nearly cured? Yet how lamentable that they merely saw the effortless practice of personal conduct as insignificant, unaware that it was not mere empty words of "serene mystery" but the very essence of inborn nature and practical utility. They grew weary of the ornate discourses of the Confucians, never realizing that these were rooted in the fundamental virtues inherent to human nature.

Appointing Jian as Chamberlain for Attendants and Qing as Prefect of the Capital—such posts of court service and fiscal administration—how much benefit could they truly bring to the state? No wonder Yi lamented with bitter tears. Let this be recorded.

Jin Midi was originally the eldest son of the Xiongnu chieftain Xiutu. His mother, Lady Guan, instructed her children with strict discipline. Midi revered his mother and practiced filial devotion. Emperor Wu, hearing of this, commended him and ordered his portrait painted in the Gansui Palace. Each time Midi passed the painting, he would bow and weep before departing. Later, Midi’s eldest son became a playmate of Emperor Wu. As the boy grew older, he once frolicked with palace women beneath the hall. Midi, chancing upon the scene, killed him on the spot. The emperor was enraged, but when Midi explained his reasons, the emperor wept and came to respect him even more.

Let this be recorded: Observing Midi’s conduct, one realizes that even among the barbarians, familial bonds endure, unlike in the Central States where they have vanished. The merits of Cheng Ji and the loyalty of Xuan Meng went unmemorialized—was this not due to the licentiousness of Yuan Tong and Ping Kuo with Lady Zhuang? The descendants of Kang Shu and the lineage of Zhurong were utterly extinguished—was this not because of Gongzi Wan’s incest with his lord’s mother? What place was this, if not the palace hall? What manner of women were these, to be treated with such familiarity as if no one would hear? Midi and [Hu] Guang were equally unlearned—was it that Guang lacked refinement while Midi possessed discernment? The difference lay solely in resolve or hesitation, in forbearance or its absence. Thus it is said: "To hesitate when one should act is to invite chaos." And again: "Lack of restraint in small matters disrupts great plans." These words require no study to comprehend.

Wei Xian and his son Xuancheng both rose to the rank of Chancellor through mastery of the Classics. Hence the saying in Zou and Lu: "Leaving your son gold is not as good as leaving him a single Classic." Xian was simple and frugal, devoted to learning, and renowned as a great Confucian. Summoned as an Erudite, he was ordered to instruct the emperor in the *Book of Songs*. During Emperor Xuan’s reign, he was held in high esteem. In the third year of *Benshi*, he became Chancellor and was enfeoffed as Marquis of Fuyang. After five years in office, he petitioned to retire due to old age and illness.
