The resignation of a Chancellor began with Xian. Xuancheng was even more modest and deferential to scholars. His elder brother Hong, serving as Assistant to the Minister of Ceremonies, was the rightful heir, but when Xian fell gravely ill, the family favored Xuancheng. The emperor issued an edict summoning him for investiture, yet Xuancheng declined, only accepting the title under duress. Emperor Xuan admired his integrity and appointed him Governor of Henan, while Hong became Governor of Donghai.

Initially, the emperor favored his concubine Zhang Jie, whose son, Prince Xian of Huaiyang, excelled in governance and was well-versed in law. The emperor marveled at his talent and considered naming him heir, yet the crown prince had risen from humble origins and lost his mother early, so the emperor could not bear to replace him. After some time, wishing to subtly influence the prince, he assigned Xuancheng—known for his propriety and deference—as Commandant of Huaiyang. When Emperor Yuan ascended the throne, Xuancheng succeeded his father as Chancellor within a decade and was enfeoffed as a marquis. Thus, their family’s glory flourished in that era.

Let this be recorded: In the Han dynasty, only Gongsun [Hong] and the Wei father and son held the Chancellorship through mastery of the Classics. Xian, though aged, wielded authority for five years before retiring—a matter of praise in his time. How could one expect him to propose reforms? Xuancheng served for seven years, maintaining integrity and prudence, though not matching his father’s steadfastness; his literary grace, however, surpassed it. The Chancellorship is a role that upholds Heaven and Earth above and nurtures the myriad things below—should it be reduced to mere literary display? Yet this was the criterion for selecting scholars. Thus, throughout the Han, no Chancellor left a mark on governance; they either timidly preserved themselves or followed old precedents. No wonder the Way of governance stagnated at this level.

In the *Records of the Grand Historian*, Sima Tan served during the *Jianyuan* and *Yuanfeng* eras. Distressed that scholars failed to grasp the essentials and their teachers led them astray, he analyzed the key doctrines of the Six Schools: Yin-Yang, Confucian, Mohist, Logicians, Legalists, and Daoists. The Grand Scribe oversaw the celestial offices and did not govern the people. He had a son named Qian, born in Longmen, who herded livestock on the northern slopes of the Yellow River. At ten, he recited ancient texts; at twenty, he journeyed south to the Jiang and Huai, ascended Mount Kuaiji, explored Yu’s cave, visited Jiuyi, and sailed the Yuan and Xiang rivers. He traveled north to the Wen and Si, studied in the capitals of Qi and Lu, observed Confucius’s legacy, and passed through Liang and Chu before returning. Thereafter, Qian served as a Gentleman of the Palace and was dispatched on a mission to the lands south of Ba and Shu, returning to report. That year, the emperor initiated the Feng and Shan sacrifices for the Han house, but the Grand Scribe was detained in Zhounan and could not participate. Frustrated, he fell ill and died. His son Qian had just returned from his mission and met his father in the region of the Yellow and Luo rivers. The Grand Scribe took Qian’s hand and wept, saying: "Our ancestors were Grand Scribes of the Zhou house. From ancient times, they achieved renown under Yu and Xia, overseeing the celestial offices. In later generations, our line declined..."

The present Son of Heaven has inherited a lineage spanning a thousand generations and performed the Feng sacrifice upon Mount Tai, yet I was not permitted to accompany him—such is fate. When I die, you must become the Grand Scribe. As Grand Scribe, do not forget what I wished to discuss and record. The world extols the Duke of Zhou for his ability to eulogize the virtue of Kings Wen and Wu, propagate the customs of the Zhou and Shao, and convey the aspirations of King Tai and King Ji, extending even to Gong Liu in reverence for Hou Ji. After the reigns of You and Li, the royal Way declined, rites and music decayed, and Confucius compiled the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, which scholars to this day take as their standard. More than four hundred years have passed since the capture of the unicorn, during which the feudal lords annexed one another, and the historical records have fallen into disuse. Now, with the rise of the Han, the realm is unified under one rule. Yet I, as Grand Scribe, have failed to record the enlightened sovereigns, worthy rulers, loyal ministers, and those who died for righteousness. To neglect the literary heritage of the world fills me with dread—you must take heed!

Qian bowed his head, tears streaming, and said: "Though this unworthy son lacks talent, I will exhaustively record all that my father has arranged and preserved, without daring to omit anything."

Three years later, Qian was appointed Grand Scribe and meticulously examined the records stored in the stone chambers and golden caskets. He did not abandon his father’s words, for what he undertook was to narrate past events and order the traditions of the ages—this was not creation, but transmission. Thus, he arranged and composed his work.

After seven years, he suffered the disaster of Li Ling. Retreating, he deeply pondered the subtle meanings of the *Book of Songs* and the *Book of Documents*, determined to fulfill his aspirations. In ancient times, King Wen of Zhou was imprisoned at Youli and expounded the *Book of Changes*; Confucius was besieged between Chen and Cai and composed the *Spring and Autumn Annals*; Qu Yuan was exiled and wrote the *Li Sao*; Zuo Qiu lost his sight and produced the *Discourses of the States*; Sun Bin had his kneecaps removed and discussed *The Art of War*; Lü Buwei was banished to Shu, and his *Lüshi Chunqiu* was transmitted to later generations; Han Fei was imprisoned in Qin and wrote *Shui Nan* and *Gu Fen*. The three hundred poems of the *Book of Songs* were, for the most part, the works of worthies and sages giving vent to their indignation. Thus, by recounting past events, one contemplates those to come.

He ultimately traced the lineage from the era of Emperor Yao to the capture of the unicorn, beginning with the Yellow Emperor. He composed twelve *Basic Annals*, ten *Tables*, eight *Treatises*, thirty *Hereditary Houses*, and seventy *Biographies*, totaling one hundred and thirty chapters. These he deposited in the famous mountains and kept a copy in the capital, awaiting the sage-kings and noble scholars of later ages.

**Record:** According to Sima Qian’s own account: The Han succeeded the legacy of the Five Emperors and continued the heritage of the Three Dynasties. The Qin destroyed ancient texts, scattering the archives of the Bright Hall, golden caskets, stone chambers, jade tablets, and maps. After the rise of the Han, Xiao He, Han Xin, Zhang Cang, and Shusun Tong, over the course of a hundred years, gradually advanced the refinement of literature. The *Book of Songs* and *Book of Documents* began to reappear. At that time, no remnant texts or ancient affairs were not gathered by the Grand Scribe, who continued the compilation of his office. Though he had received this duty by inheritance, he was still driven by indignation over the partisan disaster to complete his one hundred and thirty-chapter work. How could later scholars dare to face the wall in ignorance?

When the Ban family later continued the work, they fully adopted his text. Later, Du Yu’s *Comprehensive Institutions*, Zheng Qiao’s *Comprehensive Records*, and Ma Duanlin’s *Comprehensive Studies* were all commissioned by imperial decree to be preserved in the Three Archives, with scribes and writing materials provided by the Imperial Secretariat for transcription. Wang Anshi’s *Comprehensive Mirror*, Zhu Xi’s *Outline and Details*, and Hu Anguo’s *Commentary on the Spring and Autumn Annals* were all collaboratively edited by their disciples, sons, and even sons-in-law. Alas, how flourishing it was!

Now, some may have the ambition to strive but lack the strength to achieve; some may have the talent to exert themselves but find the records insufficient to support their efforts; some may be trustworthy themselves but find others’ preferences untrustworthy. In such cases, they can only harbor their aspirations. The noble person should not merely admire the talents of the ancients nor complacently accept the limitations of the present. Where effort is possible, one must strive; where preparation is possible, one must prepare; where trust is possible, one must be trustworthy. Only then may one approach the status of a school of thought, however modest.

Liu Xiang’s three sons—Ji, Ci, and Xin—all loved learning, but Xin was the most renowned. Father and sons were both devoted to antiquity. Appointed by imperial decree to oversee the collation of the secret archives, they lectured on the Six Arts, the *Records*, the various masters, poetry, rhapsodies, numerology, and esoteric techniques, exploring all without exception. After Liu Xiang’s death, Xin continued to oversee the Five Classics, completing his father’s work. They all began with the *Book of Changes*.

During the reign of Emperor Xuan, Xin was ordered to study the *Guliang Commentary on the Spring and Autumn Annals*. Upon encountering the ancient text of the *Zuo Tradition of the Spring and Autumn Annals*, he greatly admired it. Initially, the *Zuo Tradition* contained many archaic characters and expressions, and scholars merely explained its glosses. From then on, he began to cite the *Tradition* to elucidate the *Annals*, mutually clarifying their meanings, so that the chapters, sentences, and principles were fully expounded. Xin was deeply learned, with a broad vision and strong resolve, surpassing others. He once argued that Zuo Qiuming’s likes and dislikes aligned with the Sage and that he had personally seen Confucius, whereas the Gongyang and Guliang commentaries were transmitted by disciples among the Seventy, and thus the difference between hearsay and firsthand observation accounted for their varying levels of detail. He frequently posed difficult questions to Liu Xiang, who could not refute them.

**Record:** Ban Gu’s eulogy states: Confucius said, "It is difficult to speak with villagers." Since then, those who have continued the literary tradition include only Meng Ke, Sun Qing, Dong Zhongshu, Sima Qian, Liu Xiang, and Yang Xiong. These several masters were all broadly learned, widely informed, and well-versed in ancient and modern affairs. Their words were of benefit to the world.

The *Tradition* says: "If a sage does not appear in the world, there must be those destined for their era." Liu Xin’s *Discourse on the Great Plan* elucidated the *Great Transmission*, expounding the correspondence between Heaven and humanity. His *Seven Summaries* categorized the arts and literature, synthesizing the threads of the hundred schools. His *Investigation of the Three Sequences and the Star Calendar* calculated the movements of the sun, moon, and five planets, demonstrating his intent to trace their origins. Alas! Liu Xiang’s warnings about the dangers of imperial tombs are now all too evident.

The pointing to the pillars of catalpa and cedar makes the rise and fall clear—was this not the fruit of forthright integrity and the benefit of broad learning, to be observed and pondered? All that Liu Xiang had said in his memorials, both earlier and later, was marked by loyalty, earnestness, and sincerity; why did Heaven not protect him? Yet in the end, his words came to nothing—this was surely Heaven’s rejection, not something men could have prevented. His son Liu Xin changed his name to fulfill a prophecy and become a teacher, seeking favor in...—how shameful!

The *Later Han History* records Zheng Xuan’s admonition to his son Zheng Yien: “Our family was once poor and not tolerated by my parents or brothers. I left home to serve as a menial clerk, traveling to study in the capitals of Zhou and Qin, journeying through You, Bing, and the regions of Yan and Yu. There I met eminent scholars and great masters, receiving instruction from them. Thus I broadly studied the Six Arts, roughly perused the commentaries and records, and occasionally glimpsed the mysteries of the apocrypha and weft texts. Only after the age of forty did I return to care for my parents. For fourteen years, I was confined by the party proscription. Twice summoned by the imperial carriage, my name appeared alongside others’—I was nearly made a minister. Those several masters possessed noble virtue, worthy of serving as royal ministers, and thus were fittingly ranked in order. As for myself, I reflect and find no capacity for such a role. Yet I am mindful of expounding the original intent of the former sages and harmonizing the inconsistencies among the hundred schools—this is perhaps the utmost I can do with my abilities. But the Yellow Turbans brought chaos, and I drifted north and south before returning to my homeland. Now, at seventy, my strength and vitality have waned. According to the ritual canons, I should pass on my learning to my family. Now I tell you this in my old age: I will retire to cultivate my nature and devote myself to completing my work. Alas, you are but a solitary man, with no siblings to rely on. Strive most earnestly for the Dao of the noble person; study diligently without ceasing. Be reverent and cautious in your bearing, drawing near to those of virtue. Let your reputation shine among your peers, and establish virtue in your own resolve. If you achieve renown, it will bring honor to your parents—how could you not reflect deeply on this? If you neglect or forget this, then so be it.”

The record states: Observing Zheng Xuan’s writings during his lifetime, the difficulties he addressed amounted to over a million words. In his final years, he was deeply distressed that his beloved books had all decayed, and he could not transcribe and finalize them in the Hall of Ritual to pass on to others. He only sighed that the sun was setting in the west and, with this intent, admonished his son—he never sought recognition from others. Later, when Zheng Yien rushed to the aid of Beihai, he perished, and the family’s fortune dwindled, leaving nothing to rely on. Yet the commentaries he wrote on the Thirteen Classics and other treatises left no trace for later generations. As Confucius said, “If no one recognizes you, strive to be worthy of recognition.” Throughout his life, he had no desire for official robes and caps, and his noble act of declining a marquisate was not excessive. Compared to Ma Rong, who was ashamed of modest scholars yet indulged in luxury and self-gratification, and was ultimately ridiculed—he cannot be mentioned in the same breath.

Ban Biao was highly talented and fond of writing, devoting himself to historical works. After Sima Qian’s *Records of the Grand Historian* left off at the beginning of the *Taichu* era, the gap remained unfilled. Some enthusiasts had pieced together contemporary events, but their work was crude and vulgar, unworthy of continuing his book. Ban Biao thus gathered remnants of earlier histories and wove in diverse accounts, composing *Later Traditions* in dozens of chapters. He weighed and corrected the strengths and weaknesses of previous histories. After Ban Biao’s death, his son Ban Gu, finding his father’s continuation of the earlier history insufficiently detailed, secretly refined his thoughts, intending to complete the work. Later, someone accused Ban Gu of privately composing a national history. An edict was issued to the commandery to arrest him and seize all his family’s books. Ban Gu’s younger brother Ban Chao, fearing the commandery would torture him without cause, hurried to the capital to submit a memorial. He was granted an audience and fully explained Ban Gu’s intent in his writings. The commandery also submitted Ban Gu’s work, and Emperor Ming was greatly impressed. He summoned Ban Gu to the Imperial Library, where he served as a clerk alongside the former magistrate of Suiyang, Chen Zong; the magistrate of Ling, Yin Min; and the Attendant Officer of the Commandant of Justice, Meng Yi. Together, they completed the *Basic Annals of Emperor Guangwu*. Ban Gu was later promoted to Gentleman and tasked with collating the imperial archives. He composed twenty-eight chapters of biographies and memoirs, which he presented to the throne. The emperor then ordered him to complete the work his father had begun. Ban Gu believed that the Han had inherited the mandate of Yao to establish an imperial enterprise, reaching its sixth generation. Yet the historian had traced its merits and virtues, privately composing basic annals and placing them at the end of the hundred kings, alongside the ranks of Qin and Xiang Yu. Therefore, he explored earlier records, weaving together what he had heard to create the *History of the Han*, beginning with Emperor Gaozu and ending with Emperor Xiaoping—twelve generations spanning 230 years. He synthesized their deeds, interwove the Five Classics, and modeled it after the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, comprising annals, tables, treatises, and biographies in a total of one hundred chapters. From the *Yongping* era, when he received the imperial commission, he devoted over twenty years of thought to it, completing it during the *Jianchu* era. His work was highly esteemed by his contemporaries, and scholars all recited it.

The record states: Observing the works of Ban [Gu] and Sima [Qian], both had their precursors. Their painstaking refinement and deep thought are nothing extraordinary. Yet Emperor Ming’s severity was such that, instead of pardoning Ban Gu’s personal offense, he granted him the authority to compose history—this is unheard of throughout the ages. When Confucius wrote the *Spring and Autumn Annals* and Zuo Qiuming composed the *Discourses of the States*, they recorded events of their own time, which should have been avoided out of deference. Yet the eras they encountered were declining—if one were to be punished for such things, what would become of them? Thus, considering Hu Sui’s criticism of Sima Qian’s words, a noble person cannot but be cautious.

Ma Yuan’s nephews, Ma Yan and Ma Dun, both enjoyed mocking others and were reckless in their conduct. Ma Yuan wrote to admonish them: “When you hear of others’ faults, let it be as if you heard your parents’ names—your ears may hear, but your mouth must not speak. To delight in discussing others’ strengths and weaknesses, or recklessly judging the right and wrong of governance—this is what I most detest. I would rather die than hear of my descendants behaving this way. Long Bogao is honest, sincere, and cautious; his words are faultless. He is modest, frugal, incorruptible, and dignified. I love and esteem him—may you emulate him.”

Du Jiliang was a chivalrous man who loved righteousness, shared others’ sorrows, and rejoiced in their joys. When his father died, guests from several commanderies attended the funeral. I love and esteem him, yet I do not wish you to emulate him. If you fail to match Bogao’s conduct, you may still become a cautious and disciplined gentleman—like one who carves a magpie but falls short, yet still resembles a quail. But if you fail to match Jiliang, you will sink into the ranks of the world’s frivolous and dissolute—like one who paints a tiger but ends up with a dog. It is recorded: Though Yuan was so cautious and disciplined, he could not escape slander after his death—why? In his prime, he sought to settle in a frontier commandery to farm and herd, for he had not yet achieved his ambitions. Thus, his old resolve was that adversity would only make him firmer, and age would only make him stronger—who could take that from him? Yet when he committed himself to serving others, he became bound by his station. Though he longed to die in battle, wrapped in horsehide and content to close his eyes, how could all his wishes be fulfilled? Having once volunteered for service and shown himself ready in the saddle, slanderers seized the chance to malign him. This ruin he brought upon himself in seeking perfection resembles the case of the carved magpie—had it not been for Zhu Bo’s defense, would it not have been like painting a tiger and ending with a dog? This only confirms that even with caution and discipline, one may still fall short—how then can reckless chivalry be justified?

During Emperor Ling’s great purge of the partisans, an urgent edict ordered the arrest of Fan Pang and others. When the supervising officer Wu Dao arrived at the county, he clutched the edict, shut himself in the post station, and wept in the woods. Hearing of this, Pang said, “It must be for me.” He immediately turned himself in to the prison. The county magistrate Guo Ji was shocked, removed his official seal and sash, and urged Pang to flee with him, saying, “The Son of Heaven is vast—why should you remain here?” Pang replied, “If I die, the disaster will end. How dare I implicate you or leave my aged mother to wander?” His mother came to bid him farewell. Pang said to her, “My younger brother Zhongbo is not filial enough to support you. Now I follow Lord Longshu to the Yellow Springs, and each of us will be where we belong. I only ask that you, Mother, set aside your reluctance and not grieve too deeply.” His mother said, “Now you share the same fame as Li and Du—what regret could there be in death? You have already earned a fine reputation—can you also seek long life? Can both be attained?” Pang knelt to receive her teaching, bowed twice, and took his leave. Turning to his son, he said, “I would have you do evil, but evil must not be done. I would have you do good, but I have not done evil myself.” Those who heard this on the road could not help but weep.

It is recorded: People praise Fan Pang’s mother for her righteousness. I think her words were spoken out of necessity. Had she cherished his life, what good would it have done? Why not instead say: “Life’s length is determined by fate and duty. Even Yan Hui, who did good, fared no better than you. Fate comes from Heaven—do not blame yourself. Is this not understanding?” As for Li and Du, they lived through the same peril—why compare their deaths? Moreover, fame is but a single word, yet it sowed the seeds of disaster—such words should not have been spoken. What I privately rejoice in is that Zhongbo had a son, Longshu, a true man. The virtuous have descendants—this is not extinction. Otherwise, to suffer a premature death in the prime of life—would this not move all who walk the path to tears, and cause pain for ten thousand generations?

*The Book of Jin* records: Wang Bao’s father, Yi, served as Sima Zhao’s adjutant when the latter was General of Pacifying the East. After the defeat at Dongguan, Zhao asked the assembled officers, “Who bears the blame for today’s outcome?” Yi replied, “The responsibility lies with the commander-in-chief.” Zhao angrily said, “Does Sima intend to shift the blame onto me?” He had Yi dragged out and executed. Bao grieved deeply over his father’s unjust death. He withdrew to live in seclusion, teaching students, and declined three imperial summonses and seven offers of office. He built a hut beside his father’s grave, visiting it morning and evening to kneel and weep, clutching the trees in sorrow until his tears stained them and the trees withered. When reading the *Book of Songs* and coming to the line *“Alas for my father and mother, who toiled so hard to raise me,”* he would always reread it and weep. His disciples, studying under him, all abandoned the *“Liao and Biao”* chapters. Though poor, he tilled the land himself, farming only enough to feed his household and raising silkworms only enough to clothe them. When others secretly tried to aid him, Bao refused. After the Sima clan usurped the Wei throne, Bao never once sat facing west, to show he would not serve the Jin as a subject.

It is recorded: Wang Xiang was filial, yet when he became one of the Three Dukes, he treated his lord as a mere discarded hat or clod of earth, not even as steadfast as when he cut through ice to seek carp. Meng Zong was worthy, yet when he became a grandee, Sun Lin of Wu deposed Jing and had the matter announced at the ancestral temple before carrying it out—was this as compliant as when he wept over bamboo and moved Heaven? Then was Bao’s lifelong refusal to face west merely the result of reciting *“Alas for my father and mother”*?

The Inspector of Yanzhou, Wang Shu, was a cautious and honest man. He named his brother’s sons Mo and Chen, and his own sons Hun and Shen. In a letter, he admonished them: “I have given you these four names so that you will reflect on their meaning and never dare to transgress. Things that grow quickly perish quickly; those that mature late endure. Morning flowers wither by evening, but the pine and cypress remain lush even in the cold. Thus, the noble person is ever vigilant. To bend is to stretch, to yield is to gain, and to be weak is to be strong—few fail to succeed thus. Slander and praise are the roots of love and hate, and the pivot of fortune and misfortune. Confucius said, ‘Of the people I have met, who has slandered or praised me?’ Even a sage of such virtue was thus—how much more so for ordinary men? If someone slanders you, withdraw and examine yourself. If you have conduct worthy of slander, then their words are justified. If you have no such conduct, then their words are baseless. If justified, bear no grudge; if baseless, it does no harm. Why retaliate?”

The proverb says: "To ward off cold, nothing surpasses a thick fur; to silence slander, nothing surpasses self-cultivation." These words are truly trustworthy.

The record states: "Chang’s instruction to his son was as if preparing for a grand sacrifice." The four virtues—silence, profundity, depth, and simplicity—all embody the essence of modesty, humility, and refraining from self-boasting. Therefore, one should aspire to be like the sea, which receives a hundred rivers yet never appears full; or like a great cavern, which traverses ten thousand li yet never reaches its end. Only with such magnanimity and generosity can one attain the noble refinement of simplicity and the vast elegance of aid. If one applies this to the pursuit of merit and fame, one becomes a person of the Dao; if one expands it to embrace others with tolerance, one embodies the demeanor of a true elder. How could this not enhance one’s worthiness?

Yet if one borrows the ways of the vulgar, indulges in shame and resentment, one cannot escape the ridicule of contemporaries. And when reduced to a minor role in governance, crying out for recognition day after day, one instantly forfeits the very meaning of one’s name.

Alas!

*The Old Book of Tang* records: In the twenty-second year of the Zhenguan era, the Emperor composed twelve chapters of *The Emperor’s Model* and bestowed them upon the Crown Prince, saying: "The ruler’s conduct should be founded on reverence for kin, the seeking of worthies, the careful selection of officials, the acceptance of remonstrance, the rejection of slander, the avoidance of excess, the exaltation of frugality, the strictness of rewards and punishments, the prioritization of agriculture, and the honoring of both martial and literary arts." He further declared: "Self-cultivation and state governance are fully encompassed herein." If one adheres to even a single precept without deviation, what more need be said?

The Emperor further admonished: "You must seek out the ancient sagely rulers as your teachers, for I am not worthy of emulation. To take the highest as one’s model is merely to attain the middle; to take the middle as one’s model is to sink inevitably to the lowest. Since ascending the throne, my failings have been many. Brocade, pearls, and jade have never left my presence; palaces, halls, terraces, and pavilions have been repeatedly constructed; hounds, horses, hawks, and falcons have been procured from the farthest reaches. My travels in the four directions have imposed heavy burdens on the people. These are all grave errors of mine—do not regard them as right and follow them. Yet I have broadly succored the common people, and my benefits have been great; I have established order in the land, and my achievements have been vast. The gains outweigh the losses, so the people bear no resentment. The merits overshadow the faults, so the enterprise remains unblemished. Nevertheless, compared to perfect goodness, I am deeply ashamed. You have not my toil and merit, yet you inherit my wealth and nobility. Exert yourself in goodness, and the state may barely be preserved; indulge in arrogance, idleness, extravagance, and dissipation, and you will not even secure your own person. Moreover, a state is slow to be established but quick to fall; rank is easily lost but difficult to regain. How can you not cherish this? How can you not be cautious?"

The record states: Emperor Taizong’s instruction of the Crown Prince may be called consummate. Yet it is regrettable that in the Way of the ruler, he seems never to have heard of its true essence. The Way of the noble person begins with the relationship between husband and wife, and in its ultimate reach, it discerns the workings of Heaven and Earth. This is how the sages of high antiquity penetrated both high and low, proceeding from within to without, from the family to the court, and thus left no flaw. Now, observe how from "the ruler’s conduct founded on reverence for kin" to "the honoring of both martial and literary arts," all is set forth in full. Again, from the most trivial faults to the most manifest achievements, nothing is concealed—this may be called thoroughness itself. Yet never once does he touch upon the Way of governing the household. Could it be that the Emperor’s wisdom did not extend to this? The disaster at Wutai arose from turning the blade of *Chao Ci* back upon the nest; the words of family affairs hastened the plot to coerce the father. Not only was instruction incomplete, but even the prophecies and omens offered no remedy. Thus the noble persons of ancient Ye made it their sole duty to rectify the heart and sincerely embody virtue, to be cautious in solitude and vigilant in the slightest matters, never allowing a single thought to stray into carelessness. Only then did they proceed to ordering the state and pacifying the realm, maintaining a single thread throughout without omission. This was precisely what the Emperor alone neglected, and therein lay the deep calamity of the Tang.

Zheng Shan’guo’s father, Zheng Cheng, was a general of the Zhou dynasty who died in battle against Yuchi Jue. Shan’guo inherited his father’s title. When he later served as governor of Lu Commandery, his mother, Lady Cui, would sit behind a screen each time he held court, observing his judgments. If his rulings were just, she would return home overjoyed; if his conduct was unfair or he indulged in reckless anger, she would weep and refuse to eat. Shan’guo would prostrate himself before her bed and say: "Your late husband was upright and incorruptible in office, devoting himself to the state. You, from childhood, inherited his noble rank and now hold the position of regional governor—how can you recklessly indulge in anger, undermining public governance, disgracing the family’s legacy, and violating the Son of Heaven’s laws? With what face will you meet your late husband?" Thereafter, Shan’guo mastered his conduct and became renowned as an upright official.

Cui Xuanmei’s mother, Lady Lu, once admonished her son, saying: "I heard my cousin Xin Xuanyu say: ‘When a descendant holds office, if people say he is poor and unable to support himself, this is good news. If they say his wealth and possessions are abundant, this is bad news.’ I have always regarded this as a sound judgment. Recently, I have seen among our relatives those who amass wealth to provide for their parents, yet their parents do not inquire into its source. If it comes from their official salary, that is well. But if not, how is it different from theft? If you serve as an official and cannot be loyal and upright, you will have no ground to stand beneath Heaven and Earth. Take heed of my words." Thus, wherever Cui Xuanmei served, he became known for his integrity and purity.

The Record states: Zheng Shan’guo’s mother turned pale at the mention of tigers, for she bore wounds from them—thus her words were fierce. Cui Xuanmei’s mother, upon seeing worthies, sought to emulate them, for she had received their influence—thus her words were gentle. Both sons ultimately became known for their purity. Truly, the subtle teachings of the inner chambers are not in vain. Moreover, Xuanmei later corrected the course of the state, deposing the usurper and rendering great service to the Tang. Compared to Shan’guo, whose integrity faltered in his later years, he proved the superior.

Han Xiu had seven sons—Hao, Qia, Hong, Gong, Kuang, Hun, and Dong—all of whom were learned and prized fidelity and righteousness above all else in their time. When An Lushan rebelled, they were trapped and pressured by the rebels to accept office, but they refused and fled to the imperial court-in-exile, only to be captured. Hao, Hong, and Hun were all killed. Emperor Suzong, honoring the sons of a great minister who died for their loyalty, posthumously appointed Hao as Vice Minister of the Ministry of Personnel, Hong as Minister of Rites, and Hun as Vice Minister of Rites. Gong later became a Grand Master of Remonstrance, Qia ended his career as a Palace Censor, Dong as Grand Master of Sacrifices, and Kuang was promoted in the first year of the Zhenyuan era to Left Vice Director of the Department of State Affairs and concurrent Grand Chancellor. Kuang was frugal by nature, living in humble quarters that barely sheltered him from wind and rain. Though his residence qualified for the honor of displaying ceremonial halberds, he refused to request a grand hall, unwilling to alter the gate built in his father’s time. He had no mulberry or hemp fields; when his younger brother Dong made minor repairs, Kuang removed them, saying: "Our late father dwelt here. We serve him still, ever fearful of neglect. If the structure collapses, we shall repair it—but how dare we rebuild and mar the virtue of frugality?"

Though he held high office, he remained incorruptible, detesting evil, and never amassed wealth for his family. Early in his tenure as Director of the Bureau of Finance, Li Chen, a subordinate general, reported military matters to Kuang, treating him with great deference. He had his son bow to Kuang and presented lavish gifts of vessels, silk, and horses. Later, Chen rendered great service to the state. From his youth, Kuang bore a fine reputation, and in his later years, he further refined his family’s standards, rigorously instructing his descendants. Thus, during the Zhenyuan era, when people spoke of exemplary family traditions, they would say: "The Han and the Mu."

Mu Ning had four sons—Zan, Zhi, Yuan, and Shang—all renowned as Confucians, yet each took it upon himself to uphold integrity and moral resolve. Having passed the classics examination, Zhi was appointed magistrate of Guanshan. While passing through Pingyuan, he visited Yan Zhenqing. Upon hearing of An Lushan’s rebellion, he entrusted his sons to Zhenqing and instructed his mother and younger brother: "So long as my descendants are not wanting, that is enough." He then hastened to Zhenqing and said: "My father has heirs. Now I may follow you to death." Later, when Zhenqing crossed the river to meet Emperor Suzong, the emperor, struck by his resolve, appointed him Grand Master of Remonstrance. When Emperor Dezong fled to Fengtian, Ning rushed to the court-in-exile and was promoted to Vice Director of the Palace Library and Right Grand Master of the Crown Prince’s Household, serving until his old age.

Zan became Vice Censor-in-Chief, Zhi served as Right Rectifier of Omissions, Yuan as Supervising Censor, and Shang as Investigating Censor—all revered by the gentry for their adherence to the Dao and their conduct. Zan was the most filial and prudent; Zhi, resolute and upright; Yuan, skilled in literature; and Shang, devoted to fidelity and righteousness. Each earned a fine reputation, harmonious yet refined, likened in their time to rare delicacies. Zan, plain yet structured, was compared to cheese; Zhi, rich and substantial, to butter; Yuan, to fine wine; and Shang, to fermented bean curd. In their father Ning’s daily life, he often admonished his household, instructing his sons: "In serving one’s parents, the greatest duty is to nurture their will. My will is for the straight path alone. If I were to bend the Way, even offerings of three sacrificial animals and nine roasted meats would not be true nurturance."

The Record states: Xiu was a chief minister of his generation, and his family’s strict discipline had deep roots. Ning was merely a scholar—why should he be ranked alongside the Han? Yet fidelity and righteousness in Heaven and Earth are the same for the commoner as for the duke. Thus, only after the bleakness of winter’s desolation does the blossoming of spring unfold. Xiu pledged his state through righteousness; Ning pledged his life to his friend through death. Their towering integrity in matters of personal conduct could serve as the trunk of a tree or the face of a cliff. Others may blend as broth and season as salt and plum—no wonder they stand beyond doubt.

All regarded them as rare delicacies.

Yet was there not meaning in the sayings of that time?

*Hongdao Record*, Scroll Nineteen—concluded
*Hongdao Record*, Scroll Twenty

**Virtue: The Bond of Father and Son**

From *The History of the Song*: The mother of the Great Ancestor, Empress Dowager Zhaoxian of the Du clan, governed her household with stern discipline and strict order. She bore five sons: the eldest, the Great Ancestor; then Kuangji, Guangyi, Guangmei, and Kuangzan.

When the Great Ancestor ascended the throne, he honored her as Empress Dowager. As he paid homage before her in the hall, all present offered congratulations, but she alone wore a solemn, joyless expression. Those around her said, “We have heard that a mother is ennobled through her son. Now that your son is the Son of Heaven, why do you not rejoice?”

The Empress Dowager replied, “I have heard that to be a ruler is difficult. The Son of Heaven stands above the myriad people. If he governs with the Dao, then this position is truly worthy of reverence. But if he loses control, even to be a commoner would be beyond reach. This is why I worry.”

The Great Ancestor bowed twice and said, “I humbly receive your instruction.”

The *Record* states: The Empress Dowager had witnessed the chaos of the Five Dynasties, where even families—mother and child—could not protect one another. Thus, she offered this admonition. Yet in *The Counsels of Great Yu*, the first principle is to “overcome difficulty.” The Empress Dowager not only understood the way of a mother but also the way of a ruler. By establishing this teaching, the Song dynasty avoided external disasters like those of the Lü, Wang, Wu, and Wei clans, and internally produced worthy ministers such as Gao, Cao, Xiang, and Meng. All this was inspired by the Empress Dowager’s exemplary conduct. How could the historians’ praise of Zhaoxian’s enduring influence be exaggerated?

When Emperor Taizong fell gravely ill, the Palace Attendant Wang Jienn, fearing the crown prince’s intelligence, secretly conspired with the Assistant Director of the Chancellery Li Changling, the Palace Commander Li Jixun, and the Academician Hu Dan to enthrone the former crown prince, Prince Chu, Yuanzuo. The Chancellor Lü Duan, visiting the emperor in the palace, noticed the crown prince was not in attendance. Suspecting treachery, he wrote the character “critical” (*dajian*) on a note and sent a trusted aide to summon the prince to the emperor’s side.

When the emperor passed, the Empress Dowager ordered Jienn to summon Lü Duan to discuss the succession. Duan, aware of the plot, deceived Jienn into entering the archives, then locked him inside and stationed guards. He hastened to the palace.

The Empress Dowager asked Duan, “The imperial carriage has already departed. To establish an heir, one follows seniority—what should be done?”

Duan replied, “The late emperor enthroned the crown prince precisely for this day. Now that he has left the world, how can we so quickly defy his decree and entertain other proposals?”

The Empress Dowager fell silent. They then escorted the crown prince to the Funing Palace, where he ascended the throne.

After the prince’s enthronement, the curtain was lowered for an audience with the ministers. Duan stood upright below the steps and did not bow. He requested that the curtain be raised so he could ascend the hall and verify the new emperor’s identity. Only then did he descend and lead the ministers in paying homage.

The *Record* states: After the betrayal of the Golden Casket’s covenant, the throne had barely passed to Zhenzong when the Wang Jienn plot arose—yet it was thwarted by Lü Duan. When it passed again to Renzong, the treachery of Yun Gong emerged—yet it was thwarted by Wang Zeng. Such crises mark the perilous turns of a state’s fate, while their resolution reflects the power of loyalty and magnanimity in governance. At that time, the virtue of the Song flourished, and the Dao of the noble prevailed. Thus, great ministers could act according to their principles, and villains found no opportunity to scheme. Had it been otherwise, would Jienn not have forced his way out rather than submit to imprisonment? As for Duan’s refusal to bow before the newly enthroned emperor, it was not by choice. Since he could not emulate the *Book of Zhou*’s *Testamentary Charge*, he had no choice but to verify the emperor’s identity by raising the curtain.

Initially, when Wang Anshi held power, he disrupted the established order. Empress Dowager Guangxian, during an audience, admonished Emperor Shenzong: “The laws of the ancestral founders should not be lightly altered. I hear the people are suffering greatly—abolish the Green Sprouts and Labor Service policies.”

When Emperor Shenzong passed and Emperor Zhezong ascended, Empress Dowager Xuanren of the Gao clan assumed regency. She dismissed the laborers constructing the capital, disbanded the palace guards, halted imperial workshops, abolished the Luoyang Canal Bureau, expelled thirteen particularly unruly attendants, and issued decrees to the court and the realm: no harsh exactions, ease the people’s burdens, protect households and horses, cease the manufacture of military equipment, halt the purchase of horses in Chengdu, close the commodity markets in the eastern and western capitals and Sizhou, abolish the Market Exchange, Pawnshop, Bian River Embankment, and Land Tax Bureaus, cancel the Equalization Tax, exempt arrears of the Labor Service fee, abolish fines for delayed appointments, cease the collection of circulation taxes, disband the Militia Tax, abolish the positions of Militia Tax Supervisors and Grain Tax Militia Officials, end the Square Fields system, dissolve the Yan-Yan military units, and halt the expansion of coin minting. Fourteen agencies acted on imperial orders without the knowledge of the Grand Councilor Wang Gui and his colleagues.

The *Record* states: In my view, the relationship between Empress Dowager Guangxian and Empress Dowager Xuanren exemplified the finest transmission of virtue between mother-in-law and daughter-in-law. Guangxian had intentions she did not act upon, which Xuanren fulfilled. Guangxian had established precedents worthy of emulation, which Xuanren followed. Had the emperors of Shaoxi and Chongning been like them, what harm would there have been in continuing the legacy? Alas, in name they upheld it, but in reality, they betrayed it. If they had any conscience, how could they face the two empresses in the underworld?

When Empress Dowager Xuanren passed, Emperor Zhezong changed the era name to Shaosheng. Yang Wei submitted a memorial: “Emperor Shenzong reformed the laws to benefit all generations. I beg you to swiftly deliberate and complete the path of *shaoshu* (continuing the legacy).”

The emperor inquired which former ministers should be recalled. Wei immediately submitted a memorial recommending Zhang Dun, Lü Huizhi, Deng Wenbo, and Li Qingchen. The emperor deeply approved and appointed Zhang Dun as Left Grand Councilor, making the continuation of Shenzong’s policies the state’s guiding principle. Dun then brought his allies—Cai Bian, Lin Xi, Huang Lü, Lai Zhishao, and Zhang Shangying—into key positions, entrusting them with remonstrance and policy-making. They colluded in cliques, schemed in factions, and settled personal vendettas.

The *Record* states: The calamities wrought by Wang Anshi’s faction were dire indeed. Critics merely blame the origins of the reforms, yet the true disaster lay in the policies of *shaoshu*.

The notion of *shaoshu*—continuing the legacy—is a noble governance. Did not Kings Wen and Wu, along with the Duke of Zhou, secure not only eight hundred years of fortune but also enduring renown across millennia? All say: “They were good at inheriting the aspirations of their predecessors and carrying forward their undertakings.” Yet to call it “good inheritance” and “good continuation” is but a single character’s distinction, pregnant with boundless depth that cannot be left unexamined.

The virtue of the benevolent ruler endures without end, while the *qi* of the perverse may not yet have dissipated. Had the benevolent emperor left an heir, and Shenzong’s line not been orphaned, the calamity of barbarian invasion might never have come to pass. Yet one reign of Empress Dowager Xuanren could not suffice to repair the damage, while a single act by Zhang Dun more than sufficed to ruin it—all because Zhezong was his son. A thousand words from Cui Ou and Chen Guan fell on deaf ears, while a single remark from Deng Xunwu pleased the emperor—because Huizong, too, was his son.

Alas! The Zhou dynasty passed the throne from Jili to King Chang, and Heaven’s mandate was firmly secured. Shenzong passed it from Zhezong to Huizong, and the state’s affairs daily worsened. Was this not because, though the act of inheriting aspirations and continuing undertakings was the same, the founding and transmission of the legacy were not equally virtuous?

Dou Yujun’s five sons—Yi, Yan, Kan, Cheng, and Xi—all passed the imperial examinations in succession, earning the name “Five Dragons.” Feng Dao composed a poem in their honor:

*“Dou Shilang of Yanshan,*
*Taught his sons with righteous methods.*
*An ancient cypress stands tall,*
*Five branches of red cassia bloom in fragrance.”*

By the first year of Jianlong in the Song dynasty, Emperor Taizu told his chief councilor: “For solemn and austere posts, one must appoint venerable scholars.” He praised Dou Yi as pure, upright, and steadfast—no one else would suffice. Immediately, Yi was appointed Academician, and later, the emperor repeatedly commended his integrity, intending to make him chief councilor. Zhao Pu, however, resented his unyielding正直. When Yi died, the emperor lamented, “Why did Heaven take Dou Yi from me so swiftly?”—grieving that his talents had not been fully employed.

Yan was especially brilliant, skilled in astrology and calendrical calculations. Serving alongside Lu Duoxun and Yang Huizhi as remonstrance officials, he once told them: “In the *dingmao* year, the five planets will gather in the *Kui* constellation, and from then on, the realm will know great peace.” And so it came to pass. Taizu later remarked to his courtiers: “Among recent officials, Dou Yan is grave, dignified, and disciplined, upholding his family’s traditions. His household is harmonious, and no slanderous words are spoken of him—none of his brothers can compare.” Xi, though of only average ability, was praised for his admirable conduct.

The *Record* states: Observing the Dou family in the early Song, their adaptability in serving the times may be criticized, but their righteous methods in teaching their sons are worthy of praise. Yet even with the five planets gathering in *Kui*, the talents of an era could only be aligned if the chaos of the Five Dynasties had not preceded it; without the upheaval of those turbulent years, the paths of the five brothers’ careers might never have converged.

Human nature and the ways of the world are generally thus—gentlemen ought not to censure them too harshly.

Chen Shenghua and his wife, née Feng, were stern and resolute in character, governing their household with discipline. Their sons—Yaosou, Yaozuo, and Yaozi—were always filial and respectful in daily life, their voices gentle as they stood by their parents’ side, never presuming upon their rank. During the Jingde era, Yaosou oversaw the central administration, Yaozuo served in the Historiographer’s Office, and Yaozi held the post of Academician Drafting Edicts, all three stationed in the Northern Bureau alongside their father. Whenever guests arrived, the brothers would stand in attendance beside their father, making the visitors so ill at ease that many would soon take their leave.

Yaosou was imposing in stature, vigorous in memorials and responses, keen in judgment, and rich in resourcefulness. Having long overseen confidential affairs, he could recall in full detail the registers of military horses. Yaozuo, the youngest, was fond of learning from childhood. When their father taught the classics to his sons, Yaosou had yet to complete his studies, but Yaozuo, listening in secret, had already memorized the texts. Even after rising to prominence, he never ceased reading. Early on, he followed Zhong Fang to Mount Zhongnan, where Chen Tuan said to Shenghua: “All three of your sons will become generals and ministers, but your middle son will be the most eminent and long-lived.” This proved entirely as Tuan had foretold. When Yaozuo later passed away, he composed his own epitaph, declaring: “Having lived eighty-two years, never having served as a first-rank official of the Celestial Ministry, nor as a mere ceremonial chancellor, nor having accepted a stipend that would bring disgrace—these three things may roughly suffice to return my spirit to the realm of my parents.” Yaozi, for his part, took moral integrity as his personal duty.

The gentleman remarks that Shenghua’s reputation grew all the more illustrious through his sons. Since the founding of the Song, no family’s moral legacy has surpassed theirs. The record states: Observing the Chen family, one sees that not only were they admirable in their time, but the middle son’s eminence and longevity were especially well attested. Yet while one may take pride in such self-fulfilling prophecies and use them to spur oneself onward, boasting and flattery are unbecoming. For nobility and long life are what all desire—yet there are those who cannot attain them, such as Yanzi, who died young; Zeng Shen, who received meager stipends; and Ran Min, who never rose in rank. Yet across ten thousand generations, none fail to revere them, for the sake of their virtue. Thus, the highest achievement is to establish virtue, the next to establish merit. Only by returning to rest in the realm where the spirit dwells can one hope to live up to the devotion of rising at dawn and retiring at dusk.

Lü Gongzhuo’s two sons, Xizhe and Xichun, in their youth studied moral character under Fu Shijie, grandson of the famed Qiao Gan, and Hu Huan. Their accomplishments far outstripped those of their peers. In adulthood, they further studied under the Cheng brothers and Zhang Zai, broadening their learning. They then renounced all ambition for advancement, refusing to pursue the imperial examinations, for they saw learning as a path to integrity, not to the fleeting gains of rank or stipend. When Wang Anshi sought to recommend his son Yu as a lecturer and, considering Xizhe’s reputation for virtue, wished to appoint him first, Xizhe declined, saying: “I have long been honored by your esteem. Yet if I were to enter office, I would inevitably disagree with you, and all our past affinity would be undone.” Anshi then abandoned the idea. Later, when Shen Gong became chancellor, his two younger brothers, Gongchuo and Gongbi, had already been appointed to positions in the ministries, while Xizhe alone remained relegated to managing the imperial storehouses. Shen Gong sighed, saying: “Of all the worthy men of this age, I have gathered nearly every one—yet because of me, he alone has not been given a proper appointment.” When his mother heard this, she laughed and said: “He does not yet know his own son.”

Rang Zuyu, his brother-in-law, spoke to Emperor Zhezong, saying: “Xizhe’s classical scholarship and moral conduct make him well-suited to serve as a lecturer.” Thereupon, he was appointed *Expositor-in-Waiting* of the Hall of Esteemed Governance. In his admonitions to the sovereign, he took self-cultivation as the foundation and the rectification of the mind and sincerity of intention as the essence, saying: “If one cannot cultivate oneself, how can one even instruct those at one’s side, let alone the realm under heaven?” Together with Xichun, he carried forward their family’s excellence. Affable, unassuming, frugal, and plain, he gained ever greater renown as the years passed, and both near and far regarded him with the reverence due a teacher.

The record states: The histories say that Lü Shen Gong, though he recognized his son’s worth, could not bring himself to recommend him, and thus fell short of his forebear. I, however, believe he did no dishonor to the *Minister of Righteousness*. Why? In the time of Wenmu, the Great Dao was openly practiced, and one ought not to have declined on grounds of distant scruples. By Shen Gong’s time, the Great Dao had already receded, and men had cause to fear being branded as partisans—this was his safeguard against later reproach.

Lin Xi once remarked: “Lü Dafang owed his advancement to Gongzhuo’s patronage, and thus promoted Xizhe to repay a private debt, while Gongzhuo’s misdeeds were abetted by Xizhe’s counsel.” Alas! Does not Mencius say: “Look up and feel no shame before Heaven; look down and feel no disgrace before men”? Compared to Yu and Xi and their ilk, Xizhe was not even worthy of a rotten rat.

Hong Hao’s three sons—Shi, Zun, and Mai—were all exceptional. Shi, the eldest, was quick-witted from childhood and could recite three thousand characters a day. When Hao was sent to the northern frontier, Shi, though only thirteen, took charge of the household. In recognition of his father’s service abroad, he was granted the honorary title *Gentleman for Fostering Excellence*. In the twelfth year of Shaoxing, he and his brother Zun both passed the *Erudite Literatus and Grand Composition* examination. Emperor Gaozong sighed, saying: “With their father far away, his sons have stood on their own—this is Heaven’s reward.” He therefore ordered their promotion.

The eldest, Shi, was appointed as an editor in the Imperial Decree Revision Office, while Zun became a Corrector of Texts in the Imperial Library. Three years later, Mai also passed the same examination. Thus, the literary fame of the three Hong brothers resounded throughout the realm. When Hong Hao returned, he clashed with Qin Hui, and all three sons were demoted to posts outside the capital. After Hao was exiled to Yingzhou, Shi spent nine years traveling back and forth across the Lingnan region to visit and attend to him. Upon Qin Hui’s death, Shi rose from the ranks of the Two Academies to the government in a single month. Four days later, he was elevated to the position of Grand Councilor. Zun was appointed Academician of the Hall for Aid in Governance, and Mai became Academician of the Hall of Enlightenment. Mai’s literary attainments were especially lofty, and his discussions in court were the most numerous—truly, the reward for loyalty and righteousness is not to be doubted.

The record states: How can Hong the Loyal and Upright be compared to Su Changru? In Wu’s time, the Central Kingdom was at its zenith, and the Xiongnu relied only on their arrogance. In Hao’s time, Hua and Yi were inverted, and death was as certain as life. Had it not been for Heaven’s reward, how could his family have prospered? Yet Qin Hui’s evil surpassed that of dogs and sheep, his poison more pervasive than the barbarians’ cruelty. The barbarians could tolerate him in foreign lands, but Qin Hui could not be endured in the same court. The emperor could promote him in a moment, yet could not protect him in the days to come. Though Heaven’s ways are inscrutable, in the end, Hao’s sons brought glory to their generation and adorned the state with their writings. Though they did not hold power in their father’s lifetime, they ascended to the grand councilorship after his death. Observing this, the court historians could only exclaim indignantly: “The reward for loyalty and righteousness has its reasons indeed!”

Hu Anguo had three sons: Yin, Hong, and Ning. Anguo was steadfast in learning and conduct, taking the sages as his model and dedicating himself to the welfare of the realm. Witnessing the Central Plains’ fall and the people’s suffering, he felt as though the pain were his own. Though repeatedly dismissed from office, his love for his sovereign and concern for the state only deepened with time. Whenever imperial commands arrived, he set aside all family matters. Yet his demeanor was serene and detached, transcending worldly dust; he regarded all things under heaven as unworthy of ensnaring his heart. After the *Spring and Autumn Annals* was abolished from the official curriculum during the Zhenghe and Xuanhe eras, Anguo lamented: “This book, personally edited by the former sage, is now kept from the ruler’s ears and scholars’ transmission. The collapse of ethics and the inversion of principle, the transformation of Xia into Yi—all stem from this.” He devoted over twenty years to this text, believing it encompassed all matters under heaven. He often sighed: “This tradition is the essential canon of the heart.”

Yin, styled Zhitang, was treated by his father as a nephew or younger brother. In his youth, he was unruly and difficult to control, so his father confined him to an empty attic. The attic had miscellaneous wood, which Yin carved entirely into human figures. Anguo said: “There must be a way to redirect his heart.” He placed several thousand volumes of books in the attic. After a year, Yin had memorized them all without omission. His resolve and spirit were bold and unrestrained; when the order for his exile to Xinzhou arrived, he set out that very day.

Hong, styled Wufeng, inherited his father’s learning. He wandered leisurely at the foot of Mount Heng for over twenty years, refining his spirit and insight day and night without cease. Zhang Shi became his disciple. When Anguo transmitted the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, Ning was responsible for collation and compilation, producing the *Comprehensive Essentials of the Spring and Autumn Annals* to supplement the text.

The record states: People likened Kanghou to the harsh frost of deep winter—how could his sons wither in the cold of the year? Their memorials to the throne were as solemn as if cast from the same mold. This was due to their family learning, which took the *Spring and Autumn Annals* as its standard. The father oversaw compilation, and the son assisted in collation—within their household, it was as though a bureau of historians had taken shape. Such figures as Master Wen and Kanghou are rarely seen. Though they did not serve in office, it was as though they had. That father and sons together stood as pillars of Confucianism—was this not splendid?

Cai Yuanding had two sons, Yuan and Shen, both of whom tilled the land and refused office. When Yuanding was exiled to Daozhou, they trekked thousands of miles. Passing through the remote regions of Chu and Yue, father and sons faced each other, finding joy only in the Dao. At thirty, Shen abandoned the pursuit of examination degrees and took the sages as his teachers. Regarding the numbers of the *Great Plan*, scholars had long lost their transmission, but Yuanding alone grasped them, though he had not yet written them down. He often said: “Shen will complete my book.” Shen received his father’s teachings and immersed himself in them for decades, revisiting and refining them before finally completing the work. He held that the *Changes* embodied the images of heaven and earth’s composition, while the *Great Plan* recorded its numbers. Numbers begin with the odd one, and images are formed by the even two. The odd enables numbers to unfold, while the even establishes images. Thus, two becomes four, and four becomes eight—eight being the images of the eight trigrams. One becomes three, and three becomes nine—nine being the numbers of the nine categories. From this, they are doubled to sixty-four, and sixty-four to four thousand ninety-six, at which point the images are complete. Nine becomes eighty-one, and eighty-one becomes six thousand five hundred sixty-one, at which point the numbers are exhaustive.

The *Changes* passed through four sages before its images were set down, while the *Great Plan* bestowed upon the divine Yu did not transmit its numbers. Later scholars, ignorant of the origins of images and numbers and the subtleties of transformation and adaptation, either derived numbers from images or forced images from numbers. Some relied on the *Cave of Profundity* for their texts, others on the *Mysterious Void* for their diagrams, piecing together forced interpretations—thus, the natural numbers were obscured.

Yuanding’s father said: “The *Luo River Writing* is the origin of numbers.” I read the *Great Plan* and was moved. By examining the heavens above, the earth below, and humanity in between, the changes of past and present, the profound subtleties of principle, and the signs of rise and fall, the proper order of human relations is established, and all things under heaven find their rightful place. Thus, Jia of Xishan regarded it as equal in achievement to the *Changes* of the Three Sages.

The record states: Of the sons of these several gentlemen, only Jiufeng’s transmission truly grasped its essence. His work, *The Supreme Principle of the Great Plan*, reveals that the brush of heaven and earth is number, the generation of humanity is number, and the gains and losses of the myriad things are also number.

Number manifests its substance in form, and its function is wondrous in principle. Only those who have exhausted the spiritual and understood transformation, standing alone beyond the realm of things, are fit to partake in this. In compiling his *Collected Commentaries*, he declared: “The governance of the Two Emperors and Three Kings was rooted in the Dao; the Dao of the Two Emperors and Three Kings was rooted in the heart. Ritual, music, education, and transformation are the heart’s emanations; canonical institutions and cultural artifacts are the heart’s manifestations; the ordering of the household, the governance of the state, and the pacification of all under heaven are the heart’s extensions. How abundant is the heart’s virtue! The heart of the sage, revealed in texts, is like the marvelous workings of the Creator manifested in things—only the profoundly discerning can recognize it. This is why he stands preeminent among his peers and is rightfully enshrined in the temple of the Master—is this not fitting?”

Li Shunchen had three sons: Xinzhuan, Daozhuan, and Xingzhuan. Shunchen transmitted learning through practice and left many writings. Father and sons alike possessed historical talent; he was promoted to Recorder of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices and oversaw the revision of the jade tablets for Emperor Yuling’s mausoleum. When Zeng Bu and Lü Huiqing first rose to power, he meticulously recorded their actions. Some argued that appointments and dismissals not made by the chief minister should not be recorded. Shunchen replied: “Matters of governance and neglect cannot be bound by conventional rules.” Many of his editorial revisions followed this principle.

Xinzhuan, as Compiler, was solely responsible for compiling the veritable records of the Gaozong, Xiaozong, Guangzong, and Ningzong reigns. In the third year of the Duanning era, he submitted a memorial on the causes of drought, stating: “The increase of harmonious radiance has multiplied the people’s resentment.” And: “The confiscation of property without just cause has provoked the people’s resentment.” All these arose in the aftermath of great warfare, and with no means to resolve them, they accumulated to an extreme.

Daozhuan was well-versed in the studies of the Yellow River and Luo River. He once sought out those who had studied under Zhu Xi, engaging in discussion and obtaining all of Zhu’s posthumous writings to read. He was steadfast in practice, and on his bed, he had the large characters “Awaken, Interrupt, Sever, Decide” posted—such was his dedication to vigilance in solitude. Though he left no commentaries on the classics or histories, he said: “My learning is not yet sufficient; I dare not write poetry.” Nor did he compose casually, saying: “My learning is not yet sufficient; I have no leisure.”

Xingzhuan, during an imperial audience, spoke of “revering Daoist learning but failing to attain its substance.” The Emperor asked: “What is its substance?” He replied: “It lies in the investigation of things and the extension of knowledge, which is the foundation of governance.” He also remarked: “After the Zhou dynasty’s decline, feudal lords and high ministers all removed mourning garments after burial. By the Qin and Han eras, mourning periods were particularly brief. Emperor Xiaowen established a thirty-six-day period, which was already an improvement over the time before Emperor Hui. After the Eastern Han, it was further reduced to twenty-seven days, called ‘exchanging months for days’—the ultimate in meagerness.”

The record states: I observe that within the Li family, the three sons’ attainments were roughly the same, and their inclusion in the *History of the Song* under the “Confucian Scholars” section is no disgrace. Yet they were divided into four separate entries. Even if Xinzhuan and Daozhuan were grouped together in one lane, they were still separated into two gates. Such instances reveal the chaos of “ten shepherds for nine sheep,” with no coherence between past and present, making it impossible to avoid redundancy. Yuan Ding’s son Shen was enshrined in the temple, yet no biography was written for him, while his son Kang was given one—this was merely for official rank. Thus I say: “Is it that I delight in argument? I cannot do otherwise.”

Tang Lin, upon being appointed Investigating Censor of the Censorate, was so alarmed that he fled in panic. His mother said: “People say this is a fine office; why are you worried?” Lin replied: “This office requires one to contend over right and wrong for the court. If I oppose the emperor’s will or offend the powerful, I fear it will bring great trouble to you.” His mother said: “Just speak your mind fully. I have your elder brother.” Lin bowed in gratitude and assumed his post. His first memorial stated: “Heaven’s changes have reached the point of wrath; the people’s resentment has nearly led to separation. The realm is on the verge of collapse, and the state is about to fall. What time is this, that Your Majesty still indulges desires, accumulates faults, covers up errors, distances the upright, and clings to favored relatives and eunuchs? The chief minister employs literary talent as tools for governance, disregarding the people’s lives, recklessly provoking unrest, failing to assess circumstances, and depleting the national treasury. The imperial son governs frivolously, colludes with merchants, opens wide the path of bribery, abandons the *Xiaoya*, and allows petty in-laws to meddle in treacherous schemes, treating state affairs like a play and the sacred vessel as merchandise. The capital’s people are aghast; the court officials are pained. Why not enforce the punishment for ‘not yet traitorous’ to manifest the crime of disloyalty?”—this was directed at Jia Sidao.

In his second memorial, he stated: “Zheng Qingzhi’s incompetence and misguidance harmed the state; his son Shichang abused power and accepted bribes, promoted mediocre generals to command and corrupt officials to govern.” Lin had been in office for only a hundred days, yet the world said, “Tang Zifang has reappeared,” all due to his mother’s guidance.

According to the *History of the Yuan*: When Yao Tianfu was appointed Investigating Censor, his mother admonished him: “The ancients spoke of ‘public-mindedness, forgetting the private.’ Having pledged yourself as a minister, you must exhaust your sincerity to fulfill your duty; do not let concern for me, a widow, hold you back. If you enable me to follow in the footsteps of the mother of Ling, then in death I will be as in life.” Tianfu also petitioned the Censorate: “The duty of a censor is to speak out; one must not conceal anything, even at the risk of punishment. If I am reprimanded, I beg that my family not be implicated.” When this was reported, Emperor Shizu sighed: “Though Tianfu and his mother live in this age, their words of righteousness and integrity must be sought among the ancients.”

The record states: The maternal teachings received by Tang Lin of the Song and Tianfu of the Yuan were the same, yet their achievements differed. Lin stood in office for barely a hundred days, and though his words were incisive and unflinching, the Song was by then beyond saving. Even if Zifang had returned, who could have rescued it? Tianfu, however, served during the reign of Shizu, when his conduct was practiced and his words heeded. Not only did he rectify the Censorate’s discipline, eliminating the peril of “one snake with two heads,” but he also reestablished the surveillance system, achieving the merit of subduing powerful local families.

Yet Lin was no coward—his was the sorrow of one unable to bear the weight of a collapsing edifice; Tianfu was no hero—his was the fortune of serving when the Yuan’s destiny still rose, spared the grief of self-inflicted calamity. The mother’s joy and fear mirrored the age’s decline and ascent, as clearly as could be seen.

Baizhu was the grandson of Antong. Orphaned at five, he was raised with stern virtue by his mother, Lady Quolie. As he grew, his bearing became grand, upright, and luminous, inheriting his grandfather’s legacy. Once, he memorialized: “In office, one’s duties may be mastered through practice, but learning must be rooted in fundamentals to be applied to governance. This is the scholar’s path, the foundation of a prime minister.” When the Emperor entrusted him with great responsibility, he declared three fears: dishonoring his ancestors, failing to grasp the vastness of the realm’s affairs, and being too young to bear the burden and repay the sovereign’s grace. He served in the inner court with unflinching candor, speaking without reservation.

Upon becoming chief minister, he restored discipline, revived neglected institutions, curtailed nonessential tasks, closed the gates to favor-seekers, bestowed kindness upon soldiers and commoners, and lightened taxes. Emperor Yingzong relied on him, and together they strove to govern with vigor. The realm was at peace, the nation prosperous, the people content. Even distant barbarians, unknown in ancient times, came to pay tribute and request officials.

When he first served as Director of the Ritual Institute at just twenty, clerks came to his residence to seek his seal. Finding him in the rear garden at play, his mother rebuked him sharply: “If official matters go unaddressed, is this the conduct of a man of stature?” He immediately examined himself and repented. One day, attending a banquet, Yingzong pressed him to drink several cups. Upon returning home, his mother admonished him: “When the Son of Heaven compels you to drink, you must be all the more vigilant—do not indulge in wine.” She oversaw every aspect of his conduct. Thus, it was said that Baizhu’s virtue was the fruit of his mother’s teachings.

The *Record* states: Muhuali was one of the Four Heroes of the Yuan. Four generations later came Antong, and two generations after him, Baizhu. That they were men of reverence—three generations of grandfather, father, and grandson unashamed of their legacy—who would have thought such virtue could arise from a barbarian dynasty? Tracing its source, we find it was their mothers who, as the guiding reins, reined in their wayward hearts, lest they sink into dissipation. Thereafter, none could match them.

*The Record of Illustrious Ministers of the August Ming*: During the Jingtai reign, Minister of Rites Zhang Lun, Supervising Secretary Lin Cong, Censor Zhong Tong, and Chief Justice of the Court of Judicial Review Liao Zhuang memorialized on the occasion of calamitous omens. At that time, the Supreme Emperor resided apart in the Southern Palace, and the Xian Emperor had altered the heir apparent to a prince. The two palaces were estranged, suspicion and discord sprouting, calamities and omens recurring, and the people’s hearts trembled with fear. Yet no court minister dared speak. Zhang Lun alone presented fourteen measures to cultivate virtue and avert disaster, emphasizing filial piety: “The Supreme Emperor ruled all under Heaven for fourteen years. Your Majesty once personally received his investiture and revered him as a subject—he is the father of all under Heaven. On the first and fifteenth of each month, as well as the New Year’s Day, you should lead the assembled ministers to pay court, thereby fulfilling the utmost way of reverence. You should also restore the former empress to the central palace to rectify the motherly model for all under Heaven, and restore the former heir apparent to the Eastern Palace to secure the great foundation of all under Heaven. In this way, human relationships will be deepened, harmonious qi will fill the realm, Heaven’s will shall turn, and calamities shall cease.” His words offended the throne and led to his imprisonment.

Earlier, in the third year of Jingtai, when the court first proposed altering the heir apparent, the matter was put to deliberation among the ministers. The entire court, high and low, hesitated, none daring to speak—except Lin Cong, who first declared: “The heir apparent has committed no fault; he cannot be replaced.” Indignant, he refused to sign his name. His stance aligned with the remonstrances of Zhong Tong and Liao Zhuang before and after. Though they could not prevent the change, the people admired the righteousness of these ministers, and in the end, Heaven’s mandate remained unaltered.

The *Record* states: Observing the righteousness of these ministers, one is struck by its solemnity—it embodies the great principle of the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, upon which the present age and all generations to come depend. When Duke Zhuang of Qi fled in exile, he was never deposed; when Duke Yin of Lu acted as regent, Duke Huan succeeded him. When the Ying Emperor first returned, the Xian Emperor was at the height of his power—why then was the succession altered? Moreover, the Jing Emperor’s heir was ailing, and later, calamities recurred. At that time, it would have been fitting to heed the counsel of Zhong Tong and Zhang Lun, and the arguments of Lin Cong and Liao Zhuang: to honor the Supreme Emperor with due rites and restore the heir to the Eastern Palace. Thus, names would have been rectified, words justified, and the “Seizure of the Gate” incident might never have occurred. In but a moment, Heaven would have assented, the people followed. The Ying Emperor, though eclipsed, would have regained his radiance; the Xian Emperor, though deposed, would have been restored. The succession would have passed to Our August Emperor, extending for myriad years, boundless blessings. Were not the proposals of these ministers clear and upright? From this, we know that the great succession of Our Ming, established between Heaven and Earth, shining like the sun and moon, cannot be violated even for a moment.

*The Yan Dui Record*: In the fifth month of the eighteenth year of Hongzhi, the emperor fell ill. The Directorate of Ceremonial summoned Grand Secretaries Li Dongyang, Liu Jian, and Xie Qian to the Palace of Heavenly Purity. Approaching the imperial couch, they found the emperor seated in informal attire. Liu Jian and the others kowtowed. The emperor bade them draw near, and they knelt directly before the couch. The emperor said: “I have inherited the great succession of my ancestors and reigned for eighteen years. Now, at thirty-six, I have fallen gravely ill—it seems I shall not rise again.” His jade-like complexion flushed red, his voice fiery, his breath forceful. Liu Jian and the others said: “May Your Majesty live ten thousand years! This is but a passing indisposition; with brief recuperation, how could you speak thus?” The emperor replied: “I know my own condition. There is also the mandate of Heaven, which cannot be forced. I have upheld the laws and institutions of my ancestors and dared not indulge in idleness or excess.”

Having received the profound grace of my late imperial father, Zhang was chosen as empress. The marriage was solemnized in the twenty-third year of Chenghua, and on the twenty-fourth day of the ninth month in the fourth year of Hongzhi, the Eastern Palace heir was born. Now fifteen years of age, he has yet to be betrothed. The affairs of the altars of soil and grain weigh heavily—let the Ministry of Rites promptly arrange the proceedings.

All responded: “As you command.”

The emperor continued: “The heir is intelligent, yet young and fond of ease and pleasure. Masters, you must frequently summon him to study and guide him to become a worthy man.”

Liu Jian and the others kowtowed and, looking up, replied: “How dare we not exert our utmost?”

Lu wrote: Observing the dying commands of the Filial Emperor, one sees their unhurried thoroughness, their beginning and end in meticulous detail—comparable to the *Gu Ming* of the *Book of Zhou*, though separated by ages, they share the same principle. When he said, “I have upheld the laws of my ancestors and dared not indulge in idleness or excess,” this is a thought for ministers and sons of all generations to ponder deeply and painfully, a sentiment that lingers unforgotten in the hearts of men. Yet the warning against fondness for ease, as if foretold in his final injunctions, was soon overshadowed by the clamor of Liu Jin, Zhu Ning, Jiang Bin, and their ilk, whose blind delusions repeatedly stirred and extinguished the spirit of Heaven. That their mischief did not endure long—was this not the fruit of far-sighted counsel?

The祭酒 Song Gun, by nature pure and sincere, conducted himself with restraint, never speaking or laughing idly. When the Imperial University was established, tribute students from within and beyond the realm gathered, and the number of scholars grew daily.
