As teaching and discipline faltered, he was promoted to *jijiu*, and with tireless effort, he tightened regulations, expounded the classics, and struck the drum to clear the halls, so that students, like guests returning home, flocked to him. He customarily slept and took his meals in the side chambers, never lodging at home. One day, taken ill, the emperor dispatched an emissary to inquire and summoned his son Lin back to the capital to attend him. When Lin and others later pleaded to return home, Song rebuked them sternly: “What lack of resolve is this? So little of the spirit of wind and clouds, and so much of the sentiment of sons and daughters!” Only when his illness grew critical did he return. The emperor personally composed an elegy to be recited at his official mourning rites, and his second son, Fuzu, succeeded him as *siye*.

The record states: Day after day he toiled, ceasing only in death. This is how the sage exhorts scholars—yet never had it been heard that one should not lodge at home. To say one has too little of the spirit of wind and clouds and too much of the sentiment of sons and daughters—does this then require a heart of iron and stone? Nevertheless, for such a man to hold the position of tutor and guardian, to never rest from the ruler’s daily inquiries, to spend little time in the company of worthy scholar-officials and much with eunuchs and palace women—this is how the Dao gains the sovereign’s trust, and loyalty is embodied in action. His son Fu later became *siye*; how could he be compared to ordinary brothers and sons?

From *Yin Zhi’s Miscellaneous Records*:
Minister He, posthumously honored as Wensu, whose father was Grand Guardian and Minister of Personnel He Wenyuan: When the latter served as Prefect of Wenzhou, he refused a gift of gold, and the people built the "Hall of Refused Gold" in his honor, which still stands today. When Minister He first passed the imperial examinations and was sent to Huaixi, Magistrate Chao of Huizhou, who had once been his father’s student, presented him with silver. Minister He declined, but Chao said, "I do this to honor my teacher, not to give to you." He replied, "If you wish to honor my father, it may be done through another, but not through me." While serving in Fujian, a eunuch in charge of maritime trade died, and the regional commander divided his remaining wealth, sending a portion to the Three Departments. Minister He alone refused it; when he could not avoid accepting it, he took it and turned it over to the public treasury. Later, as Surveillance Commissioner of Bian, General Wu Chengde once recommended a ruined man and presented him with a rhinoceros-horn belt and silver vessels. Minister He smiled and said, "I know you, but you do not know me." Wu withdrew in shame. When Minister He retired, Commissioner Yang sent an envoy with gold and silk to offer birthday felicitations, along with fine timber suitable for funerary furnishings—none of which he accepted. Someone advised him, "The caution against greed applies especially today." But his incorruptibility was simply his nature.

The record states: There is an old saying, "A minister’s integrity does not surpass his father’s." Now there is also the saying, "He’s integrity does not surpass his son’s." In my humble opinion, while the purity of scholar-officials is a noble virtue, and even if it is passed down through generations by effort and example, one should still look up to such men—yet to regard it as excessive is misguided. If one’s emotions are too rigid or extreme, then the world would have no complete men. Thus, it is recorded.

In the early years of the Tianshun reign, the eunuch Cao Jixiang and the Duke of Zhongguo, Shi Heng, exploited their favor to wield unchecked power. The supervising censor Yang Yi impeached them. Soon after, comets and celestial omens repeatedly appeared, and the two factions grew even more emboldened. The official rallied thirteen circuits to jointly submit a memorial, vehemently denouncing those who privately curried favor with Heng. Thereupon, Heng conspired with Jixiang, submitting a forged document to imprison him in the Embroidered Uniform Guard’s dungeon, where he was put to death. Just then, a great storm of wind, rain, and hail struck the capital, uprooting trees and destroying houses, and even hurling the imperial horse tally beyond the Zhengyang Gate. Only then was his sentence slightly reduced, and he was exiled to the eastern frontier of Liaodong. Upon receiving an amnesty, he was restored to office. However, as the two villains still held power, some advised him to offer an apology to avoid further trouble. He refused, and was once more exiled, this time to Guangxi. Only after the two villains were executed was he fully reinstated.

His son, Yuan, served during the Hongzhi reign as an assistant observer in the Directorate of Astronomy. In the early Zhengde era, when the traitor Liu Jin held power, Yuan submitted a memorial stating: "The astrological observations reveal that the Great Horn and the central stars of the Heart Mansion are trembling, while the Celestial Pivot and Celestial Authority stars grow dim." He thus urged the late emperor to remain secluded in the deep palace, refrain from excursions, curtail rewards and construction projects, consult with elder ministers, and study the classics. In another memorial, he wrote: "On the twenty-sixth day of the tenth month, the astrological observations show that for days on end, dense mists have gathered, signifying the yin-qi of manifold evils overwhelming the yang-qi of the minister and deceiving the ruler. Petty men usurp power, subordinates rebel against superiors—this analogy is most apt." He further stated: "Since the second year of the Zhengde reign, the astrological observations have consistently shown Mars entering the Supreme Palace Enclosure, before the Emperor’s Throne, now east, now west, moving unpredictably." He urged the emperor to take precautionary measures. His intent was clearly directed at Liu Jin.

Liu Jin, enraged, summoned Yuan for a face-to-face reprimand, falsely accused him, had him caned, and exiled him to Suzhou. The record states: To observe the decree of exile—once is already excessive, yet I have never heard of one who, exiled a second time, felt no remorse. Words left unspoken—when the father has already suffered punishment, I have never heard of a son who would tread the same path. Only with a father and son of iron resolve does one find such repeated divinations and auguries. The Yang family may be said to have not perished. In this great storm of hail, one may also perceive the utmost benevolence and love of Heaven.

*Hongdao Record*, Volume Twenty—concluded
*Hongdao Record*, Volume Twenty-One

**On the Righteousness of Husband and Wife**

Wan Zhang asked: The *Book of Songs* says, *"How does one take a wife? One must inform one’s parents."* If we trust these words, no one should exemplify them more than Shun. Yet Shun married without informing his parents—why?

Mencius replied: Had he informed them, he would not have been able to marry. The union of man and woman is one of humanity’s great bonds. To inform them would have disrupted this great bond, thereby incurring the resentment of his parents—thus, he did not inform them.

Wan Zhang said: Shun’s marriage without informing his parents—I have now heard your explanation. But when the Emperor gave Shun his daughters in marriage, why did he also not inform Shun’s parents?

Mencius replied: The Emperor, too, knew that had he informed them, he would not have been able to arrange the marriage.

The record states: When Duke Zhuang of Lu ascended the throne in his twenty-second year, he was already thirty-six when he first betrothed a wife from Qi—was this not because had he informed his parents, he would not have been allowed to marry? Had a sagely king been on the throne, punishing Wen Jiang for her lack of maternal kindness and correcting Duke Zhuang for his filial impiety, then he would have been spared the humiliation at Ren Tower and Luo’s coercion, nor would he have ended as weak as King Xiang of Yin or as young as Duke Min, and the treachery of Ziya and Qingfu might never have arisen. Yet how was it that, just as Duke Huan was rectifying the state and the blood oath had yet to be inscribed, he failed to consider the great concern of leaving no heir, instead fretting over the question of avoiding calamity? Compared to one who marries without informing his parents, how much worse was his conduct? Only by considering both cases together can one understand why the two sages’ marriages without informing parents were righteous, and why Mencius’ exercise of expediency was so profound.

The *Book of Rites* states: The rites of marriage mark the beginning of ten thousand generations. To marry from a different clan is to draw close to distant kin while reinforcing distinctions. The betrothal gifts must be sincere in word, and nothing should be withheld in informing the parents with honesty and trust. Trust is the foundation of serving others, and trust is the virtue of a wife. Once united as one, it endures for a lifetime without change—thus, when the husband dies, she does not remarry.

The record states: That this is placed after the *Book of Rites* is the expediency of a great sage. The great rites are the constant principle. To correct the constant principle before it aligns with ritual is like one who can establish the norm yet speak of expediency. Thus, there were those who married within their own clan and called it "Wu Mencius," those who defied honesty and trust and wept as the woman of Wu was sent away, those who neglected the proper words and gifts and quarreled like rats and dogs, and those who betrayed their vow to grow old together and were not even as steadfast as quails and magpies—all were criminals for ten thousand generations.

The *Book of Songs* says: The queen, thinking of her lord who is not by her side, says:
*"Gathering the curling dock, I cannot fill my shallow basket.
Alas, I think of my beloved, truly upon the Zhou road.
I climb that high mound, my horses weary.
I pour from that golden goblet, hoping to ease my longing.
I climb that high ridge, my horses faltering.
I pour from that rhinoceros-horn cup, hoping to ease my sorrow.
I climb that rocky slope, my horses stumble.
My attendants are exhausted—oh, how can I sigh thus?"*

The record states: Some say this poem was composed during King Wen’s imprisonment at Youli—does this not show understanding? Though King Zhou’s governance was indeed cruel, the heart of a minister who deserved execution was not something King Wen sought to change. The queen’s inner anxiety and fear, her outward devotion and service—did she not truly walk the Zhou road? Her allusion to wine was not truly to dispel sorrow. Was it not that Chong Hou’s slander was at its peak, while Lü Ya’s schemes had yet to unfold? In the end, with no recourse, she could only sigh in despair—yet can the queen not be called a paragon of utmost virtue?

The southern states, transformed by King Wen’s virtue, saw the feudal lords and ministers serving on distant missions, while their wives remained at home. Moved by the changing seasons, they longed for their lords, saying:
*"The katydids chirp, the crickets leap.
I have not seen my lord—my heart is heavy with sorrow.
But when I see him at last, when I behold him at last, my heart is at peace.
I climb that southern mountain, gathering bracken.
I have not seen my lord—my heart is filled with grief.
But when I see him at last, when I behold him at last, my heart is glad.
I climb that southern hill, gathering ferns.
I have not seen my lord—my heart is filled with sorrow.
But when I see him at last, when I behold him at last, my heart is at ease."*

The record states: The commentary treats this poem as akin to the *Zhou Nan*’s *"Curling Dock"*—for when Zhou was above and the Lord of the West below, though the feudal lords harbored private admiration for his virtue, they were in truth serving the public duty. Their sorrow could not be suppressed. How much more so when the marshes of Youli were filled with mutilated men, as if they could not prevail? Yet once they saw their lords and rejoiced, the emotions of public and private, the distinctions of high and low, were both fulfilled. This is the transformation of *Shao Nan*. If one were to see only the affection of clasped hands and the longing of separation, how trivial would be the matters of sorrow and joy!

In Wei, a woman, thinking of her lord serving on a distant mission, said:
*"The pheasant flies, its feathers flowing.
I think of my beloved—how distant and perilous the road!
The pheasant flies, its cry rising and falling.
Ah, my lord—truly, you weary my heart.
Gazing at the sun and moon, my thoughts stretch endlessly.
The road is so long—when will you return?
All you noble lords, do you not know virtue?
Neither arrogant nor covetous—why then are your ways not good?"*

The record states: The meaning of this poem is such that even among Confucius’ disciples, few below Zilu could comprehend it.

When you and I stand face to face, only then does the heart of magnanimity arise; when presence and absence are distinguished, only then does the heart of longing arise. Yet at its utmost, a son’s devotion to his parents may lead to execution for a wife’s offense—no punishment could be more severe. A wife’s favor with her father-in-law may lead to her acceptance for her beauty—no demand could be more exacting. The state of Wei was all but ruined and lost, yet the sacrifices to Kang Shu endured, solely because even common men and women still knew ritual and righteousness. From this, one sees that Heaven’s principles and the people’s constant nature are shared alike by the wayfarer and the sage-kings Yao and Shun. How could the way of the former kings in setting forth the poems, and the work of the Master in editing and transmitting them, be but a small contribution?

A woman cast off by her husband composed a poem, saying:
*"The valley wind blows gently,
now overcast, now raining.
We strove to be of one heart—
why should you be angry?
I gathered mallows, gathered radishes,
not spurning their roots.
Let no word of virtue be forgotten—
together to the death with you.
Slowly I walk the road,
my heart at odds within.
Not far, not near—
you barely see me to the border.
Who says the bitter herb is harsh?
To me it is sweet as watercress.
Joyous in your new marriage,
like brother and sister you are.
The Jing is muddied by the Wei—
how turbid its flow!
Joyous in your new marriage,
you scorn me utterly.
Do not pass my weir,
do not touch my bamboo shoots.
My person is not welcomed—
how should I care for what comes after?
Where it is deep,
I pole my boat, I punt.
Where it is shallow,
I swim, I wade.
Whether present or absent,
I strive to seek it.
When the common folk suffer misfortune,
I crawl to their aid.
Yet you cannot bear me—
instead, you treat me as an enemy.
Having blocked my virtue,
you sell what will not sell.
Once I feared poverty and hardship,
and stood with you in ruin.
Now that we have lived and borne children,
you compare me to poison.
I stored fine provisions,
to ward off the winter.
Joyous in your new marriage,
you use me to fend off hardship.
Furious and violent,
you demand I toil for you.
You do not recall the past—
how I was steadfast in coming to you."*

The record states: Observing the words of the abandoned wife, the ancients compared them to those of loyal ministers and filial sons. Their sincerity and earnestness, the measured grace of their phrasing—these were not truly about such an event. Why? Within the inner chambers, affection often obscures righteousness. Unless one were a peddler or wanderer, who would lightly cast off his wife? Moreover, with the seven grounds for divorce clearly defined and the three conditions for not divorcing established, commoners had no reason to delay remarriage, nor was it permissible to revel in a new union. At the moment of being cast off, the mind is perverse and the words disordered—lacking the skill of a ghostwriter, and devoid of the benefit of learning. How could a woman compose *"Valley Wind"* on her own?

Yet perhaps it was a worthy of Wei, dwelling in a disordered state and serving an benighted lord. When she says *"strive, let no word be forgotten,"* it is the loyalty of heart to heart; when she says *"crawling, I feared hardship,"* it is the affection of hand and foot; when she speaks of *"mallows, radishes, and stored provisions,"* it is the grace of service; when she speaks of *"the Jing muddied, the Wei clear,"* it is the virtue of self-reflection. Yet as the newcomers were now in favor, she could not but be treated with thin courtesy—*"not far, not near"*—and could not but face punishment—*"furious and violent."* As for the heart of the noble man, how could it dwell in such meanness? It would only say: *"My person is not welcomed—how should I care for what comes after?"*

This poem carries a tone of unhurried composure, a spirit of stirring emotion, a principle of resentment without anger, and a sentiment of departure yet lingering regard—who would claim a mere woman could achieve such depth? Among solitary ministers and disinherited sons who read this, few would not set down the poem and sigh.

*The Airs of Zheng* records the admonitions of a worthy husband and wife:
*"The wife says, ‘The cock has crowed.’*
*The husband says, ‘The dawn is dim.’*
*‘Rise and see the night—*
*the bright stars still gleam.’*
*‘We soar, we hover—*
*hunt with fowling arrows, ride with steeds.’*
*‘With arrows we strike them,*
*and with you I’ll prepare the feast.’*
*‘Feast and drink wine,*
*and with you grow old together.’*
*‘Lute and zither in hand,*
*all is serene and good.’"*

The Record states: *Husband and wife determine a household’s survival or ruin. Lute and zither reflect a person’s order or chaos.* A household’s survival hinges on the cock’s crow and the dim dawn. If one indulges in dissipation and excess, life will not flourish; if life does not flourish, the household must falter. A person’s order or chaos hinges on clasping hands and growing old together. If one’s virtue wavers, the home will not thrive; if the home does not thrive, love will surely depart. This tranquility and harmony bear great weight—yet with fury and violence, how can a household’s Way ever be fulfilled?

*"Knowing your coming, I gift you with pendants;*
*knowing your compliance, I present you with pendants;*
*knowing your love, I repay you with pendants."*

The Record states: *When one gives me a peach, I return a plum—this is the common exchange of repayment. When one gives me a quince, I return jade—this is the utmost of sincerity. Thus it is said: ‘Not repayment, but eternal love.’* Yet if, knowing your coming, I present you with pendants—how then should repayment be measured?

Zheng, lost in dissipation and forgetful of return, delights only in *The Quiet Girl* and *The Lacquered Wei*—in city corners and riverbanks, in crimson flutes and peonies. One cannot demand of it kinship with the worthy or friendship with the good, for the duties within the household have already perished. Though its metal rings clear and its elegance lingers, how can the feeling of *The Black Robes* be falsely ascribed to it?

The worthy consort of Qi, attending her lord, would say at the approach of dawn:
*"The parrot has cried, the court is full.*
*Not the parrot’s cry—*
*the buzzing of flies.*
*The east grows bright, the court thrives.*
*Not the east’s brightness—*
*the glow of the moon.*
*Insects hum in flight—*
*how sweet to dream with you.*
*The assembly will soon disperse—*
*let none resent me for detaining you."*

The Record states: *Observing this poem, its meaning is clear, its words harmonious.*

For in ancient times, within the inner chambers of the palace, not only the virtuous women of the boudoir, but even the attendants and tutors—all possessed admonitory teachings and recitations of counsel. Thus their poem declares:

*"The cock has crowed, the court is full."*
—intending to urge the lord to rise early and hold court, yet he instead takes it as *"Not the cock’s crow, but the buzzing of flies."*

Again it says:
*"The east grows bright, the court thrives."*
—intending to urge the lord to rise early and hold court, yet he instead takes it as *"Not the east’s brightness, but the glow of the moon."*

Even as the insects hum in flight and dawn has broken, still he has not risen to attend court. Then she asks: *"How could I not wish to dream with you?"* Yet the assembled ministers, awaiting the lord’s appearance, will soon disperse and depart. *"Must they resent me for detaining you?"*

Here, the phrasing between superior and subordinate flows smoothly, the reasoning stands firm—thus it is preserved for reference.

From the *Shangshu Dazhuan*: In ancient times, when the queen consort was to attend the lord, she would first extinguish the candles, then relight them. Upon entering the chamber, she would remove her court robes and don the informal attire before serving the lord. At cock’s crow, the Grand Master would announce the hour to the lord, whereupon the queen consort would jingle the jade pendants of her girdle in her chamber to signal her departure. Then, the gatekeeper would strike the watchman’s clapper to announce the opening of the gates. Afterward, the Junior Master would report the break of dawn to the lord, and the queen consort would enter the courtyard to stand in attendance as the lord proceeded to court.

It is recorded: By such means, there would be no confusion—no mistaking the cock’s crow for the buzzing of flies, nor would she incur the reproach of removing her hairpin to await punishment. This is preserved for reference.

From the *Waiji*: King Xuan of Zhou once rose late. Queen Jiang removed her hairpin and earrings, awaiting punishment in the secluded lane. She sent her governess to address the king: “The king delights in sensual pleasures and forgets virtue, neglects ritual and rises late—disorder arises from this. As your humble consort, I dare to accept blame.” The king replied: “I lack virtue and have brought this fault upon myself; it is not the queen’s transgression.” Thereafter, he devoted himself to governance, holding early court and adjourning late, ultimately earning the reputation of a revival.

It is recorded: The Jiang clan of Qi were kin by marriage to the Zhou. Thus, both Yi Jiang and Queen Jiang hailed from Qi, and the *Ode of the Cock’s Crow* is also attributed to Qi. Temporally, they are not far apart, and their moral intent is closely aligned—perhaps this was the very admonition Queen Jiang presented. Thus, it was praised as the recitation of a worthy consort and her governess, distinguishing it from the *Greater Elegantiae*. Otherwise, why would one fear being resented for detaining the lord, yet regard the reversal of robes and garments as commonplace? Yet this cannot be verified.

From the *Spring and Autumn Annals*: In the first year of Duke Zhuang of Lu, in winter, the tenth month, the King’s Daughter was married to Qi. In the second year, in autumn, the seventh month, the Queen of Qi died.

It is recorded: This was the King’s Daughter, who upon marriage to Qi became a queen consort. Yet it is written that she “died”—why? For at that time, the Son of Heaven had utterly failed in his lordly duty; the Duke of Qi’s debauchery had reached its nadir; the trepidation of Wen Jiang had vanished; and Duke Zhuang of Lu had abandoned all pretense of avenging shame. Can birds and beasts share the same path as humans? Alas for the King’s Daughter, to be made equal in rank to such as these! The Son of Heaven had reduced himself to the level of beasts—did he not know that even a humble woman’s resolve cannot be forced? Scarcely had she returned to Qi when she departed this world, barely surviving a few months. Was it that her trials and tribulations proved unbearable, her shame too great to endure? Or did the overbearing lust of the Jiang clan drive her to flee, thinking, *“One with a human heart would not conceive such thoughts,”* and so she perished suddenly? The *Book of Changes* says: *“Beset by difficulties, encumbered by obstacles, riding a piebald horse—though a woman remains chaste, she does not bear children.”* The King’s Daughter embodied this. Yet the phoenix among crows, the pearl among stones, cannot be tainted by the vileness of Qi Xiang. Our Master Confucius highlighted her case to curb licentiousness, preserve chastity, shame his contemporaries, and admonish later generations—his intent was profound. Had he merely recorded her marriage and death as matters of protocol, it would have been a superficial account.

In the fourth year of Duke Zhuang, in the third month, Lady Ji of Ji died. In the sixth month, on the day *yiwu*, the Duke of Qi buried Lady Ji of Ji. In the twelfth year, in spring, the third month of the royal calendar, Lady Shu Ji returned to Hao. In the twenty-ninth year, in winter, the twelfth month, Lady Shu Ji died. In the thirtieth year, in the eighth month, on the day *guihai*, Lady Shu Ji was buried.

Hu’s Commentary states: In the fourth year of Duke Zhuang, when the state of Ji was forced into exile, Lady Shu Ji only then returned to the capital. For the Marquis of Ji had just died, and thus Lady Shu Ji returned at that time. The term “return” is used appropriately, as the ancestral temples were in Hao, and she returned to tend to their sacrifices. Lu, as the ancestral state, held the duty of receiving returning women. Though Ji had perished, she did not return to Lu—this was her upholding integrity and duty, refusing to compromise her wifely conduct despite the state’s demise. The people of Lu esteemed her virtue and bestowed upon her enhanced honors and rites. Thus, her return, death, and burial were all meticulously recorded in the historical annals. Our Master Confucius preserved them without omission, to encourage later generations.

It is recorded: Principle and power are the greatest adversaries in the world, yet they are also utterly unequal. When principle prevails, it endures for ten thousand generations without change; when power prevails, it lasts but a moment before being questioned. Why? The heart governs principle, while authority governs power. The authority of a state lies with others, but a woman’s resolve lies within herself. Thus, though Qi’s power could destroy Ji, it could not destroy Lady Ji’s resolve. A lord may be captured, but a wife’s burial rites cannot be seized. The Sage inscribed this in the Classics to reveal the beauty of steadfast integrity and duty, while the evil of Qi, Xiang, and Duke Huan of Lu stands self-condemned without need for reproach. The Commentary suggests that the burial was a display of favor—could this truly be the case?

From the *Commentary*: The Duke of Qi murdered the lord of Lu and annihilated the state of his in-laws, yet he buried their dead with ceremony—this is like inflicting cruelty upon a person and then soothing them with a caress. Such an interpretation is incorrect.

From the *Zuozhuan*: Before Duke Huan of Lu was betrothed to Qi, the Duke of Qi wished to marry Wen Jiang to Prince Hu of Zheng. The prince declined. When asked his reason, he replied: “Each person has their match. Qi is too great—it is not my match.” The *Odes* say: *“Seek abundant fortune for yourself—it lies within me alone. What need have I of a great state?”* The gentleman remarked: *“He was wise to consider his own interests.”* Later, after the prince’s defeat of the Rong army, the Duke of Qi again proposed marriage. The prince firmly refused. When asked his reason, he replied: *“Without business in Qi, I still dared not. Now, at the king’s command, I hasten to Qi’s aid—were I to accept a wife and return, it would be as if I had sold my army’s merit. What would the people say of me?”* Thus, he declined through the Earl of Zheng.

The Record states: Observing the case of Zheng’s Prince Hu, I cannot but lament that the age declines and the Dao wanes, that no hegemon has yet arisen, that a lord cannot protect his ministers and is held hostage by neighboring states, that a father cannot protect his son and must rely on powerful allies. The Five Hegemons’ decree never altered the succession of a ruler’s own son—why then should one wait upon another’s kin? It never made a concubine a wife—why then should one change chambers? If both [declining marriage and accepting it] lead to the loss of one’s state, this would be no different from the adage that the noble change friends and the rich change wives. Why then should one trouble oneself over such matters?

Yet what, then, was Prince Hu to do? Mencius said: *“Act with benevolence and you will be honored; act without it and you will be disgraced.”* Now, to hate disgrace yet dwell in unbenevolence is like hating dampness yet dwelling in low ground. This is what is meant by *“seeking abundant fortune for yourself—it lies within me alone.”*

Prince Hu lived in the age of Duke Zhuang of Zheng, when the Three Bonds had already dissolved. Even if he had striven for goodness, he would still have feared ruin—how much worse, then, that he willingly exchanged hostages, schemed for Di victories, and treated marriage to Qi as a matter of mere weight and consequence!

Some ask: *“Prince Hu once married before performing the ancestral rites, yet now he refuses this marriage—why?”* The answer lies in his being a man pleased with his own trivial virtues. Master Zhu’s criticism of him as *“weak, timid, careless, and impractical”* is apt. One who is pleased with trivial virtues has not yet attained true insight; it is only through indolence and failure to reflect, through impracticality and distance from reality, that he willingly submits to others without demur. The *Poet* rebukes him, saying: *“O reckless youth—how reckless indeed!”* Could this not be his very fault?

From the *Biographies of Exemplary Women*: Lady Xuan of Wei was the daughter of the Marquis of Qi. When she was married to Wei and had reached the city gate, the Lord of Wei died. Her governess said: “You may return now.” The lady did not heed her and entered, observing three years of mourning. When the mourning was complete, her younger brother ascended the throne and requested: “Wei is a small state and cannot accommodate two kitchens. I humbly ask to share one.” The lady refused. The Lord of Wei sent envoys to complain to Qi, and her brothers all wished to yield to him, dispatching messengers to persuade her. Yet the lady remained unmoved.

The compiler notes: Examining the rites, in *Zengzi’s Questions*, it is asked: “If a woman has been received in marriage but is still on the way when her parents die...” There is no text concerning one who has reached the city gate when the lord dies. The gentleman would say: since she had not yet become a wife, there is doubt as to whether she should observe mourning. Yet she observed three years of mourning—was this not excessively generous? Moreover, for a woman who had not yet become a wife to be asked to share a kitchen—was this in accord with ritual? The lord’s younger brother acted like a beast. The customs of Qi were licentious and decadent, so it was fitting that the lady ultimately refused.

Lady Taoying of Lu was the daughter of a Lu family. Widowed young, she raised her orphaned children without strong elder brothers, spinning and weaving to support them. Some in Lu, hearing of her virtue, sought to marry her. Hearing this, she feared she could not escape and composed a song:
*Alas! The yellow wagtail, widowed so soon,*
*Seven years alone, never paired.*
*With neck bent, she sleeps apart,*
*Not among the flock.*
*At midnight she cries in sorrow,*
*Thinking of her lost mate.*
*Heaven decreed early widowhood—*
*Sleeping alone, what harm?*
*A widow ponders this,*
*Tears falling in rows.*
*Alas, how sad!*
*The dead cannot be forgotten.*
*Even flying birds are thus—*
*How much more the chaste and good.*
*Though a worthy mate may come,*
*She will never remarry.*
When the people of Lu heard this, they said: “This lady cannot be won.” And so they dared not pursue her further.

The compiler notes: Observing the *Song of the Yellow Wagtail*, its meaning is earnest, its emotion mournful. It possesses the virtue of the *Feng* poets yet lacks resentful words—truly one who upholds ritual and propriety. Even if creatures of another kind heard it, would they not be moved? How much more so humans. This is the uprightness of wives and concubines, the model of ritual and the Way. Those who cut off their noses, sever their arms, shear their hair, or slice their ears—these cannot be called upright.

Consort Fan was the wife of King Zhuang of Chu. The king loved hunting, and though she remonstrated, he did not cease. Thus she refused to eat the meat of birds and beasts. The king mended his ways and devoted himself to governance. Once, after holding court late into the day, the consort asked: “Why so late? Are you not hungry or weary?” The king replied: “Speaking with the worthy, I forget hunger and fatigue.” The consort asked: “Who are these worthy ones of whom you speak?” He said: “Vigilant Master.” The consort covered her mouth and laughed. The king asked: “Why do you laugh?” She replied: “I have served you for over ten years, sending others to seek beauties to present to you. Now there are two more worthy than I and seven of equal rank. How could I not wish to monopolize your favor? Yet I cannot let private desires obscure the public good—I wish you to know many people. Vigilant Master has served as Chu’s minister for over ten years. Those he recommends are either his kinsmen or relatives; I have never heard of him advancing the worthy or dismissing the unworthy. This is to deceive his lord and block the path of the worthy. Is my laughter not justified?” She reported this to the king, and Vigilant Master left his mat, unable to respond. Thereupon he withdrew from court and sent for Sunshu Ao to serve as prime minister. After three years of his governance, King Zhuang became a hegemon—this was the achievement of Consort Fan.

The compiler notes: That the consort refused to eat the meat of birds and beasts may be called remonstrance through her own conduct. But to use this to advance the worthy—I do not understand it. Sunshu Ao’s worthiness was certainly beyond Vigilant Master’s ken, yet Consort Fan’s reputation was well known. Could it be that the hunting remonstrance was fabricated to support this claim? Yet this cannot be verified.

Lady Gaoxing was a widow of Liang. Her beauty was renowned in appearance and conduct. After her husband’s death, she never remarried. The nobles of Liang vied to marry her, but none succeeded. When the King of Liang heard of this, he sent a minister to propose marriage. She said: “I have heard that a woman’s duty is to remain steadfast after one marriage to preserve her chastity. How could I disregard reputation and honor, willingly debase myself, abandon virtue for profit, and thus fail to be human?” She then took a knife and cut off her nose, saying: “I have already punished myself. The reason I do not die is that I cannot bear to leave my young orphans.” The minister reported this to the king, who admired her righteousness, exalted her conduct, exempted her from taxes, and honored her with the title “Gaoxing.”

The compiler notes: According to ancient ritual, the feudal lords took nine wives, and the two strongest states exceeded this. Few rulers had the principle of not remarrying, lest they abandon virtue for lust. Thus, marrying once was the limit—how could one approach a woman who had lost her integrity? The King of Liang was arrogant and unprincipled, certainly not to be reproached. Yet the women of Liang recorded this in their annals, and readers do not censure the lack of restraint in the Han dynasty or the minister’s failure to remonstrate, instead merely praising the lady’s lofty conduct. Alas! If the lady’s conduct was lofty, how base was the king’s?

From the *Book of Han*: Ban Jieyu was the daughter of Ban Si, a cavalry officer of the Left Section. Gifted and eloquent, when Emperor Cheng toured the rear palace, he once wished to share her palanquin. She declined, saying: “In ancient paintings, the sagely rulers all had famous ministers at their side. By the end of the Three Dynasties, rulers had female favorites. If I were to share your palanquin, would it not resemble this?” The emperor praised her words and desisted. When the Empress Dowager heard of this, she rejoiced, saying: “In ancient times there was Consort Fan; today there is Jieyu.” Whenever she recited the *Book of Songs*, particularly the *Odes of the Fair and Good Maiden* and *The Female Instructor*, she would repeat them thrice. When Jieyu appeared, her demeanor always followed ancient ritual. Later, Zhao Feiyan gained favor and acted wantonly, and her partisans slandered Jieyu, saying: “She practices sorcery and curses.”

The emperor questioned her further, and Jieyu replied: “I have heard that life and death are determined by fate, and wealth and honor lie with Heaven. If one cultivates uprightness yet remains unrewarded, what can be gained by resorting to wickedness? Moreover, if ghosts and spirits possess awareness, they would not accept the complaints of the disloyal. If they lack awareness, what benefit would complaints bring? Thus, I have not done so.” The emperor approved of her response and pitied her. Fearing prolonged danger, Jieyu requested to serve the Empress Dowager at Changxin Palace, and the emperor granted her wish. When the emperor passed, she was assigned to tend the imperial mausoleum. Upon her death, she was buried within its grounds.

The chronicler remarks: Observing Jieyu’s adherence to righteousness, I lament Ban Gu’s lack of discernment. For women, the loss of favor and the ebb of influence are commonplace. Yet to preserve one’s wisdom and safeguard oneself is the mark of a true gentleman. The perils of treacherous schemes and fleeting power are like wildfire—so the *Book of Songs* says: *“The blaze spreads through the poplars.”* And again: *“Who can endure scorching heat? It cannot be restrained, nor can one draw near to warm oneself.”* Thus, it is better to dwell in seclusion, hidden like a dragon in still waters, entrusting oneself to the humble currents of Changxin Palace, than to be scorched and blinded, becoming the foremost sinner of the inner chambers. Had Ban Gu understood this principle, he might have rested upon the classics, reclined in a modest gatehouse, untethered above and unrooted below—would this not have been the lofty attainment of the enlightened and the noble integrity of the wise? Instead, he obsessed over schemes for advancement, plotting from dawn to dusk, clinging to the gates of power, and wading through treacherous paths. The words of his *Discourse on Guests* cannot be mentioned in the same breath as the sentiments of Ban Jieyu’s *Song of the Round Fan*. With Ban Gu’s vast knowledge of past and present, hailed as a master historian, how could his judgment of character, his grasp of the great principles of conduct, fall short of a woman’s? Yet he could not escape the triumph of substance over form—a cause for profound regret among gentlemen.

Empress Wang of Emperor Ping was Wang Mang’s daughter, gentle and virtuous with steadfast conduct. When Emperor Ping ascended the throne, Wang Mang wielded power and betrothed his daughter to the emperor. A year later, the emperor died, and after Wang Mang usurped the throne, the empress, then eighteen, frequently claimed illness and refused to attend court. Wang Mang, both reverent and grieving, considered marrying her off. He ordered Chengxin, Duke of the State and son of the General of the Establishment, along with his heir Xiang, to prepare physicians and inquire after her health. The empress flew into a rage, flogging her attendants, and thereafter took to her bed, refusing to rise. Wang Mang dared not press her further. When Han forces executed Wang Mang and set fire to Weiyang Palace, the empress declared: “How can I face the Han house?” She threw herself into the flames and perished.

The chronicler remarks: Did Empress Ping’s defiance of her father compare to Empress Yuan’s reproach of Wang Mang? The devotion of a dutiful wife and the longevity of a filial mother have been praised through the ages—who would have thought it could be otherwise? Empress Yuan of Han lived to eighty, spanning the reigns of Emperors Yuan, Cheng, Ai, and Ping, serving as the mother of the realm for over sixty years. Her brothers wielded power in succession, holding the reins of state, and thus she nurtured and protected them, enabling their rebellion. Only when Wang Mang usurped the throne and sought to replace the Liu with the Wang did she grasp the imperial seal to resist him—alas, too late. She was not as admirable as one so young who upheld her principles.

The *Later Han History* records: In the first year of *Zhongyuan* of Emperor Guangwu (34 CE), the emperor dispatched the Minister of Works to announce at the Temple of the High Ancestor: “The High Emperor decreed that none but the Liu clan should be enfeoffed as kings. Yet Empress Lü murdered Prince Zhao and monopolized power for the Lü clan. By the grace of the altars of soil and grain, Lü Lu and Lü Chan were executed. Heaven’s mandate nearly fell, but the perilous court was restored. Empress Lü is unworthy to share sacrifices with the High Emperor in the ancestral temple or to be honored alongside the supreme. Empress Bo, however, was virtuous, kind, and filial. Emperor Wen ruled with wisdom, and his descendants enjoyed blessings that endure to this day. Thus, let Empress Bo be honored as *High Empress* and share sacrifices at the Earth Altar. Let the spirit tablet of Empress Lü be moved to her garden temple, where offerings shall be made seasonally.”

The chronicler remarks: Observing the fates of the Lü and Bo empresses, I am struck by how fortune and misfortune, prosperity and decline, hinge upon the slightest shifts in timing. When the empress and the emperor first rose from obscurity, enduring countless battles to seek him in the marshes—this was one moment. When the emperor favored Consort Qi and doted on Prince Ru Yi, the balance of power shifting—this was another. When she arrogantly assumed regency, ruling the realm from the throne—this was yet another. At its extreme, there arose the *Book of Metal and Stone*, the poison of the zhen and the zhi birds, the calamity of clan extermination, and the schemes to change the dynasty. By the principles of the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, this was self-annihilation before Heaven—no prayers could avail. Yet the great ministers of the Han court failed to uphold their oaths of blood, nor did they condemn her by the standards of the *Spring and Autumn*. With this principle unclarified, it is no wonder that the Lü were overthrown and the Xin usurped the throne. Thus, it was fitting for the emperor to elevate Bo and demote Lü.

Wang Ba, a man of lofty integrity in his youth, had a wife of equal virtue and conduct. When Wang Mang usurped the throne, Wang Ba severed all ties with officialdom. During the *Jianwu* era, he was summoned to the capital but refused to yield. He had once been friends with Linghu Zibo of the same commandery. Later, Zibo became Chancellor of Chu, and his son served as a clerk in the commandery. When the son was sent to deliver a letter to Wang Ba, he arrived in grand style, with carriages, horses, and an entourage befitting his rank. Wang Ba’s own son was plowing in the fields when he heard a guest had arrived. He set down his plow and returned home, whereupon he saw Linghu’s son, disheveled and ashamed, unable to lift his gaze. After the guest departed, the son lingered outside, unwilling to enter. His mother, puzzled, asked the reason. Wang Ba replied: “Zibo and I were never equals. Earlier, I saw his son—his appearance and attire were radiant, his bearing refined. Yet my son is unkempt, gap-toothed, and ignorant of propriety. The depth of a father’s love made me unconsciously lose composure.” His wife said: “You cultivate purity and integrity, heedless of rank and emolument. Now that Zibo has risen in status, how does he compare to your loftiness? Why abandon your long-held principles and feel shame before a mere child?”

Wang Ba burst into laughter and said: “Indeed so!” Thereupon, they retreated into seclusion for the rest of their lives.

The record states: Why judge a person not by what they strive for, but by what they overlook? For the bonds of poverty and lowliness are hard to forget, yet when one compares oneself to another, it is difficult to let go of such thoughts. Even a minor grievance can diminish the bond of shared hardship. How profound was the insight of Wang Ba’s wife—free from self, free from others, free from worldly attachments, let alone the vagaries of世态. If one can act thus, one naturally descends from the hall of vanity, without need for deep mountains or dense forests.

Bao Xuan’s wife, née Huan, styled Shaojun, once studied under Shaojun’s father. Her father, admiring Bao’s purity and frugality, gave his daughter to him in marriage, sending her off with a lavish dowry. Bao was displeased and said to his wife: “Shaojun was raised in wealth and luxury, accustomed to fine adornments, while I am truly poor and lowly. I dare not accept such gifts.” His wife replied: “My father saw that you cultivate virtue and live simply, so he sent me, his humble daughter, to serve you with towel and comb. Since I now attend a gentleman, I will follow your command.” Bao smiled and said: “If you can do so, it aligns with my aspirations.” His wife then returned all her attendants and fine garments, donning coarse hempen skirts instead. Together, they pulled a deer-cart back to their hometown, where she bowed to her mother-in-law, carried jars to fetch water, and diligently observed the way of a wife. Their village praised her.

The record states: The allure of softness and charm not only undermines resolve but also fosters transgression. Sima Xiangru, though talented and refined, devoted himself to the zither’s seductive melodies. Ma Rong, a scholar of renown, delighted in his crimson curtains. I have seen how poverty and lowliness can sway a man, just as wealth and nobility can lead him astray. How then could he remain unyielding before power and force? Thus, only with conduct like Shaojun’s can one attain the integrity of Zidu.

The wife of Huangfu Gui of Anding was skilled in composition and calligraphy. After Gui’s death, she remained in the prime of her beauty. Dong Zhuo, hearing of her reputation, sent a betrothal gift of a hundred carriages laden with silk and treasures, twenty horses, and slaves and servants filling the road. The wife, dressed in plain garments, arrived at Dong’s gate, knelt, and pleaded her refusal with bitter sorrow. Dong ordered his attendants to draw their blades and encircle her, declaring: “My authority and teachings are meant to make the four seas submit. How could they not prevail over a mere woman?” The wife stood and cursed him: “You are but a barbarian spawn, poisoning the realm—do you not yet realize this? My ancestors were men of pure virtue through the generations. The Huangfu clan produced talents in both civil and martial arts, loyal ministers of Han. You, sir, are no more than a lackey sent to run errands. How dare you presume to act improperly toward the wife of your lord?”

The enraged Dong dragged her carriage into the courtyard, suspended her head from the axle, and whipped the horses to gallop in all directions until she died beneath the wheels. Later generations extolled her and painted her likeness, calling her the "Paragon of Propriety."

The record states: How do Guan’s resolve and his wife’s stand compare to Lady Ying’s and Kong Rong’s? Guan’s shame lay in not joining the clique, while his wife’s courage lay in not compromising herself—peerless in virtue, they need feel no shame. Yet Kong Rong, mindful of Dong Zhuo’s favor, was ultimately executed; Lady Ying, too, at Cao Cao’s tribunal, bowed her head in bitter lament. Thus, one preserved integrity while the other did not, one lived while the other died—no comparison can be made between them.

Empress Xianmu, the middle daughter of Cao Cao, was elevated to Lady in the twenty-ninth year of Jian’an. After Empress Fu’s murder, she was enthroned as empress. When Wei received the abdication, envoys were sent to demand the imperial seal and sash. The empress, furious, refused, and this occurred several times. Finally, she summoned the envoys inside, personally berated them with the seal and sash in hand, cast them beneath the carriage rail, and wept uncontrollably, saying: "Heaven will not bless you." Those around her could not bear to look up.

In the first year of Jingchu, she passed away and was interred in Shan Mausoleum, with carriages, robes, and rites all following Han precedent.

The record states: In the Spring and Autumn period, Yong Ji asked her mother: "Who is dearer, father or husband?" Her mother replied: "Any man may be a husband, but a father is only one—how can they be compared?" Yet if a father’s deeds resemble those of Wang Mang or Cao Cao, can one still value father over husband? Observing the deeds of Empress Ping and Empress Xian, the crime of Yong Ji in killing her husband and the fault of Zhong Mu in indulging her daughter can never be undone.

*Hongdao Lu*, Scroll Twenty-One, concludes.
*Hongdao Lu*, Scroll Twenty-Two, *Righteousness*.

**On the Righteousness of Husband and Wife**

From *The Book of Jin*: Princess Consort Wang of the Crown Prince Minhuai, styled Huifeng, was the daughter of Grand Commandant Yan. She was chaste and gentle, possessed of resolve and integrity. When the Crown Prince was deposed and confined to Jintang City, Yan memorialized to dissolve the marriage. Huifeng wailed and returned home, moving all who witnessed her to tears along the road.

Later, when Liu Yao breached Luoyang, he seized her and bestowed her upon his general, Qiao Shu. As they crossed the Meng Ford on the Yellow River, intending to take her as his wife, Huifeng drew her sword and rebuked Shu, saying: *"I am the wife of the Crown Prince of the August Emperor, the daughter of the Minister of Works—how dare a petty barbarian cur like you lay hands on me?"* With these words, she cast herself into the river. Her attendant concubine, named Liuchu, was the granddaughter of Wei Junyi’s admonisher. Seeing her mistress’s resolve, she declared: *"If the great one has done so, the lesser should do the same."* And she too leapt into the river.

The record states: Observing the customs of Jin, I find them benighted and deluded, ever prizing hollow reputations while heedless of flaws and faults. Yet these two women were jades among rubble, ice within a vessel. Yan, though of no worth, busied himself with schemes for three burrows and hastened to sever the marriage, yet in the end, his own integrity was wanting. Had it not been for their steadfast conduct, how could their purity have been preserved? Compared to those who, like crumbling walls, were crushed to death, they were true jewels among pebbles—how could they be ranked among the common stones?

The calamity of empty discourse left the court unable to shield the state, the elite unable to protect themselves, and the common folk unable to safeguard their sons and daughters. Alas, how grievous! This is a warning for all ages.

From *The Old Book of Tang*:

On one occasion, after Emperor Taizong dismissed court and withdrew to the palace, he raged, saying, “I must kill that old rustic!” At the time, Empress Zhangsun stood beside him. She asked, “Of whom do you speak?” The emperor replied, “Wei Zheng is so insolent—he humiliates me at every court assembly.” The empress withdrew, then reappeared in full court robes, standing in the courtyard. Startled, the emperor asked the reason. She said, “Your servant has heard that when the lord is enlightened, his ministers are forthright. Now that Wei Zheng is forthright, it is because Your Majesty is enlightened. How dare I not offer congratulations?” The emperor was pleased.

The record observes: The emperor’s anger was not truly an affront from Wei Zheng, but rather a lapse in the purity of his own heart. The empress’s congratulations were not a true alignment of her heart, but merely delight in a fine reputation. Had she truly understood the importance of a pure heart, she would not have rejoiced in this. And had she recognized the urgency of employing worthy men, she would not have been angered by it. Had the empress of later times not been so enlightened, Wei Zheng would have had cause to repay the grace of Wen’s virtue; and had the prince not lost his marriage, the empress would have had no way to dispel the resentment of that old rustic.

Consort Xu Hui, upon hearing of the campaigns to subdue Goguryeo in the east and conquer Kucha in the west, the successive construction of Cuiwei and Yuhua Palaces, and the extravagance of imperial adornments and luxuries, submitted a memorial in remonstrance: “To exhaust finite agricultural labor filling boundless waves, to pursue unsecured foreign multitudes at the cost of our own seasoned troops—this is to repeat the errors of old. When the First Emperor of Qin annexed the six kingdoms, he only hastened the foundations of peril and ruin. When Emperor Wu of Jin overran the three regions, he merely completed the work of collapse and defeat. Was this not the result of pride in achievement, reliance on might, abandonment of virtue, disregard for the state, pursuit of gain while forgetting danger, and indulgence of desire?”

Jewels and curios, craft and artifice—these are the axes that hew down states; pearls and jades, brocades and embroideries—these are the poison that bewilders the heart. To model governance on frugality is still to fear excess; to model it on excess, how can later generations be restrained?

The emperor praised her words.

It is recorded: In the reign of Taizong, how did one virtuous consort come to such renown? For the rise of Tang was but the reversal of Sui’s old ways, and the excellence of its governance was the achievement of heeding remonstrance. Thus, no one treated it as taboo, nor did near or distant kin deem it presumptuous. Were even the sinew-and-bone ministers of the state’s discipline to soften into pliable compliance, how much more so a woman of virtue within the palace chambers?

Gaozong summoned Changsun Wuji, Li Ji, Yu Zhihe, and Chu Suiliang to the inner palace. Suiliang said: “Today’s summons concerns the empress. The emperor’s will is already set—opposition means certain death. The Grand Commandant is the emperor’s maternal uncle, the Minister Over the Masses a meritorious minister. We must not allow the emperor to bear the name of killing his uncle or his meritorious ministers.” Suiliang, risen from humble origins without military merit, had attained his present rank and, moreover, received the late emperor’s charge. If he did not contest this even at the cost of his life, how could he face the former emperor in the underworld?

Li Ji claimed illness and did not attend. Suiliang then entered the inner palace with Wuji and the others. The emperor turned to them and said: “The empress has no son, while Lady Wu has borne a son. I now intend to install Lady Wu as empress. What say you?”

Suiliang replied: “The empress comes from a distinguished family, chosen for Your Majesty by the late emperor. As he lay dying, he took Your Majesty’s hand and said to me: ‘I entrust my fine son and fine daughter-in-law to you.’ Your Majesty heard these words yourself; they still ring in our ears. The empress has committed no fault—how can she be lightly deposed?”

The emperor was displeased and dismissed them. The next day, he raised the matter again. Suiliang said: “If Your Majesty is determined to replace the empress, I beg you to select from the finest families of the realm. Why must it be the Wu clan? I ask to be excused from the Three Departments.” He added: “If I now act against Your Majesty’s wishes, I deserve death.”

He then placed his official tablet upon the palace steps, removed his headscarf, and kowtowed until blood flowed, pleading to be allowed to retire to his fields. The emperor, enraged, ordered him dragged away. Behind the curtain, the Lady Wu cried out loudly: “Why not beat that old meddler to death?” Wu Zetian said: “Suiliang received the late emperor’s dying charge—he cannot be punished.” Later, Li Ji entered and said: “This is Your Majesty’s family matter; why consult outsiders further?” The emperor’s resolve was thus settled.

A record states: At that time, Wu Zetian, Suiliang, and Li Ji’s loyalties remained undivided as the Jing and Wei rivers. Yet with a single word the next day, the ancestral temples, altars of state, imperial lineage, collateral branches, all ministers, and every official of the Tang stood perilously close to ruin. If Li Ji, favored by the emperor, was indeed the one who should have spoken, then who was truly fit to advise? Suiliang’s courage in correcting the wrong ensured that for ten thousand generations hence, the duties of ruler and minister, husband and wife, and friends would still be known. Had Li Ji spoken first, the late emperor’s words—“my fine son and fine daughter-in-law”—would have been dismissed as unheard, and the principles of Heaven and the hearts of men nearly extinguished. Though his words could not reverse fate, his righteousness shone as bright as the sun; a gentleman cannot but record them.

The Valiant Lady Yang was the wife of Li Kan. When Bian Prefecture fell, enemy forces divided to subdue the surrounding counties. Fearing the city too small and the rebels too fierce, Li Kan wished to abandon it. At the end of the Jianzhong era, when Li Xilie’s forces arrived, Li Kan served as magistrate of Qingcheng. His wife said: “When the enemy comes, we must defend. If our strength fails, we die—who will hold the city if we flee?” Li Kan replied: “We lack soldiers and supplies; what can be done?” His wife said: “If the county is not defended, the land becomes the rebels’ land; the granaries and treasuries, their stores; the people, their soldiers.”

And what would remain for the state? Offer generous rewards to recruit brave men—there may yet be a way to prevail.” Li Kan then summoned the officials and people to the courtyard and said: “Qingcheng is indeed your home, but when my term ends, I shall depart, unlike you, who live on this land where your ancestors’ graves lie. Should we not stand together and die in its defense? How could we bear to bow northward and serve the rebels?” The crowd wept and pledged their allegiance. He then proclaimed: “Those who hurl tiles and stones at the enemy shall be rewarded with a thousand coins; those who slay the enemy with blades and arrows, ten thousand.” Several hundred men were thus assembled and led to the city walls. The lady herself cooked meals to feed the defenders and sent word to the rebels: “The elders of Qingcheng will not surrender. Even if you take our city, it will not enhance your might—you would do better to withdraw at once, for you stand only to lose without gain.” Just then, a rebel commander was struck by an arrow and died, whereupon the enemy retreated. The county remained intact, and Li Kan was later promoted to magistrate of Taiping.

Earlier, during the Wan’nian Tongtian era, when the Khitan raided Pingzhou, Zou Baoying served as prefect. As the city teetered on the brink of collapse, his wife Xi led their household servants and maidservants to defend the walls without yielding. By imperial decree, she was posthumously honored as Lady of Sincere Loyalty. When Mocho attacked Feigu, the wife of the county magistrate Gu Xuanying—Lady Gao—held the city fast, and was later granted the title Lady of Loyalty. During Shi Siming’s rebellion, three women—Hou of Weizhou, Tang of Huazhou, and Wang of Qingzhou—pledged their lives, rushed to the military camp, and joined the fight against the rebels. Xu Shuyuan, the military commissioner of Hua and Pu, reported their valor, and all were appointed as *guoyi* officers. Though such women never forgot their duty to the state, none matched the resolute understanding of the great principles of ruler and subject displayed by the Valiant Lady Yang.

**Recorded Note:** Reviewing the *Tang History*’s accounts of valiant women, most lack coherence, but this record is unusually well-documented, with clear beginnings and ends. Moreover, its praise and censure are never careless—could this not shame the present age? Li Kan, too, was a man who followed others to his death, yet he turned calamity into fortune. When the twenty-four prefectures heard of this, would they not spit in shame at their own cowardice? For not only was there one valiant lady, but three women who would not cease their efforts.

Emperor Wuzong’s favored consort, Lady Wang, was quick-witted by nature. At thirteen, she entered the palace. When the emperor was still Prince of Ying, Emperor Muzong bestowed her upon him. Upon his accession, she was promoted to *cairen* and enjoyed great favor, her gentle compliance much like that of Empress Shun. Whenever the emperor hunted in the imperial park, she always accompanied him, her hunting attire as splendid as his own. They rode side by side, and onlookers could not tell which was the emperor. The emperor wished to make her empress, but Li Deyu opposed it. The emperor grew increasingly obsessed with Daoist alchemists, who claimed: “If I attain immortality, the empress will not share in it, and her beauty will fade.” Lady Wang was deeply troubled. The emperor asked: “If the unthinkable should happen, what would you do?” She wept and replied: “After Your Majesty’s eternal reign, I would follow you in death.” The emperor said no more. As his end neared, the *cairen* took all her stored treasures and distributed them among the palace women. Once she confirmed the emperor had passed, she hanged herself beneath the eaves. Though some among the palace women had once resented her, they now admired her loyalty and were moved to tears.

**Recorded Note:** Following in burial was not an ancient custom, nor was hunting a virtuous pastime. Yet this account is included because, in the Tang dynasty, there were no proper norms for the inner palace, and the emperor’s indulgence in extravagance and excess was particularly worthy of reflection—not merely for the sake of the *cairen*, but as a warning to all.

From the *History of the Song*: Cui, the wife of Bao Yi, was the daughter-in-law of Bao Zheng. Yi died young, leaving behind an infant son. Bao Zheng and his wife suspected Cui would not remain chaste, so they tested her resolve by having their attendants observe her. Cui, disheveled and weeping, said to Bao Zheng: “You are a renowned statesman. I, a humble woman, am honored to serve as your daughter-in-law, performing menial tasks like sweeping and washing. How could I dare defile your household? In life, I am Bao’s wife; in death, I shall be Bao’s ghost. I swear I will never betray this vow.” Later, her son also died. Cui’s mother, Lü, arrived from Xingzhou and tried to persuade her to remarry, saying: “You mourned your husband and guarded your son. Now your son is gone—whom will you guard?” Cui replied: “I did not do this for my son, but for my parents-in-law. Now that my father-in-law has passed, my mother-in-law is aged—how could I bear to leave her?” Lü grew angry: “I would rather die than return alone.” Cui said: “You have come from afar; it would be unjust to let you return alone. But if, upon reaching Xingzhou, you are forced into an unrighteous marriage, I will die by the sword.” They departed together, and Lü, fearing her daughter’s resolve, ultimately dared not compel her.

Bao Zheng once had a concubine who bore a son while staying with her parents. Cui secretly supported the child’s mother, ensuring she cared for him properly. Later, she brought the boy back and named him Dan, so that he might continue the Bao ancestral rites.

**Recorded Note:** Bao Zheng once declared: “If any of my descendants in office commit corruption, they shall not be allowed to return to the family home, nor shall they be buried in the ancestral cemetery. Whoever defies my will is no child or grandchild of mine.” Such was his severity—yet why did he not consider his daughter-in-law’s plight? Why did he allow his attendants to test her? If even the wife of Bao Zheng faced such pressure and suspicion, what hope is there for others? Those who set examples must exercise the utmost caution. Cui not only remained steadfast in her loyalty but also secretly supported her husband’s illegitimate son to preserve the family line. This was no mere act of wifely duty—heaven, it seems, truly favored Bao Zheng’s integrity.

Zhao, the wife of Fu Cha, was the daughter of Fu Pu. Cha was the nephew of Fu Yaoyu. From childhood, he was devoted to learning and indifferent to power and wealth. At eighteen, he passed the imperial examination but had not yet undergone the palace examination. Cai Jing, seeking to recruit him, sent his son Cai Tao and several guards to press him repeatedly, even offering his daughter in marriage. Cha refused to respond. When they forced a meeting, he would not comply.

Later, he ultimately became the son-in-law of Minister Qingxian. Those with discernment already knew his character and capacity were not easily measured. When he served as Vice Minister of War and was sent as an envoy to the Jin, the barbarians had already broken their treaty. Some advised him not to rush, but he replied immediately: "I accepted the imperial command to depart; if I halt upon hearing of danger, how can I answer to my sovereign’s charge?" He proceeded without delay. When he encountered Wanyan Zongbi’s army, the envoy demanded he bow—he refused. Though blades surrounded him like a forest, and some forced him to prostrate himself, he stood firm, unmoved, and argued repeatedly. Turning to his subordinates, Attendants Hou Yan and others, he said: "My death is certain. When my parents hear of it, they will grieve deeply. I pray you remember my words and tell them I died for the state, that this may slightly ease their endless sorrow." He was then killed. When Yan and the others returned, they recounted Fu Cha’s unyielding resolve, his steadfast loyalty so vividly evident. Those who heard were moved to sorrow and admiration.

The Record states: The daughter of Qingxian and the wife of Xiaosu—how their names stand side by side! Fu Cha refused Cai Jing’s overtures and married into the Zhao family, acting without coercion. Thus, when he was sent as an envoy and died for his country, was this mere happenstance? He valued his person highly, hence his strict choice of a spouse; he cherished his kin deeply, hence his unwavering fidelity. The Zhao family’s honor is all the greater—far beyond what Cui or Lü endured under duress.

Lü Zhi’s wife was of the Wu clan. When Zhi was recruited to Zhang Jun’s headquarters, it coincided with Yue Fei’s plan for a major campaign against the Jin. Qin Hui, jealous of Fei, spoke against him to Emperor Gaozong. When Fei came to discuss matters with Commander Zhang Jun, Jun said: "Wang De, commander of the Huai-West army, wishes to be appointed as overall commander. I intend to have you, as a staff officer from the Supervisory Headquarters, lead him—what do you think?" Fei replied: "De and Li Qiong have long been at odds; if you suddenly place Qiong above him, conflict will surely arise. Minister Lü is unversed in military affairs and may not command the troops’ respect." Jun then asked: "What of Zhang Jun and Yang Yizhong?" Fei answered: "Zhang, as Military Commissioner, was once my superior—he is harsh and lacking in strategy. Yizhong is no better than De; how can he command such an army?" Jun, struck by his words, said: "I knew none but you could lead them." Fei replied: "You asked me directly, so I dare not withhold my humble opinion—how could I think of currying favor?" In the end, Jun appointed Wang De as Commander-in-Chief, with Li Qiong as his deputy, and Lü Zhi as military advisor.

When Qiong and De clashed in court, the emperor ordered De to return to Jiankang, placing his army under the Supervisory Headquarters, and sent Zhi to Luzhou to take command. An imperial messenger was dispatched to present him with saddled horses. Zhi bowed to receive the gift and told his family: "Such is the emperor’s command—how can I refuse on principle? I do not fear death, but I fear it will be of no benefit to the state." He and his wife, Wu, wept as they bade each other farewell. Upon arrival, he addressed Qiong and the others: "If you believe yourselves in the right, then you greatly deceive me. Prime Minister Zhang merely favors those who advance boldly; if you achieve merit, even grave faults will be overlooked—how much more minor grievances? You must strive to justify yourselves; I assure you, there is nothing to fear." Qiong and the others were moved to tears.

Once the situation had somewhat stabilized, he secretly memorialized the throne to have the appointment revoked. However, a clerk leaked the contents, and Qiong had the courier intercepted, obtaining the full memorial. Enraged, he happened just then to receive a summons from the court, which had appointed Zhang Jun as Pacification Commissioner of Huaixi and Yang Yizhong as Military Commissioner, ordering Qiong to report to the imperial presence. Fearing the consequences, Qiong rebelled.

That morning, the generals came to pay their respects to Zhi. Once seated, Qiong drew a document from his sleeve and said, “What crime have the officers of this army committed, that such matters should be reported to the court?” Zhi, seeing it, was greatly alarmed and tried to flee, but was too late—Qiong seized him. At the moment of his death, someone retrieved the cloth Zhi had used to bind his hair and returned it to Wu. His wife, née Wu, took the cloth and hanged herself, burying it with a dog. All who heard of it were moved to tears.

**Record:** Envy is a vicious power—whether in the highest courts or the greatest armies, whether among the worthy and loyal ministers and martyrs, or the foolish and rebellious generals and soldiers, none escape its harm. Had Qin Kuai tolerated Yue Fei, then Zhang Jun would not have been provoked to anger. Had Zhang Jun not been provoked, then affairs would not have gone so awry. Had affairs not gone awry, then disaster would not have struck so swiftly, and Qiong’s rebellion and Zhi’s death might never have come to pass. Thus, that hair-binding cloth was the very token of Qin Kuai’s treachery hastening Zhi’s end. Yet even so, Zhang Jun ought to have done all in his power to make amends to Zhi. In the unseen realm, he owes this good friend a debt—how then can he still hope for the restoration of the realm? For before the defeat at Fuli, the very deliberations of the Supervisory Headquarters had already made clear to men of virtue that nothing could be achieved.

Chen Yin’s wife, née Du, was the daughter of Chen Xian, a *Bao Mo Ge Dai Zhi* and son of Chen Cheng. Yin, appointed to office through imperial favor, served as Prefect of Xihe. Xihe was a critical frontier stronghold, yet Yin, though a scholar, did not shrink from the peril. When the Yuan forces invaded, the regional commander He Jin was assigned to defend Da’an, leaving only Commander Wang Rui and a thousand loyalists to hold the city. Yin swore to defend the land alongside its people, keeping his three sons with him. He distributed all his family’s wealth to rally the loyalists, determined to hold the city at all costs. When a Yuan army of one hundred thousand attacked, Yin led the loyalists and敢死士 in fierce battle, clashing dozens of times day and night, until the enemy retreated. However, He Jin had long been at odds with Yin, and the other generals, jealous of his merit, ignored his urgent pleas for aid. The city fell.

Turning to his wife, Du, Yin said, “Make haste to save yourself.” Du replied in a stern voice, “How can one share in the lord’s salary in life but not in his service in death?” She drank poison and died. Yin then donned his court robes, faced the palace, burned incense, and wept aloud: “I first resolved to defend this city as a bulwark for Shu. Now that the city has fallen, it is my duty to die.” He bowed twice and fell upon his sword. Twenty-eight members of his family and household perished with him. Judicial Officer Jia Zikun, Prefect of Wenzhou Liu Rui, *Tongpan* of Jinzhou Sai Yi, and *Tongpan* of Lizhou He Chong all died with their entire households. When Chong was captured, the enemy set up a tent with a ring of seats, leaving the guest’s seat empty for him. Chong said, “I have served the Zhao for three generations. To die for them is no regret.” As he was about to be executed, his wife, née Chen, bowed twice and said, “My husband and I can face the Zhao without shame.” Then she died.

**Record:** Yin’s father, Chen Cheng, was so enraged by the rebellion of the Shu general Wu Xi that he could not bear to take up arms against him. Instead, he shaved his head and donned Buddhist robes to disgrace himself. Yet Yin alone roused himself to slay the traitor. Though his strength failed and he died, he brought glory to his father’s name. Among his contemporaries—Jia, Liu, Sai, and He—entire families displayed such righteous heroism that it moved Heaven and stirred men’s hearts. Had they been gathered at court and entrusted with the nation’s vital affairs, they could have transformed weakness into strength and peril into safety with ease. Instead, they were scattered to distant posts, left to guard isolated cities in lowly positions, without reinforcements or capable commanders, and surrounded by envious and petty men. Their blood nourished the battlefield—what benefit did it bring to the state? Thus, when the Dao prevails in the world, heroes are put to use; when the Dao is lost, even the boldest are left without a home. Who, hearing this, does not weep tears of grief?

Zhao Angfa’s wife, née Yong. Angfa, having passed the imperial examinations as a *shang she*, served as *Tongpan* of Chizhou. When the Yuan forces crossed the Yangtze, the Prefect of Chi, Wang Qizong, abandoned his post. Angfa took charge of the prefecture, repairing the walls and stockpiling grain to prepare for a siege. When Yuan scouts reached Liwang River, the regional commander Zhang Lin urged him to surrender. Angfa’s fury filled his chest, his eyes blazing, and Lin dared not speak further. Later, Lin secretly sent envoys to offer surrender while publicly aiding Angfa in defending the city, though all authority fell to Lin. Realizing the situation was hopeless, Angfa held a farewell feast for his relatives and friends. To his wife, Yong, he said, “When the city falls, I, as its defender, cannot flee. You should escape first.” Yong replied, “You are an appointed official, and I am an appointed lady. You are a loyal minister—am I not to be a loyal minister’s wife?” Angfa smiled and said, “This is no task for a woman.” The next day, he distributed his family’s wealth among his younger brothers, nephews, and servants, sending them all away.

As the Yuan army pressed against the city, Angfa rose at dawn and wrote nine times: “One cannot betray the state; the city cannot surrender. Husband and wife die together—our integrity is complete.” Then he and Yong, dressed in their finest robes, hanged themselves together in the *Congrong* Hall. Angfa had built this hall earlier and once hosted guests there, pointing to its plaque and saying, “The ancients said: ‘To die with righteous fervor is easy; to die with calm resolve is hard.’” In the end, he fulfilled those words.

**Record:** I have observed Zhao Angfa’s *Congrong* Hall and Jiang Wanli’s *Zhishui* Pavilion—none of their contemporaries understood their intent. Yet these two men had already resolved their hearts in times of peace. Compare them to Dong Songchen and Lu Yunsheng’s *Furong* Pavilion and *Xianglan* Pavilion, Jia Sidao’s *Duobao* Pavilion and *Mumian* Hermitage, or Qin Kuai’s *Yide Getian*—fragrant and foul, how vast is the difference!

Alas! When the world follows the Dao, we sing the *Ode to the Hall of Mulberry*; when the world loses the Dao, we suffer the calamity of earth and wood. How much better is this hall, which adds luster to the annals of history!

Xie Fangde’s wife was Lady Li. Fangde was a man of heroic spirit—when he read, he took in five lines at once, never forgetting what he had seen. He roused himself with loyalty and righteousness. When the Yuan forces pressed southward, he served as Commissioner for Inspection along the Yangtze and Prefect of Xinzhou in Jiangdong. The following year, Lü Shikui and Military Commissioner Wu divided Jiangdong between them. Fangde led troops to resist them, rallying the Huai soldier Zhang Xiaozhong at Anren for battle. Defeated, he fled to Xinzhou, but when the city fell, he changed his name and entered Jianning. Disguised in hempen robes and straw sandals, he wailed at the borderlands, unrecognized—people took him for a sick man.

In the twenty-third year of the Zhiyuan era, Academician Cheng Wenhai recommended twenty-two former officials of the Song, placing Fangde first on the list. He declined the summons. Minister Liu Mengyan later recommended him again. Fangde wrote to Mengyan: “In the south, there are no men of talent—one seeks even a flawed Lü Yi in vain. As Cheng Ying and the Pestle said: ‘Not even a menial servant can be found.’ When King Zhou perished, though he had the finest troops of eight hundred states, none dared resist. The forthright counsel of those two men—King Wu and the Grand Duke—was met with awe and rejection. Now I am over sixty, and all I lack is death. What other hope could I have?”

The Fujian Branch Secretariat’s Vice Minister Wei Tianyou forced him north to the capital. There, Fangde inquired after the whereabouts of Empress Dowager Xie and the former Emperor Ying, prostrating himself in grief. Soon after, he fell ill. Mengyan sent a physician with medicine mixed into rice, urging him to take it. Fangde grew furious: “I wish to die—do you seek to keep me alive?” He cast it to the ground and starved himself to death.

Lady Li was beautiful and wise, well-versed in the *Nü Xun* and other texts. When Fangde’s forces were defeated and he fled into Fujian, Military Commissioner Wu, fearing he might incite rebellion, offered a reward for his capture. Lady Li hid in the mountains of Guixi with her two sons, living on wild plants. In the fourteenth year of the Zhiyuan era, Xinzhou troops tracked them to the mountains. The order was given: “If Lady Li is not captured, slaughter the people and raze the land.” Upon hearing this, she said: “How can I bring ruin upon others for my sake? I will surrender to spare them.” And so she was taken.

**Record:** The histories praise Fangde for preserving his integrity through hardship—how tragic, the difficulty of keeping one’s virtue whole! Though he knew he could not accept the summons and twice refused with resolve, how could he have known he would still face the duty of friendship? As Zhang Zihui’s poem says:
*“This journey, I rely on my three-inch tongue;
Returning, I’ll not be worth a single coin.”*
Alas!
