This reveals how the noble person aids others in achieving goodness and refrains from aiding their evil, for the treasures of the world are indeed to be cherished by all under heaven.

*The History of the Yuan* records: Yu Que’s wife was Jiang, and his concubines were Yebo and Yelü. Que defended the isolated city for six years, surrounded by bandits, yet stood resolute within—shield of Jianghuai. When Chen Youliang, Zhao Pusheng, and others joined forces to attack, they swarmed the city from all sides. With no external reinforcements and strength exhausted, the city fell. Que drew his blade and took his own life. Jiang and his concubines, leading his daughter An’an, threw themselves into a well and died. His eldest son, Dezheng, aged eighteen, wailed: “My father died in loyalty—how can I live?” He drowned himself in the pond of the rear garden. His nephew, Futong, a skilled and valiant warrior, also perished in the city moat. His nephew-in-law, Hua Li, commander of the righteous troops, and his entire family slit their own throats. The prefect, Han Jianfang, bedridden with illness, cursed the rebels and refused to yield; his whole household was slaughtered. At that time, the city’s able-bodied men all ascended the walls, casting aside their ranks and declaring: “We would rather die than surrender.” Over a thousand perished alongside them.

Que’s commands were strict yet trusted; he shared hardships with his subordinates. In battle, when arrows and stones rained down, soldiers shielded him, but he pushed them away, saying: “You, too, have lives—why shield me?” Thus, they fought all the more fiercely. In rare moments of respite, he gathered scholars to lecture, stationing soldiers outside the gates to listen, teaching them the duty of honoring the ruler and revering superiors. His devotion to the state was long established.

**Record:** The *Song Biography* names the concubine as Yebo, while *The History of the Yuan* calls her Yelü, and the *Account of Martyrs* records his wife as Jiang. The *Anqing Gazetteer*, citing Gongsun Zonglie, states: “The lord had concubines Yebo and Yelü; his true wife was Jiang. Wife and concubine—no difference in righteousness.” That a household should unite a loyal minister, a chaste wife, an extraordinary son, and a virtuous daughter is already remarkable. Yet even his nephew, son-in-law, warriors, foot soldiers, and the city’s able-bodied men all chose to die together—why? For the rise of the false Han was no just punitive campaign, and Yu Que’s pledge echoed the spirit of Suiyang. Heaven thus entrusted him with preserving integrity to illuminate great righteousness, then exposed the rebels’ villainy to reveal where the true mandate lay. To claim the Hu’s fortune was not yet spent would be a grave error.

The *Brief Account of Double Loyalty* in the *Imperial Ming Records* by Su Boheng states: Wang Zhiqing and Hu Shouzhen, sisters-in-law of the Qiantang commoner Hu Zongxin, were wife and elder sister to him. Zongxin was born as his parents passed, and his elder brothers soon followed. Young and frail, his sister feared he could not stand alone. She thought: “Whether I marry early or late, what difference does it make? If I stay to raise my young brother, even a late marriage would bring no shame.” She remained, managing the household. Before long, Zongxin also died, leaving a two-year-old son, Gongcai. His sister sighed: “Alas, I can never marry now. When my brother lived, I could not bear to leave him so young—now that he is gone, if I abandon his child, who will care for the orphan?” Zhiqing harbored no other intentions. The two wept facing each other, vowing to live and die together, sharing every waking and sleeping moment. Shouzhen treated Zhiqing as a sister-in-law, while Zhiqing served her with the devotion due to a mother-in-law. In poverty, they scraped by—opening their door to copy books for money, barely securing firewood and rice. Then they would shut the door to tend to women’s work: cold looms with twin shuttles, a single lamp burning past midnight. For nineteen years, they lived thus, never exchanging a harsh word.

When Shouzhen reached sixty and passed away, Zhiqing observed the three-year mourning rites with full propriety.

**Recorded Note:** Such was Deng Bodao’s devotion to righteousness.
**The Noble One says:** This was severed by Heaven.
Can Heaven truly sever?
For this nephew could not have survived alone.

Such was the deliverance of Lu Yigu from disaster.
**The Noble One says:** This was snatched by fortune.
Can fortune truly be seized?
For this child could not have been abandoned alone.

How much purer is she who remains chaste and unwed?
Chaste and unwed, she leaves nothing for Heaven to sever, nothing for fortune to snatch—her conduct is wholly righteous. This is the resolve of a common woman, which no other could wrest from her. Yet should the sages have cast aside the customs of village folk?

**From *Que Li Zhi*:**
Kongshi, styled Deqing, was the fifty-eighth-generation descendant of the Sage Confucius. The second daughter of Kong Zhi, a teacher in Suzhou, she was gifted with intelligence, skilled in women’s arts, and versed in all classics and histories. At eighteen, she married Wang Lun of Qufu. Upon entering his household, she was filial, respectful, and harmonious, earning praise from all relatives. After barely two years of marriage, she had no children when Lun fell gravely ill with an epidemic. He said to her: “I do not regret dying, but for your youth and lack of support—my eyes will not close in the underworld.”
Kongshi replied: “In life, we shared a chamber; in death, we shall share a grave. Do not resent me—I will not fail you.”
Lun then died. Kongshi collapsed in grief, fainting dead away. Reviving, she immediately hanged herself in Lun’s room. Her mother-in-law, who doted on her, rushed to save her, weeping: “My child’s death is already unbearable—why add to my sorrow by not considering my old age?”
Kongshi choked out: “I have already pledged my word—how can I break it?”
Her mother-in-law ordered the household to guard her closely, and Kongshi’s plans came to naught. They consoled her in every way, offering food and drink as usual. When the day of Lun’s burial arrived, the household assumed her resolve had softened and ceased their vigil. The next morning, as the funeral procession was to depart, Kongshi hanged herself in her chamber. By dawn, when each servant was occupied with their duties, her mother-in-law, surprised by her absence, called for her—only to find she was gone. She was buried alongside Lun. She was twenty years old, on the eleventh day of the seventh lunar month in the autumn of the *guisi* year of the Chenghua reign.

**Recorded Note:** Yao and Shun perfected human relationships; Confucius established the standards of ritual—both began and completed their paths. Thus is this recorded.

*Hong Dao Lu*, Scroll Twenty-Two, concludes.

**#1** *Note:* The character 毋 was originally written as 母; amended here according to context.

**Hong Dao Lu, Scroll Twenty-Three: On Righteousness**

**On the Righteousness of Brothers**

Wan Zhang asked: "May I inquire—some say 'banishment.' What does this mean?"

The Master replied: "Xiang was not permitted to act within his state. The Son of Heaven dispatched officials to govern his state and collect its tribute and taxes. Thus, it was called 'banishment.' How could he have oppressed those people?"

**Recorded Note:** In my foolish view, Xiang’s misconduct was not so severe as that of later ages. When Guan and Cai were set to oversee Yin, when Cao Shen served as minister of Qi, when Jia Yi governed Liang, and when Master Dong administered Jiangdu—did the Son of Heaven not likewise send officials to govern their states? Yet few refrained from tyranny. From this, we may see that Xiang’s desires lay only in wealth and rank; once he received tribute, he was content. The desires of later ages, however, centered on oppression—rejecting restraint, indulging in might, and growing ever more excessive. Even with the utmost benevolence and consummate righteousness of a Great Shun, how could one have dealt with them well?

Tai Kang occupied the throne in idleness and pleasure, extinguishing his virtue. The common people grew disloyal. He then roamed without restraint, hunting beyond the Luo River for a hundred days without returning. Hou Yi of Youqiong, seizing the people’s suffering, barred him at the Yellow River. Tai Kang’s five younger brothers escorted their mother in pursuit, all reaching the banks of the Luo. The five sons, filled with resentment, recited the admonitions of Great Yu and composed songs.

The first song said:
*"Our august ancestor left teachings:
The people may be drawn near, but not looked down upon.
The people are the state’s root; when the root is firm, the state is at peace.
I regard the world—
Even the humblest man or woman surpasses me in one thing.
A single ruler’s three failures—
Resentment need not be open to be plotted against.
I govern the multitudes,
Trembling as if driving six horses with rotten reins.
How can one who stands above others not be reverent?"*

The second song said:
*"The teachings declare:
Within, indulgence in beauty; without, obsession with hunting.
Sweet wine and fondness for music, towering halls and carved walls—
If any of these exist, none have not perished."*

The third song said:
*"Once, in the time of Yao of Tao Tang,
This northern land flourished.
Now, having lost the Way,
Its order is in chaos—
Thus it reaches ruin."*

The fourth song said:
*"Bright was our ancestor,
Lord of ten thousand states.
He had canons and standards,
Bequeathing them to his descendants.
Weights balanced, measures harmonized—
The royal treasury held them.
Now, his legacy is abandoned,
His lineage overthrown, his sacrifices cut off."*

The fifth song said:
*"Alas, where shall I return?
My heart is filled with sorrow.
The myriad people despise me—
To whom shall I turn?
My heart aches like clay,
My face burns with shame.
Had he guarded his virtue,
Even regret might have been redeemed."*

**Recorded Note:** Examining these five songs, their intent is earnest, their emotion mournful, their words veiled yet unmistakable—truly, they speak with weeping and tears. When Yi fled Yu’s son to the northern slopes of Mount Ji, the people of the world said, "He is our lord’s son." There was no other reason: Qi was worthy and reverent. When Yi barred Qi’s son north of the great river, the five sons’ song said, "The myriad people despise me." There was no other reason: he had not guarded his virtue. Though his fate was self-inflicted, it was indeed Yi’s doing. Had there been a Yi Yin of Yin, how could he not have acted as he did with Tai Jia of Xia? Why bar him at all?

Above, there was the legacy of Great Yu and Qi; within, the five sons and their mother’s virtue. Yi’s schemes, though not yet fully executed, were already unshakable. Thus it is said: *"Resentment need not be open to be plotted against."* Alas! When six horses bolt, the state’s root is lost; when beauty and hunting lead to indulgence, the nation’s ruin follows. Even after a thousand ages, who does not sigh deeply at this? What heart could remain unmoved? What heart?

The Viscount of Wei said: *"Father Preceptor, Junior Preceptor—
Yin’s governance is no longer upright in the four quarters.
Our ancestors’ achievements are laid bare above.
I have drowned in drunkenness,
Corrupting my virtue below.
In Yin, none—great or small—do not delight in theft and villainy.
The ministers and officials all transgress the measure;
For every crime, there is no constant punishment.
The common people rise up,
Mutually hostile and vigilant.
Now Yin is sinking—
Like fording great waters, without shore or bank.
Yin’s ruin has come to this day."*

He said: *"Father Preceptor, Junior Preceptor,
I shall go mad and flee.
Our house, in its senility, retreats into wilderness.
Now you stand at the precipice—
What is to be done?"*

The Father Preceptor said: *"Prince,
Heaven has sent down poisonous calamity to ruin the state of Yin.
Now, they indulge in drunkenness,
Without fear or reverence.
They cast aside the elders,
The old and those of rank.
Now, the people of Yin
Steal the sacrificial animals of gods and spirits,
Using them for their own indulgence.
They eat without disaster,
And Heaven watches over the people of Yin.
They levy warnings and exactions,
Summoning enemies without end.
Their crimes converge as one—
Many suffer, yet none are admonished.
Shang is now beset by calamity;
I shall bear its ruin.
If Shang perishes,
I shall not serve as a slave.
I urge the prince to depart and follow the Way.
The prince does not go.
I stand at the precipice—
I shall act on my own,
Offering myself to the former kings.
I shall not look back or proceed further."*

**Recorded Note:** Carefully considering this text—where it says, *"Now you have no recourse; you stand at the precipice—what is to be done?"*—the Viscount of Wei sought to discern the moment of decision. Where it says, *"I urge the prince to depart and follow the Way; the prince does not go; I stand at the precipice,"*—Jizi explained the principle of departure. These two passages form the essence of the text. Where it says, *"I shall act on my own, offering myself to the former kings; I shall not look back or proceed further,"*—Jizi spoke of his own duty, not that the Viscount of Wei should preserve the ancestral sacrifices to offer to the former kings. Bigan acted on his own by dying in remonstrance to offer himself to the former kings; Jizi acted on his own by feigning madness to offer himself to the former kings. For Jizi was a paternal uncle of Zhou, the elder of Yin’s lineage, entrusted by the former kings. The Viscount of Wei, as Zhou’s elder half-brother, was Yin’s heir, relied upon by Emperor Yi.

Should the ancestral state face calamity and disorder, yet its lineage elder depart, to whom would the former kings turn their hopes? If the heir apparent were also lost, and the eldest successor remained without departing, where would the ancestral sacrifices endure? This is why Jizi acted on his own, offering himself to the former kings, without regard for flight or pursuit.

Bigan, though also a paternal uncle of Zhou, was not the eldest compared to Jizi; nor was he the heir, unlike the Viscount of Wei. If death was to be his fate, he would die—what further deliberation before the former kings could there be? The *Collected Commentaries* question why Bigan alone left no words, to which Kong [Anguo] replied that their hearts were aligned, and thus no repetition was needed. Alas, were these truly his words?

The Duke of Zhou said: *"Lord Shi, it is most unpropitious. Heaven has sent ruin upon Yin, and Yin has lost its mandate. Our Zhou has received it, yet I dare not say: ‘Its foundation shall forever be blessed.’ If Heaven’s aid is steadfast, I dare not claim its end will be inauspicious. Alas, my lord! I say: ‘In this time, I too dare not rest secure in the Mandate of Heaven. I shall not cease to reverently ponder Heaven’s majesty, nor shall I allow my people to stray or transgress. My descendants, my sons and grandsons, must not fail in reverence toward above and below, nor obstruct the radiance of those who came before. Now, I, the young one Dan, am not capable of rectitude, yet I strive to extend the light of those who came before, bestowing it upon my youthful heir.’"*

The Duke said: *"Lord Shi, may Heaven grant you long life and peace, preserving the remnant of Yin. If Yin’s successors perish, Heaven’s majesty will be extinguished. Now, if you ever remember this, your mandate shall be firm, and your governance shall clearly manifest our state’s founding. Now, I, the young one Dan, am like one crossing a great river—I go forth to assist you, Lord Shi. May we succeed together! Alas, let us both devote ourselves to this task. We have striven to this day for prosperity, and together we perfect King Wen’s work without cease, so that from the seas’ edges to where the sun rises, none shall not be led to compliance."*

It is recorded: *"Whenever I read the writings of Lord Shi, I cannot but rise and sigh thrice. Though the Duke of Shao was his younger brother, he addressed him as ‘Lord Shi.’ Though the Duke of Zhou was his elder brother, he called himself ‘the young one.’ Though both dukes were aged, their reverence never waned—one sees therein the utmost sincerity of their devotion. The Duke of Zhou remained to assist the king, while the Duke of Shao retired in old age, yet neither harbored the slightest selfish intent. Thus, in their regard for their lord, they were humble and could not but be mindful; in their stewardship of their legacy, they were diligent and could not but be thorough; in their reverence for Heaven, they were profound and could not but be sincere; in their grasp of the Mandate, they were awe-inspired and could not but be steadfast. If even in old age they did not slacken, how much less should one in the prime of life?*

*In the reign of Emperor Zhezong of Song, Lord Guang served as chief minister, upholding the great principles of governance; Lord Chunren served as minister, and Empress Dowager Xuanren as regent. Yet with a single decree, all was cast aside—down to the appointments of Zeng Dun and Cai Bian—plunging the realm into chaos, toppling the Song’s legacy, and forfeiting Heaven’s Mandate. Today, those who read of this weep, yet how few are those who read the *Book of Lord Shi* without deepening their sighs!*

*The Charge to Cai Zhong* states: *"It was the Duke of Zhou who, as Grand Steward, rectified the hundred officials. After quelling the slander of the Three Guards, he exiled Guan Shu to Shang, imprisoned Cai Shu in Guolin with seven chariots, and demoted Huo Shu to commoner status, barring him from court for three years. When Cai Zhong proved himself capable and reverent in virtue, the Duke of Zhou made him a minister. After Cai Shu’s death, he commanded that a state be established for him in the eastern lands. The king spoke thus: ‘Young one Hu, only by following virtue and amending your conduct, by prudently considering your path, shall I invest you as a lord in the eastern lands. Go to your fief and be reverent! You must cover the faults of those who came before you. Be loyal and filial, and you shall draw near to yourself. Be diligent without cease, and you shall leave an example for your descendants. Follow the constant teachings of your ancestor King Wen, and do not emulate your father’s defiance of the royal command. August Heaven has no favorites—it aids only those who possess virtue. The hearts of the people are not constant—they cherish only those who show them kindness. Though the paths of goodness differ, they all lead to order. Though the paths of evil differ, they all lead to chaos. Take heed! Consider both your beginnings and your ends, and your end shall not be beset by hardship. If you neglect your end, it shall end in ruin. Strive in your endeavors, harmonize with your four neighbors, and thus strengthen the royal house and reconcile with your brothers. Bring peace and succor to the common folk, govern from the center, and do not employ cleverness to disrupt ancient statutes. Examine carefully what you see and hear, and do not alter your course on account of slanderous words. Then I, the One Man, shall praise you.’"*

The Record states: When the Duke of Zhou enfeoffed Cai Zhong, how could it compare to Ji You’s preservation of Qing Fu’s lineage? Slander was refuted and silenced at the lips, yet error, compounded by coercion from Guan, led to his imprisonment. Imprisoned—could his sacrifices truly be severed? Not only did the Duke not bear past grievances in mind, but he further appointed him as minister. The Duke’s heart was as vast as heaven and earth, as luminous as sun and moon. This is why, before the morning clouds dispersed, all under heaven became clear and bright.

From the *Zuo Tradition*: Duke Zhuang of Lu had no proper heir. While constructing a terrace overlooking the Dang clan, he saw Meng Ren and followed her, begetting a son, Ban. Wishing to enthrone him out of favor, he consulted Shu Ya. Shu Ya said, "Alternating succession is Lu’s constant practice. With Qing Fu alive, what cause for concern have you?" He then consulted Ji You, who replied, "I shall, even unto death, uphold Ban." The Duke asked, "What of Shu Ya?" Cheng Ji, by the Duke’s command, ordered Xi Shu to await at the home of Jian Wu, where he made Jian Ji drink poison, saying, "Drink this, and you shall have descendants in the state of Lu. Refuse, and you shall die without posterity." He drank, returned home, and died at Kui Spring. His son was established as the Shusun clan. When the Duke passed, Ji You enthroned Ban. Qing Fu sent assassins to kill Ban and enthroned Kai of the Dang clan, who became Duke Min. Fan Jiang conspired with Qing Fu to murder Duke Min and enthrone Qing Fu. Qing Fu dispatched Bu Qi to assassinate the Duke at Wuwei. Cheng Ji, with Duke Min’s elder brother Shen residing in Lin, and the people of Lu unwilling to accept Qing Fu, Qing Fu fled in fear to Ju. Ji You entered and enthroned Shen, who became Duke Xi. He sought Qing Fu in Ju with bribes, and the people of Ju returned him. Upon reaching Mi, when Gongzi Yu pleaded, Qing Fu refused. Yu wept as he departed. Qing Fu asked, "Whose voice is this?" and hanged himself. His descendants became the Meng clan.

The Record states: Observing Ji You’s deeds, one sees that though he overcame peril and achieved minor success, he failed to grasp the greater principle. Duke Ding of Lin said, "When a minister murders his lord, all officials involved shall be killed without pardon. Slay the perpetrator, destroy his house, raze his office, and stain the ground with red earth." Lin was a small state, yet it could adjudicate such a case—how could a great state remain ignorant of this? With this principle unclarified, further murders followed. In the matter of Shi Zhi, how could one not foresee the succession of disasters? Thus, the *Spring and Autumn Annals* records Qing Fu’s flight into exile without clarifying his death—the intent of the Sage is evident.

Duke Gong of Song sent Duke Wen of Zhu to sacrifice Zheng Zi at the altar of Ci Sui, intending to bind the Eastern Yi. Marshal Zi Yu said, "In ancient times, the six livestock were not used interchangeably. Minor affairs did not employ great sacrifices—how much less dare one use a human? Sacrifices are for the sake of humanity, for the people are the hosts of the spirits. Who would accept such an offering?" Duke Huan of Qi preserved three dying states and bound them to the feudal lords. Even righteous scholars called this "meager virtue." Now, in a single assembly, you brutalize the lords of two states and offer them to licentious and deluded ghosts. How can you seek hegemony thus? To die without disgrace would be fortunate. When the Song army besieged Cao, Zi Yu said to Duke Gong, "King Wen, hearing of Chong’s disorder, attacked it. After thirty days, it did not surrender. He withdrew to cultivate virtue, then attacked again, and it surrendered at once. The *Odes* say: 'He models himself for his wife, extends it to his brothers, and thus governs his state and domain.' Now, if your virtue is perhaps still lacking, how can you attack others? Why not first reflect inwardly on your virtue, ensuring no deficiency before acting?"

The Record states: The *Spring and Autumn Annals* criticizes hereditary ministers. Zi Yu, as hereditary Left Marshal, was no minor figure. The Shang ancestors could not bear to ensnare flying birds, yet now humans are used in place of livestock. In great droughts, the people long for clouds and rain, yet now they are coerced by force. Confucius reproached Zai Wo for his words that made the people tremble, while Boyi assisted Yu in furthering civilizing virtue. Zi Yu’s admonitions—are they not the legacy of sages and worthies? Alas, they were not heeded.

In the seventeenth year of Duke Xuan’s reign, in winter, the eleventh month, on the day *renwu*, the Duke’s younger brother, Shu Pan, died. The text reads: "The Duke’s younger brother"—why is he deemed worthy? If he is deemed worthy, for what reason? He condemned the regicide yet did not depart. One asks: "He was his brother—where could he go?" If offered wealth, he would say, "I have enough." He wove sandals to sustain himself and never consumed Duke Xuan’s food. The noble person deems this a reconciliation of kinship, and thus the *Spring and Autumn Annals* honors him.

The Record states: Was Shu Ao not truly an incorruptible scholar? Xiang Zhong’s regicide and Duke Xuan’s usurpation were enmities not to be borne under the same sky. Had Pan possessed Ji You’s authority, he could have deposed Ya and enthroned Min, or executed Meng and served Xi. Yet lacking such power, he merely clung to fraternal bonds, serving as an instrument for his enemy—nothing more than trampling and cutting down. What did the Sage find worthy in him? He took what was not rightfully his and refused to eat. Without the pretext of avoiding his brother or forsaking his mother, and enjoying surplus wealth and honor, Pan surpassed others by several degrees. How could he compare to Zhongzi of Yu Ling?

Cao Zizang, named Xin Shi, was a son of Duke Xuan. When Duke Xuan joined Jin in attacking Qin, he died in the campaign. The people of Cao sent Gongzi Fu Chu to guard the state and Zizang to receive the Duke’s funeral. Fu Chu killed the crown prince and enthroned himself as Duke Cheng. The feudal lords all requested to punish him. Zizang, deeming Duke Cheng unrighteous, prepared to flee. When the people heard this, they followed Zizang in droves. Duke Cheng, alarmed, confessed his crime and begged to remain. Thereupon, Zizang returned and relinquished his fief.

The following year, Duke Cheng met with the feudal lords at Qi, where the Marquis of Jin seized him and sent him to Zhou. All the feudal lords admired Zizang and intended to meet him in Zhou to enthrone him. Zizang declined, saying: "An ancient saying goes: The sage adapts to circumstance, the next best holds to it, and the lowest loses it. To be a ruler is not within my station. Though I may not be a sage, how dare I fail to uphold what is proper?" Thereupon, he fled to Song. Three years later, the people of Cao petitioned Jin, and the Marquis of Jin told them: "If Zizang returns, I shall restore your lord." Zizang had no choice but to return to Cao to await Jin’s decree. Later, the people of Jin again petitioned Zhou to reinstate Duke Cheng. Zizang then relinquished all his lands and person, never again serving in office.

The record states: What is called *jie* (节, integrity) is to restrain things once they have gone astray. *Jie* is the means to order the vast. Thus, its image says: "Not stepping beyond the courtyard gate, one knows what is open and what is blocked." Fu Chu’s crime reached heaven above, severed human bonds below, and abandoned the covenant of allies—unlike the case of Duke Xuan’s assassination and succession, where the people of Cao harbored no dissent and the feudal lords voiced no objection. At that time, why did none consider the people’s unity and the lords’ shared condemnation, petitioning the Son of Heaven to avenge the crown prince’s wrong? Had they rightly enforced official punishment, the fallen moral order would have been restored, and heaven and earth, darkened, would have shone anew. Could this not be called *jie*? Ignorant of this principle, they clung to petty fidelity, enabling a great evil to surge forth. Thus, the mandate of heaven, nearly extended, was withdrawn; human desires, once unleashed, became irrepressible. Thereafter, traitors and usurpers followed in succession. Mencius did not say in vain: "Though Zhongzi were unrighteous, if offered the state of Qi, he would not accept." All believed him—this was the principle of refusing meat and bean broth. Alas, none at the time reproached Zizang with this truth.

Jizha was the youngest son of King Shoumeng of Wu. Shoumeng had four sons: the eldest, Zhufan; the second, Yuzhai; the third, Yumei; and the youngest, Jizha. Jizha was virtuous, and Shoumeng wished to enthrone him. Jizha declined, so Shoumeng installed Zhufan as regent to manage state affairs. After Zhufan completed the mourning rites, he offered the throne to Jizha in accordance with their father’s command. Jizha refused, saying: "When Duke Xuan of Cao died, the feudal lords and the people of Cao deemed it unrighteous, and Cao’s lord sought to enthrone Zizang. Zizang departed to preserve the lord’s legitimacy. The noble man said: ‘He was able to uphold integrity.’ You, my lord, are the rightful heir. Who would dare contest your rule? To hold the state is not within my station." Though unworthy, he wished to emulate Zizang’s integrity. The people of Wu insisted on enthroning Jizha, but he abandoned his home to till the fields, and they desisted. When Zhufan died, he passed the throne to his brother Yuzhai, intending to transmit it in turn until it reached Jizha, fulfilling their father’s wish. Seventeen years later, Yuzhai died, and his brother Yumei succeeded him. When Yumei died, they again sought to offer the throne to Jizha, but he fled. The people of Wu then enthroned Yumei’s son, Liao.

Zhufan’s son, Guang, thought: "My father transmitted the throne through his brothers in order to ultimately bestow it upon Jizi. Though Jizi refuses the state, I should rightfully succeed." He then sent an assassin to kill Liao and usurped the throne, becoming Helü. Jizha, returning from Jin, said: "If the ancestral sacrifices of our former lord remain unbroken, the people have a lord, the altars are served, and the state stands firm, then he is my lord. Whom should I resent? For one day to die for duty is to await heaven’s decree—it is not I who stirs rebellion. He who is enthroned follows the way of our forebears." He returned, mourned at the ancestral tomb, and resumed his former position.

The record states: Jizha’s refusal of the state cannot be compared to Cao Zizang’s. Zhufan harbored no usurping intent; his transmission of the throne honored his father’s command. Thus, Jizha said: "You, my lord, are the rightful heir. Who would dare contest you?" This was to value the bonds of heaven. The succession passed to Yuzhai, then Yumei, then Jizha—who could say it was wrong? Yet King Liao did not act thus. That Guang usurped the throne was Liao’s doing, but the ministers and people of Wu were not without blame. Some attribute it to Jizha’s refusal and abdication, but this is mistaken. Shoumeng’s desire to transmit the throne to Jizha was not like the perfect virtue of Zhou. Shoumeng, having usurped the title of king, sought to emulate the deeds of King Ji and King Wen. This was what Jizha deeply feared. His intentions were subtle and concealed, unknown to others, but Jizha alone understood—how could he not repeatedly evade the throne? Our Master Confucius especially esteemed Jizha, though his meaning remained unspoken, precisely for this reason. When Jizha died, Confucius inscribed his tomb: "Alas! This is the grave of Jizi of Yanling." His intent was just so.

The Marquis of Xing of Jin disputed the fields of Hao with Yongzi, but the case dragged on without resolution. When Shi Jingbo traveled to Chu, Shuyu acted as interim judge, and Han Xuanzi ordered him to adjudicate old cases. The fault lay with Yongzi, who offered his daughter to Shuyu. Shuyu perverted justice and condemned the Marquis of Xing. Enraged, the marquis killed Shuyu and Yongzi in court. Xuanzi inquired about their punishment from Shuxiang. Shuxiang said: "All three share the same guilt. Execute the living and expose the dead." Yongzi, knowing his guilt, bribed to buy a verdict—this was the corruption of King Zhou. The Marquis of Xing took the law into his own hands. Thus, Xuanzi executed the marquis and exposed the corpses of Yongzi and Shuyu in the marketplace. Confucius said: "Shuxiang was a remnant of ancient integrity. In meting out punishment, he did not shield his kin. Though he enumerated Shuyu’s crimes, he did not flatter him. Such was his righteousness."

The record states: Formerly, when Shuxiang mourned his mother, she said: "I fear he will give birth to dragons and serpents." She also said: "Wolf cubs have wild hearts—what misfortune for the Yangshe clan!"

If only for wolves does one demand accountability, if only for serpents does one feel alarm—yet still, none admonished their licentiousness. By the time disaster befell Yongzi, all three transgressions were complete. Even had he wished to cry out against evil, who would have heeded his cry?

*The Former Han History* records: Liu Zhang, the Marquis of Zhuxu, resented the Lü clan’s usurpation of power and the Liu house’s exclusion from office. Once, attending a banquet, Zhang requested: “I am a general of the ranks—let me enforce military discipline in governing the wine.” When one of the Lü men, drunk, fled the feast, Zhang drew his sword and pursued, slaying him. As the Empress Dowager had already granted him military authority, there was no ground to punish him. Thereafter, the Lü clan feared the Marquis of Zhuxu, and the Liu house grew stronger.

The record states: King Wu of Wei exterminated the entire Tang royal line, yet Empress Lü spared the Marquis of Zhuxu because Qi stood as his shield. Thus, the Lü clan may well be called devoid of strategy. They relied on kinship through women, unaware that such kinship was not founded on womanhood; they trusted in the strength of Lü arms, unaware that such strength was not rooted in arms. Therefore, armies may be seized, but Zhang’s resolve could not be seized; forces may be relied upon, but Ying’s schemes could not be relied upon. By this point, the Lü clan had no strategy left.

*The Later Han History* recounts: As the renown of Guangwu and his elder brother Liu Yan grew, the generals of the Xinshi and Pinglin factions secretly urged Gengshi to eliminate them. Just then, Liu Ji, a subordinate commander, heard of Gengshi’s enthronement and raged: “The original architects of this great enterprise were the Bo Sheng brothers—what is Gengshi’s role?” He was arrested and sentenced to execution. Yan vehemently protested, whereupon Li Yi and Zhu Jiu urged Gengshi to seize Yan as well, and he was killed that very day. When officials came to offer condolences to Liu Xiu, he refused private conversation, maintaining only strict avoidance. He dared not wear mourning for Yan, and whenever alone, he abstained from wine and meat, his mat and pillow bearing traces of tears. Only his secretary Feng Yi sought to console him, but Xiu silenced him: “Do not speak recklessly.” Yi then advised: “Gengshi’s governance is in chaos, and the people have no one to rely upon. A starving man is easily sated—now that you command an entire region, you should dispatch officials to tour the commanderies and counties, proclaiming virtue and grace.” Xiu deeply accepted his counsel.

Lu states: The first six in *Kan* (坎) reads: "Repeated peril—entering the peril brings harm; inauspicious." The *Xiang* commentary says: "Repeated peril, entering peril—losing the Dao brings misfortune." Yan, fond of chivalry and reckless action, lived in an age of banditry and plunder—this was his "repeated peril." Though his uncle shared the same banner as Gaozu, his yielding nature remained unformed, and above him he found no support. How could he have rescued Bosheng from danger? His death was thus foreordained.

Yet the oracle’s root says: "In peril there is sincerity; only the heart is free—action brings esteem." Xiu possessed a firm and balanced talent, while Yi served as his steadfast and profound counsel. Esteeming their past achievements, Yi’s words found easy entry, and Xiu’s deep acceptance was likewise fitting. This is how they traversed peril without losing trust, and in the end, their loyal hearts proved their allegiance, their great merits honored—was this not the freedom of the steadfast heart?

Liu Yu was a great-great-grandson of Emperor Xuan. Emperor Xuan enfeoffed his son Xiao as Prince of Chu; Xiao begot Prince Si, who begot Prince Yu, who begot Ban. From Xiao to Ban, each generation accumulated benevolence and righteousness, their names and integrity renowned, but Yu was especially kind and sincere. Having lost his mother early, his younger brother, the Marquis of Yuanxiang, was still a child, so Yu personally raised him, sharing his bed, meals, and daily life. Even when the boy came of age, Yu never left his side. When Ping died of illness, Yu wept until he vomited blood, and within months, he too passed away.

Later, Emperor Guangwu enfeoffed Ban as Marquis of Leiqiu to continue the sacrifices to Prince Xiao. Emperor Ming summoned him as Commandant of the Capital and concurrently Colonel of the Garrison Cavalry; Emperor Zhang appointed him Chamberlain for the Palace Revenues and Minister of the Imperial Clan. While in office, Ban frequently spoke on governance, and his care for the nine clans, his conduct of righteousness, became especially renowned—his contemporaries praised him.

Lu states: At that time, the court was vigorously promoting the practice of modesty and deference, and the bonds of fraternal love extended from the imperial lineage to all under heaven. If one did not become a man of virtue, how could one escape the gaze of others? The days of the "peck of grain, bolt of silk" ballads were long past. Thus, this is recorded.

Du Lin and his younger brother Cheng were both devoted scholars, broadly learned and widely informed—contemporaries called them "erudite Confucians." At the end of Wang Mang’s reign, when bandits arose, they sojourned in Hexi. Yin Xiao, hearing of Lin’s integrity, deeply respected and treated him well, appointing him Keeper of the Archives. Later, Lin fell ill and requested leave, resigning his salary. Xiao wished to compel him to return, but Lin claimed grave illness. Though Xiao longed for his presence, he prioritized leniency and issued an edict: "Du Bolin cannot be a subject to the Son of Heaven, nor a friend to the feudal lords. Like Boyi and Shuqi, who were ashamed to eat Zhou grain, let him now hold the position of teacher and friend. We await the opening of the Dao so he may follow his aspirations."

Though Lin was constrained by Xiao, he never compromised his principles. When Cheng later died, Xiao permitted Lin to return with his brother’s coffin. Yet after sending him off, Xiao regretted it and dispatched the assassin Yang Xian to intercept him on the road. Seeing Lin personally pushing a deer cart bearing his brother’s coffin, Xian sighed: "In this age, who still practices righteousness? Though I am but a petty man, how could I bear to kill a man of virtue?" He then fled.

Emperor Guangwu, having heard of Du Lin’s reputation, summoned him and appointed him as Imperial Censor. After an audience, the emperor questioned him on classical texts, past affairs, and matters of the Western Regions, and was greatly pleased. Later, when the Crown Prince Jiang petitioned to be enfeoffed as Prince of Donghai, a new selection of officials was made for his household, and Lin was appointed as the prince’s tutor. He received special rewards and gifts. Eventually, Lin rose to the position of Grand Minister of Works, where he was praised for his competence in office.

The brothers Zhao Xiao and Zhao Li were known for their reverence, modesty, and steadfast conduct. During the chaos of the world’s upheaval, when people resorted to cannibalism, Li was captured by bandits who intended to cook him. Xiao then bound himself and presented himself to the bandits, offering to take his brother’s place in the pot. The bandits, astonished by this, spared them both. Their village admired their righteousness, and though the province repeatedly summoned them to office, they declined all appointments. During the Yongping era, Emperor Ming, having heard of their reputation, issued an edict appointing Xiao as Grand Master for Palace Counsel, later promoting him to Chamberlain for the Palace Garrison. He also summoned Li to serve as Palace Assistant Censor. Wishing to honor them, the emperor decreed that Li should visit the Chamberlain’s residence every ten days, where the Imperial Kitchen would provide feasts, allowing the brothers to dine together in joy. After several years, Li passed away, and the emperor ordered Xiao to accompany the funeral procession as an official escort. As Xiao had no sons, the emperor appointed Li’s two sons as Gentlemen of the Palace. The record states: I observe that Du Lin, initially caught in rebellion and pledging his life to Xiao, ultimately encountered a worthy man on the road due to banditry. As for the Zhao brothers, in that fleeting moment, could they have known they would rise to become a prince’s tutor, their rank elevated to that of a duke’s son, their meals distinct from those of common officials? Yang Xian’s righteousness and Xiao’s humility inspired their generation. Though such deeds are said to be what men believe in, they are truly what Heaven assists. Otherwise, would men like assassins or starving bandits willingly embrace righteousness? That they ultimately did not perish is indeed rare among their peers.

According to the *Book of Jin*: Right Vice Director Deng You was captured by Shi Le at the end of the Yongjia era. Crossing the Si River, You used oxen and horses to carry his wife and children forward. They again encountered bandits, who seized the livestock. Forced to proceed on foot, You carried his son and his nephew Sui, realizing he could not save both. He said to his wife, “My brother died young, leaving only this one descendant. By principle, he cannot be abandoned. We must leave our son behind.” His wife wept but complied, and they abandoned their child. In the end, You remained without an heir. The people, moved by his righteousness, mourned him, saying: “Heaven is blind—how could it leave Deng Boda without a brother?” Sui later served You’s mourning for one or two years. The record states: You’s grief is universally acknowledged across the ages. Yet history claims he preemptively bound his son to prevent escape—could this truly be the intent of a loving father and benevolent man? Do not say Heaven is blind, for it sees clearly. I believe neither account reflects the truth. When You was captured by Shi Le, he twice nearly died. By the time Le crossed the Si River, You had already smashed his cart and used oxen and horses to carry his family forward—yet pursuing soldiers were still searching for them. Judging by his intent, his son was older and more recognizable, so he bound him; his nephew was younger and less known, so he spared him. One was to delay the pursuers, the other to evade detection—not merely for righteousness. That he ultimately had no heir may have been fate, an unfortunate turn for a gentleman. To judge You by this would deter others from righteousness. This is the intent of this record.

Yu Gun was the great-uncle of Empress Mingmu, wife of Emperor Wu of Jin. From youth, he practiced diligence and frugality, devoted himself to learning, and was eager to seek knowledge. During the great epidemic of the Xianning era, his two elder brothers died, and his next brother, Pi, fell gravely ill. As the pestilential qi raged, his parents and younger brothers all fled outside, but Gun alone remained, personally tending to Pi day and night without rest. He continued to mourn and pay respects at the coffins without pause. After more than ten weeks, the epidemic subsided, his family returned, Pi recovered, and Gun remained unharmed. While Gun’s uncles and father all held prominent positions, his own father lived in humble poverty. Gun personally tilled the fields to provide for his parents, performing his duties with reverence. When planting hedges with his disciples, he would kneel to hand them the branches. Some asked, “Now that you live in seclusion, why such excessive respect?” He replied, “The principles of conduct differ in public and private—this is not the aspiration of a gentleman.” His wives all came from official families, yet upon marrying Gun, they abandoned luxury to endure hardship together. After his mother’s death, he observed mourning beside her grave. When someone cut down a tree near her tomb, he knelt, wept, and apologized: “My virtue is unrefined; I could not protect my ancestors’ trees.” The elders all wept in sympathy, and afterward, no one dared to harm the grave. The village, commandery, and province all recommended him as a Filial and Incorrupt Candidate of Exceptional Conduct, but he declined all honors, earning the title of “Man of Exceptional Conduct.”

When Qi King Tong advocated righteousness, Zhang Hong and others pillaged Yangdi. Gun then led his clansmen and commoners to take refuge on Mount Yu. Though the people lived in peace, they were unskilled in warfare or defense. Gun advised, “The ancients said: ‘A thousand men gathered without a leader will scatter or descend into chaos.’” The crowd replied, “If not you, then who should lead us?” He then made them swear: “Do not rely on terrain. Do not exploit disorder. Do not harm neighbors. Do not dismantle houses. Do not fell planted trees. Do not scheme against virtue. Do not violate righteousness. Exert your strength as one, and together we will overcome peril.” The people all obeyed. When bandits arrived, Gun organized his forces, arranged their ranks, and ordered them to draw their bows without releasing. The bandits, intimidated by their discipline and caution, retreated. The people remarked: “Only in bitter cold do we know the pine and cypress are the last to wither.” And: “He who fears in times of crisis and plans wisely will succeed—is this not Yu’s exceptional conduct?”

The record states: Observing the decadence of Jin’s customs, Yu Gun’s exceptional conduct shames not only the Eight Princes in life but also Pei Wei in death. Does it not also bring shame to Yuan Gui in life and mortify Shu Yu in death?

The disparity between recognizing the pine that stands firm in bitter cold from a single ailment and failing to discern the loyal minister amidst the turmoil of the Eight Princes—how vast as heaven and abyss! The contrast between the many who chase grandeur while one father alone upholds poverty, and those insatiable in desire and unbounded in demands—how utterly divergent! The difference between one who fears in times of crisis, plans wisely, and succeeds, and those who recklessly provoke disaster with shallow schemes—how stark as night and day! The distinction between one who remains steadfast in duty, diligent and reverent, whether in darkness or light, and those who harbor venom and act with violent impunity—how distant as north and south!

Thus we know: when demonic forces swarm, the yang virtue shines resplendent; when filth and corruption abound, luminous integrity stands pure. Without men like Shu Bao, how could Jin’s sun and moon endure?

*The History of the Southern Dynasties* records: Xie Hongwei, even as a young child, was composed and discerning. His uncle Xie Hun, upon seeing him, marveled and said, “This elder brother possesses profound innate acuity—he will surely become an exceptional vessel.” At the age of ten, Hongwei was adopted by his paternal uncle Xie Jun, brother of the Minister of Works Xie Ying, and thus became kin to Jun’s two sons. Though previously unacquainted, he conducted himself with natural propriety, aligning perfectly with ritual and sincerity.

At the beginning of the Yixi era, he inherited Jun’s title of Marquis of Jianchang. Hongwei’s family had long been poor and frugal, while his adoptive household was wealthy and prosperous. Yet he never took for himself any of the inherited wealth, stipends, or emoluments. Xie Hun, of lofty and austere character, had few close associates. He formed bonds only with his clansmen Xie Lingyun, Xie Zhan, Xie Yao, and Hongwei, gathering for literary and scholarly appreciation. They often dined and resided together in Wu Clothing Lane, hence their circle was known as the “Gathering of Wu Clothing.” Though others of high repute and renown existed, none dared approach their gate. Zhan and the others were rich in eloquence and rhetorical skill, but Hongwei always subdued them with his measured words. Hun held him in particular esteem, calling him “Weizi.”

Later, when Hun was executed for his association with Liu Yi’s faction, his wife, Princess Jinling, was ordered to sever ties with the Xie clan and remarry into the Wang family of Langye. Hun entrusted his household affairs to Hongwei. As a family of successive prime ministers, they held two enfeoffments, owned over ten estates, and commanded a thousand servants—yet had only two daughters. Hongwei managed their livelihood and affairs as if conducting public business: every coin and bolt of silk was recorded in ledgers. When Emperor Gaozu ascended the throne, he recognized the princess’s fidelity and allowed her to return to the Xie clan. From Hun’s death to her return, nine years had passed, yet the estate remained well-maintained, granaries full, and the household’s operations unchanged from former days. The fields were even more cultivated than before. The princess sighed, “The Minister always valued this child—he truly knew men. The Minister has not perished after all.”

Relatives by marriage, both secular and monastic, and old friends who witnessed the princess’s return entered the gate and could not help but sigh in admiration. Some wept, moved by Hongwei’s sense of duty.

The record states: Observing the Gathering of Wu Clothing Lane, one sees what was truly meant by “orchids and jade trees, radiant in their time.” There was Shu Yuan’s discernment, Kang Le’s literary brilliance, Xuan Yuan’s clarity and insight, and Xuan Ming’s outstanding talent—yet none met a natural end, save Weizi alone. Why was this? *The Book of Changes* in the *Hexagram of Minor Excess* says: “Failing to meet and exceeding—when the flying bird strays, it is ominous. This is called disaster and misfortune.” These men were not without talent or moral capacity, but they were all proud, impetuous, and reliant on their abilities, lacking steadfast integrity. They transgressed reason and overstepped bounds—hence their misfortune. Weizi, however, was stern and upright by nature, his conduct refined and restrained. In serving his adoptive family, he surpassed even his birth parents, acting with utmost sincerity and reverence. Inwardly, he communed with the divine; outwardly, he was cautious in speech and laughter, never compromising integrity or dignity. He seldom contended, yet was always upright—truly one whose conduct exceeded in reverence, whose mourning exceeded in grief, and whose frugality exceeded in thrift. Where could such a man not find his place?

*Hongdao Record*, Scroll Twenty-Three, concludes.

**Hongdao Record, Scroll Twenty-Four**

1. "Karma" (業) originally written as "joy" (樂), emended according to the *Thirteen Classics with Commentaries and Subcommentaries*.
2. "Eternal" (永) originally written as "garment" (衣), emended according to the *Thirteen Classics with Commentaries and Subcommentaries*.
3. "Now I" (今予) originally written as "your command" (令子), emended according to the *Thirteen Classics with Commentaries and Subcommentaries*.
4. "Follow" (從) originally written as "explain" (說), emended according to the *Thirteen Classics with Commentaries and Subcommentaries*.
5. "Duke" (公) originally missing, supplied according to the *Thirteen Classics with Commentaries and Subcommentaries*.
6. "Ultimately" (卒) originally written as "lead" (率), emended according to the *Thirteen Classics with Commentaries and Subcommentaries*.
7. "Xinghou" (刑侯) originally missing, supplied according to the *Thirteen Classics with Commentaries and Subcommentaries*.
8. "All" (咸) originally written as "person" (人), emended according to the *Book of Jin*.
9. "Crushed" (輾) originally written as "then" (輒), emended according to the *Book of Jin*.
10. "None" (無) originally written as "and" (與), emended according to the *Book of Jin*.

*Hongdao Record, Scroll Twenty-Four: Righteousness* concludes.

**On Brotherly Righteousness**

From the *Old唐书*: Yu Shinan and his elder brother Shiji studied together under Yu Gu Yewang for over ten years, their concentrated thought unrelenting—sometimes going for months without washing or combing their hair. Their writings were graceful and refined, emulating the style of Minister Xu Ling. Xu himself believed their work resembled his own, and thus they gained renown. During the Tianjia era of the Chen dynasty, Emperor Wen, knowing the two brothers to be broadly learned, sent envoys to their home to protect and observe them. Shiji’s prose was clearer and more vigorous than Shinan’s, though not as richly abundant. Contemporaries compared them to the two Lu brothers of the Jin. During the Daye era, Shiji rose through the ranks to become Gentleman of the Secretariat. Under Emperor Yang of Sui, Shiji gained the emperor’s favor, attaining wealth and eminence; his wives and concubines, along with their attire and carriages, rivaled those of princes. Shinan, however, lived in humble austerity, never altering his conduct. When Yuwen Huaji killed Shiji, Shinan clung to him, wailing and pleading to die in his stead, but was unable to do so. From that time on, he grieved to the point of emaciation. Entering the Tang, he became a Scholar of the Hongwen Academy. Though already aged, he repeatedly petitioned to retire, but was not permitted. Emperor Taizong held him in high regard, for though his appearance was that of a frail scholar—seemingly too weak to bear his robes—his inner resolve was steadfast. In discussions, he upheld righteousness, and the emperor once remarked: “When I discuss ancient and modern affairs with Shinan, if he errs even in a single word, I cannot help but feel regret.” Such was his sincerity. The emperor also praised his five unparalleled virtues: moral conduct, loyalty and uprightness, broad learning, literary skill, and calligraphy. He died at the age of eighty-one.

**Record states:** Observing the two Yu brothers, one flourished in the Sui, the other rose in the Tang. The one who flourished in the Sui was like a spring flower in full bloom, dazzling for a time—thus the comparison to the two Lu brothers, for they were indeed both excellent. The one who rose in the Tang was like a late chrysanthemum holding its blossoms, its fragrance spreading in all directions—thus the world extolled his five unparalleled virtues, none surpassing him. Though their circumstances differed, their beginnings and ends were vastly distinct, as seen here. How then can one allow poverty or success, early or late, to divide one’s heart?

Cui Deng, styled Churen, had six brothers: Deng, Yan, Zou, Du, and E, all of whom simultaneously attained the rank of Third Grade. Among them, five served as Ministers of Rites and two as Ministers of Personnel—an unprecedented achievement since the founding of the Tang. Their father, Wu, maintained a household where four generations shared the same hearth, and contemporary families seeking to govern well all emulated their methods. Deng, known for his integrity and brightness, was esteemed by Emperor Xianzong and appointed Minister of Ceremonies. Upon assuming office, he conducted a grand review of the Four Departments of Music, drawing crowds of spectators from the capital. Deng personally escorted his mother’s carriage, leading his younger brothers, and when officials and nobles saw them, they yielded the road. The people of the capital honored them. Yan’s son, Guanglüe, possessed a majestic and handsome bearing, admired by all who saw him. His subordinates dared not deceive him, and whenever he appointed officials, he personally consulted the regulations, ensuring promotions and demotions were just. Even those from distant and humble backgrounds were never overlooked. He never hoarded wealth, but whenever he had any, he distributed it among his relatives and old friends. At home, he was cheerful, and his children and younger siblings followed his example. Du served as Left General of the Gold Bird Guard and died at home, having taken no part in Li Xun’s rebellion. People attributed this to the reward of accumulated goodness. E, as Acting Minister of the Right and Chief Councilor, governed Huainan. His residence was in Guangli Alley, where he built a study for convenience. Emperor Xuanzong, hearing of this, sighed and said: “The Zheng family’s filial piety and brotherly love serve as a model for scholar-official clans.” He then inscribed the name *Hall of Virtue’s Star*. Later, the capital’s Jingzhao Prefecture established a *Virtue’s Star* community in that neighborhood.

**Record states:** The Liu clan once said: “For those who walk the Way, virtue and learning are the roots, while uprightness and fortitude are the branches and leaves. With roots but no leaves, one may await the right time; with leaves but no roots, even nourishing rain cannot revive them. As for filial piety, brotherly love, loyalty, trustworthiness, and steadfast conduct—these are the ferment and sauce of life, how can one go a single day without them?” Observing the Cui family makes this clear. How can one neglect the standards of the world and become complacent, flaunting one’s successive displays of prosperity and indulging in wealth and rank? The inscription *Virtue’s Star* will surely not shine.

When Liu Gongchuo, Military Commissioner of Hexi, was among the most renowned of the ministers, he maintained strict family discipline. Outside the central gate of his residence stood a small study. Except on days when he attended court, he would emerge each dawn to enter this study. His sons, Zhong and Ying, all dressed in formal attire and paid their morning respects at the north side of the central gate. Gongchuo handled private matters, received guests, and dined with his younger brother Gongquan and their cousins. From dawn to dusk, he never left the study. When the lamps were lit, he would have his sons and younger brothers take up the classics and histories, reading them aloud once through. Afterward, they would discuss the principles of official conduct and household governance, or engage in literary discourse, or listen to the qin. Only when the night watch’s bell sounded would he return to his bedchamber. His sons would then perform the evening rites at the north side of the central gate. For over twenty years, this routine never varied for a single day.

In years of famine, his sons all ate only vegetables, and he would say: "Formerly, when my brothers and I served our late father as Prefect of Danzhou, he forbade us to eat meat on account of our unfinished studies. I dare not forget this."

When Gongchuo passed away, Zhong and Ying strictly adhered to his ways, serving Gongquan as they had served Gongchuo. Unless gravely ill, they never failed to wear their sashes in Gongquan’s presence. When Zhong served as Prefect of the Capital and Salt and Iron Commissioner, if he encountered Gongquan on the thoroughfare, he would dismount, stand upright in formal posture, and wait until Gongquan had passed before remounting. When Gongquan returned at dusk, they would don their sashes and greet him at the head of his horse. Though Gongquan repeatedly urged them to relax, Zhong and Ying never altered their conduct in the slightest, despite their official rank.

Gongchuo’s wife, née Han, was the great-granddaughter of the Chancellor Xiuzhi. Her family’s discipline was strict, frugal, and solemn, serving as a model for official households. After marrying into the Liu family, for three years she was never seen to smile in the presence of elders or juniors. She always wore plain silk, never brocade or embroidered silks. When returning to visit her parents, she did not ride in a gilded palanquin but only in a bamboo sedan chair, followed by two maidservants on foot. She often had pills made of bitter ginseng, coptis, and bear gall mixed with powder, which she distributed to her sons to hold in their mouths during long nights of study, to sustain their diligence.

A record states: The histories praise Gongchuo as benevolent yet courageous, and Zhong and Ying as upright, austere, and unadorned. Father and sons successively governed nine frontier commands, five times as Prefect of the Capital, and twice as Prefect of Henan. In none of these posts did they report auspicious omens, ordain monks or Daoists, or pardon corrupt officials. In administering their jurisdictions, they were urgent in aiding the poor and orphaned. At the first sign of flood or drought, they would lend grain in advance. Military provisions were always abundant, tax reductions and exemptions were granted, courier stations were well-supplied, and banquets for guests or rewards for troops were lavish. Yet when they handed over their posts, the granaries and treasuries were always fuller than when they had arrived. Such was their method of governance.

As for their personal cultivation and family discipline, the histories do not record these in full. Liu once wrote a book admonishing his descendants: "To ruin one’s reputation is to harm oneself; to disgrace one’s ancestors is to destroy one’s family." He listed five particularly grave faults, urging them to take heed:

First, seeking ease and comfort, disdaining frugality, pursuing personal gain without regard for others’ opinions;
Second, being ignorant of the Confucian arts, disliking the ancient Way, ashamed neither of one’s ignorance of the classics nor of one’s frivolous discourse on current affairs, resenting others’ learning while remaining oneself unlearned;
Third, resenting those superior to oneself while favoring flatterers, delighting only in idle chatter, neglecting the ancient Way, envying others’ virtues and broadcasting their faults, gradually sinking into depravity, eroding moral principles, while maintaining only the outward trappings of a gentleman—how does this differ from a menial servant?
Fourth, indulging in leisure and dissipation, addicted to wine and ruin, prizing drinking as refinement and dismissing diligence as vulgar, habits easily formed but difficult to correct;
Fifth, being desperate for official rank, currying favor with the powerful, gaining even a minor post through such means, only to incur the anger and suspicion of the multitude, with few escaping ruin.

I have observed that eminent families and great clans are all established through their ancestors’ loyalty, filial piety, diligence, and frugality, and are all destroyed by their descendants’ obstinacy, extravagance, and arrogance. Establishing a family is as difficult as ascending to heaven; destroying one is as easy as burning a hair. These words pierce the heart—you should engrave them in your bones.

A record states: The Liu family’s standards have endured for generations. Such admonitions as these apply to all, regardless of age or status. One should copy them and place them by one’s side. Do not dismiss them as trivial—no study is more essential.

The *History of the Song* records: When the Taizu Emperor visited Luoyang, Zhang Qixian, a commoner, presented a memorial outlining ten proposals, four of which pleased the emperor. On his return, the emperor told the Taizong Emperor: "During my visit to the western capital, I gained only one man—Zhang Qixian. I do not wish to appoint him to office; one day, he may serve as your chief minister." When the Taizong Emperor ascended the throne, he held an examination for scholars, and Qixian was among the selected. The examiners, however, failed to recognize his merit, and he was ranked among those who failed. The emperor was displeased and personally inscribed the entire list as having passed, granting them all official posts as *tongpan*. A record states: The Taizu Emperor’s recommendation of Qixian to serve as the Taizong Emperor’s chief minister was sincere and virtuous. At that time, the Taizong Emperor’s private ambitions had not yet arisen, and his original intentions remained intact. Thus, he granted the entire list of candidates the honor of passing—this was truly a radiant bestowal of favor. But when his private ambitions began to stir, Qixian was overlooked. Only after Zhao Pu recommended him a second time was he finally given high office. The emperor said: "If you advance Qixian, he will feel even greater gratitude than this." The emperor was greatly pleased. From this, it may be seen that Qixian was privy to the Prince of Qin’s schemes. Alas! Qixian betrayed the founding emperor.

How could one like Wang Pu, who vacillated between past and present regimes to ingratiate himself with the current court, be expected to render loyal and corrective service? The Chen family of Jiangzhou had a clan of seven hundred members. From Chen Chong onward, for several generations they never divided their household. They established family rules to admonish their descendants, selecting capable kinsmen to manage affairs, and built a school to instruct them. An imperial edict commended them as a "righteous household" and exempted them from corvée labor. Chong’s son Yibiao, and Yibiao’s son Fang, lived together without concubines or maidservants, and no one spoke out of turn. At mealtimes, the entire family gathered in the great hall, with those not yet grown seated separately. They built a library to host scholars from all directions, and the local customs were transformed. Fang’s nephew Hong, Hong’s younger brother Jing, and Jing’s descendants grew ever more numerous, often suffering from food shortages. During the Chunhua era, the Taizong Emperor ordered the local government to lend them two thousand *shi* of grain annually. Later, when Jing died, his cousin Xu accepted only half the grain, saying: "By economizing, we can last until the autumn harvest. This year’s poor harvest has driven up grain prices." Some urged Xu to accept the full amount, hoping to profit from the high prices, but Xu replied: "The court, seeing our large family’s hardship, lends us public grain. How can we see profit and forget righteousness?"

The Emperor, upon hearing this, deeply praised and commended him.

The record states: Jing’s relation to Xu was like that of the Emperor to Mei; Fang’s to Hong was like Mei’s to Zhao. Within one family, Chong served as its elder, Fang as its successor. Fang’s nephew was Hong, Hong’s younger brother was Jing, and Jing’s younger brother was Xu—across generations, they remained of one heart, never setting themselves apart. How could the laws of the state be inferior to the rules of a household, or a dying command less far-reaching than a bequeathed counsel? Examining this closely, its root lay in never contending for profit from grain. From a single mustard seed to ten thousand *zhong*, from a single chamber to the realm entire, why the ancients—sages and worthies—remained so vigilant and diligent, never daring to act with abandon, was precisely to cultivate this heart beforehand, lest they see profit and forget righteousness. Thus, in a mere Jiangzhou, there was the Chen family with seven hundred mouths, young and old; yet in the vast realm under heaven, there was not even one brother or two nephews like those of the Song. The Emperor’s praise for one man, while willingly bearing the censure of ten thousand generations, shows his failure to grasp the essence.

Ge Gong’s younger brother, Mi, was renowned for his Confucian learning and moral integrity across generations. During the Zhenzong Emperor’s reign, he presented *Ten Elegant Odes on Great Peace* and offered a *Eulogy for the Pavilion of Auspicious Omens*, which Yang Yi praised. Appointed magistrate of Nanchong, he was known for his benevolent governance and was promoted to governor of Nanjianzhou. The mountains and streams there abounded in copper and silver, and officials, exploiting deceit for profit, claimed the harvests were poor. Gong reformed the system, yielding an annual surplus of six million. The Minister of Revenue reported this to the court, deeming it worthy of reward, but Gong said: "How dare I claim credit for what heaven and earth produce?" He ultimately remained silent. Later, he was transferred to govern Xiuzhou. Xiuzhou lay between rivers and lakes, where officials had set up barriers along the waterways to levy tolls on travelers. Many with urgent wedding or funeral matters could not meet their deadlines, so Gong ordered all such tolls abolished. He died in office as Grand Master for Palace Attendants.

Gong was by nature kind and compassionate, recording the names of his clan and aiding widows and orphans—many owed their survival to him. While serving as judicial officer in Guangzhou, a powerful figure named Li Xin murdered someone and framed a local man, Ge Hua. Gong uncovered the truth and exonerated him. Though this act also merited reward, Gong reported it to the prefect and asked that no mention be made of it. He rose to the rank of Erudite of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices, his nature ever serene and composed.

At fifty, he submitted a memorial to retire, but his relatives and in-laws all urged him to reconsider. He smiled and said: "If I wait until illness or old age forces me to die in office, how can I claim to have retired with any grace left?" His son Shusi was appointed registrar of Jiande. By then, Gong was already elderly and wished to have him nearby, but the post made this difficult. Shusi said: "Master Zeng would not leave his parents’ side even for a day—how could a mere five pecks of grain sway my lifelong resolve?" He resigned and returned home to care for his father. When his father died, Shusi’s grief was so profound that his bones jutted through his flesh. Even in the height of summer, he refused to remove his mourning hemp, and for years he could not bear to leave the family home. Only after much time did he return to office.

His elder brother Shuyuan served as magistrate of Wangjiang, both brothers under the jurisdiction of the Huainan surveillance commissioner. When someone recommended Shusi over his brother, Shusi sent a letter requesting that the recommendation be changed to favor his brother. When this was refused, he returned the official document unopened. Such was his devotion to righteousness. He rose to Gentleman for Court Service and likewise retired early. Neither father nor son waited for mandatory retirement age, and people universally admired them. Gong was posthumously honored with the epithet "Pure and Filial."

His son Shengzhong was recorded in the *Biographies of Confucian Scholars*. His grandson Lifang, great-grandson You, and five generations in all passed the imperial examinations, with three generations serving as drafters of imperial edicts. You eventually became chief minister under Emperors Guangzong and Ningzong. He once said: "In all twelve hours of the day, never deceive yourself." Such was his commitment to practice.

The compiler notes: Observing the Ge family—fathers, grandfathers, sons, grandsons, and brothers—how far their blessings extended! Some left high office for humble posts; some, though in positions of power, upheld integrity and the law; some father and son vied in their devotion to duty; some brothers recommended each other for promotion. Their purity, filial piety, and renown as Confucian scholars were unmatched in ancient times. Five generations of imperial examination success and three generations of drafting imperial edicts are rare even in recent eras. This surpasses even the Wang family’s Three Sophoras.

Song Xiang and his younger brother Qi both passed the imperial examinations. The Ministry of Rites ranked Qi first and Xiang second, but Empress Dowager Zhangxian, unwilling to let a younger brother precede his elder, promoted Xiang to first place and demoted Qi to tenth. People thus referred to them as "the Two Songs,

From the outset, he was regarded as a candidate for the position of prime minister not merely for his rank or minor promotions. The Song dynasty’s generosity toward its scholars, its deep-rooted fidelity to the village elders, surpassed that of the Han and Tang dynasties by far—yet these men, though far inferior in number, would sooner curse their own private interests than betray the public trust, sooner defy powerful ministers than deceive the court. Above, they did not fail the Son of Heaven; below, they did not betray what they had studied. In this, they may be said to have embodied the principle of sacrificing oneself for the Dao. Though some rose to high office and others did not, their essential character was already formed, and this alone qualifies them as great ministers. As for success or failure, profit or loss—what need is there to weigh such things?

Wang Anguo served as Professor at the Western Capital’s Directorate of Education. When his term expired and he arrived in the capital, the Emperor, on account of his brother Wang Anshi, specially summoned him and asked, “What sort of ruler was Emperor Wen of Han?” Anguo replied, “Since the Three Dynasties, there has been none like him.” The Emperor said, “The only regret is that his talent was insufficient to establish new laws and institutions.” Anguo responded, “When Emperor Wen came from Dai to enter the Weiyang Palace and settle the crisis, even a moment’s hesitation would have been impossible for one without talent. Yet he heeded Jia Yi’s counsel, treated his ministers with restraint, and devoted himself to transforming the people through virtue. The realm flourished with ritual and music, and he nearly achieved the abolition of corporal punishment—thus, Emperor Wen was a cut above those merely deemed talented.” The Emperor then asked, “Wang Meng assisted Fu Jian, and with such a small state, his commands were always obeyed. Now, with the vastness of my empire, why can I not make men obey?” Anguo replied, “Meng instructed Jian to enforce harsh laws and execute many, leading to the swift demise of the Qin dynasty. Today, petty and ruthless men must be misleading Your Majesty. I urge you to take Yao, Shun, and the Three Dynasties as your model—how could the people below not follow?” The Emperor then asked, “What does public opinion say of your brother’s governance?” Anguo answered, “They regret that he does not discern men’s character clearly and that his tax collection is too urgent.” The Emperor was displeased, and as a result, Anguo was only appointed Collator at the Chongwen Academy. He repeatedly remonstrated with Anshi over the harms of the New Policies and once labeled Lu Huiqing a sycophant, for which Huiqing bore a grudge.

**Recorded Note:** The Emperor’s questioning of Anguo was, in effect, a questioning of Anshi. Anshi probed the Emperor’s inclinations, which leaned toward the harshness of the two Qin dynasties, and so he exploited his power and favor to advance his private agenda. Anguo, recognizing his brother’s errors and his blindness to the flatterers around him, employed forthright words to dispel his delusions. Otherwise, the Wang family would have had no one left. Though Huiqing’s malevolence sought to behead Han Qi and Fu Bi, he ultimately lost his nerve—clearly, Heaven’s judgment was most evident. Though Anguo did not please the Emperor, he did not cut himself off from Heaven. Posterity does not condemn Anguo for Anshi’s faults; this much is clear.

Zeng Gong was orphaned young, and his younger brothers Bu and Zhao both studied under him. His writings drew their fundamental principles from the Six Classics, refined through the styles of Sima Qian and Han Yu. Few of his contemporaries could surpass his literary skill. Zhao, though young, devoted himself to study, mastering the classics and histories. His prose was temperate and well-structured. After governing eleven prefectures, he was known for his many virtuous policies. When Bu later gained power, from the Xining era onward for forty years, the struggle between the upright and the corrupt intensified, and factional disputes repeatedly arose. Zhao, caught in the midst of this turmoil, found himself at odds with his brother. When Bu served alongside Han Zhongyan as prime minister, he worked day and night to undermine Zhao. Zhao, stationed elsewhere, wrote to him, saying: “Now that you have the Emperor’s favor, you should promote good men, uphold the correct path, and prevent the resurgence of men like Zeng Dun and Bian. Yet for months, those of integrity and good fortune have left the court one after another, while those you advance to assist, attend, and oversee are often the very men who once served Dun and Bian. The situation shifts daily, and today’s allies are tomorrow’s tools for securing your position. The thought of it is enough to move one to tears. Recently, the Emperor’s intentions have shifted, the way of petty men has grown, and those who advance must first denounce the Yuanyou faction before the throne, then purge them from key positions upon returning. Even if Dun and Bian do not fully return, a single Cai Jing is enough to surpass them—this cannot be ignored.” Bu did not heed his advice. Soon after, Jing indeed gained power, and both Bu and Zhao were brought down.

**Recorded Note:** Since the two Songs and the two Sus gained renown, contemporaries like the Wangs of Jinling and the Zengs of Nanfeng were scarcely inferior in literature, conduct, or ability—one should not view them as fundamentally different. Yet a single bias of the heart, a single struggle for favor and rank, led one to deviance and the other to uprightness, as distant as heaven and earth, as distinct as fragrance and stench, as if placed in separate vessels. Their infamy persists to this day. Was this not because they slandered the upright, expelled the loyal and righteous, and devoted themselves to promoting the wicked to secure their positions and curry favor? As for the Wang brothers’ relationship to the New Policies, their divergence came late indeed.

When Emperor Huizong had already appointed Cai Jing as chief minister, he soon after reappointed Zeng Bu, and it was Zhao Ding who drafted the edict, stating: "The eastern and western halls divide the court; left and right ministers are established as aids." Alas! Why did he not at that time clarify right and wrong to determine departure or retention? Having already been relegated to external office, he then began to send letters—was this not too late? No wonder Zeng Bu could not follow his counsel.

Lü Zujian and Lü Zutai were the younger brothers of Lü Zuqian, having studied under him. After Lü Zuqian’s death, Lü Zujian was appointed supervisor of Mingzhou. According to the *Granary Regulations*, failure to submit reports within half a year constituted a violation, but Lü Zujian insisted on observing the full mourning period. The court acquiesced, issuing an edict setting a one-year limit—this precedent began with Lü Zujian.

When Emperor Ningzong ascended the throne, Lü Zujian was appointed vice-director of the Great Treasury. At the time, Han Tuozhou slandered Zhao Ruyu, and Lü Zujian submitted a sealed memorial, saying: "Your Majesty’s early governance was clear and bright, yet before long, Zhu Xi, an elder scholar, and Peng Gui’nian, a veteran of the old learning, were both permitted to depart. As for Li Xiang, whose age and sincerity inspire trust among the people—now he too is banished. I fear the realm will take warning from this."
