Here the scholars who dare to speak face their greatest difficulty not in offending ruler or father, but in defying the will of those in power. To illustrate with what I know: nothing is harder than to discuss portents and anomalies, yet men speak freely of these because such matters do not touch upon power and influence. But when an imperial brush descends, the court dares not strongly oppose, the censors dare not press the issue, and the drafters dare not hold firm—all because the matter concerns the favored and the mighty, and all fear that questioning might provoke anger and bring grave offense. Recently, when those around the throne were dismissed or demoted, those who gained audience saw carriages and horses crowd their gates like a marketplace. Relying on power and estimating favor, they shake the outer court. I fear that if this trend continues, governance will fall into the hands of the favored, not the public chamber. All those they recommend will be their own; all those they cast down will be those they hate. Not only will men avert their eyes in fear, too afraid to point and speak, but flattery and compliance will spread, and the dangers of inner and outer collusion will surely become manifest. Do not think I am willful or reckless, courting punishment—it is only that the spirit of the scholar-officials has grown weak, and my private concern has led me to overthink. I deeply fear that Your Majesty’s position will become isolated, and those who might together uphold the altars of state will grow few.

An edict ordered Lü Zujian’s banishment to Shaozhou. Zhu Xi wrote to him, saying: “In rank I stand above you, and in imperial favor and courtesy I surpass you, yet I sat by and watched the misdeeds of the young clique, unable to speak in service to the throne. Now you alone have vented your indignation, provoked the petty men, and stepped into the snare of disaster—my shame and regret run deep.” Lü Zujian replied: “At court, hearing of current affairs was like standing in fire and water. I could not remain for a single day. Now, exiled to the countryside, I know nothing of order or chaos. What more is there to say?”

He once remarked: “Those who bend to the times and lose their usual conduct are not worth discussing. But those who, because of the times, let their will and spirit grow more intense—this too is a private impulse.”

Lü Zutai was open and unrestrained by nature, valuing righteousness and loyalty. His learning was broad and profound. He wandered rivers and lakes, befriending the renowned scholars of the age. When Lü Zujian was banished to a distant province, Lü Zutai walked there to visit him, staying over a month. He told his friend Wang Shenhou: “Since my brother’s demotion, men have sealed their lips. Though I hold no office, in duty I must speak to repay the state. I will wait a little longer, lest I bring trouble upon my brother.” After Lü Zujian died in exile, Lü Zutai submitted a memorial denouncing Han Tuozhou for harboring disloyal intent. “The Dao-scholars,” he wrote, “have since ancient times been relied upon to serve the state. To impose a ban on ‘false learning’ and expel the followers of Zhao Ruyu is to empty the realm—does Your Majesty not see this? Chen Ziqiang, a mere tutor to children, was kicked into the position of chief minister; Su Shidan, a petty clerk from Pingjiang, gained military command through his connection to the former princely residence; Zhou Jun, a servant in the Han household, obtained high office through the empress’s kin. Did Your Majesty, in your former residence, truly know Shidan? Did the empress’s family truly include Jun? All of Han Tuozhou’s clique exalt themselves and belittle the court—it has come to this. I urge the swift execution of Tuozhou and Shidan, and the dismissal of Chen Ziqiang’s faction. Only Zhou Bida is fit for office and should replace them.”

The memorial shocked the court and the realm. An edict declared him “privately motivated and wildly reckless,” and he was sentenced to a hundred strokes of the rod and exiled to Qinzhou.

A record states: Master Zhenwen once remarked that Dayu possessed the bearing of Chenggong, yet he remained but a minor prefectural aide. As for Tairan, he was merely a commoner of the lowest rank—without official duties, without the responsibility of remonstrance—yet why did he willingly tread upon perilous ground? After the Song court fled south, the Ming departed never to return, and treacherous and wicked men arose in succession, yet none matched the times of Tuozhou. Since the rise of the doctrine of "heterodox learning," it has been openly claimed that depravity, perversity, and extravagance are man’s true nature, while integrity and self-cultivation are but pretense. Never since the dawn of civilization has such a doctrine existed—it is even more insidious than the treachery of calling a deer a horse, more calamitous than the disaster of burning books and burying scholars alive. Any man may justly execute its proponents, how much more so those who have inherited the transmission of the Central Plains’ cultural legacy?

Moreover, in the reign of Emperor Renzong, both Duke Lü and Duke Han-Wei held the position of chief minister and enjoyed great renown, yet the divergence between their descendants in virtue and vice could not be more stark. Lü, though repeatedly banished and exiled, left a fragrance a hundredfold; while Han’s descendants, utterly depraved and vile, have earned eternal infamy. The gentleman cannot but sigh deeply at this.

The six brothers of the Lu family—Jiulong and his kin—were born to Father He, who for generations maintained a household of shared property, designating the eldest as the family head, to whom all household affairs were entrusted. The younger members divided the labor: some oversaw fields and taxes, others managed provisions, kitchens, or guests. Jiulong, inheriting his father’s will, further refined ritual learning and governed his household with order. Within the gates, a hundred mouths—men and women alike—were arranged by rank, each fulfilling their duties. The inner chambers were as solemn as the imperial court, yet filled with loyalty, reverence, harmony, and joy. The villagers, moved by their example, deferred to them as younger brothers. Jiulong and his brother Jiuyuan treated each other as teacher and friend, harmonious yet not identical, and scholars called them the "Two Lu." When students came seeking instruction, Jiulong would respond with ease, guiding each to their own understanding. If someone was not yet ready to grasp his words, he would remain silent. He once said: "There are delusions in men that cannot be dispelled by argument. Pressing too forcefully only entrenches their views; given time, they may yet awaken on their own."

Zhang Jingfu of Guanghan, though unacquainted with Jiulong, later exchanged letters with him on learning, shouldering the weight of the world’s moral order. Lü Zuqian often praised him, saying: "His aspirations are great, his foundations solid. Though obstacles may entangle him, he dares not claim success even after piling effort as high as nine *ren*. Though but a hair’s breadth of bias may exist, he dares not rest content even as a paragon to ten thousand men. He listens broadly, observes keenly, steps back to survey all sides, and will not act until he has reached the state of perfect equilibrium and purity."

His younger brother, Jiushao, was also deeply refined in learning. He lived in seclusion among the mountains, recording his daily words and deeds each night. He composed admonitory verses in rhyme, and at dawn, the family head would lead the assembled children and younger siblings to the ancestral shrine. There, after the rites, they would strike the drum and recite his words, requiring all to listen in order.

A record states: Observing the strictness of the Lu family’s household rules and the solemnity of their inner discipline, later generations may clearly follow and practice them. Zhang Gongyi’s single virtue of forbearance, though admirable, still falls short; here, the benefits of Dao-learning cannot be dismissed as merely maintaining a household of shared property for generations.

Shi Migong was the cousin of Mi Yuan. When he entered the Imperial Academy and advanced to the upper division, Mi Yuan, then wielding power, referred to him as "Jili" to avoid the appearance of favoritism, though he was not yet an official. Thus, Migong was denied examination and remained in obscurity for a decade. Only in the tenth year of Jiading did he finally pass the imperial examinations. In the early years of Duanping, he entered the capital as a supervisor of the Memorials Office. He once responded to an imperial edict with a memorial, saying: "Calamities within the imperial family are not unique to our age. Your Majesty’s fraternal affection has often been evident. The reason Hong Zikui earned Your Majesty’s special favor was his assertion that the events in Shu were not the true intent of Prince Ji, and that Prince Ji’s death was likewise not Your Majesty’s true intent. His words deeply resonated with Your Majesty’s heart."

The late emperor’s son, Your Majesty’s elder brother, was not even allowed to rest his remains in peace—how could this not disrupt the harmony of qi and summon calamities? At the time, a certain Deng Ruoshui also submitted a memorial, saying: "Only by upholding great righteousness can great slander be dispelled; only by reclaiming great authority can the great throne be secured; only by eliminating great treachery can great peril be quelled."

When Emperor Ningzong passed, Prince Ji was rightfully heir to the throne. Yet his deposition was never heard by the late emperor, nor were his faults ever made known to the people. Shi Miyuan, unwilling to see him enthroned, falsified the late emperor’s decree, banished Prince Ji, and even murdered the imperial grandson. Within half a year, Miyuan himself perished by Lake Dongting. By the standards of the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, was this not regicide? Was it not usurpation? The realm laid blame squarely on Miyuan, yet dared not impute fault to Your Majesty—why? In that sudden crisis, it was not something Your Majesty could have known, and we trusted that Your Majesty could never have harbored such intent. But now, years have passed, and Your Majesty’s firm resolve remains unsteady, your authority unasserted, failing to fulfill the hopes of the realm. Those who once trusted Your Majesty now suspect complicity; those who once believed you unaware now suspect you knew all along. How can Your Majesty endure this stain beneath the bright sun and blue sky? This is what I mean by upholding great righteousness to dispel great slander.

The *Record* states: Deng Ruoshui’s plea for Prince Ji’s wrongs was just, but could Shi Migong, as a younger brother, rightfully plead against his elder? In the Song’s golden age, Lü Duan even locked away Li Jien’en to ensure the enthronement of the true heir, Zhenzong. At that time, did he not fear the crown prince’s brilliance, as Shi Xinen did? Yet he could not alter the succession, for the Golden Casket Pact was still fresh, and the imperial lineage’s bonds too close. No one could question the near over the distant, the old over the new. In the reign of Emperor Lizong, the empire had already faced the disgrace of the Five Nations City and the suspicion of a tenth-generation descendant. The realm’s affairs were like an inn—guests felt no gratitude, while hosts counted themselves fortunate. All was left to the whims of treacherous ministers, yet the principles of justice and the Dao of integrity could not be said to have vanished from the land. Still, no remedy could be found, for those in power saw seizing the throne as triumph and securing succession as favor. When would they have leisure to follow the example of Taibo and Jizi, acting with restraint and deference? Thus, the outcome was hardly surprising.

Cao Youwen and Cao Youliang were twelfth-generation descendants of Emperor Wu of the State of Cao. Both brothers harbored great ambitions, seeking teachers and friends without regard for distance. In the second year of Baoqing, Youwen passed the imperial examinations and was appointed instructor of Tianshui Prefecture. When Tianshui came under siege, Youwen and the prefectural governor, Zhang Wei, rallied the people to resist fiercely. After the enemy retreated, the military commissioner commended them. From then on, Youliang and Wan each gained renown for their martial prowess. They were dispatched to guard Xianren Pass and later defended Qifang Pass. When the Yuan forces invaded Da’an, Commander He Jin was killed in battle. Youwen and Wan led their troops through mountain paths, slew the enemy general, and were appointed to oversee Tianshui’s defenses. Later, Youwen and Youliang repeatedly directed battles with distinction, earning promotions to Martial Wing Grandee and Imperial Guard Commander-in-Chief.

At the time, Zhao Yannu advanced to Qingye Plain, where the Yuan forces besieged him. Youwen declared: "Qingye is the throat of Shu—we cannot delay." Wan led troops to intercept the enemy at midnight, breaking the siege. He was promoted to Martial Virtue Grandee, Valiant Cavalry General, and appointed Frontline Commander of the Sichuan Military Commission.

The following year, the Yuan crown prince, Kuoduan, assembled over five hundred thousand troops, both Mongol and Han, and prepared to advance. Youwen said: "The fate of the state hinges on this battle. Outnumbered as we are, we cannot fight recklessly. We must seize the high ground, hold the passes, and ambush the enemy with surprise tactics." Military Commissioner Zhao Yannu ordered Youwen to secure Da’an to protect the Shu frontier. Youwen disagreed, but Yannu overruled him. Instead, he sent Wan and Youliang to Yingguan Pass, where they displayed numerous banners to deceive the enemy into thinking the defenses were strong. Youwen selected elite troops and secretly set an ambush at Liuxi. He instructed: "When the enemy arrives, sound the drums and raise the signal fires."

The Yuan forces arrived as expected, and Wan engaged them head-on. Youwen dispatched Commander Yang Daquan to strike the rear, Commander Xia Yong to attack the center, and Lü Side to charge the vanguard. Youwen himself led three thousand crack troops in a swift march to the pass. A violent storm erupted; the Western troops, who used cotton cloaks in place of armor, found them soaked and useless. The Yuan forces, reinforced by iron-clad cavalry, encircled them on all sides. Youwen sighed: "This must be Heaven’s will. I can only die here." He cursed the enemy vehemently, slew his own horse to show his resolve, and fought with redoubled fury. He and his brother, along with their entire army, perished to the last man. The Yuan forces then swept into Shu unopposed.

Wang Shixian of Qinzhou and Gongzhou had long admired Youwen’s reputation. He once gifted him a fine horse. When the Yuan army passed the battlefield on their return, Wang lamented: "The Shu general was a true man of valor."

The *Record* states: By this point in the Song’s decline, even the wisest could do nothing. Earlier, Jia Sidao’s border provocations had invited disaster; the Yuan had already ravaged Jie and Cheng, harassed Xing and Mian, and penetrated Jin and Fang to threaten Xiangyang. Yet the court still debated the succession at Xianyuan, and Shu’s defenses held. At that time, no one yet considered fleeing by sea. But after Youwen’s death and the fall of Shu, the Yuan seized the advantage of the Yangtze’s currents, and nothing could stop their advance. Thus, the Song was driven to the ends of the earth. Had they recognized the signs earlier, they might have secured a better end. Therefore, how can rulers not take heed of treacherous ministers misleading the state?

The Cao brothers neither shamed the martial glory of their ancestors above nor disgraced the lineage that bore them below. Their deaths carried weight greater than Mount Tai, bearing upon the fate of the dynasty and altars of state—one cannot regard them as ordinary battles. Yuanwang, Yuanbo, and their elder brother Xuanbo, four generations unbroken in loyalty, shared a household of over a hundred without a single discordant word. When Xuanbo died, he entrusted family affairs to his nephew Gui. Gui declined, saying, "It is the duty of my uncle." Yuanbo replied, "You are the eldest son of the main line." After prolonged deference, the matter was finally entrusted to Gui. Even scholar-official families claimed they could not match them. Their wives each gathered in one room to do women’s work, pooling all they produced into a single storehouse, with no private hoards in their chambers. Even the youngest children were nursed together by one woman; if a mother returned home to visit her parents and left her child behind, the other women did not ask which was her own, nor did the children know which was their mother.

The *Record* states: The *Prefectural Gazetteer* notes that the Chen family of Jiangzhou kept over a hundred dogs that shared a single pen and ate from one trough—if one dog failed to arrive, none would eat. This was no different. Here, the account is thus abridged.

Yet when the young ones wept, whichever mother saw them would take them up and nurse them—this was indeed the case. Here it is recorded.

*The Annals of Queli* states: Kong Liang, styled Chongbo, was the fifty-seventh-generation descendant of the Sage. His father, Kong Xifeng, and mother, née Wang, had six sons: Liang, the eldest, followed by Ping, Zheng, Lun, Jin, and Zhen. Liang’s affection for his brothers was especially deep. At home, they always shared a single table for meals; when going out, they rode side by side, halting their chopsticks or reining in their horses if one was absent, waiting without sign of weariness. When relatives or friends visited, he would pour wine and summon his brothers in turn to toast and urge each other on. They discoursed on the classics, chanted poetry, and took turns reciting hundreds of lines, delightful to hear and to love. Many of his brothers were refined and improved by his influence. The elders of the clan often exhorted their kinsmen, saying, “If you could be like the Chongbo brothers, it would suffice.” The scholar-officials of Zou and Lu all regarded them as fine scions of the Kong family. When Liang died, they gathered to weep at his memorial tablet and privately bestowed the posthumous epithet *Dun You* (“Sincere Friend”).

The *Record* states: Confucius said, “Friends admonish one another earnestly; brothers dwell together in harmony.” The proper measure of each relationship differs. Yet one like *Dun You* may truly be said to have cherished the memory of his ancestors. This is why it is recorded here.

Thus ends *Hongdao Record*, Scroll Twenty-Four.

*Hongdao Record*, Scroll Twenty-Five: *Virtue*

Friendship’s Principle

Mencius said: “Those below honoring those above is called ‘honoring the noble.’ Those above honoring those below is called ‘revering worthies.’ Honoring the noble and revering worthies—these principles are one.”

The *Record* states: What is called the Grand Peace—was it not the age of Yao and Shun? How was it that high and low intermingled? When you and I stand as equals, our positions are of the same rank, and the Way of friendship becomes narrow. If one were to extend its principle to its fullest, it would be as if the Son of Heaven befriended a commoner without impropriety, or a commoner befriended the Son of Heaven without presumption. Yet when one does not fathom the Way of Heaven, it appears that those below honoring those above is compliant and easy, while those above honoring those below is contrary and difficult. Who would willingly humble themselves to take the lead before a commoner? Nevertheless, there are those who descend from their halls to seek out feudal lords—this cannot be called ‘revering worthies.’ And the so-called worthies of that time, when weighed against Confucius and Mencius, are no different from the shallow and the profound. Thus Confucius upheld the ritual of bowing to those below, and Mencius expounded the principle of revering worthies—their intent was one and the same.

The *Counsels of Gao Yao* states: “I, the humble one, once studied under Gan Pan. Later, I encountered him in the wilderness and entered his dwelling by the river. From the river to the ancestral temple at Bo, until the end of his days, his glory was unparalleled. You alone can instruct my will.”

If you brew sweet wine, you must rely on yeast and malt;
If you prepare a harmonious stew, you must rely on salt and plums.
When you cultivate yourself in relation to me, I shall not cast you aside—
I shall only advance your teachings if I am capable of doing so.

The *Record* states: In the hexagram *Dui* (兑), two marshes lie side by side, and ruler and minister delight in one another. When two marshes lie side by side, they mutually nourish and irrigate, each benefiting the other. When ruler and minister delight in one another, they mutually encourage and together partake in the blessings of great peace. Thus, its image is that of friends studying together, and its Dao is that of learning.

Later, when the minister first appeared, the yang line occupied the lowest position in the hexagram, so he had long labored in obscurity. By the time of *Shang Dui* (商兑), he had not yet found peace, so he was again driven into the wilderness, dwelling by the river. Yet when he finally arrived, he moved in accord with the celestial signs above and the hearts of the people below, standing resolute with joy, and blessings flowed without cease. This is how the governance of King Gaozong came to fruition.

Had he been swayed by the auspiciousness of *He Dui* (和兑) or misled by the inauspiciousness of *Lai Dui* (来兑), and upon his arrival indulged in the private inclinations of *Xie Dui* (邪兑), then yin would have overwhelmed yang, petty men would have thrived while the noble man stood alone, and the ensuing calamity would have been beyond description. This is why the ruler at the ninth-five position must remain vigilant and cautious.

The sage inscribed in the text: *"Trust in the stripping away brings danger."* Alas! Should this not serve as a warning for the Yin dynasty?

---

In the *Hong Fan*, in the thirteenth year of his reign, the king consulted Jizi, saying: "Alas! Heaven, in its hidden way, sustains the people below, harmonizing their dwellings. I do not understand the constant norms of their proper order."

Jizi then spoke: "I have heard that in ancient times, Gun dammed the floodwaters, throwing the Five Phases into chaos. The Lord was enraged and did not bestow upon him the *Hong Fan* of Nine Categories. Gun was executed for disrupting the constant norms. Then Yu arose as his successor, and Heaven bestowed upon him the *Hong Fan* of Nine Categories. The constant norms were thus restored. The first is the Five Phases; the second, reverently applying the Five Affairs; the third, managing the Eight Policies; the fourth, harmonizing the Five Regulations; the fifth, establishing the Royal Standard; the sixth, employing the Three Virtues; the seventh, clarifying the resolution of doubts; the eighth, heeding the various portents; the ninth, bestowing the Five Blessings and wielding the Six Calamities.

1. **The Five Phases**: First, Water; second, Fire; third, Wood; fourth, Metal; fifth, Earth.
   - Water moistens and descends; Fire flames and ascends; Wood can be bent or straightened; Metal can be molded or altered; Earth is for sowing and reaping.

2. **The Five Affairs**: First, appearance; second, speech; third, vision; fourth, hearing; fifth, thought.

3. **The Eight Policies**: First, food; second, goods; third, sacrifices; fourth, the Minister of Works; fifth, the Minister of Education; sixth, the Minister of Justice; seventh, hospitality; eighth, the military.

4. **The Five Regulations**: First, the year; second, the month; third, the day; fourth, the stars and constellations; fifth, the calendar.

5. **The Royal Standard**: The king establishes the supreme standard, gathering the Five Blessings in due time to bestow them upon the myriad people. Only when the myriad people adhere to your standard will you be granted the preservation of that standard.
   - Be without bias or partiality; follow the king’s righteousness.
   - Do not indulge personal preferences; follow the king’s Dao.
   - Do not indulge personal vices; follow the king’s path.
   - Be without faction or partisanship; the king’s Dao is vast and open.
   - Be without partisanship or bias; the king’s Dao is level and even.
   - Be without perversity or deviation; the king’s Dao is upright and straight.
   - Converge upon the supreme standard; return to the supreme standard.

6. **The Three Virtues**: First, uprightness; second, firmness in overcoming; third, gentleness in overcoming.

7. **Resolving Doubts**: Then command the diviners of milfoil and turtle shell, who will say: rain, clear skies, cloudiness, overcast, victory, constancy, or obscurity. There are seven in total—five from divination, two from oracle interpretation—lest one err in judgment.

8. **The Various Portents**: Rain, sunshine, warmth, cold, wind, and timeliness. When these five come in full measure, each in its proper order, the myriad plants flourish. If one is in excess, calamity follows.

9. **The Five Blessings**: First, longevity; second, wealth; third, health and peace; fourth, love of virtue; fifth, a good end to one’s lifespan.
   **The Six Calamities**: First, early death; second, illness; third, sorrow; fourth, poverty; fifth, evil; sixth, weakness."

The *Record* states: This is the teaching of the Royal Standard expounded in full, which Jizi conveyed to King Wu. Those who inherit the transmission of the Dao’s lineage must not regard this lightly. *Yi* (彝) refers to what is most constant and unchanging; *Hong* (洪) to what is most vast and boundless; *Lun* (伦) to the unchanging principles by which the Yin followed the Xia and the Zhou followed the Yin; *Fan* (范) to the great unity by which Yu transmitted it to Tang, and Tang to Wen, Wu, and the Duke of Zhou. None but Jizi could have grasped this, none but King Wu could have heard it, and thus it was transmitted to the world. How could rulers of all ages remain ignorant of it?

---

In the *Record of Rites*, it is said: Once, when Confucius was at the Biyin sacrifice, the rites concluded, and he went out to stroll above the ancestral temple’s terrace. He sighed deeply. Yan Yan, who was at his side, asked: "Master, why do you sigh?"

Confucius replied: "The practice of the Great Dao, and the excellence of the Three Dynasties’ sages—I have not lived to see them, but I hold them in my aspirations. When the Great Dao prevailed, the world was held in common. The worthy and capable were selected, trust was cultivated, and harmony was fostered. Thus, people did not love only their own parents, nor did they rear only their own children. The elderly were ensured a peaceful end, the able-bodied had work, the young were nurtured, and the widowed, orphaned, childless, and disabled were all cared for. Men had their roles, and women had their homes. They hated to see resources cast aside on the ground yet did not hoard them for themselves; they hated to withhold their strength yet did not exert it for their own gain."

Thus, schemes were suppressed and not entertained, and theft, disorder, and harm did not arise. Therefore, outer doors were left unbolted—this was called the Great Unity.

Now that the Great Dao has receded, the world has become a domain of private households. Each cherishes only their own kin, each rears only their own children, and wealth and labor are claimed for oneself. Lords pass down their positions to their heirs as a matter of ritual propriety; walls, moats, and ramparts are built for defense. Ritual and righteousness serve as the guiding principles to rectify the relationship between ruler and subject, to deepen the bond between father and son, to harmonize brothers, to unite husband and wife, to establish systems and institutions, to organize fields and settlements, to reward the brave and wise, and to measure merit by personal gain. Hence, schemes arise from this, and warfare emerges thereby.

Yu, Tang, Wen, Wu, King Cheng, and the Duke of Zhou were all selected under these conditions—this is called the Lesser Peace.

It is recorded: "Why did the Master utter this sigh?"
"Standing at the center of the world, securing the people of the Four Seas—this is what the noble person desires, and thus he sighed."
"Why was Yan the one to whom he spoke?"
"Yan governs through ritual and music. When the governance of ritual and music is applied in full, it becomes the Great Unity; when applied in part, it becomes the Lesser Peace. The Great Unity regards all under heaven as one family, the central states as one person, and a thousand myriad generations as a single day. The Lesser Peace may be achieved in a year or perfected in three. If I were to serve the declining Zhou, it would suffice."
"Who but Yan is worthy of such discourse?"

Some have erred in doubting that these were not the Master’s own words. When Yan Yuan asked how to govern a state, the Master said: "Follow the Xia calendar, ride the Yin chariot, and wear the Zhou cap. For music, employ the *Shao* and *Wu* dances; banish the tunes of Zheng and keep flatterers at a distance. The music of Zheng is licentious, and flatterers are perilous."

It is recorded: The Master’s sigh for the practice of the Great Dao and the heroes of the Three Dynasties—was this merely recitation and longing? What he weighed in his heart and turned over in his thoughts were the unchanging great laws of a hundred kings and the enduring great Dao of a thousand ages. Thus, he later told Yuan: "When employed, act; when set aside, withdraw. Only you and I possess this." To be employed means, at its greatest, to become like Tang and Yu; at its next, to become like the Three Dynasties—not merely petty arrangements. This is the essence of mutual refinement among the disciples of Confucius, most vital to the realm and the state. Even ten thousand generations hence, it must not be regarded as empty rhetoric. Thus, he succeeded the Four Sages.

King Xuan commanded the Marquis of Fan, Zhongshan Fu, to build a city in Qi, and Yin Jifu composed a poem to send him off, saying:

"Heaven brought forth the teeming people,
Giving them things and giving them laws.
The people’s constant norms:
To love this fine virtue.
Heaven watches over the Zhou,
Its bright majesty descending below.
To protect this Son of Heaven,
It gave birth to Zhongshan Fu.

Zhongshan Fu’s virtue—
Gentle and excellent, the very model,
With fine bearing and gracious mien,
Ever cautious and reverent.
He takes ancient teachings as his pattern,
Exerts himself in dignified conduct.
He follows the Son of Heaven’s will,
Who entrusts him with the bright mandate to levy.

The king commands Zhongshan Fu,
To be the model for all the feudal lords.
He reveres the ancestors,
And guards the king’s own person.
Issuing and receiving the royal commands,
He is the king’s voice and tongue.
Administering governance abroad,
The four quarters all respond.
Solemn is the royal command,
And Zhongshan Fu carries it out.
Whether states fare well or ill,
Zhongshan Fu discerns it clearly.
Both enlightened and wise,
He preserves his own person.
Day and night without remiss,
He serves the One Man.

As the saying goes:
The soft, one swallows;
The hard, one spits out.
But Zhongshan Fu—
Soft, he does not swallow;
Hard, he does not spit out.
He does not bully the orphaned and widowed,
Nor fear the strong and overbearing.

Another saying:
Virtue’s wheel is light as a feather,
Yet few among the people can lift it—
I take it as my measure.
Though Zhongshan Fu lifts it,
None love to aid him.
If any office has a flaw,
Only Zhongshan Fu mends it.

Zhongshan Fu sets out on his journey,
His four steeds sturdy and strong,
The travelers swift and alert.
Ever mindful of what remains undone,
His four steeds gallop,
The eight bells ring clear.
The king commands Zhongshan Fu
To build a city in the east.
His four steeds prance,
The eight bells chime in order.
Zhongshan Fu completes his task in Qi,
And prepares to return.
Jifu composes this ode,
Gentle as a pure breeze.
Zhongshan Fu bears it in mind,
To comfort his heart.

Bao Gong served as minister, aiding Su Gong,
So Su Gong composed a poem to break with him, saying:

Who is that man?
His heart is most perverse.
Why does he pass my dam,
Yet not enter my gate?
Whom does he follow?
Only Bao, it is said.
The two travel together—
Who brought this misfortune?
Why does he roam my dam,
Yet not come to console me?
At first, he was not thus,
But now he finds me unacceptable.

Who is that man?
Why does he pass my line of sight?
I hear his voice,
But see not his form.
He feels no shame before others,
Nor awe before Heaven.

Who is that man?
He is like a whirlwind—
Why comes he not from the north,
Nor from the south?
Why does he pass my dam,
Only to trouble my heart?

If you walk at ease,
You have no time to rest.
If you rush in haste,
You have time to grease your wheels.
When you came before,
Why did you sigh so deeply?

If you return and enter,
My heart will be at ease.
If you return but do not enter,
It is hard to know your intent.
When you came before,
You made me anxious.

My elder brother plays the *xun*,
My younger brother plays the *chi*.
With you, I was as close as a string of coins—
Surely you do not know me.
Bring forth these three things,
And swear an oath against me.
Be it ghost or ant,
You shall not escape.
If you have a face and eyes,
And look upon others without limit..."

This fine song is made to express all restless longing.

Master Wang says: Bao Gong was disloyal to his lord and unrighteous toward his friend—what is called a grave offense. Thus Su Gong cut ties with him. Yet in cutting ties, he did not denounce Bao Gong directly, but only spoke of those who followed him; he did not expose their discord, but merely hinted at his suspicions. Even after severing the bond, he still explained how the other’s coming had made him anxious. For the noble man is loyal in his own conduct and forgiving in his dealings with others. If Bao Gong were to repent and return with goodwill, that would indeed be his wish. Though he might not do so, he would not go to extremes—how could he be like a petty man, who, once estranged, reviles and rejects, fearing only reconciliation?

It is recorded: Fan and Yin, Bao and Su—all were ministers of the royal court, yet their bond was that of friends. Their poems are like the clear wind, like the whirlwind. When the world follows the Dao, all cherish virtue and toil day and night without respite, as naturally as the sky is high and the sun bright, unaware of their own ease. When the world loses the Dao, ghosts and demons arise, and slander spreads like wildfire, as waves surge and winds scatter, unaware of their own strangeness. When these two winds blow, the Zhou way diverges. This is how poetry can inspire and reveal.

The *Comprehensive Mirror* states: The king sought to execute Du Bo without just cause. Du Bo’s friend Zuo Ru remonstrated nine times, but the king refused. The king said, “You side with your friend against your lord.” Zuo Ru replied, “If the lord’s way is right but the friend’s is wrong, I follow the lord to punish the friend. If the friend’s way is right but the lord’s is wrong, I follow the friend to oppose the lord.” The king grew angry: “Change your words and live; refuse, and die.” Zuo Ru said, “A scholar does not bend righteousness to follow death, nor alter his words to seek life. I can only make clear the lord’s error and prove Du Bo’s innocence.” The king executed Du Bo, and Zuo Ru died with him.

It is recorded: Though Du Bo’s case cannot be verified, Zuo Ru’s nine remonstrances show his steadfast loyalty to righteousness. Yet if one sides with a friend against the lord, the friendship is forsaken; if one follows the friend when the lord is wrong, the lord is opposed. Should one take the blame upon himself to spare another, or die in vain without benefit?

The *Zuozhuan* states: Shi Bo, Shi Hui, and Xun Linfu were all ministers of Jin. When Shi Bo was sent to Qin to summon Prince Yong, Xun Linfu stopped him, saying, “The crown prince still lives, yet you seek a lord from abroad—this will not succeed. Why not decline on grounds of illness? If not, you should take the acting minister with you.”

"Why must we share the same office to be colleagues before I dare not give my utmost? He would not listen, so I composed three stanzas of the *Ban* poem—still he would not listen. Later, when Zhao Dun turned against Shi Bo to enthrone Duke Ling, Shi Bo fled, and Xun Bo sent all his family and possessions—his goods, utensils, and wealth—to Qin, saying, ‘For the sake of our shared office.’

It is recorded: Xun Bo’s reasoning was sound. Yet why did he not speak in the royal court but instead privately conspire with Mi? When Shuai and Dun, father and son, held power, their hearts remained loyal to the Jin state. The debate over enthroning the elder prince was already grave, and their resolve to resist Qin was firm. Jia Ji once summoned Prince Le, only to have him killed. Was Jia Ji’s exile not precisely for this reason? In the sixth year, Jin’s Hu Shegu killed Yang Chufu and fled. Some claimed it was for encroaching on office, others for leaking secrets—neither was true.

Alas! Had they heeded the words of Kui and Guan, the disaster at Linghu might never have arisen. Repeated strife and calamities nearly brought Jin to ruin. As the saying goes: *‘You and I conspire together—heed my clamor’*—this was surely meant for Dun. How regrettable that none could speak to him!

When Xian Mi fled to Qin, Shi Hui followed. After three years in Qin, he still did not meet with him. Someone said, ‘He could drive a man from his state but cannot meet him here—what use is he?’ Shi Hui replied, ‘I share his guilt; I do not follow him out of righteousness. What is there to see?’ When he returned, he still did not meet him.

It is recorded: This is how Sui Hui returned to his state, and why Shi Bo left no descendants. As a chief minister of Jin, when he went to Qin, the crown prince was still alive. Yet he could not speak forthrightly to admonish and uphold the duty of selfless loyalty. When Xun Bo remonstrated, he failed to act with foresight to fulfill his duty as a colleague and friend. In both advance and retreat, he had no ground to stand on. Had Shi Hui been bound by petty scruples, unaware of self-preservation, shuttling back and forth in blind allegiance, he would have lost the way of steadfast integrity and could not have achieved a good end. Thus the *Yijing* says: *‘Before harm is felt.’* How profound its intent!

The *Records of the Grand Historian* states: Guan Yiwu and Bao Shuya were friends. In Guan’s youth, when he was poor, he traded for Bao Shu and took more than his share of the profits. Bao Shu did not think him greedy, knowing he was impoverished. When Guan devised plans for Bao Shu that led to great hardship, Bao Shu did not think him foolish, knowing that times have their fortunes and misfortunes. Thrice Guan entered office and thrice was expelled by his lord; Bao Shu did not think him unworthy, knowing he had not met his time. Thrice he fought and thrice he fled; Bao Shu did not think him cowardly, knowing he had an aged mother. When the cause of his lord, Prince Jiu, failed and Guan was imprisoned and humiliated, Bao Shu did not think him shameless, knowing he did not blush at small matters but only at his name not being renowned in the world. Thus Guan once said: ‘My parents gave me life, but Bao Shu knows me.’

Lian Xiangru returned the jade intact to Zhao, and the king made him chief minister, ranking above Lian Po. Po said, ‘When I see Xiangru, I will surely humiliate him.’ Hearing this, Xiangru often claimed illness to avoid court. If he caught sight of Po, he would turn his carriage aside to hide. His retainers thought it shameful. Xiangru said: ‘Compare the Lord of Lian to the King of Qin. With the King of Qin’s might, I once berated him in court and shamed his ministers. Though I am mediocre, would I fear the Lord of Lian alone? But I consider this: the reason mighty Qin does not dare attack Zhao is solely because the two of us remain. If two tigers fight, they cannot both survive. I act as I do to put the state’s crisis before private enmity.’ Hearing this, Lian Po stripped to the waist, carried thorns on his back, and came to Xiangru’s gate to apologize. They became friends who would die for each other.

It is recorded: Since the names of Guan and Bao, Kang and Lian became renowned, none through the ages have not admired their tale. Yet observe their reasoning: it lies in the realm of reckless passion, not in the beauty of Dao, virtue, benevolence, or righteousness. As the saying goes: *‘A king seeks a king, a hegemon seeks a hegemon’*—this is generally the case. Though the world declines and the Dao wanes, there have been men like Sun, Pang, Fan, Wei, Su, and Zhang who, though their ribs were broken and their feet severed, willingly gave their lives to seek vengeance. Their lords, failing to understand, amassed grudges and repaid favors with exacting precision. It is like children in a village alley, playing at familiarity, yet when repayment does not match the deed, they erupt in anger. If their parents are wise, they apologize for them; if not, they bring shame upon their neighborhood. Thus, the deeds of these four men—were they truly virtuous?

Lu Zhonglian delighted in bold and unconventional strategies. He refused office and official duties, roaming among the feudal lords with his lofty integrity. In the time of King Xiaocheng of Zhao, when Qin’s army besieged Handan, King Anxi of Wei sent General Jin Bi to rescue Zhao. Fearing Qin, he halted at Dangyin and did not advance. An envoy, Xin Yuan Yan, persuaded Zhao through Lord Pingyuan to jointly honor Qin as emperor and thus repel its army. Hearing this, Zhonglian went to see Yan and said: ‘That Qin is a state that discards ritual and righteousness to exalt beheading as merit. If it arrogantly proclaims itself emperor, then I would sooner tread the Eastern Sea to die than be its subject. Now Qin is a state of ten thousand chariots, and Liang is also a state of ten thousand chariots. If you follow it in calling it emperor, Qin will conduct the affairs of the Son of Heaven, issuing commands to the world. It will replace the ministers of the feudal lords, removing the unworthy and installing the worthy, removing the hated and installing the beloved. How could the King of Liang remain at ease?’ Yan rose and bowed twice, saying: ‘Only now do I know you, sir, as a true man of the world.’"

The court dared not again speak of making Qin emperor.

Lu's note says: Though Lu Lian’s refusal to allow Qin’s imperial claim was grand in intent, his argument was flawed. Why not say instead: "Heaven is noble, earth is base"? Zhou was the Son of Heaven; Qin, a feudal lord; and the other states, also feudal lords. To acknowledge Zhou’s supremacy and yet make Qin emperor would be to degrade the sun’s majesty, lowering it to the level of all things—how then could the people look up to its light? Lu Lian’s vow to tread the Eastern Sea and die was not only right in name but also proper in speech.

Some say: In the Warring States, men pursued profit and shunned harm. Had Lu Lian not acted for profit, how could Qin’s demands have been met? Had there been no harm, how could the feudal lords’ aid have arrived? This is not so. Qin had once declared itself emperor, only to abandon the title—such vacillation left it at a loss. Had it not feared the principle that "Heaven has no two suns, nor the people two kings," would it have retreated fifty *li*? Others say: Lu Lian’s arguments were inconsistent—was this the Grand Historian’s error? In essence, Zou and Lu were states that upheld ritual and righteousness, and Mencius was their purest exemplar. Lu Lian and the two scholars were largely pure, with only minor flaws.

Zhao Liang met with Shang Yang. Shang Yang asked: "In your view, how does my governance of Qin compare to that of the Five Sheepskin Duke?" Zhao Liang replied: "The compliance of a thousand men is not worth the frankness of one scholar. Permit me to speak plainly without fear of punishment—may I?" Shang Yang said: "Very well." Zhao Liang said: "The Five Sheepskin Duke was a rustic from Jing. Duke Mu raised him from among the cattle herders and placed him above the people, and none in Qin dared rival him. As minister, he served six or seven years, yet when he led an expedition against Zheng, he thrice enthroned a lord of Jin and once rescued Chu from disaster. In office, he toiled without riding in a carriage, and in the heat, he did not unfurl a canopy. When the Five Sheepskin Duke died, men and women of Qin wept, children ceased their songs, and pestle-wielders paused in their labor. But your governance, my lord, has trampled the ducal clans, harmed the common people, and forced Lord Qian to bar his gates for eight years. You have executed Zhu Guan and mutilated Gongsun Jia. As the *Book of Songs* says: 'Those who win the people thrive; those who lose them collapse.' These acts are no way to win the people. Your peril is like the morning dew, yet you still covet the wealth of Shang and Yu, cling to power in Qin, and store up the people’s resentment. The day the King of Qin discards you, even your retainers will not attend court. How trivial will be the means by which Qin destroys you!"

Shang Yang did not heed him. Five months later, disaster struck.

Lu's note says: Even with Shang Yang’s authority, he tolerated Zhao Liang’s admonition—was this not the remnant of his good conscience? Tigers and wolves are fierce, devouring men while howling; the virtue that desires life exists in all things, but it is overcome by desire. Did Shang Yang initially intend such cruelty? No—his heart was mastered by desire, and without such measures, he could not have moved Duke Xiao to seize immediate, great profit. Yet the peril to himself was clear. Even so, why punish plain speech? Alas, Zhao Liang’s counsel was incomplete. Shang Yang’s abolition of the well-field system and opening of the paths and furrows was a crime that reached to heaven, nearly extinguishing the laws of the former kings—who bears the greatest blame? Even if one plucked out all his hairs, they would not suffice to count his offenses. How could mere frankness address them? Yet Zhao Liang is not to be faulted. Su Qin, though called worthy, was torn apart by chariots as just retribution for his role in Qin’s destruction. Even so, could the laws of the former kings be set aside and ignored?

From the *Later Han Records*: Yan Guang, young and renowned, studied with Emperor Guangwu. When the latter ascended the throne, Yan changed his name and concealed himself. The emperor, valuing his worth, sought him out. The state of Qi reported: "A man, clad in sheepskin, fishes in the marshes." The emperor suspected it was Yan and sent envoys with a carriage draped in black and drawn by black horses to summon him. After three missions, Yan arrived and was lodged in the Northern Army camp, provided with cushions and mattresses, and served meals by the imperial kitchen. Minister of Education Hou Ba, an old acquaintance, sent a letter: "Hearing of your arrival, I wished to visit at once, but my duties prevent me. I will come at dusk to speak with you." Yan did not reply but handed the messenger a note: "Junfang, your position is lofty—excellent. Cherish benevolence, aid righteousness, and the world will rejoice. Flatter and obey, and your neck will be severed."

When Hou Ba presented the letter to the emperor, he laughed and said, "A mad fellow—still his old ways." The emperor then personally visited Yan’s lodging, but Yan did not rise to greet him. The emperor approached where Yan lay outside, patting his belly and saying, "Tut, Ziling, can you not assist me in governing?" Yan did not respond. After a long while, he opened his eyes and fixed his gaze, saying, "Of old, when Tang Yao displayed his virtue, Chaofu washed his ears. A scholar has his own aspirations—why must you press me so?" The emperor said, "Ziling, can I truly not have you?" Thereupon, he mounted his carriage, sighing as he departed. Later, he summoned Yan again to discuss the Dao and past affairs, and they sat facing each other for days. The emperor asked casually, "How do I compare to my former self?" Yan replied, "Your Majesty has improved somewhat." Then they lay down together, and Yan placed his feet upon the emperor’s belly. The next day, the Grand Historian reported: "A guest star has trespassed upon the imperial seat with great urgency." The emperor smiled and said, "It is only my old friend Yan Ziling lying beside me." He appointed Yan as Remonstrance Grandee, but Yan refused, choosing instead to farm on Mount Fuchun. Later generations named the place Yanling Shoals.

It is recorded: Observing Yan Guang, one sees five reasons he could not be retained, and the rank of the Three Dukes was not among them. Without studying Confucius, one cannot perceive the mean of benevolence and righteousness; without consulting Mencius, one cannot grasp the balance of withdrawal and engagement. Though Yan did not display extreme conduct, he spoke of being pressed beyond endurance—this shows he did not understand the righteousness of serving the feudal lords. Thus, he changed his name and fished in the marshes. If he truly wore sheepskin, he had his reasons—this is the first. When summoned as an old friend, he should have been treated as one; that would have been proper. When a grandee summons a forester, the forester dies rather than go—how then could an old friend be kept when summoned as a remonstrance official? This is the second. Duke Mu of Lu had no one by his side, yet he could not put Zisi at ease—what was Hou Ba to Yan? Note his words: "Flatter and obey, and your neck will be severed." This rebuke to his old friend was no different from cutting ties with a senior—how could he be retained? This is the third. "The noble change friends; the rich change wives"—even the emperor does not hesitate to speak thus, and few can long maintain respect. This is the fourth. Scholars like Fan Sheng, guest stars like the Grand Historian, or a solitary Xue Juzhou—could any truly assist in governance? This is the fifth. Had he been honored with the rank of the Three Dukes, he would have been but a name on the Cloud Terrace among the worthies of an age, while his fishing terrace stands towering for ten thousand generations. Does not the *Book of Changes* say, "The noble one, when the moment is near, does not act—better to let go"? This is what Yan Ziling meant.

Lian Fan and Qing Hong of Luoyang initially pledged brotherhood unto death, and people said, "Before them were Guan and Bao; after them, Qing and Lian." At the time, Deng Rong, Governor of Longxi, respectfully invited Fan to serve as his aide. Later, Rong was impeached by the province and imprisoned. Fan then changed his name and sought to take his place as the prison warden, attending him with utmost diligence. Later, when Fan was summoned to the imperial court, Xue Han was executed for treason. None of his old friends or disciples dared approach, but Fan alone gathered his remains. When the court officials reported this, Emperor Ming flew into a rage and summoned Fan, demanding, "Xue Han conspired with Chu to rebel. You, an official of the court, do not share the heart of the dynasty—why did you bury a criminal?" Fan kowtowed and said, "I am without merit. I thought only that Han and the others had already been executed, and I could not bear the sorrow of losing a teacher." The emperor’s anger gradually subsided. "Are you a descendant of Lian Po?" he asked. "Are you related to the Right General Ai or the Grand Marshal Dan?" Fan replied, "Pou was my great-grandfather; Dan, my grandfather." The emperor said, "No wonder your resolve is so bold." He then bestowed favors upon him, and Fan’s name became renowned. Living in the border regions, he amassed vast fields and wealth, all of which he distributed to relieve his clansmen and friends.

When Emperor Suzong passed away, Fan hastened to Jingling to mourn. At the same time, Yan Lin, an aide from Lujiang, was delivering a memorial of condolence but found his horse dead on the road, unable to proceed. Fan saw him and took pity, ordering his attendants to give him a horse without a word. Lin completed his duties but did not know to whom he owed his thanks. Someone told him, "The former Governor of Shu Commandery, Lian Shudu, is known for aiding those in need. Now that you are returning from mourning the emperor, he is the one." Lin led the horse to Fan’s door, and indeed, it was he. He expressed his gratitude and returned the horse.

The record states: Histories praise Kang Fan for establishing his reputation through heroic qi. Observing how he relieved those in peril and hastened to mourn at the emperor’s tomb, his actions were sufficiently bold, and they sufficed to inspire trust and move others. When Emperor Ming grew enraged, it served only to reveal Fan’s resolve—what began as an execution ended in extended favor. Such a turn is rarely heard of in ancient or modern times.

As for the matter of the five pestles, others might also have accomplished it, so it is not recorded here.

When Emperor Huan was still the Marquis of Liyu, he studied under Zhou Fu of Ganling. Upon ascending the throne, he promoted Fu to the position of Minister. At the time, Fang Zhi, the Prefect of Henan from the same commandery, was renowned at court. The local people composed a rhyme about them: *"The world’s compass and square is Fang Bowu; by serving as teacher, Zhou Zhongjin gained his seal."*

Later, Zong Zi, the Governor of Runan, entrusted his duties to his aide Fan Pang, while Cheng Jin, the Governor of Nanyang, similarly delegated to his aide, Cen Zhi. A rhyme spread: *"The Governor of Runan is Fan Mengbo; Nanyang’s Zong Zi merely nods in approval. The Governor of Nanyang is Cen Gongxiao; Hongnong’s Cheng Jin just sits and whistles."*

These rumors reached the Imperial Academy, where over thirty thousand students—with Guo Linzhong and Jia Weijie as their leaders—joined Li Ying, Chen Fan, and Wang Chang in mutual admiration. Within the academy, they declared: *"The world’s model is Li Yuanli; fearless against the powerful is Chen Bojun; the world’s finest talent is Wang Shumao."* They spoke boldly and debated deeply, never concealing their disdain for the mighty. From the highest ministers downward, none dared face their censure, and all came to their doors in humble submission.

The record states: Mencius spoke of Yi Yin and Guan Zhong, who studied before serving as ministers. If so, why should it be strange that one gains a seal by serving as a teacher? Since Han times, when Huan Rong delved into antiquity, the so-called learning from teachers amounted to nothing more than specialized mastery of texts and phrases, never offering enlightenment or nourishment to the mind. Yet when models and standards are attributed to others, gaining a seal through teaching is deemed unremarkable. Instead of reflecting on themselves, they mock and scheme against one another, each fostering their own factions. What does this signify?

For emperors and kings, nothing surpasses learning; in learning, nothing surpasses seeking teachers. To share a heart and virtue, to trust without doubt—this is what a noble ruler deeply cherishes. To promote learning and cultivate talent, even to the extent of thirty thousand students, is a rare blessing in later ages. Yet instead of becoming a cause for praise, it became a source of division. This is because Emperor Guangwu rose through eloquence, and thus his dynasty also declined through words.

As for the rhymes, though they arose by chance, were they not perhaps the work of unseen forces? At the time, the realm’s eminent scholars were given titles: first, the Three Exemplars; then the Eight Heroes; then the Eight Guides; then the Eight Followers; and finally, the Eight Almoners—echoing the ancient Eight Yuan and Eight Kai.

The Three Exemplars were Dou Wu, Liu Shu, and Chen Fan. *Exemplars* signify those whom an age reveres. The Eight Heroes were Li Ying, Xun Yu, Du Mi, Wang Chang, Liu You, Wei Lang, Zhao Dian, and Zhu Yu. *Heroes* signify the finest of men. The Eight Guides were Guo Linzhong, Zong Ci, Ba Xiao, Xia Fu, Fan Pang, Yin Xun, Cai Yan, and Yang Lu. *Guides* signify those who lead others through virtue. The Eight Followers were Zhang Jian, Cen Shui, Liu Biao, Chen Xiang, Kong Yu, Fan Kang, Tan Fu, and Zhai Chao. *Followers* signify those who guide others to emulate their forebears. The Eight Almoners were Du Shang, Zhang Miao, Wang Kao, Liu Ru, Hu Mu Ban, Qin Zhou, Fan Xiang, and Wang Zhang. *Almoners* signify those who rescue others with their wealth.

The record states: The Eight Yuan and Eight Kai held lofty positions and noble ways, while the Guides, Almoners, Followers, and the like saw their positions reviled and their ways abandoned. Why such a vast disparity? In the Three Dynasties and before, governance flowed from one source, and worthiness was put to use. In the late ages, governance split in two, and talent became a cause for envy.

*The Rites of Zhou* states that the Grand Steward instructs the king with eight principles to govern his ministers. How could governance be divided? If one grants while another seizes, one degrades while another promotes, one spares life while another kills—even Yao and Shun could not endure a single day of this, let alone the reigns of Emperors Huan and Ling.

Schools are the wellspring of ritual and righteousness, not the domain of coercive authority. Confucius’s disciples recorded the virtues of Yan Yuan and nine others, categorizing their strengths into four disciplines. At the time, this was not seen as strange, nor did later ages find it objectionable—never did it invite disaster. If one does not hold office, one does not meddle in its affairs. If they had merely upheld ritual, righteousness, prosperity, and shame to sustain one another, then how could the names of Guides, Almoners, and Followers be deemed insignificant? How could they be deemed insignificant?

Li Ying was austere and unyielding, forming few connections. He regarded only his fellow commandery men, Xun Shu and Chen Huang, as teachers and friends. When Xun Shuang once visited him, Ying personally drove his carriage. Upon returning, Shuang rejoiced, saying, *"Today I have been driven by Lord Li!"* Such was the admiration he inspired.

At the time, Zhang Rang’s younger brother, Shuo, served as Magistrate of Yewang. Greedy and cruel, he even murdered pregnant women. Hearing of Ying’s stern authority, he feared punishment and fled back to the capital, hiding in Rang’s residence within a hollow pillar. Ying, learning of this, led his officers to break open the pillar, seize Shuo, and deliver him to the Luoyang prison. After recording his confession, Ying executed him immediately.

Rang appealed to the emperor, who summoned Ying to question why he had not sought permission before carrying out the execution. Ying replied, *"In the past, when Confucius served as Minister of Justice in Lu, he executed Shaozheng Mao within seven days. I have now held office for over ten days, and I privately feared that delay would be my fault. I did not expect to be charged with haste."* The emperor turned to Rang and said, *"This is your brother’s crime. What fault lies with the Chief of the Secretariat?"* He then dismissed Ying.

From then on, all the eunuchs of the Yellow Gates bowed in deference and held their breath, not daring to leave the palace even on their days of rest. The emperor, finding this strange, questioned them. They knelt, weeping, and replied, *"We fear the Chief of the Secretariat, Li."*

At this time, the court grew daily more disordered, its laws and disciplines collapsing into decay. Yet Ying alone upheld his moral authority, elevating himself through his reputation. Scholars fortunate enough to be received by him were said to have "ascended the Dragon Gate."

**Commentary:** Observing Ying’s shattering of pillars to bring a case to justice, his forthright words before the imperial throne—even now, his presence remains awe-inspiring, as if alive. How could those petty, lowly men not tremble and hold their breath in fear? Yet one must ask: *"Only the ruler may bestow blessings; only the ruler may wield authority."* The power of reward and punishment flows from above to below. If I seize it, the authority I wield is the authority of all under Heaven, and the blessings I grant are the blessings of all under Heaven—disseminated from the court to the realm, who could say otherwise? At that time, the emperor’s virtue failed to uphold order, and the eunuchs’ corruption followed the same path. Yet Ying alone maintained his dignity, his decisions on appointments, dismissals, and punishments bearing no relation to the court’s will. Thus, the power of reward and punishment originated from himself, no longer flowing from above to below. This allowed petty men to point fingers and fabricate accusations, mutually promoting one another, their lips and teeth intertwined. Those who did not align with them were met with ostracism. Alas! Were those who did not conform upright or wicked? Were those who were promoted and elevated right or wrong? If their wickedness went unnoticed by the emperor, and my righteousness found no recognition above, then the upright were deemed wicked, and the wicked were able to harm the upright. In such a situation, could one sit idly and fail to intervene?

The *Hexagram Pi*’s nine in the fourth place states: *"There is a command; no blame. Those who share in the blessing will be blessed."* The *Image* says: *"There is a command; no blame. The will is carried out."* Thus, a noble man would rather speak forthrightly to condemn traitors and punish rebels than arrogate to himself the power of execution, thereby distorting his peers and bringing calamity upon the good.

Fan Pang, from his youth, cultivated purity and integrity, earning the respect of his home province. He was recommended as a Filial and Incorrupt Candidate and selected for the Four Virtues of the Office of the Grand Master of Ceremonies. At the time, famine struck Ji Province, and bandits arose in swarms. Pang was appointed as an Imperial Inspector to investigate. As he mounted his carriage and took up the reins, his resolve was firm: he would purify the realm. Upon reaching the province, local officials, knowing their own corruption, fled at the mere rumor of his arrival, abandoning their seals and sashes. None of those he impeached failed to satisfy public opinion.

When the Party Proscriptions began, Emperor Huan sent the Palace Attendant Wang Fu to interrogate the accused in order. When it came to Pang’s turn, he declared: *"I have heard the words of Confucius: 'On seeing goodness, one should feel as though one cannot attain it; on seeing evil, one should recoil as though scalded by boiling water.' I sought to ensure that the good shared in purity and the wicked shared in filth—words I believed would please the governance of a king. I never imagined they would be deemed factionalism. In ancient times, following goodness brought abundant blessings; today, following goodness leads to execution. When I die, I hope to be buried beside Mount Shouyang, so that above, I do not betray Heaven, and below, I do not shame Boyi and Shuqi."* Wang Fu, moved, altered his expression in sympathy.

**Commentary:** Observing Mengbo’s response, I cannot help but weep. Yu once said: *"The people of Yao and Shun made the hearts of Yao and Shun their own."* In that era, the Nine Ministers and Twelve Governors, modest and yielding, filled the court. All under Heaven unanimously deemed them pure. The crimes of the Four Fiends were met with exile and execution, with no leniency—all under Heaven unanimously deemed them filthy. If goodness were not pure, what value would it hold? If wickedness were not filthy, what disgrace would it bring? Even in the Spring and Autumn period, though human hearts were no longer as in ancient times, the destruction of the Three Capitals and the execution of Shaozheng Mao were pursued without reservation. Thus, it was said: *"On seeing goodness, one should feel as though one cannot attain it; on seeing evil, one should recoil as though scalded by boiling water."* Such was the people of the Three Dynasties, who walked the straight path. Alas! What misfortune to be born in Mengbo’s time! Before long, external invasions and internal strife followed in succession, disasters and misfortunes piled up, and the state teetered on the brink of ruin. Was this Heaven’s decree of doom? Or was it the fault of those who brought chaos? The bitter suffering inflicted upon the people cannot be undone.

*Hongdao Lu*, Volume 25, concludes.
*Hongdao Lu*, Volume 26. By imperial decree, printed and distributed on the fifteenth day of the second month in the thirty-fifth year of the Wanli reign of the Great Ming. Collated by Zhang Guoxiang, Perpetual Successor of the Orthodox Unity Teachings and Grand Realized Man.

**On the Righteousness of Friendship**

From the *Book of Jin*: Wang Pou, though poor, tilled the land himself. When his students offered to harvest his wheat, he refused to the point of abandoning the crop. Gifts from old acquaintances were all declined. Once, a disciple was conscripted for labor by the county. He came to Wang Pou, seeking a favor to intercede, but Wang Pou said: “Your learning is not enough to shield yourself, and my virtue is too meager to shelter you. What good would intercession do? Besides, I have not held a brush in forty years.” Instead, he walked alongside the student, carrying dried rice, while his son shouldered salt and fermented beans. They accompanied the disciple to the county seat on foot.

The magistrate of Anqiu, mistaking Wang Pou’s arrival for a visit to himself, straightened his robes and came out to greet him. When Wang Pou arrived, he bowed deeply and said: “My disciple has been conscripted by the county, so I have come to see him off.” Taking the student’s hand, he wept and departed. The magistrate immediately released the disciple, and the entire county regarded the incident as a disgrace.

A townsman named Guan Yan was young and talented but not yet renowned. Wang Pou alone believed he would surely rise to prominence and singled him out as a friend. Li Chun of Beihai, though young, had set his resolve and lived in austere poverty. Carrying his books, he traveled to study, and the people of his village compared him to the reemergence of Li Yuan. Wang Pou, however, saw that Li Chun’s nature was treacherous and narrow, coveting fame, and predicted he would never succeed. Later, Li Chun indeed proved unprincipled, leaving his studies unfinished. Those with discernment attributed this judgment to Wang Pou’s insight.

The record states: His refusal to accept his disciple’s plea stemmed from his initial rejection of the harvested wheat. His disregard for the Anqiu magistrate originated from his refusal to face west in a seat of honor. Otherwise, had he shown no concern for forced labor, others would have called him impractical; had he not responded to the magistrate’s formal greeting, they would have deemed him discourteous.

Though these were men renowned for their integrity and conduct, they personally undertook tasks as humble as carrying meals and bearing straw. Thus, when it is said he did not entrust, was this not in truth the deepest form of entrustment?

*The Old Book of Tang* records: When Prince Qin, Li Shimin, had pacified the realm within the seas, his ardor for classical learning and governance burned bright. He established a literary academy west of the palace, inviting scholars from all quarters to instruct and guide. There, Du Ruhui, Fang Xuanling, Yu Shinan, Chu Liang, Yao Silian, Li Daoyuan, Cai Yungong, Xue Yuanjing, Yan Xiangshi, Su Zui, Yu Zhining, Su Shichang, Xue Shou, Li Shousu, Lu Deming, Kong Yingda, Gai Wenda, and Xu Jingzong—eighteen men in all—served concurrently as academicians of the literary academy. They were divided into three shifts, taking turns to stay overnight, seizing moments between court audiences to discuss the classics and literary works, deliberating on state affairs, often until the dead of night. The emperor ordered Yan Liben to paint their portraits, and Chu Liang composed eulogies, naming them the "Eighteen Scholars." Those among the scholar-officials who were selected for this honor were said by their contemporaries to have "ascended Yingzhou." The record states: In Mencius’ time, Tao Ying asked, "If Shun were emperor and Gaoyao were judge, and Shun’s father, Gusou, committed murder, what would be done?" Wan Zhang also asked, "Xiang made killing Shun his daily occupation, yet when Shun became emperor, he enfeoffed him. Was this not done for a reason?" To prepare in advance and lodge overnight—what difficulty could there be in this? Yet with the entire realm of Tang being the achievement of Taizong, to expect him to act like Shun and refuse such measures would have been truly difficult. Alas, though many worthy men advanced together, not one among them matched the depth of Tao Ying or Wan Zhang. What they discussed in their leisure hours, what they debated until the small hours, were nothing but the snares and traps of wealth and rank, or the savory morsels of fame and merit. From this, we know that the daily conduct of great sages and worthies, and their response to the gravest shifts in human relations, is not a matter of chance but has long been firmly established. The difficulty of preparing in advance and lodging overnight was not due to impractical sentimentality but was grounded in solid, verifiable principles. How could the selection of Yingzhou scholars ever compare?

After ascending the throne, Taizong further established the Hongwen Academy, amassing over two hundred thousand volumes from the Four Categories of books. He selected the realm’s finest scholars—Yu Shinan, Chu Liang, Yao Silian, Ouyang Xun, Cai Yungong, and Xiao Deyan—appointing them as academicians while retaining their original posts. They took turns staying overnight, and during breaks in court audiences, were summoned to the inner palace to discuss the words and deeds of the ancients, deliberate on governance, examine past and present, and explore the reasons for success and failure. From dawn to dusk, they never rested for a moment. He also chose the sons and grandsons of officials of the third rank and above to serve as students of the Hongwen Academy.

The record states: When Tang conquered Xia, it cultivated civil virtue—its sagely reverence and solemnity were daily refined—yet we never hear of it establishing a Hongwen Academy. When Zhou conquered Yin, it spread civil teachings—its ethical norms were well-ordered—yet we never hear of it amassing the books of the Four Treasuries. Tang, in its rising fortune, had a ruler of surpassing talent. Had he devoted himself to sagely reverence and striven to uphold ethical norms, rather than pursuing mere oral and auditory learning, would the governance of the Zhenguan era have been merely as it was? Generally, the learning of emperors differs from that of classical scholars. Ostentation and wastefulness are the learning of classical scholars; preserving the essential and applying it broadly is the learning of emperors. Thus, these two principles are more than sufficient—what need had he for over two hundred thousand volumes?

Li Bi of Jingzhao, renowned from childhood for his talent and quick wit, was befriended by Emperor Xuanzong as an equal of the crown prince. The prince once addressed him as "Master." Later, Li Bi withdrew to live in seclusion in Yingyang. When Emperor Suzong ascended the throne, he dispatched envoys to summon him, and Li Bi presented himself at Lingwu. The emperor rejoiced greatly, riding alongside him when they went out and sharing his couch when they slept, just as in the days when he was crown prince. Matters great and small were all consulted with him, and his advice was invariably followed. Even the appointment and dismissal of generals and ministers were discussed with him. Several times, the emperor wished to appoint him as chancellor, but Li Bi firmly declined, saying, "If Your Majesty treats me as a guest and friend, I am more honored than if I were chancellor. Why should I force myself to accept?" The emperor relented.

The record states: Could Suzong not have treated Li Bi as a guest and friend? After the affair of Consort Zhang, he exonerated Prince Jianning of false charges, urged proper rites for the retired emperor, and proposed honors for meritorious ministers—his guidance and mutual refinement were truly exemplary. Had Li Bi arrived earlier, before the emperor’s accession, the scale and vision of his governance would surely not have been so hasty and crude. Alas, the emperor’s heart was not yet pure, his trust not yet steadfast. Soon after Li Bi’s return from Mount Heng, he was sent out as an observer—despite his worthiness, he ultimately could not escape later criticism. This is why, at the juncture of merit and fame, one must maintain a heart free of desire and content with itself.

When Di Renjie was a staff officer in the same prefecture as Zheng Chongzhi, Zheng’s mother was elderly and ill. Zheng was to be sent on a mission to a distant land, and Di Renjie said to him, "How can you leave your parent to bear a ten-thousand-mile sorrow?" He went to the chief administrator, Lan Renji, and offered to go in Zheng’s place. Lan Renji praised his righteousness. At the time, Lan Renji was at odds with the military administrator Li Xiaolian, but upon hearing this, they said to each other, "We should feel some shame." From then on, they treated each other as before. Di Renjie often said, "The worthiness of Lord Di is unmatched south of the Northern Dipper."

The record states: This is like the case of exchanging Liu for Liu—it is not recorded. Why record this? Zheng’s mission was unavoidable, whereas Liu’s demotion could have been avoided. Compared to the "Eight Masters" of the Yuanhe era and after, the man "south of the Northern Dipper" was indeed of a different order. This is what sets him apart.

Han Yu’s *Disquisition on the Duty of a Remonstrating Minister* asks: "Can Yang Cheng, the remonstrating minister, be considered a man of the Dao? His learning is vast and his knowledge broad; he does not seek fame among men. He practices the Way of the ancients, dwelling in the remote regions of Jin. People are drawn to his virtue, and high ministers, hearing of him, recommend him to the emperor, who appoints him remonstrating minister. Five years have passed."

He had held office for no short time, was thoroughly familiar with the successes and failures of the realm, and was treated with no small favor by the emperor—yet he had never once spoken on matters of governance. When asked about his post, he would say, "I am a remonstrating minister"; when asked about his duties, he would reply, "I know nothing of them." Could a man of the Dao truly be like this?

I have heard that those who hold office must resign if they cannot fulfill their duties, and those charged with offering counsel must resign if they cannot speak their minds. Does Yang now believe he has spoken his mind? I do not criticize him for being forthright and imposing his views on others. Only a virtuous man can accept forthright admonition—meaning he can hear it and reform accordingly.

When Pei Yanling falsely accused and drove out Lu Zhan and others, the emperor was enraged, and none dared speak. Yang then stood at the Yan Ying Pavilion and submitted a memorial, speaking with vehement indignation, citing principle for days on end. Those who heard him trembled with fear, yet Yang’s voice and expression grew only more severe. The emperor flew into a rage and ordered Yang’s punishment, but the crown prince interceded, and he was spared. Still, the emperor intended to appoint Yanling as chief minister. Yang declared, "If Yanling becomes chief minister, I will tear up the imperial edict with my own hands." It was due to Yang’s efforts that the emperor did not appoint Yanling.

It is recorded: Han Yu’s forthright speech was not mere bluntness. Friends have a duty to admonish one another for their good, and mutual discourse brings the benefit of exchange. Though others dared not speak, Han Yu did. As the *Book of Changes* says, *"A steadfast illness brings joy."* This was Han Yu’s intent—something others could not fathom.

Yang’s silence was not truly silence. Only when the harm to the court and the loss to the ruler’s virtue were so grave that no one in the world dared speak did he finally speak. As the *Book of Changes* says, *"Tying up the sack incurs no blame."* This was Yang’s intent—something others could not perceive.

Of all matters under heaven, what could be greater than appointing a chief minister? When Lu Qi brought the state to the brink of ruin, nearly toppling it, and Yanling was about to repeat his folly, it was Yang alone who prevented it. His merit extended far beyond a single man’s fate or a single matter’s resolution. Had he submitted memorials morning and night upon taking office, not only would the meaning of loyal admonition have been obscured, but the beauty of his restrained virtue would never have come to fruition. This was Ouyang’s judgment—I find no fault with it.

Xiao Yingshi and Li Hua were friends of the same examination year. At the beginning of the Tianbao era, Yingshi was appointed Secretariat Drafter, while Hua served as Surveillance Censor and gained contemporary renown. The chief minister, Li Linfu, wished to meet them, but Yingshi, observing mourning for his father, refused to call on him. Linfu went to the home of an old friend to summon him, but Yingshi retreated inside and wept at the gate, waiting. Linfu had no choice but to offer condolences before leaving, furious at Yingshi’s refusal to humble himself. After the mourning period, Yingshi was assigned as a military aide in Guangling. Pei Yaoqing, Zhang Jun, and Wei Shu—all senior officials—esteemed his talent and conduct, often recommending him as their successor. He was summoned to the Historiography Institute, but Linfu, who then wielded unchecked power, refused to yield, and Yingshi was dismissed from office.

When An Lushan grew arrogant and overbearing, Yingshi secretly told Liu Bing, "Disorder will not be long in coming." Feigning illness, he traveled to Mount Taishi and thus escaped the calamity. Throughout his life, he delighted in hearing of others’ virtues and took it upon himself to promote the next generation. Dozens of men—such as Li Yang, Li Youqing, Huangfu Ran, and Lu Wei—rose to prominence through his praise and became renowned scholars. The world acknowledged his ability to recognize talent.

He was also close friends with Yin Yin, Yan Zhenqing, Liu Fang, Lu Ju, Shao Han, and Zhao Yi. At the time, people said, "Yin, Yan, Liu, Lu, Li, Xiao, Shao, and Zhao—all maintained their friendships with integrity."
