Li Hua was carefree in his youth, appearing open and unconstrained, yet inwardly cautious and respectful. He admired honesty and often emulated Ji Dan’s character. When Yang Guozhong’s nephews ran amok in the provinces, Hua impeached and investigated them without yielding, bringing order to the prefectures and counties. His literary style was refined and elegant, though lacking in grandeur and vigor. Yingshi was bold and unrestrained, and contemporaries often said Hua fell short of him, though Hua himself claimed superiority.

When Hua wrote the *Fu on the Hall of Abundant Blessings*, Yingshi remarked, "Above the *Jingfu*, below the *Lingguang*." Later, when Hua composed the *Lament for the Ancient Battlefield*, he exhausted his thoughts and revisions, then discarded the draft, mixing it among the covers of Buddhist scriptures. Some time later, Yingshi read it and praised its craftsmanship, asking who could match it. Hua replied, "With a little more refinement, you could reach this level." Yingshi was astonished and conceded.

His clansman Shao Han was also known as a successful examination candidate. Living in Yangdi, he wrote with precision and labored over his thoughts to the point of exhaustion. He often sought music from the magistrate Huangfu Zeng; whenever his thoughts ran dry, he would listen to music, and when his spirit was at ease, he would write. During An Lushan’s rebellion, his friend Zhang Xun defended Suiyang. When rumors spread that Zhang had surrendered to the rebels, Han, who had witnessed the city’s defense firsthand, wrote a biography and presented it to Emperor Suzong, clarifying Zhang’s loyalty. Scholars and friends praised him for this.

It is recorded: The world speaks of Xiao and Li as equals, but their excellence was not merely in talent and literature. Consider Xiao’s refusal to submit to Linfu, Li’s enmity with Yang Guozhong, and Han’s tireless memorials exposing Zhang Xun and Xu Yuan’s loyalty—they were paragons of integrity. In particular, Li’s *Lament for the Ancient Battlefield* survives to this day, and later generations with discernment can judge it for themselves. Yet he hid it among Buddhist scriptures to seek fame—how narrow was his vision!

The *History of the Song Dynasty* records: Zhang Zhongding and Kou Zhongmin were friends in their commoner days. Kou treated Zhang as an elder brother, often reproaching him to his face without mercy, never altering his manner despite Kou’s later rise to power. When Kou became chief minister, Zhang was then serving as military commissioner of Chengdu. He told his subordinates, "Minister Kou is a man of extraordinary talent, but his learning is somewhat lacking."

Later, when Zhang was transferred to Shanzhou, Kou, who had just returned from Chengdu, prepared an elaborate reception. As they parted at the outskirts, Kou asked, "What advice do you have for me?" Zhang slowly replied, "You must read the *Biography of Huo Guang*."

Kou Zhun did not grasp his meaning. Upon returning home, he took up *The Biography of Huo Guang* and read it. When he came to the line *"lacking learning and skill,"* he laughed and said, "This is what Director Zhang meant for me."

The compiler notes: Yong’s mockery of Kou for his lack of learning—what insight did it truly reveal? Confucius said: *"Even one with the talent and beauty of the Duke of Zhou, if arrogant and stingy, is not worth observing."* Yet Kou, though desiring others to cherish kindness toward him, was not impartial in his disregard for others. Brushing off a man’s beard in rebuke, he sorely lacked the capacity to tolerate others. At court, he flaunted his own merits; abroad, he boasted of his reputation. Where merit and fame lay, he was stirred to emotion—how could he not align with Sun Shuang’s judgment? Moreover, he curried favor with Zhu Neng’s schemes, allowing his disciples to criticize him and his friends to lament for him. That slander arose against him was hardly surprising. Had he read books to clarify principles and found contentment in self-cultivation, would his life’s deeds have culminated in the debacle of Chanyuan? After achieving success, had he withdrawn and left right and wrong unheard, the public judgment of later ages would have been no different. Yet though he could move withered bamboo in Leiyang, he could not illuminate the neglected classics of the past.

Tang Jie served as censor during the reign of Emperor Renzong. At the time, Consort Zhang’s favor eclipsed that of the empress, and her uncle, Zhang Yaozuo, was swiftly appointed to four prestigious posts: Military Commissioner of Xuanhui, and Director of the Jingling and Imperial Pastures. Tang vehemently opposed these appointments. The emperor said, *"The nominations originated from the Chancellery."* At the time, Wen Yanbo was chief minister, so Tang impeached him as well. Enraged, the emperor said, *"It is Tang Jie’s duty to discuss matters of state. But to claim that Yanbo rose to the rank of chief minister through the influence of the imperial consorts—what kind of speech is this?"* Tang was demoted to vice-prefect of Yingzhou, and Wen was removed to serve as prefect of Xuzhou. Court officials composed poems to see him off, but only Li Shizhong’s *Daizhi* composition gained wide circulation. It read:

*"A lone loyalist, self-assured, yet none stand with him,
He stands alone, daring to speak what others dare not.
Exiled from court, his body light as a leaf,
Yet his lofty name weighs heavy as a mountain through the ages.
Though he walks among the worthy, his face remains unflushed,
Before his death, the flatterers’ bones already chill.
Heaven aids our sovereign to uphold the state—
Would it let such a man never return?"*

Thus his reputation for integrity resounded throughout the realm, and when people spoke of a true censor, they invariably said, *"Tang Zifang."*

The compiler notes: Observing Zhang Liang’s deeds and Li Shizhong’s poem, we see not only a resounding reputation for integrity but also the emperor’s benevolent virtue, passed down to later generations, and the admirable righteousness of great ministers, worthy of emulation by scholar-officials. Thereafter, however, grievances like those of the carriage canopy and slanders like the *Dianlong* affair arose in succession, leading to lifelong strife. Once set upon this path, he never turned back, and the bonds of friendship, the virtue of ruler and minister, and the magnanimity of great officials were all lost.

Ouyang Xiu’s *On Factions* states in brief: *"The noble form factions through shared Dao; the petty form factions through shared profit. The petty have no true factions, for only the noble possess them. The petty covet rank and wealth, greedily pursuing material gain. When their interests align, they temporarily band together, feigning friendship. But when profit is at stake, they vie for advantage, or when gain is exhausted, they turn to mutual harm—even brothers and kin cannot be trusted. Thus it is said: the petty have no factions. The noble are not so. They uphold the Dao and justice, act with loyalty and trust, and cherish their reputation and integrity. In cultivating themselves, they benefit one another through shared Dao; in serving the state, they cooperate with a common heart, steadfast to the end. Thus it is said: only the noble have true factions. Though the noble’s factions may be many, they are never resented. Therefore, if a ruler merely dismisses the false factions of the petty and employs the true factions of the noble, the realm will be well-governed."*

The compiler notes: Ouyang’s discourse, though spanning hundreds of words, ultimately revolves around the distinction between *zhoubi* (cliques) and *hetong* (harmony). Mencius further expounded on the contrast between goodness and profit, saying: *"Those who rise at the cry of the quail and toil diligently for goodness are followers of Shun. Those who rise at the cry of the quail and toil diligently for profit are followers of Robber Zhi."* Though both are of the same kind, if a ruler delves deeply into the learning of sages and clearly discerns the difference between righteousness and profit, the distinction between noble and petty will become self-evident without need for comparison.

Emperor Renzong possessed a naturally pure and fine disposition, yet he lacked learning to guide him. Thus, he could not distinguish between right and wrong. During the Qingli and Jiayou eras, though noble men filled the court, petty men advanced in turn, preventing the governance from being purely harmonious and free of treacherous ministers like Gongdou, thus failing to achieve an era of grand harmony. After one or two successions, under Emperor Shenzong, cliques like those of Wang Anshi, Cai Que, Lü Huiqing, and others indulged in factionalism and scheming, toiling for profit—leading to great chaos. Is this discourse not as luminous as divination by tortoiseshell, a mirror of clarity for all ages?

Sima Guang and Fan Zhen were of one mind and close friends, delighting in each other’s company. During the Xining and Yuanfeng eras, when scholar-officials discussed the worthies of the realm, they invariably said, *"Junshi and Jingren."* Their moral character and refinement served as models for the age, and their judgments of right and wrong could bring honor or disgrace to the world—all acknowledged their superiority. Sima once said, *"You and I share the same aspirations in life; in death, we shall share the same biography."* No one dared to rank one above the other. Having made this pact, the survivor would later compose the other’s epitaph. Thus, Sima wrote *The Biography of Jingren*, stating: *"Lü Xianke’s foresight and Fan Jingren’s courageous resolve—these are qualities I do not possess."* For in matters of great integrity, whether employed or dismissed, the two acted in unison without prior consultation. Whether debating the establishment of an heir during Renzong’s reign, the *Pu* debate during Yingzong’s reign, or the New Policies during Shenzong’s reign, their words seemed as though spoken by one man. Sima also once remarked, *"Jingren and I are brothers—we merely have different surnames."*

When it came to debating the tuning of bells and pitch-pipes, however, they would argue back and forth, never reaching agreement in their lifetimes. Thus did the noble man come to know that the two were not merely pretending to consensus.

The record states: I observe that the single word *sincerity* determines a person’s fortune or misfortune, advancement or retreat, survival or demise. During the reigns of Xining and Yuanfeng, right and wrong in the realm were utterly confounded. Yet a hundred generations later, when men speak of Junshi and Jingren, their words distinguish black from white as clearly as if they were present—this is the power of sincerity. Where there is sincerity, there is no falsehood; action becomes vigorous and firm, centered and responsive. How could such harmony require prior consultation? Those so-called Dharma-transmitting monks and Dharma-protecting deities lack sincerity. Without sincerity, they are deluded and deviant, contrary to human reason and unsupported by the Dao of Heaven. How could they meet a good end? Thus, one pair shared the same biography in life and the same epitaph in death, and the people praise them to this day; the other pair, though their faces seemed alike, both perished on the same day, and the people have nothing to say of them.

Consider Zou Hao, Tian Di, and Tian Zhou, whose discussions were impassioned and whose integrity spurred one another on. Hao once impeached Zhang Dun for disloyalty and contempt toward the emperor, but before the verdict was returned, Liu the empress was enthroned. Zhou remarked to others, *"If Zhiwan had remained silent, I would have severed ties with him."* Later, when the matter was revisited, Dun was convicted and exiled to Xinzhou. After Hao was demoted, Zhou met him on the road. Hao wept upon seeing him, but Zhou said sternly, *"Had Zhiwan kept silent and remained in the capital, he would have died within five days from a chill that refused to sweat. Is it only beyond the mountains and seas that men can die? Do not take pride in this act—what a scholar ought to do does not end here."*

The record states: Zhou’s words are those of a man of insight. Let the noble man hold them in his heart, and then success or failure, advantage or disadvantage, life or death, honor or disgrace will not trouble his mind. Yet this is not what he desires. Beneath the vast sky, all things flourish in brightness—how could he deliberately imitate the chirp of fleas or the hum of mosquitoes? When circumstances compel it and the earthly Dao loses its tranquility, the noble man weighs only the gravity of ethical principles and the depth of the Way’s discourse, acting without ulterior motive. In the two reigns of Zhenzhe, both honored Empress Liu, yet Empress Mingsu met a proper end, while Chong’en perished by her own hand. Zhiwan’s integrity is now complete. Thus, though he died, he is not truly dead—how much less so for one who never dies? Even if Renzong had deposed Guo and enthroned Cao, it would have been the better choice, yet one cannot equate that time with this.

Master Hu Yuan of Anding lamented that since the Sui and Tang dynasties, official advancement had prized literary skill while neglecting classical learning, leading men to chase salaries with no higher aim. When he became professor of Suzhou and Huzhou, he established strict regulations and led by example. Even in the height of summer, he wore his official robes all day to meet his students, upholding the decorum between teacher and disciple. When explaining the classics, he would earnestly expound on key principles, teaching students first how to cultivate themselves before governing others. His disciples numbered in the thousands, and though they polished their writings daily, all transmitted the meaning of the classics, ensuring that reason prevailed. They trusted their teacher’s teachings and emphasized practical conduct. Later, when he became head of the Imperial Academy, scholars from all directions flocked to him, filling the school’s halls to capacity.

In Huzhou, he established the *Classic Meaning Hall* and the *Practical Affairs Hall*. The *Classic Meaning Hall* was for those of broad understanding and sound judgment. In the *Practical Affairs Hall*, each student managed one primary task and one secondary task, such as governing the people, military affairs, water conservancy, or accounting. The same system was implemented in the Imperial Academy. His disciples scattered across the land, and regardless of their intelligence, all conducted themselves with refined discipline. In their speech, demeanor, and bearing, one could recognize them as the master’s students without asking; when they spoke of their teacher, one could identify him as Master Hu without inquiry.

The record states: In recording Master Anding, we see that the teachings of the Luo River masters had not yet spread widely, while the educational methods of Suzhou and Huzhou came first. Without weariness in teaching or fatigue in learning, he combined the study of fundamental principles with practical application. In that era, the people were flourishing, the nation’s fortunes were ascendant, customs were pure, and virtue and achievement were profound—none of this occurred without the guidance of wise teachers and worthy mentors.

The two Cheng masters never wearied of instructing others, so their disciples were the most numerous. Those influenced by their teachings all became eminent scholars, among whom Liu Xun, Li Xu, Xie Liangzuo, You Zuo, Zhang Yi, Su Shai, Lü Dalin, Lü Dajun, and Yin Dun became especially renowned. Xun was mild in temperament yet dignified in bearing, never compromising his arguments or forgetting his steps. Scholars said, *"Mingdao’s harmony and simplicity were most closely approximated by Zhifu."* They also said, *"Zhifu was overflowing with vitality."* Xu had the talent and capacity for great tasks, his attainments profound and his understanding pure. His mind was vast and unconstrained, and among the disciples of Confucius, he resembled Zai Wo in his eloquence. Liangzuo was resolute and perceptive, tireless in his efforts. He followed the Chengs’ teachings daily, such as discussing *ren* in terms of vitality, *sincerity* in terms of reality, *reverence* in terms of constant vigilance, and *investigating principle* in terms of seeking truth. His insights were precise, and he directly pointed to *investigating principle* and *maintaining reverence* as the gateway to virtue—this most clearly captured Mingdao’s method of instruction.

Zuo’s character was pure, his sincerity internal yet manifest externally, his demeanor and speech refined and elegant. Initially, he and his elder brother Chun were both known for their literary and moral excellence. When Yichuan met them in the capital, he saw that their potential could lead them to the Dao and invited them to study under him. They abandoned their previous learning and devoted themselves to his teachings. Yi and Dun were contemporaries. Yi was known for his lofty insight, Dun for his steadfast conduct—both were praised by their master, who once said, *"In my later years, I have gained these two scholars."* Dajun was strong, bright, upright, and trustworthy. His actions never deviated from his heart, and his knowledge never diverged from his conduct. He modeled his aspirations on Confucius’ *shangda*, cultivated his virtue through Mencius’ *jiyi*, and disciplined his conduct with Yanzi’s *keji fuli*. His essential aim was unceasing sincerity and clarity, never wavering due to others’ discouragement, yielding to petty arguments, being swayed by power and profit, or halting when his strength was exhausted.

He bore the weight of sagely worthies with such resolve. Dalin was deeply introspective and meticulous by nature, his disposition fundamentally one of unyielding *qi*. Through cultivation, he attained this state—thus did the sages regard firmness as the mark of a true scholar. If one is firm and can eliminate the flaw of excessive rigidity, preserving the full virtue of firmness, what task could not be accomplished? Without firmness, nothing can be achieved in the end.

It is recorded: Those who transmitted the teachings of Master Cheng in the Song dynasty saw the great illumination of the Daoist learning. Among them, the most eminent required no teacher’s transmission, intuitively grasping the essence of the Dao—since the Han and Wei dynasties, only one such figure has appeared. Thereafter, Mingdao dredged its source, Yichuan gathered its streams, and Hui’an propagated its waves, their influence surging without end. Their efforts in refining human hearts, clarifying the Dao, and strengthening the roots of moral transformation, as well as in restoring the primordial *qi* of states and nations, were such that their ultimate aspiration was nothing less than restoring the flourishing age of the Three Dynasties. In this, their moral principles shone forth so brightly that few in later generations could match them.

Master Pingshan, Liu Zidan, was the son of the loyal and illustrious Lord Han. Grieving his father’s martyrdom, he withdrew to live in reclusion on Mount Wuyi, where he befriended Hu Xian and Liu Mianzhi, forming bonds of mutual understanding. All those with whom he associated were renowned scholars, yet only Zhu Xi was deemed capable of bearing great responsibility and achieving far-reaching aims. Once, while studying the *Book of Changes*, Liu attained a sudden enlightenment. He believed that to master the *Changes*, one must first study the hexagram *Fu* (Return), and so he imparted the teaching of "not straying far before returning" to Zhu Xi, urging him to keep it close for life. Later, Zhu Xi indeed became the preeminent Confucian master of his age.

Master Jixi, Hu Xian, was the nephew of Hu Anguo. From birth, he was serene and solemn, never speaking or laughing idly. Throughout his life, he sat upright in dignified composure; even in haste, he never raised his voice or showed impatience. If others offended him, he never retaliated. At the time, the teachings of the Luoyang school were banned, but Hu Xian and Liu Mianzhi sought out its texts, secretly copying and reciting them day and night. Hearing that Qiao Ding of Fuling had studied under Cheng Yi, Hu Xian traveled to receive instruction, though for a long time he gained little. Qiao Ding said, "The heart is overwhelmed by external things, so it cannot perceive the truth—only through learning can clarity be attained." Hu Xian realized: "Is this not the work of self-discipline?" From then on, he devoted himself to foundational study, seeking no recognition. Returning to Chong’an, he tilled the land to support his parents. As his followers grew in number, he taught them, treating their learning as his own. At first, those who questioned him laughed; later, they doubted; but over time, observing how he cultivated himself, served his parents, and interacted with others—every action aligning with his words—they came to admire and submit to him wholeheartedly. Zhu Xi once remarked: "I served Master Jixi the longest and gained the most from his teachings."

Master Baishui, Liu Mianzhi, studied under Qiao Ding, Liu Anshi, and Yang Shi before completing his education and returning to Chong’an. Near the outskirts, he built a thatched hut to read in, living by farming and remaining utterly detached from worldly desires. Scholars flocked to him, and he expounded the Way of the sages according to each student’s capacity. Zhu Xi’s transmission of the orthodox Dao lineage began with these three masters.

The record states: Observing Wei Zhai’s final charge to entrust his son, one sees not only the merit of transmitting the Dao and teaching but also the profound sense of reliance and belonging. For Master Hui’an was originally from Xin’an; initially, he resided in Chong’an, and later moved to Kao-t’ing, both times relying on Ziyu (Liu Ziyu) for lodging. Later, a hall was established there. This hall, alongside the Kong family’s ancestral temple in Queli, exemplifies the weight of ancient bonds—of gratitude, duty, and the reverence between teacher and disciple. How does this compare to the present age?

Among Master Hui’an’s many disciples, the most eminent were Huang Gan, Li Fan, Liu Hui, Liu Bing, Zhang Qia, Chen Chun, Li Fangzi, Huang Xie, Cai Shen, and Fu Guang. Huang Gan never set up a bed at night, nor did he loosen his belt, so resolute and earnest was his devotion. Master Hui’an married his daughter to him. When Huang Gan fell ill, he dressed in deep mourning robes and entrusted his writings to him, saying in parting: "I entrust the Dao to you; in death, I have no regrets." He then passed away. Huang Gan’s disciple, Sheng, compiled ritual texts and wrote books, lecturing and discussing the principles of the classics tirelessly day and night.

Li Fan was initially instructed in the teachings of Zengzi: "To achieve far-reaching goals, one must be steadfast, but to bear great responsibility, magnanimity is essential." Thus, he named his study *Hong* (Magnanimity). Whenever students failed to grasp a concept, he first directed them to consult Li Fan. Once they had some insight, he would then guide and reconcile their understanding. The students held him in awe and reverence. It was said: "Li Fan’s progress in learning is formidable, and his conduct is never careless." Others remarked: "He who will carry on this Dao must be you." Li Fan also taught: "One need not wait for official appointment or assume office to achieve great deeds. Wherever one’s abilities reach, wherever one can benefit others—that is greatness." Living at home, he lectured on the Dao, and scholars revered him.

Liu Hui elucidated the origins of Dao Learning to inspire his fellow scholars. His works, *Explanations of the* Book of Rites *and* Book of Changes, *External and Continued Medicines of Yunzhuang*, circulated widely. Liu Bing, in his studies, focused solely on expounding the Dao and clarifying principles. When Master Hui’an interpreted the *Four Books*, transmitted the *Book of Changes* and *Book of Poetry*, compiled the *Outline of the Comprehensive Mirror*, and explained the *Taiji Diagram*, Liu Bing engaged in repeated discussions and debates, refining and correcting many points. He authored *Questions on the Four Books* and *Essentials of the Outline*. In the end, he was posthumously honored as "Cultured and Tranquil," and scholars referred to him as Master Lutang.

Zhang Qia delved into the meanings of the Six Classics and their commentaries, and beyond them, he read widely among the various masters, the Hundred Schools, geographical records, and local gazetteers. Master Zhu praised his dedication, telling Huang Gan: "The hope for the enduring transmission of this Dao rests with a few gentlemen like him." From youth, Zhang Qia devoted himself to reverence. In daily life, he appeared no different from ordinary people, but when duty called, his courage was unshakable. His works, *Collected Commentaries on the Spring and Autumn Annals* and *Chronological Tables of Geographical Changes*, circulated in the world.

Chen Chun, in his youth, studied for the imperial examinations. Lin Zongchen saw him and marveled, saying: "This is no path for a sage’s work." He then gave Chen Chun the *Reflections on Things at Hand*, and Chen Chun abandoned his previous studies to pursue this learning. When Master Hui’an arrived in Zhangzhou, Chen Chun sought his instruction and redoubled his efforts. Master Hui’an said: "Since coming south, I have been glad to have found Chen Chun." After Chen Chun’s death, Master Hui’an often reminisced about him. Chen Chun rigorously disciplined himself, reading every book and investigating every thing. Through daily accumulation, the principles became interconnected, and he perceived their order with clarity. Humble and retiring, he maintained his integrity, and his reputation spread throughout the land.

When the fox-fur robe was new, its steward said: "A new carriage brings comfort, a well-fed horse runs swift, and a fox-fur robe keeps one warm—my lord ought to replace it." Viscount Jian replied: "When a noble person wears fine garments, their demeanor grows more reverent; when a petty person does so, their manner grows more insolent."

Zigong asked Zishi: "Why not study the *Odes*?" Zishi answered: "My parents demand my filial piety, my brothers demand my fraternal duty, and my friends demand my trustworthiness—when would I find time to study?" Zigong said: "To neglect the *Odes* is to forgo learning from them."

In the fourth year of the *Heping* era, the Director of Waterways and Remonstrating Counselor Liu Xiang memorialized: "The more lofty the melody, the fewer who can harmonize with it. Water may bear the boat, yet it can also capsize it."

The Master of Chuqiu, at seventy years of age, donned a fur robe to meet Lord Mengchang. The lord said: "You are advanced in years, Master—what instruction can you offer me?" The Master replied: "If you wished me to chase chariots, spur horses, pursue stags, or wrestle tigers, I would be dead by now—what time would I have to be old? But if you seek to resolve doubts, settle indecision, then I am still young—what does age matter?" Lord Mengchang’s face flushed with shame.

The King of Wei desired to build the Terrace of Central Heaven, declaring: "Whoever dares remonstrate shall die." Xu Wencai feigned madness, took up a basket, and entered, saying: "I hear Your Majesty plans to construct the Terrace of Central Heaven—I wish to offer my strength." He continued: "I have heard that Heaven is fifteen thousand *li* from Earth; if Your Majesty builds halfway, the terrace should rise seven thousand five hundred *li*. Its base would need to span eight thousand *li*, yet all the land in your kingdom would not suffice for its foundation. You would have to raise troops to conquer the feudal lords, seize all their lands, and even then it would not be enough. You would still need to attack the Western Yi to secure the rest. Then, gather timber and laborers—only then could it be built." The King of Wei fell silent and later abandoned the project.

Someone sent fish to the Chancellor of Zheng, who refused them. The man asked: "You love fish—why not accept them?" The Chancellor replied: "It is because I love fish that I do not accept them. If I took the fish, I would lose my salary and have no means to eat fish. By refusing the fish, I keep my salary and may eat fish all my life."

"Rely on the wisdom of the old and the decisiveness of the young, and Alu will surely be well governed." When Ziqi was sixteen, the Lord of Qi sent him to administer Alu. Soon after, the lord regretted his decision and dispatched an envoy to recall him. As the envoy reached the city gates, he saw that Ziqi had already begun governing, and all those riding with him in the carriage were white-haired elders. Upon arriving in Alu, Ziqi melted down the armory’s weapons to forge farming tools. The state of Wei remarked: "We hear a mere boy governs the city—its armories are empty, its granaries bare." They then raised troops to attack. The people of Alu, fathers leading sons and elder brothers leading younger brothers, fought with their own weapons and defeated the Wei forces.

*The Model Sayings* in fifteen fascicles, composed by Yang Xiong, with commentary by Li Gui and Hong Fan.

"To devote oneself to learning is not as good as devoting oneself to seeking a teacher. A teacher is the model for all people."

Those with a semblance of Yan’s countenance are still followers of Yan; horses resembling the swift Ji are still steeds of Ji’s breed.

The *fu* of the *Shi* poets are resplendent yet measured; the *fu* of mere rhetoricians are resplendent yet frivolous. Were the disciples of Confucius to employ *fu*, Jia Yi would ascend the hall, while Sima Xiangru would enter the inner chamber.

What are the Four Weighty Matters?
The Four Weighty Matters are: weighty speech possesses method, weighty conduct possesses virtue, weighty demeanor possesses dignity, and weighty preferences possess refinement.

What are the Four Frivolous Matters?
The Four Frivolous Matters are: frivolous speech invites sorrow, frivolous conduct invites guilt, frivolous demeanor invites disgrace, and frivolous preferences invite baseness.

If a blade is dull and a brush blunt, they must be sharpened and honed.

If Heaven could be measured, its capacity to cover all things would be shallow; if Earth could be fathomed, its capacity to bear all things would be meager.

Of those who expound Heaven, none are more eloquent than the *Book of Changes*; of those who expound Earth, none are more eloquent than the *Book of Documents*; of those who expound the body, none are more eloquent than the *Book of Songs*; of those who expound principle, none are more eloquent than the *Spring and Autumn Annals*.

Confucius was an exile from the state of Lu; Boyi and Shuqi were starving recluses of West Mountain. Yet they did not bend their resolve, did not disgrace their persons, and stood neither with the base nor the compliant, transcending all distinctions of right and wrong.

The Dao of Confucius is like the four great rivers flowing through the Central States, ultimately emptying into the vast sea.

*The Canon of Supreme Mystery* in ten fascicles, composed by Yang Xiong, with commentary by Yu Fan.

Eagles gather in the forest; otters enter the dry springs.

The turtledove dwells in the woods, deriding the flock of birds.

King An of Huainan was rich in florid words but poor in substance.

The hegemony of Duke Huan of Qi and Duke Wen of Jin endured as if continuing the moon’s light.

Confucius was sufficient in culture; Lord Lao was sufficient in mystery.

Mountains, rivers, marshes, and wetlands—all things return to them.

When the noble person attains office, they flourish; when they lose it, they remain steadfast. When the petty person attains office, they act tyrannically; when they lose it, they fall into ruin.

*New Discourses* in seventeen fascicles, by Huan Tan.

The Three Sovereigns governed through the Dao; the Five Emperors transformed through virtue; the Three Kings acted through benevolence and righteousness; the Five Hegemons employed cunning and strategy.

That which has no decrees or punishments is called Sovereign; that which has decrees but no punishments is called Emperor; that which rewards the good and punishes the evil, with feudal lords attending court, is called King; that which mobilizes troops and masses...

**Hongdao Record, Scroll Twenty-Seven: Righteousness – The Righteousness of Friends**

Master Lü Zuqian of Shulai, a sixth-generation descendant of Lü Yijian, inherited the transmission of Central Plains culture and scholarship from his family. In his youth, he studied under Lin Zhi, Wang Yingchen, and Hu Xian, and later befriended Zhang Shi and Zhu Xi. His inquiries into the Dao grew ever more refined. Once, upon reading an essay by Lu Jiuyuan, he admired it greatly but had not yet met the man. When he later presided over the Ministry of Rites examinations, he chanced upon a scroll and remarked, "This must be the work of the young Lu from Jiangxi." When the name was revealed, it proved true. All marveled at his keen discernment.

Earlier, a book titled *The Literary Sea of the Sagely Song* had appeared in bookshops. Academician Zhou Bida noted its flawed selections and feared it would not endure. He suggested entrusting the task of collation to an official scholar to compile a definitive anthology of the dynasty. Emperor Xiaozong commissioned Zuqian, who then selected works from before the Restoration, elevating the refined and rejecting the frivolous, arranging them into one hundred fifty fascicles. The emperor bestowed the title *Imperial Anthology of Our August Dynasty*.

Zuqian’s learning took the traditions of Guan and Luo as its foundation, yet he drew widely from the boundless records of the past. His mind was equanimous, his qi harmonious; he did not suppress dissent, and thus extraordinary talents of his time all turned to him in admiration. From youth, he had been impetuous, but upon reciting the *Analects* one day—holding himself to strict standards while lightly blaming others—he suddenly felt his habitual anger and irritability melt away like ice. Thus, Master Hui once remarked, "In learning, only one like Bogong can truly transform one’s temperament and nature."

His teachings and plans aimed to enlighten the world and accomplish great tasks. Even as he lay ill, his resolve to bear heavy burdens and travel far on the Way did not wane. The governance of his household became a model for later generations.

In his later years, the place where he gathered with friends was called the Lizhai Academy, located within the city of Jinhua. After his passing, the people of the prefecture immediately established a shrine in his honor.

It is recorded: Observing the learning of the Lian, Luo, Guan, and Min schools, each had its origins in our Zhejiang. After the Southern Song crossed the Yangtze, Lü Chenggong received the transmission of Central Plains scholarship and initiated this tradition. Later, scholars such as He Yu and Jin Xu emerged in succession, flourishing in their time. By the present dynasty, there were Liu Ji of Qingtian, Song Lian of Pujiang, Ye Chen of Lishui, and Zhang Yi of Longquan. The Taizu Emperor once praised the "Four Masters" without referring to them by name—how refined and flourishing! Yet Jinhua was truly the domain where Master Lü first propagated the Dao, and this cannot go unrecorded.

Master Xishan, Cai Yuanding, was born with exceptional intelligence. His father, Cai Fa, taught him the *Recorded Sayings of the Cheng Brothers* along with works such as the *Rectifying the World and Correcting Youth*. He said, "This is the true lineage of Confucius and Mencius." Yuanding deeply immersed himself in their meaning, and as he grew older, his discernment and reasoning became ever more precise. He climbed to the summit of Xishan, where he ate ferns and read books. Hearing of Zhu Xi’s reputation, he went to study under him. When Zhu Xi questioned him about his learning, he was astonished and exclaimed, "This is my old friend—he should not be ranked among my disciples." Thus, they shared a room and discussed the profound meanings of the classics, with Zhu Xi directing students from all directions to first seek Yuanding’s guidance for verification.

At that time, Han Tuozhou imposed the ban on "heterodox learning," falsely accusing the virtuous. The censors and remonstrators, following the trend, attacked them. Shen Jizu and Liu Sanjie submitted memorials denouncing Zhu Xi, implicating Yuanding as well. He was exiled to Daozhou. Upon receiving the decree, he did not plead for mercy but immediately set out on the journey. Zhu Xi and his disciples held a farewell banquet for him in a desolate temple. Some guests sighed and wept, but Zhu Xi glanced at Yuanding and saw he was no different from usual. He then sighed and said, "The affection between friends and Jitong’s unyielding resolve—both are perfectly realized." The crowd urged him to delay his departure, but Yuanding replied, "If I have offended Heaven, can I advance toward it?" Taking up his staff and sandals, he walked three thousand *li* with his son, his feet bleeding, yet without the slightest sign of distress. Upon arriving in Chunling, scholars from near and far gathered in great numbers. Students and scholars all rushed to attend his lectures. Even renowned scholars, though proud and aloof, came to pay their respects with reverence.

He read widely in all books and investigated all matters. His understanding of principle penetrated to its roots, and he was profoundly skilled in even the minutest details of charts, calligraphy, ritual, music, and institutional systems. Obscure passages and abstruse meanings in ancient texts that others could not comprehend, he grasped at a single glance. He delighted in explicating the *Four Books* and collaborated with Zhu Xi in compiling the *Commentary on the Book of Changes* and the *Outline and Details of the Comprehensive Mirror*. The *Primer* was entrusted to him for completion.

His medical prescriptions stated: "The subtleties of creation can only be recognized by those deeply versed in principle." After his death, he was eulogized in writing: "His profound insight, his outstanding talent, his unyielding resolve, his inexhaustible eloquence—these can never be seen again."

It is recorded: Mencius said, "One who wins people over through virtue is sincerely admired from the heart, as the seventy disciples admired Confucius." Thus, neither the hardships of Chen and Cai, nor the threats of the people of Kuang, nor the slander of Shusun Wushu, nor the harm intended by Sima Huan Tui could sway him. How much less could the fleeting opinions of the moment or the private judgments of others? Yet, I venture to compare this to the present, for the times are vastly different. Why is this so?

In the late Song, the hearts of the people remained steadfast, and the spirit of the scholar-officials endured, so those who resisted or obstructed were few. Thus, scholars still knew to adjust their robes and hasten to their seats, their hearts sincerely submitting in reverence and bow. Today, however, the hearts of men have grown utterly frivolous, and the scholar’s spirit has become exceedingly weak—those who mock and deride are without end. Where, then, can one go that is not a desperate strait or a dried-up rut, a path fraught with loathing and dread? Those who observe must discern this clearly.

Chen Tongfu Liang, with his surpassing talent and spirit, and his discussions that carried the wind of former worthies, was among the foremost heroes of his time, his aspirations fixed on ordering the world. In the early years of the Longxing reign, he submitted five memorials on matters high and low, but received no response. He withdrew to Yongkang, devoting himself to study and writing books. During the Chunxi era, he traveled to the capital and spoke boldly on current affairs, startling Emperor Xiaozong so deeply that he wished to display him in the court to inspire the assembled ministers. Following the precedent of Zhong Fang, he summoned Liang to the palace hall, intending to promote him. When Zeng Ji heard of this and sought to meet him, Liang, disdaining the court’s intrigues, avoided him and left. Zeng was displeased, and the high ministers, resenting his forthrightness, joined forces to obstruct him. Liang laughed and said, “I sought to lay a foundation for the state that would endure for centuries—would I stoop to barter that for a single office?” He crossed the river once more and returned home, his learning growing ever more vast.

After Mencius, he esteemed only Wang Tong. He once said of himself: “I delve into the subtleties of principle, distinguish the similarities and differences of past and present, trace the mind to its fleeting origins, and measure the body down to the finest detail. I take accumulation as my craft and self-cultivation as my norm. In meticulous scholarship and profound insight, I may indeed feel shame before the other Confucians. But when it comes to the majestic array of battle, the righteous banners unfurled, where wind and rain, clouds and thunder burst forth together, where dragons and serpents, tigers and leopards appear and vanish in transformation—overturning the wisdom and courage of an age, expanding the breadth of ten thousand generations’ minds—I dare say I possess some small advantage.” Here, he referred to Zhu Xi and Lü Zuqian.

It is recorded: In my humble observation of the principles and trends of the world, if crookedness does not reach its extreme, uprightness cannot attain its fullness. From the reigns of Guangzong and Ningzong onward, discussions of the Daoist learning were so reviled that they were nearly intolerable. The learning of rectifying the mind and making the intentions sincere was what the court wearied of hearing and warned against, while cautious and fearful teachings were dismissed as mere deceit. Men like Chen Jia, Lin Jing, Li Jingtang, Hu Tong, Shen Jizu, Liu Sanjie, He Dan, and Liu Dexiu, brandishing their slander, rolled up their sleeves in defiance, going so far as to exile and persecute the upright, scarcely a day passing without incident. The Dao had reached the point of utmost distortion. Yet how could they have known that the majestic array and righteous banners would stand firm and unshaken? In the blink of an eye, Emperor Lizong arose, venerating Daoist learning and honoring the Confucian spirit. Not only were Zhou, Cheng, Zhang, and Zhu exalted, but even Cai and Lü and the other worthies were invigorated. Only then did one realize that when clouds and thunder burst forth together, the sun and moon shine twice as bright; when serpents and tigers behave as demons, the phoenix and qilin become all the more radiant. Truly, there were those who could overturn the reckless ways of an era and expand the minds of ten thousand generations—how could Chen Tongfu’s small advantage be the only measure of this?

The *History of the Yuan* states: Master Wucao, Wu Cheng, was precociously intelligent from childhood. As he grew, he devoted himself to the learning of the sages and worthies, composing *Chapter and Verse on the Classic of Filial Piety* and collating the *Book of Changes*, *Book of Documents*, *Book of Songs*, *Spring and Autumn Annals*, *Ceremonies and Rites*, and the Greater and Lesser *Dai Records*. At the time, an imperial edict sought out worthy men, and the censor Cheng Jufu recommended him to the capital. He requested that Wu’s writings be placed in the Directorate of Education to benefit scholars. The provincial administration’s Xu Yuanmingshan, who prided himself on his literary talent, once questioned Wu about the profound meanings of the *Changes*, *Songs*, *Documents*, and *Spring and Autumn Annals*. Sighing, he said, “Speaking with you, Master, is like plumbing the depths of the ocean.” Thereafter, he treated Wu with the respect due a teacher for the rest of his life.

Left Minister Dong Shixuan invited him to his home, personally serving him meals and thread for mending, and declared, “Master, you are a scholar of the realm.” In the first year of the Zhida era, Wu was summoned to serve as Supervisor of the Directorate. Previously, when Xu Wenzheng had been Chancellor, he had begun instructing students in Master Zhu’s *Elementary Learning* and other works, but over time, these teachings gradually fell into disuse. Upon Wu’s arrival, he ordered the students to receive instruction in turn. Rising at dawn with lamps still lit, he would recite the *Wang* chapter of the *Analects* in the hall, then retire to his private quarters with utmost diligence. Those who came bearing classics to seek his counsel arrived in an unbroken stream. Adapting to each student’s aptitude, he patiently instructed and guided them, often until deep into the night, undeterred by heat or cold.

He established four principles of teaching: first, the study of the classics; second, moral conduct; third, literary arts; and fourth, governance and practical affairs. In person, he appeared so frail as to scarcely bear his robes, yet when seated upright with hands clasped, his qi flowed harmoniously and his spirit soared. His responses to questions were inexhaustible, dissolving doubts like melting ice. He once wrote in an essay: “The greatness of the Dao originates from the celestial spirits, and the sages inherit it. Before Yao and Shun, the Dao was in its primordial phase; thereafter, it flourished. The schools of Zhu, Si, Zou, and Lu represent its prosperity, while the lineages of Lian, Luo, Guan, and Min embody its fulfillment.

Examined in detail: in high antiquity, Fuxi and the Yellow Emperor marked its origin; Yao and Shun, its flourishing; Yu and Tang, its prosperity; and King Wen, King Wu, and the Duke of Zhou, its fulfillment. In the middle antiquity, Confucius established its origin; Yan [Yuan] and Zeng [zi] brought its flourishing; Zisi, its prosperity; and Mencius, its fulfillment. In recent antiquity, Master Zhou [Dunyi] initiated its origin; the Cheng brothers and Zhang [Zai] fostered its flourishing; and Master Zhu [Xi] achieved its prosperity. Who, then, shall be the fulfillment of the Dao in our age?” Such was his sense of mission toward this cultural legacy.

The record states: In my humble observation, the founding of the Yuan dynasty saw no cessation of warfare for scholarly discourse or dismounting of steeds for debate on the Dao. Only through the efforts of Masters Luzhai and Caolu—who conveyed the Way of emperors and kings to their sovereign above and the teachings of the Confucian sages to the people below—was the lifeline of the tradition extended for a century. Yet this was not a grand design to inherit the past sages and inaugurate future learning, nor did it generate a great momentum for the age. His use of the *yuan-heng-li-zhen* hexagram to illustrate the transmission of the Dao through the ages strikes me as less precise than Master Shao’s *Supreme Principles Governing the World*. Judging by the circumstances of his time, the era of Master Caolu may well have been the winter of Heaven—far from the convergence of Heaven and Earth.

From *Records of Illustrious Ministers of the August Ming*: Master Qianxi, Song Lian, in his youth studied under the local scholar Master Xiang, Academician Liu Gonguan, and Academician Huang Gongjin. In the early Hongwu reign, he was summoned from commoner status to court and appointed Librarian to the Heir Apparent, exhorting him to filial piety, brotherly love, reverence, respect, diligence, and assiduity, urging him to read widely, cultivate virtue, and refine his conduct to meet the world’s expectations. When the Taizu Emperor perused his writings, he was pleased and bestowed a letter in reply, saying: “Formerly, you instructed my son with strict discipline—this was for my sake. That you have not yet transformed customs with the methods of the sages shows your broad-mindedness. Your steadfast loyalty and frugality are entirely fitting.” During his time at court, he compiled and edited all matters pertaining to the rituals of suburban sacrifices, ancestral temples, mountains, rivers, and the spirits of the land and grain; court banquets and celebrations; rites, music, calendars, and measurements; the regulations for attire and headgear; the tributary missions of the Four Barbarians; the protocols for rewards and punishments; and the eulogies and commemorative writings for meritorious ministers and eminent officials.

When the emperor sought to appoint him to a high political post, he firmly declined, saying: “I, your servant, am young and without other talents; I have only devoted myself to literature and do not wish to hold office.” In his dealings with others, he was affable, genuine, and eager to guide younger scholars, fearing he might fail them. Those who came from afar were provided lodging and sustenance, and though they stayed long, his generosity never waned. His inner sincerity and outward forbearance were ever rooted in uprightness. He often said: “In ancient times, moral education was highly valued. Not only did disciples seek teachers, but teachers, upon finding a single talented youth to instruct, would rejoice visibly. This was no other reason than the irresistible pull of heavenly principle and human nature.”

In his later years, he took on Fang Sheng of Tiantai, whose demeanor was steadfast and unyielding to worldly concerns, whose intellect was keen and penetrating of all principles. When questioned, his writings flowed forth like water or emerged like mountains, standing out among the clamor of a hundred birds like a solitary phoenix.

The record states: Song Qianxi’s resolute refusal of high office was not without reason. For while his teaching of the heir apparent, cultivation of public morality, establishment of state institutions, and elucidation of classical texts were abundant and overflowing, his capacity for high political office was modest and insufficient—such were the demands of the times. Yet his humble demeanor in office seemed to subtly safeguard the principles of governance and human relations for another day. One can imagine that in his private discussions and teachings within his school, he never resorted to mere embellishment or ornate phrasing. Rather, his insights into the successes and failures of court politics, the fortunes of the state, the burdens of the heir apparent, and the latent crises were as clear and indelible as if carved in metal and stone. Only thus could he stand without betraying the intentions of the founding emperor—a standard that those in power at the time could not match.

Master Zhengxue, Fang Xiaoru, studied under Song Lian. He thoroughly investigated the lineages and sources of Neo-Confucian learning, the rise and fall of eminent figures, the subtleties of prosperity and decline, and the details of names, objects, measurements, and numbers, leaving no thread unexamined and synthesizing all into a grand unity. As he matured, he befriended renowned scholars such as Su Boreng and Hu Han, engaging in intense and far-reaching discussions, delving deeply into the classics and histories. From self-cultivation and family governance to statecraft and social conduct, all could serve as models. He held that the Dao is present in all affairs, and thus compiled a list of twenty exhortations to encourage improvement. He also wrote thirty-eight chapters of *Miscellaneous Admonitions* as warnings. He believed that transforming the people must begin with rectifying the family, and so composed nine essays on *Clan Regulations* to instruct his kinsmen. He further observed: “Today’s scholars, mired in the flaws of past learning, merely pilfer established doctrines to craft their writings.”

The miscellaneous scholars, though broadly learned in Buddhist teachings, possess base and debased aspirations, their discussions shallow and narrow, devoid of the demeanor of true gentlemen and noble men. Thus, he once rose with indignation and declared: “One who does not serve his lord with the heart of Yi Yin and the Duke of Zhou is a traitor to his lord; one who does not study with the learning of Confucius and Mencius is a traitor to himself.” All under heaven with lofty aspirations admired his words, nearly abandoning their own studies to follow him. In his own estimation, he sought to ascend and join Boyi and Shuqi above, and descend to bow before Peng Xian, willing to die for righteousness without a backward glance.

It is recorded: What did Yi Yin and the Duke of Zhou do in serving their lords? He replied: “I do not trifle with disobedience. When King Tai Jia was exiled to Tong, he proved worthy, so the Duke of Zhou restored him. As for Guan and Cai, rumors spread that the Duke of Zhou would harm the young king, but it was not the Duke of Zhou who executed them—it was the execution they deserved by all under heaven.”

What did Confucius and Mencius teach in their learning? He replied: “The scholar with resolve and the man of humanity do not seek life at the expense of humanity; they sacrifice themselves to fulfill it. As it is said: ‘Life is what I desire; righteousness is also what I desire. When what I desire surpasses life, I do not evade it for mere survival.’” Yet among the scholars of former times, how did their teachings differ from those of today? Few, however, embodied and practiced them.

Could such a man be omitted from these records? Wang Zhongwen, styled Cheng, studied alongside Song Qianxi under Liu Wensu and Huang Wenxian. Among their contemporaries, those who praised their friendship included Professor Hu Han, who said: “Bo’s prose surges forth like mountains rising from water, matching Huang’s as if from the same mold.” Hu Xingjian, the Imperial Censor of Qingjiang, remarked: “Though his roots trace back to Master Huang, his profound mastery surpasses him.” Song Qianxi himself observed: “In his youth, his works were vast in scope and grand in transformation, their brilliance dazzling among his peers. Like one constructing a great hall, he amassed abundant materials, laying a broad foundation. As he matured, his writing surged like waves where dragons leapt, and storms where rain and hail gathered; five colors vied in brightness as ten suns shone together. Like a towering pavilion already built, its pillars aligned, its eaves soaring, its grandeur ever more majestic. By forty, his prose was effortlessly refined, its structure flawless, inviting endless exploration and yielding inexhaustible depth. Like a hall of solemn depth, where ritual vessels stand to the left and zithers to the right, great scholars and noble lords, adorned in caps and jade, exchange courteous bows within, while common scholars in humble garb cannot even glimpse its reflected glory.”

Thus, his strategies flourished in the command tent, his achievements shone in governing the people, his writings served as enduring models, his Dao-learning was evident in guiding the ruler, and his loyalty and righteousness were manifest in his death. Alas, this suffices to discuss the man. Yet if judged solely by his entanglement in the Hu rebellion, his integrity would not be fully captured.

It is recorded: I observe that the Ming dynasty also arose from the Huai region, employing many refined literati, distinct from mere peddlers or butchers. Yet these were the finest of our Zhejiang, who did not favor their hometowns, nor did they, though near to Nanyang, gaze upon one another. Among them were those like Hua Chuan, who died for loyalty, and those who upheld true learning and righteousness. Compared to the likes of Sui He and Zhou Chang, how far superior they were! Tracing the cause, it was because after the great revival of Dao-learning, those who arose from humble scholars bore the legacy of culture and scholarship, vastly different from the Han dynasty’s recovery from Qin’s decay. Thus, even in the tumultuous early days of a dynasty, the aid of teachers and friends, the benefits of learned discourse and profound origins, could not be lacking.

It is recorded: Master Kangzhai, Wu Yubi, in his youth read the *Records of the Origins of the Learning of the Luo River*, and his heart yearned for the Dao. Later, upon encountering the teachings of Master Mingdao, he was deeply moved, realizing that sages and worthies could indeed be emulated. He abandoned the imperial examinations, severed worldly ties, immersed himself in the classics, and gathered his mind and spirit. He delved deeply into the principles of the Dao, regarding the world’s pursuits as beneath his aspirations, striving instead to reach the realm of sages and worthies. In his village, every action adhered to ritual propriety. Scholars from all directions sought his instruction, but he declined their gifts, excelling in enlightenment. Those who heard his words were stirred to action.

He constantly exhorted his students in four principles: One must take the sage as one’s aim; learning must take the Dao as its ultimate goal. In cultivation, one must not skip steps—first mastering the *Lesser Learning* before advancing to the *Greater Learning*. Upon completing the *Analects*, one should broadly acquire culture and restrain oneself with ritual. In the *Mencius*, one should seek the lost mind and cultivate the Four Beginnings. In the *Doctrine of the Mean*, one must be diligent in preserving, nurturing, examining, and reflecting, gradually attaining the utmost harmony. One should understand the Supreme Polarity to know the origin of human nature, and study the *Western Inscription* to grasp the essence of humanity. In the *Book of Changes*, he followed the early Cheng school and despised the novel theories of later scholars. As for the *Book of Documents*, its ancient-text versions were profound in principle, and thus could not be arbitrarily discarded.

He once lamented: “The excessive annotations in various texts obscure direct, unobstructed understanding.” Thus, he was cautious in his own writings.

In the early years of the Tianshun reign, the loyal Duke Shi Heng recommended him to the court. An emissary was dispatched bearing official summons and gifts of silk to his residence. Upon arrival, he was appointed Grand Tutor of the Eastern Palace but firmly declined the post. When summoned to an audience in the Wenhua Hall, he earnestly declined on account of his age. The Emperor Yingzong turned to his Grand Secretary Li Xian and said, “This elder is no impractical pedant—ensure he takes office.” Yet Yang Bi steadfastly refused. A record states: In observing Kangzhai’s withdrawal and engagement, one perceives an inevitability. Confucius traveled from state to state seeking an audience, and Mencius accepted patronage, yet upon hearing of the great Dao in practice or the heroic ages of the Three Dynasties, they sighed in lament. How could they not have wished to emulate Yi or Lü, enabling the sovereign to attain the beauty of self-forgetting power? Or to delight in the joy of being thrice summoned? It was not to be. What manner of man was Shi Heng? By office, he commanded troops, not the task of seeking worthies; by power, he wielded authority, not the sincerity of aligning intentions; by the times, he stood at the cusp of turmoil, not the days of tranquility; by virtue, he was aged, not suited to harmonious collaboration. Had he hesitated even briefly, disaster would have followed swiftly. Yet observe the summons and edicts: their initial sincerity and final grace, radiant and all-pervading, shone with brilliance and grandeur. For Yang Bi, such honors only deepened his glory, while office itself remained as worthless as worn-out sandals. Between sovereign and subject, between friends, all was perfectly preserved.

Master Chen Baisha of Baisha studied under Wu Kangzhai. Kangzhai often taught using the sayings of the Cheng brothers of Lu, yet Baisha found no gain in them. Returning home, he built a terrace named Yangchun, where he sat in silent reverence daily, nurturing his fundamental origin. Few saw his face. Initially, his resolve was bold and his efforts intense, nearly inducing a disorder of the heart-mind. Later, he realized his error, understanding that vigilance and awe were not one-sided admonitions. Later scholars, failing to grasp this, erred by the slightest margin. His realization came only after years of reflection. He said, “From this point onward, my heart-mind is like a horse with a bridle—whether in movement or stillness, in handling affairs or engaging with others, it is ever present, examined and balanced, never absent.” On governance, he insisted: “The world does not move without sincerity, nor is it ordered without talent. Only when talent and sincerity unite can order prevail.” To transform through teaching, one must first sit in stillness to cultivate the seeds of goodness. He said, “The purpose of learning is to hear the Dao. If it cannot be found in books, seek it in your own heart-mind. Why be burdened by external distractions? This matter demands clear perception. Without it, even daily study is but mimicry. Once this principle is grasped, the self-cultivator trusts it.” As for poetry, prose, and the like—paths of superficial cleverness—he severed and swept them all away, allowing not the slightest obstruction in his heart-mind. Only then could the seeds of goodness be nurtured, and stillness attained. With unwavering focus, his demeanor grew ever more refined, his attainment ever deeper, embodying what is called “drawing near to the numinous.” The daily practices of the common people, though unrecognized, emerged from this very source.

He once told his disciple Lin Guang: “To ‘strive unceasingly’ is merely to gather this in.” This principle is vast, without inside or outside, without before or after, reaching everywhere without pause. Once this handle is grasped, what further task remains? Past and present, the four directions and the six realms—all are threaded and gathered as one, present in every moment and place. This fills the world, as when Confucius’ disciples strolled and sang in the Apricot Altar, their joy resting in the space between forgetting and forcing. Zeng Dian’s insight was like a living craft, yet Mencius distilled it in a single breath—soaring kites and leaping fish. Without Mencius’ effort, to speak of Zeng Dian’s delight would be like recounting a dream.

Master Hu Juren of Jingzhai received the true transmission of the learning of the heart-mind from Kangzhai. Retiring, he further expanded it, aspiring to the ancients and taking the Dao as his burden. He deemed memorization and literary composition insufficient, focusing instead on the inner self, taking loyalty and trust as his foundation, seeking the lost heart-mind as his priority. He held that the sage’s learning began and ended with reverence, thus naming his studio Jingzhai. Solemn and dignified, he walked the straight path, and in his dealings with others—even in solitude or hidden moments—his vigilance only deepened. His poem read: *“In solitude, probe deeply; guard against subtle intentions. The most profound exchanges lie in this essential truth—unashamed before Heaven.”* Disciples from all directions gathered, and he built a study hall named *Liwu* (“Revering the Self”) and *Nanguo Jian* (“Southern Academy”). Later, in teaching, he often said: “First, fear not seeing the truth; second, fear interrupted effort.” Many with fine qualities aspired too high, drifting into Chan Buddhism, indulging in empty words, unaware of what it meant to preserve and examine the heart-mind. How could they reach the realm of virtue and the Dao?

He convened with Lou Yizhai of Shangrao, Luo Yifeng of Yongfeng, Zhang Shu of Nanchang, and Bai Lizhe at Guifeng in Yiyang and the Yingtiansi Temple in Yugan. His writings include the *Juye Lu* (“Record of Dwellings and Practices”) and the *Jingzhai Ji* (“Collection of Jingzhai”). He took from the *Book of Changes* the phrase *“cultivate speech and establish sincerity”* as the meaning of *juye* (“dwelling in practice”). A record states: Chen and Hu, both disciples of Kangzhai, differed in their paths—one found no gain in the sayings of the Cheng brothers of Lu, while the other attained the true learning of the heart-mind through reverence. Yet I observe in Yang Yuehu’s letter to Lin Jixi: “Baisha favored enigmatic speech. While Kangzhai often taught using established sayings, Baisha sought self-realization.” The sayings of the Cheng brothers were also their own realizations. If later scholars insist on teaching through self-realization alone, another flaw may arise. It is also said: “Baisha awakened to the Dao late, relying on simplicity for self-cultivation.”

Thus, for scholars of today who seek self-realization, what should they take as their foundation? They should take *jing* (reverence) as their foundation. What should they take as their practice? They should take *juye* (dwelling in practice) as their practice. When their perception is true and their pursuit is earnest, they need not fear failing to dwell in it with ease or to draw deeply from its resources. Having thus avoided the burden of reluctant study, they will also not fall into the errors of later generations. If they can grasp this, they will find its source wherever they turn—what more need they await?

It is asked: Does entering into discussion at once give rise to doubt? Scholars cannot afford to be unaware of this.

Master Yifeng, Luo Lun, would not let his eyes behold unseemly sights nor his ears hear unseemly sounds. He felt no shame in coarse clothing or simple food. When speaking with a son, he grounded his words in filial piety; with a minister, in loyalty. When addressing an official, he spoke of the people’s hardships. Upon seeing a virtuous person, he cherished them as if they were qilin or phoenixes; upon encountering a wicked person, he regarded them as snakes or scorpions. When he saw someone suffering from hunger, cold, or destitution, he would empty his own possessions to relieve them. In matters of righteousness, he acted with unyielding resolve. The praise or blame of others, the joy or sorrow of events, the success or failure of affairs, even his own life or death, fortune or misfortune—none of these did he consider.

Early in his career as a Hanlin Academician, when the death of Grand Secretary Li Xian occurred, the court, following precedent, ordered his immediate reinstatement. The censors and remonstrators dared not speak against it, but Luo privately advised against it and later submitted a memorial, meticulously citing the impropriety of reinstatement from ancient times to the present. He insisted that the sagely court should follow the examples of Fu Bi and Liu Qi, who had observed full mourning. Thus, Li completed his mourning period. Luo’s memorial, spanning thousands of words, was rooted entirely in the unceasing principles of Heavenly Principle and the human heart. Upon its submission, he was stripped of his office. From then on, scholars throughout the realm strove to refine themselves in emulation of him, and those who had previously relied on mere words to cultivate themselves underwent a transformation toward sincerity and integrity. By the end of Luo’s life, the practice of reinstatement during mourning had ceased entirely in the censorate and ministry.

After retiring to Mount Jinniu, he opened his doors to teach disciples, devoting himself daily to annotating the classics. His reputation spread across the land, and wherever he went, people would gather to observe him. Even military officers and vulgar officials came to respect and admire him. His associates were all the heroic scholars of the age, and when they spoke of his character, they invariably said: “Like the blue sky and the bright sun.”

It is recorded: That Luo could be a true gentleman and not a petty man was no accident. The vital *qi* of the state had been nurtured by successive sagely rulers, reaching its flourishing peak by the Chenghua era. Thus, in the earlier Kaibao era, when imperial virtue was ascendant, there was Wang Zeng, who remained unmoved by mere comforts; in the later Qingli and Yuanyou eras, there was Sima Guang, who alone refused to wear flowers. Only by being unmoved by comfort could one stand firm in the court with unyielding integrity; only by refusing to wear flowers could one pledge oneself to solitary loyalty. How rare was a figure like Luo! Though top-ranking scholars appear in every dynasty, upon reflection, few are truly exceptional. Yet Luo’s single memorial on reinstatement during mourning—rooted in loving others through virtue—stands in stark contrast to the indulgence of the present age. Is this not a refreshing breeze across the ages? His lofty office and illustrious rank were nothing compared to the unapproachable brilliance of “the blue sky and the bright sun.”

Master Fengshan, Zhang Mao, from his youth possessed lofty aspirations. In his studies and inquiries, he conducted himself with humility and sincerity. While serving at court, he associated with Luo Yifeng, Zhuang Kongyang, Huang Zhongzhao, He Kegong, Lu Keshen, Xie Yuanji, and Zheng Kexiu—all of whom admired antiquity and aspired to righteousness. With Luo’s advocacy of harmony and integrity, they mutually inspired one another, striving to guide the ruler toward the flourishing of the Tang and Yu eras. Before long, during the Lantern Festival, Zhang, along with Zhuang and Huang, jointly submitted a memorial. Its essence lay in cultivating the sagely virtue of the emperor, but it offended the throne and led to their demotion. Their reputation soared, and the capital hailed them as the “Three Gentlemen,” collectively known with Luo as the “Four Remonstrators of the Hanlin Academy.”

Zhang cultivated virtue with profound depth. His joy and anger did not show on his face, nor did grudges or resentments take root in his heart. He made no boastful claims, nor did arrogance find place in his conduct. He read widely, comprehending all matters under heaven, delving deeply into the subtleties of principle and embodying them in practice. He was tirelessly devoted to the world, never resorting to affectation. He once said: “Humans are formed from the *qi* of Heaven and Earth and endowed with the principles of Heaven and Earth. One must align one’s substance with the vastness of Heaven and Earth and one’s function with their ceaseless circulation—only then can one be called human.”

He taught that scholars must broaden their hearts and minds. For when the heart is vast, all things become interconnected. This requires the effort of investigating principle, for only then can the heart truly unite with it. Yet one must also make the heart small. This demands the work of nurturing and refining, so the heart may become small without falling into recklessness.

It is recorded: Since Kangzhai resolutely declined the role of imperial tutor, Baisha no longer took pride in his official rank, Yifeng did not cherish his top examination honors, and the names of the “Four Remonstrators of the Hanlin” and the “Three Gentlemen” became illustrious throughout the realm. Even He Jishi, hearing of their example, submitted a memorial to resign his office—what an era this was! Above, there was a benevolent and enlightened ruler; below, many ministers of true integrity. Yet how was this achieved? Precisely through the daily work of investigating principle and nurturing the self. Thus, they established hearts as vast as Heaven and Earth, unmoved by external things, and maintained their inner cultivation with meticulous care, never complacent in self-satisfaction.

Yet if one is called "reckless and arrogant," it is only because they fail to exert themselves strenuously to live up to such a name—how could others treat them with meanness? Here the compiler examines the matter in detail.

Zhang Yuanzhen’s *Epitaph for Master Chen Xuan* states: In an age of long peace, scholar-officials often lacked vigor and moral backbone. Even those who possessed some integrity frequently fell short in the work of self-discipline. Thus, their conduct lacked brilliance, and their resolve proved inconstant. But how could one find fault with Master Chen? He set his aspirations on the ancient sages and worthies, cultivating himself in quiet obscurity without seeking recognition. His learning centered on restraining the self to seek benevolence, and so he styled himself "Ke Zhai" (Restraining Studio). He read not for literary ornament but copied down maxims by hand to aid his practice. In daily life, he spoke little, yet when action was required, he acted with courage. His conduct was marked by reverent sincerity, wholly genuine. In whatever office he held, he strove to fulfill its duties; in whatever task he undertook, he gave his whole heart. He regarded personal advancement or retreat as of little consequence, caring only for the people and the state, heedless of all else. Thus, it was said of him that he possessed an unshakable moral integrity, a talent sufficient to aid the realm, and a courage that could not be suppressed. Wherever his official career took him, people were moved. When he served as inspector in Jiangxi, his reputation endures to this day. In the Southern Metropolitan Region and Henan, as educational commissioner, his earnestness inspired admiration; in Guangdong, his authority was especially relied upon. When he departed, the local gentry and scholars pressed him to stay, and afterward, they erected shrines in his honor and monuments to their longing for his return. Thus, his name filled the realm, and whether one knew him or not, when speaking of upright men of the time, all would say, "Chen so-and-so."

The compiler notes: When we speak of one whom others cannot treat with meanness, we refer to a scholar-official of Master Chen’s virtue. Though he did not rise to the highest ranks, nor did he engage in factional intrigue upon entering court, the realm recognized his impartial integrity. Consider Zhang Shoubai, a man of uprightness, loyalty, and sincerity, who lived in quiet retirement for nearly thirty years before emerging to serve. In his time, the Filial Emperor encouraged true learning and expounded the orthodox transmission. Yet merely because imperial favor flowed toward him, he was envied. Truly, men like Kangzhai and his peers cannot be lacking. Among friends, there is no duty more pressing than mutual remembrance and encouragement—thus it was to the end.

*Hongdao Record*, Volume 27, concludes.

*Hongdao Record*, Volume 28: "Rites"

**Rites of Ruler and Minister**

*The Canon of Yao* states: "Reverent, enlightened, cultured, and thoughtful, he was sincere, respectful, and able to yield." The *Record* says: No rite surpasses reverence. Yao and Shun succeeded Heaven and established the ultimate standard. The court historian, examining antiquity and rectifying terms, called it "reverent" as a means of serving Heaven; "respectful" as a means of cultivating oneself; and "yielding" as a means of bestowing upon others. In truth, it did not exceed the single word "reverence." When Yao tested Shun, consulting on affairs and examining his words, he declared, "Your achievements are complete." After three years, he said, "You shall ascend the imperial throne." Shun deferred on account of virtue and refused to succeed. The *Record* says: Great virtue and grand enterprise—do they not indeed arise from yielding? Observing the abdication of Yao and Shun, Heaven and men alike assented, and destiny was already settled, yet they persisted in yielding without cease. Later, when Shun appointed the Nine Ministers, a flourishing spirit of deference arose. In the palace halls, bows and prostrations followed one after another, as if there were no time to rest. For when superiors cherish something, inferiors will surely cherish it even more. Yet was it true that Shun avoided Yao’s son south of the Southern River? No. At the time, it was only that Shun deferred on account of virtue and refused succession. Later, those who embellished the tale fabricated this story. Now, examining the *Canon and Counsels*, the matter is perfectly clear—there is no need to transmit doubt.

The Emperor said: "Consult the Four Peaks: Is there one who can exert himself to glorify the Emperor’s undertakings, reside in the Hundred Offices, and assist in governance with beneficent planning?" They replied in unison: "Bo Yu shall serve as Minister of Works." The Emperor said: "Good. Yu, you shall regulate the waters and lands—strive diligently in this." Yu bowed and prostrated himself, deferring to Ji, Xie, and Gao Yao. The Emperor said: "Good. Go now." The *Record* says: Shun’s deference was unnamed because the imperial position cannot be named. Yu’s deference named specific individuals because the ranks of ministers can be named. For ten thousand generations, one may envision this harmonious atmosphere—not merely taking ritual deference as the foundation of the state.

The Emperor said: "Consult the Four Peaks: Is there one who can oversee my Three Rituals?" They replied in unison: "Bo Yi." The Emperor said: "Good. Bo, you shall serve as Minister of Rites. Day and night, be reverent; be upright and pure." Bo bowed and prostrated himself, deferring to Kui and Long. The Emperor said: "Good. Go and be reverent." The *Record* says: Why does it say "be upright" and "be pure"? Uprightness means not being crooked; purity means not being muddled. The sacrifices to heavenly spirits, earthly deities, human ancestors, and ghosts all have fixed and unalterable forms, ordered and unconfused. When Emperor Zhenzong of Song falsely fabricated "Heavenly Scriptures" to deceive the Supreme Emperor, even adding honorific titles to the Jade Emperor in a disorderly fashion, he turned crooked and was not upright. When Emperor Wu of Han established the Five Emperors’ Shrine, then the Great Qi Shrine, then the Earth Goddess Shrine, all杂然并兴, he was profane and disorderly, not pure. This is why the Minister of Rites, day and night, reverently served without daring to transgress.

The Emperor composed a song, saying: "Attend to Heaven’s mandate, ever timely and subtle." He sang: "Ministers rejoice! The sovereign rises! All officials flourish!" Gao Yao bowed and prostrated himself, raising his voice: "Take heed! Lead and initiate affairs, carefully observe the statutes, and be reverent! Repeatedly examine your accomplishments, and be reverent!" Then he continued the song: "The sovereign is enlightened! The ministers are excellent! All affairs are secure!" He sang again: "The sovereign is entangled and dull! The ministers are indolent! All affairs collapse!" The Emperor bowed and said: "Good. Go and be reverent." The *Record* says: In high antiquity, when the ruler was steadfast, the ministers were exalted; when the ruler employed, the ministers carried out; when the ruler bowed, the ministers prostrated—what a magnificent atmosphere! The *Book of Changes* says: "Peace: the small departs, the great arrives—auspicious and smooth." This is when Heaven and Earth unite, and all things communicate; when superiors and inferiors unite, and their aspirations align. Since the Qin dynasty, the sole aim has been to exalt the ruler and debase the minister.
