Thereafter, there were no records of emperors bowing, no ethos of ministers rising first, no recurrence of "be reverent." The *Book of Changes* says: "Heaven and Earth do not unite—obstruction." Its consequences could not be reformed. Alas, how lamentable!

*The Lesser Odes* contains a poem for feasting guests:
*"Oh, oh! The deer cry,*
*Eating the southernwood in the wild.*
*I have fine guests—*
*Strike the zither, blow the sheng.*
*Blow the sheng, sound the reeds,*
*Present the baskets of gifts.*
*Those who cherish me*
*Show me the proper way."*

*"Oh, oh! The deer cry,*
*Eating the mugwort in the wild.*
*I have fine guests—*
*Their virtuous fame shines brightly.*
*They observe the people without frivolity,*
*And gentlemen emulate them.*
*I have excellent wine,*
*To feast and delight my guests."*

*"Oh, oh! The deer cry,*
*Eating the licorice in the wild.*
*I have fine guests—*
*Strike the zither, pluck the qin.*
*Strike the zither, pluck the qin,*
*Harmonious and joyful, deeply so.*
*I have excellent wine,*
*To feast and gladden my guests’ hearts."*

The *Record* says: In the hexagram *Yi* (Nourishment), the sage nourishes the worthy and, together with the people, shares the celestial position, allowing them to partake of Heaven’s emoluments. In the hexagram *Xu* (Waiting), the worthy embrace their virtue, calmly awaiting the right time, nourishing their bodies with food and drink, and harmonizing their hearts with feasting and music. This was the flourishing age of high antiquity, when they could nourish and employ, delighting in the worthy to the utmost. Passed down through the ages as a grand ceremony for honoring guests, our Ming dynasty has placed particular emphasis on it. All the heroic talents and epoch-making scholars of the realm emerge from this. Yet I humbly believe that the great purport of this ode lies in ensuring that private favors do not overshadow virtue, that harmony and joy do not become excessive—not merely nourishing the body or delighting the exterior. Thus, I hope that those who preside over such matters will hold this in their hearts, expecting the scholars of the realm to emulate figures like Wang Zhen and Sima Junshi. And that the scholars themselves will also hold this in their hearts, taking today’s beginning as the start of their journey, and in the future, perhaps becoming like Mingdao and Xiuwen. Only then will they understand that the court’s nurturing of true virtue is sincere, not merely seeking private favors or petty kindnesses, nor treating people with indulgent leniency.

The Zhou king, in dispatching his envoys, declared:
*"The four steeds strain their shins,
The Zhou road winds afar.
How could I not long for home?
Yet royal affairs know no rest—
My heart is grieved with sorrow.

The four steeds strain their shins,
Neighing and wearying the piebalds.
How could I not long for home?
Yet royal affairs know no rest—
No leisure to sit or stand.

The fledglings flit and flutter,
Now flying, now alighting,
Perching amid the oaks.
Yet royal affairs know no rest—
No leisure to tend my father.

The fledglings flit and flutter,
Now flying, now pausing,
Perching amid the wolfberry.
Yet royal affairs know no rest—
No leisure to tend my mother.

I harness the four piebalds,
Urging them to swiftest speed.
How could I not long for home?
Thus I compose this song,
To express my longing for my mother."*

**Recorded Annotation:**
In my humble view, the *Four Steeds* first establishes the guiding principles of the former kings, for the realm had not yet found repose.
That *"royal affairs know no rest"* awakens the realm’s loyalty.
That *"no leisure to tend my father"* awakens the realm’s filial piety.
That *"no leisure to sit or stand"* awakens the realm’s discipline.
That *"how could I not long for home?"* awakens the realm’s righteousness.
That *"to express my longing for my mother"* awakens the realm’s compassion.
Such feasting and toasting serve to awaken the realm’s propriety.
Such recitation and chanting serve to awaken the realm’s deference.
As an ode for universal use between ruler and subject, could Heaven have done this without purpose?

If one were to see this merely as a eulogy for the toil of envoys, devoid of deeper principles, then why did the *Great Learning* begin its teachings with the three *Xiao Ya* odes? Is this its true intent—or merely a fleeting embellishment?

The Zhou king, in sending forth his envoys, declared:
*"Radiant are the blossoms,
Upon that high plain.
The travelers hasten on—
Each thought falls short of duty.

My steeds are young colts,
Their six reins sleek as silk.
Now galloping, now driving—
Everywhere I seek counsel and scrutiny.

My steeds are fine unicorns,
Their six reins smooth as thread.
Now galloping, now driving—
Everywhere I seek plans and schemes.

My steeds are piebalds,
Their six reins lustrous.
Now galloping, now driving—
Everywhere I seek measures and rules.

My steeds are matched bays,
Their six reins perfectly aligned.
Now galloping, now driving—
Everywhere I seek consultation and inquiry."*

**Recorded Annotation:**
The purport of this ode serves as the Zhou dynasty’s legal standard, the minister’s moral compass, the shared principle of ruler and subject, and the unchanging norm of past and present—not merely for dispatching envoys.
When Yao spoke of *"unceasing diligence"* and Shun of *"no leisure for repose,"* how could the humble duty of a minister ever be deemed sufficient?
Thus, Yu’s *"each thought falls short"* arose from his refusal to presume.
King Wen’s *"each thought falls short"* came from his longing for the unseen Dao.
The Duke of Zhou’s *"each thought falls short"* came from his *"pondering by day and continuing by night."*
To fall short is to remain empty; to be empty is to strive ceaselessly. From this ceaseless striving arises the thoroughness of *"everywhere I seek counsel and scrutiny."*
To seek the good is *"counsel"*; to seek talent is *"scrutiny"*; to seek affairs is *"planning"*; to seek propriety is *"measure"*; to seek kinship is *"inquiry."* Though one may feel *"each thought falls short,"* still one fears losing the way.
Thus it is said: *"Everywhere"* implies broadening inquiry widely; *"seeking"* means no good word remains hidden; *"scrutiny"* ensures no worthy talent is overlooked; *"planning"* brings bright governance and beneficent policies; *"measure"* fosters virtuous deference among lords; *"inquiry"* elevates the obscure and humble. How could these be easily attained?
Yet even with such teachings, there are those who devise schemes but do not follow them, or reject the unworthy only to reuse them—criticized as Xiaohao was. There are those with *"hearts of their own,"* leading the people to madness—rebuked as the Earl of Kuang was. Alas! Where can one find ministers who *"know no rest"* to discourse with them on the meaning of *"each thought falls short"*?

The Zhou king feasted his ministers with the five odes of *"Deer Calls,"* and the ministers, receiving his grace, sang this ode in response:
*"May Heaven secure you,
Firmly and enduringly,
Making you simple and generous—
What blessing will not be bestowed?
Making you ever more abundant—
Nothing will not flourish.

May Heaven secure you,
Making your blessings bountiful.
All is fitting and right—
Receive Heaven’s hundredfold blessings.
Bestow upon you distant fortune—
Day by day, it will not suffice.

May Heaven secure you,
So that nothing does not prosper.
Like mountains, like hills,
Like ridges, like mounds,
Like rivers flowing ceaselessly—
Nothing will not increase.

With joyful feasting and laughter,
Thus we offer filial sacrifices,
Spring and autumn rites,
To the former kings and dukes.
The lord declares: *'May you live ten thousand years without end!'
The spirits attend—
We pray for your manifold blessings.
The people are sincere—
Thus we feast and drink.
All the common folk,
Revere your virtue,
Like the moon’s waxing,
Like the sun’s rising,
Like the longevity of Southern Mountain,
Unshaken, uncollapsed,
Like the flourishing of pines and cypresses—
None will not uphold you."*

Master Yang of Guishan said: *"From 'May Heaven secure you' to the rites for the former kings, this is the progression of governance. Its effects are vast. Yet in its execution, how little effort it requires—rooted solely in sincerity."*

Herein lie the odes *"Deer Calls"* and *"Four Steeds"*, among others—songs by which the former kings feasted their assembled ministers and rewarded their envoys. Were one merely to take up these verses and sing them, would their efficacy remain? Surely the former kings’ intent ran deeper.

It is recorded: Upon reading Guishan’s discourse on rooting governance in sincerity, I cannot but straighten my robe and sigh in admiration. For only when the great Dao is practiced and all under Heaven is held in common can the *"demonstration of the Zhou’s ways"* be no empty phrase. Only when the heart that cannot bear others’ suffering is extended into governance that cannot bear others’ suffering can *"the mother’s aspirations be fulfilled"* without idle words. Only when advancing the worthy is pursued as if one might fall short and following goodness is as effortless as a turning wheel can *"the inquiries and counsels of the Zhou"* be no futile labor. Only when actions arise from the heart’s spontaneity, unforced by compulsion, can *"none be like brothers"* be no mere embellishment. Only when one *"reveres your station and delights in uprightness"* can the spirits’ heeding be no hollow ritual. Then, how could ministers who receive such bounty fail to repay it with sincerity as their foundation?

The ode declares: *"Simple yet profound, ever increasing"*—words not borrowed from convention. *"Waxing like the moon, rising like the sun, steadfast as Southern Mountain, flourishing as pines and cypresses"*—phrases not born of flattery or falsehood. To take *"peace and stability as Heaven’s blessing"* is to bind Heaven’s fate with the lord’s. To take *"longevity as the spirits’ blessing"* is to join the spirits’ *qi* with the lord’s. To take *"sincerity as the people’s blessing"* is to link the people’s governance with the lord’s. Such prayers and praises have form; such vows have measure. For ten thousand generations, none who cherish their lord with loyalty can surpass this. Truly, none but the Duke of Zhou could have composed them.

When the feudal lords presented themselves at the Son of Heaven’s court, the Son of Heaven feasted them to display benevolence and grace, singing:
*"Lush the mugwort, heavy the dew—*
*Without the sun, it will not dry.*
*Long into the night we drink,*
*Till drunk, none depart."*
And again:
*"Heavy the dew on the lush grass,*
*There where the thickets grow.*
*Long into the night we drink,*
*In the ancestral temple, offerings made."*
*"Heavy the dew on the willows and thorns,*
*Radiant and true, our lord—*
*None lack noble virtue."*
*"Tung and catalpa, their fruit hangs full.*
*Joyous and gracious, our lord—*
*None lack noble bearing."*

It is recorded: The feast of *"Lush Mugwort"* demonstrates benevolence and grace. The banquet of *"Heavy Dew"* deepens kinship—what is meant by *"the lord’s ancestral temple."* Thus it says: *"In the ancestral temple, offerings made."* The meaning of the feast is this: when ministers exhaust their strength and abilities to establish merit for the state, the lord must repay them. When ministers exhaust their strength and abilities to establish merit, the state is secure and the lord at peace.

Later, when Chen Chengzhong drank with Duke Huan and said, *"I have divined for the day, but not for the night,"* it was because the ruler failed to illuminate the upright Way to guide the people, instead indulging in palace dances and drunken songs within his chambers. Was this merely the failing of a lord? His ministers were already steeped in punishment and corruption—how could one speak of such things in the same breath?

The Son of Heaven feasts meritorious feudal lords, bestowing upon them the joy of bow and arrows. The song goes:

*"The crimson bow, how lustrous!*
*Receive it and store it away.*
*I have fine guests—*
*My heart already cherishes them.*
*The bells and drums are set—*
*In a single morning, I feast them.*

*The crimson bow, how lustrous!*
*Receive it and bear it forth.*
*I have fine guests—*
*My heart delights in them.*
*The bells and drums are set—*
*In a single morning, I honor them.*

*The crimson bow, how lustrous!*
*Receive it and treasure it.*
*I have fine guests—*
*My heart holds them dear.*
*The bells and drums are set—*
*In a single morning, I intoxicate them."*

The record states: Lü of Shulai says: *"Receive it and store it away"* speaks to its weight. The bows presented by bowmakers are kept in the royal treasury, reserved for the meritorious, never lightly bestowed upon others. *"My heart already cherishes them"* speaks to its sincerity. The heart truly desires to cherish them, not from external compulsion. *"In a single morning, I feast them"* speaks to its swiftness. The bow, a treasure of the royal treasury, is raised and bestowed in a single morning, without hesitation or reluctance.

Later generations, treating the treasury as private wealth, even bestow armory weapons upon favored courtiers—this differs from *"receive it and store it away."* Rewards and gifts, if not born of genuine esteem but coerced by circumstances, may see iron charters granted in the morning and executions by evening—this differs from *"my heart already cherishes them."* Stingy with rich rewards, causing meritorious ministers to disband, even to the point of coveting profit over one’s own children—this differs from *"in a single morning, I feast them."*

The Zhou king, when feasting guests, sang:

*"Lush is the artemisia,*
*There on the central slope.*
*Now that I see this noble one,*
*Joyful and full of grace.*

*Lush is the artemisia,*
*There on the central mound.*
*Now that I see this noble one,*
*My heart is glad.*

*Lush am I,*
*There on the central ridge.*
*Now that I see this noble one,*
*He grants me a hundred strings of cowries.*

*Gently the boat drifts,*
*Now sinking, now rising.*
*Now that I see this noble one,*
*My heart is at rest."*

The record states: The *Xiao Ya*’s *"Lush Artemisia"* is to the *Xiao Ya* what the *Da Ya*’s *"Luxuriant Are the Caltrop"* is to the *Da Ya*. The *"Deer Call"* rite, a grand ceremony for receiving guests, thus features zithers, reed pipes, and baskets of offerings. This chapter’s rite, fostering amity and joy, thus overflows with delight and exuberance. The gifts of the Duke of Shao to the feudal lords encompassed all things, hence the extravagance of chariots, horses, and fine robes. This chapter’s gifts prize benevolence and worth, thus employing the metaphor of abundant cowrie shells. As for *"gently the boat drifts,"* it is akin to *"tossing and turning in longing."* *"My heart is at rest"* echoes *"King Wen is at peace."* Can one not envision the splendor of nurturing talent in that era? The *Lesser Preface* may yet offer some insight.

When the Zhou king feasted the feudal lords, he sang:

*"Flitting, the shanghu birds,*
*Bright are their feathers.*
*All noble ones rejoice—*
*They receive Heaven’s protection.*

*Flitting, the shanghu birds,*
*Bright are their necks.*
*All noble ones rejoice—*
*They are the shield of the myriad states.*

*Shield and pillar of the realm,*
*A model for all lords.*
*Neither reckless nor remiss,*
*They receive boundless blessings.*

*With rhinoceros and ox-horn cups,*
*Fine wine, mellow and mild.*
*They are sociable, not arrogant—*
*Myriad blessings come seeking them."*

The record states: Zheng’s commentary says: *"All"* means *"everyone."* To rejoice with all under Heaven is the greatest joy. When the Son of Heaven’s commands are obeyed throughout the Four Seas, all under Heaven rejoice. When a feudal lord’s commands are obeyed within his borders, with no internal or external strife, the feudal lords rejoice. When a grandee’s commands are obeyed within his office, and his counsel is heeded above, the grandee rejoices. When a knight advances with propriety and retreats with righteousness, the knight rejoices. When commoners till the fields, plant crops, and support their parents, with no punishments visited upon them, the common people rejoice. This elucidates the meaning of *"all rejoice."* If taken merely as a turn of phrase, why not simply say *"rejoice"*? Yet the poem repeatedly uses *"all rejoice"*—this cannot be dismissed lightly.

The feudal lords, in response to the *"Shanghu"* song, sang:

*"Mandarin ducks in flight,*
*Trapped in nets, enmeshed.*
*May the noble one live ten thousand years,*
*With felicitous blessings.*

*Mandarin ducks on the weir,*
*Tucking their left wings.*
*May the noble one live ten thousand years,*
*With boundless good fortune.*

*Horses in the stable,*
*Groomed and tended.*
*May the noble one live ten thousand years,*
*With blessings everlasting.*

*Horses in the stable,*
*Curried and cared for.*
*May the noble one live ten thousand years,*
*With blessings secure."*

The record states: The *"Guan! Guan!"* of the osprey takes its meaning wholly. What does *"mandarin ducks in flight"* signify? The *"White Colt"* ode extols fine virtue—what does *"horses in the stable"* extol? The *Zhu Commentary* offers no insight; the *Lesser Preface* provides no confirmation. If we follow the preface’s claim that ancient enlightened kings engaged with all things in accordance with the Dao, then it should resemble the kite soaring to the heavens—each thing following its nature. Thus, *"trapped in nets, enmeshed"* does not mean waiting for them to grow large enough to fly before trapping them, but rather that engaging with all things follows the Dao. Yet to say that self-restraint is likened to grooming and tending horses—this is far-fetched indeed. Such interpretations cannot be forced.

When the Son of Heaven feasted the feudal lords, the feudal lords praised the Son of Heaven with this poem:

*"Fish among the waterweeds,*
*With heads so plump.*
*The king in his capital—*
*How joyful the drinking feast!*

*Fish among the waterweeds,*
*With tails so sleek.*
*The king in his capital—*
*Drinking wine, joyful indeed.*

*Fish among the waterweeds,*
*Sheltered by the reeds.*
*The king in his capital—*
*His dwelling so serene."*

The record states: This poem first says, *"The king in his capital—how joyful the drinking feast!"* and later, *"The king in his capital—his dwelling so serene."* From its words, one glimpses the atmosphere of effortless governance, perfectly aligned with the spirit of Shun’s *"reverent self-cultivation while facing south."* Otherwise, would ministers take warning and instead offer praise?

Some have said: The king cherishes his people, so the people delight in his joy, and the king in turn partakes of this joy. This is the very meaning expressed in the poem. This, too, must not be overlooked.

The Son of Heaven’s response to *"Fish among the Waterweeds"* is thus:

*"Gather the beans, gather the beans,*
*In baskets round and baskets square.*
*When lords come to court,*
*What gifts shall I bestow?*

*Though I grant them nothing,*
*There are chariots and teams of four.*
*And what more shall I give?*
*Black robes and fish-skin sashes.*

*Bubbling springs, brimming streams—*
*They gather the water celery.*
*When lords come to court,*
*Behold their banners’ sway.*

*Their banners ripple and gleam,*
*With ringing bells so clear.*
*With harnessed teams they come,*
*Where the lord alights.*

*Crimson knee-covers on their thighs,*
*Cross-gartered leggings below.*
*No sloth nor slackness in their stride—*
*Such are the Son of Heaven’s gifts.*

*Joyful are these lords,*
*For the Son of Heaven commands them.*
*Joyful are these lords,*
*As blessings and fortune renew."*

The record states: This was during King Wu’s selection of the capital at Hao—when lord and minister rejoiced together, a scene that remains vivid for ten thousand generations. *"What gifts shall I bestow?"*—how profound the ruler’s affection! *"No sloth nor slackness in their stride"*—how solemn the subjects’ reverence! Contrast this with King Hui, who later bestowed measures of gold upon Zheng only to be despised in return, or with Duke Wei of Qi, who came to court at Zhou only to be humiliated—how different from *"what gifts shall I bestow?"* or *"no sloth nor slackness in their stride!"*

When King Xuan commanded Duke Mu of Shao to pacify the Yi tribes of Huainan, the poets praised him. This is the text of the king’s decree:

*"Receive this jade libation cup,*
*With millet wine so pure.*
*Proclaim it to your ancestors,*
*And I grant you hills and fields.*

*From Zhou you take your charge,*
*From the Duke of Shao your mandate."*

The tiger-like lord bows, kowtowing—*"May the Son of Heaven live ten thousand years!"* The tiger-like lord bows, kowtowing—*"In response, I extol the king’s grace!"*
*"Compose this for the late Duke of Shao—*
*May the Son of Heaven live ten thousand autumns!"*
*"Radiant is the Son of Heaven,*
*Whose illustrious fame knows no end.*
*He displays his cultured virtue,*
*And brings harmony to these four lands."*

The Record states: *"First it says 'the tiger-like lord bows,' then again 'the tiger-like lord bows'—*after King Li of Zhou, the royal house gradually declined, until King Xuan internally reformed governance and externally repelled the Yi and Di barbarians, reviving the royal house with sudden vigor. The Sage inscribed this in the Classics. Thus, as for this Lord Shao Hu, his glory surpassed that of Duke Kang, his renown illuminated the land of Yan, and his deeds could not be erased. Yet when Sima Qian composed the *Hereditary House of Yan*, from Duke Shao downward through nine generations to Marquis Hui, the name of Shao Hu nowhere appeared. In the thirty-sixth year of King Xuan’s reign, when Marquis Li died, no record of his border-settling deeds was found. Still, this cannot be taken as conclusive. Yet when the *Preface to the Odes* lists the genealogies of the states, it again follows Sima Qian’s account. Examining the *Odes*, the *Jiang Han* section remains, but the *Preface* entirely lacks the name of Shao Hu—how is this to be explained? If only we could grasp the intent behind the Master’s editing to correct Sima Qian’s errors, it would be a blessing not merely for Shao Hu alone.

The *Analects* records the Master saying: *"To bow below is ritual propriety. Now to bow above is arrogance. Though it goes against the multitude, I follow the lower way."* The Record states: This was Confucius’ principle for serving a lord, perfectly embodying the family tradition of the tiger-like lord’s bow. After the decline of Zhou, the court audience rites fell into disuse, and the king would descend the hall to receive the feudal lords. When Duke Huan of Qi became hegemon, the Son of Heaven sent Steward Kong to bestow a jade tablet upon the Marquis of Qi, saying: *"The Son of Heaven, considering his uncle’s advanced age and accumulated labors, grants him one rank—no need to descend in obeisance."* This was no small lapse.

Our Master established the eternal standard for the relationship between ruler and minister, his brilliance rivaling sun and moon. In composing the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, every word and meaning embodied acts that defied the multitude—even the great worthies Ziyou and Zixia could not fully grasp them, let alone ordinary men. When he trod this path, it was like the distinction between heaven above and marsh below, the very means by which the noble man discerns high and low and stabilizes the people’s will—far beyond mere questions of minor compliance or defiance.

Some may ask: Then why did Duke Huan decline Steward Kong’s offer and descend in obeisance? Why does this record not mention it? The answer is that Duke Huan merely feigned it. His false benevolence, false righteousness, and false trustworthiness were but a pretense of ritual propriety. Even Steward Kong could not be deceived—how could a noble man be so misled?

The Master said: *"If one can govern the state through ritual propriety and deference, what difficulty would there be? If one cannot govern through ritual propriety and deference, what use is ritual propriety?"*

The Record states: The Master once mocked Zilu, saying: *"To govern through ritual propriety—yet his words lack deference."* Ritual propriety is the great guiding principle of statecraft, while deference arises from the single thought of humility in one’s heart, a principle of unceasing modesty. Observe how our Master, upon arriving in any state, would invariably inquire about its governance, saying it was attained through *"warmth, goodness, reverence, frugality, and deference"*—what a magnificent bearing! Without the genuine spirit of unceasing humility, no matter how many measures and arrangements one implements, it would be no more than what Steward Kong mocked: though it might be called ritual propriety at the time, the great root and essential integrity would vanish in an instant.

Consider how King Tai of the fading Yu state, upon entering the domain of the Earl of the West, witnessed such deference: plowmen yielding field boundaries, travelers yielding the road, and in his court, officers yielding to grandees, grandees yielding to ministers. These were the concrete realities of governing through ritual propriety. How could the rulers of the two states not feel themselves small and base, filled with shame and remorse, sighing without end—and what leisure would they have for conflict? Thus, over forty states came to submit upon hearing of it, and what difficulty remained?

The Master said: *"To serve one’s lord with utmost ritual propriety—others consider it sycophancy."*

The Record states: This does not refer to serving the lord of Lu. Serving the lord of Lu with utmost ritual propriety was never deemed sycophancy; rather, it concerns serving the enfeebled Zhou king. At the time, the world regarded it as commonplace, yet our Master alone defied the multitude by bowing below, lamenting that it was not even found among the Xia states. Consider his desire to preserve the starving sheep for the *Gao* sacrifice—even his disciples like Zigong disapproved. Was this not what others deemed sycophancy?

Elsewhere, he said: *"If someone were to employ me, I would restore Zhou to its eastern capital."* This, too, was not for Lu’s sake. Let the reader examine this closely.

Entering the palace gate, he bowed deeply as though there were no room for him. He did not stand in the center of the gate nor tread upon the threshold when passing the ruler’s seat. His countenance grew solemn, his steps quickened. His speech seemed halting, as if inadequate. Gathering his robes to ascend the hall, he bowed again, holding his breath as though scarcely breathing. Descending one step, his expression relaxed into ease. At the final stair, he hastened forward with wings outspread. Returning to his position, he settled with measured steps.

On auspicious months, he always wore court dress to attend court. When the ruler bestowed food, he straightened his mat and tasted it first. When granted raw meat, he cooked it and offered it in sacrifice. When given a living creature, he reared it. While dining with the ruler, he ate only after the ruler had made his offering.

If the ruler fell ill and visited him, he bound his hair, donned his court robe, and draped his sash. When summoned by the ruler’s command, he did not wait for his carriage but set out at once.

The Record states: These were Confucius’ rituals in serving the lord of Lu. The relationship between ruler and minister is founded on reverence; the rites of the court are founded on respect. This chapter, like a measure with its standard or a compass with its model, permits no deviation by a hair’s breadth nor a step’s transgression. Is this not the great boundary for all ages?

The *Family Sayings* records: Duke Ding of Lu met with the Marquis of Qi at Jiagu. Confucius, acting as steward, arrived at the meeting site and prepared an altar with three tiers of earthen steps, where they exchanged courtesies and ascended with bows. After the exchange of toasts, the Qi sent men of Lai to coerce the Duke of Lu with weapons. Confucius ascended the steps and advanced, shielding the duke, saying: “Soldiers! Our two lords meet in friendship—how dare these barbarian captives disrupt it with arms? This is not how the Marquis of Qi commands the feudal lords. The outlying tribes do not scheme against the Central States; the Yi do not disturb Hua; captives do not disrupt covenants; weapons do not initiate amity. To the spirits, this is inauspicious; to virtue, it is a breach of righteousness; to men, it is a breach of ritual. The lord would surely not allow this.” The Marquis of Qi, disconcerted, waved them away.

After a while, Qi performed the palace music, with jesters and dwarves cavorting before them. Confucius strode forward and said: “For commoners to delude and insult the feudal lords is a crime deserving execution. Let the Right Marshal swiftly carry out the punishment.” The Marquis of Qi, alarmed, showed signs of remorse.

When the Marquis of Qi prepared to hold a banquet, Confucius addressed Liang Qiu Ju, saying: “As for the old customs between Qi and Lu, I have never heard of such a thing. The affair is already concluded, and now you would feast us—this is overburdening the attendants. Moreover, sacrificial vessels do not leave the gate, and fine music is not performed in the wilds. If the feast is fully prepared, it is a waste of ritual; if it is not, it is a display of meanness. The lord’s disgrace in abandoning ritual and earning ill repute—why not reconsider?” Thus, the banquet did not take place.

The Marquis of Qi returned and reproached his ministers, saying: “Lu employs the Way of the noble man to assist its lord, while you alone have instructed me in the ways of the Yi and Di barbarians, causing me to incur offense.” Thereupon, he returned the four towns of Lu he had seized, along with the fields of Wenyang.

The Record states: Someone asked, “If Confucius had lived in the time of Duke Huan and Duke Wen, what then?” The reply: “Kingship and hegemony differ by the slightest degree.” Thus Master Cheng said: “With sincerity of heart, one may be a true king; with pretense, one may only be a hegemon. Though the two paths diverge, the difference lies solely in their beginnings.”

From today’s vantage, consider this: governing the tribes of the remote borderlands—Confucius could have done it, and so too could an ordinary man. Rejecting the jesters’ insults—Confucius could have done it, and so too could an ordinary man. Canceling the banquet—Confucius could have done it, and so too could an ordinary man. Yet when it came to his sincerity in service, he invariably employed the noble man’s Way to assist and counsel his lord. In his sincerity of planning, he invariably possessed the full preparation of civil and martial arts to manage affairs. Even in the words of covenants and assemblies, his genuine heart and substantive deeds inspired awe. From beginning to end, his conduct and bearing were wholly rooted in human sentiment and aligned with the Great Dao, never resorting to pretense.

The failure to present the bundled reeds as tribute, the pledge to attack Yuan as a demonstration of trust—such words commanded belief and obedience, leading to the return of the seized towns. All this arose from the power of sincerity, unlike Chu’s superficial compliance or Jin’s forced submission. Thus, who but a sage could have achieved this? Hence it is said: “The disciples of Confucius never spoke of the deeds of Huan and Wen.”

*Hongdao Lu*, Scroll Twenty-Eight, concludes.

*Hongdao Lu*, Scroll Twenty-Nine: “Rites.”

**The Rites of Ruler and Minister**

According to the *Records of the Grand Historian*, when Han Xin first joined Liu Bang, he frequently conversed with Chancellor Xiao He. Xiao He marveled at him and recommended him to the king, who then appointed him as grand general. When the time came to formally invest him, Xiao He said: “The king has long been careless and discourteous. If you now appoint a grand general as if summoning a child, this is precisely why Xin would leave. If you truly wish to appoint him, you must choose an auspicious day, fast and purify yourself, erect an altar, and perform the full rites—only then will it be proper.” The Han king agreed. All the generals rejoiced, each believing he would be named grand general. When the investiture took place and the command was bestowed, it was Han Xin—everyone in the army was astonished.

*Recorded*: Emperor Gaozu was not learned in letters, yet by nature he was perceptive and astute, as seen in this instance. How many times had he mocked scholars, belittled the literati, and favored fine horses, unaware of their worth? Had he slighted Xiao He’s counsel and treated the matter as child’s play, no one would have altered their view, the generals would not have submitted, and the king would not have recognized Xin’s merit. Had he acted too late, with whom could he have contended for the realm? This moment of command hinged on a single turning point. Though it did not fully embody the rites of the Three Dynasties, it was nonetheless rare for its time. Thus, it is recorded.

After the Han king became Son of Heaven, he abolished the harsh ceremonies of Qin and simplified the laws. When his ministers drank together to boast of their achievements, some became drunk and shouted wildly, even drawing swords to strike the pillars. The emperor grew increasingly displeased. Shusun Tong then advised: “The Confucians are difficult to employ in times of conquest, but they may be relied upon to preserve what has been achieved. I wish to summon the scholars of Lu and, together with my disciples, establish court rituals.” The emperor said: “Will it not be difficult?” Tong replied: “The Five Emperors had different music, and the Three Kings had distinct rites. Both were shaped by the times and the sentiments of the people. I wish to draw from ancient rites and blend them with Qin’s ceremonies.” The emperor said: “Try it, but make it easy to understand and within my capacity to perform.”

Two scholars from Lu refused to go, saying: “Now that the realm has just been pacified, the dead remain unburied, and the wounded have not yet risen. How can you establish rites and music? Rites and music arise only after a hundred years of accumulated virtue.” Shusun laughed and said: “These rustic scholars know nothing of adapting to the times.” He then proceeded west with the thirty scholars he had summoned. Together with the emperor’s attendants and over a hundred of their disciples, they practiced the rituals in the open fields beyond the capital.

*Recorded*: Observing the transition from Qin’s fall to Han’s rise, one finds these two scholars from Lu—who would say that phoenixes and unicorns are not seen in a land that upholds ritual? The standard of the Confucians is none other than the Zhou and Confucius. Confucius said: “If there were a true king, it would take a generation for benevolence to flourish.” The rites and music of the Zhou dynasty were only established after the Duke of Zhou’s efforts—truly, what is meant by “a hundred years of accumulated virtue.” Yet the institutions of the blazing Han, which did not arise from even a foot of land or the founding of a royal legacy, differ entirely from those built through accumulated merit and gradual transformation. Though Gaozu was magnanimous and broad-minded, his virtue had not yet permeated to the marrow; though he had eliminated cruelty and tyranny, his blessings had not yet reached the august heavens. Even his son, Emperor Wen, was not without misgivings, and his grandson, Emperor Guangwu, was no better equipped. The rites and music of the Han, as the two scholars lamented, were already beyond redemption.

Some critics merely sigh over Jia Yi’s pleas before the likes of Zhou Bo and Guan Ying, or the debates on literature that fell short at the court of Prince Liu De. Yet they fail to see that those summoned were men like Gongsun Hong, Ni Kuan, or Zhufu Yan—men like Gongsun Qing, Hu Sui, or Sima Qian. Had such figures been chosen by the two emperors to establish the institutions of the age, they would have done no more than follow Shusun Tong’s precedent—how could they have laid the foundation for rites and music? Thus, were these two scholars not merely the most eminent in Lu, but also the phoenixes and unicorns of the Han, never to be seen again?

When the Changle Palace was completed, the feudal lords and ministers attended court using Shusun Tong’s new rituals. At dawn, the masters of ceremonies arranged the order of entry. The palace courtyard was lined with chariots, cavalry, guards, and officials; weapons were displayed, and banners unfurled. The meritorious ministers and marquises stood in order, facing east on the western side, while the civil officials, from the chancellor downward, stood facing west on the eastern side. The grand procession was conducted with nine attendants announcing the ranks. Then the emperor emerged from the chamber, and the officials bearing halberds relayed the alert. The feudal kings and officials down to those of the two-thousand-bushel rank were led in to offer their congratulations. From the feudal kings downward, none failed to tremble with awe and reverence. When the rites were completed, all prostrated themselves. A banquet was held, and as the ministers sat in attendance, all in the hall bowed low, their heads lowered in accordance with rank. The toasts began with the most senior, and nine rounds of libations were offered. When the master of ceremonies declared the proceedings concluded, the wine officers and censors enforced the rules, removing anyone who violated the etiquette. Throughout the entire court banquet, no one dared to raise their voice or act improperly.

Emperor Gaozu rejoiced, saying: “Only today do I know the true dignity of being emperor.”

*Recorded*: The emperor once gazed upon the First Emperor of Qin and said: “A true man should be like this.” Now he praised Shusun Tong, saying: “Only today do I know the true nobility of the emperor.” Observing the grandeur of the occasion, it was indeed impressive. Yet it lacked the profound virtue of Yao and Shun, and how could it compare to the solemn trust of the Three Kings?

In the eighth year of Empress Lü, on the *jiyou* day of the ninth month, the chancellor, Lord Ping; the grand commandant, Lord Bo; the grand general, Lord Wu; the censor-in-chief, Lord Cang; the minister of the imperial clan, Lord Ying; the Marquis of Zhuxu, Lord Zhang; the Marquis of Dongmou, Lord Xing; and the superintendent of guests, Lord Jie, bowed twice and addressed the court: “The sons of the late Emperor Hui, such as Zihong, are not his true heirs and should not succeed to the ancestral temple.” They respectfully requested that the court, along with the marquises and officials of the two-thousand-bushel rank, deliberate on the matter. “The Prince of Langye is the son of the High Emperor and should be the successor. We humbly request that Your Highness ascend the throne as Son of Heaven.” The Prince of Dai replied: “To uphold the ancestral temple of the High Emperor is a weighty matter.”

"I am unworthy and insufficient for such a role. I wish to consult the King of Chu on what is appropriate."

"I dare not accept."

All the ministers prostrated themselves and firmly insisted. The Prince of Dai declined three times facing west and twice facing south. Chancellor Ping and the others all said: "We have carefully considered this: Your Highness is most fitting to uphold the ancestral temple of the High Emperor. Even all the feudal lords and the myriad people deem it proper. We, for the sake of the ancestral temple and the altars of the state, dare not be negligent. We humbly beseech Your Highness to graciously heed our plea and receive the imperial seal and tokens."

They bowed twice and presented them.

The Prince of Dai said: "The imperial kinsmen, generals, kings, and marquises all deem it fitting for me. I dare not decline."

Thereupon, he ascended the throne as Son of Heaven.

*Recorded:* Observing the rites of welcoming the Prince of Dai, one may perceive the grandeur of the Great Han’s qi. For it was Bo who welcomed the Emperor, and it was Wen who declined the throne—thus one knows that a ruler cannot be forced. Zihong remained within, while the Prince of Dai was without—thus one knows that a son cannot be merely nominal. That very night, he entered the Weiyang Palace and sat upon the front hall—thus one knows that the beginning must not be improper. Upholding the ancestral temple of the High Emperor, all the feudal lords and the myriad people deemed it proper—thus one knows that the succession must be grand. This is the principle of the *Spring and Autumn Annals*.

By the time of Huo Guang, he dispatched the Minister of the Imperial Clan to welcome the great-grandson to fast at the Minister’s residence. The next day, he entered the Weiyang Palace, was enfeoffed as the Marquis of Wuyang, and later ascended the imperial throne. Even if there had been three refusals facing east and two facing south, where could they have been applied? Here, the rhetoric grew more elaborate, yet the rites became more obstructed, and the qi was even less harmonious.

After the Emperor ascended the throne, when the Marquis of Jiang, having concluded his court audience, hastened out, the Emperor treated him with great reverence, often watching him depart. The Gentleman of the Palace, Yuan Ang of Anling, admonished: "The Lü clan acted with rebellion, and the great ministers jointly executed them. At that time, the Chancellor served as Grand Commandant, holding military authority, and merely happened to achieve success. Now, if the Chancellor displays arrogance toward his lord while Your Majesty practices humility, both ruler and minister失礼. I humbly submit that this is not befitting for Your Majesty."

In the next court session, the Emperor became more solemn, and the Chancellor grew more respectful.

*Recorded:* This worthy ruler, humble and frugal, deferential in ritual—how different from Huo Guang, whose carriage jolted while Emperor Xuan felt the sting of thorns on his back! Yet it is regrettable that his minister, Yuan Ang, could not fully expand the principle of reverent yielding, instead warning against arrogance toward the ruler. Though his lord possessed the innate qualities of Yao and Shun, he could not overcome the vulgar customs of Han and Peng, ultimately suffering arrest, humiliation, and execution—was this not set in motion by Yuan Ang’s words?

Alas! With the Emperor’s utmost sincerity in governing his ministers, Bo’s long-standing gravity and reputation, such solemn respect at the outset, and yet such self-destruction in the end—how can later generations of rulers and ministers hope to remain blameless from beginning to end? It is indeed far beyond reach.

The Emperor heard that the Governor of Henan, Lord Wu, was renowned as the finest administrator in the realm and summoned him to serve as Chief Justice. Lord Wu recommended Jia Yi of Luoyang, and the Emperor summoned him to serve as an Academician. At the time, Jia Yi was just over twenty years old. The Emperor admired his eloquence and erudition, promoting him within a year to Grand Master of Palace Counsel.

Jia Yi proposed revising the calendar, changing the colors of court robes, standardizing official titles, and reviving ritual and music to establish Han institutions and reform Qin laws. The Emperor, practicing humility, had no leisure for such matters.

*Recorded:* This resembles the hexagram *Xiǎo Chù* (Small Accumulation), where the firm strength of *Qián* is restrained by the yielding compliance of *Xùn*. The Sage appended to it the words: "Dense clouds, no rain, from our western suburbs." For only when yin and yang harmonize does rain descend; just as only when superiors and inferiors cooperate do achievements come to fruition. The Emperor held the power of institution-making yet remained content with humility and inaction. Jia Yi possessed the talent for action yet was misled by his youth and reputation for causing trouble. Was this not because Heaven had not yet willed the pacification of the realm?

Yet the noble man who cultivates literary virtue—surely the enterprise of moral transformation and governance is not the work of a single morning or evening. Did Confucius not say: "Without ceasing, one has no position; ceasing is how one establishes oneself. Without ceasing, none know one; strive to be known"? Had Jia Yi embraced this principle, devoted himself to obscurity and concealment, and awaited the accumulation and gradual application of his talents, would he not have achieved great accumulation? Few sagely rulers have risen to power through military means.

Why, at just over twenty years of age, did he indulge in such bitter lamentation and self-pity, composing the *Fu on the Owl* and *Lament for Qu Yuan*? Was this not too hasty? This was his shortcoming, not something others resented.

In Jia Yi’s *Memorial on Ensuring Peace*, he wrote: "The ruler’s dignity is like a hall; the ministers are like the steps; the common people are like the ground. Thus, if the steps have nine levels, with their edges far from the ground, the hall is high. If the steps have no levels, with their edges near the ground, the hall is low. The high are difficult to climb; the low are easily overrun—this is the natural principle. Therefore, the ancient sage-kings established ranks: internally, there were dukes, ministers, and grand masters; externally, there were dukes, marquises, earls, viscounts, and barons. Then came officials, teachers, petty clerks, and finally the common people—all with clearly defined ranks, above which stood the Son of Heaven. Thus, his dignity was unattainable.

A village proverb says: 'One hesitates to throw something at a rat for fear of damaging the vessel.' This is a fine analogy. If one fears damaging the vessel when the rat is near, how much more should one fear when it comes to noble ministers near the ruler? I have heard that even fine shoes are not placed upon a pillow, and even a worn-out hat is not set upon shoes. Once a man has occupied a position of honor and favor, the Son of Heaven alters his countenance to treat him with ritual courtesy, and the people bow in reverence and awe. If he later commits an offense, it is proper to dismiss him, demote him, grant him death, or execute him. But to bind him, beat him, send him to the judicial authorities, or conscript him as a convict, with petty officials cursing and flogging him—this is hardly how one should let the masses see him."

Those of lowly status, accustomed to seeing the honored in their moment of favor, may think, *"I too could be treated thus,"*—this is hardly the way to foster reverence for the noble and esteem for the exalted. In ancient times, when high ministers were dismissed for corruption, it was not called corruption but *"lack of propriety in conduct and demeanor."* When they were removed for lewdness and debauchery, with no distinction between men and women, it was not called lewdness but *"neglect of the inner chambers."* When they were relieved for incompetence and feebleness, it was not called incompetence but *"failure in office."* The ruler established the norms of integrity, shame, ritual, and righteousness in his treatment of ministers, yet if a minister did not repay his sovereign with conduct befitting his station, he was no better than a beast. Thus, when transformation was complete and customs were settled, ministers would weigh their conduct and forget profit, uphold their integrity and submit to righteousness—such men could be entrusted with unsupervised authority or the guardianship of an orphaned heir. This was the result of fostering incorruptibility, integrity, and the practice of ritual and righteousness. To abandon this and persist in that is truly cause for long sighs.

I, Jia Yi, have noted that when the Marquis of Jiang was previously arrested and imprisoned, no crime was ever proven. Thus, I used this to admonish the emperor, who deeply accepted my words and thereafter treated his ministers with measured dignity. From then on, high ministers guilty of offenses were no longer subjected to corporal punishment.

It is recorded: Jia Yi’s words proved prescient, and the emperor took them to heart. Why not say: *"Was Wu Gong’s governance not the finest in the realm?"* Had the emperor held Wu Gong accountable for the policies previously proposed, and had those policies failed, the blame would have fallen on the one who recommended them. The court rituals of the Han were not yet so crude as this. The era was not far removed from antiquity, and those who could still discern the application of the *Rites of Zhou* were not lacking. Yet later, as dynasties changed and calendars were altered, as robes and colors diverged, the names of offices, rituals, and music of old could no longer be seen in later ages. Is this not the greatest regret of a thousand generations—and the unforgivable sin of men like Jiang and Guan?

When Jia Tujia served as Chancellor, Deng Tong was deeply favored, showered with gifts worth tens of millions, and enjoyed unparalleled imperial affection. Once, as Jia entered court, Deng stood beside the emperor, displaying insolent disrespect. Jia memorialized: *"If Your Majesty favors and honors your ministers, bestow upon them wealth and rank. But court ritual must not be neglected."* After the audience, Jia sat in his office and issued a summons ordering Deng to appear at the Chancellor’s residence, warning that failure to comply would mean execution. Deng, terrified, appealed to the emperor, who said: *"Go at once."* Deng arrived at the Chancellor’s residence, removed his cap, and prostrated himself barefoot, kowtowing in apology. Jia remained seated, offering no courtesy, and rebuked him: *"The court is the court of the High Emperor. You, a petty official, dared to jest in the palace hall—this is grave disrespect, punishable by beheading."* The clerks prepared to carry out the sentence. Deng kowtowed until his forehead bled, but Jia did not relent. The emperor, judging that the Chancellor had sufficiently humbled Deng, dispatched an envoy with the imperial tally to summon him, then sent word to Jia: *"This is my plaything; spare him."* When Deng returned, he wept before the emperor: *"The Chancellor nearly killed me."*

It is recorded: Observing Jia Tujia’s conduct, one may yet speak of the rituals of the Han court. The emperor’s favored jesters were the recipients of his arbitrary favor. Petitions flowed from their gates, and their words carried the weight of influence. Had high ministers been weak, many would have bowed before them. Yet Jia, though but a single man of upright virtue, could correct court ritual and suppress disloyal impulses. How could the emperor’s governance have remained so negligent? By the time Dong Xian usurped the position of the Three Dukes and severed the line of imperial succession, all beneath the throne willingly submitted—how could one have held fast to principle then? Though schools flourished and the *Biyong* academy stood, none could speak of ritual in that age.

During Emperor Wu’s reign, the Grand General Wei Qing was greatly favored, sometimes attending the emperor as a chamberlain. The emperor once sat on the privy to receive him. When Chancellor Hong visited the emperor in private, he sometimes did so without his cap. But when Ji An came to court, he would not appear before the emperor without his cap. Once, the emperor sat in a military tent, and Ji An approached to present a memorial. Seeing Ji, the emperor, who was not wearing his cap, retreated behind the curtain and had an attendant approve the memorial. Such was the respect and courtesy he commanded.

It is recorded: Here one sees the emperor’s innate goodness—what is called *"knowing without learning, capable without deliberation."* It was not the result of forced effort. Had he extended this heart and cultivated it, he could have served the Supreme Emperor. Alas, he could not attend to the finer details and expand upon them. Envious of Tang’s virtue, the emperor’s heart was lost. This is the common failing of the Han and Tang dynasties and beyond. How could *"sincere reverence and yielding"* not become rare and unheard of?

In the fifth year of the Yuanshuo era, an edict proclaimed: *"I have heard that the people are guided by ritual and inspired by music. Now ritual is ruined and music has collapsed—I grieve deeply. Let the ritual officials observe music and revive ritual, setting an example for the realm."* Thereupon, Chancellor Hong and others memorialized, requesting the establishment of the office of Academician, with fifty disciples exempted from corvée and supported by the Court of Sacrifices. They selected commoners aged eighteen and above, of upright bearing, to become Academicians’ disciples, studying under the Court of Sacrifices. Those who mastered even one art would be appointed as Literary Attendants. Exceptional talents would be reported by name. The emperor approved.

From then on, the ranks of dukes, ministers, and officials flourished with men of learning.

It is recorded: Early in Emperor Wu’s reign, he had once promoted Zhao Wan and Wang Zang, but when the Empress Dowager disapproved of the Ru scholars, they were dismissed. He had also summoned men of learning and talent from across the realm, but when Sima Xiangru’s rhapsodies and Dongfang Shuo’s jests prevailed, the effort stalled. Now, seeking to guide the people with ritual and set an example for the realm, this was the moment for Shen Gong’s ideals to be realized. Yet how could Hong’s establishment of Academicians’ disciples and Literary Attendants—though numerous—serve any purpose? Had Jia Yi still lived and been entrusted with his words on transforming customs and turning the realm toward the Dao, would not governance have approached perfection, surpassing even the institutions of the Taichu era?

Alas! Had the Lord of Changsha (Jia Yi) not passed away, the rise of heterodox learning might have been averted. Instead, men like Gongsun Qing and Hu Sui were left to advance their proposals, and the discourse on origins and beginnings became but a lengthy exposition.

Alas! The *Treatise on Ritual* states: When Emperor Wu ascended the throne, he summoned scholars of the Ru tradition to jointly establish ceremonial norms, yet after more than a decade, nothing was accomplished. Some claimed that in ancient times, when the realm was at peace and the people harmonious and joyful, auspicious omens would arrive in abundance, and only then were customs surveyed and institutions established. Upon hearing this, the Emperor issued an edict. The Imperial Censor remarked: "Those who receive the Mandate to rule each arise from different origins, taking divergent paths yet converging upon the same end. This is to say, institutions are created in response to the people and customs are followed in their formation."

The discussants all extolled the distant past, asking what the common people could hope for. Yet the Han was but one dynasty among many—if its canonical laws were not transmitted, what would become of its descendants? Where transformation runs deep, the scope is vast; where governance is shallow, it is narrow. Could they not strive for more? Thus, in the first year of the Taichu era, the calendar was reformed, colors of attire altered, Mount Tai enfeoffed, and the rituals of ancestral temples and the hundred officials established as enduring norms, bequeathed to posterity.

The record states: In my view, the words of the Ru scholars during Emperor Wu’s reign were how misguided! The Han had endured for nearly a century by then, and the people had grown pure and honest, nearly to the point where punishments could be set aside. Even if the two Masters (Yan Hui and Min Ziqian) were to return, this would have been an opportune moment for action—why then did each man advance his own theories?

At that time, Xu Le and Ni Kuan could be said to have spoken wisely. Xu Le declared: "The sagely ruler alone perceives the source of the myriad transformations." Ni Kuan said: "The Son of Heaven establishes the ultimate mean of central harmony, unifying and governing all things with the resonance of metal and jade." Yet due to the Emperor’s many desires, these consultations dragged on for over a decade without resolution. Still, the calendar was reformed to follow the Xia system, and the errors of Qin customs were decisively corrected. From this, one may see the grandeur of his vision and strategy, which cannot be mentioned in the same breath as the petty institutions of later times.

During the reign of Emperor Xuan, the remonstrance official Wang Ji submitted a memorial: "Your Majesty, in contemplating the affairs of the age, seeks to usher in an era of Great Peace. Each time an edict is issued, the people rejoice as if reborn. In my humble reflection, this may be called the utmost benevolence, yet it cannot be deemed the foundation of governance. Rulers who aspire to order do not appear in every generation. Though the high ministers are fortunate to encounter such a time, with their words heeded and remonstrances accepted, none have yet devised a strategy to endure for ten thousand generations or elevated a brilliant ruler to the glory of the Three Dynasties. Their efforts remain confined to trivial matters—reviewing documents, adjudicating cases, and hearing lawsuits. This is not the foundation of Great Peace.

I have heard that for pacifying the realm and governing the people, nothing surpasses ritual. Thus, when a true king has not yet established new rites, he adopts those of former kings that are suitable for the present. I hope Your Majesty will expound upon the old rituals, clarify the institutions of the former kings, and guide the people of this generation into the realm of benevolence and longevity. Then how could customs fail to equal those of Cheng and Kang, or longevity fall short of that of Gaozong?"

The Emperor deemed his words impractical and grandiose, and Wang Ji soon retired on grounds of illness.

The record states: That Wang Ji’s memorial ends thus is because when the world is on the verge of order, ritual and music serve a practical purpose; when the world is in decline, they become empty formalities. Emperor Xuan’s praise for Wang Cheng, his rewards for Huang Ba, and his meticulous scrutiny of names and realities—what did these have to do with reviving old rituals and clarifying the institutions of former kings? Instead, he dismissed them as "impractical."

By the time of Emperor Cheng, when he established the *Biyong* academy, set up schools, and displayed the rituals of bowing and yielding in cap and gown, what benefit did it bring? From this, one understands that the inability to keep pace with urgent matters, while pursuing grand and distant schemes, is the true essence of a ruler’s aspiration for order. Conversely, the fuss over ritual details when the vital energy is already depleted is but the trivial pursuit of a declining age.

*The Comprehensive Mirror* records: In the fifth year of the Jianwu era, the Imperial Academy was established. When the Emperor returned to inspect it, he found the ancient models restored, rituals and music flourishing, and cultural refinements worthy of admiration.

The record states: In the fourth year of the Yuanshi era of Emperor Ping, the *Biyong* academy was also established. Yet this is not recorded. Why is that recorded here?

Emperor Guangwu was determined to revive the ancient rites, establishing schools within the court and summoning recluses from without—all things the Western Han had lacked the leisure to accomplish. Moreover, to have done so amid the chaos of war and the rampant depredations of bandits was indeed commendable. Yet the Emperor had studied in his youth with Yan Guang, and when he sought him out, he found him no ordinary man; all who knew him held him in reverence and trust. Why, then, did he not appoint him to teach at the Imperial Academy? One sovereign, one master—matched in virtue, their fellowship would have been beyond compare. Instead, he conferred upon him the post of *Lianyi* (Consultant). What manner of paragon was this to serve as the age’s teacher? In my humble view, none surpassed Yan Guang.

In the first month of the first year of the Zhanghe era of Emperor Xiaozong, Cao Bao was summoned to the Gate of Auspicious Virtue and ordered to take the twelve chapters of the *Han Rites* compiled by Ban Gu (following Shusun Tong’s model) and revise them. The Emperor admonished him: “These regulations are fragmentary and largely inconsistent with the classics. Now you must correct them according to ritual principles so they may be implemented.” Cao Bao was then sent to the Eastern Pavilion of the Southern Palace to devote himself wholeheartedly to the task. Having received the mandate, he arranged the ritual matters in order, drawing on ancient precedents and interweaving texts from the Five Classics and apocryphal prophecies. He compiled regulations for the Son of Heaven down to the common people, covering capping, marriage, auspicious and inauspicious occasions, and the full cycle of life’s rites, submitting a total of one hundred and fifty memorials. Upon Emperor He’s accession, Cao Bao composed explanatory notes for the rites, and the Emperor placed the new ritual code at the forefront of his reign.

The record states: The ritual system devised by Shusun Tong for the Han left even the noble-minded with regrets. Cao Bao, emulating him, devoted himself day and night to its refinement, clutching brush and tablets even in sleep, practicing the texts as he walked. Yet when it came to his own compositions, he again interspersed them with passages from the Five Classics and apocryphal prophecies. Thus, what he produced was not Shusun’s work but the regulations of his own age. The great origin of ritual arises from Heaven and resides in the human heart. The sages summed it up in a single phrase: “Let nothing be done without reverence.” Cao Bao, lost in deep contemplation, when his thoughts reached their zenith, forgot all else—was this not the essence of “without irreverence”? Solemn in reflection, composed in expression. Yet prophecies—prophecies cannot serve as canonical texts.

The *Old唐书·Records of Ritual and Music* states: Before the Three Dynasties, governance flowed from unity, and ritual and music permeated the realm. After the Three Dynasties, governance split in two, and ritual and music became empty names. In antiquity, palaces and carriages served as dwellings, robes and caps as attire, ritual vessels and musical instruments as tools. These were employed in suburban sacrifices, court audiences, divine worship, and the governance of the people. Seasonal gatherings facilitated court assemblies, diplomatic exchanges, and joyous interactions; archery feasts and banquets fostered communal bonds; military training and schooling united the people in shared endeavors. Even at the level of villages and fields, from weddings to funerals, all followed the rhythms of music. No aspect of the people’s lives lay outside ritual. Through these means, they were taught filial piety, compassion, fraternal duty, loyalty, trustworthiness, benevolence, and righteousness—all cultivated in their daily conduct, attire, and diet. From dawn to dusk, their every act was imbued with ritual. This was governance flowing from unity, ritual and music permeating the realm, bringing peace to all under Heaven. Through habit and practice, they unconsciously turned toward goodness, shunned wrongdoing, and formed virtuous customs.

After the fall of the Three Dynasties, the Qin altered the ancient ways. Subsequent rulers, from the Son of Heaven to the hundred officials, adopted Qin titles, ranks, state institutions, and court regalia in their entirety. Even when well-intentioned sovereigns sought reform, they could not transcend their era to restore the ways of the Three Dynasties. Constrained by contemporary customs, they made only minor adjustments, content with superficial simplicity. Their daily governance focused on documents, lawsuits, military provisions, and food supplies, declaring, “This is governance, the means to rule the people.” As for the rituals of the Three Dynasties, their forms were preserved and stored by officials, brought out only for use in suburban sacrifices and court ceremonies, called “ritual, the means to teach the people.” This was governance split in two, ritual and music reduced to empty names.

The record states: In my humble view, Master Ouyang’s discourse is the ultimate truth for all ages. The Former Kings established rituals based on their own conduct and practice, using them to distinguish high and low, settle the people’s minds, and align with the utmost principles to serve Heaven and Earth and harmonize the myriad people. Rooted in the interplay of body, mind, nature, and emotions, they established norms and forms, ensuring their application. How could such a system fail to arise from unity or lack universal reach? From the Qin onward, lacking the Heavenly virtue as its foundation and the Kingly Way as its application, rulers neglected the norms and forms. In their enactments, they knew not the proper order of precedence; in their haste, they eroded the distinctions between ruler and minister, father and son, elder and younger brother, husband and wife, leaving many virtues in shame. How then could they establish the ultimate mean and harmony, ensuring that ritual, music, punishments, and governance did not split in two? This is the divide between antiquity and the present, the origin of ritual’s flourishing and decline. Those who rule must not fail to understand this.

The *Comprehensive Mirror* records: In the first month of the first year of the Zhenguan era, the Emperor held a banquet. His ministers performed the music *Breaking Chen’s Ranks*. Taizong remarked, “I once led expeditions among the people, and this piece arose from those campaigns. Though it lacks the elegance of civil virtue, it commemorates the achievements that brought us here—I dare not forget.” Feng Deyi said, “Your Majesty pacified the realm with divine martial prowess; how could civil virtue compare?” The Emperor replied, “Quelling chaos requires martial strength; preserving order demands civil virtue. Each has its time and use. To say civil virtue falls short of martial is an overstatement.”

The record states: The Master once said, “The martial is perfectly beautiful, yet not perfectly good.” Even with martial deeds that accord with Heaven and follow the people, and the rites and music composed by the Duke of Zhou, there remains the lament that they are “not perfectly good.”

Though the Emperor had quelled the chaos of Sui, he still felt much shame in his virtue, and the beauty of his reformed governance brought only modest peace. Yet Feng Deyi flattered him, claiming rites and music fell short of governance and punishment, and martial achievements surpassed civil virtue—what was his intent? Deyi’s words were misguided, and he would be ridiculed for them through the ages.

In the seventh month of autumn in the sixth year, the Emperor feasted his close ministers in the Danxiao Hall. Changsun Wuji said, “Wang Gui and Wei Zheng were once our enemies, yet today they share this banquet.” The Emperor replied, “Zheng and Gui devoted themselves to their duties, so I employ them. Yet whenever Zheng remonstrates and I do not heed him, he falls silent—why?” Zheng answered, “When I deem a matter improper, I must admonish. If Your Majesty does not heed me yet I assent, the matter would proceed—how could I dare agree?” The Emperor said, “If you assent and then remonstrate again, what harm is there?” Zheng replied, “Long ago, Shun warned his ministers: ‘Do not feign compliance to my face, then murmur behind my back.’ If I silently assented to Your Majesty, that would be feigned compliance—how could that reflect the intent of Hou Ji and Xie in serving Shun?” The Emperor laughed heartily and said, “People say Wei Zheng is coarse and arrogant, but to me, he seems all the more charming—precisely for this reason.” Zheng rose, bowed, and thanked him, saying, “Because Your Majesty encourages me to speak, I can fully express my foolishness. Had Your Majesty rejected my words, how would I dare repeatedly offend your countenance?”

The record states: Reading the *Zhong Fu* hexagram of the *Book of Changes*, and observing the conduct of Wang Gui and Wei Zheng, I cannot but sigh in admiration. Those who conceal themselves are not vessels for bearing great burdens, yet Zheng and Gui served them—like the cry of a crane reaching the heavens, how could it last? But once they turned and changed their course, offering clarity to the clear-sighted and decisiveness to the resolute, it was as if a crane sang in the shadows and its young echoed it, or as if one said, “I have a fine office, and I share it with you.” How could they not devote themselves wholeheartedly to their duties? Had they not encountered such an enlightened ruler, they would have remained mere captives of lowly status. As the saying goes: “When one meets an enemy, some drum their chests, some cease, some weep, some sing.” Zheng could not but indulge his charm—was this not the good fortune of a noble man?

In the first month of spring in the seventh year, the Emperor feasted at the Gate of Dark Martiality, where the *Seven Virtues* and *Nine Merits* dances were performed. The former was originally called *The Prince of Qin’s Victory over Chen*, and was renamed the *Dance of Seven Virtues*. The Minister of Rites, Xiao Li, thought the depiction insufficient and requested that the captures of Liu Wu Zhou, Xue Ren Gao, Dou Jian De, and Wang Shi Chong also be portrayed. The Emperor said, “They were all heroes of their time, and some of my ministers once served them as subjects. If they saw their former lords depicted thus, could they not feel sorrow?” Li apologized for his oversight.

At the time, Wei Zheng wished to promote the cessation of martial pursuits and the cultivation of civil virtue. Thus, whenever he attended a feast and saw the *Dance of Seven Virtues*, he would turn his head away; but when he saw the *Dance of Nine Merits*, he would watch intently.

The record states: Mencius said, “Is it more joyful to enjoy music alone, or to share it with others?” “It is better to share it.” “Is it more joyful to share it with few, or with many?” “It is better to share it with many.” The Emperor came close to sharing joy with both few and many. Yet Zheng did not make his intent clear, instead merely turning his head away—ah! Was this not the guidance Mencius offered to the King of Qi?

In the twelfth year, the Emperor returned to the palace and feasted officials of the fifth rank and above in the Eastern Palace. The Emperor said, “Before the *Zhenguan* era, those who joined me in securing the realm—Li Shimin’s merit is foremost. Since the *Zhenguan* era, those who corrected my errors and rectified my faults—Wei Zheng’s merit is foremost.” He bestowed upon them both jeweled swords. Then he asked, “How does my governance compare to past years?” Zheng replied, “In the past, you worried that the realm was not well-governed, so your virtue and righteousness were ever-renewed. Now, you are complacent in its stability, so you fall short. At the beginning of *Zhenguan*, fearing that none would admonish me, you often encouraged them to speak, and gladly heeded their words. Now, though you reluctantly heed them, you still show displeasure—this is the difference.” The Emperor said, “May I hear more?” Zheng said, “Once, you wished to execute the monk Yuan Lushi. Sun Fu Ga thought the law did not warrant death, and you rewarded him with the garden of Princess Lanling. Some said the reward was too generous. You replied, ‘Since my ascension, no one has admonished me, so I reward him.’ This was your way of encouraging speech. When the registrar Liu Xiong made a false accusation, you wished to execute him, but accepted Dai Zhou’s remonstrance and desisted—this was your glad acceptance. Recently, Huangfu De Ling admonished you against rebuilding the Luoyang Palace. You were angered, but reluctantly heeded my words and halted the project—this was your reluctant compliance.” The Emperor said, “None but you could point this out. People suffer from not knowing themselves.”

The record states: Observing the waxing and waning of fortune in the *Book of Changes*, one can understand the gains and losses in the progress of remonstrance. When Han Gaozu humbled his strategists, he governed them with magnanimity. Those he employed for Han were the very ones he had discarded from Chu. As the *Book of Changes* says, “Slaughtering an ox in the eastern neighbor’s sacrifice is not as good as offering a simple libation in the western neighbor’s—yet it is they who truly receive the blessing.” Does this not describe Han Gaozu? When Tang corrected the chaos of Sui, Taizong drew forth loyalty with generous rewards. Those who devoted themselves to Tang were the very ones who had flattered Sui. As the *Book of Changes* says, “Not meeting one’s father, but meeting one’s mother; not serving one’s lord as a father, but serving him as a minister.” Does this not describe Taizong?

Yet the practice of lavish rewards cannot be sustained indefinitely. Only by handling matters with utmost impartiality and ruling without self-interest can one hope to avoid the pitfall of initial diligence giving way to later indolence.

Moreover, in the era of Taizong, when sovereign and ministers gathered in feasts, they did not indulge in extravagant revelry or grow complacent in ease, but instead spurred one another to refine culture and strengthen governance—truly a case of knowing how to strengthen oneself. This is why the governance of the Zhenguan era shone so brilliantly.

Recorded:

In the eighth month of the seventeenth year of Kaiyuan, on the day *guihai*, the emperor celebrated his birthday by feasting the hundred officials beneath the Hua’e Tower. The Left Chancellor Yuan Qianyao and Right Chancellor Zhang Yue led the officials in presenting a memorial, requesting that the fifth day of the eighth month each year be established as the Mid-Autumn Festival, to be observed throughout the realm with feasting and merriment.

Recorded:

To accompany and encourage one’s lord on his birthday is the natural affection of a filial child; to offer praise and felicitations on that day is the loyal devotion of a minister. This ritual of the Tang was not an excessive measure. Yet Zhang Yue and Yuan Qianyao did not act from sincere conviction, but merely seized upon the emperor’s feast and gifts to curry favor—far from the earnest reverence shown in the Tianbao era’s celebrations of the sovereign.

The following year, in the second month, the emperor again ordered the officials to select scenic spots for pleasure outings, verging on dissipation and neglect of duty. In our present dynasty, ritual arises from principle, and the emperor’s birthday is honored as the *Wanshou Shengjie* ("August Longevity Festival"), yet the practice of selecting scenic spots for revelry has been abolished—striking the proper balance.

When Suzong ascended the throne at Lingwu, the civil and military officials numbered fewer than thirty. They cleared the wilderness to establish a court, its institutions hastily improvised. The military men grew arrogant and unruly. The great general Guan Chongsi sat in the court with his back to the throne, speaking and laughing as he pleased. The supervising censor Li Mian impeached him, and the case was referred to the authorities. The emperor, intending to pardon him, sighed and said, “With Li Mian, the court begins to command respect.”

Recorded:

After the loss of the golden *yi*-weight, the ancestral temples and altars of the Tang were cast into turmoil. Li Mian, upholding the sagely refinement of culture and embodying a majestic bearing, stood apart from others. His defense of the court’s dignity was but a fleeting moment in time, lacking the enduring framework to sustain it. Yet the emperor, recognizing that the mandate could not be taken lightly and that the slightest misstep could not be ignored, entrusted Li Mian with great responsibilities. At opportune moments, he impeached and admonished, displaying resolute judgment to curb the arrogance of martial officers and fierce generals, preventing petty officers from overawing their commanders and ensuring that the rise and fall of *jiedu* governors did not rest with the soldiers. Had this course been followed, the later calamities of the *fanzhen* would never have arisen. To indulge in leniency as a form of kindness, unaware that gradual encroachment must not be tolerated—what could one Li Mian have done for the Tang house? Thus, observing the emperor’s special pardon, one can see why the Tang never recovered. How lamentable!

From the *Old History of the Tang*:

Dezong honored Guo Ziyi as *bushi* ("Teacher of the Realm") and styled him *Shangfu* ("Exalted Father"). The imperial edict read:

Heaven and Earth bring forth the myriad things through the four seasons; the sovereign relies on his ministers as limbs to assist him. The task of marshaling troops and stabilizing the realm has been passed down through generations. Above, he harmonizes the Three Luminaries; below, he shields the Five Peaks. He rightly oversees the myriad concerns, pacifies the four barbarians, embodies the qi of primal harmony, and roots himself in the virtue of steadfast unity. His achievements are vast yet he does not boast; his position is lofty yet he remains composed. As *Shangfu*, his name is likened to Lü Wang; as *bushi*, his rank surpasses that of the Duke of Zhou. The Prince of Fenyang, a hero sent down by Heaven, was born with the wisdom to aid a king. He trained his troops as a father, divined the enemy’s moves like a spirit. He supported Suzong and restored the realm, quelling crises for the state and driving out invaders from the frontiers. In securing the altars of the soil and grain, what did he have to envy in the Marquis of Jiang? In pacifying the Qiang and Rong, he was no less than Zhao Chongguo. At Jiangtai, he soothed the scattered multitudes; at Jingyang, he received the surrender of a hundred thousand foes. His merit towers over past and present; his fame resounds among the barbarians. His loyalty and integrity hang like the sun and moon; his favor and esteem surpass all ministers. Honoring this elder statesman, we bestow upon him this exalted title.

It is recorded: Only with the virtue of humility and radiance does one attain the most exalted title. The honorific "Grand Tutor" was how the Zhou venerated the Grand Duke. From the Han through the Tang, none but Guo Ziyi bore it without shame. As for Wang Xingyu and Liu Shouguang—those ringleaders of treason—along with Qian Liu, whose clanging cymbals marked his rebellion, though they rendered service in defending Wu and Yue, such merit suffices for one region but not for the realm entire.

*The Comprehensive Mirror* states: In the autumn of the seventh month of the first year of Baoying under Suzong, Guo Ziyi entered court, but due to Cheng Yuanzhen’s envy, he was detained in the capital.
