In the second year of Dali under Daizong, in the second month, Guo Ziyi entered court and imprisoned his son Guo Ai to await punishment. In the twelfth month, Guo Ziyi entered court, for Yu Chao’en had long despised him and desecrated his father’s tomb, yet he made no dispute. In the spring of the fourth year, in the first month, Guo Ziyi entered court, as Yuan Zai warned of Yu Chao’en’s plotting, but he neither acted against him nor heeded the warning. In the ninth year, in the second month, Guo Ziyi entered court, and the troops of Shuofang were increased. In the tenth year, Guo Ziyi entered court and memorialized to remove one prefectural or county official, but received no reply. In the winter of the thirteenth year, in the twelfth month, Guo Ziyi entered court. Altogether, he entered court seven times, and the historiographical principle states: This is why Guo Ziyi was a paragon of loyalty—Li Guangbi paled in comparison.

It is recorded: In the 242 years of the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, Confucius noted twice when dukes came to the royal court and once when they entered the capital. Yet in the twenty-odd years of Suzong and Daizong’s reigns, Zhu Xi recorded Guo Ziyi’s seven entries into court, and the records never ceased, nor did the praise. Was this not the beauty of yielding virtue and the truth of self-reflection? Thus his merit overshadowed the realm, yet the sovereign never doubted him; his rank reached the pinnacle of ministers, yet none envied him.

The *Book of Changes* says: "The laboring and modest nobleman will have a good end." Confucius appended: "To toil without boasting, to achieve without claiming merit—this is the utmost in magnanimity." This speaks of one who humbles himself despite his accomplishments. Virtue is called abundance; ritual is called reverence. Humility is the means to cultivate reverence and preserve one’s position. This describes the Duke’s conduct.

*Hongdao Record*, Volume 29, ends.
*(Note: The character "下" was originally missing and has been supplied according to context.)*

*Hongdao Record*, Volume 30: *Rites*

**Rites of Ruler and Minister**

From the *Annals of Song*: Emperor Taizu of the Great Song often studied the *Two Classics* and sighed, saying: "In the time of Yao and Shun, the punishment for the Four Felons was merely exile. Why then are the legal nets of recent ages so tightly woven?" Thereupon, he established laws: flogging and cudgeling were forbidden within the palace halls, and insults were not to reach the ranks of high ministers. Thus, from the Kaibao era onward, those guilty of capital offenses—unless their crimes were deeply harmful to law and reason—were often spared death. Only corrupt officials were executed in the marketplace, never granted clemency.

*Record* states: This household law of the Song surpassed those of Han and Tang; few later dynasties could match it. For rites and righteousness, integrity and shame are what the ruler uses to inspire and uphold. That which lifts a decadent age to the flourishing of the Three Dynasties is what distinguishes the gentry from common folk, humanity from beasts, and the noble from the base. The stakes are no small matter. As for corrupt officials, their crimes are especially grave; once convicted, they are almost never pardoned. Throughout the Song dynasty, though ministers might commit offenses, unless they were guilty of corruption, the law prescribed exile. Even then, the sovereign would personally request a favorable place of banishment. Never did one hear of a minister beaten to death or executed by executioner’s blade. Was this not the depth of the ancestral founders’ intent and the excellence of their descendants’ adherence to the law?

Emperor Taizong once summoned the Hanlin Academician Dou Yi to draft an edict. As Yi arrived at the palace gate, he saw the emperor sitting with his robes disheveled and feet bare. Yi halted and refused to advance. The emperor hastily donned his crown and robes before summoning him in. Yi then said: "Your Majesty has founded a dynasty and established a legacy. You should exemplify ritual for all under heaven, lest the heroic and talented lose heart upon hearing of this." The emperor composed his expression and thanked him. Thereafter, he never appeared before his close ministers without proper attire.

*Record* states: The emperor’s restraint of desire was not like that of the ancients, who were often indulgent. His disheveled state and bare feet were but a momentary lapse. His hasty donning of robes and composed demeanor arose from his true nature, not from pretense or affectation. Yi was esteemed for his gravity and integrity; how could he have wished to entrap his ruler in impropriety? His refusal to advance was nearly an act of self-respect. Alas! In this exchange between ruler and minister, both achieved their proper measure.

In the eighth year of the Taiping Xingguo era of Emperor Taizong, he personally examined the tribute scholars of the Ministry of Rites at the Hall of Martial Instruction. For the first time, the candidates were divided into three ranks, and a banquet was bestowed upon them at the Qionglin Park, where they were honored with poems. This became an established institution.

*Record* states: The *Deer Cry Banquet* is a grand ceremony for welcoming guests and promoting scholars. The Qionglin Banquet is an exceptional grace bestowed by the sovereign. Our dynasty’s renowned banquet of honor and favor surpasses these precedents. Moreover, when the court established the ceremonial robes for all officials, they offered congratulatory words, saying: *"Heaven unfolds the literary fortune, and the worthy and talented ascend to office—this is a fitting occasion for celebration,"* which cannot be compared to ordinary rites.

From the *Record of Words and Deeds*: In the fourth year of the Tiansheng era of Emperor Renzong, when the lecturer Hu Yuan was summoned, he was required by custom to first practice court etiquette at the Gate Chamber. Yuan said: *"All the books I have read in my life are the rites for serving the ruler. Why should I practice further?"* The Gate Chamber reported this, and the emperor permitted him to practice on his boat en route. The emperor did not press him. People assumed that this rustic scholar would surely breach protocol, but when he entered for his audience, his performance greatly pleased the emperor. The emperor remarked to his attendants: *"Hu Yuan’s advancement, retreat, and every movement accord with ancient ritual."*

*Record* states: Today’s court audience rites require all to practice etiquette at the Court of State Ceremonial, precisely to prevent those from humble backgrounds from being unaware. This is a fixed rule, recorded in the statutes. Yet Yuan’s exemption from this precedent also reveals the sagely virtue of the sovereign, whose magnanimity extends to all things. The flourishing atmosphere of the era may thus be glimpsed. Let this be recorded.

From the *Biographies*: In the first year of the Xining era of Emperor Shenzong, when Fu Bi came to court, he was permitted to ride in a palanquin to the palace gate. The emperor received him at the small hall of the Inner East Gate, ordering his sons to support him as he entered. He further instructed him not to bow and conversed with him at ease, inquiring about governance. Bi, perceiving the emperor’s determination to act, replied: *"The ruler’s likes and dislikes must not be discernible to others. If they can be fathomed, then the treacherous may exploit them. The ruler should observe the people as Heaven does—good and evil are self-chosen, and fortune or misfortune follows accordingly. Thus, merit and fault will invariably be justly assessed."* When asked about border affairs, he replied: *"Your Majesty has reigned but briefly; you should first spread virtue and bestow kindness. I hope that for twenty years, you will not speak of war."* The emperor fell silent, and only at dusk did Bi withdraw.

*Record* states: When Bi served as chief minister under Emperor Renzong, he once said: *"Exalting with empty ritual is not as good as advancing with utmost sincerity."* Now, observe how he was carried to the hall in a palanquin, seated without bowing, and engaged in unconstrained conversation—this was ritual. When he remonstrated, the emperor heeded him; when he spoke, the emperor listened—this was sincerity. At the beginning of the emperor’s reign, governance was like the sun at dawn, while Bi’s counsel was like a square piece fitting into its proper place. Truly, his words were medicine for the malady and an acupuncture needle for immediate effect. Yet why was it not so? The once-vigorous momentum turned into a silent response. Though empty ritual was exalted, sincerity was not fully extended. Observing the exchanges between these two emperors, the difference in their success and failure is as vast as heaven and earth.

In the first year of Yuanyou during Emperor Zhezong’s reign, an edict was issued appointing Grand Preceptor Wen Yanbo as Participant in the Deliberation of Military and State Affairs. At the time, he was eighty-one years old. Yanbo had served four successive reigns and held the posts of general and chief minister for fifty years, his name renowned among the Four Barbarians. When the Khitan envoy Yelü Yongchang came on a diplomatic mission, upon seeing him outside the palace gate, he stepped back, adjusted his expression, and said, “This is the *Er Teng* Duke!” He then asked his age, remarking, “How robust he is!” Su Shi commented, “The envoy has seen his bearing but has yet to hear his words.” In managing the myriad affairs of state, even the most astute and experienced youths could not match him; in his mastery of history from antiquity to the present, even specialists in their fields fell short. The envoy clasped his hands and said, “He is a man of extraordinary talent in the world.”

The Khitan’s elder brother possessed a famous horse and requested permission from the border officials to present it as a gift, which the imperial court granted. Such was the respect he commanded among foreign nations. By this time, Sima Guang remarked, “He is a venerable elder of long-standing virtue; it is fitting to recall him to assist in governance.” Empress Dowager Xuanren thus issued the decree, elevating his status with exceptional ceremony and ranking him above the chief ministers. The emperor held court with him once every six days, and he attended the imperial lecture hall once every two months—a rarity in ancient and modern times.

At the time, when the emperor received him, he showed utmost reverence. During the announcement of successful candidates in the imperial examination, Yanbo stood in attendance the entire day. The emperor repeatedly urged him, “Grand Preceptor, please rest.” Yanbo kowtowed in gratitude but remained standing until the proceedings concluded. When Cheng Yi served as imperial lecturer, he conducted himself with the dignity of a teacher, and his admonitions were always couched in subtle reproof, so that the emperor held him in awe. Someone once asked Cheng Yi, “How do you compare yourself to Duke Di?” Cheng Yi replied, “Duke Teng served as a great minister through three reigns; in attending a young sovereign, he could not but show deference. I, however, am a commoner serving as the emperor’s tutor—how dare I not hold myself in proper regard? This is why we differ.”

*Recorded:* Mencius said, “Zengzi was a teacher and an elder; Zisi was a minister and a subordinate. Had Zengzi and Zisi exchanged places, each would have acted accordingly.” Thus, had Yougong [Wen Yanbo] been in Cheng Yi’s position, he would not have abandoned the ritual of sitting while lecturing; and had Cheng Yi occupied Yougong’s rank, how could he have altered his customary reverence and prudence?

When Su Shi served as Hanlin Academician, whenever he read aloud at the imperial lecture hall—whether on matters of governance, rise and fall, right and wrong, or success and failure—he never failed to expound at length, hoping to enlighten the emperor. Once, he was summoned to stay overnight in the palace and was received in the side hall. The Grand Empress Dowager asked, “What position do you hold now?” He replied, “I am a guilty official in the Hanlin Academy.” She asked, “How did you attain this?” He answered, “Through the grace of the Grand Empress Dowager and Your Imperial Majesty.” She said, “That is not so. Was it not due to the recommendation of high ministers?” He replied, “Not that either.” Startled, Su Shi said, “Though I am unworthy, I would not dare advance through any other means.” She said, “This was the intention of the late emperor. He often recited your writings and would invariably sigh, ‘What extraordinary talent!’ Extraordinary indeed—he simply did not live to employ you.” Upon hearing this, Su Shi could not help but weep aloud, and the Grand Empress Dowager and the emperor also shed tears, while all those present were moved to tears.

Afterward, she ordered him to be seated and served tea, then had the golden lotus lanterns from the imperial presence carried to escort him back to his quarters. Cheng Yi later requested to conduct lectures in the Chongzheng and Yanhe Halls, submitting a memorial that read: “Recently, the *Jiying* Hall has grown warm, so I humbly request to move the lectures to the Chongzheng and Yanhe Halls, with the participation of the Palace Attendant.” Gu Lin, however, opposed holding lectures in the Yanhe Hall, arguing that lecturers should not be allowed in the main hall, citing the need to uphold the emperor’s dignity. Cheng Yi replied, “I need not cite distant precedents; I shall speak only of our dynasty’s own history. Emperor Taizu summoned Wang Zhaosu to lecture on the *Book of Changes*; Emperor Zhenzong had Cui Yizheng lecture on the *Book of Documents* and Xing Yu on the *Spring and Autumn Annals*—all within the main hall. At that time, the lecturers still sat; the custom of standing while lecturing was first introduced at the behest of Empress Dowager Mingsu. This was yet another manifestation of our ancestors’ reverence for scholars and the Dao—a model not only for their descendants but for emperors of all ages.

In the present age, vulgar men may speak of ‘honoring the ruler,’ but they do not understand the true way to do so. A ruler’s dignity increases only with the elevation of his virtue; in terms of power and position, he is already at the utmost height. His majesty is already supreme—how could it be further augmented?”

*Recorded:* Cheng Yi’s argument for sitting while lecturing was stern and upright; Su Shi’s audience in the side hall was a moment of profound favor. The former exemplified the house traditions of the Song, far surpassing those of the Han and Tang; the latter reflected the benevolence of the empress dowager, akin to that of Yao and Shun. Even a hundred generations hence, these events inspire unceasing reverence and admiration—how splendid they are!

According to the *Treatise on Rites*: In the second year of his reign, Emperor Taizu had the Grand Master of Ceremonies, Nie Congyi, present the *Illustrations of the Three Ritual Classics*, and he ordered scholars to deliberate and finalize them. During the Kaibao era, he commanded the Censor-in-Chief Liu Wensou, Academician Li Fang, Drafter of Imperial Edicts Lu Duoxun, Reminder Jia Huangzhong, and Gentleman for Court Audience He Xian to compile the *Comprehensive Rites of the Kaibao Era* in two hundred volumes, based on the *Rites of the Kaiyuan Era* with additions and omissions. Later, they also established the *Exegesis of the Comprehensive Rites*, compiling one hundred volumes. Emperor Taizong esteemed refined learning and restored proper institutions, largely reviving what had been neglected.

Emperor Zhenzong, succeeding a period of great prosperity, maintained peaceful relations with the Khitan, and with the realm at peace, he performed the Feng and Shan sacrifices and worshipped at the Fen River—these were all elaborate rituals of the time. Earlier, during the Tianxi era, Chen Kuan had organized the records of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices, but the constant issuance of new and old edicts had left the work unfinished. At the beginning of the Tiansheng era under Emperor Renzong, the Grand Master of Ceremonies Wang Hao began compiling edicts from the founding of the dynasty to the Qianxing era, removing redundancies and categorizing them under the five rites, resulting in a new compilation of sixty volumes. In the fourth year of Jingyou, Jia Changchao compiled the *New Rites of the Grand Master of Ceremonies* and the *Sacrificial Ceremonies*. At the beginning of the Huangyou era, Wen Yanbo compiled the *Records of the Grand Sacrifice at the Bright Hall* in twenty volumes. By the Jiayou era, as the rites had fallen into disuse, Ouyang Xiu was ordered to oversee a bureau to revise the *Comprehensive Rites*, record their changes, and organize the *New Rites* by category into one hundred volumes. This work was named the *Adapted and Innovated Rites of the Grand Master of Ceremonies*, with roughly thirteen or fourteen parts differing from the old versions.

The record states: In my humble observation, though the subtle intent of history remains unmanifest, does it not already express excessive regret for Emperor Renzong? Why is this so? Taizu inherited the chaos of the Five Dynasties; though he ascended the throne through abdication, he could not personally undertake the task of institutional creation. Taizong, amid the fortunes of a rising state, faced frequent obstructions among his kin—how could he have devised a plan of perfect goodness and beauty? The institutions of Zhenzong, replete with literary embellishments, left much to be desired. By the time of Renzong, a century of accumulated virtue had passed, and the moment had come to properly establish rites and compose music.

Moreover, the emperor’s endowment was such that he preserved benevolence in his heart and maintained ritual in his heart. What he enacted was universal love and universal reverence, so that all within the four seas were pervaded by constant respect and constant affection. No other sovereign could even faintly approximate this in the slightest. Had there been a figure like the Duke of Zhou to assist and counsel him, establishing the ultimate mean of central harmony, unifying and synthesizing all principles—like the resonance of metal and the vibration of jade—how could he have merely followed the old bureaucratic documents, lacking any substantive foundation, as history laments?

Furthermore, Renzong was deeply devoted to learning. Once, when Wang Mei lectured on the *Rites of Zhou*, the emperor ordered illustrations of carriages, robes, crowns, sacrificial vessels, and ceremonial utensils to be drawn. Yet he could not fully grasp the fundamental principles of their construction, nor could he aspire to the prosperity of the Three Dynasties—how much less could he achieve anything beyond this?

Some ask: Had the two scholars of Lu lived in his time, could they have created such institutions? The answer is: They could not. For the ultimate rites align with the order of heaven and earth, and the ultimate music harmonizes with the harmony of heaven and earth. Without the utmost sincerity of the world, exhausting one’s nature to fulfill the natures of others and all things, and assisting in the transformation and nourishment of heaven and earth, such attainment is impossible. Though the two scholars could uphold the rites and righteousness of Lu, how could they achieve central harmony as described by Zisi? Moreover, the learning of Song emperors merely pursued broad reading—how could works like the *Taiping Guangji* or *Cefu Yuangui* be mentioned in the same breath?

Thus, what Renzong cherished was nothing more than the superficial details of ritual implements. No wonder he could not meet expectations. Zhu Xi, in his petition to revise the Three Rites, stated: "I have heard that the Way of the Six Classics converges in unity, yet the application of rites and music is most urgent. After the Qin destroyed learning, rites and music were the first to decay. From the Han and Jin onward, various scholars patched and repaired them, but no complete work remained—only the Three Rites survived in part. The *Rites of Zhou* serves as the guiding principle of ritual, while its ceremonial methods and measurements are found in the *Etiquette and Rites*, which is the root text. The *Book of Rites*, including chapters such as *Jiao Te Sheng* and *Guan Yi*, serves as its exegetical commentary.

Previously, there were still examinations on the Three Rites, *Comprehensive Rites*, and other classical studies. Though the rites were not practiced, scholars could still recite and understand their doctrines. Since the Xining era, Wang Anshi disrupted the old system, abolishing the *Etiquette and Rites* and retaining only the *Book of Rites* as a subject. By abandoning the classic in favor of its commentary and neglecting the root to pursue the branches, the error was grave. Yet the erudites and students merely recited its empty text to prepare for examinations. Even when questions were based on actual ceremonial methods and measurements, all were lost in obscurity, ignorant of their origins. In any major deliberation, they relied solely on hearsay and conjecture.

When I was in seclusion, I once discussed these matters with a few scholars, intending to take the *Etiquette and Rites* as the root text and append to it relevant passages from the *Book of Rites* and other classics, histories, and miscellaneous works. We would compile annotations and the commentaries of various scholars to establish a coherent system. However, as a private individual, I lacked access to books for reference and copyists, so the work remained unfinished. Later, upon receiving an official appointment, my students dispersed, and the project could not be completed.

I humbly beseech Your Sagely Majesty to issue a special decree to the relevant authorities, permitting me to borrow books on rites and music from the Imperial Library. I would then recruit over ten former students, secure several vacant official residences for their lodging, and have them compile and categorize the materials. Though they would hold official positions, they would not receive official salaries—only a monthly stipend for food, paper, brushes, ink, oil, and candles. The copyists, over twenty in number, would be assigned by the Lin’an Prefecture, with their expenses covered by the bureau’s budget, without additional rewards. This would incur no great cost to the state yet could revive what has been lost, leaving a lasting legacy and guiding scholars toward substantive learning. In time, this could aid the sagely court in institutional creation—a great fortune for our culture."

The record concludes: The memorial of Master Song ends here. Since the mid-Song, masters from the Luo, Guan, and Min schools emerged in succession. Master Zhou said: "Only after regulating yin and yang can harmony be achieved; thus, rites come before music." He also said: "Gentle, yielding, central, and balanced—this is the flourishing of virtue. When the world is transformed by the mean, governance reaches its perfection. This is called the Way matching heaven and earth, the ultimate of antiquity." Master Cheng said: "Rites are the means by which one establishes oneself. To be at ease with rites and harmonize with music is the height of virtue." He also said: "What rites revere is their underlying principle. To lose the principle while preserving the details is the work of mere ritualists." Master Zhang said: "Rites are the means by which one sustains one’s nature. Rites originally arise from nature; sustaining one’s nature is returning to the root." He also said: "Rites are not merely visible in external forms; there are also formless rites. Without rites, there is no Way in the world." Master Zhu said: "Rites are the natural principles of heaven and earth; one cannot lack even a fraction, nor can one add even a fraction. Only the heart of the sage unites with heaven, so that every action in accordance with rites aligns perfectly with heaven."

Alas! Are not these words the very foundation of institutional creation?

Should the many sages of the Song have attained their rightful positions and practiced the Dao, then the rites and music of that dynasty might have rivaled those of earlier ages. Yet why were they confined to self-cultivation in obscurity, never finding recognition at the highest levels? Instead, men like Wang, Lü, Zhang, Cai, Qin, Han, Jia, and Shi successively occupied the positions of imperial tutors and chief ministers, monopolizing the power to create institutions. They ensured that scholar-officials and great Confucians suffered the hardships of having no books to consult and no scribes to copy texts.

Nevertheless, there remained disciples to gather and followers to entrust. Compared to the present, where profit and power dominate all, where no disciples or followers are to be found—where men willingly content themselves with brushes and inkstones, facing each other in isolation—the desolation of that era pales in comparison.

In the *Imperial Decrees of the August Ming*, the edict of the fifth year of Hongwu states: "I have heard that the Three Sovereigns established the ultimate norm, and the Five Emperors followed their teachings. In times when institutions were not yet complete, it was fitting for rulers to instruct the people. The Three Dynasties adhered to this, and the people lived in harmony. From the Zhou to the Han, Tang, and Song, each dynasty expanded and refined these institutions, and thus the state prospered, the people thrived in their time, and families enjoyed lasting peace.

By the grace of the August Heaven and Earth, the mandate of my ancestors, and the protection of the myriad spirits, I have rightfully ascended the imperial throne. Though I am but a humble man of the fields, untrained in the sacred classics, I have spent over twenty years pacifying and governing, never resting in peace, my meals coarse and simple. Thus, the Dao has not yet been fully realized, and the people remain untransformed. In villages, markets, and neighborhoods, the customs of the Yuan still linger. Now that the realm is at peace, how can rites, propriety, and social mores not be rectified?

Herein I issue this decree to all my officials and people: once this edict arrives, those who dare disobey shall be punished according to the law."

The record states: Was not this edict of the sagely ancestor far superior to the ways of those who rule by force? Shang Yang discarded rites and righteousness, cast aside honor and shame, and left a legacy of filth for a thousand generations. The Han, beginning with their three-chapter covenant, never once mentioned these principles. When Lu Jia frequently spoke of them, he was dismissed with, 'What use is that?' When Jia Yi wept bitter tears, he was met with, 'There is no time for such things.' Never was a single word or decree issued to promote rites, righteousness, or social mores. This is why, throughout the Han dynasty, they followed the Qin’s mixed legacy of hegemony, with no means of transformation. How different from the Great Ming, which, though customs had collapsed and morality had sunk into the earth, transformed the people entirely, bringing great unity to the realm! I am fortunate to have witnessed this flourishing age. Thus, I record it here.

**The Record of Sagely Governance**:
At the founding of the dynasty, the emperor governed his ministers with ritual propriety, often bestowing gifts upon his counselors. To Minister Tao An, he affixed a plaque at his gate, inscribed: *"A strategist unmatched in the imperial court, a literary master second to none in the Hanlin Academy."* He summoned the foremost scholars of Jiangnan to deliberate on rites and appointed Tao as chief compiler.

He also granted Academician Song Lian the honor of composing a poem while drinking in the emperor’s presence, declaring: *"Let future generations know that We and Our ministers shared such joy together."*

When Song Lian retired, the emperor presented him with three sets of robes and inquired: *"How old are you now?"*
*"Sixty-eight,"* Song replied.
The emperor said: *"Keep these fine silks, and in thirty-two years, they shall serve as your centennial garments."*

Initially, Song had requested to pay court once a year. In the ninth month of that year, he arrived for an audience. The emperor had long awaited him, and upon his arrival, rejoiced greatly. He dispatched the Ministry of Rites to deliver delicacies and various goods to Song’s lodgings as gifts. Thereafter, Song accompanied the emperor, touring palaces and inspecting the imperial precincts. The emperor questioned him thoroughly, and when they dined together in the side hall, Song did not retire until the feast concluded. The emperor sighed and said: *"A minister of perfect loyalty!"*

When sweet dew descended, the emperor summoned Song, seated him, and personally took up a golden ladle. Refining the broth in a tripod, he scooped the sweet dew with his own hands, pouring it into a goblet, and said: *"This is the essence of harmonious qi, capable of curing illness and prolonging life. Thus do We share it with you."*

**Recorded Note**:
This conduct was yet more virtuous than that of those who indulge in drunken revelry or treat scholars with contempt. For even the Han could not summon the likes of the Four Hoary Ones of Mount Shang...

While the Four Scholars of Zhe, the Ming Ancestor first summoned and employed. As for Tao of Dangtu, his mastery of the Learning of the Lian, Luo, Guan, and Min schools was likewise no different from that of the Four Masters. This is why his radiance illumined the Four Seas, leaving no trace of the foul, usurping, and defiling airs—precisely because he revered and honored eminent scholars, far emulating the legacy of sage emperors and august sovereigns of old. Ah, how magnificent!

During the Yongle reign, the Minister of Personnel, Sai Yi, served as Junior Preceptor for nine years, while the Minister of Revenue, Xia Yuanji, held the post of Junior Guardian for three terms. Both were granted imperial commendations and rewards, with the emperor praising them as *"pure, good, sincere, and steadfast, like the famed ministers of antiquity."* After a banquet was bestowed upon them at the Ministry of Rites, the emperor personally feasted them in a separate hall, presenting each with a silver seal inscribed: *"Rectify Errors and Correct Faults."* He further instructed them: *"Should We commit any misstep, you need only memorialize it to Us."* By this, he made known: *"We shall not hesitate to follow good counsel."*

The following year, they accompanied the emperor on his northern frontier inspection. Upon their return, the emperor, mindful of their advanced age, wished to grant them ease and comfort. He bestowed further commendations and rewards, relieving them of their duties while preserving their emoluments, so they might attend court morning and evening, ever ready to offer counsel and deliberation. Thus, the grace and favor accorded them grew even deeper.

**Recorded Note:**
Since the time when Heaven showed Us the proper path, who has not regarded private banquets as intimacy, reverence as special favor, or exceptional grace as singular kindness? Yet who has ever been charged with *"rectifying errors and correcting faults"*? Even the Crimson Sky Hall and Black Tortoise Gate of Tang Taizong cannot compare. For these two ministers, bound in trust to the sagely emperor, were as close as his own heart and spine—steadfast as divination by turtle shell or milfoil, unshaken by power or profit, untouched by slander or defamation. Such are the *"good and noble gentlemen whose hearts are knit fast."* Observing how they did not claim virtue for private favors but instead strove to guide and support one another, ever earnest in following the good, one may see the age when *"superior and inferior harmonize, and all is at peace."* Let this be recorded.

**The Record of Illustrious Ministers** states: Minister of Personnel in Nanjing, Wei Ji, lived to ninety-eight. Having already been elevated to the rank of Grand Master for Glorious Happiness, upon the petition of Censor Liang Fang, Emperor Xianzong personally instructed the Ministry of Rites: "Minister Wei Ji has reached a venerable age and possesses both virtue and prestige; We deeply admire and rejoice in this. Dispatch envoys to convey Our regards, bestow upon him mutton and wine, and have the authorities provide him monthly with three *shi* of rice for his sustenance."

Earlier, the gentleman had served as Instructor of Songjiang, conducting himself with propriety. He was recommended to the post of Erudite of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices. During the Xuande reign, he was promoted to Vice Director of the Bureau of Evaluations, then transferred to Vice Minister of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices. In the third year of the Zhengtong era, he was appointed Vice Minister of Personnel, later rising to the full ministerial rank. Throughout his tenure, he earned a sterling reputation. Even the powerful eunuch Wang Zhen treated him with deference, addressing him as "Master" and consulting him on ritual matters. Though Wang once offered him a mere square of silk, Wei did not quibble.

When the Jingtai era began, Wei arrived in the capital. At the time, Grand Secretary Chen Xu presided over the imperial examinations, and the scholars he selected were Wei’s former students. Chen entreated him: "Though you hold the highest office, you have never stood in court. I hope you will remain a while longer—such matters rest with us." Wei refused, later remarking to others: "He treats the affairs of the court as his own. How can such a man come to a good end?"

**Recorded Remarks:** Observing Wenjing’s rise from a minor educational post to the highest offices, one notes that in his early years, he devoted himself to nurturing talent, yet showed no extraordinary brilliance akin to *"mending the heavens or bathing in the sun."* In his later years, he was known for his integrity, prudence, solemnity, and reticence—yet he performed no earth-shaking deeds. This was due to the successive sagely emperors of the ancestral dynasty, who cherished talent and allowed him to serve long and effectively. Though he lacked resounding fame, his enduring influence left an indelible impression, commanding respect from high officials and earnest pleas from the Grand Secretariat to remain. Could such a man have achieved this in a single day? In the end, he attained the rare longevity of a centenarian and the lofty rank of Grand Preceptor.

Mencius said: *"In the court, nothing is as esteemed as rank; in the village, nothing as esteemed as age; for assisting the world and guiding the people, nothing surpasses virtue."* This surely describes Minister Wenjing.

In the *yichou* year of the Hongzhi era, as Emperor Wuzong ascended the throne and respectfully bestowed honorific titles upon the two palaces, he issued an edict granting favors to the elderly, extending grace throughout the realm. At the time, Grand Guardian and Minister of Personnel Wang Shu had retired to his home at the age of ninety. The emperor specially conferred upon him an imperial rescript, dispatching envoys with silk, wine, and other gifts to convey his solicitude. The ceremonial grandeur and radiant honor were extraordinary.

Wei lived during the flourishing Yongle era and witnessed the lingering legacy of the ancestral emperors. Through the Xuande and Zhengtong reigns, he basked in the abundance of their teachings, serving in the inner palace, outer prefectures, and even as a regional governor. During the Tianshun era of renewed diligence and the Chenghua reign, he roused himself to rein in the powerful, impeach the corrupt, and enforce the law with impartiality. Yet when his intentions clashed with those of the emperor, he resolutely withdrew, and his reputation soared. At the beginning of the Hongzhi era, he was specially recalled to uphold the law and govern, but was again slandered by the wicked and ultimately retired without compromising his principles.

In his later years, his bearing was dignified and magnanimous. He wrote books, studied the *Book of Changes*, and explored the principles of the world without respite. His appetite and vigor remained as robust as that of a man in his fifties or sixties. Amid the passing of his contemporaries and the transformations of the state, he alone stood tall—a true elder of the realm.

**Recorded Remarks:** Of those who attained advanced age like the legendary Chuzai, San Yuan remarked: *"Only Minister Wei Wenjing and this gentleman matched each other in rank, virtue, and moral standing."* Yet when it came to achievements and eloquence, Wenjing seemed somewhat inferior. I contend that what truly matters is the elevation of one’s name and virtue. When Wei’s disciple, Grand Secretary Chen, urged him to stay, he remained steadfast and unyielding—not only resisting corruption but also foreseeing events with unerring accuracy. In this age, could there be another like him? Thus, achievements and eloquence are but secondary considerations.

At the beginning of the Jiajing era, the emperor exhorted the retired Grand Secretary Xie Qian: *"Of ministers who serve in court, few succeed in realizing their aspirations and establishing meritorious deeds. Yet to retire to one’s hometown, enjoy longevity and health, preserve one’s reputation and integrity, and thereby sustain the hopes of the realm—this is even more difficult. You, sir, possess an upright nature and far-reaching vision. From your early years, you devoted yourself to true learning, achieving literary preeminence and rising to prominence in the Hanlin Academy, your reputation ever-growing. When Our late father, the Xiaohuang Emperor, took note of you, he promoted you from the palace to the Grand Secretariat. Day and night, you offered counsel—neither obstinate nor compliant—guarding the established norms, protecting the worthy, and advising in the imperial chambers. Your forthright and beneficial words contributed greatly to the governance of the time. The purity of the era’s administration was largely due to the efforts of you and a few other ministers. When Our father’s final instructions entrusted you with weighty responsibilities, you were deeply moved by his trust and vowed to serve with utmost sincerity. At the beginning of the Wuzong Emperor’s reign, you assisted him with unwavering resolve, yet your unyielding integrity often showed in your words and demeanor. The path of uprightness found no place, and you retired, your noble character resounding throughout the land. Later, you suffered the slander of powerful villains, but your reputation was soon vindicated, and the people’s admiration for you remained undiminished."*

This year, as you reach seventy years of age, your body remains in peace and health, your descendants flourish, and your perfect virtue and illustrious reputation are rarely matched in previous eras. We have succeeded to the celestial mandate and seek to renew governance. You, as a venerable elder of successive courts, have profoundly influenced Our aspirations. Indeed, public opinion has long extolled your excellence, which surpasses that of others by far.

We specially dispatch an emissary to convey Our esteemed regards, bestowing this exceptional honor. May you embrace Our deepest intentions, cultivate harmony with heaven, and abundantly receive longevity and blessings, thereby serving as a model for the realm. This is not merely the glory of one individual or one locality.

Recorded: At the beginning of Our reign, with no leisure for other affairs, We first dispatched an emissary to convey Our esteemed regards to Minister Liu of Luoyang, Minister Han of Hongdong, and Minister Xie of Yuyao—three elders of the era. This record concludes with Minister Xie, for We personally received his response to the imperial edict and witnessed the grand ceremony with Our own eyes, which is not comparable to hearsay. Thus, it is fully recorded here to serve as a model of the rites between ruler and minister for all generations.

*Hongdao Record, Volume 30 concluded*
*Hongdao Record, Volume 31*

The Rites of Father and Son

*The Book of Yu* states: "Reverently he appeared before Gu Sou, trembling with awe and solemnity—truly it was thus."

Recorded: During the reign of Emperor Gao of Han, he once rewarded his household steward. When his father, the Grand Duke, was received with a grand escort, people all said: "A father cannot be treated as a son." Later, when the Emperor visited Xinfeng, and his father sat leisurely with legs spread, people all said: "A ruler cannot be treated as a minister." Yet they did not realize this was the very argument of Qian Qiumeng.

The distinction between father and son is rooted in the natural order of heaven and earth, established before heaven and earth themselves. The rites of ruler and minister arise from the bonds of lineage and sustenance, born after heaven and earth. Thus, the bond of father and son may encompass the rites of ruler and minister, but the rites of ruler and minister cannot alter the bond of father and son. Those who regard an escort as reverence—have they ever known what "reverently he appeared" truly means? Those who take sprawling posture as joy—have they ever seen what "trembling with awe and solemnity" looks like? The saying that "a father cannot be treated as a son" may seem a mere turn of phrase, but the difference is as vast as a hair’s breadth to a thousand *li*—it must be clearly distinguished.

Mencius said: "The utmost of filial piety is none greater than honoring one’s parents. The utmost of honoring one’s parents is none greater than nourishing them with all under heaven." To be the father of the Son of Heaven is the highest honor. To nourish with all under heaven is the highest nourishment.

Recorded: Mencius said: "The utmost of filial piety is none greater than honoring one’s parents." After Shun became the Son of Heaven, why did he not honor Gu Sou by making him emperor? He also said: "To be the father of the Son of Heaven is the highest honor." Though Shun did not honor Gu Sou as emperor, neither did he address Yao as his father. What is the reason for these two cases?

It is said: The rites of posthumous enfeoffment were only fully established by the Zhou. It is not fitting to take Shun as the standard. The title of "Imperial Uncle" first appeared in the Song Dynasty, and it is even less appropriate to model after the precedent of the Duke of Pu. In essence, the heavenly order and heavenly ranks cannot be altered. The succession of the lineage and inheritance of the mandate cannot be delayed. The reason it cannot be delayed is that it establishes the great foundation of all under heaven. The reason it cannot be altered is that it enacts the universal Dao of all under heaven. These two principles stand and operate together without conflict or contradiction.

If one merely emphasizes honoring parents without valuing the succession of the mandate, one fails to grasp the greatness of Shun’s succession to Yao. If one merely emphasizes the importance of the successor while stripping away the affection for one’s own parents, one fails to grasp the utmost of honoring Gu Sou. The error lies in not properly observing that when one who is a ruler speaks of the way of a father, one mistakenly takes it as truly unchangeable, not realizing it is not truly so. Likewise, when one observes that one who is adopted as a successor is called a son, one mistakenly takes it as truly unalterable, not realizing it is not truly so. Thus, both fail to comprehend the principle.

*The Doctrine of the Mean* states: "Shun was greatly filial. In virtue, he was a sage; in rank, he was the honored Son of Heaven; in wealth, he possessed all within the four seas. His ancestors offered sacrifices to him, and his descendants preserved his legacy."

Recorded: Someone asked: "Shun never honored Gu Sou, so why does it say his ancestors offered sacrifices to him? He never passed the throne to his son, so why does it say his descendants preserved his legacy?"

It is said: This reflects the heart of the great sage, which others cannot fathom. Gu Sou had no part in the imperial succession, yet if honored, how could he be properly sacrificed to? Shang Jun did not measure up to the mandate of heaven, so if the throne were passed to him, how could his legacy be preserved? Honoring Gu Sou as the father of the Son of Heaven is the utmost honor. Offering sacrifices to Gu Sou with the rites of the Son of Heaven is the utmost sacrifice. Thus, it is said: "His ancestors offered sacrifices to him." Yu was enfeoffed in Yu, and Hu Gong in Chen—these were the utmost honors for the descendants of the great sage. Thus, it is said: "His descendants preserved his legacy."

*The Laws of Sacrifice* states: "The Xia dynasty sacrificed to the Yellow Emperor and offered suburban sacrifices to Gun."

Recorded: Liu’s commentary says: "The Five Emperors governed all under heaven as officials. From Yu onward, they honored merit and venerated virtue, as explained in Zheng’s commentary. The Three Kings ruled all under heaven as a family, so Gun should have been honored as an ancestor, not offered suburban sacrifices."

It is said: This is what I mean by standing and operating together without conflict or contradiction. The Yu clan sacrificed to the Yellow Emperor and offered suburban sacrifices to Yao, honoring Zhuanxu as an ancestor—this purely reflects the principle of succession, for they governed all under heaven as officials. Yet as the father of the Son of Heaven, Gu Sou’s honor remained unchanged, and his personal kinship was never abolished. As for the Xia’s suburban sacrifice to Gun, Yu’s achievements were rooted in filial piety, and with the earth pacified and heaven’s work completed, all generations relied on his offerings to the Supreme Emperor. Thus, Gun had to be paired in sacrifice, for they governed all under heaven as a family. Though Gun’s flood control efforts spanned many years, it was only after Gun that Yu arose. How could the benefits extending from east to west ever forget their origin? Yet Gun’s name remained as it was, never elevated to the status of emperor. These rites of the Two Emperors and Three Kings have been practiced for ten thousand generations without flaw.

King Gaozong of Shang said: "In Yue, there was a pheasant crying out." Zu Ji admonished the king, saying: "Only when the former kings are first revered can affairs be properly ordered. Heaven watches over the people below and upholds their righteousness." Alas!

The king, in revering the people, recognizes that none are not the offspring of heaven, and no ritual should be more lavish than that of familial devotion. The record states: Examining the lineage above Gaozong, Zu Ding passed the throne to Nan Geng, who then passed it to Yang Jia—both sons of Zu Ding. From there, through three successions—Pan Geng, Xiao Xin, and Xiao Yi—all were Zu Ding’s sons, with brothers succeeding one another. Only Gaozong, as the son of Xiao Yi, ascended the throne, thus validating Zu Ji’s admonition. *Tong* refers to the name of the expiatory sacrifice. Offerings were first made at the ancestral temple, then at the *mi* shrine—this was for Xiao Yi. It was then that the omen of the pheasant’s cry appeared, a warning from heaven to Wu Ding that could not have been more urgent.

The phrase *"none are not the offspring of heaven"* embodies the principle that one who succeeds another as heir assumes the role of their son. The statement *"no ritual should be more lavish than that of familial devotion"* underscores the duty to set aside personal ties to one’s kin. Though Gaozong was the rightful heir, continuing the line of his father’s mourning garments, with Yang Jia, Pan Geng, and Xiao Xin having reigned before him, even a slight excess in familial devotion would have invited portents of change. How could later generations fail to reflect on this—how could they fail to reflect?

The *Rites* record: When King Wen was heir apparent, he paid morning audience to King Ji three times. At the first cry of the pheasant, he dressed in court robes and, upon reaching the outer gate of the sleeping chambers, inquired of the inner attendant: "How is his health today?" The attendant replied, "Well." Only then did King Wen rejoice.

When midday arrived, he did as before. When evening came, he did as before. If there was any irregularity in his father’s health, the inner attendant would report it to King Wen, and King Wen’s countenance would grow troubled, his gait unsteady as though he could not walk properly. Only after King Ji resumed his meals would King Wen return to his usual demeanor. When the food was served, he first examined whether it was too hot or too cold; when the meal was finished, he inquired about what had been eaten. He would instruct the steward of the kitchen, saying, "Do not repeat the same dishes." The steward would reply, "Understood," and then withdraw. King Wu followed this practice as well, never presuming to exceed it.

The record states: Though this was an ordinary matter, it is said that "he never presumed to exceed it"—for the heart of a filial son knows no bounds, and if one goes too far, one may fall short instead. When Emperor Xiaozong of Song served Emperor Gaozong, father and son shared a chamber, even sleeping side by side on adjoining couches. They cut bamboo into tubes, hollowed out the center, placed a golden pellet inside, and passed it back and forth to inquire after each other’s well-being—this verged on the manner of a brother and sister, something even King Wen and King Wu would not have presumed to exceed.

*The Huainanzi* says: In serving King Wen, the Duke of Zhou acted without presuming to decide anything on his own; he undertook no task by his own authority. His bearing was as though he could not support his own robes; his words were as though they could not leave his mouth. He served King Wen with reverence, attentive and deferential, as though he could not bear the weight, as though he feared to lose it—this was true filial devotion.

The record states: Though the Duke of Zhou had the authority to establish institutions, it is said that "he acted without presuming to decide anything on his own, undertook no task by his own authority"—why? For rites and music are matters of the court, and one may exercise authority over them. But the principles of one’s will and conduct are the standards of life and death, and cannot be decided by oneself alone. Only after three years without change can they endure for ten thousand generations. If there is even a single day of self-will, it is no longer lifelong devotion. This is the difference between family and state, which a filial son must understand.

*The Classic of Filial Piety* says: In former times, the Duke of Zhou offered sacrifices at the suburban altar to Hou Ji, associating him with Heaven, and honored King Wen in the Bright Hall, associating him with the Supreme Emperor. Thus, within the Four Seas, all came to offer sacrifices according to their duties.

*The Book of Songs* says:
*"I present my offerings, with sheep and oxen,
May Heaven protect them."
Following the model of King Wen’s institutions,
He pacified the Four Quarters.
Oh, the blessings of King Wen!
He received Heaven’s favor.
Day and night I serve,
In awe of Heaven’s majesty,
Thus preserving it."*

Master Cheng said: All things originate from Heaven; man originates from his ancestors. Therefore, at the winter solstice, we sacrifice to Heaven and associate our ancestors with it—for the winter solstice is the beginning of qi, when all things take form from the Emperor, and man takes form from his father. Thus, in late autumn, we offer sacrifices to the Emperor and associate our fathers with it—for late autumn is the time when things reach completion.

Master Chen said: Heaven is the Emperor. We call it "Heaven" in the suburban sacrifice to honor it, and thus associate Hou Ji with it. Hou Ji is distant, and associating him with the suburban sacrifice also honors him. In the Bright Hall, we call it "the Emperor" to draw near to it, and thus associate King Wen with it—for King Wen is near. Honoring the honorable and cherishing the cherished—this is the perfection of the Zhou Way. Thus, the suburban sacrifice is an ancient rite, while the Bright Hall is an institution of the Zhou. The Duke of Zhou established it on the basis of principle.

The record states: Observing the sacrifices in the Bright Hall, it was not merely an empty ritual. It is said: "Following the model of King Wen’s institutions." This was the true meaning of associating one’s father with Heaven. Heaven is honored and cannot be surpassed, so it is said: "May they receive the offerings"—without presuming to add a single word. But for King Wen, there were countless ways to emulate him. Heaven requires no praise; emulating King Wen is how one emulates Heaven. The final line speaks of awe for Heaven’s majesty but does not mention King Wen—this is because reverence is unified. Awe for Heaven is awe for King Wen. Heaven and King Wen are one.

Later generations have also practiced the sacrifices of the Bright Hall and the suburban altar, yet disputes arise endlessly, and their governance does not match antiquity. This is because they honor with empty rituals rather than elevating them with true devotion.

It is also said: "May I ask how the virtue of the sage surpasses filial piety?" From the moment of birth, one is nurtured at one’s parents’ knees, and serving one’s parents is called reverence. The sage uses reverence to teach respect and closeness to teach love. The sage’s teachings are accomplished without severity; his governance is orderly without harshness—what he relies upon is fundamental.

The Way of father and son is the nature of Heaven. The duty of ruler and minister is also a principle. Nothing is greater than the continuation of one’s parents’ life; nothing is weightier than the oversight of ruler and parent. Thus, one who does not love his parents but loves others is called perverse in virtue; one who does not respect his parents but respects others is called perverse in ritual. To act with compliance yet produce rebellion—people have no model. It is not a matter of goodness but of vicious conduct. Even if one attains it, the noble person does not value it.

The noble person is not like this. In speech, he considers what can be followed; in conduct, what can bring joy. His virtue and righteousness are worthy of honor; his actions are worthy of emulation. His demeanor is worthy of observation; his advancement and withdrawal are measured. When he governs his people, they revere and love him, follow and imitate him. Thus, he can perfect his moral teachings and carry out his policies.

*The Book of Songs* says:
*"The good and noble man,
His demeanor is never improper."*

The record states: This teaching of respect and love is the model for filial sons of all generations. Associating one’s father with Heaven is the greatest ritual, not easily matched. With King Wen in the heavens, shining upon all, he is not easily emulated. Yet from birth, one is of the same body yet divided, and this division is most reverent, never transgressed. Its Way is most lofty, with none to question it. If one can be diligent in speech and conduct, governance and affairs, demeanor and advancement, then what one models and emulates lies within these bounds.

*The Book of Songs* does not say:
*"Extending above and below,
Ascending and descending in his house."*

Those who undertake the affairs of honoring ancestors and aligning with Heaven must take this as their model.

*The Testamentary Charge* states: On the day *yichou*, the King passed away. The Grand Protector commanded Zhong Huan and Nangong Mao to instruct Lü Ji, Marquis of Qi, to take two halberds and a hundred tiger-warriors to receive Prince Zhao outside the Southern Gate. They escorted him into the Wing Chamber, where he mourned in the ancestral hall. On the day *dingmao*, the decree was issued to create the ritual tablets. Seven days later, on *guiyou*, the Chief Minister commanded the officers to prepare timber, while the Di people arranged the tattered curtains and embroidered robes. The window faced south, layered with thick bamboo mats, worn-out hems, and a patterned jade armrest. To the west of the eastern sequence, facing east, were layered mattresses with embroidered hems and a cowrie-shell armrest. To the east of the western sequence, facing west, were layered fine mats with painted hems and a carved jade armrest. In the western corridor, facing south, were layered bamboo mats with black-fringed hems and a lacquered armrest. Five tiers of jade treasures were displayed: the Red Blade, the Great Instructions, the Grand Jade Disc, the *gui* and *ying* jades in the western sequence; the Great Jade, the Yi Jade, the Heavenly Sphere, and the *River Chart* in the eastern sequence. The robes for the *Yin* dance, the great cowrie shells, and the *jian* drums were in the western chamber; the halberd of *Dui*, the bow of *He*, and the bamboo arrows of *Chui* were in the eastern chamber. The great linchpin was placed before the guest steps, the threaded linchpin before the rear steps, the first linchpin before the left study, and the second linchpin before the right study. Two men in sparrow-crested caps held *hui* batons, standing within the *Bi* Gate; four men in *jing* caps held halberds with upward blades, flanking the two sets of steps. One man in a ceremonial cap held a *liu* axe, standing in the eastern hall; one held an *xie* axe, standing in the western hall; one held a *fu* axe, standing at the eastern eaves; one held a *ju* axe, standing at the western eaves; and one held a *rui* axe, standing beside the steps. The King, wearing a hempen cap and tattered robes, ascended by the guest steps. The ministers, lords, and nobles, wearing hempen caps and ant-patterned robes, entered and took their positions. The Grand Protector, Grand Scribe, and Grand Master all wore hempen caps and vermilion robes. The Grand Protector bore the great jade tablet, and the High Priest presented the jade scepter, ascending by the rear steps. The Grand Scribe held the ritual documents, ascending by the guest steps. The King was presented with the decree, which read: "The August Ancestor leans upon the jade armrest, proclaiming the final mandate. We command you to inherit the teachings, to oversee the realm of Zhou, to follow the great statutes, and to harmonize all under Heaven, thereby responding to and extolling the luminous instructions of Wen and Wu." The King bowed twice, rose, and replied: "I, this insignificant one, how could I govern the four quarters and revere the awe of Heaven?" He then received the jade scepter, performing three overnight vigils, three sacrifices, and three proclamations. The High Priest declared the offering, and the Grand Protector received the scepter, descended, washed his hands, and presented a different scepter with a libation of jade. He handed it to the Ritual Master, who bowed, and the King returned the bow. The Grand Protector received the scepter, made an offering, and placed it in the Ritual Master’s care, who bowed again, and the King returned the bow. The Grand Protector descended and withdrew. The feudal lords exited and waited outside the court gate.

The record states: This was the accession of the Son of Heaven, a model for all generations under Heaven. The Master took this ritual as his standard when composing the *Spring and Autumn Annals*. The Son of Heaven, receiving the Mandate from Heaven, differs immeasurably from the feudal lords. Yet in embodying the origin, upholding the great unity, and rectifying the Five Beginnings, the lords and the Son of Heaven are as one. Thus, the *Spring and Autumn Annals* records the first year of a lord’s reign as "the Duke acceded to his position," preserving the legacy of Cheng and Kang, Zhou and Shao. Alas! Later generations, such as Emperor Wu of Han and Emperor Taizong of Tang, knew of the *Testamentary Charge* but not of the tiger-warriors and halberds receiving the heir outside the Southern Gate, nor of the rites demonstrating the preciousness of assuming the throne. Zhou Bo and Di Renjie knew to welcome the crown prince but not of the ritual tablets, the display of jades and treasures, or the decree commanding adherence to the great statutes. When Emperor Taizu of Song passed away, even the palace attendants were kept uninformed, giving rise to endless doubts across the ages—how could this harmonize the people of all under Heaven? As for those who enthrone others while rejecting their fathers and elder brothers, or who act as regents for sons, such cases are frequently condemned in the annals. Compared to these rites, the difference is as vast as between a path and a courtyard.

*The Meaning of the Capping Ceremony* states: What makes a person human is ritual and propriety. The beginning of ritual and propriety lies in rectifying one’s bearing, aligning one’s countenance, and ordering one’s speech. When bearing is rectified, countenance aligned, and speech ordered, then ritual and propriety are complete, enabling the proper ordering of ruler and minister, the intimacy of father and son, and the harmony of elder and younger. When ruler and minister are proper, father and son intimate, and elder and younger harmonious, then ritual and propriety are established. Thus, the cap is donned only after the robes are complete; the robes are complete only after bearing is rectified, countenance aligned, and speech ordered. Therefore, it is said: The capping is the beginning of ritual. For this reason, the sage-kings of antiquity valued the capping ceremony. In the capping ritual, divination is performed to select the guest, showing reverence for the capping. Reverence for the capping shows the importance of ritual, and the importance of ritual is the foundation of the state. Thus, the proper son is capped in the rear chamber to manifest succession. He is toasted in the guest position to signify his maturity. The threefold capping, each more honorable than the last, symbolizes his aspirations. After capping, he is given a style name to honor his designation. Therefore, the ancients valued the capping ceremony and performed it in the ancestral temple. Performing it in the temple shows the importance of the occasion. Honoring the occasion without presuming its importance demonstrates humility and reverence for one’s ancestors.

The record states: For a son toward his parents, there are three mornings of mourning and three years of mourning garments. For parents toward their son, there are three cappings, showing the ritual due to the son. Thus, though the capping may differ, the proper son and the feudal lords alike are capped in the rear chamber. When Ji Wuzi requested to borrow the regalia for his brothers’ states and was capped in the temple of Duke Cheng of Wei, this was not in accordance with ritual. If it was to show respect for the command of a great state, it could be considered commendable; but in the case of Duke Xiang of Lu, it was not permissible.

*The Discourses of the States* records: When Zhao Wenzi was capped, he visited Le Wuzi, who said: "How splendid! In the past, when I had the honor of serving Duke Zhuang, it was glorious indeed. Yet I did not know its substance—let us focus on substance."

When he visited Zhonghang Xuanzi, Xuanzi said: "How splendid! What a pity—I am already old."

When he visited Fan Wenzi, Wenzi said: "Now you must be vigilant. The worthy grow more cautious when favor comes, while the unworthy grow arrogant with favor. Thus, enlightened kings reward remonstrance. If a minister grows complacent, the king punishes him."

When he visited Bu Jubo, Jubo said: "How splendid! Yet the young are not as accomplished as the old in many ways."

When he visited Han Xianzi, Xianzi said: "Be vigilant. This is what it means to become a man. To become a man lies in beginning with goodness. If one begins with goodness, goodness advances and evil does not. How could it arise? If one begins with evil, evil advances and goodness does not—how could it arise? It is like the growth of plants and trees, each according to its kind. A man’s capping is like a palace’s walls and roof. Once swept and cleared, what more can be added?"

When he visited Zhi Wuzi, Wuzi said: "Exert yourself. Chengzi followed the former will to assist the late lord, guided by principle and governed with order—could this not be called cultured? Xuanzi exhausted his remonstrance to Xiang and Ling, enduring hatred for his admonitions and advancing without fear of death—could this not be called loyal? Exert yourself. With Xuanzi’s loyalty and Chengzi’s culture, serving a lord would not fail."

When he visited Ruo Chengshuzi, Chengshuzi said: "Yet the young who hold office are many—how can I make room for you?"

When he visited Wen Jizi, Jizi said: "Whom you fall short of, you may seek to emulate."

When he spoke with Zhang Lao, Zhang Lao said: "Excellent! Following Lebo’s words can amplify Fanshu’s teachings, amplify Hanzi’s warnings, and bring things to completion. The aspiration lies with you. If not for the threefold convergence of these men’s words, what would there be to recount? Your Way is well-guided—it is the late lord’s sheltering care for you."

The record states: Observing the words of Jin’s great ministers, one knows the esteem for ritual in that era. The capping is the beginning of ritual. Fan Wenzi, young and fatherless, weak and unestablished, was held to the rites of being a son, a younger brother, a minister, and a youth—standards even more distinct than others. Yet arrogance, extravagance, and recklessness inevitably arise. These gentlemen, having petitioned to restore his rank and fief, may be called harmonious and reverent in duty. But if admonitions to goodness go unheard and loyal compliance remains incomplete, how can he compare to his forebears? With Le Fanshu’s encouragement ahead and Cheng Ji and Zhang Lao’s reinforcement behind—how fine! This is the model of ritual. Wenzi’s standing was no accident.

*The Spring and Autumn Annals* records: In the second year of Duke Min, summer, fifth month, day *yiyou*, a lucky sacrifice was offered to Duke Zhuang. In the eighth year of Duke Xi, autumn, seventh month, a sacrifice was offered in the Grand Temple to convey the lady. The record states: This is the foremost principle of *The Spring and Autumn Annals*. The governance of the Three Dynasties shared the same end, with ritual and music as their urgency. Ritual is not made by Heaven nor sprung from Earth—it arises from human sentiment. Sacrifice follows the will of the divine emperors. What is the meaning of a lucky sacrifice to Duke Zhuang? What is the propriety of conveying the lady? What is taken from the halls of the Three Families? The Master’s censure runs deep. Ai Jiang’s licentiousness and deceit honored her husband’s sacrifices, yet Duke Xi later defied righteousness and human feeling to exalt his mother. Neither lord nor minister saw this as wrong; the whole state knew no better. Thus, the Master later said: "If this can be tolerated, what cannot?" This remark arose from such circumstances—not merely for the eight rows of dancers in the Ji family’s courtyard. Readers must consider this together to grasp the profound intent of the Sage’s heart. Yet Hu’s commentary takes "conveying the living" as the principle, failing to examine this.

*The Commentaries on the Ritual Classics* record: Confucius sat in attendance to Duke Ai. The Duke said: "I wish to speak." Confucius replied: "In ancient times, the enlightened kings of the Three Dynasties invariably revered their wives and children—there was a Way in this. The wife is the host of kinship—how could one not revere her? The child is the descendant of kinship—how could one not revere him? Thus, the noble man reveres all. Revering the self is greatest. The self is the branch of kinship—how could one not revere it? To fail in revering the self is to harm kinship; to harm kinship is to harm the root; to harm the root, the branches perish with it. From self to self, from child to child, from consort to consort. If the lord cultivates these three, great transformation will spread throughout the world."

The record states: This passage speaks of the father’s reverence for his child, followed by the child’s reverence for his father.

The Duke said: "May I ask what it means to revere the self?"
Confucius replied: "If a noble man’s words err, the people take them as rhetoric; if his actions err, the people take them as models. If a noble man’s words do not exceed rhetoric and his actions do not exceed models, the hundred clans obey without command, reverent and respectful. This may be called revering the self. One who can revere the self can thereby complete kinship."

The Duke said: "May I ask what it means to complete kinship?"
Confucius replied: "The noble man is the completed name of a person. When the hundred clans ascribe the name to him, calling him the son of a noble man, this completes his kinship as a noble man. This is to complete the name of his kinship."

The Duke said: "May I ask what it means to complete the self?"
Confucius replied: "When one’s conduct does not exceed things, this is called completing the self. Not exceeding things accords with the Way of Heaven."

The Duke said: "Why does the noble man value the Way of Heaven?"
Confucius replied: "He values its ceaselessness. As the saying goes, the moon and sun follow one another east and west without ceasing—this is the Way of Heaven. Unobstructed yet able to enter—this is the Way of Heaven."

The Way of Heaven is to accomplish things through non-action; to illuminate them after they are accomplished—this too is the Way of Heaven.

The Duke said: "I am dull-witted and troubled, yet you have set your mind to instruct me."
Confucius, startled, moved from his mat and replied: "The humane person does not exceed things; the filial child does not exceed things. Thus, when the humane person serves their parents, it is as if serving Heaven; when serving Heaven, it is as if serving their parents. This is what it means for the filial child to complete the self."

The Duke said: "Having heard these words, I fear there is no remedy for my future faults."
Confucius replied: "That Your Highness has reached this understanding is this minister’s good fortune."

It is recorded: This speaks to the utmost perfection of ritual. When the hawk first cries, all wash and rinse—such is the conduct of the common people. To complete the self and complete the name is the task of the noble person. Extending this to the ceaseless Way of Heaven, to utmost sincerity without rest—this is the Way of father and son, which is the Way of Heaven. Heaven bestows its perfect goodness upon the father, and only then upon the child. Thus, the nature of father and son is the very nature of Heaven. When the noble person fully realizes their nature and stands alongside Heaven and Earth, they fully realize the Way of the father. In fully realizing the Way of the father, the Way of Heaven is nothing beyond this. Truly, to serve parents as if serving Heaven, and to serve Heaven as if serving parents—these two are one yet two, two yet one. Therefore, one is called both a filial child and a humane person, and only thus is the utmost of the rites of father and son achieved. As for stepping forward in shoes or responding with reverent words—these are not worth discussing.

It is further said: *The Doctrine of the Mean* discusses the ceaseless Way of Heaven, and King Wen was perfectly attuned to the Way of Heaven, also without ceasing. It is also said: "Unseen, yet manifest; unmoving, yet transforming; non-acting, yet accomplishing." All these teachings derive from Confucius’ response to Duke Ai. This is the ultimate of sagely transformation and the subtlest mystery of perfect virtue. No wonder Duke Ai, dull and benighted, lost himself upon hearing these words and could not be blamed for his faults. How lamentable!

Meng Yizi asked about the filial son, saying: "Do not transgress." Fan Chi drove the carriage and reported this to Confucius, saying: "Mengsun asked me about filial piety, and I replied: 'Do not transgress.'" Fan Chi asked: "What does this mean?" The Master said: "In life, serve them with the rites; in death, bury them with the rites; sacrifice to them with the rites."

The Record states: Observing the institutions of Chengzhou, one may glimpse the purport of "do not transgress." When King Wen was crown prince, he paid court to King Ji three times a day. King Wu followed this practice without daring to exceed it—this is the rite of serving in life. If the father was a grandee and the son a knight, the burial was conducted as for a grandee, but the sacrifice as for a knight—this is the rite of burial in death. If the father was a knight and the son a grandee, the burial was conducted as for a knight, but the sacrifice as for a grandee—this is the rite of sacrifice. Yet when the dynasty declined, grandees employed ritual music, and vassals wielded state authority, so that serving in life no longer followed the rites. They gazed at the pillars and set up the *bo* instrument, chanted the *Yong* ode to conclude the repast—thus burial and sacrifice no longer followed the rites. Yet how could this be altered by inferiors? Hence the saying arose as it did.

It is further said: "Let all officials and commoners in the realm, upon receiving notice, attend the mourning for three days, all removing their mourning garments to undertake the funeral affairs. Those in mourning attire shall not wear silk sashes or belts, nor exceed three inches in width; they shall not use cloth-covered carriages or weapons, nor wail in mourning within the palace halls." Alas! This long-standing doctrine of thinness as the Way has obscured that the mourning for parents—from beginning to end, with grief, sorrow, and anguish—arises naturally, not from contrivance or artifice. Though the Emperor deeply understood the former, he failed to perceive the latter. Moreover, Emperor Jing’s nature inclined toward thinness, and Empress Dowager Dou favored the teachings of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi. From ruler to subject, from high to low, all regarded this doctrine as the most proper and unchanging Way, an immutable law for ten thousand generations. Thus it was resolutely implemented. People, unaware of the reasons, merely blamed Emperor Jing, not realizing that in his heart, he felt no unease. Had a Mencius arisen in that era to expound profoundly on the original goodness of human nature, and only then discussed the three-year mourning period—shared by the Son of Heaven and the commoner alike, as in the Three Dynasties—then even with an imperial edict in place, Emperor Jing might have felt uneasy in his heart, and perhaps, by some chance, been moved to change. Alas! How could such an opportunity ever be recovered?

Thus I have recorded these accounts in full to demonstrate how the teachings of the sages and worthies, as opposed to heterodox doctrines, bear so profoundly upon the moral order of the world.

King Hejian of Han was a great-grandson of King Hui and King Xian. Among the feudal lords of the two capitals, many were arrogant and dissolute, their reputations and virtues tarnished—only King Xian and King Hui upheld proper conduct. When King Xian’s mother passed away, he observed the full mourning rites with utmost propriety. As soon as the Emperor issued an edict to praise him, it read: “King Hejian has mourned his grandmother with such exemplary devotion, completing the three-year mourning period, that he serves as a model for the imperial clan. For this, he shall be enfeoffed with an additional ten thousand households.”

Note: King Hui was a great-grandson of Emperor Jing. By this time in the Han, the practice of substituting days for months in mourning had persisted for nearly four generations. That King Hui alone adhered to the proper rites was a rarity throughout the Han dynasty. Thus, it is recorded.

*Hongdao Lu*, Volume 31 concludes.
*Hongdao Lu*, Volume 32 begins.

**Rites: The Rites Between Father and Son**

From *The History of Jin*: When Emperor Wen passed away, the entire realm observed three days of mourning. Emperor Wu also followed the precedents of Han and Wei: after the burial, mourning was set aside, though he continued to wear plain robes and white hempen caps, slept on lowered mats, and abstained from rich foods. The Grand Tutor Sima Fu and others memorialized:

“Your ministers have heard that the rituals and regulations of the past varied in elaboration according to the times. The dynasties of Yu, Xia, Shang, and Zhou did not all follow the same customs. The Great Jin, inheriting the legacy of Han and Wei, has both reformed and preserved their traditions, aiming only to foster moral transformation. Thus, it has not been possible to return entirely to the simplicity of antiquity or emulate the rituals of the earliest ages.

“Now that Your Majesty has deigned to follow the Han and Wei precedent of abbreviated mourning to address the needs of the times, yet personally embodies the utmost filial piety—his grief exceeding all bounds—even the mourning of King Wuding in the Shang era or the conduct of Zengzi and Min Ziqian as commoners would not surpass it.

“At present, the southern barbarians remain unsubdued, governance is yet to be fully established, and the myriad affairs of state weigh heavily, demanding constant mental exertion. Your ministers humbly submit that Your Majesty should resume the attire of the imperial wardrobe, allow the inner palace to restore its furnishings, and permit the imperial kitchens to reinstate the usual provisions, in accordance with the established regulations.”

The Emperor issued a decree in reply:
“Whenever I reflect upon the unseen realm, I am pained that I cannot remain in mourning weeds upon the straw mat to preserve this sorrow. That I must now eat fine rice and wear embroidered silks truly fills me with anguish and indignation—how could this bring solace? I have inherited this tradition from the house of Zhou, and its observance has endured for generations. How could I, in a single day, cast aside this devotion to my departed father? I have already yielded much in this matter. Let us consider Confucius’ response to Zai Wo and refrain from further debate.”

As he spoke, his grief overwhelmed him, and he repeated, “What is to be done? What is to be done?”

Sima Fu and the others submitted another memorial:
“At present, the weapons of war have not yet been laid down, and military affairs remain unresolved. The weight of governance is immense, and the realm vast. Yet Your Majesty, in the dignity of his imperial station, observes the rites of a commoner—wearing coarse mourning garb, sleeping on a mat of rushes, drinking plain water, and eating simple fare. His inner sorrow is profound, and his outward appearance shows the toll of grief. Yet he labors tirelessly over the myriad affairs of state, rising at dawn and retiring late, humbling himself to receive his ministers, often too preoccupied to eat. Such exertion is extreme.
