“Thus, your ministers tremble with unease, truly fearing that Your Majesty’s vital energy will be depleted, to the detriment of great matters. We implore Your Majesty to heed our humble counsel and comfort the heart of the Empress Dowager.”

The Emperor issued another decree:
“Upon reviewing your memorial again, my sorrow only deepens, and I cannot restrain myself. The three-year mourning period is a universal rite since antiquity. Truly, the sage established it to give expression to grief, enacting it with clarity and forbearance. As the spirit of the departed recedes into the distance, there is no one to whom I may address my lament. Though my devotion may be slight, to eat fine foods and wear fine clothes is unbearable. It is not fitting to revisit this matter, for it would only wound my heart anew. Let the discussion end here.”

Thus, the Emperor observed the full three-year mourning period.

Note: The three-day mourning observed throughout the realm upon Emperor Wen’s passing was the customary practice before the abdication of the throne. That Emperor Wu followed the Han and Wei precedent of setting aside mourning after the burial was the established ritual after abdication. Yet he did not go beyond wearing plain robes, a white cap, sleeping on lowered mats, and abstaining from rich foods—thus, what the Emperor preserved was akin to the “mourning of the heart.” He had never intended to observe the full three-year mourning with unhemmed sackcloth. Why, then, did Sima Fu and the others persist so earnestly?

At that time, public discourse had lost its vigor. People indulged in wine and revelry, scorned ritual and law, and upon the death of a parent, felt no sorrow. Even a single day of grief and lamentation like the Emperor’s—though not fully in accord with ancient rites—was enough to astonish the realm. Moreover, Confucius rebuked Zai Wo’s question, for no ritual is greater than that of the court, and none more weighty than the rites of abdication. Though the Jin had not yet formally ended the Wei’s abdication, they had already received its resplendent regalia—the black robes and red raven emblems, the display of titles and institutions, the interplay of bells, jades, and silks. Even if one wished to abandon these, who would permit it?

If one wished to emulate Emperor Wu of Jin—strictly upholding his ministerial duty, vowing unwavering loyalty, then retiring to a mourning hut, wearing sackcloth and eating plain fare, reviving the spirit of Zengzi and Min Ziqian while rejecting the conduct of Zai Wo—who could prevent it? Yet at the dawn of a new dynasty, to feign abstention from fine rice and embroidered silks—whom would one deceive? Deceive Heaven?

The Central Army General Yang Hu said to Fu Xuan: “The three-year mourning period, though a lofty rite, has long been observed. Now, the Emperor’s filial devotion is profound. Though his mourning garb has been set aside, he truly observes the mourning rites. If this could restore the ancient laws of the former kings, would that not be excellent?”

Fu Xuan replied: “The practice of substituting days for months has endured for centuries. To suddenly revive antiquity would be difficult.”

Yang Hu said: “If we cannot make the realm conform to ritual, at least let the Emperor observe the full mourning. Would that not be better?”

Fu Xuan replied: “If the Emperor does not set aside mourning while the realm does, this would mean there are fathers and sons but no longer rulers and ministers.”

Thus, the matter was dropped.

Note: The words of the Central Army General may well have been a once-in-a-millennium opportunity. By then, the Wei had already reformed its old ways, and the Jin was newly established. The spirit of Ji Kang and Ruan Ji could not be heard in the latter ages—how much less in a fledgling dynasty? Had this proposal been presented to Emperor Wu, he might have heeded it, establishing it as a fixed institution, recording it in the ritual codes, and promulgating it throughout the realm. Though it might not have fully restored the ancient ways of the former kings, it would at least have avoided the excesses of vulgar custom.

Alas, Fu Xuan’s foresight did not extend so far. Thus did the customs of Wang and He take hold, and the Jiangzuo court follow in their wake. Not only was the three-year mourning period left unobserved, but even for the nine-month and five-month rites, music was not set aside. For this, the ministers cannot escape their responsibility.

In the fourth year of Taishi, when Empress Dowager Wang, the elder sister of the Jin ruler, passed away, the Jin sovereign observed mourning in strict accordance with ancient ritual. After the burial, the officials petitioned for him to remove his mourning garments. The imperial edict declared: “To receive a lifetime of love yet offer no lasting repayment—how can the heart bear it?” The officials persisted in their request, and the edict replied: “The concern lies not in insufficient filial devotion, but in the fear of self-injury through grief. The ritual codes of former dynasties varied in substance and form; why must we be bound by recent conventions, leaving the full expression of mourning incomplete?” The ministers continued their pleas until at last he consented—yet still he wore plain garments for the full three years.

Note: The empress was the daughter of Wang Su. She recited the *Book of Poetry* and the *Analects* and was especially learned in mourning rites. Thus Emperor Wu remarked: “I come from a family of scholars, where the transmission of ritual has long been preserved—how could it be abandoned in a single day?” His upbringing in such matters was indeed far-reaching. Can this be compared to Empress Dou or Emperor Jing, who esteemed the Yellow Emperor and Laozi while disparaging Confucian practices?

*The History of Wei* records: In the ninth month of the fourteenth year of Taihe, when Empress Dowager Feng passed away, the Wei sovereign took no broth for five days, and his grief exceeded ritual propriety. Yang Zhuang of Huayin, a clerk of the Central Bureau, admonished him: “The rites of the sage-kings teach that one must not destroy one’s nature through mourning. Even if Your Majesty wishes to surpass all ages in virtue, what of the ancestral temples?” Moved by his words, the emperor took a single measure of congee.

Note: The sovereign’s grief was truly the work of innate nature, not the result of forced restraint or pretense. To suggest he sought to surpass all ages in virtue is mistaken. Thereupon the princes and dukes submitted a memorial requesting the timely designation of the burial site. The edict replied: “In serving the coffin, I still hope for the return of her spirit. To speak of moving the mountain tomb—how can I bear to hear it?” In the tenth month, after repeated petitions from the princes and dukes, she was interred at Yonggu Mausoleum.

Note: The rites prescribe that feudal lords be buried after five months, and after burial, they dwell in a thatched hut outside the central gate. Though Emperor Wen of Wei’s words did not fully grasp the comprehensive intent of ritual, they nonetheless unwittingly aligned with its enduring spirit. Pressed by repeated memorials—what a pity!

The Grand Commandant Pi and others advanced, saying: “We, your ministers, are aged and decrepit, having served successive sagely rulers. We are somewhat familiar with the former affairs of the state. We wish to restrain our deepest emotions and uphold the ancient canons.”

The Lord of Wei replied: “Our ancestors devoted themselves wholly to martial strategy and did not cultivate civil teachings. Now I, looking up to receive sagely instruction, hope to practice the ancient Way. Yet when I weigh the times and compare matters, they differ from those of former ages.”

*Recorded:* This is precisely what is meant by ‘having something to rely upon.’ Whenever the state’s actions and movements cannot proceed as desired, it is invariably due to such arguments. If not for a ruler of heroic mettle, who could avoid being misled?

The Lord of Wei continued: “I have considered that in the middle ages, the three-year mourning was not fully observed. This was because the former sovereign had departed the world, and the succeeding ruler had just ascended the throne. The ruler’s virtue had not yet spread, nor had the ministers’ devotion fully taken root. Thus, he donned a single robe and crown and performed the accession rites. Though I am truly lacking in virtue, I have held the throne for over twelve years—long enough for the myriad people to know they have a lord. If on this day I do not fulfill even a single moment of longing and filial devotion, causing both emotion and ritual to be lost, would that not be deeply regrettable? My lingering in mourning garb and refusal to heed your request arise from a heart that cannot bear it—not merely to avoid idle reproach.”

*Recorded:* Here, one sees even more clearly his understanding of human sentiment and clarity regarding the greater good. He is no careless, impulsive ruler driven by mere emotion. Even the heroic rulers of antiquity—how could they surpass him?

The assembled ministers spoke again: “The spring and autumn sacrifices of the Black Millet cannot be abandoned or neglected.”

The Lord of Wei replied: “In the former court, these rites were conducted by officials, but I, having received my late mother’s instruction, have begun to offer reverence in person. Now, with Heaven’s punishment having descended and both humans and spirits bereft of support, I imagine the spirits of the ancestral temples would also repay the former sacrifices. If we were to proceed with offerings, I fear it would contravene the hidden will of the unseen. Moreover, in ordinary times, the dukes and ministers often declare that the Four Seas are at peace and that ritual and music are daily renewed, such that we may compare favorably with the Tang and Yu. Yet now you seek to forcibly wrest my resolve, making me no better than the Wei and Jin. Why?”

*Recorded:* The three-year mourning is the great boundary for a filial child—once passed, it cannot be retrieved or regretted. The four seasonal rites are the state’s regular affairs—they may be remedied and restored later. The emperor may truly be said to be unconfused about what is urgent and what is not.

The Secretariat Drafter Li Biao added: “Though the realm is now well-ordered, the lands south of the Yangtze have not submitted, nor have the northern deserts acknowledged allegiance. We ministers still harbor concerns about unforeseen dangers.”

The Lord of Wei replied: “The Duke of Lu wore mourning garb while leading troops to war, and the Marquis of Jin donned black sackcloth to defeat the enemy—these were certainly approved by the sages. If unforeseen dangers arise, even if I were to cast aside mourning cords, there would be no fault, let alone wearing mourning hemp. How can we, in a time of peace and security, anticipate matters of military campaign and thereby abandon the observances of mourning?”

*Recorded:* Later ages applied the exception for war to times of no conflict. Even Confucians could not avoid this—are they not the guilty successors of Emperor Wen of Wei?

The Grand Commandant Pi and others spoke again: “In the house of Wei, after major taboos, it was customary to welcome the spirits from the west and exorcise evil to the north within three months, performing all the auspicious rites.”

The Lord of Wei replied: “If one serves the spirits with the Dao, they will come of their own accord without being summoned. If one loses benevolence and righteousness, even if welcomed, they will not arrive. These are not rites to be performed even in ordinary times—how much less in mourning?”

*Recorded:* This is how the emperor resolutely adopted the Xia and transformed the Yi. Should the various ministers not feel ashamed? Should they not feel ashamed?

The emperor further questioned the Minister of Works You Minggen, Gao Wen, and others: “The sages established the rites for the end of weeping and the changes in mourning garments, all to gradually withdraw from grief. Now, within ten days, you speak of immediately adopting auspicious rites—can this not be injurious?”

They replied: “To inter the deceased within a full month and adopt auspicious rites immediately after burial—this is the decree of the Golden Tablet.”

The emperor said: “The decree of the Golden Tablet and the petitions of the various ministers exist for this reason: to prevent the neglect of state affairs. Yet I dare not remain silent and idle, allowing governance to fall into disorder. I only wish to wear mourning garments, abandon auspicious rites, and express full sorrow on the first and fifteenth of each month. If this is not permitted, then I shall remove my mourning robes, remain in silent reverence, and entrust governance to the Chief Minister. Between these two options, let the dukes and ministers choose.”

Minggen said: “If you remain silent and inactive, great governance will be neglected. Bowing to your sagely will, we request that you continue in mourning attire.”

*Recorded:* The Golden Tablet of Wei is akin to the posthumous edicts of Han. The Tablet states that burial should occur within a full month and auspicious rites adopted immediately after—this mirrors the edicts that replaced months with days. Yet whether such decrees were followed or not depended entirely on the depth of sincerity, and thus practices varied. Emperor Wen of Wei, having inherited a grand legacy from his youth, early displayed a reverent and sagely demeanor. Without the guidance of enlightened teachers or the instruction of worthy tutors, he still aspired to the lofty examples of human relations and enacted deeds surpassing even ancient precedents. Observing his repeated questions and answers, one sees how thoroughly he dispelled the doubts of his ministers and officials. With such resolve, what mourning rites could not be properly observed? Alas.

The empress dowager Feng’s usurpation of power was not the accumulation of a single morning, and her calamity had its gradual origins. With a grandson such as this, how could she bear to betray him—only to poison his father instead? I privately marvel that the emperor, though wise, perceptive, and keen, could not discern his father’s treachery. This was because the Wei court, still smarting from the disaster of Cui Hao, had adopted concealment as its guise. Lacking the records of a Dong Hu, and never receiving the urgent admonitions of a mentor, it was not until the *Tongyi* that the celestial portents were examined, subtly revealing the truth, while the *Gangmu* forthrightly documented the events. Alas, by then it was too late.

Thus, those who govern states and households should fear not concealment but ignorance, not subtlety but blindness. They must spare no concern for scruples, laying bare even the most hidden and arduous truths—for this is the very purpose. As a result, kindness was misdirected, and generosity bestowed where it did not belong. Across the span of thousands of years, in this one moment and this one affair, such a fate befell—could there be a greater sorrow in the fullest observance of ritual?

In the ninth month of the fifteenth year of Taihe, Emperor Xiaowen of Wei conducted the *xiang* sacrifice at the ancestral temple. The officials in charge presented the divination, to which the emperor replied: “The oracle speaks of seeking auspiciousness, yet this contradicts the devotion of reverent service and violates the heart’s eternal longing. Today, we shall simply use the day preceding the dark moon.” That night, he lodged in the temple and led his ministers in weeping.

Having changed into mourning attire—plain white hempen cap and belt, black shoes—his attendants likewise donned black headbands, coarse white silk robes, unlined garments, leather belts, and black shoes. They then wept through the night. At dawn, he exchanged his mourning dress for sacrificial robes: a plain white hempen cap, white silk edging, a deep robe, and hempen sandals, while his attendants removed their coarse headbands and replaced them with caps. After the sacrifice, they exited the temple and stood weeping for a long while before returning.

In the eleventh month, for the *tan* sacrifice, he first wore the single-layered *mian* crown. At the winter solstice, he offered sacrifice at the Circular Mound, then proceeded to the Bright Hall, ascending the Taihua Palace in a *tongtian* crown and crimson gauze robe to receive his ministers. The ritual music was hung but not performed. Leading the hundred officials, he escorted the spirit tablets to the new temple.

**Record states:** In the ninth month of the fourteenth year, *gengwu* (490 CE), Empress Dowager Feng of Wei passed away. In the ninth month of the fifteenth year, *xinwei* (491 CE), Emperor Xiaowen conducted the *xiang* sacrifice at the ancestral temple. In the eleventh month, he performed the *tan* sacrifice, then donned the imperial *gun* crown and transferred the new spirit tablets to the temple. Thus, barely fifteen months had passed—far from the ancient ritual of a twenty-seven-month mourning period with the *tan* sacrifice.

In the third year of Jiande (574 CE), the third month, Empress Dowager Chinu of Northern Zhou passed away. Emperor Gaozu of Zhou resided in a mourning hut, taking only a single *yi* of rice morning and evening. Prince Wei, Yuwen Zhi, secretly informed against Prince Qi, Yuwen Xian, for drinking wine and eating meat. The emperor replied: “Prince Qi and I differ. Though neither of us was born of the primary consort, it was only for my sake that he shaved his head and wore mourning. You should feel shame—you, the empress dowager’s own son, uniquely favored by her affection. Strive for yourself; do not compare with others.”

Upon the burial, the emperor walked barefoot to the mausoleum and issued an edict: “The three-year mourning period applies even to the Son of Heaven. Yet with military and state affairs pressing, I must personally attend court. As for the rites of wailing in sackcloth and the mourning hut, I shall follow the ancient canons to express boundless grief. All officials should adhere to the late empress’s decree.” After the burial, he ended the mourning, but the ministers firmly requested that he observe the full three-year period according to the provisional system. He refused, ultimately upholding the three-year mourning. For those within the five degrees of mourning, he also ordered adherence to ritual.

**Record states:** Hu氏 remarks: Emperor Gaozu of Zhou’s wearing of sackcloth and straw, completing the three-year mourning, was the most virtuous conduct. Yet his decree clarifying that the general mourning applied only to those within the five degrees of kinship, excluding all officials, fell short of the principle of proclaiming the observance to all under heaven. In my humble opinion, this is mistaken. The very reason for the endless debates and disputes is the desire to lead all under heaven in observing the three-year mourning. Human hearts differ, and kinship varies in closeness. Only after three years does a child leave its parents’ embrace—just as there are not two suns in the sky nor two kings among the people, so too the principle cannot be the same. To demand that all within the four seas rush about wailing as if for their own parents is not the way of the ancient sage-kings Yao and Shun. Neither Emperor Wen of Han nor Emperor Renzong of Song acted thus, nor did they extend it to the private kin of the empress dowager. Emperor Gaozu of Zhou did not abandon his words nor impose rigid expectations; he sought only to fully express his grief. The noble man should not lightly criticize him. As for matters of imperial tours and military campaigns, I find no merit in them.

From *The Tang History*: In the fourth year of the Zhenguan era, the Turkic khan Illig arrived in Chang’an. Emperor Taizong ascended the Shuntian Tower, displaying a grand array of cultural treasures before receiving him, and lodged him in the Court of the Imperial Stud, providing generous provisions. When the Retired Emperor (Gaozu) heard of Illig’s capture, he sighed and said, “When Emperor Gaozu of Han was besieged at Baideng, he could not exact vengeance. Now my son has destroyed the Turks—my trust has been placed in the right person. What more need I fear?” He then summoned the emperor, over ten eminent ministers, and the imperial princes and princesses to a feast in the Lingyan Pavilion. As the wine flowed freely, the Retired Emperor plucked the pipa, the emperor rose to dance, and the ministers and nobles took turns offering toasts until the revelry lasted deep into the night.

**Commentary:** The Retired Emperor rejoiced that the Turks’ destruction proved his trust well-placed—how devoid of human feeling! Confucius said, *“Repay resentment with uprightness, and virtue with virtue.”* The Turks had once lent their strength to the Tang. At first, they were trusted as heart and limb, allies as close as hand and arm. Yet once they relied on the Middle Kingdom’s might and emptied the southern lands of the steppe, the court—secure in its belief that no external threat remained—failed to see that the true danger lay within its own walls, deeper than any barbarian foe. Had the Retired Emperor remembered their former bond and urged the emperor to restore the fallen and revive the broken, returning their homeland and repatriating their people—as Mencius did when he installed a ruler before departing—then the distinction between Chinese and barbarian would have been clear, the Tang’s grace and might resplendent. Heaven’s favor upon the Tang would not have been as it was. Ignorant of this principle, in the span of a single turn, his descendants too grew cruel and violent, as if repaying past deeds. Thus, the Retired Emperor’s joy today—can it not become the lament of noble men in days to come?

In the twelfth month of the seventh year, the Emperor accompanied the Retired Emperor in hosting a feast at the former Weiyang Palace. The Retired Emperor commanded the Turkic khan, Jieli, to rise and dance, and then ordered the chieftain of the Southern Man, Feng Zhidai, to recite poetry. Thereupon, he laughed and said, "The Hu and the Yue are one family—such a thing has never been seen since ancient times." The Emperor, raising his goblet to offer longevity, replied, "Now that the four barbarians have submitted as vassals, it is all due to Your Majesty’s teachings; it is not something within the reach of my own wisdom or strength. In the past, Emperor Gaozu of Han also feasted with the Grand Emperor in this very palace, but he vainly boasted of his greatness—a course I do not emulate." The Retired Emperor was greatly pleased, and all in the hall cried, "Long live the Emperor!"

**Recorded Note:** Taizong deemed Han Gaozu’s conduct vain boasting—was he not right? The Turks, whom the Retired Emperor once served, were of a status utterly remote. Yet now, the Hu and Yue are one family—this is not merely a reversal of lord and vassal, but how much greater is the Emperor’s own boastfulness! The Emperor once regretted that Zilu could not carry grain in time—how could he now take pleasure in such a display of the Hu and Yue? As the *Book of Songs* says: *"Set forth the baskets and beans, drink in filial piety."* Only thus may the joy of heavenly bonds be fully realized; otherwise, it is all but vain boasting.

**From the *History of Song:*** In the seventh year of Tiansheng during the reign of Emperor Renzong, Empress Dowager Zhangxian was to receive court homage on the winter solstice. The Son of Heaven led the hundred officials in offering longevity. Fan Zhongyan, serving as Academician of the Secret Pavilion, submitted a memorial in earnest remonstrance: "In serving one’s parents at home, there are the rites of the family. To stand with the hundred officials, facing south to pay homage, cannot be made a precedent for later generations." Later, when Consort Chen, Lady Li, passed away, Lü Yijian, as chief minister, memorialized: "The rites should be observed with generosity." As a minister bearing the weight of the prime minister’s office, I should be consulted on all matters, whether internal or external. I request that mourning be declared, mourning garments donned, and the full funeral procession prepared." An edict was issued to breach the palace wall to carry out the coffin, but Yijian said, "Breaching the wall is not in accord with mourning rites; the coffin should exit through the Xihua Gate." The Consort had given birth to the sacred person of the Emperor, yet her funeral rites were not properly observed—someday, there will surely be those who bear the consequences. Do not think that Yijian does not speak out today." After the Empress Dowager’s death, Prince Jing, Yuan Yan, said to the Emperor: "Your Majesty was born of Consort Chen, who died an unnatural death." The Emperor then learned he was the son of Consort Chen and wept bitterly for days. He issued an edict reproaching himself, posthumously bestowed the title *Zhuangyi*, and, in great fortune, held a memorial service at Hongfu Temple. The coffin was opened, and when he beheld the Consort, her face, preserved with mercury, retained its jade-like luster as in life, and her robes and crown were those of an empress. The Emperor sighed and said, "Can the words of others truly be trusted?" He thereafter treated the Liu clan with even greater generosity.

The Record states: The former worthies have said: "During the more than ten years when Empress Dowager Zhangxian held court, the realm remained at peace, and much of the credit goes to Yijian." It also states: "When Fan Zhongyan discussed the rites for offering longevity, even Yan Shu found it obscure." Why was this? For the merit of protection is difficult for others to speak of, while the grace of nurture is boundless as the heavens. Thus Yijian insisted that the rites should be grand and solemn, thereby silently securing its foundation. As for Fang Zhong’s proposal to establish the Seven Temples, pay homage at the Grand Temple, and don the imperial robes, such precedents could not be allowed to grow. Thus Zhongyan firmly argued that the rites should be simplified, thereby preemptively ensuring a proper conclusion. Had these two men lived in Emperor Yingzong’s time, and had there been those who advocated for the Rites of the Pu Temple, the contentious debates might have been avoided. That their contributions were great, and their arguments difficult to fathom, may lie in this.

In the second year of the Zhiping era of Emperor Yingzong, an edict was issued to discuss the rites for honoring Pu Anyi, the Prince of Pu. Sima Guang, the Supervisor of the Remonstrance Bureau, knowing the Emperor would seek to exalt his birth father, once remarked during a memorial: "Emperor Xuan of Han, though a descendant of Emperor Zhaoxiao, never posthumously honored the Prince of Weichang or the Imperial Grandson Shi. Emperor Guangwu, who succeeded Emperor Yuan, also never honored his father, the Lord of Julu or Nandun. This is the model for all ages." Subsequently, Han Qi and others memorialized, requesting that the Emperor issue an edict for the Ministry of Rites and officials of the fifth rank and above to deliberate. The Hanlin Academician Wang Gui and others dared not speak first, but Sima Guang boldly wrote: "One who is adopted as an heir becomes the son of the adoptive father and cannot attend to his private kin. The Prince of Pu should be honored according to the precedents for enfeoffing and granting posthumous titles to relatives of the same generation, to be called 'Imperial Uncle,' with high offices and great states, bestowing the utmost honor." The assembly agreed. Wang Gui then ordered the clerks to draft the memorial based on Guang’s notes and submitted it, stating: "The former kings established rites with no dual supremacy. If reverence and love are divided between two, they cannot be whole in either. Thus, since the Qin and Han dynasties, when emperors ascended the throne from collateral lines and sought to honor their parents as emperors or empresses, they were criticized in their own time and ridiculed by later generations. Your ministers dare not take this as a model for our sagely dynasty. In past dynasties, succession often occurred after the late emperor’s passing, and the choice of heir sometimes came from the ministers, unlike Emperor Renzong, who, though not yet aged, deeply considered the weight of the ancestral temples and reverently followed the will of Heaven. From among the many imperial clansmen, he selected the most sagely and entrusted him with the great enterprise. Your Majesty first became the son of the late Emperor and then inherited the throne, thereby illuminating the realm. Though Pu Anyi, the Prince of Pu, shares with Your Majesty the bond of nature and the grace of nurture, it is by the virtue of the late Emperor that Your Majesty dons the imperial robes, possesses the Four Seas, and transmits the realm to sons and grandsons for ten thousand generations. Your ministers humbly propose that the Prince of Pu be honored according to the precedents of enfeoffment and posthumous titles for relatives of the same generation, with high offices and great states. The Ladies of Qiao, Xiang, and Xianyou should also be enfeoffed as grand ladies, aligning with ancient and modern propriety."

[Text missing] The memorial stated: "Wang Gui and others have not fully deliberated. What kinship should the Prince of Pu be called, and should his name be [missing] or not?" Since the Prince of Pu was Emperor Renzong’s elder brother, to the Emperor he should be called "Imperial Uncle" without naming him. The Participant in Determining Governmental Matters, Ouyang Xiu, cited *The Great Record of Mourning Attire*, arguing: "One who is adopted as an heir wears mourning for his parents for a reduced term of one year but does not erase their names, showing that while the mourning may be reduced, the name cannot be erased." If the birth parents are redesignated as "Imperial Uncle," there is no precedent in past dynasties. To enfeoff them with greater states would also violate the principle of not increasing ranks. He requested that the matter be referred to the Ministry of Rites for deliberation by the Three Departments and the Censorate. Subsequently, the Empress Dowager issued a handwritten edict, honoring the Prince of Pu as "Pu Anyi, the August Emperor," and the Ladies of Qiao, Xiang, and Xianyou as empresses.

The Record states: Meng Yizi once asked about filial piety, and Confucius told him not to violate the rites. Duke Wen of Teng asked about mourning, and Mencius told him to fully express his grief. The words of the sages and worthies arise from the human heart and are easily seen; they originate from the principles of Heaven and are easily understood. They do not employ overly discriminating language nor establish arguments that defy the world’s customs. Thus, those who hear them do not find them contentious or difficult to follow, and those who practice them do not feel obstructed or find them hard to accept. This is why their words are recorded in the classics and remain uncorrupted for ten thousand generations. As for the Pu Debate of the Song, which stirred contention in its time and brought calamity to later generations, it was truly because the various worthies’ arguments were too divisive, their corrections too extreme, and they could not emulate the sages’ magnanimity, breadth, and unobtrusive profundity.

From today’s perspective, the words of Sima Guang and Wang Gui were correct, yet the *Great Record of Mourning Attire*’s statement is not without basis, and not erasing the parents’ names is not without precedent. However, redesignation as "Imperial Uncle" lacks evidence and is untrustworthy, making it difficult to hastily adopt. The words of Ouyang Xiu and Han Qi were sound, yet the succession of emperors for ten thousand generations cannot be neglected, and the transmission of the imperial lineage for a hundred generations cannot be divided. That one who is adopted as an heir cannot attend to private kin is clearly trustworthy, and what is trustworthy is difficult to hastily change. This is right, that is wrong; this is permissible, that is not—thus, the crux lies in fully examining one’s heart. If Emperor Yingzong had reflected above on the unshakable foundation of Emperor Taizu, the direct transmission of the succession since Yao and Shun, and that what he once guarded was one person and one matter, while what he now presides over is the realm of ten thousand states and the Nine Provinces, he would have known that the Son of Heaven holds the greatest honor, and even if he wished to hesitate and attend to his private kin, he could not. If he had next considered that Emperor Renzong raised him from among the common people and placed him above the multitudes, that what he once followed was the daily care of warmth and attendance, while what he now serves are the suburban sacrifices and the altars of soil and grain, he would have known that his single person is the foundation of the myriad affairs, and even if he wished to deeply cherish the grace of nurture, he could not.

The Emperor’s fundamental heart remains unclear, and what he speaks is obstructed by impediments. You may believe that the late Emperor’s virtue was such that he first possessed the realm, while he may hold that the proper order of succession demands his rightful place. You may see high offices and grand ranks as the utmost in honor, while he may think that a father’s nobility through his son should follow the highest rites. Thus, the bond of natural kinship and the grace of nurturing require no words from others. Yet when it comes to the strategy of enthronement and the principle of dynastic succession, if moved by sentiment, there is more than enough; if contested in debate, there is never enough. In the end, the more one contends, the more one is confounded; the more one alters, the more one loses. Truly, this is an unparalleled principle of antiquity, an unresolved doubt, arising from the failure to follow the great sages and worthies in rectifying the hearts of men. And now, how could it be remedied?

When Emperor Xiaozong ascended the throne, he honored Emperor Gaozong as the Supreme Emperor and the Empress as the Supreme Empress, residing together in the Palace of Virtue and Longevity. One day, Emperor Xiaozong, dressed in his court robes and shoes, emerged from the Xiangxi Gate, braving the rain as he was supported by his attendants, and would not stop even at the palace gate. The Supreme Emperor repeatedly waved him off, then ordered his attendants to assist him in returning. Afterward, he turned to his ministers and said, “Now that I have entrusted the realm to the right person, I have no regrets.”

It is recorded: What is meant by “entrusting to the right person” is not merely the continuation of will and the completion of affairs, but the safeguarding of the ancestral temples and the altars of soil and grain above, and the land and the people below. Emperor Taizong of Tang said, “To avenge humiliation and repay the hundred kings, to eliminate evil and requite a thousand ages.” Such was the weight of the trust he bore. Emperor Xiaozong, indeed, was able to set his mind resolutely on restoration, relying on Zhang Jun as his great wall, assessing the enemy’s strength as unlike that of Qin Hui, boldly declaring the Jin to be without propriety and peace negotiations to be misguided—truly, he was the right person. Yet alas, the urgency of external crises was ever-present, and the resolve to taste gall to the end proved difficult. The defeat at Fuli was a setback from the start, and the treachery of those advocating retreat undermined him later. Though his heart was strong and determined, there was no effectual revival. Thus do the noble sigh at the rarity of success.

In the first month of the spring of the first year of the Longxing era, on the day *renchen* marking the new moon, the Emperor received court at the Hall of Literary Virtue, then proceeded to pay homage to the Supreme Emperor and the Supreme Empress at the Palace of Eternal Longevity. From this time onward, this became an annual custom.

In the seventh year of the Qiandao era, when the Supreme Emperor reached the age of seventy, the two august sovereigns were bestowed with honorific titles: *Guangyao Shousheng Xiantian Tidao Supreme Emperor* and *Shousheng Mingci Supreme Empress*. In the twelfth year of the Chunxi era, when the Supreme Emperor’s age increased to eighty, the honorific titles of the two sovereigns were further augmented: *Guangyao Shousheng Xiantian Tidao Xingren Chengde Jingwu Weifen Supreme Emperor* and *Shousheng Qiming Guangci Supreme Empress*. Grand celebratory rites were held, and a general amnesty was declared for the rest. Each year, the Emperor accompanied them to the Garden of Assembled Scenery, the Jade Ford Park, and the Temple of the Four Saints—visits too numerous to recount—exalting their veneration to the utmost.

Liu of Yongxin remarked: “In Emperor Xiaozong’s service to Emperor Gaozong, as recorded in the historical annals, both form and sentiment were fully realized, unwavering from beginning to end. Truly, his filial duty was without flaw. Some say that Xiaozong, having entered the imperial line as a collateral descendant, inherited from his predecessor an unparalleled legacy to be transmitted endlessly—how profound must his gratitude have been! Gratitude is what enabled his filial piety. He feared that his predecessor might regard him as distant and thus strove to uphold his legacy—this striving is what enabled his filial piety. Previously, Emperor Yingzong’s adoption as heir did not fully fulfill the Way, a failing lamented by the noble. Now, was there no lesson taken from this? Such reflection is what enabled his filial piety—not that his heart arose from mere spontaneity.”

Alas, what words are these? The noble judge a person by whether they attain to goodness alone. If one were to dismiss goodness because it arose from gratitude, would one then prefer those who act without gratitude and do no good? If one were to dismiss goodness because it arose from striving, would one then prefer those who act without striving and do no good? If one were to dismiss goodness because it arose from reflection, would one then prefer those who act without reflection and do no good? Such words would lead all under Heaven to abandon goodness.

It is recorded: Observing the two reigns of Gaozong and Xiaozong, the joy of heavenly bonds endured from beginning to end. From the Longxing era through Qiandao to Chunxi, spanning twenty-five years, it was not merely a matter of revering the revered and cherishing the cherished, of father and son fulfilling their roles, with one man’s compliance alone—rather, it won the hearts of all nations. One can imagine the splendor of their rituals and cultural refinements, the grace of their yielding and advancement—what must it have been like? Nor was it merely that one was Supreme Emperor and the other Son of Heaven, their dignity unmatched—rather, they attained longevity beyond eighty. One can imagine the venerable bearing of their aged visages and silvered hair, the solemnity of their yellowed robes and stooped frames—what must it have been like? Since the abdications of Yao, Shun, and Yu, has there truly been anyone like them?

Perhaps Gaozong’s abdication arose from perfect impartiality, a mind devoid of self, and thus Heaven’s recompense bestowed upon him the fullness of longevity and blessings. Xiaozong’s great virtue surpassed the ordinary by ten thousandfold, and thus the reverence accorded him was unparalleled. Yet the minds of common men, peering from afar, deem filial piety born of gratitude, of striving, or of reflection as either impractical or envious. Alas! Such views are the very source of the ceaseless calamities that later ages cannot escape.

When the Supreme Emperor passed away, the Emperor wept uncontrollably, beating his breast and stamping his feet for two days, refusing all sustenance. He said to Wang Huai and others: “In former times, Emperor Xiaowu of Jin and Emperor Xiaowen of Wei observed three years of mourning—why should attending to governance be an obstacle?” Huai replied: “Though Emperor Wu of Jin had such intentions, later the court reverted to wearing plain clothes and white hempen caps.” The Emperor said: “At the time, his ministers failed to comply. I shall set a new precedent—what harm is there?” Huai said: “When Your Majesty holds court, will it be proper for the Son of Heaven to wear mourning while the ministers wear ceremonial robes?” The Emperor said: “There are degrees of reduction.” He then withdrew.

An internal decree was issued: “As the late Supreme Emperor has departed, I shall wear mourning for three years, while the ministers shall follow the ordinance of one month.” The hundred officials submitted five memorials requesting that the Emperor return to the palace to attend to governance, but he refused. On the day *xinchou* of the second month, the *dan* sacrifice was performed, and the hundred officials doffed their mourning garb. The ministers submitted three memorials requesting that the Emperor hold court, but he refused.

On the day *wuxu* marking the new moon of the eleventh month, the Emperor visited the Palace of Eternal Longevity. From then on, he did so on every new moon and full moon. The Emperor began to conduct affairs of state in plain clothes at the Hall of Extended Harmony; when visiting the Palace of Eternal Longevity, he wore mourning attire and leaned on his staff as before.

In the spring of the fifteenth year, on the day *dingyou* of the first month, the Emperor visited the Palace of Eternal Longevity and performed rites before the spirit tablet. In the fourth month of summer, when Gaozong’s spirit tablet was enshrined in the Imperial Ancestral Temple, an edict was issued: “I recently decreed that I would wear mourning for three years, but the ministers repeatedly requested that I hold court and change my attire. Thus, I have attended to affairs in plain clothes within the inner palace. Though I have reluctantly complied with their requests, deferring to the ancestral temple, I have examined the classical rites and find my heart still unsettled. To observe the full mourning period would be closer to antiquity. Let all understand my utmost intent and make no further requests.”

Minister Liu Zheng remarked: "The three-year mourning period is a universal observance throughout the realm. Emperor Wen of Han first altered the ancient Way, and Emperor Jing failed to follow the classical rites, so later generations adhered to their precedent, and the mourning system fell into decay. Emperor Wu of Jin sought to express his personal grief, yet ultimately yielded to the arguments of Pei Xiu and Fu Xuan. Emperor Xiaowen of Northern Wei was able to restore the ancient system, yet still did not fully conform to the rites of *liangyin* and *emmi*. The rest are scarcely worth discussing. The theory of 'changing months' originated with Ying Shao, and vulgar scholars adopted it, until it was finally fixed as a twenty-seven-day observance. The rites of the former kings were thus largely destroyed. Even with sagacious rulers and wise ministers, they feared reform and perpetuated the old ways—how lamentable!

"Emperor Shouhuang’s filial devotion to his parents arose from his innate nature, and his reverence for the departed sprang from utmost sincerity. Though his sacred person had not yet reached the age of exemption from mourning, and his ministers repeatedly urged him to change his attire, his wise resolve was already set, and he remained unwavering. After the interment rites were completed, he withdrew to serve before the spirit tablet, wearing mourning garb for three full years to fulfill the mourning system. Since ancient times, he alone has done so.

"Recorded here: This reflects Emperor Xiaozong’s steadfast adherence to the great principle of legitimacy, for he did not allow even the slightest private affection for his kin to sway his resolve. Thus, the court historians praised him, declaring that his filial piety was beyond reproach.

"I have examined the records: In the thirteenth year of Shaoxing, when the Prince of Xiu passed away, the Emperor ordered him to resign his office and observe mourning—this was before his own accession. In the third year of Qiandao, when Lady Zhang, the Prince of Xiu’s wife, also passed away, he donned mourning in the Rear Garden—this was after his accession. Yet he never altered his title to that of an elder brother. As for Emperor Lizong, who posthumously honored his birth father, Xilu, as Prince Rong, and his mother, Lady Quan, as State Lady, and had his son, Yuran, inherit the title to perform sacrifices—he never bestowed imperial honors upon them. The *Pu Debate* of our dynasty was not even settled in its own time, let alone for later generations. Yet when scholars gathered to dispute, each claiming their own wisdom, it was far better that the great Dao be illuminated and human hearts return to uprightness. Let readers take note.

"*The History of the Yuan* records: At the beginning of the Zhiyuan era, Lian Xixian, serving as Grand Councilor of the Secretariat, observed mourning for his mother. He led his kinsmen in performing the ancient mourning rites, abstaining from even a drop of water for three days. His grief was so profound that he vomited blood and could not rise, dwelling in a thatched hut beside the grave. The chief ministers, citing the unsettled state of mourning regulations, wished to summon him back to office. They went together to his hut, but hearing his ceaseless wails of sorrow, they could not bring themselves to speak. Recorded here: This was the custom of the northern tribes. Even if the precedent of military exemption did not apply, and mourning regulations were not yet fixed, he wholeheartedly followed the ancient rites and devoted himself to completing the mourning period. For while human feelings may be overridden, the customs of the northern tribes cannot remain unchanged. If filial piety can move the spirits, how could it fail to move his colleagues? Yet those who, untrained in military affairs, willingly embraced the military exemption are no better than Lian Xixian’s detractors.

"In our dynasty, Hu Juren was filial from childhood. When his father fell ill, he tasted his stool to gauge its bitterness or sweetness. Though mourning rites had long been abandoned, he resolutely observed them. At first, he took neither water nor grain, and his weeping left him unconscious until he revived. Later, he became emaciated to the bone, unable to rise without a staff. For three years, he did not enter his bedchamber. The rites of interment, the ancestral hall, monthly offerings on the first day, and seasonal sacrifices—all followed the ancient rituals. Those who understood recognized his singular conduct, while those who did not often mocked him. Yet when the gentry learned of Master Hu’s true character, they began to esteem his intentions.

"Though in the privacy of his home, he and his wife treated each other as guests. He meticulously sorted even the smallest bamboo containers, maintaining strict distinctions that lasted a lifetime. He served his elder brother with fraternal devotion, and when relatives returned home, he would greet them at the gate. If they fell ill, he personally prepared their medicine. He cherished his clan, tirelessly instructing his sons and nephews. In receiving guests, he wore the *shenyi*, cap, and slippers, remaining dignified throughout the day. Though his nature was gentle and his conversation unassuming, people often delighted in his company.

"Recorded here: Master Zeng said, 'Sincerity within manifests itself without. Thus, the noble person is ever cautious in solitude.' Could one who, like Hu, maintained reverence within fail to be devoted to his kin? Those who claim to know the Master only now truly begin to understand him—though they grasp only the surface."

*Hongdao Record*, Volume 32, concludes.
*Hongdao Record*, Volume 33.

**On the Rites of Husband and Wife**

From the *Record of Rites*: The marriage rite (*hunli*) is for uniting the good of two clans, above to offer sacrifice to the ancestral temple, and below to continue posterity. Thus, the noble person holds it in reverence. For this reason, in the marriage rites—betrothal gifts (*nacai*), inquiry of names (*wenming*), auspicious announcement (*naji*), formal betrothal (*nazheng*), and request for the date (*qingqi*)—the host spreads mats and arranges tables in the ancestral temple, bows to welcome the guests outside the gate, enters with bows and yielding, and receives commands in the temple. This is how reverence, caution, gravity, and correctness are maintained in the marriage rite. Sharing a common platter to eat, exchanging nuptial cups, and partaking of the same wine serve to unite their bodies, equalize their status, and bind them in affection. Only after reverence, caution, gravity, and correctness are established is affection deepened. This is the essence of ritual, by which the distinction between male and female is made, and the righteousness of husband and wife is established.

At dawn, the bride rises early, bathes, and awaits. At daybreak, she is presented to her parents-in-law. The bride holds a basket of dates, dried meats, and dried fish as offerings. The parents-in-law offer her sweet wine, and she makes an offering of dried meats and wine. The offering of sweet wine completes the bride’s rite. When the parents-in-law enter the chamber, the bride presents a suckling pig, demonstrating her obedience. The next day, the parents-in-law feast the bride with a single libation to honor and reciprocate. The parents-in-law descend by the western steps, while the bride descends by the eastern steps, signifying the succession of generations. The completion of the bride’s rite and her obedience are thus affirmed. The emphasis on succession further underscores the importance of the bride’s obedience.

The bride’s obedience means submission to her parents-in-law, harmony with the household, and proper conduct toward her husband. She fulfills her duties in silk, hemp, cloth, and weaving, and carefully manages the household’s stores and provisions. Only when the bride’s obedience is complete can the inner household be harmonious and well-ordered. When the inner household is harmonious and well-ordered, the family can endure. Thus, the sage-kings held it in high regard.

**Recorded here:** The meaning of marriage is primary, for only with Heaven and Earth do the myriad things arise; only with the myriad things do male and female exist; only with male and female do husband and wife come to be; only with husband and wife do father and son emerge; and only then can ruler and minister, superior and inferior, and the principles of ritual and righteousness be established. Nothing precedes the Dao of husband and wife. Thus, it is said that the noble person holds it in reverence, and the sage-kings hold it in reverence. Yet its subtle words and profound meanings are tirelessly devoted to a single principle.

In all the rites—betrothal gifts, inquiry of names, auspicious announcement, formal betrothal, request for the date, and personal welcoming—there are horse attendants and assistants to ensure reverence, caution, gravity, and correctness, not stopping at a single act. Yet later generations neglect this, reducing it to a single libation, and even the personal welcoming is often omitted. This is to treat ancestors lightly before the union is formed and to slight the bride before the bond is made. It shows ignorance of the harmony of the times and disregard for the weight of a second union. This is most improper. Thus, this record preserves its meaning.

From the *Canon of Yao*: Yao bestowed his two daughters upon Yu of the Miao, making them consorts to Shun.

**Recorded here:** In the *Yijing*, the *Zhen* hexagram seeks once, and the *Li* hexagram seeks twice, each with one yang positioned between two yin. Yao intended for Shun to emerge from *Zhen* and succeed *Li*, so he gave him two wives. Later, the ritual for the Son of Heaven was established as nine consorts. Nine is a yang number. According to this principle, Yao’s bestowal of his daughters was also necessarily imbued with meaning.

From the *Yijing* (*Guimei* hexagram): When King Yi of the Shang gave his younger sister in marriage, the sleeves of the principal wife were not as fine as those of her younger sister.

**Recorded here:** King Yi rectified the rites of marriage and clarified the distinction between male and female, and nothing was more important than the differentiation between wife and concubine. Yet the sleeves of the principal wife were not as fine as those of her younger sister. This is because ritual takes substance as its foundation, and a wife’s virtue as her priority. Without virtue, one merely flaunts embroidered robes and pheasant plumes before others, while licentiousness and malice go unashamed. Thus, observing that the principal wife’s sleeves were not as fine as her sister’s reveals why the Shang Dao flourished. Observing the extravagance of favored concubines, who outshine others in attire, reveals why the customs of Yin led to its downfall. This is not the only instance.

Emperor Taizu of Song admonished Princess Yongning not to wear embroidered or kingfisher-feathered garments, yet later, Zhao Feiyan even gilded her shoes. How could such excesses endure?

From the *Major Odes* of the *Book of Songs*: "There is a maiden in a great state, a younger sister of Heaven. The auspicious omen was settled with betrothal gifts, and she was personally welcomed at the Wei River. A bridge of boats was made, and its splendor was resplendent."

**Recorded here:** Yao’s bestowal of his daughters and Shun’s acceptance of his charge were the auspicious settling of the mandate of Heaven. Thus, a bridge of boats was constructed, and a grand thoroughfare was made. From this, one sees the majesty and grandeur of the rituals of an entire era, which then became the rites of the Son of Heaven.

Later, the state of Lu upheld the Zhou rites, yet Duke Ai considered a single ceremonial cap a great matter while unaware of the splendor of a bridge of boats. He regarded a thousand chariots as honorable while unaware of the rarity of a maiden "a younger sister of Heaven." This is why Confucius responded with solemnity and why, in the end, there was no resplendent glory.

From the *Zhou Nan*:
"The creeping vines of *ge* stretch forth,
Extending through the central valley.
Their leaves grow lush and verdant,
While yellow birds take flight,
Alighting on the thickets,
Their calls ringing clear in harmony.

The creeping vines of *ge* stretch forth,
Extending through the central valley.
Their leaves grow dense and full,
Cut and boiled to make fine cloth,
Woven into garments,
Worn without excess.

She speaks to her tutor,
Announcing her return,
Washing her private garments,
Soaking her daily robes.
Whether washing or rinsing,
She goes home to visit her parents."

**Recorded here:** The so-called "younger sister of Heaven" was not revered merely for her lofty status or wealth, beyond reproach. Rather, it was because she, though rich, remained diligent; though noble, remained frugal; respected her elders without neglecting her tutors’ teachings; and, though married, did not diminish her filial devotion to her parents. Later generations of wives, if they abandon sericulture and weaving under the pretext of no public duties, differ from the woman of *"The creeping vines of ge stretch forth."* If they indulge in bronze tripods and jade, pearls and gold, they differ from the one who *"wore without excess."* If they lament, *"The lord feasts on delicacies while my heart grieves,"* they differ from the one who *"spoke to her tutor."* If, like the wife of Qi, they return home with a retinue like clouds, they differ from the one who *"went home to visit her parents."*

When the royal daughter of King Wen was married to a feudal lord, her carriage and robes were splendid, yet she dared not flaunt her nobility to lord over her husband’s house. Thus, the poet praised her, saying:
*"How lush they bloom!
Like the blossoms of the *tangdi* tree—
Why are they not solemn and refined?
The carriage of the royal daughter!"*

*"How lush they bloom!
Fair as peach and plum—
Grandson of King Ping,
Daughter of the Marquis of Qi."*

**Recorded here:** That a feudal lord’s daughter was escorted by a hundred chariots was no exaggeration, for it revealed the effects of King Wen’s self-cultivation and family governance. That the carriage of the royal daughter was described as *"Why are they not solemn and refined?"* was no mere praise, but a testament to the transformative influence of King Wen and Tai Si’s inner governance. Those who, though wearing ceremonial caps and conducting the bride’s welcome, cannot show reverence in their bearing do so out of arrogance. Those who, though entrusted with the succession of a dynasty, cannot harmonize in their conduct do so out of perversity. In the Way of marriage, none prosper who cling to arrogance, and none find fortune who harbor perversity.

She, endowed with the virtue of the yielding and compliant *yin*, seated in the loftiest of positions, yet humbled herself in self-restraint—this is what is meant by *"solemn and refined."* The younger sister, though blessed with youthful beauty, submitted to her elder husband and moved him with her grace—this is what is meant by *"harmonious."* Thus, the grandson of King Ping and the daughter of the Marquis of Qi are still admired to this day without end.

The feudal lords of the southern lands, transformed by King Wen’s teachings, rectified their hearts and cultivated their persons to govern their households. Their women, likewise transformed by the queen’s example, possessed the virtues of serenity, purity, and singular devotion. Thus, when they married into the houses of feudal lords, their families praised them, saying:
*"The magpie has a nest,
The turtledove dwells in it.
This maiden goes to her home,
A hundred chariots escort her."*

*"The magpie has a nest,
The turtledove occupies it.
This maiden goes to her home,
A hundred chariots attend her."*

*"The magpie has a nest,
The turtledove fills it.
This maiden goes to her home,
A hundred chariots complete her procession."*

**Recorded here:** When a feudal lord’s daughter marries another feudal lord, the escort of a hundred chariots signifies the role of the wife, the duties of the lady of the state—above, she continues the lineage of her ancestors; in rank, she stands as an equal to the feudal lord. Only when the rites of marriage are complete does the chaste maiden arrive, and the governance of the inner palace is established. The *Shao Nan* begins with *"The Magpie’s Nest"* to emphasize that the lord’s wife is one whom the people look up to and must not be remiss. Such vigilance is like the pheasant-feathered curtains of the court. Even the Lady Zhuang Jiang of Wei, though unappreciated, was likened to *"the great carriage rumbling on"*—how far removed is this from the ethos of *"The Magpie’s Nest"*? And the royal minister who dared not elope—how distant is he from its spirit?

After the Marquis of Han paid homage at court and returned, he proceeded with the bride’s welcome. The *Odes* say:
*"The Marquis of Han took a wife,
A niece of the King of Fen,
A daughter of Juefu—
The Marquis of Han went to meet her.
At Jue’s village,
A hundred chariots thundered,
Eight bells chimed in harmony,
Resplendent was their glory.
Her sisters followed,
A throng like clouds.
The Marquis of Han gazed upon them,
His gates ablaze with splendor."*

It is recorded: In my humble observation, the rite of the bridegroom’s personal welcome was first corrupted in Qi and Lu, not that the rest of the world failed to follow it. Han, too, was a feudal lord, yet he conducted himself with such meticulous adherence to ritual propriety—whereupon the noble man declared: “This is still akin to antiquity.” Beyond this, one awaits the bride at the threshold, adorns the ears with white silk. How much of this remains but a vestige of Qi’s hegemonic customs and the remnants of its policies? Lu, a state that upheld ritual and righteousness, permitted the bride’s family to come and escort her—whether they did so properly or not is not for Ji to reproach, but for us to decline with justification. That a descendant of the Duke of Zhou should fall short of the daughter of Juefu—this is what the Master deeply lamented. Hence it is said: When the *Odes* perished, the *Spring and Autumn Annals* arose.

From the *Lesser Elegantiae*:
*"The rumbling of the carriage’s coupling,
Longing for the maiden’s departure—
Not for hunger, not for thirst,
But for virtue’s resonance to gather."*
Though without close companions,
One feasts and rejoices;
Leaning upon that level grove,
Where turtledoves alight—
That noble maiden of stately form.
Let virtuous teachings come,
Feast and acclaim,
Cherish her without surfeit.
Though no fine wine is poured,
Drink in hope;
Though no choice viands are served,
Eat in hope.
Though no virtue is bestowed upon you,
Sing and dance—
Ascend that lofty ridge,
Split the oak for kindling.
Split the oak for kindling,
Its leaves so lush.
How rare to behold you,
My heart is poured out.
Lofty mountains to gaze upon,
Radiant paths to tread.
Four steeds prance,
Six reins harmonize like zither strings.
Beholding your new union,
My heart is consoled.

It is recorded: The *Xian* hexagram’s image states: “Above the mountain is the marsh—*Xian*. The noble man, with emptiness, receives others.” The reason the sage values the mutual resonance of man and woman is fundamentally to bring virtuous teachings. Yet the world indulges in chasing beauty, indulges in prolonging countenance—like the ephemeral *shun* blossom, it is desired; like winter provisions, it is discarded. Thus, how fleeting is the resonance of virtue! Green silk, fine threads—then they are tended; dignified and composed demeanor—then it is neglected. Therefore, I long for the ancients—were they ever thus?

The sage applied the *Guan Ju* to one household, extended the *Peach Blossom* to one state, and disseminated the *Carriage’s Coupling* throughout the world, making known the way of righteousness. Unions are perfected only through virtue, and the lofty mountains and radiant paths suffice to permeate high and low. No ruler governing a state fails to seek worthies to assist him, just as no Daoist fails to seek friends to cultivate benevolence. This is the utmost benefit of mountains and marshes, the grand thoroughfare of harmonious resonance, the subtle intent of empty receptivity, the noble heart of radiant paths. Who would claim that the joy of new marriage exists merely for song, dance, and frivolity?

From the *Jiao Te Sheng*:
The groom personally welcomes the bride, the man preceding the woman—this is the principle of firmness and yielding. Heaven precedes earth, the ruler precedes the minister—this principle is one and the same. Holding the ritual tablet to meet, reverence is manifest in distinction. When men and women are distinct, then father and son are close. When father and son are close, then righteousness arises. When righteousness arises, then ritual is established. When ritual is established, then all things are at peace. Without distinction, without righteousness, it is the way of beasts.

The groom personally hands the reins to assist her descent, showing affection. Exiting through the main gate, he leads first—the man guides the woman, the woman follows the man—thus begins the righteousness of husband and wife. A woman follows others: in youth, she follows her father and brothers; when married, she follows her husband; when widowed, she follows her son. The husband is one who, with wisdom, guides others. Thus, a woman has no rank; she follows her husband’s rank, sits according to his seniority, and uses vessels of clay and gourd—this is the exaltation of ritual.

The next morning, the bride washes and spins; when the parents-in-law finish eating, the bride partakes of the leftovers—this is a private gesture. The parents-in-law descend by the western steps, the bride by the eastern steps—this is to receive her in the chamber. Wedding rites do not employ music, for they embody the principle of hidden yin. Music pertains to yang qi. Wedding rites are not congratulated, for they pertain to the proper order of humanity.

It is recorded: The *Te Sheng* sacrifice concludes with this: Heaven and earth are distinct, firmness and yielding intermingle; when men and women are disordered, beasts arise. Thus, there are women who bewitch men, as in the poems of Zheng; thus, there is no distinction, as in the customs of *Ju Di*; thus, there is no personal welcome, as in the conduct of *Zhong Feng*; thus, there is no following the man, as in the reins of the male fox; thus, there is private departure from the domain, as in the satire of *Fan Fu*; thus, there is wisdom that fails to guide, as in the demise in the carriage; thus, there is self-aggrandizement, as in the usurpation of imperial prerogative; thus, there is no personal spinning, as in the relocation to the western palace—all are grave violations of ritual.

From the *Zuozhuan*: In the fifth year of Duke Yin, the ninth month, the palace of Zhong Zi was inspected, and the *Wan* dance was to be performed. The Duke inquired about the number of feathered banners from Zhong Zhong, who replied: “The Son of Heaven uses eight, feudal lords six, grandees four, and officers two.” Dance regulates the eight sounds and propagates the eight winds, hence the Duke followed the number below eight. Thus, six feathered banners were first offered, beginning the use of the six-row formation.

It is recorded: Lü of Shu Lei stated: King Cheng bestowed the rites and music of the Son of Heaven upon the Duke of Zhou. Even in the time of Duke Yin, after centuries, none questioned this—why did Zhong Zhong not don armor and remonstrate, so that the world might once again witness the rites and music of the Duke of Zhou, and Lu thus establish his legacy? If so, was it true? I say: No. Ritual does not tolerate reckless discourse, nor do people shirk expense. Thus, the distinction between heaven’s crown and earth’s footwear, the precedence of ritual over music—these are unalterably fixed. That Yin, as an elder half-brother, served the ancestral temple, and that the temple of Duke Hui was paired with Meng Zi—this was ritual. Yet to indulge the whims of a dog-keeper, to exalt the office of a concubine—this is to place the cap and shoes amiss. This is what is meant by reckless discourse. For Zhong Zhong, it would have been proper to remonstrate by clarifying the order of concubines and half-brothers, the impropriety of dual origins and paired heirs, first rectifying names and ensuring proper discourse—only then could ritual and music flourish.

Now, the views of the dog-keeper and the enumeration of plumes and feathers—here, precedence is thrown into disorder. This is what is meant by shirking expense. Even if such feathers were offered in the ancestral temples, they would already disrupt the institutions of the Duke of Zhou, offering no remedy to the root of chaos and collapse—how much less could one demand redress for its peripheral abuses? When assessing total merit while inquiring into seniority, neither ruler nor minister, superior nor subordinate, knows what truly matters. Is it any wonder that slander goes unseen and disorder remains unrecognized?

When Ji Wenzi journeyed to Song to escort a bride, upon his return, the Duke feasted him and recited the fifth stanza of *"Han Yi."* Mu Jiang emerged from her chamber, bowed twice, and said: "The great officer has labored humbly, not forgetting the former lord, extending his grace to the successor, and even to this unworthy widow. The former lord would still hold hope." She dared to bow in gratitude for the great officer’s weighty toil. Then she recited the final stanza of *"Lü Yi"* before retiring.

Hu’s commentary on the fields states: Bo Ji was renowned for her filial piety and virtue within the household, hence the escort of the bride. The Duke sent a minister to particularly enrich her dowry, a ritual honoring worthiness that spread her reputation afar. Thus, the states vied in admiration, trusting in her freedom from the jealousies of women. Cheng’s commentary says: If the virtue of a single woman is heard among the feudal lords, how much more so for a gentleman? Both commentaries miss the essence of the classic.

Recorded here: Mu Jiang escorted a bride to Song, then entered and recited *"Lü Yi"*—how virtuous she seemed! Yet later, in her licentiousness with Xuan Bo, she cast milfoil stalks and received the hexagram *Sui*—how depraved she became! The *Odes* say: "Let there be no impropriety, no reproach." Yet with [lacuna] she labored to honor the great officer’s humility—this was indeed improper and reproachable. The *Documents* say: "Only when the house is in ruins..." When a lord feasts a minister while the mother emerges from her chamber, the hen crows at dawn. From this arose the coercion of the ruined state and the calamity of the usurped office—all originating here. Thus, it was not for the worthiness of Bo Ji, but to admonish the famine and disorder of Lu. The intent of the sage runs deep indeed.

The *Biographies of Exemplary Women* states: Bo Ji married Duke Gong of Song. When the Duke died, Bo Ji was widowed. By the time of Duke Jing, fire broke out in Bo Ji’s palace at night. Her attendants said: "My lady, briefly withdraw from the fire." Bo Ji replied: "According to a woman’s ritual, if both governess and tutor are not present, one does not descend from the hall at night. I await their arrival." The governess arrived, but the tutor had not yet come. The attendants again urged: "My lady, briefly withdraw from the fire." Bo Ji said: "A woman’s ritual dictates that if the tutor does not arrive, one may not descend from the hall at night. To seek life by transgressing propriety is not as good as upholding ritual unto death." She was thus overtaken by the fire and perished.

Recorded here: The lady’s refusal to act without her tutor—was this truly so? When Duke Gong died, the lady was not yet a widow. To sever her nose—this was not the proper way to hang oneself in the central chamber, for it would defile the ditches and streams. If the tutor had not arrived, she could have declined on ritual grounds. What regret would there be in death? What regret, indeed?

Meng Ji was the eldest daughter of the Hua clan and the wife of Duke Xiao of Qi. She loved ritual and was steadfast in her integrity. Once, when the Duke traveled to Langye, Meng Ji accompanied him. As they journeyed, the horses bolted and the carriage shattered. Duke Xiao ordered a four-horse standing chariot to carry her, but Meng Ji instructed the driver to lower the curtains for her concealment and had her governess respond: "I have heard that when consorts and queens travel, they must ride in a secure carriage with covered wheels; when descending from the hall, they must be attended by their governesses and tutors; in advancing or retreating, they must ensure the jade pendants of their girdles chime and their sashes are properly fastened; and when dwelling in the wilds, they must be shielded by curtains and screens—all to rectify the heart, unify the will, and restrain oneself. Now, this standing chariot lacks a canopy, and I dare not accept such an order. To dwell in the wilds without protection is not a place where I dare linger. Both violate ritual profoundly. To live without ritual is not as good as dying early." The messenger hastened to report this, and the Duke then provided a proper carriage before she would ride and return.

Recorded here: Meng Ji may indeed be called one who understood ritual. Ritual must not be departed from even for a moment. Thus, when a woman leaves her home, she veils her face—how could she accept being carried in a standing chariot? Yet, when Duke Xiao journeyed to Langye, his wife accompanied him—was this to inspect the spring plowing or the summer harvest? Or was it to indulge in hunting and revelry, abandoning himself to wine? Had Meng Ji truly considered this, she would not have waited for the horses to bolt and the carriage to shatter in the wilds before leisurely fulfilling her duties within the inner chambers.

Qi had the wife of Qi Liang Zhi. When Duke Zhuang attacked Ju, Qi Liang Zhi died in battle. As Duke Zhuang passed by on his return, the wife sent a messenger to offer condolences along the road. She said: "If my husband had committed a crime, why would Your Lordship deign to send such a message? If he died blameless, then my humble self has the dilapidated ancestral home in the lower quarters, and I cannot receive your condolences at the outskirts." Thereupon, Duke Zhuang turned back, went to her home, and performed the rites before departing. The wife had no children, and neither within nor without did she have relatives of the five degrees of kinship. She laid her husband’s corpse beneath the city wall and wept, her inner sincerity moving all who heard. Travelers passing by could not help but shed tears, and for ten days, the city walls collapsed. After the burial, she said: "Where shall I return? When my father lived, I relied on him; when my husband lived, I relied on him; when my son lived, I relied on him. Now, above, I have no father; in the middle, I have no husband; below, I have no son—whom shall I depend upon?" She then threw herself into the Zi River and died.

The gentleman says: The wife of Qi Liang Zhi was chaste and understood ritual.

Recorded here: The wife of Qi Liang was not to be compared with Meng Ji of the Hua clan. For a man to go forth on service is righteous; to wander for pleasure is not. Thus, the bearing of shields in *Bo Xi* and the parting gifts in *Xiong Zhi* are not actions a woman should undertake. That the city walls collapsed was no marvel, nor was the transformation of customs extraordinary—both were stirred by her inner sincerity. Alas! To conduct oneself with composure and uphold ritual, never daring to act on one’s own—this is called being chaste and ritually correct. Truly, is it not so?

In the *Guo Yu*, when the mother of Gongfu Wenbo wished to arrange his marriage, she feasted the elders of his clan and recited the three stanzas of *Lü Yi*. The elders requested to divine the match by tortoise shell. Master Hai heard of this and said: "Well done! When men and women feast, they should not involve the elders of the clan. In matters concerning the clan, one should consult only the clan members."

To scheme yet not transgress, to be subtle yet luminous—such is the way. Poetry serves to unite intentions, song to chant the verses. Now, poetry is used to unite the household, song to chant it—this accords with the law.

It is recorded: Can the feasts of Jing Jiang and Mu Jiang truly be spoken of in the same breath? The union of partners marks the beginning of the people’s life; to honor the ancestral temples and consult the clan elders is how the bond between two families is forged. The *Book of Changes* says: "To be vigilant in one’s household—regret vanishes." This surely speaks of Jing Jiang.

Thus, to keep one’s words from straying to the outer court is wisdom; to entrust the door’s lock to the tortoise-shell divination is trust; to exclude clan ministers from the feast is ritual propriety; to labor without forgetting one’s duties is righteousness; to speak without forgetting one’s parents-in-law is benevolence. When it is said, "To scheme yet not transgress," and "To accord with the law"—how deeply the noble one approves!

In the *Rites and Their Commentaries*, the Lu master Chun Jiang said: "A woman’s duty is to be compliant and obedient, with chastity and reverence as her foremost virtues. Thus, in serving her husband, there are five observances: At dawn, she rises and attends to her toilet, then presents herself in audience—this embodies the solemnity of ruler and minister. In washing hands and partaking of the morning meal, she maintains the reverence of father and child..."

Returning home to fulfill her duties, she embodies the bond of siblings; in receiving appointments with utmost sincerity, she upholds the trust of friends; and only after the intimacy of the bedchamber does the relationship between husband and wife take form.

Lady Zong of Song was the wife of Bao Su. After Su had served in Wei for three years, he took an outside wife. Her sister-in-law said to her, "You may leave him now." Lady Zong asked, "For what reason?" The sister-in-law replied, "Since the lady has taken a new favor, why do you remain?" Lady Zong said, "A woman’s chastity lies in unwavering devotion, and her compliance in following what is good—how could monopolizing her husband’s love be considered virtuous? By ritual, the Son of Heaven has twelve consorts, the feudal lords nine, high ministers and great officers three, and scholars two. My husband is a scholar, so is it not fitting that he has two wives? Moreover, a wife may be sent away for seven reasons, with usurping the proper order foremost among them. My sister-in-law does not instruct me in the rites of household conduct but instead urges me to act in a way that would lead to my dismissal—how could this be right?" She refused to heed the advice. When the Duke of Song heard of this, he honored her dwelling, naming it "Model of Ritual." It is recorded: Lu and Song were states renowned for ritual and propriety. Thus, whether as a teacher or a model, they truly set the standard for inner chambers and official quarters, becoming the exemplar for later generations in matters of ritual instruction. This is worth recording.

The *Elementary Learning* states: When Wei Jiang passed through Ji, he saw Ji Que weeding, his wife bringing him food. They treated each other with the reverence due to guests. Returning home, Wei Jiang spoke of this to Duke Wen, saying, "This is the gathering of reverent virtue. One who is reverent must possess virtue, and virtue is what governs the people." The Duke was urged to employ him. "I have heard that when one goes out, one should conduct oneself as if in the presence of honored guests, and when serving others, as if performing a sacrifice—this is the principle of benevolence." Duke Wen appointed him as a great officer of the Lower Army.

Lord Pang never entered the city or court. He and his wife treated each other with the respect due to guests. Liu Biao visited him and found Lord Pang resting from plowing on a ridge, while his wife and children weeded before him. Pointing, Biao asked, "Sir, you toil in the fields and refuse official salary—how then do you intend to provide for your descendants?" Lord Pang replied, "The world leaves its descendants peril, while I alone leave them peace. Though what we leave differs, neither of us fails to leave something." Biao sighed and departed.

It is recorded: In the weeding of Ji Que and the plowing of Lord Pang, is there truly a difference? Ji Que was one who bent his name, while Lord Pang was one who bent his person.
