One who bends his person retreats without ceasing; one who bends his name may advance and extend himself. This is where they differ. Who has not heard of Lü Sheng’s crisis? Yet it was not widely emulated. The matter of the shot hook, however, became a model. When Ji made a single remark, he received the highest reward; when Que served the Three Jin, he was appointed to the rank of chief minister. Duke Wen’s judgment was indeed precise.

The *Book of Han* records: Emperor Wen’s favored consort, Lady Shen, once sat on the same mat as the Empress within the palace. When the Emperor visited the Shanglin Park, the Empress and Lady Shen accompanied him. The chamberlain laid out a mat, but Yuan Ang drew it back, preventing Lady Shen from sitting. Enraged, she refused to sit, and the Emperor, also angered, rose. Ang then stepped forward and explained, "I have heard that when there is proper order between high and low, there is harmony above and below. Now that the Empress has been established, Lady Shen is but a concubine—how can she share the same seat? Does Your Majesty not see the greed of others?" The Emperor was pleased, summoned Lady Shen to speak with her, and bestowed upon Ang fifty catties of gold.

It is recorded: Observing the early years of the Han, one sees that not only in the court and among ruler and ministers, but even within the inner palace, there were many instances of such coarseness. Later generations would see nothing like it.

During the Eastern Han, Empress Deng of Emperor He entered the palace as a Noble Lady at the age of sixteen. She was reverent, cautious, and meticulous, conducting herself with strict adherence to ritual. She served Empress Yin day and night with diligence, treating her fellow consorts with humility, always putting herself below them. Even the palace servants and attendants received her kindness and compassion. At gatherings, while the other consorts and noble ladies vied in lavish delicacies, adorned with gleaming hairpins and radiant garments, Empress Deng alone favored plainness. Her attire was simple, without ornament, and she deeply restrained herself. If her clothing’s color matched that of Empress Yin, she would immediately change it. When they appeared together, she dared not sit upright but stood aside, making herself small. Whenever the Emperor asked her a question, she would first glance at the Empress before answering, never daring to speak before her. The Emperor, knowing the Empress labored with such care, sighed and said, "The toil of cultivating virtue is truly like this."

It is recorded: From this, one sees that not only were there no incidents like that of Lady Shen, but the frugal and virtuous example of Empress Ma would come to prevail throughout the court.

Ban Zhao, wife of Cao Shishu, was known as the Great Lady. She was broadly learned and highly talented, her conduct always proper, her moral integrity and adherence to ritual complete. She composed the *Lessons for Women* in seven chapters: "Humility" first, "Husband and Wife" second, "Reverence and Caution" third, "Wifely Conduct" fourth, "Wholehearted Devotion" fifth, "Compliance" sixth, and "Harmony with Sisters-in-Law" seventh. In summary, it states: In ancient times, when a girl was born, after three days she was placed beneath the bed and given a tile to play with, while an offering was made. Placing her outside, beneath the bed, made clear her humble and submissive nature, that she was to serve others...

Giving her a tile to play with made clear her practice of labor and devotion to diligent work; making an offering to the ancestral lord made clear her duty to preside over sacrifices. These three are the constant Dao of womanhood.

The canons of ritual and law teach humility, deference, and reverence—placing others before oneself. One should not boast of good deeds nor deny faults; endure humiliation and bear disgrace, ever as though in awe. Rise early and retire late, never shirking day or night. Attend to private duties without shunning difficulty or ease; whatever is undertaken must be completed, with hands ever diligent in order. Maintain a proper demeanor and upright conduct to serve one’s husband.

If these are fully observed, yet one still suffers from obscurity or faces disgrace, such has never been known. The Dao of husband and wife is to match yin and yang, to commune with the numinous, embodying the great principle of Heaven and Earth and the cardinal bonds of human relations. If the husband is not virtuous, he cannot govern his wife; if the wife is not virtuous, she cannot serve her husband. Yin and yang differ in nature, as do the conduct of men and women. Yang’s virtue lies in strength, yin’s function in softness. For men, vigor is prized; for women, gentleness is beauty.

In cultivating oneself, nothing surpasses reverence; in avoiding conflict, nothing surpasses compliance. Thus it is said: the Dao of reverence and compliance is the great ritual of the wife. If a wife is disrespectful and unrestrained, she invites reprimand; if her anger persists, she invites the rod. The bond of husband and wife is rooted in righteousness for harmonious kinship and in affection for mutual love. Once the rod is wielded, what righteousness remains? Once reprimands are uttered, what affection endures? When both affection and righteousness are forsaken, husband and wife part ways.

A woman has four virtues: wifely virtue, wifely speech, wifely bearing, and wifely work. Wifely virtue need not be of extraordinary talent or wisdom; wifely speech need not be eloquent or sharp-tongued; wifely bearing need not be of dazzling beauty; wifely work need not surpass others in skill. To be pure, serene, and steadfast, to uphold integrity and order, to conduct oneself with shame, and to act with propriety—this is wifely virtue. To choose words carefully, avoid harsh speech, speak only when appropriate, and never weary others—this is wifely speech. To wash away dust and filth, keep clothing and food fresh and clean, bathe at proper times, and keep the body free from defilement—this is wifely bearing. To devote oneself to spinning and weaving, avoid frivolous laughter, prepare wine and food for sacrifices, and serve guests—this is wifely work. These four are the great virtues of womanhood and must not be lacking. Yet they are easily practiced—only the will to uphold them is required.

If one’s conduct offends the gods, Heaven punishes; if one strays from ritual and propriety, one’s husband scorns. Thus the *Women’s Precepts* states: Winning one’s husband’s heart is eternal fulfillment; losing it is eternal ruin. From this it follows that a wife must seek her husband’s heart. Yet what she seeks is not flattery or improper intimacy. Rather, nothing surpasses wholehearted sincerity, proper demeanor, and adherence to ritual and duty. Let her ears hear no improper speech, her eyes see no indecency; let her go out without adornment and return without neglecting her duties. Let her not gather with crowds or gaze idly at the gates—this is wholehearted sincerity and proper demeanor.

If, however, she is frivolous in movement, careless in gaze and hearing, disheveled indoors and coquettish outdoors, speaking of what she ought not and gazing at what she ought not—this is failure to uphold wholehearted sincerity and proper demeanor.

It is recorded: The words of ritual expound the great principle of yin and yang, hardness and softness; the words of the *Lessons for Women* detail the intricacies of conduct within and without the household. Thus I have recorded them in full, to instruct those within the inner chambers who would know ritual.

Some say: In Ban Zhao’s time, power lay with the empress. The *Lessons for Women* could not rectify this, and she even engaged in external affairs—how does this accord with the Dao of reverence and caution, or the virtue of wifely compliance? Yet I have often observed the *Book of Changes*: The *Hexagram of Small Excess* states: "Smooth progress, favorable for constancy. Suitable for small matters, not for great affairs. It is not fitting to ascend; it is fitting to descend. Great good fortune." This is its meaning.

Thus, when a minister usurps the king’s authority, he is punished, for hardness has lost its proper place. When a concubine or wife seizes the moment, she is praised, for softness has found its proper place. First suffering obscurity and hardship, then attaining prominence—this is the smooth progress of *Small Excess*. Following the completion of the *Hexagram of the Gentle*, it is favorable for constancy. Composing seven chapters of instruction to aid and encourage women is not fitting for those above but fitting for those below. Yet only when the empress, like the sixth line of the hexagram, assumes control can great goodness be realized—is this not what is meant by "great good fortune"? The words of the many traditions seem to have been spoken with purpose. Let the reader consider them carefully.

Liang Hong, styled Boluan, was poor in family but noble in integrity, mastering all worthy teachings without exception. The villagers admired his loftiness and many sought to marry their daughters to him, yet Hong steadfastly refused. In the same county lived a woman of the Meng clan, stout and plain in appearance, who declined all offers of marriage. When her parents asked her reason, she replied, “I wish to wed one as worthy as Liang Boluan.” Hong, hearing of this, sent a betrothal gift. The woman requested hempen cloth for clothing, sandals of woven hemp, and tools for basketry and sewing. Upon marriage, she prepared the wedding feast and, entering his home, waited seven days before performing the rites of a wife.

The record states: Master Gui once served as tutor to Prince Tai of Wei. The Emperor said, “Serve Gui as you would serve me.” If the prince could be granted rank, how could the sovereign alone be exempt from proper observance? Though Gui failed to correct Prince Tai’s faults, he succeeded in perfecting the sovereign’s virtue—how different from the conduct of Fang and Du in their time.

In the sixth year of Jianzhong during the reign of Dezong, the ritual for princesses paying respects to their parents-in-law was first established. Previously, when a princess married, her parents-in-law would bow to her, while she made no return. The Emperor ordered the Ministry of Rites to determine the proper ceremony: the parents-in-law would sit to receive her in the central hall, while uncles, brothers, and sisters-in-law stood to receive her in the eastern chamber, following the rites of common households.

The record states: Since the Southern Peace princesses married, their customs had already diverged from those of former dynasties. Yet over time, old ways were lost, and世俗 clung to inherited practices, making sudden change difficult. Now that the ritual has been set, it may be called good.

The Tang court, generation after generation, indulged in favoritism toward women, inviting strange misfortunes. Though the realm enjoyed peace and prosperity, the same errors repeated, leading many to marry late. Some wed with gray hair, yet even then, how could they avoid observing proper rites? Emperor Dezong once rebuked his officials, saying, “You value frugality; I value ritual.” Yet when Princess Tang’an passed, he blamed his ministers, claiming their expenses had exceeded his own. How inconsistent his pursuit of reputation—first one way, then another! Was it that when he established the rites, the state faced many troubles, but when building pagodas, extravagance reemerged? His love of ritual was not steadfast, and for good reason.

According to *The History of the Song*: Empress Meng of Emperor Zhezong was the granddaughter of Meng Yuan, Defender-in-Chief of Meizhou and posthumously enfeoffed as Grand Preceptor, and the daughter of Meng Zaizhi, Gatekeeper of the Palace. In the seventh year of Yuanyou, Empress Dowager Xuanren addressed the chief ministers: “Meng’s daughter is sixteen, well-taught in feminine virtue, and capable of observing the rites of a wife. She is fit to be established as empress.” Considering the recent simplification of court rituals, she ordered the Hanlin Academy, the Censorate, the Remonstrance Bureau, the Secretariat, and the Ministry of Rites to deliberate and present the six rites for the empress’s investiture.

Thereupon, the Emperor appointed:
- Left Vice Director of the Department of State Affairs Lü Dafang as Acting Grand Commandant and Chief Envoy for the Welcoming Ceremony;
- Vice Director of the Bureau of Military Affairs Han Shiyan as Acting Grand Tutor and Deputy;
- Left Vice Director of the Department of State Affairs Su Song as Acting Grand Commandant and Chief Envoy for the Presentation of the Edict;
- Participant in the Bureau of Military Affairs Wang Yansou as Acting Grand Tutor and Deputy;
- Right Vice Director of the Department of State Affairs Su Zhe as Acting Grand Commandant and Chief Envoy for the Announcement of the Auspicious Day;
- Imperial Uncle, Participant in the Court of the Imperial Clan, Zong Jing as Acting Director of the Court of the Imperial Clan and Deputy;
- Imperial Great-Uncle, Supervisor of the Court of the Imperial Clan, Prince Zongchen of Gaomi as Acting Grand Commandant and Chief Envoy for the Presentation of the Betrothal Gifts;
- Hanlin Academician Fan Bolu as Acting Director of the Court of the Imperial Clan and Deputy;
- Minister of Personnel Wang Cun as Acting Grand Commandant and Chief Envoy for the Auspicious Inquiry;
- Acting Minister of Revenue Liu Fengshi as Acting Director of the Court of the Imperial Clan and Deputy;
- Hanlin Academician Liang Tao as Acting Grand Commandant and Chief Envoy for the Betrothal Proposal and Inquiry of the Bride’s Name;
- Palace Censor-in-Chief Zheng Yong as Acting Director of the Court of the Imperial Clan and Deputy.

The Emperor personally ascended the Hall of Literary Virtue to invest her as empress. The Empress Dowager later told the Emperor, “To gain a worthy inner helper is no small matter.” She promoted the empress’s father to Commander of the Guard of Honor and Prefect of Rongzhou, and her mother, née Wang, was enfeoffed as Lady of Huayuan Commandery.

The record states: In this era of the Song, rituals surpassed those of all former dynasties, exceeding even the Tang and Han. Through the virtuous conduct of a refined woman, the court established its rightful lineage. Above, she was guided by a mother and sovereign of the highest cultivation; below, she was assisted by a multitude of great ministers. How solemnly the six rites were observed! Yet before long, a petty official’s slander sundered them. When Zhang Dun plotted against her and Hao Sui fermented disaster, though the Emperor knew her virtue had been maligned, he remained deluded. Was it that he once valued inner helpers but later exalted external treachery, ever opposing the empress? Or was it that calamity loomed, and he became so disordered he knew not his own mind? King You deposed Queen Shen and brought the Rong to attack Zhou; King Xiang deposed Queen Di and brought ruin upon Zheng. From ancient times, such mirrors abound—let the noble man observe them. If the beginning was marked by meticulous ritual, how could the middle lack benevolence? And if the middle lacked benevolence, how could the end escape disaster? Success and failure truly cannot be used to judge a person.

Princess Jingguo, the eldest princess, disliked frivolous play from childhood. Emperor Taizong once opened the imperial treasury and allowed his daughters to choose treasures to observe their inclinations. The princess alone took nothing. When Emperor Zhenzong ascended the throne, she married the Attached Attendant and Commandant-escort Li Zunxu. By old custom, when a princess married, her father was demoted to the status of a brother. At the time, Zunxu’s father, Jichang, was still living. The princess, on his birthday, paid her respects to him as an uncle. The Emperor, hearing of this, secretly sent her ceremonial robes, a jeweled belt, vessels, and silks to aid in offering birthday felicitations. Whenever Zunxu feasted with guests—all of them worthy gentlemen—the princess personally oversaw the preparation of the feast. When Zunxu was appointed Prefect of Xuzhou and suddenly fell ill, the princess hastened to visit him. Her attendants reminded her that she should first memorialize the throne, but she did not wait for a reply and departed, accompanied by only five or six attendants. The Emperor, learning of this, swiftly ordered eunuchs to command the local garrisons to escort her. After her husband’s death, she wore mourning garments without respite. Even after the mourning period ended, she refused to wear fine or ornate clothing. Once, while feasting in the palace, the Emperor personally adorned her with flowers, but she declined, saying, “I have vowed never to do so again.”

The record states: According to the house laws of the Song, Emperor Renzong treated his aunt as a mother. How could the princess alone fail to serve her father-in-law as a wife serves her father?

Thus, the Jinguo Princess’s adherence to ritual propriety was indeed preceded by the Emperor’s own example. The practice of demoting parents-in-law to the status of siblings was unheard of before the Three Dynasties; it depends entirely on how the wife conducts herself. Those who observe this must not remain ignorant of it.

From the *Collected Works of Yichuan*: The late father of the Two Chengs, Cheng Xiang, and his mother, Lady Hou, served her parents-in-law with filial reverence, treating her husband with the deference due a guest. Cheng Xiang relied on her inner support, honoring and respecting her all the more. Yet Lady Hou remained humble and self-disciplined, never presuming to decide even minor matters without first seeking his counsel. She cared for all her stepchildren as if they were her own, treating her husband’s younger cousins and aunts with the same attentiveness as her own kin. She governed the household with order, maintaining discipline without severity, never resorting to corporal punishment. Whenever Cheng Xiang was angered, she would mediate. Only when her sons erred would she not conceal their faults, saying, “A son’s failings stem from his mother shielding his mistakes and remaining unaware of them.” Her discipline allowed no leniency. If her children, even at a young age, walked too hastily, she would rebuke them, saying, “Had you walked calmly, would you have stumbled?” When meals were placed beside her, she often ate only plain porridge, and if her children sought richer fare, she would scold them, saying, “If you indulge your desires now, what will you become when you grow older?” If they quarreled with others, even when in the right, she would not take their side, saying, “One should fear their inability to yield, not their inability to prevail.” Thus, the Two Chengs lived their lives without fuss over food or clothing, never speaking ill of others—such was the effect of her teaching.

From her childhood at seven or eight, Lady Hou recited the poem *“A woman does not go out at night,”* and from then on, she never left her chambers. As she grew older, she loved literature but did not indulge in ornate compositions. If she saw someone circulating writings or letters, she would investigate, deeming it improper.

The record states: Yichuan instructed his household, saying, “In family life, between flesh and blood, between father and son, people often let emotion override ritual and let affection override righteousness. Only by not allowing private love to obscure proper principle can one succeed.” Thus, in the hexagram *Household*, the essence lies in maintaining dignity to ensure good fortune. The *Guimei* hexagram’s second nine says, “She guards her secluded chastity, never straying from the constant and correct path.” Yet the world takes frivolity as normal and views steadfastness as unusual. These words were meant for Lady Hou. Looking back, her wisdom as a wife and virtue as a mother shine forth; looking forward, her model of feminine conduct and exemplary womanhood stands resplendent. Such a record must not be omitted.

From the *Records of Illustrious Ministers*: Xin Ciying was pure in conduct and upright in bearing, keeping far from sensual indulgence. He and his wife treated each other with the respect due guests. Even in private, she maintained a dignified demeanor, sat properly, and spoke sincerely. Admiring the character of Chao Youyuan and Sima Wenzheng, he guarded himself with ritual, carefully avoiding suspicion. Even his servants and maids were not seen unless properly attired. When the Prefect of Poyang, Cheng Mai, sent him fresh fruit and silver, he refused it. Though he endured hardship and poverty in turbulent times, unable to support himself, he would not accept even a single bowl of porridge without justification. The Emperor remarked, “Your reputation for integrity is well-known; they say you do not accept your salary in Fujian.” Xin Ciying replied, “I entered office out of poverty—how could I refuse my salary? I only decline what I ought not to accept.” The Emperor said, “If everyone were like you, how could the realm not be at peace?”

The record states: “If civil officials do not love money and military officers do not fear death, the world will be at peace.” These words were once spoken by Yue Fei, and the Emperor was well aware of them—yet he failed to act upon them. As for the rise of the Jianmu era, it began with a scholar whose words moved the court.

On an auspicious day of the Lantern Festival in the *dingwei* year of the Wanli reign (1607), Zhang Guoxiang, the Orthodox Successor of the Zhengyi Tradition, Devout Practitioner of the Dao, Expounder of the Mysteries, Great Perfected Master, and Overseer of Daoist Affairs Under Heaven, respectfully oversaw the carving of the woodblocks.

*Hongdao Record*, Volume 33—End
*Hongdao Record*, Volume 34—Begins

The Rites of Fraternal Bonds

Mencius said: "Desiring to see one another constantly, they come ceaselessly like flowing water, without the formality of tribute, meeting as kin rather than through state protocol."

The record states: "The term 'constantly' (*changchang*) signifies unbroken succession. Consider Emperor Jing of Han and his brother, the King of Liang—though their mutual warnings and escorts were frequent, such indulgence could not be sustained. The term 'ceaselessly' (*yuanyuan*) signifies inexhaustibility. Consider Emperor Xuanzong of Tang and his five brothers—though they shared pillows and blankets, even the closest bonds may falter over time.

The *jin* and *pin* rites are ceremonies of the court, while meeting as kin is the intimacy of siblings. Without tribute, private affection flourishes; without state protocol, the impropriety of usurping the ruler’s authority is avoided—thus allowing constant meetings and ceaseless visits. Was not Mencius one who profoundly understood the Sage?"

Mencius said: "To walk slowly behind one’s elder is called *ti* (fraternal duty). To rush ahead of one’s elder is called *bu ti* (lack of fraternal duty). Walking slowly is not something one cannot do—it is something one chooses not to do. The Way of Yao and Shun consists solely of filial piety and fraternal duty."

The record states: "*Ti* (弟) means order, an inherent sequence bestowed by Heaven. Thus, the elder’s rank follows the procession, while the younger’s rank attends the feast—once established, can this order be disrupted? Yet some, in their haste, abandon their elders, whether through power, favor, or gain. From rulers of great states to sons of humble households, those who confuse their place will meet ruin. Mencius, in emphasizing what one *chooses* not to do, aligns with the principle of 'breaking a branch for an elder'—both awaken the natural Heavenly nature of the human heart. In an age of chaos where such virtues are forgotten, this cannot be overlooked."

The *Xiao Ya* states:
*"Rejoicing in brothers’ company,*
*Like the blossoms of the cherry tree,*
*Radiant, resplendent.*
*None among men compare to brothers.*

*In the terror of death and mourning,*
*Brothers hold deepest care.*
*When the dike crumbles,*
*Brothers seek one another.*

*Gazing upon the plain,*
*Brothers rush to aid in crisis.*
*Though good friends may sigh in sorrow,*
*When walls divide, brothers unite to repel insult.*

*Though good friends may lack resolve,*
*Once calamity is stilled, peace and tranquility return.*
*Even with brothers, none compare to friends—*
*Yet when cups are raised and feasts prepared,*
*With brothers gathered, joy and affection run deep.*

*With wife and children in harmony,*
*Like zither and lute in concert.*
*With brothers in accord,*
*Joy abounds in profound delight.*

*May your household prosper,*
*And your wife and children rejoice.*
*Reflect upon this truth—*
*Is it not so?"*

The record states: "After *Lu Ming*, *Si Mu*, and *Huang Hua*, the *Book of Songs* continues with *Tang Di*—for the Zhou and Shao clans were the pillars of the royal house, the reliance of the people’s hearts. The Sage did not discard change for constancy, nor let righteousness override affection, nor alter enduring priorities for momentary circumstances. His impartial and loving heart shines as clearly as the sun and moon in the sky. Rain and dew, frost and snow—all serve as teachings. Thus it is said: When he errs, it is like an eclipse of the sun or moon—all witness it. When he corrects himself, all look up to him in reverence."

This is what is meant.

Thus, when harmony and joy prevail, and affection runs deep, one need not consult even parents—how much less others? When harmony and joy are profound, even the ancestral rites for one’s wife should not take precedence—how much less external matters? This is why, though slander arose and Guan and Cai faced punishment, it never equaled the later ages’ abandonment of the weight of close kinship or the distrust of brothers.

Now, thousands of years removed from the era of the Duke of Zhou, when the *Tang Di* is sung, none fail to respond from the heart. Who could remain unmoved when receiving it at the feast? Indeed, one need not shed tears—even the people of Yue would be transformed without exception.

Another poem sung at the feast of brothers and kin declares:
*With caps adorned with tassels,*
*What do they signify?*
*Your wine is fine, your dishes excellent—*
*Are they for strangers? No, for brothers alone.*
*Like the kite and the dodder vine,*
*Twining upon the pine,*
*Before I see my lord,*
*My heart is heavy with sorrow.*
*When I see my lord,*
*How joyful I become!*

*With caps adorned with tassels,*
*What time do they mark?*
*Your wine is fine, your dishes timely—*
*Are they for strangers? No, brothers all come.*
*Like the kite and the dodder vine,*
*Clinging to the pine,*
*Before I see my lord,*
*My heart is filled with dread.*
*When I see my lord,*
*How content I become!*

*With caps adorned with tassels,*
*What do they rest upon?*
*Your wine is fine, your dishes abundant—*
*Are they for strangers? No, for brothers and brothers-in-law.*
*Like the falling snow,*
*First comes the sleet,*
*Death and mourning may come any day,*
*With little time to meet.*
*Rejoice in wine this evening,*
*For the lord’s feast is here.*

The record states: Observing this poem, with its threefold structure complete, it truly moves people to their core. The magpie, though a small creature, flies, calls, and flutters with such intimacy—how could it lack meaning? The dodder vine, though a humble plant, clings and entwines with such steadfastness—how could it be severed? This is because the Sage, in embodying the heart, responds to the urgency of brothers in distress, leaving no time even to bind one’s hair. Those who regard the people of Yue as distant are like the wagtail—what do they know of brothers’ mutual dependence? Those who teach climbing by bending trees—how do they compare to the dodder vine? This is the great meaning of studying poetry and the foundation of ritual—it cannot be overlooked.

Another poem sung after the sacrifice, at the feast for fathers, elder brothers, and venerable elders, says:
*Tender are those young reeds,*
*Let no ox or sheep trample them.*
*In budding form, in full growth,*
*Their leaves lush and green.*
*Dear are brothers,*
*None should distance themselves.*
*Some spread the mats,*
*Some set the armrests.*

*Mats are laid, seats arranged,*
*Armrests set with care.*
*Some offer toasts, some drink deeply,*
*Washing cups, pouring libations.*
*Fermented wine is presented,*
*Some roasted, some grilled.*
*Fine dishes of spleen and tripe,*
*Some sing, some dance.*

*When the great vessel stands firm,*
*When the four goblets are aligned,*
*When the arrows are matched in flight,*
*Guests are seated by worthiness.*
*When the great vessel is full,*
*When the four goblets are grasped,*
*When the four goblets stand like trees,*
*Guests are seated without disrespect.*

*The lord’s descendant presides,*
*Wine and sweet liquor flow.*
*Poured with the great ladle,*
*To invoke long life for the elders.*
*Elders with hunched backs,*
*Supported and guided.*
*May they live long,*
*And receive great blessings.*

The record states: The composer of this poem truly understood ritual to its utmost. Ritual does not indulge in frivolity; people do not shirk expense. It neither exceeds moderation nor encroaches upon dignity, nor fosters undue familiarity. The Zhou dynasty’s virtue was loyal and sincere, fostering kinship within the nine clans and honoring elders without—all arising naturally, without coercion. How could it indulge in frivolity?

Though mats and armrests are set, they are not excessive; though attendants are many, they are not overburdened; though the feast is abundant, it is not lavish—how could it shirk expense? Only after toasts and exchanges does ritual unfold; only after ritual is complete does music arise; only then does archery display virtue—how could it exceed moderation? With bowing and yielding, ascending and descending to drink, seating guests by worthiness, and competing with gentlemanly conduct—how could it encroach upon dignity? Honoring elders by guiding and supporting them, invoking great blessings for long life, bringing glory to the state and blessings to ruler and minister—how could it foster undue familiarity? With these qualities, it is said: they understood ritual to its utmost.

The fathers and elder brothers respond to *Xing Wei* with:
*Now drunk with wine,*
*Now sated with virtue,*
*May the lord live ten thousand years,*
*And receive great blessings.*

*Now drunk with wine,*
*Your dishes are fine,*
*May the lord live ten thousand years,*
*And receive radiant brightness.*

*Radiant brightness shines forth,*
*Lofty and clear, ending well.*
*A good end brings goodness,*
*The revered spirit declares favor.*
*What does it declare?*
*That the sacrificial vessels are serene and fine.*
*Friends assist with dignity,*
*Dignity perfectly timed.*
*The lord has filial sons,*
*Filial sons never lacking,*
*Ever bestowing upon your kind.*
*What is your kind?*
*The harmony of household and home.*
*May the lord live ten thousand years,*
*Ever granting descendants.*
*What are descendants?*
*Heaven covers you with blessings.*
*May the lord live ten thousand years,*
*With a glorious mandate and attendants.*
*What are attendants?*
*They order your women and scholars,*
*Ordering your women and scholars,*
*Followed by sons and grandsons.*

The record states: Why, from *"Now drunk with wine"* onward, do those who praise great peace always begin with this? The *Book of Rites* says: *"Dao, virtue, benevolence, and righteousness are not perfected without ritual."* The Dao encompasses vastness, thus *"radiant brightness shines forth"*; virtue is embodied in the self, thus *"dignity is perfectly timed"*; people gather in harmony, thus *"a glorious mandate brings all blessings"*; righteousness harmonizes benefit, thus *"descendants and sons follow."* These are the deepest wishes of human nature and the purest virtues of a lord. Moreover, with harmonious qi circulating, human hearts rejoice.

Thus it begins with *"Now drunk with wine, now sated with virtue,"* revealing the lofty attainments of the king and the noble integrity of fathers and elder brothers. Even ten thousand generations hence, none can depart from this as the foundation of praise and prayer.

Alas! By this, the eight-hundred-year foundation of the House of Zhou was firmly established.

On the day following the sacrifice, the *Yi* ceremony was held, and the music for entertaining the *gongshi* (honored ancestral representative) proclaimed:
*"The egrets rest on the Jing,
The gongshi comes to feast, comes to bring peace.
Your wine is clear,
Your viands fragrant.
The gongshi feasts and drinks—
Fortune and blessings come to fruition."*

*"The egrets stand on the sands,
The gongshi comes to feast, comes to bring harmony.
Your wine is abundant,
Your viands fine.
The gongshi feasts and drinks—
Fortune and blessings come to be."*

*"The egrets rest on the islet,
The gongshi comes to feast, comes to dwell.
Your wine is rich,
Your viands are dried meats.
The gongshi feasts and drinks—
Fortune and blessings descend."*

*"The egrets are seen on the moat,
The gongshi comes to feast, comes to the ancestral temple.
Having feasted in the temple,
Fortune and blessings are bestowed.
The gongshi feasts and drinks—
Fortune and blessings come in abundance."*

*"The egrets gather in assembly,
The gongshi comes to rest, serene and steadfast.
Fine wine gladdens,
Roasted meats fragrantly steam.
The gongshi feasts and drinks—
No future hardship shall arise."*

The record states: Zheng’s commentary explains: *"It is called gongshi because the Son of Heaven refers to feudal lords as ministers. Those feudal lords who possess merit and virtue enter to serve as the Son of Heaven’s ministers, and during sacrifices, they serve as the ancestral representative—hence, gongshi. Thus, none but the likes of Zhou, Shao, Bi, or Rong could bear such a role. At this time, above there were sovereigns who maintained the legacy, and below there were upright ministers to assist them. In themselves, they were enlightened and clad in splendid robes; in others, they inspired reverence and upheld virtue. In ritual, perfect governance spread its fragrance; in offerings, jade and silk intertwined. When the gongshi was at peace, the spirits were all at peace; when the gongshi was in harmony, the spirits were all in harmony. Thus, joy overflowed, and harmony prevailed—all effects of great peace, the blessings of perfect governance. Otherwise, clear wine and fragrant viands are common to all—why then praise only the egrets and the drunken feast?*

The gongshi’s response to the egrets declares:
*"Rejoice, O noble lord,
Radiant is your illustrious virtue.
Fitting for the people, fitting for all,
You receive blessings from Heaven.
May Heaven protect and command you,
And from above, renew its favor."*

May you reap a hundred blessings,
And your descendants number a thousand millions.
Majestic and august,
Fitting for a lord, fitting for a king.
No transgressions, no forgetfulness,
Following the old ways in all things.
Dignified in bearing, solemn in demeanor,
Your virtuous renown ordered and grand.
No resentment, no hatred,
Following the will of the many.
May you receive boundless fortune,
A pillar for the four directions.
A pillar and a guiding principle,
Bringing peace to friends and companions.
The hundred lords and ministers,
Charm the Son of Heaven,
Unremitting in their duties,
The people’s firm reliance.

The Lü family of Donglai says: When the lord feasts his ministers, and the ministers charm their lord, this is the time when above and below are in harmonious exchange. In such times of harmony, the only concern is laxity and neglect. This is why the poem concludes with "unremitting in their duties, the people’s firm reliance."

Recorded here: In times of harmony, the concern is not merely laxity and neglect. What is most to be feared is the exercise of cleverness that disrupts old statutes, the use of eloquent words that subverts established governance, the preference for the young and new over the venerable and experienced, and the abandonment of humble counsel in favor of flattery and profit—all of which are enough to tarnish illustrious virtue and erode grand and ordered renown. This poem first declares, "No transgressions, no forgetfulness, following the old statutes"; then it says, "No resentment, no hatred, following the will of the many." If one can adhere to old statutes, then there are models to rely upon and established laws to measure by. If one follows the will of the many, then there are the experienced to employ and filial virtue to depend upon. In such a case, if the people are not at peace and Heaven’s blessings do not endure, if the guiding principles do not prevail in the present and a good name is not passed to posterity, I would not believe it. Yet for the gongshi to speak thus—could anyone but the likes of the Zhou and Shao ministers, Bi and Rong, have done so?

In the *Spring and Autumn Annals*: In the second year of Duke Wen, on the dingmao day of the eighth month, sacrifices were offered at the Grand Temple, and Duke Xi was elevated in rank. Recorded here: I observe that in the Spring and Autumn period, the chaos and usurpations each had their beginnings. If Duke Zhuang could be deceived, then Lady Ai Jiang could be summoned. If Lady Ai Jiang could be summoned, then Duke Xi could be elevated. Thus, the ancient sage-kings were cautious and deliberate, for if compelled, a single misstep could lead to the ways of the Yi and Di barbarians, and a second misstep to the ways of beasts. Could one not be cautious?

There was the argument of Xia Gong Fuji—this is the way of barbarians and beasts. Hence it is said: If this can be tolerated, what cannot be tolerated?

In the *Zuozhuan*: The Marquis of Jin sent Gong Shuo to present the spoils of Qi to the Zhou king, but the king refused to receive him and dispatched Duke Xiang of Shan to decline on his behalf, saying: "The Man, Yi, Rong, and Di barbarians do not follow the king’s commands. When they are dissolute and violate constant norms, the king commands their punishment, and they present spoils. The king personally receives and rewards them to punish disrespect and encourage merit. But when brothers, nephews, and uncles invade and disrupt the king’s domains, the king commands their punishment, and they merely report their actions—no spoils are presented. This is to respect kinship and prohibit wickedness. Now, uncle, you have achieved merit against Qi, yet you have not sent a minister of command to console me. Though I wish to favor Gong Bo, he holds no office under the king and has violated the rites of the former kings. How dare I abandon old customs to shame you, uncle?"

Zhuang Bo could not respond. The king ordered the spoils to be entrusted to the three officials, and the rites were conducted as for a lord who had defeated an enemy, with the grandee sent to offer congratulations—a rank below that for ministers.

Recorded here: The Marquis of Jin’s dispatch of Gong Shuo and Gong Shuo’s presentation of Qi’s spoils were for profit. The king’s dispatch of Duke Xiang of Shan and Duke Xiang’s response to the Marquis of Jin were for righteousness. Since the campaign against Qi was for profit, the king demanded righteousness from Jin. The king’s refusal to receive Zhuang Bo had its reasons—why then should there be private feasting and bribes? It is like raising a child: one wishes them to be upright, yet offers them pears, chestnuts, jujubes, and persimmons—who can say what will come of it? Or like playing with a guard: one indulges their play, yet suddenly adopts a stern countenance—who can say what will come of it? Why was this done? At that time, Duke Xiang of Shan was at court, and Wangsun Man held office and settled matters. Even if the king wished to treat it as child’s play, what could he do with these two ministers? Yet when Wangsun Su later disputed with Liu Kang Gong over the tally, the original intent of pacifying the Rong was lost. One could not help but descend into child’s play.

In the *Book of Later Han*: Emperor Guangwu, considering that King Qiang of Donghai had been deposed without fault and had conducted himself with propriety, bestowed upon him a generous enfeoffment, granting him the twenty-nine counties of Lu Commandery in addition to his own, along with tiger-guards bearing bannered spears. The palace halls were adorned with bells and chimes, equaling the imperial carriage. When King Qiang arrived in his domain, he repeatedly memorialized to decline and return Donghai, and further, through the Crown Prince, firmly declined. The emperor did not permit it and deeply praised him, presenting King Qiang’s memorial to the public ministers.

Earlier, King Gong of Lu had favored palace construction and built the Lingguang Hall, which was grand and magnificent and still stood at that time. Thus, the emperor decreed that King Qiang reside in the palaces of Lu, with rituals and music distinct in every detail. In the first year of Yongping, the king fell ill, and Emperor Ming dispatched a eunuch attendant with imperial physicians to attend to him. He also ordered the kings of Pei, Jinan, and Huaiyang to visit Lu, their carriages following one after another without cease. When the king passed away, the emperor was deeply grieved. Accompanying the empress dowager, he went to the Jinmen Pavilion to mourn. He sent the Minister of Works with the imperial staff to oversee the funeral, assisted by the Grand Master of Ceremonies and the Chamberlain for the Imperial Clan, with the Superintendent of the Imperial Household in charge of the funeral rites. The king was posthumously honored with exceptional rites: a dragon banner, bannered spears, a phoenix carriage, a dragon canopy, and a hundred tiger-guards. The emperor decreed that King Ying of Chu, King Xu of Zhao, King Xing of Beihai, the Princess of Guantao, and the imperial relatives in the capital, along with the ladies of the four great families and the young marquises, all attend the funeral.

The emperor, reflecting on the king’s deep commitment to humility and frugality and his aversion to lavish burials, feared violating his wishes. Thus, he specially decreed to the eunuch attendant Du Cen and the tutor and prime minister of Donghai: "The king was reverent, frugal, and fond of ritual, ending his life with virtue. The funeral offerings must be simple and restrained to manifest the king’s noble and singular conduct."

The Record states: In the hexagram *Sun* (*Decrease*), the first nine reads: "Having completed one’s affairs, to proceed further is deluded—no blame." The six in the fifth place reads: "Someone increases it: a tortoise worth ten cowries cannot refuse—supreme fortune." The king, by yielding the imperial vessels to the sunlit [hall], and the emperor, by altering the succession to the next in line, were like those who decrease yet rely on the increase of the first line.

Having yielded in matters of honor, he was further able to diminish himself without considering it a merit. The emperor, restored to his rightful place of honor, reflected on the king’s steadfast humility and frugality, his devotion to restraint and decrease, and his profound attainment of emptiness at the center with perfect responsiveness. Compared to those of Tang times called the "Abdicated Emperor," he cannot be spoken of in the same breath. This supreme goodness and fortune cannot be surpassed.

When Emperor Suzong honored the Prince of Dongping, Yu, he surpassed all precedents, and no other prince could compare. In the seventh year of *Jianchu*, when the prince came to court, the emperor granted his request and specially bestowed fifteen million cash for his travel expenses. Fearing the prince might suffer from the cold dew, the emperor dispatched an emissary to present him with a sable fur, along with delicacies and rare fruits from the imperial kitchens. He sent the Grand Herald Dou Gu to welcome him beyond the suburbs with the imperial insignia.

The emperor personally inspected the prince’s residence, arranging curtains and bedding in advance, and ensuring that money, silk, and utensils were all abundantly provided. He issued an edict, saying: "The *Book of Songs* states: 'Uncle, establish yourself—reverence for the eldest son reaches its utmost.' In the past, the Chancellor Xiao was honored by being addressed without his name, to favor the loyal and worthy. How much more should this apply to one who is both kin and honored?" Thus, the princes of Pei, Jinan, Dongping, and Zhongshan were all addressed without their names in court.

When Cang arrived, he ascended the hall before performing the bow, and the Son of Heaven personally returned the courtesy. Thereafter, whenever the princes entered the palace, the emperor would greet them according to their rank and only dismount upon reaching the inner chambers. Cang, feeling the emperor’s grace exceeded propriety, was ill at ease and submitted a memorial to decline the honors. The emperor, upon reading it, esteemed him even more.

When the imperial cortege saw him off, the emperor wept as they parted, and again bestowed upon him imperial robes and carriages, rare treasures and horses, and money and silk numbering in the hundreds of millions.

The Record states: Fan Ye’s commentary says: Confucius praised "poverty with joy, wealth with love of ritual." If the Prince of Dongping, Xian, could be called one who loved ritual, then so be it. In declining the closest of kin and forsaking the empress dowager, how could he have sought merely to establish a reputation or abandon filial duty? For when suspicion blurs discernment, rifts arise; when encumbrances draw near, greatness is lost. This is what the wise sigh over.

Alas! To distance oneself from rifts and preserve loyalty, to cast off encumbrances and fulfill filial piety—such was the resolve of the Prince of Dongping. Thus, it is recorded.

From *The Book of Wei*: The Yang family lineage was pure and generous, valuing righteousness and yielding. Among the brothers, their service to one another was as between father and son. Yang Zhuang and Yang Jin were reverent, modest, loyal, and dutiful. Seated in the hall, they faced each other all day without ever retiring indoors. If there was but a single dish or a single meal, they ate together. Within the hall, curtains and screens were often hung to serve as resting places, where each would retire to rest before reuniting to converse and laugh. Though they passed sixty years of age and all rose to high office, they continued to inquire after one another morning and night. Once, when Zhuang returned drunk from elsewhere, Jin supported him back to his chamber and rested by his bedside, awaiting his condition. Their sons and nephews lined the steps below, yet if not bidden to sit, none dared take a seat. Whenever Jin went out and did not return by dusk, none dared eat first. Only after his return would they share a meal, whereupon he personally handed them spoons and chopsticks, tasting each dish before them. When Jin governed four provinces and Zhuang remained in the capital, Jin would send seasonal delicacies with envoys whenever possible. If none were sent, Zhuang would not taste them first. Within the household of over a hundred men and women, all shared the same hearth, and no discordant word was heard in the courtyard.

The Record states: The histories praise the Yang brothers for their loyalty, integrity, modesty, and prudence, bearing responsibilities both within and beyond the court. As high ministers and provincial governors, their glory spanned generations, yet their words and demeanor remained humble, arising from utmost sincerity. Their reverent virtue and cautious conduct became a model for the age. Since the founding of the Later Wei, no other family has matched them. Their sons and nephews distinguished themselves, filling the court with officials in blue and purple robes—a blessing borne of accumulated goodness.

When the rebel Hu usurped the court, wielding cruel punishments and spreading poison, how could such a family meet such disaster—was this not a reversal of reward and retribution?

I say: Not so. Confucius said: "In a state with the Dao, to be poor and lowly is a shame. In a state without the Dao, to be prosperous and noble is a shame." The ancients did not rely on their inherited blessings to secure lasting peace, and this was no accident. The Yang family, in the flourishing era of the Northern Wei, embodied righteousness and devoted themselves to public service, serving their lord with loyalty—who could deny this? Yet after Emperor Xiaowen, the sovereign grew ever more immature, governance decayed day by day, empresses usurped power, treacherous ministers seized control, and the realm fell into chaos. The Wei had ceased to be a true state. At such a time, Yang Bo observed the world from afar, realizing that accumulated blessings could not be relied upon, while inherited peril brought only grief. He relinquished the highest honors of the court as readily as Guang Shou of Han—who could have taken them from him? By the time the Erzhu clan rose, murdering the emperor and drowning the empress dowager, spreading their poison across all living things, disaster had become inevitable. Thus, the calamity that befell Zhuang and Jin was not merely more brutal than the slander endured by Shilong, nor did it first manifest when Yuan Chao entered Luoyang. It was not only more perilous after Emperor Jiemin’s edict, but had its roots even earlier, in the days when Emperor Xiaozhuang served as Attendant-in-Ordinary. In this light, reverent virtue and cautious conduct merely bestowed the reputation of a model, while the privileges of power and favor across generations became a grave warning for the wise.

The Boling Cui clan, with Cui Ting at its head, maintained three generations under one roof, their household governed by ritual and deference. Ting and his brother Zhen yielded fields and dwellings to each other, content in their modesty. His sons—Xiaofen, Xiaozhang, Xiaoyan, Xiaozhi, and Xiaozheng—were filial, fraternal, and deeply kind. When Xiaoyan and Xiaozheng passed away, Xiaofen and the others wept in inconsolable grief, abstaining from meat and vegetables, their faces gaunt with sorrow, moving all who saw them. Xiaozhang and the others served Xiaofen with utmost reverence, rising and sitting, eating and withdrawing only at his command. They rose at the cock’s crow, greeting him each morning with care, and not a single coin or length of silk entered their private chambers. For weddings and funerals, they pooled resources and divided them equally. Their wives, too, lived in mutual affection, sharing all they had. After their uncle Zhen’s death, they served their aunt Lady Li as if she were their own mother, tending to her day and night, reporting to her upon leaving and returning, and consulting her on all household matters, great and small. Whenever the brothers went out and acquired goods of even the smallest value, they placed them in Lady Li’s storehouse, and at each season’s end, she distributed the rewards herself. This continued for over twenty years. They raised their cousin Lang, son of Xuanbo, as if he were their own brother.

The Record states: Yang Bo’s generosity and deference did not preserve his family because they had long enjoyed power and favor. Cui Ting’s kindness and sincerity safeguarded his clan because they had never held high office. Thus it is said: Blessings are to be respected, not relied upon. How fortunate is the noble man who lives in a state with the Dao, where the scholar-officials uphold ritual, and conduct and integrity are revered throughout the court and countryside. If one can uphold the rites of the scholar-official even in a disordered state, how could loyalty, integrity, remorse, and uprightness not be sufficient to rely upon? Each observer must judge according to what is fitting.

The *Book of Sui* records: Wang Ning lived as frugally as a commoner. His sons and younger brothers would not meet him unless in official attire, and within his inner chambers, all was as solemn as the imperial court. Tong sighed and said: "How worthy is Ning! He governed his household with the Four Teachings—culture, conduct, loyalty, and trust—and ordered his family with the Four Rites—capping, marriage, mourning, and sacrifice. He acted only in accordance with ritual, nearly all his life. The books of the sages were always at hand, and he never borrowed official robes or ritual vessels. His walls, roof, and household items were sturdy and plain, for he said: 'Let there be no waste.' The trees and fruit in his courtyard were planted in orderly rows, for he said: 'Let there be no disorder.' He accepted no gifts from others, ate only what he had earned, and never added extra dishes to feasts, saying: 'What is proper is enough.'"

In the early years of the Zhenguan era of Tang, Emperor Taizong refined his governance, and his ministers—Fang, Du, Wei, and the Prince of Wei—promulgated their teachings, while the works of Master Wen Zhongzi were poised to flourish. Ning sighed and said: "How great is your elder brother’s legacy! In speaking of the imperial net and the Dao of the sovereign, it is brilliantly clear. In speaking of the realm between Heaven and Earth, there is nothing it does not reach. When the world has the Dao, the sage advances and acts. When the world lacks the Dao, the sage retreats and preserves. This is what is meant by: 'Flow it, and it becomes a river; dam it, and it becomes a deep pool.' Ascend, and it becomes clouds; descend, and it becomes rain; hidden, it nourishes—where does it not bring benefit?"

The Record states: Ning’s insight was as profound as that of the most enlightened. How do we know this? The Dragon Gate was illustrious, yet when the *Twelve Policies for Great Peace* were presented, they did not fully align with his ideals, so he deemed adhering to ritual throughout his life and continuing the classics as the loftier path. If a ruler of an age of governance does not fully adopt one’s counsel, it is better to withdraw and preserve it. This is why Fang, Du, and the others, though esteemed, were not enough, while a single remonstrance from Changsun was more than sufficient. It is far better to ascend as clouds, descend as rain, and nourish in seclusion—bringing benefit everywhere—than to seek such limited influence.

The *Old唐书* records: In the twenty-ninth year of the Kaiyuan era, Prince Xian of Ning, the Grand Commandant, passed away. Emperor Xuanzong mourned him deeply, saying: "The realm was my elder brother’s realm. He yielded it to me, becoming the Taibo of our Tang. A mere posthumous name is not enough for him." Thus he bestowed the posthumous title "Emperor Rang" (the Yielding Emperor). His son, Prince Cui of Ruyang, submitted a memorial to honor his father’s wishes, firmly declining the title, but the emperor did not permit it.

The Record states: Lu Zuan said: "When the Dao aligns with Heaven, it is called 'August'; when virtue matches Earth, it is called 'Emperor.' These are the most exalted titles, the greatest of honorifics. They cannot be casually assumed—how could they be yielded like a dish of food?"

The emperor, out of familial affection, performed bows and kneelings within the palace as if among kin. This is how the celestial order of uncle and nephew must not be disrupted—such is the proper Way. Yet to yield the supreme title out of private sentiment, treating the loftiest of honorifics so lightly, leaves the recipient uneasy and the bestower acting against reason, even appearing absurd. This does not elevate the title but rather demeans it, and cannot serve as a model for later generations.

The *Song Records* state: Li Jiǎnzhī, Sùzhī, Chéngzhī, and Jízhī were all sons of Chancellor Dí. Chéngzhī was orphaned young, and Sùzhī raised and instructed him until he came of age, after which they served in the imperial retinue in succession. When Jízhī was promoted to Academician of the Dragon Diagram Hall, he earnestly declined, requesting that the post be given to his elder brother, saying: "As a minister, I was raised by my brother, and he has already served as a Grand Master of Remonstrance for a decade." The emperor replied: "The fraternal devotion between you brothers is enough to inspire the customs of the age. Sùzhī shall also be promoted." Thus both were appointed together.

Jízhī was meticulous and clear in administrative matters, excelling in every office he held. He once compiled a history of the Tang, offering insights beneficial to governance, serving as a mirror for rulers and ministers. Jiǎnzhī, from a young age, was favored by Kou Zhun. When Emperor Yingzong ascended the throne, Fu Bi recommended him for his learning and conduct. The emperor commended him, saying: "You are a venerable scholar well-versed in statecraft. I shall consult you to remedy my shortcomings—this is not merely about classical scholarship." He was also appointed as Reader-in-Waiting to the Heir Apparent and presented with birthday gifts for Prince Ying. By precedent, the prince would bow in gratitude and withdraw, but Yingzong instructed the prince to detain Jiǎnzhī for a meal, hoping to engage him in unhurried counsel.

As soon as Emperor Shenzong took the throne, Jiǎnzhī immediately requested retirement. From Minister of Works, he was appointed Grand Guardian of the Heir Apparent and retired. As there was no precedent for a retiring official to take leave at the Gate of Heavenly Peace, he was specially granted an audience in the Hall of Extended Harmony, seated, and then hosted at a banquet in the Hall of Nurtured Goodness. The lecturers were all commanded to compose poems in his honor, lavishing him with praise. The emperor also instructed Wang Gui to record the event. His son, Xiaoji, held a position in the palace service but, needing to care for his parents, requested an appointment as Supervisor of Chongfu Abbey. After a decade of quietude, he retired at the same time as his father, at the age of fifty. Scholars and officials praised them, comparing them to the two Shu brothers of the Han.

His younger brother, Xiaoda, was summoned for an audience, and Shenzong inquired about his well-being, sighing that their conduct far surpassed that of ordinary men.

The *Record* states: Hu Mingshen, regarding the departure of the two Shu brothers, believed that the heir apparent could not be relied upon—this is not necessarily so. As for Jiǎnzhī and his sons, was their integrity not genuine? Shenzong, however, indulged his own preferences upon assuming power, adopting the proposals of Wang Anshi and recklessly pursuing disruptive schemes. Could the gentlemen well-versed in statecraft have failed to take heed? Later, Xiaoshou and Xiaochen, though of one mind as brothers, were nonetheless implicated in the case instigated by Zhang Dun. With Cai Jing and Cai Bian wielding authority, how much was left of fraternal devotion? This is why the emperor sighed that their conduct far surpassed that of ordinary men.

The Lü brothers—Da Fang, his elder brother Da Zhong, and younger brothers Da Jun and Da Lin—lived together, mutually refining their conduct, discoursing on the Dao, and examining ritual, all rooted in antiquity. Scholars of ritual in Guanzhong held them in high esteem.

They once established a community compact, declaring: "Encourage virtue and learning among one another, correct each other’s faults, interact with ritual propriety, and aid one another in times of hardship." When Xie Liangzuo served as instructor in Qinzhou, Da Zhong would visit to attend his lectures on the *Analects*, always straightening his robes and composing his countenance, saying, "The words and deeds of the Sage are present here—I dare not but show reverence."

Da Jun, while serving as Remonstrating Censor, mourned his mother from the onset of her illness through the interment, adhering strictly to ancient rites in all that could be observed. His mourning observances, from the grandest to the most minute, conformed precisely to ritual. Extending this principle to sacrifices, capping ceremonies, weddings, drinking gatherings, social visits, congratulations, and condolences, he never allowed custom to obscure proper form. He compiled written guidelines for each occasion, and people grew accustomed to following them with ease.

Da Lin was well-versed in the Six Classics, particularly profound in ritual studies. He sought to revive the institutions and texts of the Three Dynasties, aiming to make them practicable rather than mere empty words, even if it meant defying worldly conventions and shocking the vulgar. When Fu Bi retired to private life and turned to Buddhist teachings, Da Lin wrote to him, saying: "In antiquity, the Three Dukes deliberated on the Dao within the court and oversaw education in the countryside—was this role altered by the rise or fall of rank, the vigor or decline of strength? Now, the Great Dao remains obscured, and people flock to heterodox teachings, doubting the Sage’s perfection and dismissing ritual and righteousness as unworthy of study. This is the moment for elders of integrity to feel compassion and act, to rouse a degenerate age—such is your responsibility. As for refining the spirit and transforming qi in pursuit of longevity, these are the practices of recluses in mountain valleys, seeking only personal perfection. How could they be expected of you?" Fu Bi deeply acknowledged his words.

The *Record* states: The *Doctrine of the Mean* says, "The Way of the noble person begins with the relationship between husband and wife." The community compact of Lantian endures even today. Geng Guang once called Huang Tingjian his father. The compact’s principles—"encourage virtue and learning" and "correct each other’s faults"—serve above all to guard against shallowness. As for "interacting with ritual propriety" and "aiding one another in hardship," these may be practiced in tandem. If, within the privacy of one’s home, conduct is found wanting, then within the village, words will lack credibility. Even in instructing a child of five feet, one would fail—how much more so for a grand minister of state?

Moreover, the customs of Guanzhong have been renowned for their antiquity since the Zhou dynasty, and the teachings of Master Hengqu are also well-known. The Lü brothers were towering figures within that tradition—what difficulty could they have had with ritual learning? This, too, is worth noting.

The *Tianshun Daily Record* states: In the year *xīnwèi* of the Jingtai era (1461), when the former emperor returned in triumph, court discussions on the rites for his restoration frequently cited the unpredictability of the northern tribes as a pretext, proposing only a single carriage and two horses for his reception.

At that time, Supervising Secretary Lin Cong submitted a memorial, stating: "Now, the northern chieftain, in awe of Heaven and repentant of his transgressions, has merely escorted the imperial carriage back. For the rites of reception and restoration, the grand imperial procession with full regalia should be employed."

Meanwhile, Minister of Rites Hu Han produced a document for Vice Minister Ye Sheng, which had been shown to him by Grand Secretary Gao Gu of the Inner Court. Its contents were earnest and impassioned, declaring: "Between His Majesty and the Supreme Emperor, the bond is both that of sovereign and subject and of brothers. The rites of reception and restoration ought to be conducted with utmost generosity." He wished to present this document to the throne, that the intent to honor and esteem might be known throughout court and realm alike.

Minister of Personnel Wang Zhi also voiced his approval, saying: "This is a matter of seeking lost rites among the common people—it should be brought to the emperor’s attention." Only Wang Wen dismissed it as nothing more than an anonymous missive. The affair was on the verge of being shelved when Lin Cong resolutely submitted another memorial, asserting: "Wang Zhi and Hu Han are both trusted ministers of the heart. Matters concerning the great principles of state should be decided by public consensus, not private discourse." Thereupon, the document was presented to the throne, and the rites for the Supreme Emperor’s reception and restoration were duly carried out in full accordance with protocol—all through Lin Cong’s efforts.

The *Record* states: Master Zhou observed, "The dynamics of the world are but a matter of power: when one side grows heavy, the other naturally lightens—such is the principle of Heaven." The sage in governing the realm ensures that neither side holds an imbalanced weight, and that neither self nor others harbor partiality or bias. Only after Lin Cong advanced this proposal did the deliberations on the heir apparent follow. Had every official at court acted thus, how could the confinement in the Southern Palace, the restraint of the imperial carriage, the rectification of the regency’s authority, or the clarification of the regency’s propriety have been necessary? Not only could the later crisis of the *Duomen* Incident have been averted, but the former guilt of Lang Li might also have been redressed. Between sovereign and subject, between brothers—why wait to seek lost rites among the common people?

*Hongdao Record*, Scroll Thirty-Four concludes.
*Hongdao Record*, Scroll Thirty-Five begins.

On the Rites of Friendship

*Mencius* records: Shun had an audience with Emperor Yao, who lodged his son-in-law in the secondary chamber. They also feasted Shun, taking turns as host and guest—this was the Son of Heaven befriending a commoner.

**Recorded Note:** The qi of Heaven and Earth arises at *zi* and converges at *wu*; the destiny of emperors emerges from *Zhen* and meets in *Li*. Yet Yao’s rise came through the virtue of Fire, attaining the central number of Heaven and Earth, while Shun’s rise came through the virtue of Earth, attaining the central qi of Heaven and Earth. Thus, Heaven’s number is five, Earth’s number is five, and the five positions interact, each containing the other. How could one argue that a commoner and the Son of Heaven are unequal? Though their virtue and sagacity were equal, this was truly the work of Heaven’s destiny and the numerology of qi. How could later generations dare hope to emulate even one ten-thousandth of this?

Boyi fled Zhou and dwelt by the northern sea, where, hearing of King Wen’s rise, he said: “Why not return? I hear the Lord of the West excels at honoring the aged.” Taigong fled Zhou and dwelt by the eastern sea, where, hearing of King Wen’s rise, he said: “Why not return? I hear the Lord of the West excels at honoring the aged.” When the world has one who excels at honoring the aged, the benevolent regard him as their refuge.

**Recorded Note:** According to the rites, the near-honoring of the aged was practiced thus: the House of Yu used the *yan* rite, the House of Xia the *xiang* rite, the Yin people the *shi* rite, and the Zhou people employed all three comprehensively. At fifty, one was honored in the village; at sixty, in the capital; at seventy, in the academy, extending even to the feudal lords. Thus, the two elders promptly returned, and King Wen’s transformation arose swiftly. Yet when King Wu campaigned against Zhou, the two elders’ responses diverged sharply. Why?

Confucius said: “The noble man may emerge or withdraw, speak or remain silent.” When two share a single heart, their strength can sever metal. Thus, the eagle’s soaring flight is guided by the Dao; the fern-root diet is sustained by righteousness; the exhortation against divided loyalty is secondary to serving the emperor; the rebuke at the horse’s bridle is devoted to Heaven. Taigong took the world as his duty, while Boyi took the relationship between ruler and minister as his responsibility. Yet both aligned with the correctness of Heaven’s principle and the peace of the human heart—why then compare their similarities or differences? Though the paths of the two elders diverged, their destination was the same; they cannot be divided into two.

*The Record of Rites* states: Three days after King Wu of Zhou ascended the throne, he summoned Grand Tutor Shangfu and asked: “Do the ways of the Yellow Emperor and Zhuanxu endure?” Grand Tutor Shangfu replied: “They are recorded in the cinnabar texts.” The king said: “I wish to hear them,” and then purified himself. After three days of fasting and donning court robes, Grand Tutor Shangfu, also in court robes, entered bearing the text. The king stood facing east, while Grand Tutor Shangfu faced west and recited the text’s words: “Reverence overcoming indolence brings fortune; indolence overcoming reverence brings ruin. Righteousness overcoming desire brings compliance; desire overcoming righteousness brings misfortune.”

**Recorded Note:** King Wu of Zhou honored Taigong as his teacher and also styled him “Father Shang,” showing the utmost respect. In their ritual, the king stood facing east while the Grand Tutor faced west, perfectly embodying the principle of teacher and friend—not only Yao and Shun acted thus. Reverence is the beginning and end of sagely learning. When reverence overcomes indolence, one serves day and night with awe, daring not deviate—hence fortune. Indolence is the seed of carelessness and licentiousness. When indolence overcomes reverence, one grows contemptuous of the Five Phases and scorns the Three Norms—hence ruin. Righteousness is the foundation of judgment and governance. When righteousness overcomes desire, one is not enslaved by the senses, and all measures remain upright—hence compliance. Desire is the perilous origin of the human heart. When desire overcomes righteousness, one wallows in excess and dissipation, acting without restraint—hence misfortune. These principles were transmitted by the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors of high antiquity and inscribed in the cinnabar texts. That they mention only the Yellow Emperor and Zhuanxu is an illustrative reference, fitting that one must fast and don court robes before hearing them.

*The Minor Odes of the Kingdom* sings of the joy of friends:
*Thwack! Thwack!* go the axes felling trees,
*Ying! Ying!* cry the birds.
From dark valleys they emerge,
to settle in towering trees.
*Ying! Ying!* they call,
seeking the sound of friends.
Look at those birds—
even they seek the sound of friends.
How much more should men,
not seek companions in life?
May the spirits hear this,
bringing harmony and peace.

**Recorded Note:** The *Odes* says: “The birds cry *ying! ying!*” and also: “From dark valleys they emerge, to settle in towering trees.” Clearly, this is no comparison to the destitute or lonely. Even the lines: “The phoenix cries upon the high ridge” serve as metaphors for the court. Yet how could the spirits hear this? The ancients invariably invoked the divine to show no partiality between self and others, as in: “August Heaven is bright, accompanying your emergence as king; August Heaven is radiant, accompanying your joyful wandering.” These noble men take benevolence and righteousness as their mates, morality and the Dao as their neighbors. Their mutual accord in heart and will is established before Heaven and Earth. With united hearts and strength, they secure the royal house; serving day and night without slack, they attend to the One Man. Their mutual sincerity shines like liver and gall, tested before ghosts and spirits. A single word uttered brings shared benefit to all under Heaven; a single deed established brings shared blessing to the myriad people. Thus, the harmony’s blessing endures without end, and the beauty of Great Peace descends for eternity. Without this, one harms the people and injures things, slanders the worthy and envies the capable—then court and world alike fall into chaos. The bond of friendship bears most critically on the world’s order, far beyond mere exchanges of “you” and “me” or hollow courtesies.

*Thwack! Thwack!* go the axes,
fine wine is prepared.
With fat lambs at hand,
we hasten to invite our uncles.
If some should not come,
do not blame us for neglect.
Sweep the hall, set out the mats,
arrange the eight baskets of grain.

With fat rams at hand,
we hasten to invite our uncles.
If some should not come,
do not fault us for neglect.

*Thwack! Thack!* go the axes on the slope,
rich wine overflows the cups.
Plates and bowls are set in order,
let no brother keep his distance.
When the people lose their virtue,
dry crusts and cold water bring blame.
If there is wine, pour me a draught;
if there is none, brew me some.
*Thump! Thump!* beat the drums for me,
*Stomp! Stomp!* dance with me.
While I have leisure,
let us drink this draught.

Recorded saying: What one seeks in friends, one must first offer—though one may not yet be able. The ancients’ earnest and sincere conduct was ever thus; how could others fail to turn to me? Hence it is also said: If there is wine, purify it for me; if there is none, concoct it for me. The utmost effort lies with me, leaving nothing undone.

King Xuan commanded Yin Jifu to lead the army northward on campaign. Upon his triumphant return, the poets composed songs in praise, saying:
Jifu feasts in joy,
having received abundant blessings.
Returning from Hao,
our march was long.
He entertains his friends with drink,
serving phoenix-turtle and carp in minced slices.
Who else is present?
Zhang Zhong, the filial and fraternal.

Recorded saying: Jifu, honored as marshal and a hereditary minister of the state, having strenuously established merit in campaigns and endured the hardships of hunting and warfare, would summon men of extraordinary strategy and secret counsel—#1 consulting them as advisors in council and riding beside them as his chariot companion. Such is the duty of generals and ministers. Yet why does he ascribe his success to Zhang Zhong?

For filial piety and fraternal devotion stand foremost among the six virtues and precede the eight penal codes. When the state appoints officials, it relies on these to protect the people; when a family establishes its laws, it depends on these to cultivate posterity. Thus, the governance of Jun Ya is none other than the wise counsel of Zhang Zhong, and Jifu’s reverent friendship is what the poets delight to extol.

Alas! By offering drink to advance the worthy, there is no room for arrogance or indulgence; by honoring with simple fare rather than turtle, where lies the fault of extravagance and excess? In a single feast, three virtues converge—is it not fitting to call this "abundant blessings"?

From *The Greater Elegantiae*:
At the guests’ first seating,
left and right are well-ordered.
Baskets and platters are arrayed,
meat and fruit arranged in rows.
The wine is harmonious and fine,
all drink in perfect accord.
Bells and drums are set in place,
the company rises with ease.
The great target is raised high,
bows and arrows drawn.
The archers stand as one,
each displays his skill.
They shoot at the mark,
vying for their cups.

At the guests’ first seating,
their demeanor is warm and respectful.
Before they are drunk,
their bearing is solemn and restrained.
Once drunk,
their manner becomes erratic.
They abandon their seats,
dancing wildly in disarray.
Before they are drunk,
their mien is grave and measured.
Once drunk,
their bearing turns unruly.
Thus, when drunk,
they forget all propriety.
The guests, now drunk,
shout and clamor.
They disrupt the baskets and platters,
dancing in reckless abandon.
Thus, when drunk,
they forget all restraint.
Their caps askew,
they dance with ungainly steps.
Those who leave while drunk
share in the blessing.
Those who remain drunk
are said to assail virtue.
Drinking is most excellent
when marked by proper conduct.
In all such drinking,
some are drunk, some are not.
A supervisor is appointed,
an assistant scribe attends.
Those who are drunk bring ruin,
while the sober feel shame.
Do not follow their words,
lest sighs arise.
Speak not what should not be spoken,
utter not what should not be uttered.
From drunken words,
childish babble emerges.
After three cups, they know not restraint,
how dare they drink more?

Recorded saying: The preface claims this poem was composed to lament the faults of drinking. Yet in my humble view, what the records say of Duke Wu of Wei and what the poem describes are entirely different—could it be that he reformed only after losing himself?

The Master said: Duke Mu of Qin was deeply esteemed by the sages. Yet those who sing of the guests’ feast and fail to reflect on themselves—are they not inferior to such men?

From *The Analects*: Confucius said, "Yan Pingzhong was skilled in befriending great men, maintaining respect over time."

Recorded saying: I have heard from Master Zhang: Yan Ying was wise, yet he did not know Confucius, yet he praised his virtue. Why? The Master’s friendships were based on the Dao and virtue alone, thus he valued longevity and respect. Later generations’ friendships are based on power and profit alone, hence they rush to curry favor. Yet destiny is what the Master rarely spoke of—who would say Master Zhang did not understand this?

Qu Boyu sent an emissary to Confucius. Confucius sat with him and asked, "What is your master doing?" The emissary replied, "My master wishes to reduce his faults but has not yet succeeded." When the emissary left, Confucius said, "A true emissary! A true emissary!"

Recorded saying: Among the Master’s friends were Boyu of Wei, Yan Ying of Qi, and Zichan of Zheng—all men who held rank and governed states. Yet when they sent emissaries to Confucius, they did not speak of diplomatic exchanges or official decrees, but only of reducing faults. From this, one sees how the ancients, in their mutual refinement through the Dao and virtue, never allowed even a minor envoy to be swayed by wealth or power. Boyu’s steadfast conduct and careful virtue, unwavering even in old age, were evident in the words of his emissary, leaving no room for doubt.

The achievements of friendship—even with carriages and horses, one does not bow except for sacrificial meat.

Recorded saying: One must hold this intention within. Without this intention, achievements may seem substantial, yet their absence may seem slight. Extending this principle, even when Shun received the realm from Yao, it was in accord with the mutual exchange between ruler and subject. If not for returning to the ancestral arts with reverence, where would respect be directed? If one values the trappings of office—oxen, sheep, granaries, and storehouses—reducing oneself to toil while the deputy bows, this is what displeased Zisi. Would Shun or the Master have done such a thing?

From *Mencius*: Duke Mu repeatedly sought an audience with Zisi, saying, "In ancient times, the ruler of a state of a thousand chariots befriended scholars—how was this?" Zisi was displeased and said, "The ancients spoke of serving—how could they speak of befriending?" Zisi’s displeasure was not without reason: by rank, you are the lord and I the subject—how dare I befriend you? By virtue, you serve me—how could I befriend you? The rightful ministers of a state of a thousand chariots seek to befriend such men but cannot—how much less can they be summoned?
