Recorded saying: In my humble view, the ancient sages and worthies valued the Dao, and this was not unique to Zisi. Zengzi said, "The wealth of Jin and Chu cannot be matched. They rely on their wealth, while I rely on my benevolence; they rely on their rank, while I rely on my righteousness—what have I to fear?" Mencius said, "What lies with them are all things I do not do; what lies with me are all the ancient institutions—what have I to fear from them?" The sages’ Dao was vast, their virtue expansive, embracing all without exception. The worthy, however, follow the Dao when it is exalted and sink with it when it is debased—this is why one must be cautious. This can be seen from the foregoing.

Meng Xian of a household with a hundred chariots had five friends: Yuezheng Qiu, Muzhong, and three others whose names I have forgotten. When Meng Xian befriended these five, it was not because of his household’s status. Had these five possessed households like Meng Xian’s, they would not have befriended him.

Recorded saying: When one is noble and the other base, true friendship is revealed—this is one who values the other’s power. When one is rich and the other poor, true friendship is revealed—this is one who covets the other’s wealth. Thus it is said: alliances of power do not last, and bonds of profit are not intimate. Can such relations truly be called friendship? When this principle is not understood, the rich grow arrogant, the poor grow obsequious, and the pursuit of power and profit flourishes while the Dao and virtue wither. Mencius set forth this argument to establish the model for aiding benevolence and to close the door to flattery and sycophancy—this cannot be ignored.

This is not only true of households with a hundred chariots; even the lords of small states have such distinctions. Duke Hui said: "With Zisi, I take him as my teacher; with Yan Ban, I take him as my friend; Wang Shun and Chang Xi serve me." Recorded saying: Though Duke Hui’s deeds cannot be verified, his ability to distinguish the greatest worthies as his teachers and the next as his friends shows he was no ordinary man. Moreover, when the Zhou Dao declined and the custom of "felling the trees" faded, even rulers and grandees could still exalt some and humble others, treating teachers, friends, and beneficial companions as matters of praise—was this not the influence of the moral teachings of Confucius’ school? Beyond this, such examples are rare indeed.

This is not only true of the lords of small states; even the rulers of great states observed such distinctions.

Duke Ping of Jin, in his regard for Hai Tang, would enter when told to enter, sit when told to sit, and eat when told to eat. Though it were only coarse vegetables and plain broth, he never failed to eat his fill—indeed, he dared not do otherwise.

Recorded saying: As a ruler, Duke Ping of Jin indulged in excesses of pleasure, imprisoned Shu Xiang, succumbed to the sickness of dissipation, and established the office of *Luxi*, thus confounding his resolve and rendering himself incapable. Yet toward the worthy, he still observed proper courtesy, maintaining reverence and humility in his every movement—whether advancing or retreating, hastening or lingering—circumspectly upholding ritual propriety as if it yet endured. Thus, the noble man does not dismiss him entirely on account of his faults.

In the *Comprehensive Mirror*, it is recorded that Marquis Wen of Wei took Bu Zixia and Tian Zifang as his teachers. Each time he passed the residence of Duan Ganmu, he would bow from his chariot, and worthy scholars from all directions flocked to him.

Recorded saying: Among the kings of antiquity, even those who bore the imperial seal had Zixia as their teacher—how could a disciple of such eminence in the Sage’s school bring shame? As for Tian Zifang and Duan Ganmu, I cannot judge their worth. Nevertheless, that a usurper of such rank could recognize this much is still worthy of praise. Later, Marquis Ying of Wei, with humble deference and generous gifts, sought to attract the worthy, and even Mencius came to him. Though Liang was but a small state, it twice became the seat of a great worthy’s governance—could one not have striven to set the precedent? Alas, the rulers of Wei merely feigned reverence for the worthy to curry favor, wielding wealth and rank to overawe others. They bore the name of honoring the worthy but lacked the substance of employing them. Is it any wonder they ended as mere usurpers?

When Mencius met King Hui of Liang, the king said: “Venerable sir, you have come a thousand *li* without regard for the distance—what benefit will you bring to my state?” Mencius replied: “Why must Your Majesty speak of benefit? Let there be only benevolence and righteousness. Never has one who was benevolent neglected his kin, nor one who was righteous put his lord last.” The king said: “How may I benefit my state?” The great officers said: “How may I benefit my house?” The knights and commoners said: “How may I benefit myself?” When superiors and subordinates vie for profit, the state is imperiled. In a state of ten thousand chariots, he who murders his lord is invariably a noble with a thousand chariots; in a state of a thousand chariots, he who murders his lord is invariably a noble with a hundred chariots. To take a thousand from ten thousand, or a hundred from a thousand, is no small share. Yet if one puts profit before righteousness, nothing short of total seizure will satisfy.

In the *Records of the Grand Historian*, it is told that when King Zhao of Yan ascended the throne, he humbled himself and offered lavish gifts to attract the worthy. He said to Guo Wei: “Qi exploited the chaos in my state to invade and crush Yan. I know full well that Yan is small and weak, and cannot avenge this. Yet if I could but obtain worthy men to share my thoughts and wipe away the shame of my predecessors, that would be my greatest wish. Sir, if you see one who is fit, I shall personally serve him.” Guo Wei replied: “In ancient times, a ruler sent a eunuch with a thousand gold to seek a thousand-*li* horse. The horse had already died, yet the eunuch bought its bones for five hundred gold and returned. The ruler flew into a rage, but the eunuch said: ‘If even a dead horse is bought at such a price, how much more will the living be drawn here? The horses will come soon enough.’ Within a year, horses from a thousand *li* arrived in threes. Now, if Your Majesty truly wishes to attract the worthy, begin with me, Wei. How much more will those greater than I come from afar?” Thereupon, King Zhao had a new palace built for Wei and took him as his teacher. From this, scholars vied to come to Yan: Le Yi arrived from Wei, and Ju Xin from Zhao. King Zhao appointed Le Yi as his deputy minister and entrusted him with state affairs.

Recorded saying: In Mencius’ time, Shen Tong once asked him a private question, yet the name of Le Yi was never heard. The Grand Historian also remarked: “Whenever I read Mencius’ passage where King Hui of Liang asks, ‘How may I benefit my state?’ I cannot but lay down the book and sigh. Alas! The Master seldom spoke of profit, ever guarding against its source. From the Son of Heaven to the common folk, what difference is there in the harm wrought by the love of profit?” Yet in the tale of the eunuch and the horse’s head, who indeed was the architect of such a scheme? By that time, the calamity of benevolence and righteousness had grown thorny, and the harm of profit and desire blazed fiercely. Mencius, with his generation-transcending talent, advanced a discourse of surpassing insight. If one observes these two matters together, one may see that the weight of honored guests and teachers, the esteem of elders and seniors, were not in vain. As for King Zhao of Yan and Le Yi, who zealously pursued profit and never spoke of benevolence and righteousness, the instability of their lord-minister relationship was plain to see. The admonition that “nothing short of total seizure will satisfy” is especially worthy of being handed down. For in the beginning, they emerged from one path only to enter another; thus, in the end, they emerged from this path only to return to that. Then, neglecting kin and putting one’s lord last—was there anything not so? How could a Le Yi or a Ju Xin have understood this? Alas! Later generations have even compared themselves to such men—how paltry was their vision!

The *Records of the Western Han* state: The scholars of antiquity were broadly learned in the texts of the Six Arts, establishing the canons of the Five Teachings—these were the perfected laws of governance. When the Zhou declined, the words of Confucius went unheeded and the Dao was not practiced. Thereupon, he accepted invitations from the feudal lords, traveling with the rites and upholding righteousness. His seventy disciples scattered and journeyed to the four directions: the greater became tutors and mentors, the lesser became companions and friends. Thus, Zizhang resided in Chen, Tantai Ziyu in Chu, Zixia in the West River, and Zigong ended his days in Qi. When Qin unified the realm, it burned the *Book of Poetry* and *Book of Documents*, executed the Ru scholars, and the Six Arts fell into ruin.

When Chen She proclaimed himself king, the Ru of Lu carried the ritual vessels of the House of Confucius to join him. Kong Jia thus became Chen She’s erudite, and ultimately died with him. Now, Chen She rose from a commoner, rebelled from his penal labor to establish his claim, and perished in less than a year—yet the gentry and scholars flocked to him. Why? Because Qin had banned their studies and accumulated resentment, so they vented their indignation through Chen She.

When Emperor Gao of Han executed Xiang Yu and led his troops to besiege Lu, the Ru within the city continued their recitations, practicing rites, and the sounds of zithers and songs never ceased. Was this not the enduring influence of the Sage? By the time of Emperor Wu, Gongsun Hong rose from a commoner to become chief minister and be enfeoffed within a few years. Thereupon, he established guest halls at the prime minister’s residence, built the "Tied Pavilion," and extended invitations to worthy men. Later, Li Cai, Yan Qing, Zhai Zhao, Zhou Shi Qing, Gongsun He, and Liu Quwu succeeded him. From Cai to Qing, the guest halls of the prime minister’s residence lay in ruins, while He and Quwu repurposed them as stables and quarters for slaves and servants.

It is recorded: Our Ru, in their inquiry into the workings of Heaven and Earth, at their greatest continue the legacy of past sages and open the way for future learning; at the least, they exalt governance and bring about great peace. This ritual must not be abandoned for a single day. Even the petty Chen She understood this. Alas, the rise of the Great Han failed to honor and esteem it, allowing men like Jia Yi and Dong Zhongshu no opportunity to expand their influence, while Gongsun Hong later usurped the glory. That historians repeatedly recount this with sighs of lament—could it have been without purpose? Their sorrow runs deep. Let the reader ponder this.

In the early Han, there were the Four White-Haired Ones: Master Dongyuan, Qi Liji, Xia Huanggong, and Master Jiaoli. During the Qin era, these four men fled into the depths of Mount Shang and Mount Luo, awaiting the settling of the world. Emperor Gao heard of them and summoned them, but they did not come. Later, when Emperor Hui was crown prince, he sent humble words and gifts of silk, dispatching a comfortable carriage to welcome them. Once they arrived, they accompanied the crown prince to see Emperor Gao, who treated them as honored guests. Later, in Gukou there was Zheng Zizhen, and in Shu there was Yan Junping, both of whom cultivated themselves and preserved their integrity, wearing only what was proper and eating only what was fitting. During the reign of Emperor Cheng, Zheng Zizhen was formally invited but declined and died without accepting. Yan Junping practiced divination in the markets of Chengdu. Though the world deemed divination a base profession, it could be used to awaken the masses. When faced with questions of wickedness or impropriety, he would rely on the oracle’s pronouncements of fortune or misfortune; when speaking to sons, he grounded his words in filial piety; to younger brothers, in obedience; to ministers, in loyalty. Adapting to each situation, he guided them toward goodness—more than half of those who followed his words corrected their faults.

When Yang Xiong was young, he traveled to study, and even after entering officialdom, he often praised Yan Junping’s virtue to prominent figures. When Du Ling, the governor of Yizhou, heard of this, he rejoiced, saying, “I have truly found Yan Junping!” Yang Xiong replied, “Receive him with full rites, for he may be seen but cannot be compelled to stay.” When Du Ling arrived in Shu and met Yan Junping with due ceremony, he sighed, “Yang Ziyun truly knows men.”

It is recorded: The Han succeeded the Qin, beginning with the burning of books and burying of scholars, and ending with the neglect of scholars and the feeding of horses with fine grain—it nearly became a world without scholars or friends. Yet when a crown prince emerged to seek them with humble words, those in tall caps and wide sashes, refined and elegant, reappeared in the Han court. Could this not show that the way of friendship had not been entirely severed? Later, the lingering influence of Zheng Zizhen and Yan Junping spread through their era.

Mencius did not say: If their lord employs them, they enjoy peace, wealth, honor, and glory. If their sons and younger brothers follow them, they embody filial piety, brotherly respect, loyalty, and trustworthiness. Could these not describe such men?

When Cao Shen served as prime minister of Qi, the realm had just been pacified, and King Hui of Qi was young. Cao Shen summoned all the elders and scholars to ask how to settle and unite the people. In Jiaoxi there was a certain Master Gai, whom he sent for with generous gifts. After meeting him, Master Gai spoke of governance, valuing clarity and inaction so that the people might stabilize themselves. He expounded on this principle in detail. Thereupon, Cao Shen yielded the main hall to house Master Gai and fully implemented his methods. Thus, he served as prime minister of Qi for nine years, bringing stability and unity to the state, and was hailed as a worthy minister.

It is recorded: Cao Shen’s governance of Qi and later of the realm followed this same Dao. This shows that even the renowned ministers of the Han could find their own teachers and did not merely favor those who flattered them. How much more worthy were they than later generations!

When Wei Qing served as Grand General, all the feudal lords were subordinate to him, and none among the ministers rivaled his honor and favor. All the dukes and ministers deferred to him, save for Ji An, who treated him as an equal. Someone advised Ji An, “The Grand General is honored and esteemed—you cannot refuse to bow.” Ji An replied, “If the Grand General receives guests with a bow, does that make his guests any less weighty?” When the Grand General heard this, he esteemed Ji An even more, frequently seeking his counsel on matters of state and the court, treating him with greater respect than before.

It is recorded: Why did Ji An not bow to Wei Qing? Because a man with desires lacks firmness, and firmness does not yield to desire. Those who deferred to him did so out of desire. Ji An, being without desire, could openly rebuke him without transgression and defy propriety without shame.

You are upright as a lord—how much more should your ministers be? Some say: "Ji An often wished to enter and leave the palace gates; could he truly have been without desire?" Now, one whose nature is upright and loves righteousness is *enlightened*; one who feigns virtue while acting contrary is merely *reputed*. Ji An’s conduct was enlightened. Whether within the court or beyond it, what weight did he gain or lose?

Ma Yuan and Gongsun Shu were old neighbors from the same district and shared a close friendship. Later, when Shu declared himself emperor in Chengdu, Chen Ao sent Yuan to observe. Yuan expected that upon arrival, they would clasp hands and rejoice as in former days. Instead, Shu arrayed a grand procession of steps and guards to receive him. After exchanging bows, he sent Yuan to lodgings, then had a court robe and *jiaorang* cap prepared for him. He assembled all his officials in the ancestral temple, setting a place for his old friend. Shu arrived with phoenix banners and feathered canopies, his cortege clearing the way with warnings. Yuan entered, bowing deeply, and was feasted with great ceremony.

When Yuan later presented a letter in Luoyang, Emperor Guangwu was seated at the southern steps of the Xuande Hall, weaving silk. He rose to greet Yuan with a smile: "You have roamed between two emperors—seeing you now, I feel deeply ashamed." Yuan replied, "In this age, not only does the lord choose his ministers; the minister also chooses his lord. I am from the same county as Gongsun Shu and was close to him in youth. When I visited him before, he received me with halberds at his steps. Now, coming from afar, how could Your Majesty know I am not an assassin or a traitor, yet you treat me with such ease?" The emperor laughed again: "You are no assassin—you are but a persuader." Yuan said, "The world is in turmoil, and those who falsely claim great names are beyond counting. Seeing Your Majesty today, with your magnanimity and breadth of spirit, you match the greatness of Gaozu. Now I know that emperors have their true measure."

It is recorded: Should the emperor’s ease not have been thus? When King Liao was slain by Zhuan Zhu’s blade and Qin’s laws forbade bearing arms, Jing Ke revealed his dagger—such matters do not hinge on ease or its absence. Yet did the emperor act so deliberately? A voice, a smile, a demeanor may suffice for common men, but to open one’s heart and reveal sincerity is how one binds oneself to heroes. Yuan’s observations were made in a single glance.

Alas, the words of a persuader do not grasp Yuan’s true nature. His choice of lord arose from his innermost heart. His whole intent was fixed on the east—this was his long-held wish, not the scheming of a fickle turncoat. Had his lord been worthy of service, even if the halls were guarded and the steps fortified, he would have pledged himself without hesitation. Had his lord been unworthy, even if they clasped hands in joy, he would have seen no cause for intimacy. In the end, he destroyed Ao and vanquished Shu, never overstepping his bounds. Thus, Yuan was no persuader—he was a *virtue*-guest. What place had fleeting flattery in his heart?

*The Hongdao Record*, Scroll 35, ends here.
*The Hongdao Record*, Scroll 36: "Rites"

**The Rites of Friendship**

From *The Book of the Later Han*: In the second year of the Yongping era of Emperor Ming, the emperor visited the *Biyong* [Imperial Academy] and first performed the Rites of Nurturing the Aged, appointing Li Gong as the *Sanlao* [Elder of the Three] and Huan Rong as the *Wugeng* [Elder of the Five]. The *Sanlao* wore a grand robe with a sash, a *jinxian* cap, and leaned on a jade staff, riding in a carriage. Upon arriving at the ritual hall of the *Biyong*, the emperor’s seat was set in the eastern chamber. Envoys were dispatched in state carriages to welcome the *Sanlao* and *Wugeng* from the lecture hall of the Imperial Academy. The Son of Heaven received them at the gate, exchanging courtesies at the screen. The emperor ascended by the western steps, while the *Sanlao* ascended by the eastern steps. When they reached the platform, the emperor bowed in accordance with ritual. The *Sanlao* faced east, the Three Dukes set out his armrest, and the Nine Ministers adjusted his shoes. The emperor personally bared his arm to carve the sacrificial animal, held the sauce to season it, and raised the goblet to offer wine. The *zhuheng* [prayer for ease of swallowing] stood before him, and the *zhuti* [prayer for bodily health] stood behind. The *Wugeng* faced south, while the Three Dukes presented offerings—the rites were the same. After the ceremony, Huan Rong and his disciples were led to ascend the hall, where he lectured himself. The scholars held their texts and raised questions before him, while officials in caps and sashes gathered at the *Qiaomen* Gate to observe. The listeners numbered in the hundreds of thousands.

The *Record* states: Emperor Guangwu established the *Biyong* but did not live to perform the rites. It was Emperor Ming who personally attended and first carried out the ceremony. Today, we see the grandeur of its majesty and cultural splendor, the meticulousness of its ascent and descent, its bows and yielding—rarely has its equal been seen since the Three Dynasties. Alas! This may be called one who "well inherits the will of others and well continues their affairs." Yet it is regrettable that these rites were reserved for kings, nobles, high ministers, and imperial relatives, seldom extending to the realm at large. Thus, imperial edicts were not widely proclaimed, and local schools were not established. The *Qimen* and *Yulin* guards, the cap-and-sash gentlemen at the *Qiaomen* Gate—these were but spectators of its beauty. The so-called human ethics of filial piety and fraternal duty had no bearing on them, and the transformative power of education went no further than this.

When the emperor was still crown prince, he studied the *Book of Documents* under Huan Rong. After ascending the throne, he continued to honor him with the rites due a teacher. Once, he visited Huan Rong’s hall, where he had a seat set facing east, with an armrest and staff. He assembled the hundred officials and several hundred disciples. The emperor personally held the text, and when some students rose to pose questions, he humbly said, "The Grand Preceptor is here." After the gathering, he presented all the delicacies of the imperial kitchen to Huan Rong’s family. Whenever Huan Rong fell ill, the emperor would send envoys to inquire after him, with imperial physicians and provisions crowding the roads. When his illness grew severe, the emperor visited his home to ask after his condition. He dismounted at the entrance to the lane, cradling the texts as he approached. Huan Rong, moved to tears, was gifted with bedding, curtains, canopies, swords, clothing, and quilts. The emperor lingered for a long while before departing. Thereafter, when feudal lords, generals, and ministers came to inquire after his health, none dared ride their carriages to his gate—they all bowed at his bedside. When Huan Rong passed away, the emperor personally donned mourning attire to attend the funeral and escort the coffin, granting him a tomb site on the southern slope of Mount Shou.

The *Record* states: Uprightness and deceit cannot coexist; Confucianism and Buddhism do not walk the same path. Only after the existence of heaven and earth did Confucianism and Buddhism arise—what are they, then? The emperor knew to honor Confucianism and nurture the aged, yet he also served Buddhism. Why? This is the common affliction of those like Lord Ye. The value of Confucianism does not lie in its chapters and verses, just as the power of a dragon does not lie in its claws and teeth. To seek the pursuits of the Two Emperors and Three Kings in the studies of the *Sanlao* and *Wugeng* is like expecting the divine transformations of a spirit from the sluggish movements of snakes, lizards, and worms. Yet this is not only the case with Confucianism. Buddhism speaks of emptiness, stillness, and extinction, of seeing one’s nature through the mind, of natural wisdom and enlightenment—what need has it for the transmission of the *Forty-Two Chapters*? Thus, the essence of the śramaṇa is no different from what Huan Rong studied, and both Confucianism and Buddhism have missed the mark.

Cui Shi was broadly learned and possessed great talent, mastering the exegesis of ancient and modern texts and the teachings of the Hundred Schools. From youth, he excelled in composition. While studying at the Imperial Academy, he stood alongside Ban Gu and Fu Yi in fame. He devoted himself to classical learning and had no leisure for official advancement. During the Yuanhe era, Emperor Suzong began to revive the ancient rites and tour the sacred mountains. Cui Shi presented his *Four Tours Eulogy* to extol the virtues of the Han, his words elegant and refined. The emperor, who had a refined taste for literature, sighed in admiration upon reading Cui Shi’s eulogy. He said to the Attendant-in-Ordinary Dou Xian, "Do you know of Cui Shi?" Dou Xian replied, "Ban Gu has often spoken of him to me, but I have not yet met him." The emperor said, "You cherish Ban Gu but overlook Cui Shi—this is like Lord Ye’s love of dragons." He then ordered, "Summon him for an audience." Cui Shi thus paid his respects to Dou Xian, who greeted him at the gate in his clogs, laughing as he said, "Tingbo, I have long wished to befriend you—why have you been so distant?" He then bowed and welcomed him as an honored guest.

The *Record* states: In observing Emperor Suzong’s discussion of these two men, it is clear that his judgment was not merely about their words and writings—it already foretold the differences in their lifelong fortunes and fates. Cui Shi had previously submitted dozens of memorials, directly pointing out strengths and weaknesses. Though Dou Xian could not tolerate this, Cui Shi kept his distance and preserved his integrity. As the saying goes, "When hunting deer without a guide, it is better not to pursue them at all"—his ability to avoid disaster was fitting. Ban Gu, however, did not instruct his sons, and most of them failed to follow the law. Even the historians grew weary and fearful, reluctant to record the truth. As the saying goes, "When wives and children are frivolous, the household loses its discipline"—how could his family not come to ruin?

Chen Zhong and Lei Yi, both from the same commandery, were close friends and studied the *Lu Spring and Autumn Annals* and the *Yan Family Spring and Autumn Annals* together. When the Grand Administrator Zhang Yun recommended Chen Zhong as a *xiaolian* [filial and incorrupt candidate], Chen yielded the honor to Lei Yi. Later, when Lei Yi was recommended as a *maocai* [exemplary talent], he likewise yielded to Chen Zhong. The Grand Administrator refused to accept this. Lei Yi then feigned madness. Later, both were recommended as *xiaolian* and appointed Gentlemen of the Imperial Secretariat. When Lei Yi took the blame for a colleague and was dismissed, Chen Zhong, seeing him depart, resigned on grounds of illness. Thus, their hometown coined the saying: "Even the firmness of glue and lacquer cannot compare to Lei and Chen."

The *Record* states: In observing the deeds of Chen and Lei, their full story is not detailed—history merely records its general outline. How distant and remote it seems!

Should every person yield virtue to another, with households mutually deferring, would not a flourishing custom arise in that age? Such was nearly the case with Wang Ji and Gong Yu, who rejoiced in each other’s promotion as if donning caps anew. Yet Zhu Bo and Xiao Yu could not match this. Ren Yannian, at twelve, studied in Chang’an, mastering the *Book of Poetry*, the *Book of Changes*, and the *Spring and Autumn Annals*. His fame spread through the Imperial Academy, where he was hailed as the "Divine Youth." In the first year of Gengshi, he was appointed Grand Administrator of Kuaiji at nineteen. Upon arrival, he governed with quietude and non-action, first dispatching an envoy to offer sacrifices at Yanling. At the time, the realm had just stabilized, roads remained blocked, and those who had fled to the south to escape chaos had not yet returned to the Central Plains. Kuaiji boasted many scholars. Ren, upon taking office, sought out men of lofty conduct—such as Dong Ziyi and Yan Ziling—and treated them with the courtesy due to teachers and friends.

There was a man named Longqiu Chang of Wu, who lived in reclusion in Taimo, resolved never to submit to humiliation. During Wang Mang’s reign, he was repeatedly summoned but refused to serve. An official suggested compelling him, but Ren said: "Master Longqiu embodies virtue and walks in righteousness, possessing the integrity of Yuan Xian and Boyi. Even if the Grand Administrator were to sweep his gate, it would risk dishonor. Summoning him is out of the question." Instead, he sent a functionary bearing a letter and gifts of medicine, with envoys traveling back and forth along the road. After a year, Longqiu Chang finally rode a donkey to the prefectural office, requesting to be enrolled as a recorder. Ren then appointed him as Libationer of the Advisory Bureau. Soon after, Longqiu fell ill and died. Ren attended his funeral in person and did not hold court for three days. Thus, the worthies and gentlemen of the commandery vied to come to him.

The *Record* states: History tells of Yan Ziling donning a sheepskin and altering his name to advance, yet judging by how Ren treated him, he had never truly fled. At the time, a great influx of scholars arrived, and Ren, though but a youth, inclined his heart to defer to the worthy. This may be called not losing the mean of uprightness. In the end, he moved Longqiu to respond, willing to be enrolled. Confucius said: "If a friend dies with no one to care for him, say: ‘Let me bury him.’" This may well describe Ren’s conduct.

Guan Ning of Beihai, in his youth, befriended Hua Xin and Li Yuan, studying abroad together. They all revered Chen Zhonggong. When the realm descended into chaos, they heard that Gongsun Du’s commands held sway beyond the sea and fled with Wang Lie and others to Liaodong. Du prepared lodgings to await them. Upon their arrival, their conversations touched only on the classics, never on worldly affairs. They built huts by the mountains and dug caves for dwellings. Many who crossed the sea to escape hardship joined them, and within months, a settlement arose. There, they lectured on the *Book of Poetry* and the *Book of Documents*, arranged ritual vessels, refined their bearing, and clarified rites and deference. None but scholars were admitted. Thus, Du came to esteem their worth, and the people were transformed by their virtue. Where they settled, wells were dug for communal use, and men and women jostled at the ropes. Guan Ning, troubled by this, bought many vessels and placed them by the well, allowing people to draw water without knowing who had provided them. When newcomers asked in surprise, they learned it was Ning’s doing. Thereafter, they reproached one another and ceased their quarrels. When a neighbor’s ox trampled fields, Ning led it to a frozen patch, fed it, and returned it to its owner, who was deeply ashamed, as if facing severe punishment. Courtesy and deference spread beyond the sea.

In the fourth year of Huangchu, an edict called for the recommendation of reclusive gentlemen of integrity. The Minister of Education, Hua Xin, nominated Guan Ning, and an edict appointed him Grand Master of Splendid Happiness, but he firmly declined. When Emperor Ming ascended the throne, Hua Xin became Grand Commandant and resigned his post to yield to Ning, who again pleaded illness and returned by sea. Upon his return, he sat on a single wooden couch for over fifty years, never stretching his legs. The couch’s surface, where his knees rested, wore through. Though he lived to eighty, his resolve never waned. He rested in a humble lane, ate simple fare, chanted and savored the *Book of Poetry* and the *Book of Documents*, and remained content. In hardship, he found a way; in peril, he stood firm. Through danger and risk, his integrity never wavered. His voice was like gold, his countenance like jade—his brilliance only grew with time. Measuring his life from beginning to end, it seems Heaven itself had blessed him.

The *Record* states: Confucius said: "Speak with loyalty and trust, act with earnestness and respect—even in the lands of the barbarians, one may go." Guan Ning purified himself and bathed in virtue. Amid chaos, he did not stray; facing governance, he did not bend. This may be called: when the state has the Dao, he did not alter his simplicity; when it lacked the Dao, he did not change even unto death. As for his relationship with Hua Xin, at first he would not share a mat, and in the end, they could not share a day’s conversation.

The *Records of the Three Kingdoms* state: Liu Bei met Xu Shu in Xinye. Xu turned to Bei and said: "Here there is one Zhuge Kongming, a hidden dragon. Would the General wish to see him?" Bei replied: "You may bring him here." Xu said: "This man may be visited, but he cannot be summoned. If the General wishes to see him, you should condescend to call on him." Bei said: "Very well." Thus, he personally went to Longzhong to visit Zhuge Liang, and only after three visits did he gain an audience.

The *Record* states: The *Hexagram* *Jian*’s top line reads: "Going brings hardship, coming brings greatness. It is auspicious to see the great man." At the time, imperial authority had shifted, and the Han’s mandate was about to fall—hardship had reached its extreme. Liu Bei rose amid peril, his resources exhausted, with no support. Had he not possessed a resolute and discerning talent, a great and capable assistant to aid him through danger and relieve his difficulties, how could he have emerged from hardship? Thus, the image speaks of great auspiciousness, and the oracle speaks of the benefit of seeing the great man. The three visits were not without reason. Yet while Xu Shu urged Bei, the means to restore the Liu clan had already been determined from the outset—how could this be mere coincidence?

The *Wenzhongzi* states: Wang Tong’s father, Long, transmitted the legacy of the former kings and taught over a thousand disciples. Once, he sang the *Ode on Felling Trees* and summoned Tong, saying: "From the Son of Heaven to the common people, none have succeeded without relying on friends." Thereupon, Tong set his heart on traveling the four quarters. He received the *Book of Documents* from Li Yu of Donghai, studied the *Book of Poetry* under Xia Diao of Kuaiji, inquired about the *Rites* from Guan Lang of Hebei, corrected the *Music* with Huo Ji of Beiping, and examined the *Book of Changes* with his clansman, Zhonghua. Filled with resolve, he harbored the ambition to aid the common people.

Journeying west to Chang’an, he met Emperor Wen of Sui and presented his *Twelve Strategies for Great Peace*, advocating the royal Dao and expounding on hegemonic statecraft. The emperor, however, could not employ them, so he returned to teach between the Yellow River and Mount Fen. There, he continued the *Book of Poetry* and *Book of Documents*, rectified the *Rites* and *Music*, revised the Six Classics, and elucidated the Dao of the *Book of Changes*. After nine years, his work was largely complete, and disciples came from afar to study under him.

Among them were Dong Chang of Henan, Yao Yi of Mount Tai, Du Yan of Jingzhao, Li Jing of Zhaojun, Cheng Yuan of Nanyang, Dou Wei of Fufeng, Xue Shou of Hebei, Jia Qiong of Zhongshan, Fang Xuanling of Qinghe, Wei Zheng of Julu, Wen Taiya of Taiyuan, and Chen Shutong of Yingchuan—all of whom deferred to him as their master. His paternal uncle, Wang Gui, remarked: "After prolonged chaos, a great sage must arise. None in our age are as steeped in ritual and music as our clan—who but you can revive this culture?"

Upon his death, his disciples deliberated, saying: "Was our teacher not a perfected being? Since Confucius, there has been none like him." Citing the *Book of Changes*—"Yellow skirts, supremely auspicious; culture resides within"—they posthumously styled him *Wenzhongzi*. They arranged mourning rites with hempen garments and observed a single day of mourning to send him off.

The record states: According to a letter from Wang Ji (Zigaozi) of Donggao to Minister Chen Shuda: "In the early Zhenguan era, Wang Ning, serving as Investigating Censor, impeached Hou Junji, implicating Grand Commandant Changsun. For this, he was punished. At the time, Du Yan was Censor-in-Chief and secretly memorialized that Ning’s forthright speech was unjustly condemned. Thereupon, Wuji bore a grudge against Yan, and the Wang brothers were all suppressed and left unappointed. When Shuda later compiled the *History of the Sui*, Yan’s account of the *Wenzhongzi* lineage was included. Yet, fearing the Grand Commandant’s power, Chen concealed it and did not publish it.

Later, Wei Zheng, while presenting a memorial, encountered the Grand Commandant and asked: 'Was Hou Junji’s case truly false? Then the Censor should be exonerated. If true, why doubt it?' Thereupon, the Grand Commandant’s resentment gradually eased. Subsequently, Junji was indeed executed.

Thus, Tong’s misfortune arose not from any grave fault, yet historical records omitted him—no surprise. Even when Zheng Qiao later compiled the *Comprehensive Records*, he followed the old accounts and did not write a biography for him. What purpose did this serve? Yet how precious is the work of a noble scholar, a blessing for the culture of a thousand ages!" The record concludes.

From the *Old唐书* "Biographies of Confucian Scholars": In the sixth year of the Zhenguan era, an edict was issued to honor Confucius as the Foremost Sage and Yan Hui as the Foremost Teacher. All venerable masters and elders of virtue across the land were summoned to serve as academicians. The emperor frequently visited to observe and partake in the offering of vegetables, commanding the Libationer and Erudites to expound upon the classics. Grain and silk were bestowed as gifts, and students who mastered a single classic were permitted to enter officialdom. Over 1,200 school buildings were constructed, with the student body reaching 3,200. Scholars from all directions, carrying scrolls and bearing satchels, gathered in the capital, and the governance of culture flourished. With robes billowing and hems trailing, order and decorum prevailed in every corner—such splendor had not been seen even in the golden ages of the Three Dynasties.

The record states: Since ancient times, the people have been nurtured by the Three Bonds, and all affairs are treated as one. Emperor Taizong may be said to have fulfilled his duties as sovereign and teacher without fail. Yet how could he have known that the Dao of the noble person is vast yet subtle? Externally, the states of Gaochang, Baekje, Silla, and Tubo sent their sons to study, while internally, within the palace chambers and behind the palace gates, there was no absence of shameful conduct. This is the greatness of Heaven and Earth, yet still, man harbors regrets. Thus, those who carry scrolls and bear satchels are surely not equal to the wonder of the soaring kite and leaping fish. Herein lies why the Tang did not match the Three Dynasties.

In the seventeenth year, protocols were established for the crown prince’s audience with his Three Mentors: he was to greet them outside the palace gates, bow first, and the Three Mentors would return the bow. At every gate, he was to yield precedence to them. Only after the Three Mentors were seated would the crown prince take his seat. In correspondence with them, he was to sign his name before and after with reverence. The record states: Emperor Taizong’s veneration of the Three Mentors may be called utmost. When Wang Gui was appointed tutor to Prince Wei, the emperor bowed first; when Fang Xuanling was made tutor to the crown prince, he again bowed first. These protocols were codified as permanent standards for his descendants to uphold. Yet why, in the span of a single step, did they vanish? What was the reason? The institution of the Three Mentors originated with the Duke of Zhou, who possessed the virtue of the Foremost Sage within and upheld the laws of Bo Qin without—thus was the Way of the teacher established. As for Li Ji, the emperor sought to tame him with the stratagem of "morning four, evening three," and he responded in kind with "morning three, evening four." In the mere exchange of bows and courtesies, the timing of rising and sitting, the pace of movement—it was no more than a staged performance. How could such a thing be esteemed? Not only could the humiliation of mentors occur in the blink of an eye, but the calamity of the Five Princes was also not far off.

This is the intent of this record. When Gao Shilian served as governor of Yizhou, he convened literary assemblies, commanding scholars to lecture on the classics and histories, exhorting and encouraging later generations—thus did the schools flourish once more. There was one Zhu Taochui, a recluse who refused office, drifting among the common folk. When Dou Gui was stationed in Yizhou, he heard of him and summoned him for an audience, presenting him with robes and silks, and pressing him to serve as village chief. Taochui remained utterly silent, cast the garments to the ground, and fled into the mountains. In summer, he concealed his form; in winter, he covered himself with tree bark. He accepted no gifts whatsoever. Often, he would leave worn sandals by the roadside, and those who saw them would say, "These are the sandals of the recluse." They would leave rice for him in the same spot, and Taochui would take it at dusk, never allowing himself to be seen. Commentators likened him to Jiao Guang.

When Shilian arrived in his post, he extended an invitation with full ceremonial courtesy. Upon Taochui’s arrival, Shilian descended the steps to speak with him and instructed his officials to pay him regular visits. Given that in recent times many had treated recluses with disdain, Shilian alone bestowed upon him honors and rites, becoming a subject of praise throughout Shu. The record states: Shu retains the customs of the Man and Yi; it was not only Wen Weng alone, nor the single case of Junping, to whom this may be compared. Yet if one wishes to transform the stubborn and strengthen the weak, unless one attends with utmost care to the most lowly, one cannot stir their currents; unless one embraces the humility of the noblest, one cannot manifest their transformation. Thus, the bestowal of honors upon a humble scholar cannot but become a subject of praise.

During the Huichang era, Bai Letian resided in Luoyang, where he, along with Hu Ji, Liu, Zheng, Lu, and Zhang—six men of advanced age—held gatherings in the Lüdao Ward of the Eastern Capital to honor seniority. Two elders, Li Yuanshuang and the monk Ruman, also joined these assemblies, where they inscribed their names in verse, exchanged compositions, and had their likenesses painted as a cherished affair.

By the Song dynasty, She Qigong, along with Wang Huan of Taiyuan, Bi Shichang of Hezhong, Zhu Guan of Peiguo, and Feng Pingxian of Shiping—all having retired in their old age—formed the "Assembly of the Five Elders of Suiyang." They composed poems in response to one another, delighting in harmonious fellowship, and commissioned paintings to commemorate their grandeur.

During the Yuanfeng era, Di Gong Wen Yanbo, though possessing boundless wealth and the highest rank, conducted himself with humility in daily life, revering virtue and delighting in goodness as if he could never do enough. Scholars such as Shao Yong, Cheng Hao, and Cheng Yi, who esteemed the Dao above all, were received by him as equals among commoners. At that time, the wealthy Han Gong, having retired from his position as Minister over the Masses, gathered the aged and virtuous among Luoyang’s ministers and grandees to form the "Assembly of the Venerable and Eminent." Valuing seniority over official rank, they constructed a grand hall at Zisheng Monastery called the "Hall of the Venerable and Eminent," where their portraits were displayed. Wang Gongchen, the Military Commissioner stationed in the Northern Capital, sent a letter to Di Gong expressing his desire to join the assembly. Though Master Wen was not yet seventy, Di Gong, who held him in great esteem, invited him to participate, bringing the total to thirteen members.

Luoyang abounded with renowned gardens and ancient monasteries, graced with waters, bamboo groves, and pavilions. The elders, their brows and beards snowy white, dressed in stately robes, gathered for feasts that drew crowds of onlookers from the city. Di Gong also established the "Assembly of Shared Birth Year," including Sima Langzhong Dan, Cheng Dazhong, Xiang Xi, and Minister over the Masses Ru Yan—all born in the year *bingwu*—and had their portraits painted at Zisheng Monastery. Master Wen further initiated the "Assembly of Unaffected Sincerity." All these were flourishing affairs of Luoyang in times of peace.

The gentry and commoners erected a shrine to Di Gong at Zisheng Monastery, inscribing on its plaque a poem sent by Emperor Shenzong upon Di Gong’s appointment as Prefect of Henan, naming the hall "Hall of Earth’s Reverence." Within it stood a statue of Di Gong, imposing in cap and sword, which the people of the city revered with solemnity.

The record states: Luoyang, the center of the realm, has witnessed customs of hares startled and deer intoxicated—how many such scenes has it beheld? These elders were the vital *qi* of the state and the models of peace. Even Boyi and the Grand Duke cannot claim exclusive glory from antiquity. Thus, it is recorded.

**The Record of Illustrious Ministers of the Song Dynasty** states: When Yang Shi heard that the Cheng brothers—Cheng Hao and Cheng Yi—were expounding the lost learning of Confucius and Mencius in the region of the Yellow and Luo Rivers, he declined official appointments to travel instead to Yingchang, where he paid homage to Cheng Hao as his teacher. Their meeting was one of profound joy. As Yang Shi took his leave, Cheng Hao watched him depart and remarked, *"My Dao now flows south."* After Cheng Hao’s death, Yang Shi became a disciple of Cheng Yi

Though he repeatedly failed the imperial examinations and was about to abandon all thought of official advancement, ceasing to sit for them, it so happened that Chen Xuan of Tiantai was overseeing education in the southern capital. Recognizing him as no ordinary bird, Chen ordered the authorities to dispatch him to the capital examinations with all due courtesy. There he placed third in the provincial examination, first in the metropolitan examination, and upon entering the palace examination, emerged as *zhuangyuan* and first-ranking graduate.

Earlier, having entered the Imperial Academy by way of tribute, he was seen by Zhang Rubi of Donghai, who exclaimed, *"Can there truly be such a tribute scholar in the world?"* Bian Huabo of Jiangyin likewise composed the line, *"I bow my head in homage to Shu Ye."* Xu Wugong, a man of lofty and unyielding character who seldom praised others, humbled himself to befriend him, declaring, *"He is a vessel for the Hanlin Academy."* Once installed in the Academy, every composition he produced was immediately disseminated throughout the realm, and as his rank rose, so too did his reputation. Scholars honored him as Master Pao’an.

The record states: Ritual is that which *arises*; to arise is to be inspired and set in motion. For a time, Master Wen Ding lingered long in obscurity, yet once he was provided with the resources of a man of the Dao to be dispatched beyond the ordinary, it was as one in ten thousand. Thus did he suddenly rise, his talents and bearing towering above all. And given such extraordinary circumstances, can ritual toward the scholar ever be deemed insignificant? Can it ever be deemed insignificant?

Chen Zhenchen, a commoner of Longxi in Zhangzhou, hailed originally from the seacoast. His frame was tall and imposing, his spirit solemn and pure; at first glance, one knew him not to be a man of the dusty world. By seventeen or eighteen, he had already extricated himself from the vulgar crowd, devoting himself wholeheartedly to the Confucian calling. Once his studies were complete, he awaited recommendation to the authorities.

Upon arriving in Fuzhou, the Fujian authorities enforced their inspections with excessive strictness, offering no courtesy befitting a scholar. Thus, he took his leave and returned home. From that time forth, he no longer concerned himself with the imperial examinations, instead devoting himself to the practice of the learning of the sages and worthies.

He journeyed to Jiangxi to seek instruction from Zhang Yuanzhen, who praised him highly, saying: “Zhen dares to presume that this is precisely what I mean.” He declared, “Since the time of Cheng and Zhu, only you, sir, have grasped their true essence. Even Wu [Cheng] and Xu [Heng] fell short of this.” Thereupon, Chen returned home.

Though Putian in Minhai was home to many Confucian families, it was only with this commoner that the purity of scholarship began to flourish. Together with his fellow townsman Li Wenju and other elders, he expounded and practiced the Family Rituals of Master Wen [Zhu Xi], and thus the local customs were rectified. This legacy endures to this day.

The record states: Li Wenyu’s act of escorting his teacher was how a disciple honored his master. Wu Wending’s provision of resources for his student was how a master elevated his disciple. As for Chen Shengfu’s pursuit of what was good, though neither master nor disciple, it was how he conducted himself. These three are all indispensable aspects of the rites of friendship, and thus the account concludes here.

*Hongdao lu*, Scroll 36, ends.
*Hongdao lu*, Scroll 37: "Wisdom"

**The Wisdom of Rulers and Ministers**

From the *Family Sayings of Confucius*: Confucius praised Yao, saying, "His wisdom was like that of the spirits." The record states: The *Appended Judgments* says, "Refine it to the point of spirit-like clarity." All affairs and all things emerge from Heaven. If they emerge from Heaven, they are unseen when looked upon and unheard when listened to. Principle has no form, and thus cannot be called spirit-like. Yet when all principles are possessed and all affairs are governed, this depends on man. If it depends on man, doubts may be articulated, comparisons may be made, and the mind may awaken—this is what makes it spirit-like, not some obscure and inscrutable ghostly spirit.

From the *Doctrine of the Mean*: The Master said, "Shun—was he not a man of great wisdom? Shun loved to ask questions and loved to examine the words of those near at hand. He concealed what was evil and proclaimed what was good. He grasped the two extremes and employed the mean among the people—this is what made Shun, Shun." The record states: Yao’s wisdom was called "like that of the spirits," for its application was unfathomable. Shun’s wisdom was called "employing the mean," for what resided in his heart was neither excessive nor deficient.

Yet if one stubbornly clings to one’s own views, forcing others to comply with what is difficult to follow, this cannot be called "employing the mean." If one startles the ear with sensational claims, presenting others with what is difficult to attain, this cannot be called "near at hand." If one rejects remonstrance and adorns wrongdoing, taking cunning for clarity, this cannot be called "loving to ask questions." If one is indecisive and fails to distinguish slander from flattery, this cannot be called "grasping the two extremes." If loyal and sincere words are branded as slander, and profound calculations are dismissed as ominous speech, how can one conceal evil and proclaim good? These are all flaws in wisdom, arising from excess or deficiency. Thus the sage does not follow such paths.

Mencius said, "The wise know all things, but what is urgent is their primary concern." The wisdom of Yao and Shun did not neglect even the smallest matters, for they prioritized what was most pressing. To be unable to govern for three years yet obsess over scrutinizing minor tasks, or to eat hastily and gulp down one’s food while inquiring about trivialities—this is what is called "not knowing what is urgent." The record states: Those who are despised for not knowing what is urgent are like Emperor Dezong of Tang, who was suspicious and harsh, priding himself on his stern clarity, yet was deceived by Lu Qi and Zhao Zan. How, then, can one properly examine things?

The laws of the Yu court were all in place, and the means by which they were taught were: straightforward yet gentle, lenient yet firm, resolute yet not oppressive, simple yet not arrogant. The means by which they were examined were: lenient yet firm, yielding yet steadfast, sincere yet reverent, disorderly yet respectful, compliant yet resolute, upright yet gentle, simple yet peaceful, strong yet restrained, forceful yet righteous. Above all, one must be especially cautious of clever speech and insinuating appearances. Then, even if there were a hundred Yi and Zans, where could they find room to operate? This is why the Four Fiends could not endanger Shun, yet a single Yi was enough to throw Tang into chaos. Mencius’s words are urgent and must not be overlooked.

Mencius also said, "What is despised in the wise is their tendency to overcomplicate." If the wise were like Yu in channeling the waters, then there would be nothing to despise in wisdom. Yu channeled the waters by following their natural course. If the wise likewise followed the natural course, then their wisdom would be great indeed. The record states: Yu’s wisdom was what Gun called "unwise." The Way of father and son is rooted in human nature—one followed his nature and brought benefit, while the other forced his way and brought harm. Those who have not yet attained sageliness must take heed!

Today, those who overcomplicate things are not limited to Gun. Some are harshly scrutinizing yet self-satisfied, some are rigid yet self-righteous, some are impetuous and self-reliant, some are stingy and self-indulgent, some are opportunistic and self-aggrandizing—how could this be just one flaw? Mencius’s teaching of "following the natural course" is profoundly beneficial to the world’s moral order; it cannot be dismissed as a minor matter of channeling water.

When King Tang exiled Jie to Nanchao, he had only a moment of virtue, saying, "I fear that later generations will use me as a precedent." Zhong Hui then composed an announcement, saying: "Alas! Heaven gives birth to the people with desires, and without a ruler, they fall into chaos. Heaven, in its enduring wisdom, saw the Xia dynasty’s dark virtue and the people sinking into suffering. Thus, it bestowed upon the king courage and wisdom to rectify the myriad states." The record states: Why was Tang called courageous and wise? The abdication of Yao was achieved through culture, while the revolution of Tang was achieved through force. Yet without an inner endowment of resolute clarity, how could one know that in a single day’s inquiry, the Mandate of Heaven had already been severed, and thus truly respond to the will of Heaven above and the will of the people below?

Yet Tang still said, "Alas!" and spoke of "trust," for he feared that later generations would use him as a precedent. In truth, the people’s hearts were joyful. Even without divination confirming trust, he still spoke of "revolution." The phrase "three submissions" was Zhong Hui’s way of dispelling Tang’s doubts. Otherwise, even if one sighed and wept like Wang Mang, who presented the *Golden Coffer* to declare his innocence before the ancestral temple, or issued decrees like Cao Cao, who proclaimed his own virtue, yet remained unaware that others saw into his very heart and lungs—what good would it do? What good would it do?

Mencius was asked by Wan Zhang, "Is it true that Baili Xi confined himself in Qin as a keeper of sacrificial animals, herded cattle in exchange for five sheep skins, and thus ingratiated himself with Duke Mu of Qin?"

Mencius replied, "No. That is not so. It is the fabrication of meddlers. Baili Xi was a man of Yu. The people of Jin, offering the jade of Chuiji and the horses of Quchan, borrowed the road from Yu to attack Guo. Though Gong Zhiqi admonished the ruler, Baili Xi did not, knowing that the lord of Yu could not be admonished. He left for Qin, already seventy years of age. Had he truly been unaware that serving Duke Mu of Qin by herding cattle would be demeaning, could he be called wise? Yet if he knew the lord of Yu could not be admonished and still did not admonish him, could that be called unwise? Knowing that the lord of Yu was doomed and leaving beforehand—could that be called unwise? When he was later employed in Qin, recognizing that Duke Mu was one with whom he could act, and thus serving as his minister—could that be called unwise? By serving Qin and making his lord renowned throughout the world, leaving a legacy for later generations, could an unworthy man have achieved this? To humble oneself to advance one’s lord—would a man of integrity in his village do such a thing? Could a worthy man have done so?"

It is recorded: What is called wisdom is the ability to comprehend principles and move through affairs without obstruction. Yet while benevolence can be cultivated through effort, wisdom cannot be forced. Since the end of the Three Dynasties, those who discuss historical figures have been unable to adhere purely to heavenly principle, and thus men like Baili Xi, Guan Zhong, and Yanzi are still recorded. Observing the discussions of the "Four Wisdoms" and "Two Worthies," one understands that the earnestness of those who debated them was not without reason. Let the reader examine this carefully.

In the *Guoyu*, when Duke Huan appointed Bao Shu as minister, Bao Shu declined, saying, "Your Grace has shown me kindness, ensuring I do not suffer cold or hunger—this is your grace. But if you wish me to govern the state, that is beyond my ability. Only Guan Yiwu is fit for this." He continued, "There are five ways in which I am inferior to Yiwu: in being generous and kind to the people, I am not his equal; in governing the state without losing hold of its authority, I am not his equal; in loyalty and trustworthiness that bind the people, I am not his equal; in establishing rites and righteousness that serve as models for the realm, I am not his equal; in standing at the military gate with drum in hand, inspiring the people to greater courage, I am not his equal."

Duke Huan said, "Yet Guan Zhong once shot me, striking my belt buckle, nearly killing me." Bao Shu replied, "He did so out of devotion to his former lord. If you pardon and restore him, he will serve you just the same." Duke Huan sent envoys to request Guan Zhong from Lu. By the time he arrived, the duke had him purified three times and bathed three times. Duke Huan personally welcomed him at the outskirts and entrusted him with governance.

It is recorded in the *Xugua*: "Things cannot remain in decline forever, thus they are followed by *Tongren* (Fellowship)." The *Commentary* states: "When Heaven and Earth do not interact, it is called *Pi* (Obstruction); when above and below are in harmony, it is called *Tong* (Fellowship)." When the world is in decline, one must join forces with others to overcome it. After Duke Huan had reached the depths of decline, he suddenly rose, seeking to subdue the world through wisdom and strength. Had he not found a man of foresight and shared purpose, how could he have been persuaded to trust? Bao Shu’s recommendation of the worthy and yielding to the capable was free of favoritism; Duke Huan’s acceptance of remonstrance and heeding of advice demonstrated his resolute clarity. The prosperity of Qi arose from this.

Duke Huan sat with Guan Zhong and asked, "In the past, our former rulers built lofty palaces, indulged in hunting and archery, neglected state affairs, belittled the wise, and disdained scholars, while exalting women. The warriors suffered cold and hunger, the war chariots awaited the entertainers, laughter and jesting filled the court, while the worthy were relegated to the rear. Thus, the state did not progress day by day or month by month. What should be done about this?"

Guan Zhong replied, "In former times, our former kings, King Zhao and King Mu, followed the laws of Wen and Wu. They achieved distant merits and established fame, uniting the lords and comparing the people’s resources. They set up models to guide the people, balancing authority with reciprocity, linking and measuring with standards. They traced the root to the branch, encouraging with rewards and punishments, correcting with penalties, and ordering the people by age and rank to serve as the state’s guiding principles."

The duke asked, "How should this be done?"

Guan Zhong replied, "In ancient times, the sage kings governed the world by dividing the capital into three parts and the outskirts into five, settling the people’s dwellings, and establishing their occupations, while carefully employing the six handles of governance."

It is recorded in the *Xugua*: "When people unite, things naturally gather. Thus, it is followed by *Dayou* (Great Possession)." The hexagram depicts fire above heaven, its light reaching far, illuminating all things. This was the moment when Duke Huan and Guan Zhong sat and discoursed on the Dao.

The duke asked, "How should the people’s occupations be established?"

Guan Zhong replied, "The four classes of people should not be allowed to mix. In ancient times, the sage kings settled the scholars so that when they gathered for leisure, fathers spoke to fathers of righteousness, sons to sons of filial piety, those who served the ruler spoke of reverence, and the young spoke of brotherly respect. From youth, they grew accustomed to these ways, their hearts at ease, not swayed by foreign influences. Thus, the teachings of their fathers and elders were effortlessly fulfilled, and the learning of their sons and younger brothers required no labor. Now, as for the artisans, they should be settled near government offices, where they examine the four seasons, distinguish their tasks, regulate their use, compare and coordinate materials, and work from dawn to dusk, applying their skills across the land. They instruct their children, discussing their work, demonstrating their craft, and presenting their achievements. As for the merchants, they should be settled near marketplaces, where they observe the four seasons, assess their region’s resources, and understand market prices. They carry loads on their shoulders or heads, drive oxen and harness horses to travel the four directions, exchanging what they have for what they lack, buying cheap and selling dear. From dawn to dusk, they engage in this, instructing their children, discussing profit, demonstrating gains, and sharing knowledge. As for the farmers, they should be settled in the fields, where they observe the four seasons, regulate their use, prepare for cold and heat, clear the land to await the proper time, plow deeply and harrow diligently, awaiting the seasonal rains. When the rains come, they take up their spears, sickles, and binding ropes, working from dawn to dusk in the fields."

These three occupations, when practiced from youth, settle the heart, and those who follow them do not waver upon seeing other things. Thus, the teachings of fathers and elder brothers succeed without sternness; the learning of sons and younger brothers is effortless. The finest among the people, when they become scholars, will surely be reliable. Duke Huan said: "Excellent."

A record states: This is an unchanging, settled principle—how could it apply only to one state? Every person and every household is no different. When those above lose the Dao, the people lose their sense of duty. Scholars indulge in idle wandering, farmers are drawn to secondary crafts, the court no longer trusts the Way, artisans no longer follow standards, the noble violate righteousness, and the common people break the law. That the state does not perish is mere luck. This is why Zhong’s concerns run deep.

The Duke said: "How should we settle the people’s dwellings?"
He replied: "Divide the state into twenty-one districts: six for artisans and merchants, and fifteen for scholars. You, my lord, will lead five districts, the crown prince five, and Gaozi five. The state’s three divisions will establish offices, I will appoint three stewards, you will establish three clans, the market will have three districts, the marshes three wardens, and the mountains three overseers."

A record states: This is how Lu established its three armies. The wise must simply observe well.

The Duke said: "I wish to engage with the feudal lords—is this possible?"
He replied: "Not yet. The state is not secure. Restore the old laws, select the best and put them into practice, nurture the people and those without wealth, and respect the common folk—then the state will be secure."
The Duke said: "Now that the state is secure, may I proceed?"
He replied: "Not yet. If you properly organize the troops and repair the armor and weapons, the great states will do the same. If you possess the tools of attack, the smaller feudal lords will prepare defenses, making it difficult to swiftly achieve your ambitions. If you wish to quickly prevail over the feudal lords, then your affairs must be concealed. Implement domestic governance and embed military commands within it."

The Duke said: "Excellent."
Thereupon, the state was organized: five households formed a *gui*, with a leader appointed. Ten *gui* formed a *li*, with an overseer. Four *li* formed a *lian*, with a leader. Ten *lian* formed a *xiang*, with a *liangren* to enforce military commands. Five households formed a *gui*, so five men made a squad, led by the *gui* leader. Ten *gui* formed a *li*, so fifty men made a small unit, led by the *li* overseer. Four *li* formed a *lian*, so two hundred men made a company, led by the *lian* leader. Ten *lian* formed a *xiang*, so two thousand men made a brigade, led by the *xiang* leader. Five *xiang* formed a command, so ten thousand men made an army, led by the leaders of the five *xiang*. In spring, they assembled to review the troops; in autumn, they drilled and trained. Thus, squads were organized within the *li*, and armies were arrayed beyond the suburbs. Once domestic training was complete, no one was allowed to relocate. Within a squad, members shared blessings in sacrifices, supported one another in death and mourning, and bore misfortunes together. People lived alongside one another for generations, grew up together, and thus in night battles, their voices could be heard, ensuring no separation; in daytime battles, they recognized one another by sight. Their mutual trust was such that they would die for one another. Thus, in defense, they were unshakably solid; in attack, they were unyieldingly strong. With thirty thousand such soldiers, you could march across the world, punish the lawless, and shield the Zhou court. No ruler of a great state could resist you.

A record states: This is domestic governance with embedded military commands. Yet in Zhong’s design, outwardly it appears as deception, while inwardly it is a desperate bid for strength. His tireless efforts were all for the sake of achieving his ambitions. A noble person would not follow such a path. However, the former kings’ method of uniting the people and embedding military training within agriculture largely resembled this. Alas! Qi was but one state, and Zhong but one man. With thirty thousand soldiers, he could rampage across the world, punish the lawless, shield the royal house, and none could resist. How much more so for the majestic realm as a whole? This is something we cannot fail to ponder deeply.

The Duke said: "I wish to engage with the feudal lords—is this possible?"
He replied: "Not yet. The neighboring states are not yet close to us. If you wish to engage with the feudal lords, first befriend the neighboring states. Examine our borders and return any encroached land. Do not accept their resources, but instead offer them generous gifts. Humble yourself before the feudal lords, and they will say, ‘Our neighbors are close to us.’ When the four neighbors are all close, secure the borders and strengthen the land. To the south, reach the Yin of Tao; to the west, the west of the Ji River; to the north, the Yellow River; to the east, Ji. Qi will have eight hundred war chariots. Select the most profligate and disorderly among the feudal lords and attack them first." Within a few years of his reign, he conquered Lai and Ju, the Xu Yi and Hao Yue, and in a single campaign, brought thirty-one states to submission.

A record states: Mencius said, "Those who subdue others by force do not win their hearts; their strength is insufficient." Thus, when we observe how he pleased the ruler’s heart, even the smallest details were illuminated, revealing his abundant wisdom. Yet when we examine his shifting, treacherous intentions and the foundations of his ambitions, we see that his magnanimity was lacking. Should a noble person not cultivate the great wisdom of emperors and kings, rectify himself, and order all things?

From the *Zuozhuan*: Duke Jing of Qi was hunting at Pei. Upon his return, Yanzi attended him at Yitai, when Liang Qiuju arrived in haste. The Duke said, "Only Ju is in harmony with me." Yanzi replied, "Ju merely agrees—how can that be harmony?" The Duke said, "Are harmony and agreement different?" He replied, "They are. Harmony is like a stew: the flavors are blended, excesses are tempered, and deficiencies are supplemented. A noble person eats it to calm his heart. The relationship between ruler and minister is the same. When the ruler deems something acceptable but it has flaws, the minister points out the flaws to perfect the acceptable. When the ruler deems something unacceptable but it has merits, the minister presents the merits to eliminate the unacceptable. Thus, governance is balanced and unobstructed, and the people have no contentious hearts."

Thus it is said: there is also the harmonious stew. Once prepared and balanced, it is offered in silent reverence, and in that moment, no contention arises.

Yet Ju does not act thus. When the ruler deems something acceptable, Ju also says it is acceptable; when the ruler deems something unacceptable, Ju also says it is unacceptable. This is like adding water to water—who could consume it? Such is the unacceptability of mere agreement.

It is recorded: Confucius said, "The noble person harmonizes yet does not agree; the petty person agrees yet does not harmonize." Harmony and agreement are precisely opposite, and therein lies the division between public duty and private interest.

For agreement, profit and harm are not distinguished, right and wrong are not discerned; one merely follows the superior’s words without contradiction. Thus, such words may be heard, and what is heard may be accepted. But harmony seeks only not to contravene principle, not to avoid contradicting words. Who can avoid straying from the Dao? Yet one cannot stray from forthrightness, nor will one flatter or blindly comply to entrap the ruler in wrongdoing. Thus, such words may not always be heard, and what is heard may not always be accepted.

In essence, to advance without obsequious compliance and to retreat without slanderous speech—this is harmony. To follow or oppose based on profit and harm, to advance or retreat based on gain and loss—this is agreement.

The *Book of Changes* says: "A deviation of a hair’s breadth leads to an error of a thousand miles." Those who stand above others—can they afford not to examine this?

Duke Jing wished to relocate Yanzi’s residence, saying, "Your dwelling is near the market—cramped, noisy, and dusty, unfit for habitation. Allow me to move you to a more open and pleasant location."

Yanzi declined, saying, "Your lordship’s former ministers dwelled here. I am unworthy to succeed them—such a move would be excessive for me."

Moreover, for a petty man to live near the market is advantageous, for he may obtain what he seeks morning and evening—this is to his benefit. How could I trouble the neighbors?

The Duke laughed and said, "Since you live near the market, do you know what is dear and what is cheap?"

Yanzi replied, "Since it is to my advantage, how could I not know?"

The Duke asked, "What is dear and what is cheap?"

At that time, Duke Jing had become excessive in his use of punishments. There were those who had undergone foot amputation, so Yanzi answered, "Prosthetic feet are dear, while shoes are cheap."

Thereupon, Duke Jing reduced his use of punishments.

Later, when Yanzi was in Jin, the Duke had already rebuilt his residence. After bowing in gratitude, Yanzi had it demolished and reconstructed as a neighborhood hall, restoring it to its former state before allowing the original residents to return. He said, "It is not the dwelling that is divined, but the neighbors. You, gentlemen, have already divined your neighbors—going against divination is inauspicious. A noble man does not transgress against ritual propriety; how could I dare to do so?"

In the end, he returned to his old residence. The Duke did not consent, but after Yanzi presented his request through Chen Huanzi, he was permitted.

The record states: How wise was Yanzi Zhong! First, he declined the sixty villages offered by Qing of the Tian clan; second, in his conversation with Ji Zha, he declined both fief and governance; third, he declined the new residence and ultimately returned to his old one.

Those who know not how to preserve themselves—though they may now dazzle with splendor and bask in illicit favor, how can they be certain that one day they will not be overthrown and utterly condemned by public judgment? Thus it is said: "Not that wealth is detested, but that its loss is feared."

Amidst Qi’s many calamities, with the Cui and Qing clans’ uprisings preceding and the Le and Bao clans’ following, Yan alone stood firm in his court robes, unshaken. His virtue lay in yielding. Therefore, profit cannot be forced; reflection on righteousness is superior, for hoarded gain breeds disaster. Let the noble man be ever vigilant.

During a famine in Lu, Zang Wenzhong said to Duke Huan: "The state is afflicted. Why not use our ritual vessels to request grain from Qi?" The Duke asked, "Whom shall we send?" Wenzhong replied, "When the state suffers famine, ministers go forth to seek grain—this is an ancient institution. Chen is prepared; let him go as envoy to Qi." The Duke sent him.

His attendants said, "The ruler did not command this request—will it not appear presumptuous?" Wenzhong replied, "The worthy hasten to relieve distress and yield to the secure. An official in office must not shirk duty. I do not surpass Qi in virtue; this is no fault of the heart. To hold high office without caring for the people below, to serve as an official yet grow indolent—this is no way to serve a lord." Thereupon, he took a jade tablet and chime-stones to Qi. The Qi people returned the jade but granted the grain.

The record states: At the Kuiqiu assembly, it was decreed: "Do not block the sale of grain." To block grain was a warning of the Five Hegemons. Yet here was Wenzhong’s request, and Qi’s compliance. Why, then, in this age, is it otherwise? Even the distant Hu and Yue are as one household; how can the Qin regard the plight of the Chu with such indifference? Moreover, beneath all heaven, none is not the king’s land; within the bounds of the realm, none is not the king’s subject. Why, then, bar the sale of grain?

Ever-normal granaries and community granaries have long been established. "Three years of tilling, nine years of storing"—such foresight is distant indeed. Yet the ever-ready granary is now a pressing concern. If recruiting the people yields no solution, and state grain purchases are not yet perfected, forced loans become a last resort. Yet once corruption and penalties are imposed, how can the people’s needs be fully met? If they could freely exchange surplus and deficit, why should officials wield authority to intervene?

Consider a single prefecture or commandery: its produce is limited, sourced from its own soil, not imported from afar—this might suffice. Yet on the four thoroughfares of commerce, even in years of plenty, people rely on trade. Block but one route, and rumors spread from all directions. Markets then impose restrictions, the common folk spread falsehoods, travelers are deterred, residents hoard, and how can prices not soar? Only without obstruction will people pursue profit, undeterred by distance or summons, coming freely from afar. Though the people’s hearts are simple, they are wondrously attuned—prices rise and fall in unspoken accord.

Moreover, those whose grain we can obtain are but a fraction of those en route, while most remain unharvested. The people’s reliance on grain extends beyond those already in transit—those yet to set out are far more numerous. Has this not been considered? This is why relocating people and grain has its limits, and those who claim to have done their utmost have not truly succeeded.

Zang Wuzhong was renowned for his wisdom, called a sage in his time. When Lin Shuqi fled to Lu with his followers, claiming fame for his lacquerware, Ji Wuzi gave him a wife from the duke’s family and bestowed gifts upon his retinue. Soon after, Lu suffered a surge in banditry.

Wuzi said to He, "Why not interrogate the bandits?" Wuzi replied, "They cannot be interrogated," and He could not do so either. Jisun said, "I have four borders—why can I not interrogate the bandits within them? As Minister of Justice, you must prioritize their eradication. How can you say you cannot?" Wuzhong replied, "You welcome foreign bandits with great ceremony—how can you stop our own? As chief minister, you bring in outside bandits, then task He with expelling them. How can he succeed? Shuqi stole a city to come here, yet you wed him to a lady of the Ji clan and granted him a city, rewarding his followers. This is rewarding banditry. To reward and then expel them—will this not prove difficult? I have heard that those in high office must purify their hearts, treat all with consistency, and act with integrity before governing others.

The people follow the example of their superiors. If the people do what their superiors do not, punishments are applied, and none dare disobey. But if the people do what their superiors do, it becomes their norm—how can it be forbidden?"

The record states: The Master once told Jisun, "If you yourself do not desire it, though you reward them, they will not steal." His words align perfectly with He’s. Who would say Wuzhong’s wisdom was slight?

After Duke Xuan’s command to accept the fleeing servant from Ju, Ji Sun rewarded Shuqi; after Duke Huan’s acceptance of the He-ding cauldron, Yang Hu stole the state’s jade treasures. The proof of inciting banditry is as unerring as shadow following form, echo answering sound. Can one not strive to purify one’s heart?

With He’s wisdom, he could have refuted Jisun’s argument about foreign bandits, and none would not have respected and believed him. Yet how could private favoritism be sacrificed for it? Though he followed orders in armor, he was praised; though he breached gates and broke locks, he was slandered.
