He spoke justly, yet Su bore a grudge, and his words brought disaster—how far did it go!

When Duke Mu of Qin escorted the Jin prince across the Yellow River, Jiu Fan presented a jade to the prince, saying: "I have followed you through the world, bound like an ox or horse, and my crimes are many. Let me take my leave here." The prince replied, "If I do not share your heart, let it be as this river." He cast the jade into the river and entered Quwo, becoming Duke Wen. In Duke Wen’s first year, the royal house fell into chaos, and King Xiang fled to Zheng. Duke Mu of Qin stationed troops by the river, preparing to restore the king. Fan said to Duke Wen: "To win the allegiance of the feudal lords, nothing surpasses aiding the king."

The feudal lords trusted him, for it was a matter of great righteousness. The duke agreed, so he declined Qin’s forces and advanced, encamping at Yangfan. His right army besieged Wen, while his left army welcomed the king, escorting King Xiang into Zhou. He seized the king’s younger brother, Shu Dai, at Wen and executed him.

*Recorded:* The *Xugua* of the *Gu* hexagram states: "One who follows others with joy will surely encounter affairs." Thus, it is followed by the *Gu* hexagram. For one who delights in following others, affairs are certain to arise. Without affairs, what joy would there be to follow? Therefore, presenting the jade and requesting departure—how could it have been avoided? The case of Jie Zitui may serve as a mirror.

The *Xiang* further states: "*Gu* is fundamentally pervasive, and all under heaven is governed." At the outset of governing *gu*, if one can ensure that the noble and base, high and low, halt in order and settle in peace, what affair cannot be governed, what achievement cannot be accomplished? Thus, to win the allegiance of the feudal lords, nothing surpasses aiding the king—how could there be no proof? The affair of Marquis Wen’s vengeance may serve as a model.

It further states: "Beneficial to ford the great river, for going forth entails affairs." Could this not refer to the exiled prince’s Jiu Fan?

The ruler of Chu and the feudal lords besieged Song. Gongsun Gu went to Jin to report the crisis. Xian Zhen said: "To repay kindness, rescue distress, seize prestige, and establish hegemony—here lies the opportunity." Hu Yan said: "Chu has just gained Cao and newly allied with Wei through marriage. If we attack Cao and Wei, Chu will surely come to their aid, and Qi and Song will be relieved."

Thereupon, they mustered at Bi Lu, established the Three Armies, and deliberated on a commander-in-chief. The lord of Jin, having just entered the state, had instructed his people. In the second year, he wished to employ them. Zifan said: "The people do not yet know righteousness, nor are they settled in their dwellings." Thus, he went forth to secure King Xiang and entered to devote himself to benefiting the people. The people cherished life.

When he was about to employ them, Zifan said: "The people do not yet know trust, nor have they been made aware of their use." Thus, he attacked Yuan to demonstrate trust. The people, though their resources were meager, did not seek abundance, clearly verifying his words.

The duke said: "Is it sufficient now?"
The people did not yet know ritual, nor had they cultivated reverence.

Thus, he performed the great *gui* sacrifice to demonstrate ritual, and established the *Zhizhi* to rectify their offices. Only when the people’s understanding was no longer confused did he employ them. He sent forth troops to relieve the siege of Song at Gu. In a single battle, he established hegemony—such was the fruit of Duke Wen’s instruction.

It is recorded: Confucius said, “When those above esteem ritual, none among the people dare fail in reverence. When those above esteem righteousness, none among the people dare fail in obedience. When those above esteem trust, none among the people dare withhold their service.” Though Jin was but a hegemonic state, Heaven’s intent favored its rise, yet it still relied upon these precedents. This is what is meant.

Duke Wen asked Zhao Cui about a commander-in-chief. He replied, “Xie Hu is suitable. Though he has reached fifty, his devotion to learning grows ever more earnest. The laws of the former kings are the repository of virtue and righteousness. Virtue and righteousness are the foundation of the people’s lives. Those who are sincere and steadfast do not forget the common folk.” The duke followed his advice and appointed Zhao Cui as minister. Zhao declined, saying, “Le Zhi is upright and prudent, Xian Ju is wise and foresighted, and Xu Chen is broadly learned—all are fit to serve as assistants. I am not their equal.” The duke again urged him, saying, “These three virtues are your own achievements. To govern the people through virtue is of great significance; it cannot be abandoned.” He then appointed Hu Yan as minister. Hu declined, saying, “Mao’s wisdom surpasses mine, and he is also my elder. Not holding office, I dare not accept your command.” Thus, he appointed Hu Mao to lead the Upper Army, with Hu Yan as his assistant. When Mao died, he ordered Zhao Cui to replace him. Zhao declined, saying, “In the Battle of Chengpu, Xian Ju was first to act. Moreover, as my assistant in the army, he was rewarded for his military skill, for serving the ruler well, and for fulfilling his office. Xian Ju has earned three rewards; they cannot be set aside.” The duke said, “Zhao Cui has thrice declined what he declined—all for the defense of the altars of state. To abandon such deference is to abandon virtue.”

It is recorded: In observing Chengzi’s aspirations and cultivated conduct, how could one not trust him? To serve one’s lord with loyalty is called devotion; to yield thrice and gain thrice is called refinement. Those who hold the world cannot but attend to such things. Yet some, merely for hegemony, cast aside refinement, seize high position, and covet exceptional favor. Viewed today, their conduct is no better than a rotting rat. How then do they compare to Zhao Cui?

When Chengzi died, Xuanzi took command of the Central Army and began to administer state affairs. He established administrative codes, rectified laws and punishments, reformed penal cases, supervised appointments, adhered to essential principles, restored neglected institutions, reinforced hierarchical ritual, continued regular duties, and promoted those long overlooked. Once completed, he entrusted the system to Grand Tutor Yang Chufu and Grand Preceptor Jia Tuo, ordering them to implement it throughout Jin as a permanent standard.

It is recorded: The *six-five* line of the *Gu* hexagram states, “Rectifying the father’s corruption brings praise.” The Lord of Jin, by nature yielding and indirect, was devious and unprincipled, yet he was able to employ ministers of firm and upright character. Observing his establishment of governance and ordering of affairs, how could he not be deemed a man of great capability? Thus it is said: The merit of Chengji and the loyalty of Xuanmeng—between ruler and minister, father and son, their good reputation endured for generations. This is what is meant by “inheriting through virtue.”

Zi Pi of Zheng entrusted governance to Zi Chan. Zi Chan declined, saying, “The state is small and exposed, the clans are powerful and favored—it cannot be done.” Zi Pi replied, “If a tiger leads with attentiveness, who would dare offend? If you govern well, no state is too small. A small state that serves the great will find its own security.” Zi Chan took office and ensured that the capital and outskirts had clear distinctions, superiors and inferiors observed their duties, fields had boundaries and irrigation channels, and villages and wells were organized into units. He supported those among the great officers who were loyal and frugal, while restraining those who were extravagant. After one year in office, the people composed a song: “He takes our clothes and caps to store them; he takes our fields and plots to organize them. Whoever kills Zi Chan, we will support him.” After three years, they sang again: “I have sons and younger brothers—Zi Chan instructs them. I have fields and plots—Zi Chan cultivates them. If Zi Chan should die, who will succeed him?”

It is recorded: Observing Zi Chan’s governance, the state of Zheng came to understand the well-field system and schools. At that time, both could have been revived. Zheng, like Lu and Teng, was small, and its claim of being “small and exposed, with powerful and favored clans” was no empty boast. Yet when he took their fields and plots to organize them, ensuring the capital and outskirts had clear distinctions, superiors and inferiors observed their duties, fields had boundaries and irrigation channels, and villages and wells were organized into units, it was no reckless act. When he took their clothes and caps to store them, supporting the loyal and frugal among the great officers while restraining the extravagant, it was no indulgence. These two measures were remnants of the well-field system and the educational legacy of the former kings. Those who initially wished to kill him were accustomed to the withering of favor and the collapse of power; those who later wished to succeed him did so out of sincere admiration. Then who was it that cultivated the fields and plots? Who was it that instructed the sons and younger brothers? The people had truly turned their hearts toward the Dao. This was no empty talk from Youzi or Mencius—Zi Chan put it into practice. How can one limit oneself on account of weakness or smallness? Let the observer consider this carefully.

Zi Pi wished to appoint Yin He as steward of a city. Zi Chan said, “He is too young.” Zi Pi replied, “Let him go and learn.” Zi Chan said, “That will not do. When one loves another, one seeks to benefit them. Now, my lord loves him and entrusts him with governance—it is like handing someone an unhandled knife and ordering them to carve. The harm would be great. You, my lord, are the ridgepole of Zheng. If the ridgepole breaks and the rafters collapse, Jiao will be crushed beneath them. How dare I not speak fully?” He continued, “If you have fine brocade, you would not send someone to learn how to tailor it. High offices and great cities are the shelter of one’s person—how can you send a learner to manage them? I have heard that one studies and then enters governance; I have never heard of using governance to learn.” Zi Pi said, “Well said. I have heard that the noble person strives to know the great and distant, while the petty person strives to know the small and near. I am a petty person. Clothing and garments cling to my body—I know them and take care with them.”

Great offices and great cities are the shelter of one’s person—yet I have kept them at a distance and neglected them. Without your words, I would not have understood. From now on, I shall heed your counsel and act accordingly.

*Recorded:* If Yin He was deemed unfit to be employed, then Zi Gao was unfit for office. This shows how closely contemporary judgments aligned. The analogy of wielding blades and tailoring brocade has endured through the ages, winning universal acclaim. Can one afford not to pursue learning? Thus it is recorded.

When Zi Chan took up governance in Zheng, he selected men of ability and entrusted them with tasks. Feng Jianzi could decide weighty matters; Zi Dashu was refined and cultivated; Gongsun Hui understood the affairs of the Four States and could distinguish the clans, ranks, statuses, and capabilities of their ministers, while also excelling in rhetoric; Bi Chen was skilled in strategy—his plans succeeded in the countryside but failed in the city. Whenever Zheng faced matters concerning the feudal lords, Zi Chan would consult Zi Yu about the affairs of the Four States and compose numerous diplomatic missives. He would then travel with Bi Chen to the countryside to deliberate on the feasibility of their plans, before reporting to Feng Jianzi to render a final decision. Once the matter was settled, he would instruct Zi Dashu to carry it out, handling the responses to envoys and guests. Thus, he seldom met with failure.

*Recorded:* Observing Zheng’s diplomatic declarations, those that have won lasting renown—such as the debates over tribute during the Jin court audience, the refusal of the ruined wall to the Prince of Chu, the disputes over battle formations, the *Li Si* response to Yuan Xianzi, and the reply to Shi Jingbo—all remain preserved. Even today, reading them invigorates the senses and enlightens the mind; how much more stirring must they have been to those who heard them spoken aloud! Truly, words without refinement do not travel far. Can rhetoric go unpolished?

Bi Ao said to Zi Chan: “Song, Wei, Chen, and Zheng will all catch fire on the same day. If we employ the ceremonial jade scepter *quanmao*, Zheng will not burn.” Zi Chan refused. In the fifth month of summer, fire first appeared at dusk.

On the *bingzi* day, wind arose. Zi Jin said: “This is called the *Rong* wind, the beginning of fire.” Seven days hence, would the fire not break out? On the *wuyin* day, the wind grew fierce. By the *renwu* day, it raged violently, and fire erupted in Song, Wei, Chen, and Zheng.

Bi Ao said: “Had you heeded my words, Zheng would not have burned again.” The people of Zheng entreated to employ the ritual, but Zi Chan refused. Zi Taisu said: “Treasures exist to protect the people. If fire comes, the state will nearly perish. If this can avert disaster, why withhold it?” Zi Chan replied: “The Dao of Heaven is distant; the Dao of Man is near. It lies beyond our reach—how can we claim to know it? How does Ao know the Dao of Heaven? He merely speaks too much. Could it not be untrue?” Thus, he neither granted the request nor did fire strike again.

The record states: The *jiaoren*’s reproach asked: “Who calls Zi Chan wise? Yet in dismissing Bi Chong, was he not wise in wisdom itself?” Thus, treating invocations and chronicles as secondary while self-reliance as primary. If a state lacks governance and decrees, how can it resolve calamity before it arises? Those who hold states or households—can they not be vigilant?

Herein lies the principle that good and ill fortune, blessings and misfortunes, may indeed be altered. This is why the ancients always prioritized human affairs before speaking of fate or destiny.

*Hongdao Lu*, Scroll Thirty-Seven—end.
*Hongdao Lu*, Scroll Thirty-Eight.

**On the Wisdom of Rulers and Ministers**

From the *Comprehensive Mirror*:
Wei Wenhou asked Li Ke, “You once said: ‘A poor household longs for a worthy wife; a disordered state longs for a good minister.’ Now, between Cheng and Huang, whom should I appoint?” Li Ke replied, “Observe whom he befriends when in low station; whom he bestows upon when wealthy; whom he promotes when successful; what he refrains from doing when in straits; and what he refuses to take when impoverished. With these five, one may determine his fitness.” Wenhou said, “Return to your lodging; I have decided on my minister.”

The record states: Are these five truly sufficient to determine a minister’s worth? The *Book of Changes* calls Qian the father and Kun the mother; the great ruler is the eldest son, and the great minister is the steward of the household. Thus, across the vastness of Heaven and Earth and among the teeming multitudes, all are kin as siblings, all are companions as ourselves—this is the minister’s duty. Yet if one merely observes whom he befriends in low station, those he does not befriend are still many. If one observes whom he bestows upon when wealthy, those he does not bestow upon are still many. This may suffice to judge a minister of the Three Jin, but not one for all under Heaven. A minister for all under Heaven must be like those of Qin and Jin—steadfast and without other skills, his heart at ease, his demeanor capacious. Only thus can he safeguard descendants and the common people. Compared to the five criteria’s narrow scope, this is as different as night and day. Those who wish to judge ministers in the future should take this as their model.

Han Zhaohou had a worn-out chair and ordered it stored away. His attendants said, “Your Majesty is unkind—why not bestow it upon your courtiers instead of keeping it?” Zhaohou replied, “I have heard that a ruler’s every word and smile must be earned. Is this chair not worth a word or a smile? I will wait for one who has rendered merit.” The record states: In this, Zhaohou misspoke. The red bow and the beckoning bow are received and stored away as rewards for merit—this is how the former kings honored achievement. Though their spirits are few, they are not bestowed lightly upon others, let alone something worn-out. As for words and smiles, their significance is profound. Anger may provoke a rebuke; joy may elicit a laugh. The ruler’s joy and anger concern the state’s fate—how can they be compared to a worn-out chair? He merely considered the cost of his actions but failed to weigh the long-term implications for his person and mind. Indulging private affections and heeding the whims of courtiers—this is no way to speak of wisdom.

From the *Records of the Grand Historian*:
When the Lord of Pei entered Xianyang, his generals all scrambled to seize gold, silk, and valuables. Xiao He alone entered first to collect the maps and registers of the Chancellor’s office, thereby gaining full knowledge of the land’s strategic points, population size, and areas of strength and weakness. Later, when the Han King entered Rongyang, he ordered Xiao He to guard Guanzhong. Xiao He tallied the households of Guanzhong, organized transport and provisions, and supplied the army without fail.

The record states: This is why Xiao He’s merit ranked first. The foundation of the Han’s realm was thus secured. To criticize him for not collecting the books of the academicians and archivists is baseless slander. Initially, Xiang Yu and his generals had agreed: “Whoever enters Guanzhong first shall be its king.” When they grew suspicious of the Lord of Pei, though the matter had already been settled, they secretly plotted: “The roads to Bashu are treacherous, and Qin’s exiles all reside there. Yet Bashu is also part of Guanzhong.” Thus, they enfeoffed the Lord of Pei as King of Han. The Lord of Pei was enraged and wished to attack Xiang Yu, but Xiao He counseled: “To be content under one man yet trusted above a myriad chariots—this was the way of Tang and Wu. I urge Your Majesty to rule Hanzhong, nurture its people, attract worthy men, and harness Bashu’s resources. Then, returning to pacify the Three Qin, the realm may be seized.” The Han King said, “Well said.” He thus went to his fief, appointing Xiao He as Chancellor.

The record states: This is how Xiao He later employed Han Xin—not in the moment of chasing the fugitive, but at the very founding of the Han kingdom. In crushing Qin, destroying Xiang, establishing Han, and subduing Chu, he had already calculated it all in his heart. How could he not be worthy of the title of Chancellor?

The Han King asked Han Xin, “The Chancellor has spoken of you often. What strategies do you offer me?” Han Xin declined, then said, “Now, with Your Majesty’s generals, is not Xiang Yu the only rival?” The king said, “Yes.” Han Xin asked, “Does Your Majesty consider yourself equal to Xiang Yu in courage, ferocity, benevolence, or strength?” The king said, “I do not.” Han Xin said, “Xiang Yu’s manner is harsh and intimidating; though he can terrify a thousand men, he cannot employ worthy generals—this is merely the bravery of a commoner. Xiang Yu treats others with reverence and kindness, speaks gently, and weeps for the sick, sharing his food and drink. Yet when it comes to rewarding merit with titles, he clutches the seals so tightly he wears them down, unable to bestow them—this is what is called ‘the benevolence of a woman.’ Though Xiang Yu is hegemon over the realm and lord over the feudal lords, he does not reside in Guanzhong but makes Pengcheng his capital. He exiled Emperor Yi and leaves devastation wherever he passes. Though called a hegemon, he has truly lost the hearts of the people. Thus, his strength will easily weaken. If Your Majesty can reverse his ways, employ the realm’s warriors, and punish the unrighteous—whom could you not destroy? If you enfeoff cities to meritorious ministers—whom could you not subdue? If you lead righteous troops and summon those longing to return—whom could you not disperse? Moreover, the Three Qin kings were once generals who led Qin’s sons and brothers for years. When their forces surrendered to the feudal lords at Xinan, Xiang Yu deceived and buried alive over three hundred thousand Qin soldiers, sparing only Zhang Han, Sima Xin, and Dong Yi. The people of Qin hate these three to the bone. Now, though Chu is strong and rules them by force, the people of Qin do not love them. When Your Majesty entered Guanzhong, you harmed nothing, abolished Qin’s harsh laws, and the people of Qin all wished for you to rule them. Now, if Your Majesty advances eastward, the Three Qin can be pacified with a single proclamation.” The Han King rejoiced greatly, realizing he had recognized Han Xin too late. He thus heeded his counsel.

It is recorded: Observing what Han Xin cultivated, I now understand that even the most resolute warriors and nobles submit in their hearts—this is no falsehood. That jade is tempered into completion lies with Heaven; it cannot be known by human means. With Han Xin’s poverty, humiliation, and bodily hunger, the trials and tribulations he endured were already many—how could his heart not be moved? Thus, only by refusing to settle for the bravery of a common fighter did he realize the Three Qin could be broken; only by disdaining the mercy of a mere woman did he recognize that Xiang Yu could be opposed; only by not dismissing the words on nurturing the people and attracting the worthy did he understand the Chancellor could be served; only by not abandoning the ritual of erecting an altar to appoint a general did he grasp that the Han King could be served as lord. Had he not heeded Han Xin’s counsel, I would not know what would have become of him.

Zhang Liang sought to avenge Han for his grievance, so his grandfather had once ambushed the First Emperor. Enraged, the First Emperor scoured the realm for ten days but could not capture him. Liang then changed his name and surname, fleeing into hiding in Xiapei. Once, strolling leisurely by the bridge, an old man approached where Liang stood and deliberately dropped his shoe beneath the bridge. Turning to Liang, he said: “Boy, go down and fetch my shoe.” Liang suppressed his anger and descended to retrieve it. The old man then said: “Put it on for me.” Liang knelt and placed the shoe on the old man’s foot. Smiling, the old man said: “This boy can be taught.” He set a time to meet again at dawn five days later. Liang arrived, but the old man was already there. Angrily, he said: “You are late for an appointment with an old man. Go.” He set another meeting for five days later, at the crack of dawn. At the crow of the rooster, Liang arrived, but the old man was already there. Again, he scolded: “Why are you late? Go.” He set yet another meeting for five days later, to come even earlier.

At midnight, Liang went to the appointed place. After a short while, the old man arrived, and with delight, he bestowed upon Liang a bound book, saying: “Read this, and you shall become the teacher of kings.” He added: “After ten years, you will see me again. At the foot of Mount Gucheng near the Ji River, beneath the Yellow Stone—that is where I shall be.” Then he departed without another word. At daybreak, Liang examined the book and found it to be *The Art of War of the Grand Duke*. He marveled at it and diligently studied and recited its teachings.

It is recorded: In their beginnings, was there truly such a great difference between Zhang Liang and Yu Rang? In an age where the world treasured the violent and sudden—where blades flashed in alleyways and seizures were made in the streets—men like Zhuan Zhu, Cao Mei, Nie Zheng, and Jing Ke, with their daggers and sevenfold stratagems, were renowned in their time. Even one as virtuous as Lin Xiangru still longed to spill blood upon the Qin king within five paces. Such was the spirit and temper of the age, its origins stretching far into the past. When Heaven wearied of the savagery of men, the old man upon the bridge appeared, destined to aid in the rise of the Han. Only then could Zifang (Zhang Liang) discern the wisdom of patience and concealment, mastering the art of biding his time. In the end, he was celebrated for his cunning.

Thus, when viewed from what came before, Zifang was like unrefined steel or an unshaped blade—how could he have avoided the fate of a mere butcher? Yet when seen from what followed, he was like a maiden’s form or a fleeing hare—no bridle could ever restrain him again.

Liang had long suffered from frailty. When he followed the Lord of Pei (Liu Bang) into the pass, he practiced *daoyin* and abstained from grains. After the realm was pacified and he was enfeoffed as the Marquis of Liu, he resigned from the Han court, saying: “My family served the state of Han for generations. When Han fell, I did not惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜

The teachings of Yi Yin state: "A minister must not be corrupted by favor, nor seek profit from success." The hexagram of the Duke of Zhou declares: "The dragon soars to the limit and meets with regret." These are the lessons of the sages and worthies. To retire and find contentment in quietude, to roam with the red crows in leisure—this is the Dao of the sages and worthies. From the three visits to the thatched cottage to the restoration of governance, from the regency to the request for retirement, what was this if not this very Dao?

The Three Dynasties have passed, and the schools of power, strategy, and profit—what do they truly aspire to? They often know how to advance but not how to retreat, how to preserve but not how to perish. Thus, when they first encounter the deeds of Zifang, they regard them as rare and transcendent, as if he had cast off the world like a pair of worn shoes. Yet they do not realize how much he relied on cunning and followed the currents of fate.

Why is this? The teachings of the Yellow Stone say: "There is no greater peace than enduring humiliation, no greater fortune than knowing contentment." Alas! Though these words may not fully align with the intent of the sages, they cannot be rejected as devoid of the Dao. Compared to Han Xin, Peng Yue, and Zhou Bo, how much wiser was he! Had he not met the right man, I see that the scheme at Bolang would have been more misguided than the strategy of feigning illness, and he would not have been far from the fate of Jie or Zhi.

The Emperor held a feast at the Southern Palace in Luoyang and addressed his ministers: "Let the marquises and generals speak without concealment: Why did I gain the realm, and why did Xiang Yu lose it?" Wang Ling replied: "Your Majesty is arrogant and insults others, while Xiang Yu is benevolent and loves his men. Yet when Your Majesty sends men to attack cities and seize lands, you reward them with what they gain, sharing the profits with all. Xiang Yu is jealous of the worthy and suspicious of the capable; he harms those who achieve merit and doubts the virtuous. This is why he lost the realm."

The Emperor said: "You know one part but not the other. In planning strategies within the tent to secure victory a thousand *li* away, I am not the equal of Zifang. In stabilizing the state, comforting the people, ensuring provisions, and keeping supply lines unbroken, I am not the equal of Xiao He. In commanding a million troops, ensuring victory in battle and conquest in attack, I am not the equal of Han Xin. These three are all outstanding men, and I was able to employ them—this is how I gained the realm. Xiang Yu had Fan Zeng but could not use him—this is how he was captured by me."

The record states: Master Cheng said: "The constancy of heaven and earth lies in their mind pervading all things yet being without mind. The constancy of the sage lies in their emotions aligning with all things yet being without emotion. Yet it is not that they are truly without mind—it is that the mind of one becomes the mind of ten thousand, so what person cannot be embraced? Nor is it that they are truly without emotion—it is that the emotion of one becomes the emotion of ten thousand, so what thing cannot be employed? Though the High Ancestor of Han did not closely approach the sages, his efficacy in that moment was such that heaven was made clear and earth was made tranquil by it. Had he not been magnanimous and broad-minded, receptive to good counsel like flowing water, and aligned with the vast openness of the Grand Duke, responding to things as they came, how could he have attended to every matter and discerned every person?

If one harms others in the name of wisdom yet fails to unite the hearts of the multitude, or if one insists on one’s own virtue yet fails to harmonize with the aspirations of all, this is what heaven abandons—not merely what men capture.

After Empress Lü passed, Lü Lu and Lü Chan plotted rebellion but feared the Marquis of Jiang and the Lord of ZhuXu, hesitating without resolve. The Marquis of Jiang sent Li Qi to deceive Lü Lu into relinquishing command of his troops to the Grand Marshal. The Grand Marshal entered the military gate and issued an order: "Bare your right shoulder for the Lü clan, bare your left for the Liu clan." The entire army bared their left shoulders. The Grand Marshal then led the Northern Army, dividing his forces to arrest all the Lü men and women, young and old alike, and executed them without exception.

The record states: Some say the Grand Marshal’s question was improper, some fearing for him, others considering him fortunate. Yet if we rely solely on the words recorded on paper, [the Grand Marshal must have first secured his position before issuing the order]. [As the saying goes]: From Li Qi’s deceptive persuasion, we can infer the truth. When Chen She, a mere commoner, was about to rise, he still had men cry out in the groves of the village shrine, "Chen She shall be king!" before the people followed him. How much more so for the wisdom of Chen Ping and Zhou Bo, who relied only on the Six Armies! Moreover, if they dared not openly declare the need to punish the Lü clan, how would the people know the direction of loyalty and rebellion? With a single question about baring shoulders, the distinction between rebellion and loyalty became clear—this is evident. Only then did all know that the Lü clan deserved execution and the Liu clan deserved to be restored. The Lü clan’s supporters, front and back, left and right, dissolved in disarray. Was this not the result of deep and interlocking calculations?

When Emperor Wen ascended the throne, he became increasingly familiar with the affairs of state. At court, he asked the Right Chancellor Bo: "How many cases are adjudicated in the realm in a year?" Bo pleaded ignorance. The Emperor then asked: "How much money and grain enter and leave the treasury in a year?"

Bo again pleaded ignorance, his sweat soaking his back. The Emperor then asked the Left Chancellor Ping, who replied: "There are officials in charge of such matters. If Your Majesty inquires about adjudicated cases, hold the Minister of Justice accountable; if about money and grain, hold the Minister of Revenue accountable." The Emperor said: "Then what affairs does the Chancellor oversee?" Ping replied: "The Chancellor assists the Son of Heaven above in harmonizing yin and yang, aligning with the four seasons, and below in nurturing the proper growth of all things. Externally, he pacifies the four barbarians and the feudal lords; internally, he draws close to the common people, ensuring that the high ministers and great officers each fulfill their duties." The Emperor praised his answer. Thereupon, the Marquis of Jiang realized his wisdom and ability were inferior to Ping’s, so he resigned on grounds of illness and requested to return the Chancellor’s seal. The Emperor granted his request, and Ping served as sole Chancellor.

It is recorded: Ping’s words truly embodied the Chancellor’s duty. The Emperor already understood this—could he not then demand its fulfillment? In demanding its fulfillment, could he not also seek the right person for the task? Alas, the Emperor’s keen wisdom did not extend to this. I have once pondered the reason. Emperor Gaozong reverently observed silence to contemplate the Dao, and what he pursued was learning. Through learning, he knew that understanding was not difficult, but practice was—this was to seek what benefits attainment. Emperor Wen, in profound silence, transformed the people, and what he admired was Laozi. Laozi taught knowing the masculine yet embracing the feminine, knowing the white yet guarding the black—this was to seek what brings no benefit to attainment. Thus, when martial generals and village officials—men of bluster and bravado—are governed by a ruler of pure virtue, their conduct and demeanor instead bow to his authority and look up to his radiance. How could one demand that they sit and discourse on the Dao? Yet all possess a single virtue, and those who aspire to emulate the Three Kings do not do so to display difference. Without such ability, one cannot assist the Son of Heaven in rectifying the Central Kingdom and pacifying the four barbarians.

Chen Ping had once followed in military campaigns, devising six extraordinary strategies: first, proposing to distribute gold to sow discord among the enemy; second, presenting a crude letter to deceive the Chu envoy; third, sending out two thousand women by night to break the siege at Zhongyang...

Seizing the opportunity to request the enfeoffment of Han Xin as King of Qi was the fourth; proposing a feigned excursion to Yunmeng to capture Han Xin was the fifth; and breaking the siege at Bailang was the sixth.

Recorded thus: To turn peril into victory and devise extraordinary strategies by assessing the enemy are matters of the moment—what is called the cunning of a single general, and in this he was more than sufficient. Yet to extend Heaven’s benevolence and harmonize yin and yang are affairs of an age—what is called the talent of a ruler of ten thousand chariots, and in this he fell short. Such was the Emperor’s judgment of his chancellor: a name without substance.

As the imperial carriage passed the office of the Gentlemen of the Palace, the Emperor asked Feng Tang, “Where is your father’s family from?” Tang replied, “My grandfather was from Zhao.” The Emperor said, “Once someone spoke to me of the worth of the Zhao general Li Qi, who fought beneath Julu. Now, whenever I adorn my thoughts, I cannot but dwell upon Julu.” Tang said, “Yet he was not even comparable to the generals Li Mu and Lian Po.” The Emperor struck the railing and sighed, “Alas! If only I could have Li Mu or Lian Po as my general, what worry would I have of the Xiongnu?” Tang said, “Though Your Majesty might obtain men like Lian Po and Li Mu, you would not be able to employ them.” The Emperor angrily rebuked Tang, who replied: “In ancient times, when the Son of Heaven sent forth a general, he would kneel and push forward the chariot hub, saying, ‘Within the gates, I command; beyond the gates, the general commands.’ Military merit, ranks, and rewards were all decided by the general in the field. Thus they were able to pursue the Xiongnu chanyu, shatter the Eastern Hu, destroy the Danlin, curb the might of Qin in the west, and prop up Han and Wei in the south. Now Wei Shang serves as governor of Yunzhong, and he devotes all the taxes from the military market to feasting his soldiers. The Xiongnu keep their distance and dare not approach the frontier. Once, when the barbarians made a single incursion, Shang led his chariots and cavalry to strike them, inflicting heavy casualties. Yet when he reported his victory, the headquarters staff found a single discrepancy in his account, and the scribes bound him by the law. Your Majesty’s rewards are too meager and your punishments too severe: though Shang was only six enemy heads short of his tally, he was handed over to the officials and stripped of his rank. From this it is clear that even if you had Lian Po and Li Mu, you would not be able to employ them.” The Emperor was pleased and ordered Tang to take the imperial tally and pardon Wei Shang, restoring him as governor of Yunzhong and appointing Tang as Commander of the Chariots and Cavalry.

Recorded thus: When the Emperor longed for Lian Po and Li Mu as generals, why did he not also long for the Duke of Zhou and the Duke of Shao as his chancellors? As generals, Lian Po and Li Mu pursued the chanyu, shattered the Eastern Hu, and annihilated the Danlin—nothing more than keeping the Xiongnu from approaching the frontier. But as chancellors, the Duke of Zhou and the Duke of Shao brought the Yuechang people to present tribute through repeated interpreters, saying, “For three years now, Heaven has sent no violent winds or excessive rains, and the seas have not stirred with waves. We suspect there must be a sage in the Central Kingdom—why not go and pay homage?” Then which was greater: the merit of generals or chancellors? The limbs and joints are but ministers; good ministers are the sages. The Three Dynasties brought the four barbarians to submit by this Dao. Emperor Wen did not seek out the supreme sage to join forces with him, but instead fixated on what he had heard of Zhao and Dai. Though he daily struck his thigh in regret, what benefit did it bring? This is why, though he heard Chen Ping’s words, they were no different from Feng Tang’s argument—neither sufficed for great wisdom.

During Emperor Wu’s reign, Ji An was often ill, and Zhuang Zhu requested leave on his behalf. The Emperor asked, “What sort of man is Ji An?” Zhu replied, “If Ji An were to hold office, he would have no advantage over others. But when assisting a young ruler and safeguarding an established legacy, he is deeply steadfast: summoned, he does not come; dismissed, he does not leave. Even if Meng Ben and Xia Yu were to oppose him, they could not dislodge him.” The Emperor said, “Indeed. Of old there were ministers of the altars of soil and grain—Ji An comes close to that.” Recorded thus: This was why, when Emperor Wu later entrusted his orphaned heir, he alone found the right man. Only when one truly knows a man can one employ him with full commitment—how much more so for those as foolish as Xiao He or as stubborn as Wang Ling! Without true knowledge, who could achieve success? Those who are neither foolish nor stubborn avoid harm and chase profit, and what need would there be to summon them to come or dismiss them to go?

Emperor Taizong of Tang only failed to truly know Xiao He and Li Ji, and so when entrusting his heir, he relied on their talent and intelligence while overlooking their moral integrity. Yet men like Hongshi, Ni Kuan, and Zhuang Zhu had long been fostered and employed. What did they have to do with the altars of soil and grain?

Lady Gouyi’s son, Fuling, was but a few years old, yet his frame was sturdy and tall, and he possessed great intelligence. The Emperor marveled at and cherished him, and upon observing that among his ministers only the Palace Attendant and Chariot Master Huo Guang was loyal and steadfast enough to entrust with great affairs, he had the eunuchs present Huo with the *Illustrated Scroll of the Duke of Zhou Assisting King Cheng in Receiving the Feudal Lords*. When the Emperor’s illness grew severe, Huo Guang wept and asked, “If the unmentionable should come to pass, who ought to succeed?” The Emperor replied, “Have you not yet understood my earlier intent? Establish the youngest son, and you shall act as the Duke of Zhou did.” On the day *yichou*, an edict was issued to appoint Fuling as Crown Prince, with Huo Guang as Grand Marshal and Grand General.

Huo Guang had entered and exited the palace’s inner chambers for over twenty years, ever cautious and meticulous, never once erring. His demeanor was composed and deliberate; each time he passed through the palace gates, his steps and pauses were measured with precision. The Gentleman of the Palace and the Captain of the Guard secretly observed him, never finding his conduct off by even a fraction.

Recorded thus: The Emperor’s appointment of Huo Guang was likely informed by Zhuang Zhu’s assessment of Ji An, revealing his discernment in knowing men. To entrust a six-foot orphan to another requires recognizing Huo Guang’s loyalty, steadfastness, and meticulousness—qualities as sharp as a blade. Had there been no usurpation of Liu He or the authority to establish Emperor Xuan, would Huo Guang not have been a man of perfect integrity? If Ji An had lived in those times and faced such events, I know he could not have tolerated others’ faults—how then could he have endured his own? The affairs of Chao Cuo and the abdication of Emperor Wen were his forte. Yet when it came to the later conspiracy of the Prince of Huainan, even his own wife and children could not restrain his desires. The Emperor had reason to trust Huo Guang, but Huo Guang failed to live up to the Emperor’s expectations—this was another failing of Ji An.

The daughter of Huo Guang’s granddaughter, the child of Shangguan An, was his own great-granddaughter. Shangguan An, seeking to make her Empress through Huo Guang’s influence, was refused on account of her youth. He then turned to the Emperor’s elder sister, Grand Princess Gai, who had her enter the palace. She was made Empress at the tender age of six. Thereupon, Shangguan Jie and Shangguan An grew deeply resentful of Huo Guang. Learning that Prince Dan of Yan, the Emperor’s elder brother, harbored resentment for not being named heir, they had someone forge a letter in the Prince’s name, proposing to jointly seize and depose Huo Guang. When the memorial was submitted, Huo Guang, upon hearing of it, did not enter the palace. The Emperor asked, “Where is the Grand General?” Shangguan Jie replied that the Prince had accused him of crimes, so he dared not enter. An edict was issued summoning the Grand General, and Huo Guang entered, removed his cap, and kowtowed. The Emperor said, “Put on your cap, General. I know this letter is forged. You were only recently appointed to oversee the Colonels—how could the Prince have known of it in less than ten days?” At the time, the Emperor was but fourteen years old. The officials and attendants of the Imperial Secretariat were all astonished, and the forger of the memorial was indeed found to have fled. Thereafter, when members of Shangguan Jie’s faction slandered Huo Guang, the Emperor would grow angry, saying, “The Grand General is a loyal minister, entrusted by the late Emperor to assist me. Those who defame him shall be punished.” From then on, Shangguan Jie and his associates dared not speak against him.

Recorded thus: It is commonly said that the wise do not live long—yet is it not also true that the long-lived are not wise? What one receives from Heaven may be abundant and pure, or pure yet meager. From clarity arises sincerity—this is called “nature”; from sincerity arises clarity—this is called “teaching.” Sincerity is clarity, and clarity is sincerity. Those who possess abundance and purity endure without limit. Glass is a treasure, no less lustrous and white; ice and jade are vessels, no less radiant and bright. Yet they possess purity but meagerness, and so shatter at the slightest touch. Though their clarity may be the same, their sincerity differs—this is why Emperor Zhao of Han was limited to such an extent.

Since Emperor Wu established the offices of the Left Fengyi, Right Fufeng, and Metropolitan Governor of the Capital, among officials and commoners, only Zhao Guanghan was universally esteemed. By nature astute and perceptive, he excelled in his duties as an official, particularly skilled in the technique of *gouju* for uncovering the truth. *Gouju* works thus: if one wishes to know the price of a horse, one first asks about dogs, then sheep, then oxen, before finally inquiring about horses. By cross-referencing their prices and comparing them by category, the true value of the horse is revealed without error. Only Zhao Guanghan was so precise that he could employ this method—others who imitated him could not match his skill. The bandits, rogues, and local toughs of the commandery, along with the locations of their dens and hideouts, as well as the bribes and illicit gains taken by officials—all were known to him. Several young men of Chang’an gathered in an abandoned house in a poor quarter to plot a robbery. Before their discussion was even finished, Zhao Guanghan dispatched officers to arrest them, and they confessed in full. When the wealthy man Su Hui, a Gentleman of the Palace, was abducted by two men, Zhao Guanghan led his officers to the house. Standing in the courtyard, he had the Prefect of Chang’an, Gong She, knock on the door and address the bandits: “The Metropolitan Governor, Lord Zhao, apologizes to the two gentlemen. Do not kill your hostage—he is a servant of the imperial guard.” The two men were stunned.

Once, Zhao Guanghan summoned the warden of Hudu Pavilion. As the man traveled west to the border, the warden at the frontier post jested, “When you reach the prefectural office, give my regards to Lord Zhao.” After the warden arrived and Zhao spoke with him, concluding their business, Zhao said, “The warden at the frontier post sent word to thank me—why did you not convey his greeting?” The warden kowtowed and admitted it was true. Zhao then said, “When you return, thank the frontier warden for me. Encourage him to diligently attend to his duties and prove his worth, and the Metropolitan Governor will not forget his kindness.” His ability to uncover hidden crimes and expose the guilty was as uncanny as this.

**Recorded Note:** I have heard from the former worthies that benevolence may be excessive, but wisdom must not be. The custom of exposing others’ faults and the art of probing secrets—these are excesses of wisdom. Such excesses cannot be called “seeking counsel and acting with moderation,” nor “concealing evil and extolling good.” Moreover, when combined with harshness, overbearing strength, and a reckless spirit that stirs trouble like the wind, this is precisely the path to self-destruction—not what is meant by “wisdom like a god.”

**From *The Book of Later Han*:**
When Dou Rong heard of Emperor Guangwu’s might and virtue, he wished to submit, but the distance of Hexi made direct communication difficult. Yin Xao sent the eloquent scholar Zhang Xuan to persuade Rong, saying, “Gengshi’s cause has already succeeded, only to perish soon after. The destruction of this one clan is a lesson that will not repeat. Each of you should secure your territory and ally with Long and Shu in a vertical alliance. At best, you could become the Six States; at worst, you would not fall below Wei Tuo’s rank.” Rong summoned the local elites to discuss the matter. Among them, those with discernment said, “Now the emperor’s name and surname appear in the prophetic texts. The Han has received the mandate anew.” Rong then resolved to submit and dispatched his chief clerk, Liu Xun, to present a letter at Zhuoyang.

The emperor replied to Rong: “Now Gongsun Ziyang holds Yizhou, and General Yin commands Tianshui. As Shu and Han attack each other, the balance of power rests with you. A single step to either side will tip the scales. Given this, if you wish to deepen our bond, how could there be limits? If you intend to establish yourself like Duke Huan or Duke Wen, aiding a weak state, you must strive to complete your achievements. If you aim to divide the realm into three, forming alliances and coalitions, you should decide this without delay. The world is not yet unified, and you and I are separated by vast distances—not nations that would devour each other. Those who advise you now must be following Ren Ao’s plan to have Wei Tuo control the seven commanderies. A true king grants land but not people; each should attend to his own affairs.” He then appointed Rong as Governor of Liangzhou. When the imperial seal and edict reached Hexi, the entire region was astonished, believing the Son of Heaven could see beyond a thousand *li*.

**Recorded Note:** Dou Rong’s submission was a turning from darkness toward light. The emperor’s foresight in discerning affairs was often accurate. Only with Rong’s clarity could the emperor’s vision be realized.

The *Tun* hexagram’s first nine says: *“Lingering, it is favorable to abide in constancy.”* Dou Rong embodied this. The *Image* states: *“Heaven’s creation is in the midst of chaos; it is fitting to establish lords, yet not to rest.”* Emperor Guangwu embodied this. This is why, to the end of the Han era, his illustrious reputation knew no bounds.

That reckless Ren Xiao—just as the saying goes: *"Mounting a horse in disarray, weeping blood in streams"*—was destroyed before he could even turn his heel. Yet this was not merely the emperor’s foresight spanning a thousand *li*; the sage had already made it plain for ten thousand generations.

Emperor Guangwu, observing that the registered acreage of cultivated land across the realm was largely fraudulent, and that household records and annual registers showed discrepancies in gains and losses, issued an edict ordering the provinces and commanderies to conduct a thorough land survey. Thereupon, many inspectors and governors resorted to cunning pretexts, using the land-measurement campaign as an excuse to assemble the people in the fields, where they proceeded to measure not only the land but also their homes and village compounds. The people wailed in protest along the roads, while the powerful and wealthy were often favored, and the poor and vulnerable were exploited and oppressed.

At the time, each commandery had dispatched envoys to present memorials at court. The emperor noticed that a document carried by an official from Chenliu bore writing on its back. Upon examining it, he read: *"Yingchuan and Hongnong may be investigated, but Henan and Nanyang must not be questioned."* When the emperor interrogated the official, the man refused to admit anything, claiming he had found the document on Changshou Street. The emperor grew furious.

Just then, the emperor’s son, Prince Yang of Donghai, aged twelve, who had been standing behind the screen, spoke up: *"The official was acting under his commandery’s orders, intending only to compare land measurements."* The emperor asked: *"If that is so, why did he say Henan and Nanyang must not be questioned?"* The prince replied: *"Henan is the imperial capital, where many close ministers reside, and Nanyang is the emperor’s hometown, where many close relatives live. Their landholdings and estates exceed regulations and cannot serve as a standard."* The emperor ordered the imperial guards to question the official further, and the man finally confessed, confirming Prince Yang’s account. From that moment, the emperor’s admiration and affection for Yang only deepened.

**Recorded Note:** Is not such discernment the sagely virtue of a sovereign?

Yet there exists a meticulous clarity and a scrutinizing clarity. The former is the fullness of illumination—thus, when the great light hangs in the sky, it bathes all directions equally, yet never troubles itself with the faintest glimmer in the cracks or the faintest shadow beneath an overturned basin. The latter is the severity of illumination—thus, when a rhinoceros-horn torch lights the riverbank, every detail stands exposed, yet the tiniest fish in the depths or the most hidden subtlety may still elude its grasp.

Though the torch is a thing, illumination itself is no thing: it may shine upon the riverbank, yet when turned toward the sun, it casts no light at all. This explains why the Han emperor Ming could discern the truth in the case of the clerk’s kneecap, yet remained blind to the excesses of the Chu trials.

When Emperor Guangwu was in Ji, Wang Lang rose in rebellion and issued proclamations to frame him. The emperor ordered Wang Ba to recruit men in the marketplace, intending to strike at Lang, and hastened to depart. The day was bitterly cold; as they galloped south to Xiaquyang, word came that Wang Lang’s troops were approaching from behind, and all in the retinue grew fearful. Upon reaching the Hutuo River, a scout returned to report: *"The river flows swiftly, and with no boats, we cannot cross."* The officials were seized with dread.

Guangwu sent Ba to assess the situation. Fearing he would alarm the others, Ba feigned an attempt to block the water’s advance, then returned and knelt, saying: *"The ice is solid—we can cross."* The officials rejoiced. Guangwu smiled: *"The scout was indeed lying."* They pressed forward to the river, where the ice had indeed frozen over. He ordered Ba to oversee the crossing. Before even a handful of riders had passed, the ice began to break. Turning to Ba, he said: *"That our company crossed safely is thanks to you."* Ba demurred: *"This is the supreme virtue of Your Highness, the blessing of divine spirits. Even King Wu’s omen of the white fish cannot compare."*

Later, he told his officials: *"Ba’s timely measure to meet the crisis was like a heavenly sign."* The Record notes: *"This should be likened to the white serpent, not the white fish—only then would the divine blessing be fittingly matched."*

It further states: *"What is meant by ‘timely measure to meet the crisis’ is no deceptive path. When affairs reach the brink of peril, with not a hair’s breadth to spare, that is the moment for heroes to employ their wisdom. Had we followed the scout’s report, would we have advanced to block the water? Before Li Ling, the barbarians dared not press; after Zhao Yun, one man held a thousand hearts—all achieved thus. To claim foreknowledge of the ice’s freezing as a celestial omen would be beyond Ba’s reach."*

*Hongdao Record, Scroll 38 (concluded)*
*Hongdao Record, Scroll 39: Wisdom*

**The Wisdom of Ruler and Minister**

From *The Records of the Three Kingdoms*: Zhuge Liang of Langye resided in seclusion at Longzhong in Xiangyang, tilling his fields with his own hands. He was fond of singing the *Liangfu* hymns and often compared himself to Guan Zhong and Yue Yi, though none of his contemporaries acknowledged this. Sima Hui, a man of refined elegance and keen judgment, shared his hometown with Pang Degong, who was widely respected. Degong once remarked, "Kongming is the Crouching Dragon; Decao is the Ice Mirror." Thus, when Liu Bei was in Jingzhou, he sought out scholars from Sima Hui. Hui said, "Scholars and common men—how could they recognize the demands of the times? Those who know the times are the outstanding and heroic. Among them are the Hidden Dragon and the Young Phoenix." When Bei asked who they were, Hui replied, "Zhuge Kongming."

The *Record* states: Observing Zhuge Kongming, I realize that the talents nurtured in the Eastern Capital cannot be easily obtained. People merely see the humiliation of the partisans and deem it the calamity of the virtuous and worthy, unaware that the purge of the corrupt and the rise of the outstanding foster the winds of pure virtue. Kongming knew how to cultivate himself in stillness and nurture his virtue through frugality. Without detachment, one cannot clarify one’s aspirations; without tranquility, one cannot attain far-reaching goals—was he not a dragon in virtue, though hidden? He also said: "Learning requires stillness; talent requires study. Without study, one cannot broaden one’s talents; without stillness, one cannot complete one’s learning—is this not the unceasing diligence of the *Qian* hexagram?" And again: "Indolence and arrogance prevent deep inquiry; impatience and rashness prevent sound governance. As years race by and intentions fade with time, is this not the vigilance of one who trembles even at dusk?" Thus, he was called the "Outer Dragon"—rightly so.

Yet the three visits in earnest revived the long-suppressed spirit of the age, and his grasp of the times was truly the most celebrated praise. Bei visited Liang and, dismissing his attendants, said: "The Han house is collapsing; treacherous ministers usurp its mandate, and the sovereign is humbled in the dust. Though I lack virtue and strength, I wish to uphold righteousness in the realm. But my wisdom and strategy are shallow, and I have faltered to this day—yet my resolve remains unshaken. What plan should I adopt?" Liang replied: "Since Dong Zhuo’s time, heroes have risen in great numbers, seizing provinces and commanderies beyond count. Compared to Yuan Shao, Cao Cao was weaker and fewer in number, yet he overcame Shao and turned weakness into strength—not only by heaven’s timing but also by human strategy. Now Cao commands a million troops and wields the Son of Heaven to command the lords—truly, none can contend with him. Sun Quan holds the lands east of the Yangtze, having ruled for three generations. His state is secure, his people loyal, and the worthy and able serve him—he can be an ally but not a target. Jingzhou, north of the Han and Mian rivers, commands the resources of the southern seas, connects eastward to Wu and Kuaiji, and westward to Ba and Shu—this is a land for martial exploits, yet its lord cannot hold it. This is likely heaven’s gift to you, General—do you have the will to take it? Yizhou is a land of perilous passes and fertile fields, a natural stronghold where Gaozu built his imperial enterprise. Liu Zhang is weak and ignorant; Zhang Lu lies to the north. The people are prosperous, the state is rich, yet they lack care—thus the wise and able yearn for a worthy ruler. You, General, are of imperial lineage, your integrity renowned throughout the realm. You gather heroes and thirst for the worthy. If you seize Jing and Yi, secure their strategic defenses, make peace with the Rong tribes to the west, pacify the Yi and Yue to the south, ally with Sun Quan externally, and govern justly within—when the realm changes, you may dispatch a great general with Jingzhou’s troops to advance toward Wan and Luo, while you personally lead Yizhou’s forces into the Qin plains. Who would not welcome you with baskets of food and pots of drink? If so, hegemony can be achieved, and the Han restored."

Xuande said, "Excellent."

The *Record* states: Observing Kongming’s counsel to Xuande—seizing and holding Bashu, reclaiming the Three Qins, and seizing the realm—it was all one vision. Yet why could he not restore the imperial enterprise? In Gaozu’s time, the Three Heroes were employed together. Capturing Wei, subduing Dai, overthrowing Zhao, Yan, and Qi, and destroying Chu in the south—all were Xin’s achievements. Consider his words: "The more, the better"—how different from the slaying of Yan Liang and Wen Chou! The one who sets the course and points the way is this man; the one who hunts rabbits and foxes is also this man—how can the world bear both at once? Moreover, Cao’s use of troops resembled Sun and Wu, yet the petty state of Shu ultimately perished in obscurity. Who could have been its mighty arm? Though Kongming outmaneuvered Sima Yi, it may have been too late. Thus Gaozu sighed: "You know one thing but not the other."

Sun Quan said to Lü Meng: "Now that you hold power, you cannot neglect learning." Meng excused himself, citing military duties. Quan replied: "Do I wish you to become a scholar-official? Simply read broadly to understand past affairs. You say you are busy—who is busier than I? Yet I have read, and it has greatly benefited me." Meng then began his studies. Later, when Lu Su passed through Xunyang and discussed matters with Meng, he was astonished: "Your talent and strategy now surpass the old Lü Meng of Wu!" Meng replied: "A scholar, after three days apart, must be viewed with fresh eyes. Why are you so slow to see this?"

The *Record* states: What was the purpose of learning in ancient times? Fine qualities are easily found, but the supreme Way is rarely heard. Learning was for sincerity and trust. What is the purpose of learning today? To seek success in affairs and achievement in deeds—learning has become a tool for deceit and fraud. Thus, before Sun Quan’s exhortation, Lü Meng’s innate goodness was unrefined, and heavenly principle remained intact—how could he have earned such admiration? After his studies, he relied on cunning and calculation, displaying his abilities and scheming for success—no longer the old Lü Meng of Wu.

Yet if this were not Lü Meng’s gain, would it not be Guan Yu’s loss? When Sun Quan discussed Zhou Yu, Lu Su, and Lü Meng with Lu Xun, he said: "Gongjin was fierce and heroic, his courage and strategy surpassing others. He crushed Cao Mengde and opened up Jingzhou—truly peerless. Zijing, through Gongjin’s recommendation, came to me. At our first banquet, our conversation soon turned to grand strategy and the enterprise of emperors and kings—this was one joy. Later, when Mengde seized Liu Zong’s momentum and boasted of leading hundreds of thousands by both land and water, I consulted my generals for advice. None spoke first, until Zhang Zibu suggested sending envoys to welcome him. Zijing urged me to summon Gongjin at once, entrust him with troops, and strike in reverse—this was another joy. Though he later advised me to lend territory to Xuande, this was his one flaw, insufficient to overshadow his two strengths. Thus, I have always compared him to Deng Yu.

As for Ziming, in his youth I thought him incapable of handling strenuous tasks, possessing only boldness and courage. But as he matured, his studies flourished, and his strategic brilliance emerged, placing him second only to Gongjin. His capture of Guan Yu surpassed even Zijing’s achievements."

The *Record* states: How unreasonable is Sun Quan’s assessment! Gongjin’s success at Red Cliffs was spurred by the Shu sovereign and his ministers. Instead of gratitude, he met with mockery—how could he not have struck back? To invite an enemy and not seize the chance, then lend them territory, and call the lender flawed—what of the borrower? Sun Quan’s treachery as a Han usurper is extreme. His cunning in ambushing Guan Yu was no better than a thief’s stealth. To claim superiority over Zijing and equate such deeds with petty thievery is still tolerable—what wonder that he flattered the deceitful usurper with talk of Heaven’s mandate?

The *Book of Jin* records: Du Yu, though the realm was at peace, held that forgetting war invites peril. He diligently trained troops, constructed floating palaces, and won the devotion of the Jiang and Han regions, his influence spreading for ten thousand *li*. He crushed the mountain tribes, established garrisons, and secured strategic positions to strengthen the state’s defenses. He also restored the legacy of Zhao Xinchen, dredging and channeling waters to irrigate over ten thousand *qing* of fields. He demarcated boundaries with stone markers, ensuring shared benefit for public and private alike. The people relied on him, calling him "Father Du." Formerly, the waterways only linked the Mian and Han to Jiangling, with no northern passage for over a thousand *li*. The confluence of Lake Baju with the Yuan and Xiang rivers, surrounded by mountains, was a natural stronghold on which the Jing and Man peoples depended. Du Yu then opened Yangkou, dredged the Xia River, and extended the route to Baling for over a thousand *li*, draining the Yangtze’s excess inward while connecting the grain transport of Ling and Gui outward. The southern lands sang of him: *"No rebellion in later ages—who but Father Du discerned wisdom and valor?"*

The *Record* states: Who does not admire wisdom and valor? Yet who truly understands them? The *Book of Documents* says: *"Possessing goodness, one loses it; boasting of one’s name, one loses its merit."* People’s wisdom is shallow and narrow, so they fail to grasp this. In the campaign to pacify Wu, the planning, decision-making, and strategic direction all came from Du Yu. The other generals merely hunted beasts. Thus, though he never mounted a horse or shot through armor, this was not due to aristocratic indolence but because his broad learning and deep immersion in the classics led him to greater heights. He neither boasted of his virtues nor flaunted his merits. Yet his admonition to *"never forget peril in times of peace"* surpasses common insight—how could mere dredging or military skill compare? Even the cunning of Hua and Gui could not match him. How could one not strive to diminish complacency and uphold the foundation of deeds and words? Alas, he is worthy of emulation.

From *The Old Book of Tang*: Emperor Taizong said to Xiao Yu, "In my youth, I was fond of bows and arrows. I acquired over a thousand fine bows and believed none could surpass them. Recently, I showed them to a bowyer, who declared, 'None are made of good wood.' When I asked why, he replied, 'If the heart of the wood is not straight, its grain will be askew. Though the bow may be strong, the arrow will not fly true.' Only then did I realize my earlier judgment had been unrefined. If I, who subdued the realm with bow and arrow, could not fully discern their quality, how can I presume to grasp every matter under Heaven?"

Thereupon, he ordered officials of the fifth rank and above to take turns lodging in the Secretariat and Chancellery, frequently summoning them to inquire about the people’s hardships and the successes and failures of governance.

A record notes: "In ancient times, artisans used their craft to admonish rulers—this is what the bowyer and Wheelwright Pian meant. Even today, their words are still praised, for they exhaustively revealed the principles of things, demanding careful consideration. Thus, if the heart of the wood is crooked, its grain will be askew; if the ruler’s heart is not upright, governance will be perfunctory. The bowyer’s insight may well surpass that of ministers like Wei Zheng. Yet Taizong merely grasped the words but not their deeper meaning. He could inquire into the origins of hardship and failure but failed to exercise caution in matters concerning his wife and kin—was this truly the balanced practice of seeking counsel?"

The emperor asked Wei Zheng, "How does a ruler attain clarity, and how does he fall into darkness?" Wei replied, "Clarity comes from listening widely; darkness, from trusting one-sidedly. Yao sought the voices of the people below, so the crimes of the Three Miao could reach his ears. Shun’s four eyes saw clearly, his four ears heard all, so Gong, Gun, Huan Dou, and the others could not deceive him. The Second Emperor trusted Zhao Gao alone, bringing the disaster of Wangyi Palace. Emperor Wu of Liang trusted Zhu Yi alone, inviting the humiliation of Taicheng. Emperor Yang of Sui trusted Yu Shiji alone, leading to the mutiny at Pengcheng Pavilion. Thus, when a ruler listens broadly and accepts counsel, powerful ministers cannot block the truth, and the sentiments of the people rise to him."

The emperor said, "Well said."

A record notes: "In the *Yi Jing*, the hexagram *Li* represents brightness, for its two luminous lines shine forth, symbolizing civil brilliance. The hexagram *Ming Yi* represents obscurity, for its light enters the earth, symbolizing hidden darkness. This is the division between broad listening and one-sided trust. Even with such lessons, later rulers still trusted Yang Guozhong, bringing the catastrophe of the Tianbao era."

He trusted Lu Qi, bringing the chaos of the Jianzhong era; he trusted Li Xun and Zheng Zhu, leading to the Ganlu Incident.

The emperor asked Fang Xuanling and Xiao Li, "What kind of ruler was Emperor Wen of Sui?"

They replied, "Emperor Wen was diligent in governance. Whenever he held court, he might remain until sunset. He would seat officials of the fifth rank and above to discuss matters, eating only when his guards brought him meals. Though his nature was not benevolent, he was indeed an emperor who exerted himself to the utmost."

The emperor said, "You have grasped one aspect but not the other. Emperor Wen was unenlightened yet fond of scrutiny. Being unenlightened, his perception was incomplete; being fond of scrutiny, he grew suspicious of all things, both of which stemmed from his failure to trust his ministers. The realm is vast, and the affairs of a single day are myriad. Even if he wearied his spirit and exhausted his body, how could he ensure every decision was sound? Once his ministers understood his intent, they merely followed his decrees and accepted his judgments. Even if they erred, none dared to remonstrate. This is why the dynasty fell after two generations.

I act differently. I select the realm’s worthiest talents and appoint them to office, entrusting them to deliberate on the empire’s affairs. After the chief ministers have thoroughly examined and settled matters, they report to me. Those who render merit are rewarded; those who commit faults are punished. Who would dare not exert their utmost to fulfill their duties? What cause is there to fear the realm will not be well governed?"

Thereupon, he instructed all offices: "From now on, if any edicts or decrees issued are deemed unsuitable, all must memorialize their objections. None shall comply out of deference without fully expressing their views."

A record notes: The emperor’s words serve as a mirror for rulers. To be unenlightened yet fond of scrutiny is a common flaw of later ages. Right and wrong cannot be obscured by one man’s judgment, yet if one relies solely on personal approval, right and wrong become confused. Good and evil cannot be ranked by one man’s standards, yet if one indulges personal preferences, good and evil grow muddled. Merit and fault cannot be decided by one man’s decree, yet if one acts out of private bias, merit and fault become indistinguishable.

Thus, while one may defer to others due to lack of enlightenment, it is still defensible; but to take on petty details oneself while constantly doubting others is indefensible. The realm is vast, yet the mind’s capacity is small; the people are boundless, yet one’s ears and eyes are limited. If one allows all offices to memorialize objections when inconvenienced, one avoids the burden of partiality; if one can select the worthy and employ the capable, there is no fear of neglected affairs. This is why the governance of the Zhenguan era may be deemed exemplary. Let later rulers take heed.

Fang Xuanling was astute in administrative matters and refined in letters. Day and night, he devoted himself wholeheartedly, fearing even a single thing might be misplaced. He applied the law with leniency and fairness, hearing of another’s goodness as if it were his own. He did not demand perfection in others nor measure things by his own strengths. Together with [Du] Ruhui, he promoted men of talent, ever fearful of falling short. Even the regulations of the imperial secretariat were established by these two.

Whenever the emperor consulted Xuanling on affairs, he would say, "Without Ruhui, matters cannot be settled." Yet when Ruhui arrived, he invariably adopted Xuanling’s plans. For Xuanling excelled in strategy, while Ruhui excelled in decisiveness. The two complemented each other deeply, governing with a single heart. Thus, when the age speaks of worthy ministers, it extols Fang and Du.

A record notes: In my humble view, the Tang ministers Fang and Du differed from the Han’s Xiao [He] and Cao [Shen]. Their steps were not seen to follow, nor their ears to heed, yet history praises their strategic acumen. Why? They were adept at concealing their utility.

When comparing Tang Taizong to Han Gaozu, one sees a difference in their magnanimity and breadth of vision. Thus, with the emperor’s spirit so radiant and heroic that the world bowed before him, had men like Fang and Du proposed a single strategy, he would have claimed it as his own strength; had they devised a single plan, he would have boasted of it as his own achievement. How then could men like Xiao and Cao have maintained their standing to the end? Yet now, when the emperor consulted Xuanling on affairs, he would say, "Without Ruhui, matters cannot be settled." And when Ruhui arrived, he invariably adopted Xuanling’s plans. Was this not, between sovereign and minister, between friends, the art of concealing one’s utility?

The emperor said to Changsun Wuji and others, "Men suffer from not knowing their own faults. You may speak plainly of mine for me." They replied, "Your Majesty’s martial prowess and civil virtue leave us no choice but to follow and obey—what faults could there be to speak of?" The emperor said, "I ask you to point out my faults, yet you flatter me with empty praise. I wish to enumerate your strengths and weaknesses before you, that we may admonish and correct one another. What say you?" They all bowed and expressed their thanks.

The emperor said, "Changsun Wuji excels at avoiding suspicion, responds to matters with agility, and judges affairs with acuity—no ancient could surpass him—yet leading troops in battle is not his strength. Gao Shilian has read widely in ancient and modern texts, his mind is clear and far-reaching, and he does not waver in times of peril. In office, he is free of cliques, but lacks the backbone to offer forthright remonstrance. Tang Jian is eloquent and quick-witted, skilled at reconciling others. He has served me for thirty years yet never once offered advice on governance. Yang Shidao is pure and gentle in conduct, never erring or transgressing, but in truth he is timid and weak—of no use in times of crisis. Cen Wenben is sincere and steadfast, his writings rich and elegant, yet in debate he clings stubbornly to his views. Though he may plan for the long term, he does not betray his principles. Liu Ji is utterly steadfast, always acting for the common good, yet he still values private promises to friends. Ma Zhou perceives matters with swift clarity and is upright in character. When assessing others, he speaks with unvarnished honesty. I have employed him often, and he has seldom disappointed. Chu Suiliang’s learning is somewhat advanced, and his nature is firm and upright. He pours out his loyalty without reserve, drawing close to me like a bird alighting on a man’s shoulder—how could one not cherish him?"

A record notes: At first, the emperor sought to hear his own faults, then turned to those of his ministers. In the end, he enumerated the faults of his ministers while forgetting his own. Later, in his appraisal of Cao Cao, he said: "In peril, he could devise victory; in war, he could outmaneuver the enemy—his generalship was more than sufficient, but his capacity for rulership fell short." Alas! Taken together, this reveals the emperor’s gains and losses. Why then resort to empty flattery?

When Emperor Dezong ordered Guo Ziyi to return and appointed Li Guangbi in his stead, the soldiers wept and blocked the imperial envoy, begging to keep Ziyi. Ziyi deceived them, saying, "I am merely escorting the envoy; I have not yet departed." Then he spurred his horse and left. Guangbi rode with five hundred cavalry to the eastern capital, entering his headquarters by night. The commander of the army, Zhang Yongji, and other generals plotted to lead their elite troops into Luoyang, drive out Guangbi, and recall Ziyi. They ordered their men to arm themselves and mount their horses in readiness. Kang Yuanbao remonstrated, saying, "If you use force to summon the Duke, the court will surely suspect you. This is the Duke’s way of testing your loyalty—would you ruin his house for this? What have the Guo family’s hundred lives ever done to you, that you would act thus?" Yongji desisted.

A record notes: When Yue Fei of the Song was ordered to withdraw his troops, it was much like Duke Guo’s spur-of-the-moment departure. Yet some pedantic scholars criticize him, saying that when a general is in the field, even the emperor’s orders need not be obeyed, and that he should have waited until the Central Plains were recovered before complying. How is this different from Yongji’s scheme?

From *The History of the Song*: Though the Taizu Emperor had never studied in his youth, he took up reading in his later years. Yet his nature was magnanimous, and he did not affect refinement. When the new palace in the capital was completed, he sat in the main hall and ordered all the doors thrown open. They stood straight and unobstructed, revealing all within. He said to his attendants, "This is just like my heart—if there were the slightest crookedness, all would see it." He once said to his chief minister Xue Juzheng and others, "Few ancient rulers could govern their hearts and reach a state free of error. I have always risen early and retired late, guarding against wrongdoing and restraining desire, hoping to transform the people through virtue. When Tang Taizong received memorials from his ministers, they would openly criticize his faults, yet he showed no shame. How is it better to act thus than to refrain from error in the first place, sparing one’s ministers the need to speak?"

A record notes: *The Book of Yu* warns that "the human heart is perilous," not to indulge desire. *The Doctrine of the Mean* teaches vigilance in what is unseen and unheard. The emperor’s mind was as vast as the heavens—what room was there for doubt? That Tang Taizong could accept written remonstrance was still deemed shameful by later generations. Was this not a case of concealing one’s faults? No one since has matched him.

Taizong was diligent in his studies. After each court session, he would read until the hour of *shen* (3–5 p.m.) before setting his books aside. He ordered the Historiography Institute to compile *The Imperial Reader for a Peaceful Age* in one thousand volumes, presenting three volumes daily. Song Qi and others remonstrated, citing the labor involved. The emperor said, "Opening a book is always beneficial—it is no hardship. I intend to read this work in its entirety within the year."

A record notes: The learning of emperors differs from that of scholars. I believe scholars, too, should seek to understand human nature and pursue the essence of principle. To boast of vast knowledge or compete in ornate prose is merely laborious and of no benefit. As for Taizu’s engagement with the *Two Classics*, he not only read them but put them into practice—later generations would do well to follow his example. Yet the compilation of *The Imperial Reader for a Peaceful Age* was fragmented and disjointed, of no practical use. Though three volumes were presented daily, what benefit did it truly bring?

No doubt this explains why Tian Xi refused to accept it. Tian Xi was upright and unyielding, with few allies, yet shrewd and fond of ritual propriety. He once memorialized: "The existing *Imperial Reader* merely categorizes matters by type, offering no benefit to the sagely mind. Your servant requests leave to compile a new *Imperial Reader*."
