He further gathered essential passages from the classics and histories to create an *Imperial Screen*, placing it beside the imperial seat, so that the lessons of order and chaos, rise and fall, might always be before the emperor’s eyes.

The preface to his *Imperial Reader* states: "The Way of the sage is spread across the pages of books. The Six Classics speak in lofty terms with profound intent—without careful study and discussion, their depths cannot be fathomed. The various histories record disparate events—without comparing and synthesizing their differences, how can one easily grasp their complexity? The masters’ texts abound in heterodox doctrines; literary collections are sparse in words that uphold the classics. Without extracting their essential meanings to serve as warnings, distilling their guiding principles to perceive their coherence, and compiling a daily reader to cultivate daily-renewed virtue, even a lifetime would not suffice to exhaust them."

The preface to the *Imperial Screen* states: "The ancient emperors inscribed admonitions on their basins and goblets, their tables and staffs. For they saw them in their daily life and never forgot them, day or night. Your servant, whenever perusing the classics, histories, masters, and literary collections, selects their essential words and presents them for Your Majesty’s perusal. By observing and reflecting on them day and night, the sagely virtue will be renewed daily, rivaling that of Tang and Wu."

A record notes: "I observe that the founding emperors of the Han and Song dynasties never engaged in formal study, yet they did not lose the imperial standard. The rulers of the Tang and Song, though they toiled in broad learning, ultimately incurred the criticism of later generations. Why? Could it be that their pursuit of vast knowledge and strong memory did not closely align with the investigation of things and the extension of knowledge? Thus, their achievements were confined to literary refinement and calligraphy, without touching upon the sincerity of intention and rectification of the mind. Emperor Zhenzong merely sighed in admiration of Tian Xi, lamenting that heaven had taken him too soon, and failed to fully heed his memorials to reap the merit of forthright remonstrance. How much less could the placement of a single screen suffice? Even if a new *Imperial Reader* were compiled, it would be no different."

Zhao Pu, in his youth, was versed in official affairs but lacked scholarly learning. Emperor Taizu urged him to read, and thereafter he never let go of a book. Each time he returned to his private residence, he would open his cases, take out books, and read them through the night. When asked about this, he replied, "In governance, decisions flow like water." After his death, his family opened his cases and found *The Analects* in twenty chapters. He often told the emperor: "Your servant possesses a copy of *The Analects*—with half of it, I assisted Taizu in pacifying the realm; with the other half, I assist Your Majesty in achieving great peace."

Li Hang once read *The Analects*. When asked about it, he said: "As chief minister, even the words 'practice frugality and love the people, employ them at the proper seasons' from *The Analects* remain beyond my ability to fully enact. To recite them for a lifetime would suffice."

A record notes: "Zhao the Loyal and Wise’s reading of *The Analects* may be called arrogantly self-assured. Yet he did not know whose fault it was when tigers and rhinoceroses escaped their cages or jade was damaged in its casket—thus, when he said, 'I desire it,' he also made excuses for it. Li the Cultured and Resolute’s reading of *The Analects* may be called humbly self-effacing. Yet he truly governed without weariness and acted with loyalty, so that when he spoke, his words invariably hit the mark. Alas! Such a man—what he foresaw first may be called wisdom; what he did not deceive may be called benevolence; and his lifelong recitation may be called courage. In light of the sage’s words, is he not one who is free from worry, confusion, and fear?"

Later, when Li Hang served as chief minister, Wang Dan became a participating minister. With warfare in the northwest depleting resources to the point of famine, Wang Dan sighed: "How can we sit back and achieve great peace, enjoying leisure without concern?" Li Hang replied: "A little hardship and vigilance serve as warnings. One day, when the realm is at peace, the court may yet face troubles." Wang Dan did not agree. Li Hang further proposed presenting reports on floods, droughts, and banditry from the four quarters, but Wang Dan deemed such matters trivial, unworthy of troubling the emperor’s ears. Li Hang said: "The emperor is young. He should be made aware of the hardships in the realm. Otherwise, with his vigor and strength, if he does not attend to governance but indulges in sensual pleasures, hunting, or extravagant construction, military campaigns, or excessive sacrifices, I, being old, will not live to see it—but you, Participating Minister, will bear the burden of this worry."

After Li Hang’s passing, Emperor Zhenzong, with the Khitan having made peace and the Western Xia having submitted tribute, proceeded to perform the Feng and Shan sacrifices, offer prayers at Mount Fen, and extensively construct palaces and Daoist temples. He sought out and expounded upon neglected classical rites, never resting for a day. Wang Dan, witnessing the conduct of Wang Qinruo, Ding Wei, and their ilk, wished to remonstrate but had already been complicit; he wished to resign but was treated with great favor by the emperor. Thus, recalling Li Hang’s foresight, he sighed and said: "Li Wenjing was truly a sage." From that time on, Li Hang was called the Sage Minister.

A record states: Since *The Book of Shang* sought the Primordial Sage, who has ever been called a Sage Minister? Li Hang’s prescience was as clear as divination by milfoil or tortoiseshell. Throughout the Song dynasty, he stood alone.

Li Hang was sparing in speech when receiving guests and officials. Outside observers thought him as silent as a dried gourd. His younger brother, Wei Cheng, questioned him about this, to which Li Hang replied: "I am not unaware. Yet today, from the highest to the lowest officials in the court, all may speak on matters of state. Memorials submitted under seal reach the throne without obstruction, and upon descending, all may be seen by the relevant offices. For matters of great national importance, men like Li Zongkuo and Zhao Anren—among the finest talents of the age—when discussing affairs with me, still cannot stimulate my thoughts. As for the rest, those newly entered into officialdom, they stumble over their bows and greetings, flustered and at a loss. Once seated, they inevitably boast of their own merits and urge me to recommend them for favor and reward. What strategies could they possibly have to discuss with me? If I were to stoop to empty flattery, that would be what the world calls ‘cage-capturing.’ But cage-capturing is something I cannot do."

A record states: Observing Li Hang’s words, none fail to thoroughly capture the character of later generations. His reference to "cage-capturing" outwardly feigns empty courtesy while inwardly lacking sincerity—a perfect reflection of worldly customs, rendered with utmost precision. Thus, one sees that the Sage Minister’s wisdom left nothing unknown. How, then, could one seek the pity of marketplace urchins and willingly endure the scorn of the discerning?

Chen Shu had long overseen the Three Departments. When Emperor Zhenzong first ascended the throne, he repeatedly ordered Chen to itemize and report the quantities of money and grain held within and beyond the court. Chen delayed for a long time before complying. When repeatedly urged by imperial edict, he replied: "Your Majesty is young and prosperous. If you learn of the fullness of the treasuries and granaries, I fear it may give rise to extravagant desires. Therefore, I dared not report it." The emperor praised him.

A Record states: Chen Shu served in office through mental calculation alone—nothing worthy of note. Yet he had long discerned the emperor’s inclination toward extravagance. Had Chen still been alive, he would never have consented to the elaborate "Heavenly Script" affair, nor could such a thing have been expected of him. Thus, he is recorded here.

When Cao Bin conquered Jiangnan, he returned with nothing but maps, books, and a few garments. His entire household submitted a petition stating: "We humbly advise that he be dispatched to Jiangnan to manage official affairs." Upon his return, people praised him for his lack of boasting. Earlier, when Cao was about to campaign against Tang, the emperor told him: "Once you capture Li Yu, I shall appoint you as a Legate-Minister." Pan Mei offered congratulations in advance, but Cao said: "Not so. In this campaign, we rely on the might of Heaven and follow the court’s strategy—what merit is mine? How could I presume to such a rank?" Pan asked: "What do you mean?" Cao replied: "Taiyuan has yet to be pacified." Upon his return with captives, the emperor said: "I originally intended to appoint you as Legate-Minister, but since Liu Jien has not yet been subdued, we shall wait a while longer." Pan glanced at Cao with a faint smile. The emperor questioned him, and Pan answered truthfully. The emperor laughed heartily and bestowed upon Cao fifty thousand strings of cash. Cao withdrew and remarked: "Why must one be a Legate-Minister? A good official is one who simply acquires more money." Later, he was appointed Military Commissioner.

A Record states: How could Cao Bin’s wisdom and discernment be slighted? Even Ma Yuan faced slander from Liang Song, and Wang Jun was maligned in Zhou Jun’s writings. When a gentleman stands amid merit, he cannot be too cautious. Yet even those who drew their swords to strike pillars or rolled up their sleeves in fury could not silence such calumnies—how much less could a mere Legate-Minister matter? As the *Book of Songs* says: "Without arrogance, without greed—what could go amiss?" In Cao Bin and Pan Mei, one sees a mutual fulfillment.

When Zhang Yong governed Yizhou, the people spread a rumor that a white-haired old man devoured people after noon, throwing the entire prefecture into uproar. The governor inquired in the markets and, upon returning, summoned the rumor’s originator the next day. The man arrived, trembling, and Zhang explained: "When strange rumors arise, it is because perverse qi has taken hold. The strange has form, the rumor has voice. To stop a rumor, one must discern and decide—not outdo it." Moreover, in the aftermath of war and fire, people’s hearts were restless. One day, during a grand military review, the assembled troops had just marched out when suddenly three shouts of "Long live the emperor!" erupted. Zhang dismounted, gazed into the distance, then remounted and continued on. The crowd dared not stir. Someone reported this to Han Qi, who said: "At such a moment, even I would not have known what to do." Zhang’s resourcefulness was largely of this kind.

He once told Li Tian: "In matters great and small, one must employ wisdom. Wisdom is like water—if it does not flow, it stagnates. If one never uses wisdom in ordinary affairs, how can it arise in a moment of crisis?" He also said: "There are three difficulties in handling affairs: first, to perceive the issue; second, to act upon what one perceives; and third, to act decisively when the time comes."

A Record states: Since Mencius spoke of "boring and chiseling," no words have been as urgent as those of the Loyal and Steadfast [Zhang Yong]. Wisdom cannot be forced, nor can it be exhausted. To force it is to bore; to exhaust it is to stagnate. Following principle is to flow; not depleting it is to keep it unexhausted. Thus, to halt a rumor’s spread is to gather it through decisive action; to rein in a shout is to respond with agility. Indecision and slowness are thieves of wisdom. Without these three, one cannot govern a single person, take a single step—how much less the great affairs of the world? Therefore, the words of the Loyal and Steadfast are truly urgent.

When the Khitan invaded Chanzhou, the emperor was greatly alarmed and consulted Kou Zhun. Kou replied: "If Your Majesty wishes to resolve this, it will take no more than five days. I urge you to visit Chanzhou." His colleagues, hearing this, were terrified, and some wished to retreat, but Kou stopped them. He ordered that preparations be made for the imperial procession. The emperor hesitated and was about to return to the palace when Kou urgently detained him, saying: "If Your Majesty enters, I will not be able to see you, and the great matter will be lost." Bi Shi’an strongly urged the emperor to follow Kou’s advice. The emperor then resolved to lead the campaign personally and summoned his ministers to discuss strategy. Wang Qinruo, a man of Linjiang, proposed retreating to Jinling; Chen Yaosou, a man of Meizhou, suggested fleeing to Chengdu. The emperor again asked Kou, who knew full well the二人’s schemes but feigned ignorance, saying: "Whoever devised this plan for Your Majesty deserves execution. Now, with Your Majesty’s divine martial prowess and the harmony of your generals and ministers, if you personally lead the campaign, the enemy will surely flee. Otherwise, we may deploy unexpected tactics to disrupt their plans, hold firm to wear down their forces, and turn the balance of labor and ease to our advantage—victory will be ours."

How could one abandon the ancestral temples and the altars of soil and grain, seeking refuge in Chu or Shu—distant lands where the people’s hearts would collapse? If the enemy, emboldened by victory, pressed deeper, could the realm still be preserved? The emperor then resolved to encamp at Chanzhou.

The *Record* states: During the Jisi Incident of our Ming, Xu Youzhen advocated for a southern retreat, but for Zisu’s resolute opposition, the matter was halted. Which of these two situations was more dire? In my humble view, the Khitan incursion at Chanyuan was but a border skirmish for the Song, with no threat to the stability of the ancestral temples. Yet during the Zhengtong Incident, the imperial carriage was lost in the wilds, the court and realm thrown into turmoil, and the question of whether to stay or flee hung by a thread. At such times, Wang Qinruo and Xu Youzhen were still at large. Given their cunning, why were they not swiftly removed, allowing them to later sow discord? Ah, when a ruler of discerning wisdom sits the throne, black and white are easily distinguished; but when a ruler indulges in ease, right and wrong blur. Once complacency in wealth and comfort takes hold, arrogance and extravagance arise; when the seeds of disaster are forgotten, calamity sprouts. Thus, in the Jingde and Zhengtong eras, the sound counsel of these two men was heeded at first, only for their schemes to bring ruin in the end.

The Sage’s *Book of Changes* warns: *"When it comes to the eighth month, there will be misfortune. How can the noble man be careless? How can he evade it?"*

When the emperor reached the southern walls of Chanzhou and saw the Khitan forces arrayed in overwhelming strength, his attendants urged him to halt. Kou Zhun, however, insisted: "If Your Majesty does not cross the river, the people’s hearts will grow more fearful, and the enemy’s morale will remain unchecked. This is no way to assert authority and secure victory." Though the court’s counselors trembled with fear, Kou pressed his case relentlessly. As he left, he encountered Gao Qiong, the Commander of the Palace Guard, and said: "General, you have received the nation’s favor—how will you repay it today?" Gao replied: "I am but a soldier. I am willing to die for this." Kou then reentered the hall, with Gao standing at attention below. Kou declared in a loud voice: "If Your Majesty does not heed my words, why not ask General Gao and the others?" Gao immediately looked up and proclaimed: "Minister Kou speaks the truth." He then ordered the guards to advance the imperial carriage. The emperor crossed the river and ascended the northern gate tower. From afar, the sight of the imperial canopy stirred the Song troops, who leapt and cheered *"Long live the Emperor!"*—their voices carrying for miles. The Khitan’s spirit was broken.

The emperor entrusted all military affairs to Kou, who exercised command with strict discipline. His orders were clear and solemn, and the soldiers both feared and revered him. Kou did not wish to bribe the Khitan with wealth; instead, he sought to compel their submission, demand the cession of You and Ji, and then proposed a strategy: "If we do this, we may secure a century of peace. Otherwise, in a few decades, the barbarians will grow restless again." Kou’s true aim was to strike them so decisively that none would return. Yet the emperor, weary of war, said: "I cannot bear to further burden the people. Let us accept their offer of peace for now."

The *Record* states: The Song’s Chanzhou is today’s Great Ming. The former’s capital at Bian and the latter’s at Yan are not so far apart in distance. When the Khitan invaded Dingzhou, attacked Baozhou, then Shun’an Army, and finally Beiping, their incursions were much like those of today. The Song had generals like Wei Neng and Shi Pu to repel them in the vanguard, and Tian Min and Wang Chao to block their retreat. Thus, whenever they clashed with Song forces, the Khitan would retreat after minor setbacks, feigning disinterest in battle. Yet at Chanyuan, Kou Zhun stood alone at the front, ready to engage and crush them so thoroughly that not even a single wheel would return. But Emperor Zhenzong first said he would sue for peace, then declared his weariness of war. When the matter of annual tribute arose, he said: "If there is no other choice, even a hundred million could be granted." Are the histories exaggerating?

Moreover, the Han and Tang’s policies of *heqin* relied on a single strategy, while the Song’s oaths combined two approaches. Why were these not fully debated in court, allowing the ruler and his ministers to choose wisely? This year, we recover the River Bend; next year, we change the grand coordinator—yet we never find respite, merely hoping the enemy will not come, or if they do, that they will leave of their own accord. Some say their aim is mere plunder, not conquest—so what harm is there? Alas, this is precisely the "five baits" by which they ensnare us. Why not test this once, rather than let the people’s blood and brains stain the earth?

Thus, I recount the events of Chanyuan to admonish those in power: for the wise, this is the most pressing matter. The urgent task lies here.

*Hongdao Record*, Scroll Thirty-Nine concludes.
*Hongdao Record*, Scroll Forty.

The Wisdom of Ruler and Ministers

Yan Shu, at seven, was already skilled in composition. In the early Jingde era, Zhang Zhibai, pacification commissioner of Jiangnan, recommended him as a child prodigy. Emperor Zhenzong summoned him to court, where he took the examination alongside the *jinshi* candidates. Unperturbed, Yan Shu took up his brush and wrote with ease. The emperor praised him highly. Whenever he sought Yan’s counsel on governance, the latter would respond on small slips of paper, sealing his replies with medicinal wax. The emperor valued his prudence, discretion, and wisdom, promoting him to governor of Yingtian Prefecture. There, Yan invited Fan Zhongyan to instruct the students, for he had a lifelong talent for recognizing men of ability. Thus, renowned scholars of the age—such as Zhongyan and Daofu—emerged from his tutelage, while Fu Bi and Yang Cha became his sons-in-law. When he later became chief minister, he devoted himself even more to advancing worthy men. Later, Zhongyan, Han Qi, and Fu Bi all rose to prominence together, filling the court with the finest talents of the day. The emperor, roused to purpose, sought to cultivate these talents to revive the Dao of governance. By the Kangding and Qingli eras, the court was famed for its assembly of able men—all due to Yan Shu’s efforts.

*Record* says: Mencius said, “The wise know all things, but they attend first to what is urgent.” Can the office of chief minister afford not to focus on recognizing talent? Yan Shu began as a child prodigy and ended renowned for his discernment of men—was he not one who, rather than merely observing minor achievements over three years, saw the greater whole? No wonder he became a celebrated minister.

Fan Zhongyan governed Yan Prefecture. Previously, border defenses had been divided, with the *zongguan* commanding ten thousand men, the *ganxia* five thousand, and the *dujian* three thousand. When raiders attacked, the lowest-ranking officer would lead the defense. Fan objected: “To appoint commanders by rank rather than ability is a path to defeat.” He conducted a grand review of the prefectural troops, selecting eighteen thousand men and dividing them into six battalions, each led by a general commanding three thousand. Day and night, they drilled, rotating their deployments according to the enemy’s strength. When the raiders heard of this, they warned one another: “Do not underestimate Yan Prefecture. That ‘Little Fan’ has tens of thousands of armored troops in his belly—he is no ‘Big Fan,’ to be trifled with.”

*Record* says: I observe Fan Zhongyan—at first, he was but a scholar. Yet whence came the tens of thousands of armored troops in his belly? Alas.

This reflects what Zhang Yong meant when he said: "In matters great or small, one must employ wisdom." And was it not such adaptability that enabled the rotational deployment of troops? Thus, those who can apply wisdom find their minds transformed and inexhaustible; those who cannot remain at a loss, unable to advance even a single step. All this lies within oneself—there is no distinction between great or small, old or young. Let the reader take heed.

Di Qing was cautious and reticent, his demeanor deep and strategically astute. He deliberated on affairs only after discerning the opportune moment, then acted decisively. When leading troops, he first disciplined their ranks, enforced rewards and punishments with clarity, and shared in their hunger, cold, and toil. When the enemy dared to challenge him, not a single soldier dared to lag behind or rush ahead. He began as a common soldier, serving as a *sanban* officer. At the start of the *Baoyuan* era, when Zhao Yuanhao rebelled, the troops were fearful and timid. Di Qing, however, would charge into battle with his hair unbound, wearing a bronze mask, cutting through enemy lines without resistance—thus achieving repeated extraordinary feats. Yin Mo admired him and recommended: "This man has the makings of an excellent general."

Fan Zhongyan presented him with the *Zuo Tradition of the Spring and Autumn Annals*, saying: "A general who knows neither past nor present is but a foolhardy braggart." From then on, Di Qing humbly devoted himself to study, mastering all the military strategies from the Qin and Han dynasties onward. Later, when Nong Zhigao rebelled, the emperor grew anxious. Di Qing, then serving as Vice Commissioner of the Bureau of Military Affairs, submitted a memorial requesting to lead the campaign. He was appointed as Pacification Commissioner and dispatched to Guangnan. Initially, the commander Chen Shu had lost discipline, and his troops were routed. Di Qing declared: "When orders are inconsistent, defeat is inevitable." He then executed Chen Shu. At this, the other generals trembled in fear, none daring to meet his gaze.

Di Qing halted his troops and ordered the soldiers to rest for ten days, leading the rebels to assume he would not advance immediately. The next day, he drilled his forces, then marched day and night, cutting through Kunlun Pass to emerge at Guiren Station, where he crushed the rebel army. Among the slain, one corpse wore a golden dragon robe, and the soldiers believed Nong Zhigao had perished, wishing to report this to the throne. Di Qing said, "How can we be certain this is not a ruse? I dare not deceive the court for the sake of claiming merit."

Though Di Qing held high rank, the tattoo on his face remained. When the emperor once ordered him to remove it, he pointed to his face and said, "Your Majesty promoted me for my merit, not my lineage. My present standing comes from this mark. I beg you to leave it, that it may encourage the troops. I dare not obey the decree."

Later, while serving in the Bureau of Military Affairs, someone presented him with the official commission (*gaoshen*) of the Tang statesman Di Renjie, claiming it as an heirloom of his distant ancestor. Di Qing declined, saying, "I rose by chance—how dare I presume kinship with Lord Di?" He rewarded the man and sent him away.

**Record:** Some say Nong Zhigao was not so cunning—yet was he not? The wise seize opportunities swiftly, adapt with agility, and alter their forms without fixed pattern, concealing their moves without fixed exposure. To refuse luck, never forget humiliation, and avoid reckless risks—these are the marks of a true strategist. A general of such caliber is rare indeed. Yet even he could not escape suspicion and doubt. Had he erred in any of these, he would have met his end. The wise must observe a man not only in his strengths but also in his oversights.

In the winter of the eleventh month of the first year of the Xining reign of Emperor Shenzong, the court prepared for the southern suburban sacrifice. The chief ministers, citing drought and famine in the Hebei region and insufficient state funds, petitioned to forgo the customary distribution of gold and silk. The emperor ordered the academicians to deliberate. Sima Guang said, "To relieve disaster and practice frugality, one must begin with the high and near—only then will the people heed the call." Wang Anshi replied, "When Chang Yi declined the post of *biaoci* academician, he said he knew his own limits and should resign, yet could not refuse his salary. The reason for the state’s financial shortage is the lack of a skilled fiscal manager." Sima Guang said, "A skilled fiscal manager does no more than impose head taxes and basket levies." Wang Anshi said, "Not so. A skilled fiscal manager ensures sufficiency without increasing taxes." Sima Guang said, "How can this be? The wealth and goods produced by heaven are finite—if not in the hands of the people, they are in the hands of the state. To devise schemes to seize from the people is more harmful than raising taxes. This is the deceitful rhetoric of Sang Hongyang, which Sima Qian recorded to criticize Emperor Wu’s lack of discernment." Their debate continued without resolution. The emperor said, "My view aligns with Guang’s. For now, reply that the request is denied." As Wang Anshi drafted the edict, he cited the case of Chang Yi to rebuke the two chief ministers, and the matter was dropped.

**Record:** Formerly, Bi Zhongyou, favored by Sima Guang, wrote to him, saying: "Wang Anshi swayed the late emperor with his theories of construction and reform, fretting over insufficient funds. Thus, he implemented every policy that could extract wealth from the people. The *Green Sprouts* loans and *Market Exchange* schemes were his methods, but his true aim was construction, driven by his anxiety over scarcity. If one cannot suppress his motives but merely prohibits his methods, no argument will prevail." How wise were these words!

Moreover, in the mid-Song era, at the height of peace and prosperity, with no external threats and the frugal reigns of Emperors Renzong and Yingzong, no harm had yet been done. Yet the state coffers were empty, and even the customary rewards for the suburban sacrifice were lacking. How could a newly enthroned, ambitious emperor not be moved? The emperor’s refusal was, in truth, a deeper affirmation. Thus, the sage rulers of old, free from desire, sought neither sufficiency nor abundance—yet achieved both. Those who fret over scarcity and strive for abundance, no matter how they scheme, only drift further from the truth, while their opponents’ arguments gain traction. Thus, it was not that Wang Anshi swayed the emperor, but that the emperor surrendered to Wang Anshi. How could this align with Sima Guang’s intent?

When the *Bingyi* official Yue Fei violated military law and faced execution, Zong Ze met him and marveled, saying, "This man is general material." As the Jin forces attacked Fan River, Zong Ze entrusted Yue Fei with five hundred cavalry and ordered him to redeem his crime through merit. Yue Fei routed the Jin and returned, whereupon Zong Ze promoted him to *tongzhi* and said, "Your intelligence, courage, skill, and artistry surpass even the great generals of old. Yet you favor open-field battles—this is not a foolproof strategy." He then presented Yue Fei with battle formations. Yue Fei replied, "To array troops before battle is the common practice of warfare. The subtlety of their application lies in the commander’s mind." Zong Ze approved his words, and Yue Fei rose to fame.

Yue Fei submitted a memorial, saying: "The armies rallying to defend the throne grow daily. We should strike while the enemy rests. Yet Huang Qianshan, Wang Boyan, and their ilk fail to uphold the imperial will to recover lost lands, instead escorting the imperial carriage ever southward, which cannot inspire the hopes of the Central Plains. I beg Your Majesty to seize the moment before the enemy’s lairs are fortified, personally lead the Six Armies north across the river, and rally the troops’ morale—then the Central Plains may yet be reclaimed." For overstepping his rank in submitting this memorial, he was stripped of his post and returned home. He then sought out Zhang Suo, who placed Yue Fei in command of the central army. Zhang Suo asked, "How many enemies can you defeat?" Yue Fei replied, "Bravery alone is unreliable; victory lies in planning. The Han general Le Yi feigned retreat with firewood to lure the Xiongnu into an ambush, while Mozi prevented the siege of Song by sending woodcutters to the enemy—both were cases of premeditated strategy." Zhang Suo nodded in approval and said, "You are no mere soldier." He appointed Yue Fei as *Wu Jing Lang*.

**Record:** Observing how Zong Ze and Zhang Suo recognized Yue Fei’s talent, one sees why, during the Jingkang era, when Zhang Suo sent wax-sealed letters through enemy lines to recruit troops, the people of Hebei rejoiced, saying, "Though the court has abandoned us, we still have a censor like Zhang who can employ men of ability." Those who answered the call numbered nearly 170,000. Zong Ze, as defender of the Eastern Capital, planned to cross the river at Huazhou in the summer, seize Huai, Wei, Jun, and Xiang provinces, and advance along multiple routes. The loyal and righteous people of the mountains responded in the millions. Yet Huang Qianshan and Wang Boyan treated the very foundation of the state as if it were beyond concern.

Yet Yue Fei’s overstepping of his rank was precisely the fulfillment of duty by these two men. Had there been one like Gaozu who heeded Xiao He’s counsel and embraced Deng Yu’s strategies, would he not have been counted among the founders of great merit? Instead, burdened with measureless wisdom and courage, he met the same fate as those who cast their lots blindly. The gentleman may only lament the fortune or misfortune of such men, not the clarity or blindness of the emperor or his ministers.

Zhao Ding and Zhang Jun both served as Left and Right *Shangshu Pushe*, concurrently overseeing the Bureau of Military Affairs and commanding the armies of all circuits. At the time, Ding and Jun enjoyed great harmony. When their appointments were announced, Yu Chu, a collator of the Historiography Institute, came to Zhang’s gate and said: "The two of you should first serve together in the Bureau of Military Affairs. Later, when Zhao retires, Zhang may succeed him. In matters of governance and personnel, if your approaches are not too divergent, your influence will endure. But if you share the same office and later disagree—even if one of you must resign—it will inevitably lead to reversal. Thus, the worthy will turn against one another." The outcome later proved Chu’s words true.

The Record states: In observing Yu Zicun’s predictions of events, one may call them largely accurate. When Xiao passed and Cao rose, when Bing preceded and Wei followed, when Fang devised plans and Du made decisions, when Chong initiated change and Jing established laws—though they were said to harmonize in heart and share virtue, in truth, they carried forward excellence and trod in fragrant footsteps. Thus, the Dao and virtue flowed endlessly, and their achievements and merits endured through the ages. These are what later generations look up to with admiration.

As for Ding and Jun, though they claimed to govern with upright hearts and lofty aspirations, their resolve fixed on the public good, one sees how a single word from Fei led to discord, and how deep trust was withdrawn due to Kui’s deceptive appearance. This shows they had not truly forgotten self-interest or cultivated a mind free of ego. How, then, could they have avoided turning against one another? In the end, petty grievances from others gave rise to their mutual disharmony. Zicun’s words were not without proof. Thus, they are recorded here.

Han Shizhong, chastened by the affair of Yue Fei, thereupon returned to the state the million strings of cash, ninety thousand *shi* of grain, and fifteen wine storehouses he had accumulated as military provisions. He submitted a memorial requesting retirement. From then on, he shut his gates to visitors and never spoke of military matters. At times, he would ride a donkey, carrying wine and accompanied by one or two servant boys, roaming freely among the lakes and mountains for his own enjoyment.

Few of his generals and aides ever saw his face in ordinary times. When he first fell ill, the court urgently sent physicians to treat him, but Shizhong said: “I rose from common cloth to fight through a hundred battles, attaining the rank of duke. By the grace of Heaven’s spirit, I have kept my head and limbs intact. Why should you gentlemen still mourn my death?” He once admonished his family, saying: “My name is Shizhong. Let none of you avoid the word *zhong* [loyalty]. To avoid it in speech is to forget loyalty.” He had particularly opposed the peace negotiations, incurring much of Qin Hui’s resentment. When others urged him to desist, he replied: “Today, fear of disaster makes compliance easy. But when I close my eyes in death, how could I bear to face the iron staff of the Grand Progenitor in the underworld?” At the time, most great generals curried favor with Qin Hui to seek temporary safety. Though Shizhong and Qin Hui served together in government, they exchanged nothing beyond a single bow, never speaking. The weapons and armor he designed were of unparalleled precision. He knew men well and rewarded them generously, so his subordinates remained steadfast in their loyalty. Though he lay at home for a decade, stripped of his banner and staff, he remained composed and at ease, as if he had never held power or rank.

It is recorded: The joys of lakes and mountains were, for Shizhong, a mark of wisdom, yet for the noble man, they are deemed unworthy. Why? Since King Goujian of Yue slept on brushwood and tasted gall, only then did Wu perish.

Since the wanton southern expeditions of the late capital’s Jing Dynasty, the Song began its fall—all witnessed firsthand. How could it be that rulers did not set their hearts on avenging humiliation and eliminating villains, while their ministers instead made it their business to resent merit and envy ability? Thus, heroic generals were turned into sycophantic courtiers, scheming only for self-preservation. Was there any other choice?

Though they resisted the peace negotiations, their words remained empty, never put into action. Then did the spirits of the successive sagely emperors in heaven know of this—or did they not?

During the Battle of Shunchang, Liu Qi recruited two men, Cao Cheng and another, to serve as spies. They feigned falling from their horses upon encountering the enemy and were captured. Wumu asked, “What sort of man is Qi?” They replied, “A frontier commander in peacetime, fond of singing girls. The court, seeking harmony between the two nations, stationed him in the Eastern Capital merely to indulge in leisure.” Wumu laughed and said, “This will be easy to crush.” The next day, he arrived beneath the city walls and rebuked his generals for their losses. They all said, “The Southern Court’s military prowess is not what it once was.” Wuzhu refused to believe them, and Qi advanced his troops.

His officers urged him to strike Han Chang’s army first, but Qi said, “Even if we drive Wumu back by defeating Han, his elite troops will remain, and we cannot withstand them. Our strategy must be to strike Wumu first. Once he moves, the rest will be powerless.” At the time, Wumu wore a white robe, discarded his armor and horse, and led three thousand elite troops into battle. These men wore heavy lamellar armor and iron helmets, called the “Iron Pagodas.” Qi used spears to knock off their helmets and axes to sever their arms. There were also the “Crutch Horses,” known as the Ever-Victorious Army, which were likewise broken in this battle.

In this engagement, Qi’s forces numbered no more than twenty thousand, with only five thousand deployed in combat. Yet through premeditated strategy, undistracted by the counsel of other generals, and refusing to be misled by past victories or overconfidence, he triumphed with the few against the many, the rested against the weary. Thus did he achieve success.

Hong Hao secretly memorialized from Jin that the victory at Shunchang had struck terror into the enemy, who now considered abandoning the lands south of Yan. He wrote that if the various generals had united at that moment, advancing along separate routes, Wumu could have been captured and Bianjing recovered. Yet the imperial armies hastily withdrew, squandering the opportunity—truly a pity.

It is recorded: The *Art of War* states that a general must possess wisdom, trustworthiness, benevolence, courage, and strictness; lacking even one, he is unfit. Wisdom stands foremost. This is why Liu Qi achieved victory at Shunchang, and even the mediocre would leap for joy at such a triumph.

By then, the peace accords were already concluded—like an examination essay barely worth glancing at. Beyond this, all was a realm of forced compromise. What further opportunities remained?

Wang Lixin, serving as Pacification Commissioner Along the Yangtze in Jiangling, memorialized to strengthen the garrison at Anlu Prefecture, warning that frontier defenses should not be depleted. He proposed three measures:

First, all troops from the inner provinces should be deployed to reinforce the outer defenses. With over seven hundred thousand soldiers available, the old, weak, and unfit—two out of every seven—should be weeded out, leaving a select force of over five hundred thousand. The Yangtze defenses, spanning no more than seven thousand *li*, should be garrisoned at intervals of a hundred *li*, each post under a commander. Ten posts would form a prefecture, each with an overseer. At critical points, troop numbers should be doubled or tripled. In peacetime, patrols would sail the Huai River, maintaining vigilance; in war, they would strike east and west, combining offense and defense, with watchtowers signaling and supplies flowing uninterrupted, forming a linked and mutually reinforcing formation. A royal prince of the imperial clan and a capable, loyal minister should be appointed as supreme commanders, dividing authority between eastern and western prefectures to achieve the unity of a coiled serpent. This is the highest strategy.

Second, the prolonged detention of envoys benefits us nothing, merely giving the enemy pretext for delay. They should be sent home with courtesy, and annual tribute offered to postpone hostilities. Within two or three years, the frontier would stabilize, defenses strengthen, and fresh troops grow in number, enabling both offense and defense. This is the middle strategy.

Jia Sidao cast the memorial to the ground, declaring, “Mad bandit! How dare you speak such treason!” He then used legal pretexts to dismiss Wang from office.

Later, after Jia Sidao’s military defeat, Wang was recalled as Pacification Commissioner and ordered to recruit troops in Jiankang to reinforce the Yangtze commanderies. He set out at once and encountered Jia Sidao at Wuhu. Jia patted Wang’s back and said, “Had I heeded your words, this would not have happened.”

Upon reaching Jiankang, the garrison had already collapsed, and Yuan forces surrounded the city on all sides. Wang, realizing the situation was hopeless, sighed, “I lived as a Song minister; I shall die as a Song ghost.”

When someone relayed Wang’s two strategies to Boyan, the latter sighed and said, “Had the Song possessed such a man and truly employed him, how could I have come to this?”

It is recorded: Mencius said, “One without a sense of right and wrong is not human.” By then, the Yangtze strategy had already descended to the lowest plan—like a man with a scorched head and blistered face, not a moment to spare. To call this madness is to ask: had he truly lost his mind?

Yet Jia Sidao was not mad. He was merely intoxicated by poison, steeped in corruption to the point of no return—no longer human. Heaven would use the hand of Zheng Huchen to expose his treasonous crimes, leaving him no choice but to meet this end.

*The Record of Illustrious Ministers of the August Ming* states: Liu Ji, Earl of Chengyi, was a man of fervent intelligence, versed in astronomy. While staying in Hangzhou, he once strolled by West Lake when a strange cloud arose in the northwest, its light shimmering upon the water. His companions took it for an auspicious cloud and composed poems on the theme, but Liu drank deeply and said, “This is the *qi* of an emperor, destined for Jinling. In ten years, a true king shall rise, and I shall serve him.”

When the Grand Progenitor seized Jinhua and pacified Kuocang, Liu pointed to the celestial signs and told his confidants, “This is the Mandate of Heaven. How could mere human effort achieve it?”

Indeed, an envoy was dispatched to extend an invitation. Liu then took a secret route to Jinling, where he presented eighteen strategies on current affairs. At the time, the Chen clan had launched an invasion, and some schemed to surrender the city, while others, noting that Zhongshan bore the *qi* of a king, sought to flee and occupy it. Liu alone declared: “In my judgment, nothing is better than emptying the treasury, opening our hearts with utmost sincerity, and thus securing the loyalty of our soldiers. Moreover, the Dao of Heaven favors those who act last—we should lie in ambush, wait for an opening, and strike. Seizing authority to subdue the enemy and establishing the royal enterprise—this is the moment for it.” The Emperor accordingly adopted Liu’s strategy, launching an attack with the wind at their backs. The ambush succeeded, and the enemy was slaughtered without count.

When the Secretariat set up an imperial throne to honor the Young Ming King, Liu angrily rebuked them, saying: “That herdsman—why honor him?” He refused to bow, declaring that the Mandate of Heaven lay elsewhere. The Emperor, moved by his words, resolved upon a campaign of conquest.

When Hu Junmei, the defending general of Hongdu, sent his son to negotiate surrender, the Emperor initially hesitated. Liu, standing behind him, kicked the leg of the Emperor’s folding chair, signaling his approval. Hu Junmei then surrendered the city.

Later, the Emperor repeatedly sought to appoint Liu as prime minister, but Liu declined, saying: “The office of prime minister is a weighty responsibility for the state. It is like replacing a pillar—only the greatest talent will suffice; if one binds small timbers together, collapse will come swiftly. Though I am not unaware of my own abilities, my hatred of evil runs too deep, and I cannot endure the burdens of the post. To accept would be to betray the great favor shown me.” The Emperor thus held Liu in even higher esteem, addressing him as “Elder Master” without using his name, and saying: “He is my Zhang Liang.”

Liu once wrote a book, fearing he would not live to see its completion, and left it to the world, hoping that later generations would take its intent to heart and apply it themselves. Thus, Liu’s achievements are fully set forth in his writings—this is why the Yuan fell. And his writings are manifest in his achievements—this is why the August Ming rose. The acceptance or rejection of a single man bears such weight upon the realm and the state.

The *Record* states: Yang Wenyi once remarked: “Zhang Liang’s strategies are not found in literary compositions, and Fang Xuanling’s writings consist merely of memorials and official documents, with no manifestos or proclamations to be seen. To possess the merit of founding a dynasty while also leaving behind writings for posterity—Liu may be called the hero of a thousand ages.”

Some question his service to the Yuan, while others praise only his observations of celestial phenomena. This is like criticizing Yi Yin for his five submissions or reducing the Duke of Zhou to his talents and skills alone. In my view, Liu’s refusal of the prime minister’s post is clear evidence of his sagely wisdom. The world deemed no one superior to him, yet he humbly saw himself as lacking—his superiority over others was vast, far beyond those who rely on cunning and schemes.

During the Yongle and Xuande reigns, the eminent ministers were known as the Three Yangs: Yang Wenjing of the West, Yang Wenmin of the East, and Yang Wending of the South. Yang Wenmin was naturally bright and quick-witted, possessing decisive talent. Whenever court matters arose and eunuchs were sent to the Grand Secretariat for deliberation, they would invariably ask: “Is the Eastern Yang Master present?” If told he was not, they would return at once. Yet in discussions, he never failed to defer to others. If Yang Wenjing insisted something could not be done, the matter would ultimately be decided by Yang Wenmin, who would resolve it with such clarity that no obstacles remained.

Each autumn, when the emperor ordered civil and military officials to review cases of serious offenders, all from the Duke of Ying downward would defer to the Two Yang Masters for judgment. Yang Wenjing would examine the cases but never render a decision; when matters became irresolvable, Yang Wenmin would ask a single question and settle them, leaving all in awe.

At the time, the sovereign was martial and heroic. Few among the assembled ministers could satisfy him in their memorials and responses, but he cherished Yang Wending’s talent and never let him leave his side for a day. The most confidential plans and strategies invariably involved him. When major ministers deliberated on unresolved matters and the Emperor grew displeased—even to the point of anger—Yang Wending’s arrival would calm his wrath, and the matter would proceed smoothly.

Yang Wending once said to Xia Zhongzhao, the Minister of Rites: “I have often deeply regretted seeing ministers who, by resisting with unbending integrity, brought disaster upon themselves. There is a proper way to serve a ruler, and a proper way to offer remonstrance. For example, if the Emperor reads the *Thousand-Character Classic* and says, ‘Heaven and Earth, dark and red,’ one should not immediately correct him. How can one know he is not testing me? And how can one know what is truly on his mind? Wait until he repeats it, or asks a question, then respond: ‘In my youth, I read the *Thousand-Character Classic*, which says, “Heaven and Earth, dark and yellow”—I do not know if this is correct.’ His wisdom was generally of this kind.”

Li Shimian later added: “Before Yang Wenjing entered office, he and Wu Youweng, a tutor to the Prince of Chu, had been implicated in a treasonous plot. Youweng told me: ‘Master Yang was broadly learned and wise, upright yet sensitive, generous and kind, perceptive in understanding affairs, and never arrogant or dismissive of others. Once he entered the inner court and took charge of state affairs, his fairness and magnanimity, his tolerance and discipline, were all directed solely toward the state, never toward private gain. When facing major policies or resolving great doubts, while others argued endlessly, he alone remained unshaken. After a long silence, he would offer a single word, and all would be subdued and convinced. If public opinion was divided and required the Emperor’s attention, once it was presented, the Emperor would ultimately follow Master Yang’s counsel. In the Emperor’s presence, he spoke his mind on all matters, regardless of personal advantage or harm. When evaluating talent or correcting others’ faults, he acted with impartiality, never weighing favor or enmity in his judgments. In recommending the worthy and rejecting the unfit, he possessed the power to turn the heavens and shift the earth—yet he never boasted of it. The duties of a great minister and prime minister are evident in such conduct.’”

The *Record* states: In my view, the circumstances of the Three Yangs were no different from those of earlier eras. In the records of today, one sees the spirit of Fang Xuanling and Du Ruhui’s deference; in the annals of the Eastern Waters, the dynamic of Chen Ping and Zhou Bo’s rise from obscurity; and in their collected writings, the foundational principles of Han Qi and Fan Zhongyan’s conduct. How wise were these men, who emerged from darkness into light, built merit, and established great deeds!

The *Record* concludes: Chen Yi, the Earl of Pingjiang, was resourceful and strategically astute. During the Jingnan Campaign, when the imperial army reached the north bank of the Yangzi, Chen, recognizing where the Mandate of Heaven had settled, led his naval forces to welcome and ferry them across. He was enfeoffed as Earl of Pingjiang.

At the time, the military provisions in Beijing were insufficient, so the court commanded him to oversee the annual transport of a million *shi* of grain, conveyed by sea. He established the Million-*Shi* Granary at Zhigu, constructed the walled city of Tianjin Garrison, and registered ten thousand soldiers to defend it. Along the sea islands through which the transport routes passed, the barbarian tribes, struck with awe, all hid themselves. He issued orders allowing them to come forth for trade, dispatching officials to supervise and maintain fairness. No one dared to cause disturbance, and both sides found it convenient.

After Beijing was established as the capital, sea transport was abolished. He proposed the construction of two thousand shallow-draft barges, initially transporting two million *shi* annually, later increasing to five million *shi*. He dredged the Qingjiang and Pu waterways, channeling water from Guanjia Lake into Yachenkou to reach the Huai River, thereby avoiding the perils of wind and waves on the outer river. Along Guanjia Lake, he built a ten-*li* embankment to facilitate the passage of boats. He cleared the silted tidal inlets of the Yizhen and Guazhou dams, leveled the massive rocks of the Lüliang and Xuzhou rapids to calm the water flow, constructed long dikes at Diaoyang Lake in Pei County and Nanwang Lake in Jining, opened the Baita River in Taizhou to connect with the Yangzi, and built dikes along Gaoyou Lake. Within the dikes, he dredged a forty-*li* canal to allow boat passage, constructing bridges north and south for ease of travel.

From the Huai River to Linqing, he surveyed the water levels and built forty-seven locks, timing their opening and closing to ensure perpetual navigation. He also established 568 stations along the river, each staffed with guides to assist shallow-water passage, and dug wells and planted trees along the embankments for travelers’ convenience. Every consideration was thorough, and every undertaking was decisive.

The *Record* states: At that time, when north and south were not yet connected, Heaven in its bounty raised an extraordinary man by the aid of the Yangzi. Though one might wish to dispense with the mountains and rivers, how could they be set aside? Alas! He began with the enfeoffment of Pingjiang and ended with renown for his river-crossing feats. As the *Book* says: "To cross a great river, I employ you as my boat and oar." These words were no falsehood. Thus, his temple sacrifices were held in assembly, and his offerings of blood and flesh never ceased—surely for this reason.

Zhou Chen, Duke Wenxiang, initially passed the imperial examinations and was selected as a bachelor of the Hanlin Academy, among twenty-eight men including Zeng Cai. He personally petitioned to join their studies. Emperor Taizong rejoiced, saying, "This is a man of true ambition," and ordered his inclusion.

Later, he served as Vice Minister of Works and Grand Coordinator of the Southern Metropolitan Region for twenty-two years. Profoundly astute and wise, he was humble and courteous, rarely speaking harshly, yet his plans and considerations were far-reaching, and he excelled at gathering diverse opinions. For every policy he implemented, he first consulted the common folk, elders, and local officials before making decisions. He had an exceptional memory, even for details. Once, a cunning man attempted to deceive him with several fabricated grievances. He said, "You were already compensated for that matter in such-and-such a place. Why do you speak of it again?" When officials concealed tax grain, he would say, "In such-and-such a year, so much was allocated there; in another year, so much was retained." Verifying the records confirmed his words, and the officials, astonished, acknowledged his uncanny precision.

Initially, Suzhou’s tax grain was in arrears by over 7.9 million *shi*, and the same was true for Changshu and Songjiang. Repeatedly dispatched officials pressed for payment, but the situation remained unresolved. Upon his arrival, he inquired of the elders, who explained that in Suzhou and Songjiang, the wealthy households did not pay the additional surcharge, burdening the smaller households with the shortfall. He then mandated that all households, large and small, pay the surcharge equally. He memorialized the throne, and the Southern Capital cast iron measuring vessels to ensure fairness. He also abolished the old practice of allowing local organizations to collect grain.

He said, "This is the reason for the arrears." He then ordered each county to appoint a single overseer at the water’s edge, called the *zong*. Collection standards and surcharges were fixed, and after fulfilling transport quotas, any surplus grain stored in the granaries was designated as "reserve rice." The following year, the surcharge was adjusted based on the previous year’s surplus. After meeting transport quotas, any remaining surplus was stored in newly constructed granaries called "Aid-the-Farmer" granaries. This grain was used for famine relief, or lent to farmers in need or transport workers who suffered from wind damage or theft, to be repaid in kind at harvest. All official textile production and military provisions were drawn from these reserves. Thus, beyond the annual tax of one *shi* and five *dou*, the people saw no additional corvée labor, and officials no longer imposed extortionate demands.

He repaired and dredged the temples of former worthies in county schools, as well as bridges and waterways in various prefectures, all funded by the surplus grain. The people competed to erect living shrines in his honor, and after his death, he was enshrined and worshipped.

Later, the Ministry of Revenue reported that the Aid-the-Farmer surplus grain had gone unaccounted for and dispatched officials to reclaim it entirely for the state. Thereafter, miscellaneous levies proliferated, and tax arrears returned as before. The people longed for him all the more.

The *Record* states: Minister Wang Wenke, discussing Censor-in-Chief He Yin, said: "Wealth is born of the earth, completed by Heaven, but its governance lies with man. When governance has method, insufficiency becomes abundance; when it lacks method, abundance becomes insufficiency. Its expansion and contraction, gain and loss, all depend on the person. As for Wenxiang, he was truly such a man." Thus, he often cited him as a model for grand coordinators.

In former times, the prefectures of Jiangnan suffered frequent shortages in both public and private stores. Yet in recent years, bountiful harvests followed one another, and grain overflowed. Had one investigated the cause, it would have been found in human effort, not the timing of Heaven. During Grand Coordinator He’s tenure, Jiangnan faced a great famine. He submitted twelve strategies for famine relief, securing 800,000 *shi* of grain from military provisions, local reserves, and official salaries. Thus, every prefecture in Jiangnan was well-supplied, and the court approved the dredging of Wusong and Baimao Port. When funds were lacking, he requested that military provisions be redirected, using 280,000 *shi* of grain without waste. Upon completion of the project, the southeast was free from water disasters.

To attribute the abundance or scarcity of the harvest solely to the timing of Heaven—can this be right? What is meant by "turning insufficiency into surplus" is not this. Such was the wisdom of Wenzheng, which is still remembered today.

The Suzhou Prefect Kuang Zhong began as a minor clerk serving Minister Lü Zhen. Impressed by his talent, Lü recommended him for the position of Director in the Bureau of Ceremonies under the Ministry of Rites, later promoting him to Gentleman of the Ministry. At the beginning of Renzong’s reign, an edict commanded all officials of the fifth rank and above in the capital to recommend those they knew. Kuang Zhong thus recommended Zhang Zongkuang of the Left Spring Pavilion. Renzong summoned Yang Shiqi and asked, "Everyone recommends low-ranking officials from distant prefectures—why has Kuang Zhong recommended one of my palace officials?" Yang Shiqi replied, "Wang Zhi and I had intended to recommend him, but he has unexpectedly beaten us to it." Renzong exclaimed with delight, "That Kuang Zhong recognizes Zongkuang’s worth—this truly marks him as a man of virtue." For he had already intended to employ him.

When Xuanzong ascended the throne, his ministers memorialized that Suzhou, a vast and complex prefecture, was difficult to govern. Kuang Zhong was thus promoted to Prefect.

Upon arrival, he dismissed five corrupt and oppressive subordinate officials and over ten incompetent and weak ones. He then conferred with Inspector Zhou to study methods for grain collection. Since the Yongle era, grain had been transported to Beijing, but the supply route to Liaodong was long. For every *shi* of grain levied, three were collected, so that the prefecture’s 2,700,000 *shi* became 8,100,000 *shi*. After deducting the regular tribute and the costs of ceremonial vessels and transport, the surplus was concealed by the grain chiefs. Kuang thus proposed establishing separate grain heads to divide their power, abolishing one-third of the old triple levy and designating the remaining two-thirds as transport fees. The rest of the grain was stored in the *Jinong* Granary to serve as capital for the following year’s expenditures.

That year, tens of thousands of *shi* of horse fodder and grain, tens of thousands of *jin* of summer tax cloth and silk, tens of thousands of bolts of silk fabric, and tens of thousands of *shi* of wheat were all paid using surplus grain. All miscellaneous expenses were also procured with these reserves. The court did not miss its tax deadlines, nor did the people bear the slightest burden. In times of drought or disaster, he promptly distributed relief, saving hundreds of thousands of lives each time. His beneficence extended endlessly to the poor and destitute.

When his nine-year term ended, over 80,000 people of the prefecture besieged the palace gates to petition for his retention, and he was thus sent to serve a second term. Later, he died of illness, and the people vied to establish shrines in his honor.

**Record states:** The depletion of resources in Suzhou and Songjiang before this time—where great households avoided surcharges—was perhaps of this kind. At the time, the court had a sovereign like Renzong and ministers like Wenxiang; Kuang’s wisdom and kindness were like a goose feather borne on a favorable wind. Had it not been so, a minor clerk daring to act would have been outmaneuvered by the grand ministers of the court; a mere prefect securing the support of 80,000 petitioners would have faced opposition from court deliberations. It would have been difficult to escape such a fate in the world of today. Thus, it is recorded.

*Hongdao Record*, Scroll Forty—end.

**Hongdao Record, Scroll Forty-One: Wisdom – The Wisdom of Father and Son**

From the *Canon of Yao*: The Emperor said, “Whom shall I consult to ascend the throne?”
Fang Qi replied, “Your son Zhu is enlightened.”
The Emperor said, “Alas! Is one so litigious and perverse fit for this?”

**Record states:** This was the unique insight of a great sage, surpassing all ages. Here, he decisively chose to transmit the throne to the worthy rather than to his son. The distinction between sagacity and folly lies in the subtlest of margins. A nature inclined toward clarity approaches the mind of the Dao, yet if it is not wholly aligned with heavenly principle, its expression in speech will inevitably descend into contention. Thus, the sage adjudicates between principle and desire at the finest of lines. If even the slightest deviation occurs, one may mistake clarity for wisdom and contention for talent—how much more so with the coarseness of Dan Zhu or the wickedness of the Emperor’s son? If such were the standard, later ages would still see those whose intelligence resists remonstrance, whose words gloss over faults, and who believe all under heaven inferior to themselves. By this measure, Zhu was already above ten thousand men.

From the *Records of the Grand Historian*: Emperor Yi of the Shang had three sons. The eldest was Weizi Qi, the second Zhonghang, and the youngest Shou Xin—who was none other than King Zhou. Zhou’s mother was a virtuous queen, and when Zhou was still young, Emperor Yi and the queen wished to appoint Qi as crown prince. The Grand Historian, citing the law, objected: “The son of a wife cannot be passed over in favor of the son of a concubine.” Thus, Zhou was made heir.

**Record states:** Emperor Yi’s decision was an ill fate for the Shang, yet perhaps it was also the ordained end of Heaven’s mandate. The Grand Historian’s objection was the just law of the realm. At the time, Zhou’s mother was virtuous and her son still young—how could Emperor Yi have foreseen the kingdom’s ruin and preemptively altered the succession? Later cases, such as those of Fusu and Yang Yong, were truly failures of human counsel. Moreover, the Shang abandoned Weizi despite his inability to inherit, while the Zhou went further with Taibo and Boyi Kao, both passing over the eldest to enthrone the younger. Was this not the work of Heaven’s mandate?

King Gu of the Zhou had three sons: the eldest Taibo, the second Zhongyong, and the youngest Jili. Jili married Tairen, a woman of virtue and wisdom, who bore Chang, marked by auspicious omens. King Gu said, “Our line is destined to rise—surely it will be through Chang.” Taibo and Zhongyong, perceiving their father’s intent to enthrone Jili and thus transmit the throne to Chang, fled to the Jing barbarians, tattooing their bodies and cutting their hair to signal their withdrawal from succession. After King Gu’s death, Jili ascended as Duke Ji. Duke Ji upheld his father’s legacy, devoted to righteousness, and the feudal lords submitted to him. Upon his death, his son Chang succeeded him as the Western Earl.

**Record states:** The hexagram *Sheng* (Ascending) is yielding yet compliant, firm yet centered, thus achieving great success. From King Gu onward, the Zhou ascended through sincerity, with Taibo and Zhongyong responding in faithful submission below. Thus, Duke Ji’s rise to his empty domain met no obstruction, culminating in the Western Earl’s founding of the royal enterprise—was this mere chance? Had King Tai lacked the clarity of trust and compliance, or had Taibo lacked the wisdom of yielding response, Chang’s dragon-like virtue and centered strength would have been of no avail. This shows that King Wen’s *Book of Changes* was rooted in his family’s tradition and embodied experience. The line, “The king offers sacrifice on Mount Qi,” was no empty claim—how could it lack verification?

In the *Kong Congzi*, Duke Mu asked Zisi: “Is there a fixed rule for appointing a crown prince?”
Zisi replied, “There is.”
The Duke said, “In the past, King Wen passed over his eldest to enthrone his second son, while Weizi passed over his grandson to appoint his younger brother—what law governed this?”
Zisi said, “The Shang valued substance and honored the most venerable, hence they appointed the younger brother. The Zhou valued refinement and cherished kinship, hence they appointed the son. Each followed its own rites. Though substance and refinement differ, their rites vary accordingly. King Wen’s passing over the eldest to appoint the second was an exercise of discretion.”
The Duke said, “If discretion may be exercised, is it only sages who may appoint the worthy or beloved?”
Zisi replied, “Sages do not teach discretion, so they establish systems and bequeath laws, prizing compliance. If one insists on violating these, what difference remains? The distinction is clear.”
The Duke said, “Is it better to pass over the worthy to appoint the sagely, or the foolish to appoint the worthy?”
Zisi replied, “Only a sage appoints the sagely—was this not King Wen? Those lesser than King Wen each favor their beloved, making no distinction between them and the eldest. How can they be constrained? If they cannot discern the difference between the worthy and the foolish, let them consult their fathers, elder brothers, ministers, and divine in the ancestral temple—this, too, is a permissible exercise of discretion.”
**Record states:** These are the words of a great worthy, precisely targeting the failings of humanity—unalterable for ten thousand generations. Yao’s son was enlightened, and Shun’s son embodied yielding virtue. Without the utmost sagacity, who could pass over one to appoint the other? How much more so for later ages, where blind affection prevails? Without fixed limits, if discretion is left to individuals, the resulting calamities would be beyond reckoning. As for divination, though the ancients did not abandon it, it was a last resort of discretion, not the attainment of wisdom.

From the *Zuozhuan*: The Marquis of Jin rewarded those who had followed him in exile. Jie Zhitui did not speak of reward, and thus received none. He said, “Of Duke Xian’s nine sons, only the lord remains. Hui and Huai were devoid of kinship, spurned within and without. Heaven has not yet severed Jin’s line—there must be a master. Who but the lord could preside over Jin’s sacrifices? Heaven established him, yet these few gentlemen claim it as their own achievement—is this not a deception? To steal another’s wealth is called theft—how much worse to covet Heaven’s merit! Below, they justify their crimes; above, they are rewarded for their treachery. With superiors and inferiors deceiving one another, how can one dwell among them?”
His mother said, “Why not also seek reward? To die—whom would you blame?”
He replied, “To imitate their faults would be an even greater crime. Moreover, I have spoken resentful words—how could I consume his food?”

His mother said, “Then at least let him know—what would be the harm?”
He replied, “Speech is the ornament of the person. If one’s person is about to withdraw from the world, why adorn it with words? That would be seeking renown.”
His mother said, “If you can be thus, I shall withdraw with you.”
Thereupon they went into hiding and died.
The Lord of Jin sought them in vain and made Mianshang a field in their memory, saying, “To mark my error and to honor a man of virtue.”

It is recorded: When Jie of Mianshang abandoned his lands, was he not wiser than those who opened Nanyang for Jin? In the troubles at Wen, Heaven had not yet turned from the Zhou. Zidai’s impiety and want of filial devotion meant his ruin could not be long delayed—how the Earl of Qin counted it his achievement! Yet Lord Wen appropriated it as his own, differing from the beggar who merely sought a single draught of ale. As for the hardships endured in the wilderness, those nineteen years were not the work of a single morning or evening. Jie declined office and received no emolument—could he have sought it through royal decree? Though the recluse conceals his person, his name becomes renowned. How noble was Master Jie! Had he not acted thus, he would have been clad in enmity and waited upon by thieves—could he truly have remained silent? To speak would have been to grovel before eunuchs and lackeys—no wonder Master Jie chose silence.

The mother of Jin’s Shu Xiang, like the mother of Tuo Shu Hu, saw beauty but would not allow it. Both sons remonstrated with her. She said, “In the depths of mountains and marshes, dragons and serpents are born. That beauty—it makes me fear she would bear dragons and snakes, bringing calamity upon you.” She sent someone to observe her in sleep, and she gave birth to Shu Hu, who was handsome and possessed great strength. Duke Huai of Yue delighted in him, and so he returned to face peril. When Shu Xiang wished to marry the daughter of Shen’s Lord Wu Chen, his mother said, “The wife of Ziling brought three husbands, one lord, and one son to servitude, and destroyed one state and two ministers. Should we not take warning?” I have heard it said: extreme beauty must harbor extreme evil.

This was the son of Zheng Mu’s lesser consort, Lady Yao, and the younger sister of Zi Mo. Zi Mo died young without an heir, and Heaven concentrated beauty in her, surely intending thereby to bring great harvest. Shu Xiang feared and dared not marry her, but Duke Ping forcibly compelled him to do so, and she bore Bo Shi. When Bo Shi was first born, the mother of Zi Rong hastened to inform the aunts, saying, “Elder Shu Si has given birth to a boy—come, aunts, and see him.” When she reached the hall, she heard his cry and turned back, saying, “That is the voice of a jackal or wolf. A wolf cub has a wild heart; if not this, nothing will destroy the Yang She clan.” And so she refused to look at him.

It is recorded: In my foolish view, the wisdom of the mother of the Yang She clan is worthy of much praise; one ought not to slight her merely because she was a mother-in-law. When the age above is sagely, the means by which it is perfected lie far back; when within there is a worthy consort, the aid she provides runs deep. If one is to serve the age with perspicacious virtue and upright conduct, this is the thread upon which it hangs—how much more so when one slays Heaven’s favored son, calling him a man who would ruin state and family? In a well-ordered age, criminals are not taken as wives; here, one may say, judgment failed. Her vast learning and wide hearing were but the chaff and husk of knowledge.

Thus the noble man must devote himself to sincerity of intention and rectitude of heart, cultivating the self and ordering the household, not permitting the slightest laxity or the least carelessness. Proceeding thus to beget and rear descendants, there will be none who are not good.

In the *Guo Yu*, Qi Xi declined the post of military commander. The Duke asked him, saying, “Who is fit for the position?” He replied, “My son Wu is fit.” Someone said, “In choosing ministers, none is better than the ruler; in choosing a son, none is better than the father.” When Wu was young, he was gentle and obedient, moving among ministers and dwelling in his place; he loved learning and did not play. In his prime, he was strong of purpose and followed commands, guarding his inheritance without excess. When he came of age, he was harmonious and tranquil, reverent and kind to small things, while steady in great matters; he had an upright nature and no wayward heart, changing only for righteousness and advancing only at his superior’s behest. If faced with great affairs, he would surely surpass his father. I ask to recommend one whom I can choose, and whom Your Lordship may judge by righteousness. The Duke then appointed Qi Wu as military commander, and throughout Duke Ping’s reign, the army was without misgovernance.

It is recorded: In my foolish view, Qi Xi’s words differ not at all from the teachings of today’s humble scholars to their sons. From youth to prime to coming of age, his description exhausts every aspect—how perfectly a man may be as heir and successor! Today, when people see a young scion—radiant as jade, resplendent as coral—who does not love and admire him? Yet they do not know how he is nurtured in ease, refined and polished, nor how earnestly his heart is devoted. If by good fortune he becomes like Wu, joyful and without reproach, or like Xi, impartial and without suspicion, then between father and son, affection is as boundless as Heaven and Earth, illumination as bright as the sun and moon—how could it be merely a matter of one military command?

Yet observe the flourishing age of Jin: when Zhao Wenzhi was orphaned, he brought things to abundant completion; when Fan Wenzhi was retiring, he elevated reverence and deference. But in its decline, one like Bo Lu was at a loss for even a single word; another like Zhi Yao, though strong, overawed the Five Worthies. From this, one may see: not only is family fortune at stake, but the fate of the state truly hangs upon it.

Now that the realm is unified and worthy talent is shared in common, how can one fail to devote oneself to prior cultivation?

In the *Comprehensive Mirror*, Zhao Jianzi had two sons: the elder, Bo Lu, and the younger, Wu Xu. Wishing to establish an heir but uncertain whom to appoint, he wrote words of instruction on two tablets and gave them to his sons, commanding them, “Remember them well.” After two years, he questioned them. Bo Lu could not recall a single word; when he sought the tablet, he had already lost it. When he questioned Wu Xu, the latter recited the words with great familiarity; when he sought the tablet, he drew it from his sleeve and presented it. Thereupon Jianzi, deeming Wu Xu worthy, established him as heir.

It is recorded: Was Zhao Jianzi more worthy than Zhi Xuanzhi? The one who picked up the tablet in the night and the one who set it down—how vastly different were their fortunes! The *Yi* says: “Xu means to await. When peril lies ahead, if one is strong and does not fall, its meaning is not to be reduced to straits.” With Xiao’s ferocity written on his face and Yao’s ferocity lodged in his heart, could they not have waited and obtained it? The three families divided Jin, and their power could not coexist; yet they were obstinate and self-willed, falling into unrighteousness—how many days passed before their ruin?

Thus Shang Yang’s tablet was questioned only after three years—this is what is meant by “awaiting at the outskirts, advantage lies in constancy.” Wu Xu’s floodwaters were released only after three boards—this is what is meant by “awaiting at the blood, emerging from the cave.” The ancients’ preparedness for difficulty was thorough indeed; how clearly they sought their own fortune or misfortune!

When Qin attacked Zhao, the King of Zhao sought aid from Qi. Qi said, “You must send the Lord of Chang’an as hostage.” The Queen Dowager refused, and Qi’s army did not advance. The great ministers strongly remonstrated, but the Queen Dowager grew angry, saying, “If anyone again speaks of sending the Lord of Chang’an as hostage, I will surely spit in his face.” Then the Left Minister, Chu Long, wishing to see the Queen Dowager, entered with a fierce demeanor and awaited her. He advanced slowly and apologized, saying, “Your old servant’s feet are afflicted, and I have not been able to see you for a long time. I privately feared that Your Majesty’s person might be suffering.” The Queen Dowager said, “This old woman relies on a palanquin to get about.”

She then asked, “Has your appetite waned at all?”
He replied, “I sustain myself on porridge alone.”
Gradually, the displeasure on the Queen Dowager’s face softened. Then he said, “My youngest son, Shuqi, is the most unworthy, yet I secretly cherish and love him. I humbly wish to fill a vacancy among the Black Attire Guards to protect the royal palace.”
The Queen Dowager said, “Do men also dote on their youngest sons?”
He answered, “Even more than women do.”
The Queen Dowager laughed and said, “Women dote far more.”
He replied, “Your servant privately believes that Your Majesty’s love for the Princess of Yan surpasses that for the Lord of Chang’an.”
The Queen Dowager said, “You are mistaken. It does not compare to my love for the Lord of Chang’an.”
The Left Minister said, “When parents love their children, they plan for their long-term future. I have often heard how Your Majesty sent off the Princess of Yan, holding her heel and weeping, praying at every sacrifice that she would never be sent back. Was this not planning for her lasting welfare, ensuring that her descendants would continue to rule?”
The Queen Dowager said, “Indeed.”
The Left Minister continued, “Now, looking back three generations to the descendants of former Kings of Zhao who were enfeoffed as marquises—do any of their lines remain?”
She said, “None.”
He said, “This shows that misfortune befalls them sooner or later—either in their own lifetimes or in those of their descendants. Is it that the sons of rulers are inherently unworthy when enfeoffed? No. It is because they hold high rank without merit, enjoy lavish stipends without labor. Now, Your Majesty exalts the Lord of Chang’an, bestowing upon him fertile lands and abundant treasures, yet you do not require him to render service to the state. If, one day, the unforeseen should occur, how will the Lord of Chang’an secure his place in Zhao?”
The Queen Dowager said, “Very well. I leave him to your disposal.”
Thereupon, she prepared a hundred chariots for the Lord of Chang’an, who was sent as hostage to Qi. Qi then dispatched its army, and Qin withdrew.

The record states: The Left Minister’s enlightenment of the Queen Dowager and the Four Elders’ pacification of Emperor Hui are both recorded in the *Commentary on the Book of Changes* by Master Cheng of the Yi River. Is this truly the case?
It is not. The Left Minister’s remonstrance was unhurried and gentle, arising from affection and remembrance, never straying from his innate goodness. This is what is meant by “guiding with restraint through the side door to dispel a single deluded thought.” Empress Lü, however, used favors to coerce the virtuous, just as the virtuous later used the Four Elders to coerce the emperor.
