This is what is meant by “soaking a garment to meet an urgent need.” Alas!

Had any man ever held high office yet inspired the realm’s people to crane their necks, longing to die for the heir apparent? Thus the emperor’s compliance with goodness was as effortless as a turning wheel—this was the beauty of his inborn nature. Yet his responses to myriad affairs were often flawed and regrettable—this was the fault of his lack of learning.

The *Biographies of Exemplary Women* records: The mother of Sunshu Ao, prime minister of Chu, was the wife of the magistrate of Sun. When Sunshu Ao was a child, he went out to play and saw a two-headed snake. He killed and buried it, then returned home weeping. His mother asked the reason, and he replied: “I have heard that whoever sees a two-headed snake will die. Today I saw one while playing.” His mother asked: “Where is the snake now?” He answered: “I feared others might see it, so I killed and buried it.” His mother said: “You will not die. One who possesses hidden virtue receives manifest reward. Virtue overcomes misfortune, and benevolence dispels a hundred calamities. Heaven, though high, hears the lowly.” Does not the *Book of Documents* say: “August Heaven shows no partiality; it aids only those who possess virtue”? Be silent, and you will surely rise in Chu.

When he grew up and became prime minister, the noble-minded called Sunshu Ao’s mother one who understood the sequence of Dao and virtue. As the *Book of Songs* says: “The mother was sagely and good”—this is what it means.

The record states: How keen was Sunshu Ao’s mother in her discernment! The boy’s initial words were not necessarily pleasing, yet in a single turn, her bearing was transformed without need for deliberation. That the reward for hidden virtue would come to pass was not yet certain, but her sagely wisdom was unmatched in antiquity. This further confirms that the noble-minded in their intentions must never harm the people or destroy things. If he feared a single snake might bring harm again, how much more should one refrain from wanton violence?

Now consider the wife of Ma Fu Jun She, mother of Zhao Kuo. When Qin attacked Zhao, King Xiaocheng appointed Zhao Kuo as general. His mother said to the king: “Kuo must not be sent.” The king asked: “Why?” She replied: “When I first served his father, he was a general. Those to whom he personally offered meals numbered in the tens, and those he befriended in the hundreds. Whatever gifts of silk and coin the king and the royal clan bestowed, he gave entirely to his officers and soldiers. When they received their orders, they said: ‘Do not ask about household matters.’ Now Kuo, as general, sits stiffly facing forward at court, and none of the military officers dare look up at him. Whatever gold and silk he is given, he takes home and hoards, saying only to look for advantageous fields and estates to purchase. Do you think he is like his father? Father and son are not the same; their natures differ. I beg you not to send him.” The king said: “My decision is already made.” His mother said: “If you still send him, and he proves unworthy, I ask not to be implicated.” After Kuo departed, the Zhao army was indeed defeated, Kuo was killed, and the army was annihilated. Because his mother had forewarned the king, she was ultimately spared punishment.

The record states: That Zhao Kuo was unfit to be a general was known by his father and his mother—only the ruler was ignorant. At that time, the six states, mere wandering souls clinging to breath, brought about their own destruction. Thus they first lost the fundamental sense of right and wrong in their hearts, and in their haste for quick success, had no leisure to turn back and reflect. This is why Mencius deeply sighed: “When Heaven sends calamity, one may still avoid it; when man brings calamity upon himself, there is no escape.”

The *Book of Han* records: The mother of Chen Ying, Marquis of Tangyi. Initially, Ying was the magistrate of Dongyang, where he had long been kind to the people and was known as a man of integrity. During the reign of the Second Emperor of Qin, the young men of Dongyang killed the county magistrate and gathered in the thousands, seeking to appoint a leader. They requested Ying. Ying declined, saying he was incapable, but they insisted and made him their leader, intending to make him king. His mother said: “I have been a daughter-in-law in your family and know that our ancestors were never very noble. Now to suddenly gain such great fame is inauspicious. It would be better to place your troops under another. If the matter succeeds, you may still be enfeoffed as a marquis; if it fails, it will be easy to flee, and you will not be singled out by name.” Ying followed her advice and placed his troops under Xiang Liang, who made him a senior minister. After the Xiang clan was defeated, Ying later joined Han and was indeed enfeoffed as Marquis of Tangyi for his merits.

The mother of Wang Ling, Marquis of Anguo and Chancellor. Ling was originally a powerful figure in his county. When the High Ancestor was still obscure, Ling attended to him in all matters. When the High Ancestor rose in Pei, Ling also gathered a band of several thousand and later submitted to the King of Han, placing his troops under him. At the time, Xiang Yu was Han’s enemy. Having captured Ling’s mother, he placed her in his camp. When Ling’s envoys arrived, they were made to face his mother, who was bound and seated, in an attempt to lure Ling. Later, Ling’s mother sent off the envoys in tears, saying: “Tell Ling to serve the King of Han well. The King of Han is a man of integrity; do not, for my sake, harbor divided loyalties.” Having spoken, she fell upon her sword and died. Later, Ling helped the High Ancestor pacify the realm, rising to the position of Chancellor and being enfeoffed as a marquis. His title was passed down for five generations.

The record states: At this, Fan Zeng should have felt ashamed. That Xiang Yu was unfit to be assisted was known even by women and girls. Alas! This man of over seventy years in life was outdone in wisdom by Chen’s mother and in death was more despised than Wang’s mother. Had Fan Zeng been able to persuade Xiang Yu to honor the agreement to enter the Pass, and to maintain the boundary at Honggou, then the Xiang clan’s sacrifices would not have been cut off. Had he made clear the intent of Heaven’s decree and turned the swords of the dancing blades, he might still have retained the enfeoffment of Xiang Bo. Having lost both opportunities, was his wisdom truly inferior? Yet the insights of the two mothers were straightforward and easy, while Fan Zeng’s task was arduous and difficult. When a noble-minded man encounters times of hardship and adversity, he may be fortunate enough to be employed like these two sons, achieving the reputation of a worthy mother; or unfortunate enough to be like Fan Zeng, bearing the world’s blame in vain.

The *Records of the Historian* states: Zui Cuo was sharp-tongued, forthright, and severely exacting. During the reign of Emperor Wen, he was promoted to Household Administrator of the Heir Apparent for his proposals on expediency. His eloquence won him favor with the heir apparent, who called him the “Bag of Wisdom.” He frequently submitted memorials on reducing the power of the feudal lords and revising laws and ordinances. Emperor Wen did not heed them but admired his talent and promoted him to Palace Grandee.

The heir apparent favored Xiao Cuo’s strategies, and upon ascending the throne, appointed him as Internal Scribe. Xiao frequently sought private audiences to present his proposals, and the emperor invariably heeded them. His favor eclipsed that of the Nine Ministers, and many laws and ordinances were revised at his behest. Chancellor Shentu Jia found this intolerable and repeatedly plotted to execute Xiao, though his schemes failed. Xiao’s influence only grew, and he was promoted to Censor-in-Chief. He then thoroughly investigated the crimes and faults of the feudal lords, seizing their subsidiary commanderies. The thirty chapters of revised decrees he issued provoked an uproar among the lords.

Xiao’s father, hearing of this, traveled from Yingchuan and said to him: “Now that the emperor has newly ascended the throne, you, a distant relation, wield power and encroach upon the feudal lords. You estrange close kin and provoke widespread resentment. Why?” Xiao replied: “Indeed. Without such measures, the Son of Heaven would lack dignity, and the ancestral temples would be insecure.” His father said: “Alas! The House of Liu may be secure, but the House of Zuì will not.” He then took poison and died, declaring: “I cannot bear to witness the calamity that will befall you.” Ten days later, the seven kingdoms of Wu and Chu indeed rebelled.

**Recorded Remarks:** Observing the *Records of the Historian*, I note that two men were called “Bags of Wisdom,” yet each had his blind spots. Ning Li was blinded by Hu Qing, and Xiao Cuo by Yuan Ang. Could it be that they loved wisdom but not learning? Nevertheless, Xiao’s intent to curtail the feudal lords was nearly a case of “forgetting oneself for the sake of the state.” Yet he was executed in disgrace, becoming a laughingstock. Had he cherished his kin and esteemed his superiors, he might have preserved his life and retired to his estate in Zhang Terrace south of the Wei River. Emperor Jing of Han proved no match for King Zhao of Qin—this much is clear. As for Xiao’s father’s foresight, it may have come too late.

The mother of Yan Yannian, Governor of Henan, bore five sons, all of whom rose to the rank of Two Thousand Bushels. People called her “The Ten-Thousand-Bushel Matriarch.” Yan Yannian, as governor, was renowned for his severity and competence. In winter, he would summon prisoners from the subordinate counties to his headquarters for sentencing, their blood flowing for miles—hence his nickname, “The Butcher Governor.” His mother once traveled from Donghai to Luoyang and, upon witnessing this, was horrified. She stayed at the capital’s post station and refused to enter the governor’s residence. There, she reproached Yan Yannian, saying: “Fortunate to be a regional governor, you have not heard of governing with benevolence and righteousness to protect and pacify the people. Instead, you rely on punishments, slaughtering many to establish your authority. Is this the intent of one who would be a parent to the people? The Way of Heaven is spiritually luminous; one cannot kill with impunity. I never imagined I would live to see my own son executed.” She then departed, saying: “Go east and return home. I will only sweep the graves.” A year later, the Palace Assistant Secretary impeached Yan Yannian on over ten charges. The case was referred to the Censorate for investigation, and he was ultimately executed in the marketplace. The people of Donghai all praised his mother’s wisdom.

**Recorded Remarks:** Alas, how unlike the ancients was Yan’s mother! The ancients’ methods of prenatal instruction and the “Three Moves” were means by which worthy mothers nurtured this heart and fortified the defenses of benevolence. Had Yan’s mother carefully observed her son’s inclinations from the start, curbing his excesses and restraining his worst impulses, ensuring he cultivated the pure ways of his elders in childhood and embodied compassion in adulthood—had his heart lacked cruelty, even rewards would not have made him brutal. How could one dubbed “The Butcher Governor” have preserved his life? In truth, she suffered the grief of sweeping graves, while her reputation for wisdom was but an empty tale. How unlike the ancients was Yan’s mother! How lamentable.

The mother of Jun Buyi, Prefect of the Capital, was kind and wise in her teachings. When Jun served as prefect and returned from inspecting the counties and reviewing prisoners, his mother would always ask how many he had acquitted and spared. If Jun reported many acquittals, his mother would rejoice, her speech and appetite surpassing her usual demeanor. If he reported none, she would grow angry and refuse to eat. Thus, Jun conducted his duties with severity but without cruelty.

The noble-minded say of this mother: she may be called one who “eternally bestows blessings upon her kind.”

**Recorded Remarks:** In my humble view, Jun Buyi’s mother differed from Yan Yannian’s. The essence of teaching lies in foresight. Jun was no “Butcher Governor,” nor did his mother face the sorrow of sweeping graves. Her son earned a good name, and she bequeathed him blessings—was she not both enlightened and wise?

**The *Book of Later Han* states:** Wu You’s father, Wu Hui, served as Governor of Nanhai. At twelve, Wu You accompanied his father to the post. Wu Hui wished to burn the bamboo slips to transcribe the classics. Wu You remonstrated: “Now, sir, you have crossed the Five Ridges to this distant coastal region, where the customs are indeed coarse. Yet the land holds rare treasures, viewed with suspicion by the court above and coveted by powerful relatives below. If these books are completed, they will require a double cartload to transport. In the past, Ma Yuan was slandered for his ‘gray cocoons,’ and Wang Yang’s clothing sacks aroused suspicion—these were matters the former worthies took care to avoid.” Wu Hui desisted and, stroking his son’s head, said: “The House of Wu will not lack its own Ji Zha!”

As Wu You grew, he possessed keen insight into character. After being nominated as Filial and Incorrupt, he served as Chancellor of Jiaodong. He led by example, and his subordinates could not bear to deceive him. The bailiff Sun Xing privately levied funds from the people to buy clothes for his father. Upon receiving them, the father grew angry and urged his son to return and confess. Sun Xing, trembling with fear, went to the government office, clutching the clothes, and confessed. Wu You said: “You endured humiliation for your father’s sake—this is what is meant by ‘observing faults to know virtue.’” He sent Sun Xing home to apologize to his father and returned the clothes to him.

**Recorded Remarks:** In this light, Zhao Guanghan’s “hook-and-line” interrogations and Zhang Xu’s “floss-trailing” tactics were unnecessary. This was a clarity of innate nature, wisdom that required no instruction. Let this be recorded.

From *The Book of Jin*:

Tao Kan’s father, Dan, served the Kingdom of Wu as General of Yangwu. His mother, née Zhan, was a concubine who bore Tao Kan. The Tao family was poor, and Zhan spun hemp to provide for her son, enabling him to associate with those superior to himself. When the Filial and Incorrupt Candidate of Poyang, Fan Da, lodged with Tao Kan, a great snow fell. Zhan cut off her hair and sold it to obtain a pair of tresses, which she exchanged for wine and delicacies. They drank merrily, and even the servants were treated beyond their expectations. When the feast ended, she lay on firewood to keep warm and personally fed the horses.

Later, Tao Kan was appointed Supervisor of the Yuanliang Canal in Deyang. He sent his mother a jar of salted fish as a gift. She returned it with a rebuke: “You send me official goods—this not only brings no benefit but only increases my worries.” When Fan Da heard of this, he sighed and said, “Without such a mother, this son could not have been born.” He recommended Tao Kan to Zhang Kui, the Prefect of Lujiang, who then employed him. Later, through military merit, Tao Kan became Prefect of Jiangxia and was promoted to General of Soaring Hawk. He prepared an honor guard to welcome his mother, bringing glory to his hometown.

Zhou Yi’s father, Jun, was General of the East for Pacification. A man of keen judgment, he once went hunting and was caught in the rain, taking shelter at the home of Li, styled Luoxiu. At the time, her father and brothers were away. Hearing that a nobleman had arrived, Luoxiu and a maid slaughtered pigs and sheep inside the house, preparing a feast for dozens with great care—yet no other voices were heard. Suspicious, Jun sent someone to investigate and saw only a single, exceptionally beautiful woman. He sought her as a concubine, but her father and brothers refused. Luoxiu said, “Our family is poor and struggling—why惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜惜一女? If we form an alliance with a noble family, it may bring great benefit in the future.” They consented. She bore three sons—Ji, Song, and Mo—all of whom rose to eminent positions.

On one Winter Solstice, she prepared wine and, raising her cup, addressed her three sons: “When I first crossed the river, I had nowhere to set foot. Who could have imagined that I would be embraced by a distinguished clan and that you would all attain high rank before my eyes? What more could I wish for?” Song rose and said, “We fear we may fall short of your expectations.”

Lady Ji was ambitious but lacked ability; his reputation was great, yet his judgment flawed. To ride another’s worn-out steed is no way to preserve oneself. Song’s nature was unyielding and upright, and thus he could not be tolerated by the world. Only Asnu, mediocre and unremarkable, would remain beneath his mother’s gaze. (Asnu was Mo’s childhood name.) Later events unfolded exactly as she had foretold.

**Record states:** Observing the mothers of Tao Shixing and Zhou Boren, one may call them perceptive and discerning. Both arose from humble origins to become concubines, their status by no means tied to their世 lineage. Yet some may harbor doubts regarding the cutting of hair and the preparation of the feast. How much could a single lock of hair be worth, that she could drink with such joy and merriment? How could a frail young girl, in haste and alone, manage the slaughter and butchery of so many beasts? Was it rather that her virtuous reputation had long been known, so that even when it came to cutting her hair, none would dare refuse? That her skill in preparation was so renowned that even should the task require the labor of several, she would not decline? And thus, was this later taken as fact? As for descending into the depths of Song’s imprisonment and inscribing his name among the state’s pillars, though it may seem the work of human design, the will of Heaven was truly at play—beyond all measure or conjecture.

*Hongdao Record, Volume 41, concludes*
*Hongdao Record, Volume 42: Wisdom*

**On the Wisdom of Father and Son**

From *The Old Book of Tang*: In the summer of the twenty-third year of the Zhenguan era, the fourth month, Emperor Taizong fell ill. He addressed the Crown Prince, saying: "Li Shiji possesses abundant talent and wisdom, yet you share no bond of gratitude with him—he cannot be made to submit willingly. I shall now demote him. If he departs at once, then after my death, you may later appoint him as Chancellor and entrust him with authority. But if he lingers or hesitates, you must put him to death." Thereupon, Li was appointed Chief Minister and concurrently Governor of Diezhou. Shiji received the decree and departed without returning home.

**Recorded Note:** How fitting that Emperor Taizong could not protect his son, much less his grandson! The command to entrust the orphaned heir had not yet been issued, yet the words to entrust Li Shiji had already taken root—this was how he taught his son to set a trap. The emperor, by nature, relied on calculation and stratagem, excelling in employing men but lacking discernment in judging them. Thus, today’s trusted confidant would become tomorrow’s sworn enemy; today’s clever scheme would become tomorrow’s root of disaster. He believed himself shrewd, yet failed to see that one who betrays his former lord would not hesitate to betray a secret trust. At first, he acted solely to sever a single strand of hair for the sake of the state, unaware that the nature of hawks and hounds cannot be measured by such small favors. In the end, he resorted to the same cunning that had once removed a rival, hoping to secure the distant future of the Liu clan—how grievously misguided! This matter bears heavily upon the ancestral temples and altars of the Tang; it cannot go unrecorded.

In the first year of Emperor Ruizong’s reign, the court prepared to establish the Crown Prince. Though Prince Song, Chengqi, was the eldest legitimate son, Prince Ping, Longji, had rendered great service, leaving the emperor uncertain. Chengqi declined, saying: "When the state is at peace, precedence belongs to the eldest legitimate heir; when the state is in peril, precedence belongs to the one with merit. To defy this principle would dash the hopes of the realm. Though I die, I dare not stand above Prince Ping." For days, he wept and firmly refused, while many ministers also urged that Prince Ping’s merits made him the rightful choice. Liu Youqiu declared: "He who eradicates the realm’s calamities shall enjoy its blessings. The prince rescued the state from danger and saved his sovereign and kin from peril—no merit is greater, no virtue more exemplary. There is no cause for doubt." The emperor relented and named Prince Ping, Longji, as Crown Prince.

**Recorded Note:** All say that the restoration of Prince Luling marked the Tang’s second founding, yet none realize that the true founding lay in Prince Ping, Longji, being named Crown Prince. Now, Zhen was the eldest son. Yet Jiancheng, Chengqian, and Prince Chen, Zhong, were all mediocre and unworthy—mere trembling shadows, doomed to perish. As for Emperor Zhongzong, his folly was even more extreme: at first, he endured humiliation without regard, then suffered deposition without shame; in the end, he lived in constant anxiety yet remained oblivious, ruled by his wife and eunuchs without concern—truly a shadow lost in the mire, devoid of light. But when Emperor Xuanzong arose in majestic wrath, startling the realm, the hearts of the wicked were laid bare, and the accumulated yin of the age gave way to the spirit of the Divine Yao. Thus, the old order was not lost. As the saying goes: "The thunderclap shakes a hundred li, yet the sacrificial ladle remains unharmed"—such a one may guard the ancestral temples and altars, serving as the master of rites. The proof lies in what followed.

Quan Gao was the father of Quan Deyu, chief minister of the Tang. Renowned for his talent, he was appointed as an aide to An Lushan’s tyranny. Secretly planning to flee, he feared that uncovering An’s treasonous designs would bring disaster upon his aged mother. When An sent him to present captives in the capital, Gao passed through Fuchang on his return. The magistrate, Zhong Mou—Gao’s cousin by marriage—privately devised a plan with him. Upon reaching Heyang, Gao feigned grave illness and summoned Mou. When Mou arrived, Gao staged a display of grief and lamentation. An Lushan, thus deceived, permitted Gao’s mother to return home. Gao then disguised himself, concealed his tracks, and awaited his mother at Qimen. Escorting her day and night, they fled south. By the time they crossed the Yangtze, An Lushan had already rebelled, and Gao’s name resounded throughout the realm. The Investigating Censor Gao Shi recommended him as an adjutant. When Prince Yong, Lin, stirred rebellion and seized many officials, Gao changed his name to evade capture. Emperor Xuanzong, then in Shu, heard of his deeds and praised him. Gentlemen of learning such as Li Hua and Liu Shi revered Gao’s virtue, declaring him the sole arbiter of good and evil in the world.

De Yu, at four, could compose poetry; by seven, he was already filial and refined. At fifteen, he had written hundreds of essays, and his reputation grew daily. Han Hui appointed him as an aide, and he later passed the examination in the Secretariat. Eventually, he became Minister of Rites and Chief Minister. From the Zhenyuan era to the third year of the Yuanhe era—thirty years—he stood as a paragon of the court. Upright, candid, magnanimous, and forgiving, his every word and deed bore no pretense. His grace and refinement were celebrated in his time. His writings were especially prolific, steeped in the Six Classics and the hundred schools. His prose was elegant, correct, expansive, and profound, earning him the title of master among his contemporaries.

**Recorded Note:** Though Quan Gao’s entanglement in the den of rebels may seem a lapse in judgment, he ultimately preserved himself to serve his mother—securing not only his integrity and reputation but also ensuring the prosperity of his descendants. Han Hui and Wang Dingchang’s assessment that Gao was fit to be a chief minister or imperial tutor was no empty praise. Father and son, steadfast in culture, filial piety, and virtue, stood as exemplars of the court—were they not men of profound wisdom?

Fu Lingqi’s son, Lin, initially served as a general in Youzhou. When chaos erupted in the region, he fled to Zhaoyi. Tian Yue defied imperial orders, and Lingqi secretly advised Lin: "I have witnessed much of the world. Since the An Lushan rebellion, no rebel faction has survived. I see that the Tian clan’s downfall is imminent. If you pledge loyalty to the court and become a faithful minister of the Tang, my name will also be honored by posterity." Lin wept and replied: "Yue is a ruthless man—his impending doom is terrifying." Lingqi said: "Now, the royal armies converge from all sides. We are like fish in a cauldron. If you do not act, I shall die beneath the ramparts of the rebels. What then?"

Lin clasped his father’s arm in farewell. At that time, the court had dispatched Ma Qiong to suppress Yue, and Lin surrendered. Enraged, Yue berated him bitterly for betraying loyalty and abandoning his lord, declaring, "You shall die at dawn—what use is regret now?" The imperial edict appointed Lin as *Tejin*. Lingqi said, "I taught you to follow the Way of obedience—yet now you face death for killing Sui." Later, Sui’s forces appointed Lin as deputy commander. Another man, Yi Zhang, had long observed Zhao Yuanhao and knew he would rebel; he was enfeoffed as Prince of Yiyang Commandery, and his petition redressed his father’s grievances, earning him the titles of Left *Sanqi Changshi* and Minister of Revenue.

**Recorded Note:** This affair parallels that of Quan Gao. Had Lingqi truly died, Gao’s survival would have been but a pretense. Yet history omits such exemplary conduct—could it be because his son never rose to the rank of minister? Let this be recorded.

In *The History of the Song*, Cao Zan and Cao Wei were both sons of Cao Bin. Zan was steadfast, resolute, and shrewd; Bin saw himself in him and doted on him, appointing him Military Commissioner of Heyang and *Tong Zhongshu Menxia Pingzhangshi*. Wei was courageous, strategic, and fond of reading, particularly the *Three Commentaries on the Spring and Autumn Annals*, with especial mastery of the *Zuo Tradition*. When Li Jiqian rebelled, the generals sent to suppress him repeatedly failed. Emperor Taizong asked who could lead the campaign, and Bin replied, "My youngest son, Wei, is capable." Summoned to court, Wei was appointed *Tong Zhi* of Weizhou at the age of nineteen. When Bin fell gravely ill, Emperor Zhenzong visited him and inquired about his final wishes. Bin replied, "I have no concerns to voice—only that my two sons possess talents worth employing. If I may recommend from within my family, both are fit to be generals." The emperor asked which was superior, and Bin answered, "Zan is not Wei’s equal." Later, Wei’s merits earned him a place alongside Bin in the ancestral temple. Bin was honored by Emperor Taizu; Wei, by Emperor Renzong—truly, no one knows a son like his father.

**Recorded Note:** Bin’s preference for Wei—could it have been foresight that he would not ally with Ding Wei? Thus, it is better to be a partisan of Kou than of Wei. Though a partisan of Kou may be condemned, he remains honorable, for he bears no shame before Heaven. Though a partisan of Wei may rise high, he is still executed, for he wears a face of hypocrisy. Is this not a pillar of the state and a guardian of justice in the realm?

Wei once observed Zhao Yuanhao and, knowing he would rebel, told the Chief Military Affairs Commissioner, Wang Zong: "While in Shaanxi, I heard that Zhao Deming often sent men to barter horses. Enraged by meager profits, he once sought to kill a trader, but none dared dissuade him. At the time, Yuanhao was barely over ten years old. He remonstrated, 'We are a people of the saddle and horse, yet we trade our resources to neighboring states for frivolous goods—this is already poor strategy. To kill the trader on top of it—who among the borderlands will serve us then?' Deming heeded his advice."

Zhuang privately thought to himself: "This son seeks to employ such men—he must harbor rebellious intentions." He had heard that Yuanhao often frequented the military markets, and wishing to recognize him, repeatedly sent men to lure him, but to no avail. He then dispatched a skilled painter to capture his likeness for observation. Truly a remarkable figure—one day he would become a scourge along the frontier. Calculating the time, this was precisely when Wang Zong held office. Wang had greatly encouraged Zhuang, though at the time he did not agree; only later did he sigh in admiration at Zhuang’s foresight.

The record states: This was not merely a case of Tan falling short of Zhuang’s judgment, but even the discussions at the time were misguided. Bin could truly be said to have remained steadfast in his recommendations from beginning to end.

Xiang Minzhong’s father, Li, personally oversaw his education, sparing no leniency, and declared: "This child will bring greatness to our family." As he grew, Minzhong possessed a dignified and imposing bearing, was affable and wise, understood governance, and excelled at managing complex affairs. Having borne great responsibilities for thirty years, he was regarded by all as a man of profound virtue. The sovereign held him in high esteem, and though he endured trials, he was never dismissed from office. Once, he was promoted to Right Vice Director of the Chancellery and concurrent Attendant of the Gate of the Bureau of Scrutiny. Emperor Zhenzong said to Academician Li Zongkuo: "Since my ascension, I have never appointed a Vice Director of the Chancellery. Today I appoint Minzhong—this is an exceptional decree." Minzhong should have been overjoyed, and well-wishers would surely gather. "Go observe him," the emperor instructed, "but do not reveal my intent." When Zongkuo arrived, the gates were quiet. He entered to offer congratulations, saying: "Today, upon hearing of the imperial decree, all officials and scholars are both awed and delighted." Minzhong merely murmured in assent. Zongkuo continued: "Since the emperor’s enthronement, no one has been appointed to this post. Your merit and prestige are unmatched, and the emperor’s favor is extraordinary—how has this come to pass?" Minzhong again murmured in assent. Zongkuo then recounted the illustrious deeds and honors of past Vice Directors of the Chancellery, but Minzhong still only murmured in assent, uttering not a single word. His prudence and discretion were ever thus.

He had five sons: Chuan Zheng, Chuan Shi, Chuan Liang, Chuan Shi, and Chuan Fan. Chuan Liang’s son, Jing, had a daughter who became Empress Qinsheng Xiansu. Later, Minzhong was posthumously enfeoffed as Prince of Yan, Chuan Liang as Prince of Zhou, and Jing as Prince of Wu. Their descendants all rose to prominence.

The record states: Among the consort clans of the Song, some were known for benevolence, others for wisdom, and others for courage. Benevolent yet not excessive, wise yet not cunning, courageous yet not reckless. Thus, Bin’s integrity and humility were free from excess; Minzhong’s affability and wisdom were free from cunning; and Qiong...

Though unaware of this principle, seeking only through beauty and charm—how could one hope for fourteen sons, all taught to read, thus preserving the blessings of conjugal harmony and the excellence of posterity?

Lu Yijian and his son Gongzhuo were both appointed Grand Mentor and Grand Councilor. Since the founding of the Song, only four men had held the concurrent titles of the Three Dukes and Grand Councilor, and two of them were from the Lü clan. Scholars marveled at their glory.

Yijian’s father, Mengheng, was the younger brother of Mengzheng. During the Xiangfu era, when Emperor Zhenzong made his imperial progress to Mount Tai and visited Mengzheng’s residence, he asked, “Which of your sons is fit for office?” Mengzheng replied, “None of my sons are worthy, but I have a nephew, Yijian, who has the talent to be Grand Councilor.” From that moment, Yijian’s name was known.

From youth, Gongzhuo took the cultivation of the heart and nurturing of nature as his foundation. He remained indifferent to the clamor of fame and profit, unmoved by worldly splendor. In summer, he did not wave a fan; in winter, he did not warm himself by the fire. His manner was simple, grave, and serene—such was his natural endowment. His intelligence and insight were keen, and he excelled at making decisions. If something benefited the state, he was unmoved by personal gain or loss. When he met scholar-officials who took an interest in talent, he would inquire about their knowledge, cross-referencing what they knew with what he had heard to verify the truth, then reporting it to the throne. In deliberating policy, he broadly adopted the best suggestions from all sides.

Emperor Shenzong once remarked, “In matters of talent, he is never deceptive—like a scale weighing objects. He is especially adept at keeping his distance from fame and reputation, never presuming to claim credit for discerning others.” Sima Guang also said, “Whenever I hear Huishu speak, I feel my own words are superfluous.” Such was the esteem in which he was held.

The record states: In my view, not only did Lord Wenmu of the Lü clan recognize Yijian’s worth, but so did Wang Wenzheng. Observe how a single word from him could decide matters—even divination by tortoise shell or milfoil could not compare. This is what is meant by “intertwined stalks of grass, their kind portending good fortune.” As for Zhixian, though he said, “In talent, he is never deceptive, like a scale weighing objects,” he had not yet seen its efficacy in practice—still, he was one who “embraced both honor and shame.” Here, human affairs intersect with the Dao of Heaven, and the distinction between rise and fall, success and failure, is clearly evident.

Su Xun named his two sons *Shuo* and *Shi*. Of *Shuo*, he said: “The wheel, spokes, and axle all have their functions, as does the carriage itself—but *Shi* alone seems to do nothing.” Yet if *Shi* were removed, I would not consider the carriage complete. *Shi*, I fear you will not balance inner and outer. All carriages in the world follow the ruts, yet when praising the carriage’s merit, the ruts are not mentioned. Nevertheless, if the carriage overturns or the horse dies, the misfortune does not extend to the ruts. Thus, the ruts lie between fortune and misfortune. *Shi*, I now understand.

In *Record of the Wooden Mountain*, he wrote: My family has three peaks. Whenever I reflect on them, I suspect some fate governs their existence. Though gnarled, they are not harmed; though towering, they are not felled. Used as beams, they are not cut down; uprooted by wind or swept away by water, they do not break. Unharmed, unrotted, unbroken, yet not deemed useful by others—only after enduring the axe’s edge and emerging from the rapids’ sands, untouched by woodcutters or rustics as firewood, do they attain their present state. This seems no mere coincidence. Yet my love for them is mingled with deeper feeling.

I see the central peak, majestic and unconstrained, its bearing dignified and weighty, as if commanding the two flanking peaks. Those two are solemn, stern, and sharply defined, formidable and untouchable. Though their power submits to the central peak, they stand aloof, as if disdaining attachment. Alas, how admirable! How moving!

The record states: Historians say that *Shi* slightly restrained himself, and though he never gained power, he thus avoided disaster. Could this truly be so? Observe how Old Su foresaw his son’s fate with unerring precision, and how his analogy of the three peaks is so vivid and apt that, even a thousand years later, one can imagine the intimacy of that household, the depth of understanding between father and son—how could their wisdom be compared to the ordinary man’s cursory knowledge of his children?

Ouyang Xiu lost his father in childhood. His mother, Lady Zheng of the State of Han, personally taught him to read. Poor and without resources, she used reeds to trace characters in the earth, instructing him thus: “Your father was an official. Often, he would work late into the night by candlelight, repeatedly setting aside his brush with a sigh. When I asked why, he said, ‘A case involving a capital sentence. I sought a way to spare the condemned, but could not.’ I said...”

"Could one seek to spare a life?"
"Yes. If one seeks to spare a life but fails, then both the condemned and I will have no regrets. If, by seeking, one sometimes succeeds, then one knows that those who die without such effort are indeed beyond saving. To constantly seek to spare life and yet still err in sentencing to death—how much worse, then, is it to constantly seek death?"

Ouyang Xiu took these words to heart for the rest of his life. In all cases involving capital punishment, unless the crime was murder, he often overturned the sentence. Even in private, when instructing other young men, he would repeat these words.

**Recorded thus:** Ouyang Xiu’s father did not act out of self-interest; he simply exhausted his own conscience. His mother, too, did not act for any personal gain; she merely illuminated her husband’s resolve. This is something others could not understand, yet she alone knew it. In the unseen realm, no hidden virtue surpasses this. Thus, one need not explicitly speak of karmic retribution—merely to hold these words in reverence for a lifetime is already a lesson worthy of the wise.

Liu Anshi’s mother was renowned for her wisdom. When Anshi was appointed to the post of remonstrance official, he had not yet assumed the position. He entered to inform his mother, saying: "The court, not deeming me unworthy, has placed me in a position to speak truth to power. If I hold this office, I must act with bold clarity, bearing full responsibility. Should I offend, punishment will follow swiftly. The emperor now governs by filial piety—if I decline on account of my aged mother, I may be excused."

His mother replied: "It is not so. I have heard that a remonstrance official is the emperor’s loyal critic. Your father longed to hold such a post but never had the chance. Now that you are fortunate enough to occupy this position, you must risk your life to repay the nation’s grace. Even if you are exiled for your crimes, no matter the distance, I will follow you."

Thus, Anshi accepted the appointment and served with unwavering integrity. He stood firm in court, openly challenging authority, earning the nickname "the tiger of the hall."

**Recorded thus:** Observing Anshi’s deeds, I sigh that life and death are fated, and a gentleman must accept his lot. With the power of a minister like Dun Bian and the cruelty of a tyrant, many would willingly submit. Yet not only did exile to the southern frontier fail to claim lives, but reprieves often arrived after repeated petitions—some dying just before pardon, others spared after traveling only a few post stations. Later generations hearing of this would merely scoff. As if some unseen force willed it so! Had his mother fretted over danger and urged caution, the path of integrity would not have shone so brightly. Without that integrity, the virtue of mother and son would have remained obscure. Their hesitation and restraint could never compare to the unashamed boldness of facing the world with open eyes.

Chen Tuan’s mother was Lady Chen. When Tuan sat for the imperial examination, one of the policy questions called for the punishment of the Yuanyou-era ministers, offering them a chance to redeem themselves by governing a prefecture. The emperor, however, feared their departure and refused. Emperor Renzong once remarked to his attendants: "All the Confucians have been employed—only Yu Bogsheng remains unpromoted."

When Emperor Yingzong ascended the throne, Baizhu, then chancellor, spoke to the emperor and dispatched envoys to summon him. Bogsheng, citing mourning, returned home. The censor Zhao Shian seized the opportunity to petition: "Bogsheng has long resided in the capital in dire poverty and suffers from an eye ailment. It would be merciful to grant him an external post for medical treatment."

The emperor grew angry: "Yu Bogsheng—do you all not tolerate him?" At the time, the emperor favored literary men. Bogsheng’s vast learning and broad knowledge made him indispensable, which is why the emperor so reluctantly allowed his departure.

**Recorded thus:** That women of old read and grasped grand principles is well-documented. Yet even the *Zuozhuan* and the prose of Ouyang Xiu and Su Shi remain challenging for today’s scholars—how much more so for women? In the *Records of the Historian*, when Wen Zhong governed Hengyang, the Ji couple followed him. They prayed to the Southern Marchmount for a son, and thus Bogsheng was born, and Wen Zhong marveled at him.

Alas! The birth of a child is rooted in their *qi*. Ji was discerning in character, steeped in Confucian tradition, while Yang’s wisdom and virtue were unblemished by worldly conduct. With such a worthy match, their descendants were bound to be exceptional. A wise observer could foresee their accomplishments without relying on dreams or divination.

From the *Imperial Literary Collection: Edict to Xuiping Marquis Mu Ying*:
"Rewarding merit with noble rank is the established system of emperors and kings. Longing for kin and cherishing old bonds are the natural sentiments of humanity. In the chaos of those years, I was already twenty-five and still childless. You, Mu Ying, suffered hardship in war at the age of eight, orphaned and unaware of survival. I pitied your youth and raised you as my own son. We slept side by side at night, and you often snored in my arms. Later, when I had sons of my own and you had grown, considering human nature and heavenly principle, I did not obscure your name but allowed you to reclaim your surname and worship your ancestors. Today, I still recall your childhood innocence and how I treated you no differently than my own father. Thus, I now enfeoff you as Xuiping Marquis. You must remember our first meeting and the great mercy of your deliverance. Strive to repay this boundless grace, dedicating yourself to the welfare of others, and you shall enjoy endless blessings and good fortune."

**Recorded thus:** In my view, Xuiping Marquis was no different from Liu Fei of Han. Yet Fei perished soon after, while Mu endured to this day—why? Without witnessing the case of Qi, one cannot understand the flaws of Han law; without observing the imperial clan, how can one appreciate the virtue of the Ming founder? At first, his care and upbringing were no different from the love for a biological heir. In the end, his impartiality and justice never concealed his past affection. Moreover, he allowed Mu to restore his surname and ancestral rites, avoiding not only the usurpation of kings and lords but also clearly upholding the principle of rewarding merit with rank. This was the great wisdom of an emperor, the great impartiality of heavenly principle—preserved for ten thousand generations without flaw. How could it not endure as long as heaven and share the prosperity of the nation? Even the most eloquent ministers and persuasive scholars need not add a word. Such imperial decrees and rescripts must be recorded.

From *Chen Yi’s Record of Cultivated Virtue*:
When Academician Xie Jin was commanded to inscribe the *Tiger Gazing at Its Cubs* painting, he wrote:
"The tiger is the lord of beasts—who dares provoke its wrath?"

Only the bond of father and son—
with every step, a backward glance.
Emperor Wen had long disliked Renzong,
yet moved by this poem, he yearned deeply.
At the time, Renzong was stationed in the Southern Capital,
his heart heavy with foreboding.
Thus, he dispatched his trusted minister Xia Yuanji
to hasten and welcome him home.

*Recorded thus*: In my humble view, this poem surpasses Zhang Liang’s stratagems by far. For the love between father and son is a bond of heavenly nature, unlike the schemes of rival states’ ministers. Rival states divide into self and other, calculating gains like mere objects; but father and son arise from the heart’s sincerity, their affection profound and irrepressible. The Han founder, swayed by his ministers’ counsel, could not advance his grand design. But Mingzong, guided by the benevolence of his innate nature, discerned the subtle admonition—this, for ages to come, may be observed.

Since the raising of troops by conscription and recruitment alike,
all matters were left to his discretion.
Even when meritorious, he was not hastily transferred,
but rather promoted in rank with distinction.
Thus, men of talent vied to exert themselves,
and in times of crisis, their utmost loyalty could be relied upon.

At the time, court discussions turned to military campaigns,
but you argued repeatedly against reckless action.
Later, when the Three Capitals were reclaimed
and the Jin forces freshly defeated,
the three frontier commanders were rewarded with higher ranks.
Yet you knit your brow and said:
“The borderlands have no one to depend upon.
I beg you to cast aside rigid constraints,
select and promote the outstanding—
men like Wu Yong, Zhou Yu, Lu Su,
or the ancients Ren Renfa, Zu Ti, and Tao Kan—
and assign each to a region,
entrusting them with command over dozens of cities.
Grant them full authority,
whether in Bashu, Jingxiang, or the two Huaidong regions,
to act with complete discretion.
Then, with flexibility at their command
and strategy springing from their own minds,
they may respond as needed.”
The court did not heed your counsel.
Twenty years later, Henan indeed fell to the Jin,
the power of border prefectures was greatly diminished,
and no one was willing to take responsibility for military affairs.
Soon after, Luoyang’s forces were defeated,
and the court at last acknowledged your foresight.

*Recorded thus*: In my humble view, these two men served during the perilous reigns of Emperors Guang and Ning, when Han Tuozhou held power, enduring factional strife and closing their doors in confusion. From youth to old age, they never set aside their books. They once remarked that Han Fei and Li Si, though endowed with Xun Qing’s talent, were debased by the world for their craving of wealth, honor, and profit. Only Xun Qing preserved his integrity, refusing to seek favor through flattery—how can a scholar fail to value himself?

They also said: “What allows external things to disturb the five senses and five desires, clouding the mind’s clarity, is the failure to grasp the principle of steadfast unity and tranquility. If one attains it, then sound and beauty cannot penetrate, riches and treasures cannot sway, fame and glory cannot move. Serene and unshaken, what can assail them?” From this, we see they were truly enlightened scholars of their age. Alas, their talents were never put to use.

*Recorded.*

From *The History of the Liao Dynasty*:

Yizong Bei, the eldest son of Abaoji, was intelligent and studious from childhood, outwardly magnanimous yet inwardly sincere. In the first year of the Shence era, he was named Crown Prince. When Taizu passed away, Bei, knowing the Empress Dowager favored De Guang, joined the ministers in petitioning the Empress Dowager to yield the throne. He declared: “The Grand Marshal’s virtue and power are vast, and all within and beyond the realm look to him—he is fit to rule the state.” Thereupon, the Grand Marshal ascended the imperial throne, becoming Taizong.

After Taizong’s enthronement, he established Dongping as the Southern Capital and relocated Bei there. He ordered Wang Jiyuan to select and erect the Southern Capital Stele. Bei, in turn, built a library in the Western Palace and composed poems on music, fields, and gardens. When Emperor Mingzong of Later Tang learned of this, he dispatched envoys across the sea with a secret letter summoning Bei. Bei reflected: “I yielded the realm, yet the sovereign now suspects me. Better to depart for another land and fulfill the renown of Wu Taibo.” He boarded a ship with the letter and set sail. Later Tang received him with celestial regalia; Bei sat in the ship’s hall as officials lined the shores in attendance.

Upon arriving in Bian, Mingzong bestowed upon Bei the surname Dongdan and the name Muhua. He renamed Ruizhou as Huaihua Commandery and appointed Bei as its Military Commissioner, concurrently appointing him as Surveillance Commissioner over Duanshen and other prefectures, later transferring him to Huazhou. Though residing in a foreign land, Bei never ceased longing for his kin, and his envoys to Taonan remained unbroken.

A record states: The Liao Crown Prince Bei may indeed be said to have known how to cherish his own integrity. Yet it is lamentable that he admired the renown of Wu Taibo but did not seek his resolve, emulated the footsteps of Ji Zha but failed to grasp his intent. The verses of *Xiaoshan* verge on resentment and folly; his acceptance of governorship was driven by a thirst for reputation; the surname Dongdan bespoke a lapse in remembering his roots. As for the one who granted him the name Muhua—his father in rebellion, his son in defiance—where lay the reverence and harmony implied in "Muhua" and "Huaihua"? In the end, it was but a path trodden among the barbarians.

*Hongdao Lu*, Scroll Forty-Two, concludes. #1 (The preceding two sections overlapped with earlier text and have been omitted; this section may be incomplete.)

*Hongdao Lu*, Scroll Forty-Three: Wisdom.

The Wisdom of Husband and Wife

From the *Family Sayings of Confucius*: Shuliang He of Lu took a wife from the Shi clan, who bore him nine daughters but no sons; his concubine gave birth to Meng Pi, who suffered from a foot ailment. Shuliang He said, "Though I have nine daughters, none are fit to inherit—this is as good as having no son." He then sought a marriage alliance with the Yan clan. The Yan family had three daughters, the youngest named Zheng Zai. Their father asked them, "Zou’s grand minister, though his father and grandfather were ministers of state, is descended from the ancient sages. Now the man himself stands nine *chi* tall, with unmatched martial prowess. Though he is advanced in years and stern in temperament, these are no cause for doubt. Which of you three would be willing to be his wife?" The two elder daughters made no reply, but Zheng Zai stepped forward and said, "I will follow whatever my father decides—what need is there to ask?" Her father said, "Then you shall do." And so he gave her to him in marriage.

The record states: Sima Qian’s judgments often deviate from those of the sages—how could this be mere error? His fabrications are extreme. That the *Family Sayings* should follow the *Analects* is itself evidence enough—why then does he treat it with such contempt? Zheng Zai took it upon herself to be worthy and sagely, a claim unheard of in ancient times. Yet he calls her union a "wild coupling" and even suggests that her son doubted his father’s burial site, forcing his mother to conceal the truth. Could this be so? Could this be so?

Some say: In Sima Qian’s time, the *Family Sayings* had not yet appeared. Yet by the time of Zheng Qiao’s *Comprehensive Records*, the text was already in circulation. Though he corrected Sima Qian’s errors, he still failed to include Zheng Zai’s story—little better than the original.

From the *Analects*: The Master said of Gongye Chang, "He may be given a wife. Though he was once imprisoned, it was not for any crime of his." And so he gave him his daughter in marriage. The Master said of Nan Rong, "When the state follows the Dao, he will not be cast aside; when it strays from the Dao, he will escape execution and punishment." And so he gave him his elder brother’s daughter in marriage.

The record states: Foolish as I am, I observe that among Confucius’ female disciples, why were they so preoccupied with imprisonment, execution, and punishment? The way of a wife is to follow her husband. Her fortune or misfortune, honor or disgrace, are tied to him for life—her hopes for a worthy husband are most earnest. Thus, she wishes only to grow old hand in hand with him, yet deeply fears parting midway. Even the sages could not help but be moved by such concerns. If this is the lesson, then in Lu there were those who killed their wives to seek military command, and those who mocked their wives for accepting bribes. Who would say that the marriages of these two men should not serve as models for later generations?

From the *Biographies of Exemplary Women*: The wife of Liu Xia Hui, a grand minister of Lu. Though Hui was dismissed from office three times, he refused to leave, grieving for the people and rescuing them from chaos. His wife said, "Is this not excessive? A gentleman has two sources of shame: to be honored when the state lacks the Dao, and to be lowly when it follows the Dao. Now, in this age of disorder, you have been dismissed three times yet remain—what good does it do?" Hui replied, "When the people are drowning in turmoil, how can I stand by? Let them be as they are; I will be as I am. Even if they stripped naked before me, how could they defile me?" And so he remained among them, unshaken.

After Hui’s death, his disciples wished to compose a eulogy. His wife said, "You do not know him as I do." Then she recited:
*"Unboastful was my husband,
Unwearied was my husband,
True and sincere, he harmed no one.
Yielding and adaptable, he did not force his judgment.
Though humble, he saved the people—his virtue grew ever greater.
Though dismissed, he was never obscured.
Oh, joyful and steadfast, ever able to refine himself!"*
The posthumous name "Hui" was fitting, and his disciples followed her words, unable to alter a single character.

The wife of Master Qian Lou of Lu. When the master died, Zengzi and his disciples went to offer condolences. His wife came to the door, and Zengzi entered the hall. There lay the master’s body beneath the window, his head resting on a well-curb, his mat woven of rushes, his quilted robe unlined, covered only by a plain cloth. His limbs were not fully concealed—when the cloth was drawn over his head, his feet were exposed, and when it covered his feet, his head was exposed. Zengzi said, "If you pull the cloth diagonally, it will cover him properly." The wife replied, "A diagonal may be ample, but a straight covering is insufficient. My husband, by refusing to compromise, reached this state. In life, he did not deviate; in death, to deviate would not be his wish." Zengzi asked, "What posthumous name should he be given?" His wife said, "Call him 'Kang.'" Zengzi said, "In life, he could not fill his mouth with food or cover his body with clothing. In death, his limbs are not properly arranged, and there are no offerings of wine or meat. In life, he did not attain righteousness; in death, he did not receive honor. What joy is there in this that he should be called 'Kang'?" His wife replied, "Formerly, the Lord of Lu wished to appoint him to office and make him chief minister, but he declined. This shows he had more than enough honor. The lord bestowed upon him thirty *zhong* of grain, but he refused to accept it. This shows he had more than enough wealth. He savored the blandest flavors in the world, content with the humblest positions. He was not distressed by poverty and lowliness, nor dazzled by wealth and nobility. He sought benevolence and attained it; he sought righteousness and attained it. To call him 'Kang' is most fitting." Zengzi said, "Only such a man could have such a wife!"

The record states: I observe that the transformative power of exemplary conduct was not unique to King Wen. Even in the households of grand ministers, it was evident. Liu Xia Hui’s integrity could not be swayed even by his disciples; Qian Lou’s joy was not fully grasped even by Zengzi. Could these great scholars and learned Confucians truly not match the insight of these common men and women? What they perceived and were moved by ran deep—how wise were these two wives! Those who seek virtue and instruction should take note: even wealth and nobility are not worth prizing.

The wife of Da Fu of Tao, the minister Da Zi. After Da Zi governed Tao for three years, his reputation did not flourish, though his family’s wealth tripled. His wife admonished him, but he paid no heed. Five years later, he returned home with a retinue of a hundred chariots, and his clansmen slaughtered an ox to celebrate. His wife alone held their child and wept. Her mother-in-law grew angry and said, "Why are you so inauspicious?"

The wife replied: "That my husband holds a high office yet performs little duty is to invite harm; that he achieves no merit yet his family prospers is to accumulate misfortune. Recall how Lord Wen of Chu governed the state: his family was poor while the nation grew rich, the ruler respected him and the people revered him, so blessings extended to his descendants and his name endured through later generations. Now my husband pursues wealth and seeks grandeur, heedless of future calamity. I have heard that on South Mountain there is a dark leopard that fasts for seven days in the mist and rain, seeking to moisten its fur and perfect its markings—thus it conceals itself and avoids harm. But the dog that gorges without restraint grows fat only to await its slaughter. Now my husband governs Tao: his family grows rich while the state grows poor, the army holds no respect for him, the people offer no allegiance, and signs of ruin are already manifest. I wish to take our young son and depart." Her mother-in-law grew furious and cast her out. In his later years, Da Zi’s household was indeed executed for banditry, only his aged mother spared. The wife then returned to care for her, and her mother-in-law lived out her natural span.

It is recorded: In observing Da Zi’s wife, can one not see her as a person of the Dao? Only the sage can truly recognize the thief. Those who are not sages, even if burdened with the weight of state and family, still cannot perceive it—how much less can common men and women? The thief need not be plundered by others; one plunders oneself. Today, how many in the world hold high office with little merit and grow wealthy without accomplishment? I fear the people of Qi would still feel shame at such conduct, let alone Da Zi. Thus the noble person must take heed.

The wife of Le Yangzi. Yangzi traveled afar to seek a teacher and returned after a year. His wife knelt and asked the reason. Yangzi said, "I have been away long and miss home; there is no other cause." His wife then took up a knife and approached the loom, saying: "This cloth begins with silkworm cocoons and is completed on the loom. A single thread is piled upon another to make an inch; inches accumulate without cease to form a bolt. Now if this weaving were cut short, the loss of progress would bring shame, and time would be wasted. My husband accumulates learning, daily striving to know what he lacks and to perfect his virtue. If you return halfway, how is this different from severing this cloth?" Yangzi was moved by her words, returned to complete his studies, and did not come home for seven years.

It is recorded: Le Yangzi’s learning does not appear in the classics or histories. If we consider it the learning of sages and worthies, it must reach the depths of sincerity; if we consider it the learning of the common world, it must attain precision and refinement. The ancients toiled unceasingly, their efforts and encouragement like this. Yet today, those who idle away their days and willingly remain ignorant are truly inferior even to common women.

From the *Zuo Tradition*: When Qu Xia of Chu attacked Luo, Guo Boyi saw him off and said, "Mo’ao is certain to fail. He raises his banner high, but his heart is not steadfast." He then went to see the Viscount of Chu and said, "You must reinforce the army." The Viscount declined. Guo Boyi returned and told his wife Deng Man. Deng Man said, "The great officer does not refer to the multitude; he means that the ruler should comfort the common people with trust, instruct the officials with virtue, and restrain Mo’ao with punishment. Mo’ao was arrogant after the battle at Pusao and will act on his own. If he attacks little Luo and you do not pacify him, will he not neglect precautions?" She had meant that the ruler should instruct the troops and favor pacification, summon the officials and encourage them with commands. But Mo’ao did not heed this. How could he not know that the entire Chu army had marched? The Viscount sent men of Lai to pursue him, but they did not catch up. Mo’ao reviled the men of Chu, saying, "Those who remonstrate will be punished." When he reached Hao, the troops crossed in disorder, without formation or preparedness. At Luo, Luo and the Lu Rong routed them, and Mo’ao hanged himself in the wild valley.

King Wu of Chu arrayed his troops in the Jing formation and entrusted command to his generals to attack Sui. As they prepared to set out, he entered and told his wife Deng Man, "My heart is restless." Deng Man sighed and said, "The king’s fortune is at an end. To be full and restless is the Way of Heaven. Our late lord must have known this, for when he faced military affairs, he issued great commands to unsettle the king’s heart. If the army suffers no loss, and the king perishes on the march, it will be the state’s blessing." The king proceeded and died beneath the Gou tree.

It is recorded: In observing Deng Man’s words, one sees she did not let private concerns override public duty, nor affection obscure righteousness, and she knew the altars of the state were weightier than the ruler. In speaking thus, she must have hit the mark. Auspicious and inauspicious omens manifest in one’s bearing; goodness is always foreseen, and evil is always foreknown. Mo’ao’s lifting of his foot and King Wu’s restless heart—disaster was already certain. Why did the Viscount of Chu not perceive it? The attack on Luo and the alliance with Sui only hastened their doom.

How well put were the words of Empress Dowager Guangxian of Song: "If successful, one receives congratulations facing south; if not, the lives of ten thousand miles of people are at stake." Alas!

Should there have been admonitions given before matters unfolded, perhaps the disaster of Deng’s annihilation might have been averted. Yet how could one say Deng Man’s wisdom fell short of this?

When Duke Wen of Jin fled into exile and passed through Cao, Duke Gong of Cao showed him no courtesy. The wife of Xi Fuji said to her husband: "Our lord has been discourteous to the prince of Jin. I observe that his followers are all worthy men—if he takes the throne, the prince will surely return to Jin, gain supremacy among the feudal lords, and punish those who showed him no respect. Cao will be the first to suffer. Why not early distinguish yourself from the rest?" Thereupon, she wove a meal into a gourd and placed a jade disk within it. Duke Wen accepted the meal but returned the jade. Three years later, the Jin army attacked Cao, capturing it in the third month. On the day *bingwu*, they entered the city, reproaching Cao for its failure to employ Xi Fuji while maintaining three hundred chariot officials, and decreed that no one was to enter the precincts of Xi Fuji’s residence. Thus his clan was spared—a repayment of kindness.

It is recorded: Observing the songs of the clam and the mantis, one already knew Cao’s doom. Was this not because they indulged in petty amusements while neglecting far-sighted planning? The woven meal and the hidden jade were precisely such far-sighted planning. The spectacle of conjoined ribs was but a petty amusement. At that time, the way of petty men flourished, their qi and arrogance rampant, while the way of the noble waned, leaving even husband and wife to eat in poverty. Outwardly, their robes and adornments were fine and lovable, yet inwardly, their sense of shame, right and wrong had long since perished. This was the earnest devotion of common folk, unyielding in their attachment. Those who would take this as a mirror should take heed: never let the great affairs of state be reduced to private vengeance, and you will do well.

In the *Book of Han*, when Emperor Gaozu fell ill, Empress Lü asked: "After Your Majesty’s passing, when Chancellor Xiao is gone, whom should we appoint in his place?" The emperor replied: "Cao Shen will do." She asked again, and he said: "Wang Ling is suitable, though somewhat blunt. Chen Ping can assist him. Chen Ping’s wisdom is abundant, yet he cannot bear the burden alone. Zhou Bo is steadfast and unassuming, though lacking in refinement—yet he who will secure the Liu house must be Bo. Let him be made Grand Commandant." The empress pressed further, and the emperor said: "Beyond this, it is not for you to know."

It is recorded: The rise of the Liu house relied entirely on the collective strategies of many, yet its preservation sprang from the emperor’s singular insight. Could the emperor not have foreseen this and made arrangements in advance? Emperor Hui was weak, the forces of Wu and Chu vast, Han Xin and Peng Yue had perished, and the Han house stood alone and vulnerable. Had there been no wise empress, how could order have been restored? This is what is meant by: "To take, one must first give." As for the command of the Northern Army, it was no harder to entrust to kinsmen; the wisdom of Chen Ping and Zhou Bo was most evident in their days as ministers. Could the empress not have made subtle preparations, yielding in every matter? The crisis of the state was unfolding, the royal house newly stabilized, the unraveling of disaster by Bo and Kuai, the growing power of Chan and Lu—without men of paramount merit, other upheavals would surely arise. This, too, is what is meant by: "To take, one must first give." All was the wisdom of emperor and empress.

When King He of Changyi ascended the throne, he indulged in debauchery. Grand General Huo Guang and General of Chariots and Cavalry Zhang Shizhi plotted to depose him. Once their plan was settled, they sent the Minister of Agriculture, Tian Yannian, to inform Chancellor Yang Chang. Yang was startled and fearful, at a loss for words, sweat soaking his back, and could only murmur assent. When Tian left to change his clothes, Yang’s wife hurried from the eastern chamber and said to him: "This is a matter of state. The Grand General’s decision is already made, and he has sent a high minister to inform you, my lord. If you do not swiftly respond and align your heart with his, you will be no better than those who wavered—and will be executed before the deed is done." When Tian returned from changing clothes, Yang’s wife joined the conversation, and they agreed to follow the Grand General’s instructions.

It is recorded: Observing the words of Yang’s wife, one laments the reckless folly of King He of Changyi. What manner of affair is deposition? What office is the chancellorship? The Grand General could send someone to convey his words, and the chancellor’s wife could interject in the discussion. At such a critical juncture for the state, Yang, as chancellor, did not remain in the government but stayed at home. Had there been someone like Song Chang or Zhang Wu at King He’s side, Huo Guang’s plan would have failed; if his plan had failed, Yang and Tian would have met with execution. Thus, Yang’s wife was fortunate to have guessed correctly, while Xiahou Sheng was unfortunate not to have done so. What wisdom was there in this?

Consort Feng was the daughter of Feng Fengshi, the Right General. During the Jianzhao era, the emperor visited the tiger enclosure to watch beasts fight, and the ladies of the rear palace all followed. A bear broke free, climbed the railing, and tried to mount the hall. The consorts and noblewomen all fled in terror, but Feng Jiehao stood directly before the bear. The attendants slew the beast. The emperor asked Jiehao: "Everyone was frightened—why did you alone stand before the bear?" She replied: "I heard that when a fierce beast seizes a person, it stops. I feared it would reach the imperial seat, so I placed myself in its way." The emperor greatly admired her, and his esteem for her grew all the more.

It is recorded: This was an omen of the waning of the Han’s fiery mandate, a sign that the imperial line would soon end. It was no cause for praising the consort, but rather for lamenting the times. The admonition against sitting beneath the eaves, the caution of the son of a thousand gold—even such warnings pale beside the omen of dreaming of bears in the *Shi Gan* poem. Never has there been mention of making sport of fierce beasts for amusement, nor of standing fearless before a bear. A bear may be dreamed of, but it should not be seen. For it to break free without cause distorts the omen. Before long, Consort Zhao emerged, and though she bore children, auspicious signs were repeatedly obstructed. Was this not the clear verification of the bear’s escape?

In the *Book of Later Han*, in the first year of the Jianchu era of Emperor Ming, he wished to enfeoff his maternal uncles. Due to a great drought, critics attributed it to the lack of benevolence in such a move.

The officials again memorialized that the old precedents should be followed, but the Empress Dowager refused, issuing an edict that read: "Those who speak on this matter all seek to curry favor and secure blessings for themselves. In the past, the five marquises of the Wang clan were enfeoffed together, and at that time, yellow mist blanketed the land—yet no timely rain fell in response. Moreover, the disasters of Tian Fen and Dou Ying—whose favor and arrogance led to their downfall—have been passed down through the ages. Thus, the late Emperor guarded against the maternal uncles, forbidding them from holding positions of power. How could I betray the late Emperor’s intent, dishonor the virtue of my ancestors, and repeat the ruinous missteps of the Western Han?" She firmly refused.

The Emperor read the edict and sighed, saying: "Since the founding of the Han, the enfeoffment of maternal uncles has been as natural as the investiture of the Emperor’s sons as kings. Though the Empress Dowager is truly modest, how can I alone withhold grace from my three uncles?" He replied: "I have pondered this repeatedly. If grace is bestowed, both sides benefit—how could I merely seek the reputation of humility while leaving the Emperor open to the charge of failing in familial duty? I have often observed that in wealthy and noble families, when ranks and emoluments accumulate excessively, it is like a tree bearing fruit twice over—its roots will surely be harmed. The highest act of filial piety is to bring peace to one’s parents. Now, with repeated portents and grain prices soaring, I lie awake day and night, unable to rest. How could I prioritize the enfeoffment of my uncles and defy my mother’s earnest wishes? I am by nature stern and quick-tempered, with a fiery qi in my breast—do not oppose me." The Emperor then desisted.

Lu observed: The steadfast humility of Emperor Ming’s virtue was rooted in his profound reflection on past events. Those luminous pearls and verdant seedlings were but the burdens of empty reputation—could the late Emperor truly have been unenlightened? Chastened by the folly of concealing true intent for the sake of repute, he could not dismiss even ambiguous omens. The enfeoffment of princes and the ranks of kings were but tangible proofs—could he truly have been unmindful at the time? Warned by the yellow mists that shrouded the four quarters, he could not treat such matters with indifference. Later, Emperor Ming adhered to this principle, and thus in the portraits of the Cloud Terrace, he omitted even the relatives of the Empress’s chamber. Between husband and wife, mother and child, there was unity without discord.

Empress Deng of Hexi was five years old when her grandmother, the Elder Lady, doted on her and personally trimmed her hair. The old woman’s eyes dim with age, she accidentally cut the girl’s forehead, drawing blood, yet the child made no sound. When those around her marveled, she said: “It is not that I feel no pain, but I could not bear to distress an elder’s heart, so I endured it.” At twelve, she had mastered the *Analects* and other classics, her aspirations fixed upon the canonical texts, never inquiring after household affairs. Her family called her “the scholar.”

When she grew older and was selected for the palace, her beauty and grace set her apart from all others. Once, when she fell ill, the Emperor ordered her mother and brothers to enter and personally attend to her care. The Empress demurred, saying the palace’s prohibitions were too weighty for her kin to bear. The Emperor replied: “Others count repeated entry as an honor—do you alone regard it as a burden?” At that time, the vassal states vied to present rare and exotic treasures as tribute. Once she was established in the central palace, she ordered all such offerings forbidden.

Whenever the Emperor sought to bestow offices and ranks upon the Deng clan, the Empress would plead in sorrow, and thus her brother Deng Xun remained a mere Gentleman of the Tiger Guards throughout the Emperor’s reign. When she later became Grand Empress Dowager, a favored attendant named Jicheng was falsely accused of sorcery and witchcraft. The case was sent to the palace prison for interrogation. Recalling the late Emperor’s kindness toward the man, she summoned him and questioned him closely. It was revealed that the deed had been committed by an imperial servant. All marveled at her sagacity, deeming her truly enlightened.

She often held that spirits were inscrutable and that excessive sacrifices brought no blessing, and so she abolished all the offices of the various cults. She also sought out the younger brothers of Emperor He, along with over forty male descendants of the Princes of Jibei and Hejian, as well as more than thirty young men of the Deng clan’s close kin. She established residences for them, instructing them in the classics, personally overseeing their studies and admonitions, following the precedent of the Yongping era. As the late Duke had recorded his martial achievements on bamboo and silk, she complemented this with the civil virtue of educating descendants, ensuring they were well-disciplined and never transgressed the laws and statutes.

Lu observed: Some say that Empress Deng, in assuming regency, issued decrees throughout her life, to the point that the young Emperor cast sidelong glances and clenched his fists, while upright officials harbored resentment and met their deaths. Yet when Ban Zhao admonished her, she dismissed her entire household from office. When a beloved nephew committed a minor transgression, she shaved his head and beard in apology. This, too, may be called enlightened.

After the Jian’guang era, when power reverted to Wang Mang, worthy men were humiliated and executed, while flatterers and partisans advanced. Thus it is known that wielding authority invites slander, and what one cherishes may not be one’s own. Only by straining one’s heart to relieve the realm’s woes can a ruler strengthen the state. The noble person must not, for the sake of a single flaw, sever all ties with the mother of the world. Thus I record this.

From *Records of the Three Kingdoms*: The Breaker of Bandits General was of the Wu clan, wife to Sun Jian. In Jian’s youth, her kinsmen sought to refuse his suit. The lady said, “Why cling to a single daughter and court disaster?” Thus she consented to the marriage, bearing sons—Ce and Quan.

Once, Ce, on account of a grievance with the Merit Officer Wei Teng, was about to kill him. The lady leaned over the great well and said, “You have newly established yourself south of the Yangzi and ought to honor the worthy and overlook faults to record merits. This Merit Officer Wei serves the public good, offering you counsel in full. If you kill him today, tomorrow all will turn against you. I cannot bear to see calamity befall you and shall first cast myself into this well.” Ce was greatly alarmed and immediately released Teng.

When Quan, in his youth, assumed leadership, the lady aided in governing the state and military, bringing great benefit. Cao Cao sent a letter demanding Quan send a hostage. Quan was about to comply when Zhou Yu called upon the lady, saying, “Now Wu inherits the legacy of father and elder brother, commanding the multitudes of six commanderies. Our troops are well-trained, provisions abundant, and officers and soldiers obey orders. We smelt mountains and boil seas, enriching all within our borders—what compulsion is there to send a hostage?” The lady replied, “Lord Yu’s counsel is sound,” and thus did not dare proceed.

She was honored as Grand Empress and, before her passing, summoned Zhang Zhao and others to entrust them with affairs of state.

From this region emerged fierce and resolute figures, bearing the bold spirit of Sun Ce. His wife, Lady Xu, was wise and perceptive, skilled in divination. When Sun Quan executed Wu Commandery’s Grand Administrator Sheng Xian, Xian’s former subordinate Yan Lan sought vengeance, and Xu Xu’s attendants also plotted rebellion. As the various county magistrates and prefects gathered for a meeting, Xu Xu intended to follow the road to Sheng Dao, and consulted Lady Xu for divination. She warned that the omens were inauspicious and advised waiting for another day, but Xu Xu ignored her and held a grand banquet for his guests. Drunk, he was killed by the conspirators among his attendants. Yan Lan entered the residence, seized all the concubines, and attempted to force himself upon Lady Xu. Fearing harm if she resisted, she deceived him, saying, “Wait until the end of the mourning period, when I will perform the rites and remove my mourning garments.” Lan agreed. Secretly, she sent a trusted servant to summon former generals Sun Gao and Fu Ying, and covertly assembled over twenty attendants to lie in wait and plot. When the day came, after the rites were completed and mourning clothes removed, she perfumed her garments and set up a separate curtained chamber to await Lan. She then sent for him, and he, suspecting nothing, entered with a lavish feast. As Lady Xu went out to greet him and had just begun to bow, she called out, and Gao and Ying emerged, seizing and killing Lan. Lady Xu then donned her mourning attire again, presented Lan’s head at Xu Xu’s grave, and the entire army was stunned, regarding the event as divine.

It is recorded: Sun Ce’s impulse to kill Wei Teng mirrors Sun Quan’s grudge against Sheng Xian. Lady Xu’s divination to stop her husband parallels the remonstrances against the young lord of Wu.
