Ce was fortunate to heed the warning before disaster struck, while Xu Xu, tragically, ignored it on the brink of ruin. Had the mother’s wisdom and strategy been heeded, her honor would have endured to the end; instead, the wife’s foresight was in vain, and all was lost in sorrow. Yet as a woman, she displayed resourcefulness and cunning, unyielding resolve—not only avenging her husband but also preserving her own chastity. This aligns with the *Yijing*’s words: “Grieving for her virtue, steadfast, a woman’s warning: the husband meets misfortune.” Lady Xu’s divination surely reflected this understanding.

The *Book of Jin* records: Hua Dan’s wife, Lady Xin, styled Xianying, was the daughter of Wei’s Palace Attendant Xin Pi. She was intelligent and discerning. When Emperor Wen of Wei was at odds with Chen Si Wang and later named heir apparent, he embraced Xin Pi and said, “Lady Xin, do you know my joy?” Pi relayed this to Xianying, who replied, “The heir apparent succeeds the ruler to oversee the ancestral temples and altars of state. Ritual dictates sorrow, yet he rejoices—how can this last?” Later, her younger brother Xin Chang served as an aide to the Grand General Cao Shuang. When Sima Yi was about to execute Shuang, he closed the city gates while the emperor was outside. Chang, alarmed, asked Xianying, “The Son of Heaven is beyond the walls, and the Grand Tutor has sealed the gates. Rumors say this bodes ill for the state.” She replied, “As I see it, the Grand Tutor would not act thus—this is merely to execute Shuang. Yet you must not remain inside.” He asked, “How can I abandon my post?” She said, “Upholding duty is a person’s great principle. Even in peril, one may still show compassion. Follow the crowd.” Chang went out, and Sima Yi indeed executed Shuang. After the affair settled, Chang sighed, “Had I not consulted my sister, I would have nearly failed in righteousness.”

Later, when Zhong Hui was appointed General Who Pacifies the West, Xianying asked her nephew Xin You, “Why is Zhong Shiji heading west?” You replied, “To conquer Shu.” She said, “Hui indulges his impulses in office—this is no way to endure in a subordinate’s position. I fear he harbors other ambitions.” When Hui prepared to depart, he requested You as his aide. Xianying grew anxious, saying, “Disaster will come to our family.” You repeatedly petitioned Emperor Wen, who refused. Xianying told You, “Go then. Remember: the noble person of old devoted filial piety at home and upheld loyalty abroad. In office, think of your duties; in righteousness, think of your principles. Do not bring your parents sorrow. Amidst the trials of war, only benevolence can prevail.” Hui reached Shu and indeed rebelled. You ultimately returned unharmed, such was her foresight.

It is recorded: Observing Lady Xin’s wisdom, she did not merely predict events accurately. Her words on Wei’s succession touched upon the great balance of gain and loss; her counsel on Cao Shuang’s execution concerned the critical moment of dynastic transition; her warning about Zhong Hui’s rebellion addressed the paramount duty of governance. In matters of ruler and minister, inner and outer, kin and stranger, she discerned truth as if by candlelight, weighing right and wrong as with a scale. Even the so-called great men and gentlemen of her time fell short. Alas! Should such paragons be sought only among the women of the inner chambers?

Lady Zhong, wife of Wang Hun, styled Yan, was the great-granddaughter of Zhong Yao, Grand Mentor of Wei, and the daughter of Zhong Hui, Gentleman of the Yellow Gate. From childhood, Yan could compose essays, and as she grew, she became wise, magnanimous, and refined. Well-versed in the classics and histories, she possessed a graceful bearing, excelled in whistling and connoisseurship, and her conduct in ritual and propriety served as a model for her kin. After marrying Hun, she bore Wang Ji.

Once, as husband and wife sat together, Ji passed through the courtyard. Hun joyfully remarked, “To have a son like this is enough to console a man’s heart.” Hun’s younger brother Lun had a daughter who was also talented and virtuous, and they sought a worthy husband for her. At the time, there was a remarkably handsome son of a military family, and Ji wished to arrange a marriage for him. He informed Yan, who replied, “First, let me see him.” Ji had the young man mingle with a group of servants, and Yan observed him from behind a curtain. She then said to Ji, “The one in coarse clothing—was he not the one you selected?” Ji replied, “Yes.” Yan said, “This man’s talent is indeed outstanding, but his lineage is humble and his lifespan short; he will not live to fulfill his potential. The marriage should not proceed.” They abandoned the idea, and the man indeed died a few years later. Yan’s keen judgment and foresight were all of this kind.

It is recorded: With Hun’s profound insight came Yan, and with Yan’s discernment came Ji. Within one family, fathers were true fathers, sons true sons, husbands true husbands, and wives true wives—truly a flourishing household. Was it not fitting that the Wang clan should rise to prominence? Hun’s younger brother’s wife, Lady Hao, was also virtuous. Though Yan hailed from a noble family, she treated Hao with warmth and respect, and Hao did not humble herself in deference, nor did Yan lord her status over her. Contemporaries praised Lady Zhong’s propriety and Lady Hao’s exemplary conduct.

Du Youdao’s wife, Lady Yan, styled Xian, was chaste and virtuous, possessing both wisdom and magnanimity. Her husband died young, leaving behind a young son, Zhi, and a daughter, Han. Though still young herself, Yan vowed never to remarry. She raised her children with care, instructing them in ritual and propriety. Zhi later gained renown, and Han, too, was known for her virtue. Fu Xuan sought her as his second wife, and Yan consented. At the time, Xuan was at odds with He Yan and Deng Yang, who constantly sought to harm him, so no one dared arrange a marriage with him. When Yan agreed to the match, those within and without expressed concern, saying, “He and Deng hold power and will surely bring ruin to Xuan—like toppling a mountain onto an egg or pouring boiling water on snow.” Yan replied, “You see only one side of the matter, not the other. He and Deng are arrogant and extravagant; they will surely bring about their own downfall. I fear the egg will shatter and the snow melt—what is to come will come.” Later, they were indeed executed by Emperor Xuan. Zhi rose to the position of Governor of Nan’an. His cousin Yu, serving as Inspector of Qinzhou, was falsely accused and summoned back. Yan sent him a letter admonishing him to endure humiliation and bear disgrace, for he was destined for the rank of the Three Excellencies. Yu indeed became a Cavalier Attendant-in-Ordinary.

Xuan’s son by his first wife, Cheng, was six years old when he accompanied his stepmother to visit Yan. Yan said to him, “You are a thousand-mile colt—you will surely go far.” She arranged for him to marry her niece, and he, too, later gained fame throughout the land. Such was her ability to recognize talent.

The *Record* states: Observing the mother of the Yan clan, her virtue, wisdom, and insight were far beyond the ordinary. In foreseeing the downfall of He and Deng, she did not merely rely on conventional sayings like “Deng’s sinews fail to bind his bones—this is the restlessness of a ghost” or “He’s blood lacks luster—this is the gloom of a ghost.” Yet in recognizing the talents of Chang Yu, was she not akin to the scholars of Yingchuan, such as Yu Chun, who marveled at Xian Xian’s writings as nearly poetic? One judgment was made by principle, the other by observing conduct. How, then, did she attain such discernment? Precisely because she preserved within herself the trials of adversity, and thus Heaven refined her into a paragon. This is not only true for orphaned ministers and disgraced sons, but also for widows and chaste wives.

Liu Yin’s wife, née Zhang, was such a woman. Yin was deeply versed in the classics and history, endowed with lofty aspirations for service, frugal yet not austere, pure yet not aloof—all in his village and clan praised him. When the Prince of Qi, serving as Minister of Works, summoned him as an aide, and General Yang Hu of the Southern Campaign invited him to join his staff, he declined both on grounds of illness. At the time, a fellow townsman, Zhang Xuanzi, a man of keen perception, urged Yin to accept the appointments. Yin replied: “The two lords of our age are the pillars of Jin. I aspire to greatness, yet I am but a rough-hewn beam. Without their support, how could I stand?” Moreover, with his grandmother still living, if he accepted another’s command, he could not fulfill his filial duty to serve her—this was why Ziyu declined the Qi minister’s offer. Xuanzi said: “What you say is beyond the understanding of ordinary men.” He then gave his daughter to Yin in marriage.

Xuanzi was a powerful clan leader in Bingzhou, wealthy in resources. His wife protested: “Our daughter is only fourteen, with such beauty and intelligence—why fear she could not become the consort of a duke or marquis? Why marry her to Yin so hastily?” Xuanzi replied: “This is not for you to comprehend.” He instructed his daughter: “Yin is profoundly filial, his devotion moves even the unseen; his talents and insight surpass the age. This man will surely rise far, becoming a renowned statesman. You must serve him with care.” Zhang, gentle and obedient by nature, was known for her filial devotion to her mother-in-law and treated Yin with the reverence due a lord or father.

She bore seven sons, five of whom each mastered one classic, one the *Records of the Grand Historian*, and one the *Book of Han*. Within a single household, ten scholarly pursuits flourished. In the northern provinces, the Liu family’s learning was unrivaled.

The *Record* states: In ancient times, filial piety brought men to office, and thus tales of miraculous grain and mulberry transformations appear in their biographies—here, we omit such accounts, for mere records cannot do justice to their virtue. Yet Xuanzi’s discernment was such that he settled his daughter’s marriage based on a single conversation. This is the beauty of judging words and observing deeds—a model for those who cherish their daughters. As for the five sons each mastering a classic, one the *Records of the Grand Historian*, and one the *Book of Han*, with seven scholarly pursuits thriving in one household—this is especially worthy of emulation.

From the *History of the Song*: Empress Liu of Emperor Zhenzong, known posthumously as Zhangxian Mingsu, was quick-witted and well-versed in history. When she heard matters of court, she could recount their origins and conclusions. Zhenzong often reviewed memorials from across the realm late into the night, and she was privy to all palace affairs. When questioned, she would cite precedents in response, earning the emperor’s deep respect. In the fourth year of Tianxi, the emperor fell gravely ill and remained in the palace, with many affairs entrusted to the empress. After Zhenzong’s death, she became Grand Empress Dowager. Matters of state and military importance were decided by her authority. For eleven years, the emperor and the empress dowager jointly presided over the Chengming Hall. Though governance emanated from the palace, her decrees were strict and clear, her grace and authority extended throughout the realm. Those close to her were granted little leniency, and she never made arbitrary changes. Rewards within and beyond the court were measured. Formerly, tea bestowed upon great ministers bore dragon and phoenix motifs. The empress dowager said: “How could such designs befit subjects?” She ordered the ministry to create new designs for imperial gifts.

The empress dowager would replace the imperial tableware with plain vessels whenever her clan members dined, saying: “These are court utensils—do not let them enter my household.”

The *Record* states: The precedent of an empress dowager of the Song assuming regency began here—why is this worth noting? The *Book of Changes*, in the hexagram *The Family*, says: “Wealth within the family brings great fortune, for the proper order is maintained.” At that time, the emperor was gravely ill, and the heir apparent was still young. Had the empress dowager not possessed such wisdom, who else could have governed the realm? The emperor’s deep trust in her was well-founded.

When she first took the throne, there was no precedent to follow. Had she repeated the mistakes of the Han and Tang, how could the Song have maintained its rule? Her conduct was beyond reproach. She upheld authority without overstepping her subordinate role, and followed the Dao of Heaven without defying the times.

When Fang Zhonggong requested the establishment of a temple for the Liu clan, she refused. When Cheng Lin presented a portrait of Empress Wu of Tang holding court, she rejected it. Other measures—such as reclaiming surplus grain from transport officials, replacing imperial utensils, heeding the counsel of chief ministers, and bestowing honors upon the deceased—were all matters of state that could not be disregarded.

Empress Cao of Renzong was wise and well-versed in classics and history, skilled in *feibai* calligraphy. In the intercalary first month of the eighth year of Qingli, when the emperor ordered lanterns to be displayed again for the full-moon festival, she admonished him to cease.

Three days later, several palace guards mutinied. They leapt over the rooftops and stormed the imperial bedchamber. The empress, who had been attending the emperor, rose at once upon hearing the disturbance. The emperor attempted to flee, but she barred the door, shielding him, and urgently summoned the palace guard commander Wang Shouzhong to lead troops inside. Anticipating the rebels would set fires, she secretly ordered water to be prepared. As expected, the rebels lit torches to burn the curtains, but the flames were extinguished at once.

That night, she personally cut locks of hair from the attending officials and maids, declaring: “Tomorrow, rewards will be given—this will serve as proof.” Thus, they fought with all their might, and the rebels were swiftly captured and executed.

When palace concubines conspired with the guards, they deserved execution. Some pleaded for mercy through favored consorts, and the emperor spared their lives. The empress insisted they be punished according to the law, saying: “Without this, how can the palace be kept pure?”

When the future Emperor Yingzong was only four, she examined his character thoroughly. Later, when he was named heir, her counsel played a significant role. When the emperor suddenly passed away at night, she gathered all the palace gate keys before her and summoned the crown prince. By dawn, the chief ministers, including Han Qi, arrived and escorted Yingzong to the throne.

When the emperor fell ill, she requested to temporarily manage state and military affairs. She held court at the small eastern hall of the inner palace. When ministers presented matters of doubt, she would say: “Discuss it further among yourselves,” never imposing her own opinion. Though dozens of memorials arrived daily, she could recall every detail with precision. She granted no leniency to the Cao clan or her attendants, and the palace remained orderly.

The *Record* states: When Empress Mingsu held court, she intended to wield power. Thus, within the palace, there were rebellions by Zhou Huaizheng, Yang Chongxun, and Yang Huaigao; outside, plots by Ding Qing, Qian Weiyan, and Cao Liyong. Had Wang Zeng not stood firm, her reign might not have ended well.

When Empress Guangxian held court, she had no desire to seize authority. When ministers presented uncertain matters, she would say: “Discuss it further among yourselves,” never imposing her own will. Though she lacked Han Qi’s bold admonitions, she never clung to power. This became a model for later generations.

Empress Gao of Yingzong was benevolent, wise, and discerning. When Emperor Shenzong repeatedly sought to build a grand residence for the Gao clan, she refused. Eventually, she accepted only a plot of unused land outside Wangchun Gate, and all construction costs were borne by the empress dowager, without drawing a single coin from the state treasury.

When the emperor fell ill, the chief ministers, including Wang Gui, came to inquire. The empress wept and, caressing the young Zhezong, said: “He is filial. Since the emperor took medicine, he has never left his side. He delights in studying the *Book of Documents* and reciting the *Analects*.” She then presented him to the ministers, and that very day, he was named crown prince.

When Cai Que was demoted, the empress told the ministers: “At the end of the Yuanyou era, I showed the present emperor’s writings to Wang Gui. He submitted a memorial of congratulations, and the succession was settled. Since the son succeeds the father, what objection could there be? Yet Cai Que, claiming credit for securing the succession, recklessly stirred up trouble, seeking to sow confusion in the future. I banished him. This concerns the great plan of the imperial house—how could I heed the slander of treacherous men?”

When her paternal uncle Zun Yu was punished for military failure, Cai Que flattered her by requesting his reinstatement. She replied: “During the Lingwu campaign, Zun Yu brought suffering to millions. The late emperor received the news and was so shocked he could not sleep all night, leading to his sudden illness. The disaster was Zun Yu’s doing. That he escaped execution is already fortunate. How dare I favor private ties over righteousness?”

After Song Yongchen was dismissed, a wet nurse entered to plead for his return. The empress, seeing her approach, asked: “Why have you come? Are you here to lobby for Yongchen and others? Do you still seek imperial decrees to interfere in state affairs, as before? If you persist, I will have you executed.” From then on, such decrees ceased.

When she fell ill, Lü Dafang, Fan Chunren, and others came to inquire. She said: “Tell me—over the past nine years, have I ever shown favoritism to the Gao clan? I have been utterly impartial. Even when my own son and daughter were dying, I did not see them.” With tears in her eyes, she continued: “The late emperor often regretted past events, weeping over them. The emperor should remember this well.”

She added: “I wished to speak plainly to the emperor. After my death, many will try to manipulate him—he must not listen. You ministers should also retire early, so the emperor may employ a new generation.” Then she called her attendants and asked: “Have the communal festival meals been distributed?” She instructed the ministers: “Each of you, take a spoonful. Next year, when you eat the festival meal, remember me.”

The Record states: Observing the dying admonitions of Empress Dowager Xuanren of the Song, one cannot but weep upon repeated reflection. Comparing her with Empress Dowager Feng of the Northern Wei—both having ruled as grandmothers—Xuanren embodied ten virtues, while Feng committed ten transgressions.

What are the ten virtues? First, her benevolence and clarity; second, her compassion and resoluteness; □ third, her trust in the worthy; fourth, her reverence for the old; fifth, her abolition of harsh governance; sixth, her repeal of the New Laws; seventh, her pacification of the realm; eighth, her suppression of border conflicts; ninth, her refusal of court congratulations in the main hall; and tenth, her rejection of private favors for her maternal clan. Which of these is not worthy of contemplation?

What are the ten transgressions? First, her usurpation of power; second, her assumption of imperial prerogatives; third, her misconduct; fourth, her private indulgence of favorites; fifth, her murder of the sovereign; sixth, her arbitrary executions; seventh, her jealousy of the sovereign’s brilliance; eighth, her confinement of the sovereign without food in bitter cold; ninth, her heeding of eunuchs’ words; and tenth, her flogging of the sovereign dozens of times. Which of these is not deserving of hatred?

Yet no sooner had the communal festival meal cooled than her policies were fiercely overturned. In one case, the golden tablets and funeral armlets were presented, and mourning never ceased.

Thus it was that Wei employed the Xia to transform the Yi, thereby suppressing their urgent and anxious longings; whereas Song, on the verge of being transformed by the Yi, suffered no less than the turmoil of confusion. Though this arose from human failings, it was also the decree of Heaven’s course. Had it not been so, though grandfather and grandson were of one body, the latter’s earnest admonitions would have been met with the sovereign’s indifference—what the wise would call folly, and what in governance is deemed a grievous error.

*The Record of Song’s Illustrious Ministers* states: Fu Bi, Duke of Zheng, married Lady Han of the State of Han, who was the daughter of Yuanxian. When Bi first entered the examination halls, Mu Xiu said to him, “The civil service examinations are not enough to fully display your talents; you ought to make your name in the higher examinations.” It so happened that an edict was issued to select scholars through the higher examinations. At the time, Bi’s father was serving as an official in Yaozhou and was about to return west. Fan Wenzheng sent someone to pursue him, urging him to hasten back to the capital. Upon meeting Wenzheng, Bi declined, saying he had never studied for such examinations. Wenzheng replied, “I have already heard of your recommendation from the ministers. For some time now, I have prepared a chamber for you, filled with texts for the higher examinations—you may go and reside there.”

At the time, Yuanxian was serving as chancellor and sought to arrange a marriage with Wenzheng. Wenzheng said, “If your daughter is to marry an ordinary official, I dare not presume to know. But if you seek a scholar of national distinction, none surpasses Fu Bi.” Yuanxian, upon meeting Bi, held him in great esteem and immediately proposed the match. Bi thus passed the examination for *Xianliang Fangzheng* with distinction.

Earlier, Bi’s father had been a retainer in the household of Lord Wenmu of Lü. One day, he said to Wenmu, “My son is about ten years old; I wish to send him to the academy to study under the tutelage of Attending Secretary Tai Zhu.” Wenmu agreed. When he met the boy, he was astonished and declared, “This young man will one day hold a position like mine, but his achievements will far surpass my own.” He ordered that Bi be educated alongside his own sons and provided him with generous support. Later, Bi indeed rose to the rank of chancellor. It was said that the three lords—Wenzheng, Wenmu, and Yuanxian—were unmatched in their ability to recognize talent, and Lady Han was no less discerning.

The *Record* observes: Though the dust of worldly appearances may be difficult to transcend, the discernment of dragons and qilin among steeds must naturally exist. In this, the three lords each acted without partiality: one did not favor his son because of a retainer’s lowly status; another did not withhold his daughter due to his own high rank as chancellor; and the third did not shrink from advancing his disciple despite the risk of suspicion. In the end, phoenixes shone together, ice and jade gleamed in mutual brilliance, pillars stood in equal splendor, and both family and state alike reaped the benefits. Such deeds are truly rare and worthy of record.

*The Hongdao Record*, Scroll Forty-Three Concluded
*The Hongdao Record*, Scroll Forty-Four: Wisdom

**Wisdom Among Brothers**

From *Mencius*:
Wan Zhang asked, "Was Shun in the right?"
Mencius replied, "How could he not have been?"
"Yet Shun did not know that Xiang was about to kill him."
"How could he not have known? When Xiang grieved, he grieved; when Xiang rejoiced, he rejoiced."

Chen Jia asked, "When the Duke of Zhou appointed Guan Shu to oversee Yin, Guan Shu rebelled with Yin. Did this happen?"
Mencius said, "Yes."
"Did the Duke of Zhou know he would rebel yet still appoint him?"
"He did not know."
"Then even sages may err?"
"The Duke of Zhou was the younger brother; Guan Shu, the elder. Was the Duke of Zhou’s error not fitting?"

The *Record* observes:
Expediency (*quan*) is the great application of the sage; wisdom (*zhi*) is the foundation of practicing expediency. Expediency is not something the great sage fails to employ, nor is wisdom something he fails to follow—each is required to its utmost.

In Xiang’s time, Shun was not incapable of exercising expediency. Yet with nine sons, two daughters, a hundred officials, oxen, and sheep, his heart was like that of a destitute man with nowhere to turn. Thus, when Xiang grieved, he grieved; when Xiang rejoiced, he rejoiced. This was not due to any lack of true wisdom but to his desire to accord with his kin.

In the time of Guan and Cai, the Duke of Zhou was not incapable of employing wisdom. Yet with the royal house newly stabilized and stubborn people still numerous, how could his heart bear to slight his kin? Thus, he first appointed Guan Shu to oversee Yin and later punished his rebellion. This was not due to any lack of true benevolence but to his desire to secure the royal house.

If later generations fail to bestow rewards as at Taiyuan—withholding what should be given, provoking the shame and resentment of foolish sons, or believing hollow words of deference; or hesitating when decisions must be made, leading to great bloodshed—then both benevolence and wisdom are lost.

The *Yi Jing*'s *Ming Yi* hexagram states: "It is advantageous to abide in hardship and correctness," for one must obscure one’s brightness. When inner turmoil arises yet one maintains rectitude of purpose, as did Jizi.

The *Record* says: The *Book of Documents* states, "I shall emerge and dwell elsewhere; my aged house has yielded to desolation." This is what is meant by outwardly obscuring one’s brightness. "To pacify oneself as a common man and offer oneself to a master" is what is meant by inwardly preserving one’s rectitude. Such were the ancient sages—luminous yet wise, preserving themselves. Those whose intelligence dazzles others while their inner substance is lacking cannot be spoken of in the same breath.

The *Zuozhuan* records: Duke Hui of Lu’s primary consort was Mencius. After Mencius died, he took Shengzi as his secondary wife, who bore Duke Yin. Duke Wu of Song had a daughter, Zhongzi, whose palm bore a mark at birth reading, "To be the Lady of Lu." Thus, Zhongzi was wed to Lu and bore Duke Huan. When Duke Hui died, Duke Yin ascended the throne to serve as regent.

The *Record* says: Observing the affairs of Duke Yin and Duke Huan is like watching an infant at play—tossed into a nest, given three times, taken three times. It is a jest for all ages. The failure to clarify great righteousness and the lack of secrecy in critical matters are equally unworthy of concealment. When Duke Hui’s primary consort died, both Sheng and Zhong were but concubines, and the mark on the palm should have been disregarded. When Duke Hui died without a testament, both Yin and Huan were merely sons of concubines, and the name of filial devotion should have been set aside for this principle. Had this been done, the scheming of petty men would have been averted. One ought to have forthrightly clarified great righteousness, rectified past errors, ensured names were correct and words proper, and cut off the source of trouble at its root. Then Yu Fu’s wickedness would not have dared to run rampant, and Huan might have found contentment in his station. This was the critical moment—both opportunities were lost, yet Duke Yin remained blithely unaware of impending disaster. I cannot fathom his state of mind. Confucius said, "One without foresight will surely face immediate woe." Hu’s commentary also states: "If one does not resolve matters early, how can good prevail?"

When Lord Huan of Cai died, the people of Cai summoned Cai Ji from Chen. Ji was the courtesy name of the younger brother of the Marquis of Cai. In autumn, Cai Ji returned from Chen to Cai, and the people of Cai praised him.

According to He [Xiu]’s commentary: The Lord of Cai had no son; Ji was next in line to succeed, but the Lord wished to enthrone Xianwu and despised Ji, so Ji fled to Chen. When the Lord died, Ji returned to attend the funeral, harboring no resentment, and was praised for his virtue, hence his courtesy name.

The *Record* says: Duke Yin was one who could have halted but did not, could have hastened but did not. Duke Mu was one who gave as though not giving, seized as though not seizing. Cai Ji was one who could depart when he should, remain when he should, take when he should, and relinquish when he should. In this, none were not deemed wise and virtuous.

In the autumn of the eleventh year of Duke Zhuang, Song suffered a great flood. The Duke sent an envoy to offer condolences, saying, "Heaven has sent excessive rains, harming the sacrificial grains. How could one not offer condolences?" The reply came: "It is I alone who was irreverent; Heaven has sent this disaster. Yet you deem it a concern for your lord, and I bow to the honor of your command." Zang Wenzhong said, "Song shall rise again! When Yu and Tang blamed themselves, their rise was swift. When Jie and Zhou blamed others, their fall was sudden. Moreover, when states suffer calamity, it is proper to express sympathy. To speak with trepidation and name it propriety—this bodes well." Later, it was heard that this referred to the rebellion of Prince Yushuo. Zang Sunda said, "He is fit to be ruler, for he has a heart that pities the people."

The *Record* says: Zang Wenzhong believed Song would rise because it blamed itself. Was this so? The omen of the great flood was the portent of regicide. Better to reflect inwardly and trace the true cause of disaster than to blame oneself and gain an empty reputation. To be unrestrained yet without propriety is the root of chaos; to conceal evil and shun criticism is the harbinger of calamity. Min’s self-debasement and self-aggrandizement brought Heaven’s punishment, like a shadow following form, like an echo answering sound—this was no true concern for the people.

The Viscount of Chu attacked the Rong of Luhun and proceeded to Luo, displaying his military might at the borders of Zhou. King Ding sent Wangsun Man to offer labor to the Viscount of Chu, who inquired about the size and weight of the Nine Tripods. Wangsun Man replied: "It lies in virtue, not in the tripods. In ancient times, when the Xia possessed virtue, distant lands depicted their creatures and offered metal from the Nine Provinces to cast the tripods, engraving images of all things to prepare the people. Thus, when they entered rivers and marshes, mountains and forests, no demons or sprites could harm them, enabling harmony between high and low and the reception of Heaven’s favor. When Jie’s virtue was benighted, the tripods were transferred to Shang, which endured for six hundred years. When Shang Zhou was cruel and tyrannical, the tripods were transferred to Zhou. When virtue is radiant and bright, even if small, it is weighty. When it is treacherous and benighted, even if great, it is light. Heaven blesses bright virtue, which has its limits. When King Cheng established the tripods at Jiao Ru, he divined thirty generations and seven hundred years—this was Heaven’s mandate. Though Zhou’s virtue has declined, Heaven’s mandate has not changed. The weight of the tripods cannot yet be questioned."

The *Record* says: I observe that Wangsun Man’s wisdom was sufficient for action, yet he did not act—he lacked self-strengthening. Mencius said, "When a state is at leisure, if one clarifies its governance and punishments at such a time, even great states will surely stand in awe." The *Book of Songs* says, "Before Heaven’s rain darkens, strip the mulberry’s bark, mend the windows and doors. Now, among these people below, who would dare insult me?" Chu is lawless, usurping the rites of the Central States, its heart that of a serpent or pig, its might that of a tiger or wolf—how could this be unknown? If Zhou’s lord and ministers truly valued virtue, honored scholars, placed the worthy in office, and entrusted the capable with duties, Chu would be too busy submitting to take heed. Why then did Zhaizi falsify commands, Mao Su disrupt the state, commit usurpation, murder, and treachery, bringing such great shame?

Though they might gain praise from external voices, they lacked the resolve to rouse themselves with plans of self-strengthening, and thus it came to pass that Prince Chao fled to Chu and the Nine Tripods failed to serve their purpose—this much was already evident.

Wu Shang and his younger brother Wu Yuan were the sons of She. When King Ping of Chu seized She at Fei, Wu Qi said: "She’s sons are talented; if they remain alive, they will surely bring trouble to Chu. Why not summon them under the pretense of sparing their father’s life? They will surely come." The king sent for them. Shang said to Yuan: "Go to our father. I will return to die. My wisdom does not match yours. You have heard the command to spare our father—how can you not hasten to him? Our kin have been slaughtered—how can you not avenge them? Fleeing to save our father is filial. Weighing your actions by their merit is benevolent. Choosing your duty and going forth is wisdom. Strive for this." When She heard that Yuan was not coming, he said: "The lords and ministers of Chu will surely eat late into the night."

The *Lu Record* says: "Yuan’s perverse actions and inverted schemes were not without resentment. As for Wu Qi, I know not what blame he deserves. The stain of the *New Terrace*, the defilement of the green fly, the grievance of *Xiao Bian*, the sorrow of *Zhen Cui*—his accumulated evil had reached its limit. Why then did he urge Yuan to avenge him, seeking to sever the root of disaster only to nourish it further? There was no end to the ruin. Knowing Wu’s existence, he fanned its rise; knowing the calamity to come, he stirred its waves. Had Yuan not fled, how could he have failed to flee?"

Thus, without the summons to spare their father, the plan to attack Chu might have been delayed; without the flight of the Lord of Tang, Wu Zixu’s departure might not have been so swift. Heaven favors retribution, and principle follows echo—none can fathom how this comes to be.

The *Comprehensive Mirror* states: Tian Dan was a clansman of Qi, serving as a market officer in Linzi. When the people of Yan attacked Anping, Dan had his clansmen reinforce their chariot axles with iron bands. When the city fell, the people fought to escape through the gates, and their axles snapped, causing their chariots to break down and leaving them to be captured by Yan. Only Dan, with his iron-reinforced axles, escaped and fled to Jimo. At the time, all of Qi’s lands belonged to Yan except for Ju and Jimo, which remained unconquered. Yue Yi thus combined the right and front armies to besiege Ju, while the left and rear armies surrounded Jimo. The people of Jimo said: "In the battle of Anping, Tian Dan’s clansmen survived thanks to their iron bands—he is full of stratagems and skilled in warfare." They therefore made him their general to resist Yan.

The *Lu Record* says: "Yue Yi conquered over seventy cities, yet these two cities could not be subdued. What was the reason? Mencius’ words had already settled the matter—why seek further explanations? The enmity between Yan and Qi had festered for a long time. At its beginning, the fault lay with a single son, and it had nothing to do with the ancestral temples or altars of the state. In the end, the fault lay with King Min alone, and it had nothing to do with the ancestral temples or altars of the state. Had they executed that one son and sought a replacement, it would not have been for Qi’s sake; had they killed King Min and sought a replacement, it would not have been for Yan’s sake. Why then did the two states not act thus? In their invasion, they did not prioritize establishing a ruler but sought only to reach Yan. Thus, in their retaliation, they did not consider peaceful restoration but sought only to seize more. Had they followed Mencius’ counsel, there would have been no affair of Yue Yi, and what need would there have been for Ju and Jimo?"

Among the neighbors of Bi there was a litigant who, instead of addressing the grievance in his heart, clung to what he valued in secret. For years on end, the case remained unresolved, awaiting a reversal through coercion before it could be settled. Later, Tian Dan recovered all of Qi’s lost lands without coveting Yan’s gains, and only then did the enmity between Yan and Qi cease. This is what wisdom truly entails—it did not lie in the stratagem of iron bands.

Zhi Guo was the younger brother of Xuanzi. Initially, when Xuanzi’s son Yao was to be named heir, Guo said: "He is not as good as Xiao. Yao surpasses others in five ways but falls short in one. His fine beard and tall stature are virtues; his skill in archery, charioteering, and strength are virtues; his mastery of arts and readiness are virtues; his eloquence and intelligence are virtues; his resoluteness and daring are virtues. Yet he is utterly lacking in benevolence. With these five virtues, he will overpower others, but if he acts without benevolence, who will endure him? If Yao is established as heir, the Zhi clan will surely be destroyed." Xuanzi did not listen, so Guo separated his branch of the family in the grand historian’s records and renamed it Fu.

The *Lu Record* says: "How wise was Zhi Guo! His assessment of Yao was as clear as divining with tortoise shells. Why did Xuanzi not perceive this? The Way of benevolence has been obscured for a long time. If Lu’s ordinances could be called both fine and benevolent, could Yao’s virtues not be called benevolent? Yet if one does not examine his heart, then Jie was not lacking in eloquence and intelligence, Zhou was not lacking in resoluteness and daring, the Di were not lacking in fine beards and tall stature, Duan was not lacking in skill in archery and strength, and Nan Gong Changwan was not lacking in mastery of arts. Thus, in Confucius’ school, none spoke of the five virtues but took benevolence as the foundation. Without benevolence, the people cannot be preserved. Therefore, when the three families divided Jin, the hearts of the people were lost. How could one then occupy a lower position?"

Guo separated his clan and named it Fu to avoid the world’s hatred being directed at him.

The *Book of Han* states: Liu De was the son of Marquis Fu of Xiu. From a young age, he was astute and resourceful, often offering counsel. He was summoned to the Ganquan Palace, and Emperor Wu named him "the thousand-mile colt." At the beginning of Emperor Zhao’s reign, he served as assistant to the Minister of Ceremonies, then was promoted to Grand Master, and later returned to the Ministry of Ceremonies to investigate cases involving the Shangguan family. When Princess E was involved in affairs, De consistently adhered to Laozi’s principle of knowing contentment.

When his wife passed away, the Grand General Huo Guang wished to marry his daughter to him, but De declined the offer, fearing the perils of excessive prosperity. He often reproached Princess E’s grandson, Gai Chang, for his misconduct and held deep resentment toward him. Princess E’s grandson, Tan, intercepted De on the road, claiming to be an imperial attendant, and, believing Huo Guang’s displeasure at De’s refusal of his daughter stemmed from imperial directive, accused De of slander before the throne. De was imprisoned, stripped of his rank, and reduced to commoner status. Upon learning of this, Huo Guang regretted his actions and subsequently recommended De to serve as Acting Governor of Qingzhou, later reinstating him as Minister of the Imperial Clan.

When Emperor Xuan ascended the throne, De was enfeoffed as Marquis Within the Pass for his role in securing the succession, and later, in recognition of his kinship and virtuous conduct, was further honored as Marquis of Yangcheng. By nature, he was generous and kind, fond of aiding the living. Whenever he served as Prefect of the Capital, he frequently overturned unjust cases. Though his family wealth exceeded a million, he distributed it to relieve his kinsmen, guests, and retainers, saying, "This is how one averts the resentment of the wealthy."

The *Record* states: The *Great Learning* teaches: "What issues forth in defiance will return in defiance; what enters in defiance will depart in defiance." Wu’s defiance was indeed misguided, and propriety was not observed. Yet before long, Yan Shou met his demise—this was the consequence of defiance repaid. When Fu returned to the capital, he did not seek refuge in a distant land, which may be called prudent virtue. Thus, his son, too, knew contentment and restraint. This is how one discerns the origins of fortune and misfortune, the distinction between loyalty and arrogance. The sages of antiquity have long settled this truth, and it is not merely the teaching of Laozi.

In the fifth year of Yuan Kang during Emperor Xuan’s reign, when Emperor Yuan was still Crown Prince, Shu Guang served as Grand Tutor and his younger cousin, Shu Shou, as Junior Tutor. The Crown Prince, at twelve years of age, had already mastered the *Analects* and the *Classic of Filial Piety*. One day, Guang said to Shou: "I have heard that he who knows contentment avoids disgrace, and he who knows when to stop avoids peril. Now, I have risen to a salary rank of two thousand *shi*, achieved official success, and established my reputation. If I do not retire at this juncture, I fear future regret." That very day, both submitted memorials claiming illness and requested to return their bones to the soil. The emperor granted their pleas, bestowing upon them twenty catties of gold, while the Crown Prince presented fifty. The court officials and old friends prepared a farewell feast with elaborate decorations at the Eastern Capital Gate. Hundreds of carriages came to see them off, and onlookers along the road exclaimed, "How virtuous are these two great men!" Some sighed in admiration, and others wept in sorrow. Upon returning to their hometown, they sold their gold to purchase wine, inviting kinsmen, old friends, and guests to share in joyous celebration.

Some urged Guang to use his gold to establish substantial property for his descendants, but Guang replied: "Do you take me for a senile fool who does not think of his children and grandchildren? I already possess old fields and a homestead; if my descendants work diligently there, it will suffice to provide clothing and food, placing them on par with ordinary folk. To further increase their wealth would only breed indolence. The virtuous, when burdened with excess wealth, feel shame at the erosion of their resolve; the foolish, when enriched, only deepen their faults. Moreover, wealth invites the resentment of the multitude. Since I lack the means to instruct my descendants in virtue, I would not add to their faults and provoke enmity. As for this gold, it is the sagely ruler’s gift to nourish an aged minister. Is it not fitting that I share its bounty with my village kin and clan, thus spending my remaining days in joy?"

The record states: The abrupt resignation of the two Shus served as a rebuke to the precedent set by Huo Guang. Their refusal to amass property likewise exposed the folly of Yu Yunshan. Before them, Zhang Anshi had acted similarly; after them, Wang Ji followed suit, both adhering to the principle that "knowing contentment averts disgrace, knowing when to stop averts peril." Yet it was not that these two foresaw the untrustworthiness of the Crown Prince. Another passage remarks: How could Xiao Wangzhi be compared to the Shus? Wangzhi, upon learning that Han Yanshou would succeed him and that Feng Lan possessed a reputation surpassing his own, grew envious and sought to entrap them in legal transgressions. The two Shus, by contrast, were preoccupied with the fear that excess wealth would compound their descendants’ faults and breed resentment—would they ever engage in such mutual recrimination?

When Hong Xian framed Wangzhi, it was akin to Yanshou’s fate upon hearing the news—neither outcome was the emperor’s doing. Feng Yeshu’s father, Feng Fengshi, had served as General and Grand Master of Ceremonies, and Yeshu himself later became Left Fengyi. Father and son both held court positions, and critics praised their competence as befitting their offices, not the result of feminine favor. When Yeshu was promoted to Grand Herald and dispatched as Governor of Shang Commandery, his governance was ranked first. His younger brother, Feng Li, served as Governor of Pingyuan and later succeeded Yeshu in Shang Commandery. In office, Li was publicly upright and governed with a clemency akin to his brother’s, though he was more astute and generous, fond of issuing systematic instructions. The officials and people praised him, singing: "Great Lord Feng, Little Lord Feng, brothers in succession, one after the other, wise and virtuous, bestowing grace upon the people, their virtue and transformation like that of Lu and Wei, even the Duke of Zhou and Kang Shu cannot surpass these two lords." Alongside their brother Feng Bian, they were renowned in their time, each governing five commanderies and invariably achieving the highest evaluations in their posts.

The record states: In my humble view, while all deemed the Junqing brothers more worthy than the officials of Bohai, I would argue they were less adept at securing their own futures. Why? They declared: "All men seek favor and rank, but we alone embrace lowliness, for as brothers of the imperial in-laws, we cannot hold pivotal positions." Alas, such words betray a submission to the times. Had they not bowed to the era, they would have either become one of the Five Marquises or joined the ranks of Ding and Fu—how could they be called wise? By then, the royal net was in disarray; even Feng Meng and Mei Fu feared they had acted too late. How could earthworms linger in the damp? This is why Wu Zhangxu of Tang stood apart, beyond emulation.

In his youth, Ma Yuan, finding his family’s resources insufficient, asked his elder brother Shi to release him from his duties so he might seek land and livestock on the frontier. Shi replied: "You are a man of great talent, destined for late success. A true king does not flaunt his unpolished worth—follow your inclinations." Yuan thus went to Beidi to farm and herd. Once, addressing his guests, he declared: "A true man’s resolve grows firmer in adversity and stronger in old age." Later, when he possessed thousands of livestock and tens of thousands of *hu* of grain, he sighed and said: "Wealth is merely accumulated property, its value lying in relief and generosity. Otherwise, one is but a miser guarding his coins." He then distributed all his wealth among his relatives and old friends.

Hearing that Yin Xiu was fond of scholars, Ma Yuan went to join him, and Xiu held him in great esteem, consulting him on strategy. Lu remarked: "Observing Ma Kuang’s words, I sigh at how difficult it is for a great tree to meet a skilled craftsman. For Yuan lived in the time of Wang Mang, when the realm offered no refuge. Thus, when abroad, he became a Ji Tang; when at home, a Gong Bao. Had he resigned himself to old age and poverty, would he not have ended his days herding and farming in the borderlands? Yet in the end, by the rise of the Dragon in Nanyang, he became a general and minister, his name inscribed on bamboo and silk; his daughter became an imperial consort, her virtue foremost in the rear palace. Was his late success ordinary? Therefore, one must not judge a scholar by the speed of his rise, nor cling stubbornly to one’s lot—for such is the resolve of a true man, and one must not fail to hold oneself in high regard."

According to the *Book of the Later Han*: Liu Xiu, Prince of Dongping, was fond of the classics from youth, possessed keen intelligence, and was kind and handsome, with a beard and broad forehead. His waist measured eight spans, and Emperor Ming held him in great esteem, appointing him General of the Swift Cavalry, his rank above the Three Excellencies. At that time, the dynasty had been restored for over thirty years, and the realm was at peace. The Prince, believing the world well-ordered, advocated the revival of ritual and music. Together with the high ministers, he established the rites for the southern and northern suburban sacrifices, as well as the regulations for crowns, robes, carriages, and court attire. He also determined the number of dancers for the eight-row formations in the Guangwu Emperor’s temple. Whenever the Emperor traveled, the Prince was often left to guard the capital. After the Empress Dowager had reigned for several years, contributing much to the state, the Prince, though closely related to the throne, grew uneasy with his growing influence. He submitted a memorial to resign his duties, offering to return his seals and retire to his fief. The Emperor, in a gracious edict, refused, but the Prince persisted earnestly. After five years, he was permitted to return to his principality, though he was not allowed to relinquish his general’s seal. His Chief Clerk was made Minister of Works for Dongping, his Attendant Officer became a Palace Gentleman, and his Clerks became Gentlemen of the Royal Household. He was further granted 200,000 cash and 100,000 bolts of cloth.

Lu remarked: "Since the decline of the Zhou house, the prestige of the Ji and Shao clans has also waned. Since the rise of the Han, no imperial kinsmen have been allowed to hold the highest offices—only the relatives of empresses have been so entrusted. Yet are not the mother’s kin even more distant than those who share the same vital breath? All these errors stem from partiality, from favoring those one loves and delights in. Thus, the self is not cultivated, the family is not ordered, the state cannot be governed, and the realm cannot be pacified—disaster and chaos inevitably follow. The sages warned of this long ago, and the Western Han repeated their mistakes. Only later, after changing course, did the situation under Emperors Zhang and He gradually return to the ways of old."

Li Gu’s daughter, Wenji, was the wife of Zhao Boying of the same commandery. She was virtuous and wise. When Gu was dismissed from office, Wenji, foreseeing disaster, lamented: "The Li house is doomed. Since the time of our ancestor, we have accumulated virtue and benevolence—why must we meet such a fate?" Gu had a young son, Xie, whom she secretly planned to hide. Soon after, the catastrophe struck, and her two elder brothers were killed. Wenji told her father’s disciple, Wang Cheng: "Our late father embodied the integrity of the ancients. I entrust you with this duty: take in this orphan of six *chi*, for the survival or extinction of the Li house rests with you." Moved by her righteousness, Cheng took Xie and fled eastward by boat, entering the borders of Xuzhou. They changed their names, Xie becoming a servant in a tavern, while Cheng told fortunes in the market, each pretending to be strangers while secretly keeping in touch. Xie studied under Cheng, and the tavern keeper, impressed by him, married his daughter to him. For over a decade, Xie devoted himself to the classics.

After Liang Ji was executed, omens of disaster appeared repeatedly. The court historians advised that an amnesty should be granted to preserve the descendants of wronged ministers. Thus, a general pardon was issued, and the search for Gu’s heirs began. Xie then revealed his true identity to the tavern keeper and returned to his hometown. When brother and sister met, their grief moved all who witnessed it. Wenji then warned Xie: "Our late father was a loyal minister of the Han. Now the court is in turmoil, and Liang Ji runs rampant—our ancestral sacrifices are about to be cut off. That you have survived is surely heaven’s will. You must sever ties with others, avoid reckless associations, and never utter a word against the Liang clan. Acknowledge only your own faults." Xie carefully heeded her advice.

Lu remarked: "In comparing the wisdom of Li Wenji with the charm of Cai Wenji, can they truly be spoken of in the same breath? Caution in self-preservation is called wisdom; pleasing others is called cleverness. The differences between the two women reflect the distinctions between people. Yet though Gu’s calamity was deep and Wenji’s foresight keen, what could they ultimately do?"

The father refused to enthrone the Emperor, and now the son refuses to enthrone the king—what failure to take warning has brought us to this? As for Xie, not only has his family long upheld integrity through the generations, but he may truly be called one whose virtue shines with the brilliance of bestowed favor.

*Hongdao Lu*, Scroll 44, ends here.
*Hongdao Lu*, Scroll 45

**Trust**
**The Trust Between Ruler and Minister**

*Lushi* states: During the seventy years of Yao’s reign, the people did not resort to arms, pheasants and magpies fled to the remotest regions, and qilin roamed the marshes—this was because he was trusted by the people.

The record states: What is meant by "embodying trust and achieving harmony" is that harmony is what heaven assists, and trust is what people assist. As a ruler, Yao, by embodying what heaven assists, caused the two forces to respond in harmony, all living things to flourish, qi to flow without obstruction, and the four spiritual creatures to appear. By embodying what people assist, his wisdom and insight were sufficient to oversee all, and his magnanimity and gentleness were sufficient to embrace all. Thus, taking heaven and earth as his foundation, all things could be governed; taking yin and yang as his starting point, all emotions could be ordered; taking the four seasons as his handle, all labors could be encouraged; and taking the sun and stars as his guide, all affairs could be arranged and all achievements recorded. Taking ghosts and spirits as his companions, all affairs could be preserved and all actions verified; taking human sentiment as his field, the people did not resort to arms; and taking the four spiritual creatures as his livestock, pheasants and magpies fled to the wilds while qilin appeared in the outskirts.

*The Doctrine of the Mean* says: "In this way, though unseen, it is manifest; though unmoving, it transforms; though inactive, it accomplishes." This is how the sage-kings of high antiquity matched heaven, partook of the sacrifices to the Supreme Emperor, and served as the masters of the Three Powers, becoming models for the rulers of all ages.

*The Doctrine of the Mean* further states: "In governing the world, there are three essential matters. Those who are sparing in errors excel in them. The highest, though good, lacks proof; if proof is not trusted, the people will not follow. The lowest, though good, lacks dignity; without dignity, it is not trusted, and if not trusted, the people will not follow." Thus, the Way of the noble person is rooted in the self, verified among the common people, examined against the Three Kings without error, established in heaven and earth without contradiction, tested before ghosts and spirits without doubt, and awaits the sages of a hundred generations without confusion. Therefore, when the noble person acts, the world takes it as its Way; when he moves, the world takes it as its law; when he speaks, the world takes it as its standard. From afar, he is admired; up close, he is not resented.

*The Book of Songs* says:
*"There, none find him hateful;
Here, none find him wearisome.
Day and night, he strives
To long preserve his good name."*

No noble person has ever gained renown in the world without first embodying this.

The record states: Speaking of the three essential matters, when Shun refined the five rites—five jades, three silks, two living animals, and one sacrificial victim—he presented them like the five ritual vessels to deliberate on propriety. He harmonized the seasons and months, standardized the calendar, and unified the measures of pitch pipes, weights, and volumes to establish institutions. He disseminated proposals in words and tested them by merit to examine culture. Confucius traced his lineage back to Yao and Shun, hence his caution in these matters, despite possessing virtue without position. Through these six affairs, he bequeathed teachings to all generations. Though he could not gain trust in his own time, he truly earned renown throughout the world. To this day, his actions serve as the Way for all generations, his words as their law, and his conduct as their standard—far beyond a single era.

Later examples, such as the rituals of Mian Zhuo, the infrequent systems of the Han, the characters of Wutai, and the texts of the *New Classics*, though unrelated to the six affairs, may have deceived people’s eyes and ears and blinded their hearts for a time, yet they could not earn true renown in the world. Thus, they perished swiftly, vanishing together. Then, were the words of the six affairs truly trustworthy or not? If one holds the power of creation, one cannot evade this responsibility.

*The Analects* records: Zigong asked about governance. The Master said, "Sufficient food, sufficient arms, and the people’s trust." Zigong said, "If forced to relinquish one of these three, which should go first?" The Master said, "Relinquish arms." Zigong said, "If forced to relinquish one of the remaining two, which should go first?" The Master said, "Relinquish food. From ancient times, all must die; without the people’s trust, the state cannot stand."

The record states: This discourse transcends past and present. Many have debated arms and food through the ages, but who would dare abandon them? Yet the Master and Zigong pursued the matter to its ultimate conclusion. In making such a statement, was there no subtlety in their trustworthiness? The eras of Qin and Sui serve as proof.

Since the time of Shang Yang, the Qin abandoned trust and righteousness, focusing solely on wealth and power. The First Emperor further established an unshakable foundation—what could he not relinquish when forced? Yet when a commoner raised a cry, the people could only die—how could the state stand? The Sui, following the Six Dynasties, boasted of strength surpassing all previous ages—what could they not relinquish when forced? They stored grain at Luokou, allowing the people to take it freely, yet this abundance was in vain. Only when the Three Articles of Law were established did the people begin to revive; when prisoners returned, the people no longer rushed to their deaths. Trust cannot be abandoned.

Thus, though arms and food are relied upon by all, and life and death are known to all, without trust, they cannot rely on one another or know one another. Hence, in critical moments, trust is paramount.

It is also said: "If a person lacks trustworthiness, how can they be of use? A great cart without its yoke-tie, a small cart without its crossbar—how can they move?" Alas! Knowing that a cart cannot move without these, one understands why the people cannot stand without trust.

*The Outer Records* state: When Yu went out and saw a criminal, he dismounted, questioned him, and wept. His attendants said, "This man has violated the Way—why does the lord grieve for him?" Yu replied, "The people of Yao and Shun took the hearts of Yao and Shun as their own hearts."

The ruler, being a lord, weeps for the people because each takes their own heart as their heart. The *Records* state: This shows that the people cannot stand without trust. That the people of Yao and Shun all took the hearts of Yao and Shun as their own hearts was because ruler and subject were united in trust. The ruler, being a lord, sees the people each take their own hearts as their hearts—this is because without trust, the people do not follow. Though there be court assemblies, lawsuits, feasts, and songs, they do not return to the standard of Shun but are compared to Yu. When the common people undergo change and the four auspicious winds stir, questions arise. The lords of the ages after the Three Dynasties cannot but place the people deep in their hearts and minds.

Mencius said: When Tang first campaigned, beginning with Ge, the world trusted him. When he turned east to campaign, the western Yi complained; when he turned south to campaign, the northern Di complained, saying, "Why leave us for last?" The people longed for him as those in great drought long for clouds and rainbows. Those returning from the market did not stop; those plowing did not change their course. He punished their lords and comforted their people, like timely rain falling—great was the people’s joy. The *Records* state: Between Tang and Yu, there is also a question. As it is said, "Heaven and the people turned to him"—this speaks of his ultimate end. Had he, at the outset of his campaigns, lacked trust with the people, how could he have justified himself before the world and posterity?

The *Book of Documents* says: "Be tolerant and kind, manifesting trust to the myriad people." Mencius’s words take their foundation from this. How can one compare them to the lords of the Warring States, who acted unjustly, killed the innocent, failed to win the trust of the world, and merely gratified their momentary desires?

*Tai Jia* says: "Only Yi Yin first appeared in the western city of Xia. From the Zhou onward, those who had a good end had ministers who also had a good end. The later successor kings could not have a good end, and their ministers likewise could not have a good end. Let the successor kings take heed!" The *Records* state: Mencius said, "One with the resolve of Yi Yin may be released." He said: "Yi Yin’s resolve was to take the public good of the world as his heart, without a single mote of self-interest." I deem that when Yi Yin first exiled Tai Jia, people trusted that he had not a single shred of self-interest—this began with these words.

Those who, as ministers, usurp their lord’s authority to shield their ruler—were they only Li Si and Zhao Gao of Qin? The affairs of Yi and Mi serve as a mirror. At that time, Tai Jia, entrusting Yi Yin with the weight of the world, thought that even if he indulged his desires, he would not immediately perish. Yet Yi Yin, as minister, warned him of the failure to have a good end, admonishing him to deeply examine his self-interest and break his reliance. Had men like Wang Mang, Cao Cao, or Sima Yi been in his place, what would they have done? Thus we know the hearts of sages and worthies truly can establish heaven and earth and serve as the substance of ghosts and spirits. Though a hundred generations await the sage, their clarity shines forth without doubt—how could they not be trustworthy?

It further says: "Let the lord not use clever words to disrupt old policies; let the minister not use favor and profit to claim success. Then the state will long be blessed with good fortune." The *Records* state: This was when Yi Yin returned the government to Tai Jia, and people trusted that he had not a single shred of self-interest. Those who employ cunning, disrupt old institutions, and use favor and profit to claim success—were they only Duke Xiao’s Shang Yang? To deceive Heaven above and curry favor with the powerful while rejecting the worthy—the affairs of Jie serve as a mirror.

Though Yi Yin held the weight of the *Aheng* and had the authority to restore order, had he harbored even a shred of desire for favor or profit, what would he not have done? Yet his heart was tranquil and content, no different from when he had tilled the fields. No sooner had his work succeeded than he retired, owing no debt to the former kings above, nor to Tai Jia in the middle, nor to the people below. Thus, like the bright sun in a clear sky, his loyalty and uprightness shone forth; heaven and earth, ghosts and spirits, bore witness to his brilliance; and from ancient times to the present, the world admires his breadth of mind.

Even men like Cai Ze knew the sequence of the four seasons—how could others be different? Yet Shang Yang suffered dismemberment by chariot, and the Five Princes were exiled and rescued—such cases are many. Are they not the guilty ones before Yi Yin?

The *Counsels of Gao Yao* says: The king treasured his sorrow and observed mourning for three years. After the mourning period ended, he still did not speak. All the ministers remonstrated with the king. The king then composed a text to proclaim: "I, the One Man, rectify the four quarters. I fear my virtue does not match, so I have not spoken. Reverently and silently, I ponder the Way. In a dream, the Lord charged me with a good assistant to speak in my stead." He then examined the image, had it depicted, and sought throughout the world. Yue, building walls in the wilds of Fu Rock, was the very likeness.

The *Records* state: How did Gao Zong come to have such a dream? His heart of utmost sincerity merged with Heaven, and the resonance of his spirit and the sincerity of his thoughts and concerns were such that they came about without his knowing why. Moreover, how did the image come to be? The records of true principle take form everywhere, and the signs of their emergence and the reasons for their exact likeness likewise come about without his knowing why.

The Way lies in non-action and non-thought, in stillness and motionlessness. Had there been even a hint of scheming, a slight display outwardly, a single word taken in first, or the slightest stirring within, others could have perceived his flaw and exploited it. Duke Xiao of Qin, resolved to change the laws and alter the decrees, allowed Shang Yang to sell his schemes. Emperor Shenzong of Song, resolved to investigate antiquity and act, allowed Wang Anshi to advance his treachery. The two rulers, in appointing their ministers, thought them worthy, yet in dreams and divination, they did not know—they were deceived by spirits.

Only then do we know that the heart of reverent silence and pondering the Way truly joins with Heaven and Earth and communicates with ghosts and spirits. Otherwise, how could men like Deng Tong with Emperor Wen or Wang Liang with Emperor Guangwu have won the trust of later ages? They are few indeed.

From the *Missing "Jin Teng" Chapter of the Book of Zhou*: In autumn, the harvest ripened, yet before it could be reaped, heaven sent great thunder and lightning with wind, flattening all the grain, uprooting great trees, and striking terror into the people of the state. The king and his ministers, donning ceremonial caps, opened the golden-bound coffer and found therein the record of the Duke of Zhou’s merit, his plea to take King Wu’s place in death. The two dukes and the king then inquired of the historians and all the officials. They replied, “It is true.” Alas! The Duke had commanded us never to speak of it. The king, holding the document and weeping, said, “Let us no longer divine with milfoil. In the past, the Duke labored diligently for the royal house, yet I, in my youth, failed to understand. Now heaven displays its majesty to manifest the Duke’s virtue. I, the little son, shall personally welcome him, and our state’s rites shall duly honor him.” The king went out to the suburbs, whereupon heaven sent rain, the wind reversed, and the grain all stood upright again. The two dukes commanded the people to raise and rebuild every tree that had been felled, and the year yielded a great harvest.

The record states: Master Zhang said, “Will and qi, heaven and man—there is a principle of mutual overcoming. When the sage is on the throne and slander arises, it is the stirring of qi that unsettles the will. When the heart of heaven responds and thunder and wind arise, it is the will that stirs qi. Thus we see that in the flourishing age of the Three Dynasties, ruler and minister were in perfect accord, their sincere hearts and true intentions flowing between high and low, like yin and yang in motion and stillness, each rooted in the other. For those who fail to grasp this, a single inquiry suffices. In later ages, yin waxes while yang wanes, heaven and earth do not commune, high and low grow estranged. Witness Emperor Ling of Han, who pardoned the partisans because of the Yellow Turban rebellion, or Emperor Huizong of Song, who lifted the stele prohibitions due to the appearance of a comet—how far they fell behind! Those who stumble in their steps and let their hearts be swayed—how can they not gaze at heaven in bewilderment?”

From the *Spring and Autumn Annals*: In the first year of Duke Yin of Lu, in spring, the third month, the Duke and Yiyi Fu of Zhu made a covenant at Mie.

The record states: Confucius said, “Since ancient times, all must die; but without trust, the people cannot stand.” The commentators explain: “Better to die than lose trust with the people, so that the people, too, would rather die than lose trust with me. If I would rather die than lose trust with the people, why should others demand pledges from me? If the people would rather die than lose trust with me, why should I demand pledges from them? Such was governance in antiquity. When the age declines and the Way decays, the ruler does not trust his ministers—how much less a neighboring state! A father does not trust his son—how much less a stranger! Thus, the practices of pledges and covenants proliferate. The Master composed the *Spring and Autumn Annals* to make trust the great treasure of rulers. Therefore, he first recorded the covenant at Mie, intending that later rulers and ministers would hold fast to this principle, firm as metal and stone, and guard it steadfastly, as constant as the four seasons. Thereby they might discipline their mutual resolve, align the wills of high and low, preserve the Way of beginning and end, and forestall the seeds of reversal. His intent in bequeathing this teaching to the world was most profound.

Yet did Duke Yin of Lu truly uphold trust? When profit and harm stir within, public and private become divided without; when a false heart lurks at the outset, betrayal appears in the end. Yin feigned deference to make a show of righteousness, and adorned his consent to make a show of trust. Observe how he first made the covenant at Mie, then later launched an attack on Zhu—his true nature is plain to see. The *Poetry* says, ‘The nobleman makes covenants time and again, and disorder only grows thereby.’ Does this not refer to such cases?”

From the *Zuo Tradition*: Duke Wu and Duke Zhuang of Zheng served as ministers to King Ping of Zhou. The king divided his favor toward Guo, so the Earl of Zheng resented him. The king said, “I have done no such thing.” Thus, Zhou and Zheng exchanged hostages: Prince Hu of Zhou went to Zheng as hostage, and Prince Ignorant of Zheng went to Zhou as hostage. When the king died, the people of Zhou intended to demote Guo and entrust governance to him. In the fourth month, Zhai Zu of Zheng led troops to seize the wheat at Wen; in autumn, they seized the grain at Chengzhou, and Zhou and Zheng grew mutually hostile.

The noble man says: “If trust does not arise from within, hostages are of no benefit. Act with clarity and forbearance, and bind it with ritual—even without hostages, who could challenge it? If there is true trust, the grasses of mountain streams and marshy pools, the water-plants and algae of ponds and ditches, the vessels of baskets and earthenware, the water of flowing gutters and stagnant puddles—these may be offered to ghosts and spirits, presented as delicacies to kings and dukes. How much more, when a noble man establishes trust between two states and conducts himself with ritual—what need has he for hostages?”

The *Airs* contain “Gathering the Fennel” and “Gathering the Water-Plant,” while the *Odes* contain “Walking Among the Reeds” and “Pouring from the Gorge.” These all illuminate loyalty and trust.

The record states: “‘Gathering the Fennel,’ ‘Gathering the Water-Plant,’ ‘Walking Among the Reeds,’ and ‘Pouring from the Gorge’ are all poems of Zhou. Yet by its decline, sons did not trust their fathers, and ‘The Little Grievance’ was composed; wives did not trust their husbands, and ‘The White Blossoms’ was composed.”

That King You of Zhou was a son by blood, flesh and bone, yet he deposed and murdered him—where then lay the safety of Prince Hu of Zheng and Prince Hu of Zheng? This is why hostages were exchanged in such profusion, and why enmity repeatedly flared. The words of *Master Zuo* are thus a lament for the divergence of order and disorder.

Mencius said: “Of the Five Hegemons, Duke Huan of Qi was the greatest. At the Assembly of Kuiqiu, the feudal lords bound their sacrificial animals and inscribed their pledges without even smearing their mouths with blood. The first decree proclaimed: ‘Punish the unfilial; do not alter the heir apparent; do not make a concubine your wife.’ The second decree proclaimed: ‘Honor the worthy and nurture talent to manifest virtue.’ The third decree proclaimed: ‘Revere the aged and cherish the young; do not neglect guests and travelers.’ The fourth decree proclaimed: ‘Scholars shall not hold hereditary office; official duties shall not be concurrently held; select officials with care; do not execute great officers arbitrarily.’ The fifth decree proclaimed: ‘Do not bend embankments to your will; do not block the sale of grain; do not enfeoff without reporting to the Son of Heaven.’ It concluded: ‘All who share this covenant, after swearing this oath, shall return to amity like the waters of Yu.’”

The record states: The one who later commended Duke Huan of Qi was Zai Kong; the one who first returned to meet the Lord of Jin was also this same Zai Kong. At first, he feared the Son of Heaven’s majesty; in the end, he made clear the Son of Heaven’s prohibitions—how then could he have deemed the assembly unnecessary?

Mencius said: “The reverent do not insult others; the frugal do not seize from others. A lord who insults and seizes from others fears only that his subjects will not submit. How could such a one truly be called reverent and frugal? Reverence and frugality cannot be feigned with mere voice and smile.”

Though Zai Kong was a minister of the royal court and never wielded power like Guan Zhong, he had thoroughly studied Duke Huan’s intentions. Thus, when the Duke vented his fury at Shao Ji’s northern campaign, or when he honored Chu for attacking the Mountain Rong only to turn north and scheme against Yan—at this very assembly, he dazzled the eyes and ears of men and delighted their hearts, yet in Zai Kong’s eyes, he was as transparent as if his lungs and liver were exposed. This is why the sages of antiquity devoted themselves to cultivating virtue and guarding their solitude. Even when they possessed two-thirds of the realm, they still served the Yin with deference.

Alas! The supreme virtue of Zhou—how could it have fallen behind others in its words and deeds?

In the winter of the thirteenth year of Duke Zhuang, the Duke met with the Lord of Qi and swore an alliance at Ke. The *Gongyang Commentary* asks: “Why is the date not recorded? Because it was an easy matter. How so? Duke Huan’s alliances did not record dates, and his assemblies did not require full attendance—this was a sign of trust. The omission of dates began here.”

When Duke Zhuang was about to meet with Duke Huan, Caozi stepped forward and asked: “What is Your Lordship’s intention?” Duke Zhuang replied: “In life, I am no better off than dead.” Caozi said: “Then let Your Lordship confront his lord as a lord, and let your servant confront his minister as a minister.” Duke Zhuang said: “Very well.”

At the meeting, Duke Zhuang ascended the altar, with Caozi following, sword in hand. Guanzi stepped forward and asked: “What does Your Lordship seek?” Caozi replied: “The city walls have collapsed and pressed upon our borders—why has your lord not addressed this?” Guanzi said: “Then what does Your Lordship demand?” Caozi said: “I request the fields of Wenyang.” Guanzi turned and said: “Your Lordship consents.” Duke Huan said: “I consent.”

Caozi then demanded an oath, and Duke Huan descended to swear with him. After the oath, Caozi brandished his sword and departed. Though the oath could have been violated, Duke Huan did not deceive; though Caozi’s demand could have been refused, Duke Huan’s trust became renowned throughout the world, beginning with the Alliance at Ke.

The record states: This was a minor minister of Lu, yet the hegemon humbled himself to comply—was this not trust? No. Guan Zhong said: “To grant what is requested is the treasure of seizing power.”

After the Battle of Changshao, Cao’s schemes had nearly crippled Qi. When Qi missed the Assembly of Beixing, Duke Huan and four other states were slighted, and Lu could not be pacified. Guan Zhong’s foresight was as clear as Zhu’s. Lu was the ancestral state; Qi had murdered its lord and violated its lady. At the Assembly of Ke, Duke Zhuang deemed life worse than death—was this not a shameful oath? Had Lu used this to punish Qi, even if it had to endure humiliation before the feudal lords, how could it have won the hearts of the world? How base were those schemes!

Wielding a sword is the courage of a commoner; the fields of Wenyang are but a trifling morsel. The entire state followed this misguided path, with neither lord nor minister discerning the grand strategy. They cast aside petty gains to steal a resounding reputation. Thus Guanzi said: “To grant what is requested is the treasure of seizing power.” Was this not Guanzi’s foresight?

The Lord of Jin besieged Yuan, ordering provisions for three days. When Yuan did not surrender, he ordered a retreat. As the troops withdrew, it was said: “Yuan is about to surrender.” The officers said: “Let us wait a little longer.” The Duke said: “Trust is the treasure of the state, the refuge of the people. To gain Yuan but lose trust—how could we shelter the people? What we would lose would be far greater.” They withdrew thirty *li*, and Yuan surrendered.

The record states: Duke Wen’s achievements were indeed great, but they were merely the duties of a minister and son—how could Jin have taken the Son of Heaven’s four cities? Zhou’s territory was no larger than Cao or Teng, its people no more numerous than those of Guo or Ju. Any man of conscience would not have entertained such thoughts—how could he bear to further divide what little remained?

Yuan had committed no act of rebellion; its defenders were guarding it for the king. The court had lost the Way and pressured them, forcing them to rebel and follow ruin. Alas for the Lord of Yuan! Had Duke Wen rectified the royal domain, he could have repelled the encroachments of the feudal lords. Had he attacked in this manner, his trust would have shone like the sun and moon. Instead, he ignored the people’s sentiments and indulged in hegemonic ambition—this was “clever in employing words,” not “enlightened in upholding trust.”

Prince Hu of Zhou swore an alliance with the feudal lords in the royal court, with this essential pledge: “All shall assist the royal house and not harm one another.
