If any violate this oath, may the bright spirits punish them, casting down their armies and cutting short their state’s lineage, so that even their distant descendants, young and old alike, shall perish.”

The gentleman deems this alliance trustworthy, and deems Jin’s conduct in this campaign an attack by virtue. It is recorded: At the Assembly of Kuiqiu, the feudal lords sought the sacrificial beast and inscribed the pledge, yet did not smear their mouths with blood—such was the awe and trust Duke Huan inspired, that he needed not wait for their words to be spoken. At the Alliance of Jiantu, Zheng and Wei wrangled endlessly—such was Duke Wen’s insatiable demand for gain, heedless of the king’s diminished authority. Thus, ere the blood on their lips had dried, each man’s heart had already turned to his own concerns. Where then was their shared support for the royal house? Where then was the pledge to extend to distant descendants? Viewed together, one may see that one hegemon was not the equal of the next.

In the fourth year of Duke Dao of Jin, Wei Jiang served as Minister of War. The ruler of Wuzhong sent his minister Meng Le to present tiger and leopard pelts and sue for peace with the Rong tribes. The Duke said: “The Yi and Di are faithless and greedy. Better to attack them.” Wei Jiang replied: “The Two Lords have newly submitted, and Chen has newly come to make peace. They will observe our virtue. If we act with virtue, they will be harmonious; if not, they will grow estranged. To exhaust our forces against the Rong while Chu attacks Chen would leave us unable to save Chen—this would be to abandon it. All the Central States would surely rebel. The Rong are but beasts. To gain the Rong but lose the Hua—would this not be unwise?” The Duke said: “Then what of making peace with the Rong?” Wei Jiang replied: “Peace with the Rong brings five advantages. The Rong and Di are nomads who value goods and readily exchange land—thus land may be purchased: this is the first. The borderlands will no longer be alarmed, the people will grow familiar with the wilderness, and the farmers will reap success: this is the second. The Rong and Di will serve Jin, the neighboring states will be stirred, and the feudal lords will hold our might in awe: this is the third. By virtue we pacify the Rong, our troops will not be wearied, and our armor and weapons will not be deployed: this is the fourth. Taking the fall of Hou Yi as a warning and employing virtue and restraint, distant lands will come and near lands will be secure: this is the fifth. Let Your Lordship consider this.” The Duke was pleased and sent Wei Jiang to make an alliance with the Rong.

The Record states: In my humble observation of the Spring and Autumn period, Wei Jiang secured peace with the various Rong and Di tribes through five advantages—why should our own age be any different? Jin occupied what is now Shanxi, its territory then governed by the Ministry of Announcement. At the time, it was called unrivaled in strength; today, it is but a single regional bulwark. Though Wei Jiang was renowned for his strategic acumen, he would now be no more than a minor attendant minister. Yet the respite he brought to the border commanderies was immense. The responsibility was not that of the Wu Zhong clan, the calamity not comparable to the abandonment of Chen, nor the gains and losses akin to forsaking Hua for the Rong. If we harass them year after year, when will it ever cease? If we drive them from place to place, where will it end? The benefits and harms are too numerous to count.

Thus, valuing goods in exchange for land is a sentiment shared by all Yi and Di; the success of the farmers and the reliance of the borderlands are mutual. How could this be true only of Wei Jiang’s words? Rather than squandering incalculable expenses to maintain idle garrison troops, would it not be better to follow the precedent of former dynasties and emulate the achievement of peace with the Rong? Even the leather of sheep and dogs has its proper use. For our present strategy, why not dispatch a single envoy of communication to the assembly point of the Three Lu tribes, binding them with trust, winning them with kindness, and enticing them with profit? Let us maintain our old borders as boundaries, allowing them to withdraw far away and follow their own customs. Each year, on a designated month and day, let them meet at a specified border point. At that time, we shall tighten our defenses, fortify our outposts, display our might, and ensure they harbor no intent to belittle the Middle Kingdom. During all other months, they must not approach the border passes, lurk in river bends, or encamp in the Ordos. Command their chieftains to enforce these orders, so that all people along the frontier may rest. When our military strength is fully restored, our provisions ample, and our trust unshaken, we may then gradually plan a distant campaign—whether like Emperor Chengzu’s proclamation of might in the desert or the Great Han’s inscription of merit on Yanran Mountain. Is this not the most essential strategy?

To neglect this and instead drift through the years, counting mere survival as achievement—now halting troops, now reinforcing defenses, with no reliable plan—is a shortsighted policy, not the way of an emperor who subdues enemies without battle. In my waning years, with no opportunity to offer counsel, I record these thoughts, inspired by Wei Jiang’s proposal, to express my earnest intent.

When Zhao Meng grew anxious over the armored troops of Chu, he informed Shu Xiang, who replied: “What harm is there? If even a common man breaks his word once, it is unacceptable. How much worse if the ministers of the feudal lords collectively act in bad faith? They will surely fail. Those who break their word suffer no ill—this is not your concern. To summon others with trust and then betray them is to ensure no one will stand with you. How could they harm us?” At the meeting at Hao, Qi Wu said to Zhao Wenzi: “At the Alliance of Song, the men of Chu had their way with Jin. Now the Chief Minister’s lack of trust is known to all the feudal lords. You should be on guard.” Yet, as with Zimu of Song, whose trust was praised by his followers, they still outpaced Jin—how much more so with one so egregiously untrustworthy? Wenzi replied: “I have received your counsel. However, at the Alliance of Song, Zimu harbored malicious intent, while I acted with benevolence. This is why Chu outpaced Jin. Now, I still hold that same heart, while Chu continues its deceit. It poses no threat. I will take trust as my foundation and act accordingly. Like a farmer who plows and weeds, though there may be famine, there will surely be years of plenty. Moreover, I have heard that one who keeps faith will not be subordinate to others—I have not yet achieved this. As the *Book of Songs* says: ‘Without deceit or harm, few do not take it as a model.’ Trust is the way.”

The Record states: Lü of Lai in Shulai claimed that Zhao Wenzi handled the crisis of the armored troops with ease, as if he truly understood Wenzi. Yet he did not grasp that trust was Wenzi’s guiding principle, and thus he had nothing to fear. Mencius said: “I understand words, and I nourish my vast and unyielding qi.” Zimu’s greed and ambition for dominance foretold his impending doom—even his peers knew this, and Wenzi knew it well. Hence it is said: “He alone met his end.” And again: “Those who break their word suffer no ill.” Though Wenzi appeared frail, as if he could not bear his robes, and reticent, as if he could not speak, he stilled the weapons and pacified the people, while Chu’s hostility grew ever more dire. How distant was his resolve! To abandon trust upon gaining power, or to provoke conflict without redress—how could this come first? Wenzi’s inner resolve was firm, but his established principles were not. Jin’s trust was reliable, while Chu’s outpacing was not. Could such things truly sway his heart? Alas, his resolve was not yet pure. He sought to use Song to guard against weakness and to die for his policies rather than betray Chu. Thus, though he gained a momentary reputation, he lacked the enduring righteousness of the ages. In the end, he and his adversaries alike succumbed to exhaustion, and he could not escape the affliction of reckless passion.

When Jin’s Xun Hao led troops to besiege Gu, some of Gu’s people requested to surrender the city in rebellion. Muzi refused. His aides said: “Our troops will not be wearied, and we can take the city—why not do so?” Muzi replied: “I have heard from Shu Xiang that if likes and dislikes are not excessive, the people will know where to turn, and no affair will fail. If someone rebels with our city, it is what I deeply detest. If someone offers a city to us, what do I particularly favor? To reward what I deeply detest—how then can I reward what I favor? If I do not reward them, it is a breach of trust. How can I protect the people? If we have the strength, we advance; if not, we retreat. We act according to our capacity. I cannot covet a city and thus draw near to treachery—what we would lose would be far greater.” He had the people of Gu execute the rebels and repair their defenses. After besieging Gu for three months, some of its people requested to surrender. He had their people appear before him. Seeing they still had food and color, he temporarily repaired their city. His officers said: “We have taken the city but do not seize it, wearying the people and exhausting the troops—how will this serve our lord?”

Muzi said: "In serving one’s lord, if seizing a single city teaches the people to grow lax, what use is the city? A city is meant to purchase respite—better to preserve what we already have. Leading with unerring righteousness, the city may be taken, and the people will know where righteousness lies. They will hold fast to their lives without divided hearts—is this not acceptable?"

When the people of Gu reported their food exhausted and strength spent, he conquered Gu and returned without executing a single person.

The record states: *The Spring and Autumn Annals* declares there are no righteous wars, yet was not the siege of Gu such a case? Those who act with righteousness inspire awe for righteousness in others; those who act with trustworthiness inspire awe for trustworthiness. But when one feigns a meeting with the Qi forces—where is trustworthiness in that? When one borrows passage through Xian Yu—where is righteousness? The destruction of Fei was severe indeed. Could such a course be repeated?

To indulge the lord’s faults and then condemn others for rebellion; to delight in others’ fine words yet willingly embrace barbarism—these are things the noble person does not accept.

*The Records of the Historian* states: Sun Wuzi presented his *Art of War* to King Helü of Wu. The king said: "I have read all thirteen of your chapters. May I test your methods on a small scale with troops?" Sunzi replied: "You may." Thereupon, the king brought forth palace beauties, one hundred eighty in number. Sunzi divided them into two companies, appointing three of the king’s favorite concubines as captains, each holding a halberd. He instructed them: "Do you know your heart, your left and right hands, and your back?" The women replied: "We do." Sunzi said: "When I say 'forward,' look toward your heart; 'left,' toward your left hand; 'right,' toward your right hand; 'turn,' toward your back." The women assented. After the commands were issued, axes were set up, and the orders were repeated three times and reinforced five times.

Then he sounded the drum, and the women on the right burst into laughter. Sunzi said: "When commands are unclear and orders not thoroughly drilled, the fault lies with the commander." Again he repeated the commands three times and reinforced them five times before sounding the drum once more. The women on the left then laughed aloud. Sunzi declared: "Though the commands are now clear, those who fail to follow them bear the fault of officers and troops." Thereupon he ordered the execution of the two company captains. From his terrace, the king of Wu witnessed this and, alarmed at the prospect of losing his beloved concubines, hastily sent a messenger to command: "I now see that the general is truly skilled in warfare. Without these two ladies, my meals would lose their savor—I beg you spare them." Sunzi replied: "Having received my commission as commander, I must obey military law even if it means disregarding the ruler’s orders." He then beheaded the two captains and displayed their heads, appointing their seconds in command. When the drum sounded again, the women moved left and right, forward and back, kneeling and rising—all in perfect accord with the rules, without a single sound. Sunzi sent word to the king: "The troops are now well-ordered. Your Majesty may descend to inspect them. They will obey any command, even to march through fire or water." The king said: "Let the general rest in his quarters. I do not wish to descend and observe." Sunzi replied: "Your Majesty merely delights in fine words but cannot put them into practice."

Thereafter, King Helü recognized Sunzi’s military prowess and ultimately appointed him as his general. To the west, he crushed the mighty state of Chu and entered Ying; to the north, he overawed Qi and Jin, winning renown among the feudal lords—Sunzi’s contribution was decisive.

**Record:** This act of Sunzi’s surpassed even that of Shang Yang or Wu Qi. For while commands must be enforceable, the people must not be coerced; concubines may be executed, but wives must not be killed. The opening of Sunzi’s *Thirteen Chapters* states: "Wisdom, trustworthiness, benevolence, courage, and strictness." Though the king had read it all, why did he not reflect: "When the ruler issues orders, the minister obeys"? To delight in words yet fail to apply them is unwise. To let favoritism disrupt military discipline is cowardly. To treat palace women as playthings is to lack strictness. Trust is the greatest treasure of a ruler—if even a small test is mishandled, how much more so in great matters? One who acts thus cannot be called trustworthy.

Some may say: "Etiquette does not deign to mention the ruler’s carriage horses." Yet favored concubines are not the same as carriage horses—how could their defiance and arbitrary execution reflect a benevolent heart? Mencius said: "With benevolence comes honor; without it, disgrace." Sunzi was not inherently cruel, but he detested those who laughed in defiance of the law, just as one detests those who force wine upon the drunk. In the end, he broke Chu and entered Ying, overawed Qi and subdued Jin, winning renown among the feudal lords. Though he may not have prized virtue, did he not honor the worth of his officers?

*Hongdao Record*, Volume 45, concludes.
*Hongdao Record*, Volume 46: "Wisdom" begins.

**On the Wisdom of Friends**

From the *Analects*: The Master said to Zigong, “Between you and Yan Hui, who is the superior?” Zigong replied, “How dare I compare myself to Hui? Hui hears one thing and understands ten; I hear one thing and understand two.” The Master said, “You are not his equal. Neither you nor I are his equal.”

*Recorded*: At the gate of the sage, instruction is generally not given unless one is struggling, nor is enlightenment offered unless one is hesitating. Comparing others is not inherently blameworthy, but if I do not desire something, yet others impose it upon me, I take it upon myself to broadly bestow it upon the people and aid the multitude—this is benevolence. Compared to Yanzi, the difference is as vast as heaven and earth. Yet if one possesses a keen and sharp nature, though not yet truly able to draw near analogies, one should not take Zigong’s words of self-deprecation as entirely trustworthy. Thus, the Master prompted him with the question of who was superior. And Zigong, in truth, was able to reflect inwardly and advance himself, engaging in the ceaseless pursuit of learning—gazing upward, drilling downward, ever striving, unable to desist. What manner of man was Yan Hui? To aspire to him is to look back; in terms of his innate endowments and the heights he attained, if one merely reaches that level, it is enough. Among Confucius’s disciples, why would one need a wise man to recognize Yan Hui? Thus, the Son of Heaven twice declared, “You are not his equal.” If this were the end of Zigong’s story, it would suffice.

The Master said: “Yan Hui’s character was such that he chose the Mean, and having grasped one good, he held it fast in his heart and never lost it.”

*Recorded*: This is the foundation of hearing one and knowing ten. If there is nothing he does not choose, then there is nothing he does not attain or fall short of. If there is nothing he does not grasp, then there is nothing he does not hold fast to or lose. Accumulating this, one reaches a state where there is nothing left to choose and nothing unattained. Thus, hearing one and knowing ten arises spontaneously. Scholars who have not yet reached this level need only avoid failing in the task of choosing the good and holding it fast—then they may attain Yan Hui’s station.

The Master said: “Yan Hui was nearly perfect, yet he was often in want. Zigong did not accept his fate and engaged in trade, and his conjectures were frequently correct.”

*Recorded*: Confucius once spoke of Yan Hui and Zigong together, for their natures were similar, though their practices diverged. Yan Hui’s nearness to the Dao lay in his ability to choose, finding joy in all things—not merely due to his natural endowments, but because of the depth of his learning. Zigong did not accept his fate and could not choose, yet his conjectures were often correct, a result of his natural alignment rather than the utmost clarity of his understanding. This “fate” does not refer to wealth, poverty, honor, or lowliness, but to the mandate of Heaven that is called nature. His frequent want and his trading were but incidental matters.

The Master said: “Zigong, do you take me to be one who learns extensively and retains it all?” Zigong replied, “Yes—is it not so?” The Master said, “No. I have one thread that runs through it all.”

*Recorded*: This moment of belief followed by sudden doubt arose not from the depth of his accumulated learning, but from his imprecision in choosing. Yao, Shun, Yu, Tang, Kings Wen and Wu, the Duke of Zhou, Confucius, and Yan Hui all followed the same Dao, threading it through all things. Thus, rites, music, culture, and the events of past and present can be learned extensively and retained, but the essence of utmost precision, singularity, and holding fast to the Mean cannot be grasped through extensive learning alone. Had he chosen carefully from the outset, this doubt would not have arisen. The Master’s teaching of the “one thread” to Zigong was the same as to Zengzi, but he prefaced it with “extensive learning,” differing from his approach with Zengzi. For Zengzi focused on preserving simplicity, while Zigong sought broad application. Simplicity requires no explanation to be understood; breadth leads to belief followed by doubt.

The Master said: “Shen, my Dao is threaded through with one.” Zengzi replied, “Yes.” When the Master left, the disciples asked, “What did he mean?” Zengzi said, “The Master’s Dao is nothing more than loyalty and forbearance.”

*Recorded*: In my humble view, Zigong’s wisdom was such that he dared not compare himself to Yan Hui, nor could he dare compare himself to Zengzi. Yan Hui held fast to one good and thus effortlessly understood ten. Zengzi strove for loyalty and forbearance and thus clearly grasped the one thread. Zengzi did not borrow from scholars to clarify the Dao; he grounded it in his heart without fear, applied it to himself with certainty, and expressed it in words without confusion. Loyalty and forbearance are not two paths, just as the one and the thread are not two things. Yet how does one unify the one and thread it through the myriad things? How does one attain this? Here, the diligent scholar finds ample ground for effort. One can strive to exhaust oneself and extend to others, but unity cannot be forced, nor can threading be contrived. Yet when one reaches the ultimate state, self and others merge into one path, Heaven and humanity unite in one Dao. Without seeking unity, unity is found in the heart; without seeking to thread, threading is found in all things. This is not only to learn well from the Master but also to teach disciples well; not only to teach disciples well but also to instruct all generations. If one merely pursues the lofty and distant without knowing the method, even a thousand words would be insufficient—how could one word suffice?

From the *Zuozhuan*: When Wu Zixia visited Lu, he requested to hear the music of Zhou. The musicians sang for him the *Zhounan* and *Shaonan*. He said, “How fine! The foundation of the state is laid, yet it is not yet complete. Still, the people labor without resentment.” They sang the *Bei*, *Yong*, and *Wei*. He said, “How profound! Though troubled, they are not overwhelmed. I have heard that the virtue of Duke Kang and Duke Wu of Wei was like this—this must be the *Wei Feng*.” They sang the *Wang*. He said, “How fine! Though pensive, they are not fearful—this must be the Zhou of the east.” They sang the *Zheng*. He said, “How fine! Yet it is too refined; the people cannot bear it. Will this not be the first to perish?” They sang the *Qi*. He said, “How magnificent! Vast and mighty, like a great wind.”

When they sang of the lands east of the Huai, he said, “This must be the realm of the Grand Duke—its future cannot yet be measured.” They sang the *Bin*. He said, “How fine! So expansive—joyous yet not excessive. This must be the eastern legacy of the Duke of Zhou.” They sang the *Qin*. He said, “This is what is called the Xia sound. To embody the Xia is to be great, for its influence reaches far. This must be the old domain of Zhou.” They sang the *Wei*. He said, “How fine! So stirring—grand yet gentle, pure yet yielding. To govern with virtue as aid—this is the mark of an enlightened ruler.” They sang the *Tang*. He said, “How profound! Could these be the remnant people of the Lord of Tao-Tang? If not, why would their sorrow run so deep? Only the descendants of noble virtue could be thus.” They sang the *Chen*. He said, “A state without a master—how can it endure?” From *Bin* onward, he offered no further critique.

When they sang the *Lesser Odes*, he said, “How fine! Thoughtful yet unwavering, resentful yet unspoken. This must mark the decline of Zhou’s virtue, though the people of the former kings yet remain.” When they sang the *Greater Odes*, he said, “How vast! So radiant—bent yet upright in form. This must be the virtue of King Wen.” When they sang the *Hymns*, he said, “Perfect indeed! Upright yet not haughty, yielding yet not submissive, near yet not cloying, distant yet not estranged, adaptable yet not excessive, returning yet not wearying, reversing yet not distressed, joyful yet not dissolute, enduring yet not exhausted, expansive yet not ostentatious, bestowing yet not wasteful, taking yet not greedy, abiding yet not stagnant, flowing yet not drifting. The five notes harmonize, the eight winds align, rhythm has measure, order is preserved—such is the shared mark of supreme virtue.”

When he saw the dance of *Xiang Yin* and *Nan Lü*, he said, “How fine! Yet there is still regret.” When he saw the dance of *Da Wu*, he said, “How fine! This must be the height of Zhou’s glory.” When he saw the dance of *Shao Hu*, he said, “The greatness of the sage! Yet even here, there is a fleeting flaw—how difficult it is to be a sage.” When he saw the dance of *Da Xia*, he said, “How fine! Diligent yet not self-congratulatory—who but Yu could have perfected this?” When he saw the dance of *Shao Yin*, he said, “Virtue has reached its utmost! Vast indeed—like heaven, which covers all without exception, like earth, which bears all without limit. Even the most exalted virtue cannot surpass this.”

The record states: *The Great Plan* says, “Thought is called wisdom.” Master Zhou said, “Non-thought is the root; thought is the means of connection. Without thought, there can be no connection. Without subtle wisdom, there can be no all-encompassing connection.” When Ji Zixia abandoned his home to till the land, his nurtured nature was already settled, and the spirit of Tai Bo in heaven subtly worked to connect his hidden depths. Thus, before he heard the music, it was as if the valley’s echo had not yet changed, the reeds had not yet stirred, rare sounds were scarce, and true connoisseurs were few. But after he heard the music, it was as if the nine heavens had opened, the hundred rivers had arrived in season, veins and channels had become clear, and all was suddenly and thoroughly connected. He understood its rising and fading, its beauty and grandeur, its diligence and sorrow, its vastness and refinement, its depth and breadth, its foundation and culmination—until it reached the point of being like heaven’s covering and earth’s bearing, and only then did it cease.

Was it that he sang every line or parsed every word? Rather, the all-encompassing connection arises from connecting the subtle, and connecting the subtle arises from thought. Did not the Master say, “I never expected music to reach such heights”? In his daily recitations and longings, his admiration and delight were as urgent as one drawing water from a well. Yet once he heard it, there was an ineffable melting of the heart and a profound sigh. Alas!

Today, those who recite the *Three Hundred Poems* are not even equal to a single phrase sung by a musician—this is because they do not think and thus cannot connect. Though the Master’s sighs were many, what use are they? And though one may observe, what use is that?

Jizha, while in Lu, met Shusun Muzi and spoke with him, saying to Muzi: "You will not die a natural death, for you love goodness yet cannot choose men wisely. I have heard that the noble man’s duty lies in selecting the right people. You, as the chief minister of Lu, hold its great governance, yet you do not exercise caution in appointments—how can you bear this? Disaster will surely befall you." He then journeyed to Qi, where he spoke with Yan Pingzhong, saying: "You hold both fief and office. Without fief, without office, you would have escaped calamity. Qi’s governance will soon pass to another; until it finds its rightful steward, strife will not cease." Thus, Yanzi, through Chen Huanzi, returned his fief and office, thereby evading the disaster of Le Gao.

He then visited Zheng, where he met Zitu, treating him as an old acquaintance. They shared a white mat, and Zichan presented him with a patterned robe. Jizha said: "Zheng’s ruling ministers are extravagant, and disaster is near. Governance will soon fall to you—rule with care, through ritual. Otherwise, Zheng will fall." Proceeding to Wei, he spoke with Lian Huan, Shi Gou, Shi Qi, Prince Ke, Gongshu Fa, and Prince Chao, saying: "Wei abounds in noble men; it has no cause for concern."

From Wei, he traveled to Jin, intending to rest at Qi. Hearing the sound of bells, he remarked: "How strange! I have heard that one who is discerning yet lacking in virtue will surely meet with execution." He then departed. When Wenzi learned of this, he never again listened to the zither or lute.

In Jin, he spoke with Yuefuzi, Han Xuanzi, and Wei Xianzi, saying: "Jin’s governance will likely gather in the hands of these three families." He then spoke with Shu Xiang, and as he prepared to leave, he said: "Exert yourself. The lord is extravagant and surrounded by many worthy men, while the ministers are all wealthy—governance will soon lie with the great families. You value uprightness; you must think how to preserve yourself from disaster."

The record states: The so-called learned and refined noble man does not merely understand past events but also foresees what is to come. Through stillness, emptiness, and clarity, clarity leads to comprehension of movement; uprightness leads to impartiality, and impartiality to universality. All these arise from the absence of desire. Looking at the present, men like Yan Ying of Qi, Zichan of Zheng, Boyu of Wei, and Shu Xiang of Jin were all extraordinary figures of their age. And men like Bao, Wu, Qi, Shu, Shan, Jing, and Chao were all prominent in governance. Though Wu was distant from the Central States, Jizha was close to benevolence and worthiness—was he not one who befriended the good throughout the world? Had he confined his renown to a single state or indulged in the riches and honors of his time, failing to befriend the wise and worthy, how could his illustrious name have endured to this day?

Yet even one as sagely as the Master once heard his voice and cough, and when Yan You was in Lu, he never once sent Jizha so much as a messenger—thus he remained but a man of a single state.

*Comprehensive Mirror*: Tian Dan was about to attack Di when he went to see Lu Zhonglian. Zhonglian said: "General, you will not take Di." Tian Dan replied: "I, with the remnants of Jimo’s broken troops, defeated the ten-thousand-chariot state of Yan and restored Qi’s ruins. Now you say I cannot take Di—why?" He mounted his chariot without a word of thanks and departed. He then attacked Di but failed to capture it after three months. Alarmed, he returned to see Lu Zhonglian and said: "Sir, you said I could not take Di—pray, let me hear your reasoning." Zhonglian replied: "When you were in Jimo, you sat on a basket of earth and stood with a spade in hand, rallying your soldiers with these words: ‘There is nowhere left to go—our ancestral temples are lost! Now, what hope remains? Where shall we turn?’ At that time, you had the resolve to die, and your soldiers had no thought of living. When you spoke, none failed to weep and raise their arms, eager to fight. That is how you defeated Yan. Now, you enjoy the revenues of Yeyi to the east and the pleasures of Zishang to the west, girded with gold, galloping between Zi and Mian. You know the joys of life but have no thought of death—this is why you cannot prevail." Tian Dan said: "I have taken your words to heart."

The next day, he roused his qi and patrolled the city walls, standing where arrows and stones rained down, seizing the drum and beating it himself. Thereupon, the Di people withdrew.

Lu writes: How perspicacious, this Lu Zhonglian! How keenly he struck the heart of the matter. Even with a man of Yue Yi’s worth, why did he falter at Ju and Jimo? Was it not for lack of such resolve? Thus the sages and worthies of old, ever vigilant and ever striving, kept Heaven’s principles ever in mind and dared not entertain thoughts of death. They feared only that the enemy’s resolve might harden while their own defenses slackened—was this not the reason?

When Tian Dan conquered Liaocheng, he spoke of Lu Zhonglian to the King of Qi. The king wished to ennoble him, but Zhonglian fled to the sea, saying: “I would rather embrace poverty and low station, free to follow my will, than accept wealth and rank and [lacuna].”
Lu writes: Lu Lian’s indulgence of his will—was it not excessive? Such indulgence is not what the worthy desire. When ruler acts as ruler, minister as minister, father as father, son as son, and when husband and wife, elder and younger, friends all fulfill their proper roles, how can the world be treated lightly? How can the will be left unchecked? Yet in Zhonglian’s time, the feudal lords sought to make Qin emperor, abandoning the righteousness between lord and minister; Yan’s king ceded his state, forsaking the benevolence between father and son; Queen Junwang remarried, defiling the rites between husband and wife; King Huiwen enthroned his younger son, disrupting the order between elder and younger; and the likes of Sun Bin, Pang Juan, Su Qin, and Zhang Yi sowed discord among friends, betraying the trust between them. Was it not for these reasons that Zhonglian sought to cast himself into the Eastern Sea? Even before the world’s scholars had spoken, men of middling ability could see that such a course was untenable.

Zishun was a sixth-generation descendant of Confucius. When the King of Wei heard of his worth, he sent an envoy bearing gold and silks to summon him. Zishun said: “If the king can truly put my Way into practice, then my Way is indeed for governing the world. Though I eat coarse food and drink plain water, I will serve him. But if he merely wishes to bind me to his service with high rank and generous emolument, then I am but one man—what need has the King of Wei for one man?” The envoy pressed him, and Zishun went to Wei. For nine months, he laid out his grand designs, but they were never adopted. He then retired, pleading illness. His friends said to him: “You should leave.” He replied: “Where would I go? Now, the states east of the mountains are exhausted and cannot recover. The Three Jin have ceded land to seek peace. The Two Zhous have collapsed and fallen to Qin. Yan, Qi, and Chu have already submitted. Judging from this, within twenty years, the world will surely belong entirely to Qin.”
Lu writes: In observing Zishun’s plans and wisdom, how different he was from others! When the state has the Way, one serves; when it does not, one folds one’s wings and keeps them close—this was the family tradition of Confucius. Qin’s cruelty is like a raging fire, and the world is but tinder. It cannot be extinguished or contained—how then can one wash oneself of it and flee? The rulers of the six states are like sparrows nesting in a hall—how can they remain even for a moment? How can they hope for lasting peace? His prediction that the world would belong to Qin within twenty years was not mere calculation, but principle. None but Zishun could have spoken thus.

The King of Qi enfeoffed Tian Ying at Xue, styling him Lord Jingguo. Lord Jingguo wished to fortify Xue. A retainer said to him: “Have you not heard of the great fish of the Eastern Sea? Nets cannot haul it, hooks cannot pull it, but when it strays from the water, even ants and frogs can overpower it. Now, Qi is your water. If you can long possess Qi, what need have you of Xue? But if you lose Qi, though you raise Xue’s walls to the heavens, will they suffice to rely upon?” Thereupon, he did not fortify Xue.
Lu writes: This retainer’s remonstrance with Ying was far wiser than the schemes of those like Wu and Lian Wen. What place have the likes of hawks, owls, and thieves in the records? Who could recall a retainer like this? Yet history has lost even his name. Later generations, such as Meiwu and Jin Hao, are not only a disgrace to gentlemen—if this retainer had any awareness, would he not grind his teeth in the underworld?

From the *Book of Han*: In his humble days, Cao Shen was on close terms with Xiao He, but later, as generals and ministers, they fell into discord. Upon hearing of Xiao He’s death, Cao Shen instructed his attendants to prepare for his journey, saying, “I shall enter the capital to become chancellor.” Soon after, an imperial envoy indeed arrived. Before his death, Xiao He had recommended only Cao Shen as worthy. When Cao Shen succeeded him as chancellor, he altered nothing, strictly adhering to Xiao He’s regulations. He selected officials from the commanderies and kingdoms who were inarticulate in rhetoric but steadfast and venerable, appointing them as his aides. Those clerks who were eloquent and harsh, seeking fame, he promptly dismissed. If he saw someone commit a minor fault, he would deliberately conceal and cover it up, so that the chancellery remained untroubled.

The Emperor, puzzled that the chancellor did not attend to affairs of state, asked, “Does Your Majesty consider himself as sagely and martial as the late Emperor?” The Emperor replied, “How dare I compare myself to the former Emperor?” Cao Shen then asked, “Does Your Majesty consider me as worthy as Xiao He?” The Emperor said, “It seems you do not measure up.” Cao Shen replied, “Your Majesty speaks truly. The late Emperor and Xiao He established the laws and decrees of the realm with utmost clarity. Now, if Your Majesty governs with ease while we ministers uphold our duties, adhering to these statutes without fail, would that not suffice?” The Emperor said, “Well said.”

After serving as chancellor for three years, the people sang of him: *“Xiao He made the laws, clear as day and night; Cao Shen succeeded him, guarding them without fail. His purity and constancy brought the people peace and unity.”*

Lu writes: Observing the relations among the meritorious ministers of Han, I see that their wisdom—or lack thereof—determined whether fortune or misfortune befell them. Comparing Xiao He and Cao Shen to Han Xin and Peng Yue is like comparing Han Xin and Peng Yue to Zhou Bo and Guan Ying. The histories praise Chancellor Cao for his achievements in storming cities and battling in the wilds, attributing his many victories to his association with the Marquis of Huaiyin. It is also recorded that after Han Xin had conquered Zhao and become chancellor, Cao Shen served as his right-hand minister, assisting in the conquest of Qi and the subjugation of the Lixia army. Later, he followed Han Xin to strike Long Ju, encamping at Gaomi. Cao Shen had risen alongside the Emperor from Feng and Pei, sharing such deep bonds, and both had served as chancellors, enjoying equal esteem. Yet when Han Xin gave orders, Cao Shen obeyed; when Han Xin led, Cao Shen followed—never once harboring the slightest resentment. Han Xin, once stripped of his kingship, grew despondent and discontented, even ashamed to be ranked alongside Zhou Bo and Guan Ying. Thus, Cao Shen’s heart was not merely set on maintaining peace and uniformity once the realm was settled. Even amid the clamor of war, he neither overreached nor sought gain, so that Xiao He’s legacy remained unmarred.

It is further said: Had Cao Shen still been alive, could the Lü clan have usurped the throne, and could the House of Liu have avoided peril? The answer: Huangshi Gong’s maxim states, *“A plot leaked in secret brings ruin.”* At that time, Emperor Hui was weak and ineffectual, while the Lü clan was swift and cunning. Yin waxed as yang waned—a case of *“the marsh drowning the wood,”* as the *Book of Changes* warns. Had Cao Shen failed to heed the omen of a sagging ridgepole and instead rushed headlong into peril, could he have succeeded? Yet it was not that he was unaware of the dangers of indulgence or the troubles of the realm. Between failure through exposure and success through retreat, which was the wiser choice? Later, when Ju Shou’s words spurred the downfall of the Lü clan, it was Cao Shen’s foresight that made it possible. Yet the historians Ban and Ma recorded Cao Shen while omitting Ju Shou—was this not an oversight?

During Empress Lü’s reign, the Lü clan monopolized power, scheming to coerce the young emperor and endanger the House of Liu. Chancellor Chen Ping, though troubled, lacked the strength to resist and often sat in deep contemplation. Lu Jia visited him unannounced and entered without ceremony, saying, “Why do you ponder so deeply?” Chen Ping replied, “What do you suppose I am pondering?” Lu Jia said, “Your Excellency holds the highest office and enjoys the revenue of ten thousand households—one could say you have attained the utmost wealth and honor without further desires. Yet your worries can only concern the Lü clan and the young emperor.” Chen Ping said, “Indeed.”

"What is to be done?" Chen Ping asked.

Lu Jia replied, "When the realm is at peace, attention turns to the chancellor; when the realm is in peril, attention turns to the general. If general and chancellor are in harmony, then the officers will be content and loyal. With officers content and loyal, even if the realm undergoes upheaval, power will not be divided. When power is not divided, the fate of the altars of state rests in the hands of you two alone. Why not befriend the Grand Marshal and bind him to you in deep alliance?"

Chen Ping followed his advice, presenting the Grand Marshal with five hundred gold pieces as a birthday gift and hosting him with lavish feasts and music. The Grand Marshal reciprocated in kind. The two forged a deep alliance, and the Lü clan’s schemes grew ever more precarious.

*Recorded Note:* Chen Ping devised six extraordinary strategies, priding himself on his own wisdom, yet he still deferred to Lu Jia—why? At that time, fearing disaster would befall him, he was too entangled in the crisis to see clearly, and thus fell short of the clarity of one observing from the side. Yet this view is but one interpretation. A scholar of the Southern Song later countered: "Since ancient times, no general has ever achieved great deeds abroad while a powerful minister held sway at court." Their understanding was much the same—who would have thought these two scholars, separated by time, would follow the same line of reasoning? Yet their intent was as different as yin and yang, day and night, warmth and cold—utterly irreconcilable. Thus their outcomes diverged in peace and peril, advantage and dullness, fortune and misfortune, survival and ruin. Those who govern the realm must take heed of this principle.

Zhu Yi, ranked first in administrative conduct, was appointed Grand Minister of Agriculture. He was sincere and generous, deeply loyal to old friends, yet his nature was upright and incorruptible, refusing to engage in private dealings. The Son of Heaven held him in high esteem, and the court respected him.

At the time, Zhang Chang served as Chancellor of Jiaodong. He wrote to Zhu Yi, saying: "The enlightened ruler turns his mind to the distant past, broadly seeking worthy scholars—this is truly the time for loyal ministers to exhaust their thoughts. Yet I, Zhang Chang, am exiled to govern a troubled commandery, constrained by regulations and ink, my heart bound and knotted, leaving no room for extraordinary ideas. Even if I had them, where could they be applied? You, sir, possess a virtue of clarity and integrity, overseeing the affairs of the grain and fields. In the past, though Chen Ping was wise, he needed Wei Qing to advance; though Han Xin was brilliant, he relied on Lord Xiao to gain trust. Thus, each case reveals the heroes of its time. If one insists on recommending only those of Yi Yin or Lü Wang’s caliber, then such men would never have risen through your aid."

Moved by Zhang Chang’s words, Zhu Yi recommended many worthy scholars and officials, and many benefited from his support.

*Recorded Note:* According to the *Rites of Zhou: Grand Minister of Education*, "With the three virtues of the village, teach the myriad people and summon the worthy"—this is the duty of the Grand Minister of Agriculture. Zhang Chang’s counsel to Zhu Yi may be called discerning of urgent priorities, neither failing to recognize talent nor indulging in grand words. Thus it is recorded.

Yú Bǎo, by virtue of his mastery of the classics, served as a clerk in the commandery. The Censor-in-Chief, Zhāng Zhōng, summoned him as an aide and wished him to instruct his son in the classics. He had a residence prepared and provisions arranged for him, but Yú Bǎo submitted a memorial to resign and left. Zhāng Zhōng repeatedly urged him to return, though inwardly he felt displeased. Later, when Yú Bǎo was appointed as chief clerk, he moved into the official residence and performed the house-warming sacrifice. Zhāng Zhōng, secretly observing this with suspicion, sent a close associate to inquire: *"Previously, the Censor-in-Chief had a grand residence prepared for you, yet you resigned in protest, seeking to display lofty integrity. Now, the chief clerks of both offices are men of refined conduct, yet you have accepted the post. Though you delight in the new residence, your actions before and after seem inconsistent."*

Yú Bǎo replied: *"That refined scholars do not serve as chief clerks is their own choice, but the Censor-in-Chief deemed me worthy of the post—none in the entire office objected, so how could I alone claim superiority? Earlier, your son wished to study the classics, and you sought to bring me closer to him. The rites prescribe that students come to the teacher, not that the teacher go to them. The Dao cannot be compromised, but what harm is there in personally demonstrating this? Moreover, if one has not encountered the right opportunity, there is nothing one cannot do—how could I refuse the post of chief clerk?"*

Yú Zhōng, having heard this, promptly memorialized the throne, praising Yú Bǎo for his mastery of the classics and his upright character, recommending him for appointment as a close attendant. Thereupon, Bǎo was made *Yìláng* and later promoted to *Jiàn Dàfū*.

The compiler notes: At the time, Bǎo was still a minor official, yet his lifelong wisdom was first set down in these words. Why? The threat of wolves and jackals is long known, yet the warning against the fox in the city walls must not be neglected—this refers to his refusal to implicate Dù Yǔ in the affair of Jì. The roots of calamity run deep, yet the grievance of the fierce beast must not be erased—this refers to his memorial of a few lines that rescued Zhèng Chóng from prison. In the end, he preserved himself and even secured his descendants. Was he not a man of keen insight?

*Hong Dao Lu*, Scroll 46, ends.

---

*Hong Dao Lu*, Scroll 47: Wisdom
**Wisdom Among Friends**

From *The Book of the Later Han*: Zhōng Hào was renowned for his steadfast conduct, and along with Xún Sù, he was admired and sought after by scholar-officials. Lǐ Yīng once sighed, saying, *"Master Xún’s discernment is peerless, while Master Zhōng’s perfect virtue is worthy of emulation."* A fellow townsman, Chén Huáng, was younger than Hào, yet Hào drew him close as a friend.

When Hào served as *Gōngcáo* of the commandery and was summoned to the Minister of Justice’s office, the governor, upon his departure, asked, *"Who can take your place?"* Hào replied, *"If Your Excellency truly seeks the right man, the warden of Xīmén, Chén Huáng, will do."* Upon hearing this, Huáng said, *"Master Zhōng seems not to judge others well—how did he recognize me alone?"*

Hào’s nephew, Jǐn, was also fond of learning and admired antiquity, embodying a spirit of modesty and deference. He was the same age as Yīng and equally renowned. Yīng’s grandfather, the Grand Commandant Xiū, remarked, *"Jǐn resembles our family’s nature: when the state is well-ordered, he will not be cast aside; when it is not, he will escape execution."* Thus, Yīng married his sister to him.

Hào often advised, *"In the past, Guó Wǔzǐ delighted in exposing others’ faults, inviting resentment. The true Way lies in preserving oneself and one’s family."* Later, Jǐn died at home, and the scholars composed a eulogy for him:

*"Of virtuous conduct in Línlǜ,
He dwelt only where propriety allowed.
Delighting in the *Odes* and *Documents*,
He played the zither, cherishing antiquity.
Five times summoned by the provinces,
Nine times offered the highest offices,
He declined imperial commands,
Passing his years in ease."*

The compiler notes: The advice of Yīng’s grandfather seems at odds with Yīng’s own character. Why? From the middle of the Han onward, eunuchs and upstarts wielded unchecked power, and society came to exalt those who risked their lives through defiant purity and outspoken criticism. Those who did not conform were denounced even by commoners and herdsmen. Thus, the sage guides the people toward balanced reason, curbing excess and recklessness, cautioning whom they associate with, and tempering their biases. Men like Línlǜ possessed the wisdom to preserve themselves, their Dao never cutting off from others. Neither the treacherous nor the powerful could sway them with authority or arrogance. Truly, they were those who had extricated themselves from the currents of desire.

Xú Yǔ was poor and tilled the land himself, eating only what his own labor produced. Yet he was reverent, frugal, dutiful, and yielding, and all who dwelt near him admired his virtue.

When Governor Chén Fān served in his commandery, he would receive no guests—save for Chēng alone, for whom he would set out a special couch, which he would hang up once Chēng departed. In the second year of the Yánxī era, Chén memorialized Emperor Huán to recommend Chēng, and the court dispatched an honored carriage with black curtains and full ceremonial protocol to summon him, yet he did not come. He had also been repeatedly recruited by Grand Commandant Huáng Qióng, but declined each time. When Huáng later died, Chēng walked on foot all the way to Jiāngxià to attend the funeral. There, he set out a simple offering of wine and a single dish, wept, and departed without leaving his name. Those gathered were all renowned scholars from the four quarters; when Guō Líntōng and several dozen others heard of it, they suspected it was Chēng. They sent Máo Róng, who rode swiftly to intercept him on the road and prepare a meal. As they spoke of farming and husbandry, Chēng, upon leaving, said to Róng: “Convey my regards to Guō Líntōng. When a great tree is about to fall, no single rope can hold it. Why cling so stubbornly, refusing to seek peace in quietude?”

The record states: The *Yìjīng*’s *Zhú* hexagram, top yang line, reads: *“Abundant pursuit brings no disadvantage.”* The commentary explains: *“Abundant” means broad, at ease, and self-content in one’s disposition. “Pursuit” means to drift far away, unbound and unentangled—this is what is good.* The top yang line, firm and radiant, stands at the hexagram’s outer edge, free from entanglements below, and thus dwells in ease. Where could it go that would not be advantageous? These words were written for Chēng. As for those others, though they knew to scorn the world with aloof disdain and refuse minor appointments, they could not drift far away—entering neither the deepest mountains nor the densest forests. Instead, they brought factional disaster upon themselves, willingly enduring execution and humiliation. These are what the *Yìjīng* calls *“pursuit with entanglements, illness, and peril.”* Could such a path truly be called wisdom?

Guō Tài was broadly learned in the classics, skilled in discourse, and possessed a refined voice and bearing. When he first met the Prefect of Hénán, Lǐ Yīng, the latter was deeply impressed and befriended him. Soon, his name resounded throughout the capital. Later, when he returned to his hometown, scholars saw him off at the riverbank in a procession of thousands of carriages.

Lin Zōng crossed the river in the same boat as Lǐ Yǐng, and the assembled guests gazed upon them as if they were immortals. Some urged him to enter officialdom, but he replied: “By night I observe the celestial signs, by day I examine human affairs—what Heaven has cast aside cannot be propped up.” Naturally perceptive of others, he delighted in encouraging and instructing scholars. Standing eight feet tall, with a commanding presence, he wore flowing robes and a broad sash, traveling through commanderies and states. Once, while journeying between Chén and Liáng, he was caught in the rain, and one corner of his headscarf drooped. Thereafter, people deliberately folded one corner of their headscarves in imitation of *Línzōng’s scarf*, so great was his renown.

Someone asked Fàn Pāng of Rǔnán: “What sort of man is Guō Línzōng?” Pāng replied: “He withdraws without defying his kin, remains true without cutting himself off from the world. The Son of Heaven cannot make him a minister, nor can the feudal lords claim him as a friend. I know nothing beyond this.” Though skilled in discerning human character, he avoided provocative or abstruse discourse, so that even when the eunuchs monopolized power, they could not harm him. When the partisan affair erupted, many renowned scholars suffered for it—only Línzōng and Yuán of Rǔnán escaped unscathed.

**Recorded Note:** Fàn Yè remarked: Zhuāng Zhōu once said that human nature is more treacherous than mountains and rivers, for though its movements may be discerned, its depths and obstructions are hard to fathom. Thus, even the closest bonds can deceive in appearance, and even a sage’s judgment is challenged by this. Yet Línzōng never erred in matters of refinement or vulgarity—his clarity of nature was truly exceptional. Nevertheless, by tempering his words and conduct, he ultimately thrived in an age of obscurity. Through humble guidance, he inspired scholars to pursue fame, a legacy even the followers of Mò and Mèng could not surpass.

Mèng Mǐn, a guest in Tàiyuán, dropped his bowl of rice to the ground, paid it no heed, and walked away. When Línzōng saw this and asked his reason, he replied: “The rice is already broken—what use is there in looking?” Struck by this, Línzōng urged him to study, and after ten years, Mǐn became renowned.

**Recorded Note:** In my humble view, Mèng Mǐn possessed innate excellence but lacked learning. Because of his innate excellence, he was free from regretful attachments and could order his affairs with precision. Because he lacked learning, he suffered unforeseen setbacks and held divergent opinions. Had he been encouraged to study, he would have become a man of true cultivation. This is how the noble person brings out the best in others, and why guidance and encouragement are indispensable.

Shēntú Pán was endowed with subtle and wondrous *qi*, his nature keen and his mind penetrating. He observed mourning rites for his parents with such devotion that he nearly perished from grief. His conduct was virtuous, his principles noble—few could match him. Content in poverty, he delighted in seclusion, savoring the Dao and upholding authenticity. Neither prosperity nor adversity swayed him, neither praise nor blame altered his resolve. Cài Yōng compared himself to Pán, acknowledging that though he was older in years, Pán surpassed him in virtue and wisdom. Later, when the commandery summoned him to serve as a clerk, he declined and remained in reclusion, mastering the Five Classics and delving into apocryphal texts.

When Línzōng met him, he marveled at his exceptional qualities. Earlier, Fàn Pāng and others had openly criticized the court, and from the highest ministers to the lowest officials, all deferred to them. Students at the Imperial Academy vied to emulate their example, believing that literature would flourish and recluses would once again be employed. Pán alone sighed and said: “In the age of the Warring States, recluses debated recklessly, and the kings of the various states even cleared the way for them as escorts—yet in the end, they suffered the calamity of the burning of books and the burying of scholars. We are witnessing the same thing now.” He then severed all ties with the world, built a hut from trees, and lived as an ordinary man. Poor, he worked as a lacquer artisan. After two years, the partisan proscription erupted, and hundreds were killed or punished—yet Pán remained untouched by suspicion.

In the fifth year of *Zhōngpíng*, fourteen men, including Xún Shuǎng, Qiáo Xuán, Hán Róng, and Chén Jì, were summoned by the imperial carriage. Pán alone did not respond, though many urged him to go; he merely smiled and said nothing. Soon after, Shuǎng and the others were coerced by [Dǒng] Zhuó. When the imperial court relocated westward and the capital descended into chaos, many high officials fell victim to war and famine, their families scattered—only Pán preserved his lofty aspirations to the end, dying at home at the age of seventy-four.

**Recorded Note:** The histories praise Shēntú Pán for perceiving the subtlest signs—yet his insight was not merely into signs, but into the Dao itself, and his judgment was sound. For though criticizing the court led to officials deferring to them, and though the court was corrupt, they achieved personal loftiness—what manner of affair was this? As the *Zhōngyōng* says: “Everyone calls themselves wise, yet when driven into nets, traps, and pits, they do not realize it.” This is precisely what it describes.

With Pán’s endowment of qi so profound and subtle, his nature keen and his mind penetrating, he was thus able from the outset to stand resolute, free from doubt and dispute, and thereafter to remain unhurried, fulfilling his far-reaching vision—just as the *Yìjīng* says of one who “pursues excellence with steadfast virtue and meets with good fortune.” That he preserved his lofty aspirations to the end was only fitting.

Xǔ Shù in his youth was renowned for his unyielding integrity and his love of human relationships, discerning and esteeming many. Figures like Fán Zǐzhāo and Yáng Shì rose to prominence in the world, and thus whenever the realm spoke of those who elevated men of talent, they invariably praised Xǔ Shù. When he often traveled to Yǐngchuān, he associated with many elders—save that he never paid a visit to Chén Tài. Moreover, when Chén Fán returned to bury his deceased wife, all the villagers attended, yet Shù alone did not go. Someone asked him the reason, and he replied: “Tàiqiū’s Way is too broad; what is broad is hard to encompass fully. Zhòngjǔ’s nature is too severe; what is severe allows little accommodation. Thus I did not call on him.” Such was the frequency of his measured judgments.

When Cáo Cāo was still obscure, he often humbled his words and offered lavish gifts, seeking to be assessed by Shù. Shù, however, disdained the man and refused to respond. Cāo then lay in wait to coerce him, and Shù, having no choice, said: “You are a treacherous villain in times of peace, a hero in times of chaos.” Cāo departed greatly pleased. Shù and his elder cousin Jìng were both of lofty discernment, fond of discussing the characters of their village and district. Each month they would revise their evaluations, giving rise to the local custom of the “monthly critique” in Rǔnán.

**Recorded Note:** Observing Xǔ Shù’s monthly critiques and comparing them to Xì Yě’s *Spring and Autumn* judgments, how far apart they are! The Master said: “Cì, are you truly worthy? As for me, I have no leisure for such things.” The sage’s way of engaging the world and managing affairs was indeed thus. Since he had already deemed Tàiqiū too broad to encompass and Zhòngjǔ too severe to accommodate, his judgments were sound—so why did he not have the leisure to attend to them? Though Cāo was cunning and shrewd, his time had not yet come; yet in the end, even a single *yào* rib was not tolerated—how fortunate he was to escape disaster! This was no way of the wise preserving themselves.

The *Book of Jìn* records: Huángfǔ Mì was tranquil and sparing of desires, diligent and untiring in his efforts. He mastered the classics and the hundred schools’ teachings, devoting himself to writing, styling himself the Master of Mystic Repose. He composed the *Discourse on Preserving the Mystic* and the *Treatise on the Music of the Sages and the True*. Some urged him to cultivate fame and expand his connections, but Mì replied: “No one short of a sage can fully reconcile withdrawal and engagement. Dwelling among fields and villages, content in poverty and tilling the soil, one may still delight in the Way of Yáo and Shùn—why must one pursue worldly advantage, entangle oneself in official duties, and only then be deemed worthy?” He wrote the *Discourse on Preserving the Mystic*, saying: “What men most cherish is life; what the Way must fully preserve is form. What harms form and nature is illness. If one disturbs the Way of wholeness to harm life and nature, how can one escape poverty and lowliness while preserving what one desires? When one person dies, mourners deem it a loss; when one is born, laughers deem it a gain. Yet mourning and laughter are not truly gains or losses of life and death. Thus the supreme Way is not diminished, and the highest virtue is not augmented. Why? Because it is complete in itself. If one were to turn the thoughts of all under heaven toward averting the calamity of harming life, or direct the hearts of the four seas toward spreading the disease of false augmentation, would this be the perfection of the Dao and virtue? Only that which is not diminished is supremely firm; only that which is not augmented is supremely substantial. Firmness endures without diminution; substantiality endures without attenuation. If one can embody the reality of firmness and substantiality, abide in the truth of non-attenuation, stand beyond gain and loss, and wander beyond the bounds of form and body, then one’s Way is whole.” Thus he never entered official service. When Emperor Wǔ issued an edict pressing him, Mì submitted a memorial calling himself a rustic, a younger brother borrowing books. The emperor sent him a cartload of books.

**Recorded Note:** How wise was the Master of Mystic Repose! Indeed, he not only understood but lived by this principle.

Amidst poverty and low station, he could still attend to illness and affliction, evading the chaos of a disordered age. His learning arose from purity and emptiness, his aspirations rooted in ritual and law. Neither could he be likened to the vulgar crowd, nor did he regard wealth and honor as more than floating clouds—such a man was beyond comparison. The discourse of Mystic Repose penetrated the truths of life and death, offering much worthy of contemplation. Here it is recorded.

Wei Zhong was magnanimous and fond of learning. He shut his door to cultivate himself, refusing to associate with the men of his time. Pei Gu spoke of him several times to Zhang Hua, who summoned him to office, but Wei declined on grounds of illness. When asked the reason, he replied: “I am but a thatched-roof rustic, with no ambition for officialdom. Moreover, Maoxian [Zhang Hua] is all blossom and no fruit, while Pei is ever desirous yet never satisfied. To abandon classical rites and cling to the heels of traitors—is this conduct befitting a true gentleman?” Pei had long harbored designs on him, but Wei feared that if great waves toppled the mountains, even the ripples might sweep him away—how then could he approach the tail of a tiger and risk scalding burns?

Zhang Han possessed refined talent and excelled in literary composition. When He Xun of Kuaiji received a summons to Luoyang, he passed through Wu, playing the zither within his vermilion gates. Though Han did not know him, he approached and engaged him in conversation, and the two took great delight in each other. Learning that He was bound for Luoyang, Han remarked, “I too have business in the Northern Capital.” They departed together in the same carriage, without even informing Han’s family.

The Prince of Qi summoned Han to serve as Gentleman of the Yellow Gate. As power was then concentrated in the prince’s hands, Han said to his fellow townsman Gu Rong: “The world is in turmoil, and calamity shows no sign of abating. For one with a name spanning the Four Seas, retreat is exceedingly difficult. I am but a man of the mountains and forests, with no aspirations for this age. You would do well to guard against danger ahead with clarity and contemplate what lies behind with wisdom.” Gu grasped his hand, moved to tears, and said: “I too shall join you in gathering bracken on South Mountain and drinking from the Three Rivers.” Soon after, Han saw the autumn wind rise and longed for the water oats and caltrop of Wu, the fine wine and sliced perch. He mused: “In life, what matters most is following one’s heart. How could I endure an official’s palanquin for thousands of miles just to chase after empty titles?” He promptly ordered his carriage and returned home. People praised him for perceiving the subtle signs.

**Recorded Note:** In Wei’s refusal of Zhang Maoxian’s summons, he discerned the signs before any movement had begun—this is what is meant by resolute action and nurturing virtue. Thus, when a spring emerges from the foot of a mountain, though it has yet to encounter peril or find its course, like clouds ungathered above the peak or waves unstirred upon the water, it remains beyond reach. In Zhang Jiying’s [Han’s] departure from Gu Yanxian [Rong], he feared disaster only after it had become visible—this is what is meant by perilous virtue and avoiding calamity. Thus, when Heaven and Earth fail to commune, the Way of the petty man grows long while the Way of the noble man wanes, like water sinking into drowning depths or fire raging in scorching flames—there is no time to delay. Does not Mencius say: some distance themselves, some draw near; some depart, some remain—all to preserve the purity of their person? Are these not men of clear wisdom?

Yan Han’s restrained wisdom won the admiration of the multitude. He formed a deep bond with Deng You, once remarking: “Z

Here the admiration of Renjie for Shide, though at first indifferent, ultimately turned to reverence—what harm did this do to their unity? What of Pei Xingjian’s discernment of men? When he first met the future examination graduate Wang Bo and the Xianyang constable Su Weidao—both then unknown—he declared: “These two will in time succeed one another in overseeing the selection of officials. I have a young daughter, and I would entrust her to your care.” At that time, Wang Bo’s younger brother, along with Yang Jiong of Huayin, Lu Zhaolin of Fanyang, and Luo Binwang of Yiwu, all enjoyed great renown for their literary brilliance. Li Jingxuan held them in especially high regard, certain they would rise to prominence. Xingjian, however, remarked: “For a scholar to go far, he must first cultivate his character and judgment, and only then his talents and skills. Though these men possess literary refinement, they are restless and shallow, hardly vessels fit to receive rank and emolument. Yang alone is somewhat composed and may yet become a district magistrate; the rest will be fortunate to die in peace.” Later, Bo drowned in the Southern Sea, Zhaolin threw himself into the Ying River, Binwang was executed for rebellion, and Jiong ended his days as magistrate of Yingchuan. Bo and Weidao both oversaw the selection of officials—all exactly as Xingjian had foretold.

The Record states: Confucius praised Zigong as a *hulian* vessel—this is what is meant by character and judgment. King Wen commended the unhewn timber of the talented scholar—this is what is meant by talents and skills. Yet one must first possess the substance of gold or jade before carving its patterns. As for those mere clay pots, no matter how brightly adorned, can they ever serve in the ancestral temple? Jia Yi was a man of exceptional talent, yet the noble man still faulted him for his grand ambitions and narrow capacity, his surplus of talent but want of judgment—how much more so the Four Masters! Thus the noble man values himself all the more, not content merely to craft fine phrases.

In *The History of the Song*, it is recorded that Zhang Yong and Fu Lin of Qingzhou were schoolmates in their youth. Lin withdrew from public life, while Yong rose to prominence. For thirty years, Yong sought Lin in vain. One day, Lin arrived unannounced. When the clerks announced “Fu Lin requests an audience,” Yong rebuked them: “Master Fu is a scholar of the realm—even I cannot claim him as a friend. Who are you to address him by name?” Lin smiled and said: “After a lifetime apart, you still cling to such formalities? Does this mean you remain unaware that there exists in the world a man named Fu Lin?” Yong asked: “Why did you withdraw before, and why have you emerged now?” Lin replied: “You are about to depart, and I have come to bid you farewell.” Yong said: “I knew it myself.” Lin said: “Then what more is there to say?” The next day, he took leave of Yong’s family. A month later, Yong passed away.

The Record states: This resembles the bond between Yuan Bo and Ju Qing—such is the power of sincerity, which knows no bounds. Thus when hearts mirror one another, nothing stands between them. Yet even the recluse of Shu Mountain, who could foresee events ten years hence by stilling his thoughts, cannot compare to Fu Lin, who remained secluded for thirty years. His freedom from worldly enticements and his ability to cast off wealth and honor are plain to see.

Bi Zhongyou was deeply favored by Sima Guang, Lü Gongzhu, and Fan Chunren. At the time, Su Shi served in the Hanlin Academy, often critiquing current policies through his words and writings. Fearing he would invite disaster, Zhongyou wrote to warn him: “Mencius spoke only when compelled, and Confucius wished to remain silent. The ancients, in their meticulous planning and deepest reflections, sought to establish their achievements and preserve their lives—never did they stray from this principle. Since entering court, you have never weighed the consequences of fortune or misfortune, gain or loss, as they pertain to your person. The harm of speech is not limited to what leaves the mouth; it manifests in poems and songs, in praises and odes, in inscriptions and prefaces—all are forms of speech. Now you fear what you say aloud but not what you commit to writing. When you affirm what you believe, those who agree will rejoice; when you condemn what you oppose, those you offend will resent you. Those who rejoice cannot advance your designs, while those who resent may already be undermining your affairs. The world already associates your name with your writings. Even if your words contain no explicit judgments, suspicions of bias will still arise—how much worse if they do! You hold no office as remonstrator or censor, yet you risk your safety to provoke taboos, courting danger as recklessly as a rolling stone or a drowning man.”

The Record states: According to historical accounts, Chao Gu was a fellow townsman of the Three Su in Meishan and had long been close to them. Yet when the Su brothers rose to prominence in the same court, he never once visited them. When they were exiled in succession to the southern frontiers, none of their old friends or relatives reached out—only Chao Gu, alone in Meishan, sought out the two Su brothers. They were astonished and overjoyed, exclaiming: “This is no man of our time—he is a man of antiquity!” I humbly submit that what sets the men of antiquity apart from those of today is their weighty sense of duty in admonishing others. And the essence of such admonition lies first in wisdom and clarity. Had the two Su brothers heeded Zhongyou’s words earlier and benefited from his forthright counsel, they might not have been banished to the ends of the earth. And Chao Gu’s name, so striking to the ear, would not have appeared in the historical record. Instead of valuing loyal warnings, they boasted of their extraordinary conduct—this Record, in omitting Yuan Xiu and including Ju Gongshu, reflects the same principle of preserving oneself and speaking with caution.

Shao Bowen was the son of Shao Yong. Yong’s reputation was immense in his time, and he associated with Sima Guang, the two Cheng brothers, and other eminent scholars. Thus Bowen, raised on his father’s teachings and serving these great men, acquired a broad and penetrating understanding of affairs, particularly those most pressing. When Emperor Shenzong passed and Zhezong ascended the throne, Cai Que still held the position of chief minister. Xing Shu, transferred from Xiangzhou to Heyang, visited Que to conspire on the matter of establishing the succession. By then, Guang had already died, and his son Kang was expected at court. Shu summoned him to Heyang. Bowen advised: “You have not yet completed your mourning rites. Before presenting yourself to the emperor, you should not take a detour to visit friends.” Kang replied: “I have already agreed.” Bowen said: “Shu is cunning and opportunistic. He may use this to pressure you. If you comply, you will surely regret it later.” Kang went regardless, and Shu indeed urged him to write a letter praising Que. Kang, being of the same examination year as Shu and a disciple of Guang, complied and wrote the letter as Shu instructed.

Cai Que and his faction, considering Kang the son of Guang, believed that if they claimed Que had rendered meritorious service in establishing the succession, the world would surely credit it, thus securing Kang’s future and protecting his family. Later, when Liang Tao was summoned as a remonstrance official, Shu also lured him to Heyang, where they debated day and night. Que presented Kang’s letter as evidence, but Tao was displeased. Coincidentally, Wu Chuhou memorialized that Que’s poems had slandered the court. Tao and Liu Anshe jointly petitioned for Que’s execution and Shu’s punishment. The court ordered Kang to adjudicate the case, and only then did he regret his actions.

After Kang’s death, his son Zhi was still young. Empress Dowager Xuanren took pity on him, and Lü Taifang, noting that Kang had always trusted Bowen, requested that Bowen be appointed professor of the Western Capital to educate Zhi. Upon arrival, Bowen admonished: “The grandson of Wengong, the son of a great remonstrator—whether wise or foolish, the world watches with awe.” Hearing this, Zhi studied diligently without respite and ultimately established himself.

At the beginning of the Shaosheng era, Zhang Dun became chief minister. Dun had once served Kangjie and wished to employ Bowen, but Bowen refused. When the law required him to report to the Ministry of Personnel for appointment, Cheng Yi warned: “I fear for your journey.” Bowen replied: “Would I not wish to meet my late father in the underworld?” Upon arrival, he first accepted the ministry’s official assignment before meeting the chief minister. Dun then broached the subject of Kangjie’s learning, sighing: “Alas, I could not complete my studies under the Master.” Bowen said: “My late father’s ‘Pre-Celestial Learning’ expounded upon heaven, earth, and the myriad things—nothing was left unexplained. If one truly believes in it, even the enmity of those who turn against one can be forgotten.” At the time, Dun was instigating factional persecutions, so Bowen sought to move him with these words. Dun was momentarily shaken and recommended him to the court, but Bowen requested a local post. Displeased, Dun appointed him supervisor of the Yongxing Army’s coin-casting office.

At that time, the worthies of the Yuanyou era were being exiled south, and few scholars visited them. Bowen met Fan Zuyu in Xianping and Fan Chunren in Yingchang, undeterred by the risks. Earlier, Yong had once said: “When the world is about to descend into chaos, only Shu remains safe—one should flee there in time.” At the end of the Xuanhe era, Bowen moved his family to Shu and thus escaped disaster.

Zhao Ding, who had studied under Bowen in his youth, later inscribed his tomb: “Rising through learning and conduct in the Yuanyou era, upholding moral integrity in the Shaosheng era, and being anciently dismissed in the Chongning era.” The world took these three phrases to summarize Bowen’s life’s course.

**Recorded Reflection:**
In my humble observation, Kangjie not only foresaw the rise and fall of the past but also verified the order and chaos of the future. His son Bowen not only did no disservice to his father but also sought to benefit his friends. Looking back today: of the eminent ministers of the Yuanyou era, who among those who bowed their heads to execution preserved themselves? Of the foremost disciples of the Two Chengs, who among those whose families were harmed protected their households? Acting rashly brings regret, and one’s reputation is ruined; rushing to martyrdom for others leads to one’s own destruction. Falling into enmity is pitiable in human terms, while blindly following the tide violates the principles of things. Why not strive in a well-governed court and avoid calamity in a chaotic age? Advancing through the gate of the sages, one may be called prescient—this is the unconfused wisdom of the enlightened, not something to be burdened by those who attribute all to fate and qi.

**From the *Reflections on Things at Hand*:**
Zhang Hengqu asked Cheng Mingdao: “Though I cannot yet still my nature from being disturbed, I am still troubled by external things. What should I do?”
Mingdao replied: “What is called stillness is stillness in motion and stillness in quietude—without grasping or rejecting, without inner or outer. If you regard external things as external and allow them to pull you along, you treat your own nature as having an inside and an outside. Moreover, if you consider your nature as following things externally, then when it is outside, what remains inside? This is to deliberately cut off external temptations while failing to recognize that nature has no inside or outside. Having divided inner and outer into two roots, how can you suddenly speak of stillness? The constancy of heaven and earth lies in their mind pervading the myriad things without a mind of their own; the constancy of the sage lies in their emotions responding to the myriad affairs without being bound by emotion. Thus, the learning of the noble person should be nothing less than vast and impartial, responding to things as they come.

*The Book of Changes* says: ‘Persistence brings good fortune and eliminates regret. Though thoughts come and go, friends follow your intent.’ If you rigidly focus on removing external temptations, you will find them vanishing in the east only to arise in the west—not only are they unworthy of concern, but their beginnings are endless and cannot be eradicated. Human emotions each have their blind spots, so they cannot accord with the Dao. The general problem lies in selfishness and the use of cleverness. Selfishness prevents one from taking action as a proper response; the use of cleverness prevents one from attaining clarity and awareness as natural. Now, to hate external things and seek a realm where nothing exists is like turning a mirror backward to seek its reflection.

*The Book of Changes* says: ‘Stopping at the back, one does not obtain one’s body; walking in the courtyard, one does not see others.’ Rather than rejecting the external and affirming the internal, it is better to forget both inner and outer. When both are forgotten, the mind becomes clear and unburdened; unburdened, it is still; still, it is bright; bright, it is lofty. How then can responding to things be a hindrance? The sage’s joy arises from what is right to rejoice in; the sage’s anger arises from what is right to be angry at. Thus, the sage’s joy and anger are not tied to the heart but are triggered by things. Does the sage not respond to things? How can one deem following the external as wrong and seek what is within as right? Now, compare the joy and anger of those who are selfish and use cleverness with the proper joy and anger of the sage—how do they measure up?

Of human emotions, anger is the easiest to arouse and the hardest to control. Yet if, in the moment of anger, one can suddenly forget the anger and examine the rightness or wrongness of the matter, one may see that external temptations are not worth hating and may grasp more than half of the Dao.

**Recorded Reflection:**
In my humble observation, the essay *On Stabilizing One’s Nature* reveals the Master’s profound and unique attainment, surpassing what other scholars could achieve.

When one is burdened by external things, one cannot reclaim one’s wandering heart. Yet in stabilizing the nature, there is no grasping or rejecting, no inner or outer, and movement and stillness merge into oneness.
