The most wondrous attainment lies in being vast and empty like the Grand Duke, responding to things as they come. All reasoning and verification return to this. Yet what can be pointed to and easily aged is none other than the emotions, hence the discussion of joy and anger. If one seeks the path of progress, it begins with forgetting anger and examining principle.

The essence of this essay lies in illuminating natural awareness, while its greatest warning is against selfishness and the use of cunning. It aligns with Yanzi’s luminous insight, Zengzi’s stability and tranquil reflection, Zisi’s sincerity and clarity of nature, Mencius’s foundation in profit, and Master Zhou’s enlightened universality—nothing is left unexhausted. This is why it surpasses all ages, and why it need not wait for confusion to be deemed a completed work.

Lu Jiuyuan, at the age of three or four, asked his father: “Where do the boundaries of heaven and earth end?” His father laughed without answering, and Jiuyuan pondered deeply, even forgetting to sleep or rest. As he grew older, he differed from others. All who met him as a child respected him, saying: “When I hear others recite Master Yichuan’s words, why do they not resemble the teachings of Confucius and Mencius?” Upon first reading the *Analects*, he doubted the words of Master You. Later, while reading, he encountered the term “universe.” The commentary explained: “The four directions and above and below are called *yu*; past and present are called *zhou*.” Suddenly, he had a great awakening: “Matters within the universe are matters within my own duty. Matters within my own duty are matters within the universe.”

He also once said: “If a sage were to emerge from the Eastern Sea, this heart would be the same, this principle would be the same. Even if a sage were to emerge from the Western, Southern, or Northern Seas, it would be no different. A thousand or ten thousand generations ago, if a sage had emerged, this heart would be the same, this principle would be the same. And a thousand or ten thousand generations hence, if a sage were to emerge, this heart and this principle would remain unchanged.”

After passing the imperial examinations, when he arrived at the temporary capital, scholars vied to study under him. His words inspired and moved many to action. He did not rely on rigid learning rules. If a student had a minor fault, his words would strike their emotions, sometimes even bringing them to sweat. For those harboring confusion they could not articulate, he would analyze the causes, making their hearts fully known. Even those separated by a thousand *li* could, upon hearing his broad principles, grasp his character.

He once said: “When thoughts and considerations are improper, one can recognize this in an instant and correct them. When thoughts and considerations are proper, if they are lost in an instant, they become improper.” To his students, he said: “Your ears are naturally sharp, your eyes naturally bright. You can naturally be filial to your father and respectful to your elder brother. There is nothing lacking—no need to seek elsewhere.”

He also said: “Speaking of the Dao to those drowned in profit and desire is still easy. Speaking to those drowned in rigid opinions is far more difficult.” When urged to write books, he replied: “The Six Classics annotate me; I annotate the Six Classics. If one truly understands the Dao, the Six Classics are all my footnotes.”

Once, he met Zhu Xi at Ehu Lake, and their discussions on learning often diverged. Later, when Zhu Xi governed Nankang, Jiuyuan visited him. Zhu Xi took him to the White Deer Grotto, where Jiuyuan lectured on the passage: “The gentleman is guided by righteousness; the petty person is guided by profit.” Zhu Xi believed his words precisely targeted the hidden and pervasive flaws of scholars, so much so that some listeners were moved to tears.

**Recorded Reflection:**
In my humble observation, the differences between the teachings of Zhu and Lu arise from their innate dispositions. From the age of three or four, Jiuyuan already explored the boundaries of heaven and earth. How could he not, in maturity, focus on nature? Zhu Xi, however, accumulated knowledge bit by bit, inch by inch. How could he not, in the end, focus on learning? Yet the strengths of these two masters each reach their own depths, neither conflicting nor contradicting. It is like the disciples of the Sage: Zengzi’s talent was slow, Zigong’s nature was quick, yet both attained the same unity through the Sage’s guidance. Now, with no sage appearing in the world, each master establishes their own school, lacking a unifying authority. Thus, differences and disputes arise, and those who follow them echo their divisions, unaware of how to honor the cultivation of virtue and the pursuit of learning. Zisi, who transmitted the teachings of Confucius, never favored one over the other—how could they be divided into two? Would it not be better if the great Dao were impartial? If one fears their wisdom does not fully apply to oneself, they should not reject what differs from them. If one fears their learning does not benefit others, they should not force it upon them. If this were so, no one in their time could criticize them, and later generations would have no grounds for reproach. Would this not be the great harmony?

I fear that later critics will grow ever more numerous and stray further from the truth. This record aims to propagate the Dao, and thus cannot be omitted.

**From *Shuidong’s Records*:**
Master Wu Sian of Ming once said: “When shallow scholars of the world discuss later generations, they often say: ‘These are mere *Yunfu* and *Tan Yu*, scholars who merely chase the ferryboat.’” This refers to their fragmented and disjointed learning, like idle chatter among travelers, lacking any profound insight or key understanding.

The Master was well-versed in the *Records of the Historian* from a young age. Exceptionally perceptive, he surpassed others in his reading, leaving no book unexamined. He once traveled with his late father through various regions, gaining broad experience. Upon retiring, he cultivated and nurtured himself for thirty or forty years. Thus, his learning was vast yet precise, his spirit firm and great, his insight lofty and clear. His works, such as *On the Nature and Principle* and *Annotations on the Elementary Learning*, contributed to the legacy of the Confucian masters. His discussions on the profundities of nature and principle were especially illuminating.

The Record states: The Master rose to prominence through recommendations rather than the imperial examinations, yet his words precisely diagnosed the ailments of contemporary scholars and officials—far surpassing the likes of Zhang, Cheng, Zhu, and Lu of former times. Should not learners then awaken with urgency? Here ends this record.

*Hongdao Record*, Volume 47 (concluded)
*[Note: "辆" was originally written as "两."]*
*[Note: "昼" was originally written as "书," amended here according to the context.]*

*Hongdao Record*, Volume 48
**On Trust: The Trust Between Ruler and Minister**

From the *Book of Han*: King Huai of Chu made a pact with his generals, declaring that whoever first entered and pacified the Guanzhong region would be enfeoffed as its king. At that time, the Qin forces were strong, and their commanders, ever victorious, pursued fleeing enemies. None of the generals dared to be the first to enter the pass—save Xiang Yu, who harbored deep resentment over Qin’s killing of Xiang Liang. He vowed to join the Lord of Pei in marching west into the pass. The elder generals of King Huai all advised: "Xiang Yu is fierce, cruel, and treacherous. When he once attacked Xiangcheng, not a soul was left alive; wherever he passed, none survived. It would be better to send a virtuous elder to proceed west with righteousness, to proclaim the will of the Qin fathers and brothers. The people of Qin have long suffered under their ruler. If we truly send a man of virtue, who commits no violence or oppression, the land should readily submit. Xiang Yu cannot be sent—only the Lord of Pei, known for his magnanimity and virtue, is fit for this task." King Huai thus refused Xiang Yu and dispatched the Lord of Pei to the west to secure the territory.

The Record states: Was King Huai of Chu comparable to Gengshi of Han? Huai favored the Lord of Pei and rejected Xiang Yu. Observing his words in dispatching his generals, one might have hoped for a semblance of sovereign wisdom. Yet in the end, he fell to the humiliation of brute force—what is called "crossing the river only to drown," a fate beyond reproach. Gengshi, on the other hand, resented Liu Ji and seized Liu Xian, his craven demeanor revealing his true mediocrity. Yet he brought upon himself the guilt of treacherous murder—what is called "the stocks crushing his neck, his ears and eyes failing him." How could their outcomes be the same?

After the Lord of Pei pacified Guanzhong, he summoned all the elders and local leaders of the counties, declaring: "For too long, you have suffered under Qin’s harsh laws. Those who slandered were exterminated, and those who spoke in pairs were executed in the marketplace. I shall rule Guanzhong and establish but three laws with you: those who kill shall die; those who injure or steal shall be punished accordingly. All other Qin laws shall be abolished. Officials and people shall remain in their posts as before. I have come solely to relieve you of harm, not to oppress or violate you. Have no fear. I have stationed my army at Bashang to await the arrival of the other lords and finalize our agreements." He then sent men with Qin officials to the counties, towns, and villages to proclaim this. The people of Qin rejoiced greatly, vying to offer cattle, sheep, wine, and food to the soldiers. The Lord of Pei declined, saying: "Our granaries are full; we lack nothing and do not wish to burden the people." The people rejoiced even more, fearing only that the Lord of Pei would not become King of Qin.

The Record states: The foundation of the Western Han’s two-hundred-year enterprise was ultimately secured in Guanzhong through this initial compact. Mencius said: "Terrain is not as advantageous as harmony among the people." Jia Yi’s argument likewise held: "Without the practice of benevolence and righteousness, the dynamics of offense and defense shift." Now, observing the debates at the Han court—so varied and discordant—even figures like Lou Jing and Tian Ken are not worth deep scrutiny. As for Zhang Liang’s wisdom, one would expect greater discernment, yet he too followed the residual thread of Li Yiji, failing to grasp the fundamental truth. He did not realize that the Three Articles of Law were worthier than the strategic advantage of "a hundred men holding two," nor that the people’s contentment in their homes outweighed the tactical posture of "establishing the capital at the neck of the land." Though one might wish to abandon such measures, the mountains and rivers would not permit it. Thus, is a fortress of metal and stone truly superior to the hearts of the elders? Is the fertility of a rich land more valuable than the humble offerings of wine and grain? Xiang Yu may have broken a temporary pact, but could he overturn the cauldron of a hundred generations?

When Emperor Wen was first enfeoffed as King of Dai, the Lü clan had been exterminated, and the great ministers deliberated to welcome and enthrone the King of Dai. Zhang Wu and others among the assembled ministers said: "The Han ministers are former generals and commanders from the time of the late Emperor Gao. Skilled in warfare and full of schemes, they cannot be trusted. We should claim illness and refuse to go, observing their maneuvers." Palace Attendant Song Chang countered: "Not so. When Qin lost its governance, heroes rose in every corner, each believing they could claim the throne. Yet in the end, it was the House of Liu that ascended. Even under the stern authority of Empress Lü, who monopolized power, when the Grand Commandant entered the Northern Army with a single tally and issued a call, the soldiers all bared their left shoulders for the House of Liu, ultimately annihilating the Lü clan. This was the mandate of Heaven, not the work of men. The King of Dai is renowned throughout the realm for his sagacity, benevolence, and filial piety. The great ministers, acting on the will of the realm, have come to welcome and enthrone him. The King should have no doubts." When the King of Dai arrived in Chang’an, the Grand Commandant Zhou Bo sought an audience. Song Chang said: "Matters of public concern should be spoken openly; matters of private concern have no place for a king." The Grand Commandant then knelt and presented the imperial seal and tally. That night, Song Chang was appointed General of the Guards, commanding both the Southern and Northern Armies, while Zhang Wu was made Prefect of the Palace Gentlemen, overseeing the palace halls.

The Record states: The empire of Emperor Wen’s twenty-three years was secured by the single utterance of Song Chang—how could Zhang Wu and his ilk compare? His refusal of the Grand Commandant’s request, resolute in word and intent, further revealed the sincerity of his heart. Who would have thought that in the humble residence of Dai, such a man could emerge—such a man! The Emperor’s enfeoffment of Chang was well justified. As for Zhang Wu and his associates, though their offices did not exceed the Nine Ministers, this was sufficient to demonstrate the king’s impartiality. Was it merely to spare the inch of land for Zhu Xu, or to uphold the trust of the great ministers and reassure their hearts? If so, then those who spoke openly may have ultimately failed, while those who sought leisure cannot be blamed.

Emperor Wen wrote to Zhao Tuo, King of Nanyue: "I am the son of a lesser consort of the late Emperor Gao. Exiled to the northern frontier in Dai, the distance was vast, and I was cut off, simple and ignorant, never having sent letters to the late Emperor or abandoned the assembled ministers."

When Emperor Hui passed away, Empress Dowager Gao personally took charge of affairs, but alas, she fell ill, and the Lü clan staged a rebellion, which was suppressed only through the efforts of the meritorious ministers. Once the matter was settled, We, though a king and marquis, were not released from duty by the officials, and thus had no choice but to ascend the throne.

Recently, We received a letter from Your Majesty to General Longlü and the Marquis of Longlü, seeking to claim kinship with your brothers and reproaching the two generals of Changsha for their dismissal. In response to Your Majesty’s letter, We dismissed the generals. As for the Marquis of Boyang, your own brother in Zhen Ding, We have already sent envoys to inquire after him, tend to the tombs of your ancestors, and make repairs.

Previously, We heard that Your Majesty had mobilized troops along the border, causing unceasing raids and disasters. At that time, Changsha suffered greatly, and Nan Commandery suffered even more. Even if it were your own domain, could such actions truly benefit you? They would only result in the slaughter of many soldiers, the wounding of good generals, the widowing of wives, the orphaning of children, and the bereavement of parents—gaining one while losing ten. We cannot bear to do such a thing.

We wished to adjust the borders where they interlock like dog’s teeth, and so We consulted the officials. They said: "This was how the late Emperor Gao demarcated the land of Changsha." Thus, We could not alter it without authority. Now, even if We were to gain your territory, it would not be of great significance.

Obtaining the king’s wealth would not suffice to make Us rich. All lands south of the Ling Ridge shall remain under your governance. Yet though your title is "Emperor," two emperors cannot coexist—this would leave not even a single chariot’s worth of gain. To force communication through such a path is contention, and contention without yielding is not the way of the benevolent. We wish to cast aside past grievances with you. From this day forward, let envoys resume their former exchanges as before.

When Lu Jia arrived in Nanyue, the King of Nanyue kowtowed in apology, pledging to obey Our enlightened decree and serve forever as a vassal, offering tribute and fulfilling his duties.

**Recorded Note:**
Confucius told Zizhang: "Speak with loyalty and sincerity, act with earnest respect—even in the lands of the Man and Mo, this will suffice." As for Nanyue, Wei Tuo was but one among those condemned. Even without the majesty of ten thousand chariots, who would not heed the words of a lesser house? Had he not heeded them, who would not boast of the Central Kingdom’s grandeur and the might of its arms? Yet he did not realize that Heaven bestows the Mandate upon the Emperor through perfect virtue, and the Emperor, in turn, wields his perfect name with unrestrained authority. His words arose from his heart, unforced, truly capable of piercing metal and stone, reaching even the swine and fish, the Yi, Di, Man, and Mo—are they not also men? His heart rejoiced and submitted in sincerity, not merely by compulsion but as naturally as could be.

Zizhang could only inscribe such words on his sash but failed to put them into practice. The Emperor’s innate disposition aligned with the Dao, and though he lacked the merit of "measuring with the plumb line and balancing with the scale," his achievements were manifest and great. Thus, the Sage’s words stand between Heaven and Earth like the work of Creation, effortlessly shaping all things—no need to listen or observe, for they command all faces and directions.

He also sent a letter to the Chanyu of the Xiongnu, saying: "The Emperor respectfully inquires after the Great Chanyu of the Xiongnu. Recently, We received your letter expressing the wish to cease hostilities, rest the troops, erase past grievances, and restore the old treaty to bring peace to the border peoples and eternal harmony. We greatly approve—this is the aspiration of the ancient sage-kings. Han and the Xiongnu pledged brotherhood, and thus We have sent you generous gifts. Yet those who break the treaty and sever fraternal bonds have always been the Xiongnu. However, the matter of the Right Virtuous King occurred before the amnesty and shall not be deeply pursued. If the Chanyu upholds the meaning of this letter and clearly instructs his officials to avoid violating the treaty, maintaining trust and respect as stated in your letter..."

**Recorded Note:**
In observing the Emperor’s treaty with the Xiongnu, how could it compare to the *Spring and Autumn Annals’* oaths invoking ghosts and gods, or the covenant sealed with blood? His sincerity and trust arose from his true heart, as expressed in his words—like Heaven and Earth, which sustain and cover all without exception. Truly, he mastered the way of the Emperor in governing the Yi and Di. Not only did he secure their trust, but he also knew how to treat them. Hu and Yue as one family, Hua and Yi as one body—when future generations look back upon this day, will it not be deemed magnificent?

Once, while the Emperor was traveling and crossing the Zhongwei Bridge, a man ran across the bridge, startling the imperial carriage’s horses. Riders were sent to capture him. At the time, Zhang Shizhi served as Commandant of Justice and memorialized that the man should be fined. The Emperor angrily said: "This man personally startled my horse. Had the horse not been gentle, would another not have thrown me and injured me? Yet the Commandant of Justice only imposes a fine!" Shizhi replied: "The law is shared by all under Heaven. If the law is as it stands, and you now increase the penalty, the law will lose credibility among the people."

Later, someone stole a jade ring from before the seat of the Gao Temple. When caught, the case was also sent to the Commandant of Justice for judgment. Shizhi memorialized that the thief should be executed in the marketplace. The Emperor was furious: "This man is lawless, stealing an object of the former Emperor. I wished to execute his entire clan, yet you, citing the law, oppose me—this is not how We should jointly uphold the ancestral temples." Shizhi removed his cap, kowtowed, and apologized, saying: "The law is sufficient as it stands. If stealing from the ancestral temple warrants extermination of one’s clan, then suppose a foolish commoner took a cup of earth from Changling—what greater punishment could Your Majesty impose?" The Emperor then relented.

**Recorded Note:**
People know that Shizhi upheld the law, but they do not realize the Emperor’s ability to employ it. The world does not complain of the law’s unfairness but only of the ruler’s failure to apply it. Gaoyao said, "It lies in punishment," and the Emperor echoed, "It lies in punishment." Gaoyao said, "It lies in leniency," and the Emperor echoed, "It lies in leniency"—this is the ability to employ the law. If one’s words suffice to refute remonstrance and one’s wisdom suffices to gloss over wrongs, believing all under Heaven are beneath oneself, one cannot employ the law. Thus, if branding is insufficient, it escalates to burning; if burning is insufficient, it escalates to dismemberment—was there truly no law in these cases?

After the Han established the Three Articles of Law, Emperor Wen abolished mutilating punishments, the confiscation of wives and children for a relative’s crime, and the prosecution of slander and heretical speech—his heart was truly rooted in loving the people. The offenses of startling the imperial procession and stealing the jade ring arose from momentary anger, a private matter; the fines and execution were the law’s public measure. Only by refusing to let private concerns override the public did he not ultimately bend the law with emotion. The Emperor may be likened to Heaven and Earth, the sun and moon.

Beyond this, figures like Zhang and Du of Youning manipulated legal cases according to the ruler’s whims—from this, one may infer the nature of the rulers of that time. Alas! The mere mention of "a cup of earth from Changling" was something ministers could not bear to hear. If one fears and avoids such words, what is the reason? Thus, it is said: Those who know Shizhi upheld the law but do not recognize the Emperor’s ability to employ it do not truly understand the law.

Ni Kuan, during Emperor Wu’s reign, served as a Palace Grandee and was promoted to Left Internal Minister. In governing the people, he observed agriculture and sericulture, relaxed punishments, adjudicated lawsuits, humbled himself before scholars, and focused on winning the people’s hearts. He selected and employed benevolent and generous officials, extended empathy to his subordinates, and did not seek fame. The officials and people greatly trusted and loved him. When collecting taxes, he adjusted the rates flexibly, and the people borrowed from one another, so much so that many taxes went uncollected.

When the military campaign later concluded, Ni Kuan was ranked last in tax collection due to arrears. Upon hearing this, the people, fearing his demotion, mobilized en masse—wealthy households with ox-carts, poorer ones with shoulder poles—delivering taxes in an unbroken stream until his assessment became the highest. Later, he rose through the ranks to become Imperial Censor.

It is recorded: Though Ni Kuan was originally a Confucian scholar, his governance of the people may be called Confucian, but not truly *legalist*. Why? In the present age, officials of the Direct Inspectorate regard flexible tax collection as a breach of discipline, and a single demotion or promotion cannot be easily overturned—how much less so during military mobilization? Yet in the Han, where laws were loose and prohibitions lenient, such customs could still be witnessed. These customs were far superior to those of degenerate eras. Had he not been a man of warmth and integrity, steadfast in his principles, how could this have been achieved? Otherwise, with the prevalence of cunning and deceitful men, who would have spurred the people—wealthy households with ox-carts, poorer ones with shoulder poles—to act thus? This shows that trust and affection prevail over penal law, and Confucian officials stand apart from vulgar clerks—hence it must be recorded.

During Emperor Xuan’s reign, Zhang Anshi and Du Yannian both held positions among the Nine Ministers. Both were renowned for their loyalty and trustworthiness, meticulous and discreet in all matters, whether internal or external. Whenever major policies were decided, they would feign illness and withdraw, so that even the court’s highest ministers remained unaware of their involvement. When they recommended someone, and that person came to express gratitude, they would grow furious, declaring: *"To recommend the worthy and capable—how could there be private thanks?"* Once, a palace gentleman of great merit, passed over for promotion, spoke of it himself. Anshi replied: *"Your merit is known to the enlightened ruler. As a minister, how can you speak of such things yourself?"* When his chief clerk was about to depart for a new post, Anshi asked him to point out his faults. The clerk said: *"The General serves as the ruler’s right hand, yet no scholars are advanced under him."* Critics took this as a rebuke. Anshi responded: *"With an enlightened ruler above, the worthy and unworthy are clearly distinguished. A minister need only cultivate himself—how would he know whom to recommend?"* Thus, he sought to conceal his name, avoid border posts, and distance himself from power. The Son of Heaven deeply respected and feared the Grand General, yet privately favored Anshi, trusting him even more than [Huang] Guang.

Du Yannian was likewise gentle and composed, thorough in all affairs. Having long overseen court administration, the emperor trusted him completely. When the emperor went out, Yannian attended his carriage; when he returned, Yannian served as a palace attendant. At that time, the four barbarians were at peace, and the realm was tranquil. After the Grand General’s death, Yannian alone maintained his position from beginning to end, earning universal praise.

It is recorded: Since Confucius declined the flawless sacrificial ox, critics have often misjudged men, and even great worthies are not exempt—how much less so for Anshi and Yannian? Yet some argue: *"Heaven’s way is retribution,"* but this is a shallow view. Does Heaven concern itself with such trifles? If one does evil, all under Heaven and posterity will call him evil; if one does good, all will call him good—is this not all the more credible? To foresee what has not yet come to pass, without observing what has already occurred—I have never seen such discernment. The loyalty, trustworthiness, prudence, and sincerity of these two ministers embody what Confucius meant when he said: *"Even if you wished not to employ them, would the mountains and rivers abandon them?"* Thus, the lofty essence of the Sage’s judgment is again evident.

Han Yanshou served as Governor of Yingchuan, where powerful clans made the commandery difficult to govern. Previously, Zhao Guanghan had been troubled by the prevalence of cliques among the people, so he incited officials and commoners to inform on one another. Yanshou sought to change this but feared the people would not comply. He summoned the commandery’s elders—those trusted and esteemed in their villages—and hosted them with food and drink. Speaking to them face-to-face, he inquired about local customs, then discussed and established standards for weddings, funerals, and sacrifices, roughly following ancient rites without exceeding legal bounds. When collecting taxes, he first issued clear proclamations, setting deadlines as a priority. Initially, this seemed cumbersome, but later, officials were spared the toil of chasing delinquents, and the people were free from the fear of beatings. All found it convenient and settled into it.

He treated his subordinate officials with great generosity, yet his covenants were clear and strict. If any dared deceive or bully others, he would immediately reproach himself, saying: "Have I failed them? How could this have come to pass?" The people revered and trusted his teachings, and within several years, Yingchuan was thoroughly governed.

Later, he was promoted to serve as Left Fengxu. While touring the counties and arriving at Gaoling, he encountered two brothers disputing over farmland. Yanshou was deeply grieved, saying: "Fortunate to hold this office as a model for others, I have failed to propagate and clarify moral instruction, allowing kin to engage in litigation. This harms public morality, and the fault lies with me, Fengxu." He then retired to the post station’s outer quarters, shut the gates, and reflected on his errors. He ordered his magistrates and clerks to bind themselves and await punishment. Hearing of this, the litigants reproached one another, shaving their heads and baring their shoulders in apology. They pledged to cede the land to each other, vowing never to dispute again, even unto death. Overjoyed, Yanshou emerged to resume his duties. Throughout the commandery, all were moved, and none dared transgress. Thus, his virtue and trust extended across all twenty-four counties, and none dared bring forth lawsuits.

The record states: In my humble view, Yanshou seemed intent on transforming customs and guiding officials and people to turn their hearts toward goodness. Yet in the end, he could not secure a virtuous conclusion. Why was this so?

The former Confucians have said: Of the figures since the Three Dynasties, all acted on the impulses of blood and qi, unlike those before the Three Dynasties, who relied purely on virtue and nature. Alas! This saying applies not only to Yanshou, but also to Zhao Gai and Yang Mo—none were exceptions. By this time in the Han court, the primal qi had already dissipated. Yet in the end, they still fell into the warning of "favoring trust but not learning," inevitably bringing harm to others. Thus, they earned the praise of "hoping for it," unaware that this was precisely what our Master Confucius detested. Alas, what a pity!

When Zhao Keguo was in office, the Xianling tribes of the Qiang rebelled. Emperor Xuan sent Bing Ji to ask, "Who can lead the troops?" Keguo replied, "There is no one but this old minister." Bing Ji then asked, "General, how do you assess the Qiang rebels?" He answered, "It is difficult to judge from afar. I wish to go to Jincheng to devise a strategy and present it." Thereupon, a great army was dispatched to Jincheng. Keguo always prioritized distant scouting, ensuring battle readiness when marching and fortifying encampments when halting. He was especially steadfast, cherished his soldiers, and planned thoroughly before engaging in battle. Though the rebels frequently provoked him, he refused to act rashly, seeking instead to use his prestige and trust to persuade Han Kai and those who had been coerced into plunder to surrender. He waited for the rebels' alliances to dissolve and their strength to wane before striking decisively. Xin Wuxian, the Governor of Jiuquan, memorialized that troops should be sent in the seventh month to attack Han Kai. Keguo argued that the Xianling were the primary instigators; if they were eliminated first, the followers of Han Kai would submit without the need for force. An imperial edict approved Keguo’s plan, and Han Kai indeed surrendered without a battle.

The record states: In my humble view, the achievements of the ancients all stemmed from the absolute trust placed in them by their superiors and their own unwavering self-confidence. They often subdued others through prestige and trust, refusing to act lightly—this was the reason. Even with Emperor Xuan’s wisdom and Bing Ji’s loyalty, they still deferred to others’ opinions. When the Emperor asked, "General, how do you assess the Qiang rebels?" that was one moment; when Wuxian memorialized to send troops in the seventh month, that was another. Had Keguo lacked a resolute conviction in his heart, advancing when ordered and halting when commanded, he would have been like a disciple carrying a corpse. For rulers and ministers who do not trust the strategies of their generals but instead weigh them against others’ words—unaware of advantages, indifferent to benefits—they are like teachers carrying a corpse. When both superiors and subordinates act recklessly and neither trusts the other, success is rare. This is a profound warning for later generations.

According to *The Later Han History*: Initially, Li Tong of Nanyang served Liu Yin and was fond of astrology and calendrics. The *Chenji* stated: "The Liu clan will rise again, and the Li clan will assist them." He privately cherished this. When Ban Biao fled to Tianshui to avoid danger, Yin Xun asked him, "In the past, when the Zhou fell, the Warring States contended, and the realm was divided. Only after several generations was it settled. Do you think the strategies of the Vertical and Horizontal Alliances will resurface today? Or will the Mandate pass to one man in succession?" Ban Biao replied, "The rise and fall of the Zhou differ from that of the Han. Formerly, the Zhou enfeoffed five ranks of nobility, and the feudal lords governed themselves. As the root weakened, the branches grew strong, so in the end, the Vertical and Horizontal Alliances arose—this was the natural course of events. The Han inherited the Qin system, establishing commanderies and counties. The ruler held absolute authority, while ministers lacked hereditary power. By the time of Emperor Cheng, who indulged his maternal relatives, the dynasty’s fortunes declined. The imperial line was severed thrice, allowing the Wang clan to usurp the throne and seize power. The crisis originated from above, sparing the common people. Thus, after the restoration, all under heaven stretched their necks in longing. Within a decade, turmoil erupted both within and beyond the court. Distant and near regions rose in rebellion, all claiming the Liu name and speaking with one voice. Now, the heroic leaders controlling the provinces lack the resources of the Seven States of old, yet the people’s sighs and yearning for Han virtue are evident." Yin Xun said, "Your words on the circumstances of the Zhou and Han are apt. But to claim that the Han will rise again merely because foolish people are accustomed to the Liu surname is far-fetched. When the Qin lost the people’s support, Liu Ji rallied them—did the people of that time know of the Han?" Ban Biao then wrote the *On the Mandate of Kings*, arguing that Han virtue inherited Yao’s legacy and bore the signs of a sacred Mandate. The rise of a true king is not achieved by deceit or force. He hoped to move Yin Xun with this.

When the generals urged Emperor Guangwu to ascend the throne, a fellow lodger, Qiang Hua, presented the *Red Symbol of Submission* from Guanzhong, which read: "Liu Xiu raises troops to punish the unrighteous. The Four Barbarians gather like clouds, dragons battle in the wild. At the time of four sevens, fire shall reign." The ministers then memorialized: "The symbols of the Mandate are grand when people respond. Though separated by a thousand miles, their hearts align without dissent. How can the Zhou’s white fish compare? Now, with no Son of Heaven, the realm is in chaos. The responses of auspicious omens are manifest and widely known. We should answer the will of the gods to fulfill the people’s hopes." Thereupon, Emperor Guangwu ordered the officials to prepare an altar, and on the *jiwei* day of the sixth month, he ascended the imperial throne.

The record states: The sayings of *chenji* have long been doubted by former Confucians. As for those who curry favor with the powerful or opportunistically attach themselves to such matters, these are not the discussions of upright men or the earnest admonitions of the sincere. Have they not read Ban Biao’s treatise? He expounded on the Dao and discussed the Mandate, analyzing principles and discerning the times. His words were precise and trustworthy. The Han’s reception of the Mandate is evident here. Had Guangwu not secretly favored Qiang Hua’s words, the founding of the Later Han would have been even more illustrious. What a pity the generals could not do so! Nevertheless, at that time, the Youlai, Dashi, Chimei, and Wuxiao rebels had not yet submitted, while Yin Xun, Gongsun Shu, Dou Rong, and others had not yet pledged allegiance. Without invoking the Mandate of Heaven, how could they win the people’s hearts? The Emperor’s reverence for such omens was a temporary measure to address the exigencies of the moment. Once the realm was pacified, he should have followed King Wu’s example in respectfully receiving the *Red Book* or Ji Zi’s in expounding the *Great Plan*. Who would not call this the grand strategy of an emperor for ten thousand generations?

The pedantic adherence to past precedents—such as sequentially establishing military merit or arbitrarily revising sacrificial rites—is truly misguided. This is precisely what drew Zheng Xing’s censure.

Guo Ji, from youth, possessed noble aspirations and conduct. After returning from a mission to Pingwen, he was summoned to the office of the Grand Minister of Works, then promoted three times to become Prefect of Yuyang. When Emperor Guangwu ascended the throne, Guo was transferred to serve as Grand Administrator of Yuyang. At the time, the region had suffered the chaos of Wang Mang’s usurpation, compounded by the defeat of Peng Chong, leaving the populace rife with cunning and malice, and bandits rampant. Upon his arrival, Guo demonstrated trust in rewards and punishments, executing the ringleaders of the rebels. The bandits dispersed, and over five years in office, the population and households flourished.

Later, when bandits arose in Yingchuan, he was appointed Grand Administrator of Yingchuan. Upon arriving in the commandery, he summoned and pacified hundreds of fugitives, including Zhao Chong and Zhao Hao. Hearing of Guo’s prestige and integrity, their followers—some from as far as the south of the Yangtze, others from You and Ji—came in an unbroken stream to surrender. He was then transferred to serve as Governor of Bingzhou. Guo had previously governed Bingzhou and had long cultivated virtue and favor there. Upon re-entering the province, wherever he went, the elderly and young lined the roads, welcoming him. When he first began his tour of inspection and reached Meixi in Hexi, several hundred children, each riding bamboo horses, came to greet and bow to him along the road. Guo asked the children why they had come from afar. They replied, “We heard Your Excellency was arriving and came joyfully to welcome you.” Guo declined their gesture with thanks. After his duties were complete, the children escorted him beyond the outer walls and asked, “When will Your Excellency return?” Guo calculated the date and told them. When he returned from his tour, he arrived a day early. Fearing he would break his promise to the children, he halted at a wayside pavilion and waited until the appointed day before entering the city.

*Recorded:* How does Guo Xihou’s keeping of his promise to the children compare to Marquis Wen of Wei’s adherence to his appointment with the forester? The forester’s appointment was merely for the pleasure of hunting—whether it rained or not, whether he went or not, mattered little. Yet when the realm had just been pacified and those who usurped names and seized power were beyond counting, relying on one’s own integrity to win over the hearts of the people—if words were spoken and then broken, or matters changed on a whim, even small affairs would falter. How much more so for great matters? How could one demonstrate trustworthiness to others? The *Book of Changes* says: “Going forth without recklessness brings good fortune.” Perhaps this is how Xihou achieved his aims.

Zhang Gang, ranked highly among the imperial censors, was sent by Emperor Ming along with seven other envoys to tour the realm and receive reports from the provinces. Yet Zhang alone buried the wheels of his carriage at the capital’s post station in Luoyang, declaring, “When wolves and jackals block the path, why trouble with foxes?” He then submitted a memorial impeaching the Grand General Liang Ji and the Prefect of the Capital □, listing fifteen instances of their disloyal and unprincely conduct. When the memorial was presented, Liang Ji flew into a rage and sought to punish him by law.

At the time, the bandit Zhang Ying in Guangling had amassed tens of thousands of followers, killing two governors and other high officials. Cao Cao commended his sense of loyalty. Later, when Guan Yu slew Yan Liang, he sent a letter of farewell before fleeing to Liu Bei’s camp among Yuan Shao’s forces. Cao Cao’s advisors urged him to pursue Guan Yu, but Cao said, “Each serves his own lord—do not pursue him.”

*Recorded:* Guan Yu’s slaying of Yan Liang—was this not akin to Zhang Liang’s attempt to assassinate the First Emperor? What a pity there was no one to lend him support or persuade him otherwise. Zhang Liang’s refusal to restore the Six States was like Cao Cao’s capture of Guan Yu and defeat of Liu Bei. Liang’s avenging of Han for his native state was like Guan Yu’s following of Liu Bei to revive the Han house. Yet heroes found no ground for their valor. Though they swore to die together, would their deaths not be in vain? Had Guan Yu, through his own integrity, moved Cao Cao to admiration and joined forces with him to destroy Yuan Shao, then submitted a memorial to welcome Liu Bei, would his merit not have been great? In this way, he could have served both Cao and Liu, achieving a dual success. Yet his mere slaying of Yan Liang was but a trifling deed.

Later, when Cao Cao launched a southern campaign against Liu Biao, Liu Biao died, and his son Zong succeeded him, promptly surrendering the province to Cao. At the time, Liu Bei was stationed in Fancheng. Some advised him to attack Liu Zong, saying Jingzhou could be taken. Liu Bei replied, “Liu Jingzhou entrusted his orphaned heir to me. To betray trust for my own gain is something I will not do.” When he passed through Xiangyang, many people flocked to join him. By the time he reached Dangyang, his followers numbered over a hundred thousand, slowing his march to a mere ten *li* a day. Some urged him to hasten to Jiangling, but Liu Bei said, “In accomplishing great affairs, one must take the people as the foundation. Now that the people have come to me, how can I bear to abandon them?”

Cao Cao, fearing Liu Bei would seize Jiangling, which held military supplies, led his elite troops in a forced march of over three hundred *li* a day, catching up with Liu Bei at Changban in Dangyang. Liu Bei abandoned his wife and children and fled.

Later, when Fa Zheng served as Military Advisor to Liu Zhang, he and the Chief Clerk Zhang Song privately concluded that Liu Zhang was incapable of great deeds. They secretly urged Liu Bei to take Yizhou. Liu Bei hesitated and consulted Pang Tong, who said, “Yizhou is fertile and wealthy, its resources sufficient to support a great enterprise.” Liu Bei replied, “My present adversary, who stands with me like fire and water, is Cao Cao. He acts with urgency, while I act with patience; he is violent, while I am humane; he is deceitful, while I am loyal. In every way, I oppose him, and only thus can success be achieved. Now, to gain a small advantage and lose trust and righteousness before the world—how could I do that?” Pang Tong said, “To seize by force and govern with virtue—this is what the ancients prized. Once affairs are settled, you may enfeoff him with a great state. What breach of trust or loss of righteousness would there be? If you do not take it now, it will ultimately benefit another.” Liu Bei then began to see the wisdom in his words.

Leaving Liu Liang and Guan Yu to guard Jingzhou, he led his infantry into Yizhou.

The *Lu* Record states: Many scholars of former times have debated Emperor Zhaolie’s seizure of Jing and Yi. What principle should we ultimately follow? Confucius said, “The noble person is steadfast but not rigidly bound by small promises.” Mencius said, “When a sister-in-law is drowning, to extend a hand to save her is a matter of *quan* (expediency).” The commentators explain: *Zhen* means steadfastness in what is right and firm, while *liang* refers to petty fidelity. A drowning sister-in-law is a grave matter, while lending a hand is a minor impropriety. Measuring the petty by the standard of what is right allows one to grasp righteousness; weighing the minor against the major allows one to grasp *quan*.

Since the rise of the Two Han, no dynasty has begun without even a foot of land, yet none has known hardship like that of Emperor Zhaolie. Among the contending warlords, none seized and usurped territory as they did in his time. Why was this so? The reason lies in the necessity of possessing a domain when establishing a state. When the Duke of Pei was already King of Han, and Liu Xiu was already Prince of Xiao, these were their rightful lands. Later, having gained Long, they still coveted Shu—how much more so for Liu Bei? One year he fled to Xuzhou, the next he was defeated at Xiapi, gaining not an inch of land. Is this how one who aspires to kingship should act?

As for Liu Biao’s occupation of Jing and Liu Yan’s occupation of Yi, these were not rightful domains but mere usurpations seized in the moment. Moreover, both died without heirs—could their lands truly have remained the spoils of petty villains and cunning usurpers? Yet when Liu Zhang, on his deathbed, entrusted his domain, it was a matter of petty fidelity, not the words of one who discerned the times and was a hero of his age.

Thus, Zhuge Liang first said, “Heaven has placed this in the General’s hands—does the General have the will to take it?” And again, “Yizhou is a land of natural barriers and a celestial repository—can you still fail to understand?” To cling to the minor impropriety of betraying a trust while forgetting the great crisis of the realm—had Liu Bei publicly declared his defiance of his father’s dying command, surrendered his state, and submitted as a captive, no sin of unfiliality could have been greater. How could he have justified himself at the time, or how could later generations have excused him? Moreover, had he not forgotten Liu Zhang’s past generosity in supplying his needs, he would not have reared a tiger and left behind a calamity, nor would he have faced accusations of seizing another’s throat and striking his back. A moment’s failure to perceive the opportune moment led, in the end, to his inability to avoid taking Yi.

Thus, Master Zhu said, “Both the constant principle and expedience were lost.” This is precisely the case.

*Hongdao Lu*, Scroll 48 (conclusion)
*Hongdao Lu*, Scroll 49: *Trust—The Trust Between Ruler and Minister*

From the *Book of Jin*: When Yang Hu was stationed in Xiangyang, he soothed and pacified both near and far, winning the hearts of the people along the Jiang and Han rivers. He established profound trust with the people of Wu, and if any who had surrendered later wished to leave, he allowed them to do so. In camp, he often wore light furs and loose sashes, never donning armor, and in his command pavilion, no more than ten or so guards attended him. He devoted himself to winning over Wu through virtue and trust. Whenever battles were fought, even when the hour was set for combat, he refused to employ ambushes or surprise attacks. If any of his generals or commanders proposed cunning strategies, he would ply them with fine wine until they could no longer speak. When his troops ventured into Wu territory and reaped grain for provisions, they always calculated the amount taken and sent silk in compensation. Whenever his forces hunted along the Jiang and Mian rivers, if they captured game that had already been wounded by the people of Wu, they would return it. Thus, the borderland people were pleased and submitted. His counterpart in Wu, Generalissimo Lu Kang, held the opposite bank, and their envoys frequently exchanged messages. Once, Lu Kang sent Yang Hu a cask of wine, which Yang drank without suspicion. When Lu Kang fell ill and requested medicine, Yang Hu sent him a prepared remedy, which Lu Kang immediately consumed. Many advised Lu Kang against this, but he replied, “How could Yang Shuzi ever poison anyone?” He often instructed his border garrisons: “They rely solely on virtue, while we rely solely on force—this means they will submit without a fight. We need only guard our borders and refrain from seeking petty gains.”

The record states: The governance of the Duke of Shao beneath the sweet pear tree—is it the same as, or different from, Yang Hu’s weeping at Xianshan? For even a gentleman of discernment cannot always illuminate the hidden with clarity. After Jin destroyed Shu, it never forgot Wu for a single day, as Zhang Ti observed: “Their success is our peril.” How could Wu have been so deceived? The examples of Chen Ping’s generous bestowals and Lü Meng’s displays of trust should have served as warnings. The people of Wu ought to have been tending their firewood and tasting gall, donning armor and resting on spears, to preserve their ancestral legacy—yet they had no time for such vigilance. Instead, they declared, “They rely solely on virtue, while we rely solely on force,” unaware that they were already trapped in their own defenses. Alas! Force is untenable, but was their virtue genuine? The intoxication from fine wine had not yet worn off, yet plans to conquer Wu were repeatedly proposed. It was said, “If Wu installs a worthy ruler, it will be difficult to subdue.” Ah! Was this truly virtue? Was it trust? It was nothing more than a strategist’s ruse to disrupt the enemy’s resolve. Yet compared to those who merely erect wooden tablets to feign trust, leaving only devastation in their wake, there is still cause for inquiry. Had it not been for Yang Hu, Du Yu’s achievements would not have been realized. Yang Hu—was he not a hero of his age?

The *Old唐书*’s “Treatise on Penal Law” records: Emperor Taizong personally reviewed the prisoners sentenced to death. Moved by their plight, he released them to return home, ordering them to come back in autumn to face execution. He then decreed that all death-row prisoners in the realm be similarly released, with the stipulation that they present themselves in the capital by the appointed time. The following September, the three hundred and ninety prisoners released the previous year all returned to the imperial court as promised, without a single one fleeing or hiding. The emperor then pardoned them all.

The record states: The *Yi*’s *Wuwang* hexagram states, “The remedy of the unwavering must not be tested.” The Sage’s intent was that a ruler governing the realm should do so with utmost impartiality and absolute integrity, guiding with perfect sincerity and utmost trust. If one harbors deceitful intentions, employs cunning and deception, seeks fortuitous gains by chance, or forces outcomes through artifice—even a momentary trial is impermissible, let alone sustained use. Emperor Taizong of Tang rose to power by his father’s rebellion, wielding the blade against his kin, slaughtering many innocents. The wrongful deaths of Lu Zushang and Zhang Yungu were especially lamentable. Yet he released prisoners only to pardon them—if even release was improper, how much more so the pardon? This treated human lives as child’s play and the legal code as a toy, merely providing a spectacle for posterity. For death is what people most dread and fear.

If survival may be sought by any means, what extremes would one not resort to? How can one be certain that those who turn themselves in are not impostors sent in their stead? The Emperor was bold in pursuing reputation yet obstinate in self-righteousness. In the court’s deliberations, how many more like Yungu were there—substituting falsehood for truth, pretense for sincerity, playacting for law, and death for life? Even a hundred releases would be of no avail.

Wei Zheng submitted a memorial, citing the words of Wenzi: “When words are the same and yet trusted, trust precedes the words; when commands are the same and yet obeyed, sincerity lies beyond the commands.” Though the imperial Dao had been resplendent for over a decade, the transformative power of virtue had not yet permeated all, for the emperor’s treatment of his ministers lacked perfect sincerity and trust. Now, in establishing governance and achieving order, one must entrust matters to the noble-minded. Yet in matters of success or failure, one might consult the petty-minded. The noble-minded are treated with respect but kept at a distance; the petty-minded are treated lightly but drawn close. Familiarity breeds unrestrained speech, while distance prevents true sentiments from reaching above. Even those of middling intelligence may possess small cunning, yet their talents are unsuited to governing the state, and their foresight does not extend far. Though they may exhaust their strength and sincerity, failure is still inevitable—how much worse when they harbor deceit? The depth of the ensuing disaster would be profound.

Even the noble-minded may commit minor faults, yet these do not harm the upright Dao—such lapses may be overlooked. But if one calls them noble-minded yet still doubts their trustworthiness, how is this different from gazing at a straight tree and suspecting its shadow is crooked? If Your Majesty carefully selects the noble-minded and employs them with ritual propriety and trust, what cause is there for concern over governance? Otherwise, the hour of peril and ruin cannot be assured.

The Emperor bestowed a handwritten edict in praise, saying: “After Jin Wu conquered the realm, his will grew arrogant and indolent. He Chong, though holding the highest office, dared not offer forthright remonstrance. Instead, he privately boasted of his wisdom to his descendants—this was the height of disloyalty. Receiving your admonition, I recognize my error. I shall place it upon my desk, comparing it to the leather and bowstring.” The record notes: The Emperor likening Zheng’s memorial to the leather and bowstring was apt. Yet did he not realize that the leather’s suppleness and the bowstring’s straightness arise naturally from their inherent qualities—or must they be forcibly shaped? In this, Zheng’s memorial was not entirely exhaustive. For when the shadow is straight, the object itself is upright; when the source is pure, the stream flows clear. If the ruler’s heart is wholly sincere and trustworthy, transformation occurs without words, and commands are obeyed without decree—why then would the treatment of ministers lack perfect sincerity? If this were not so, one might today call them noble-minded, only to deem them petty-minded tomorrow. That Taizong’s era did not attain the purity of the Three Dynasties, with the noble-minded and petty-minded in constant flux, was entirely due to the ruler’s heart not being wholly sincere and trustworthy. Zheng knew to observe the shadow yet did not seek the straight tree; he compared himself to the leather and bowstring yet failed to grasp the essence of their natural straightness and suppleness—what difference was there?

The Emperor said to Wang Gui: “Your discernment is keen and your understanding profound, and you excel in discourse. Among those like Fang Xuanling and the others, you should assess them all. How do you compare to these men?” Wang Gui replied: “In diligent service to the state, knowing no bounds in action, I am not the equal of Fang Xuanling. In talent encompassing both civil and martial arts, serving as both general and minister, I am not the equal of Li Jing. In presenting memorials with clarity and precision, ensuring all responses are fitting, I am not the equal of Wen Yanbo. In managing complex and demanding affairs, ensuring all tasks are completed, I am not the equal of Dai Zhou. In feeling shame that the ruler does not match Yao and Shun, and taking remonstrance as my duty, I am not the equal of Wei Zheng. However, in exposing corruption and extolling purity, detesting evil and cherishing goodness, I possess a slight superiority over these men.” The Emperor affirmed this, and the court acknowledged the accuracy of his assessment.

The record notes: In the era of a wise ruler, all submit to righteousness, and judgments may be tested. In a mediocre and benighted court, right and wrong are confused, and baseless opinions surge. At that time, ruler and ministers were in perfect accord, like limbs and vital organs—supporting one another in conduct, aiding one another in action, and thus applying this to all they saw and heard. How could anything fail to be genuine?

Empress Wu held Di Renjie in the highest esteem, surpassing all other ministers, and often addressed him as “National Elder” without using his name. Renjie frequently engaged in direct remonstrance in court, and the Empress often yielded to his counsel. Once, she asked: “I wish to appoint an outstanding official—who would be suitable?” He replied: “If you seek one learned and refined, then Su Weidao and Li Jiaogu are fitting choices. If you desire one of exceptional and extraordinary talent, then Zhang Jianzhi, the Prefect of Yuezhou, is your man. Though he is advanced in years, he possesses the qualities of a prime minister.” The Empress promoted him to Controller of Luozhou. Some days later, she asked again. Renjie replied: “I previously recommended Jianzhi, yet he has not been appointed.” The Empress said: “I have already promoted him.” Renjie responded: “The one I recommended is fit for prime minister, not Controller.” She then appointed him Vice Minister of Justice, and he was eventually made prime minister. Renjie also recommended dozens of others, including Vice Minister of War Yao Yuanchong, Investigating Censor Huan Yanfan, and Prefect of Daizhou Jing Hui, all of whom became renowned ministers. Someone remarked to him: “All the peaches and plums of the realm are in your courtyard.” Renjie replied: “Recommending the worthy is for the state, not for myself.”

The record notes: The peaches and plums of Di’s courtyard were the radiance of all things. The peaches and plums of later ages were but the fleeting brilliance of spring’s breeze. Observing those he recommended, his merit in fostering worthiness is truly worthy of esteem.

Zhang Jiuling, noting Yao Yuanchong’s esteemed reputation and the Emperor’s trust in him, sent a letter advising him to distance himself from flatterers and the restless, and to advance the pure and sincere. Yuanchong praised and accepted his counsel. One day, he requested the promotion of certain officials. The Emperor looked up at the palace ceiling and spoke repeatedly, yet gave no response. Yuanchong grew fearful and hurried out. After the court session, Gao Lishi admonished: “Your Majesty has newly assumed the reins of governance. When the prime minister presents matters, you should respond directly—why remain so inattentive?”

The Emperor said: “I have entrusted Yuanchong with the administration of all government affairs. Matters of great import should be reported to me, but petty officials of the sixth rank—must he trouble me with every single one?” It so happened that Gao Lishi came to the ministry to deliver an imperial message, and he relayed the Emperor’s words. Yuanchong was pleased, and all who heard marveled at the Emperor’s discernment in judging the qualities of a ruler.

The chronicler notes: This was the beginning of the influence of Li Linfu and Yang Guozhong. The heart of the noble man is virtuous: he defers to his sovereign, ever fearful that authority might slip from the throne into his own hands. The heart of the petty man is deceitful: he indulges his whims before the multitude, ever fearful that authority might remain firmly in the hands of the ruler. Though the rank of these officials was low, were they not like the constellations in the heavens? To find them a burden was one thing for Yuanchong, but for others, it would not have been so. Moreover, Yuanchong had thrice failed to report his decisions, yet a single word from Gao Lishi echoed like thunder, turning the public discourse of the court into private whispers within the ministry. How could one hope to prevent the usurpation of power under such circumstances? A single moment of silence or speech was enough to foretell that his end would not be good. Those who rule must be vigilant.

Zhang Shougui sent An Lushan to campaign against the Xi and the Khitan. Relying on his bravery, Lushan advanced recklessly and was defeated by the enemy. Shougui memorialized the throne requesting his execution. As Lushan stood before the executioner, he cried out: “Does the General not wish to destroy the Xi and the Khitan? Why kill me?” Shougui, valuing his courage, wished to spare him and instead sent him under guard to the capital. Zhang Jiuling memorialized: “In ancient times, Rangju executed Zhuang Jia, and Sun Wu beheaded the palace ladies. If Shougui’s military discipline had been enforced, Lushan should not have escaped death.” The Emperor, pitying his talent, issued an edict sparing his life, ordering him to serve as a general in commoner’s garb. Jiuling firmly remonstrated: “Lushan violated military discipline and lost his army; by law, he cannot be spared. Furthermore, I observe his countenance—it bears the signs of rebellion. If he is not put to death, he will surely become a future calamity.” The Emperor replied: “Do not, like Wang Yifu who recognized Shi Le, wrongly harm a loyal subject.” In the end, he pardoned Lushan.

The chronicler notes: The Emperor’s words are perplexing. If Wang Yan had truly known Shi Le, then Jiuling’s warning was nothing extraordinary. But if Wang Yan did not know Shi Le, then the wrong done to Lushan remains doubtful. For if he had recognized Shi Le, why then speak of wrongly harming a loyal subject? At that time, the cosmos had already shifted, and hardship was imminent. Heaven had deprived the Emperor of his wisdom, blinding his heart and will. If one so lacking in benevolence could still be reasoned with, how could there be the ruin of nations and the downfall of houses? Otherwise, how could he have failed to recognize not only Lushan but also Shi Siming? Even if his judgment was clouded, such confusion was inexcusable.

In the second year of the Zhide era of Emperor Suzong, the retired Emperor longed for Zhang Jiuling’s foresight and wept for him. He dispatched an emissary to Qujiang to offer sacrifices and generously provided for Jiuling’s family.

The chronicler notes: Jiuling’s words before and after were as clear as divination by tortoise shell or milfoil. Yet the Emperor not only failed to heed them but even doubted them. Thus, the sword of Li Linfu was not wielded by himself—it was the Emperor who wielded it. The sweetness of honeyed words was not tasted by himself—it was the Emperor who tasted it. Though the deception of petty men is evident in the moment, the trust earned by noble men often comes only after their deaths. The momentary is like the stench of rotting flesh, so foul that even then men cover their noses; the posthumous is like medicine and acupuncture, striking a chord with all ages. Was this not why, even beyond the tears shed in Shu, the legacy of Qujiang’s integrity endures to this day?

In the first year of the Yongtai era of Emperor Daizong, the armies of the Uyghurs and the Tubo besieged Jingyang. At that time, Pugu Huai’en had died, and the two barbarian forces, vying for supremacy, were at odds. They divided their camps, with the Uyghurs stationed to the west of the city. Guo Ziyi sent his adjutant Li Yuanzan to negotiate with them, proposing a joint attack on the Tubo. The Uyghurs did not believe him, saying: “Where is Lord Guo? You are deceiving us. If he is truly here, can we see him?” Yuanzan returned and reported this. Ziyi said: “Our forces are outnumbered, and victory by strength is unlikely. It would be better for me to go forth alone and persuade them. We may subdue them without battle.” He then opened the city gates and rode out with a few horsemen, sending a messenger ahead to announce: “The Duke of Ying is coming.” The Uyghurs were astonished. Their great chieftain, Yüge Luo—a younger brother of the Khagan—stood at the front of the ranks, bow drawn and arrow nocked. Ziyi removed his helmet, doffed his armor, cast aside his spear, and advanced. The tribal leaders looked at one another and said: “It is he.” They all dismounted and prostrated themselves. Ziyi also dismounted, took Yüge Luo’s hand, and reproached him: “The Uyghurs have rendered great service to the Tang, and the Tang’s repayment has not been meager. Why have you broken your oath, deeply invading our land, forsaking past merit, and sowing enmity? How foolish! Moreover, Huai’en betrayed his lord and abandoned his mother—what concern is that to your nation? Today, I have come alone. If you wish to kill me, my officers and soldiers will surely fight to the death against you.”

Yüge Luo said: "Huai’en deceived us, claiming that the Heavenly Khagan had passed away, that you, my lord, had also perished, and that the Central Kingdom had no ruler. That is why we dared to come with him. Now we know the Heavenly Khagan resides in the Upper Capital, that you, my lord, have once again taken command of the armies, and that Huai’en has been slain by Heaven—how could we possibly fight against you?"

Ziyi then persuaded him, saying: "The Tubo are without the Dao. Taking advantage of our nation’s turmoil, they disregarded the bond of uncle and nephew, devoured our borderlands, and burned and ravaged our capital districts. The wealth they have plundered is beyond measure—this is what Heaven has bestowed upon you."

Yüge Luo replied: "I was misled by Huai’en and have deeply wronged you, my lord. Now I shall exert all my strength to strike the Tubo in your service and atone for my error."

The Uyghur onlookers gradually advanced, and Ziyi’s troops also moved forward. He waved his hand to hold them back, then took wine and drank with Yüge Luo, presenting him with three thousand bolts of silk. In the end, they sealed the pact and withdrew.

Upon hearing this, the Tubo fled under cover of night. Yüge Luo led his forces in pursuit, while Ziyi dispatched Bai Yuan’guang with elite cavalry to join them. They engaged the enemy at Xiyuan west of Lingtai and crushed them.

**Record states:** Observing Ziyi’s conduct in this affair, it was not merely his sincerity and trustworthiness that brought about such an outcome. One can see how his qi swallowed both Hua and Yi, his capacity embraced all within the Four Seas—this was no petty display of removing his helmet before barbarians.

When Han Yu was Prefect of Chaozhou, he inquired about the people’s hardships. They all said: "In the waters of the Jiao River, there are crocodiles several *zhang* in length that devour our livestock, leaving almost none to breed." After a few days, Han Yu went to inspect the site. He cast a piglet and a sheep into the water and composed a proclamation, ordering the crocodiles to move south into the sea within three days. If they could not do so in three days, then five; if not in five, then seven. If they still refused to leave, it would be clear they had no intention of doing so. The prefect would then select strong men armed with sturdy crossbows and poisoned arrows to engage the crocodiles.

That very night, a violent storm arose with thunder, and the waters of the pool dried up within days. The crocodiles relocated sixty *li* west of their former haunt, and from then on, Chaozhou was free of their menace. Han Yu was later transferred to the post of Vice Minister of War.

When rebellion broke out in Zhenzhou and Tian Hongzheng was killed, with Wang Tingcou installed in his place, an imperial edict ordered Han Yu to pacify the region. As he set out, all feared for his safety. Upon arrival, Tingcou surrounded him with heavily armed troops. Han Yu shouted: "The Son of Heaven appointed you as a general and bestowed upon you the staff of office—how could you turn against him and side with rebels?"

Before he could finish, a soldier stepped forward and cried: "Our late Grand Preceptor fought for the state, and the bloodstained robes of Zhu Tao still remain—what wrong has this army committed to be branded as rebels?"

Han Yu replied: "I thought you had forgotten your late Grand Preceptor. If you still remember him, that is well. Since the Tianbao era, have any sons or grandsons of An Lushan, Shi Siming, or Li Xilie remained? Are any of them still in office?"

The crowd answered: "None."

Han Yu continued: "Tian Hongzheng returned the six prefectures of Weibo to the court, was appointed Chancellor, and both he and his son received the imperial staff. Liu Wu and Li You were also granted great commands—these are matters your army knows well."

The crowd said: "Hongzheng was harsh, which is why this army was unsettled."

Han Yu replied: "Even so, you murdered Tian Hongzheng and slaughtered his family—what justification can there be?"

The assembly fell silent, then murmured: "Well said."

Then Ting Geng said: "Now what would you have me do?"

Han Yu replied: "Commanders of the Divine Strategy’s Six Armies, such as Niu Yuanwei, have done no wrong. Yet the court, considering the greater peace, cannot abandon them. Why then have you long besieged him?"

Ting Ling said: "I shall let him go."

Han Yu said: "If so, then there is no further trouble."

Just then, Yuanwei also broke through the siege and escaped, and Ting Ling did not pursue. Han Yu returned and reported their exchange, and the Emperor was greatly pleased.

The record states: *The* Yi *says in* Zhong Fu*:* "Trust extends even to pigs and fish." It also says: "It is beneficial to cross great rivers, for thus the state is transformed." Now fish are creatures of stillness, without awareness, yet trust can move them—what matter cannot be accomplished, what thing cannot be transformed? One may tread through water and fire, or face the unfathomable, and still succeed. Hence it is said: "It is beneficial to cross great rivers." At that time, though Ting Ling was violent and lawless, he was, after all, only a man. By Han Yu’s loyalty and sincerity, he was able to subdue his heart, so that Ting Ling readily obeyed—there was no other way. Thus it is also said: "Thus the state is transformed." Can men not strive to emulate this?

Yet Su Shi once said: "Your utmost sincerity could part the clouds of Mount Heng, yet could not dispel Emperor Xianzong’s delusions; it could tame the savagery of crocodiles, yet could not silence the slander of Huangfu Bo and Li Fengji; it could earn the unwavering trust of the people of Nanhai, so that you are worshipped in temples to this day, yet could not secure you a single day’s peace at court." For what you could accomplish was ordained by Heaven, while what you could not was the work of men. His words are thorough, and so I record them here.

*The History of the Song* states: Emperor Taizu asked Zhao Pu: "Since the end of the Five Dynasties, in just a few decades, there have been eight ruling houses and twelve emperors, each usurping the throne in turn, locked in endless war, with the people suffering terribly. What is the reason for this? I wish to end the wars of the realm and establish a lasting foundation for the state. How may this be done?"

Zhao Pu replied: "That Your Majesty should speak of this is a blessing for Heaven, Earth, man, and the spirits. There is no other reason: the regional commanders grew too powerful, and the sovereign weak while his ministers grew strong. To remedy this, one must gradually strip them of their authority, control their finances and grain, and reclaim their elite troops. Then the realm will naturally be at peace."

At the time, Shi Shouxin, Wang Shenqi, and others were the Emperor’s old comrades, men of merit who commanded the imperial guard. One evening after court, the Emperor invited them to drink, and when they were merry, he dismissed his attendants and said: "Without you, I would not have attained this position. Yet being emperor is far more difficult than being a regional commander—indeed, I have not slept soundly a single night. Who in this position would not desire it?" Shouxin and the others bowed their heads and said: "Why does Your Majesty speak thus? Heaven’s mandate is now settled; who would dare harbor other thoughts?"

The Emperor said: "That may be so. But what of your subordinates? If they seek wealth and rank, what then?"

Shouxin and the others wept and said: "We are fools, unworthy of Your Majesty’s wisdom. Pray, show us the path to life."

The Emperor said: "Man’s life is fleeting as a white colt glimpsed through a crack in the wall. Those who covet wealth and rank do so only to amass gold and silver, to indulge themselves and their pleasures, and to ensure their descendants want for nothing. Why not relinquish your military commands, take up governorships in the great provinces, and purchase fine estates and houses to secure an unshakable inheritance for your children? Buy singing girls and dancers, feast and revel day and night, and live out your years in joy. I shall form marriage alliances with you, and between sovereign and ministers, there will be no suspicion—would this not be good?"

Shouxin and the others all thanked him, saying: "That Your Majesty should think of us thus is as if you had given us life from death, bone from flesh." The next day, they all claimed illness and begged to be relieved of their military posts.

The record states: The events at Chen Bridge arose suddenly, following the old ways of the Five Dynasties. The relinquishing of military power nipped trouble in the bud, and this became the unshakable foundation of the Great Song. *The* Yi *says:* "In danger, one raises the alarm in the royal court; trust is proclaimed, and there is peril." The *Image* says: "Raising the alarm in the royal court—this is the yielding riding upon the five strong. Trust is proclaimed, and there is peril—thus danger is transformed into radiance." When the disorder of petty men reaches its limit, the cycle of decline and renewal ensures that Heaven raises up a sovereign of great ability, aided by ministers of integrity, clarity, and resolve. The power of the Dao flourishes, and the weak and yielding are vanquished. Thus he could act openly at court, making clear to all the principles of advancement and retreat, the subtleties of action and inaction. His utmost sincerity and trust were not born of deceit or reliance on force, nor was his grand proclamation the work of secret schemes. This is what sets him apart from those who seize power by stealth or cunning, who are ultimately overthrown and destroyed. Was this not the foundation of the Song’s enduring governance, surpassing that of the Han and Tang?

When Zhao Pu was Chancellor, he took the realm as his own responsibility. Emperor Taizu entrusted him with all matters, great and small, seeking his counsel on every decision. Once, he recommended a man for office, but the Emperor refused. The next day, he submitted the recommendation again, and again it was refused. He then brought the man to court himself, and the Emperor, enraged, tore the memorial to pieces and cast it to the ground. Zhao Pu’s expression did not change; he knelt and gathered the fragments. Later, he pieced the memorial back together and resubmitted it as before. The Emperor then understood and ultimately appointed the man. On another occasion, a minor official was due for promotion, but the Emperor, who had long disliked the man, refused to advance him. Zhao Pu insisted, and the Emperor grew angry, saying: "I have decided he shall not be promoted. What can you do about it?"

Zhao Pu replied: "Punishment is for deterring evil, reward for recognizing merit—this is the universal principle of past and present. Moreover, punishment and reward belong to the realm, not to Your Majesty alone. How can you wield them at the whim of your likes and dislikes?" The Emperor was furious and rose to return to the palace, but Zhao Pu followed him and would not leave. After a long while, the Emperor finally granted his request. His resolute integrity and steadfast sincerity were ever thus.

The record states: The piecing together of the torn memorial—this was an act of a flourishing age.

Zhao Pu may truly be said to have borne no fault in recommending the worthy. Yet why, when it came to the memorial he had signed at the imperial couch, could he bring himself to tear it apart? At that time, when the Grand Progenitor held the Mandate of Heaven, Pu took the altars of state as his own responsibility; his private desires had not yet stirred, nor had considerations of gain and loss arisen, and so he was able to devote himself wholly to the service of his lord. But after he was reappointed as chief minister, his private desires had already stirred, and considerations of gain and loss had already arisen, so that he could not but weigh promotion and demotion with favor and disfavor.

Nevertheless, if one were to observe him as others do—merely following the dictates of personal likes and dislikes, never daring to dissent—how could there have been repeated remonstrations or the piecing together of torn memorials? In Pu’s case, it was not that he was able to enlighten the Emperor, but rather that the Emperor was able to enlighten him.

When King Shupu of Wuyue heard of the fall of Tang, he grew fearful and came to court with his wife, Lady Sun, his son Weijun, and his grandson Chengyou. The Grand Ancestor bestowed upon him a residence befitting a worthy and personally attended a banquet in his honor, trusting him without suspicion. After two months, he sent them back, presenting them with a yellow-wrapped bundle, its seals tightly affixed. He admonished them, saying, "Observe carefully along the way." When they opened it, they found it filled with memorials from the court ministers begging to detain Shupu. Shupu was all the more awestruck and fearful. Upon returning to his duties, he ordered his seat moved to the eastern side, saying, "The northwest is where the divine capital lies. The Emperor trusts me—how dare I not show reverence?" With every tribute he sent, he would first arrange it in the courtyard, burn incense, and only then dispatch it.

The record states: The Emperor’s restoration of Shupu was perhaps a lesson drawn from Li Xuan’s criticism of Li Yu. If others’ snoring slumber could not be tolerated, yet one’s own solitary wakefulness could not be trusted, this would only confuse the bond between ruler and minister and fail to establish a clear and far-reaching vision. Had there been another like Li Xuan, the Emperor’s words would have faltered. By demonstrating such trust, he ensured that in later days, even if Shupu were detained and not sent back, the depth of the two emperors’ magnanimity and the weight of their virtue would have been all the more evident.

When Minister Wang Wenzheng served as chief minister, the Emperor grew ever more trusting, following his counsel without exception. For nearly every memorial or request from high officials, he would first ask Wang, "What do you think of this?" before acting.
