Wang Wenzheng scrupulously upheld the laws and institutions of the ancestral founders, making no changes. He frequently inquired into the benefits and harms of the realm, sometimes sending envoys to gather opinions and present them. Observing the strengths of various talents, he secretly recorded their names without summoning them again. When making appointments, he would first submit three names and ask the Emperor to select one. The Emperor would mark his choice with a brush, and none of the other ministers knew of it. Thus, whenever Wang Wenzheng made a recommendation, it was invariably approved.

The record states: Did Emperor Zhenzong truly trust Wang Dan with sincerity and the straight path of virtue? At first, he flattered him to secure his loyalty; in the end, he trusted him to fulfill his ambitions. Had Wang Dan not borne the Emperor’s deceit, how could the Emperor have trusted Wang Dan’s words? One may say he was close and discreet, but to call him scrupulous in upholding the law would be inaccurate. For scrupulousness is the duty of an official, requiring unwavering diligence from beginning to end, without the slightest negligence—how could it lead to regret at the brink of crisis? Let the reader silently take note of this.

In *Records of Illustrious Ministers*: When Minister Zhang Zhongding governed Shu before and after, he did so with benevolence and trust. The people rejoiced as if children long separated from their parents had been reunited. Upon his arrival, he replaced severity with leniency, and every decree he issued brought comfort to the people. Shu was thus greatly pacified. The Emperor said, "With Yong in Shu, I no longer have any concerns about the west." Such was the extent of his trust.

Once, he asked Li Tian, "Do the common people truly trust me?" Li replied, "Your Excellency’s authority and kindness have reached the people—how could they not trust you?" The minister said, "In my previous term, that was not yet the case. This time, it should be somewhat better. It took five years to achieve even this single word: *trust*." He also said, "If you govern in the future, first ensure that trust reaches the people, then instruct them. Speak to them of righteousness, then encourage them. Act with propriety, then transform them. Remain impartial and selfless, then the people will be at peace and content in their livelihoods. If these four principles are in place, first set the example yourself."

Minister Wang Yigong once said, "In a person’s conduct, nothing surpasses sincerity and integrity, which remain constant in both safety and peril." When he governed Daming for a second term, his trustworthiness deepened among the people. Civilians and soldiers alike painted his portrait to honor him. When envoys from the northern tribes passed through his jurisdiction, they would say, "The Lord Wang is here," and would bathe and dress in clean robes before entering.

Minister Du Qigong was upright and forthright throughout his life, earning the trust of the realm through his loyalty and sincerity. He once said, "I have served for many years, long in office, known by the Emperor above and trusted by the court and the people below. Thus, I have been able to fulfill my aspirations in most matters." He also said, "From my time in the provincial administration to my tenure as a regional inspector, people did not yet trust me. But when I became Vice Minister of Finance and repeatedly argued my case before the Emperor without wavering, people began to trust me." Moreover, in his dealings with others, he delighted in their goodness. Once he knew someone, he harbored not the slightest doubt. When Qi began as Vice Minister of Military Affairs and debated one or two matters with him, the minister was displeased. Later, whenever Qi discussed affairs, the minister would ask, "Has the Remonstrator reviewed this?" If he had, he would bring it for Qi to sign. Qi thus devoted himself wholeheartedly, never daring to be negligent. From this, one can see how rare it is for a person to trust himself and others as he did.

The record states: These three ministers were the pillars of the state and the cornerstones of their time. Their self-trust and trust in the people—whether toward the ruler above or their peers—were not easily matched. If so, how can a gentleman not strive ever harder? Strive ever harder!

*Hongdao Record*, Scroll Forty-Nine—End.

**Hongdao Record, Scroll Fifty**

**On Trust**
**Trust Between Ruler and Minister**

Emperor Renzong trusted his great ministers. When selecting an envoy to the Khitan, Lü Yijian recommended Fu Bi. At the time, the emperor entrusted the chief ministers with the governance of the realm, assigning Fu Bi to manage northern affairs and Fan Zhongyan to oversee western matters.

Upon his audience, Fu Bi declared: “When the ruler is troubled, his ministers are shamed. I dare not spare my life.” The emperor was visibly moved. He promoted Fu Bi to *Direct Academician of the Bureau of Military Affairs*, but Fu Bi firmly declined, saying: “When the state faces crisis, one cannot shrink from toil. How could I accept office and rank as a bribe?” He then departed.

The record states: Histories claim the emperor lacked firm resolve—how could this be so? By entrusting governance to his chief ministers, northern affairs to Fu Bi, and western matters to Fan Zhongyan, his decisiveness was more than sufficient. In an age governed by the Dao, matters generally proceed thus. Yet when such an age declines, suspicion and mistrust arise, doubts multiply. Tracing the cause, it lies precisely in the abundance of those who cling to salary and the scarcity of those who serve the state as a loyal hound. The worthy and the unworthy become indistinguishable, leading to the ruler’s wavering resolve. Thus, Fu Bi’s refusal of office was not without reason.

Upon arriving in Khitan, Fu Bi met with its ruler and asked: “Our two courts have maintained good relations for nearly forty years. Why now demand the cession of land?” The ruler replied: “The Southern Court has violated the treaty—blocking the *Daomen* Pass, raising embankments, repairing fortifications, and conscripting militia. What is the meaning of this?” Fu Bi answered: “The *Mingmen* Pass was sealed to guard against Yuanhao. The embankments began with He Chengju, a measure in place since the establishment of friendly relations. The fortifications were merely restored from old structures, and the militia were raised to fill vacancies—none of this violates the treaty.”

He then pressed further: “Has the Northern Court forgotten the great virtue of Emperor Zhangsheng? During the *Chanyuan* campaign, had he heeded his generals, not a single northern soldier would have escaped. Moreover, in peacetime, the ruler alone reaps the benefits. In war, the gains flow to his ministers, while the ruler bears the calamity. Thus, those who advocate war do so only for their own gain.” The ruler exclaimed in surprise: “What do you mean?” Fu Bi replied...

“In former times, the Jin High Ancestor deceived Heaven and betrayed his lord, while the Last Emperor was muddled and chaotic, so that superiors and subordinates fell into mutual estrangement—hence the Khitan army prevailed. Yet even then, half their stalwart warriors and sturdy steeds perished. Today, China’s troops are well-trained, her horses strong, her laws and commands clear, and her people of one heart. If war is truly willed, can victory be assured? Even if victory comes, who bears the loss of men and horses—the ministers, or the ruler? If friendly relations endure unbroken, the annual tribute flows entirely to the ruler; what profit do his ministers gain?”

The ruler was deeply enlightened, nodding for a long while, and said: “Without your words, I would not have known these details.”

It is recorded: When the Khitan first sent envoys in return, none dared readily go. Though Lord Zheng resolutely requested the mission, and Lord Ouyang submitted a memorial to detain him, was this not because the task was supremely difficult? Yet when Lord Zheng arrived, the barbarians found nothing to fear. Though he spoke back and forth for hundreds of words, they never once pressed him with a challenge—where, then, was the difficulty? The difficulty lay not in the barbarians, but in trust and righteousness. What China relies upon are only trust and righteousness, by which the hearts of the barbarians may be subdued. If these are weighed in the balance of strength and the scales of victory and defeat, it is not for the gentleman to presume to know.

Yet now, among the Tatars, are there truly none with the slightest human heart? Or have they been deceived by false trust and hollow alliances? If one were to open sincerity and lay bare the public good, enticing them with considerations of profit and harm, clarifying honor and disgrace, even if they could not be made entirely compliant, they would not have turned so perverse. Then why should those who govern the state shrink from such action?

Fu Bi again went to the Khitan, addressing only two matters: alliance by marriage and increased tribute. When the oath document arrived, they no longer discussed marriage, but insisted solely on increased tribute, saying: “Since the Southern Court has increased our annual tribute, the wording should read ‘presented.’” Fu Bi replied: “The Southern Court is the elder brother; how can an elder brother present to a younger?” They then proposed the word “delivered.” Fu Bi again refused, saying: “Since the Southern Court has bestowed such generous tribute upon us, it is because we are feared. What weight do two characters carry?” Fu Bi said: “Our court cherishes both north and south alike, and thus does not shrink from renewing the accord. How can this be called fear? If compelled, then in matters of war, victory and defeat should be determined by right and wrong—not for an envoy to know.”

The Khitan ruler said: “There are precedents for this.” Fu Bi replied: “Since antiquity, only the Tang High Ancestor borrowed troops from the Türks. At the time, it may have been called ‘presentation,’ but later, when Illig was captured by Taizong, did such a thing recur?” His tone and expression grew stern. The ruler, knowing his resolve could not be shaken, said: “I shall send my own envoy to discuss this.”

It is recorded: The oath document of Jingde was one; the oath documents of Qingli were two. The peace of Jingde was near; the peace of Qingli was distant. In the era of the fallen Yan and extinguished Zong, China was in no way comparable to Han in strategy, to Tang in planning, to Qin in strength, or to Sui in wealth. She relied solely on Fu Bi’s sincerity and persuasive contention. The two characters of “presentation” and “delivery” in the exchange between Hua and Yi are worth observing.

Yet with the emperor’s humility and brilliance, contending over the word “delivered” was not excessive; with his frugality, increasing the annual tribute was not extravagance; with his innate sevenfold love, ceasing hostilities was not empty rhetoric. Otherwise, the words received in audience might differ from those spoken at departure—how much more so the brush of later historians? This, too, must not be overlooked.

At that time, as military campaigns raged along the western frontier and defenses proved inadequate, **Zhong Shiheng** proposed: "East of Yan’an lies the abandoned fortress of the former Kuanzhou, which should be rebuilt to block the enemy’s main route. To the right, it would secure Yan’an’s position; to the left, it would facilitate the transport of grain from the east of the Yellow River; to the north, it would allow for the recovery of the former territories of Yinchuan and Xiazhou." The court approved his plan. Upon completion, the fortress was named **Qingjian City**.

Among the **Fan** tribes was a chieftain named **Niujia Nuer**, who had long dominated the borderlands and never once paid homage to the prefectural governor. Upon hearing of Shiheng’s name, however, he immediately rode out to greet him. Shiheng made an appointment, promising to visit Nuer’s encampment the following day to extend his regards to the tribe. That night, snow fell three feet deep. His attendants warned, "The terrain is treacherous—you cannot go." Shiheng replied, "I am now forging trust with the Qiang tribes; I cannot break my word." He pressed forward through the perilous paths. Nuer, still abed in his tent, assumed Shiheng would never arrive. When Shiheng suddenly roused him, Nuer was astonished: "Never before has an official come to my camp. Yet you place such trust in me!" He led his clan to prostrate themselves and pledge obedience.

While stationed at Qingjian City, **Yuan Hao** had not yet submitted. His trusted advisors, the **Yeli** brothers, held great influence, and Shiheng sought to sow discord between them. There was a monk named **Wang Guangxin**, a man of valor who knew the tribal roads well. Shiheng memorialized the throne to appoint him as a *sanban jiezhi* (temporary official) and had him deliver a letter to the Yeli brothers, urging them to defect early. Yuan Hao believed the ruse and grew suspicious of the brothers, ultimately executing them. He then sent his minister **Li Wengui** to report, offering to negotiate peace and requesting a single word of assurance. Shiheng informed **Fan Zhongyan**, who instructed him to convey the court’s magnanimous intent to accept their submission and allow Wengui to return with the message. Thereafter, Yuan Hao sought surrender and resumed his former vassalage.

**Record states:** Observing the Zhong clan, we see they descended from exiled royalty and initially held no renown in their time. Yet their descendants became famed generals. The key to their achievements began with Qingjian and Nuer, and concluded with the Yeli brothers. At first, they faced unfathomable depths and unforeseen dangers; in the end, they leveraged past trust to devise future strategies. Those who command the frontier today—how could they not grasp their duty?

Some say: "In Shiheng’s era, **Emperor Renzong** ruled above, and **Zhongyan** served below—thus success was possible. Had the sovereign not been magnanimous and broad-minded, or the general not upright, impartial, and trustworthy, even a momentary stratagem would have failed, let alone securing a legacy for posterity." This, too, must not be overlooked.

**Sima Guang** was a man of loyalty, integrity, and honesty. From youth to old age, he never spoke falsely. He once said: "I have no extraordinary qualities, but all my life, I have never done anything I could not declare openly." His sincerity was innate, and the world revered and trusted him. In the regions of **Shan** and **Luo**, people were transformed by his virtue. If someone acted wrongly, they would ask, "Surely **Junshi** (Guang’s courtesy name) does not know of this?" When he entered the government, he abolished nearly all the new laws that harmed the people.

Some warned: "Many of the old ministers from the **Xining** era are cunning and frugal. One day, if the emperor questions the righteousness of father and son, disaster will strike." Guang replied sternly: "If Heaven blesses the Song, such a thing will not occur." Thus, the realm placed its faith in him, saying, "This was the late emperor’s true intent."

**Record states:** Why should one do anything that cannot be spoken of openly? For "man" is the term by which one refers to oneself—how can one deceive oneself and expect to deceive others? Those who seek to deceive others may employ a hundred schemes, yet the clarity of their true heart will never be obscured. Such efforts are but fragmented and muddled, like a drunken man babbling and stumbling. The *Commentary on the Great Learning* states: "What is meant by making one’s intentions sincere? It is to not deceive oneself." It also says: "Others see one as if they could perceive one’s lungs and liver." How can one who does not trust themselves be trusted by others? The reforms he implemented and the harmful laws he abolished all stemmed from this self-trust. Even Heaven’s favor toward the Song could not alter this.

**Tang Jie**, appointed as *Can Zhizhengshi* (Vice Grand Councilor), believed his advancement came through upright conduct. Moved by the emperor’s recognition, he devoted himself to serving his lord with pure sincerity and utmost dedication, offering candid advice on governance. In personnel matters, he forthrightly assessed abilities, neither currying favor nor shirking enmity. When debating policies with colleagues, he argued repeatedly without yielding. He was especially cautious regarding changes to ancestral laws or the promotion and demotion of close ministers. Even before the emperor, he would press his case with incisive reasoning, never wavering from what he deemed right. The emperor thus held him in greater respect and trust, and the realm eagerly admired his conduct.

**Record states:** How fortunate was **Tang Zifang**! At first, his reputation for integrity resounded throughout the land; in the end, his uprightness filled the court.

Though born into this world as one of its people, even the lowliest scholar should aspire to live up to his station, for does not even the earthworm value its own worth? Though holding but a single office, he should still seek to render service, for does not even the ant aspire to great deeds? Thus, when one’s worth is recognized and met with unwavering trust and respect, the bond between ruler and subject remains unbroken—nothing more is needed.

Chang Anmin believed that governing with sincerity and trust was the foundation of order, for the noble of heart cannot bear to deceive. When he and An Dun were colleagues, Dun—a man of deep cunning—would often slander those he had once befriended. Anmin said to him, "Does such a man not owe loyalty to his lord? Why do you speak so harshly of him?" Dun replied, "In truth, I despise him—I merely feign friendship." Anmin said, "What you describe is ‘concealing hatred while pretending friendship’—the way of Li Linfu." Dun laughed and said, "If the Way of uprightness prevails, you shall surpass me in rank." Thus, Anmin often remarked, "If men like Dun are honored, the fate of the realm is clear. I should retire and withdraw, for why contend over right and wrong? I fear only that it would harm my hidden virtue." Later, Dun’s son was executed for crimes, just as Anmin had foreseen.

During the Yuanfeng era, though the powerful ministers of the time had been removed from court, their factions still spread throughout the bureaucracy, advancing private agendas to sway governance. Anmin was deeply troubled by this and wrote to Lord Lü Ruo, saying: "To discern the trends of the world is like a skilled physician examining an illness. In times of peace and calm, if one warns of future peril, the crowd will surely mock and scoff. Only those with keen insight can foresee the subtle signs. Thus, true wisdom lies not in worrying over what is already worrisome, but in worrying over what seems unworthy of concern—this is the deepest worry of all.

Removing petty men is not difficult; defeating them is. The disasters of the Five Princes of Chen and Dou are precedents from past ages. Even if loyal and upright men are promoted today, unless we gather the finest talents from across the land and assemble them at court to overpower the petty men, I fear that the principled and the righteous will not rest easy. For if ten men oppose one tiger, the men prevail; if one man opposes two tigers, the tigers prevail. How then can a few dozen contend with a thousand tigers?" His words proved prophetic in every detail.

He further remarked: "Zhang Huiqing is base by nature and deeply treacherous. Now, as he passes through the capital, he will surely invoke the late emperor with tears to move Your Majesty’s heart, hoping to remain in the capital." Later, when Huiqing requested an audience, the emperor maintained a stern countenance and did not respond, much to the satisfaction of contemporary opinion.

He also spoke at length against Zhang Dun, Cai Que, and Zeng Bu. At the time, Cai Jing’s wickedness had not yet become apparent, and many did not believe it. Yet Anmin alone declared: "Jing’s treachery is sufficient to delude the masses; his eloquence is sufficient to gloss over his faults; his cunning is sufficient to distort the sovereign’s perception; and his power is sufficient to invert right and wrong across the realm." His memorials on this matter numbered in the dozens or even hundreds, and all were incisive.

**Recorded Reflection:**
Divination by milfoil and tortoise shell, along with medicine and stone needles, are all prized in the world. For medicine and stone needles can cure existing illnesses, while milfoil and tortoise shell can foretell future calamities. Without divination, medicine and stone needles would have no recourse; without medicine and stone needles, divination would lack proof of its efficacy. The crux lies in how one weighs and decides.

The realm of Song may be likened to a single human body. At first, it did not trust gentle remedies, recklessly administering potent drugs without restraint, so that internally, its vital organs, and externally, its limbs, all fell gravely ill. Midway, it vigorously applied old prescriptions, devising countless measures to protect and restore itself, so that above, its brow and countenance, and below, its complexion, all showed signs of recovery. In the end, however, the medicine failed to induce the necessary shock, and the illness did not abate. Thus, the malady worsened even as slight improvement appeared; complacency arose from indolence; and between the region above the diaphragm and below the heart, the affliction became irreparably entrenched.

Anmin’s words were as certain as divination or lightning. Yet they went unused because the nation’s primordial qi had been exhausted. The flourishing or decline of a dynasty hinges on the waxing and waning of its fate; the life and death of men depend on the length of their allotted span. Had the Seven Worthies of the Xuan era been blessed by Heaven to live long, to uphold perfect impartiality, and to forever secure the altars of state, how could mere trifling missteps have led to ruin? Even with a hundred wolves or a thousand tigers, they would have seen the sky brighten and the sun rise, unable to indulge their roars. Alas!

The Yuanyou era fell into ruin, and the Shaosheng era followed in its wake. The imperial court became a thicket of thorns, and men were transformed into gulls and wagtails. As the *Book of Songs* says: "Within, it festered in the Central Kingdom; without, it spread to the distant lands." These words are not [missing character] to be trusted, and all the more grievous to bear.

Yang Bangjiu possessed a radiant and refined countenance, tall as a mountain in stature, and all who saw him cherished him. In times of peace, he harmed no one, but when faced with crisis, he acted with resolute courage—ten thousand men could not sway him. His virtue was cultivated at home, renowned in his village, and trusted among his friends. That he ultimately gave his life for the state, establishing a monumental moral standard for all ages, was no mere accident of the moment.

When he first took charge of Liyang, his decrees were clear and steadfast. At the time, the rebel soldier Zhou De had seized the prefectural city, killing officials. Bangjiu then released the imprisoned Zhao Ming in the courtyard, binding him with sincerity and trust before sending him away. The next day, Zhao Ming indeed rallied the village’s stalwarts to capture the rebels and quell the uprising.

Later, as *Tongpan* of Jiankang, when Jin forces crossed the river, Du Ke ordered the city to be defended, and Bangjiu once more placed his trust in him. The following day, Ke fled, leaving Jinling empty of troops. Prefect Chen Bangguang then exited the city to surrender to the enemy, and Ke was the first to yield. Only Bangjiu remained unyielding, shouting: "Do you take me for one who would bow to barbarians?" Bangguang relayed this to Wumu, who said: "Bangjiu has long been ill." He sent a close associate to persuade him: "You have always been poor. Your elder brother is aged, relying on your salary for support. Your widowed sister-in-law and orphaned nephews have come from afar to depend on you. You have five young sons and an unmarried daughter—do you not think of them?" Bangjiu replied: "These are the common sentiments of men. Are my five children devoid of feeling? The state and the family cannot both stand. I have no doubt in my resolve."

Wumu set out wine and summoned those who had surrendered to drink. Bangjiu ascended the steps but struck his head against a pillar, declaring: "How could I share a feast with dogs and swine?" The next day, Bangguang again urged him: "There is no recourse in this matter. I beg you to reconsider. To die in vain is of no benefit." Bangjiu glared and said: "You, a minister of the court charged with defending the realm, failed to die in the face of disaster, instead willingly bending the knee. If all follow your example, what will become of the court?" At that moment, the military commissioner Liu presented him with a slip of paper, saying: "Speak no more. If you act for the Zhao house, write 'death'; if for me, write 'life.'" Bangjiu took the brush and wrote "death." Liu still did not believe him, so Bangjiu cut his flesh and wrote in blood on his robe: "I would rather be a ghost of the Zhao house than a minister of another state." The following day, when questioned again, Bangjiu cursed fiercely, tore his robe to reveal the bloodstained words, and the barbarians finally believed him. They then put him to death, cutting open his abdomen to examine his heart.

The record states: I observe that Zong Ze’s indignation, Du Ke’s cowardice, Bangguang’s surrender, and Bangjiu’s disembowelment all stemmed from the machinations of Wang and Huang and the sovereign’s lack of firm virtue. Moreover, Jinling was the convergence of imperial *qi*—not to be compared with a mere corner of Jiangzhe. Though the emperor had lost the east, he might yet have recovered in the west. Yet, lacking any strategy, he sat and awaited destruction, prolonging the dynasty’s twilight for a few generations more. Confucius said: "Since all must die, the people will not stand without trust." Thus, a city may be breached, but a slip of paper cannot; a general may be captured, but a blood oath cannot. Had the loyal minister not acted, Jin would have been reduced to barbarian status. Yet by establishing sincerity and demonstrating trust, his integrity pierced the heavens and shone like the sun. Though he perished, his name endured, still relied upon.

Yue Fei was ordered to suppress Yang Gong, with Zhang Jun as overseer. As the court issued a decree to recall troops for autumn defense, Jun summoned Fei, intending to wait until the following year to discuss the matter. Fei said: "The plan is already set. If the overseer can delay but a little, the rebels can be crushed in no more than eight days." Jun asked: "Why do you speak so lightly of this?" Fei replied: "When the imperial army attacks the water bandits, it is difficult, for I attack them with their own kind—it is easy. In water warfare, our strength is their weakness. To use our weakness against their strength is why it is difficult. But if we turn their generals against their soldiers, sever their limbs from their body, and cut off their heart’s support, leaving them isolated and scattered, then the imperial army can strike. Within eight days, all their chieftains will be captured." Jun agreed, and Fei proceeded to Dingzhou.

Previously, his troops were all from the northwest and unskilled in naval combat. Fei said: "Soldiers are not inherently limited; it is how they are used that matters." He sent envoys to persuade the bandits, and Huang Zuo came over. Fei said to Cun Zuo: "Do you know that by distinguishing between rebellion and loyalty, you can achieve merit and be enfeoffed? Such things are hardly worth mentioning." At this, Zuo persuaded Yang Qin to surrender. Fei rejoiced: "Yang Qin is fierce and valiant. Now that he has surrendered, the bandits’ heart is broken." He sent Qin back to the lake, where Qin further convinced Quan Zong and Liu Si to defect. Gong, however, remained defiant. He moored his boats on the lake, using waterwheels to propel them swiftly. The imperial ships that approached were shattered by his ramming poles. Fei had trees from Junshan felled to build massive rafts, blocking the ports and shallows. He then sent rotting wood and tangled grass floating downstream. At shallow points, he dispatched skilled provocateurs to taunt the bandits, cursing as they advanced. Enraged, the bandits pursued, only to find their boats entangled in the debris, their wheels immobilized. The imperial forces then struck swiftly. The bandits fled into the ports, only to be blocked by the rafts. The imperial troops, shielded by cowhide against arrows and stones, used massive logs to ram the bandit boats, destroying them all. Yao then plunged into the water and drowned.

Fei entered the bandit stronghold. The remaining chieftains, astonished, exclaimed: "What manner of spirit is this?" They all begged to surrender.

The victory dispatch arrived in just eight days. Jun exclaimed in delight: "Commander Yue is truly a divine strategist!" Earlier, Yao had boasted of his stronghold’s impregnability, declaring: "Only if Fei himself flies here could anyone breach my defenses." Now, people took his words as prophecy fulfilled.

The record states: While all praise Commander Yue’s divine calculations, I humbly suggest it was Fei’s self-assuredness that prevailed. He himself declared: "Wisdom, trustworthiness, benevolence, courage, and discipline—none may be lacking." Observe how he turned water bandits against water bandits: this was his wisdom. Victory in eight days as promised: this was his trustworthiness. Able to summon them at will and dismiss them without harm, winning their hearts: this was his benevolence. His bold claim—"Only if Fei himself flies here"—demonstrated his courage. Insisting the regional commander remain without delay, brooking no further debate: this was his discipline. Wisdom kept him from entrapment; trustworthiness ensured no deviation; benevolence spared lives; courage banished fear; discipline prevented confusion. Compared to the futile campaigns at Fuping and Fuli, those were but child’s play.

Yet when this man of peerless strategy later faced the deliberations of the high command, he was forced to act against his convictions—how much more so in other matters! This is cause for lament on Jun’s behalf, not reproach for Fei. Alas, how lamentable!

Yang Cunzhong was a man of loyalty and prudence. When Emperor Gaozong was still Prince Kang, establishing the Grand Marshal’s Headquarters, he placed his utmost trust in Cunzhong. At the time, the headquarters was newly formed, and Cunzhong guarded the imperial sleeping quarters day and night, never leaving his side even for a moment. After the court crossed the Yangtze and settled in the Jiang-Zhe region, Cunzhong, leading the Shengjie Army, followed Zhang Jun to defend Wumen. During the rebellion of Miao and Liu, he accompanied Jun to face the crisis and was promoted to Commander of the Imperial Guard, then to Commander of the Central Shenwu Army. Jun later sought to retain him in the military, but the Emperor said: "The imperial guard lacks a commander, and I have already made my choice—this cannot be altered." For twenty-five years, he served at the palace. When the Jin ruler Wanyan Liang harbored intentions of invading the south, Cunzhong submitted ten strategies for defense. The infantry commander Zhao Mi conspired to seize his authority, falsely accusing him of seeking glory and stirring trouble, and ultimately replaced him. Soon after, border tensions escalated daily, and the Emperor traveled to Jiankang, ordering Cunzhong to oversee the imperial guard and escort his retinue. He told his chief minister: "Yang Cunzhong obeys commands without hesitation—his loyalty is unmatched. He is my Guo Ziyi." He also said: "Among all the generals I favor, I have shown Cunzhong the deepest care, treating him more warmly than my own sons and brothers. When Zhao Mi replaced him, I could not sleep for three nights." Thus, he served the court for over forty years. Emperor Xiaozong later held him in even higher esteem, addressing him as "Prince" without using his name.

The chronicler notes: Observing the generals of the Restoration, Yue Fei was the most perilous, while Yang Cunzhong was the most steadfast. The perilous one was like surging waves and roaring thunder, yet never strayed from righteousness—thus, he is revered by later generations. The steadfast one was like a finger to an arm, an arm to a body, moving east or west only as commanded—thus, he brought comfort to his sovereign. Consider how Qin Hui executed Yue Fei without a word, yet when Zhao Mi replaced Cunzhong, the Emperor could not sleep. Here, the depth of the Emperor’s regard is revealed—not merely a matter of trust between ruler and subject.

From *Records of Illustrious Ministers of the August Ming*: The virtuous Minister Li Wenda was a man of loyalty, integrity, strictness, and discretion. In dealings with colleagues, he upheld harmony, valued trust, and even when opinions clashed, never lost his composure. When opportunity arose, he acted on his convictions—after the Three Yangs, none could match him. Emperor Yingzong favored him uniquely, and Emperor Xianzong, upon ascending the throne, trusted him even more deeply. Early on, he recommended Provincial Administrator Lu Yu for Minister of Justice. When Shi Heng endorsed the recommendation for personal gain, the Emperor delayed the audience, causing others to fear for Li. Yet when Lu Yu arrived and the edict for his appointment was drafted, colleagues suggested demoting him to Vice Minister. Li said: "I recommended him as Minister. To change it to Vice Minister would be a breach of my word." The Emperor ultimately appointed him as Minister. Later, Lu Yu proved highly capable, and the Emperor resumed their regular audiences.

Li also recommended Geng Jiujiu as Censor-in-Chief, who was soon promoted to Minister of Works. When Geng was sidelined by Shi Heng and the latter encroached on his authority, Geng feigned illness and resigned. Li repeatedly petitioned the Emperor to reinstate him. Nian Fu was falsely accused of rebellion by Shi Biao, but after Heng’s downfall, Li argued that Fu was worthy of high office and had him appointed Minister of Revenue. When a vacancy arose for Vice Minister of Rites, a court favorite sought Li’s recommendation. The Emperor asked: "What do you think of him?" Li replied: "I do not know the man. The one I know is Academician Li Shao." He added: "Recently, the scholar-official class has declined, with many currying favor for advancement. If we appoint based on merit and summon the Ministry of Personnel to issue a decree, perhaps the literati will take heed." At the time, Chief Minister Wang Ao was respected for his seniority, and Ma Xu for his dignified bearing—both were favored by the Emperor. Whenever Li made recommendations, he would first convey his intent: civil matters to Wang, military to Ma. When presenting candidates at court, after stating his opinion, he would always say: "This is my judgment, but it would be best to summon them for further review." In the end, both men’s assessments aligned with Li’s. Thus, the Emperor never doubted him, and all below trusted him.

The chronicler observes: During the reign of Emperor Yingzong, slanderers and malefactors thronged the court. Fortunately, Heaven’s will turned against disorder, and men like Cao Qin and Shi Heng proved intolerable to the throne. Thus, the sovereign reclaimed the authority they had usurped and wielded it anew. Lord Li, ever mindful of the Sweet Dew Incident and the calamities of factional proscription, refused to indulge in the reckless acts that prolong strife. Thereby, slanderous words found no purchase, trust deepened, and in time he fulfilled his role as chief minister in securing the realm’s peace.

Later generations, failing to learn from what has already come to pass, nor to guard against what is yet to be, rely solely on impassioned conduct, hoping to achieve the impossible. Not only do they forfeit trust, but they invite ruin. This is why readers must take heed.

Censor-in-Chief Han Yong was a man of penetrating insight and forthright candor, steadfast in loyalty and resolve, unafraid to act and unwavering in his duty. In the yiyou year of Chenghua (1465), the two Guang provinces remained unsettled. Han, together with Commander-in-Chief Zhao Fu, was dispatched to quell the unrest. The two men deferred to and trusted one another, deliberating in close counsel as if they were brothers or friends in private discourse.

Initially, they planned to divide the Jiangxi troops, sending them through Shouling into Guangdong, while the main force would advance from Huguang into Guangxi. Their reasoning was that if the rebels were in Guangdong, they should be driven out, and if in Guangxi, they should be encircled. Han disagreed: "This is not so. In ancient times, generals commanding troops beyond the frontier were granted full authority. If their actions could secure the state and benefit the realm, such discretion was justified. Armies may be concentrated for direct assault or divided for surprise maneuvers. Now, the two Guang provinces lie in ruins, and the rebels’ stronghold at Dafeng Gorge remains untouched. To pursue peripheral threats while neglecting the heart of the matter is no path to victory. If we advance with our forces intact, we may strike Dafeng to the south, reinforce Nanshao to the east, seize Liuqing to the west, and cut off Yangdong to the north. With all routes engaged, nothing will withstand us—why waste effort on mere pursuit?"

He further proposed luring the rebels from Xiuren, Lipu, Yao, and Kao, then striking them down, so that the remaining factions might be pacified without further labor. Han countered: "To issue an imperial decree and launch a punitive campaign, righteousness must prevail. To lure and then kill them would be a breach of trust and honor." Thus, he dispatched twenty-five patrols in all directions, while he, along with the eunuch overseer, the commander-in-chief, and Guangxi’s regional commander Ou Xin, led the central column in a coordinated assault.

Within a month, Xiuren and Lipu were pacified. The army then advanced to Dezhou, pressing forward with momentum. Han proclaimed the weight of the court’s authority and the inevitability of the rebels’ destruction. The troops responded with a thunderous cry, and in the end, the rebellion was crushed.

Han’s strategy was guided by adaptability as its core and strict rewards and punishments as its support. His impartiality and lack of self-interest ensured swift and decisive success.

The chronicler notes: As the *Tradition* states, "What Heaven aids is alignment; what men aid is trust. To walk in trust and attain alignment—this is the way to success." Thus, a man like Han Yong may well be counted among the heroes of his age.

*Hongdao Record*, Scroll 50 (concluded)

**Hongdao Record, Scroll 51: Trust**

**Trust Between Father and Son**

Mencius said: When all under Heaven rejoice and turn to one, to regard the world’s joy and allegiance as mere grass or dust—only Shun could do so.

One who fails to win the trust of his parents cannot be called a man. One who is not filial to his parents cannot be called a son.

The chronicler notes: Shun’s heart was steadfast in its conviction that his parents were utterly trustworthy, without the slightest doubt. Those who betray the bond between father and son do so because trust was lacking from the very beginning. Thus, when Emperor Xuanzong suspected Emperor Ruizong of plotting against him, the slander of Wang Ju later found purchase. When Emperor Suzong suspected Emperor Minghuang of winning the people’s favor, the schemes of Li Fuguo then took hold.

Liu Weng further expounded: Those ministers who murder their lords, or sons who murder their fathers, often begin by finding fault in them. Alas! What they first perceive becomes the seed of their later suspicion.

*The Shang Hymns* say:
Heaven commanded the dark bird,
Descending to give birth to Shang,
Dwelling in the vast land of Yin.
The ancient emperor commanded Wu Tang,
To rectify the four quarters.

*The Greater Odes* say:
At the beginning of the people’s birth,
There was Jiang Yuan.
How did she bear the people?
She was able to offer sacrifice and pray.
Having no child, she trod in the prints of the Lord’s steps and rejoiced.
There she conceived and rested,
Carrying the child in trembling care.
She bore and reared him,
And he became Hou Ji.

The chronicler notes: These are the founding ancestors of Shang and Zhou, recorded in the *Odes*—but can they truly be trusted? No. Poetry seeks to grasp the intent behind the words. Only with the virtue of a fitting match can there be the virtue of worthy descendants. This is the constant principle of Heaven and Earth, the supreme truth of human life.

In ancient times, when Gaoxin ruled all under Heaven, he bestowed benefits universally, not for his own sake, acting with awe in governance and trust in kindness. The emperor took four consorts: his first, a daughter of the Youhe clan, named Jiang Yuan, who bore Hou Ji; next, a daughter of the Chenfeng clan, named Qingdu, who bore Yao; then, a daughter of the Youe clan, named Jiandi, who bore Xie; and finally, a daughter of the Shenzi clan, named Changyi, who bore Zhi. Though Gaoxin possessed sagely virtue and his four consorts were his matches, the birth of his sagely sons was but the natural course of things. The auspicious sign of the dark bird and the marvel of treading in the Lord’s steps occurred by chance—not that there was no human agency, that a child was born merely from the hatching of an egg or the following of footprints.

Those who composed the *Odes* sought to craft fine words, so they added the phrase “Heaven’s command” and embellished the tale of Qi’s birth with details like the narrow lane, the frozen ice, and the calves of oxen and sheep shielding him. Such is the way of poetry—one must not let the words obscure the meaning. How could one take such accounts literally? To ascribe to the sagely Gaoxin as father and then burden the sages of all ages with fantastical and implausible tales is to miss the true purpose of the *Odes*. The fault lies in failing to grasp their original intent.

The Confucian scholar’s duty is to fathom principle. Even those who recite the *Three Hundred Odes* may not fully understand them—so why be surprised by the absurdities of Buddhism and Daoism? Consider the tales of the Buddha emerging from his mother’s side, filling the room with fragrance; Yi Yin born from a hollow mulberry; or Laozi born with white hair—such accounts, though recorded to convey truth, cannot go unexamined.

*The Spring and Autumn Annals* record: In the ninth month of the sixth year of Duke Huan of Lu, on the day *dingmao*, Zitong was born.

The chronicler notes: Since the lament of *Xiao Bian* arose, the way between father and son has been fractured. In composing the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, the Master was grieved by this. Thus, though the record concerns Lu, it was not for Lu’s sake alone. It was to express sorrow for Duke Huan’s misfortune that the birth was recorded with joy. How true this is in the end!

Yet the *Zuozhuan* states: Our Master’s intent in distinguishing suspicion and clarifying doubt reached its utmost here. Only after husband and wife are properly ordered can father and son be close. Duke Huan’s infatuation and Lady Wen Jiang’s transgressions were unheard of in all history. The *Annals* record the birth on the ninth month, *dingmao*, to reveal the truth. The *Odes* say, “Behold my nephew,” subtly indicating the matter. This was to guard against other claims. Duke Huan himself said, “Tong is not my son, but the son of the Marquis of Qi.” Thus, the text does not merely clarify the law of father and son, nor does it merely prevent the usurpation of legitimacy (as Hu Anguo’s commentary suggests). Rather, it was to condemn Duke Huan’s later misdeeds and resolve a doubt that had lingered for ages. In its concern for the teaching of the world, the *Annals* begins here with utmost urgency.

In the summer of the fifth year of Duke Xi of Lu, the duke met with the Marquis of Qi, the Duke of Song, the Marquis of Chen, the Marquis of Wei, the Earl of Zheng, the Baron of Xu, and the Earl of Cao at Shouzhi, along with the Crown Prince of Zhou. In the eighth month, the feudal lords swore an alliance at Shouzhi.

The chronicler notes: Why did the Zhou court move east? Why was King You killed at the foot of Mount Li? Why was the *Spring and Autumn Annals* composed? All stemmed from the instability of the crown prince. Once the foundation was shaken, disaster followed: the altars of the state were laid waste, the palaces overgrown with millet, the ruler himself slain—and still, they did not awaken. After one or two successions, there came the rebellion of Zi Ke, then the calamity of Zi Tui, and finally, the personal lesson of King Hui. Yet shortly after returning to the capital, the seeds of Shu Dai’s treachery sprouted. What was King Hui thinking?

Tracing the cause, it all arose from ignorance of the *Great Learning*’s way: delighting in what is not upright, becoming biased toward those one loves. If the self is not cultivated, the family cannot be ordered; if the family is not ordered, the state cannot be governed; if the state is not governed, all under Heaven cannot be at peace. Though King Hui was enlightened and trusted in others, in the end, he dared not announce the emperor’s death or mourn him, losing the bond between father and son.

The Rong tribes assaulted the royal capital, violating the bond of brotherhood; the Son of Heaven fled to reside in Zheng, abandoning the rites of lord and minister—all was provoked by King Hui’s own doing. Had it not been for Duke Huan and Guan Zhong, King Hui’s fate would have been scarcely distinguishable from that of King You, and where then would the Zhou have found refuge?

That our Master Confucius chose to record the affair at Xu was for the sake of the great plan of all under Heaven and myriad generations, not merely the fleeting seat of one man.

From the *Zuozhuan*: Ying Kaoshu was the warden of Yinggu. He presented a gift to the Duke, who bestowed food upon him. Kaoshu set aside the meat, and when the Duke inquired, he replied: “This humble one has a mother who has tasted all my food, yet never your lordship’s broth. I beg to offer it to her.” The Duke said, “You have a mother to whom you may give it, while I alone have none.” Kaoshu asked, “May I dare ask what you mean?” The Duke recounted the past and confessed his regret. Kaoshu replied, “Why does my lord trouble himself? If you dig down to the springs and meet in an underground passage, who would say it is not so?” The Duke followed his advice. Entering the tunnel, the Duke recited: “Within the great passage, joy flows as one.” Emerging, Lady Jiang recited: “Beyond the great passage, joy overflows in ease.” Thus, mother and son were restored as before. The noble man said: “Ying Kaoshu was pure in filial piety. Loving his mother, he extended it to Duke Zhuang.” As the *Poetry* says: “The filial son never fails, forever bestowing upon his kind.” This is what it means.

It is recorded: In my foolish view, Ying Kaoshu’s ability to illuminate great trust lay in this: the oath of a common man is shown in his sincerity, while the covenant of a noble man is bound by righteousness. Thus, a single word dispelled Duke Zhuang’s confusion.

Some say: Regret lies between trust and doubt. Without regret, one cannot guide another by what they already understand.

The mother of Ji You was a daughter of Duke Huan of Chen, favored and cherished by Duke Huan of Lu. When Ji You was about to be born, the Duke sent someone to divine his fate, who said: “A son, his name shall be You. At the Duke’s right hand, he will consult the two altars and serve as the state’s pillar. If the Ji clan perishes, Lu will not prosper.” They also cast milfoil, encountering *Great Possession* under *Qian*, and said: “The Zhou returns to the father, reverent as the lord’s command.” At birth, there was a mark on his hand reading “You,” so he was named thus and styled Chengji.

It is recorded: In my foolish view, Ji You’s birth was Heaven’s way of suppressing chaos, not merely for Duke Huan’s sake. For Duke Huan and Duke Zhuang failed as rulers, Duke Wen and Duke Ai failed as wives, the repeated assassinations of Duke Ban and Duke Min, and the prolonged rebellion of the two Shus—Lu had ceased to be Lu, teetering on the brink. Had no worthy man been born in its midst, would the sacrifices to the Duke of Zhou not have fallen? The mark on his hand was a sign from his palm. Heaven’s intent seemed to say: “Those who befriend shall prosper; those who do not shall perish.” To succeed Duke Ban and Duke Min was the Way of friendship. Otherwise, Ji You was but the descendant of a licentious man—what virtue did he hold before Heaven? His enthronement of Duke Xi stabilized Lu, averting disaster and preserving the state.

Divination and milfoil omens run deep indeed.

When Cheng Feng heard of Chengji’s peril, she served him and entrusted Duke Xi to his care. Thus, Chengji established him.

It is recorded: Was Duke Xi’s enthronement the work of man or of Heaven? It was Heaven. The calamity of Peng Sheng was brought about by Wen Jiang—this was the first severance by Heaven. The arrival of Ai Jiang was abhorred by the ancestral temples—this was the second. Then came Meng Ren’s elopement, followed immediately by the strife of the stableman Luo—this was the third. The enthronement of Zikai was met with the usurpation of the divined fields—this was the fourth. That the Feng clan succeeded the Jiang clan in producing an heir was like the Bo clan succeeding the Lü clan in assuming the throne. Was this not truly Heaven’s doing?

Xi Qi and Zhuo Zi were the sons of Li Ji. Xun Xi was their guardian. As Duke Xian neared his end, he said to Xi: “What must a man be to be called trustworthy?” Xi replied: “If the dead could return to life and the living feel no shame, then his words may be called trustworthy.” The Duke approved.

After the Duke’s death, Xi Qi was enthroned. Li Ke said to Xi: “The lord killed the rightful heir and enthroned the unrightful. What is to be done? I wish to deliberate with you.” Xi replied: “The lord once questioned me. I answered: ‘If the dead could return to life and the living feel no shame, then his words may be called trustworthy.’” Li Ke knew he could not be swayed. Retreating, he assassinated Xi Qi, then Xi. Xi remained loyal to the end.

The noble man said: “Xun Xi may be said to have not broken his word.”

It is recorded: Weili was trustworthy, yet he secretly met a woman—this was not upright. Why then does the noble man praise Xun Xi? In praising Xun Xi, he condemns Li Ke all the more. For Ke’s transmission to Shensheng was rightful in name and principle, unlike Xi’s transmission to Xi Qi. A single word from You Shi struck the mark, yet how vastly different was it from “the dead returning to life and the living feeling no shame”? Had Ke upheld righteousness without wavering, he might have saved Shensheng from disaster—this would have been best. Or, had he remained unwavering unto death, perishing alongside the crown prince, that would have been next. Yet he not only yielded to his desires but also masked his face, assassinating one lord at dawn and another at dusk. Of such a man as Ke, I know not why Duke Hui did not clearly punish his crime, instead using the pretext of deposition and enthronement. What then was the state of Jin’s laws and governance? Thus, the Master repeatedly condemned Duke Hui. In condemning Duke Hui, was it not also for Li Ke’s sake?

The Lord Wen of Zheng had a lowly concubine named Yan Gu, who dreamed that a celestial messenger gave her an orchid, saying: “I am Bo Tiao, your ancestor. Take this as your son, for the orchid bears the fragrance of the state.” Such was the allure that captivated all who beheld it. Later, Lord Wen saw her, presented her with the orchid, and lay with her. She declined, saying: “This handmaid is unworthy. Should I bear a child by fortune, none would believe it. Dare I ask for the orchid as proof?” The lord replied: “Very well.” She gave birth to Duke Mu, whom she named Lan.

It is recorded: Mencius said, “The Son of Heaven may recommend a man to Heaven, yet cannot make Heaven grant him the realm. The feudal lords may recommend a man to the Son of Heaven, yet cannot make the Son of Heaven grant him a state.” When Zihua was established as crown prince, he had already received Heaven’s mandate, pledged as hostage among the feudal lords, and Zheng’s succession was firmly settled. The birth of Zilan was met with doubt and uncertainty, let alone the multitude of other princes. Yet through Zheng’s internal strife, he was slain, leading to a tumult of exiles and pursuits—the flight of Zizang, the poisoning of Zishi, the early deaths of Zixia and Ziyu without heirs. Only then did Shigui’s counsel prevail, the plans of the three Kongs take hold, and the great covenant of the high ministers secure the flourishing of the Ling and Xiang lineages for generations. Was this not Heaven’s doing? Though later omens like the blue dragon coiled upon the belly differed in form, alas, Lan—was he not fragrant as the orchid, was he not Heaven’s chosen?

King Gong of Chu had no principal heir but five favored sons. Unsure whom to appoint, he performed grand rites at the altars of the land and grain, praying: “Let the spirits choose among these five to rule the state.” He then wrapped a jade disk in cloth and presented it at the altars, declaring: “Whoever bows directly over the disk shall be Heaven’s chosen. Who would dare defy this?” Secretly, he and Lady Ba buried the disk in the courtyard of the great chamber, then had the five sons enter in purification to bow. King Kang stepped over it, King Ling placed his elbow upon it, while Zigan and Zhezhe kept their distance. Prince Ping, being young, was carried in; he bowed twice, pressing down upon the clasp. Dou Weigui and others affirmed this as Cheng Ran’s doing.

It is recorded: Observing King Gong’s actions, I cannot but sigh. A father betrays his sons, trusting not himself but spirits, choosing not men but ghosts, eschewing open and evident deeds for covert and inscrutable schemes. Yao and Shun received Heaven’s mandate through their conduct, not through signs. Never have I heard of one pressing down upon a disk’s clasp to claim it. What role did Lady Ba play? Her love and aversion were surely embedded in the burial of the disk. That some bowed rightly and others did not—was this not a lesson in usurpation? Where there are usurpers above, there will be those who aid them below. This is how Chu became Chu, and why the five sons ultimately rose and fell through regicide. Who, then, was truly Heaven’s chosen?

Lady Jiang, wife of Duke Xiang of Wei, bore no sons. A palace woman, Chou Shi, gave birth to Meng Zhi. Kong Chengzi dreamed that Kang Shu said to him: “Establish Yuan. I have sent Ji’s grandson Yu and the scribe Gou to assist him.” Scribe Zhao also dreamed of this, and their visions aligned. In the year when Han Kangzi of Jin visited the feudal lords, Chou Shi bore a son, whom she named Yuan. Meng Zhi’s feet were weak, and he walked with difficulty. Kong Chengzi divined for him, saying: “Yuan shall enjoy the state of Wei and preside over its altars.” He showed this to Scribe Zhao, who said: “If Yuan is to enjoy it, what doubt remains?” Chengzi asked: “Does this not refer to the eldest?” Zhao replied: “Kang Shu named him—can he not be called eldest? Meng is no true son; he will not be listed in the ancestral temple and cannot be called eldest. Moreover, the oracle says: ‘Benefit in establishing a lord.’ The divination aligns with the dream, as used by King Wu. Though his feet are weak, he shall reside as lord, preside over the altars, oversee sacrifices, govern the people, serve the spirits, and attend court assemblies. Each shall act according to what benefits him—is this not fitting?” Thus, Kong Chengzi established Duke Ling.

It is recorded: Observing the blessings of virtue and the calamities of vice, Heaven’s Way has never failed. Amid the chaos of Xuan Jiang and the infirmity of Meng Xi, Heaven had surely revoked Wei’s heir. Yet Kang Shu’s sacrifices could not be abandoned, nor the transmission of the Ji virtue erased. Even without the dream of the yielding clasp or Scribe Zhao’s divination, could the enthronement of Ziyuan have been averted? Yet without proof, there is no trust, and without trust, the people will not follow. Wei’s ministers were truly followers of goodness. In the end, Gong Meng was content in his place, not resentful of not being eldest, and Duke Ling benefited as lord, not deprived for being a younger son. Was this not why the Master, in recording Duke Xiang of Wei’s death, also praised him? Otherwise, the ensuing chaos would have far exceeded what has been recounted.

The Master said: “How filial was Min Ziqian! No one could find fault with his father, mother, brothers, or kin.”

It is recorded: In praising Ziqian’s filiality, the Master necessarily grounded it in his parents and brothers, for Ziqian’s mother was like Shun’s mother, and his younger brother like Shun’s brother. If a father is kind but a mother unkind, people will fault the mother; if an elder brother is loving but a younger brother unkind, people will fault the younger brother. This is why Shun’s mother could not escape resentment, and his brother Xiang could not escape arrogance. Ziqian, with utmost kindness and sincerity, guided them with sorrowful words and actions. Thus, his father abandoned his intent to expel his mother, his mother relinquished her resentment, and the three sons each adhered to their kin. Only then did Ziqian escape others’ reproach. This was the practical conduct of the Confucian school, not something that can be refuted.

The *Book of Han* states: Emperor Gaozu’s surname was Liu. His father was called the Grand Duke, and his mother, Madam Liu. Long ago, Madam Liu once rested by the embankment of a great marsh. She dreamed of encountering a spirit. At that moment, thunder and lightning darkened the sky. The Grand Duke went to look and saw two dragons intertwined above her. Soon after, she conceived and gave birth to Gaozu.

High Ancestor was a man of towering brow and noble visage, with a beard and left-leaning thigh, bearing seventy-two black moles. He was broad in virtue and love for others, his spirit expansive and unconstrained.

High Ancestor once resided in Xianyang, gazing upon the First Emperor of Qin in solemn admiration. He sighed deeply and declared, *"A true man should be like this!"*

The *Record* states: *"The interplay of yin and yang is called the Dao. The Dao cannot be pushed to its extreme, for extremes inevitably reverse."* The flourishing of the Three Dynasties reached its zenith when the capital was established at Zheng and Luoyi, with the imperial domain at its grandest—thus the yang principle was pushed to its limit, fulfilling the warning of *"The overbearing dragon meets regret."* Hence arose the upheaval of the Zhou relocation.

The rise of the Five Hegemons reached its peak when the Jin was divided among three families and the Six States formed alliances—thus the yin principle was pushed to its limit, fulfilling the omen of *"The dragon battles in the wild."* Hence arose the calamity of Qin’s unification.

When both yin and yang were exhausted, the Dao of Heaven and Earth faltered gravely, giving rise to monstrous omens: chickens with the souls of ostriches, horses with horns—all signs of the debased replacing the noble, the insignificant displacing the great. Heaven and Earth’s intent, rather than bestowing blessings upon the exalted, prefers to entrust them to common folk. Even the Grand Duke and Madam Liu’s encounter with the divine, marked by thunder and darkness, was no grander than the traces of a giant or the auspicious phoenix—thus the Mandate of Heaven for Han was confirmed.

Bao Ji, the mother of Emperor Wen, was once young and loved by Guan’s wife, Zhao Ziren. They swore: *"Whoever rises in fortune first shall not forget the other."* Later, Guan’s wife, Zhao Ziren, was favored by Han Ruler first. In the fourth year of Han Ruler’s reign, while he sat upon the platform at Gaoling in Henan, these two beauties served him and laughed at Bao Ji’s earlier vow. Han Ruler inquired, and they truthfully reported it. His heart ached with pity for Bao Ji.

That day, he summoned her, intending to take her as consort. She replied, *"Last night, I dreamed of a black dragon pressing upon my chest."* The Emperor said, *"This is an omen of noble fortune. I shall fulfill it for you."* Thus she conceived and bore Emperor Wen within a year.

The *Record* states: *"Madam Liu’s dream was the Heaven-ordained sign of a new age. Bao Ji’s dream was the symbol of one who would aid the world and its people."* The rise and fall of the Qin and Han dynasties, from Madam Liu to Bao Ji, marked the beginning and end of an era. Thus, each bore Heaven’s appointed omens.

As the *Odes* say:
*"Bright and resplendent below, radiant and awe-inspiring above—
Heaven’s will is not to be trifled with.
If one takes it lightly, it becomes a curse;
If one cherishes it, it becomes a blessing.
How could it not be the blood of hidden enmity,
The flesh of rival contention?"*

When Hun Douyi served as Prefect of Jingzhao, a man arrived, riding a yellow ox-drawn chariot, bearing a yellow canopy, clad in yellow robes and a yellow hat, claiming to be the Crown Prince of Wei. The public carriages reported this, and Douyi summoned officials, generals, and high-ranking officials to examine him. Tens of thousands in Chang’an gathered to watch. Neither the Chancellor, Grand Scribe, nor the high officials dared speak. Douyi said, *"Gentlemen, what fear do you have of the Wei Crown Prince? In the past, when he rebelled against the Emperor’s command and fled, he was resisted and not received. Now that he has come himself, guilty of treason, he should be punished."* He had the man sent to the imperial prison, where the Grand Prosecutor interrogated and exposed his deceit. Originally from Xianyang, he was named Cheng Fangsu, a fortune-teller by trade. A former servant of the Crown Prince had once consulted him, saying, *"Your appearance resembles the Wei Crown Prince."* Fangsu, coveting wealth and rank, falsely claimed the title to gain favor. After Douyi’s handling of this case, Zhao Guanghan also served as Prefect of Jingzhao and remarked, *"In detecting deceit and suppressing evil, I may have some skill, but in deciding matters of state, I fall far short of Douyi."*

The *Record* states: *"During the Tang Dynasty under Emperor Dezong, there was one who falsely claimed to be the mother of the Emperor, St. Shen, similar to this case, both convicted of fraud."* Only during the Song Dynasty under Emperor Gaozong was there one who falsely claimed to be Princess Yongfu. The Emperor accepted her without doubt, showering her with favor beyond measure. Though later exposed by Empress Wei and allowed to flee, he did not seek punishment—thus the Emperor’s regret was profound. This case of Cheng Fangsu’s treachery could not have been better handled than by Douyi.

Yu Dingguo’s father, Yu Gong, served as a county clerk and adjudicated cases with strict adherence to law, never harboring resentment. In the Lake region, there was a孝妇 (filial widow) who diligently cared for her mother-in-law. The mother-in-law, pitying her youth and childlessness, wished to remarry her, but she refused. The mother-in-law, burdened by her, hanged herself in despair. The mother-in-law’s daughter reported the matter to the authorities, and the filial widow confessed under interrogation. The case was submitted to the prefecture, but Yu Gong contested it, failing to overturn the verdict. The widow was executed, and the region suffered three years of drought. Later, when a new governor arrived, he consulted omens about the cause. Yu Gong said, *"Do not consult omens. The blame lies here."* The governor then sacrificed an ox at the widow’s grave, erected a tablet, and prayed for rain. Heaven answered with a great downpour, and the region revered Yu Gong, erecting a shrine in his honor.

Dingguo studied law under his father and also served as a clerk, later promoted to Lin Gao. When he became Grand Prosecutor, he was deeply trusted. He adjudicated cases with mercy, favoring the weak and elderly, and applied the principle of *"doubt in guilt, acquit."* He was renowned for his meticulous care. The court praised him: *"When Zhang Shizhi was Grand Prosecutor, there were no wronged subjects in the land. When Yu Dingguo was Grand Prosecutor, the people themselves felt no wrong."* From Yu Gong’s humble beginnings—when his gate collapsed and neighbors offered to repair it, he insisted it be made grand enough *"to hold a four-horse chariot and high canopy"*—he declared, *"I have often done hidden good in my judgments. My descendants will surely prosper."* Indeed, Dingguo became Chancellor, and his son, Yu Yong, served as Grand Scribe, receiving a hereditary marquisate.

To this day, people regard his words as trustworthy.

The *Record* states:
*"Zhang Shizhi’s ‘no wronged subjects’—this was Emperor Wen’s virtue.
Yu Dingguo’s ‘people felt no wrong’—this was Emperor Xuan’s wisdom.
His saying, ‘Hidden virtue ensures prosperity for descendants,’ was also the fate bestowed by the sovereign and ministers.
Those who observe should believe these accounts.*

*The Book of Later Han* records: *Mao Yi of Lujiang, in his youth, endured hardship with strict integrity and was renowned for his filial piety. Zhang Feng of Nanyang, hearing of his reputation, went to visit him. After sitting down, an official summons arrived appointing Yi as the Magistrate of Anyang. Yi took the writ and left, his face beaming with joy. Zhang Feng, who prized scholarly virtue, secretly despised this and regretted his visit, firmly declining to stay.

When Yi’s mother died, he resigned his post and observed mourning rites. Neither the government nor the public offices sent invitations. Zhang Feng then sighed, saying: *"The virtuous cannot be emulated. My earlier joy was for my own sake, bending to my parents’ will."*

Xie Bao of Samnan was studious and upright, and his filial devotion to his mother was widely known. When his father remarried and sent him away, Bao wept day and night, refusing to leave. He was beaten with a whip until, reluctantly, he built a hut outside his home. Each morning, he entered to sweep the stepmother’s quarters, but his father, enraged, drove him out again. He then built a hut at the village gate, attending to his duties without pause for over a year, until his parents, moved by his sincerity, took him back.

The *Record* states:
*"History says of these two sons that they acted from utmost sincerity, their hearts true, and thus could move others. Only then could they achieve renown in later ages and receive honors in their time. This is what it means to honor one’s parents."*

The *Record* continues:
*Lu Ji, when accused of conspiracy with King Ying of Chu, was imprisoned in the capital. His mother, traveling from Wu, arrived to visit him, but the guards barred her entry. She prepared food for him, and Ji, seeing it, wept bitterly. The guards, hearing his sorrow, asked why. Ji replied: *"My mother cuts meat always in squares, and chops scallions by the inch. The soup she sends is unlike any other—only she could prepare it this way. That is how I know."*

Cai Shun, orphaned young, was known for his filial care of his mother. Once, while gathering firewood, a guest arrived unexpectedly. His mother, seeing him delayed, bit her finger to summon him. Cai Shun, feeling the pain, rushed home and knelt, asking the reason. She said: *"A pressing guest has come—I bit my finger to awaken you."*

The *Record* states:
*"I observe how Lu’s mother prepared the meal and how Cai’s mother bit her finger—these acts prove the depth of natural filial trust. What is prized in the *Zhongyong* and shared by all is this: what is prized, one does not hesitate even for a meal’s time to disobey one’s parents; what is shared, one does not dare forget one’s mother even in a single step. Unlike others, who wait for trust to be earned before believing."*

*End of Volume Fifty-One of the *Principles of the Way Record*.
*Volume Fifty-Two: Faith—Parent-Child Trust.*

《Book of Tang》 records that the Great Sage Emperor of File and Martial Virtue, **Taizong** (posthumous title), whose personal name was **Shìmín** (世民), was the second son of **Gāozǔ** (高祖). His mother was **Empress Taimu** (太穆皇后, **Dòu Shì** 窦氏), born on the **wùwǔ** (戍午) day of the twelfth month in the **Kāihuáng** (开皇) seventeenth year of the **Sui Dynasty** (隋), at the **Biéguǎn** (别馆) of **Wǔgōng** (武功).

When he was just four years old, a scholar came to pay respects to **Gāozǔ** and said: *"You are a noble man."* Then, seeing **Taizong**, he declared: *"This one bears the bearing of a dragon and phoenix, the mark of heaven’s favor."* He added: *"When he reaches twenty years of age, he will surely be able to save the world and bring peace to the people."* **Gāozǔ**, taking these words to heart, named him **Shìmín**.

The *Record* states:
*"Mencius said: 'In five hundred years, there will surely arise a kingly sage, and among them will be one who is renowned in the world.' From the Han High Emperor (汉高) to the Tang, over five hundred years have passed. In between, there were the **Jìn** (晋), **Sòng** (宋), **Qí** (齐), **Liáng** (梁), and **Chén** (陈) dynasties, where usurpers and regicides numbered six or seven. Their courts lasted no more than a century, and the empire was plagued by chaos. Only the **Sui Dynasty** (隋) could unify it, yet it too began with usurpation and ended with usurpation. The **Tang Emperor’s** (皇矣) wisdom sought to avoid such fate repeatedly. This prophecy of saving the world and bringing peace was indeed trustworthy—it did not rely on the testimony of strangers, but was grounded in the natural order of **dharma** (理数)."

In the **Zhēnguàn** (贞观) seventeenth year, the Emperor decreed that **Lángsūn Wújì** (长孙无忌), **Fáng Xuánlíng** (房玄龄), **Lǐ Jì** (李绩), and **Chǔ Suìliáng** (褚遂良) draft a plan to designate **Jìnwáng Zhì** (晋王治) as the **imperial heir** (皇太子). At that time, a flock of flying pheasants numbering over ten gathered in the palace. The Emperor asked: *"What is this auspicious sign?"* **Suìliáng** replied: *"In the time of the Duke of Jin (晋文公), there was a **zhènzǐ** (振子) that transformed into a pheasant. The female cried at **Chéncāng** (陈仓), the male cried at **Nányáng** (南阳). The **zhènzǐ** said: 'He who obtains the male shall become king, he who obtains the female shall become a hegemon.' The Duke of Jin then sought the male among the feudal lords and established the **Bǎoxī** (宝鸡) shrine. Emperor Guangwu of the Han (汉光武) obtained the male, rose from **Nányáng**, and ruled over the Four Seas. Your Majesty was originally enfeoffed in **Qín** (秦), hence the appearance of both male and female pheasants—this is to proclaim Your Majesty’s enlightened **virtue** (德)."* The Emperor rejoiced and said: *"A person’s establishment in life cannot be without learning."* **Suìliáng** was indeed the kind of **scholar-official** (君子) who possessed broad knowledge.

The Emperor then appointed **Suìliáng** as **Tàizǐ Bīnkè** (太子宾客).

The *Record* states:
*"**Suìliáng** surely knew that **Jìnwáng Zhì**’s childhood name was **Jīnúnú** (雉奴). The gathering of flying pheasants was an omen for the **imperial heir** (太子). **Jìnwáng Zhì**, whose name was **Zhì**, had the childhood name **Jīnúnú** (雉奴)—how could he have been referring to **Qín** (秦) and Your Majesty’s enlightened **virtue** (德)? This was **heaven’s** (天) confirmation of trust, not requiring repeated commands to be believed.*

During the reign of **Empress Wu** (天后), **Emperor Ruizong** (睿宗) was the **imperial heir** (皇嗣). The ministers and officials rarely dared to hope for another audience, but **Tàicháng Gōngrén ān Jīnzàng** (太常工人安金藏), a **craftsman** (工人) under the **Tàicháng** (太常) office, managed to gain access. Soon after, a false accusation of treasonous plotting against the **imperial heir** arose. The Empress ordered **Lái Jiùnbīn** (来俊臣) to interrogate him, but the officials feared the **cruel tortures** (酷焰) and wished to extract a confession. **Jīnzàng** cried out loudly: *"You do not believe my words! Let me cut open my heart to prove that the **imperial heir** (皇嗣) has no treasonous intent!"* He drew his dagger and stabbed his abdomen, spilling his intestines onto the ground before collapsing in a faint. The Empress, hearing of this, was deeply shocked and had him carried to the **imperial palace** (禁中). The physicians stitched his intestines back inside, and he was supported with **mulberry paper** (桑楮) until evening, when he recovered. She then personally visited him, sighed, and said: *"I have sons who cannot prove their innocence, but none like your loyalty."* She immediately ordered the case to be dismissed, and **Ruizong** was spared. At that time, the officials of the court all praised him, saying none could surpass his loyalty.

During the **Jǐngyún** (景云) era, **Emperor Xuanzong** (玄宗) entrusted his affairs to the **historians** (史官) and ordered his name inscribed on the **Tàihuá Èrshān Bēi** (太华二山碑), a monument of honor. He was ultimately enshrined in the **temple courtyard** (庙庭) of **Ruizong**.

The *Record* states:
*"**Ān Jīnzàng** (安金藏) and **Léi Hǎiqīng** (雷海清) were both **craftsmen** (工人). One could uphold the profound **parent-child trust** (父子之信) even in the face of **severe tortures** (酷焰炎灼), while the other could endure the **agonizing pain of loyalty** (君臣之至痛) amid **tyrannical oppression** (凶虐滔天). To them, facing death was like returning home—this was their natural disposition."*

The **Dao** was severed yet revived, torn yet restored—his name carved upon the **Qín Huá** (秦华) monument, his honor enshrined in the imperial ancestral temple. Such deeds are rare in history, ancient or modern.

The *Song History* records:
**"Emperor Taizu** of the Song (宋太祖), surnamed **Zhào** (赵), given name **Kuāngyìn** (匡胤), had a father named **Hóngyìn** (弘殷), who held the titles of **Duke of Zhōu** (周检校司徒) and **Defense Commissioner of Yuè Prefecture** (岳州防御使). His mother, **Lady Dù** (杜氏), gave birth to Taizu in **Luòyáng’s Jiāmǎ Yíng** (洛阳夹马营). A crimson radiance filled the tent, and an unearthly fragrance lingered for days—men called him the **Fragrant Child** (香孩儿).

From the year **Emperor Míngzōng** of **Pòu Táng** (后唐明宗) ascended the throne, he would nightly burn incense in the palace and pray to Heaven: *'I, a mere Hu barbarian, seized power through chaos. I pray the Celestial will soon send a sage to rule as the people’s true sovereign.'* The following year, on a **Dīnghài** (丁亥) day, Taizu was born—fulfilling the prophecy.

As he grew, his bearing was majestic, his demeanor open and commanding. The wise knew he was no ordinary man.

The *Record* states:
According to the *History of the Five Dynasties*, when **moral order decayed** and **human bonds collapsed**, the very principle of **parental affection** was inverted—**arms rose against kin**, and **foreigners were adopted as sons**. In the fifty years spanning the **Kāipíng Xiǎndé** (开平显德) era, the **Five Dynasties** ruled China, yet truly eight lineages held sway, three of them rising from **beggars’ cradles**. Alas, how far had civilization fallen!

Yet Heaven, in its providence, bestowed upon the **Song Founder** a birth marked by omens, a mandate sealed in signs—**unplanned yet undeniable**, **self-evident in its truth**. Before this, **Emperor Shìzōng of Dà Dào** (后周世宗) once found in a document pouch a wooden tablet over three *chǐ* long, inscribed: *'Inspect and govern as the Son of Heaven.'* When the **Chénqiáo Uprising** (陈桥兵变) unfolded, he sent **Cǔ Zhāo Fú** (楚昭辅) to comfort his family in **Biànlǐng** (汴梁), who returned with the message: *'The Inspecting Officer has already ascended the throne.'* **Empress Dowager Dù** (杜太后) heard this and said: *'My son has always harbored grand ambitions—now they have come to pass.'*

The *Record* states:
Men wrongly took the Empress Dowager’s words as proof that Taizu had secretly harbored treasonous intent. How could this be? The **Inspecting Officer’s** destiny was already whispered throughout the empire long before—only now did she confirm its truth. Unlike **Emperor Táng Tàizōng**, who, when pressed, sighed: *'Today, I lose my family and life because of you. Tomorrow, I transform my house into a realm—also because of you.'* Thus, the Empress Dowager’s joy was grounded in evidence, while **Emperor Táng’s** words carried the weight of **coercion and brilliance**.

When the Empress Dowager fell ill, she urgently asked Taizu: *'Do you know how you came to possess the realm?'* Taizu, choked with emotion, could not answer. She pressed him again, and he replied: *'I, your subject, owe this realm to the accumulated blessings of my ancestors and Your Majesty.'* The Empress Dowager shook her head: *'No. It was because **Emperor Shìzōng of Dà Dào** entrusted the empire to a child that you now stand here. After your hundredth year, you must pass the throne to your younger brothers, **Guāngyì** (光义) and **Guāngměi** (光美), down to **Dé Zhāo** (德昭). A kingdom with a rightful heir is the nation’s greatest fortune.'* Taizu bowed his head to the ground: *'I dare not disobey.'* There, at her deathbed, he swore an oath, which she sealed with her imperial signet and entrusted to a **golden casket**, kept by the most trusted palace attendants.

The *Record* states:
The Empress Dowager’s single utterance thus bequeathed **two generations of peace**. Had such an oath been made in **early Táng**, how could the **Jīnyìng Palace massacre** (玄武门之变) have ever occurred?

Alas, petty men, driven by **greed and fear**, have distorted this **greatest of just principles**, omitting **Guāngměi and Dé Zhāo’s** rightful succession from the **veritable records**, consigning it instead to **frivolous tales**. Hence, the *Record* also omits **Zhào Pǔ** (赵普), for the deeds of the virtuous are beyond the comprehension of the common man.

When **Emperor Yīngzōng** (英宗) first ascended the throne, the **Empress Dowager** (皇太后) ruled alongside him. When the two palaces fell into discord, **Yáo Yù** (尧愈) dared to speak out, and the eunuchs **Rèn Shǒuzhōng** (任守忠) and others slandered him. Yáo Yù then submitted a memorial: *'The most trustworthy deeds in the world are: to entrust the realm to another, and to receive the realm from another. Today, the court needs only to purge these slanderers, and the voices of filial piety and loyalty will resound across the land.'* Thus, the eunuchs were banished, and the Empress Dowager restored full authority—mother and son once more in harmony.

The *Record* states:
