**Yáo Yù’s** words were bold, and all at the time recognized their truth;
**The memorial’s** intent was subtle, yet few grasped its depth.
For discord arose from slander, slander from suspicion, suspicion from distrust—beginning with **trifling doubts**, ending with the **abandonment of the greatest grace**. Some may shatter a **thousand-gold ingot** yet cling to a **broken cauldron’s suspicion**. Only those of **golden and jade character** can speak and be believed.

Let the discerning examine this closely.

「Sun Chuan was a man of steadfast faith and strict adherence to law. He once addressed the throne, saying: *"The ancestral policies benefit the people; blood and law ensure the nation’s welfare. Since the reign of Emperor Shenzong, these policies have favored the wicked."* These were considered sound arguments at the time.

Later, when Emperor Qinzong sought refuge in the Jin camp, he left the Prince of Zhi (太子) to Sun Chuan as the acting regent (留守), also entrusting him with the office of Minor Transmission (少传). The Jin demanded the Prince again, but Sun Chuan refused to send him, secretly plotting to conceal him. Instead, he ordered the execution of men resembling the Prince in appearance, sending their heads to the Jin camp with the claim: *"The eunuchs sought to steal the Prince and deliver him to the military camp. The people of the capital resisted and killed them, mistakenly harming the Prince. Thus, the military has been dispatched to quell this rebellion and present the head."* If this was not enough, he added: *"If they persist, I will follow with my own death."* After five days, no one dared to take up the matter. Fu Bi, bearing the grief of the Prince’s death, declared: *"I am the Prince’s attendant; by duty, I must die with him."* Lu Shu, though not summoned by the Jin, said: *"I will go with him."* At the time, Sun Chuan was staying in the Imperial City (皇城司), and his son came to visit. He scolded him, saying: *"If you had not come, I would have already divided my death with the country to preserve my integrity. Your coming serves no purpose."* He waved his son away urgently. The son wept, saying: *"Your honor has sacrificed your life for the country; what more is there to say?"* Sun Chuan then entrusted the regency to Wang Shiyong and departed.

The *Record* states:
*"Many officials faced death in this crisis, yet only one dared to stand alone—Fu Bi. Fortunately, the Prince of Kang (康王) remained. If Heaven does not abandon us, the Song will not perish. However, since no one dared to take up the matter, Heaven’s revulsion against deceit and treachery has reached its limit. If the old ways were discarded and new ones established to revive the legacy of the Founding Ancestor (艺祖), then the succession of the rebellious (绍迷) would be extinguished. With the rebellious succession diminished, the policies favoring the wicked would also cease."*

Empress Dowager Wei, originally the Consort of Virtue (贤妃), accompanied the Emperor Huizong (上皇) on his northern migration. In the early years of Emperor Gaozong’s reign (建炎初), she was pressured to be honored as the Empress Dowager of Emperor Qinzong (宣和皇后), later elevated to the title of Grand Empress Dowager (皇太后). The Emperor once wept and instructed his ministers, saying: *"The Grand Empress Dowager’s years are advanced; I cannot rest without thinking of her. I have the realm, yet I cannot provide for my own kin. You must swear in earnest: if I return the Grand Empress Dowager to you, I will not be ashamed of reconciliation. If not, I will not hesitate to use force."* Just then, the Jin sent Xiao Yi (萧毅) to negotiate peace, and the Emperor again spoke to him, saying: *"If the Grand Empress Dowager truly returns, I will strictly uphold the oath. If she does not, even with an oath, it is but empty words."* When he ordered He Zhi (何铸) and Cao Xun (曹勋) to express gratitude, he summoned them to the inner palace and said: *"Gazing northward toward my home, I have no tears left to shed. When you see the Jin ruler, tell him: ‘My maternal kin in the northern realm are but an old man. In my own realm, they hold great weight. Speak to him with utmost sincerity, and perhaps he will be moved.’"* He Zhi and the others repeatedly pleaded in the Jin court, and the Jin ruler finally agreed.

The *Record* states:
*"The Emperor’s true intentions were fully revealed here. Though he demanded the return of the two Saints (二圣) and the recovery of the Central Plains (中原) with countless words, it all boiled down to one principle. Why? Because love is singular, gain and loss are twofold, and benefit and harm are threefold. These three things stem from his heart, and no one can alter them. Men see only that their fathers begot them, yet they do not know that thirty-one persons share the same fate as one child and one mother—who is closer? And if one loses the warm affection of a parent or elder, though their flesh may still be connected, how deeply does it cut? If the father and elder still lived, they would merely hold the title of king. Compared to the Father Heaven and Mother Earth, who grasp the *Dao* (乾) and tread the *Qi* (坤), whose subjects number countless myriads and whose commands sway the armies of the world—who is more worthy? The capital’s recovery is but a return to the south. Compared to laughing in defiance of mountains and lakes, free from peril and obstruction, where the southerners remain in the south and the northerners in the north—who gains more? Even if the kin are as close as enemies, they will not be spared. This is because they lack the singular loyalty that all others share. This is the Emperor’s true heart, clear as a mirror. How could anyone take it from him?*

*Thus, the virtuous value the expansion of the Four Cardinal Virtues (四端)—do not allow any one of them to be obscured. And they say: *If one can fully embody them, it is enough to preserve the Four Seas. If not, it is not enough even to protect one’s own wife and children.* These words seem made for the Emperor himself, proving that the wisdom of the sages was already settled long ago. How could later generations’ endless speeches ever rival it?"*

On the birthday of the Empress Dowager of Longyou (隆佑太后), a banquet was held in the palace. The Empress wept and said to Emperor Gaozong: *"I am old now, with deep regrets. Speak them for me to the sovereign."* She continued: *"I served under Empress Dowager Rongren (宣仁); she was a sage and virtuous mother, her wisdom unmatched in ancient or modern times. In the past, wicked ministers spread slander and false accusations. Even in the early years of the reign of Emperor Qinzong (建炎初), though decrees were issued to clarify the truth, the official histories had not yet been revised. How could this suffice to convey my intentions? The spirits of the two Empresses in Heaven still hope for your justice, O Emperor."*

Emperor Gaozong was deeply moved and ordered the revision of the histories. The *Record* states:
*"Empress Dowager Rongren’s knowledge of Empress Dowager Longyou was as steadfast as pine and cypress in winter’s chill, unchanging even in adversity. Empress Dowager Longyou’s favor toward Empress Dowager Rongren was as inevitable as the spring thaw, where snow cannot linger. With such a woman, how could one not repay such a mother? This is Heaven’s comfort to one old soul, allowing her to guard our dynasty. Alas! In life, she was called the ‘female Yao and Shun’ (女中尧舜), yet in death, she was slandered. The crimes of Empress Dowager Rongren and Empress Dowager Du (惇) are too grievous to recount. The histories written in black and red ink are lamentably late in coming. The Fan family, from Fan Zheng (范镇) to Fan Yu (祖禹), served three generations in the Forbidden City (禁林), earning the admiration of scholars. During the Yuanyou era (元佑中), Fan Yu revised the *Real Record* (实录) of Emperor Shenzong, heavily criticizing Wang Anshi’s faults. Wang Anshi’s son-in-law, Cai Bian (蔡卞), hated this, and Fan Yu was exiled and died in the Lingbiao Mountains (岭表). Now, Emperor Gaozong urgently commands the revision of the *Real Records* of the two reigns of Shenzong and Zhezong (神哲两朝实录), summoning Fan Yu’s son, Fan Chong (冲), to serve as the Minor Assistant of the Bureau of Ancestral Sacrifices (宗正少卿), and concurrently as the Deputy Director of the History Bureau (兼直史馆)."»

The Emperor said to him: *"The great records of the two reigns have all been corrupted by deceitful ministers, hence I entrust them to you."*

Fan Chong composed *Considerations on Differences* (《考异》), clearly marking what was retained, what was deleted (in yellow ink), and what was newly added (in red ink), earning the name *Jumu History* (朱墨史). He also wrote *Defending Zhezong Against False Accusations* (《辩诬录》), thereby restoring the truth of both histories and exposing the true nature of the deceitful ministers even more clearly.

Before this, when Empress Dowager Xuanren passed away, the court and the people mourned deeply, yet none dared speak out. Fan Chong submitted a memorial stating:

*"Your Majesty now governs all affairs and receives the ministers. This is the foundation of the state’s prosperity or decline, the pivot of the dynasty’s safety or peril, the source of the people’s joy or suffering, and the moment when the worthy and unworthy rise or fall, when Heaven’s mandate and human hearts converge or diverge. How can this be taken lightly?

The Empress Dowager had great merit for the dynasty and great virtue for the people, remaining steadfast for nine years. Yet the scheming ministers harbored resentment, and they will surely seek to alter the policies of the late Emperor and drive away his ministers, using false accusations to sow discord. This must be carefully examined.

The Empress Dowager adapted to the changing hearts of the people—these ministers betrayed the late Emperor above and the people below. They are the very ones the realm despises and seeks to remove. How could the Empress Dowager have hated them?

Only by clarifying right and wrong, firmly rejecting false doctrines, and punishing those who deceive with the law—severely punishing one to deter others—can harmony be restored without further incident."*

He further said: *"The Empress Dowager governed with absolute impartiality, abolishing Wang Anshi and Sima Guang’s new policies and restoring the old ways of the ancestors. Thus, the dynasty was saved from peril and the people’s divisions healed, even to the point where the Liao ruler warned his ministers not to provoke conflict. If the barbarians’ sentiments are thus, how much more so the hearts of the Chinese people!

The Empress Dowager toiled night and day to establish a foundation of peace for Your Majesty. I pray that you govern with humility and act with an open mind, so that the loyalty and disloyalty of your ministers and the right and wrong of all matters may be clearly known to Your Majesty."*

His memorials went unanswered, and only now did the Emperor believe his words.

The record states: *"I observe the Jumu History—not only a blessing for the Empress Dowager, but also for the Fan family. His father was exiled and died for his honest *Real Record*, while his son now corrected the falsehoods, clarified the truth, and recorded it, so that the affairs of that time, long shrouded in darkness, were restored to light. Within one family, it was as if embers had been fanned back to flame.

This shows that Heaven’s principle and human conscience are indeed worthy of trust, and that right and wrong, though obscured in the moment, will shine clearly for ten thousand generations. How can one content themselves with the fleeting present and abandon the eternal future?"*

Chen Qun served as Left Secretary and temporarily as Censor-in-Chief. Once, Zeng Bu sent a messenger to persuade him to accept an imminent promotion. Chen Qun told his son, Chen Zhengui: *"I have disagreed with the Chancellor on matters of governance. If I accept his favor now, and later we differ again, I would be shamed by both public opinion and private gratitude. I have written a letter exposing his faults and will send it to urge him to resign. But his influence is vast.

If he cannot tolerate me, his favor will not extend to you. Can you bear this in your heart?"*

Chen Zhengui wished to see the letter and deliver it to Zeng Bu, who flew into a rage and had him dismissed, exiled to Yuanzhou. While in Hangzhou, Zhengui reported that Cai Jing was plotting against the Eastern Palace, so he was arrested and sent to Kaifeng Prison, where Chen Qun was also imprisoned. The jailer, Yin Li, forced him to falsely accuse his son. Chen Qun replied: *"Zhengui heard rumors that Cai Jing intended harm to the state and spread them on the streets. How could I have known? To betray filial piety for personal gain and falsely accuse my son is something I cannot bear. To fabricate evidence out of private resentment is also against my conscience.

Cai Jing’s treachery will surely bring ruin to the state—I have already spoken against him in the Hall of State Petitions and the Censorate, and it is not as if I am speaking now for the first time."*

The eunuch overseer, Huang Jingcheng, interrogating him, said: *"The Emperor merely seeks the truth. You should answer as you spoke."*

Chen Qun had previously written *The Collection in Honor of Yao* (《尊尧集》), stating: *"During the Shaoshing era, the historians relied solely on Wang Anshi’s daily records to rewrite Emperor Shenzong’s history, distorting right and wrong and making it untrustworthy. I have investigated and exposed the falsehoods to uphold the duty of ruler and subject."*

Now, the Chancellor ordered a brutal executioner, Shi, to bring Chen Qun to court, where he laid out the charges and threatened him with death. Chen Qun, sensing their intent, shouted: *"Is this by imperial decree?"*

The executioner then said: *"The court commands you to revere *The Collection in Honor of Yao*."*

Chen Qun replied: *"Then why all this? Do you know why it is called *The Collection in Honor of Yao*? It is because it upholds the divine teaching of Yao and treats the Emperor as Shun. How can revering Yao be a crime?"*

The Chancellor, whose learning was shallow and who had been deceived by others, asked: *"What have you gained from public opinion? Do you not fear it?"*

The executioner withdrew in shame.

The record states: *"Fan Chong’s revisions span the Southern and Northern dynasties, while Chen Qun’s writings were contemporary with Cai Jing and Cai Bian. Yet the state histories may be altered, but human hearts cannot; the halls of power may be neglected, but the common people cannot. The tyranny of a single era may be feared, but the verdict of ten thousand generations cannot be erased.

What the virtuous trust is only this: that a father believes his son and sends a letter to urge him to resign, while the son believes his father and exposes his crimes to correct them. He would rather defy familial favor than betray his father, and rather endure false accusation than falsely accuse his son."*

The executioner withdrew in shame.

The record states: *"Fan Chong’s revisions span the Southern and Northern dynasties, while Chen Qun’s writings were contemporary with Cai Jing and Cai Bian. Yet the state histories may be altered, but human hearts cannot; the halls of power may be neglected, but the common people cannot. The tyranny of a single era may be feared, but the verdict of ten thousand generations cannot be erased. What the virtuous trust is only this: that a father believes his son and sends a letter to urge him to resign, while the son believes his father and exposes his crimes to correct them. He would rather defy familial favor than betray his father, and rather endure false accusation than falsely accuse his son."*

This is indeed the utmost of human sentiment, yet truly the glory of the realm and the state. Thus, when recording his deeds, Fan Chong felt no shame.

Zhao □, having moved from Chaozhou to Jiyang Military District, his son Fan Cheng had already served in his retinue. The father did not permit him to accompany him on that day. In the early years of the *Shàoshèng* era (1094–1100), Lü Dàfáng was exiled to Lingnan, and only his son Lü Jǐngshān loved him, refusing to let him go alone, though Lü Jǐngshān insisted on following.

Upon arriving at his destination, as he prepared to cross the mountains, Lü turned to his son, weeping: *"I am old, and death is of no consequence to me. You are young—what crime have you committed that you must die with me in this malarial land? If I die first, you may return in mourning and still have descendants of me."* Thus, he drank to excess and died.

I did not command you to accompany me, but this was Lü’s own intention. When Fan Cheng arrived, he secretly lived in secluded places, and neither his disciples nor former officials dared to communicate with him. Later, an imperial edict was issued to the local military district, requiring monthly reports on his life and death. At this point, Fan Cheng called his son to him once more and said: *"If Qie (Zhao □) insists on killing me, I will not let his misfortune extend to our entire family. I have already inscribed my epitaph and removed the date of my birth, adding instead: ‘My body rides the *Jīwěi* constellation back to the heavens, my *qi* becomes the grandeur of mountains and rivers, aiding our dynasty.’"* Then, he refused food and died. Fan Cheng escorted his remains back home.

The local governor, Zhāng Jié, knew that Fan Chong’s correspondence with officials across the empire had been intercepted during his funeral, and that the documents would be a valuable commodity. He quickly dispatched soldiers from the lower county under the pretext of searching for illicitly brewed wine, rushing to seize the letters hidden behind the walls of the county magistrate Wēng Méng’s residence. Wēng Méng, pursued from behind, hurriedly delivered them, and Fan Cheng promptly burned all the documents in the basket, including the writing knives and tools. By the time the officials arrived, nothing remained.

Qie’s resentment was not yet satisfied, so he persuaded the *Censorate* official Xú Jiā to accuse Fan Cheng of conspiring with the royal family—specifically, the official Zhī Quán of Quanzhou—over lavish farewell feasts and excessive drinking, implying treasonous intent. Fan Cheng was sent to the *Dàlǐ* (Supreme Court) prison, compelled to falsely implicate himself in a plot of great treason alongside figures such as Zhāng Jùn, Lǐ Guāng, Hú Yín, and Hú Chuán, totaling fifty-three people. The case was concluded, but Qie fell ill and could not write his own testimony, so Fan Cheng was released.

As for the words between a father and son, none were untrue.

The record states: *"In my view, Fan Chong’s final words—could they truly be trusted?"*

Mencius said: *"As for his **qi**—it was of the utmost grandeur and firmness. If he nourished it uprightly without harm, then it would have filled the space between heaven and earth. Even heaven and earth could be filled, yet mountains and rivers alone could not have made him mighty. Alas, he failed to accept its rectitude! Death is the supreme fate of man. To be bound in chains and imprisoned in a dungeon, or to be cast into cliffs, walls, ditches, and filthy sewers—what matters is how I face my own death. If he had been treated justly, then even being bound in chains would not be a crime, and being imprisoned in a dungeon would not be a disgrace. But if he had not been treated justly, then his fate would be equal to that of cliffs, walls, ditches, and sewers. Why then did he insist on refusing to eat the flesh of the dead?*

*The home is an external thing, easily obtained; the body is within oneself, hard to preserve. Rather than grieve for my one family, I would prefer to lament my one body. Though Qie’s tyranny was dreadful, my life still remained—how could I not fear being captured like Zhang Jie, or ending up in Qie’s prison?*

*Or was it that Master Zhong and the dull-witted were merely sparing their children, yet they did not compare to Tian Hua’s censure of Zou Hao—could it be that they grew old and gained wisdom? No! Even if one indulges in drinking or remains pure, it is not possible to bring the dead back to life outside the regions of Linghai (southern China)."*

*The **Imperial Collection of Writings** states: In the 11th year of Hongwu (1378), the emperor commanded Jiangyin Marquis Huo Liang to oversee the construction of a new imperial ancestral hall. At the time, the Taizu Emperor (Hongwu) believed that the inscriptions on the ancestral tombstones, all written by Confucian scholars, might not suffice to convey his true legacy. Thus, he personally recorded his struggles and the blessings of Ming prosperity, so that future generations might witness them and have no doubts.*

*His words were as follows:*

*"In the past, my father the emperor resided here, toiling morn and night in hardship, wandering in search of sustenance. Soon, calamities struck, and his kin suffered misfortune. My father died at sixty-four, my mother at fifty-nine. The ancestral spirit had nowhere to rest, and his noble resolve was cast adrift like a gallant roaming without purpose. His body was driven like a tumbleweed by the wind, never ceasing; his heart seethed like boiling water. He was but a lone cloud amid three years of turmoil, yet by the age of twenty, he was already strong.*

*At that time, bandits rose along the Huai River, and the people lived in chaos. Later, he returned to his ancestral duties, but within three years, mighty rivals emerged. First, they struck at Ruyang and Yuzhou; then, they moved south to Fenyang’s outer precincts. I led my troops, guiding my horses and controlling the reins, venturing into the southern lands. My **qi** expanded and shone brightly, rallying farmers to join my ranks. This was my mission to restore order, and within a month, my forces swelled, their red banners covering the fields and filling the hills. I led the waves of the clear river, garrisoned at Suiyang, and yearned for my kin in their old homes. All day long, I spoke with passion and resolve, driving the rival warlords onward. My meals were hurried, and I briefly defended Hezhou. Crossing the great river to the east, I first pacified Gusou (modern Suzhou), upholding proper rites. Thus, I established my base in Jianye (Nanjing).*

*I held the four passes, sharpened my weapons, and fed my horses, calmly observing the treacherous and the obstinate. I personally led campaigns into Jingchu (modern Hubei and Hunan), intending to subdue the lakes and rivers of Hunan. The Three Miao tribes surrendered, and the southern seas grew strong.*

*I commanded the great general, Huo Liang, to march through Qilu (modern Shandong and Henan), his banners gleaming. To the west, I had the regions of Yilu (modern Henan), Qinling, and the narrow passes of Hengshan—territories where the rivers were perilous and the land treacherous. When I entered the barbarian capital, the markets did not even dare to close. The fierce warlords displayed their weapons, yet they shone like stars in the sky. Later, I advanced along the Jingdian (modern Jiangsu and Shandong) route, and all the people within and beyond the rivers and mountains looked up to me in awe.*

*Once the Central Plains were pacified, the streets resounded with festive music. The lands of Xuanbo (modern Korea) and Yuelang (modern Liaoning) submitted their records, and the thirteen southern vassal states came to pay homage. I leaned upon Jinling (Nanjing) to establish my throne, relying on the tiger’s crouch and the phoenix’s perch. The stars hung high, the moon cast its radiance upon the vast seas, and the Zhongshan (Purple Mountain) range stood firm, its peaks meeting at the Silver Gully.*

*I wished to bestow a modest burial upon my ancestors, but the diviner said: ‘The earth here is unsuitable; they must be buried elsewhere.’ The rites of the ancestral sacrifices were already established, and each time I offered pure and refined sacrifices, I reflected upon my labors and the boundless grace that could never be fully repaid. Thus, I inscribed these words upon the imperial ancestral hall: ‘May future generations uphold the Mandate of Heaven and cultivate virtue, so that they might always come to honor and feast upon me.’*

*The record states: ‘I humbly read the imperial words on the ancestral tombstones. Not only did they reveal the hardships and blessings of prosperity, but they also contained profound meanings that must not be overlooked. The ancestral hall’s location was not chosen arbitrarily; it was a matter of necessity. Now, though he is already the Son of Heaven, possessing all under heaven, even if he were to alter it, what could not be done? Yet, he knew that wise men understand what is yet to come, rather than merely what has already happened. The earth’s **Dao** is vast, yet distant and hard to discern, while human affairs are plain to see. Though the ancestral spirits are subtle and hard to measure, their deeds are known. Before the burial of the imperial ancestors, the Jiangbei region was but a commoner’s dwelling. Thus, the sagacious pen recorded what was yet to be. After the burial of the imperial ancestors, the Huai River region became a true dragon’s domain. Thus, the divine achievements were as they should be. Should one not inquire into their reasons?*

*To strive and then succeed, to seek and then obtain—this is human, not divine. To act without intent, to cause without purpose—this is divine, not human. The Great King’s migration to Qi (modern Shanxi) led to his descendants ruling the land for three generations; yet, even the sages still regard it as a fortunate turn of fate, occurring after his body had been cast aside. Moreover, the earth’s **Dao** takes tranquility as its foundation, and the ancestral spirits seek peace above all. The dragon’s **qi** lies hidden, not dependent on whether the burial mound is small or grand. The gathering of blessings and virtue does not hinge on whether the location is distant or near. If one opposes human schemes here and defies the **Dao** of heaven, then even if the ruler possesses the power to create life, the earth’s **Dao** will rarely grant peace and tranquility. Though the ruler’s heart may be filled with utmost reverence, the ancestral spirits cannot be free from the fear of disturbance. Comparing this to that, who gains and who loses?*

*Though the words of the sage-ancestor were written with a straightforward pen, their meaning was profound and far-reaching. May the sacred descendants of all future generations uphold and believe in them, never letting them be forgotten.’*

*The **Record of Distinguished Officials** states: *"Nee Minister Wuyue (倪尚书岳) served in both capitals and the four ministries, eventually rising to the position of Grand Tutor to the Crown Prince."*

「Furthermore, Wen Xi Gong (文僖公) was also a minister of virtue and humility, serving as the Vice-Minister of the Imperial Sacrifices Department in the Southern Capital (南京礼部尚书). His mother, Lady Yao (夫人姚氏), was of noble lineage.

Initially, when Wen Xi Gong was commissioned to perform the ritual of succession for the Northern Peak (北岳), Lady Yao dreamed of a divine figure in flowing robes (徘袍神人) entering the chamber. Upon waking, she gave birth to the minister, believing it was due to the influence of the Northern Peak’s sacred **Dao** (岳柙所感). Thus, she named him **Yue** (岳).

As he grew older, his physique was robust and imposing, with piercing, radiant eyes (目光炯炯). Simply by looking at him, one could perceive his divine aura (真若神人). Both father and son were appointed as scholars (学士), with the father known as Wen (文), and the son’s works—*The Green Creek Herbs* (*青溪草*) and *The Collected Works of Wen Xi* (*文僖集*)—circulated together in the world, rare treasures indeed.

Later, when afflicted by illness, he still personally inscribed the *Recommended for Verification* (*荐真*) text. As death approached, he insisted on writing with his own hand. Throughout his life, he was upright and impartial, yet in his final words, he spoke not of family matters but only of matters of **virtue/power** (福德).

Such was his integrity—whether living or dead—far surpassing the ordinary mourners who merely weep in passing.

Minister Wen of the Han (韩尚书文), descended from the Wei Duke (魏公) of the Song Dynasty, hailed from the lineage of the ancient Xia Dynasty’s Wen Tang Gong (文汤公).

At the time of Wen Xi Gong’s birth, his mother dreamed of a man in purple robes (紫衣人) telling her: *"I am the one who delivered Wen Tang Gong to you."* Hence, she named him **Wen** (文), and later, he rose to the position of Grand Tutor to the Crown Prince (太子太保).

In the early years of the Jiaqing era (嘉靖初), he was honored with a posthumous edict of praise and inquiry. Among the words spoken were: *"Though you endured the usurpation of power by corrupt officials and lamented the chaotic governance of the realm, you upheld righteousness without favor, pledging your loyalty to the end. You spoke out against danger with resolute words, unshaken like mountains and rivers (屹乎山岳之难摇). You embraced misfortune to forget your own family, remaining steadfast as ice and snow (凛尔冰霜之不变). The world admired your bearing, and the divine spirits blessed your longevity (寿康).

You revived Wen Yianbo (文彦博) from his ninefold mourning, and the people’s hearts turned to you in trust. You succeeded the Han Wei Duke (韩魏公), and his family’s blessings grew ever more manifest. None could doubt your sincerity."*

The Record states: *"The deeds of these two ministers were not mere chance but the inevitable result of their nature. They were born as great figures of their age, not by coincidence. Thus, they are recorded."*

The *Record of the Upholding of the Dao* (弘道录) concludes its **Volume Fifty-Two** and begins **Volume Fifty-Three** with the entry: *"The Faith of Husbands and Wives"* (夫妇之信).

The *Yao De* (尧典) states: *"Let me test him."*

At that time, Yao observed the conduct of Shun through his two daughters. The Record says: *"I observe Yao’s testing of Shun—not only in what he urged him to do, but also in what he overlooked. What he urged was in their formal morning audiences; what he overlooked were the casual conversations at the hearth. Thus, the two daughters, though dwelling together, had differing intentions—a common human trait. But when he observed Shun through his few wives, extending even to his brothers, because they were close to his household, this was the unique insight of the Sage. Yet how must he have acted before Yao could truly call him tested? He must have shown mutual respect like honored guests, and thus virtue and propriety arose; he must have maintained proper distinctions of rank, and thus harmony between superiors and inferiors was achieved; he must have upheld firmness and gentleness without disorder, and thus the wife’s caution was kept at a distance; he must have moved and remained still without contradiction, and thus inner and outer harmony prevailed. These were the profound *virtues/powers* (玄德) that ascended to Yao’s ears—what appeared as nothing but the unseen reality of his *temperate and respectful demeanor* (温恭允塞), which in truth was the subtle essence of *self-discipline and reverence* (戒谨恐惧). Who would say that Yao’s governance did not originate from this very foundation of *caution and solitude* (慎独)? If not so, how could Shun have been deemed worthy of succession each day?"*

Five households were thus tested.

The *Book of Odes* (《诗》) speaks of the *Southern States* (南国):

*"The influence of King Wen!*
*There were women who could maintain their chastity and sincerity (贞信) against violence and oppression (强暴),*
*and yet they would declare their own resolve,*
*compose verses to break off relations with those who sought to defile them:*
*'To walk in rain and be drenched—*
*Is it not day and night?*
*I fear to walk where the rain is heavy.'*

*'Who says the sparrow lacks a beak?*
*Yet how it pecks through my house!*
*Who says you lack a family?*
*Yet how you hasten me to prison!*
*Though you hasten me to prison,*
*my household and kin are not lacking.*

*'Who says the rat lacks teeth?*
*Yet how it gnaws through my embankment!*
*Who says you lack a family?*
*Yet how you bring me to court!*
*Though you bring me to court,*
*I will not follow you.'*

*The record says: ‘Why does this woman thus shine?’*
*She replied: ‘My younger sister delayed her return,*
*and there was a time for her delay.’*
*Confucius said: ‘Ah, ah! She waits for her worth to be recognized!*
*This woman, though fair as *Tao* (桃) and *Ying* (夭), yet does not adorn herself,*
*and though steadfast as firm stone, yet does not falter.*
*Her chastity (贞) is self-guarded,*
*yet she must await the refined and gentle (妩婉) to seek her.’*

*‘How few know *virtue/power* (德)!*
*Yet how many are violent and oppressive!’
*Thus too with the virtuous scholar (士):*
*His *qi* (气) is like the white *Hóng* (虹) yet unbroken,*
*His spirit manifests in mountains and rivers yet does not fade.*
*The scholar’s embrace of the *Dao/Way* (抱道),*
*must await the gathering of the wise and virtuous (明良).’*

*‘How few days are marked by order (治),*
*and how many by chaos (乱)!’*
*This is why there are such fears,*
*and such declarations of resolve.*

*Examining the accounts of *Xūmǐ* (胥靡) in the *Transmissions* (传说),*
*of *Guan Zhong* (管仲) pleading for his prisoner,*
*of *Shu Xiàng* (叔向) in his fetters,*
*and of *Wang Wèi* (王魏) reversing his greatness—*
*how could one not see their plight reaching even to prison?*

*This is the distress of the humble and constrained (人村困顿),*
*and the dread of women facing violence (女子强暴)—*
*a shared sorrow through the ages.*

*Zhuāng Jiāng* (庄姜) was beautiful yet childless,*
*and so she took *Dài Mǎ* (戴妈) of *Chén* (陈) as her own son,*
*the child of *Wán* (完) who had been given to her.*
*When *Zhuāng Gōng* (庄公) died,*
*Wán ascended the throne,*
*but *Zhuāng Jiāng’s* son *Zhōu Yú* (州吁) assassinated him,*
*so *Dài Mǎ* returned to *Chén* in great disgrace,*
*and *Zhuāng Jiāng* composed verses to send her off:*
*'The *Zhōng* (仲) clan’s duty is clear,*
*their hearts deep as the *Yuān* (渊) abyss,*
*yet they remain warm and kind,*
*refined and cautious in their conduct.*

*‘In memory of my former lord,*
*I exhort the one left behind.’*

*The record says:*
*The *I Ching* (《易》) in its *Gūi Mèi* (归妹) hexagram states: ‘The dim-sighted can see.’*
*Though *Dài Mǎ* was virtuous (贤),*
*she endured *Zhuāng Gōng’s* cruelty (暴),*
*and yet the self-aware observe her—*
*one might almost wish to pluck out the blindfold from her eyes!*
*Yet she still bore the thought of her former lord,*
*and where is the cruelty now?’*

*‘It benefits the secluded to maintain their chastity.’*
*Though *Zhuāng Jiāng* was without favor,*
*she faced *Zhōu Yú’s* usurpation (篡逆),*
*and yet people did not abandon her,*
*as if overturning a stool to gnaw at its legs—*
*yet she still held her position as a minor lord (小君),*
*and where is the usurpation now?’*

*Thus it is known:*
*Chastity (贞) can rectify (格) the heavens,*
*and compliance (顺) can win the people.*

*The *I Ching* (《易》) has ‘*Xìn* (信) and *Tún* (豚鱼),*
*and the *Book of Odes* (《诗》) has ‘*My heart is not stone* (我心匪石),*
*illuminating chastity and compliance (昭贞顺).’*

*The *Shì* (世子) of *Wèi* (卫), *Gòng Bó* (共伯), died young,*
*and his wife *Gòng Jiāng* (共姜) upheld righteousness (义).*
*Her parents wished to take her and remarry her,*
*so *Gòng Jiāng* composed verses to swear her resolve:*
*'She drifts upon the paired boat,*
*on the central stream.*
*Her hair is shorn, two locks remain—*
*this is my solemn vow.*

*‘My oath to the dead is unaltered,*
*my parents, though stern, do not sway me,*
*and I will not heed the words of others.’*"*

「The records state:
Chastity (贞) harmonizes with Heaven (天), yet if a person does not follow it, one can discern their nature.
*Sincerity* (信) aligns with the spirits (鬼), but if a father does not uphold it, one can perceive the father’s true character.

Indeed, the outward form and blood-flesh that may be shared by others—this is humanity (人), and humanity is easy to observe.
Yet the resonance of resolve and *qi* (志气) that Heaven responds to—this is Heaven, and Heaven is difficult to comprehend.

Thus it was fitting that her parents sought to take her and remarry her.

*The Biographies of Exemplary Women* (《列女传》) recounts: **Zhēn Jiāng** (贞姜) was the wife of King Zhāo of Chu (楚昭王).
When the king went on a journey, he left his wife on the **Jiān Tái** (渐台) terrace.
As the river waters surged violently, the king heard of it and sent an attendant to fetch his wife.
Yet the attendant forgot to bring the royal seal (符), so when he arrived, the wife said:
‘The king and I made an agreement: if he summons me, he must bring the seal.
Now that the seal is not brought, I dare not follow.’

The attendant replied:
‘The waters are now surging violently; if we return to fetch the seal, we may be too late.’

The wife said:
‘I have heard that the duty of a chaste woman (贞女) is to uphold her resolve (义), never breaking an agreement, and to remain steadfast (守一) in one path.’

Thus, the attendant went back to retrieve the seal, but by the time he returned, the waters had overwhelmed the terrace, and the wife was swept away and died.

The records state:
A virtuous woman (妇人) remains steadfast until death (从一而终).
“Steadfast” (一) does not necessarily mean one person—it may refer to a single principle, a single virtue, or a single vow of sincerity (一约一信).
The king had agreed to bring the seal; when the seal did not arrive, her life was forfeit—why then did he not trust her resolve?

Thus, her death or survival depended on whether he forgot or did not forget.
This is why a *junzi* (君子) holds fast to sincerity and diligently studies the Dao/Way (善道), guarding their life with virtue (守死善道).
If one could be summoned or abandoned at will, how could they be called a *junzi*?

*The Book of Han* (《汉书》) recounts: Lǚ Gōng (吕公), the father of Empress Lǚ, was skilled in divining human fortune (相人).
Seeing the appearance of the High Ancestor (高祖), he revered and trusted him, saying:
‘I have divined many people, but none like this man (季).
I hope he will take care of himself.
I have a daughter, whom I entrust to him as a match for **Jī Chóu** (箕筹).’

Lǚ’s mother, angry, said:
‘The two gentlemen initially praised this girl, saying she would marry a nobleman (贵人).
Yet the magistrate of Péi (沛令), Shàn Gōng (善公), sought her but was refused—why did you rashly promise her to him?’

Lǚ Gōng replied:
‘This is not something a child or woman can understand.’

He ultimately gave his daughter to the High Ancestor, who became Empress Lǚ, bearing the Prince of Huì (惠帝) and Princess Lǚyuán of Lǔ (鲁元公主).

Once, while Empress Lǚ was in the fields with her two sons, an old man passed by and asked for water.
Empress Lǚ offered it to him.
The old man divined her fate (相后), saying:
‘Madam, you are a noble one destined for greatness (天下贵人).
Seeing the younger son, he said:
‘The reason Madam will ascend is because of this boy.’

After the old man left, the High Ancestor happened to come from a nearby dwelling.
Empress Lǚ told him everything.
The High Ancestor then pursued the old man, who said again:
‘Your son and the son of Madam will both become kings (君).
The king’s fortune is too noble to speak of.’

The High Ancestor thanked him, saying:
‘Truly as you say, I dare not forget this virtue/power (德).’

In the Later Han (后汉), during the reign of Emperor Hépíng (和熹), Empress Dēng (邓皇后) was the granddaughter of the Grand Tutor Yǔ (太傅禹), whose father was Xùn (训) and mother was Lady Yīn (阴氏).
Empress Guāngliè (光烈皇后) was her younger sister.

Empress Dēng once dreamed of a vast, swaying sky, its azure expanse like a bell-shaped breast (锺乳状).
She gazed upward and drank from it, and when she consulted the dream diviners (占梦), they said it was an auspicious omen beyond words.

Her maternal uncle, Shàn Cháng (陕常), was a towering figure (一高).
He said:
‘I have heard that one who saves a thousand lives will have descendants who receive noble titles (封).’

Her elder brother, Xùn, as a **Yèzhě** (谒者) in charge of palace seals, carved an inscription on a stone:
‘The Yellow River annually saves thousands of lives—Heaven’s decree is trustworthy, and this family will surely prosper.’

The Grand Tutor Yǔ also sighed:
‘Five mouths sustain a hundred thousand souls, yet he has never wrongly taken a single life.
His descendants will surely be blessed with fortune.’

To this point, Empress Dēng was selected to enter the palace as a **guìrén** (贵人).」

When Empress Yin grew increasingly distant, seeing the empress’s favor and grace flourish, she resorted to witchcraft and curses, hoping to harm her. At that time, the emperor fell gravely ill again.

Empress Yin secretly declared, *“Now that I am in favor, I will ensure no remnant of the Deng family remains.”*

Upon hearing this, Empress Deng wept before her attendants and said, *“I have served the empress with utmost sincerity, yet she does not even grant me protection. I willingly pledge my life to this oath.”* She then sought to take poison, but the palace woman Zhao Yu firmly restrained her. The prince (弘) urgently reported that the emperor’s illness had already abated, and the empress believed him.

The next day, the emperor indeed recovered.

Empress Yin was deposed for her use of witchcraft, and the emperor, moved by pity, declared to his officials, *“The noble virtue of the Deng guiren surpasses all in the palace—she should be elevated as a brother’s wife.”* Thus, she was made empress.

**Recorded:** The rise of emperors and kings is always bound by Heaven’s decree. The two empresses, both contending for supreme authority and ruling in the emperor’s stead, thus met with swift divine omens—far beyond the fleeting favor of the inner court. Ultimately, their rivalry revealed the extraordinary virtue of the inner consort, further strengthening the emperor’s original resolve, while the treacherous schemes of the outer court only served to elevate the Deng clan. Heaven’s will is indeed trustworthy.

---

**The Filial Wife of Chen (陈孝妇):**
At sixteen, she was married and bore no children. When her husband was conscripted for military service, he entrusted her, *“My life may not return, but I have an aged mother with no other relatives to care for her. If I do not return, will you nourish her?”*

She replied, *“I will.”*

Her husband died and never returned. Yet the wife never faltered in caring for her mother-in-law. Her own parents, pitying her youth and childlessness, sought to remarry her.

The wife said, *“I have heard that trust is the foundation of one’s reputation, and righteousness the measure of one’s conduct. To abandon a dependent without fulfilling my vow, to betray a dead man’s trust—this is unrighteous. Better to die upholding virtue than to live dishonoring it. And if I fail to complete the care of an elderly mother, or break a promise made to another, how then shall I establish myself in the world?”*

She attempted suicide, but her parents, fearing for her, compelled her to continue tending her mother-in-law until her death. Thereafter, she faithfully maintained the ancestral sacrifices.

The governor of Huaiyang reported her deeds, and Emperor Wen praised her virtue and integrity, sending an envoy to bestow forty pounds of gold and grant her lifelong exemption from taxes.

**Recorded:** Death is the fate of all, but without trust, humanity cannot stand. This filial wife was but a soldier’s spouse, yet from the Han to this day, her story has endured for nearly a thousand years. Without virtue and integrity, would she not have rotted like grass and wood? The fleeting glory of a moment is slight, but the enduring treasure of a thousand ages is weighty.

Alas! Even today, commoners still speak of betraying their lords, breaking their own vows, and violating others’ agreements—as the *Odes* censure: *“Their words are hollow, their speech as drunken as wine.”*

---

**Liu Changqing’s Wife (沛郡刘长卿妻),**
of the same district as the magnate Huan Luan’s daughter, bore one son. When the son was five, her husband died, and fearing suspicion, she refused to return to her natal home. When the boy reached fifteen, his mother and stepfather, fearing for his future, preemptively mutilated his ear as an oath of their sincerity.

The matrons of the clan pitied them and said, *“If your family truly harbors no ill intent, then even if suspicions arise, you could still demonstrate your honesty through your aunts and sisters—why resort to such extreme measures as maiming?”*

She replied, *“My ancestors were the Five Dawn scholars, revered as imperial preceptors across generations without interruption. My male descendants have been honored for loyalty, my female descendants for chastity. The *Odes* say: ‘Do not forget your forebears, but cultivate their virtues.’”* The prefect of Pei, Wang Ji, reported her case to the court, which honored her as *“The Righteous Huan Zheng.”*

---

**Yin Yu’s Wife (南阳阴瑜妻),**
the daughter of Yingchuan’s Xun Sui, named Cai. She bore one daughter before Yu died. At the time, she was still young and comely. Later, a fellow district man, Guo Yi, lost his wife, and Xun Sui arranged for Cai to marry him. Pretending to be gravely ill, Xun Sui forced her into the marriage. Cai, clutching a dagger, swore an oath, but Xun Sui ordered servants to seize the blade and tightened the guards around her. She was thus delivered.

Guo Cai feigned joy and told her attendants, *“I had resolved to share a grave with Yin, yet I was coerced to this point. My sincerity is unshaken—what can be done?”*

She then ordered four lamps lit, adorned herself richly, and invited Yi to an audience. They spoke at length, their words unceasing. Yi, respectful and awed, dared not press further, and she left at dawn.

Cai then ordered her attendants to prepare a bath. After entering her chamber and sealing the door, she wrote in powder on the door: *“My corpse returns to the Yin clan.”* She hanged herself with her sash.

**Recorded:** These two women were both of noble lineage, their conduct a model for the age. Xun Sui, failing to trust his own daughter, brought ruin upon himself—how lamentable!

As for Cai, she never wavered from her original vow. Truly, *“If I prove untrustworthy, let the wind of bright day bear witness against me.”* Though she feigned conversation and forced smiles, it was still better than preemptively maiming oneself to prove sincerity before suspicion arose.

Let observers examine this closely.

The *Wei Shu* records: Cao Shuang’s younger brother Wen Shu’s wife, from the Qiao Commandery, was the daughter of Xiahou Wen Zhi (née **Ling Nǚ**). Wen Shu died early, and she, being young and childless, feared her family would certainly remarry her. Thus, she cut her hair as a vow of fidelity and habitually resided near Shuang.

When Shuang was executed, Ling Nǚ’s uncle petitioned the Cao family to dissolve their betrothal and force her return. At the time, Wen Zhi served as the Liang Commandery’s governor, pitying her youth and the Cao family’s extinction, hoping she would relent. He subtly sent someone to persuade her, but Ling Nǚ sighed and wept. Upon returning to her chamber, she severed her own nose with a knife, wrapped herself in her bedclothes, and lay down. When her mother called to her, she did not respond. Upon uncovering her, blood flowed across the bed and floor, shocking the entire household.

Some said to her: *“Life in this world is fleeting—like dust resting on fragile grass. Why endure such suffering?”*

Ling Nǚ replied: *“I have heard that the virtuous do not abandon their resolve even for a single morning of prosperity, nor do the righteous alter their hearts with life or death. When the Cao family was still in power, I still wished to preserve my fidelity to the end. How much more so now, when they are fallen? How could I bear to abandon them? I would never act like a beast.”*

**Recorded:** The principles of virtue and righteousness lie within the human heart. Even the sagacious and noble differ from common folk and women—yet here, their resolve is reversed in contradiction. Why?

The Dao/Way’s defilement above, the Liang Commandery’s governor willingly embraces it; the boiling broth of the sun’s brilliance, the drooling glutton sates himself upon it. But as for the springs beneath the mountains, their purity remains unchanged. Though the great stew’s flavor may fade, its essence still lingers.

The hearts of ordinary men and women can move the heavens and earth, pierce metal and stone—yet in the face of the court’s inquiries, not even the slightest resistance is shown. This is why the virtuous sigh deeply.

The record cannot cease to lament.

**Book of Jin:** The wife of Yu Zhong, Lady Sun, was a daughter of the powerful Sun family. After Yu Zhong’s death, she swore never to alter her virtue, and raised his orphaned children. When they were young, she instructed them in loyalty and righteousness. In the late years of the Yongjia era, Sun Tan served as Governor of Nankang, and when Du Qiang rebelled, he led troops to suppress him. Lady Sun exhorted her son with the resolve of certain death: *“I have heard that loyal ministers emerge from the gates of filial children. You must abandon life for virtue—do not concern yourself with my old age.”* She then emptied her household’s wealth to reward the soldiers, and offered her own jade belt and pendants as military funds. Sun Tan thus achieved victory. When Su Jun’s rebellion arose, Sun Tan defended the Huxing stronghold, holding imperial credentials to command the suppression of Su Jun. Lady Sun admonished him again: *“I have heard that loyal ministers arise from the gates of filial children. You must abandon life for virtue—do not let my age weigh upon you.”* She further dispatched all her household servants to aid in the war. At her death, aged ninety-five, the Emperor sent envoys to offer condolences and bestowed upon her the posthumous title of *Definite Virtue* (Ding). The Record says: *“A woman of such virtue—this was unheard of in antiquity.”* With Lady Sun’s unblemished conduct, the title *Definite Virtue* was truly well-deserved. It was only because her devotion to her husband was sincere that her instruction of her children was steadfast, her adherence to virtue unyielding, and thus her longevity so great. Did not Confucius say: *“Only when winter’s chill arrives do we know the pine and cypress are the last to wither?”* Could this not be referring to Lady Sun’s steadfastness?

**Book of Tang:** Empress Shun of the Taimu lineage, the Wudou clan, was from Pingling in Jingzhou. Her father, Wudou Yi, served as *Upper Pillar General* (Shangzhuguo) in the Zhou dynasty and married the Emperor’s sister, Princess Xiangyang of the Shouyang lineage. Upon entering the Sui dynasty, he became *General of Dingzhou* and *Duke of Shenwu*. When the Empress was born, her hair hung down past her neck, and by age three it was already level with her body. The Emperor cherished her and raised her in the palace. Once, another nephew remarked to the Princess: *“This girl has an extraordinary appearance and uncommon insight—how can she be rashly given to another?”*

The Emperor then ordered two peacock screens to be painted, and when suitors came seeking her hand, he instructed them to shoot two arrows—if they struck one eye of each peacock, she would be granted to them. Though many tried, none succeeded until the High Ancestor [Emperor Gaozu] arrived, who struck one eye of each peacock and thus won her.

The record states: *"The Way of perfect matching is not merely the husband choosing the wife, but also the wife choosing the husband. When their union is fated, there is always a predetermined harmony."* As the *Book of Odes* says: *"Heaven’s appointed union."*

At the turn of the Jin and Sui dynasties, even skilled artisans like Du Zhuo could easily paint peacocks—yet to strike both eyes was no trivial feat. That the Sage-Emperor [Gaozu] succeeded proves that this was Heaven’s predetermined will, not mere human contrivance.

Later, when Longsun [Empress] sought marriage, the same method revealed that the High Ancestor’s extraordinary son [Taizong] was destined for greatness. Two emperors and two empresses, matched in virtue and reverence, achieved two successive unions of perfect harmony—could this truly be mere chance? Could this truly be mere chance?

The Emperor secretly asked the Astrologer Li Chunfeng: *"Does the Secret Record truly speak of this? Is it real?"*

The Astrologer replied: *"Your servant gazes upward to examine the celestial omens and downward to scrutinize the calendrical portents. The man in question is already among Your Majesty’s officials as a kinsman. Within thirty years from now, he shall reign over all under Heaven, slaying the descendants of the Tang nearly to extinction—his destiny is already manifest."*

The Emperor said: *"If we execute all those who seem suspicious, what then?"*

The Astrologer replied: *"Heaven’s decree cannot be defied by mortal hands. Moreover, the Sovereign does not die—only the innocent perish in vain. But from this day forward, even if thirty years pass, the man will have aged, and perhaps his cruelty may lessen somewhat, his calamity abating. If we were to kill him now, Heaven might raise another in his vigor, and Your Majesty’s descendants would be utterly exterminated."*

The Emperor desisted.

It was recorded: *"If Striking General Pei had died, the world would have lacked Striking General Pei—this was a calculation of power. Now, if we were to kill him now, Heaven might raise another in his vigor—this is mere speculation. As for the sage’s resolve, what need is there for such schemes?"*

To commit one injustice, to slay one innocent, and thereby gain the world—there are things even the Sage would not do. Thus the two dynasties endured for generations, following this Way.

The Emperor’s unrighteous deeds and the slaughter of the innocent—how many were they? Heaven’s retribution was but delayed. With Your Majesty’s brilliance and decisiveness, even to uncover a single kinsman in the ranks of officials—could it truly be so easily done? If another were to rise in his vigor, would he escape the dust of obscurity?

The sage weighs not the scale of gain or loss, but the rightness of principle. In the Dongdu neighborhood of Renhe Street, the kuei-shih Pei [family] flourished with numerous descendants, a veritable noble house. During the reign of Empress Wu, the Chancellor Wei Xuan sought to marry his daughter to the Pei family before the betrothal was finalized, Wei was ensnared in the Luo Ji conspiracy, his household reduced to rags and empty tables. Upon his return from the north, the daughter had already taken the veil, and her family, despairing of sustenance, sought to send her to a convent. A nun arrived from outside and said: *"Your daughter’s fortune is vast and abundant; she shall have a noble match, and her descendants will spread across the land. She should return north."* The family dared not speak further. When the gate was opened, Pei Baozhuang came to greet her in splendid array.

Pei Baozhuang bore eight sons, all of whom excelled in the *Mingjing* examinations and held positions as officials, prefects, and governors.

When Pei Kuan served as the *Censor* of Yunzhou Prefecture, the prefect Wei Shuo had a daughter, and he sought a suitable match for her. On a day when Wei Shuo rested, he ascended a tower and saw a man in the rear garden behaving suspiciously. Upon inquiring, the attendants replied: *"It is the Censor Pei."* Shuo asked about his conduct, and the man answered: *"Pei Kuan is virtuous; he would not let a crooked deed tarnish his family."* Just then, there was a delivery of meat as tribute, which the man took and left, not daring to deceive himself, so he hid it away. Shuo marveled at his integrity and agreed to marry his daughter to him, telling his wife: *"I have always sought a fine son-in-law, and now I have found one."* The next day, he gathered his relatives to let them see him. Pei Kuan at the time wore a long, coarse green robe. When he entered, the relatives all laughed, calling him *"Green Heron Sparrow."* Shuo said: *"I love my daughter, and I believe she will become the wife of a worthy minister or high official. Why should one judge a person by appearance alone?"* He ultimately married his daughter to Pei Kuan.

Madame Liu once remarked: *"In this age of power and profit, people abandon their promises as easily as turning their palms. Yet the flourishing of the Pei clan is a manifestation of Heaven’s reward for their sincerity."*

The *Zhou* hexagram, in its formation, shows that the Sage abides long in the Dao/Way, first leading with genuine sincerity, then following with unyielding faithfulness. When the beginning and end align, its way becomes abundantly successful.

The *Cheng* hexagram, in its formation, shows that the noble one receives others with humility, attains their uprightness through mutual resonance, and matches his daughter according to her worth. When there is resonance, understanding follows, and thus its way also becomes successful.

When the Wei clan was facing misfortune, how could they have leisure to ponder the vast fortune of their daughter? Yet the bond between an elder sister and elder brother remains unchanged.

Once both firm and yielding align, and their descendants flourish, the match is found without seeking.

When the Wei family chose a husband, how could they have cared for the mockery of their relatives? Yet his steadfast sincerity and earnest virtue were truly evident.

Once harmony and resonance were established, and she became the wife of a worthy minister or high official, who could have known this by divination alone?

It is clear that ancient people acted with sincerity in every move and upheld faithfulness in every matter, and Heaven’s rewards and responses were indeed beyond doubt. How could mere worldly power and profit compare?

From the *Song History*: Zhou Wei’s wife, Mo Qian, was a virtuous woman. Zhou Wei, with the courtesy name Dechen, hailed from Gongcheng, Zhao Prefecture. Liu Yin occupied the Five Ridges, and Zhao Prefecture was his territory. The governance was oppressive and the taxes heavy, leaving the people barely able to survive. Zhou Wei led the villagers to the mountains, intending to flee to Lingling. Before reaching their destination, bandits arose along the road, cutting off supplies and forcing them back to Gongcheng, where their homes were burned to ashes. Zhou Wei then escaped northward.

In the early years of the *Jiànlóng* era, he arrived in the capital, where he was honored by Xue Ju Zheng. He submitted a memorial on ancient governance and current affairs, was summoned for examination, and granted the rank of *Jìnshì* (advanced scholar). During the second year of the *Taiping Xingguo* era, Zhou Wei served as the *Deputy Commissioner of Transportation* for the various prefectures of Guangnan.

When Zhou Wei fled north, he had no time to bid farewell to Mo Qian. Their two children were still young, and Mo Qian was still of tender age. Her parents wished to marry her off, but she wept and swore: *"Zhou Wei is not the kind to endure prolonged hardship. If he defies difficulties to travel far, he will surely rise by his own efforts."* She took up weaving early, laboring diligently at her loom to provide for their daily needs. By the time of the *Kāibǎo* era, the sheep were raised, and after the pacification of the *Zhāo* region by the Southern Han, officials sought her out and granted her money and rice for sustenance.

Nearly twenty-six years later, Zhou Wei finally returned to his homeland and reunited with Mo Qian. People marveled at their story. Their two sons had both completed their marriages.

「Zhū Yáng took the matter to heart and spread it as truth.

The record states: *"Foolishly observing Mo Qian’s story, I lament the perverse customs of the Qin and Han dynasties.* For the wife of **Su Qin** (*Su Qin*), even a single meal was hard to secure, while the wife of **Liang Yi** (*Liang Yi*) would not wait even for a night’s rest. Yet here was a woman who endured separation for **twenty-six years**, with two children still in their infancy. At the time, the **Song** dynasty’s *virtue/power* (*德*) was just emerging beyond the Five Passes, and the customs of the barbarians had greatly changed—yet still, it did not reach the point where a man of high rank, like **Wei Qi**, would have numerous attendants escorting him, and then take a woman as his consort merely for her ability to manage affairs. Alas, she may truly be called an **accomplished woman** (*贤*).

Empress **Xie** of **Emperor Lizong** (*理宗谢皇后*), her father was **Qú Bó** (*渠伯*), her grandfather **Shēn Fǔ** (*深甫*). The Empress was born with a dark complexion, and one eye was blind, having suffered from **black medicine** (*黑医*). Qú Bó died young, and the family’s fortune declined further. She once personally drew water and cooked meals to sustain them.

Initially, when **Shēn Fǔ** (*深甫*) was appointed Chancellor, he had rendered service in supporting **Yang Taizhou** (*杨太后*), and she held him in *virtue/power* (*德*). When **Lizong** (*理宗*) ascended the throne, there was discussion over selecting a **central consort** (*中宫*), and **Yang Taizhou** (*杨太后*) ordered the selection of women from the **Xie** clan. The Empress alone remained at home, and her relatives chose to decline the appointment, saying: *"If we accept the imperial decree, we must be prepared to provide lavish dowries."* By chance, on **Lantern Festival** (*元夕*), a magpie came to nest in the **Lantern Mountain** (*灯山*), and the people regarded it as an auspicious omen. Thus, they answered the summons, and the Empress soon fell ill with **erysipelas** (*病疹*), her skin peeling away until she became as **radiant and pure as jade** (*莹白如玉*). Later, the **black medicine** (*目医*) was removed through medicine.

At the time, **Jiā Xiè** (*贾涉*)’s daughter was renowned for her beauty and was also chosen. When she entered the palace, **Lizong** (*理宗*) wished to establish her as the **central consort** (*中宫*), but **Yang Taizhou** (*太后*) said: *"The Xie girl is dignified and blessed; she should be the true central consort."* The officials also whispered among themselves: *"Should we not establish the true Empress, and instead install a false one?"* The Emperor could not override this, and so the matter was settled.

The record states: *"The* **Book of Songs** (*《诗》)* says: ‘A beautiful wife stirs up strife, yet she is deeply cherished.’* The misfortune of **favoritism** (*女宠*) stems from this. The reason the **Song** dynasty’s household laws surpassed those of the **Han** and **Tang** dynasties was surely because **external kin** (*外戚*) did not interfere in governance. Yet even though **Jiā Xiè**’s daughter was chosen despite the objections of many, she was never properly installed as the **central consort** (*中官*), yet her **bed and mat affection** (*椎席之爱*)—who could truly take that away?

Thus, **Ximǎ Shìdào** (*似道*) rose from **Superintendent of the Imperial Granaries** (*司仓*), a low-ranking clerk who answered summons in the grand court, to be swiftly appointed as **Right Chancellor** (*右相*) in the military. This was because the **harm of poison** (*鸩毒之害*) festered in his heart, and the **menace of ferocious wolves** (*虎狼之威*) corrupted his governance, ultimately leading to the **ruin of the Zhao lineage** (*赵社丘墟*), the **capture of Empress Xie** (*谢后俘虏*), and the Emperor’s skull not even being spared. His name was indeed **Jiā** (*贾*), and his misfortune was real—just as the officials had whispered.

The contrast between his words in declining marriage and **Mo Qian’s** resolve is clear and convincing.»

The *Record of Words and Deeds* (*言行录*) states: When **Huáng Guīnián** (*黄龟年*) was still unmarried and his family was poor, he conducted himself with quiet dignity. Later, when he took the county examination, the examiner **Lǐ Cháoqíng** (*李朝旌*), who held the post of county magistrate, saw him and was deeply impressed, saying privately: *"How I wish this young scholar could be my son-in-law!"* Soon after, he indeed recommended Guīnián, and the magistrate, overjoyed, wished to marry his daughter to him.

When Guīnián later passed the imperial examination and returned home, the magistrate had already passed away. His widow, in mourning attire, met Guīnián on the road. He wept bitterly and sent word through a messenger, asking to fulfill their original betrothal. The widow replied:

*"How can I speak of past matters? Your former magistrate was a poor official with no private wealth. I, with nothing but my bare hands, escorted his remains west to his homeland, selling even our clothing and furnishings until they were nearly exhausted. I feared we could not reach our destination—how could I now discuss a marriage for your family? Your family’s lineage was once of the highest rank, and you should seek alliances with powerful clans. I must now depart. Please convey my refusal."*

Guīnián, tears streaming down his face, said: *"I gave my word, and if I die without keeping it, how can I face myself? A woman should not speak like a common barbarian, dismissing the words of the dead. If you allow me to fulfill my promise, I will provide for myself—do not refuse me."*

Thus, the marriage was settled. When they parted ways, they wept bitterly before going their separate paths.

The record further notes: *"Both **Liú Tíngshì** (*刘廷式*) and **Huáng Guīnián** (*黄龟年*) did not betray their original intentions after their success. Those who easily abandon friends in wealth or take wives in prosperity have already lost their virtue long before. How can one blame others?"*

The **four memorials** (*四疏*) of **Hōu Zhì** (*桧*) were not written out of self-reproach for lost virtue. Few were like him in shared ideals with **Zhān Dàfāng** (*詹大方*). His intent was clear: if one’s moral conduct is flawed and one associates with unworthy people, the consequences for the times are inevitable.

From **Chén Ràng’s** (*陈让*) *Annalsof Shàowǔ Prefecture* (*邵武府志*): The **Huáng** family, named **Shú** (*淑*), with the courtesy name **Zhìróu** (*致柔*), hailed from Sānxiā (*三溪*) in Jiànníng County (*建宁县*). As a child, she mastered the classics and histories, excelled in poetry and prose, and possessed elegant calligraphy. She married **Wáng Fáng** (*王防*), a fellow villager who had passed the imperial examinations. When Wáng died as the **Magistrate of Hù** (*泗州户曹*), Huáng personally carried his coffin home. Within a single day, her grief shattered her bones. After her mourning period ended, relatives suggested she remarry, but she declared: *"How could I show my face to Magistrate Wáng again?"* She refused, and in the end, she died from sorrow and melancholy.

「As she lay dying, she entrusted her concubine, saying: *"The poems I composed for the five households are dear to me—I cannot bear to abandon them, so let her perish with them."* The concubine then placed poison in the coffin. Her father later collected the remaining works, still numbering over a hundred, among which was one extolling bamboo:

*"Upright and steadfast, like the virtue of loyal ministers,
Lofty and solitary, like the resolve of virtuous women.
Through all four seasons, its hue remains unchanged,
Unassailable by frost and snow."*

The annalist recorded: *"From my humble perspective, reading the *Zhōu Nán* (*周南*) poem ‘Jiāo Mù’ (*乔木*), it seems to say ‘unacceptable.’ Yet the eight noble trees never lamented the chaste woman’s self-assurance, for others also held her in reverence."*

*"Could the later generations—like Cài Wénjī (*蔡文姬*), Lǐ Yì’ān (*李易安*), or the virtuous Huáng Shú (*淑*) who lost her chastity—have matched this?"*

*"This poem was composed by Huáng Shú herself. If the concubine perished with her, how could others trust her sincerity? Thus, even scholars may not always be fully trustworthy in their works. Alas!*

*"How could one not be cautious?"*

From the *Jiāhé Annals* (*嘉禾志*): **Hánxiāng** (*含香*) and **Wǎncuì** (*晚翠*) were the two concubines of **Zhāng Huángmén** (*张黄门*), the **Níng** (*宁*) family’s retainer in Míng’s **Fāngzhōu** (*芳洲*). Both were young and graceful, deeply devoted and beloved, and had been raised as virtuous daughters of good families to serve him. When their master died, the senior wife, recognizing their beauty, intended to send them away.

The two swore oaths to remain together, each cutting their hair to seal their vow, and thereafter dared not speak of it.

From then on, in lonely pavilions amid the cold winds, they spent their years in silent devotion. When their master’s fortunes waned—his coffers emptied across the four seas—his household fell into decline. They ate coarse grains and bitter herbs, unaware of age’s approach. Few in the family ever saw their faces again.

Moreover, the master’s daughter, **Héng Qīng** (*恒清*), was wed to **Yáo Líng** (*姚麟*), a military commander. She too became a widow young and kept her vow.

Thus, the virtuous say: *"As the verse goes:*
*'Laughter and speech were ever bright,
Oaths sworn day by day, unbroken light.'*
This is what they meant."

During the **Jiājìng** era, an imperial edict honored them as *"Double Virtue"* (*双节*).

The record states:
*"I observe the bonds between lord and subject, husband and wife—all united by righteousness. These two concubines remained faithful to their master because he had once been trustworthy to his lord. In life, he boasted of his martial prowess, earning the emperor’s confidence, yet drew the enmity of scheming ministers. When the prime minister conspired against him, he fell from favor, and though he lingered in quiet sorrow, he never again sought advancement. How then could these two concubines bear to serve their mistress and not live out their years?*

*Recorded thus."*

—From *Principles of the Way* (*弘道录*), Volume 53.

**Principles of the Way, Volume 54: Faithfulness in Sibling Bonds**

From *The Records of the Grand Historian* (*Shǐjì*): When King Cheng pitied his younger brother Chú Yú for playing, he carved a jade tablet from a mulberry leaf and said, *"With this, I grant you this fief."* The historian Yì selected an auspicious day, but the king replied, *"I was merely jesting with him."* Yì said, *"The Son of Heaven does not jest. When a gentleman’s words are sincere, the historian records them, rites are established, and songs are composed."* Thus, Chú Yú was enfeoffed at Yáo’s ancient domain and titled **Táng Hóu**.

The record states:
Gōu Zǐ said: *"If the king’s younger brother was meant to be enfeoffed, the Duke of Zōu should have spoken to the king in due time, not waited for the jest to be confirmed. If he was not meant to be enfeoffed, the Duke of Zōu should not have formalized the jest, granted land, and made him a ruler of the weak and small—how could this be considered sage?"*

I do not agree. The ancient sages and worthies, in their proper service to their lords and adherence to the **Dao**, would always take even the slightest good inclination—its initial appearance—and nurture it, guiding, encouraging, and fostering its virtues.

「Mencius, in his discourse on *Gǔlìán* (谷练), had his reasons, yet how much more so for a ruler still in his formative years? In the *Mèng* (蒙) hexagram, the second line of the ninth position states: *"Bāo Mèng, auspicious."* The fourth line of the sixth position says: *"Kùn Mèng, regretful."*

Indeed, for one so young and of the **Kūn** (坤, receptive) nature, his heart is like a tender sprout—soft and pliable, not yet firmly rooted. If guided with **Shùn** (顺, harmony) and **Zhèng** (正, rectitude), it will grow straight and flourish; if obstructed by **Fú** (拂, discord) and **Nì** (逆, resistance), it will wither and turn crooked. Thus, those entrusted with nurturing such a ruler must expand his capacity for tolerance, broaden his benevolent governance, and seek to harmonize and assist him. If they do not, they may well achieve the task of guiding him, yet find no path without regret. But if a single word uttered is not yet evil, yet swiftly suppressed and stifled; if an action taken is not yet contrary to **Dao**, yet immediately checked and restrained—then the ruler’s heart will only grow more stubborn, bound, and constrained. He may even be overwhelmed by his own frustrations, and our own conduct will likewise find no path without regret. This is what the **Sages** deeply warn against.

Among the ancients who excelled in fostering such rulers, none surpassed **Mèng Mǔ** (孟母). When young **Mèngzǐ** (孟子) once asked why his mother bound a pig for slaughter, she replied: *"I meant to feed it to you."* Later, she regretted her words and bought meat instead. The matter of the **Jiān Tóng** (剪桐) was of the same intent.

Though **Chéng Wáng** (成王) spoke in jest, it was to his closest kin—those who, as **Zhōu Gōng** (周公), would suddenly alter their demeanor, grow stern in their words, and insist that the younger brother should not be enfeoffed, nor should jesting be allowed. Yet **Chéng Wáng**’s single jest was not inherently wrong; it was merely the fear of our rigid constraints and the dread of our stern commands that caused his heart to veer toward other paths. Hence it was said: *"Formalize the jest, for that is how one harmonizes and guides him."* Moreover, if the ruler’s jest were utterly erased, leaving no trace, then our words would naturally sink deep into his heart. Would this not make both ruler and minister virtuous?

Yet in later ages, there were those who could not grasp the ruler’s slightest inclination and expand upon it, instead fixating solely on restraining him, thereby inviting their own regret. What then could they have in common with **Zhōu Gōng**?

In the *Zhuàn* (左传), during the twenty-second year of Duke **Lí** (僖), the people of **Sòng** (宋) formed an alliance at **Lùshàng** (鹿上), seeking the **Zhūhóu** (诸侯) status from **Chǔ** (楚). The **Chǔ** people agreed. **Gōngzǐ Mùyí** (公子目夷) said: *"For small states to vie for alliances is a calamity. Will **Sòng** not perish?"* Fortunately, the disaster was averted later that year. In autumn, the **Zhūhóu** assembled at **Mèng** (孟) to meet with the Duke of **Sòng**. **Zǐyú** (子鱼) remarked: *"The calamity lies here. The ruler desires too much, how can he endure it?"* Thus, **Chǔ** seized the Duke of **Sòng** and attacked his state. In winter, they met at **Bó** (薄) to release him. **Zǐyú** said: *"The calamity is yet to come; this is insufficient to punish the ruler."* In the twenty-first year, the Duke of **Sòng** attacked **Zhèng** (郑). **Zǐyú** declared: *"This is the calamity we spoke of."* In the eleventh month of that year, on the day of the **Xī** (己巳) new moon, the Duke of **Sòng** clashed with the **Chǔ** forces at **Hóng** (泓), and the **Sòng** army was defeated. In the spring of the twenty-third year, **Qí Hóu** (齐侯) attacked **Sòng**, besieging **Hūn** (婚). That summer, in the fifth month, **Sòng Shànggōng** (宋襄公) died, wounded from the battle at **Hóng**.

The record states: *"Though divination by **shì** (筮) and **guī** (龟) may not always be accurate, **Zǐyú** possessed wisdom. His words ring true and resolute."* Though **Bó** (伯, the leading state) relies on strength, it also adheres to **Dao**. His virtues are: **ài zhòng mù qīn** (爱众睦亲, loving the people and harmonizing with kin), **pái nán xī zhēng** (排难息争, resolving difficulties and quelling strife), **shēng shèng zhì zhì** (声盛致志, commanding presence and inspiring resolve), and **dù dé liàng lì** (度德量力, measuring **virtue** and assessing strength). **Shànggōng** (襄公), at their first assembly, humiliated two **Zhūhóu** (诸侯) rulers—this was excessive cruelty. He began with an alliance yet later waged a merciless siege—this was excessive lack of **virtue**. He, though a **Bó**, was captured and attacked—this was excessive lack of **courage**. He faced repeated defeats yet never reflected upon himself—this was excessive lack of **wisdom**. Without these four virtues, I do not know how **Shànggōng** could have sought longevity among the **Zhūhóu**.

Now there are petty market traders who, though lacking in **virtue**, act with reckless **courage**. They bully and dominate their neighbors as if no one could oppose them. One day they sue a man, the next another, and if they win, they exult in self-satisfaction; if they lose, they do not reconsider their own actions. Instead, they separate the cases and seek victory elsewhere. Yet in the end, they are bound in chains, subjected to punishments, their bodies left unmarked—still, this is not enough to deter them. Only when they face great slaughter do they cease.

The calamity of **Jū Shàng** (朱襄) was no different. Taking this as a lesson, divination by **shì** and **guī** is no longer to be trusted.

In the case of **Wèi Xuāngōng** (卫宣公), he was pressured by **Yí Jiāng** (夷姜), **Sǔzǐ** (土急子), and so he sent his son to **Qí** (齐) to be married, choosing a beautiful woman. Yet the Duke took her himself, giving birth to **Shùzǐ** (寿子), who was later known as **Xuāngōng** (宣姜). **Xuāngōng** (宣姜) then conspired with **Sǔzǐ** (土急子) against the Duke, who ordered her to be sent to **Qí**. He commanded a thief to ambush her at **Shēn** (莘) and kill her. **Shùzǐ** (寿子) informed her of this, urging her to flee, but she refused, saying: *"To abandon my father’s command—why should I live? Even if there were a land without fathers, it would still not be worth it."* When she left, she was given wine to drink, and **Shùzǐ** (寿子) carried her banner ahead. The thief killed her. When **Sǔzǐ** (土急子) arrived, he said: *"I sought her, what crime did she commit to deserve death?"* He was killed again. The people of **Wèi** (卫) lamented her fate and composed a dirge:

*"Two children ride in a boat,
   drifting, drifting in the shadows,
   wishing to speak of you, my son,
   my heart aches with sorrow.
   Two children ride in a boat,
   drifting, drifting in their passing,
   wishing to clothe you in a single armor,
   yet harm comes not from afar."*

The record states: *"In ancient times, when executing the condemned, one would always choose a virtuous reason to justify the act. Later generations, however, merely erased their names and left it at that."* The **Wèi Tàizǐ** (卫太子) of the **Hàn** (汉), **Shǐ Huángsūn** (史皇孙) of the **Táng** (唐), **Jiànchéng** (建成) and **Yuángjí** (元吉) of the **Táng**, **Guāngměi** (光美) and **Dézhāo** (德昭) of the **Sòng** (宋)—all met the same fate, yet each case invites public judgment. The people of **Wèi** (卫) still honor **Shùzǐ** (寿子), and those of **Jìn** (晋) still honor **Shēngshēng** (申生)—was this not a way of choosing death with **virtue**?

Some say: *"The virtuous man is steadfast yet not lenient. The two children’s dispute was lenient yet not steadfast."* Words must be kept, actions must be fulfilled—this is the clear principle of the petty man.

Although lacking in sincerity and resolve, one who seizes his elder brother’s food—how long could such a man remain among the virtuous sons? How long could he remain among them?

*The Dànxī* (檀兮) recounts: When **Shí Qí’s** (石祁) father, **Líng Zhòng** (龄仲), passed away, he had no legitimate sons, only six younger brothers.
