They consulted the oracle to determine who should inherit, and the people said: *"If one washes, dons jade, and the divination responds, then he is chosen."* Five of them washed, donned jade, and the divination responded. **Shí Qí** said: *"Who, in mourning for a parent, would wash and adorn himself with jade?"* He did not wash, did not don jade, and the divination responded. The people of **Wèi** (卫) believed the tortoise shell had knowledge.

*The Record* (录) says: Filial piety and fraternal respect are in harmony with **virtue** (德). Thus, they resonate with the divine and are confirmed by divination. As it is said: *"Official divination is first obscured; one’s intent is revealed through the tortoise shell."* These five men trusted the diviner but not themselves, schemed against others but not against the divine—why wait for the oracle’s keys and scriptures before knowing the three tortoises would not comply?

From the *Book of Han* (汉书): Empress Dowager **Gāohòu** (高后) wished to enthrone her nephews, the **Lǚ** (吕) brothers, as kings. She asked **Right Chancellor** **Líng** (陵), who replied: *"The High Ancestor swore a blood-oath with white horses, vowing not to enthrone anyone outside the **Liú** (刘) clan. If you enthrone the **Lǚ**, it violates the oath, and the realm will rise against you."* The empress was displeased. She then asked **Left Chancellor** **Píng** (平) and **Grand Marshal** **Bó** (勃), who answered: *"The High Ancestor established the realm and enfeoffed his sons. Now that the empress governs, enthroning the **Lǚ** is permissible."* The empress rejoiced. After court dismissed, **Líng** reproached **Píng** and **Bó**: *"Did you not witness the High Ancestor’s blood-oath? Now that he has passed, the empress seeks to enthrone the **Lǚ**—how can you, flattering her, face him in the underworld?"* **Píng** and **Bó** replied: *"Now, we dare speak plainly in court—you cannot. Preserving the state and securing the **Liú** lineage—you cannot either."* **Líng** had no response.

*The Record* says: What difference is there between the **Qián Tóng** (剪桐) oath and the blood-oath? **Chóu Yú** (叔虞), though a hand and foot relative, was enfeoffed by decree—thus **Zhōu Gōng** (周公) had reason to fulfill it. The **Lǚ** were private favorites; their enthronement was perverse—thus **Wáng Líng** (王陵) had reason to oppose it. This is the duty of a minister; **Wáng Líng**’s stance was correct, while **Píng** and **Bó**’s words were unworthy.

Empress **Dòu** (窦) of **Wén Dì** (文帝) had an elder brother, **Láng Jūn** (郎君), and a younger brother, **Guǎng Guó** (广国), whose courtesy name was **Shào Jūn** (少君). When he was four or five, his family was poor, and he was sold into slavery by bandits. His family lost track of him, and he passed through over ten households until reaching **Yìyáng** (宜阳), where he worked in the mountains cutting charcoal. One evening, as he slept by the riverbank, a landslide buried over a hundred people—yet **Shào Jūn** escaped unharmed. He returned to **Cháng’ān** (长安), where fortune-tellers said he would soon become a marquis. At the time, the empress had just been enthroned, and her family lived in **Guānjīn** (观津), bearing the surname **Dòu**. Though **Guǎng Guó** was young, he remembered the county name and surname, and recalled his sister had once fallen while picking mulberries with him—details he used as verification. He wrote to the empress, who told the emperor, who summoned him. **Guǎng Guó** recounted his story, and it was confirmed. The emperor further questioned him: *"When your sister left you, she gave you a message at the inn, bathed you after ten days, and fed you before departing."* The empress wept, bestowed great riches upon him, and enfeoffed his brother as **Jiàng Hóu** (绛侯).

**Guàn Jiāng Jūn** (灌将军) and others said: *"We owe our lives to fate, yet we would hang these two men."* These two men’s origins were humble, and their rise was extraordinary—worthy of guidance and transmission. Moreover, they were involved in the **Cháng** (昌) family’s great affairs. Thus, they were placed under the care of virtuous elders of upright conduct, and from then on, they became modest and unassuming, never abusing their wealth and power.

*The Record* says: I observe that **Han**’s great scholars were unclear in their teachings. They gathered the emperor’s eldest and younger sons but did not educate them—yet they singled out these two men for instruction. Truly, they did not understand their kind. As for **Jiàng** and **Guàn**, what did they not scheme for themselves? At first, they feared retribution; in the end, they dreaded losing their lives. Given their humble origins—rare in history—how much more cautious would they be if they held power for generations? The decline of the **Mǎng** (莽) dynasty did not begin overnight.

From the *History of Sòng* (宋史): When **Wáng Ānshí** (王安石) held power, **Wáng Ānlǐ** (王安礼) submitted a memorial: *"When human affairs falter below, omens appear above. Your Majesty has a heart for benevolence and compassion, yet your blessings do not reach the people. The cause lies with the great ministers around you—unjust and crooked, they slander the loyal as disloyal, elevate the unworthy as virtuous. Those who wield power exploit it for private gain, their efforts as futile as digging in ditches or gathering in gardens. Their actions disrupt the harmony of **yin** and **yang**, summoning celestial anomalies. If you investigate the conduct of those close to you, block the gates of deceit, and perform rites of supplication—even a few sincere words would suffice to avert heavenly retribution."*

Shénzōng, upon reading the memorial, praised and sighed, replying: *"Wáng Guī wishes you to elaborate fully, but I say you should not obstruct or resist the words of others, lest you blind yourself. Now, if one covers his eyes with a single finger, even Mount Tàihé before him would remain unseen—how different is this from those close confidants who blind their sovereign? This is where you must place greater trust in yourself."*

Shénzōng further addressed the chief ministers: *"Fù Bì has submitted a memorial."* Zhāng Dùn asked, *"What does Bì speak of?"* The Emperor replied, *"He says those around me are filled with petty men."* Dùn said, *"Let him be examined—who among them are petty?"* The Emperor said, *"Bì is a veteran minister of three reigns—how can I order him examined?"* Left Chancellor Wáng Ānlǐ said, *"Bì’s words are correct."* After court adjourned, Dùn rebuked Ānlǐ: *"Your words to the throne were mistaken."* Ānlǐ replied, *"If today we speak sincerely as you describe, and tomorrow claim the Emperor’s wisdom surpasses our own, how can we not be called [□ □ □ □] in response?"*

Lù recorded: *"From ancient times, treacherous ministers might deceive their sovereign, yet could not deceive their own households; they might deceive the realm, yet could not deceive those of shared breath. If one brother says, ‘Celestial omens are not to be feared, nor are the words of men,’ while another says, ‘When human affairs falter below, omens appear above,’ and if their sovereign declares, ‘A single finger covering the eye obscures even Mount Tàihé,’ and their chief ministers add, ‘Those close about the throne are many petty men, blocking their sovereign’s path’—is this not perfectly clear? Yet still they cannot be moved. This seems contrary to reason—does Heaven truly steal their natural judgment, as when a great cart lacks its draft poles and a small one lacks its axle?"*

The Way is not thus—waiting upon one’s elder brother as an aide, yet failing to fulfill his trust, while the younger brother rebels against the elder and yet claims the elder should trust him even more. Even if he were misled, how could he fall so utterly?

In the Song dynasty’s Yuanfong eighth year (1085), the elder brother, Cheng Hao (伯淳), of the Henan Cheng clan, passed away. His younger brother, Cheng Yi (文颜), inscribed his tomb: *"Mingdao Master."* In response, Cheng Yi composed:

*"When Zhou Gong died, the Way of the Sage did not prevail.
When Mencius died, the Sage’s learning was not passed on.
The Way not prevailing, a hundred generations lacked good governance.
The learning not transmitted, a thousand years lacked true Confucians.
Good governance not achieved, yet scholars still could discern its essence.
But when true Confucians vanish, men drift without direction—human desires prevail, and Heaven’s principle is extinguished.*

*Our Master was born fourteen hundred years later, retrieving the untransmitted learning from the ancient texts and taking upon himself the task of reviving this tradition. He refuted heterodoxies, rejected false teachings, and made the Sage’s Way resplendent once more in the world. Since Mencius, he stands alone.*

*Yet scholars, lost in their pursuit of the Way, do not recognize his achievement. They do not grasp its depth, nor do they understand the fittingness of his name.*

*Recorded is his conduct: his upright bearing, measured steps, and composed speech—none questioned his parents or siblings on these matters. Mingdao’s teachings were the unbroken transmission of sages and the lineage of teachers and friends, not mere speculation from private reflection.*

*Yet while You Gong could inscribe his epitaph, he could not compose his eulogy. Why?*

*The two brothers, in their time, were equals in virtue and achievement—like jade and precious stones, their worth was unmatched. Yet the connoisseur distinguished their grades, and the world may doubt this judgment.*

*Compare this to the case of An Li suing An Shi—how could they be likened?*

*Wang Cheng (王庠), the younger brother, recorded their family’s ancestral residence as the *Yimen* (義門, "Hall of Righteousness"). His father, Wang Mengyi (王梦易), once served as acting governor of Xingzhou and later oversaw tea distribution in Sichuan, establishing tea shops and conscripting labor. The regional governor resented his authority and, under false charges, demoted him by three ranks before he died in disgrace. His mother, Lady Xiang (向氏), was the aunt of Empress Chen Shengxian (钦肃皇后). She mourned with such fervor that her grief was extreme.*

*Cheng told his brother: ‘Our father was driven out for his integrity. Mother, holding his coffin, swore we must succeed in restoring his rank before she would allow burial. We must strive together.’ Thus, they shut themselves away, immersing themselves in classics and history, seeking teachers far and wide, and probing the essence of the Way.*

*In his youth, Cheng wrote to the chancellor, advocating balanced, impartial governance. Both Tao Qiu (陶渊明) and Su Xie (苏辙) held him in high regard. He also sent a letter to Su Shi (苏轼) on the *Classics*, stating:*

*"In the ages of the Two Sovereigns and Three Kings, scholars aspired to moral cultivation. Because self-realization was so difficult, their resolve was unshakable. Since Confucius and Mencius established the Six Classics, the Way became fixed in doctrine, and scholars’ cultivation lagged behind the ancients. Thus, later ages, seeing the Classics as easy, neglected them and failed to practice them."*

*Su Shi replied: ‘Truly, your words are profound.’*

*During the Yuanyou era (1086–1094), Lü Tao (吕陶) recommended him for the *Yingzhi* (应制) examination. He then critiqued the times’ failures, declaring: ‘Obstruction within and without will breed military threats.’ His younger brother returned home in defeat.*

*In the Daoguang era (1107–1110), when the *xingshe* (行舍) system was implemented, he was again summoned by imperial decree. He declined, saying: ‘Earlier, I sought office to care for my aging mother; now that she is old and I answer the decree, is this truly my original intent?’ Instead, his brother was elevated to court, his father’s rank was posthumously restored, and only then was burial permitted. After his mother’s death and the completion of mourning, he was again recommended for the *Baxing* (八行) examination. The Grand Secretary deemed him first in the land, and an edict honored his family.*

*The empress dowager once wished to appoint him, but he consistently deferred to his brother. After Cheng’s death, Emperor Xiaozong (孝宗) posthumously conferred the title *Xianjie* (贤节, "Virtuous and Righteous").*

*Recorded is this: ‘How difficult it is to maintain integrity in later years! Cheng, with his sincerity and love of learning, did not seek advancement lightly. He delighted in honoring his kin and trusted friends, never scheming for wealth or status. Some may criticize his later years for seeming to wane in resolve, but scholars must take heed.*

*Others say: Cheng was a noble kinsman of great influence. Initially, he refined himself, associating with eminent scholars and seeking to uphold his family’s prestige. Yet in the end, his fortunes fluctuated, and he achieved nothing of lasting worth, fulfilling only his own ambitions. His lavish estate and imperial honors were perhaps unavoidable, but one cannot demand of him the grandeur of Yu Yuan’s conduct or Zhongche’s integrity. Observers must understand this.*

*As for Emperor Lizong (理宗), his childhood name was Yuju (与莒), and his younger brother was Yujie (与苒). During the *Qianlong* era (潜龙), soothsayers had foretold that the two would rise to great nobility, though few believed it. At the time, Shi Miyi (史弥远) had long held the chancellor’s office, and Prince Zhan (皇子站) despised him. The chancellor, pondering a successor, saw an opportunity when Prince Yi of Yi (沂靖王) had no heir and could be manipulated as a pretext. Among the chancellor’s guests was Yu Tianshi (余天锡), a man of scrupulous integrity who avoided external affairs. Shi Miyi held him in high regard.*

*When Yu Tianshi prepared to return home for the provincial examinations, Shi said: ‘Prince Yi has no heir. If there are worthy and virtuous princes among your kin, I would be honored if you could bring them forward.’ Yu Tianshi crossed the Yangtze to the western gate of Yue (越), where a torrential rain forced him to take shelter. A village elder named Quanbao (全保) invited him in, offering him a meal. The elder was distinguished by his dignified beard, and soon introduced his two grandsons to stand before him. Yu Tianshi was struck by their bearing and asked about them. Quanbao said, ‘These are my grandsons.’ Yu Tianshi recalled the chancellor’s request and, deeming their lineage fitting, reported them. Shi Miyi summoned the boys, examined them, and was greatly impressed. Fearing leaks, he hastily sent them back.*

*Quanbao was overjoyed. The following year, Shi Miyi suddenly asked Yu Tianshi: ‘Could the two boys return?’ Quanbao declined, but Shi secretly instructed him: ‘The elder will rise highest—he should be nurtured at home.’*

「Not long after, he was summoned to succeed the Prince of Yi (嗣沂王), and thus ascended to the imperial throne—this was Emperor Lizong (理宗). 录 said: ‘In my humble view, Yu Tianshi (余天锡) and Zheng Qing (郑清) both attained high office through their scholarly pursuits, while Zhao Yujin (赵与莒) and Zhao Yurang (赵与苒) rose from common citizens to the lofty heights of imperial favor. At this time, the weight of the eight prerogatives and the dignity of the nine ranks lay in the breath and grasp of those who could sway advancement and decline, yet the court did not hear of it, nor did the Empress Mother know. The empire of Song now rested merely on an empty name.’

In such circumstances, how could loyalty not run deep, trust not be absolute, favor not be supreme, and yet the tutors and ministers dare not again impose their will, nor the designated heir rely on their support? The *Book of Changes* (《易》) speaks of ‘what is not sealed will not be completed,’ and the *Book of Odes* (《诗》) warns of ‘ears listening at the wall’—these are words about power.

The *Comprehensive Records* (《通志》) states: Li Chengfang (李承芳) of Mingjia (明嘉鱼), styled Moqing (茂卿) and surnamed Dongjiao (东娇), with his younger brother Li Chengji (李承箕), styled Shiqing (世卿) and surnamed Dayaya (大崖), both cultivated themselves with austere resolve, cherished antiquity, and strove to embody its virtues. They harbored lofty ideals, their *qi* (气) unyielding to the world’s inclinations. Their studies did not dwell on pedantic commentary but sought to penetrate directly the essence left by Confucius and Mencius. When young, their father pointed to a local scholar, Kong the Censor (孔御史), who loved reciting the classics, clad in purple robes and girdled with gold, and asked, ‘Do you believe this? Can you follow his example?’ They replied, ‘We do not indulge in wealth nor lament poverty—our brother admires this path alone.’

When they grew older and became *xiangsheng* (庠生, students of the village school), they despised the pursuit of official examinations. The local authorities pressed them, and when they took the test, they both passed by chance. Upon reading the annotations of earlier scholars, they deemed them as fragmenting the sacred texts, saying, ‘The *Shijing* (《诗》) and *Shujing* (《书》) are the nearest foundations of our Dao (道).’ Since ancient times, the greatest harm to the hearts of the people has been none more than that caused by the *xueguan* (学官, officials of learning); the greatest harm to the cultivation of scholars has been none more than that wrought by the examination system; the most shameless in leading the masses without restraint has been none more than today’s teachers and generals. They resolved to abolish all such practices entirely.

Seeking true teachers and venerable scholars, they treated them as the virtuous men of their village—then they would teach one village; as the virtuous men of their country—then they would teach one country; only then would they be considered worthy. When they paid respects to the Grand Magistrate of the Supreme Court (大理评事), they sighed and said, ‘This office cannot save lives nor discern the shifts of the times; my body cannot bend to the world’s demands nor rise to its heights. I am unworthy of this post.’ Thus, they declined due to illness and returned home.

Shiqing (世卿) once attended the provincial examination, but upon returning, he did not hesitate to travel a thousand miles to study under Chen Baisha (陈白沙). With him, they ascended heights and lamented antiquity, composed poetry and inscribed calligraphy, yet none surpassed his method of true learning. After some time, he exclaimed in joy, ‘I have attained it!’ For learning is not merely transmitted through words—this is not true transmission. There are those whose eyes are bound, yet whose Dao remains intact. Thus, he returned home, abandoning all ambitions for advancement, and daily sat alone in a chamber, purifying his body and mind, without climbing the ranks but directly seeking the fundamental truth. In matters of seniority, they treated each other as teacher and friend.

Later, he inscribed Chen Baisha’s tombstone with the words: ‘The void establishes the foundation; movement attains the divine. Doubt is contained within it, as heaven soars and the depths plunge.’ The gentlemen took this as his own insight.

录 said: ‘Wang Wenku (王文恪) remarked: There is one who feels indignation at the common practices of the world and expresses it through his singular vision. What the world approves, I alone reject; what the world condemns, I alone do not reject. What I reject and do not reject is what my heart finds at ease. What does my heart find at ease? It is *li* (理, principle), it is *yi* (义, righteousness). Are not such as these two gentlemen the ones who stand firmly in their convictions and are unmoved by external influences?’

*Principles of the Great Dao*, Volume 54, Complete.
Volume 55, Trust.

(Original text: 「期」—corrected to 「欺」 based on context.)

**The Trust of Friends**

From *The Great Chronicle of the Sovereigns*: Shun at the age of twenty, his filial piety and loyalty to friends renowned among people, had seven friends: Xiong Tao (雄陶), Fang Hui (方回), Xu Ya (续牙), Bo Yang (伯阳), Dong Bu Zui (东不訾), Qin Bu Xu (秦不虚), and Ling Fu (灵甫). At that time, he did not speak for the sake of speaking, nor did his words lack purpose; he wielded the *Black Virtue* (玄德) with resolve, transforming it in his heart, swift as divine command. Without trust, even if one’s words were eloquent and heard by all, one could not transform even a single person.

*Record of the Great Dao* said: These seven cannot be verified.

If one speaks of *li* (理, principle) and *yi* (义, righteousness), which the common people do not see, there is still much more they do not know. *Recorded.*

*The Transmission of the Great Learning* states: "In dealing with the people of one’s state, one must stop at trust."

*Record of the Great Dao* said: What people did King Wen deal with? He had Bo Yi and Tai Gong as his exemplary teachers, and Da Dian (大颠), Hun Yao (闳夭), San Yi (散宜), Sheng (生), Nan Guan (南官), and Bao as his loyal attendants and ministers. If the roots of *shu* (芍, *Pueraria lobata*) were not firmly established, then every word and deed would be nothing but flattery and deceit. The affairs of *gu* (苟, temporizing), *ze* (责, blame), *li* (戾, calamity), and *wang* (罔, confusion)—if one served the Shang (殷) dynasty with such motives, it would be mere hollow words. Thus, it does not say "friends" but "the people of one’s state," for in dividing the realm into three, he held two-thirds of the mandate. *The Analects* state: The Master said, "Take trust as the foundation among friends."

*Record of the Great Dao* said: Trust in the Five Constants (五常) is like the earth among the Five Phases (五行), the foundation upon which one stands firm and completes the beginning and end. If one does not uphold this, then one’s nature and alignment with the *Dao* (天道) are merely words passed from mouth to ear. The practice of the *junzi* (君子) has not yet reached the level of true cultivation, yet one dismisses me as an eccentric, as hidden, as knowing, or as overly learned. Then comes the confusion.

Only trust is such that one’s words are as boundless as heaven, and one’s actions are as steadfast as earth. Neither exhaustion nor the four teachings (四教) can diminish it. It is difficult to display in speech, yet difficult to conceal in silence—only when it is resolute and true can it stand. Later, those who take trust as their foundation for all ages, their reverence for virtue and repayment of merit, are none other than these. Thus, is this not the very intention of the Sage?

Further, it discusses the duties of a disciple: "Be cautious and trustworthy; extend universal love and hold close to the virtuous." It discusses the learning of the *junzi*: "Take loyalty and trust as the foundation; do not befriend those who are not like yourself."

*Record of the Great Dao* said: The duties of a disciple are not yet the concern of those who seek learning. The *junzi*’s learning, however, is the business of the *daren* (大人). Yet one says "cautious and trustworthy" while the other says "take loyalty and trust as the foundation"—why is there no distinction? Learning is to align with the times and cultivate habits; delight is to harmonize with friends. These are all matters of human nature, from the novice to the Sage, one and the same. It is only that people fail to observe this: some, when speaking of the novice, regard caution and trust as essential, but when discussing the affairs of the *daren*, treat trust as a minor matter and friendship as frivolous. They do not know that the essential path to governing the state and pacifying the world is to be found in loyalty and trust, and lost through arrogance and complacency.

Thus, the *junzi* cannot neglect loyalty and trust, for they are the foundation.

Zengzi said: "Can one be trusted in dealings with friends?"
Zixia said: "In dealings with friends, one’s words must be trustworthy."
Youzi said: "Trust is close to righteousness; words can be reconsidered."

*Record of the Great Dao* said: From ancient times, trust has been spoken of as the root of all things. Why focus solely on friends?

Father and son are bound by nature, brothers by affection, ruler and subject by righteous duty, husband and wife by form. Each has a clear, unalterable division, and one’s heart and resolve cannot diverge from it, nor can one’s words and deeds ignore it. But friends—those from east, west, south, or north—once gathered, share no kinship of bone and flesh, nor fixed mandate of heaven. Their depths are uncertain, their intentions unclear. Without trust to sustain them, there is no way to ensure their loyalty like that of a ruler and subject, or their steadfastness like that of a husband and wife, or their unbreakable bond like that of father and son or brothers.

If one does not care for their sincerity, what does one know of their clasped hands?
If one does not heed their words, what does one know of their shoulder-taps?
This is not unlike the lament of *Gu Feng* (谷风) or the mockery of the *Gui* (鬼) of the netherworld.

Yet the most essential and most essential thing is to establish trust and harmonize with what is fitting. If one does not harmonize with what is fitting, then there are those called "dying companions," those called "mercenary friendships," and those like the conduct of Tai Sheng (尾生) and Bai Gong (白公). Among the Sage’s disciples, Param (参) upheld the agreements, Shang (商) was deeply trustworthy, Ruo (若) diligently rooted himself in principle. Thus, trust in the *Dao* was firmly established.

The joy of having friends is such as this—how can the scholar afford to neglect it? The Master sent Qi Diao (漆雕开) to serve, and he replied: "I have not yet attained trust." The Master was pleased. *Record of the Great Dao* said: The Master said, "Ancient scholars cultivated for themselves; modern scholars cultivate for others." Those who cultivate for themselves seek attainment within themselves: "I have not yet attained trust." Those who cultivate for others seek recognition from others: there are the common people, there are the ancestral altars and the state granaries—why must one read books before calling oneself a scholar?

Ah! Knowing the thief who harms the lamb, one understands the Master’s words.

He told Fan Xu (樊须): "If the ruler values trust, then the people will not dare to betray their sincerity. If this is so, then the people from all four directions will bring their children to settle here—why would one need to marry?"

*Record of the Great Dao* said: Others have intentions; I measure them. The Sage has never abandoned sincerity. The one without sincerity cannot find the right words, nor has he ever indulged in mere sentiment. Yet this is beyond what Fan Xu could comprehend.

Though the virtuous recognize the greater truth, and the less virtuous recognize the lesser, Yi Yin (伊尹) plowed as a farmer, and the Duke of Zhou (周公) managed agriculture—these were their outward appearances. But in their hearts, they delighted in the *Dao* of Yao and Shun, and in the affairs of the Three Sovereigns (三王).

Thus, even common folk and common women may not be blessed by the virtue of Yao and Shun. If one were to cast them into the ditch, would they not still act with sincerity? The heavens have not sent violent winds or torrential rains, nor has the sea raised its waves—this has lasted three years now. Perhaps there is a Sage in the Central States, who has never failed to value trust.

This is why our scholars are matched with Heaven and share with Earth, not sharing the same fate as the mere four classes of commoners—precisely because of this. If we take this as a lesson, there are still followers of Chen Liang, like Chen Xiang, who abandon their learning to study Xu Xing instead.

From the *Spring and Autumn Annals*: When Ji Zha passed through Xu, the ruler of Xu admired his sword but dared not speak of it. Ji Zha knew this in his heart and did not yet present it as a tribute to the superior states. Upon returning to Xu, the ruler of Xu had already died, so Ji Zha unsheathed his sword and struck the tree of the Xu ruler’s house before departing. His attendants said, *"The ruler of Xu is already dead—who remains to receive this?"* The *Rites* say, *"No. My heart had already promised it—how could I, upon his death, betray my sincerity?"*

The *Record* says: The ruler of Xu’s desire for the sword was not yet revealed, yet Ji Zha knew it by heart. The intention of Shou Meng in establishing Ji Zha was also not yet revealed, yet Ji Zha knew it by heart. It was not about the sword itself, but about confirming his own trustworthiness. Thus, if one’s heart cannot be betrayed, then the refusal of a state becomes clearly justified.

Han Xuanzhi had a jade pendant, one of which was with Zheng Shang, who had already sold it. The merchant said, *"You must inform your lord."* Han Xuanzhi asked Zi Chan: *"I will request the pendant from you. If the officials do not approve, I dare not take it again. Now I am buying it from the merchant, who says I must report it—dare I ask your permission?"*

Zi Chan replied: *"Our former lord, Duke Huan, and the merchants all originated from Zhou. When they were common laborers, they swore an oath with a bundle of *Ai* grass, cutting reeds and wild plants, and lived together. There was a covenant: 'Do not betray me, and I will not force you into unfair trade. If either party seizes profit or treasures, the other shall not be informed.' Relying on this oath, they have protected each other until today. Now you come with favor and shame us, yet claim our city forcibly takes the merchant’s goods—this contradicts our ancient oath. Would it not be better to refrain? You gain the jade but lose the alliance of the feudal lords—this you would not do."* He dared to announce this publicly.

Han Xuanzhi declined the jade and secretly visited Zi Chan to pay his respects and offer the gift. The *Record* says: This was about maintaining trust in dealings with the people. It shows that even in the smallest matters, the ancients would not betray trust or break promises. Yet later generations sometimes considered such matters harmless—only to see harm follow swiftly. Thus, gaining the jade while losing the alliance of the feudal lords was already a reality in the *Spring and Autumn* era. Who, then, could truly emulate Han Xuanzhi’s willingness to correct his mistakes?

The people of Zheng gathered in the village schools to discuss the officials. Ran Ming openly said to Zi Chan: *"How can we destroy the village schools?"* Zi Chan asked, *"Why?"* He said: *"People retire in the morning and evening to discuss the officials’ good deeds—I will implement them. What they dislike, I will change. This is my teacher. If so, why destroy them? I have heard that loyalty and goodness reduce resentment, not that tyranny prevents it. If I were to suppress it abruptly, the damage would be like a great flood breaking its banks—many would be harmed, and I could not save them. It is better to make a small mistake and correct it through guidance."* Ran Ming said: *"Alas, only now do I know that your sincerity is worthy of serving."* Though I am unworthy, if I truly carried this out, Zheng would indeed rely on me.

The *Record* says: Han Yu once composed an ode: *"When Zhou rose, the elders sought counsel; when it declined, slanderers were appointed as censors. Only Zi Chan, the model of governance, was not met with his due. His influence transformed but one state."* Perhaps this was lamenting the past. He also said: *"If one sincerely follows this Way, governing the world’s lords, their virtue spreads far and wide, benefiting all under Heaven. Alas, the four seas are ungoverned—there are rulers but no ministers."* Perhaps this was lamenting the future.

Yet, considering how the gentleman conducts himself: In times of order, speaking and acting boldly—like the people of Zheng gathering in the village schools. In times of disorder, acting cautiously and speaking modestly—like the Duke of Zhou’s virtue in the case of the Wei pervert. Thus, discussing officials in times of peace is acceptable, but censoring slander in times of chaos is not. To consider only whether it is condemned, without reflecting on whether it is right or wrong, is mere empty talk. This is something one must truly understand.

The Sea Crow spoke: *"It dwells outside the eastern gate of Lu."* Two days later, Zang Wen Zhong had the people of the state sacrifice to it. Zhan Qin remarked: *"How excessive! Zang Sun’s governance!"*

Sacrifice is the great ritual of the state. The sage-kings established sacrifices according to this principle: if one’s actions benefit the people, they are enshrined; if one dies in service, they are enshrined; if one labors to stabilize the state, they are enshrined; if one wards off great calamities, they are enshrined; if one alleviates great sufferings, they are enshrined. Those who do not meet these criteria are not included in the sacrificial rites.

The five categories—*jiao* (sacrifices to the land), *zong* (ancestral rites), *zu* (sacrifices to the state’s founders), *fu* (sacrifices to the five great sacrifices), and *bao* (sacrifices to the five great offerings)—are the state’s established rites. Added to these are the altars of the soil and grain, the mountains and rivers, all of which have rendered great merit to the people. The three celestial luminaries, which the people revere; the five phases of earth, which bring forth life; the nine regions, great mountains, and rivers, which provide wealth and resources—these are the foundations of the state’s prosperity.

Now, the Sea Crow has arrived, yet it is unknown and uninquired after, and yet it is being sacrificed to without merit, as if it were an established ritual. This is difficult to call both virtuous and wise. Will this year bring disaster to the sea?

The birds and beasts of the broad waters instinctively know and avoid calamity. This year, the sea has seen great winds and winter frosts. Zang Wen Zhong, hearing the words of Liu Xia Ji, said: *"Indeed, I have erred."* The words of the Master of Liu Xia are not to be disregarded. He ordered them recorded as the *San Jia* (Three Admonitions). The record states: *"Liu Xia Hui was harmonious in nature—why were his words so decisive, not mere empty conformity?"*

The Sea Crow’s ignorance is a minor fault; not inquiring after it is a grave one. A high official, the people’s model and guide, whose actions determine their obedience or defiance—if he persists in error and never acknowledges his faults, this has indeed happened before.

Yet there were ancient officials who were open-hearted, joyful in goodness, balanced in spirit and calm in *qi*—none of them held rigid personal opinions. Some might call this lack of obstinacy unvirtuous. But to know yet feign ignorance, to accept frank criticism, and to acknowledge and correct one’s faults—this is true wisdom, this is true sincerity.

Cheng Ying and Gong Sun Chujiu were guests of Zhao Shuo. During the disaster at Xia Gong’s palace, Chujiu said to Cheng Ying: *"Why do you not die?"* Ying replied: *"Zhao Shuo’s wife is with child. If a son is born, I will raise him. If it is a daughter, I will die soon enough."* Soon after, a son was born, and Tu An Jia learned of it and demanded the child. Zhao Shuo’s wife hid the boy in a basket and prayed: *"If the Zhao lineage perishes, may this jade shatter. If it does not, may it remain silent."* When Tu An Jia searched for the child, the jade made no sound. After escaping, Ying told Chujiu: *"Now one search has failed, but they will return. What shall we do?"* Chujiu said: *"Choosing between saving the orphan or dying—which is harder?"* Ying replied: *"Saving the orphan is harder."* Chujiu said: *"The Zhao ancestors treated you generously. You take on the harder task, so I will take the easier."* The two plotted to take another infant, wrap it in fine cloth, and hide it in the mountains, then send word to summon the troops. Chujiu said: *"What a petty man Cheng Ying is! Unable to die, he conspires to hide the orphan—and now he sells him too."* He embraced the child and cried out, begging for its life, but was refused. They killed Chujiu as well, and the generals rejoiced.

Yet the true orphan lived on, hidden with Ying. Fifteen years later, Duke Jing fell ill. When divination was performed, it was said: *"The descendants of the two great houses will not perish."* Chong Gong asked Han Yue, who knew the Zhao orphan still lived. He said: *"The descendants of the two great houses have been cut off—perhaps it is the Zhao lineage."* He then revealed the truth. Duke Jing summoned the orphan.

When the generals entered to inquire after the duke’s health, Jing used Han Yue’s forces to coerce them into seeing the Zhao orphan. Yue said: *"The disaster was caused by Tu An Jia. Had it not been for your illness, the ministers would have already petitioned to restore the Zhao heir. Now that you have given the order, the ministers are in agreement."* Thus, Zhao Wu was summoned, and the generals knelt in submission. They attacked Tu An Jia, exterminated his clan, and restored the Zhao lands.

Ying then took leave of Zhao Wu, saying: *"Long ago, I did not die so that the Zhao lineage might endure. Now that you are established, I will descend to report to Zhao Meng and Gong Sun Chujiu."* Wu wept and begged: *"I beg you, strain your body to the utmost, and serve until death. How can you abandon me?"* Ying said: *"It cannot be. They believed they could accomplish the task, so they died before me. If I do not descend to report, it will be as if my mission failed."* He then killed himself.

The record states: *"In my view, the loyalty of Cheng Ying and Chujiu does not fall short of Li Ke and Gu Si’s service to their lord. Loyalty is not merely about being unashamed of difficult words but also about consistently fulfilling one’s promises.

Before Shen Sheng’s death, Gu Si was honored as a high minister, and Li Ke served as the prime tutor—unlike the two men, who were merely guests. Had these two ministers exerted themselves wholeheartedly, united in purpose, and taken on the difficult tasks while dividing the easier ones, personally escorting the prince into exile as Ying preserved the orphan, it could have been done. That Shen Sheng did not escape and Li Ke did not perish with him—this was Li Ke’s greatest failing. To personally await execution in court, as Chujiu falsely accused himself, could also have been done. But failing that, to rely on figures like Ji Qi and Zhi Zi to devise shifting strategies—this was precisely what Ying called the ‘harder’ path. The danger lay in a single search; if they had not been forced to kill again, it would have been clear.

Alas! A mere orphan, yet a noble lord. If one believes the difficult is impossible, the living may die; if one believes the easy is certain, the living may perish. This is evident in the four men.

As for the idea of descending to report—generally, the scholars of the *Spring and Autumn* would not delve deeply into such matters. When Jin held Duke Xiang captive, Duke Li of Wu saw Xiang and said: *"I will plead your case."*

Chu Xiang made no reply and left without bowing. The others all blamed Chu Xiang, but he said, *"It must be Qi Dai."*

The senior retainers heard this and said, *"Le Wang’s words to the lord were unrestrained—nothing was left undone. He sought pardon for your son, but your son refused Qi Dai. This was beyond the power of the ministers. Yet he insists it must be so—why?"*

Chu Xiang replied, *"Le Wang is a follower of the lord—how could he act alone? Qi Dai, when recommending others, never discarded even the lowliest; when promoting from within, he never overlooked his kin. Yet he alone abandoned me."*

Now Qi Dai was old. Hearing this, he hurried by courier to see Prince Yuan and said:

*"The *Odes* say: ‘Grant me no harshness, that my descendants may preserve it.’ The *Book of Documents* says: ‘The sage’s counsel is steadfast, his virtue unwearied—thus he secures and preserves.’ He who plans with few errors and teaches with unflagging kindness—Chu Xiang is such a man, the bulwark of the state. Even if his descendants were to be spared for ten generations, it would be to encourage the worthy. But now, he is not even spared himself, and the state is abandoned—is this not bewildering?

Gun was prolonged, and Yu arose. Guan and Cai were executed, yet the Duke of Zhou upheld the king. How could one, with the ferocity of a tiger, abandon the state?"*

Prince Yuan was pleased, took Qi Dai with him, and spoke to the ministers, securing his pardon. Chu Xiang was not informed, and when he was freed, he attended court as usual.

The record says: *"I observe Chu Xiang’s affair and sigh at the difficulty of ascending like Mount Song and the ease of collapsing like a cliff. The one who would spare ten generations is the path to encouraging the worthy; ‘my descendants shall preserve it’ is the matter of perpetuating the lineage. Yet with the Ji She clan, one Chu Xiang’s virtue was insufficient to sustain it, while one Chu Hu’s ruin was more than enough. This is something to fear, yet not to rely upon.

Though Qi Dai’s words temporarily spared one man’s humiliation, yet Bo Shi further damaged his lineage—where is the ten-generation pardon now? Thus, the virtuous man is ever vigilant. Even if he has merit, he cannot rely upon it, let alone the degenerate descendants of licentious and greedy ancestors.

Now, observing the origins of these two men’s misfortunes, they all stemmed from the words of their junior officials. Though the historian may not trace their full consequences, if one seeks to benefit his lineage, he must heed the warnings of Yin’s downfall.

Chu Xiang traveled to Zheng. He Ming’s son, Hei Mei, wished to see him and, following the baggage carriers, stood beneath the hall’s eaves. With a single word, he corrected him.

Chu Xiang heard this and said, *"It must be He Ming’s son."*

He took his hand and raised him, saying: *"In days past, Jia Dai had a wife of great beauty. For three years, he neither spoke nor smiled. When he drove to Ru Gao and shot a pheasant, his wife first laughed and spoke. Jia Dai said: ‘Talent cannot be suppressed—if I could not shoot, you would not have spoken or laughed.’ Now, though you are young and unrenowned, if you had remained silent, I would have nearly lost you. The necessity of speech is such."*

They parted as old acquaintances.

The record says: *"I ponder the ancients’ love of virtue—truly, it was as if they could not help themselves—and sigh at how modern men abandon themselves and neglect their duties. Mencius said: ‘If Xi Zi were covered in filth, all would hold their noses and pass by. Yet even with evil men, if they fast, bathe, and purify themselves, they may serve the Lord on High.’ Though appearance may not suffice for attendance, how much more so for virtue!

To seek Chu Xiang—why? For his vast learning? For his virtue? Yet in the end, he was praised for his virtuous observation alone, known and valued for his discernment. Imagine, in the moment he descended the hall, when their hands met—what joy was there!

The *Odes of Zhou* say: ‘Having seen the noble one, he bestows upon me a hundred *peng*.’ What was gained was far more than a single pheasant! A wife like this—was it not enough to rejoice over?

Wu Can of Chu and Cai Tai Shi’s son, Zi Chao, were friends. Their sons, Wu Ju and Sheng Zi, were also close. Wu Ju married into the family of Wang Zi Nian, who later became Shen Gong and fled. The people of Chu said, ‘Wu Ju must have sent him away.’ Ju fled to Zheng and was about to proceed to Jin. Sheng Zi, intending to go to Jin, met him on the outskirts of Zheng. They spread out their mats and ate together, renewing their old friendship. Sheng Zi said, ‘You are departing—I will certainly restore you.’

Arriving in Song, Xiang Wu’s general was about to pacify Jin and Chu. Sheng Zi served as an envoy to Jin. Upon returning to Chu, Ling Yin Zi Mu asked, ‘Which is more virtuous, the ministers of Jin or those of Chu?’ He replied, ‘The ministers of Jin are not as virtuous as those of Chu—their great officers are all of ministerial caliber. Even if they were to attack with leather and hide, coming from Chu, though Chu may have talent, Jin would truly employ it.’

Zi Mu said, ‘Surely there are kinsmen among them?’ He replied, ‘Though there are, Chu’s talents are truly the ones being used. Now there is one even worse than Wu Ju marrying into Shen Gong. Shen Gong fled, and it was said that Ju had sent him away. Fearful, he fled to Zheng, stretching his neck southward, hoping for pardon—yet none came. Now he is in Jin, and the Jinese intend to execute him, comparing him to Chu Gou. If he conspires to harm Chu, would he not be a menace?’

Zi Mu feared this and spoke to the king, increasing his rank and restoring him. Sheng Zi sent Wu Jiao to welcome him back.

The record says: *"Sheng Zi’s assessment of Chu’s talents mirrors Li Si’s argument for retaining the exiles—his words and intent are identical. ‘If it is mine, I shall cherish it; if I do not cherish it, others will seize it’—the past serves as a warning. Learning from history is to caution the future.

To exhaust one’s abilities for today’s Wu Ju is to repay kindness; yet to fail to cherish talent tomorrow is to invite the fate of Wu Sha. One day, Zi Jin fled to He Men, and the men of Wu he employed were those praised by Gui Sheng. Jin then turned and gave them to others. Only then did the ‘spreading mats and renewing old friendships’ prove that, though bonds of friendship were not abandoned, the pity for talent and love of men were what the state must prioritize.

Perhaps this is not just about superficial exchanges of heart, but truly heeding the calamities of listening to slander and favoring the unworthy."*

Wu Yuan and Shen Bao Xu were friends. When Wu Yuan fled, he told Shen Bao Xu: *"I will surely avenge the state of Chu."* Shen Bao Xu replied: *"Endeavor, my friend. If you can avenge it, I will surely revive it."*

When King Zhao of Chu was besieged in Sui, Shen Bao Xu went to Qin to beg for aid, saying: *"The Lord of Heaven has made the Brute of Wu a long serpent, to offer it as tribute to the Central States. The suffering began with Chu, and my unworthy ruler lost his ancestral temple and domain. The state of Yue now dwells in the wilds, and I, your lowly subject, come to plead for help: The Brute’s insatiable greed is like a neighbor to your lordship, a menace to your borders. When Wu’s fate is yet undecided, I pray you take a share in its ruin. If Chu falls completely, its land will be yours. If your lordship’s spirit guides it, the world will serve you. The Qin sovereign sent him away with words of refusal.*

*"I have heard your plea," he said. "You have only just arrived at my court, yet you speak of plans before reporting them."* Shen Bao Xu answered: *"My unworthy ruler is still in the wilds, not yet having secured his allies. How dare I presume to rest?"* He stood by the courtyard wall and wept, day and night without ceasing, his voice unbroken. For seven days, he drank only from a ladle yet never let it pass his lips.

When the Qin lord saw this, he composed the ode *Wu Yi* ("No Garments") and, bowing nine times, agreed to send his troops. The record says: *"I observe the resolve of those in days gone by—how sharp it was! But today’s men, how weary they are in their thoughts. One state falls, another rises, yet they do not share in its fate. While you perish, my heart rejoices—why not let you perish? The times cannot be shaped by human will, and affairs cannot always be as one desires. They have weighed this well. Now, the harm of unchecked slander cannot be undone; the death of Wu Sha cannot be remedied. A whole clan was destroyed, and noble kin were slaughtered. How pressing were the hearts of filial sons and benevolent grandsires! If Shen Bao Xu had been in their place, with the same resolve, he would have met the same fate. When Yue had already taken the capital and the enemy had turned, the ancestral temple of Chu could not be altered. The king’s exile in the wilds was no longer constant, yet the hearts of loyal ministers and righteous warriors remained steadfast. If Wu Yuan had been in their place, with the same resolve, he would have achieved the same revival. Such was the clarity of their oaths and the firmness of their deeds—what they held in mind was already determined.*

Now, as for those who echo the words of the barbarians and rely on others to accomplish their ends—this is the work of mediocre, unprincipled men. Could they be compared to Wu Yuan and Shen Bao Xu?

From *Shiji* (*Records of the Grand Historian*): Su Wu and Li Ling were both attendants and court officials, close friends. Later, Ling surrendered to the Xiongnu, while Wu was detained and refused to yield. He was sent to the northern sea, where food ran out, and he survived by eating wild grass and gnawing on the roots of plants. His hair and beard fell out completely from neglect. The Xiongnu chanyu made a pact with him: *"Only when you accept a white ram as tribute shall you be allowed to return."* Ling, moved by this oath, set out wine and said: *"Life is like morning dew—why endure such suffering?"* Wu replied: *"My father and I have no merit or virtue, yet we were granted high rank as generals and marquesses. We have always vowed to spill our livers and brains for the state. Now we have the chance to fulfill this, and we truly rejoice. Do not speak further."* Thus, they drank together in harmony.

After several more days, Ling said again: *"I have already resigned myself to death. If Your Majesty insists on my surrender, let me first enjoy today’s feast, then I shall die before you."*

Moved by his sincerity, Ling sighed deeply and said: *"Alas! My crime with the Xiongnu chanyu is a transgression against Heaven itself."* He wept, his tears soaking his robes, and parted from Wu. Then he composed a poem:

*"The bow’s strength shines with virtue bright,
White-haired, yet still my pledge holds tight."*

Wu answered:
*"If I live, I shall return once more,
If I die, my love for you shall endure forever."*

The commentator records: *"In the beginning, Li Ling and Su Wu were not so different. Yet in the end, one became a noble minister, the other a traitor. The noble minister’s portrait graces the Hall of Eminent Worthies; the traitor, content to rot in obscurity. Then which brings greater joy—today’s fleeting pleasure or tomorrow’s enduring fame? True integrity is the grandest of all virtues; wealth and rank are but morning dew in a mortal’s life. Though Ling brought this upon himself, Sima Qian’s *Records* still weighs his loyalty in the scales of his heart. The bias against loyalty in *Records* is no accident. Alas! The ram may be milked, but the rotten cannot be revived. The pain of Sima Qian’s omission makes Wu’s persuasion of Ling all the more futile."*

From the *History of the Later Han*, it is told that **Fan Shi** of Mount Yang and **Zhang Yue** of Ru Nan, both young scholars at the Imperial Academy, swore to reunite after returning to their hometowns. Shi said to Yue: *"In two years, I shall return to pay my respects to your parents and see your children."* They fixed a day together.

When the appointed time came, Yue informed his mother and prepared a feast to await him. His mother said: *"Two years apart, a thousand miles between you—how reliable can such a promise be?"* Yue replied: *"Shi is a man of his word; he will not fail me."* His mother said: *"If so, then I shall brew wine for you."* On that very day, Shi arrived, ascended the hall, and bowed in greeting. They drank together in joy before parting.

Later, Shi served as a county magistrate, but Yue fell gravely ill and died. In a dream, Shi saw Yue say: *"I shall die on this day and be buried on that day. Do not forget me, though you cannot reach me."* Shi awoke in sorrow and hurried to attend the funeral. Before he arrived, the coffin had already been carried away. When he reached the grave and the mourners prepared to lower it, the coffin refused to move. His mother-in-law wept and said: *"Could Yue have hoped for this?"* The coffin remained still for some time, then a white carriage with black horses arrived, bearing a wailing figure. The mother-in-law exclaimed: *"It must be Fan Shi!"* Shi arrived, knelt at the coffin, and said:

*"Farewell, Yue. Life and death part us now,
Never to meet again on this mortal path."*

He took the funeral rope and led the procession forward.

The commentator records: *"Yue’s spirit, in death, was moved by what Shi had sworn in life. Life and death follow two paths, yet sincerity and spirit are one in essence. Thus, though unseen and unheard, sincerity persists; though unseen, the spirit’s influence endures. Only through sincerity does the spirit manifest; only through the spirit does response arise. Even sorcerers and diviners rely on this. The effects of ghosts and the power of spirits are but refined essences of our vital qi, the original guardians moving and responding within us. When one is moved, the other responds—naturally, without intent. Had Shi broken his oath of a thousand miles, Yue’s spirit would have been alienated in the unseen world. If Fan’s mother-in-law had doubted her son’s promise, her words at the grave would have been in vain. The *Book of Changes* says: ‘Without tokens, there is no trust.’ The hexagram *Inner Truth* declares: ‘The first nine, the *Yu* line, brings good fortune.’ This is the case of Jinxiang and Ru Nan."*

Jú Huī’s father, **Cén Shēn**, was a youthful friend of Emperor Guangwu in Chang’an. When Guangwu ascended the throne, he sought Shēn, but he had already passed. Thus, he summoned Huī and appointed him as a Gentleman of the Palace, later promoting him to Prefect of Linhuai. Huī was strict in governance, upright in conduct, and both officials and commoners revered and loved him. They sang of him:

*"Strong and just, he fulfills his duty,
A true son of Nanyang’s Zhu Ji."*

Zhang Kān, a fellow native of the same county, had long been renowned. While studying at the Imperial Academy, he had met Huī and held him in high regard, treating him as a brother. He once said to Huī: *"I entrust my wife and children to you."* Huī, though Kān was his senior, hesitated to accept, and afterward, they no longer saw each other. When Kān died, Huī learned that his family was in dire poverty. He went to visit them and provided generous aid. Huī’s youngest son, **Jié**, questioned him: *"Why did you not befriend Zhang Kān? You never even spoke to him in life."* Huī replied: *"Kān once spoke of me as a true friend, and I believed him."*

Again, from the same region, **Chén Yì** died young, leaving behind a posthumous son, **Yǒu**. Huī befriended him as if they had known each other for years. When **Huán Yú**, the Grand Tutor, served as Prefect of Nanyang, he summoned Huī’s son, **Pián**, to office. Huī declined and instead recommended Yǒu, who was then called to serve. Such was his integrity.

The commentator records: *"Since Guangwu’s strict adherence to principle, and the rise of Mount Yang and Ru Nan’s scholars, figures like Shēn and Huī have followed their example. Beyond this, the doctrine of absolute estrangement arises. Truly, the virtuous observe the changes of the age."*

Cái Yōng composed *The Treatise on True Friendship* to expand upon Zhū Mù’s ideals. Its essence states:

*"The virtuous man has no licentious friends,
His bonds are sincere, his oaths unshaken.
When Zhou’s virtue began to decline,
The *Ode of the Valley Wind* lamented betrayal—
Its cause was corruption in governance.
From then on, the decline deepened:
Some abandoned their principles from the start,
Others forced false harmony.
Some despised shallow men for their duplicity,
Others rejected friendships entirely.
Thus, the wise man is cautious in choosing friends,
And discerning in how he treats others.
Examine their origins, and you know their endings;
Observe their beginnings, and you foresee their conclusions."*

The virtuous and upright, though poor and lowly,
do not await wealth and honor—
and those who are wealthy and honored do not scorn the poor and lowly,
thus they are worthy of esteem.

Indeed, the Dao of friendship:
when there is *virtue*, they unite;
when there is no *virtue*, they part.
The good endure with lasting loyalty,
never forgetting their words of old,
while the wicked are admonished with sincerity
and guided toward the right path.

Thus, the virtuous do not practice actions worthy of abandonment,
nor do they grieve when others stray from them—
for they possess *virtue* worthy of return,
and do not lament when others keep their distance.

Should misfortune befall them,
they cultivate self-forgiveness
while holding others lightly accountable,
thus warding off resentment.

In days past, Zǐ Xià was of broad nature,
so the Master warned him to repel others,
while Zǐ Zhāng was narrow in disposition,
so he was instructed to embrace the multitude.

As for Zhōngní’s true teaching,
it was to love all universally while cherishing the virtuous.

Gǔ Liáng Zǐ said:
*"When hearts are unaligned and reputations unheard,
this is the fault of friendship."*

Now, if we fear its consequences,
we must block the source—
it is better to choose what is upright
and reject what is perverse,
to trust in the good
and abandon the evil together.

The record states:
*"Jú Gōngzǔ’s discourse on severing ties*
was a correction of the age’s superficiality,
spoken only when necessity demanded it.
Cài Bóxiè lamented Zháo’s words,
moved by how others treated him,
and thus spoke of it as well.

Yet if we abandon the principle of rejecting evil and embracing the good,
what remains?

Thus it is also said:
*"Those who scorn the shallow are broad and inclusive,
while those who sever ties are upright yet solitary.*
The solitary lamb preserves its integrity—
if it cannot be gained,
it flees, yet remains steadfast in its solitude.

These words are all the more true.

*The Book of Wèi* records:
Liáo Shù Gōng Yì Hēizǐ, favored by Emperor Tàiwǔ,
was dispatched to Bìngzhōu,
where he received a thousand bolts of cloth."

When the matter was exposed, Gao Yun consulted with the **Zhuòzuò Láng** **Gāo Yǔn** and said, *"The Sovereign inquires of me, and I should answer truthfully, yet fear to conceal it."* **Gāo Yǔn** replied, *"You are the favored attendant, and if you confess the truth, perhaps mercy may be shown. It would be unwise to deceive further."* The **Zhōngshū Shìláng** **Cuī Jiàn** **Gōng** **Sūn Zhì** declared, *"If you confess, the punishment will be incalculable. Better to conceal it."* **Hēizǐ** resented **Gāo Yǔn** and said, *"How could you lead me to this death?"* When **Hēizǐ** entered to see the Emperor, he did not speak the truth, and the Emperor executed him in anger.

The Emperor then ordered **Gāo Yǔn** to tutor the **Tàizǐ** in the Classics. At that time, **Cuī Hào** was arrested for his historical writings, and **Gāo Yǔn** was about to share his fate. The **Tàizǐ** said to **Gāo Yǔn**, *"When the Sovereign questions you, I will guide you to safety."* When the Emperor questioned him, the **Tàizǐ** spoke, *"Yun is cautious and humble, yet lowly in status. The decree came from Cuī Hào; I beg Your Majesty to spare his life."* The Emperor summoned **Gāo Yǔn** and asked, *"Are the records all the work of Cuī Hào?"* **Gāo Yǔn** answered, *"Your servant and Hào both composed them."* The **Tàizǐ**, fearing the Emperor’s wrath, said, *"Your Majesty’s authority is stern and grave. Yun, this humble subject, was confused and lost his bearings. All those questioned say it was Cuī Hào’s work."* The Emperor asked **Gāo Yǔn**, *"Do you confirm the words of the Eastern Office?"* **Gāo Yǔn** replied, *"Your servant’s crime deserves only a lesser punishment—he does not dare speak falsely. Your Majesty, in your long service as my tutor, has but once involved me, only to grant me life. In truth, Your Majesty did not question me, and I spoke no such words."* The Emperor turned to the **Tàizǐ** and said, *"Straightforward indeed—this man, even at death’s door, does not alter his words. He is a loyal subject who does not deceive his lord."* And so he pardoned him.

Later, the **Tàizǐ** reproached **Gāo Yǔn**, saying, *"I wished to save you from death, yet you would not comply. Why?"* **Gāo Yǔn** replied, *"Your servant and Cuī Hào truly shared responsibility for the historical records. In matters of life and death, honor and disgrace, it would be unjust to punish me alone. Though I owe Your Majesty kindness for sparing my life, I would not survive by betraying my conscience. My fate is not what I desired."* The **Tàizǐ** was moved by his words.

**Gāo Yǔn** later said to others, *"I did not follow the **Shù Gōng**’s guidance, lest I betray **Hēizǐ**."* The record states: *"**Gāo Bó Gōng** did not betray **Hēizǐ**, and this was his integrity. Yet he did not know that integrity is most valued when aligned with **righteousness (yì)**, and that one should take **righteousness** as the ultimate principle. **Hēizǐ**, with his greed and betrayal of trust, abandoned **righteousness** and dishonored his life—he was the first to be slaughtered and the leader of the guilt. Thus, confessing the truth led to death, and not confessing also led to death. Why then could **Hēizǐ** not simply conceal it, yet instead seek **Cuī Jiàn**’s **Sūn Zhì** to question him over every detail?

**Cuī Hào**’s private desires and his **Wèi Gōng**’s **Sūn Zhì**’s **mǐn zàn** (partiality in love and hate) obscured the truth—this was the people’s misfortune and Heaven’s punishment. Therefore, **Hēizǐ**’s death was just whether he confessed or not, yet why did he not perceive the danger and instead differ from **Mǐn Zhàn** **Pó Bāi** (those who remained steadfast in their principles)? Truly, **Gāo Yǔn** held **Dao/Way** and Buddhism in high regard, yet he lacked **Confucius**’s teachings as his foundation. His beliefs were not without flaw. If misfortune had befallen him, **Jǐng Mù**’s plea would have failed, and **Tàiwǔ**’s cruelty would not have ceased—then I would see only his ruin. Therefore, **Zōng Qīn** said, *"Yun was saintly."* I say, *"Yun was foolish."*

The *Book of Táng* records:
**Wú Jìng** and **Zhāng Yuè**, together holding the position of **Shǐ** (historian), were appointed to oversee the compilation of the *Zhēntiān Shílù* (True Record of Empress Wu). **Wú Jìng** wrote directly that **Wèi Yuán Zhōng** had served as Chancellor and frequently advised the two previous Emperors, receiving boundless favor. Now, though he held the Chancellorship, he could not fulfill his loyalty, allowing evil men to stand beside him—this was his crime. The Empress was displeased.

**Zhāng Yuè**’s associates, fearing her anger, then fabricated a record against **Yuán Zhōng**, claiming, *"The Empress has grown old; it would be better to enthrone the Prince as heir for a lasting dynasty."* The Empress was enraged and ordered his arrest, intending to interrogate him in court. **Chāng Zōng** secretly bribed **Fèng Gé Shèrén** **Zhāng Yuè** with a high office, instructing him to testify falsely against **Yuán Zhōng** in exchange for favor.

The next day, the Emperor issued a decree summoning **Yuán Zhōng**, the **Xiàng Wáng** (Prince), and the Chancellors for a joint interrogation. **Yuán Zhōng**’s guilt was debated back and forth without resolution. **Chāng Zōng** said, *"Let **Zhāng Yuè** be called, for he heard **Yuán Zhōng**’s words."* As **Zhāng Yuè** entered, **Sòng Yíng** said to him, *"Reputation and principle are most weighty—even spirits and gods cannot be deceived. Do not side with evil to ensnare the righteous, seeking only to escape punishment. If you are exiled or demoted, your honor will be great. If calamity befalls you, I will strike my chest and plead for you with all my strength, even if it means dying with you."* **Zhāng Yuè** was moved by his words and said, *"If Your Majesty grants me this chance, I will ensure future generations look up to me for this act."* The **Zǔoshǐ** **Liú Zhī Jǐ** said, *"Do not sully the annals of history, lest you burden your descendants."*

**Zhāng Yuè** then entered the court. The Empress questioned him, but before he could answer, **Chāng Zōng** pressed him from the side. **Zhāng Yuè** said, *"Your Majesty, if you scrutinize me in court like this, how much more would you question me outside!" I truly did not hear such words, but **Chāng Zōng** forced me to fabricate them in exchange for his favor.* Later, under similar circumstances, **Yuán Zhōng** was spared.

At this time, the historians saw **Zhāng Yuè**, who secretly prayed for changes in the records. **Wú Jìng** refused, saying, *"If I comply with your request, then this history will not be written with honesty. How can it then gain the trust of posterity?"* The record states: *"I observe the ancients in upholding integrity, even when pressed over minor details, yet they remained firm and did not yield to improper requests. Thus, the virtuous in their conduct must strive to have no regrets in their hearts. Only when there are no regrets in the heart can one then have no need to seek favor from others. **Zhāng Yuè**, having already betrayed **Sòng Yíng** with shameful death and burdened himself with **Yào Chóng**’s misdeeds, looked upward with guilt and downward with deeds of dishonor. Even if he could split a single hair in **Wú Jìng**’s records, could he escape the censure of all ages to come? Alas!"*

「Speaking from the perspective of the past, it is about **power**; speaking from the perspective of the future, it is about **gain**. **Power** and **gain**—how few can remain steadfast and unconfused! Is it only **Zhāng Yuè** who falters?

Li Huá held firm trust in **Yuán Déxiù**, **Xiāo Yǐngshì**, and **Liù Xuàn**’s characters, composing *The Treatise on the Three Virtuous Ones* and stating:
Déxiù’s resolve was to uphold the **Dao** in governing the world,
Xuàn’s was to harmonize the hearts of all with the Six Classics,
Yǐngshì’s was to transform the **mid-Qín** era into the present age.
Déxiù sought to equalize the wise and foolish,
Xuàn was moved by even a single thing not aligned with its proper **dharma**,
Yǐngshì adjusted his conduct with each breath to secure high office,
never forsaking even a moment’s ease.

Had Déxiù held the position of **teacher and guardian**,
his benevolence would be evident in his bearing.
Xuàn, dressed in the robes of a **ministerial aide**,
among guests and friends, plotted against the roots of chaos.
Yuán, drawing from the **primordial essence** (*yuánjīng*), revealed his subtlety.
Yǐngshì, like steel tempered a hundred times,
when faced with questions of rise and fall, departure and acceptance—life or death—
demonstrated his unyielding **virtue**.

Déxiù, in composing music for the king to venerate **virtue**,
reached the pinnacle of **heavenly and human harmony** (*tiānrén jīzhì*),
yet his literary works fell short—this was no **music of virtue** (*wúlè*).
Thus, he wrote *Breaking the Battle Array* to correct the **Zhōu** and **Shāng** traditions.
Xuàn, as a **historian** (*shìguān*), expounded the *Rites*, *Changes*, *Book*, *Poetry*, and *Spring and Autumn Annals* as the **Five Ancient Schools** (*gǔ wǔshuō*), tracing their lineage and documenting the shifts between past and present.
Yǐngshì, though his son **Cháng** was long without an annual biography,
wrote **biographies** (*lièzhuàn*) instead—later generations followed this, deeming it unconventional.

Yet each had flaws:
Yuán’s was **excessive drinking** (*jiǔ*),
Liù’s was **greed for material gain** (*shǎngwù*),
Xiāo’s was **overzealous censure of evil** (*biǎn'è tájí*), risking excessive severity,
but if one takes their **virtue**, all could serve as models for humanity.

The world called it a **sincere treatise** (*dǔlùn*).

The record states:
I observe the ancients’ **Dao of valuing friendship** (*shàng yǒu zhīdào*),
where each **perfected sage** (*zhìrén*) was distinct in his **virtue**.
Later generations, however, merely indulged in frivolous associations.
The **Dao of friendship** transcends mere **lofty counsel** (*cāncān*),
**harmonizing governance** (*jīnglún*), or **guiding the misled** (*biānzuò*).
**Zǐzhī**’s solitary conduct,
his **straight path** (*dàdào zhīxíng*), was to make the world **public** (*wèngōng*),
his **qi** reflecting the grandeur of **heavenly virtue**—a figure from before the **Three Dynasties** (*sāndài*).

**Mào Tǐng**’s resolute **virtue**,
even the **barbarians** (*yídí*) sought to emulate,
yet **China** itself did not.
**Jiéqīng**’s **family tradition** (*jiālù*), encompassing the **Dao of kings** (*huángwáng zhīdào*), was complete—
what need for later generations?

Li Huá’s **sincere trust** was well-founded.

**Volume 55 of *Principles of the Great Dao*** (*Hóngdào Lù*), originally titled *"Resentment"* (*Hèn*), revised based on context.
**Volume 56 of *Principles of the Great Dao* #1: *Trust***.」

**The Trust of Friends**

From *Song History*: Liu Anshi and Sima Guang were friends of the same year and age. After his younger brother’s death, Anshi declined an official post and returned to Luoyang. When Sima Guang asked him why, he replied: *"I have not yet attained sincerity."* Sima Guang rejoiced and invited him to join his circle. One day, he rose from his seat to ask: *"What is the essential principle of wholehearted conduct that one can follow for life?"* Sima Guang answered: *"It is sincerity."* He asked further: *"Where should one begin in practice?"* The reply came: *"Begin with never speaking falsely."* From then on, Anshi held fast to this principle, adhering to it all his life.

Later, when he was appointed to govern a prefecture and served as a judicial officer, the tax official was accused of corruption. The regional inspector, Hu Daogu, intended to investigate, but consulted Anshi first. Anshi declared: *"There is no corruption."* Though Hu Daogu hesitated, his conscience troubled him: *"The tax official is indeed corrupt, yet I did not answer truthfully—have I betrayed Master Sima’s teaching?"* Later, reading Yang Xiong’s *Fa Yan* ("The spoken law"), he found the line *"A gentleman avoids obstacles by aligning with principle,"* and his doubts were resolved.

Even in private, Anshi never showed laziness; he sat upright without leaning, wrote characters with precision, and took no pleasure in music, women, wealth, or gain—all mirroring Sima Guang’s conduct. Though he lamented the decline of worthy scholars, he remained steadfast, and his reputation grew ever stronger. Liang Shicheng admired his virtue and sent his son, Liang Wen, with a letter urging Anshi to accept office for the sake of his descendants. Anshi laughed: *"If I were thinking of my descendants, I would not have reached this point. I wish only to be a complete man of the Yuan You era, meeting Sima Guang in the underworld."* He returned the letter unopened.

The record states: *"Liu Anshi’s devotion to Master Wen [Sima Guang] was such that he stumbled and rose again, yet never wavered—until death, he still sought to meet him in the afterlife. Why?"* The *I Ching*’s *Wu Wang* (Hexagram 62) says: *"Without tilling, there is no harvest; without gathering, no assembly—yet there is advantage in going forward."* If one does not begin with sincerity and constancy, how can one remain unmoved by profit or swayed by power? Later, Li Guang, treating Anshi as his teacher, reported to Sima Guang: *"Learning must begin with *Wu Wang*."* This was the very meaning.

Thus it is said: *"Without sincerity, there is nothing. How can one who lacks self-trust trust others? How can one who lacks trust in life trust the dead?"* Alas, Anshi did not betray the teachings of the Sage’s school.

Chen Xiang, from his youth, was friends with his fellow villagers Chen Lie, Zhou Ximeng, and Zheng Mu—all men of ancient bearing and lofty conduct, their words sharp and precise, their resolve set on the weight of the world. At a time when scholars drowned in ornate calligraphy and dismissed *"knowing Heaven, fulfilling nature"* as absurd, these four men proclaimed their Dao in the coastal regions. Though initially mocked, they never wavered, and their steadfastness grew. They practiced sincerity in their families and extended it to the governance of their districts, and people came to trust them. Soon, their parents urged their children to follow them, and the scholars of Fujian revered them as the *"Four Masters."* Even those of reckless or arrogant nature dared not offend them.

The record states: *"At that time, Fujian’s learning was unheard of. The Four Masters, through their personal practice, led their fellow villagers, beginning with great difficulty but ultimately transforming the age. This was Heaven’s awakening of culture—a spontaneous harmony across the seas."*

She Liangzuo was one of deep sincerity and trust, studying under the Two Chengs [Cheng Yi and Cheng Hao]. One day, Cheng Yi said to him: *"You gather here, yet only study words—your heart and mouth do not align. Why not apply this to your conduct?"* Later, when parting from Cheng Hao, he returned after a year to ask: *"We have been separated for long—what progress have you made?"* Cheng Hao replied: *"I have only removed the character *jiān* [‘arrogance’ or ‘self-importance’]."* She Liangzuo asked: *"How so?"* He said: *"Examined closely, all suffering stems from this. If one subdues this fault, there is room for advancement."* Hu Wending asked: *"Why is *jiān* such a grave offense?"* She Liangzuo answered: *"People act only to impress others’ eyes and ears, caring nothing for their own benefit."* Cheng Hao rejoiced: *"You are one who strives in learning, questions earnestly, and reflects on the near—truly so!"* He added: *"Though fate may be humble, one must trust in it. Future efforts must be grounded in reality; fate cannot be bargained with by human calculation. I have never sought favor from others, nor in the Bureau did I curry influence with officials. When urged, I replied: ‘How can they shape me? My fate is my own.’ If trust is lacking, even a breeze stirs fear or joy—wasting effort and energy. But with trust, fate is nurtured, and qi remains unbroken."*

The record states: *"How is *jiān* such a great offense? Yu, the great Sage, said: ‘Do not be arrogant, and none will dispute your ability. Do not boast, and none will dispute your merit.’ Yan Hui, the great Virtuous One, said: ‘May I not praise my virtues, nor claim my labors—let others see me as shallow.’ Thus, one who is content with a single word or an inch of progress is truly unrestrained. But if one does not know their own insufficiency and only sees excess, this is the scholar’s great ailment—one that can never enter the Dao of Yao and Shun."* Alas, Shangcai’s [Cheng Yi’s] learning was so elevated, so just, that even the most upright could not surpass it. Scholars—how can they fail to reflect? How can they fail to strive?

Zhu Guangting first studied under Hu Angding, who taught him that the foundation of learning lies in *"upholding loyalty and sincerity."* He adhered to this all his life. Later, when he studied under the Two Chengs, others were astonished, but Zhu alone trusted without doubt, his learning and resolve unshaken as adamantine. His conduct was such that it could be measured by the divine—whether in governance or family, in dealing with the people or in affairs, in every action and stillness, it flowed from utmost sincerity.

「Discussing the ancients, how could their example be easily matched? His conduct was steadfast as a worthy minister, his bearing noble and upright, following the traditions of the historians. During the reigns of the **Qianxi (国一盒)**, **Yuanyou (元佑)**, and **Jingguo (靖国)**, affairs changed frequently, yet he was a man renowned across the land, attaining high office, and able to practice what he learned. However, upon closer examination of his deeds, there remained still some regret.

As for **Master Gong (公)**, one could say he was unwavering in his devotion, never losing it. **Liu Ruo (刘绚)** from the time of his first sprouting hair studied under the Two Chengs.

**Master Mingdao (明道)** once said to others: *"Others may have learning, but if they are not diligent, it is difficult to preserve. I have no doubt about this man’s resolve."*

**Master Yichuan (伊川)** also said: *"Many have entered my doors, but few are as steadfast in their belief, as thorough in their understanding, or as resolute in their practice as this one. Truly, such individuals are rare. His foundation in learning was unshaken, his grasp of profound truths subtle, and he labored tirelessly, knowing nothing else. His innate nature delighted in goodness and was never swayed by heterodox teachings, so his steps were secure. His inner life grew ever weightier without the turmoil of conflicting thoughts, thus his actions were firm. His aspirations aligned with those of Li Qixu (李吁志).*

Since the Two Chengs first expounded the **Dao Learning (道学)**, the world was astonished, yet these two could make scholars observe, emulate, and believe in their teachings with conviction.

**Master Lü Taijun (吕太钧)** was a man of simple sincerity and uprightness. He took the **Confucian Way (圣门)** as his own mission, and if he understood and believed in something with sufficient resolve to act upon it, he did so without hesitation or fear. Thus, those who knew him compared him to **Zilu (季路)**. He studied under **Zhang Zai (张载)**, and though he could uphold his teacher’s doctrines, he also implemented them in practice. He particularly favored elucidating the **Jingtian (井田)** and military systems, asserting that governance must begin here. Even when composing records for **illustrative diagrams (图籍)**, he ensured their practical utility, though all were rooted in Zhang’s teachings. He could firmly believe and act upon them. Zhang often sighed in admiration, saying he could not surpass him.

Yichuan further remarked: *"When Master He (和叔) and I meet, there is no need for further recognition. But once parted, I cannot help but doubt him. Yet I do not know if he truly remains undoubting. Nor do I know if, after he no longer doubts, he will still harbor doubts when separated from me."*

Mingdao then asked: *"Why not ask him what he doubts?"*
He added: *"Master He’s sincerity and straightforwardness are such that he firmly believes. That is why he is steadfast in his faith."*

**Master Gong** recorded: *"Since the time of the Confucian School (孔门) teaching others, it is only now that scholars truly recognize the Dao of the Sage (圣人) and yearn toward it. If one does not firmly believe and resolutely act, then it is mere ‘Jiang’er Learning’ (江耳之学), which benefits neither one’s body nor mind. How can it be guaranteed that such a person will not suddenly change, let alone remain steadfast throughout life? This is most crucial in the Dao Learning tradition, yet it is something the Confucian scholars of old—like Kong, Zeng, and Shang—exhaustively discussed in the *Analects (论语)*. Now we see it again."*

**Yang Wanli (杨万里)**, from his first meeting with **Zhang Zhongxian (张忠献)**, was exhorted to study **upright-heart and sincere-intent (正心诚意)**. He accepted this teaching wholeheartedly, naming his study hall the **Sincere Hall (诚斋)**. In the twelfth year of **Chunxi (淳熙)**, during an earthquake, he submitted a memorial stating: *"I have heard that speaking truthfully during times of peace is not harmful, but speaking falsely during times of crisis is gravely so.
