The affairs of the realm have roots and branches. What I have previously submitted were merely the branches. The true roots lie in the ruler not acting from personal whim. If the ruler acts from personal whim, then ministers cannot bear responsibility. Today’s affairs will have no precedent. This is the lofty principle of the Sage’s teaching, and I wish to further ponder its original essence."*

When he was transferred to attend the **Imperial Academy (束宫)** as a **sitting reader (侍读)**, he advised the **Prince of the Heir Apparent (太子)** on matters as they arose, and the prince deeply respected him.

When **Emperor Gaozong (高宗)** passed away, **Emperor Xiaozong (孝宗)** intended to observe a three-year mourning period and established the **Hall of Consultation (议事堂)**, commanding the **Heir Apparent (皇太子)** to participate in state affairs. Yang Wanli submitted a memorial forcefully opposing this. Before Gaozong’s burial, **Han Hu (韩怩冑)**, the **Chancellor (翰林学士)**, and **Hong Mai (洪迈)** did not await the collective deliberation and ancestral rites, but instead submitted the names of **Lü Xihao (吕熙浩)** and others alone. Yang Wanli wrote a memorial denouncing them, even going so far as to say, *"There is no difference between this and pointing at a deer and calling it a horse."* Xiaozong was displeased and remarked: *"What kind of ruler does Yang Wanli think I am?"* He was then exiled to **Junzhou (筠州)**.

Han Hu, wielding excessive power, sought to entrap and control scholars across the land. He constructed a **Southern Garden (南园)**, commissioning Yang Wanli to write its record in exchange for a recommendation to the **Imperial Academy (掖垣)**. Yang replied: *"The office can be abandoned, but the record cannot be written."* Han Hu’s arrogance grew even greater, leading Yang to fall gravely ill with worry and distress.

When his relatives knew the cause, they kept all official dispatches from him. Suddenly, a nephew arrived from outside, urgently declaring news of military mobilization and conflict. Yang Wanli wept uncontrollably, gasping for breath, and quickly summoned paper to write: *"The wicked ministers have no bounds. They provoke wars, harm the people, and endanger the state. My head is like this—there is no way for me to repay the country, only my solitary resentment."* He then wrote fourteen more words, bade farewell to his wife and children, and died as the pen fell.

**Emperor Guangzong (光宗)** once inscribed the characters **Sincere Hall (诚斋)** for him, and scholars thereafter called him **Sincere Hall Master (诚斋先生)**.

**Master Gong** recorded: *"Zhang Zhongxian’s relationship with Yang Wanli was akin to that of Fan Zhongwen (范文正) with Hengxu (横渠). Such mentorship in perfecting later generations is rare among the ancients. If one could merely acknowledge the Dao in the teacher’s hall but fail to internalize it in oneself, would that not be futile? Now, observing Yang Wanli’s responses to imperial edicts, one sees the earnest principle of preparing beforehand to establish, or failing to do so will result in ruin. His memorial on the **Regency (监国)** was heartfelt, echoing the words ‘Heaven has no two suns, the people no two kings.’ Even when facing the ruler’s misguided favoritism and the peril of heterodox support for the state, he died content, not doubting even in the face of death. Is this not one who ‘dies without regret’? The name Sincere Hall is indeed well-deserved.*

**He Ji (何基)** was steadfast in his faith. **Huang Gan (黄干)**, whose father **Huang Bofen (黄伯焚)** served as **Magistrate of Linchuan County (临川县丞)**, saw that at the time, Gan was studying **filial piety (丝事)**. Huang Bofen, delighted by his son’s sincerity, took him as his teacher. Gan instructed him that one must first cultivate a **true and genuine heart-mind (真实心地)**, then refine through **bitter toil (刻苦工夫)**. He Ji received this command with solemn resolve.

Thus, Gan guided him through every matter, helping him attain the **profound essence (渊源之懿)**. He explored subtle nuances and profound truths, delving deeply into meditation, calming his heart and regulating his **qi (气)**, awaiting enlightenment without ever imposing his own views or deviating for personal gain. He was thus called a **simple and sincere man (平狗人)** with little change in his ways.»

In whatever studies he undertook, he would meticulously annotate and punctuate, rendering meaning clear and self-evident without need for further exposition. He often said:

*"In learning, establishing resolve must be firm, and one’s vision must be grand. One must embody and practice with unwavering dedication, persisting until death. When reading the **Odes (《诗》)**, one must first purge the mind of encumbrances, then recite and chant with ease, allowing its words to stir the heart—only then does study bear fruit. In studying the **Changes (《易》)**, one must discard rigid and fragmented interpretations, purifying the mind to explore subtle principles. Through profound meditation and immersion, one grasps its roots, only then may one gradually discern the **trigrams (爻象)**.*

*He adhered strictly to his teacher’s instructions, refining his understanding with precision, like a comparison. When Wang Xiang became his disciple, his brilliance and sharp insight shone through in his expansive arguments and eloquent debates. Even when questioning doubts—sometimes returning to a single matter ten times—He Ji never wavered, awaiting resolution with steadfastness. He once remarked: ‘In studying the Classics, one must focus on careful contemplation, not excessive speculation. For those who would instruct later learners, caution must be doubled.’*

*He recorded: ‘Confucius said: **“Sincere in faith, loving of learning (笃信好学).”**’ Its explanation reads: ‘Without sincerity, one cannot truly love learning. Yet sincerity without learning may lead one astray from truth.’ This is why the lineage of the Four Masters—He, Wang, Jin, and Xu—remained unbroken in its essence.*

*Alas! The teachings of the Western River (西河) were transmitted directly from the Great Sage’s lineage, yet his followers distorted them through blind imitation. How much more so under the suppression of false doctrines and rigid prohibitions! Thus, he approached his studies with utmost diligence, unyielding in tenfold inquiry until clarity emerged.*

Wang Xiang’s great-grandfather, Wang Yu, studied the **Changes (《易》)** and the **Analects (《论语》)** under Yang Shi. Later, he also learned from Zhu Xi, Zhang Shou, and the brothers Lü Zuqian and You Wenhan.

Young, Xiang admired Zhuge Liang’s character, adopting the sobriquet *Changxiao Erdie* (长啸二蝓). At thirty, he realized the source of his family’s learning and sighed: *“Changxiao*—this is not the special reverence of the Sage’s Gate. I must now follow the teachings of Lu Zhi.”

Someone mentioned that He Ji had received the transmission of Zhu Xi, so Xiang sought him out. Ji taught him the principles of **establishing resolve and dwelling in reverence (立志居敬)**, and Xiang embraced them with wholehearted sincerity, steadfast and unyielding. Whenever doubts arose, he would consult Ji without fail.

Xiang once said: *“The **River Diagram (河图)** used to arrange the **Eight Trigrams (八卦)** through odd and even positions, while the **Later Heaven sequence (后天)** unified them as a whole. Only the **Four Generations (四生数)** remain fixed, forming the basis for the **Fourfold Numbers (四成数)**, ascending and descending—even and odd, all in accordance with Nature.”*

He further stated: *“Great Yu received the **Lu Diagram (洛书)** and arranged the **Nine Categories (九畴)**, while Ji Zi passed down the **Nine Categories** as the **Great Plan of the Five Powers (洪范)**. The numerical patterns of the **Five Powers** unknowingly align with the **Great Plan**—this is the essence of the Classics and commentaries. The first line begins with **Five Phases (五行)**, followed by sixty-five characters as the **Great Plan of the Five Powers**, then sixty-four characters as the **Plan of the Five Powers (皇极经)**. This is the grand tradition passed down by emperors, not Ji Zi’s words alone.”*

He also said: *“The **Three Hundred Odes (《诗》三百篇)** were not all finalized by the Master. Some deleted poems may still exist, and Han scholars supplemented the lost with their selections. Thus, the **Southern Odes (二南)** were set at ten each, *He Bi Naiyi (何彼秾矣)* was reassigned to *Gantang (甘棠)*, *Wild Goat (野有死麝)* was removed from the **King’s Odes (《王风》)**, and the licentious poems of Zheng and Wei were censored. The **Spring and Autumn Annals (《春秋》)** were then expanded upon.”*

*“The chapter on **extending knowledge and investigating things (致知格物)** in the **Great Learning (《大学》)** was lost, and the chapter on **stopping at knowledge (知止)** was placed above the section on adjudicating disputes. The original **Doctrine of the Mean (《中庸》)** consisted of two sections. **Sincerity and Enlightenment (诚明)** should serve as the framework, not mere details. The final text was set at eleven chapters each for **Doctrine of the Mean** and **Sincerity and Enlightenment**.”*

His profound insights were of this caliber.

He recorded: *“Wang Hui’s reflection on principles was indeed a model of scholarly rigor. Yet he was ultimately renowned for his clarity and insight—was this not the interplay of **foolishness revealing wisdom, softness overcoming strength**?”*

Though his writings were voluminous and his debates rich, they were not without foundation. Thus, scholars must prioritize **grasping the essential**. Mastering the essential allows one to adhere to brevity, and brevity suffices to encompass the vast.

Though *Changxiao* emphasized stillness, it was merely a means. Without stillness, one cannot attain the distant. Yet **delving into subtle principles and establishing resolve in reverence**—these are but two aspects of one path.

The **Yuan History (《元史》)** states: *“Jin Liuxiang, from his youth, adhered to the teachings of the School of Principle (濂洛之学). He served Wang Xiang of the same prefecture and once asked about the method of study. Xiang instructed him: ‘Nothing precedes establishing resolve. Resolve stands beyond things, and reverence dwells within them—this is the great method of learning.’*

*“When the Song Dynasty’s cause was beyond redemption, he abandoned worldly ambitions, secluding himself in the Jinhua Mountains. He pursued clouds and moonlight, finding solace in whistling, detached from worldly affairs. In solitude, he maintained an upright demeanor, embodying **dwelling in reverence to uphold resolve, establishing resolve to fortify the foundation**. Truly at ease, yet when interacting with others, his demeanor was harmonious and respectful. He tirelessly guided later learners with earnest patience.*

*“He often said: ‘Liu Shu’s **External Records (外纪)** lack foundation in the Classics, instead relying on the sayings of a hundred schools. This contradicts the Sage’s teachings and is unworthy of trust. Before Yao, what the Master did not establish cannot be verified; the **Spring and Autumn Annals** recorded only what was conveyed through jade and silk—no additions could be made by later historians.’*

*“Thus, he adopted the **Royal Extremes of the Great Plan (皇极经世历)** by Shao Kang and the **Grand Framework of the Sovereign (皇王大纪)** by Hu Angu, adjusting and reconciling them. Primarily relying on the **Book of Documents (尚书)**, he extended his research to the **Odes (《诗》)**, **Rites (《礼》)**, and **Spring and Autumn Annals (《春秋》)**, supplementing with chronicles and biographies from ancient histories and the **Records of the Grand Historian (《史记》)**, arranging events by year. Beginning with Emperor Tang Yao and continuing to the **Zizhi Tongjian (《通鉴》)**, he compiled a work titled **Preface to the Comprehensive Mirror (《通鉴前编》)**.”*

「In all cases where he cited sources, he would immediately annotate and elucidate them to clarify their meaning, often uncovering insights that earlier Confucian scholars had overlooked. After completing his work, he entrusted it to a worthy recipient—**Master Xu Qian**—who remarked: *“The grandeur of the Two Sovereigns and Three Kings should be emulated by later rulers; the harsh laws and chaotic schemes of the Warring States period and the Shang Dynasty must be heeded as warnings by those who follow, so this compilation cannot be disregarded.”*

At that time, critics observed: *“His personal conduct was pure and upright, akin to the integrity of **Yin He** and **Jing** [the recluse]; his governance was lofty and resolute, resembling that of **Xie Shangcai** [Xie Shang of Shangcai]. Yet he absorbed the teachings of both **Lin Lixiang** and **Fu Yizhi** while refining them into his own approach.”*

The record states: *“When **Master Ren Shan** expounded the **Dao**, was he merely echoing **Master Xu Yun**’s discussion of **Little Sima** [Sima Qian]?”*

**Sima Tan**, the Grand Historian, explicitly declared that the *Book of Documents* alone recorded events from **Emperor Yao** onward, while the **Hundred Schools** spoke of **Yellow Emperor**, whose accounts were unrefined and improper. **Master Yan Sheng** found them difficult to accept, and **Master Zheng Naihe** dared not supplement them. Thus, **Heavenly Sovereign (天皇氏)**, **Earthly Sovereign (地皇氏)**, **Human Sovereign (人皇氏)**, **Nüwa (女娲氏)**, **Suiren (燧人氏)**, and **Pangu (盘古氏)**—among others—proliferated in conflicting versions, all originating from **Zheng’s** school. Later, **Hu Wufeng** and **Hu Shuangfeng**, though self-proclaimed Confucians, further distorted and misaligned these traditions—no wonder **Qin’s** scholars and **Emperor Wu of Liang** rejected them!

Even the **Shouwei School**, which included **Pangu** and six other figures in its early sections and **Fu Yi** and eight others in its later ones, totaling **fourteen sovereigns**, left unclear distinctions between the **Three Sovereigns** and **Five Emperors**.

Now, I propose to eliminate all such discrepancies and establish the *Preface to the Comprehensive Mirror* as definitive—this is the proper course.

**Xu Qian**, a disciple of **Lin Lixiang**, once said to him: *“A scholar’s learning should be like the five flavors blending into harmony; once the fermentation and seasoning are applied, the distinctions of sour and salty become pronounced. Yet you still treat me as a layman—does this mean my studies have failed to awaken you?”*

Upon hearing this, **Xu Qian** was deeply stirred and, over the course of several years, mastered all the profound teachings his master had transmitted. He read every text thoroughly, never forcing interpretations where they were unclear, and if any passage seemed unsatisfactory, he would not hastily agree with it.

To other scholars, he declared: *“Learning must take the **Sages** as its standard. Yet one must first grasp the Sage’s intent before attempting to emulate their deeds.”*

In his study of the *Odes*, he composed the *“Annotations on Names and Objects”* to correct pronunciation and exegesis, examining the names and measurements of things to supplement what earlier Confucians had overlooked, while preserving their obscure meanings. He drew from distant sources and concluded each analysis with his own reflections.

For his examination of history, he produced *“Critical Moments of Governance,”* following the **Historian’s** method of recording events by year and by nation, beginning with **Taizong (太嗥氏)** and ending with **Sima Guang’s** death in the **Song Dynasty’s Yuan You era (宋元佑)**. He believed that with Sima Guang’s passing, China’s restoration could no longer be revived—this was indeed the critical juncture of decline.

He also compiled *“Self-Reflection Records,”* where he recorded his actions by day and, if they were unworthy, refrained from doing them at all. He opened his doors to teach, welcoming students from afar—even from **Yuyang, Jizhi, Qi, and Lu**—and nearby—from **Jing, Yang, and the regions of **Hao** and **Yue****. He never tired of instructing them, regardless of their origins.

In his teaching, he was earnest and meticulous, ensuring that his students’ understanding was thorough, both in doctrine and practice. He often said: *“If I possess knowledge and can impart it to others, why should I not rejoice?”*

When students posed difficult questions that they struggled to articulate, he would clarify their intended meaning and resolve their doubts. His lectures and debates lasted all day without fatigue, guiding coarse learners toward subtlety, while those who were sharp were restrained, the rigid were liberated, and the wayward were brought back to discipline. He adapted to each student’s abilities, ensuring they made progress accordingly.

Yet he never taught the **examination essays** of the **imperial civil service**, declaring: *“Such writings stem from mercenary motives and cannot be reconciled with true learning.”*

He was deeply devoted to filial piety and brotherly love, exhibiting conduct beyond the ordinary. In his interactions with the world, he neither rigidly adhered to antiquity nor blindly followed contemporary trends.

During the **Great Virtue era (大德中)**, the **wandering star (Uranus, 荧惑)** entered the **Southern Dipper (南斗)**, and **Xu Qian** interpreted this as a calamity for **Hao and Chu (昊楚)**. He secretly pondered the coming misfortune. That year, the **Great Flood (大侵)** struck, and the people suffered further loss from famine and disease.

Someone asked him: *“Is this not due to insufficient food?”*

**Xu Qian** replied: *“Now, both the public and private granaries are depleted, and the **Dao** and its adherents face mutual suspicion. How can I alone remain well-fed?”*

His inner resolve was indeed such.

The record states: *“My observations of **Xu Baiyun’s** concerns align with yours, yet he neither clung to antiquity nor followed contemporary trends. For one who clings to antiquity, the **wandering star’s** anomalies would not be confined to the **Great Flood**; for one who follows trends, the calamity of **Hao and Chu** would not necessarily strike close to home. But **Xu** understood the Confucian heart: the heavens, earth, all things, China and the **Four Barbarians**, none were excluded from his purview. The **Dao of Heaven** and human affairs were all subjects he diligently studied.

Initially, his teachings were not the kind suited for **imperial examinations**, nor could those focused solely on **examination categories** comprehend them. His critiques of China’s flaws and his warnings against the **barbarians** were subtly woven into *“Critical Moments of Governance”*; yet his efforts to uphold **orthodox learning**, restore the **fundamental principles**, and his deep engagement with the **essence of Buddhism and Daoism** were equally evident.

This is why he was worthy of bearing the weight of **correct studies**, and why his personal safety or misfortune mirrored the rise or decline of this **Dao** itself.*

In the early **Ming Dynasty**, **Master Zhao Kaogu** traced **Xu Qian’s** lineage to the **Sixth-generation grandson of Song Emperor Xingzong (宋秦王)**, while his own family had remained uninvolved in government service since entering the **Yuan Dynasty**. **Xu Qian**’s distant ancestors were from **Mifu (沬泗)**, and his recent teachers were from **Guanshan (关问)**. He was sincere in his adherence to the **Dao** and diligent in its study.

At the beginning of the **Hongwu era (洪武初)**, he was summoned to the capital. Upon returning home, he built **Kaogu Terrace (考古台)** and composed *“The Unified Treatise on Sounds, Scripts, and Meanings”* in **one hundred volumes**, expounding upon the **Six Classics** and the **Hundred Schools**. He claimed his work revealed the **profound and divine insights** of the **Sages**, though contemporaries did not accept his assertions.

Only **Song Jinglian** instructed his son **Song Zhongshi** to study under **Xu Qian**, along with **Song Jizi of Jiangxi**, **Lin Fu of TianTai**, and **Tang Xinshi**, who all agreed that his teachings were sound. **Hou Yong**, a **Minister of Personnel (吏部侍郎)**, treated him with the respect due to a master.

Later, when **Xu Qian** returned to the capital, the court officials declared that **sagely orthodox learning** from beyond the seas had never been heard of before, and that he should be sent to teach in **Qiongzhou (琼州府学教授)**.»

When he arrived, he established the **Jongtai Learning Framework**, expounding the **Patterns of Transformation and Governance**, compiling and supplementing the works of former sages, recording teachings according to their objects, and taking it upon himself to revive and elevate this **Way**.

Though barbarian and armed tribesmen turned toward his teachings in reverence, scholars from distant lands did not hesitate to cross mountains and seas to follow him. Among them were **Zheng Shangbin of San Mountain**, **Wang Zhongdi of Hefei**, **Zhu Bishao of Putian**, **Sun Zhongyue of Fengyang**, and **Hao Wenxiang of Jongtai**, all of whom revered him as their master.

**Qiu Wenzhuang Gong** held him in particular devotion, for it was only after **Xu Qian** that **Jongzhou** came to recognize **sagely learning**.

Wenzhuang initially found **Zhu Xi’s** subtle teachings scattered in commentaries and recorded sayings, which were difficult for scholars to grasp. He thus gathered the most precise passages into twenty chapters, composing *The Principles of Learning* (*Xue de*).

For *The Outline of Principles* (*Gangmu*), he took **orthodox succession** as his foundation, acknowledging that **Qin and Sui** could not be hastily deprived of their legitimacy, nor could **Han and Tang** be hastily granted it, thus writing *The Rectified Framework of World History* (*Shishi Zhenggang*).

Though *The Family Rituals* (*Jiali*) preserved the essence of reverence and sincerity, its rites were incomplete, so he composed *The Ritual Complements of Family Etiquette* (*Jiali Yijie*).

Since *The Extended Meanings of the Great Learning* (*Daxue Yan Yi*) lacked guidance on **governing the state and pacifying the world**, he drew from the **Classics, Histories, and Masters**, adding his own interpretations, and wrote *Extended Meanings* (*Yanyi*).

These were his greatest contributions to the **Four Books**.

At the **Imperial College**, he strictly followed the established precedents of **Li Zhongwen**, yet refined and systematized them with meticulous care. None could surpass his mastery.

In high office, he sought to broaden the emperor’s perspective with **magnanimity**, fostering **loyalty and benevolence** among scholars. In all matters of personnel advancement or dismissal, as well as policy implementation or reform, he adhered strictly to ancestral precedents.

When compiling the **Imperial Annals of the Ying Temple**, he boldly spoke of **Yu Qian’s** wrongful accusation, and only then did others believe the truth, allowing his deeds to be accurately recorded.

In overseeing the **Ministry of Personnel’s** performance evaluations, he was known for dismissing many officials. Those dismissed dared not complain, but he deeply understood the flaws in the system and reported to the throne:

*"In the ages of Yao and Shun, officials were assessed every three years, and those failing were dismissed after three evaluations. Now, some officials are dismissed before even half a year in office, based merely on hearsay, not necessarily truth."*

The emperor agreed. When the Ministry proposed dismissing nearly two thousand officials—some not yet three years in service, others though evaluated three times but lacking clear evidence of corruption—he ordered none be dismissed. This was in accordance with the master’s words.

The record states:
*"I observe that **Zhao Kaogu** deceived the former dynasty, refusing office under the Yuan. Though he claimed his writings contained profound and divine insights, few accepted them. Had it not been for the **Great Clarity of the Ming**, honoring true scholars and promoting **Daoist learning**, how could his words have been fully trusted? Since then, the **Four Seas** have united in shared culture, and soon after, **Wenzhuang** emerged—deeply enlightened and devoted. He applied this learning to his conduct and governance, aiding the **glorious Ming**. It is evident that the former dynasty could not partake in this **Way**, yet the **Four Seas** now flourish in civilization. Where did this transformation originate?"*

**Record of Promoting the Way, Volume Fifty-Six** *(Hongdao Lu, Vol. 56)*
